description:
Great stuff. Schnitzel to die for. Buttery Spaetzle. I'm a Jager fan but almost choked on saliva trying to pick my entree. 

No food for the pale, quiet, or anemic. Leave your kale or chia seed fantasies at home. I will be back so I can sample the whole menu.  The specials are sumptuous as are the zuppe. 

The bier selection is awesome, as is the bier. No puny light stuff or bitter microbrewery IPA. The real deal.
author: Byron H.

description:
Went here on a busy weeknight for a friend's birthday. We had a reservation and were seated right away. The space is quite tight and loud, which is fun but also difficult to have conversations.

The beer menu is great and I had a dunkelweiss. Unfortunately, due to the loud atmosphere the waitress got a couple beer orders wrong. My boyfriend didn't care for the one he received by mistake.

As for the food, I shared a Brezel with my boyfriend to start. It had some sort of beer cheese dip, which some people thought was like a pimento cheese. For my main, I had the sauerbraten, which the waitress said was really popular. I enjoyed the meat, but lovvved the spaetzel. It's like a combination of macaroni and cheese and gnocchi. This is a must- and if I try another dish that doesn't have it on the side next time, I'm going to ask to substitute.

At the end of the meal, the server brought out an apple strudel-type dessert for the birthday boy. He generously passed it around and I enjoyed my bite, with some thick whipped cream on top.

Overall, the restaurant offers some delicious traditional German food, and the price is reasonable for the portion sizes. Would recommend for a lively night out.
author: Roya B.

description:
Crowded on a Friday night but I hadn't realized it was almost closing (30-45 mins prior). But the waitress had us come in and told us to wait at the bar and she'd get us. 

At the bar, the bartender let me taste a few beers before deciding. The hubs ordered his beer and while signing the receipt/check, he accidentally broke his beer glass. A guy next to us seemed super concerned about his leg but I didn't see any blood or anything, but we of course apologized. The bartender quickly reassured us that 'it's a bier hall' meaning 'it happens' and not to worry about it so much. 

Shortly thereafter, we were seated at the lash 2 seats of a 6-top. There were 4 women sitting there who kept looking at me as if they didn't know what I was. (??) Any way, I just looked at them and smiled, then when the waiter came by I asked for a bandaid for my hubs who apparently had a cut on his hand from the broken glass. He went to the bathroom to clean up and the waiter brought me a few bandaids (super nice).

Okay, about the restaurant-- the ambience was like a bier hall: funky ceiling decor, loud with folks drinking and celebrating Friday, and an active service scene. 

We order schnitzel and pork sausage with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. Both were delicious. The schnitzel was amazing with the lemon... and at first the hubs thought he was gonna want mashed potatoes (I assured him I'd have some on my plate he can have), but his potatoes tasted better! 

Overall, despite the broken glass on our end, the restaurant was a nice stop after a show @ The Nourse. The service was kind and attentive (which is hard to say for many places that are busy on a Friday) and the food and beer were spectacular.
author: Roxane P.

description:
It has been a long time since our last visit to Suppenkuche.  We recently spent a few nights in the city and decided to stop in.  We were glad we did!

Our party of five started with pickled herring (Hering nach Hausfraunart ...) and German Ravioli (Maultaschen ...).  

The herring had a surprisingly creamy consistency which went well with the crispy apples, onions. The sour cream cut through any fishiness and allowed the flavors of the salad to come through.  Excellent.

A first for us was the Ravioli.  This was an excellent starter and could be your meal if paired with a soup or salad.  Rather than pasta "pillows" with filling, these were "blankets" of luscious pasta filled with bits of beef, pork, and veggies that paired perfectly with the mushroom sauce! You must try this.

For entrees, we went straight to our all-time favorites: Schnitzel and Meatloaf.

Schnitzel (one order was more than enough for two) is two large breaded and sauteed pork fillets, crispy and juicy perfection, served with roasted potatoes and salad.  Again, with a starter, this was a great way for us to start a night of fun.

As we remember, the meatloaf (Falscher Hase ...) was the best we've had.  Sorry Mom, this meatloaf is on a new level.  A large slab is served over buttery mashed potatoes drizzled in savory onion sauce.  This is an amazing blend of ground meats with sausage spices and bacon that made each bite more satisfying than the first.  I enjoyed this with a draft Kolsch.

We shared an apple tart for dessert, just a bite or two was all we needed to end an entirely perfect meal!
author: Albert Y.

description:
I really enjoyed the atmosphere at Suppenkuche.  I felt like I was in Europe.  We showed up around 1:00 on a Sunday and they offered the brunch menu.  I had the chicken schnitzel, which consisted of pounded and fried chicken breast with potatoes and a salad.  I enjoyed them all, but wouldn't return for the same dish.  There was so much chicken that my leftovers provided two chicken sandwiches.  My girlfriend had the currywurst.  She said it was OK.  She picked this place based on the pictures on Yelp.  What she wanted was not served at brunch.  I had a glass of Pinot and she had the Eggenberger Pilsner.  Neither one of us wanted a second glass.

We might give it another go when the full menu is offered.
author: Jan F.

description:
The banana weizen is delicious and refreshing, definitely give it a shot if you want something lighter.

The braised beef was also delicious, especially if you're a fan of a more sour, vinegary taste. Great taste and texture! Wasn't a big fan of the spatzle though, thought that could have been done a bit better.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Just amazing. I am German by heritage. My mother makes spatzle and has taught me how, I always liked pilsner's and meats with mushroom sauces. I am a major fave on brats and sauerkraut. This meal got it all right! There was a roast chicken special - - a half chicken, most tasty, crispy skins. just wonderful.

Its shared seating, so come in and make friends. Service was very attentive and friendly. Took the orders,  handled request easily, took no notes - and got it right.

Busy, loud but fun and worth making the trek. If I get to come back to the city - I hope to get back here.
author: Larry S.

description:
Suppenkuche is a medium sized German restaurant on the western border of Hayes Valley that serves very simple meals like sausages, trout, and herring with an incredibly wide variety of beers and wines. If you or your group of friends do not enjoy beer and/or wine, I would recommend staying away from Suppenkuche. Even if you do enjoy beer and wine, I would advocate eating dinner elsewhere and then coming here for drinks. This review is written from the perspective of a non-drinker.

I dined here with a large group and had the breaded pork loin with potatoes and was very disappointed with my meal. It was something that felt uninspired, and unoriginal, not much different than diner or cafeteria food. While my friends loved the beer selection here, they agreed that the meals were very one dimensional. At $21, my dish wasn't expensive but if given the opportunity again, I would rather walk over to the many other excellent Hayes Valley restaurants nearby, eat dinner, and then come back with my friends for beers. I wondered in the past why there aren't many other German restaurants and after dining here understand that the simplicity of German food isn't well suited for the restaurant setting especially in a city like San Francisco that has so many other impressive options.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Pro:
Great portions.
Patient waiters. 

Con:
They don't seat you until everyone is there. 
They make you share tables. 
I saw a big guy that literally had to squeeze in a edge with very little table space. 
This place is hard to have great convos 
Restaurant is too dark. can't even see what you're eating on your plate. 

Get the:
Chicken
pork with mushroom 
Salmon

Don't get the:
BBQ ribs

2 stars for the host, she was rude and bossy.
4 stars for the waiter, they were good
author: Linda L.

description: Amazing food, festive environment!  Went here for my friends bachelor party dinner and was not disappointed.
author: Dan B.

description:
Glad to know it's still good after all these years
Prepare for a hearty meal with a hefty stein of beer

Some of my favorites here are actually the sides:
- The spaetzle is cheesy with great mouthfeel  
- Cooked sauerkraut helps cut down the meatiness of your main dishes
- fried potatoes pair well with whatever protein you happened to get (i usually ask for the potatoes in replacement if the dish originally lists mashed potatoes)

If you get the boot, make sure to do the little twist at the end so the air bubble in the toe doesn't splatter the last few ounces of beer all over your face
author: Marshall Y.

description: German food is not my favorite. The prices here are pretty high but they give you pretty large portions. I had the cheese spatzle and it had an odd texture. I had a couple bites of other meals include the schnitzel which was perfectly fine. The service was good and the draft beers were great. I got a light Hefeweizen which was quite good. Considering Beigarten and Rosalind's Sausage are nearby, it felt especially hard to pay the prices
author: Sharvari J.

description:
Had an early dinner here for a party of 3 on a Monday (got in right at 5pm). It wasn't that crowded, but I wanted to make sure we got in (heard about the possible long wait times if you don't get there early).

Started off with some great draft beers:
1. Andechser Doppelbock Dunkel (in their new .5 liter boot glass!)
2. Weltenburger Hefe-Weissebier Hell (1 liter boot)
3. Kostritzer Schwarzbier (.5 liter)

We liked #2 the best, but all were tasty.

We started with the legendary potato pancakes. They were good as their reputation. Crunchy outside, and soft inside, and great applesauce to go with them. Sour cream was good with it too.

Entrees (large portions!):
1. Meatloaf with bacon. Another favorite - and very tasty
2. Chicken schnitzel with mushroom sauce, mashed potatoes and peas. This was one of the daily specials. It was quite good and flavorful. Schnitzel was crunchy without being hard.
3. Sauerbraten with spaetzle and cabbage. Very tender and flavorful.

We finished with a slice each of the apple and cherry strudel, and whipped cream. Yummy all the way.

I would definitely come back here, and try some more of their specialties!
author: June W.

description: If I had to describe their food in one word, it would be hearty. Their food reminds me of Christmas time or thanksgiving. My favorite dishes are the pork with mushroom sauce and SPAETZLE and the ravioli with mushroom sauce. I am no expert in German food, but spaetzel is the most memorable German food to me because it is so nice and chewy. Their ravioli is special because it is not a regular one you would find in a supermarket -- it looks and tastes homemade. I also love getting a beer here because it feels so German and their cups are huge!
author: Andrea T.

description:
No matter the time of week, if you walk by Suppenküche the muffled sounds of lively diners and the flickering candle light from the intimate atmosphere will call you in from the street. Open those sturdy wood doors and walk through the thick curtain and you suddenly feel like you could be in Germany.(k maybe that's a stretch - but it's super warm and cozy and lively here). 

Frankly, this is such a neighborhood staple. Great beer. Generous portions of really hearty food. Definitely enjoy it everyone I come here. 

Things I've tried:
Grilled trout 
The pretzel
The spatzel
The wild boar sausage

Other than the wild boar sausage, I personally find everything to be really good here. A little bland, but German food often is for my tastes. The quality is always superb and the texture/composition never disappoints. As for the flavor, it's nothing a little salt, mustard and/or some lemon can't wildly improve. The boar sausage on the other hand is really gamey and kind of inconsistently textured. 

2 more things to note: 
1. This place is pretty cozy - expect to share a communal table with  strangers if you show up on a popular night. 
2. While it looks fun to order a boot and heartily cheers/clank your boot with someone else's beers, the boots are fragile and if you break one, they cost $50 (+ the cost of beer).
author: Quinn Li O.

description: Finally tried this place! I live just down the street and have always wanted to check it out but it's so under the radar I've forgotten. Walking in it's super packed with tables and chairs and it feels like a true home atmosphere. Proportions are huge and the price is about right for what you pay for. Be sure to get beer to complete your meal. Definitely comfort food for a chill date night
author: Kaylin-Marie D.

description: Awesome food! Great folks but it does get a bit loud in there. The schnitzel with mashed potatoes is the bomb.  Been going there since they opened.
author: Lou Z.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here on a Friday night around 6pm and this place was poppin'! All the tables were fun and it was loud and rambunctious! Luckily after we checked in with the host who let us hang out by the bar, a table opened up within 5 minutes! The restaurant is not that big but they have lots of tables, which some are family style too.

The waiter was quite accommodating. We are quite indecisive so we weren't sure what to order. He helped us figure out what we wanted but also Gabe us ample time to talk it over amongst ourselves.

We ended up sharing the pretzel with cheese! Warm and tasty! And then their special pork belly appetizer. The skin was crispy but the meat was tender. And then sauce to go with it was ideal.

And then for the main course we went with the classic of sausages and mash, of course! Their sauerkraut was picked enough to get the taste but not overpowering. The mashed potatoes were so creamy and the sausages were very tasty! 

The selection of beers was good too. Ended up getting a radler which is Helles w/ Lemon Soda. So delicious! Tasted like sparkling juice!
author: Natalie V.

description: I was so excited that I finally found a German Restaurant around me. The restaurant is in dire need of some TLC. The potato pancakes were delicious. The perfect balance of the crunchy outside to the fluffy inside. For my entree I ordered the sauerbraten, my absolute favorite, but this dish was a dissapointment. The meat wasn't as tender as it should be and the sauce wasn't that balance of sour and savory, rather it was just pure sour. I am still on the hunt for a good German place..
author: Allie P.

description:
My friend's mom is a well-traveled individual, hence, we came here for dinner! We arrived at the restaurant around 4.30PM and no lines were formed. As time gets closer to 5 pm (opening time) there were at least good 20-30 people. As the time past by 5.30PM you'll have a great chance to wait for a 1-hour wait! So make sure you come before 5.30PM.

Anyway, let's get to the food itself. We ordered German mulled wine, aka, Glühwein, (Mulled wine is a traditional warm beverage combined with different spices, red wine, citrus fruits and sugar). Their mulled wine is not overly sweetened and the aroma of the spices was great at the right level! Would recommend this drink to try it out during the winter. They will not serve this beverage during Spring and Summer time as what I heard from the waitress! 

We also ordered the potato pancake. That is like one of the most order starters should be ordering! The saltiness from the potato, sourness from the cream and sweetness from the apple sauce all together have a harmony in your mouth. The balance is great and definitely a delightful dish! Would definitely recommend ordering this to share with friends/family (believed is 3 pieces of potato per plate)

As for entre, we ordered the pork shoulder and veal (veal is the special for that night or the season (not 100% sure). Personally, I prefer the pork shoulder. The pork shoulder is not overly seasoned and it's not too salty. The flavor is great and the meat was not overly cooked! As for the veal, I believed it's a bit underseasoned. But it was really tender.

Lastly, you cannot forget about the cheesecake! Their cheesecake is as good as it can be. Personally, I think it's better than the cheesecake factory.

Overall, I would recommend this place for dinner and/or a place to hang out if all you want to do is to drink! Since they have a bar that just serves alcohol!
author: Jeff H.

description:
First of all, we were a bit confused by the entrance as it didn't quite look like an entrance. I pulled the door to see if it was unlocked and indeed it was. As soon as you open the door, everyone is sitting right there eating which had me wondering if we came in the wrong way. We had it right.

All the tables were full, but there was some bar stool spots against the wall we sat at. I would have preferred a table to stretch out more, but I'd also rather not wait to sit down somewhere. No biggie. 

I ordered a delicious beer that I believe was some kind of Dopplebock (the one closest to the camera) along with a pork sausage plate that came with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. Also I had sampled a delicious pretzel with some great sauces. I couldn't have been happier with everything I consumed and never even liked sauerkraut until I tried it here. Maybe the only way for me to enjoy sauerkraut is authentic style.
author: Joseph H.

description: Best German food I've had. Came here with coworkers and I think we ordered everything on the menu. I've made a lot of potato pancakes and this one amazing, thick and fluffy, but crunchy on the outside. Fresh pretzel, good schnitzel, mashed potatoes were to die for. Looking forward to taking friends and family here in the future.
author: Alex G.

description: As authentic of a German/ Belgian experience as you can get. The owner is passionate about his work and the food speaks for itself. The communal dining arrangement is icing on a lovely experience cake.
author: Akash D.

description:
I had a chance to visit this popular joint again recently during Oktoberfest 2017 and had a great time! German brew is always delicious and the food here tasty and filling.

This time I had the trout (buttery good) and the pork knuckle which was juicy and tender. Larger groups are doable, but I'd advise against it unless you had a reservation or come early. Love me some Suppenküche!
author: Marlon T.

description:
After my trip to Germany, I fell in love with the hearty german meals. This was the first german I went to after coming back to the states. It is definitely something I wouldn't eat often but this is definitely where I would go if I need to satisfy my cravings. It is also not a cheap meal.. so its not a weekly/monthly meal :) 

The wiener schnitzel is perfectly crispy and flavorful. Not extremely oily!! The pork sausage and mashed potatoes is my favorite. I'm a huge fan of sauerkraut and it does a great job in cleaning my palette. Yes, I left feeling like a ball but it was worth it! Also, its a must to get beer to compliment your meal!
author: Joyce S.

description:
A real gem placed in the middle of Hayes! It is a cozy little spot that is a real contrast to some of its sleek and classy restaurant neighbors.

Menu is filled with hearty food options and beers. Definitely come with a big appetite because the dishes are huge!

German ravioli: so good. The mushroom sauce is creamy and not too heavy.

Schnitzel: Definitely order this as one of your main dishes. Breading was on point.

Bratwurst: pass. Not that much flavor. 

Spatzle: AMAZING. I could eat bowls of this. cheesy onion goodness.
author: Courtney N.

description:
Brunch review! Suppenküche now does brunch on Sundays and it's affordable, delicious and different. 

In the mood for German food for brunch? I didn't think so either. But surprisingly, it was delicious and yummy. Yes, it was a bit heavy and that's what I was worried with German food this early in the day but if you take it easy, it's amazing! 

I had the wild boar which came topped off with an egg and surrounded by delicious potatoes, peppers and a bit of ham. For less than $10, this could easily feed a person. What a steal! It's hard to find good boar in the city and suppenküche delivers. 

We also split the Kaiser Schmarrn (emperor's pancake) which came with raisins, plums and other seasonal fruits that made it quite different than the typical French or American style pancake you get at brunch places. It wasn't too sweet which I appreciated. 

For drinks, if you want something different, you can go with their sparking raspberry water (the European in me appreciated the option) or if you want something alcoholic but lighter, they have a lot of beer cocktails such as the Raddler (helles and lemon soda).

The service was friendly, fast and great. No complains there. 

The ambience is also very charming - basic and plain but authentic. 

Overall, if you are looking for something different for brunch than what you typically get and don't mind the food being on the heavy side, I'd highly recommend this!
author: Mario B.

description:
We came here on a busy night, so grabbed the only free spots behind the bar at the long wall connected table top. Which was perfectly fine, I like a little seclusion sometimes. (Especially when it's a nice and dark corner, completely non sarcastic btw)

The cheese that came with the pretzel was very unique in it's consistency and flavor, in a good way.  Also, the GF has been on the hunt for the mustard they served us for years. Finally, we know what it's called, and it's delicious.

Everyone enjoyed their meals, and my schnitzel was perfectly fried. 

Great selection of German beers, and if you can't pronounce it, just point at it on the menu and try your best.
author: Rob W.

description:
Wait -  5 Minute  @ 19:30 Saturday 

Value - $20 / dish.

Dish Size: Very Large

Wild Boar with Sauerkraut & Dumplings *Daily Special  - First impression is, there's so much food. The slab of wild boar is huge and the two dumplings are the size of baseballs. This is a meal fit for at least three people. Sometimes when given large portions you tend to think that the quality is sacrificed. However, the wild boar was tender and juicy and the dumplings were not overly dense. 

Berliner Weisse (Woodruff) - It's a light sweet session drink that has a nice herbal undertone. A great drink to get to compliment all the heavy and savory dishes. 

Suppenkuche is a great place for what seems to be traditional German food and ambiance. I can't speak if Suppenkuche is "truly traditional" but the flavors do have a homemade comfort food feeling. The portions are large, the beer is good, and the meat is tender. The space is reminiscent of a post WWII Berlin restaurant. It's not large and has a handful of large communal tables where different dining parties sit together. Overall the space is stripped back and bare boned with little decoration. 

The food carries a similar tone to the interior. It's very direct and there won't be any surprises diverging from the menu - what you see is what you get. What you get is very large portions of very heavy food. It's usually a combination of large slabs of meat and dense bread or a version of bread. I suggests ordering a Berliner Weisse which will add a nice refreshing element to the meal as the heaviness from the food does become a bit daunting. 

Suppenkuche is a great place to come to hungry. It's a no frills type of place, with it's sole mission to make good tasting food. If you can finish your plate, you'll probably be deep in a food coma soon after.
author: Julian L.

description:
Favorite place. Of all time. I can count on the same meal, every time. 

If you're into beer and a loud place to catch up over delicious food, Suppenküche provides all of the above in addition to a pretty attentive wait staff.

I'd give my earnings to this place any day as it's always been a memorable time since 2012 

Prost!!!
author: Linja L.

description:
German restaurant with a pub situation in Hayes Valley. Busy and clamoring, 10-minute walk from City Hall.

Food:
Way too famished to dance the next hour away, my friend and I decided to roll up to the Khalid concert a little late and instead drop by this highly rated hot spot for a quick bite. Ordered the sausage with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes to share. Maybe we were just hungry but nothing was salvaged...it was 10/10. Sauerkraut was tangy and fresh. Sausage was the right amount of spicy and mashed potatoes were creamy. My friend also ordered a pretzel with cheese and a beer...pretzel was cheewy and soft and the brie cheese and onion dip! I have never tasted cheese so deliciously tart. 

Ambiance:
First time eating at a German restaurant - expect German vibes. Tables are shared during busy hours, noise level is loud and restaurant is very lively. No TV at the pub put still very welcome to drink and chat with your buds. 

Come here if:
Oktoberfest is your Coachella. 

Forget it if:
What language is this place in - did someone sneeze?
author: Kaitlyn C.

description: If you like German beer and Schnitzel, congratulations you've found the best spot in SF to enjoy both of these. Prost. Tschüss!
author: William N.

description: Not only is the beer amazing, but the staff and atmosphere is the best in Hayes Valley by far. Make sure to head to the bar and ask for Craig - he will never steer you wrong!
author: Trevor R.

description: Although very crowded the wait staff found a long table for a single to sit, unobtrusively, with three other patrons. Again, although very busy, wait staff had a nice half liter of Pils in front of me within two minutes. Ordered the Jagerschnitzel w/spaetzle. The onion sauce wonderful and the spaetzel was a perfect texture. All in all an excellent late night dinner with very friendly wait staff and fellow diners!
author: Sirdrewbrew ..

description:
Entrance is on the corner. The inside is like a cozy beer hall with a european vibe. Seating is communal and a little narrow to get into the benches. 

Beer menu had a nice variety of German and Dutch beers with large and larger portions, although I couldn't find the boot! I liked my Helle beer, which was honey-forward and light and refreshing.

Definitely get the potato pancakes, they were so crispy and went well with the sour cream and apple sauce! They reminded me of a super crispy McDonald's hash brown and I mean that in the best way possible.

Pretzel was nice and soft and came with a chunky onion cheese. I'm not fully sold on the cheese texture but it was alright.

I got the jagerschniztel, the pork was too dry for my liking. My friends liked their Wiener schnitzels so maybe I ordered wrong. The mushroom gravy was pretty salty.  Spaetzel tasted like gnocchi without sauce. The butter lettuce salad was necessary because the acidity helped cut through the heaviness of the rest of the food. Portions are very generous though.

Service was ok. Our waitress seemed impatient when taking our orders because we had a hard time pronouncing the german beers. I shared my jagerschnitzel with my husband and she split our plate, which was appreciated.

I would maybe come back to drink beer and eat the potato pancakes, but would pass on the jagerschnitzel.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
2 reasons to come here: good food + beer in a boot

This place is pretty popular so don't be surprised if you have to wait. But since it's in the popular area of Hayes Valley, there's plenty of bars around to hang out and wait. They were able to accommodate my group of 9 at a large table. We only waited around 20 mins to be seated.

We got the boot, which is a boot shaped glass that holds 2 liters of beer. Apparently they only have ~5 for the whole restaurant, so your whole table will have to share. It's only available in the Pilsner, Helles, and I think dark stout varieties. The price is 4x the size of the .5 liter draft. The beer isn't anything special obvi but you do it for the snapchat lol

As for food, I recommend the Wiener Schnitzel (breaded and sauteed porkloin), Sauerbraten (braised beef with cranberries), and Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst (pork sausages). They're all around $20 and come with 2 sides. The spatzle was good and the red cabbage was vinegary.. which I liked.

There's only 2 bathrooms for men and women.. don't wait until you really have to pee to wait in line.
author: Sally L.

description:
Went here looking for some beers and sausages.  They didn't have many sausages on the menu.  So I decided on the pork knuckle.  I had never had it before, and it was great.  The skin was super crispy, and the meat was very tender and juicy.

It came with a bread dumpling and saurkraut. Decent selection of dunkels.
author: Mark W.

description: I'm very familiar with German food (having lived there for several years), as well as Suppenküche (having lived in SF for 20 years). SK has deteriorated steadily for the last 15 yrs. Very sad! Little flavor, quality or inspiration. Come on! I know you can do WAY better! If you do, my German friends and I may start coming back.
author: Philip R.

description:
Call little place gets busy weekdays after six for a beer. The food is actually very good too.    Most other beer and German eateries in the area including Eastbay are authentic and Decour but not in food. This place happens to dish out very good meats and the sptzel tasty which in most cases it's very bland typically. 
I had the meatloaf with a crispy bacon around the edge which was delicious and the schnitzel is also the best I've ever had including having been in Germany many times.  
Space in this restaurant is very very limited and no matter where you said people will bump into you. The back room although it offers a little more privacy is very tight.
author: David C.

description:
Suppenkuche is one of the most popular German restaurants in SF. If you have a large party of six or greater, than I would advise you to get a reservation because this place is small so the wait will be long (for sure over an hour). My favorite beer here is their bananaheizen (a mixture of hefeweizen with banana juice). It is so good! Smooth and easy to drink but each party is ONLY allowed to order ONE German boot. The German boot itself is equivalent to 2-liter of beer. As a petite size girl, I finished 1.5-liter of beer by myself so I would recommend ordering at least the 1-liter if you are a beer drinker. The servers here are excellent, and they will give you samples of draft beer upon request. 

Now, my favorite dish here is their Sautéed Trout in Lemon Butter Sauce with Boullion Potatoes and Spinach. Something about their sauce just goes so well with the potato and fish. Their potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce and the Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut and Mashed Potatoes are pretty good too! I would highly recommend trying this place out if you are looking for a great time with good food but okay with splurging a little bit. Note: German food is not cheap.
author: Monica C.

description: Very good overall.  Good, solid German food, plus delicious German beers.  What could possibly be better?
author: William L.

description:
This was recommended by a friend's friend, and I can see why this would be a German gem.

We got there a little early with no reservations, but the bar was quite inviting and the tender was excellent at helping us find the perfect drink for the night. Our group of 5 seated on a table bench near the front, and was quickly ordered up. 

We all requested different plates - a variety of schnitzels and spatzles and sausages. Everything tasted delicious and hearty and filling, so much food to absorb all that good beer. That red cabbage though ... mMMMm bursting with flavor. 

This place just has such a good vibe... I could hang out forever with friends and a full tummy.
author: Katy Q.

description: Went here on a Saturday evening. It was very lively and had good vibes. Beer selection was great - Helles, German specialties, etc. I've tried the Jägerschnitzel, Falsche Hase, and Käsespätzel and they were all delicious! Even though it was busy it did not take a long time to get our food.
author: Ronica S.

description:
First of all, this place is pretty packed. Never did I think that a German spot would be the hit of Hayes Valley! 

It's a pretty spacious restaurant but it's set up communally so you'll be sharing a table with other patrons. 

Pretty extensive menu with lots of options. In addition, they provide you with the specials (5-6 items) which kind of felt like overload to me, but again, nice to have options? 

I've eaten a good amount of German food. I have a good amount of family in Germany. Still don't feel like that makes me a fair critic on German food so I'm going with my gut here. 

Wasn't a huge fan. I got the pork sausage + mashed potatoes because it seems to be a popular item here. The pork sausage was too rich for me and the portion size was pretty large (standard in German food but I'm basing this on my personal preference) but the mashed potatoes were wonderful. 

Service wise...pretty hard to flag anyone down in here. We were finished for a while trying to catch any server that walked by for water or a check and that took forever. By the time we were asking for the check, the restaurant had slowed down a lot so I'm surprised we couldn't get a single server to help us. 

I want to rate this a 3.5 just because I'm sure someone loves this food but the service was rough for my taste.
author: Adrianna L.

description:
Looks like my hunt for a *real* northern europe restaurant is at its end. Suppenkuche is THE place if you are looking for authentic German food and people who knows about German beer - not only they have the menu, but they have the glass to peer with the beer! I have seen this kind of dedication to beer only in Belgium... and in Germany!

I went with my wife on a Friday evening, right after the 5 PM opening, and the place was just starting to feel up.

We had Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus und Schmand
(Potato Pancakes with homemade Apple Sauce, Sourcream & Chives) and that was my only disappointment of the day: there is no way that a German cook will just deep fry potato the way this dish was served. Once the 4 stars instead of 5.

Also, the place gets loud very fast. And I mean, LOUD. VERY LOUD.

I went with a German classic, sausage and sauerkraut:
Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei
(Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes)
and the wife went with 
Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und grünem Salat
(Breaded and sauteed Porkloin, Roasted Potatoes with bacon & Green Salad)
Both were excellent!
My mashed potatoes were tick (so, made with real potatoes instead of fake potatoes flakes) and well seasoned; the sauerkraut was mild of taste and soft of texture; and the sausages tasted like they were made in the kitchen! Overall, really good and brought me right back in Europe.
I tried my wife's dish and the pork loin was a surprise (I expected veal) but very smooth and tender. The roasted potatoes were perfectly cooked (crisp outside and tender inside). Again a great dish, with the European level of quality I was expecting.

Then, we had a sour sherry pie slice with whip cream for dessert that we shared. Very good too!

Also, the beer we each chose were served in the right glass - I am not a beer snob but I believe that if German and Belgium brewery created their own glass, it is because using them will deliver the best experience while tasting their beer. So I am very glad that the Suppenkuchen staff is knowledgeable enough to use the right glass accordingly. 

There are so many dishes (and beer!!!!) on the menu we want to try, "we will be back (©Schwarzenegger's voice)" :)
author: Jerome C.

description:
Not the kind of place you go on an intimate date, or any kind of outing where you really want to talk to someone... anyone, really. But if you're feeling like you just need to be immersed in a social setting for no reason at all, this'll do.

Great meatloaf (my go to), pretzels, and beers. Kind of pricey compared to how much you'd spend on similar comfort-food-type dishes elsewhere, but you come here for the name recognition more than anything. 

Great location, attentive/overwhelmed staff, and a typically loud and rowdy crowd.

I'm a big fan of the corner by the window in the front because you'll get all the elbow room and plenty of breathing space...Until you need to leave or go to the bathroom because everyone you're sharing the table with will sigh really heavily as they get up so you can get out. Yeah. Well then.
author: Colleen M.

description:
Really fine German food here! The restaurant is cozy where guests are seated community style. Meaning that you might be seated amongst strangers. If you have a party of 6 you can get your own bench/table and I think you can reserve ahead. For all other number of guests, reservation is not an option. If you get there early, once you put your name on the waitlist you can wait by the bar area and order drinks ahead of time. 

We had ordered:
- Pretzel with Obtazda ($8) - the pretzel comes out warm, it's toasty on the outside and soft on the inside. Really good bread!!! The obtazda is some type of curd cheese that's been soften? At first I thought it was a weird mixture but ended up liking it
- Potato Cakes with Apple sauce, sour cream and chives ($12.50) - not sure how to eat this at first. We had ordered this because every single table there had this exact dish. After several different dipping process I decided that the best way to eat this is dip the potato into sour cream then coat it with the apple sauce. This was my favorite dish here tonight
- Breaded and sautéed porkloin ($19.50) - out of all the mains, this is definitely the favorite!! I'm not a big fan of pork but this is very well cooked. The meat is tender, tasty and crisped on the outside. 
- Sautéed porkloin in mushroom sauce ($20.50) - although I love mushroom sauce, this was my least favorite dish. Everything is cooked very well, but for some reason it just didn't click with me
- Grilled Pork Sausage, Sauerkraut and mashed potatoes ($19.50) - I'm not a big fan of sauerkraut so I asked the waiter if they can switch it out with a salad. Super happy that they obliged! Also not a fan of mustard so I used the apple sauce from the appetizer earlier and wow, it tastes really really good!! Totally advise in trying out my concoction!! 

Generally, I thought this place had food that is very well made. It seems to be a very thoughtful process to have food not on the high salt side yet still taste rich.

Totally forgot to take snaps of the mains. It was so delicious we gobbled up everything before I remembered. Portions here are pretty big, I think each main is about 2 servings.
author: Catherine N.

description:
Great place for dinner! I came here with a large group, and they sat us immediately - it's a large place with many tables compared to other spots in SF. Our waiter was incredibly nice and didn't rush us at all. He also gave great advice on the alcohol selection and the different dishes. Great service overall.

I ordered the Aviary Cabernet, which was incredible! Highly recommend if you like red wine. For appetizers, we got pretzels for the table. Definitely a great choice - they are soft and salty and tasted nice with wine. For my main course, I got the trout, which was very filling. It is very fishy so if you're not a big fan of fish, I wouldn't recommend it. It comes with a great fish sauce and potato on the side. 

The only reason I gave this a 4 is because there aren't many options if you don't eat red meat (like myself). Other than that, great restaurant!
author: Remy B.

description: Lovely German place. Felt like we have gone to Germany for mini vacation. Food was great and staff was helpful and friendly. The ower was charming as well.
author: Heidi P.

description:
What happened to the food? I've loved this place for years, but tonight 9/11/2018 my beloved yeager schnitzel was unrecognizable. By looks the spatzle was the first sign. But the gravy was totally different as was the meat.

What happened? I haven't been gone that long. Was it just tonight?
author: V M.

description:
Been waiting to write this review for after having eaten here (my previous few times I've only only joined friends for the beer). 

This is a very busy business around dinner time, so I'd definitely budget your time properly if you want to eat at a specific time. Getting seated as a smaller party is definitely easier. 

You order the beer by the half liter, and they have a variety of choices. My personal fav is the 5L stein, but they also have boots and smaller steins. 

For the food, I ordered the pork shoulder. This came with bread dumplings. The shoulder was delicious, and by the end of the meal I was stuffed. I also tried some of my friend's pork knuckle. It was surprising to see it come out, but it had a nice taste. That type of meat just isn't for me though. 

All in all, will be back without a doubt
author: Rajeev S.

description:
Went here for dinner on 3/26/17 after going here for brunch back in September 2013 and remembered how great it was. 

Dinner is a whole different ballgame. At our table of 5, couldn't hear anyone because it's a legit deafening roar of people. I mean, we were sharing a table with 2 strangers and couldn't hear a word they said even though they were maybe 2 feet across the table from me.

I felt really bad for picking this restaurant because for 3 entrees and 3 waters, it was $70 before tip. It's too loud and chaotic for a nice dinner to catch up with old friends.

Food is decent, but on the smaller portion size. I walked out hungry.

I'd be less upset if we could have leisurely ate but the restaurant is frantic and they definitely need some sound proofing on the ceiling.
author: Rachel S.

description:
This is probably my favorite German place in the Bay Area! It's crowded every night of the week and has an awesome beer haul vibe, similar to what you would find in Munich. Definitely don't go here if you're looking for a quiet date spot. 

Aside from the awesome atmosphere, they have great German beer on draft that can be ordered in a variety of glasses (including a boot ;)

The food is delicious as well. If it's your first time, I highly recommend starting with the schnitzel. If you're feeling adventurous there a many other authentic German classics.
author: Sam A.

description:
Delicious, delicious, delicious!! We had to wait for a table, but in this area there's so much to wander around and see that we didn't mind a bit. The hostess came up with creative seating arrangements to get us in quicker and the food was more than worth the wait. The schnitzel was melt in your mouth tender and the spaetzle was otherworldly. I'm from Winnipeg, Manitoba where we've recently lost our beloved Gasthaus Gutenberg and this place was everything I miss about Gasthaus. 

My one minor complaint is that it was intensely loud, so this would not be the best place to bring a date. 

Don't come here if you want to have a conversation - come here if you want to fill your pie hole with the best damned German food I've had in a long time. Yum!
author: Sarah R.

description:
The special, deep fried Pork knuckle, was AMAZING!

Pretzel with cheese, also amazing!

Pickled beets are next level, so is the red cabbage!

Despite that, the braised beef was just mediocre, same with the dumplings served with the pork knuckle.

Servings are huge for the price in this are. I like that they have many sizes to choose from for beers.

Service is great, ambience is just ok.

Good place to go with a group if you can get in, do not really recommend this for a date unless you like feeling gassy. Lol.
author: Kimia M.

description: I have a friend who is Swiss German, and he really likes the food here.  I have been to Germany multiple times, and the food is authentic.  It is home-cooking, and so not very fancy, but it is satisfying.  Gets pretty crowded, but you are sharing tables with good folks.  They even have smaller sized beers so that you can choose a larger variety from the many that they have on tap.  All of the dishes I have tried are solid.  I don't think you can go wrong, unless you are vegetarian.
author: Benjamin H.

description:
If you like standing in long lines, like most people in this City, this is the place for you! Here you can enjoy long wait times if you are looking to eat here for dinner AND once you get inside it's so noisy you can't hear your friends anyways! Have a relative visiting from out of town that you can't stand? This is the perfect place to take them since you won't be able to hear them complain about what your great aunt is doing. The beer is this place's saving grace; you know it's amazing because it takes literally 20 minutes of standing near the bar to get one. Clearly it's superb! Also you will definitely want to order lots of beers to quench your thirst after eating their overly salted food. 

My advice: go to their beer garden that is a few blocks away. The food is good (and not overly salty), the lines are shorter and you can generally hear your friends talking to you while you sit in the sunlight. Don't waste your time standing in line or waiting for a table when you could literally get the same beer a few blocks away.
author: Bex L.

description:
This is a really authentic German restaurant in Hayes Valley! Walking towards the restaurant, the entrance is located right at the corner - it's a little more difficult to find at night because there aren't any lights at the door entrance. 

Walking in, we were surrounded by a really warm atmosphere - a hostess served us right away and we were seated at a share table with two other groups for the evening. We let them know we were in for dinner, and we were given a menu with about 15 items on the menu. They had many authentic foods and foods that I recognized from visiting three cities in Germany. We also decided to grab one of their Schwarzbier (Dark Beers) because even dark German beers aren't bitter at all! We tried the Pfungstadter Schwarbier 0.5L for $8. This one was a little less strong, I'd say it was even a little watered down. Next time, I think I would go for the Kostritzer Schwarzbier-same price!

My partner tried something I tried in all three cities that I've been to in Germany, which was the Grilled Pork Sausages with Sauerkraut and Mashed Potatoes for $19.50. I was expecting this to be a little saltier but I really appreciated that the sausages weren't that salty at all, and yes, there were three sausages on the plate - i wonder if that's a common thing to do in German restaurants - to place three sausages on it. The mashed potatoes were in a smaller portion than the restaurants in Germany - though I appreciated this more!

I decided to try their Potato Pancakes with Apple Sauce. I've never had this before and I thought it was delicious! The potatoes were cut into small strips and it was deep fried with strips of flour or sliced potatoes (a little different than the average chicken nugget). I thought that the apple sauce paired with the potato pancakes was an interesting mix - though I think I would enjoy it more if the apple sauce was heated up in some sort. 

Overall, I think this is a delicious German restaurant that actually tasted like German food, located in the heart of San Francisco!
author: Kristy N.

description:
1. Not baby-friendly, but they're VERY accommodating. Service is top notch 

2. Can get very noisy. Live kitchen bell (mad respect) best enjoyed if you're an audiophile or just plain weird.

3. If you're trying to be healthy, share a plate (they're huge) and definitely get the salad. The pickled herring salad is the same as the regular salad but with the herring. Totally worth it considering all the housemade elements. Great for acid fiends like me.

4. If you're trying to he healthy, don't eat here. You kinda have to get beer. And nobody wants to share even if they're 20oz.

5. Chicken schnitzel available for non-pork eaters. Comes with yummy mushroom gravy too.

6. Solid SF eats and service. 

7. When busy (I'm guessing often), you may have to share a communal table and let's just say it can get cozy.

8. Yummy spatzle! & Meatloaf was popular at our table.
author: Thu T.

description: OH MY GOSH this place was phenomenal. I liked everything about my experience. We were seated immediately on a busy Saturday night with no reservation, I was able to easily find a low-carb option on the menu, and the food came out extremely fast! All around a delicious, authentic spot that is a must-try. I got the bratwurst- highly recommend.
author: Abby R.

description: Wow!!! So freaking authentic its crazy!!! Food was out of this world, tasted just like back home in Germany!!! Thank you Stephanie for the A+ service!!!
author: Victoria D.

description: Great German place with beer to match.  A nice place in the Hays Valley area of SF. German food is authentic and the beer is tasty
author: Larry C.

description:
This was the first authentic German restaurant I've ever been to. I went with another friend and she said it was very authentic, as authentic as the ones in Germany. The restaurant is small, so you might have to wait to get a seat, and be expected to share a table with other people. They have a loud, rowdy environment with a nice authentic feel. They had a small bar and the staff was very friendly and polite.

We had the Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes which was $19.50. And Potato Pancakes with homemade Apple Sauce for $12. The Sauerkraut wasn't as sour as I heard it would be, it came with this horseradish mustard sauce that was pretty strong initially but I grew to enjoy the taste. The sausages were a bit small, but packed had a kick to it. When you mixed the sausage and everything else it tasted really good. The Potato Pancake was also good, it had a hard crunchy outer shell made out of thin potato sticks, and the inside it had a softer fine texture that went well with the crunchy outer texture. The apple sauce wasn't too strong either so it added a nice sweet note to the dish

I have to admit the food seems more expensive than what I'd imagine but it was worth it. We got a medium dark beer that was pretty smooth and wasn't that bitter at all. So I enjoyed that a lot.
author: Christopher L.

description: First German restaurant and it was the best experience I could of received! The employees were very hospitable and were patient with my many questions. I absolutely loved this place and will be back!
author: Daisy R.

description: We visited this place at around 11:00 on a Saturday and there was a brunch menu. Most things were fresh and good in taste. This one is definitely worth trying and visiting again.
author: Jack T.

description: Excellent food. Even excellenter beer. Good service. The strangers they sat us next to were boring. They got mad when I tried their food. Four stars only because nobody could tell me the correct way to pronounce Super Kootchie
author: Mark S.

description: I really love this place. The service is top notch and they have a really awesome selection of beers. I have yet to order food but will definitely be back to try some menu items.
author: Elvia D.

description: Our go to place for an authentic German food and beer fix!  Have had many dishes like the sausages, and Wiener schnitzel but keep coming back to the sauerbraten which is a huge portion you can split if you go for a soup or appetizer like the tasty pretzel or add a potato pancake that I dream about. The sauerbraten is always tender and I could eat the spaetzel until I bust. The red cabbage is good but don't need to eat all of that. The pea soup with sausage we had on the last visit was hearty and not overly pea-ey, which I prefer. Service has always been friendly and pretty speedy. Oh wait...the beer:  just go for it. I have my faves but I like just about anything. The dunkels are especially tasty and smooth.
author: Mark O.

description:
I just realized today that this place is much better for brunch than dinner! Less just-sausage options. Found egg in a hopeless place.

I came as a group of 6 on a Sunday around 12 and there was no wait at all. I ordered the ravioli, which came with a side butter lettuce salad. Very tasty. 

Good beer (I think, lol. I don't know anything about beer actually but it was German)

Prost!
author: Juliana P.

description:
-Brezel mit Obatzda / Pretzel with Obatzda (traditional Bavarian Cheese mix) 

^Obatzda was so good.. A little pickly. It's like a hummus texture if you've never had it. It was my first time. And I liked the red onions in it.. so good.


-Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus und Schmand
Potato Pancakes with homemade Apple Sauce, Sourcream & Chives

^Pancakes were great. The Apple Sauce was actually good, but I thought it was a weird combo in my mouth (hot potatoes vs cold sweet sauce). It's like savory+sweet not my favorite combo. I usually don't sourcream, but it was good paired with the potatoe pancakes. 


-Maultaschen in Pilzrahmsoße
German Ravioli filled with Pork and Vegetables served with Mushroom Sauce

^Eat this while it's still hot. Super good. It's on the creamy end, but if I can handle it.. it's not that creamy. But it's really really good.


And I liked my beer, but I don't even know what I had.. haha.

-

I liked the food and the overall experience. Its very communal with the seating and let's be honest: some people are cool and some people just aren't and that could alter your experience, but everything is just perspective. You make it what you make it.
author: Lilian L.

description: Delicious! I loved it and would recommend this place to anyone in the area! I have not tried German food before, but after trying this place will definitely be eating at more German restaurants. To start with we were immediately greeted at the door and motioned to a table (they do have customers share tables with other customers; but that was completely okay with us).  The food was amazing. I went there on a Sunday for brunch and had the bauernfruhstuck mit gewurzgurken.  The egg scramble and pork in it was so good! Anyways check it out if your in the area you will not be disappointed!
author: Dakota S.

description:
As amazing as always.
Great beer, amazing food, beautiful atmosphere.
Almost always, i get an order of Brezel Obatzter. 
Love their Sauerbraten ( a to go to dish)
Tried their slow boiled beef this time... pretty good but not better than the sauerbraten.
Stuffed ravioli was nice too.
author: Mary N.

description:
Perhaps it was the circumstances... Or my poor planning. I didn't have the best experience here, either with the service or the food. I've been wanting to come here for awhile, and I don't blame others for wanting to, but I wouldn't recommend it. First of all, make a reservation. They're available for parties of 6 or more. Unfortunately, there were only 3 of us, which put us at a disadvantage. We put our names down for dinner then went back outside to stand in the cold dark. Slowly, we saw large parties go inside and get seated. Low key annoying.

We were eventually placed at a communal table. It was loud and dark inside the restaurant, and generally I didn't care for the vibe. The wide beer selection was the best part, though our bartender was apathetic about making recommendations. So useless. For food, I ordered the pork loin in mushroom sauce. My boyfriend had the trout in butter-lemon caper sauce. I found both to be tasteless and dry. Also, the trout had too many pesky bones for me to eat enjoyably.

The portions were hearty, and I appreciate the limited, specialized menu, but the quality just isn't what I was looking for. I have my favorite German restaurants in San Francisco, and I was hoping to add Suppenküche to that list, but it ended up being quite disappointing. Sounds like I'm being generous with my 3 stars, but honestly if it wasn't so busy and cramped, I would love to come back to enjoy some German beers. Just not a fan of the food.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Through the years, I've been to Suppenküche a few times, but it had been awhile... First, the things to like: the appealing spartan decor and seating and the small, but well selected, variety of German beers.

What not to like? THE FOOD. I had no idea when or how the food became an afterthought of this restaurant, but it was lacking. 
Tasteless, no care or love in the preparation, combined with tough meats and an overall lack of freshness.
Bland and without distinction; Suppenküche is not serving German food. The meals that my wife and I received were no better than what you might get at a smorgasbord like SF's Tommy's Joynt, but at twice or three times the cost. 

Having lived and studied in Germany, I am well-versed in traditional German dishes. Merely slapping together a recipe which has a German name (Jägerschnitzel, Sauerbraten, Käsespätzle, etc.), but not taking the time and care to prepare it properly, and without proper seasoning, is NOT the way Germans prepare these dishes (at home or in restaurants). 
There was no depth to the food here; no soul-satisfying taste to make it distinctive (as Germans pride their food to be), and there certainly wasn't a freshness to it (another hallmark of German cuisine). We were served our dishes about 10 minutes after they were ordered, Suppenküche has become an assembly line of mediocre fare.  

One of the reasons I like to go our to eat is to have meals, well prepared, with distinction, by chefs who bring expertise and knowledge to their craft. None of that was present any longer at Suppenküche. 
It is disappointing to go out to dinner only to discover that you would easily be able prepare the same dishes at home, and that they would be far superior to anything Suppenküche is offering.

If you have the misfortune of eating at Suppenküche, please know that it does NOT represent actual German cuisine; it is just a shadow of it by using some of the ingredients combined with the German names of the dishes. 

Sorry, but unless only for a beer, I won't be returning to Suppenküche again. Instead I will be seeking out German restaurants in the Bay Area that know what they are doing and care about the quality and taste of the food they serve.

The service, however, was attentive and friendly.
author: Bryce A.

description: The pretzels here are to die for - salty and soft - with their special German cheese (that is cold and mushy) this place is a total win! Also tried the potato pancakes with Apple Sauce (a little too tried for my liking) and the classic sausage and potatoes which was also delicious. They have the most amazing German beers on tap as well and it's a great spot for either an intimate dinner or a large group - even for brunch.
author: Sam M.

description:
Super lively place for someone who wants to come for a beer and some solid German hearty food. Employees and super friendly and happy to explain you the menu as many times as you need. Also appreciated the fact that we were able to easily get a table without having reservations and without having to way, something hard to find in San Francisco.

Only thing was that my wife had to choose a different main dish twice because each time the waitress came by later to say that it was sold-out. My wife ended up choosing a dish that was not exactly what she was hoping for but it was still pretty tasty. We also got a dessert for free without even asking which was nice from them.

Will come back again!
author: Nuno S.

description: Be careful what you order! Hubby and I just ate dinner and split the pretzel, potato pancakes, and chicken schnitzel. Everything was great until I cut into my chicken and it was completely raw in the middle.  I was brought another plate of chicken, however my husband had already finished eating by the time it arrived. We get our bill and the waiter had comped our $5 pretzel. Doesn't quite feel fair so hubby says something about it. He then comps HALF of the chicken entree?! Dude really, I can potentially get sick from this and you can't even credit us fully for the dish you screwed up?! We won't be back!
author: Nicole G.

description:
Loved loved lovvvvvee their place can't wait to return. 
Food was excellent, beer and wine excellent,service was fast. Make reservations it's packed standing room only. They will seat u with strangers but in the end it all works out. Great place to entertain. Very loud and bz. If u looking for quite dining and private this isn't it. I loved the whole experience.  Also the street outside great for shopping and bar hopping. If u want real hot chocolate at the end of the block great great choice!
author: Lika G.

description:
I've heard great things about Suppenkuche, and I'm a huge fan of beer so I figured this place was well suited for my boyfriend and I as we love good food and delicious beer!

We came here on a Tuesday evening before a show at the symphony and it was busy! Each table they have here is communal so most likely if you're a party of 2, they'll sit you next to bigger table to chat with others around. 

The food here is delicious. For roughly $20 a dish, each plate is very filling! Their menu is pretty simple as they offer different platters with a main meat dish (or fish, if you don't eat meat) with a side of mashed potatoes or a salad. I chose their classic grilled pork sausage with sauerkraut & mashed potatoes and my boyfriend got their porkloin in mushroom sauce with Spatzle and green salad. We couldn't even finish our meal but my goodness this place is one of my favorite spots for German food. As for the beers, they offer a wide variety of German style beers with a wide palette of flavor notes and from hefs to a dark lager. My favorite was a seasonal mixed banana beer which was really light and refreshing. Yum!
author: Kathleen S.

description: This review is only for the drinks and service not the food since I did not eat here! My friends brought me here with the sole purpose of trying the banana beer, I know it sounds weird but if you like light, refreshing beers you will absolutely love this beer! Great and super friendly service, even on a busy Friday night they took the time to answer our questions and made sure we had a good time.
author: Rachel N.

description:
Threw the boyfriend a surprise party here. It was a bit of a pain to make a reservation because they have a voicemail where you can leave a message so you don't get an immediate confirmation since you're not talking to an actual person. This was annoying as I had to change the reservation a couple of times and they call you back at odd hours to confirm.

Because our party was so big (16 people) we were seated by splitting two big tables. The waitress was pretty on point and the food was good if not particularly memorable but the beers and wine were decent. 

We were surprised when we got the bill cos it was about 30 dollars a head so we walked out after paying but later realised that someone on the wait staff had messed up and had billed the two tables separately and another friend had to cover the extra $250 that they hadn't given us on the first bill. Such a hassle. 

I'm actually really annoyed by this because they knew that the two tables were an entire party and the first bill I ended up paying stated the number of people in the party so not sure why they would separate the bill on the two tables but it was not a great way to end the night.
author: Eunah T.

description:
Ich möchte einen Wein, bitte!

2 months of German lessons have all boiled down to that one glorious sentence. Hey, when you're thirsty, you need to be able to communicate thirst first, food second! ;-)

I had a glass of the 2008 Gerhard Riesling Spatlese and he a pint of the Franziskaner on draft  while we were waiting for our party. I didn't mind the wait and neither did the staff. They were gracious and checked on us often, supplied us with Brot und Butter while we peruse the menu. 

We were 10 minutes past our reservation when all 6 of us were complete. (anything less than 6 are taken on a walk in basis) A few more chatter here and there, what looks good (crispy potato pancakes!) and what doesn't (nothing!); orders were placed and talks about what we learned in German class followed. 

Dishes appeared soon after: tender braised beef with cranberries, red cabbage & spatzle; sauteed trout in lemon butter sauce with bouillon potatoes and spinach; grilled bratwurst with sauerkraut & mashed potatoes; Weiner schnitzel with roasted potatoes & green salad. We all laughed and dared for someone to get das boot -- but that night we kept it low-key and classy. (i.e. saved room for Smitten ice cream nearby) 

We left with a full belly and a warm feeling from the group's camaraderie and the welcoming atmosphere from Suppenkuche. 

Ich hoffe Sie bald zu sehen.
author: Janice C.

description: We used to like this place for the occasional meal, but had to stop coming because the last two times I ate here, I got food poisoning. I had the weiner schnitzel and spatzle both times, and it the incidents were about 3 months apart. I hadn't thrown up in almost 30 years before that. Broke my streak. Proceed with caution.
author: Laetitia S.

description: My son and I came here after finishing Wagner's Ring cycle at the San Francisco Opera so it was a perfect way to cap off that experience. He ordered Jaegerschnitzel and I ordered Wienerschnitzel and then we shared. The staff allowed us to sub Spaetzele and red cabbage for potatoes and salad. I have to say that the red cabbage was not really as good as what I make at home but everything else was delicious. I had a draft German lager which set off the food perfectly. Service was speedy and friendly. The setting was quite loud so, if you are looking to have quiet conversation, this would not be your best bet, for for tasty basic German-style food and authentic German beer this is the place to come.
author: Patricia L.

description: My Dutch husband and I loved this restaurant.  He thought the pea soup authentic.  The schnitzel was tender and crispy; potato pancakes came with applesauce that did taste homemade.  Beer is great too.
author: Edith V.

description: This place is awesome!! The pork roll was mind blowingly phenomenal!! We are just visiting but I will talk about this place to everyone back home!! If I'm ever back in the Bay area I will be here again!!
author: Kyle J.

description:
When we arrived at this place, it was packed. While we waited for a table, we went to the bar for beers. Despite being so busy, the owner took his time to go over the beer selection with us.

When we were seated, I ordered  he schnitzel. It was cooked very well and tasted tender and delicious. The sides were also quite good. This restaurant was very good and I would come again.
author: Keith L.

description: Amazing German food, super tasty and very light, if German food can be. Got the trout and pork roll. The trout was very well made with good flavor, spinach side was perfect. The pork roll was amazing, very nice fat content and great chew and sauce. The potato salad was on point with the cucumber slices. Also their tartar sauce was amazing, it's more sauce than paste like most places.
author: Phillip T.

description:
I've been eyeing this place for quite a while, finally we were able to make it here. This place has mostly communal tables, and you definitely get that German vibe when you walk in. 

Once seated, I ordered a pilsner which the only size option was .5 liter, I was really hoping I could get a 1 L right off the bet. Perhaps they offer that for some of the other beers. As an appetizer we got the pretzel with cheese, by the pics on yelp o thought it was going to be much bigger than what got to our table. We also got a wiener schnitzel and split it, please note that it's more than plenty for 2 people. The wienerschnitzel was perfectly cooked.

I would definitely come back here to try some of their other dishes.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: Love this place! It's apparently been around for 25 plus years but I'd never heard of it before going. Best kept secret in Hayes Valley for amazing German cuisine. Upon entering, you feel like you have stepped into an upscale pub in Germany. We sat at the bar and got amazing service. Definitely recommend the chicken schnitzel and suckling pig. It's A LOT of food and very filling, but that's what German food is all about! Will definitely be back for a return visit.
author: Carol Ann V.

description:
First time here, after many recommendations! Brought me back to traveling in Germany, and the amazing food and beers.
Our friend got a 5 liter beer which is pretty cool, and we all enjoyed the food! We got the braised beef, and pork with mushroom sauce and both are highly recommended. The pretzel and cheese was delicious!
author: Veronica B.

description: One of my go-to spots in Hayes valley; their brunch on the weekend is especially delicious! Communal table seating, it can be a bit noisy, but overall cool atmosphere.
author: Ange R.

description:
I drank beer from a Stein that was bigger than my head. It was incredible. Food was great, too!

While not worth losing a star over, my only issue is that the place gets insanely busy and incredibly loud.

Drink beer and it won't bother you, though.
author: Mike W.

description: My wife knows I have a special place in my heart for German food from my childhood. For my first Father's Day she brought me to Suppenküche. It was a Saturday and the place was packed so we were concerned about getting a table. Went to the bar and ordered a beer and within 10 minutes we were seated at a table with another party. Some people might be put off by this but it's pretty common in German beer halls to have communal seating. Menu has an assortment of traditional German dishes. I had the Sauerbraten and she had the Jägerschnitzel and we split and order of the brad and butter and potato pancakes. The bread had a nice slightly sour flavor to it and the potato pancakes were nice and crispy on the outside but soft in the middle with a good flavor. The sauerbraten was well cooked and served with spätzle and red cabbage. The wife's jägerschnitzel was also good and the gravy was excellent. Both of us were happy with our meals. Our daughter had her first German food here and she devoured everything we fed her.
author: David T.

description: I was so excited to try this place, as my boyfriend who is German raved about it but admittedly had not been in years. He ordered the Maultaschen and I the Jägerschnitzel. His ravioli were cold and had little flavor. My pork collar was mushy and tasted as if it were all fat... it actually tasted like mushy fat stuffing. I will say that the service was great, our server offered to make him another dish but he declined, I didn't bother to complain about my meal. Loved the beer selection. Sadly we won't be back
author: Tricia B.

description: If you are looking for authentic German food, beer and experience look no further! This is a great spot to forget that your in the US for a little while, the atmosphere is very European with the pick-nick tables, music, and decor. I almost felt like I was back home for a little bit. The food and drink was also amazing! There's not a whole lot of places you can get a proper sausage or schnitzel!! I loved every second of the dinner and I will definitely come back!
author: Charlene C.

description: I was told there is usually a long wait especially on a Friday or weekend. But luckily our wait this Friday night was only about 10min. The smoked herring and the salmon dish was delicious! Will be coming here again for sure!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Came on a Friday night around 6pm and the place was packed and rowdy. Ate in the nook area near the bar and it was significantly quieter.

I ordered the Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spätzle & Green Salad. The mushroom sauce complimented the porkloin and spätzle well because they were on the drier side. Flavors were pretty mild, nothing over salted or peppered. The salad was also surprisingly tasty. 

The area we sat in orders the food directly from the bar, but then they'll bring the food to you.
author: Edward W.

description:
Went here to try some German authentic food after reading all the reviews on yelp....was a Tuesday night about 8 pm....I have not had the chance to taste the food due to the fact that the moment we walked in we were hit by a bee hive like noise ..please was super packed ,everyone was talking loud to hear each other, we asked to have a table for 2 ..and they pointed us to a ide of table that had 2 more people sitting on it..
So basically we would seat at a 4 ppl table sharing it with 2 other ppl..my friend, in order to and down had to ask another person's from neighbour table to get up and make roo....
RIDICULOUS!!..IT was so loud we could not hear eachoher talking...
Talking about management trying to use every inch of the restaurant to seat customers and make money. No privacy,no space to put yiur coat ,you pretty much had person next to you breathe on your neck...
Psssss....we walked out ....if you want that feeling, enjoy!!
author: Florin C.

description: I like German culture and I was really surprised to find this place. I had never heard about this restaurant before. A big selection of beers. If you don't know which beer you wanna to order - ask the waiter. Their staff are very friendly and they can help you with your choice.
author: Yana T.

description: Coming to this restaurant used to be a highlight of my San Francisco visits. We got fairly authentic German food for decent prices. The last time, however, was a great disappointment. The spaetzle were extremely mushy and bland, the fried potatoes cold, the schnitzel dry and obviously deep fried and the Jaeger sauce, which used to be refined, with small mushrooms and a fairly liquid gravy was now a grayish, flour filled mush with thick mushroom slices and stems. To add insult to injury, I got the wrong beer and wrong sides even after pointing to the beer on the menu.
author: Chris T.

description: This is absolutely the worst service I've received in SF in a long time. We came with a party of 5 around 6:30pm on Saturday and was told approximate wait time of 30 mins. Two hours later we are still not seated and there are tables with people sipping water for a long time. I talked to that table and they said nobody has come to collect their bill. The food here is good but I'd never recommend anyone to come on a weekend.
author: Cassie Z.

description:
Suppenküche is always loud and crowded, but in a charming and welcoming manner. Unsurprisingly, it has a large selection of flavorful beers ranging from belgians to plisners to dopplebocks (I would not recommend 1L+ of dopplebock unless you have a heavy palette or can tolerate large amounts of rich flavors).

Their pickled herring with red cabbage appetizer demonstrates marked subtlety. Sour and sweet notes mesh together in a balance of tang rarely found in pickled dishes, complementary rather than overpowering. The pork schnitzel in mushroom sauce with spatzle is incredibly savory but not overly rich, salty, or oily.
author: Justin S.

description:
I've been here at least half a dozen times. It has remained one of my favorite restaurants. Last night I visited again and was really looking forward to enjoying the Jägerschnitzel, which I've had several times here in the past. 

Unfortunately they've changed their method of preparing it. Traditionally, Jägerschnitzel is prepared by pounding the cutlets so they are thin, breading the cutlets, and frying them, then topping them with a mushroom sauce. I've had it at Suppenküche before and this is how they prepare it. 

This time, they apparently just pan seared a pork chop that was was cut in half and topped it with mushroom sauce. When I told the waiter I wanted to send it back and have it prepared the way Jägerschnitzel is normally prepared--just like Wienerschnitzel-- he argued with me and said this is the way Jägerschnitzel is always prepared. I informed that I lived in Austria for two years and it's not prepared like this, and in fact I've had it prepared the right way at Suppenküche in the past. 

He took it back and returned a few minutes later. The cook just took the same chops off my plate, fried them, and poured the mushroom sauce over them. It wasn't pounded thin. At that point I just gave up and ate it. 

Another person in our party orders the sauerbraten and it was a tiny portion. He wasn't happy about that. 

I ordered a side of Knödeln (a dumpling of sorts), something I very much enjoyed when I lived in Austria. These ones were heavy, pasty, and flavorless. 

On the other hand the pork knuckle, potato pancakes, and gemischte Salat were all terrific. 

As disappointing as this visit was I will give it another try at some point. After all, I love the ambience and beer selection.
author: Beefalo B.

description:
Satisfying and filling comfort food! 

Suppenküche has been on my radar for years and I'm glad I finally tried it. I came here on New Years Day, a Monday, and a small line started to form 15-20 minutes before opening. Suppenküche is relatively small (approximately 12 communal tables?) so I'd suggest arriving shortly before opening. I can't speak about a typical day, but the restaurant was filled within 30 minutes on New Years!

I tried:
- Potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce: Fried to a perfect crisp! One order comes with three and I could probably eat them all. Simple yet tasty. 
- Wiener schnitzel with roasted potatoes: Satisfying, but a little on the dry side possibly due to the nature of pork loin. I found myself dipping it in mustard and wishing it came with some sort of gravy. I would substitute mashed potatoes next time to compensate for the dryness. Portions are large (2 pieces of schnitzel) and enough to share even though I finished it all with the exception of sharing a few bites. 
- My boyfriend ordered the grilled pork sausage and he seemed to enjoy it. Portions weren't as large, but it was tasty. The mashed potatoes, sauerkraut and mustard complimented the sausage well. 
- Can't forget the beer! That two liter boot is so picture worthy, but I ended up sharing one liter of hefeweizen. They offer a wide selection of beer - I wasn't sure which hefeweizen to pick but my server was helpful and knowledgeable!

Service here was excellent. Water was constantly refilled, everyone was friendly and accommodating and it was no trouble finding help even with a full house. I wouldn't hesitate to return.
author: Charlene E.

description:
Food has gone downhill, and prices have increased tremendously since I started eating here. Last night I took a friend and my usual Jaeger Schnitzel was just..bad. Like overcooked, under sauced, nothing like the magic of the old days. Potato pancakes were cold and undercooked in the middle.
