Likely won't go back. I've updated this from 4 stars to two stars. Additionally a friend of mine said that they changed all the recipes 6 months ago and the food isn't good anymore. Perhaps explained why it was only half full last night.

How sad. WHy would the owner betray his customer base like this?
author: Jordan C.

description: To be frank, as a Chinese I haven't much experience in German food. I just wanted to find a place to dine and then head to warfield theater. But this place really impresses me with its service and popularity. Even though the whole restaurant is full but they serve really fast after hearing that we are in a rush. Nice pig knuckle and sausage !
author: Wenqian T.

description:
So loud. SO LOUD. Like breaks OSHA rules for the employees loud. Long-term hearing loss for anyone that has to work in that regularly.

Meh food. I guess it's popular for the beer and drinks. Cheese spaetzle - gross. Beets that came with it good. Pork with mushrooms - ok.

Nice space, good service. Just loud and more about the drinks than the food.
author: Ryan B.

description: This is a great place. Fantastic beer, make sure to order a boot, and food. The potato pancakes are the best version of potatoes I have ever eaten. The owner and staff could not have been better. If you arrive and it seems crowded, don't worry you will be seated surprising fast. Very nice people! Great experience. I will be back.
author: James M.

description: The moment you enter this place , you'll be transported to 1940s Germany . Insane energy, lovely vibes . Great food and beers are the heartbeat of this place . Go in big groups and you'll never want to leave this place .
author: Rajil S.

description: I have never had German food before, and I can't believe I waited so long!! The chicken is literally half a rotisserie chicken when has a delicious sauce all around it. The pretzel appetizer is a must, as is the potato pancakes. I also tried my friends Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein which was so good with a drizzle of lemon juice on top, I'm ordering that next time!
author: Run.It.Off V.

description:
Any time that I'm in San Francisco, this is on my list of restaurants to eat at. It is great for drinks and dinner. 

The seating is semi-communal so you will be sharing with other people but everyone is so friendly that it's nice.  

Food: I had the meatloaf which is wrapped in bacon so how can you go wrong! Comes with mashed potatoes which are smooth and creamy, also a tasty onion gravy. 

Drinks: one of the reasons that I love this place is that they have my favorite beer. It's a Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbier. Super huge glass, super good beer. 
They also have a huge selection of bottled beers and wines. 

Dessert: try their cheesecake, comes w a special berry sauce. It's delicious. 

The staff is super friendly and the service is pretty fast. Get here early because tables fill up quick!
author: Rachael K.

description:
Tip: there are currently only 2 vegetarian options, potato pancakes and pretzels. (I'm confused about the "vegetarians go nuts for this spot" tag).

I've been here a few times, and each time the food was great and the beers were interesting. I recommend the radler (light beer + lemon soda) if you want something light and slightly fruity. 

Come early if you want to skip the crazy wait, I came at 5:30pm for an early dinner and we were seated right away. 

The braised beef and cranberry sauce was hearty and flavorful, and the portions are generous. I took 1/3 of my meal home.
author: Leeyen R.

description: Good German food, not a lot of options. Great beer of course. Not much room either but a good atmosphere.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Some people like crowded noisy places, considering them high energy. I'm a peace and quiet type myself, so Suppenkuche was not really my kind of place.

I arrived early enough so it was busy but not packed. I got a seat in a row opposite the bar, facing away. The server kept calling me "young lady" even when I pointed out I have not been a "young" lady for a good many years (I'm 63). One of the specials was asparagus with hollandaise appetizer. Hollandaise is not classically German but I like it and asparagus is one of my favorite vegetables. Menu said it came with "cured egg". Asked server the difference between a cured egg and one that is still sick. He didn't get the joke. He said the egg was part of the sauce.

Speaking of sauce, it seemed all the sauces on the various entrees were cream-based which I don't like, so got schnitzel. Very generous portion. Meat was tasty, potatoes a bit dry and bland. Side salad was butter lettuce, with a good dressing. Ordered a glass of Austrian wine on server's recommendation.

And the place got fuller and fuller. People who were waiting for tables packed themselves into the small space between the row of seats where I was and the bar. Made it virtually impossible to get attention of server, I felt hemmed in, even mildly anxious. And LOUD. A man directly behind me kept shouting right in my ear. Was this a restaurant or a baseball game?

Asked for apple streusel cake. Very few desserts should be served ice cold. Even ice cream, especially if premium, should come out of the freezer for a few minutes. The cake was ice cold. I mean ice cold. It had clearly been plated directly out of a refrigerator. Streusel cake is best slightly warm. I know they were busy, but 1 minute in microwave would have made a huge difference. Ice cold crust was so hard I could not cut through it with spoon and had to pick up and bite. 

OK, I can now say I've tried German food. But food, while OK, was not great and it was just not my kind of place. If you like noise and crowds, enjoy.
author: Carol S.

description:
This review is for the dinner service only, the brunch items look much better and would probably earn more stars.

The pork schnitzel was overcooked, dry and rather flavourless.

The sauerbraten was so tough you could not even cut the meat. Pretty bland too.

The pretzel with Bavarian cheese is worth getting as an appetizer though.

Did not try the potato pancakes.

This restaurant is very loud (read: basically a bar).
However I did not discount any stars for that nor the long wait.
author: Tom P.

description:
Deeeelicious. Went to dinner with several friends, managed to taste most of the menu and was delighted with all of it. I ordered the braised beef and I have to say the red cabbage was a perfect assist. While the beef was wonderfully moist, the red cabbage had an excellent accompanying bite. The breaded and sautéed porkloin was crispy without being overly greasy. The braised veal was amazingly tender and if you're like me, the marrow was very flavorful. 

The beer selection was wide and the portions were VERY hearty.  Average pricing was around $20 an entre but there was no way anyone in our group was leaving still hungry. 

It's a bit crowded so I'd highly suggest a reservation. The seating is....intimate. Family style. You'll be sitting shoulder to shoulder with other tables. Somehow that just seemed appropriate for the restaurant tho so I had no problem with it. Again, highly recommend.
author: Daniel R.

description:
Get there within a few minutes of opening and they'll still be packed. Showed up at 5:05 on a Wednesday and barely snagged seats in the back bar area before the place was flooded. Luckily, staff at the bar are attentive and you can order both food and drink there.

The large selection of German beers is a highlight- I can't remember exactly what we got (a hefeweizen and some sort of ale?) but they were both good. The food was decent- herring app was reminiscent of a russian dish, potato pancakes with applesauce had a good sweet-salty balance, and the mushroom gravy with the German ravioli was signficantly better than the ravioli itself.

Prices are fair for the portion sizes and quality. Go early or prepare to wait.
author: Stefany V.

description:
Yes, I am another person who claims the place is loud. But I think it's the whole point - it's a pub with amazing food. Pubs usually are loud! 
We were seated promptly; however been told to wait for 20 minutes. I loved the idea of communal dining: you meat cool people just like you. 
We ordered bratwurst; it was so soft and fresh, although a bit tasteless. 
We ordered different beer and every beer was very delicious. 
I love the place a lot and want to come back soon!
author: Jenna F.

description:
Super noisy! Mediocre food that had no flavor. Disappointed! Charge way too much!

The schnitzel is just a breaded and fried pork chop; not done right. They give three skinny bratwurst that have no flavor. The potato pancake is formed, deep fried hash browns. 

My expectations were pretty high going in, having had authentic German food in Germany where I couldn't get enough!! 

I wonder if the name means 'soup kitchen' in the American meaning.
author: Shamrock S.

description: Ah, Suppenkuche, you are a gem. Sure, it's a little pricey to get get 5L of beer for ~$65, but damn, it makes for a hell of a good time. What's good? 3 deliciously fried potato pancakes for only $12.50? Yes, you want that, and you want the apple butter that goes with it. Smoked salmon salad? Another $12? Great deal when you get a huge plate and a big load of meat coming out next. They have a special of roasted pork shoulder and homemade deconstructed German dumplings right now. It's about $23, but the pork is perfectly roasted to the point where the edges fall apart and the meat is super tender. It's enough to make a grown man cry.
author: Danny C.

description: There's not enough I can say about Suppenkuche! It is one of the only restaurants I feel holds true to the type of cuisine it represents. The vibe is very quaint with beirgarten style seating and the food is deliciouuus. Flavorful but clean in taste -- doesn't feel like an "Americanized" style German.
author: Marisa R.

description:
First time ever trying German food, and I gotta say Suppenküche did not disappoint. Never even knew what German food was, but after I have come upon this place, I will look forward to eating more. 

No doubt German food is a little on the heavier side--big chunks of meat and a big plate of carbs side by side. There are plenty of options to choose from, but you can't skip their APPLE SAUCE. This does come with the potato pancakes, but I definitely recommend getting the pretzel to dip in this apple sauce. ITS AMAZING. Really. Don't skip on the apple sauce and the pretzel. 

I would say that their rice dumplings are worth a try. And since these dumplings came with the pork knuckle dish I ordered, get it just to try some rice dumplings. The pork knuckle was nothing special, but if you love pork skin I think this is the right option for you because there's plenty of that fatty goodness--and maybe even a little too much meattttttt.
author: Wendy T.

description: Amazing sausages, deliciously fillings German starchyness  (bread, potatoes galore) and best of all, amazing pretzels with mustard and cheese!
author: Mike I.

description:
Finally got to try this place! It has a very fun, loud atmosphere and the service is awesome. They seat you at communal tables so not the best if you're looking for something more intimate.

Got the potato pancakes with apple sauce ($12). They were a little crispier than I expected but tasted great with the apple sauce. The German ravioli in mushroom sauce ($14) was my favorite dish. It's a huge appetizer and can basically be its own entree. The inside of the ravioli was so meaty and flavorful!

For the entree I got the jagerschnitzel that came with a small salad and spätzle ($20). I thought the porkloin was delicious and the spätzle was just okay. My group didn't like the Sauerbraten entree much. The beef was a little tough and the sauce was too tangy for me. The highlight of the dishes for all of us was the German meatball special with mashed potatoes and peas/carrots. It was so well cooked and seasoned. I could eat this dish all the time!
author: Linda X.

description:
A great place with communal seating that adds to the charm of a German restaurant. The inside reminded me of the many local eateries in villages in Germany mixed with a little bay area charm.  The food is not overly complex but delicious. I had the Wild Hog Scramble - the potatoes and the sausage was flavorful, and the bites of bacon added an aura of smokiness to the entire dish. 

If you are looking for a restaurant to sit with your friends, talk loudly, and revel in fun, cozy atmosphere, this is the perfect place. I went here for brunch and like many of the restaurants in Hayes Valley, this restaurant accentuates the idea of a community.
author: Shounak C.

description:
this was a great find in hayes Valley, the decor had nice soft colors, white and tan and cute paper birds hanging from the ceiling. the food was great and cooked well, I personally loved the pretzel and Bavarian cheese, the pretzel  was cooked perfectly and  cheese was very tasty and had a unique flavor. 
Drop by for a good beer and authentic German cuisine!
author: Cheryl P.

description:
I was kinda sad to see that there's no more giant pretzel, but everything else like the beer selection, potato pancakes, and wienerschnitzel is still top notch. 

I tried something new here this past weekend: the meatloaf. They put bacon in it so I couldn't say no. It would've been better if the egg was runny, but the smoky bacon made the meatloaf extra tasty. I think they also add some sage in the meatloaf, because it had some fresh piney flavor. The sage (or whatever they seasoned it with) was a good highlight without overpowering the meatloaf. With the mashed potatoes and delicious gravy on the side, it's hard to go wrong with this dish.
author: Nei N.

description:
i cant believe that i've been in sf for 6.5 years and last night was the first time that i had been at suppenkuche.  well, maybe because there are too many great places to eat at, and that i didnt start coming to hayes valley until recently. or that german food is sometimes just a little too heavy.  but anyhoo, a high school friend was in town for a conference and decided suppenkuche is the choice restaurant on a tuesday evening - i had tickets to aida too, so the location was perfect.  the restaurant space is really cute - totally reminiscent of germany.  there is, as one might expect, a large selection of german biers.  in a variety of sizes.  so you can really push the limits of your liver :)

we ordered 1/2 liters to start - a good size.  the pilsner i had was really refreshing!  the menu is pretty simple and straightforward. some appetizers, 5-6 entress, and 5-6 specials any given day.  our waitress was pushing the goose leg special or the pork knuckle, but my friend and i are #basic AF and got pork sausages and the weiner schnitzel. lollll - they were both really delicious!  i substituted the spaetzel with red cabbage (SO NOMS) and felt better about consuming just straight up fried pork chop. 

we came before 6 pm and the restaurant was pretty empty, but by the time we left at 7, it got pretty rowdy and crowded.  on a tuesday! really goes to show how much this spot is loved in this 'hood.  communal seating makes everything more lively!
author: Christina L.

description: Zer gut! This is the real deal for German food and beer. You wanna get your pork itch scratched?.... this is your spot.  25 years in the biz, they must be doing something right. The place is super cas, on a table for 6  you might have three couples eating separately. The beers are outstanding from the pilsner on up. The food ranges from smaller plates and salads to hearty pork cuts and wienerschnitzel. There are 2 or 3 veg plates even. You gotta have the spaetzel, it's maybe the only place you'll find it this good in town. Service is friendly and accommodating. Jägerschnitzel was excellent, as was the German Ravioli filled with Beef and other goodies. Only down side for me, anyway-  is it is extremely noisy. The walls bounce the sound all around, so much so that it can be hard to carry on a conversation. Some thick sound deadening material could easily be hung creatively from all those hooks in the ceiling.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
I really liked Suppenkuche's food! We arrived 1/2 hour after they opened on a Saturday, and the restaurant was already packed with a 45 minute wait. I opted to leave and come back towards the end of the night, at 9:30 PM (1/2 hour before their food closed). We left close to 11 PM -- I have no idea when the restaurant officially closes, but it was really nice of them not to kick me and my friend out.

The food I got here was delicious. The two stand-outs in my mind was the späztle and the potato/celery soup. The cheese in the späztle tasted really flavorful, and the dumplings + cheese blended perfectly with the purple cabbage + carrot sauerkraut. The potato soup was also really nicely seasoned, with a hint of celery in the aftertaste.

The one dish that I probably wouldn't get again was the potato pancake. It was a good, crispy potato pancake, but the insides were mushier than I'd expected (like mashed potatoes coated in hash browns), and there was no sour cream to cool down the oiliness. The pancakes came with deliciously seasoned applesauce though.

Overall, a wonderful restaurant that I wouldn't hesitate to go to again.
author: Sherry Z.

description: Soooo authentic I loved it. I really felt like I was in an old Bavarian restaurant and it's totally hidden away you'd never stumble upon it. The noise level is a bit high as the restaurant acoustics aren't that good so tuck away behind a bar if you want to be able to hear. Good malt beer. I recommend at least one visit.
author: Shannon D.

description:
Get a little cultured while you eat here and soak up the Oktoberfest feels with loads of beer to try from.

I can only attest to trying the German Ravioli but it is delish! For dinner, it's covered in rich, creamy gravy, but for breakfast, it's added together and enjoyed with scrambled eggs, butter lettuce, and pickles. I will be honest, I was skeptical at first and questioned the concoction, but it worked and tasted great. Different from your typical scramble and definitely worth trying. The creaminess of the scrambled eggs with the rich, savory ravioli, slight crunch of lettuce, and tart pickle pull everything together nicely to give you a delightful bite. Portions are decently sized and your meal is quite fulfilling. 

The service is on point and everyone is so friendly. I loved the character of the interior and sitting in the nook by the bar. Peep their website for some history.

I will definitely be back with the fam to try the rest of the menu. A solid choice for a group meal and kid friendly, win-win.

Note: Reservations accepted for parties of 6+.
author: Amy L.

description:
We LOVED this place. I wish I was hungrier when we ate here so we could've sampled more. We came here on a Wednesday night with some friends and it was very crowded - at least a 30-40min wait to be seated, and it's family-style seating, where you could be seated with strangers if your party is not large enough. 

Anyway, we had the spaztle, german ravioli, soup of the day, a few pretzels, and a bunch of drinks. The spaztle was excellent, soup of the day (celery potato - way better than it sounds) and the pretzels were perfect - warm, doughy, and soft. The ravioli was average as it was on the more bland side. 

In regards to drinks, they have a very European spread of beers and whatnot on tap, lots of wine choices, and friendly bar service. Again, I wish we had made more of a night out of it!

Also, Yelp says "vegetarians go nuts for this place" - eh, definitely not. There are few vegetarian-friendly main dishes, and of course you can get pretzels, but this is real German food we're talking about.
author: Leanna W.

description: This food is so good that I can't even make pictures of it because I just need to munch on it right away. I am Dutch myself and German food is and will always be my favorite "cuisine" of all. It reminds me of apres ski in Austria and I love it. Yay for Wienerschnitzels and Erdinger beer!
author: Styn V.

description:
I'm definitely a fan of Suppenkuche. But that being said, my friends and I also had a shitty experience. It's hard to decouple it from the total rating though since I'm sure it was a unique situation, but here I go. 

I came to Suppenkuche with a fairly large party. They were great about letting us make reservations ahead of time and the process, though antiquated because we had to call, was relatively painless. When we showed up a bit too early, we just hung out at the bar and grabbed drinks, and then they let us sit pretty soon after.

The good:
I thought the food here was tasty, as was the beer. It's pretty much what I would have expected coming to a German style restaurant. I had a delicious Pilsner, and the pork schnitzel with spaetzle. I loved that they let you swap sides, as the spaetzle entree looked delicious but I wanted a bit of protein with my meal. The schnitzel felt a bit dry to me, but I am no expert of German food and xchnitzel has generally always tasted dry to me. The dish also came with a salad that was surprisingly tasty. I don't even like leaves, but these tasted pretty darn good. Overall, I was having a five star experience up to here. The food was good, the atmosphere is great, and it's just a wonderful environment to hang out with friends over delicious food. 

the bad:
They overcharged my party by around $50... that's no joke. If you overcharge by a drink... I could maybe let it slide. But $50?? They put two additional plates on our receipt. It was our fault for not detecting it and resolving it in the restaurant, but one of my friends called afterwards and the issue was never resolved... and that felt really shitty to me as a customer. I understand that mistakes get made, especially when you're in a really busy restaurant and there's a large party, but overcharging by such a significant amount of money is no joke. Our party probably could have been ore aggressive in getting the money back and calling them more, but it's just such a hassle and pain that it's almost not worth it.

I don't think my bad experience will necessarily deter me from coming back because the food was so good and the atmosphere is great, but I guess my warning is more, if you have a large party, just remember to check your receipt so this doesn't happen to you!
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Oh my goodness. Where to start. 

The place is a bit small, but has a lively, buzzing atmosphere. It can get pretty crowded since the place is not huge.There is only one bathroom stall for the women and one for the men, so the line can get long (so be prepared!).

We came here for the boots. Not just a boot, but boots. We had a group of 11 people. Our waiter told us they normally only allow one boot per table, but given the size of our group, he managed to squeeze in one more for us (much appreciated!). They hold onto your credit card in case any damages occur. I handled that boot like Cinderella's glass slippers and couldn't breathe normally until the busboy came by to take it away (thank goodness). I'm not much of a beer person, but I really enjoyed the Oktoberfest (and that's not because it came in a boot). 

The food was heavenly. Had the sliced lamb chops in a truffle butter sauce that came with mixed veggies and potato pancakes (normally comes with potato au gratin, but substituted the potato pancakes in). The lamb chops were cooked on the outside and reddish-pink in the center - a perfect medium rare! Plus, I loved how they were served it with the bones so I could continue gnawing on them to get every last morsel. The truffle butter sauce only made the dish that much better and even made the vegetables taste divine! The potato pancakes came with a side of applesauce, a combination I am not familiar with, but that definitely rocked my world. Fried to perfection and the applesauce adds a nice sweetness and cleanliness to the potato pancakes. Makes me want to try making it at home (though I think I will fail epically).

Service was spot on.The busboy and waiter did a great job of taking our orders, getting our orders out, and clearing our plates and glasses. Never had to request anything twice. Really, I can't think of anything to complain about. 

Cheers to the food, beer, and service!
author: Nina Z.

description: A great place for small special events. Excellent German beers. You have a decent selection of tapped beers. They also have seasonal rotations and various bottled beers you can try. Bartenders know their craft.
author: Margaret P.

description: Absolutely fabulous and authentic German as it gets!  Don't mind the community table thing but do wish that they had a few romantic tables for two.
author: Tim G.

description:
Always a line but it leads to this magical world of beer and fried food

The schnitzel www great as well a German beard with an orange on it
author: Laura G.

description: Great spot for german food in sf. The menu has many german dishes which is awesome. Small, lively and very packed restaraunt with a large part of the space dedicated to the bar (it's really not a big space). It appears that ALL the tables are social so you'll probably be seated with other folks. Lots of tables had several couples and there were actually quite a few groups of about half a dozen the time I visited. Reasonable selection of german beer as well.
author: Will D.

description:
Love this place when you have a big group! 

All of the food is so good- get the porkloin in mushroom sauce! And a boot :)
author: Tara N.

description: Simply one of the best German food restaurants. Surprisingly not too heavy food. Tender meats and well balanced flavors. Excellent German beers. You have a decent selection of tapped beers. They also have seasonal rotations and various bottled beers you can try.  Attentive staff, no complaints.
author: Wyatt M.

description:
I came here last week to try real German food for the first time. When we got in, all the tables were community tables. I decided to go with a seat in the bar area. Craig took our order and he was great! He had wonderful beer suggestions and helped me a ton. 

After a while in the booth, the temperature got extremely hot so I asked to sit at a community table. It cause a lot of problems and I felt bad about it.. But I'm pretty particular and I can't eat while sweating. It takes away from the eating experience! 

Anyway, the hostess told me next time I should stick with the spot.. I just didn't know it was going to be that hot. Our food came out shortly. I got the sausage with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes plate and my boyfriend got fried pork with potatoes and bacon! The sausage was really good! Very juicy and it went well with the mashed potatoes. The fried pork was good too! It was breaded and crunchy! Both meals went well with the beer. It was extremely filling! I was so full by the end of the night. 

When the bill came out, I asked who my tip would go to and it was transferred to the waiter who only helped us by saying "do you need anything else?"  So I tipped the bartender, Craig, and the waitress separately since I had caused a problem for everyone. :/ but yeah. It was a nice restaurant and the food was delicious! I would come back to try their other beers!
author: Meliza M.

description: I'm one of those Germans that hardly ever eats German. Unless I'm in SF because Suppenküche is the most authentic, friendliest and hippest German restaurant I've been to outside of Germany.
author: Neil D.

description:
I rarely eat German food, but after coming here I wanted to try more!

Hayes Valley area always has good food, and this place makes the list. I came in here shortly after 11am because I know finding parking in this district can be a pain during rush hours. Street parking here. The exterior of the restaurant isn't eye catching, but once you're inside, it has a nice feel to it whether it be the customers, the servers, or the overall atmosphere. If by chance there are not enough tables to accommodate your group (the smaller the better), they offer the option to seat you with a party at another table. Some seating may be a bit tight, but it works. Service is very friendly; they always check in on you to see how you are and how you like the food, which is super kind of them.

Here's a Tip: If you aren't too familiar with German cuisine or German food in general, I advise you to look at Yelp photos for references since the menus are all text. I'm a picture menu guy, so I'd rather know what the food looks like before I order it.

Got the Potato Pancakes, Grilled Pork Sausage w/ Sauerkraut and Mashed Potatoes, & Chicken Schnitzel. Also ordered a Schneider Weisse Hefeweizen.

I wanted to try the Marinated and Braised Beef, but they don't serve that during brunch/lunch hours. The potato pancakes were bomb. Basically crispy hash browns with aside of cinnamon apple sauce. Whoever came up with this idea is a genius! The grilled pork sausage and chicken schnitzel were delicious as well. Individual bites of the meat, potatoes, and sauerkraut taste alright, but if you eat all the ingredients at once, then you're in for a delight.  Same goes for the chicken schnitzel. The beer tasted nice, but I wish I could've tried the big boot though.

Would recommend this place to all my friends.
author: Kevin S.

description: First off, I got the Ruß and loved it! I can taste the lemon soda but it did not overpower the beer. For my entree, I got the Jägerschitzel. The food came out pretty quick. The pork was perfectly cooked so that it was not too dry. The mushroom sauce was delicious and definitely enhanced the flavor of the pork. I've never had spätzle prior to coming here but the flavor and texture reminded me of gnocchi. Overall, love this place and would definitely return!
author: Rose L.

description:
My favorite restaurant to date in San Francisco, I go here whenever I can. It's loud, but intimate. Quaint, but foreign. The service is great even when it's packed to the gills.

I've been here maybe half a dozen times. I don't even like pork, which makes up half the menu. But the trout. I dream of the trout. It's fried with a creamy lemon sauce and served sauteed spinach, and a delectable potato. It's filling, warm, comforting.

Equally good when on the menu is the roast chicken and dumpling. I want it back on the menu. Really badly. 

The goose is also.... Well just woah. Where else can you get goose? Much less well done????

Although I don't eat pork, I hear good things about the jaeger snitzchel, which comes with a creamy mushroom sauce. 

If you're in the market for an appetizer, get the pretzel. The cheese sauce is cold, but savory.

And you can't beat the beer selection. Just come here. You won't regret it.
author: Adriana A.

description: My mainstay for home-style German cooking. The house spätzle (served with many of the mains) and beer selection are great. This place can get a bit noisy, though.
author: David S.

description:
Great German restaurant with a wide selection of beer and delicious food. The decor/interior is uniquely German, appropriately so! The pork entrees are excellent,  and potato pancakes is a must-order appetizer! 

Patrons should be aware that they won't seat you until your full party has arrived and if there are only a few of you, you might be sharing a larger table with others. 

Service is quick if not a bit rushed, the staff could be a bit more friendly.
author: Critic X.

description:
How come I've never had a MIXED BEER DRINK (beer + lemon soda) before here?  It's my favorite drink now.

I would recommend everything we got:

1. Pretzel with Bavarian cheese - Bavarian cheese is a mix of soft cheese and either butter or cream cheese.  It's not everyone's cup of tea but it's delicious.

2. Pickled herring with sauerkraut, beets, carrots, cabbage, butter leaf lettuce, and a perfectly soft potato.  The pickled herring was the perfect texture and the flavor wasn't too strong in any way.  I would highly recommend this.

3. Roasted pork with sauerkraut and dumpling - To me, the dumpling was the STAR of this plate.  I thought it would be just like a plain piece of dough to serve as a side, but it's more like round meatball with many spices and herbs.  

4. Marinated and braised beef with lingonberries, red cabbage, and spätzle - Beef almost tasted like it was braised in wine (which it probably wasn't) but it had the same depth that is both hearty and comforting.

The bartender helped us pick a drink based on a series of questions; I appreciated the effort.  I loved the hustle and bustle of this place.  Suppenkuche isn't a beer garden so expect a slightly more intimate environment.
author: Shannon L.

description: Solid with all kinds of beer from Germany, bread and spread is very authentic.  We ordered Neuberger sausages with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes- it is good but in Germany, one would always serve it with German potato salad (not with mayo) - I suppose mashed potato is an american modification- otherwise the table, silverware, vintage decorations in the bar room - just like Germany !
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
We came for dinner during an extraordinarily hot weekend in the city (87°F!) which made German sort of a weird dining choice, but we'd heard great things and wanted to taste that meatloaf pretty badly. 

The place was packed fairly early (6:00) on a Sunday but we lucked out with a super sweet spot on the corner at the back portion of the bar. 

Service was a little bit slowish, but nothing to really complain about as we were able to hail the bartender whenever we needed anything. 

I ordered a beer and the venison dish that comes with sauerkraut and spatzle which was so well cooked and very flavorful! I almost thought it was beef because for venison it was much less gamey than I'm used to. Of course the bf ordered himself the meatloaf and mashed potatoes which was awesome too! We originally thought that maybe the egg could be weird, but it added a really nice flavor that I wouldn't have expected.

We barely had room but the black forest cake sounded really good so we went ahead and ordered that too to finish the meal. We pretty much inhaled the cake as fast as we inhaled our entrees and I think our entire meal lasted less than 45 minutes in total.. 

If you're looking for hearty German nibbles, definitely bookmark Suppenkuche! You won't regret it.
author: Siobhan F.

description:
FOOD = 5 (looks plain, but tastes amazing)
DRINK = 5 (lots of good beer)
AMBIENCE = 4 (lots of *communal* seating, which could potentially be awkward, but we had very friendly tablemates!) 
SERVICE = 4 (great/normal)

RECOMMEND
- pork sausages w/ mustard dip
- potato pancakes (like the McDonald's hash browns of my youth, on steroids) w/ applesauce dip (pairs amazingly well with the hash)
author: Allison T.

description: Best schnitzel I've had in years, had the Gefluegelschnitzel!!  so happy I found this place, beer list is on point. Staff were amazing and made our experience great! It's my new favourite place in the city.
author: F T.

description:
Hmmm....I wish Yelp allowed the option of giving 3.5 stars because that is my true rating of the place. I came here primarily because of the wonderful Yelp reviews, and I can certainly understand why people enjoy this restaurant. 

The interior has a very homey, casual feeling--nothing fancy. There were communal tables, but since I was by myself, they seated me at the bar. The bartender was very friendly and accommodating, and I think that's ultimately what pushed my rating up to a 4. He gave a great suggestion for beer, and it definitely complimented the weiner schnitzel I ordered. 


That being said, the bill amounted to $30 after tax (no tip included yet) which to me is a bit pricey, considering the relative simplicity of the meal. The food and beer were good in my opinion (this was my first time having German, so I had nothing to compare it to but I enjoyed it nonetheless), and while I enjoyed the experience overall, the price was a little too steep for my liking.
author: Allison T.

description:
Overall Service: A-
Food: A
Beer Selection: A
Our server: A+
AMBIANCE: A+
Crowd: A+
Only one le Boot per table : frowny face

Every time I come here, I have a really good time. I love love the servers here. They are so personable and make sure you have a good experience. You feel like you are friends with them. Also the customers who come here usually have a good vibe and easy to make friends with at the community tables.

This place can seat a lot of people, I barely had to wait each time. Longest I had to wait might be around 20mins, that was only once. I think if you come right when they open or little before, you might get a seat. Coming with a group bigger than 4 or 5 is not really recommended. It can be really busy and hectic, and might be hard to get your server's attention.

Food: The food here is pretty good and generously portioned. My favorites are the Breaded and Sautéed Pork loin with potatoes and Sauteed Pork loin with mushroom sauce. Ultimate comfort food!

Beer selection: Excellent. If you don't know what to get, ask for suggestions from your server. Also get the big boot, but they only give you one per table. Just pass it around and share the goodness, if you can't finish by yourself.

Parking: Street parking can be tricky, but it is manageable. On average you might spend 5-10mins trying to find parking. Good luck!

Overall: Definitely recommended. I will be frequenting this place.
author: Solongo B.

description: I'm originally from Germany and have been at this place a couple of times and tried most of their dishes. While I like the atmosphere and the beer selection, I would consider their food as 50% German. It's very Americanized and I expected it to be more on the german side. For SF, this is a good spot to get some german food but comparing it to real german food, I wouldn't recommend it. I still go here because I really like the beer (Andechs is great). I would come here all the time if they got a chef that worked in Germany for a while and knows the secrets of real german food. Example: in Germany, we NEVER serve hot  Hey pretzels. Never! We like them freshly baked, cold, non fatty and crunchy.
author: Maria H.

description:
Favorite brunch spot in the city. Check it out if you're into: German food, meat, brunch in a very casual spot. We loved this place so much we had to make a concerted effort to make ourselves  brunch elsewhere on Sundays. Sadly they don't do lunch on Saturdays. 

We always got seated very quickly, probably because of some communal style tables. Still pretty surprising given that you have to wait 1+ hour in other joints. Service is super friendly, they take their time to explain whatever questions you may have about the German food and bring out a beautiful basket of breads. It's nice to have some good salty bread and butter as a precursor to the actual meal. 

It has large windows so it's bright and light. Like in other brunch restaurants, there's alcohol available and it's pretty common to see others drinking beer even at brunch hours. But here you can get a radler (half-and-half mix of blond lager and lemonade). 

Delicious grub includes:
Jägerschnitzel (Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce). The shniztel is very freaking good. 
Spätzle (Egg noodle dish)
SAUSAGES = true German-style sausages, long and thin. And of course, delicious mustard.  
Sweet wise I had a nutella thing that was great but that I can't remember what it was and is no longer on the menu (I'm clearly not a sweet brunch type of person). I'd trust them with my food though. Five thumbs up.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Decided to come here on a Sunday around 1 p.m. while visiting San Francisco. 

It was pretty chaotic when I walked in with no place to wait to get a table. I just had to wander in and flag someone down which frankly took longer than it should of.

Seating is limited for this popular place, so my options for someone dining solo was either at a communal table or in the dark behind the bar. Since I hate sitting in the dark, I opted for this communal table next to a family where this woman had to move her purse off a chair to accommodate me. It was slightly awkward, but definitely could be worse. Too bad the few seats at the bar where already taken.

They were serving brunch at this time so I ordered the following two things:

1.Museli with Yogurt, Milk and fresh Seasonal Fruit for $11
2. Warm Pretzels with Bavarian Cheese Mix for $8

My food was pretty good.

This place is not meant for people who want to dine solo comfortably, but it's pretty unique which is why I'm giving them 4 stars.
author: Regina W.

description:
I have been here twice and both times have been really fun. I like the ambiance and lively energy of this place. The beer options are wide and you can even order different sizes...from .02 ounces (great for trying different things) to 5 liters (great for sharing)! It is a great place to go with friends. I think the 2 liter option is a fun boot shaped glass. If you have 6 people or more I would highly recommend that you make a reservation. 

Both times I have ordered a pretzel and thought it was delicious, warm, and perfectly salty. I have also ordered the german ravioli. It is an appetizer but for me it is entree sized. It comes with three large raviolis stuffed with meat and covered in mushroom cream sauce. So good! 

The other meals are mostly meat and potatoes. I have not tried anything else though.
author: Diane R.

description:
A nice chill place to grab a German brew and some authentic (from my limited experience) German food. I didn't know what to expect and didn't think I would be a huge fan of German food but I ended up really enjoying both the veal schnitzel and potato pancakes. The food is pretty heavy (schnitzel also came with potatoes) which depending on your take either helps to soak up some of the alcohol or simply prevents you from getting your buzz on. I was very fond of the cucumbers (pickles?) that came with the schnitzel - a nice and refreshing palate cleanser between all of the bites of fried tastiness.

The atmosphere is laid back but loud, and when it's crowded they will seat tables with multiple parties. If you are in a social mood then this is a great way to meet some new people (and to size up their food and beer selections). As a side note, they do bring out bread and butter to start, which is always a plus for me.
author: Nerri Y.

description: I've wanted to go to Suppenkuche for the past 10 years or so, but it'd never worked out, and maybe my expectations had just gotten too high. I'd stopped by a couple of times but it'd always been impossible to get a table, so I was happy that a little before 6 pm on a Tuesday night, it was not too crowded - although to wait for my dining partner, I had to be corralled into the tiny, crowded bar area. Once we found each other, we were able to sit in the relatively more spacious common dining area. But, I don't think either of us was particularly impressed with our food - the spaetzle was bland (and not in a carby delicious way!), and the pork was nothing special. I hope the homeless person I gave the leftovers to enjoyed it more than I did.
author: Lisa K.

description: Have been going to Suppenküche since it opened and never been disappointed. Love the decor and the fact that the place has kept its identity through the many trends of SF. The food has actually gotten tastier and lighter over the years. We always go for Christmas goose around the holidays and once in a while for brunch -- a go to place for the family. Love the schnitzels, the sausages and the butter lettuce side.
author: Laurence P.

description: Awesome food.  Great german flavors.  Great beers.   Tell them what flavor you're looking for and go with their suggestion.  Clean and Simple environment.   Friendly place.   Good service.   Great at noon on a Sunday
author: Barry J.

description: Great cozy atmosphere, delicious food and awesome beers. The portions are sizable so definitely go with an empty stomach! We had the chicken schnitzel, sausage, and cabbage salad. 10/10
author: Hadley B.

description: I like the idea of this place, and the look, but the food is definitely not as good as it is in Germany, and it's overpriced for lacking in flavor. The service is always so-so, nothing special. I like that they have community seating and that the place is like a block away from the beer garden in Hayes valley.
author: Natasha K.

description:
Ok this review breaks my heart to write. My husband and I have been patrons of Suppenkuche since 2000.  I'm talking 17 yrs of fierce loyalty including birthday celebrations, dinners with out of town guests, and the occasional brunch (cuz beer in the morning!). We schlepped our babies here once we moved to the suburbs. We get there at 4:50 for the first seating. We bring ear plugs for the kids now grown. But last week they let us down. We hadn't been since the summer (which is rare cuz we never miss the gluhwein in December). You see, we lived in Heidelberg, GE for a few years and when we found Suppenkuche we were ecstatic!  The only place we found that did schnitzel right, thin and crispy and as big as a plate. The germischte salat was perfect, the bread...dark with the crust that sticks in your teeth, the chive butter and the butter lettuce salad! All of it! Like stepping into the gasthaus we loved!  But then they went and CHANGED it. I should have known something was up. First it was the Bretzel, 1 not 2 anymore. Ok, no big deal, I like to put the extra cheese on my bread. I asked the waiter for bread, "we are out of bread and we have to charge for it now" huh? No bread?!  Ok, then the meal comes. The schnitzel is thick, like a pork chop (what the..?) the gravy on the jagerschnitzel was smoky (no!).  The last straw was when I asked for the abfelstruddel. The abfelstruddel that my kids literally fight over when they have to share it (I'm talking elbows flying and spoons wars). Waiter: "We don't have it anymore" Me: "ok, what about the Black Forest cake" Waiter: "no, but we have a killer cheesecake" Me: "huh?! Ok wth is going on?!  The schnitzel is thick, no bread, I'm distraught!" Waiter: "well we have a new chef. I've been giving him feedback about the schnitzel" 
I just sat their with my mouth hung open and tears in my eyes. No abfelstruddel? So I ordered another beer, cuz that's still good, and drowned my sorrows. It took me days to get over this. I guess this is what happens as you get older. Your favorite places change and then you die. It was great while it lasted. Thanks for the years Suppenkuche. It's been real.
author: Tracie P.

description: Speaking as a German and a person I would describe as a food connoisseur This is the best authentic German food you will find anywhere in the world (besides Germany obviously)  do not miss out on this hidden gem !!!!
author: Kk S.

description:
Love traditional food in real home setting. 
Comfy food just like home...loved the potato soup and potato pancakes with applesauce.
Definitely someplace I could easily sit for hours with friends if the food was not so filling--definitely need a nice walk after..lucky, there's a cool park about a week up.
author: Dianne A.

description: I love German food and this is some of the better cuisine I have gotten outside of Europe. Really good schnitzel and relatively reasonably priced. Also very much enjoyed there potato pancakes. Design and decor was minimalist and would be my only two cents for improvement but all in all great spot.
author: Sean S.

description: I'd give this a 4.5 only because it doesn't open until 5 pm on weekdays and no reservations for smaller groups. Servers aren't the most friendly and insist on having you share your table even when not necessary. But food is excellent--we have been 2 or 3 times and all is very good. Been to Germany and even authentic. GO if you are in the Hayes Valley area for sure. And the beer is awesome but do not try to huge boot unless you have a lot of time!
author: carol p.

description:
Come hungry!  The portions here are huge and the food is delicious. 

The service is efficient and friendly. Not overly chatty, but very accomodating and quick.  This allows for freedom of conversation at your table, where you're sat communal style with other groups. 

This place is crazy popular, so if you don't want to wait forever, or you have someplace to be by a deadline, try to get there as close to opening as you can. We were seated straightaway last time we visited (we arrived shortly after 5) but there have been other times we had to find food elsewhere cuz the wait was so long (like 45 minutes+).
author: Charlotte B.

description:
THE PLACE 
Quite small, big communal tables. Very crowded and a lot of noise so maybe not the best place to have "quiet conversations" but I love the lively atmosphere. 

YUMMY.
We ordered some potato pancakes which was some kind of potato fritters served with Apple sauce. Tasty 
We had a mixed of salads and veggies served as pickles raw. And some excellent Mac and cheese sort of pasta that I couldn't figure out what I was but was so Damn good. 
Tons of Belgium beers served. You can get the extra extra big size for you and your friends (or just yourself if you're up for a challenge) 

MONEY 
We got away for 50$ for two with three dishes and two Belgium small beers.
author: Daphnée A.

description: We used to eat hear once a week when we lived in Hayes Valley.  Now it's once a year around Christmas, mostly to appease my German roots.  Food is still fantastic and the beer selection is the best in the city for those of us who still don't buy into the IPA madness.
author: Aaron G.

description: Very friendly bartender, very knowledgeable about beer. Food is great, the sausage is a must try. Excellent service
author: Rocky Y.

description:
Yum! Cool German place with a rustic vibe to it. The decor was kind of cute and silly with all the planets hanging from the ceiling.

The place gets really busy so my friend's friends tried to get a reservation. My friend and I thought they had secured a reservation so we arrived first (super early for our supposed 6:30pm reservation). We were told we were not on the list and the hostess was super helpful in double checking for us. Turns out the friends had not reserved anything - miscommunication on our part! The hostess still put us down on a waitlist and my friend and I headed to the bar area for some beers. We did end up getting a table for 6 just a little later! Nice and lucky.

I ordered the pork sausages with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. Filled me up much more than I expected. One person in our group had ordered a 2L boot of beer! That was a fun experience.

I liked how cozy and clean the restaurant was. Everyone was enjoying their food and having a good time. There was a lot on the menu that caught my eye like the potato pancakes and the ravioli, mmmm maybe next time. :)
author: Shanise M.

description: They make all tables communal, which could be a good or bad thing depending on how much you value your privacy! The food and vibe is great though, so might be worth the sacrifice at least once :)
author: Vivian W.

description:
Wow, I really loved the food! 

I came here for Saturday dinner for 2 and found parking very close to projects. Surprisingly it was not very busy and found parking relatively quickly. Also, the Suppenkuche sign isn't too noticeable when you drive by. It's written on the windows, which can be hard to see. I just made an assumption that this was it since there were so many people in front of it. I was afraid we would have to wait.

We got very lucky once we got in and were seated right away! I was thrown off because we were seated in their communal style tables. It may be uncomfortable for some. 

We ordered the German ravioli with mushroom cream sauce,  grilled pork sausage, and the lemon hefeweizen. We shared all of this and were pleasantly full. The food was delicious! I especially liked the pork sausage. It was served over potato,  saurkraut, and a side of mustard. It was SO good. The flavors were on point! I also generally don't like "bier", but the added sweetness of the juice made it tasty. Loved it. Would try again.
author: Lyra C.

description:
As others have said, Suppenkuche is loud, crowded, and no frills, but it delivers on the German beer hall atmosphere, beer, and food. The fact that you can order 2 liter boots or 5 liter steins should clue you in on the vibe. I came here with my husband for dinner on a Friday night and we didn't have to wait too long (30 min). We were seated at a communal table and got the pork knuckle and spatzle. The portions are HUGE - I'm not one to take home leftovers (go big or go home) but I only got through half of my spatzle. The pork knuckle was unique and yummy, as long as you're prepared for fried, fatty food. My husband was meh on the bread dumplings that accompanied it, though. All of the food is pretty heavy... probably to help absorb all the beers you'll drink! I'd say the food is about a 3.5 for my taste, but I bump up my overall rating to a 4 because this restaurant is so unique and has a large beer selection.

Overall I think Suppenkuche is best for a small group looking to have a celebratory meal with lots of beer. It's pretty loud for a date spot, but I'm happy that we tried it and I appreciate the unique setting.
author: Cynthia S.

description: One of my favorite Austrian/German Restaurants in SF. Such friendly staff and intimate/hipster vibe. Highly recommend.
author: Shannon P.

description: Excellent food! Authentic German food, and great service. Definitely recommend for anybody. A little crowded and noisy but that's the true German feel! Food was delicious!
author: Michaela O.

description:
Perhaps Suppenkuche is the type of place you visit to drink until you're so full that you can't move anymore. Maybe it's where you have dinner while you're downing that boot of beer. I suppose I can give it another chance if that experience is pitched to me.

We went for brunch, however. We had a group of 7 (originally 8) and my friend called to make a reservation for opening time. All of the tables seem to be about the same size and to be honest, the table is too small for 8. I couldn't understand why we had to squeeze even though we had a reservation. Luckily, the 8th didn't come and 3 not too big Asians fit on one long side of the table.

The food options didn't wow me but I decided to get the first item on the menu. Please don't ask me to pronounce it. Essentially, it was a few slices of smoked salmon, raw onions, and capers on top of a couple of pieces of butter lettuce. It was served with a not so "soft-boiled" egg and cream cheese. Seriously? The portion size was tiny and the price was too high for what I was getting. Luckily, I had an afternoon tea to go to but if it wasn't for that, I would've been starving all day.  The smoked salmon was nothing special; actually, the whole dish was unimaginative and boring. And the egg yoke was almost as solid as a hard boiled egg. One of my friends was super enthusiastic about this place and I didn't want to let her know but this was a waste of my time and money.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Wonderful place to start out the night. They have a wonderful list of German beers to slaughter the pronunciation of and you can get them all the way from a middling .5L to a giant 4L boot. That's a lot of boot.

I had the Jägerschnitzel with spatzle and a few .5L beers. The communal tables and beer garden like vibes make for a fun place to get full and buzzed at. Service was friendly and the food was good.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night with a party of 6 for a friend's birthday celebration and I thoroughly enjoyed my experience here at Suppenküche!

Suppenküche is a nice bar and restaurant situated on a street corner within the Hayes Valley. The interior is decorated and laid out quite nicely, but still leaves a comfortable and somewhat casual feel to it. My group had a reservation and was seated in a room towards the back where there were long wooden tables with some small candles on them.

Looking at the menu, I really had no idea what any of the food was, but given that two of my friends knew the German language and the food/culture, I knew I was in for a treat. We started off the night with some pretzels to share. I thought the pretzels on their own weren't really that special, but with the addition of their mustard and creamy cheese, it was a delight to eat. The cheese had a very unique texture and flavor to it, being quite creamy and having a nice pungent kick to it reminding me of certain fermented foods.

Afterwards, a whole lot of dishes landed onto our table at once. Without going through dish by dish, I would generally say that the pickled vegetables were the highlight of my meal. Most of the meat dishes come with it and they also have some salads with a variety of them. They have a nice acidic sour punch to them that makes them interesting. The starches of the meal were quite interesting as well. Their spätzel was on point. It looks like scrambled eggs from a distance and has a nice doughy consistency to them with a rather neutral taste. The potato pancakes had a nice outer hash brown like crisp to them and went surprisingly well with the applesauce served with it. Other than that, I thought the meats and fish were cooked rather well, but tasted fairly typical. It were the various sauces such as mustard and cranberry sauce that added to the meat to make them memorable.
author: Joshua M.

description:
So I've been here twice. First time I had a poor experience, and second time didn't get much better.

Food: less than palatable. All the meats are soaked in salt, it seems. And if a place can't serve good meat why would you go there? 

Service: very rushed, to their credit they do try to get to you in time but it's just too busy. The wait generally ranges from 10-30 minutes before they seat you on an average night. 

Atmosphere: it's dank, dark, cramped, and not pleasant to dine there. Somewhere between a bar and barn, this place isn't somewhere I'd take family, friends, or a date. There are far better places in this city. 

Drinks: they have a very good selection and mix them well. I had  a banana beer and it was the tastiest part of my dinner, which is why this review earns 2 stars. 

Each time I come here I have to navigate the menu to find something palatable. Usually my friends and I encounter a 15 min on average wait and expect a 25-40 dinner tag. Add in the cramped space and dark atmosphere sitting on benches, and you can feel why this place is a tad overrated.
author: Henry L.

description: Absolutely one of the best German restaurants in San Francisco! Great food, beer and service.
author: Billy N.

description: Came out with a friend to finally try some German food and this place was pretty decent. I'm very into sour beers at the moment, so I knew I had to try the sour beer here. I was expecting there to be a bit more sourness, but it slightly lacked. The sour beer at Gourmet Haus Staudt in Redwood City is one of the better German sours.. The food was pretty good here. Nothing screamed out and stood amongst the others, but it was fun to be able to try something that isn't very prevalent in the Bay Area. The staff however were incredibly friendly and welcoming. I would probably come back to try and defeat the boot... maybe.
author: Brie R.

description: Found out about this place from the Travel Channel. I live in San Diego and have been wanting to go here for a long. Finally got the chance traveling for my company at the time. Street parking can be tricky. But once you're inside is all good! Great beer & food! Wow! Highly recommend! Enjoy!
author: Richard C.

description:
Looking for a great place to grab some German comfort food? Well, look no further. My boyfriend and I love German food, and we've had a couple other places scattered around the bay, but this place really takes the cake thus far. 

I don't believe they take reservations. There was already a line outside even before they opened! So, if you don't like waiting, show up early, because there might be a bit of a wait just 30 minutes after they open. 

We passed on the beer, since we drank earlier at Japantown's annual Cherry Blossom Festival. We went straight for the food. After careful consideration, we ordered 2 specials--the bacon-wrapped asparagus with potato covered in a lemon butter sauce, and the roasted dumpling-filled half chicken with potato pancakes--the meatloaf, and the salad.

Starting out with delicious complimentary bread and herb butter, we quickly filled up on the asparagus and half of the salad. The lemon butter that covered the asparagus was so good, we ended up sopping a bit of it up with bread. The salad consisted of lettuce topped with a variety of tangy cabbage, beets, shredded carrots, and potato salad. The tanginess of the salad really balanced out the flavors for the rest of the meal.

We thought we weren't going to be able to eat the entrees, but once the meatloaf and chicken arrived, it was bite after bite of amazing foodgasm. The potato pancakes taste like amazingly crispy hash browns. I was in love with the creamy mashed potatoes and the savory meatloaf--comfort food at its best. The chicken was moist, and the skin was crispy. I only got a bite or two in, because my boyfriend devoured that chicken dish so fast, he might as well had inhaled it.

Bookmark this place! It's really worth the trip, especially if you don't live in the city.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Get the salad (there's only one on the menu), and the pork chop.  Delicious!!  

I love the atmosphere here.  The waitstaff is always friendly, never any attitude.
author: Kristen S.

description: I love this place. The food is great and the beer selection is second to none. Staff is wonderful. We've had lots of bday dinners here.
author: Alan H.

description:
The food here is really good. I love this type of German food. Always find it very comforting. My favorite is the breaded pork with roast potatoes and peas. It's on the specials menu but think they've had it all the times I've been here. The jäger schnitzel is not breaded for some reason, which is a disappointment, as that's what I'm here for. 
The service is really good in general. The main downside though is that the tables are very close together. If you're only two you'll most likely sit near bar and it's not very comfortable- no leg room for tall people. And also you'll be sitting really close to people too. Seems more of a place for a good food experience rather than a long dining and conversational type dinner experience.
author: Derek M.

description:
*** In Short ***

Enjoyable, but not particularly memorable, pricey German food.

*** In Depth ***

Finally made it out here a few weeks ago, after having heard rave reviews about them for years, and I can't say I was particularly wowed - though, to be fair, I don't remember a time when German food has ever really blown my mind.

* Potato Pancakes - These were, admittedly, pretty tasty, but it's hard to mess up what is essentially just hashed browns with a side of apple sauce. Or, well, I say it's hard, but a number of the ones we had actually came out slightly burnt and bitter.

* Herring Salad - This one can probably be put on me, because the texture of the herring was a lot like that of sashimi, which I'm not really a fan of. Texture aside, the flavors of the overall dish weren't bad.

* Meatloaf - I was one of those weird kids that liked meatloaf, so I have a tendency to try it when I see it on the menu. Good flavors all in all, but a bit too salty and plain to me: I mean, yes, there's a lot of flavor in the meatloaf itself, but all the plate is is a slice of meatloaf and a heaping of mashed potatoes, which'll run you $18.50.

So, the real issue here is highlighted by the last item above: it's not that Suppenkuche is bad, it's just that it's not good enough for me to justify going again, given the prices. If not for what I consider to be slightly poor value, they'd qualify for a low three stars instead.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - There's a large single step ledge at the entrance, which can be traversed with the aid of a somewhat narrow, portable steel ramp that the staff can bring outside for you. If you're not with a group of friends, I suspect you'd have to try your luck either flagging down a stranger to fetch an employee, or calling their main number to have them bring it out. The inside itself is a bit on the crowded side, and getting to your table may necessitate having to ask some people to shift around.

Bathroom - As far as I could tell, the only restrooms they had had incredibly narrow entrances, and were not accessible whatsoever.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Loved this place! Our group didn't know much about German food so we split a bunch of stuff family style (soft pretzel, meat loaf, pork sausage and braised beef) and it was all fantastic. I recommend trying a bunch of things to see what you like best, as we each had a different favorite! This is definitely comfort food and portions are large. 

The beer selection is great too. If you don't know German beer it's pretty inaccessible at first glance, but the bartender was helpful in trying to find us something we each liked and letting us taste a few things. I had a dark beer I absolutely loved that I definitely wouldn't have figured out to choose on my own!

I'm only deducting a star because the service at our table was not the best. We ordered a round of drinks we never got and had to wait really long stretches of time to get the server's attention.
author: Christine G.

description: Great place for try good German food. Always great. Delicious brunch, friendly service and good German beer selection!
author: Payton R.

description:
First all, this is comfort food. It's gonna be a little heavy. Factor in the beers and you might die of food coma. You've been warned.

This place is great, albeit a little crowded. Expect to sit family style (and if you get there late or on a weekend night, to wait awhile) and be treated to the most delicious beers and German food ever. 

I highly recommend the bratwurst and the kolsch that they have. Their spaetzel is also very good, depending on how hungry you are. The pretzels are warm and come with home made mustard :) or cheese.

The decor is sparse, but whimsical and the whole room (especially on rainy nights) feels so cozy you'll never want to leave.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
A seriously grand time was had by all!  

For my pal Eamon B's birthday, family and friends gathered for boots and boots of beer and rich German food. Suppenkuche has oft been raved about by members of my crew, but I never even knew where or how awesome it was. The vibe is modern and chic, the staff is friendly and attentive. I've frequented the sister bar, Biergarten hella times, but was very excited to try the food at the restaurant.

Eamon B, Jeremy P, Ally S, and I arrived early and started on our first boot, dark bread and chive butter, and warm soft pretzels with cheese. The appetizer was super good, and we played the boot game were you can't set down the glass, can't have the toe pointing at you, and have to flick the glass before you pass it - very fun. I got splashed in the face and everyone got a good laugh. We even got an applause from the rest of the folks in the back room where we sat for embarking on such a large boot de brew.

Ally S and I shared the Kartoffelsuppe (Potato Soup) which was comforting and delicious. For my main I had the Veal which I think was one of the specials of the evening. It was bomb digginty! My mom used to make my dad veal a lot when I was a youth, but Italian-style and over pasta with lots of homemade spaghetti sauce. But she and my pops don't eat meat no mo', so I must either learn how to re create this dish, or just head to Suppenkuche because their veal was off the charts. Served with a pickled cucumber and tomato salad and over a bed of roasted potatoes and lardons. Om nom nom. HUGE portions. 

I also tried the Potato Pancake from Jeremy's meal and some of the Roasted Chicken from Eamon's. The chicken seemed to be a real hit at our table with most of the folks ordering that. My friend Aaron W got the Falscher Hase mit Zwiebelsoße und Kartoffelbrei (Meatloaf wrapped in BACON and EGG!) with Mashed Potatoes, and we really didn't hear from him until he came back up from polishing off the whole plate. 

Needless to say, it was an epic meal from beginning to end and I hope to be back soon. Reasonably priced, make a reservation if possible, we didn't have to wait at all which was very nice.
author: Crystal C.

description:
This was probably my first time trying real German food. We started off with beer, my friend and I both opted for a Belgian sour. I think it could've been a little more sour, but it was pretty refreshing. We ordered the smothered pork chops and the bratwurst plates and shared it among ourselves. I'm not a fan of sausage at all, but theirs was really good! Especially with the sauerkraut and mustard- MMMMM. Nothing to rave about the pork chop dish- kinda just tasted like the pork chops I cook at home and it was paired with (what looked like) mac n cheese. Overall, I enjoyed the experience. The staff and bartender were really nice and welcoming and I like how they have communal tables. 

Next time, I'm going to order a 2 liter beer in the boot cup. It looked like it would be fun lol.
author: Dara S.

description:
My cousin says to me, I'd take you to get Filipino food but it's a bitch to get to and we can't all fit in the car.  German food it is, I say!

I came to the city for an overnight conference and to visit family I hadn't seen in a while.  Dinner here was an awesome idea.

Seating is Euro-share-sies style and there were 5 of us at a table with room for a couple on the end.  I started off withHofBräu Helles, a style I have been enjoying of late.  

We shared an order of the Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus ($12.00, Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce) which were nice and crispy.  The common comment amongst us though was that we found them a tad too greasy.  The apple sauce was nice though and, greasy or not, we finished them.

I hadn't had wiener schnitzel since going to Leavenworth, the little German town in Washington, not the Fort variety.  The Suppenkuche version was Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und Grünem Salat ($19.50 Breaded and Sautéed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad).  It was also super crispy, like the potato pancakes, but what's it take to get veal anywhere?  When I make it myself from a legit recipe I found, I use a nice and tender veal.  The meat here could have been anything with a nice crispy breading.

The potatoes on my plate were diced so it was a nice change from the pancakes and the salad had a nice and light vinegar dressing a la Italian style dressing.

The restaurant was packed for dinner and the place got noisy.  We had 2 kids with us and apparently it was deafening for them.  If you want to take a date here and actually get to know one another, here's where an exception to texting might be okay.  The couple at the end of our table were talking like they whispering into each other's ears but you could hear that they were talking loudly to one another.

Everything was brought out and cleared from the table in a timely manner.  The waitstaff was totally nice.

I'd come back again for sure and next time partake in more of the beers and try something else besides their schnitzel like the beef with lingonberries or the venison or the pork sausage...all which sound amazing!
author: Phoenix A.

description:
It was my first time eating German food and I would say that it was an experience! My friend's cousin chose this place and apparently made a reservation so I suggest getting one because when I went inside, it was packed!

We waited for about 5 minutes until our server seated us in a table that we had to share with another party which was awkward... The place was kind of tight too and the lighting was dim.

I ordered the bratwurst with roasted potatoes. I totally forgot the name in German because it was long. Our food took a little bit to get to us just because it was packed which was understandable. Took about 10 minutes but it was worth it. The mustard with the bratwurst was tasty and I couldn't get enough of the roasted potatoes!

I would definitely love to come back here again and try their other dishes just because I feel like I got an appetizer rather than an entree and I ate prior.
author: Aj C.

description:
Great atmosphere and great company. Had brunch here and ordered the eggs, potatoes, and daily sausage. Such a great meal. The food was 10/10 and the beer selection was great. The seating is community style which was pretty unique and we had a great conversation with the people next to us. 

Definitely would recommend!
author: Boris T.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, and the reason I moved to the neighborhood. In addition to the friendly and authentic atmosphere, the staff is very knowledgeable and always providing spot on recommendations! The beer menu is superb, and the menu has an option for everyone! If you're not looking for a full meal, I recommend taking a spot at the bar where you can order a few bites!
author: Liz P.

description:
Wow was this place busy in a Friday evening.  Either that or it is just really small, but maybe a combination of both.  We got sat on the same table as a party of 6 which was kind of awkward.  Reminded me a bit like London seating at restaurants.

I ordered the sautéed porkloin with mushroom sauce which was very tasty.  The sauce was amazing and was full of flavor.  Went very well with the porkloin.  

My bf had the marinated and braised beef that he thought was mediocre.  I agreed but my dish was amazing.  The waitstaff was nice and very attentive.  Our food came out super fast.  Seems like we sat and ate all within 30 mins! lol 

I should have gotten the potatoes to start since apparently that is the thing to get.  My bf lived in Germany for a bit so I trust his opinion but I enjoyed the dinner! 

Oh the free bread appetizer and butter was good too!
author: Nyla K.

description:
Such a fun and energetic restaurant! Love this place. Everything is perfectly themed, from the straw flower light fixture to the servers' whole getup. 

We ordered the pork sausage and sauteed trout and both were delicious! Even had leftovers after downing our beers haha. Don't think you could go wrong with anything on the menu, though everything is heavy, so steer clear if you're looking for something light. Will definitely return for dinner and am genuinely curious about this German brunch! 

A table across the room ordered the giant boot and lemme tell you, it is no joke. They must've been passing that thing around for a couple hours. 

Typically has a line, try to make reservations. You'll likely end up sharing a table at peak hours, which only adds to the jovial and lively atmosphere. We ended up talking about mustard  with the group next to us and it was a great time! :D
author: Jennifer L.

description:
4.5 stars

Sometimes, grabbing dinner with a fellow adventurous eater can be comically frustrating thanks to some dire need to try the new and unique. At least that was the case when I came back home to the bay. We'd toss out some dinner ideas only to have them impulsively tossed back along with an "I've had it before." haha 

And that's how I found myself here. My friend and I arrived about 15-20 mins after opening and Suppenkuche was already packed! Moreover, we were told the wait was an hour! I didn't feel like looking for another place so I decided to wait it out. 

Was it worth the wait?

You bet your sweet ass it was! The food was quite heavy and filling but that worked out perfectly on a cold December San Francisco night. My dinning companion was really feeling like comfort-food so she ordered the meatloaf and mashed potatoes ($18.50) which had bacon and egg and was topped with onion gravy. The meatloaf was super delicious and the bacon really came through. The mashed potatoes were rich and smooth. But it was the gravy that brought it all together.

As for me, I ordered the weiner schnitzel ($19.50) which were breaded pork loins with roasted potatoes and a side salad. Man, that was tasty. The pork had great texture and I loved the crunch on the outside but there wasn't a whole lot of moisture inside (though it wasn't dry). Then I realized that Suppenkuche actually gave me a couple lemon wedges! T'was buried under the pork loins haha. It worked out perfectly and brightened the flavor. The potatoes were rustic and I liked that they added substantial pieces of bacon. However, that side salad seemed rather half assed as it looked like someone cut a wedge of lettuce (just a wedge) and doused it with a simple dressing. We both thought that was funny.     

All in all, I am a fan of suppenkuche and I will be back at some point. Don't come here expecting privacy as you will likely share a table with other customers but if you are just looking for delicious (albeit heavy) food and copious amounts of beer, stop by!
author: John B.

description:
Fantastic German food.

German food is inherently pretty mediocre, but this is fricken great mediocre German food (and I mean that as a completely non-ironic compliment). The potato pancakes and pretzel/cheese appetizer situations are both so, so good. And all the German mains are hearty and delicious. Also, the beer selection is, as would be expected, solid.

You will leave here with a full belly and a warm heart, assuming you love yourself some gut Deutsche cuisine, ya! (My only complaint is I wish the waitstaff all had thick hardly-understandable German accents. It would really add to the ambiance.)
author: Megan B.

description:
This place is lots of fun.  They let us taste before choosing our beers, and they have a large assortment of sizes, up to ginormous.  We enjoyed sitting in the little alcove behind the bar area where it's warm, wood, and old pictures that remind me of my grandma's.  The beer was good and the food looked and smelled delicious, though we didn't eat.  My sister likes to bring folks here when they visit from out of town.

Only drawback was it was super crowded and noisy, but that kind of goes with the whole feel of it, so it was fine with us, but I wouldn't bring my parents here if it were this crowded.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Really yummy food! I had the potato pancakes, and it was definitely crave-worthy. Love the ambience inside, and since we got there at opening time, there wasn't a huge wait. Definitely going to come back here and try the spatzle and get a huge boot of beer!
author: Priya B.

description:
Enormous portions for both food and drink! The food is heavy and tasty - but I really mean it when I say heavy, not for the faint-hearted. We food coma'd for a good hour after our meal, but we also ordered too much; again, come prepared. 

It does get crowded so come early if you can. We ended up getting seated in a dark corner facing the wall. (To be honest, we didn't really care; we just started inhaling our food.)
author: Judy S.
