description: A Hayes Valley staple, this restaurant always makes a visit to SF special. The wait for a table -- no reservations -- can be horrendous on the weekend. Better if you can be there as they open. Seating is European style, so be prepared to meet the other folks at your table. I would avoid on special occasions, like Father's Day, as the wait can be hours. So negative so far, but note I've given, AND THEY DESERVE, five stars. Because the food is awesome. Order anything, it'll be great. I'm personally a fan of the Jagerschnitzel and garlic soup, but IT JUST DOESN'T MATTER what you order. Just go! Go now!
author: Al P.

description: Nothing but love for suppenkuche. Great food awesome atmosphere. They have an awesome selection of German beer, and an equal selection of German food. Schnitzel and sausages = :)
author: Samuel S.

description:
This place is popular, like wait-for-a-while-in-line-for-a-table or be-prepared-to-squeeze-your-way-to-the-bar popular.

I'm a big fan of the sausage ravioli. And I didn't get the chance to try this time, but I definitely want to try the beer in the boot :) 

Casual atmosphere - kinda loud, but that's perfect if that's what you're looking for. Relatively young and active crowd on a Saturday night. 

I definitely plan on coming back here again
author: Bianca C.

description: Great place for German beer and cuisine. Although the wait is long since its always busy, it's worth the wait if you have the patience.
author: Kepano L.

description:
I never thought I would be giving this place less than 5 stars... it's been one of my favorite restaurants in SF for almost a decade.

I don't know if they switched owners or got a new chef, but the food was just not great. My salad was wilted and soggy, but most importantly - the jaegerschnitzel! What happened?! They changed the recipe of this almost iconic dish to something completely underwhelming. Now it's covered in this bland, orange-colored mushroom sauce and the pork was super dry. 

I hate to say it, but I may not be coming back very often - I'll be at Walzwerk.
author: Cory D.

description:
Came here for Sunday brunch because it was highly recommended by hubs. It was definitely his favorite German food place in San Francisco he's been here previously with family definitely highly recommended by him.. He says it's the erdinger beer for him, reminds him of Germany.. 

Walked into it, looked around it was a super cute quaint little place, it's very different from anything I've ever been to before because they have a type a seating where it's like strangers sit together if there's no seating at other tables, so everybody gets to know each other that way like a friendship table.. 

Waiter came took our drink orders and gave us some time to look to the menu. On the table top, there was homemade fresh strawberry jam, berry jam, churned butter and fresh fennel/ poppy bread. 

The waiter brought back our drinks and took our order..  I ordered a pork schnitzel with a mushroom gravy sauce with homemade spätzel with a home garden salad and hubs had chicken schnitzel with a gravy, creamy mashed potatoes and two over easy eggs.. 

It was really such a awesome atmosphere to be in, everyone was happy smiling, just super friendly and having a wonderful afternoon.. Our Waiter came and checked on us every so often to make sure that we were happy that everything we had and needed..  

After meal he came over and spent some time with us to have a chat about why we were there, where we were from and told us places that he recommended for us to go to while visiting San Francisco.. He didn't have to do that but it just made the experience so much more personal.. Would definitely recommend this place for anyone visiting the Bay Area and who wants to venture out and try amazing/ tasty German food..
author: Diana B.

description:
Nice german restaurant in the middle of Hayes Valley. Drawn to it after hearing loud chatter through an open window while on the street corner--that kind of energetic people-are-having-fun-in-there chatter. Curiosity got the best of me and after a cursory review of the menu, I dove right in. Turned out to be a good decision.

The ambiance is very traditional german. Dark, dim lighting, big communal tables for seating (sit with strangers unless you're a group of 6), boisterous chatter (particularly at the bar area), and minimalist design (felt like I was inside a renovated barn). 

I ordered the porkloin and braised beef. The porkloin was thinly breaded, tender, and came with a side of roasted potatoes with bacon bits; a dash of lemon made this dish just right. The braised beef was on a dry side, but the cranberry sauce and red cabbage added some needed flavor for the otherwise plain dish. The Hefeweizen was predictably fantastic. 

Altogether a nice unique experience. German food isn't my favorite. But going outside my comfort zone led me to really good comfort food.
author: Behnam S.

description:
I've been here twice for dinner.  Things I've consumed in that time: Trout, suckling pig (on the Tageskarte), späztle, troughs of beer, pretzels served with a side of german potato salad.  Things I haven't liked out of the above list: nothing.  literally, nothing.  Bonus points for awesome service, and it is in my hood.

Side note: if you pan fry leftover spätzle, it turns into a magical pile of melty cheese and noodles encased in a crispy brown crust.  I have a weird obsession with fried cheese that has culminated in my pan frying shredded cheddar on more than one occasion just so I can have a giant fried cheese pancake, but I'm not even overreacting at the deliciousness of this.  I would seriously order it to go just so you can do this the next day.  You can thank me later.
author: Daniella S.

description:
Got in for a late dinner at 9pm. We put our names down and headed to the bar in the middle of the restaurant while we waited for our seats. 

Great selection of beer and the crowd was cool. Chill atmosphere. Got seated within 10 min.

I ordered the beef with spatzle. Hit the spot. Meat was tender and sauce was on point. Would recommend.
author: Amanda H.

description:
Some of the best German food (and beer) in the Bay. I'd recommend Suppenkuche to anyone for a good meal and a fun evening. Great selection of beers and serving sizes, up to the 5L stein!

Make a point to get by Suppenkuche sometime. It's great.
author: A O.

description:
LOVE this place! 

AMBIANCE
its a small neighborhood restaurant located on the corner of Laguna & Fell. When you walk in, there's a velvety curtain that separates the waiting area from the dining area. The moment the curtains open, you are literally in the dining room. They have a small bar towards the back side of the dining room. They serve the full menu at the bar and the bartenders are all very fun and nice. Its busy, lively, vibrant, romantic and cozy. Communal seating is their thing. A table of 4 will seat 2 random couples, a table of 6 will seat a group of 4 mixed with a group of 2. This may be a little awkward but trust me, once you start drinking and eating, you'll forget all about this set up and might even make few new friends!

FOOD
Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus (Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce). This is to die for!!! Super crispy on the outside and chewy with the perfect amount of salt on the inside. Their homemade apple sauce is amazing and goes so well with the mouth watering potato cakes! 
Kassler vom Grill mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei (Grilled Cured Pork Chop with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes) Its HAM cooked to perfection!. I'n not a huge fan of sauerkraut HOWEVER, i'll eat it here!. it has the perfect amount of seasoning and "sourness" where its not overpowering other things i'm eating with it. Mashed Potato is creamy and once you put a spoonful into your mouth it just melts. If you want, you can actually substitute the mashed potatoes for the Potato Pancakes.
Few other things to note - their Spätzle is the BEST and Wiener Schnitzel is two thumbs up! 

DRINKS
Beers Beers Beers! so many variety to choose from. if you're not too familiar with german / Austrian / Belgianbeers beers, ask the servers/bartenders. All of their suggestions has hit home run with me! Want something different ? try their BANANA BEER! it tastes just like a Banana Smoothie! I'm not a beer drinker but this! i'll always order when i'm here! They also serve their beers in a boot. Perfect for a large group to share.

OVERALL
if you don't mind waiting, check this place out ! it's definitely worth trying! Service is friendly and its just a fun little neighborhood restaurant!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Brunch at a German Beer Hall, Yes Please! 

I ordered the standard breakfast plate (two eggs, links and potatoes) 

Eggs-sunny side was ok, could have been cooked less and seasoned more 
Link-had an amazing snap, well seasoned, reminiscent of vienna sausage 
Potatoes-cooked well, bits of bacon was a nice touch 

Beer-believe I had a kolch?, definitely had a much stronger finish that most that I have tried 

Bar area is a little cramp but still a nice intimate vibe

They offer Das Boot! 

Overall Thoughts

Solid brunch fare with a causal upbeat environment
author: Eddie W.

description:
German food, and German beer, how could you possibly go wrong? I've visited the city a few times and finally had the chance to visit. 

We didn't get to sample the menu in depth, but everything coming out of the kitchen looked wunderbar! Ordered the schintzel with roasted potatoes and a pretzel with obatzda. They were both really good. I wish the rye bread was fresh. We had what I assume was the left over end of the day batch. I will be sure to come back and eat everything on the menu! Prost!
author: Will H.

description:
I really enjoy this place but there are some quirks that you have to be ok with.  The seating is all communal and the place is loud.  The tables are fairly close together and if you are not ok with being close to people this is not the place for you.

The beer and the food are awesome.  Get some beer and a pretzel to start out.  There is a great selection of German beers and you can order a boot of beer if you feel adventurous.  I saw someone get one and its actually about the size of four beers so you have been warned.

I usually get the Wiener schnitzel.  That's a breaded pork cutlet served with potatoes and salad. I eat the pork with a sweet german mustard but there is also a version with a tasty mushroom gravy.  

If you are looking for a fun (but loud) environment with good German comfort food you will enjoy this place a lot!
author: Gabriel R.

description: Whenever out of state friends visit San Francisco I bring them here. Seating is communal, and although frequently loud and busy the restaurant is a fun place for dinner. The selection of German beer is wide enough to suite any palate. The meals are hearty. I recommend the venison when it is on the menu.
author: 0 R.

description: We loved the restaurant and the food was great.  It is small and very noisy.  Most likely, you will have others seated at your table that you do not know.  It's a fun place.
author: Nancy W.

description: Came for brunch; was disappointed by the mediocre food. Can't say much about dinner anymore, but this was definitely a letdown for the price. Different kitchen staff?
author: John B.

description:
Gosh I just love this place because of the delicious food and friendly staff.  I suspect a German Grandma is being held captive in the kitchen and forced to produce the best and most flavorful Bavarian cuisine.  
Favorites - smoked pork chop, trout, roast chicken (when they have it OMG) cooked to absolute perfection.  The bread is a dark german sour delight! Even the side salad was simple and fresh with just enough fresh herb and a light dressing to make it exquisite.
A beautiful dinner for a great price so expertly cooked.
author: Kathy O.

description:
As my significant and I approached the front of the restaurant, Debbie Downer, nearby, was shaking his head, exclaiming, 'Forget it. It's packed.' We entered anyway, flagged down a server, and she proceeded to walk us to a table with two other couples, and whadda ya know? They have communal sitting here! Comeuuup. We urgently accepted the seats and a minute later some random dude comes out of nowhere to bring us bread (Uh dude, were you watching us? 0.o). Impressive service despite how busy it was. 

Mehr Bier, Bitte!: More beer, please! 

We ordered a liter of a regional German specialty, Gravensteiner, (unfiltered, unpasteurized lager) for $16.00. The golden-colored Gravensteiner was smooth, crisp, and had a soft taste. Its brightness paired well with the rich and heavy flavors of our entrees. Shout out to our server, Stefi, for recommending this one. 

Hau Rien!: Dig in! 

Again, despite how busy it was our food came out ASAP. I went for the sautéed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce with Red Cabbage & Spätzle ($22.00), while my significant ordered the Sauteed Trout in Lemon Butter Sauce with Bouillon Potatoes & Spinach ($17.50). 

THE VENISON

The venison was lavishly drenched in its red wine plum sauce, which gave it a sweet and tart flavor. The meat itself was eh, kinda chewy, similar to a skirt steak. I favored the meat towards the center of the venison, as it was delicately tender, and less chewy than the surrounding meat. Unfortunately, I would rather eat a medium-rare rib-eye steak. :( The red cabbage that accompanied the dish was too sour for my liking. The fluffy pillows of chewy Spätzle on the other hand, were a splendid side for the venison. Similar to the texture of gnocchi, the Spätzle, was doughy and light. You could say that the Spätzle was an upgraded version of macaroni. The dish also came with extra red wine plum sauce, that I did not pour onto my venison, as the existing amount of sauce on the venison was sufficient. 

THE TROUT

Thee underdog of all entrees served here, as most patrons overlook this one. Mmm those luscious Bouillon Potatoes though. The creamy and buttery potatoes reminded me of a slightly firmer mash potato side. I guess I got too excited about them potatoes though, because I almost forgot to commend the exquisitely moist trout. The skin of the fish was notably crisp and provided additional flavor. Squeeze the lemon all over the trout for a slightly fresher, livelier taste. 

Wo finde ich die Toiletten?: Where can I find the toilet?

The result? A gratifying food coma and ultimately, a pleasurable numero dos session. Yes, we shall be back for the praise worthy service and good food.
author: Merica S.

description:
For the average San Franciscan, consuming huge quantities of burritos, lumpia, ramen, and sourdough can be monotonous and rather exhausting over time. (Le'sigh- life is so hard for us!) Although the average Bay Area resident seems to have every kind of cuisine at his fingertips and around every corner, it's somewhat infrequent that one stumbles upon an authentic German restaurant. Cue Suppenküche: a lively -aka hella LOUD and crowded- fun, and legitimately German eatery, to break the invariability of the usual SF meal! 

Suppenküche serves up a diverse menu of super heavy, hardy dishes that are smothered, slathered, and nothing less than drenched with huge quantities of delicious sauces and STUFFS for lack of accurate descriptors. (I -told- you German food is rare in the Bay, okay!?) Pair these offerings of rich food with giant boots of delicious beers, and you have an establishment that all of your soul-cycling, body-pumping, cross-fitting loved ones who respect their health will run far, far away from. That means more space for US!

DO: Come here after work to get sloshed with co-workers over boots and pints of [banana-infused] German beers | for a night of a different kind of meal than the usual Chinese take out with your family | to show your friends you are trendy, adventurous, and somewhat financially afloat because you're taking them out to Hayes Valley

DON'T: Come here ready to sing your favorite, sexy German lullaby to your date. This place ain't really romantic unless you get hot and bothered by huge crowds and breaded pork | Expect low-cal, fat-free, vegan fun. These plates are as brown as you can get. Sorry to burst your Whole Foods-formed, gluten free bubble!

If you can get over the noise, long waits, and the sheer volume of calories entering your body, you're really, really going to love this place! I recommend it to anyone and everyone in the area.

As they say in Germany: "PROST!!!!!!!!!" *clink* *gulp*
author: Stephen D.

description:
Came to Suppenkuche once with a group of friends to celebrate a birthday dinner. The entrance was a bit hard to find, and I'm pretty sure I entered through a side door or something...

We ordered a few appetizers and entrees to share. We ordered pretzels+cheese and some salds to share; those were pretty average.

We then ordered a few meat entrees: meatloaf, jagerschnitzel, trout to name a few. They were all pretty tasty, but none of them were particularly memorable.

The highlights for me were definitely the:
- Spatzel and sauerkraut: which were perfectly cooked and flavored.
- Potato pancakes: cooked very well, very flavorful, and went well with the applesauce.
author: Alvin W.

description:
Went in based on Yelp reviews. Street parking only and can be a challenge. Got there at 6pm on a Sunday. Girl said 20-30minute wait but closer to 30. We walked around but thankfully only walked for 15minutes as our table was ready. It is somewhat family sitting so u may have to sit at a table with others unless u have a party of 6 or so(we had 3). 

The spaetzle ($19.98) was cheesier than I expected. Like a super rich mac n' cheese. Not to my liking and overpriced for it. Their grilled salmon with lemon butter caper sauce $23.00 was delish. My man had the sausage plate and said it was great. Beers come in humangous mugs depending on the size u order.
author: Ann N.

description:
This place is really good! I came on a Thursday night with two friends and we were seated immediately! The seating is really unique in that they just seat you wherever they have space so I would say 90% of the time you go with a small group - you'll be sitting with randoms at your table! The restaurant itself is very very dark (see my pictures) and I just wished it was a little more lit in there. 

We ordered the potato pancake and raviolis in mushroom sauce as our appetizer and they were both super super good. The potato pancake is perfectly fried on the outside and soft on the inside. The complementary apple sauce that goes with the pancake is also really good and makes the potato pancake taste even better! The raviolis in mushroom sauce was really good as well - I love the mushroom sauce! 

For our entree, we got the meatball entree and the sausage entree. Both were good. I wouldn't suggest getting the meatballs since they were kinda dry but the sausages were really good! Both came with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. The entrees were super big and by the end of the meal I was stuffed!


Parking is only on the street and it can be sometimes hard to find... okay usually hard to find :)
author: Stephanie W.

description:
When I think of German food, nothing really comes to mind other than...beer, wiener schnitzel, beer, and pretzels. But little did I know, this place would open my mind up to some amazingly delicious German cuisine!!

Struggling to find a place to eat, my friend saw that I had this restaurant bookmarked so he suggested that we try it since it was on my  "to try" list anyway. We stopped by around 4, but it wasn't open til 5. So on we went to kill an hour time before coming back. Luckily we came back 15 mins before opening cause there was already a huge line of people standing around already. I was slightly shocked. Who eats at 5pm?!?!

Anyway, it was already packed inside when we got seated. Didn't know what to expect from the food, but we ordered chicken and beef...

Chicken with dumpling and potato pancakes: OFF THE HOOK. The chicken was executed SO well. The skin was super crispy, but not oily either. How?! And the chicken itself was so tender and juicy. It was just excellent. The potato pancakes reminded me of dry instant ramen since it looked so stringy, but those were so good as well! Just think of a round stringy hashbrown.

Marinated and Braised Beef & Spätzle: The beef was so delicious. Also VERY tender and juicy. Spätzle was kinda like a pasta of some sort, not really my cup of tea...but the meat is something to drool over.

Both entrees came out to be really hefty, so you won't leave hungry. The food definitely left an impression on me. I'm so glad we came here for dinner!! Also really glad I came 15 mins earlier to stand in line too. This place got really really packed in the first hour. Definitely would come back!!!
author: Yannie S.

description: I like this place.  It is a cozy neighborhood place that has been really full when I've gone.  It feels so cozy on the inside and makes me feel like it should be snowing outside.  The food is good and the beer is great!
author: Lynda M.

description:
Eh, not really digging the food, service, and the communal seating.

My friend from out of town came to visit and we were looking for a good place to eat in Hayes Valley. Sunday nights out could be pretty busy, so we anticipated that. We called up Suppenkuche to check how long the wait was, and the waitress mentioned that there were still open tables left, and that we would not need to wait. 

We walked over there in a minute since we were in the area, but the host told us to wait about 20 mins (lol.. ok.). We proceeded to the bar to try some of their beer (from what we heard, the beer is good).

My boyfriend got a sour ale, which was super tasty, and a few of my friends got the porter with a coffee base. Overall, the beer was bold tasting, and good.

We got seated pretty soon, but the waiter told us how to be seated so that they can fit other people into our table too. First off, it's awkward to be told how to be seated, and secondly, we were a group of five that was squeezing into a table that was probably made for 4. 

Another couple walked in and got seated into our table. Being seated in the specific positions our waiter suggested and having another group within our table made the flow of the conversation within our friends pretty awkward. We then politely asked the couple if they wanted to trade seats so that they can be closer to each other, and that our group can keep our conversation within ourselves. 

From there, the experience still did not get better. It took us forever to flag down a waitress. It took forever to get our food. I even asked our waitress where our food was. Towards the end of our wait, we were pretty cranky.

Anyway, about the food:
- Pork Sausage - This was good, but not outstanding. I don't know how to describe it-- it was limp. And not juicy. I did like the sauerkraut though.
- Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce - Pork was dry. Cuts were thin. I was still hungry afterwards
- Salad (the one that came with my porkloin dish)- One of the best salads I've ever had. I think this wins, but it's freaking sad because I came here for German food, but their best item was their salad. *face palm*
- Trout - Ok seriously though, the trout was better than the sausages. It was slightly crisp on the outside, and soft on the inside, and very buttery.

Overall, I think there are better German styled dining experiences in SF that I would rather return to (Paprika in the Mission is one of my favorites).
author: Grace H.

description:
I might be falling for some of the hype by giving it 4-stars. I'd say it's more like 3.5. But I digress.

Good
- German food and german beer. Need I say more? :)
- Community/shared tables. This can be good or bad depending on who you're sitting with. We shared a table with some people who were, let's just say, less than ideal to become long time friends with, but it good go the opposite way, too.
- Food and service were good. I wouldn't say either were out of this world, but good. I got the venison and my wife got the sausage platter. Hers was much better than mine, so maybe I just picked the wrong thing (wasn't a fan of the sweet cabbage, but that's probably just a personal preference).

Not so great
- The wait to get a seat. The 1.5 hour wait itself isn't their fault. In fact, it's probably a good sign. However, most places nowadays offer to take your number and text/call when a table is available. This would be especially helpful due to their bar being extremely small. There are tons of places in the area to grab a drink, so it'd be awfully helpful to be able to do so without fear of missing your table. It also seems like it would help the staff out as well. I'm sure there are instances where wait times are misquoted and people aren't there, then get upset when they come back to check and find out they missed their name.
- Again, food and service were good, but not great. Maybe I just expected much more based on how everyone talks about this being *the* german place to go to.

After my first experience at Suppenküche, I much prefer Leopold's (which I've only been to once as well). I would say that Suppenküche might be more fun if you have a large party and Leopold's if it's just 2 of you (smaller tables). That said, it's german beer and german food - which is always amazing - so check it out at least once. Make sure, though, you either go right when they open, or have something to do as you spend an hour stuck right outside the door.
author: Derrick S.

description:
We arrived at prime time on a Saturday night. After attending the bacon and beer festival in the South Bay earlier that day, a good, substantial meal was needed. We were quoted an hour and a half wait for or party of two, and unusually they will not call or text, if you're not there... Too bad! I kind of like it because it meant people didn't always stick around and our wait only ended up being a little over an hour.

We hung out at the bar and worked our way through our half liters of beer, which I didn't manage to finish before being sat and a family style table. The atmosphere is very chill, the noise is the sound of conversation and in this age of being so engaged in your phone, it was kind of nice to just hear the noise of fellow diners' chatter.

They have a (forgive my German) Targes Karte with some great specials, how pretzels aren't in the regular menu I don't know but we started with those and they were delicious. I went with the sausage, sauerkraut and mash potatoes for my entree, seemed the right thing to do and I wasn't disappointed.

Our glasses were kept full, which is awesome because I am that person who chugs my water as soon as it is filled. The server, bar tenders and host were all very friendly and I'm sure we will be back!
author: Sarah S.

description:
I love in the area so come here a fair bit. 

This place is especially great for groups, since they have a number of larger tables. 

Food:
- great selection of beers and the bartenders are very knowledgeable 
- the pretzels are amazing - Warm and soft!
- the spätzle is really good, but the entree is impossible to finish because it's so rich! Though I highly recommend getting one to share if you're in a group or getting an entree which serves some as a side (such as the porkloin which was great!)
author: Tanay J.

description:
German food has become somewhat popular over the recent years outside of Deutschland. In the US, you'll now find Oktoberfest parties in every city, you can get a Pretzel year-round, and order a Hefeweizen (wheat beer) at certain burger joints (no kidding).

The German in me wants to pull a face and rant about the stereotypes out there - although Oktoberfest originates from Munich, Bavaria is actually only a small part of the country. Outside of Bavaria, we laugh at people in Lederhosen, eat Pretzels only if a Doner Kebab is not around, and hate Bayern Munich. Okay, we do enjoy a Hefeweizen from time to time.

My German and Dutch friends had some convincing to do but I left my skepticism at the door when I entered Suppenkueche. A German beer bar and restaurant in Hayes Valley? Let's give it a try.

Interior - simple. Not too big of a place. Get here early or make a reservation. Something between restaurant and beer hall. It will get noisy. Ganz schoen.

Drinks - Wein und Bier, das rat ich Dir. German beer from the bottle or draft, wine selection. If you had a craving for a specific Pilsner or Hefeweizen, this is your place.

Food - Surprisingly good. Portion size decent, nicely arranged on the plate. Tried the Kartoffelsuppe (potato soup, $6.50), Linsensuppe mit Bratwurst (lentil soup with Bratwurst, $6.50), Nuernberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut ($14.50) and Rehmedaillons in Rotweinsauce (sauteed venison medaillons in red wine plum sauce, $20). 

The food was good and tasted almost like home. Almost, as home for me is what my mom cooks but this food comes close (Mom, if you read this, you're still the best, I love you).

And: service was fast and friendly, including German natives. 

Overall, if you never had German food and want to get an idea of what these Germans eat at home, Suppenkueche delivers. 

And if you're German and you miss your mom, maybe this place can take away a little bit of Heimweh.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
***** My Star rating is based ONLY on the food quality. Price, service, etc are not factored *****

Food: 
 This place blew my mind. If I lived in SF I'd come here every week (I'm on the East Bay, so it's not easy for me to get here).
 Sausages - AMAZING
 Braised Beef - Meh
 Porkloin - Wonderful!(Please do try this, the sausages were great, but these were just as good. I just didn't expect the sausages to be as good as they were).
 Spätzle/Spatzle - AMAZING!!

 I don't really like beer, but the beer here was wonderful. I tried several different beers, but one stood out the most. Schlenkerla marzen (a smokey beer). It was smooth. So smooth it didn't even taste alcoholic. And the smokey flavor was great. Afterwards I went to buy this beer from Total Wine, but it was not the same. 

Service:
 It was great, but I wasn't really paying attention to it. All I can say is that they were very nice and fast :)

Other: 
 Parking is just like most places, street parking. Good luck have fun finding it. It took us a while to find street parking, but that's ok since we had to wait a while for our table anyways. I can't wait to come back here.
author: Phil K.

description:
A great place to try German food if you've never tried before.  

For food, I've had the potato pancakes with apple sauce; which was crispy, filling, and delicious with the sauce.  The Wiener Schnitzel as the main entree is a big piece of breaded pork loin.  The meat is tender with a nice crunch, and a lemon is provided to give extra flavor.  There's a long list of German beers, so it's easy to find something you'll like to drink.  

This place fills up quick so come early.  Tables are shared, so that needs a bit getting used to.
author: Karen L.

description: Great spot, a little crowded.  The food is good but could use a little more flavor and a little more German love.  The Jaeger Schnitzel was a little dry and the spatzle lacked as well.  Atmosphere is great though like a German guesthouse.  You do feel rushed though as they want to quickly turn over tables.
author: Scott S.

description:
SF has a plethora of restaurants, so I made a mental resolution a while back that I would try a new restaurant every time I dine out. Suppenkuche is one of the exceptions. The food here is amazing - the fried pork loin in mushroom sauce with spatzle on the side is one of those dishes that are too big for me to finish, but I'll scarf down anyways because I just can't stop eating.

Aside from the wonderful spatzle, the atmosphere here is just wonderful and adapts well to almost any occasion, from a fun, rowdy night out with friends (thanks a delicious and varied selection of beer served by the boot-full, so emphasis on rowdy), to a romantic dinner date (thanks to the candle lighting and whimsical dining room decor).

Suppenkuche, if not famous for their food, is famous for their wait, but never fear - the bar is near! Beers flows freely from an island (like a kitchen island) in the middle of the restaurant and patrons can gather around and enjoy a few brews with friends to pass the time. So prost!, and head over for some good times.
author: Patricia K.

description: Fantastic and refreshing german beers for a Friday afternoon! Liked the hefeweizen. Great pairing with the sausage, tasty! Also had the beef stew but this one was on the dry side.
author: William J.

description: The WORST waitress EVER. Ever, ever.  I don't care how good the food is suppose to be if the waitress just dumps ones plate with her back to the table so she can get back to her conversation with the hostess.  I was the only customer.  She was not busy.  Her total disregard for me was insulting, a beyond rude presentation of the food.  I went up to San Francisco to experience many different cafes for lunch and dinner and was treated really well by everyone so it wasn't me.  This girl should not be in the food business.  She should get a job data filing so she doesn't have to interact with anyone.  I will never recommend or go back to a place that hires someone who treats paying customers with such awful disregard.  No thank you!
author: Laurel M.

description:
My fiancé and I arrived at the Suppenküche around 6:30pm on a weekday with no reservations and got seated automatically. There table seating is communal in a small space. It's a great place for groups. Note, it did get busy and crowded around 7pm.

Beer: Ayinger Celebrator Dopplebock (highly recommend) and Radler. The staff and bartenders are very knowledgeable of what's on the menu. Here's proof:  my fiancé didn't know what kind of beer he wanted. Our amazing server with an amazing mustache asked what the fiancé was feeling for, which was "dark and heavy, but not hoppy". The server replied, "I know what you want. Trust me." He came back with an Ayinger Celebrator Dopplebock and my god, it was delicious and on point what the fiancé wanted. I had the Radler and it was quite refreshing.

Food: 
Appetizer: Potato Pancakes with homemade Apple Sauce (Rating: 4/5) - crispy and delicious. The potato pancakes is a little saltier than my preference but luckily the apple sauce is there to balance it out.

Entree: "Sauerbraten", Marinated and braised Beef with Cranberries served with Red Cabbage & Spätzle (Rating: 4.5/5) - NOTE: Portions are HUGE! My fiancé and I shared this dish and without asking the server, he had requested to split our dish into two so we didn't have to share off from one plate. It was really nice of them to do that without charging us the split fee and each plate looked like a complete full plate! The beef was so tender and delicious with the cranberry sauce. The spätzle...oh the spätzle...is my favorite of all on this dish. The only feedback I would have about this dish is that there was a lot of red cabbage. If there were more spätzle and less red cabbage, this dish would absolutely perfect.

Lastly the service at Suppenküche  - awesome. Period.
author: Kelly T.

description: This restaurant has always been LOUD and BUSY and CROWDED. Personally, I do not have problem with sharing tables with strangers but for some of you, this might be a head up. Overall taste for food is great, great selection of beers as well! Definitely will be back!
author: Evander J.

description:
Amazing everything!

+Excellent beer food and service , I had a great time.

-Crowded
author: Silvia U.

description: I absolutely loved the atmosphere! Bartender was a character and made the wait pass by quickly. The food was pretty good too! Great beer. I would recommend going here.
author: Monica F.

description:
Fantastic German Restaurant!

I ordered the Kartoffelsuppe (Potato Soup) and it was great had a great consistency and taste. My friend ordered a Linsensuppe (Lentil Soup) and I could just see his eyes watering remembering the flavors of his childhood in Europe. Needless to say a strong start to our dinners.

Then we shared the Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei (Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes) and it was definitely the highlight of our dinner, tender and just perfectly seasoned. So good!

The ambiance is relaxed and causal, there's communal tables and service is warm and fast. I'll come back.... many times.
author: Angel J.

description:
+ amazing food, truly spectacular with tons of flavor, large portions
+ authentic beer selection

- kinda crowded
author: Jonathan Q.

description:
Suppenkuche is one of my go-to spots to take visiting friends. While it does get very busy on weekends and evenings, on my latest visit with a party of 3, we were sat immediately on arriving around 7pm on a Wednesday. 

The wait staff here know their stuff and can recommend and describe dishes and drinks well. The food seems pretty traditional (to the extent of my limited knowledge of German food), and has always been tasty in my experience. The serving sizes are pretty substantial also. I've gotten the wiener schnitzel and meatloaf and have gone home with at least half of the dishes leftover. 

They do the whole "drink out of a big boot-shaped glass" thing, but they also have a range of sizes, including a more petite pour. It doesn't feel like a touristy gag to me. 

A big bonus for me is the location. I love the Hayes Valley neighborhood and have spent many a perfect evening there with a good meal at Suppenkuche and a stroll around the block to peep in at the myriad boutiques (shoe store, cards/gifts, clothing, leather goods, travel, etc.) followed by a night cap or ice cream from Smitten.
author: Rachel Y.

description:
Suppenkuche is simply amazing! 

We ordered the Potato Pancakes served with homemade apple sauce, Wiener Schnitzel served with roasted potatoes and the Venison served with red cabbage. Every dish was delicious and prepared superbly!

To quench my thirst I ordered the Schneider Weisse Hefeweizen. Probably the best tasting beer I've ever tasted. Flavorful and mild. My new favorite beer!

If you love food and beer, this place is calling for you!
author: Philip K.

description: Having lived in Germany in my youth, I was so happy to spend an evening enjoying the flavors of German cuisine
author: Christina H.

description:
This place is good but it's not worth an hour and a half wait for just 2 people. Our waiter was nice despite the fact that the restaurant was busy, loud, and crowded. 
I ordered the potato pancake, meatloaf, pretzel & bf got the sausage with sauerkraut. The potato pancake is pretty much a hash brown. It was still really good as well as the meatloaf, pretzel and sausage.
author: Joyce C.

description: Had roasted duck, while buddy had pork.  Everything was very good.  Great beer selection.  They did run out of bread to eat with it which was a bummer but the food was delicious.  The Black Forest cake... Is a must!  Was very crowded... To the point it was annoying just walking in and out of the restaurant.  For some reason they put a table right at the entrance which was bothersome to the lady sitting at the end and for those of us coming and going.
author: Mahesh N.

description:
They close at 11pm, we got here at 10pm. 
There's no host but the we found a waitress straight off who put us on the list & let us know that we can wait by the bar.
The bathrooms are located in the hallway that connects on part of the restaurant to the other. It locks via a 2 by 4. Lol. Like legit.

We initially went here for the BOOT BEER.
Apparently, it's a game.
They take a $50 deposit in case the boot breaks.
Once the boot is full, it is NOT meant to be put down. Or the boot will break.
The boot is actually pretty big in size so for us 3 girls to try & do it, the bartender was like .... *blank stare.
So maybe , next time.

The bartender was super nice. I asked what he recommended & he asked if I like light or dark then he gave me Schneider Weisse to sample & it was soooo good that I decided to order a glass. My friend had the Banana beer, it was super banana-y. lol.

The seating is family-style. So you end up sharing a table with another party but we got lucky with seats that wasn't so crowded, right by the door actually.
The ambiance is quite romantical. Bar-esque but the candle-light gives it a really romantic-vibe. Lol. Too deep? Yeah, maybe. Whatevs.

The bread that came before our entrees was quite interesting.
My friend said it might have been soda bread. It was dark & quite dense, the outside was super burnt.
I ate it anyways, so that it could soak up the alcohol.

I ordered the Portobello Mushroom. OMG guys, for all your vegetarians out there. THIS IS THE DISH YOU NEED TO ORDER! I am telling you. You will not regret it. Non-vegetarians might enjoy it too. So delicious!

Overall, my first time trying German food & I must say, I enjoyed it :)
author: Camille C.

description:
Unconventional, hearty, full of life and overall fun times are just a few of the words that describe our experience at this establishment. I am not going to lie, at first I thought wow it is loud in here and when the bartender pointed out that there were open seats available at a random party's table I thought oh dear. It is not what what had in mind but I am.so glad we stayed! So if you're expecting to have your own table this isn't the place for you. You might end up sitting with random people and you'll have to speak up because there is just so much going on in here. It seems like an excellent place to eat great German food or even grab some beers.

Well, we ended up sitting by the bar and Craig was phenomenal with us. He has such great knowledge of beer and great attitude. He made our dining experience so much fun and introduced us to several great beers! My favorite was the Hefeweisen Dunkel. Craig truly made us feel welcomed. 

The food was pretty delicious too! I was a bit sad that they only serve chicken schnitzel on Sundays but our experience here made up for it. Their lentil soup was full of great flavor and so were the ravioli stuffed with pork and veggies on a mushroom sauce.

Our experience exceeded our expectations and that is a plus on my book. The place is small and loud but robust! A solid establishment with a very personable and laid back attitude. Go check it out, and let Craig introduce you to some of his favorite beers.

A quick note: Keep your eyes peeled when searching for this diamond because the sign is very small :-D
author: Nasha W.

description: All around good food/huge portions. My only 2 -'s. My Dad is from Landau (100% Bayern durch und durch) 1.Obatzda needed to be creamier (was somewhat clumpy, no bite and a tad too much Paprika) 2. Need more traditional desserts real Käsekuchen and Apfel Strudel would be awesome. WILL DEFINITELY GO BACK AGAIN AND AGAIN.
author: Cindi S.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here with high hopes but were very disappointed. The restaurant itself was very loud and over crowded. After waiting for 20 mins we were seated at a small table with four other people. I normally don't mind communal tables but there were six of us squashed round a table that, at any normal restaurant, would seat four people. The door opens right into the restaurant and the host just wanders around trying to seat people so at all times there is a constant flow of people standing around looking confused and waiting to be seated. 

The potato pancakes we had to start were very good. The venison was ordered medium rare but came very over cooked and no one came to check on the food so we ended up stuck with it. The chicken schnitzel had a lot of gristle. 

Overall our experience was very underwhelming and at a price of $45 each (for food and one beer) it was ludicrously overpriced!
author: Hannah D.

description:
This was my first time at a German restaurant. Maybe it is because I am unaccustomed to German food, but I was not impressed. 

The lobster soup from the specials menu had good flavor, but I felt like it was too salty. The potato pancakes, which I had been most excited about, were okay. Very fried. Much better when dipped in the applesauce. I was not a fan of the meatloaf. There are actual pieces of egg in it. It was weird. Also tasted too salty to me. The mashed potatoes that came with the meat loaf is extremely rich and filling. 

The restaurant gets really crowded, and unless you want to sit at the bar, you have to find a table with open spots. Communal seating. It also gets VERY loud in the restaurant. I had to shout to my friend to carry on our conversation. I don't think I will be back.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Valentine's Day Grub N' Guzzle. Me and the lady took a ride to the other side. Service was great. Meatloaf was my choice this time around. Delicious! My lady had venison. Delicious! The potato cakes were good, as well. The manager, Erin, was exceptionally helpful and friendly. Great customer service, great food, great sippy sippy, random table mates and a great atmosphere. WINNER! 

Cons
We drove from Fairfield for pretzels. They were out.
I wanted the strudel for dessert. They were out.

Not enough to lose a star, but still disappointing. I'll be back for the pretzels and the strudel. 

Thanks again...
author: Zac O.

description:
German food is hard to find in general, so I'm glad this place exists for the option.  

We came here on a Sunday night with a large party for a friend's birthday, and the place was a complete zoo.  Maybe turning 32 has wore my nerves down but the entire restaurant was packed to the aisles.  There are apparently 2 main rooms, separated by a narrow corridor that houses the 1 room bathrooms (no space to wait I guess).  We had a reservation so I'm not sure how long it would have took to get seated if you just dropped by.  The decor is cute with the weathered wood picnic tables and benches, and some communal seating.  Noise really carries in this place -- I felt like I was having a screaming contest through the whole meal, so don't expect to come here and have a family dinner for conversation.  

The beer menu is pretty much the same as its outdoor rendition down the street -- I had the Radler (a light lager and lemon soda) and it was ok.  We also had everything on the appetizer menu -- the food is not bad but I'm not overly impressed.  Some items that stood out included the German ravioli in mushroom sauce, the potato pancakes with applesauce, and the currywurst.  

Other details: 

* Parking is ok in Hayes Valley -- one of the easier places to park in the city.  

* a lot of other venues and shopping in the area -- convenient location to a lot of fun stuff (like the park on Octavia st)

* Price is a little high IMO but it IS the city and I'd assume everything here costs a little more than other parts of the peninsula.
author: Anita T.

description:
Meatloaf $18.50 
potato pancakes with out of this world applesauce that gives you a lil taste of heaven $12
Light Pilsner -crispy and not too strong $9 

I'm not sure what authentic German food is, but the potato pancakes are a must. The outer texture is a crispy hash brown, simply delish. The meatloaf was meatloaf but it was bordered with bacon, which I really appreciated, with a boiled egg at the center. The gravy was great, not too salty and not your typical out of the can gravy. There was not much onion as the menu indicated. 

the sauerkraut my friend ordered was AMAZING. 

Ambience is very cozy and hip, very rustic with the wood furniture. I felt like I was in a cabin hidden in a German village somewhere. I really want to come back and try their other drafts on tap. Lots of yuppies.
author: Christina O.

description: I dont need to say much! Beer in a boot, superb german cuisine, somewhat of a beerhall setting and a good clean plqce to eat! Parking is a hassle but where isnt it a problem in the city?
author: Frank F.

description:
Amazing German restaurant near my cousin's apartment. They have family style seating which means you may share your table with other diners. I like this because it reduces wait time for a table. This place is so good it does tend to develop a wait.

I really enjoyed the cheese spaetzle and my cousin chowed down on the wiener schnitzel.  The pretzel is a must, and the cheesecake is absolutely to die for.

Great place for dinner and beer on tap!
author: Mrs. C.

description:
Come for the vast array of cured meats, stay for the quaint ambiance!

Being gluten free, the brunch menu was what appealed to me so we swung by here on a late Sunday morning. It wasn't too crowded and we got a seat right away. Yay!

I had a frankfurter plate which was pretty good, but what my boyfriend got was where it's at. He got the meat and cheese platter. It was so much food we could have both made a meal on it. Their mustards that come with are fantastic and I also loved the apple butter. They make a dang good cup of coffee too.
author: Carol M.

description:
Excellent German pub in walkable Hayes Valley.  Sometimes it's empty and sometimes there's a line down the block, and I haven't been able to find a pattern.  

We've gone with our toddler a couple of times.  Before you raise the pitchforks, know that we went just looking for German food for her to try.  I didn't know ahead of time that I was soooort of taking her to a bar, and if it had been busy with twenty-somethings knocking back their biers we wouldn't have subjected them to the objectionable sight of a baby (the horror).  They do have high chairs, and our waitress was friendly with the babe, so clearly they're cool with kids (probably less so during the later hours).  

We've returned twice since then, once we skipped it because it was busy but the other time had the same experience as the first.  

The food is fantastic (though everyone has a different idea of authenticity based on what region's cuisine they were exposed to first).  I highly recommend the mushroom dumpling appetizer, pretzels, banana beer, and the sauerbraten is great (though on the sweet side).  Great for an early dinner or late drinks & bites.
author: Kali M.

description: A bit of old Munchen in SF. Good selection of German beers but they were out of Hacker Pschorr Marzen. Their other Marzen was just as good. I enjoyed the Wiener schnitzel- good size and tender. The potatoes were delicious and the chunks of bacon added a nice touch. Loud but fun. Could use some music for atmosphere. Looking forward to the schweinshaxe.
author: Paul K.

description:
Delicious place for dinner! It get's crowded, so come earlier if your schedule allows it.

The great:
- The pretzel appetizer with bavarian cheese. Perfect with their sweet mustard as well
- Potato pancakes - soft interior, perfectly crispy exterior
- The braised beef with spatzle and red cabbage. The beef was tender, and the cabbage delicious.

The good:
- Pork with mushroom sauce and spatzle. The mushroom sauce with spatzle was divine, bu the pork was a little tough for my liking
- The meatloaf. Great meatloaf (with bacon and egg!), but just a tad heavy

Come hungry! As with most German cuisine, this place is extremely heavy. But don't fret - you can always wash it down with a beer ;)
author: Michelle L.

description:
Kind of a disappointment.  The service and beer were excellent, the food not so much.  We had a party of six and between us ordered three different entrées.  The Sauerbraten was pretty good, but the three of us who ordered the pork schnitzel were really disappointed. It was dry and over cooked with little flavor. The spetzel (sp?) was also fairly tasteless. I've had both of these before at other German restaurants with excellent results.

There were other items on the menu that looked like they were worth a try, but after this experience, I think I look elsewhere for German food.
author: john r.

description:
All of us were pleasantly surprised 
Four Germans/Austrians in a German restaurant owned by a guy from Mexico

But the food, even though rather pricey was excellent.

Sauerbraten and Spaetzle just like at home.  Kaesespaetzle too
German beer and Geroldsteiner water

One of the better German restaurants here in the US
author: Frank R. K.

description: I have been coming here since it first open in 1993 . Still fantastic still delicious !! We have made it a family tradition .
author: Leonore S.

description:
We got a wide variety of fare and drink among the five of us, and none of it really impressed me. The venison was flavorful and the rum sauce was really great, but the mashed potatoes, red cabbage, and spaetzle were all bland, as was the lentil soup and farmer's wurst. The fish was good, but nothing spectacular. They forgot one of our plates, so all our food got cold before we were even checked on to see how the food was. The beers were great, and the bartender, Greg, was probably the highlight of the place. Otherwise the place was extremely loud, wayyyy overpriced for the quality and flavor, and our seating was awful (five people crammed in a corner spot next to a party of seven). The coffee was ok, and at least there were free refills.

Update:
The server couldn't even split our bill himself and made us parse it up and write on the receipt for him. I am thoroughly displeased with this place. If it wasn't for Greg, I'd give the place one star.
author: Jacob S.

description: This place has been on my friend's wish list for a long time, and we finally got a chance to check it out during this holiday season. Glad it's open on the Boxing Day for dinner. The food is fantastic. We had pork sausages and pork knuckle, and we shared them among three of us. The portions are pretty big. Though I would say the knuckle is a bit greasy, but that's what you expect when you made the choice. The skin has been grilled (or maybe fried) to crispy, and the inner part has been well seasoned as well. The waiter is also very pleasant and recommended us a good German draft beer. Overall, this place is great if you want some German food and drink.
author: Chen L.

description:
For some reason I thought this was going to be an "upscale" version of German fare.  Nope, it is very casual and quite homey, like being in a Bavarian cabin, only with a ton of hipsters as the patrons.  I still like the confines, able to share a large table or sit on each others laps in the bar area (super tight!).  

Beer selection not overwhelming but quite representative.  There will be 1-3 selections for each well known German style.  Pils, bocks, dunkels, hefe, etc..  Love the appropriate steinware here, quite authentic.

Still haven't indulged in any of the substantial meat dishes here, as it is hard to finish a plate of German man-food, after quaffing a litre or two of fine German suds.  But sharing a few plates may prove worthwhile.  Potato Pancakes are legit here, hefty thickness and the right texture.  Sometimes they can be a tad over-browned but it never taste burnt.  And the accompanying apple sauce is hard to beat.

The German raviolis are really worthy, with a delicious meatloaf-like filling enrobed in a more delicate pasta sheet.  The luxurious mushroom gravy just sets it over the top, plate-licking worthy!

Great casual hang with a German swag.  I can dig it.
author: D.wight L.

description: Good food, I had the meatloaf and devoured it. Don't bring people here if you want to talk/ catch up. Impossibly loud! Interesting interior, set up of restaurant a little awkward
author: Zoe D.

description:
Pros: It is a pretty lively place with a wide beer selection! The staff is really friendly and on top of it in terms of getting people to fit into the little spot. I got to try out different beers before settling for the one that was the right fit for me! The bar tender was really cool and this old German man was trying to teach me about German beer which was kind of entertaining. 

Cons: Maybe I had too high of expectations as I saw the 2000+ reviews on this place. It was my first time getting German food so maybe I'm just not that into German food or didn't get the right stuff. The flavors didn't seem that distinct and the food was just okay. There just wasn't anything too special about it. The deep fried pork just tasted like normal tonkatsu from a Japanese cuisine without the Asian dipping sauce. For the price, I feel like there is tastier food.

Overall: If you have to wait more than 30 minutes, I don't think it's worth it. You are in San Francisco where good food is EVERYWHERE. For a try, definitely check it out!
author: Timothy Y.

description:
In need of a social remedy?  This is pretty social.  Tables are to be shared.  If you're sitting behind the bar you must order from the bar tender.  There's always some type if friendly interaction.

-Potato Pancake w/ Homemade Apple Sauce  - Delicious 
-Porkloin Jagerschnitzel w/ Mushroom Sauce - Hearty but I didn't care for the noodles that it came with

This new flavor makes me want to come back again.
author: Lea M.

description:
Authentic Bavarian food -- and I've traveled myself. The owner is apparently from Munich. Great variety of beer, amazing food, and delicious apfel struedel :) The service is excellent too, very friendly bartender (who has worked there for 16 years) and waitstaff. 

We always come early to get a seat right when they open. They do family-style seating.
author: Kate B.

description:
You like beer?  This is the place!  You better have a designated driver...You'll want to try the buffet of outstanding selections.  Our group enjoyed the Reutberger Marzen but the Welten Helles was a outstanding starter for us to ease into the other selections.  
Food-wise- You must order the potato pancakes and the pretzel.  All knives were fighting for the cheese spread that accompanied the pretzel--perfection.  The sauerbraten was good, but have had better, ravioli was excellent, jagerschnitzel was tasty, and the bratwurst was lovely. 
The decor is sparse but who cares.  You might have to share your table--This is the European way, so get out your friendly and get to know a stranger.  All around, it's a great place and we'll be back for a visit soon.
author: Sharon E.

description: Portions hefty, taste up to expectations. However, nothing blew us away as being spectacularly delicious, so even though this is in our neighborhood, we won't likely return in a while.
author: Hua W.

description:
BEST. GERMAN. FOOD. In the Bay.

Holy I am still dreaming about the amazing dinner I had this past Sunday. We had 6 people in our party, arrived a little past 5:10pm, and were seated immediately/took up a whole table. Woohoo! No wait. (I've heard waiting can take a while especially on weekends). If you have smaller parties, you may have to share a communal table with another party. So get friendly!

WHAT YOU SHOULD GET:
1) Pretzels (with cheese and red onion)--Freshly baked right out the oven. They are so soft and fluffy inside, eating it with the cheese is to die for already. Ugh...mouth is watering. In addition, adding bits of the red onion to the cheese & pretzel is the perfect component to cut the cheese/pretzel. Suppenkuche...you are already killing me here and I'm only on the appetizer.

2) Potato Pancakes-- FRIED GOODNESS. Oh my god they are so incredibly crispy but soft inside towards the middle. That's all I have to tell you. Get this.

NOW...the next couple things I'm going to talk about were SPECIALS for the day that most of my party got...so be warned, they might not be there on the menu when you go.

1) Lamb chops with truffle butter, mashed potatoes, and brussel sprouts. 
Simply freaking amazing. Lamb was cooked perfectly, not too chewy. MMmmm. And the mash was good with the smallest of chunks of potato that hinted that these potatoes were made from actual potatoes getting mashed, not the flakes that come in boxes (I always am hesitant on any dish at any restaurant with mashed potatoes).

I got the:
2) Roasted and stuffed dumpling and half chicken and chicken sauce with potato pancakes.
Some of the chicken was a little on the dry side...but the semi-crispy, flavorful skin made up for it. The dumpling was so good...dense, almost like a matzo ball. Mmmmmmm....

3) Bratwurst with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut: This was also a party favorite. The sauerkraut is perfect. Not that stuff you get in jars/they serve at hotdog stands. ACTUAL sauerkraut that wasn't too acidic. The bratwurst was good though, I can't even describe it. 

DRINK:
I got the bananaweizen. If you're a fan of beer, prepare to drink up because they have a good selection. Bananaweizen is basically banana juice mixed with their hefeweizen (you can see banana pieces floating around! Yum!) This beer came out in a very tall glass...needless to say I'm not much of a drinker and this beer got me feeling it. If you don't drink beer/drink.....well, don't force yourself! I probably wouldn't drink another next time I come. The food is why I'll go again.


SERVICE:

Very attentive, friendly, and fast.


TIPS:

The sooner you get here during opening hours, the better. 
Come hungry.
Try out their daily specials.
author: Shannon N.

description: Eat the cheese spatzle. It's basically German mac n cheese. Drink a boot of beer if you dare. Invite the waiter to chat with your book club and be mildly embarrassed that he knew more about the book than you. Whatever. Beer boot.
author: Amber F.

description: Delicious! I am kinda a picky eater and I loved everything here. We were in a group of 10 and everything was amazing. I don't remember the last time I went to a restaurant and everything I tried was so good.
author: Katie H.

description:
Suppenküche is a German bar and restaurant located right in the heart of Hayes Valley. I must say--even though I studied abroad in Germany, I wasn't particularly fond of German food, but Suppenküche offered some of the best German food I've had. The restaurant offers a relatively small menu and somewhat loud atmosphere, and I visited with a group of friends to celebrate a birthday on a weeknight. 

Our group started by splitting two pretzels--while the pretzel dough itself wasn't all that memorable, they were served with mustard and a cheese dip that was strong and flavorful. We decided to split a bunch of dishes among us, and shortly after placing our order, they all came out at the same time--very quick and efficient service! We had the German mixed salad, which was an absolutely delicious amalgamation of potato salad and a bunch of different pickled vegetable salads including carrot, cabbage (like cole slaw), red cabbage, and beets. This was a fantastic dish that was fresh, savory, colorful, and diverse. We also got the pickled herring salad, which contained many of the components of the mixed salad, with, of course, the addition of pickled herring dressed in a creamy sauce. We also had the potato pancakes served with applesauce--while the potato pancakes were nice and crispy, I didn't find this dish to be particularly memorable. And then the entrees. The wild boar sausage (daily special) and the meatloaf (with bacon and egg) were both solid dishes, but the Jägerschnitzel (pork cutlet in mushroom sauce) I found a little bit on the dry side. We also had the delicious grilled trout, which was served with a creamy lemony sauce, and the standout of the dinner was the Sauerbraten, a braised beef pot roast. Interestingly, the Sauerbraten was not very sour at all, but it was fall-apart tender! Many of the main dishes came with the same couple of sides--salad, potato, and my favorites--braised red cabbage and spaetzle. The combination of all of these different dishes and sides made for an absolutely fantastic meal. In general, the dishes were not overly heavy (which can be typical of German cuisine), but creatively plated and seasoned.
author: David K.

description:
I'd always been told how great Suppenküche is, even by German friends, and I finally got to try their brunch the other week. It was very good, everything good quality and hearty, and I loved the simple and authentic decor. I'd thought it would be kitschy/touristy, but it's pretty industrial (especially the bathroom - feels like a WWII era bathroom with all the barren concrete).

SERVICE: Great, very friendly! They were efficient with our huge table of about 20 people.

MUST-HAVES: Everything was solid and nothing disappointed. The one that stood out to me the most flavor-wise was the Currywürst mit Pommes Frites, and the pancakes are worth going for if you're craving something sweet. The potato pancakes are done really well and a good smaller side.
 
* Bauernfrühstück mit Gewürzgurken (farmers omelette w/ potatoes, bacon & cheese w/ pickles & pork sausage. $12) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#lFSxUe8ubhCBSSBXWhChUQ
cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#p6fgxqKazBcxt1nTw4ROHQ
Nice! The eggs were soft and this was a great filling dish. The sausage was a little hard if I'm being picky.

* Geröst Maultaschen mit Zwiebeln, Ei und Gurkensalat (sauteed german ravioli scrambled w/ eggs & onions w/ cucumber salad. $11.50) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#GdABLO_hwB2zQ39JawKvkA
This was really interesting. It looked like an omelette but had ravioli mixed in, so it was like eating a brunch item that was also kind of like a lasagna, but really egg-y. Also well done, and very big! I took half home.

* Kaiserschmarrn mit Apfel und Pflaumenmus (emporer's pancake w/ brandied raisins, w/ apple & plum compote. $11) - 4 stars
Tried a bite of my friend's - even though it was cold, the pancake was still very soft & moist and the raisins with the compote went together great.

* Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus (potato pancakes w/ homemade apple sauce. $9.50) - 4 stars
Also tried a bite, great thick crisped outside, soft inside. The applesauce is a bit overly sweetened and a little watery, but works well w/ the pancakes.

BRUNCH SPECIALS
* Obatzda mit Brezeln (warm pretzels w/ bavarian cheese mix. $7.50) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#4RkNjC5sKL67vr1M4Oxv8w
Tried a bite, was great! Soft middle part, crisped outer part. 

* WeiBwürste mit Brezel (white veal & pork sausages in butter broth w/ a pretzel. $11.50) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#X39Mzej8Kq78Ioa6ERpUgw
This was interesting - two giant raw-looking sausages sitting in a very clear broth, with a pretzel sitting on top of it. The pretzel has just the right texture so soaking it in the broth kind of ruined its perfect texture, making it too soft and causing it to lose its crisp. 

* Omelette mit Lachs, Spinat, Tomaten, Zwiebeln und Käse (special omelet w/ smoked salmon, spinach, tomatoes, onions & cheese. $12.50) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#H0tYWddAJoHpGppGUxCwCQ

* 20 Cm Wienerwürstschen mit Zwieblen Ei und Bratkartoffeln (20 cm frankfurter sausage links w/ 2 eggs & roasted potatoes. $11.50) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#kj2jXeieitYkJ4o0_DptGQ
Stands out with the super long raw-looking sausages. Good meat but a kind of straightforward plain dish.

* Gefluegelschnitzel mit Kartoffelbrei und Gurken Salat (organic chicken schnitzel w/ mashed potatoes & cucumber salad. $13.50) - 4 stars
Tried a bite and the chicken was tender and the breading crumbly and even. The mashed potatoes had a lot of good texture from chunks of potato and skin, and it had just a hint of seasoning.

* Currywürst mit Pommes Frites (white chicken & pork sausages in tomato curry sauce w/ french fries. $11.50) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#GqcYGzve4mk9YuBqEjHkcg
This was the most interesting w/ the most flavor. I tried a bit, the curry sauce was very sharp and delicious with the hearty sausages. The fries were crisped enough that even with curry sauce on top, it remained just crunchy enough.

Brunch menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ

Brunch daily specials: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/suppenk%C3%BCche-san-francisco-2?select=ipZLUbIawjEnpl-2d21zFQ#fVc81cbtT080Xvp5-bpKeA
author: Ziyan C.

description: Loud! Communal tables! Beer everywhere! Three major turn-offs for me. However, the service and food hit the mark. We were seated promptly and attended to. While German isn't my favorite cuisine, I enjoyed it here. Everything was cooked and seasoned well, and the portions certainly didn't leave us hungry.
author: Paulina F.

description: The food was delicious, and the beer was great. I enjoy watching people drink beer out of giant boots. But it was just so unbearably loud, to the point of being comical. My husband and I were sitting across from each other, and had an entire conversation of, "What?" "Sorry, what'd you say?" "What?" "Say that again?" "What?" We didn't even bother talking to people at our table that were sitting two people down from us. My ears are still ringing.
author: Dana O.

description: Great service from our server Ashley, fun family style atmosphere and delicious food. We make it a point to visit here whenever we come into to town. This round we ordered the pretzels, schnitzel, Mac n cheese, boar sausage, pork knuckle and beer. You will enjoy!
author: Joseph H.

description:
I've spent my short life convincing myself I am NOT a fan of German food. Potato salad? No thanks. Sauerkraut? I'll pass. 
Then I was brought to Suppenküche, and was shown the err of my palate. 
I ordered Weinerschnitzel with roasted potatoes and a salad. The following was also ordered by our party: potato pancakes and cheesey spaetzle, sausage with mashed potatoes & cabbage and lentil & sausage soup. It was all delicious! 
I'm sold. Not a hint or jarred sauerkraut or soggy, sad potatoes. 
I wish I lived closer, but since I don't, they have set the bar for me, and I look forward to the day I can come back. Until then I'll just be searching for an equally good cheesey spaetzle (and menu!).
Thank you for the delicious meal Suppenküche!
author: Michelle H.

description: I had German food here for the first time outside of Germany and really enjoyed it.  It's has communal seating so you're going to be sharing a table with another group probably.  It was also funny watching other rowdy groups drink beer out of giant steins and boots. The line dies down an hour before closing time.
author: Jane H.

description:
This was my first visit to Suppenküche, and I had a blast! We walked in around 8:30 PM and it was packed! We found a spot at the bar and quickly set about ordering. Two delicious wheat beers, the mushroom ravioli, and the beef. It was pricier than I wanted by a dollars per dish, but it was worth it. Absolutely fantastic.

Place your order at the bar and sit yourself down and enjoy your beer. Be prepared to get cozy with your fellow patrons if you're sitting at the bar--it's close quarters in there.

The ambiance is solid, too. Cozy, but without feeling hemmed in. It's a small place, so it has a bit of a community feel. Nice bartenders, knowledgable and happy to help. 

The good: great food, variety of beers, nice people.
The bad: be prepared to wait if you go during peak time. Not bad, but to set reasonable expectations. :)
author: Amanda B.

description: AMAZING FOOD!!! What can I say, I love this place!! They have consistently great food.. the beers aren't bad as well. It can be hit or miss with the type of people you get paired with to share a table... I pick up on energy of people. Anyhoo, the Wiener Schnitzel is amazing.. so much flavor.. perfectly salted and the perfect balance of crunchy/ tender. The roasted chicken is good, meatloaf is good, spatzel is great, the potato pancakes are super crunchy and great with sourcream and applesauce. The cheesecake is super yummy and decadent. I have never had to wait too long.. the food comes out pretty quickly. Great place to go!!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I love the ambiance and service most of all. 
They have some vegetarian options and they are all pretty good.
The beers are really awesome and so is the boot!
It's difficult to find a spot here, but whenever we do, it's always fun.
author: Namrata J.

description: Loved their food! Has that family style dining room feeling since they seat you with other parties. I liked everything on the menu and the size is shareable. Meatloaf was bomb and pretzel was good too! Fish was on point for a German restaurant. There was a limit of one boot per table when we went and my boyfriend ended up drinking the whole thing by himself. Will definitely come back here again.
author: Eunice M.

description: Excellent and classical German taste food. Good beer, good pork dish and friendly service. Definitely come again!!
author: Hsinling T.

description:
If you're looking for good German food, that's definitely a place you should consider (and I know what I'm talking about as I went there with my German boyfriend!). It's very authentic: menu is in German and beer selection is great. 

The place is packed but waiters don't lie on waiting times: they said 30min and it was even a bit less. We had a drink by the bar while waiting, which was totally fine. Luckily, they found us a little table in the second room, which is less crowded and less noisy. 

So, what did we have?

Appetizer: 
 - Hering nach Hausfrauenart = 4 stars
Main: 
 - Wiener Schnitzel  = 4 stars - I loved it but you can find better ones in Berlin
 - Gebratene Rehmedaillions in Rotwein-Pflaumensoße = 5 stars - Just perfect
Dessert
 - Apfelstrudel = 2 stars - not good compared with what we had before. I would recommend to skip dessert!

Of course we had leftovers and were totally delighted to have German food again on the following day :)
author: Clémentine C.

description: I went here with a friend about a month ago and really enjoyed it. Our service was wonderful and the food was quite delicious. Portions were awesome! The only drawback is that it was very, very crowded and quite loud. Even though we were only two people and I arrived earlier than my friend, I could not be seated until she'd arrived. There was no place to wait inside, so I waited outside. We sat at a table with others, which was fine. I echo what other reviewers have said: come - with all of your party - as close to opening as you can.
author: Astrohfiziks A.

description:
I was excited to try German food for the first time but I left disappointed. I don't think I'm a fan of this type of food. I'm not a beer person either and it seems like a lot of people are a huge fan of the beer selection. The flavor didn't impress me but maybe it's the beer + food that complements each other very well here.

The Potato Pancakes were underwhelming. The taste of potato and apple sauce just didn't make sense to me. My entree was the sauteed porkloin with spatzle. I thought the porkloin was dry. Spatzle is very heavy. I was so full after a few bites. Food wasn't bad but I don't think it was good either. I'm not sure how this place compares but I don't think German's flavor profile suits me. 

Portions are generous. Communal seating is interesting. I don't mind it but there was a couple across at the same table who kept whispering and staring at us. I don't recommend this place as a first date because it is very hard to hear each other when the place gets crowded.

Nice addition to diversify the selection of food in the city but do you ever hear someone say, "I'm craving German food"?
author: Pansy L.

description:
This place feels as authentic as you can get. The design, the menu and the atmosphere..spot on. The place is a bit tight and you may have shared seatings...which is okay in a friendly place like this. Food is a bit pricey based on the simplicity of the food. Thee Draft beer choice is fantastic. Excellent hefeweizens. 

Will be back.
author: Tyler v.

description: A slice of Europe in Hayes Valley - one of a kind place. Excellent food and terrific service. Try their Pretzel with obatzda! One of my favorite restaurant.
author: Kriska N.

description:
2nd time being here, and both times have been nothing short of spectacular.

First, if you know you're going to go with a group, get there early. This is San Francisco, they maximize space, so if you want to make sure you get a table, plan accordingly.

Second, you MUST try one of their beers. One of the things Germany is known for is their biers, if you're feeling brave, you could get a Boot or a 5L (I have yet to see someone drinking from one of those). 

Entrees: I ordered the pork chop on my first visit, which was awesome. This was my first time having tried sauerkraut, and there's is delicious. My second visit I ordered their meatloaf, which has bacon and an egg in the middle with some mashed potatoes. Both dishes are sublime

Lastly, if you're a human being, you'll be pretty full from your dinner. Order one of their digestifs, they're these half shots of alcohol that will actually help you digest your food. I ordered a Kuemmerling.

Have a good time, eat lots, drink lots. PROST! (German way of saying cheers)
author: Aaron C.

description: I went here with my friend! We loved this place! Great food! Yummy beer! I'll definitely recommend this place to all my meat lover friends and I can't wait to come back here!
author: Maria O.

description: Great beer selection- however the German food did not taste very authentic. I'm sure it's great if you've never had 'real' German cuisine before...
author: Rob M.

description:
This place is great if you want to party and be LOUD. The food is ok.
Walzwerk and Schmidt's are much more GEMUETLICH :)
author: Ana M.

description:
Came here with my husband (he's German) for the 1st time 2 years ago. The food was horrible. Not an authentic German food, by far. The schnitzel was super dry and the spaetzle was literally cooked like a mac N cheese. I've eaten German food before when I visited Germany. Suppenkuchen food does not taste like German food. Even the Radler tasted too sweet! It sure didn't taste like the ones I drank in Germany.

One day my husband and I decided to give suppenkuchen another try.. Nope.. Feeling still the same! Food not German at all. The spaetzle was watery. Super gross. Quite disappointing. I know its popular among so many people in SF and I don't understand why. Never ever again!

I love Schmidts!!! They never disappoint.
author: Rachelle L.

description:
Suppenkuche for me clears the bar year after year, for an unique, casual, tasty spot to meet up with friends for a German beer, dinner and conversation.

Its crowded, communal table, shoulder to shoulder fun, with food that is simple, unique and fantastic.  There are not many places that continue to be enjoyable and kind of a destination to hit when I come to town, but Suppenkuche fills that spot.  Favorite orders include the beer, a german mixed salad, the german ravioli as a starter, the potato pancakes, and the wiener schnitzel.
