If you get claustrophobic in crowds though, this may not be the spot for you, because Suppenkuche is packed to the gills most nights, but especially on the weekends where it swells to an almost nightclub-like capacity.  If you like a more mellow experience, head here during the week, and early.

if you come for Sunday brunch, its an even more relaxed setting.  I've hosted a large party for Sunday brunch in the backroom, and had a relaxed, fun, not pressure-filled experience.  We enjoyed ourselves and stayed as long as we liked, and the hospitality didn't skip a beat.

Kudos to Suppenkuche, which has been consistently fun for years, always is great for an out of town guest, and never seems to decline despite all those great years and fantastic San Francisco memories.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Went here for brunch this wkd. Was greeted (after a few mins) by friendly staff. My boyfriend & I sat @ the bar & the bartender was awesome! She was incredibly knowledgeable & let me try a few beers to help make my decision.
Great loud atmosphere & beer.
It was a bit fattier than German food I had in Germany but, it's German food, obviously going to be heavy.
author: Ashley G.

description:
Suppenkuche's brunch is one of the tastiest you'll find in the city.  With the amount of food you get, and the awesomeness of the beers they have, this is a total gem in Hayes Valley.  Greg and I have been trying to explore new neighborhoods and determined that this past Sunday was going to be Hayes Valley's turn.  We were entertaining going to either Lers Ros Thai or Suppenkuche, and we basically coin flipped on which one we would end up at.  Looking back now, we should have just gone straight to here.  We showed up around 1ish and were pleased to see that we were going to make it for brunch (which goes until 2pm).  There was hardly a wait, and we ultimately didn't have to share a table for too long.

I can't say I'm well-versed in German food at all, so looking at the menu, I was SO grateful for the English translations.  I also perused Yelp while I was at the table, really racking my brain on what I wanted to eat.  I ordered the organic chicken schnitzel served with mashed potatoes and cucumber salad, and Greg had the Bratwurst with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes.  We both ordered the Schneider Weisse Hefeweizen; I had a half liter, while Greg ordered the liter.

The food came out fairly quickly, and much to my surprise, the chicken schnitzel was HUGE.  The chicken itself was cooked to perfection.  It was crispy, breaded perfectly, and wasn't dry at all.  That combined with the mashed potatoes was definitely a winning combination.  Greg's bratwursts were also tasty, but personally, I enjoyed mine more.  Between the two of us, we spent about $30 each for the food and drink and it was totally worth it.  We definitely want to come back here with some friends and do brunch again, it is most definitely worth the effort to eat here!
author: Lisa I.

description:
Food was good, service was very slow. I ordered the pretzel and cheese and the waiter didn't  tell me that it only came with one pretzel despite me being there with another person. It's certainly not an obligation to tell me, but it would have been helpful as I would have ordered another so we didn't have to split. 

We ordered some German beer (tasted great) but they took forever to get. I saw that the bartender had poured it out already but the waiter was too busy chatting with his coworkers to get it to us before I finished my pretzel. I would have really loved to have had a pretzel with beer.... I even tried saving a few bites hoping he would deliver the beer, but nope, he was just chatting with the bartender.

The entrees were good, comparable to Leopold's. But  the service I got was so lackluster it made the experience less than it could have been. I felt like the waiter we had was not a professional.
author: Justin I.

description: Fantastic selection of German beer! But don't expect to find any American IPAs. It's also pretty crowded but the wait is worth it! I had the sausage with sauerkraut and potatoes which was underwhelming but my companions ordered much yummier dishes. The best thing to order was the spatzle, a German take on Mac and cheese. Be sure to get it!
author: John P.

description:
Cute spot, great service. If you're okay with communal tables, perfect; otherwise, try to come at an off-peak time so you can enjoy pretty good German food in spite of your social anxiety.

My husband and I had taken a early morning flight to San Francisco and were wandering around trying to find something good. Suppenkuche is open for brunch on Sundays, so I didn't even bother trying to find anything else. The restaurant was relatively empty when we arrived, and we were seated right away.

My husband ordered the gravlox with a soft-boiled egg and I had the bread dumplings with eggs and sausage. Mmm. We agreed that the bread dumplings tasted like stuffing (or filling or dressing, whatever you call it), which was interesting. Loved the sausage and my husband's gravlox was the perfect texture. Good coffee, too. I thought the prices were super reasonable, if not a little lower than what I was expecting!
author: Rachel C.

description:
Found this gem a couple weeks ago while I was exploring Hayes valley.

The most authentic German restaurant I have ever been to! 

I ordered a German resiling , mushroom soup,potatoes pancakes and a lamb main course dish.

Everything was spectacular. 

It was a pretty packed on a Friday night and our wait was around 25-30 mins. 

Will def come back for more !!
author: Reet R.

description:
One of the first things i noticed when i walked in. 

Very. good. looking. servers. Hahahahhahahahahaa yeah, I have no shame. 

Okay, on a note relevant to the restaurant, I'm happy to have had my first time eating German food at this restaurant. I'm always a little hesitant to step outside my comfort zone when it comes to food, but I really enjoyed the food here. The environment tone was cozy and warm. They really set a good ambiance in the restaurant. Side note: it's also a good idea to go to the Asian American Art Museum if you're around the area.

We arrived at a good time, which was around 5:30 pm and we beat the crowd. There's two portions of the restaurant. The front has a few tables and a bar. In the back, there is more seating--they have community seating which is nice too. I got a smoked salmon dish and a apple cider beer, which was AMAZING. My friend got lamb chops and 3 different kinds of beer. Until this day, I still regret not having a bite of his dinner, but at least I tasted his beers and they were all pretty good. 

I will be returning here when my sister comes to visit me. Great place!
author: Emily F.

description:
I ate here as part of a party of four after receiving several recommendations to try it. Sadly it did not come close to living up to the hype. The place was super busy and as with popular places there was a wait for a table.... Sadly the host was not in any way welcoming and there was minimal space to wait.
We shared potato fritters which were ok. I had the Pork chop for a main which was awful. It had the consistencies of a frankfurter, the mash potato was tasteless and watery. For desert I shared a strudel, which had nuts in that I was not informed about despite declaring my allergy. The waitress was rude & impatient.
The only saving grace for this place was the friendly, knowledgeable bar staff & wide selection of beer.
author: Barry O.

description: Good traditional German food with table sharing  dining. Not expecting a loud and young bar scene crowd.  If you want German comfort food at a reasonable price, then good, but not for a cozy quiet dinner.
author: Gordon H.

description:
Obtaining a table here is no joke.  Either make reservations days or weeks in advance or be brave and go around happy hour times before dinner.  Even then, you might be at a communal table depending on your party size.  Speaking of party size, the smaller the better in terms of increasing your odds.

Now, I'm extremely familiar with Italian, Asian, Mexican, and American food.  What I'm a novice in is German food.  How often do you stumble upon a German restaurant?  There's maybe 1 or 2 in SF.  Leopold is technically Austrian but we'll let that slide and consider it German.  When you think of German food, you think of wiener schnitzel (not the hot dog kind), large beers, and sausages.  Suppenkuche has that and more...

If you're a beer lover (and you better be), you can order your beer in a boot.  It's several liters if I recall and it takes a lot in order to finish it.  Ask your server for beer recommendations because you don't want to be stuck with one you hate.  EG: A friend hates hoppy beers and somehow ended up with one.  Another item known to Germans is pretzels.  Now, it's not the Auntie Anne pretzels but the harder and salty kind.  It's the carbs to absorb the beer.  As mentioned earlier, wiener schnitzel is another famous dish.  Think of a tonkatsu without the tonkatsu sauce.  Still confused?  Think fried pork chop.

Overall, the food is solid.  Bring beer loving friends and you'll have a great time.
author: Ronald L.

description:
A good spot for dinner when you're looking for 1) something a little different, 2) something loud and lively, 3) giant portions, and 4) heavy/hearty food. You'll also need to be okay with communal tables.

I don't think I'm a huge fan of German food, but I'm giving Suppenkuche 4 stars because it's such a fun and unique spot. My friend and I arrived at 6 PM on a Sunday night, and though the restaurant was quite busy already, we were seated immediately. We decided to order the pretzel with Bavarian cheese, potato pancakes with apple sauce, and pork schnitzel. We thought two appetizers and an entree would be just the right amount of food, but it turns out 1) their entrees are huge, and 2) German food is super heavy. I would definitely recommend splitting an entree if you don't want to take home leftovers (and actually, we still did). I can't say I was deeply impressed by anything I ate, but I thought the food was good enough for a solid meal, and again, the experience was fun. The only comments I have to make about the food are that the potato pancakes reminded me of thick hashbrowns (and definitely need the apple sauce), and the texture of the cheese accompanying the pretzel is kind of unexpected but worth trying!
author: Kelly R.

description:
We have been eating at Suppenkuche for over 15 years. We now live in LA and always make time to eat here when we are in San Francisco. It is always GREAT. There's a few things you need to know though:  (1)  It is always packed, this time we arrived at 4:55 and there was already a huge line of people waiting for the restaurant to open.  We were seated in the first round and within 15 mins there was already a 45 min - 1 hour wait.  (2)  If your party is smaller then 8 ppl you need to be ok with family style seating where they will seat you with people you don't know. (3)  It is cold in there! Bring a jacket!

We always order the same thing because it is always delicious. We have 2 small children and it is very kid friendly. They love the potato pancakes and the Wiener schnitzel. The salad is my favorite. The German beer is YUMMY!!!

Be prepared for an awesome meal, yummy beer and a loud, kid friendly environment!!!
author: Jenny S.

description: Awesome beer selection and really enjoyed the meatloaf with egg.  Pretzel was an easy appetizer to share.
author: Angelina G.

description:
Is it a cool hipster beer bar? Is it a German restaurant? Is it a rustic, wooden cafeteria? It's everything and more. The place gets packed, so be prepared to wait. The good looking host seater dude is there to look good. Period, I'm convinced. Squeeze a spot at the bar and indulge in any choice of legit German beer. 

When you get that precious seat it'll be loud, you'll be squeezed in next to future new friends and you'll be overwhelmed with the smells and thoughts of food. You'll want to order everything but the serving sizes are huge and it won't take that long for your fish to come. I've read other reviews that the food can be pricey. But this isn't Applebee's. And you can't get amazing schnitzel anywhere. This isn't a place for an intimate experience and you won't find tapas here. Indulge in the loud noise, the tight hot spaces and the overflowing plates and mugs. You won't be disappointed.
author: Kara S.

description:
Gotta love the Suppenkuche. The atmosphere is merry (as it should be) and the quarters are tight so be sure you come here with people you like to sit close together with. 

The beer situation here is great and while the Boots are pretty much a novelty is is pretty awesome to witness. The pilsner was great and easy to drink and a perfect pairing to all the german food!

The pretzels, bread with spread and potato pancakes are perfect appetizers. I went with the chicken as an entre and it was really well down...a little crispy on the outside skin with juicy center. Not a weekly spot but this is perfect for a group dinner night out with the dudes.
author: Derek S.

description: This place has the atmosphere of a bar. However, there are a sizeable number of seats and numerous diners during peak hours. I ordered the popular meatloaf. The mashed potatoes were soft and creamy with some tiny chunks of potato here and there. The sautéed onions in the gravy gives it a slight hint of sweetness. The meatloaf was very soft and had a slight creamy consistency. The bacon around the meatloaf was savoury but it did not significantly elevate the flavour of the meatloaf. To my pleasant surprise, there was an egg in centre of the meatloaf.
author: James S.

description:
Come at 5 (or even a little after 5) and there will be no wait whatsoever!

Order the venison - it is out of this world! I had it both times I've been here, and it was amazing both times. The meat was really tender and moist and easy to chew, and tasted amazing with the red wine plum sauce that comes on top. It also wasn't gamey at all which was a fear I had. They give 2 large pieces of venison - portions are massive and you could split a dish with another person and leave totally satisfied.

I'd also recommend trying the potato pancakes - they're kind of like pancake shaped hash browns, but crispier and heartier and better.

Environment is not the best - communal seating in a pretty small space, so it's crowded and VERY loud. Prepare to yell with your friends. If you'd like a quieter more spacious environment, try Walzwerk in the Mission.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Good afternoon everyone, 
     It is Sunday August 21st of 2016 & relaxing at home watching Food Paradise.  Thus restaurant appeared on the Food Paradise Special.
Mouth watering just looking at it on television. 
I just went to San Francisco two weeks ago and wish I knew about this spot then.
Next time I am up North I will stop in & leave an official review of what I ate & the end results.
author: Julian S.

description:
OMG this was my first time having German food, and boy was it mmmhhhmmmmhhhmmhhh.. So good. 

So when you come here make sure you show up like 30 mins before they open if you want to get a seat at 5pm when they open. We showed up around 4 walked around and got back at 4:35 and there were already like 10 people in line and many more showing up.  

So we had the wienerschnitzel and the roast suckling pig oh these were both so delicious... So with the roast suckling pig it came with the sauerkraut and this awesome bread dough ball that was so good, and the sauerkraut was good you could eat it by itself!!! That i believe was the first time I found sauerkraut that good!!  I also had two of the german beers they had on tap and I haven't had beer in a while and they definitely hit the spot.  So on to the wienerschnitzel it was so good and perfectly crispy!!! I now know I never had a real wienerschnitzel until I had it at suppenkuche.
author: Shantiel P.

description: Great authentic German food and great beer! The atmosphere is great and relaxed. The place is very loud which is the major drawback.
author: Karen M.

description: Stopped off for a beer after dinner last night. A lot of selections (15 or so probably on tap) and many sizes to chose from up to a 5 L glass for ~$85. (That's 10 pints or so.) Bartender said we could try up to two (?!) after not knowing much about any. The hefeweizen I ended up with was delicious. Not a lot of seating if you are only going to drink; tables are reserved for those eating dinner and the waitstaff will be quick to tell you to move. That's the only downer. Old time German bar feel. Worth checking out.
author: Mark H.

description:
I've been here a couple times. Both times the service has been great. We're seated almost immediately and the servers are very attentive and personable. 

There's all different kinds of beersfor those connoisseurs! And in every size possible!

The food is also pretty solid German fare. I tried the pork chop one time and got a giant helping that was pretty good, but maybe I'm just not a pork chop person. Their sauerkraut on the other hand is AMAZING. It's the best I've ever had and normally I don't even like sauerkraut! I don't know how they prepare it, but it's sweet, almost like sautéed onions!

 A fun place to bring a group of friends for a birthday or random night out!
author: Leana L.

description: Awesome food, although I'm going to minus one star for the loud af death metal they played. Great classic German food. There is usually a line here. It's located in the hip neighborhood hood of Hayes Valley. Seating is communal, so don't be shy.
author: Kristina S.

description:
Suppenkuche is so good. I never thought oh yum, German food...until Suppenkuche. I have been here multiple times and always enjoy my meal. 

Pretzel with Bavarian Cheese- You need this. I love this pretzel. My boyfriend who is not a pretzel lover, even enjoyed this. 

Wiener Schnitzel- I order this every single time. It is so so good. Perfectly fried on the outside, juicy on the inside. I always order with a side of sauerkraut because it is delicious with it.  

Meatloaf with Bacon- Good, but not my favorite thing on the menu. It's juicy and has good flavor. I like that there is an egg. I have never had meatloaf and egg together, but I am dwon with it. 

Brautwurst- This is another favorite. The sausage is so juicy. It melts in your mouth. 

And of course you need to wash this all down with some tasty beer. 

I'd say Suppenkuche is one of my favorite SF restaurants.

Curious to try brunch now
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
Came here with 2 other people for dinner and it was extremely crowded. This place is actually very large on the inside, and we were seated in the extension room (which was a little bare). We sat on a bench with another party of 6.

I ordered the Sauteed Trout in Lemon Butter Sauce with Bouillon Potatoes & Spinach (19). I substituted the bouillon potatoes with mashed potatoes, and also ordered a side of Bratwurst. The food was good, but everything just felt so heavy. It was like everything was covered in cream or butter -- my spinach, which was under the trout, was just swimming in oil. I ordered trout because it seemed like the lightest item on the menu, but even then I had trouble eating it. I have also decided I do not like bratwurst, and have never eaten a bratwurst I've liked, and will probably never buy it again.

Because of this, I actually prefer the food at Schroeder's, which I find to be a lot less greasy.

I also felt really claustrophobic here -- being seated next to a loud large party didn't help. We had a lot of trouble hearing each other talk, even though we were sitting right across from each other. We were also seated right next to the kitchen door, and people would run into each other all the time since the door swung open every 10 seconds. Lastly, when we were leaving, the people waiting for our table literally stood over us and put their things down before we had even gotten up.

I would be willing to give this place another try if I came here in a more "outgoing" mood, mentally brace myself for the mass of people and noise, and order different food items.
author: Cynthia W.

description: Wow! I was so excited to eat here ... Had to walk 1.5 miles to get here from my hotel but so worth it... Good beer and good food =the best of time I ordered the bratwurst and the bartender recommended a beer (don't know the name) but he is definitely on point and knew what I would like I just described my likes and dislikes in a beer. U won't regret it if u eat here
author: Mari B.

description: Lovely interior design. Very pure, alpost scandinavian. Good german food - yet it's german food so not for every week. Nice staff. Very noisy.
author: Nicolas R.

description:
This was my first German dining experience and it was delicious. The place has a very cozy and authentic vibe, with community tables. Although I was not used to this style of seating, I did not mind it, for it still allowed for a one on one conversation.   

We were seated before the rush came around 6 pm on a Tuesday night. It definitely started to fill up from then on. I started with the mushroom soup. It was good, but I was hoping for a little more flavor. I then went with the wiener schnitzel- lightly battered and fried pork.  A typical German dish but a good transition for somebody who was new to this style of food, like me. It was served with fried potatoes as well. The service was efficient. Friendly, and direct. Just like the food, simple and to the point.  

I will be back but will be asking for some recommendations so I can try something new. Also looking forward to trying another German beer from their selection!
author: Taylor M.

description:
We came for weekend brunch and the place was packed.  After a long, painful wait (almost an hour, plus we were starving), we were finally seated at a tight, communal table.  The place is rowdy and the beer was flowing, but it was too early for me, so I opted orange juice.

The food was just okay.  The Wiener Schnitzel (Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin) was crispy, but really dry and bland.  Unless that's the way it's supposed to be... then it was amazing.  But I probably wouldn't get it again without getting the the mushroom sauce on top.  I'm sure tastes a lot better with it.

My friend got the Leberkäse (Sauteed Bavarian Meatloaf) and thought it was pretty good.  I liked it more than my dish at least.  It came with a perfectly fried sunny side up egg on top and potatoes that were less than memorable.
author: Peter P.

description: Always satisfying! Great beer, food, and atmosphere. Owner and staff are awesome. Highly recommend!
author: gary s.

description: I was drug here by my German wife. I was pleasantly surprised. We had an assortment of appetizers that were delicious. The pretzels were what you would expect from a German restaurant. We had different entrees to sample things, all were delicious. I'm not a fan of sharing a table family style, hence the four stars.  The single hole restroom could use updating.
author: Rich K.

description:
Very tiny interior for the amount of people enjoying good food, good friends, and good times at Suppenkuche, but that's just part of the experience here. Because of this, I am especially impressed with the staff here for being able to keep up and keep track of everything, especially given how loud and crowded it was. The food was scrumptious and the beer selection was big. Many delicious beers were had at our table, along with endless story-telling accompanied by laughter. Between the 13 of us, we got to taste a large variety from the menu, and everyone was impressed. 

A helpful hint for all those readers planning a large group gathering at Suppenkuche: the back room is reserved for large parties. It snugly fits 3 tables of 12. We had a party of 13 come for a birthday dinner, which required a reservation in advance. We were told on the phone that the max amount they could accommodate was 12 per group, due to limited seating, but if we squeezed, we could possibly fit 13. That was not a problem to us, and it actually turned out comfortable and fine, due to the tables having bench-style seating instead of individual chairs. Smart move, maximizing buttcheck space, Suppenkuche ;] So, if you wanna squeeze together with all your friends, it's very do-able, but the people at either end of the table might have a hard time hearing one another.

Overall a great birthday dinner for my dear friend, with great service, to boot ;] I'm not one of those people who will say "no pun intended" when you KNOW they just said that to call attention to their pun. I'm just gonna flat out say: yes, pun very much intended!
author: Tuwie N.

description:
I can officially add Suppenkuche to my list of favorite restaurants in SF.

I was excited to split a 2 liter boot of erdinger (hefeweizen). They charge per 0.5 liter and ask for your credit card. Drop the boot, steal the boot, or do anything damaging and you'll get a $50 charge. I'm sure our neighbors at our shared community table could only roll their eyes as we tried to think of beer drinking games we could play during dinner. I suggest passing the 2 or 5 liter boot around the table until it's finished without letting anyone set it down on the table :)

The special of the day caught my eye. I ordered roasted chicken and dumplings with potato pancakes to share and and a pretzel to start. Wouldn't say the chicken was anything to rave about but their crispy potato pancakes are like tasty big flattened out tater tots. It was the perfect beer food! Quick shout out to their complimentary bread dip. I don't know what's in it but i liked that spread better than the one that came with the pretzel.

I have to come back again. And again. Need to order more potato pancakes!!
author: Samantha L.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for Suppenkuche but it might be because the food is so good I forget to write a review.

Located at the end of the Hayes Valley shopping district, Suppenkuche is one of the best German inspired restaurants in California. The menu is small, but everything is delicious and German. There is a large beer menu specializing in German beers which can be hard to find. 

The schnitzel is the best I've found outside of Germany and Austria. It's really good and a huge portion. The pretzels are really good too.

This place gets really busy really fast. There is usually a line before they open.

Overall, I can't recommend this place enough.
author: Ryan L.

description: Had pork chops, potato celery soup, and beer (forgot name). Loved all of it.  I've always had a fantastic meal with great company (shared table).  Shared table with a German gentleman and he gave his approval of Suppenkuche
author: Pablo S.

description:
Hey I'm a versatile muthafucka!
The food here was very tasty:) I felt the love when they broke out the plethora of bread slices:) I had the venison and it was delicious...
Would definitely go back:)
author: Al T.

description:
Have had dinner several times, and always amazing. It is community style seating so you share your table with everyone else. Not the place for a romantic date. Also it is super noisy.  All of that adds to the Suppenkuche experience. 

Had brunch here for the first time and it did not disappoint. The bread they bring at first is great, but heightened with the apricot preserves. There is another berry one as well, but the apricot is where it is at. 

 Bonus, the coffee at brunch is $2! that is what coffee should cost at a brunch spot and its pretty good. I have had terrible coffee for brunch that they charge $5, but somehow my caffeine deprived brain gets it. Here, they dont mess around. 

Their dinner and brunch is awesome German comfort food at its finest.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Suppenkuche is everything you'd expected in a stereotypical German restaurant, whether it's accurate or not.  It's loud, you'll share benches with strangers, you'll drink lots of beer and eat hearty food in large portions... all of which I love.  

It's not the cheapest place in the world, but Suppenkuche is an overindulgence kind of place.  I came here with a large group of a birthday, and it was perfect because Suppenkuche is the type of place you feast and sing out loud with close friends.  We tried everything from appetizers to desserts, and stayed here over 3 hours doing it because there'll be no way you can stomach all of that at once (:

We also brought two birthday cakes from outside the restaurant, and they were sweet enough to cut it up + serve it to us without charge!  

On a side note, the bartender was super nice.  But only to me.  I say this because there were some drunk assholes trying to get hammered... and I just stood at the bar waiting patiently.  The bartender let me sample a couple of beers that I couldn't pronounce before making my final decision.  As a rule of thumb, just be courteous / treat your waiters / bartenders with respect, and they'll treat you well.  You may be drunk, but you're not stupid.  It's easy to have manners!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Yummy! They can up their game on the size of their beer to stay true to the Deutsch roots, and they can also use a little extra space because it gets really crowded, but the food is divine. I have not tried out their brunch, but I had thei potato cake and it was amazing!
author: Leonora H.

description:
After walking around almost everywhere in San Francisco, we stopped by Suppenkuche for some beer. We were seated in the bar area since we weren't eating dinner, but it was nice and cozy. (Cozy as in a dark and mysterious corner with candles.. but front and center at the bar, so I ain't complaining!)

My friend got a wine - not sure what it was called, but she drank it with a straw! The bartender said it should be the only kind of wine that should be drank with a straw. ;) My other friend and I ordered their new beer. It came in a pretty tall and cool looking glass. Our bartender said the only bad thing about the glass was that it wasn't see through, so he couldn't know when we were ready for another round. ;) After our drinks came, they gave us a basket of a variety of breads and an herb butter. Some of the bread was a bit on the hard side, but the butter was definitely interesting to eat. We also ordered pretzels to snack on. I don't think I've ever had beer and pretzels together before, but it's pretty good! 

For a drinking place, this place is pretty awesome - mainly because the bartenders are super cool and knowledgeable about all the drinks they serve. The food does look pretty awesome, so I definitely want to come back and eat here for dinner one night!
author: Christine S.

description:
Great German food - check
5L beer jug - check
Delicious german beers - double check

If these don't speak to you don't bother, but if they do. this spot is awesome!!!!
author: Greg F.

description:
Great food, and large selection of German beers on tap! Expect shared community tables, and a loud restaurant with a definitely unique european vibe to it :) 

Waited about 30 minutes for a table.

- Free bread: a bit too dry for me, served with a spinach garlic butter I believe... either way I got a bite of sand in my first taste :( boo
- Pickled herring: a bit too salty for me, but I was a fan of the marinated beets, carrots and cabbage
- Sautéed trout: yummmm... nice and crispy served with lemon, lightly salted and served over a bed of spinach
- Warm pretzels w/cheese dip: also tasty, not too buttery which was good, soft and warm pretzel is always something I'm down for

Would love to try their dessert (Apple strudel or black forest cake) but didn't have room since the portions are relatively large! :)
author: Kristie C.

description: One of my favorite places in SF. I go here whenever I can. It's best to arrive right when they open so you don't have to wait for a long time for a table. Great beer selection and tasty food.
author: Sal R.

description:
Great German food in a lively atmosphere! Had dinner with a group of friends for NYE and everyone enjoyed the food and beer selection. 

I've heard the wait is normally VERY long, but we arrived at 7:30pm on NYE and were seated within 30min! While waiting, we enjoyed a large boot of kolsch beer (note you have to put a deposit down for the boot). The bar area is fairly small, but we were lucky to find a spot.

For dinner, we started with the potato pancakes and apple sauce- crispy and delicious. Sadly we wanted to sample the pretzel but they were sold out. For mains I had the house made boar sausage (nightly special) with sauerkraut and spaetzle. The sauerkraut was not your standard - there were large chunks of bacon and it had great flavor. The sausage was delicious- unique rich flavor- I would definitely recommend ordering if it's on the specials again. My husband ordered the weinerschnitzel - two huge patties fried perfectly. Others ordered venison medallions and potato soup- both got rave reviews. 

The atmosphere was very lively- not sure if that's just because it was NYE- but everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves and toasting. 

Overall, the food was fantastic and it was a fun spot to celebrate. I would definitely go back.
author: Kara C.

description:
I absolutely love this place. Sat down at a table with a group of interesting people from Germany who said some of the dishes were better than what they have in Germany. Enjoyed dinner with them at the communal table and exchanged info, offered us a visit to Germany. 

Very casual and trendy ambiance that takes you out of SF into Germany. Really great beers. 

I highly recommend the pork schnitzel (with potato salad and side salad which is a traditional way to eat it I hear) and the braised beef. I absolutely loved the pork schnitzel -- reminded me of donkatsu but German! Side of sauerkraut adds so much to the entrees I highly recommend getting this too!!

I'll def be back for my authentic German cuisine. Highly recommended!
author: Sarah K.

description:
We were seated with a group of 3 at a 6 people table.  Considering we had saved long wait, not bad at all! If you like fish, definitely try their trout! It is amazing!!

I'm not a big beer drinkers but if you like light beer, don't forget to try their kolsch!
author: YJ L.

description:
omg.

I'm really glad I haven't found this place earlier...because if I had. MAN! I'd be an oompa loompa NO JOKE.

The food here is amazing. It's been 3 weeks since I've been here and I've thought about this place.hmm maybe...9x a week? Everytime a meal time rolls around I think to myself.. ughhhh Suppenkuche sounds sooooo good right now.

Spatzle - AMAZING. Perfect combo of cheesy oniony mac & cheese. It comes out piping hot and seems to STAY hot the entire time I'm delicately picking at it so not to seem like an ogre at the dinner table.

Potato hash fried thingies - so amazing crispy, not oily at all and the best apple sauce to dip t them in. A basic thing DONE RIGHT!

Mushroom raviolis - HUGE raviolis ... but I still wish I had a galloon tub of these. Amazing flavor.

hmm...what else did I get, I honestly can't remember because I stuffed myself silly. My boyfriend got the pork chop, friend got a schnitzel..and I can barely remember what else because all the plates were cleared. ha ha :P

Get here RIGHT at opening to grab a table - or else it will be a 1+hr wait ( worth it ). Good bang for your buck :)

YUM. can't wait to try their breakfast :D
author: Selina W.

description:
Despite growing up in a German family, I never went out for German food except at Oktoberfest.  I guess we didn't consider it haute cuisine or maybe it was just too close to what we served at home.  Now that I live in SF, Suppenküche has made me rethink my assumptions about German food.

Everything here is delicious and they have a great beer selection.  The staff are friendly enough (it is a German restaurant, after all) and the family-style seating means less waiting time.  The main drawback is the noise level.  I'm usually ok with it but it's loud enough my father won't eat here.  Go for Sunday lunch if you want the food without the usual wait and noise.
author: Bucky P.

description:
Das Boot is a meal itself! I have to congratulate those who can finish it all by themselves, as for me I had to share with a friend. We got Weltenberger Pilsner to fill up Das Boot. We ordered:

- potato pancakes = crispy texture and i like it with ketchup better than apple sauce.

-Wiener Schnitzel = love the fried breaded porkloin

Suppenküche did not disappoint. I love the food and the ambiance. Cannot wait to come back here with my fellow food buddy from Germany. Hope he likes this place as much as I do!
author: Owie N.

description:
Kind of want to kick myself for not trying Suppenkuche sooner.  

Came here relatively early (not even 1 hour since the doors opened) and it was already a 30-45 min wait for a party of 5. So we wrote our name down and headed for the bar and got that 2 liter boot! I don't remember the exact beer we got but it was a light one and it was pretty damn good. 

Anyway, I grabbed the lamb chop with brussel sprouts for myself and the potato pancakes to share. Everyone else got different dishes, so I managed to take a bite of theirs to try (sausage, and meatloaf). They're all really good, but I must say mine was the best. Lamb chop was extremely juicy and delicious, mashed potatoes were on point and the brussel sprouts were just amazing. Made me actually want to finish my green veggies (yes, I'm guilty of pushing veggies of my plate). 

The potato pancake are like super crispy hash browns and I enjoyed every bite. I thought it was interesting that they give apple sauce as a dipping sauce. 

Also, the portion size were good and I was stuffed.  May sound a little pricy for such a rowdy place, the but food is most definitely well worth every bite.

Can't wait to come back here again.
author: Harriet W.

description:
*Most important* make sure your entire party is on hand when you want to be seated. I dropped off my wife and parked the car only to lose our table while I was making my way to the restaurant. An hour later we returned and was seated 15 minutes later. 
-If you don't like a crowd and noise don't go here. The restaurant is small and they get as many people inside as possible. 
-The lighting is dim to the point I had to use my phone light to read the menu.
-I craved a beer to take the edge off of the noise level. I wanted dark and full bodied beer so they served us the Celebrator(not bad,but prefer a bit heavier)
-6 or more make reservations. 
-A nice experience was our party of 4 sharing a table with a one family followed by another family until we left. Our table was larger than we needed.  
FOOD
1. We started with LOX, the salmon was a bit stringy( spoiled by Japanese  sashimi) but the cream was delicious with what seemed to be apples.
2. Sautéed Trout which was an entire trout fried. I tasted a piece that was crunchy and flavorful
3. Meatloaf wrapped in bacon which was the least expensive as well as being a very large portion. I tried it and it tasted good so much so that I will order it next time.  
4. I shared the Jagerschnitzel(pork loin with mushroom sauce) with family. The pork was well done stacked thin pieces covered in mushroom sauce(not bad, but will order meatloaf of try something else next time- yes there will be a next time. 
OVERALL
-Good food 
-good service 
-good portions 
-good value
author: Michael A.

description:
Big Beer Booty!  This beverage is huge and it sure was fun drinking it with a whole group of people!  You must be a beer lover and a tank if you want to or think you can drink all of it by yourself.  

Tip: When your beer is at the heel of the boot level, drink from the side rather from the front or back of the boot glass.  The air rises from the bottom up due to the way the boot is formed, so drinking it from the side of the boot, you won't have the rising bubbles pushed up against your nose or face when trying to chug the beer.

What I recommend ordering:

- Fried Potato Pancakes with Applesauce - I have never tried that combo together and it tasted great.  A part of the potato pancake that I bit into, however, had a little too much salt on it.  It is forgivable though.

- Wiener Schnitzel!!! - It's delish!  Eat it with the sauerkraut and the creamy mashed potatoes that is on the bottom of the sausages!  I didn't need the mustard they provided on the side because it would cover the flavor of the sauerkraut and sausage. Every bite is so savory!!!

Biggest booty beer size as a beverage! - Not only is it a challenge to finish the whole thing, it is a fun group activity during the whoooole dinner!  Must get!!!

Their steak dish was a good hearty meal.  I thought it needed more flavor to it and I found myself using the mustard from the sausage dish as a flavor booster.  Yes, steak and mustard goes quite well with each other. 

The wait was extremely long for big parties, such as the number of people I was with (10), BUT IT WAS DEFINITELY WORTH THE WAIT!  Make reservations ahead of time.  It takes about an hour to get seats!

Overall, I love this place!  The atmosphere, dining experience, food specialty and taste is all there!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I don't have get German food but when I do get the chance I always seem to love it.  Tonight was no different.  The potato pancake was great and meatloaf was a great pick.  

Tg communal seating is somewhat disconcerting but easy enough to get used to.  

I'd say the price to quality ratio to be spot on.  Very good food at reasonable prices.  

Although it doesn't "look" trendy I believe it is.  It looks more like an old country pub, the clientele would scream trendy.
author: Dan Q.

description:
I can see why the place only has 4 stars. it should be 6 stars, but it does get packed in there and the wait could take almost an hour. BUT very well worth it. Great beer, great food, love the place.
they also do beer garden a block down, also great.
author: Ashot B.

description:
I've been coming to Suppenkuche since they opened up many moons ago. The restaurant is always completely full of interesting people from different backgrounds. The crowd reminds me of a semi-civilized European Tapas scene. 

There are many good beer choices to pick from as you decide what sausage to munch on as you wait for your table. If you are fortunate enough to get good seats in the bar then you are all settled in for a good night.

Marinated, Braised Beef & Spätzle: The beef was cooked perfectly and tasted delicious. Warm pretzels w/cheese dip was soft, warm and tasty; not too buttery which washed down nicely with a good dark German beer. If you share a table the vibe is cool and the conversations can take a life of its own.
author: Greg O.

description:
If you like hearty, German food, sausages and drinking beer out of boots, you'll love this place. Be sure to get there early to stake a claim on a table. We arrived just before they opened and we still had to wait a little bit. If your entire party isn't ready it could be tough to secure a spot.

It's also really noisy in here so if you want a quiet place to catch up with friends, this is not the right place for you.

The sausages are unbelievably good though as well as the potatoes. We shared a bunch of items for my friends birthday and he was quite happy. That's all you really can ask for, right?
author: Amy J.

description:
Food:  5-star
Linsensuppe - Lentil soup which is was creamy and delicious.  Worth every penny.

Bacon Wrapped Asparagus - was surprisingly light.  The asparagus were grilled perfectly and flavourful.  A must try.

Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce
with Red Cabbage & Spätzle - friend had this dish for main course.  It was very tasty but I thought the venison was little tough but I never had venison before so I am not sure if it was not the right texture, it was not rubbery but I thought that this meat would be a little tender that it was.  However, it had great spices and was very delicious.

Lamb Chop - There was a German name but I couldn't remember was it was, now this is one tasty dish, when I return an unsure of what to have, I will definitely have this dish again.  Lamb was tender and cooked perfectly.

Atmosphere:  5-star
The ambience was very comfortable and friendly.  I like the community table style setting.  The place is not very big but it did not feel crowded even when there was a 30 minute wait for the table.  They are very busy.

Location: 4-Star
The restaurant is located on the corner of Laguna and Hayes.  There are plenty of parking around the neighborhood.

Service/Staff - 5-star
Very friendly staff.  Service is top notch.  I'd would have come back just on atmosphere and services alone but the food are great too.  Bonus!
author: Bob S.

description:
We've been to the Suppenkuche a number of times.  We really appreciate having a good German restaurant in the area. We lived in Germany a number of years. The family tables are great and the food is typically very good. I particularly liked the schweinehaxe on a recent visit.

There is one real downside however that on our last visit was so pronounced we may not return. The clientele are unbelievably loud. The yup crowd that appears to have invaded the place can't seem to control themselves, one screaming louder than the next to be heard above the din - a complete lack of consideration of other diners. 

Very good food - way too loud - so loud that the health department should look into worker health issues.
author: Bill J.

description:
If you are looking for some German fanfare, then this is the place to go (better than Schroeder's in FiDi). I came here with a few friends on a Sunday eve. They told us that it would probably be a 45 minute wait. Because of this, we ended up running over to Smitten to grab some ice cream as an appetizer. I guess because of that, I got pretty full quickly. I can't totally recall EVERYTHING that we ordered... HOWEVER, I DO know that we ordered the following: veal schnitzel, pork schnitzel, pork chop, bratwurst. I was a big fan of the bratwurst. I'm a sucker for sausage. ;)

On top of that, we had beers. A many. I had myself a radler (which could've contributed to my full-ness mid meal).

Warning though: this place is LOUD. I guess it was a good thing that my friends were a little buzzed that we were already yelling at each other anyway.
author: Joanne W.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place for two years or something so I pretty stoked when I finally got the chance to get dinner there.

The place was full when we got there and we were told that the wait would be 20 minutes (for three of us). Whatever they tell you, I recommend waiting outside the restaurant anyway because within five minutes, the hostess told us there would be seats for us in five minutes. 

We were seated next to another group on the same table. Not a big deal to me, but just heads up.

Upon recommendation from my friend, I ordered the bratwurst with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. My friends ordered the cheesy spaetzle and feta cheese/spinach stuffed portobello mushrooms respectively. 

We were given rye bread (or something) with herbed butter. Kind of heavy but so delicious. I really like the butter! 

My friend told me the portion size was pretty small but I found that I had a hard time finishing everything (I didn't finish the sauerkraut). Food was pretty good though. The bratwursts (there were 3) had a nice snap to them and was delicious with the mustard they provided. The sauerkraut was delicious. The mashed potatoes were very creamy and simply seasoned. Probably the best mashed potatoes I've had anywhere. 

I tried my friends dishes and I liked the spaetzle the best. It's a simple dish and is really similar to mac n' cheese but seriously delicious. The portobello mushrooms were good too but I remember the spaetzle the most.

Overall good food. The place was pretty hyped up for me so I actually expected more, but I would love to go back and try the other things on their menu.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Suppenküche is my favorite German restaurant, hands down. I came here before when I was in college and never knew the name of the place. You can imagine my excitement at unintentionally rediscovering such a neat restaurant/bar.

I was with a group of four that arrived around 7:45. The estimated wait was 30 minutes, so we decided to grab drinks at the bar. Please note, there are only "good" beers and drinks here--no Bud Light or fountain drinks. If you want a Sprite, you will receive a bottled lemon fizz drink that tastes like Sprite. If you want a lambic, they have framboise for about $8. If you want a German beer, they have plenty.

German food isn't really a delicacy, nor is it a typical craving. But what it is is comfort food that fills you up and makes you happy. I am partial to their kaese spaetzle and their potato pancakes. I also thought the Sauerbraten (that includes spaetzle and some other sides) was quite good, although I would be perfectly content with a bowl of spaetzle by itself.

Overall, definitely a solid German choice. I will be back!
author: Julia N.

description:
With Germany fresh on my mind from a trip the week before, the thought of authentic German cuisine sounded liked a great idea. Fellow Yelpers had great things to say about this place and it was in a city I hadn't explored in MANY years.

After settling into parking my rental car, I entered the packed house at Suppenküche. Initially, I almost turned around as the place looked incredibly packed at 7 PM on a Sunday. But I wandered up to the hostess and asked for a table for one. I lucked out as there was a seat at the bar with my name all over it. I settled into the corner and was immediately greeted by the friendly bar staff. Suppenküche is about as authentic as you can get for the German experience in San Francisco. 

The bearded bartender served me a Hefeweizen beer along with bread and butter with chives. They have an excellent variety of German beers on tap, as expected. For an entree, I ordered one of their specials, chicken meatloaf wrapped in bacon, served with mashed potatoes. If it sounds rich, it was! But in all the right ways, Every bite was hearty and flavorful.  

All evening, the staff was beyond friendly and the atmosphere relaxed. I rarely dine out alone but this ended up being a great spot for it. Not sure when I'll be back in SFO but I'd definitely return to Suppenküche!
author: Benjamin L.

description:
this place gets PACKED on weekends! I came with my bf and three friends on a Saturday around 7pm and we had to wait over an hour to be seated, but the food was worth it! also, there's a bar so you can chill and drink while you wait although it will probably be crowded. you can order Das Boot (2 liters of beer) if you're hardcore, but before that, my suggestion would be to make a day out of this and start at Biergarten then continue drinking at Suppenkuche while you wait for dinner. this is what we did and I'm sure many of the people who end up here migrate over from the beer garden too. 

for food, my bf and I decided to share two things (as usual) - the wiener schnitzel and jaeger schnitzel. our group also shared the potato pancakes as an appetizer. the main entrees seemed pretty pricey at almost $20 per plate, but the portions are huge!

potato pancakes - 5/5 - this was so yummy. it came with 3 potato pancakes that had the crispy texture of hash brown and apple sauce (literally tasted like the apple sauce that kids eat) to dip it in or spread over. the saltiness of the potato combined with the sweet apple taste was amazing. 

wiener schitnzel - 3/5 - i was expecting this to be better. don't get me wrong though - the breaded pork was very good, but I thought it was lacking something. the dish only came with 2 large breaded pork patties and a heap of small potato wedges. the lemon didn't give the pork enough flavor and I ended up dipping pieces into the jaeger schnitzel gravy. 

jaeger schnitzel - 5/5 - this was my favorite dish! when I took the first bite of it, I wished that I ordered my own although half of this huge portion was plenty for me. this plate is pretty much the same as the schnitzel except that it's doused with delicious gravy and comes with spatzle instead of potatoes, which was cooked perfectly. loved it! I highly recommend this dish!

I definitely want to come back here and try their strudel for dessert next time!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Super excited to find a German restaurant in SF after visiting Germany a few years ago. On the exterior, Suppenküche is actually pretty easy to miss due to it's unassuming facade. However, once inside, you are welcomed with a loud and lively atmosphere.

Some key points:
1) Patrons are seated in communal tables.
2) Large food portions.
3) GERMAN BEERS!
4) There is a bar.

We met up at 6:30 pm on a Friday night and luckily we did not have to wait too long for a table. We shared a table with a couple, but there was more than enough space for us all. 

Food:
1) Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und grünem Salat (Breaded and sauteed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad) - Classic German staple. MUST GET. Schnitzel was super delicious, crunchy, fresh, and filling. Loved that the "Green Salad" was a few baby lettuce leaves covered with a light vinaigrette. 

2) Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße mit Spätzle und grünem Salat (Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spätzle & Green Salad) - Pork was slightly tough and chewy. The mushroom sauce was less salty and more herby than the American mushroom sauce - different, but good. Spätzle (soft egg noodle) was served with a cheesy sauce and tasted like a less cheesy version of the American mac and cheese.

Drink:
1) Bananen Weizen: Hefeweizen with Banana Juice. Simply delicious. Tasted like a smoother version of a banana smoothie. Highly recommend and must get if you eat here. The glass sizes range from 0.2 L to 2L (Germany boot) to 5L.
author: Angel G.

description:
Having spent almost 7 years of my life in Germany, every once in a while I crave some good hearty German food.  I've had the Jägerschnitzel and Sauerbraten so far and both have hit the spot.  Ambience there is pretty lively (you can hear from across the street). Beer selection is pretty good too.

In the typical German fashion, it's multiple parties/groups sitting at the same table and they'll squeeze you in where they can.  Also they can fill up quickly and it's first come first serve with no reservations unless you have a large group.
author: Mark A.

description:
Today's Sunday brunch was extra special because it was also my first time trying German food. Everything was delicious, well presented and basically flavor explosions.

From the outside it looked intimidating to because the doors looked like it was an entrance to a dungeon. But after going inside, you're greeted by a friendly gentleman and seated. The decor is light and airy, a bit whimsical with the in-flight birds on the ceiling. Very Pinterest-style. 

I got the meatloaf on the brunch menu. It was so good! The meatloaf is very different from the typical American one. The meat is cured and has a crunchy springy texture. Cross between the look and cut of spam to the texture like cured Vietnamese meat. It was so flavorful, and hearty. The roasted potatoes and the two sunny side eggs on top added additional protein for a substantial meal that calls for an afternoon nap.

My girlfriend got the pork chop which is part of their regular menu. The entire pork chop was cured. So very different than what we are used to but it tasted amazing. The pork chop had texture like holiday ham in its hearty briny flavor that never ceases to be perfection. It sat on top of creamy mashed potatoes and sauerkraut, which gave the pork chop depth and richness. So yummy! Flavor combinations were spot on. I only wished we had room for the potato pancakes. 

I look forward to going back here again. The food was all delicious and I could tell the people who dine here really enjoy the food and beer and their culture. It was such a great experience to even get a glimpse of it. The food is comforting, atmosphere is nice during weekend mornings.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
- Locale Destination - 
It's on Laguna St and Hayes St in Hayes Valley, SF. 

I like the atmosphere - simple, sophisticated yet casual - very San Francisco. It gets packed right after they open. They have lots of tables and a little seating area behind the bar. Service is friendly. Street parking. 





- Gluttony Expedition - 
Andechs doppelbock: Sour /soy sauce like taste.. Not so heavy body. Very black in color. I don't like this type of beer.




- Conqueror's Deduction - 
Interesting beer selections. Foods are tad expensive (around $18 for bar foods/German foods, which are very "homey") and not so exciting... You don't even pay that much at the proper German restaurants... I like the atmosphere - Nicer neighborhood bar/chic dive bar.
author: Akiko I.

description:
You will ask: "How can it be that a German girl, who has been living in the Bay Area for over 5 years, has never been to Suppenküche before?" Well, let me tell you... when I lived in SF during the first year, I was so fresh off the boat that I was not too interested in food from the homeland (and too broke anyway). And then I moved to the East Bay and the schlepp to The City just became too much for a Schnitzel. As a friend just said: why should you leave the East Bay when you can eat at places like Speisekammer, Gaumenkitzel and Brotzeit? But I can tell you: Suppenküche is so worth it! Schlepp me there any time! I took the first bite from my huuuuge mixed salad and felt like home. Somewhere on the Bavarian countryside in the summer. Sitting in a beergarden under a chestnut tree. Holy beets, carrots and Kartoffelsalat! SO FREAKING GOOD! Then I took a bite of my Maultaschen and started to dream even more... The husband had the venison and loved it as well, but he is not as vocal as I am. And the beer! Oh holy Augustiner Edelstoff, glowing like you have a halo. 
I. Will. Be. Back.
author: Alexa W.

description: I love Bavarian food and I have had my fair share in the motherland. I ate my way through Germany from top to bottom, and it was a spectacular experience. I was so excited to find Suppenküche by chance and the food was no disappointment! Loved the: beer selections, the lamb was off the hook, the chicken was super delicate and moist, and the pretzel/cheese was super authentic. It is kinda loud, but what do you expect in a  beer hall!!! I can't wait to go back!!! Danke!
author: Erica K.

description:
This place is so good!

Came here on Friday night, arrived early because we were expecting a wait. The place was really packed, so we had drinks at the bar while we waited and were teased by all the delicious looking plates flying by. After an hr or so we were finally seated.

We ordered:

Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce ----$12
- German hash browns with a yummy sweet, tart apple sauce

German Ravioli filled with Pork and Vegetables served with Mushroom Sauce ----$13.5
- MUST GET... *insert serious emoji*

Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes ----$18.5.
- It was a little salty for my liking, but still good.

Didn't get to try the boot since I was driving. Super cozy and lively atmosphere. Left with a happy tummy! I will be back to try other dishes!
author: Michelle M.

description: They are getting cocky. Went here for years and now they even charge for the bread. Wiener schnitzel is tiny and close to $20. Still tastes good, but just not great value any more. Waiters are also not that friendly any more.
author: Robert A.

description:
Small cozy restaurant with a great beer selection and excellent food! The best part is, when you order drinks at the bar, the bartender simply asks you a few question of your taste preferences and BAM! The beer of your dreams is served!

Warning: This joint gets insanely packed on weekends, so reservations or early arrival is highly recommended. The restaurant is so small that there's literally no room to wait for the bathroom. I had to shift countless times during my 10 min wait for the restroom. However, the superb food definitely makes up for it, and here's what we ordered.

Appetizer: Meat platter & Potato pancake
Main Course: Bratwurst with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut & Venison

My favorite part of this entire meal was probably the potato pancakes, except I would have preferred it to be served hot instead of lukewarm. With the apple sauce, this dish is absolutely wonderful. Who would of thought that hash browns would go well with apple sauce? Just genius!

My second favorite was the infamous sausage, of course. It definitely deserves credits for being homemade, but it should receive a trophy for making it THAT good. It's just the perfect texture and seasoned so well that along with a bite of creamy mashed potatoes, my night was complete. The meat platter and venison on the other hand was not pleasing to my palette. I personally don't enjoy the gamey taste of venison, but if you are a fan, I would go for it since my boyfriend seemed to have praised the dish. The meat platter through, I do not recommend. There wasn't anything special about it and really, it just reminded me of a platter of deli meat...sorry.

Overall, service was great and food was excellent, would definitely visit again!
author: Luby H.

description:
Dunkels, Doppelbock, and Chicken and Apple Sausage with Mashed Potatoes and Sauerkraut: I want this in my stomach again!

Got to try this place out with a group of 5 colleagues (thank you company!) to celebrate our recent victory (go Team A!). And boy, this place did not disappoint.

Btw, it's a little hard to spot in the dark but it's the restaurant on the corner! 

When we finally made it, wow was it packed! Be prepared for a loud loud night but your orders will certainly come out great. Our waiter came back to make sure we were happy the right amount of times and made sure our beers were at our satisfactory levels. 

And the food? I'm a 5'4, 115-120lb girl. I can eat a lot if I want but I ended up having to pack 50% of my food home (and the boy loved the leftovers). It was amazing and I want more, now.
author: Leslie L.

description:
PACKED. Wall-to-wall hipster people in old clothing.  LOUD, it's a small space and we couldnt move yet servers and patrons kept running us over.  We put our name in with the creppy hostess and moved to the bar, waited an hour and she forgot us repeatedly.  I found people to be rude and useless, so we left afters a few beers and ate dinner across the street at the kebob house.  Waste of my time.  I'm german, and was looking forward to some German food, but honestly looking at peoples' plates while I waited, the food looked sloppy, soggy, and not appetizing...so i guess the rude hostess saved me from wasting a meal on it.

NOT WUNDERBAR!
author: Scott Z.

description: We love this restaurant. Definitely a staple when we visit the city. Such a lively feel and communal dinning at its best. They make great German dishes and have a solid beer list. My husband always orders a beer in das boot :) Only downside can be the wait to be seated.
author: K R.

description:
When people stand in line even before the restaurant opens, you're guaranteed to be in for a treat! Tasty food and beer. Great service. 

My party of four had the German ravioli (highly recommended) for appetizer; grilled lamb chops with Brussels sprouts and mashed potatoes and roasted dumpling half chicken with potato pancake for entreés, and their German apricot IPA boot size beer to share. We'll most definitely go back for their schnitzel and mushroom soup and pretzels and desserts and other beers. 

Can't wait!
author: farida r.

description: Very disappointed!  We have ate here several times over the years.  Apparently they have a new cook that has no clue how to cook German food. It was blan and over cooked and both the chicken and beef was tuff.  The red cabbage was under cooked and had no flavor. We are also beer drinkers and it seam like there beer was oxided.  The are not serving enough so it's old.  Sorry to say we will not be going back.
author: Brenda M.

description: Consistently the best, most satisfying dinner in the neighborhood. Potato pancakes, trout, meatloaf, venison, and breaded pork chop dishes are all epic. Lots of german classic brews on draft that you can't find anywhere else. Service is great, always!
author: Nann N.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the city. I wouldn't typically opt for german cuisine but this place has completely changed my mind. I bring all out of town visitors here and it is my go-to recommendation for anyone who asks. 

Great atmosphere - communal tables, friendly/cool staff + managers
Great location - even if you have to wait, you can grab beers at the bar or wander down to other local bars in hayes valley to pass time. **worth the wait**
Great food/drink - be prepared for rich but scrumptious german food + authentic german beers served in all sizes (+1 for the Boot)  

Food recommendations:
Apps - 
Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce
Pretzels

Dinner -
Wiener Schnitzel
Venison 
Cheese Spätzle
Grilled Pork Sausage
author: Caroline L.

description:
Despite it being my heritage, I've typically stayed away from German cuisine, with past experiences of being drowned in massive plates of cabbage salad, fried chicken, and bland pork chops (my childhood involved endless trips to a German village in Michigan, it was not great).

 Suppenküche is the exact opposite of everything I despised in German food, and honestly one of the cutest little restaurants I've had the pleasure of dining at in San Francisco. I'm not sure how much of it was the holiday decorations and how much was their normal decor, but the interior is gorgeous - huge wooden tables with benches and chairs, a tree situated on the bar itself with tiny wooden red & white mushrooms sticking out, and fun wall decor as well.

I regretfully did not try das boot (of course I give up beer the one month I go here), but it looks entirely awesome. They have a great selection of beers and wines, so I wasn't too left out.

Per a friend's recommendation, I ordered the potato pancakes to share (and you definitely want to share them). It came as three huge pancakes (sort of like thick hash browns), with applesauce on the side. We ended up taking about half home, but still quite good!

I ordered the venison medallions served in red wine plum sauce, and with sides of red cabbage and spätzle. Even by sharing the venison with the table, I still took over half of the meal home. Everything was delicious though - the venison was quite rich, and the sides were a nice change in texture and flavor.

I didn't order, but did sample the butternut squash soup, the goose, and the sautéed pork loin, all of which were excellent.

Come hungry and thirsty, or be prepared to have a lot of leftovers of excellent food!
author: Claire S.

description: This restaurant is the best in Hayes valley in my opinion. The food (including the delicious pre-meal bread and jam basket) is impeccable and well priced, but the ambience of the restaurant is what really wins you over. It is a simple, but thoughtfully decorated space where communal meals with friends (or strangers, as tables are often shared among multiple parties) are cherished. It felt like everyone in the place was smiling and enjoying a beer, and it was only brunch. One of my new favorites spots in SF.
author: Johanna B.

description: I tried the Wienerschnitzel here and it is fantastic. The atmosphere here is also nice. The servers are excellent.
author: Huy N.

description:
Delicious!  

Getting there a few minutes before opening is a good idea to snag a good table. We were a party of 6 and were seated at a nice long table in the middle of the restaurant.  The service was excellent and they gave us some excellent beer suggestions.  The potato pancakes and pretzels were amazing!  I could eat a whole meal of just the appetizers.  

The meatloaf was incredibly moist and tasty and the lamb chops with truffle butter was so tender and flavorful.
author: Becky L.

description:
I had never been to a German restaurant before. 
I told my wife I was looking for a restaurant that served meat loaf. She found this restaurant.

My first thought when I walked in was "Man, this place is dark."
The room was filled with candles and small Christmas lights on the ceiling.
 Actually it was quite nice.

Anyway, I ordered the meat loaf. It has a much longer German name I could begin to pronounce or spell.
I loved it.  The meat loaf was wrapped with bacon and eggs were cooked in the middle. It sat on top of mashed potatoes. I could eat this every night.

The only problem I had was being seated by the door.
Every time someone came in, I could feel all 55 degrees. 

The service was just ok. The food came relatively fast.

I plan to return in the near future.
author: Darryl L.

description:
Came here during Oktoberfest and my group totalllyyy forgot until we got there and it was jam packed! All I wanted was the potato pancakes and the boot-shaped glass of beer but since Oktoberfest was happening, these were unavailable this particular evening. How sad ):

We ended up getting the half chicken, a pretzel, bratwurst sausages, mac'n'cheese and a side of fries. When the food came out, it all looked smaller than we anticipated for the four of us but the meats were all quite delicious. I usually like sauerkraut but for some reason, the ones that came w/ the bratwurst tasted a bit off for me.

On another occasion, I was nearby Suppenkuche during lunch time so we decided to go on in and give it a try. Why not? When else will we ever try German brunch? There was a general brunch menu and a daily brunch menu. This time, the potato pancakes were available so of course, we got it.

POTATO PANCAKES
It's like hash browns but with a thicker layer of fried goodness. It almost looked like fried ramen noodles haha but it was very good. It came with a side of cold apple sauce. I wonder how it would taste with hot apple sauce instead?

VEAL + CHICKEN SAUSAGE SOUP W/ PRETZEL
Slightly full from the potato pancakes, soup sounded just right. The sausage was tasty but the soup was a bit too salty. It tasted like chicken broth from a can... The pretzel was spot on with the crisp yet soft texture.

SMOKED SALMON OMELETTE
My friend ordered this and it was insanely overwhelming in its salt levels. My first bite of it and I'm already doubting if I can even finish it. My friend didn't finish it... he left maybe 7 bites of it behind.

So now I know. German brunch is not the way to go. At least for me. I gotta come back to give this place a REAL try and order the wiener schnitzel with a side of potato pancakes. But as of now, I'm at a 3.5 rounded up to a 4 for the hopes of a good dinner meal here one day soon.
author: Sandy T.

description: Awesome food, awesome beer. Keeping it simple! The service isn't as great (but 9 out of 10) cause we were regulars of a separate bartender who's no longer there. A San Fran spot you need to try out, even if it takes an extra few minutes to find parking.
author: Bryant B.

description:
Used to really like this place - it is authentic German cuisine - but last night we went for dinner and this morning we are still reeling from how salty the food was. I literally dreamt of buying a gallon of water, that's how parched I was.

Maybe dial down the sodium just a tad, guys?
author: Joyce Y.

description:
I never thought I liked German food until I finally made my way to this restaurant. Really flavorful and rich meals in a very cute environment. I ordered the Venison Medallions and my friend had ordered a special involving lamb, and both cuts were cooked to perfection and paired really well with the sides (that I at first thought sounded bland).

It is a little on the pricey side, but the portions are generous (easily 2 meals unless you eat a lot) and they have a very impressive beer selection.

The wait can get a little long but they do allow you to sit at the bar and drink while you wait for a table. I went on a Friday night once and was seated immediately, but a Tuesday night was a 40 minute wait for us, so it depends. They only do reservations for 6+ so might be worth it to get a group going.

Really cute inside, but seating is communal tables that fit 6 (I think), so a little awkward if you're looking for an intimate date spot.

Next on my list is to come for Brunch and to share a Boot!
author: Christina R.

description:
This place rocks!

I had been eager to visit a German Restaurants for YEARS now. Especially considering the last one I went to was at the age of 13....yeah, its been a while. 

After finishing assisting my agent friend with an open house somewhat close by, they decided to treat me to dinner here before I headed back to the east bay. 

This place reminisces a little whole in the wall place that I can imagine would be similar to something you would encounter/experience in Germany.

It was a Sunday evening and when we arrived the place was PACKED! We went to the bar area where the hostess took our names and told us it would be like a 40 min wait. We decided to just of course wait at the bar and order a drink. I really was not much in a beer mode( this is a beer place) so I decided to order a glass of Cabernet off of their very small, less than appealing wine list. My friend ordered a beer. My Cabernet was just ok. 

We were then seated with another group of people. It seems to be how the seating arrangement goes. It turned out to be quite fun. 

I then decided to order a darker style beer that I had a sample of at the bar being the wine just wasn't doing much for me. The beer was actually quite excellent tasting. For food, we ordered a bowl of Lobster soup to share. For my main dish I ordered Gebratene Forelle in Zitronen Buttersoßemit Kartoffeln und Spinat which is Sauteed Trout in Lemon Butter Sauce with Bouilon Potatoes & Spinage. My friend ordered Grilled Cured Pork Chop with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes.

Lobster soup was ok. I mean it was decent in flavor but nothing exceptional. It was also warm and not hot like fresh soup should be. 

Dishes arrived excellently authentic and hearty looking. And excellently hearty tasting it was!!! Trout was grilled/sauteed to perfection, leaving a nice savory flavorful crust on top of the fish that was just superb tasting. The sauce was also quite delectable. Oh and the potato's were rich, creamy and tasteful as well. Especially considering I am not a fan of potato s in general. I also had a few bites of my friends pork chops that were too, cooked PERFECTLY and tastes wonderful.

Overall, the ambiance is very lively, loud, and authentically entertaining. Service was right on top of it- as well as charming and sincere. I also found most of the food to be phenomenal tasting in a very hearty, home cooked way. I even enjoyed the stranger group seating arrangement that I was a little hesitant at first. Turned out to be a blast.
author: Shannon H.

description: Short wait on a Sunday evening, all seating is communal (you share a large table with other parties). Got the venison, cooked perfectly and had the right amount of flavor. My friends and I also got the potato pancakes and bread to start. Potato pancakes were super crispy/kinda salty but I loved em. Bread was good. Would definitely go again to try the other dishes or come just for beer/the bar!
author: Sarah M.

description: In the spirit of OktoberFest, my boyfriend and I paid a visit to Suppenkuche to feast on schnitzels, potato pancakes w/ apple sauce, pretzels, German raviolis, and of course, beer. We came in on a busy Saturday night around 5:30pm and were given a 45 minute wait time. The wait time was expected, so we just strolled around the streets of Hayes Valley marveling at the local boutiques, restaurants, and bars. Upon arriving back at the restaurant, we were seated approximately at the estimated time of seating. From the time we sat to the time we left the restaurant, only 30 minutes passed. LOL. My boyfriend and I shared a giggle as we both noticed that it only took us 30 minutes to order, scarf down our meal, and chug our beers. However, we waited 45 minutes just to get a seat at a communal table. If you don't mind sharing a table with 2 parties of two and being in close proximity to strangers, then this place is for you! The food is divine. Everything is hearty, huge in portion, and it down right touched my soul. I highly recommend!
author: Briana H.

description: Spatzle!!!! Spatzle with the tender pork loins and creamy mushroom sauce! Omggg so delicious paired with a mixed beer. I got a mixed beer of some sort with lemon soda added to it? Sweet and delicious. this place is also crazy packed all the time so prepare to wait!
author: Diane H.

description: Ive always wanted to try this place when I drive by heading on the freeway and see the crowd lining outside..great service with tastey German food . I like the pork with mushroom sauce ...we also had the venison with cranberry sauce dip that was superb I'd be back for that.
author: Juila L.

description:
A good friend with impeccable taste and a defused bomb as a living room ornament who I trust implicitly took me here with her husband. 

And man, was it the bomb. See what just happened there? That little, ah, that little segue ah you know what never mind, it was super lame. What wasn't lame was the  hearty, carby, good-to-jam-in-your-wordhole Germanic fare at this trendy little suburban brat-fest. 

Schnittys, sausages, gravy, bread dumplings, sauerkraut - you know the drill, it's like Oktoberfest on a plate. And in your stein. Because you'll be drinking here. You may even order The Boot, a giant glass boot filled with beer, because why the hell not drink from a shoe. 

And who doesn't like Germans? Or a schnitty? I do. I like them a lot.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
We ate here for the first time last week.  Reviews by my party of three were mixed: I was fairy enthused, my wife was wholly unimpressed, and our friend split the difference. 

We shared several dishes and, as others have pointed out, it's impossible to finish what you are served, so leftovers were inevitable.  We shared a composed salad that included beets, cabbage, carrots, potato salad, and butter lettuce with a lovely vinaigrette.  If you can accept "simple" as an adjective to describe your starter, this was great.  We also had potato pancakes, which were a bit less successful.  The exterior surfaces were nice and crusty, but the interior wasn't so flavorful, and the "apple sauce" was not what those raised on Mott's would expect, but, rather, a fruity syrup.  

My wife ordered the wienerschnitzel, about which none of us was too enthused. The pork was a bit tough, the batter unseasoned, and the promised green salad conspicuously absent.  Our friend ordered the bratwurst, which were very flavorful, but not what we expected: they were not plump at all, but, rather, about the form factor of a hot dog.  Once the surprise about their appearance wore off, we enjoyed these.  Finally, I ordered the meatloaf.  It was a bit dry, but, otherwise, it was lovely.
