It had overtones of, I think, sage and a nice hardboiled egg in its middle, and the mushroom gravy was rich and delicious.  Sides included delicious roasted potatoes alongside the wienerschnitizel, mashed potatoes with the bratwurst and meatloaf, and a world-class sauerkraut added to the bratwurst.  There were leftover sausage pieces and meatloaf to take home.

The beer list is pretty long and appeared esoterically German.  I don't know enough about it to be aware of whether Suppenkuche covered all the bierkeller bases, but I found a really enjoyable cider that went well with the hearty food.

Nearly all seating is communal; luckily, we had respectful table companions.  Service is competent, with the bussers checking on us more often than our order taker; our order taker was very, very gracious about correcting a small error on our bill, so kudos to her for a good attitude.  Noise level is nuts, however; by the time all the tables filled in, we could not hear anything said at our table, so I downgrade a bit for that, as well.

Finally, I am downgrading one star for this very specific reason:  Neither the person who seated us and handed us menus nor the order taker ever mentioned there were specials. We learned of them only as we were getting up to leave and saw some incredible-looking, big fat sausages on another diner's plate.  At that point, the bus person we asked about the sausages told us that they were on the "specials menu."  The specials menu turned out to be a thing: it was left on each of the tables, but, at our table, it never left the side occupied by the other party, so we had zero awareness of it.  When we looked at it, we each decided that we'd have ordered something else than we actually had ordered, i.e., a salmon dish for my wife, the sausages (which were made from wild boar) for our friend, and a roast suckling pig dish for me.  The specials might be the only thing that actually gets us back to Suppenkuche.  The greeter and order taker need to do a much better job of pointing out their existence, especially if there is only one copy of that menu per communal table.
author: Mike R.

description: Oh yeah. Oktoberfest all year long baby! Their menu changes all the time so it is hard to recommend a specific dish. The last time I was there, I had wild boar with these amazing potato pancakes. One thing that is kind of funky is you eat on a park bench with the rest of the humanity. Reminds me more of eating in the Czech Republic than Germany but this is a quibble. You should eat here if you like German food and find yourself in the City.
author: Ken R.

description:
A little disappointing.

The food was just too darn rich for us. The speatlze was so cheesy we could not eat it, the apple pancakes were super deep fried - we couldn't eat much of them. 

The beers were great.

The atmosphere was good, but we were backed into a small area behind the bar which was relatively cramped.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Place was aweson..first time last weekend.  The bar tender was amazing good advice on what to drink..was on point with all our drinks. Food was excellent large portions. Have to get there early, we got there 15 mins before opening and there was a line already.  But it's worth the wait. Definitely going back.
author: Kharla T.

description: We've been coming to Suppenkuche since 1999 for brunch and this was our first dinner here. As expected, we were not disappointed! The sauerbraten and jäger schnitzel could have been just flown in from Bavaria. What a great meal! Combined with a true German ambience, great service (thanks, Matthew!), and draft German beer, you just can't go wrong! It was a hard choice as the regular menu was supplemented by th specials - hard to make a choice, but when you can't go wrong, it fun to be adventurous.
author: David C.

description:
I've never had German food so I'm not knowledgeable about German food at all, but I do know when I've had a tasty and hearty meal. Let me tell you... this place will get you ridiculously full from all the delicious appetizers but you'll die the happiest person alive. 

All my friends ordered a variety of different dishes so I got to taste a bit of everything. I myself ordered the Bratwurst with a replacement of the sauerkraut for spatzle ($18.50). Spatzle is a doughy pasta like side dish. It looks like tiny bits of dough essentially. It's a lot of carbs but I don't even care, it tasted so good.

Pros:
1) Easily shared appetizers
2) Large portions for a growing body
3) Everything is flavorful and delicious
4) 2 liters of beer in a boot 

Cons:
1) Overly crowded and tight space
2) Fairly expensive if you're on a tight budget
3) It costs $50 if you break the boot. Don't break the boot.

Dishes to try:
1) Potato Pancakes (appetizer)
2) German Ravioli (appetizer)
3) Sauteed Venison Medallions
4) Grilled Cured Pork Chop
5) Bratwurst
author: Kathy V.

description: My fiancé and I were visiting SF and stumbled upon Suppenküche. We were looking for good food and beer. Luckily we found it easily here! The food was AMAZING and the severs were very quick, friendly and knowledgeable. We were helped by a good looking fella with a Burt Reynolds type mustache. I'm kicking myself for not getting his name... If you're hungry and in SF I highly suggest you give them a shot. You'll be very pleased. Keep up the good work guys! I'll definitely be stopping in next time I'm in the area. Good service is hard to find these days so praise it when you receive it.
author: Tony T.

description:
Found this spot on yelp while we are roaming in Hayes valley. We arrived at 5:30 sunday night, and we was shocked by such a crowd in the restaurant already. Everyone here seems enjoy food and bear a lot. when we have seat we realize you have to seat with other people together, but it has better atmosphere this way. 

As first time Visitor, we just order Potato pancake, sausage, and a beer. It's amazingly good!! We fall in love with the food on every bite. Food are simple, full of flavors, and so good to pair with beer. The beer is fresh and one of the best in the city, too.

the only down side I think is you can't order too much food while you have to drink lots of beer :) 

We can't wait to be back to try out other selections!
author: angiesftpe l.

description: Absolute 5 stars. Get the Jagerschnitzel. The mushroom sauce was amazing. Ask about the 5L boot. Then drink all of it.
author: Zach M.

description:
I've wanted to come by to this restaurant to try out the German beers and food and was pretty pleased. When you enter into the restaurant, you see like planets hanging on the ceiling, which was interesting but not too sure why they added that element to the restaurant. Anyways, when I looked at the beer menu, they had Hefeweizen beer which is my favorite type of beer to drink! It was refreshing and tasty!

I was a little bit confused as to the way they operated here. From what a waitress told me, people reserved tables for a block period (6pm-8pm, 8pm-10pm) and if you don't have a reservation, you can be put in a wait list. When I arrived at 6pm, I was not aware that my friend didn't get a spot for us so I just added my name to the list in hopes we got a table. When my friends finally arrived, she notified the waitress about how she called earlier and tried to get a spot but couldn't. The waitress was kind about it and she found an open table for us to sit and dine.

The food I ordered was veal with potatoes and a salad. At the time, I thought veal was some German food sauce (had a dumb moment there) being added to the potato. It was until after I ordered my friend told me what it really was, to which I was kinda sad. When the food arrived, I'll be honest, i felt guilty about it but it did tasted pretty good. It was tender and easy to eat and the potatoes was really good. One of my friends ordered a 2 liter boot which is huge! He had to share with all of us to finish it. 

Overall, this is place is pretty cool and would probably come back to this place if I'm around the area. Kinda pricey, but tha's expected when you are in SF.
author: Tito G.

description: Friendly staff and decent food. But not mind blowing. The seats are too small. We had to share the table with other two customers.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
Northern Californians are so lucky when it comes to German Food! Between Suppenkueche, Speisekammer and Gaumenkitzel  you have at least food somewhat representative of tasty German cuisine. I have been frequenting Suppenküche since it first opened, and thanks to Fabrizio , it has always been a welcome trip to revisiting the yummy comfort food of my first 18 years in Deutschland. Raised by a great German cook mother from Bavaria and having had the good fortune of dining in some of the best restaurants in Germany in 2015 and 2016 I know my Leberknödel done by an Oma in a Bavarian Village to the modern Gourmet "Quartett vom Schwein" at Atelier Wilma In Frankfurt.
Oh but loathe the SoCal German restaurants! Ii am  sitting in "Jeanette's Edelweiss" in a strip mall of Northern L.A. Suburbia with cheap annoying German Schlager music blasting. Note the difference in restaurant names ( seriously "Edelweiss" ?) which is a dead giveaway to smart creative substance restaurateur (translate my NorCal mentioned restaurants) vs. dummy tourism. Absolutely insulting beer prices with $9 for German tap beer. The veal Wiener Schnitzel tasted like dog food, the "German" potato salad was a disgrace. Also sampled Bratwurst and Sauerbraten. At best this is what food in a bad Bahnhof Kneipe (Railway Station joint) would taste like in Germany,  - At 4 Times the Price!!!  As for Jeanette:            " Schuster Bleib Bei Deinen Leisten' ( a "film producer career" ????) 
My dear Conejo Valley Americans who are swilling this food in honor of their German roots or Germany connections: Please don't take this as representative for German food! This old Kraut will go across the street to "In n Out Burger" for better food.
author: Michael H.

description:
5 LITERS, bro. \m/ Party of 14, Saturday night.
Love how the waitress kept asking me "the five, or the point-five?" and "the five. the five liters...?" BOCK and BELGIAN ALES categories are off-limits for the 5L because of their higher %ABV. Everything else is #gameon.
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=a4nJxhKOVmCHjGBTJul_ZQ&userid=WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA

Food MENU seemed small, but everything we got was good. They did run out of one then another entree, so we didn't get to try some things.

RSVP NOTES
Phone mostly goes to voicemail.
They don't always call back.
I recommend RSVPing in person.
Keep asking till they say yes.
+1 edits are generally okay.
Last-minute absentee leniency.
Were able to sit with an incomplete party.
author: Dan B.

description:
Go see Kenneth. He will know what beer to give you. The service is great. Relaxed & knowledgeable. Food is phenomenal. Typical German. Protein & carbs...good stuff. 
Try & get a seat at the bar so you can chat while you drink. The guys really know their stuff how to pronounce everything! 
The grilled pork sausages & mashed potatoes are especially good. Perfect drinking food!
author: Oliver P.

description:
This was my first experience with German food.. and I was pleasantly surprised! 

We arrived there around 8pm on a Friday night. it was PACKED. They do not take reservations so get ready to wait. The environment is very friendly, loud, and overall fun! We waited at the bar with some beers. They have a wide selection of german beers (of course) and the bartender was very helpful. Since our wait was about an 45 minutes, we decided to order some food at the bar. If you get a good spot at the bar and don't want to wait, their full menu is available at the bar just keep in mind that there are no chairs at the bar. When we got seated, we shared a big table with another party. I thought it would be a little awkward since we were sitting so close but it was fun and we had a great time chatting with the party next to us! 

Now for the food: 

Pretzel: so soft and warm! It was a perfect appetizer while waiting. 

Potato Pancakes: It was crispy, thin, and simple. 

Pork Shoulder: DELICIOUS. This was my favorite dish of the night. I was a little taken back by how big it was. I thought it was going to be dry but don't let that deceive you. It was crispy on the outside and so tender inside!! I don't know about you but I love crispy pork skin! 

Bratwurst with Mashed Potatoes: Delicious and full of flavor! This was also very moist. 

Boot of Beer: Huge! I personally probably wouldn't be able to finish it by myself. We ordered one for the experience and it was so fun! Probably wouldn't order it again just because it was already so full from all the food! 

We shared everything between three people and it was the perfect amount. We all left full and happy!
author: Thatcher H.

description: From the moment you walk into SuppenKuche, the positive energy and the friendliness of the staff makes it feel like you are having a family reunion with strangers. Great beers, great food (yes, German food can be heavy) and the only thing missing is someone playing the chicken dance on an accordion.
author: Bob S.

description:
Saturday was my first experience with true German food and I loved it! My friend gave us two options- really good pizza or German food with beer in a boot!

While the aroma of pizza captivated my senses as we walked past the first restaurant the idea of 2 liters of beer in a boot intrigued me more.

I knew this place had to be good when I noticed the line forming outside half an hour before they were about to open. The restaurant is small but really nice inside and seating is communal. We were seated with 2 other elderly German couples which made the experience even better! The were fun, had plenty of recommendations and told us about some of the boot traditions. 

Most of the foods at Suppenkuche are rich in quality and flavor. We had:

German Bread- typical german brown bread with a creamy, buttery, herb spread.

Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus AKA... THE BEST Potato Pancakes EVERRR!!!! (with Homemade Apple Sauce) I don't know what they put in these things or how they make them but don't call them hash browns! You can order them as an appetizer or they are included with some of the entrees. These Potato Pancakes are $$$ and make me want to return for brunch just to have more and try other menu items.

Pretzel with Cheese Sauce- I don't know if I've ever had a pretzel this good before. Probably not. The pretzel was warm, slightly chewy on the outside and soft and fluffy on the inside. The cheese sauce was an amazing buttery seasoned sauce that melted in the mouth.

Krautwickel is ground pork wrapped in cabbage. The lady next to me said it was one of her favorites. It was suppose to be less rich than some of the other dishes and tasted really good. She was right! The sauce poured on top of the cabbage rolls was warm and savory. It was so good I could eat it with rice! The pork was flavorful and not dry. The side of mashed potatoes were creamy and smooth.

The Boot of Beer was quite a site. The boot itself was tall and really heavy. We ordered a dunkel which complimented all our foods well.

For being really busy service was excellent. The food came out really fast and waitress checked on us often. I'll be back the next time I'm in Hayes Valley in SF since the only German place in Sac so far is a sausage/beer place! We need more German FOOD!
author: Cindy S.

description: Incredibly authentic and perhaps even tastier than some dishes in Germany as my Frankfurt-born hubby has proclaimed. We must order the herring salad as a starter and it's a safe bet to order anything seasonal off the special menu. Portion sizes are on large side. The beer is always fresh and we like the German-style community seating, too. Place gets loud but it's always a good time and we leave with happy tummies!
author: Denise R.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place forever after hearing about Das Boot. 

On our first try, it was over an hour wait and they closed in roughly an hour. Bad planning on our part. So we came back that Thursday around 530/6pm.

Fairly simple decor, all your basic necessities are laid out on the table, low lighting and candles on the table. We were seated next to this other couple, who I want to apologize to at this time if we were rowdy and disruptive. But then again, once the place started filling up, I think everyone gets a bit loud; especially at the bar.

The waitress helped us select a beer for Das Boot; which we were eager to drink out of. You do have to put a credit card on file for collateral in case you break the glass though. And drink out of it with the toe face down so the beer bubble won't burst on you! 

Since none of us knew much about German food, we just ordered a bunch of things to share. The Lentil soup was hearty and I actually preferred it over the Potato Soup Special. Stuffed Portobello Mushrooms, Wild Boar Sausage and Skirt Steak were all delicious. Finished off our meal with Apple Strudel. 

I'm excited to come back to try out more items on the menu!
author: Jenn Y.

description: First time trying out german food but it was a great experience and had amazing atmosphere!
author: Daniel L.

description: We don't have any German options at all in our area, so when we travel, we look for spots with traditional favorites that seem to be local favorites.  So we found Supenkuche.  The feel combined some German restaurant attributes (group seating, Octoberfest posters, glass beer mugs) with San Francisco touches, windows open, funky crowd.  Very good schnitzel dishes and beer selection. Wurst was excellent, try the wild boar and loved the Gemischter Salat.  The beers may not match the labels on the mugs.  So what?!  Good food, friendly staff, definitely worth a return visit.  Oh...spaetzle and potatoes were also good!!!  Next time I'm trying the soup.
author: Sherrie H.

description: I visited this place twice already - and I love their food and beer. Schnitzel might be a bit on the thicker side, but it's not greasy at all - very crispy outside and meat is tender though. Got an order of beer + lemonade drink (forget what it's called), which was also perfect; the right ratio of beer and lemonade (compared to the one in biergarten which was too sweet for me). My bf says it brings back his memories from Germany ;)
author: Ella K.

description:
I used to love Suppenkuche, in Feb, 2015 I made the mistake of celebrating my birthday there. 

They were overwhelmed, had overbooked, I suspect. They added an extra table or two in the back, in what was already a tight space. They questioned and initially rejected my drink order, when I told them I wanted a boot with a strong ale. It was my birthday celebration, I'm a huge guy, experienced, and was not driving. The food was okay, it was better six months earlier, the potato pancakes were a bit overcooked; but my entree was what I expected, nothing more. Our waitress was slow to take our initial drink order, provide bread, and one or two at our table got their food 5 or 10 minutes after the rest of us. That's an eternity for a big guy to be polite, wait, and stare at his meal! 

I realize they have only a little control over who their patrons are, but if your going to question the very large and expensive beer boot I requested, then don't over serve the tourists. There was a party of Europeans next to us with a group member, lets call him "Denny", bumping into us and passing out in the bathroom. Sure, they likely drank before, outside the restaurant, and the guy probably needed some food in him, but it was just one more thing and the boot thing really pissed me off! Oh yeah, they served him drinks, not a boot mind you, but still!

So, I'm a bit introverted and was really looking forward to birthday celebration with my family. I don't mind a bit of noise and watching people mess up a bit, but Suppenkuche was not what it once was. Perhaps it's gotten too popular, perhaps they have slipped, perhaps it was a really really bad day. It was the worst celebration in a restaurant I have ever experienced. Time for me to find a new favorite. :(
author: Jonathan B.

description: Pretty good German food. Not as good as Germany, but close. Traditional limited seating, so be prepared to share a table with strangers. Most things on the short menu are worth a try, can't really go wrong.
author: Adamme K.

description:
Being someone all too familiar with Authentic eastern European food and having this be my 2nd time here (came with a group of friends celebrating a yearly anniversary) I still find the food, with the exception of the meatloaf and mash potatoes to be just "ok." The prices are expensive for this type of food and being a large party, the waiter knew he was guaranteed the large gratuity, was STILL less than attentive towards our group. It took 30min just to get my glass of water and for drinks order in general to be taken, followed by another 20 to order our food. Our waiter not once checked in with us to see if we needed water refills (even though everyone's glass was standing empty.) 

Overall, some of the entree's are quite tasty but I would have to say, save your money and stop by MY mom's kitchen for some TRULY authentic Eastern European fare instead, minus the expensive prices and less than attentive service! ;)
author: Petra S.

description:
Came here for a brunch with people I've never met before!

I know - back up a bit. I was going to a meet-up for people going to make candy (in the review for papabubble) and we met up for food prior to going. 

I ordered the farmer's omelette with potatoes and cheese and then there's some pickles that came with it. The farmer's omelette was heavy, but so good. The cheese and potatoes and vegetables were all mixed in the omelette so it's not pretty, but it was so good. 

Some of the other ladies I met ordered other things and we all shared: chicken schnitzel with mashed potatoes, emperor's pancake (which was like pancakes sliced up with the compote), meatloaf with egg, and german dumplings. Overall, all the dishes were so good. 

Protip: Make a reservation so you don't have to wait, and try some of their delicious food and maybe share a plate with a friend. It was definitely was big portions and delicious food!
author: Nina Y.

description: You think all german food is heavy? Think again! Sometimes they'll have a special that's smoked salmon with a large side salad of apples, potatoes, mayo, etc...and it's definitely enough to split. If you want delicious german food...this is your place. Bartenders are fantastic and will take the time to tell you about a special little monk that brews beer on a mountain top somewhere in germany...and then they will pour you a sample and it will be amazing german beer. Stay at the bar and bang an Underberg on the bar and drink it with no hands.
author: Laura S.

description:
Alright, so the service was pretty awful from the start but the food is hard to criticize. Being German, I had to check it out, and I was delightfully satisfied. Community tables were distracting, but mainly because the restaurant is so loud to begin with. 
Waitress seemed like her life was spiraling out of control, but it was hard to tell since the only light in the room was emitting from candles practically...good food outweighs it all
author: Dominic G.

description:
This place definitely gets crowded. The food is decent but quite pricey. There's nothing really memorable other than the pretzel. The potato pancakes tasted like over fried hash browns but the sauce was good. We tried the venison which was tender but the cabbage was over cooked. We also tried the sausage which was definitely over priced. The pork ribs were the special of the night; tender but lacking in seasoning. The asparagus wrapped in bacon topped with cheese wasn't very hot when it came out so the cheese got colder faster than expected. 

The beer however, is great. Not sure if I would come back but it was worth a try.
author: Marlene T.

description:
Ambiance and music is chill, the decor is quaint and the food? Well I was expecting more but German food is bland so I set expectations too high.

My friends and I started with potato pancakes with apple sauce which were delicious! I ordered the Wiener Schnitzel with potatoes and salad. The potatoes were good only because they had bits of bacon. The schnitzel was a little too salty for my taste. All in all I regretted not getting the meatloaf with mashers. I'll give this place another try but no more Wiener schnitzel for me!
author: V G.

description:
The food here is great, a solid 4 stars.  Delicious Carrot salat.  Jägerschnitzel with champignonsoße was delicious.  I wanna come back for the breaded fried schnitzel.  Good beer selection as well, the Franziskäner hefeweizen on tap was so hoppy and sweet, it tasted like bananas.

However, minus 1 star for the experience -- the wait and the shoving and crowding is just harrowing and so loud you have to yell at the person beside you at your table.  I've gotten turned away a couple times from Suppenküche as well.  I recently went to Schmidt's and had a lovely evening there.  The food is slightly better and it's a venue where you can actually have a civilized meal.
author: Letitia L.

description:
I was here last night with a friend ordered two dinners with a pretzel here
Since we were tired we asked them to get our food to go
When we got home there was no pretzel (but we were charged for it) in our boxes
author: Arash R.

description:
Best german food in the city. The place feels lively and transported straight from Germany. It's a casual but warm feel here.

I recommend of course the potato pancake to start and the schnitzel. These are hearty and always filling.
author: Victor W.

description:
I lived in Germany for 9 years. Does that prove anything to you, that I am giving this delicious, happy, fun, busy... and delicious place a 5 star?

Our favorite place to go for Sunday brunch, and almost a guarantee that I bring my "visiting from out of the bay area friends" here. 

The atmosphere is fab, you get to talk to the people you are sharing the table with, and huuuuge REAL beer selection in all the sizes you can imagine. Yes the boot, they have it, and my friends have ordered it, and loved it.

85% of the time there is a wait, so be prepared. But TOTALLY worth the wait, and my boyfriend and I always need our "Suppenküche fix" so we don't care if we have to wait, even though we hate waiting lol

Just do it, trust me, best german food that I have had in this large country called the USA.
author: R M.

description:
Unfortunately as far as the food goes, this place does not live up the hype. I would definitely be back for different occasions but not for taking a friend who just wants to have great food. We tried jagerschnitzel and pork ribs and I was not impressed with either. 

On the flip side, service was decent, everyone working there was friendly and the beers they have are just amazing. However, I am rating a restaurant that has one of the highest number of reviews on Yelp and I am a bit disappointed with the food. 

Walzwerk in Mission, is way ahead of Suppenküche.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
I love this spot!  So good. The only thing I don't like about this spot is that you sometimes have to share a table with other guests. It's not all that bad but it's worth mentioning. 

The good is crackin!!!  I been here twice and liked it both times. The first time I got the trout and it came with some cabbage. It was awesome. Jus recently, I had the sautéed pork loin with mushrooms and spatzel. This was even better. So good. 

The atmosphere was cool. It's a fun, loud place with great German beers. They also have a boot if anyone is dating enough. :) 

Awesome place. Try it.
author: Steve J.

description:
I really love Schmidt's in the Mission. So having never tried the very popular Suppenküche, which offers a similar menu, I gave this place a go while my parents were visiting SF. 

First things first: holy moly, this place is 1) tiny, and 2) crowded. It's like being on Bart or getting on the N train from the Castro. You will be all up in someone else's business and then also constantly trying to make your body smaller to make room for the waitstaff as they walk by you. 

On a Friday night, the wait for dinner was 45 minutes. My parents and I squeezed ourselves into the area behind the bar, which is a pretty cool, funky little spot. They have some really good pilsners on tap and even a few IPA's, which is unusual for a German restaurant. 

I got the Wiener Schnitzel and the parents got the lamb and the venison. Everything was really good, especially with the house-made rye bread they set at the table; however, the venison was definitely the best. Go ahead, eat some deer when you come here. 

I feel like it took me 24 hours to digest my meal from Suppenküche - this is some really great comfort food.

Seating is very limited, so you might be seated at a community table. We were, and some drunk millenials taught my dad what being cross-faded is. *cringes*
author: K M.

description:
Standards be slippin' or the new chef messed with the recipes. Jaeger schnitzel is no longer the schnitz.

Been going to this place for ten years, but tonight's meal was disappointing. German beer selection remains it's strong suit. Unfortunately, it's off the crave list.
author: Chris L.

description:
Came excited about the beer, left extremely happy about the food. 

Great beer selection in a wide array of glasses and even boots. Seems like a very fun atmosphere. We were there on a Sunday night and they even had a crowd going. The beer selection was pretty good and 7-8 bucks for. 5l isn't too bad in this city. Especially for great imported beer. 

I got the special, chicken meatloaf with bacon and potatoes, and it was very good. Maybe it was the half liter of dopplebock I had before it was served, (or the half liter after) but it definitely hit the spot!
author: Ian F.

description: The food portions here are huge and really heavy, so remember to pack the antacids and elastic pants.
author: John B.

description: Came here for brunch. I don't eat German food at restaurants in San Francisco very much, so I was excited. I wish I had ordered something else because I was not that amazed by getting the 20 cm sausage with eggs and potatoes. It was okay. I wonder about having dinner here. I'm still curious.
author: Denise C.

description:
Prost!

A friend of mine mentioned that this restaurant had a boot you can drink beer out of, so I knew I had to check it out. We arrived before opening and weren't alone when waiting for the doors to open; I saw that as a good sign.

Atmosphere: 
It was pretty dark inside, which made it difficult for us to take pictures (flash was a no-no). My friend and I were seated at a communal table that was lite by candlelight. It would be romantic if it wasn't for the fact that the place can get loud and that you had to share a table with strangers. Luckily, this didn't bother me so I enjoyed my time there. 

Food: 
-We were brought complimentary bread that came with a herb butter. The bread was fresh and it certainly helped with soaking up the beer, but the herb butter was the highlight. It was so yummy! I tried to restrain myself from slathering the entire thing on my little slice of bread, it was that good. 
-Piping hot pretzels! A bit smaller than I expected but it was good. It came with a cheesy onion spread that I thought was too salty, but it's all right in small doses.
-I ordered the Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße mit Spätzle und grünem Salat (thank you copy & paste!) and I thought it was decent. The porkloin was a bit tough to cut and I thought the spatzle was bland without a sauce. I'm not sure I'll order again.
-My companion had chicken with potato pancakes. The chicken was dry, BUTOHMYGOD the potato pancakes were lovely! Crunchy on the outside, but soft in the middle. It's a must-try.

Beer:
Honestly, I'm no beer expert. I felt so confused looking at the vast German and Belgian selection so I texted my bf the menu, asked what was good, and then ordered what he recommended. Mmm... yeah, they did the job. I didn't get to drink out of a boot, but at least I got to drink new things.

Service:
Good. Our server was attentive and helpful when recommending and explaining beers to my friend. 

Overall:
I would come here again. It seems like a great place to bring a bunch of friends and to hang out, drink a couple of beers, and munch on German food. I'll totally try das Boot next time ;)
author: Adri A.

description:
Wanted to cook a traditional Danish Christmas dinner at Christmas eve, so I called this restaurant to hear if I could buy some red cabbage and eventually lingonberry jam and cherry sauce.
I only managed to ask for the former as I got the answer "we do only have enough red cabbage for our costumers". Uh okay? So me buying some products does not make me a costumer? And your inventory is so small you only have enough for eat-in costumers?
Very well, I ended the call saying "merry Christmas" and was met with a somehow offended "what's that?"
This restaurant might have good food (in a very limited amount I assume) , but their costumer service is worth 1 star.
I ended up using cranberry sauce instead which mixed very well with my dinner.
author: Joachim J.

description: Places like this are made for me. I love meat and I love beer, especially tasteful German beer. My girlfriend took me here for my birthday and I could not have been any happier. The service was solid and the food was extremely good. I had the pork chop, which was large and tasty with some fantastic mashed potatoes. My girlfriend had the goose, which we both loved. I will definitely eat here again. My only tip is to get here exactly at 5 because we got there around 5:30 and had to wait about 30 minutes. They only take reservations for groups larger than 6.
author: Tyler K.

description:
The Good: This is the best Jaeger schnitzel I've had since my mom used to make it for my birthday dinner. Killer mushroom gravy, and all of it served on an embarrassment of buttered spaetzle. Our table also ordered the half chicken, the lamb chop, and the schwardwalder kirschtorte. I'm not a beer drinker, but everyone else seemed to enjoy it. Everything we ordered was ausgezeichnet (excellent).

The Bad: The stuff we did not order seemed off-kilter. Two loaves of rough brown bread with insufficient butter appeared and I was intrigued. I expected (or wanted) hofweissbrot, but this was some next-level winter-grained toothfulness. Not bad, but a lot of work and not enough herb butter. The green salad that accompanied the pork dishes read like a half-assed apology; lettuce cut too large dressed with something very simple (vinegar and mayo, I think) and barely playing at being a vegetable. I get the aim: to serve heart meat and potatoes and be different, but a vegetable wouldn't kill us. 

Overall: I would love to go again. I would recommend it heartily to anyone craving German fare and unafraid of large servings of meat. Noch ein!
author: Meghan E.

description:
I had been here many years before and totally forgot about it. I do remember I really liked the food the first time. This time around, it was just ok. I shared the Appetizer plate, which had a lot of meat on it, but not enough cheese or bread to pair. It's huge, this is good to share with up to 4 people. To drink, I ordered a Belgian triple. This was good. I remember they used to have little boots, that you can order for your drinks, but I guess they got rid of it and only have the giant 2 liter boots now. 

For my main course, I got the weinerschnitzel platter. I didn't really like the pork, not that flavorful. felt like it was lacking a sauce or something. However, the potatoes mixed with sauerkraut, and chopped up sausages was really good. The greens it came with was good as well. I do wish they had some high quality mustard here, like other german places I've been to. 

Overall, I see this as a good place for beer, rather than food. This place is busy, so get here early or later. The tables are also communal and picnic style.  They only take reservations for groups of 6+.
author: Lisa T.

description:
I have been to Suppenkuche many times, and though some days are misses, overall they're very consistent.  They have an excellent beer selection and great hearty meals.  Potato pancake is a must, and try to get a meal with some spaetzle.

Lines and waits can be long, and I tend to HATTTTTTTTEEEEEE waiting for food.  It's also pretty crowded inside, which I also hate.  But for Suppenkuche, I'll occastionally make an exception.
author: Andy V.

description:
My boyfriend wanted to try German Food so we drove from San Jose to try this highly rated establishment. BEWARE parking is hard and there are no big parking garages or lots like in other part of the city. After we found parking we had to wait about another half hour for our table which wasn't bad for a saturday night. We had the pretzel, the brat plate, and the meat loaf. All the meals were very good. Make sure you get a beer while you are there! It was hard to read the beer menu because there wasn't a translation on what they were. Make sure you ask your waiter for a recommendation. You won't be disappointed. 
The restaurant had communal tables, so you might end up sitting with some other couples. It could be a little awkward but just remember you will be enjoying some yummy food and beer so that won't matter!
author: Irina L.

description:
I had dinner here last fall with one of my friends who had lived in Germany for over a year. She said the Suppenkuche was incredibly authentic and reminded her so much of her time in Germany. Eating here definitely made me want to go to Germany soon.

The restaurant itself was small and pretty simple in decor. They have communal tables so we were seated with another party. It was really crowded and I had to yell for my friend to hear me even though she was only a couple of feet away. I was in a social mood that night so it was fine, but if you want a more relaxing environment to dine in, you should look elsewhere.

Our service was really good, especially considering how busy the restaurant was. Our server also gave me a great beer recommendation.

For my meal, I had the wiener schnitzel with roasted potatoes and a green salad. The pork was cooked nicely and the potatoes complemented it well. However, I felt like the green salad didn't really contribute much and seemed like more of an afterthought. 

Overall, this was a really good meal, and I would definitely come back again.
author: Ravi S.

description: Great authentic German restaurant. Go for the atmosphere, beer, and portions. There's usually a line so show up early.
author: Bill H.

description:
Another impromptu dinner with the sis and the S.O.

We came in and thankfully, we got a little help with getting a table since we had connections... If not, we would have been freezing our butts off outside and or getting bumped inside because it was crazy packed!

Everything was a blur... it was loud... and since the S.O had been there before, he took charged and ordered the following:

- Potato Soup = that's a meal on its own! It was hearty and filling... Perfect for a cold night!

- Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce = dessert cam first! My oh my... these are good and huge! We all had a piece and after the soup and then this... I was getting full. The S.O. was loving this... 

- Appetizer Plate with Ham, Blood Sausage, Salami & Cheese = S.O. and sis picked on this... while I watched. Wasn't appetizing to me... but they enjoyed it although both of them were getting full so they ended up taking it home. 

- Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spätzle & Green Salad = S.O.'s meal. He inhaled it. He was raving about this the whole night and he kept repeating like a broken record... that it's his favorite and he ALWAYS gets it every time... sis and I was just in awe...

- Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce with Red Cabbage & Spätzle = Sis's meal... wasn't sure if she liked it but she ended up taking the whole thing home... by the time our food came, the soup and the potato pancakes settled in our tummies.

- Marinated and Braised Beef with Lingonberries served with Red Cabbage & Spätzle = My meal... and it was gigantic. I was very much overwhelmed. The beef... it was ok. It wasn't as tasty as I imagined it to be or as tender... the Spätzle... that was interesting as well. First time ever having it... so I can't really base it of anything since I don't know what it should really taste like... 

The group's beer of choice: Bitburger

Overall... HUGE portions... loud... yes, patience is the key and bring your empty stomach in! Very filling and not for the healthy folks... well you can splurge and let it all loose once in a while!

I have a feeling I'll get dragged back here by the S.O. ... so until then...
author: Cath M.

description: Delicious Spatzle. Noisy. Cute bartender. German style seating. I was so happy to get Spatzle. The wild boar sausage was great with the Spatzle and sauerkraut. I want to try the maultauschen next time.
author: Peter K.

description: I came here a couple of weeks ago for a friends dinner party. It had been a long day, so first thing's first...das boot. While I'm not much a beer drinker the beer was so good and I managed to finish a 2L boot (with the help of some friends). For dinner I had the German ravioli, not amazing but pretty good. I don't think German food is really my bag but the beer and service were great. 4 stars!
author: Allison D.

description:
This is a place for BROS to hang out at because of the beer selection and all the dishes were very meat heavy

I love the butter they give for the free bread, very light kind of rosemary (?) flavor

The ham was quite salty so I would definitely not get that again. The Wiener Schnitzel  was definitely a winner, but to me anything fried tastes good and doesn't have to be specially prepared. The salad that came with it was just a few pieces of cabbage so..I'm sure not a lot of people order the salad.

I tried some of my friend's venison, but I can't say much about it since I was never a fan of venison...it tastes like venison...?

The potato pancakes were definitely delicious and filling.
author: Dorris W.

description:
I came to this place for the first time for a friend's birthday party. I love German food but am sometimes nervous that I will call it quits halfway through my meal since there is often a lot of meat. This place was different... yes, a lot of the dishes on the menu are meat dishes but they don't comprise of most of the dish. I decided to keep it classic with bratwurst with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes and it was delicious. In fact, in the end, I was craving for more of the sausage, which doesn't usually happen to me. Their beer selection was excellent. I had one of their specials, which was a dark beer with strong notes of chocolate. It was excellent with my dish. I also got to pick around at my friend's dishes, which were also delicious. My friend got the "boot" beer, (more than a gallon of beer in a boot-shaped glass, which was a sight to see. We had to help her finish it, since it was a lot of beer.

Some extra comments:

- luckily, we had a reservation so the wait time was minimal, which was fortunate because it seems like you have to wait a while for a table... there were a lot of people waiting outside
- the food came out pretty fast... since we were a big party, we thought we would be waiting for twenty minutes or so... food came out in about ten
- the service is on par... our waitress was very friendly and patient
- this place is very lively... I would not come here for a date night
author: Kunal N.

description: I came here for the first time a few nights ago. It was busy, but we were able to get a drink at the bar and those potato cakes with applesauce. I got the jagerschnitzle and my friends split the wiener schnitzel. I love pork chops but find that they are usually dry when I order them at a restaurant. Both dishes were juicy and delicious. All of the servers and bartenders are very welcoming. I plan on going back soon.
author: Karissa Q.

description:
die beste Deutsch Lebensmittel ein San Francisco. I've eaten here on many different occasions (low key drunk German brunch FTW) for the simple reason that this place is the best
half chicken w/ dumpling is my favorite entree
pretzels and potato pancakes are great
cool little 8 person bar/stool area
service has been mixed but generally very good
author: Daniel C.

description:
Some friends visiting from out of town chose this place to meet for drinks and have dinner.

We didn't have reservations (none available by the time our friends checked), and our friends had their hearts set on this spot, so we waited.
 It was over 2 hours to get a table for 9, and  the table wasn't quite big enough, and I felt cramped for the entire meal. (Poor planning, but i wasn't the one who did it.)

The bar area isn't a great spot for hanging out. It's right in the flow of traffic, and I felt like we were in everyone's way, (servers included.)

I don't really drink beer, but i did have some good wine, and it was a large pour:)

When we did finally get to eat, I was less than impressed. I had the "Sauteed Trout in Lemon Butter Sauce with Bouillon Potatoes & Spinach". I got the sauce on the side, and had a hard time picking all the bones out in the darkness of the restaurant. It was OK, nothing special. My husband had:  "Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und Grünem Salat". He was very disappointed, as he had been looking forward to this, (since it's something he never gets.) It was too dry and too salty.

Everyone else seemed to like theirs, (granted, they were all a bit drunk.)

There were also a few dishes shared: currywurst, which was good, but not great, and what was basically a meatball, tasty but not worth a return trip for. Although, their version of a potato potato latke, (it's called something else, but that's what it is) was crispy and totally delicious. Loved it. 

I might come back if someone wanted to, but there are other places that serve similar food I'd prefer to try first.
author: Amanda G.

description:
We visited on a Wednesday night around 6pm and was seated without a wait. Though the hostess did spend a fraction of a minute standing and just looking at me and looking at the space around her before leading me to a seat. Which was... odd.

Ordered the lobster soup, roasted half chicken stuffed with dumplings with potato pancakes, and the veal and pork sausages with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes.

So, the complementary rye bread was dense, sour, moist and chewy. The crust carried with it a slight ash taste that I quite enjoyed, though the bread itself was bland, merely a vessel for the delicious green onion butter on the side.

The soup was more chowder than soup. It was very creamy and lobster-y. I could taste all the flavors of the crushed shells in the soup although it was on the slightly salty side.

The roasted chicken had the most wonderful crispy skin that contrasted so well with the moist and tender meat. I only had a piece of the dark meat that was very juicy, but apparently the white meats were rather dry. The potato pancakes were ridiculously crispy on the outside with the awesome texture of hashbrowns on the inside. Oh man, how I love hashbrowns. The only down side is that with the crispiness came a slight burnt and bitter taste. Trade-offs ya'know.

The sausages were delicious. Once I cut into them, juice just poured out of it like as if it were a soup dumpling or something. The meat inside was still very juicy and true to the original flavors of the meat. There weren't a ton of fancy spices added to these sausages, and that was refreshing to experience. The mashed potatoes were solid. Overall, this dish was very heavy. I didn't have my full appetite and felt slightly overwhelmed after 1/4 of the dish.

The strudel. Man, ever since I watched Inglorious Basterds five goddamn years ago I've been craving a damn strudel with a huge dollop of whipped cream on top. Do I seriously have to fly back in time to Nazi Germany in order to get me one of those???

They had an apple strudel special here tonight and I was thoroughly disappointed. Not only were there raisins, ew, in my apple strudel, there was zero laminated dough. It only had this one thin crust on top of some streusel, the rest was a mush of soggy apples. Sigh.


The place is seated communally, so be prepared to be sharing seats with random strangers. Make some friends, but be ware that this place is insanely loud.
author: Chia L.

description:
YUMMY.  what a cute place to wind down after a long day at work/school.  

first of all, i have to say that RUSTY, the bartender, is the greatest.  kudos to him and his awesome service!

so bff and i decided to head in around 9pm on a monday...to our surprise, the place wasn't super packed like it normally is.  woohoo!  we got a table right away...and we were ready to get our grub on.  

we started off with the Kartoffelsuppe (potato soup).  potato soup...yes, as bland and not so appetizing as it may sound...it was freakin delish.  get a round of bowls of this stuff...you won't be disappointed.  

our next dish?  Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und Grünem Salat...translation?  Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad.  a little disappointed with this dish as it was a bit on the dry side...but still good enough to put in your belly.  my least favorite dish of the night.

and finally...Falscher Hase mit Zwiebelsoße und Kartoffelbrei...Meatloaf with Bacon and Egg served with Onion Sauce & Mashed Potatoes.  Probably the best meatloaf dish i've ever had at a restaurant.  super delish...moist, and spiced perfectly.  

for dessert, we shared an apple streudel with ice cream a la mode.  YUM.  the top of the streudel was crisp...the filling was the perfect sweetness...and the bottom was money.  it was like layered with bread pudding or something...it was just...AMAZINGNESS.  

unfortunately, i'm not a drinker.  but bff is!  she had some sort of beer that sounds like masturbator or something...i can't remember the name.  but she's ravin about it.  haha.  they have boots of beer if you're ready for the challenge.  i'll just stick to my boring glass of water on the rocks.  

suppenkuche is serious...seriously good.  if you live in the city and you haven't tried this place out...you don't belong here!!!
author: Jen W.

description: the best potato pancakes and chicken in the US! This is a party place fun for holidays and Sundays. lots of people crammed in there. Casual.
author: Minnie G.

description: This place. Friends took us here to nosh. The food is authentic and you're never disappointed. Were here with four people and every meal was amazing. Line to get in before they even opened. Great beer selection. Beer was awesome. That is all.
author: Rachael D.

description:
Wifey and I were in the City and had heard about this great place for good German beers and food - Suppenkuche.   After finding a place to park, we walked in to find a very crowded bar about two deep all the way around plus all the tables packed to capacity.   And this was at 6 on a Saturday.   We took this to be a very good sign.   

After a moment or two, we were able to get a spot at the bar.   We both ordered some helles.   The bartender was super friendly and got us our beers very quickly.   I have to say, everyone working there hustled their backsides off.   Even though the place was super crowded, they kept things moving.   Great job folks!

We did a little people watching in the restaurant.   The food people looked really good.   I just wish we didn't have to leave, because I was ready to order another beer.  But it went down so smoothly, I knew two would lead to three... and then I'm not driving anywhere for a while.   

Next time, we are going to get there earlier and prepare to spend a couple hours there.   I think we need that much time to fully enjoy the place.  

Will I be back?  Heck yeah.   Great job folks!
author: Bill C.

description: Came here right before the dinner rush so we were seated immediately. Get the potato pancakes!! It's a bit like hash browns, but crispier. It comes in 3 with a side of apple sauce. I was really surprised at how well the sauce paired with the potatoes. I got the meatloaf (it was wrapped with bacon) with mashed potatoes and onion sauce. There was half an egg inside the middle of the meatloaf as well. I wasn't a fan of the egg, but everything else tasted so good! The meatloaf was so soft. My boyfriend and friend loved their dishes as well. They  have a large variety of beers and sizes. They even have 2 liter boots! And a 5 liter mug! Def recommend!
author: Jessica L.

description:
First time I came, they weren't able to accomodate our party of like 12.  Came back again with a party of 2 and reservations.  

The place is small and all the tables are a little squished together.  It's hard to maneuver around.   Anyway...

When you come, you order the boot.  DAS BOOOOOT.  Yes, I did it and yes I finished it.  Probably one of the worst ideas ever before a trip to Tahoe.  But still ... we came, we drank, and we survived!  It's fun to try once, but I don't think I'd do the boot again.  

The food was good, but nothing spectacular and not that I can remember what we had after drinking the boot.  

I don't know if I'd come back here to eat because parking sucks and there's other food places in the area, but it's definitely one for the books and something to knock off the bucket list!
author: Jae W.

description:
Avoid weekend craziness. 
Food was good. 
Potato pancake was awesome. 
Service was okay. 
Host was so friendly. 
But crowds were not so fun at all.
People were waiting with beers and standing right behind you. 
Loud and noisy, we can hardly talk and hear each others. Ruthless waiting crowds were really disturbing us by talking loud and standing close to sitting down customers. 
It's more like a bar then a restaurant to me. 
Want to have a taste the food And enjoy your meal? Avoid weekend. 
I would come back for sure food is good :) 
They just need to fine a way to handle those waiting crowds. Disturbing people who actually have a table is not cool to me.
author: JustinE Y.

description:
I don't know what real German food is but this was so amazingly scrumptious. I've had German one other time and this definitely surpassed that place. 

We ordered the lentil soup, venison, and the pork special (can't tell you the proper German name for them). The lentil soup was hot just like a soup should be and really good. The venison wasn't gamey and was very tender. It came with cabbage and schnitzel .... Great combo. The pork was tender and came with a stuffing-like potato ball. And you can't go wrong with the beers. We will definitely be going back. There's a long wait (which is worth it) or if you're by yourself or with one other person you can find seating on the small bar area faster.
author: Yen H.

description: Delicious hearty authentic German food! Loud but the atmosphere was very lively and the service was surprisingly fast.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Pro's:
delicious food, boot beer, **weinerschnitzle"!

Con's: ridiculous wait, pricey, indifferent staff, over crowded tables, noisy
author: Risque B.

description:
Definitely on the pricier side for some bratwurst and/or breaded pork chops and beer. 

Pros:
Beer is great, but still expensive.

Cons:
Expensive bratwurst.
author: James A.

description:
I love their brunch, I love their beer.
It's small and cozy and fun. Come here to feel relevant & cool.
author: Hailie S.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE! BEER & German food! What else do you need! This place never disappoints.
author: Kyle W.

description:
Cool experience.  
Beer in a boot! Awesome.  The food is great, it's not cheap but it's a must try.  The dough pasta is good and the postage pancakes as well as the pretzels and more.
Give it a go!
author: Christina C.

description:
Simply put, disgusting and highly disappointing. As one time residents of SF, now living in lower CA, we have always fancied ourselves as Suppenkuche devotees, which is the why we have loyally been coming back time and again since their initial opening some 20 plus years ago, back when the Hayes Valley was a no man's land, safe only for prostitutes and drug dealers.

The key to Suppenkuche's success was simple: unpretentious, affordable and delicious authentic German comfort food lovingly prepared fresh and tasty, night after night, predictably good whether you ate there five times a year, or once every five years. No more, that consistency is gone, and so has the affordability.

I had noticed that the quality at Suppenkuche had been slipping for a while, but it has hit an all-time new low, in my opinion. It is abundantly clear that the absentee owner and original founder of this one-time gem of a restaurant has just completely given up the ghost, has lost all interest in the customer experience and is just phoning it in. It's said success breeds complacency, and in the case of Suppenkuche, when it comes to the kitchen, I wholeheartedly agree. 

The Nitty Gritty. 
The kitchen is staffed with dubiously skilled cooks that excel at cranking out volume with little attention to detail or quality. When the restaurant first opened, the kitchen was populated with newish culinary school type grads under the direct supervision of the owner himself, nowhere in sight today. When I saw the "pantry chef" tossing my mixed salad with his bare hands, I was not sure if I should cancel my order or call the health dept. The service was totally de-personalized and in no time since I was old enough to eat in restaurants has so few words been exchanged with my waiter. He was polite enough but showed no interest in our dining experience.

The warmed over Wienerschitzel tasted as if if had been cooked hours before and reheated at the time of serving. 

The mixed salad was a tasteless mound of mush and totally disgusting. In retrospect we should have sent it back to register our dissatisfaction but did not really want to make a scene. This was really sad because this dish, like the schnitzel, had previously been signature dishes.

Sadly I have to say with heavy heart, that after 20 years of dining at Suppenkuche, I am finished. With so many other well run eating establishments in the city that are passionately pouring heart and soul into what they are doing, why waste precious restaurant dollars on this dressed up dog food.
author: Jeff Y.

description:
2 liter boot. Spaten Optimator. 43 minutes. 
Followed by savage kareoke and attempts to flag down taxi cabs with my well-crafted calves. 

There is decent seating if you get here early enough, and the food is warm and comforting...and more importantly, filling. Carb up, friends. 

My future children will be so proud of me.
author: Jonathan Y.

description: I love this place, the food is gorgeous and the beer is amazing. Highly recommend it to everybody who likes good food. The only tip is to come early, cause the place fills up pretty quickly, and I get why!
author: Julia G.

description:
Came here for Le Boot. Took 2 men and 1 women (moi) to finish. Fun for TOURISTS to stop by for beer in Le Boot experience. 
It was all great vibes and got a biergarten experience.
author: Gi Yung B.

description:
Go there early or you will not be able to get a table. 

This is a very NOISY neighbourhood restaurant, if you ever watched the movie 'Beerfest' and wondered where they find the glass boots, Suppenkuche have them all. If you want to try drinking from the Glass Boot, this is the place to be.

We decided to order take out and the meal was fantastic and filling. The restaurant is very noisy and expect to share tables family style with others. Not a place to bring a new date as you won't be able to hear each other.
author: Sarah W.

description: Excellent service and great food.  Close communal seating so if this is not your thing, you may not like that. I had the Schnitzel which was outstanding , the red cabbage was pretty good. Nice beer selection, and our server was on top of everything.  Would go back to this place in a heartbeat.
author: Chris G.

description:
This is really a 3.5 Star review.  

Maybe its because German food doesn't wow me.  I mean I love the sausages, the meats, and the beer.  But i guess its not my favorite type of meal for dinner.

There were a couple of really good stand outs.  First the sauteed Venison Medallions In Red Wine Plum Sauce.  It was cooked perfectly and was not gamy but full of flavor.  The red cabbage and spatzle around it was okay.  The best plate of the night was the meat loaf!  A must try.  Full of flavor and wrapped with bacon and topped with a hard boiled egg.  So delicious.  The potatoes and gravy compliment it perfectly.  

The other stuff didn't stand out too much for me.  The pork chop was good, but not great.  Tasted like Ham too.  The jager schnitzle was okay as well, good flavor, but not my thing.  That's two pork dishes I wasn't a big fan of!  Unbelievable.

As for the settings...very tight and crowded but it feels like you are in a german house.  We had a big group and sat at the big table, but the way to tables were pushed in towards the benches, made for a tight fit.

And to top it off, I originally wanted the Suckling Pork, but they were out.  They were also out of Das Boot, what the...
author: Veasna H.

description: Huge portion for brunches. I really liked the roasted potatoes and enjoyed the German salad. But the place is rather crowded and we had to share the table with others.
author: Victoria M.

description: Good German food. Possibly the best venue in the city for large groups, as you can reserve the one of the large tables in the back (but do so early).
author: Jordan J.

description: No real wait when I went and the service was fast and friendly I went during lunch. I had the ravioli with the cucumber salad which was very refreshing. I could have had more food but then again I was meeting an old roomie afterwards so I didn't want to over eat. This was a great mix and if I had gotten some schnitzel it would have bee the perfect combo. Though they were busy...they let us sit and talk for a long time.
author: Lily P.

description: Great place for food and beer. Glad to try this place out. Really hard to find German cuisine that is done well. It gets really crowded and the wait for a table can take a while. The tables are communal, meaning you can be seated with a different party - reminds me of Taiwan and ensures there are no empty seats. It gets really loud here so it can be hard to hear the person next to you. The food is solid. The bread comes with a yummy herb butter, the potato pancakes were divine - crispy on outside and soft inside. The apple sauce gave a good contrast of sweet and salty. The sautéed trout was fresh and delicious. The beef hands down was the winner - it was soft and tender. We also liked the spätzle. Next time we want to try the pretzels! The place was really busy and service was sporadic because of it. I also think they were close to running out of plates because they kept trying to take our plates even though we were still using them!
author: Bebe W.

description: Had pretzel (ok), jäger schnitzel, maultasche and a beer. Next time would have two of the maultasche and the cheese spätzle.
author: Peter and Julie H.

description:
Maybe I'm partial to German food, but this had to be my favorite restaurant I've been to in San Francisco. It's loud, it's crowded, and it's kind of expensive, but completely worth it.

I went for the latkes, but I will never forget the onion and cheese spaetzle. I dream about it. It's better than any of the kaese spaetzle I had in Germany. It's easily one of the best things I've ever eaten.
author: Andie B.

description:
I can't say I've tried much German food in my life.  In fact, the extent of my German cuisine extends pretty much to only bratwurst and sauerkraut.  Wienerschnitzel to me is still a hotdog joint and jägerschnitzel.. well, is that made of jäger?  

Nested in the cozy neighborhood of Hayes Valley, Suppenkuche is definitely no stranger to large crowds and drunk patrons.  Not surprising since this is one of the few places that actually serve THE  BOOT.  Not only do they have the boot, they also serve beer in 5 liter jug!  (Please do not attempt to drink this all by yourself!  Although I have seen people try...... It is meant to be shared and passed around the table without it actually touching the table.. or so I've been told)  Needless to say, they also have an awesome variety of German beer on tap - great for beer afficianados.

There were so many delicious choices on the menu, but I wanted to try a German favorite.  I was torn between the wienerschnitzel and jägerschnitzel.  In the end, I opted for the jägerschnitzel because I love mushroom sauce on everything and anything.  FYI, the jägerschnitzel is a sauteed porkloin in mushroom sauce... kind of heavy but oh so delicious!  

The atmosphere is welcoming; the service is attentive but not overbearing; our food came out quickly; and the beer was just never ending.  Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed my first German cuisine experience.  It's definitely not something I would indulge in very often due to my extremely food coma afterward.  But I would most certainly recommend it to anyone who has not been here before.  I'll add it to my San Franciscan great eats list :)
author: Cecilia S.

description: I would have given 5 stars if it was easier to eat here. When I arrived it was crowded and it took a while for for somebody to let me know that food is ordered at the bar which was packed. Having people fight through those who are not ordering to get dinner doesn't sit well with me. That being said, the food is delicious, the beer I ordered (their dopple bock) was amazing and the staff is great. I'll try and arrive earlier next time.
author: Dylan T.

description:
I haven't had enough german food to clearly review their dishes but their selection of beers and main courses is pretty much off the charts. 

Beers: great selection of different european based beers, ranging from belgiums to pilsners of all sorts and most (or all) aren't the typical beers you'd find in a Safeway to Bevmo (maybe at a boutique liquor shop). I got the triple belgium IPA that was pretty damn good and best of all, it's on tap! 

A summary of my food review in a sentence: filling, tasty, and decent value. Majority of the dishes are priced around $18-$25 but will most likely get most dudes full and definitely most girls full (assuming you have a small appetite). 

Reservations are only available for parties larger than 6 otherwise its a first-come first-serve. Waiters were all jolly and nice but can be a little slow when it gets busy.
author: Victor C.

description:
Loved it here! Truly German.
Good food and good service! 
Definitely going back when I'm in the area again!
author: Miranda M.

description:
DELICIOUS homey comfort food! How on Earth have I not been here for all these years?! I came here on NYE with a few friends for dinner and was Suppenkuche good or what?!

What we ordered:
Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus - Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce
Linsensuppe w/ mit Bauern-Bratwurst - Lentil Soup w/ Farmers Bratwurst
Falscher Hase mit Zwiebelsoße und Kartoffelbrei - Meatloaf with Bacon and Egg served with Onion Sauce & Mashed Potatoes

The potato pancakes were crispy on the outside but soft on the inside, which made it very tasteful. It's pretty much a German style hashbrown in my opinion. The homemade apple sauce accompanies the potato pancake very well! This is a must for appetizers!

My significant other and myself had the lentil soup with bratwurst and the meatloaf with bacon and egg with mashed potatoes. The soup was healthy with the bratwurst. To me, the bratwurst tasted more like a German hot dog, rather than a bratwurst, but it was very delicious! My significant other actually was quite full from the soup.

I ate most of the meatloaf because it was that darn good! The meatloaf surrounds an egg wrapped in bacon on the inside which gave it a very delightful taste. I cannot explain how good the meatloaf was, but I highly recommend it. I thought it wouldn't fill me up, but it did!

I would most  definitely return in the future because the food is good and on point. In addition, the crowd is lively, so that may be good for those who want to enjoy comfort food with German beer, and also annoy those who want to dine at a quiet restaurant.
author: Edgar G.

description:
I know my Bavarian food and I'm always looking for authentic tasting Essen. The food was great as was the beer. 
The communal dining reminds my of the Oktoberfest in Munchen. They have bread dumplings but I would like to see potato dumplings on the menu.

Go for it, it will be sure to please! Prost !
author: Stephen N.

description: We lived in Bavaria for 2 years and found this place to be very authentic.  Great German food and healthy size portions as well as a good selection of biers. Definitely try the celery root and leek soup for starters; it's sehr gut! Our group had the wiener schnitzel and and jäger schnitzel and were pleased. If you dare order the 2 liter size boot of bier!
author: Christine D.

description:
This place really upset me! Now that I have had a taste for this amazing German style food and beer I can't get enough and we don't have anything similar back home. 

Cant recommend this place enough.
author: Aaron D.

description: I REALLY liked the food here! And the beer! The problem here is getting a seat, so come early. The staff is great but only once you get they're attention, the night I came in it was packed so you needed to hunt em down for stuff.
author: Raquel R.

description: Love this place. A really fun spot for groups, as it has large tables (sometimes communal seating if you go in a small group), good beer, and hearty, delicious fare. Everything I've tried here has been delightful. Start with some pretzels to share!
author: Jane V.

description:
Decent beer list, friendly staff, Bohemian decor, but the food could be much better.

We showed up on a busy Saturday night and were told there would be a 45 minute wait. We put our names down, waited at the bar, and were seated within 15 minutes. So far, so good. We ordered the potato soup, which was tasty but over-seasoned (too much salt, and this coming from someone who loves flavorful/salted foods!). Then came the potato pancakes with apple sauce, which were okay. They seemed a little bland. Then the German Ravioli filled with pork and vegetables served with mushroom sauce showed up. This is a dish that I really wanted to like. I love ravioli and dumplings of any kind. This dish had so much promise, but like the potato soup, it arrived over-seasoned (too much salt!). If it hadn't been so over-seasoned, the German Ravioli would've been the star of the show. One thing that we did like were the warm pretzels, which were paired with what appeared to be a cream cheese/curry sauce. The pretzels were fantastic - chewy and salty, and everything you would expect. The cream cheese-based sauced could use some work, but offered an interesting perspective on the pretzels, at least. The last thing we ordered was another pork dish that was one of their nightly specials, and it came with a German dumpling and sauerkraut. They paired it with a sweet, salty sauce that was wayyyyy over-salted (again, this is coming from someone who loves well-seasoned food and LOVES salt!).

Overall, this was a restaurant that me and my date really wanted to love, and their dishes really have some promise if the kinks were worked out of them, however, the food clearly wasn't the focus at this restaurant, and we don't think we'll be coming back.
author: Cameron N.

description:
What a treat! Walking from a night at the Ballet in heels to Suppenkuche was well worth it.  With so many German friends, I can't believe I've never heard of this place.  In fact, it was my Yugoslavian friend and his girlfriend who brought us here.  

By the time we got there 9:45 pm on a Sunday, they were still serving dinner.  We were lucky to catch the last of the dinner service.  There were so many good choices on the menu.  We got into a conversation about Duck and thought Goose probably taste very similar.  Because we love to be food adventurous, we went for the Goose entree.  

Wow! Prepared perfectly. I think my husband just became a fan and forgot all about the Duck.  The dish came with what taste like sour-cabbage and a mash potato dumpling.  Not sure if I particularly liked the potato dumpling, but overall the dinner was great.  

To wrap it up, everything from the comfort food to the conversations and decor; it made or two hour stay here comfortable and warming!
author: Moua L.

description: I'm a vegetarian, so let's start there - not a great vegetarian selection and who would expect so, at a german restaurant. I had the potato pancakes which were very good, but very fried. my friend had sausages which came with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. we both agreed that the sides were fantastic, but he said the sausages were not standout. they do a good job of getting people efficiently into the tiny place, but it is LOUD. actually, too loud. too loud to talk, by the time we left, too loud to think (I forgot my leftovers, which I NEVER do).
author: Laura H.

description:
Go.
Look at the menu.
Walk inside & look at what others are eating.
Place your order by pointing, discretely, at what looks and smells good.

Ironically, this is awesome for non drinkers.  There are colorful, flavored waters that resemble absinthe and are delicious.

If you drink beer then this is your Valhalla.
author: Joanna B.

description:
Unpleasant, awkward attitude. We first stepped in while one of the buddies was looking for parking and they won't let us sit until all party arrives. Ok, fair enough. So we went to wait at the bar for few min and thought starting with drinks till we get seated. The barman was an anti-social rude snut (or maybe just had bad day or new out of town and stressed out with serving people making eye contact). From some weird reason they do not allow to take the drinks to the table and pay the whole round as part of the dinner, so you must pay before "leaving the bar" to the table 3 feet away. I asked what is the reason for this hassle, he responded in his unique irritated demeanor "we are just this kind of place!". Yes indeed you are. 
Then when finally seated - they have that so-called "communal sitting", just that the tables are not actual long benches for that kind of configuration. These are simply 4-person tables they randomly squeeze 7 around with strangers, making it super awkward experience.  And they don't even bother trying to leverage some space to give some sort of separation between parties. If you do communal seating - do it right. Not with cheap family-style tables. Luckily there was just a nice adult couple sharing our table so it was kind of Ok, but still, weird.
Took ages for anyone to take the order, and yet same feel of impatience from any staff walking around. Like they just wish you take the simplest gig on the menu and get out already as soon as possible. Not sure why people who hate serving people are getting into restaurant business to start with. Service comes first, food comes second.
As for the food - meh. I am hard to be disappointed with German style kitchen,  but this one was just bland and not authentic. The best thing was the mustard.  Everything else felt like microwaved dish from the local supermarket. Will not go back.
author: M B.

description:
I'm gonna give it to you straight: if you don't like people, or noise, or noisy people, steer clear of this place (and most of the City, but definitely here), because the volume level on a Tuesday night is 15... out of 10.

Ziggy Zaggy Oi cheers from across the room, the table with the 60-somethings (chugging brews faster than us--how embarrassing), and the gaggle of girls beside us with the piercing laughs (seriously, loud, like gunshots), it's a maddening circus of suds, flying pieces of sauerkraut, a "here, try this wiener" (wait, what?!) and you, squeezed between your (hopefully) least smelly (or most-recently showered) pal.

The waitstaff is comprised of magical humans (though I doubt their species). They got all of our orders over the madness of it all. We had a group of nine, and we all got our brews and eats around the same time and without missing a beat. No major screw-ups, no "I'm sorry, I didn't hear you" (the girl taking our orders has magical hearing), nothing of the sort.

As for the food and drink, not surprisingly, it's pretty great. Of course, I'd been famished and probably could've sustained my hunger on rocks and pebbles, but the wiener schnitzel was great (one piece was plenty, though you get two breaded slabs of pork loin) and went really well the Paulaner Oktoberfest.

The beer menu, like the restaurant, is maddening. Don't bother picking, just ask for recommendations, and then strain as hard as you can to hear the response past the "whooos" and the "Ziggy Zaggys" because I couldn't hear anything else.

Good luck in there, chap.
author: Adena B.

description: This was my first time here. Up to now I've been disappointed by almost all German restaurants across this nation. This place managed to not quite do that. The sour rye wheat bread (from Firestone bakery in Emeryville) was almost exactly as I remember it growing up as a kid in Germany. My dinner was meatballs with mashed potatoes and creamed veggies. The mashed potatoes were runny like instant potatoes but tasted like real ones. The veggies were just right and not over cooked and tasted great. The meatballs were not what I expected but then again every region in Germany prepares the same dish just a little bit differently. Personally I didn't care for these meatballs.
author: David S.

description: Came here with a friend when the power had gone out in the city.  They were open and a bit busy.  German food much like mom and the aunties used to make.  The delicious food made me feel like I was back home with family, friends and cousins.  Wunnerful, wunnerful, wunnerful!
author: Mikala T.

description:
Great place.  Can't believe it took me so long to get here.

I am the first to admit that I know nothing about German Beers.  Went with the bartender's suggestion.  Was good.  Name was something German (duh).

The potato pancakes are the best.  

The bread they served us was some kind of pumpernickle, which is my favorite.  It was great, but it was hard to NOT eat it and save room for the entree.

We split the meatball entree.  It was pretty tasty although, I felt the meatballs were a touch on the dry side.

Service was great.

Recommended....especially for potato pancakes.
author: Christian C.

description:
Wow, I really enjoyed the food here!  We shared potato pancakes to start (don't even want to think how much oil went into making those cakes so crispy and yummy), and then I ordered one of the specials - roasted and dumpling-stuffed half chicken with (more) potato pancakes.
