The chicken was so moist and tender, and was so large that I never even saw the stuffing underneath until I packed it up.  And I've already mentioned how I liked the potato pancakes!  The side salad was good too.  All in all, it was a huge portion, and was plenty for lunch the next day as well!  Everyone liked their entrees - including the meatballs, the sausages, pork loin, etc.  We were a bit cramped sitting at a long wooden table with nearly 10 people though. 

We'd been warned ahead of time they wouldn't seat us until everyone was there, but luckily (maybe because it was Sunday night) they were a bit lenient.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Can I give more than 5 stars? If I could, Suppenkuche would qualify for more. This is simply one of the best restaurants in SF and my fav in the trendy Hayes Valley area. I'm a little bit surprised I haven't written a review here already. Been here a couple of times and loved it every time. 

That said, I finally discovered my absolute go-to dish. It's the breaded pork loin. Moist and thinly cut with a perfectly fried breading along with a surprisingly fantastic side of roasted potatoes. A couple of other strangers at the table ordered the same thing and also admitted that was their favorite dish here. 

Still, the grilled pork chop, chicken, sausages are all fantastic. The "salad" that included some great pickled beets is a good started (and seems healthy). And the potato pancakes are simply a must. Oh... and the streudel is heavenly, if you have space for it. Share it. Even one or two bites will take you to Heaven. 

As for beer... it's a German restaurant. They're going to have great beer. I go for a Radler and the BananaWeizen. Not traditional beer, true, but where else can I find these? Get whatever you want, but the Banana Beer is a treat. Even my girl friends enjoy drinking it despite not being beer drinkers. 

The restaurant is loud. I mean, you gotta be yelling. If you want a candlelit romantic dinner, go elsewhere. If you want a great, great meal in a fun and vibrant semi-communal environment, this is your place. You will feel alive and have fun in this awesome little gem. Enjoy.

And, you're welcome.
author: Phil N.

description: This place gets loud and crowded like a bar and justly so.  They have Hofbrau here! It's one of the best beer I've ever had.  They have a fair selection of beer.  The food is only okay here.  The goose is good.  What makes me like this place other than the beer is the vibe.  It's vibrant.  A lot of wood.  Wood table.  Wood chair.  Wood bar.  Wood wood wood.  Not cheap wood, but good sturdy rustic wood that brings you back to country life.
author: Byron L.

description:
I could eat a trough of their cheese spätzle (Käsespätzle) for a long time. It's like the best mac n' cheese you've ever had, but with the perfect smooth texture of irregular noodles. So rich that it's probably good I split the order. It comes with a side salad of pickled things to trick yourself into thinking you're not just guzzling butter and heavy cream.

We also split the salmon dish. Nicely cooked fish, with a hefty side of mashed potatoes and some food karma greenery. The trout is also a good dish to order, with a ridiculously tasty gravy for the potatoes and spinach.

Somehow we showed up at a magic timeslot during the dinner crush where there was no wait. Ridiculous. Our second visit, we showed up ten minutes before they opened, got into the little queue, and again, no real wait.

Love the little paper cutouts on the ceiling!
author: Kevin L.

description: Extremely Loud. You cannot carry on a conversation. Food mediocre. Service was good. Not going back.
author: Steve G.

description: Amazing food!! Seriously worth it, and worth splurging at. The spätzle (with cheese on the main dish menu) is amazing! The service and experience is always way above par. It's become the best little restaurant I've ever visited! (Also try the Pretzel, and potato pancake, and sauerkraut!)
author: Emily D.

description:
After waiting 2 and half hours, we were seated and promptly ordered. The potato pancakes arrived cold.  The meatloaf was the best entrée we tried. The jäger schenzel ended up being sub par macaroni and cheese. The weiner schenzel was generously portioned but bland. Also no boots or mash potatoes were available (although roasted potatoes were) . 

Maybe our expectations were too high. It was an overall disappointing dining experience.

Beer was great though! Also, the bus boy was super attentive. Too noisy to really converse.
author: Chrissy B.

description:
My friends and I came for my birthday this past weekend and we had such a great experience.

Our main goal going was for me to get a boot and finish it all by nyself. Since the boot is a good 2L, I was a little wary of what beer to order. The waiter was gracious enough to allow us to taste a few of their beers before we committed to a full 2L. I ended up with the schneider weisse which was good for the first litre, but what do you expect? lol.

As for the food, the trout I had was amazing, it was perfectly cooked. My friends couldn't stop raving about their suckling pig so I can only assume that that was amazing too.

They also gave me a slice of black forest cake at the end since it was my birthday. It was moist and tasty :)

I would definitely recommend this place for a fairly large group (6+) but be sure to make reservations ahead of time so that you don't have to wait!
author: Geraldine C.

description:
You want to drink giant Steins (boots) of beer with your buddies? This is your place. Also a great place to enjoy some hearty German fare. 

The beers are gigantic: http://www.flickr.com/photos/calmenda/4666239250/in/set-72157624194954946/

They have smaller ones (the reason she is sad in the pictures)

http://www.flickr.com/photos/calmenda/4666241416/in/set-72157624194954946/

The servers are friendly and the place has a great vibe. Don't go here if you expect a quiet place to dine.
author: Carlos A.

description: Friendly, helpful bartenders. Amazing beer selection. Great food, especially the spaetzle.
author: Alex N.

description:
Personally, the only thing I've ever liked here is the Banana Beer. I LOVE the Banana Beer!. Other than that, this place is "eh". 

I really like Hayes Valley. Location of this place is pretty great, close to restaurants, bars and boutiques. I'm not a huge fan of German food, so I didn't really like anything. Bar at Suppenkuche is super small. It's very hard to get a drink and when you get a drink, expect to stand for a while before you can be seated. Staff is great, I've never had any reason to not like them. Super friendly. 

If you're into German Beers, you'll like this place.
author: Nitu B.

description:
I love this place. However, right now I am sitting here eating and can tell they don't want us here. We walked in at 930 and  ordered. We received our appetizers then
Immediately received our entrees.. Ok I get it.. Don't come here late .. Thanks for the tip.
author: Shaun C.

description: Saturday evening meal at the bar, celebrating my birthday. Craig the bartender was friendly, fun and helpful with the beer selections. My husband and I ate the venison with rotkohl and spaetzle, perfect and delicious! The Firebrand bread they serve is hearty and flavorful. I have dined here many times over the years and have always experienced good food and service. My only eh, is the noise level, but it will not stop me from coming back!
author: Lise K.

description:
When I left my last job, I sent out a farewell email to my co-workers with the subject line, "So long, farewell, auf Wiedersehen, goodbye!" (from the Sound of Music song). I was proud of my cleverness and eagerly showed the email to my boyfriend (who took German for 4 years). He immediately started laughing. It turned out I had misspelled "auf Wiedersehen" despite googling the phrase and directly copying and pasting it. (I realized later I had accidentally deleted a letter after pasting it). Ever since then, I have decided that all future attempts at German should be confined to food and drink. No more linguistics (despite the fact that I have a degree in linguistics).

Suppenkuche is a casual restaurant with a rowdy vibe. You sit with strangers at large, family-style picnic tables (about 8 people to a table) and get your napkins and cutlery from a container in the middle of the table. This is not a place for a quiet, romantic, intimate dinner. This is a place to drink lots of beer and laugh over tales of yore.

I tried the Radler, which was the perfect drink for a cocktail-lover who only drinks beer when she absolutely has to. For entrees, I got the special of roasted- and dumpling-stuffed organic half chicken in chicken sauce with potato pancakes. The sauce was delicious, but the entire dish was way too salty. The potato pancakes, although very crisp, had the texture and flavor of McDonald's hash browns (which I enjoy, but let's be honest, they're not healthy). My friend had the Sauerbraten mit Lingonbeerkonfitüre, serviert mit Rotkohl und Spätzle (marinated and braised beef with lingonberries served with red cabbage & spätzle). I thought it was tasty but not really anything thrilling.

Service was fantastic (our waitress was so nice) and the proximity to other strangers guarantees you'll make new friends by the end of your meal, but I don't think I'll be returning unless I've pounded back a few Heinekens first.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Good place to pop your German food cherry. 
The place is pretty cool, they have like big communal benches. 
We had a large party of like 20 people and they were able to accomodate us with a reservation. A few of my friends started with the boots. There are some beers that they don't allow the boot because the alcohol content is too high. 
It is amazing to me that people can finish the boot. It is two litres of beer. TWO! I probably can't even drink two litres of water in one sitting, let alone beer.

We started with pretzels and an appetizer sampler of cold cuts, cheeses. The pretzels were really good. I had the meatloaf with bacon and egg. It's a hard boiled egg, whereas I would probably have enjoyed a fried egg more, but that might not be german at all. Like all the food there it is really heavy, but that's what the beer is for. To balance it all out. I was able to taste some Jägerschnitzel and the bratwurst. Everything I had was good. If you're torn between the Jägerschnitzel and the Wiener Schnitzel, I would go with the Jägerschnitzel. The Wiener Schnitzel doesn't have any sauce so it can be a bit dry with it just being a fried pork cutlet. Or I mean, two fried pork cutlets.
author: Lan N.

description:
I brought my friend here to celebrate her birthday and BEER IN A BOOT!! is equal to awesomeness! I believe its around $25 ish for a boot but definitely worth sharing with some friends.

I recommend the potato pancake served with house-made apple sauce. great textural contrast. The venison with (some berry sauce) is divine and carries the gamey taste well, serves with spatzle and sauerkraut. The lamb shank with dumpling was divine. It was braised to perfection, tender and collected the flavors of the wine. Their stuffed mushroom with roasted pepper sauce was very tasty. It was my first time trying German food, but a pleasant eating experience. The waiters are generally cordial and offered suggestions on the wide beer selection. 

Maybe it was just my server...but my only complaint was that our group had left more than enough tip for the night, though some friends paid their tip using card (having separated the check). The tip was enough, however, the waiter miscalculated the tip (in cash) on the table w/o counting the tip of the cards, and stood outside the restaurant to ask for more tip. our group didn't bother to sour the mood so just gave him more tip. My personal opinion was that its was rude of him to do that, knowing now that it was probably his mistake but eh. 

ah well. the food was great. so i might come back again but I will definitely be more wary about making sure the waiter calculated the tip right.
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Food is amazing no matter what you choose, beer is delicious (and prime picture taking material if you get a boot) and it's overall a fun place to visit. Parking and getting a seat at a table can be rough, however.

The first time we went here we didn't get off on a great start.... The hostess forgot about us, and we had been waiting for a few hours. When she realized her mistake, she had us wait in the front of the restaurant, practically right on top of people that were already seated. They were running low on boots, so the waitress tried to convince me that pint glasses were "more ladylike", which did not fly with me, and she tried to take my boot before I was finished. 

Second trip went without a hitch, and there was much less wait on a weekday.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Went here Saturday and there was a line forming...thank god we found parking near the restaurant! :)

Pretty good food! And decent proportions.

Lentil soup: Tasted ok, just reminds me of progresso canned soup! LOL!

Potato pancakes w/ Apple sauce: Meh, nothing spectacular. It was ok though.

Wiener schnitzel: Tastes ok...I'm not really a fan of breaded pork.

Meatloaf w/ Bacon and egg: Was good, nothing spectacular.

Marinated and braised beef: Was the highlight of the evening. I loved this dish! Very flavorful!

Great service and nice people!

This is a very small place that got packed very, very quickly! It gets really really loud in there, so be prepared for eardrum destruction! :p

Wish we had a bigger group so that no other group was sitting with us! 6 is the magic number! I'll remember that next time! :)
author: Marc E.

description:
Rated mostly for the vibe. Very rustic, bench style tables and community style dining, where you share a large table with other parties. Dim lighting.

The food was just ok. I really could have done without the boiled sausage. The veal schnitzel was a very big portion, but it was a little dry and the seasoning wasn't strong.  A bit bland. 

I assume the usual long lines here are for Das boot.

I'd say 3.5 stars but rounding up to 4 for yelp.
author: Mark T.

description:
Always wanted to try Suppenkuche but didn't want to wait in the long line.  Since we had a 7:30 show at the Symphony, we decided that we would try to get in when they opened at 5:00, which we were able to do without any problems.  
The four of us were seated in a communal table of six, which we share with two of people three-quarters into our meal.  

They have over a dozen German beers on draft and many others in bottles.  We ordered Köstritzer Schwarzbier, Weltenburger Dunkel and Bitburger and all three were tasty.

For appetizers, we ordered the potato pancakes with homemade applesauce and the German Ravioli filled with Pork and Vegetables served with Mushroom Sauce.  
Of the two, the pancakes were amazing.  So light and crispy.  Delicious with the applesauce.

For entrees, we ordered the Sauteed Pork loin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spätzle & Green Salad and the Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce with Red Cabbage & Spätzle.  The pork loin was tender and had a nice mushrooom sauce.  The venison was not gamey and was very flavorful.

We ordered the Apple Streudel with ice cream for dessert.  It was not sweet and had nice apple filling.  

Overall, we loved the food and beer and would definitely come back try some of the other entrees.
author: Al L.

description: 5 stars alone for that 2 liter beer I had , after that i dont remember anything except that the place is perfect if you want to have your birthday dinner and pre drinking game , wait the potato pancakes and the pork shnitzel were amazing , see you next year Suppenkuche
author: NAEL K.

description:
So delicious and a great deal. Share the salads (they are huge), and give time to wait for a table. 

I would go back any night.
author: Valerie T.

description:
Chicken Schnitzel is the reason I come here.
Often. Like once a month.
With a group of schnitzel minded friends we come and order all the same plate, but different beers.
It's like a weird family tradition. It works only because we do it during the week. 
'Cause last night I showed up at 7 with no reservation and "no dice". Getting a table on weekend it's impossible. We waited for an hour, then we went elsewhere.
Even during weekdays, as you go inside, the hostess points at the beer bar, but it really is uncomfortable to drink a beer and chat with friends (waiting for your table), while you have to keep moving, and being pushed around, because people have to pass by.
That's my only critique: if you have a place that is so popular, everyone has to wait for their table, why don't you make that wait more bearable?
author: Amira T.

description:
Our most recent visit was a perfect hit.

We shared a dinner of breaded pork with mashed potatoes and peas (a special), a pickled herring appetizer, and a variety of beers. The pork was perfectly cooked and seasoned and came with a delicious apple mustard sauce. Even the mashed potatoes were yummy and flavorful. The pickled herring appetizer was a surprise, not the herrings in acid that we expected but a wonderful mix of different pickled veggies with a sizeable portion of herring. Absolutely delicious! We sat at the bar and got lots of beer recommendations and heartily enjoyed them (especially since we got to try them before buying). Overall had an amazing meal here -- our best yet.
author: Amy D.

description:
On a Tuesday night the place is packed - wall to wall people.  I'm glad we had a reservation. It was also loud, there were 9 in out party and I could talk with one person at each side of me and the person across from me and after that it was just yelling and "what?".

BUT, the food.  The Food is amazing.  We had the pretzel with spicy cheese and the potato pancake with applesauce appetizers an they were outstanding.  I had the port sausage, kraut, and mashed potatoes and it was spot on. Our waiter was great, knew about the food and most of the drinks and didn't rush us out of the place.
author: Sean S.

description: Delicious bratwurst and mashed potatoes and met some fascinating fun young men at our table.  Service was fast and they were so sweet. Had the best time! Who doesn't love drinking out of a boot?
author: Lenore F.

description: The braised beef was really tough and cold.  The potato pancakes were just OK and the purple cabbage had no balance between sweet and tang.  I hope people don't think all German food is like this. The bartender did use his German accent to make up for the awful and rude service he gave us but everyone else who waited on is was really nice and cheery.
author: Ian H.

description: We just got back from Munich and were missing bavarian fare :) while not exactly the same it was pretty damn close. Nurnberger with sauerkraut and pretzels with sweet mustard were great. Very fun ambience too.
author: Priyaanka S.

description:
I can't believe it took me THIS long to write a review for Suppenkuche. Well, maybe it's because every time I come here, I can't seem to remember the night... das boot!!

The food here is really really good. I didn't really expect much from German food having had it several times before and not being the biggest fan... but my god, the food her is SO flavorful and amazing! The weinerschnitzel here is great. I love how they give you a "salad" with your meal, too... it's basically a hunk of cabbage the size of your face. German food clearly does NOT excel in making "salads". 

You also have to get the beer here. Their German beer selection is fabulous. I usually get a pint or two because the beer is just so good! I also did the boot once before... let's never talk about that night again.

Last, the ambiance is energetic and fun, but also dark enough to be a little romantic. I wouldn't recommend for a first date because German food isn't exactly a cute or sexy food to eat... but maybe for a second or third? 

All of this would merit 4 stars, but the 5th star is because of the consistency. I've never been disappointed here and I've come here so many times! Check it out. It's worth the wait!
author: Jade R.

description:
My friend and I came here to try the banana beer. So I can't really speak for the quality of the food but looking at the menu it seems kind of expensive at about $20 a plate.

We were served free bread and butter while we were looking at the menu. The bread was dark and had a very strong flavor I did not really like. 

The banana beer ($7 for .5L) is a hefeweizen with banana juice. It's a golden yellow color and I was pleasantly surprised with the taste. It definitely tastes like bananas and was very drinkable.

We also ordered the soft pretzels. I liked these a lot with the cheese spread they came with. It's a stronger cheese which I am in to but I do not think my friend enjoyed it. The pretzels were soft and warm, so I liked them a lot too, but I have a soft spot for soft pretzels.

There's a little area in the corner with some stools, otherwise there are a bunch of communal tables. I think it'd be more fun to come here with a bigger group of people.
author: Ella C.

description: Delicious food! Community seating made it an awesome experience where we could chat with our neighbors and enjoy our dinner with each other at the same time. They don't take reservations but we went on a Monday around 6:30 pm and got right in.
author: Amy B.

description: 5 stars for having awesome beers on tap.  This is a very authentic german spot in the city.  Highly recommend if you either really like german food or if you've wanted to try it.  Getting a beer is an absolute must.  They have an excellent selection.  A lot of the staff is german or very familiar with the cuisine so they are helpful with recommendations as well!
author: Alyx F.

description:
Came here for the first time ever today, and I can honestly say that I had the best meal I've had in a very long time here at this restaurant. Suppenkuche has broken my German food virginity with such perfection that I am craving for more as I type these very words. 

I ordered myself something simple. The pork sausages with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut, and an Erdinger for my drink. Every single item on my plate complimented each other so perfectly. It was like a 3 piece puzzle that magically fit everything. The mashed potatoes were my favorite part, because they were cooked so well. Just a hint of butter, and they were super smooth. I hate it when mashed potatoes have that "wet sand" texture, but there was none of that here. The sauerkraut had a strong taste that blended well with the potatoes. The sausage was actually pretty mildly flavored, which as very nice because it didn't get overwhelming at all. The Erdinger beer was very smooth going down and it had a slightly fruity taste.

Service was very nice and friendly. The cost of the meal was a bit much but considering the size and taste, it was worth every penny. I can't wait for the next chance I get to eat here!
author: Sean H.

description: We came here for my boyfriend's birthday and even though we had to wait an hour to be seated, we got a liter of beer and soft pretzel with cheese and honey mustard at the bar while we waited. For any party less than 6 people, you can't make a reservation in advance. This is probably the friendliest atmosphere we've ever been in! At the bar, extremely tall people (they're all like 6'6) suggested an off-menu beer: banana and Hefeweizen. It was seriously the best beer I've ever had. It had a distinct banana flavor throughout the entire liter, but it wasn't overpowering and almost tasted like a bubbly juice. The pretzel was incredibly soft and the combo of the honey mustard and cheese was divine! It was really loud, which is perfect for parties and large groups, but probably not great for people on early dates. The sauerkraut actually tasted like authentic, slightly fermented cabbage (the best I've ever had), the sausage was delicious, and the mashed potatoes was perfectly creamy. The bread and homemade butter that's provided on the house is so dense and unique, it was hard to stop eating it. While eating, the table next to us sang songs in harmony and had neighboring tables joining with clapping and singing. It was a unique experience. We felt like we were transported to Europe! We have to come back again very soon!
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place is truly fantastic! I lived in Germany for 4 years and was missing/craving some authentic food. This restaurant hit the spot! Food! Beer! Das boot! Atmosphere! All combined for complete happiness! Nom nom!
author: Loretta B.

description:
3.5 stars

I've been wanting to try this place for over a couple of years since I saw it on Check Please. There was quite a wait when we came, so we hung around the bar area. The staff were friendly and helpful. 

We shared the potato pancakes, which were yummy with the applesauce. I had the meatloaf with bacon warped around it and the egg in the middle, with a side of mashed potatoes. It was a hearty meal, but I thought it was not bad. That dish didn't "wow" me as much as the potato pancakes.

It's a great place to experience, but I don't think I will come back. I can finally delete this place off my bookmarks of "To Try" list.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Very nice restaurant with typical
German dishes.  The schnitzel is the best!  The staff is very professional and the serving is always within a reasonable time no matter how crowded it is.  Do not go there without a reservation on a Friday or Sunday, as it gets really busy.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Been here multiple times and I guess if you are in your 20s, this is the place to be seen to drink beer in a boot! 

Otherwise, difficult parking and loud.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I used to love this place I would come here once a month during the 90's thru the mid 2000's. My friend and I were in the area and last week I ordered my "ol'reliable" the wienerschnitzel, my friend has never had German food and perhaps I oversold it or ordered the wrong thing but the schnitzel had to be the most bone dry thing I have ever eaten. My friend is looking at me like "ok so this is the German food you've been talking up for 20 years? Sheesh James I thought you knew food? DAAIM THIS IS DRY!"

After the second bite my friend and I said the hell with it pick it up with your hands because it's going to slip off the plate and land across the room! The service was great
the sides were great so was the bread but the schnitzel, I've had way better in Concord at DJ's Bistro or Speisekammer in Alameda and I don't have to contend with traffic and parking. People were eating the jaegerschnitzel and that looked delicious.
author: .James A.

description:
Loud. Good for groups. Don't eat lunch before you go here, the portions are HUGE. Perfect for birthday parties. I've had better food in Germany, and more tasty. However, San Francisco is not Germany, so I am not going to complain too loudly. 

Last time I went there...I don't drink beer, so I ordered wine. The wine was badly corked. How many people before me got corked wine? I got the servers attention. Apparently, multiple bottles in the shipment were corked. I switched wines. The bartender should be watching out for those sort of things. 

It's a good place to go in a group. Definitely not a first date sort of place. However, the amusement of watching the guy next to you trying to drink a five liter beer is worth it.
author: Danielle L.

description:
Sorry I don't see it.  

We were excited to try SuppenKuche so we planned an early meal on a Thursday night.  We arrived at 5:30 prior to the crowds just for that reason.  The disappointment started the second we walked through the door.  We were a party of 2 and after hunting down the hostess we were directed to the shelf they call a bar table in the back of the bar.  I was confused, there were 4 open tables with no one at them?  I asked and was told those were reserved for parties of 6 or more.  OK, they have rules I get it.

We made our way to the bar area and I could tell it was going to be 2-3 deep in no time at all.  While we were the only one sitting there for dinner, our chairs were already being bumped and the crowd had yet to arrive.  It was obvious this was not going to be a pleasant relaxing enjoyable dinner. 

This is why the one star. While I sat there 2 minutes after we  waked in and were shoved into the bar, the hostess guided a family of 4 directly behind us to one of the empty tables.  So much for the rules.  Getting lied to the second we walk it just is not a good start to an evening.

It is their restaurant, they can do anything they want, I just don't have to spend my money there - and we didn't, and we never will.  No food, german or otherwise is worth it. Loud, hot, uncomfortable and not very nice staff....who needs that?

For those of you checking yelp on your phones looking at  Suppenkuche and deciding if the hour plus wait is worth it, move on.  There are so many other  choices.
author: Drew M.

description: Absolutely authentic German cuisine. Fabulous service which was amazing considering the crowd.
author: William L.

description: Really good food and beer but super crowded and noisy. You might have to share a table with some other people, which I don't mind so I enjoyed the experience.
author: Rajveer P.

description:
After living in the Hayes neighborhood for several years, Suppenkuche became a favorite among our local dinner spots. 

After a trip to Berlin, my wife and I became huge fans of German cuisine, beer and traditions. This place truly captures the high spirited vibes that a typical German bar/restaurant has.

I always enjoyed the lamb dishes while my wife always ordered pork or chicken. Consistently meeting expectations in food and a good time!

Crowded and loud, family style seating makes this place best for groups!
author: Jessica H.

description:
I hate that German restaurants are always associated with BEER and/or sausages. This review will be a bit tough to critique because I have devoted time to living in Germany, and, believe me, German restaurants are not always loud and full of drunkenness. (:


Anyway, this place is always packed. It is hard to get a table without a long wait, so if you are really hungry, just order to-go, it might be the best you can do. Food-wise, the sausages were okay, and the sauerkraut was meh. I was actually quite disappointed with the amount of food I got for the price. The service was pretty average too, though I think a lot of that contributes to the crazies that goes on around here. If you are looking for beers and not really quality, this place may be for you. But if you are looking for both, I might suggest trying somewhere else. I know I will not be here again, sadly. /:
author: Kelley L.

description:
I was in Germany a couple of weeks ago and acquired a huge crush on maultaschen, a savory dumpling sorta thing.  So, since being back, I've been dreaming of and craving this plump, wonderful item.  

After going dancing all day yesterday, some friends and I decided to grab dinner.  One of my friends, from Germany, brought up that we *could* go to Suppenkuche.  I was surprised because he had mentioned that he doesn't love the place because it's just not like the homemade stuff he can get in Germany (you see the irony here, right).  

ANYWAY, we did go to Suppenkuche, and the meal and service were fantastic.  Even my German friend did not complain.  We started with three apps, the mixed German salad, maultaschen and pretzels.  Then we each ordered a main, mine being jägerschnitzel in mushroom sauce with spätzle with a green salad.  Everything was really tasty (and filling and rich).  Will definitely be back but am very glad to not live close to this joint - otherwise I'd be 300 pounds.
author: Kimberly Q.

description: We waited an hour and half to get a table but it was totally worth it. The food and beer here is incredible. I got the pork chop with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. I've never had pork that tender in my life! The mashed potatoes were so buttery and delicious. The sauerkraut added a nice crunch and acidity to the dish. I also got the beer in a boot shaped glass and that was a fun experience! Fair warning: You do have to give your credit or debit card to the waiter/waitress to get the beer in a glass boot. Apparently a lot of people break it or steal it. I would recommend this place to anyone. Fantastic place!
author: Hana K.

description:
What can you say about German sausages? They're the best in the world. How did Suppenkuche compare? The grilled pork sausage, mash potatoes, and sauerkraut were very, very delicious. Too bad we only had one plate to share among a group of five! I only wish we had more. We actually traveled to SF for vacation and this restaurant was one of the few places that we had the chance to check out. It has been a while since I ate German sausage so I was really craving some. Their sausages were very soft & flavorful so you could imagine how fast five people chowed down on one plate of sausages. We also shared a plate of potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce. It was an interesting yet delicious plate. That disappeared quickly too.

This place is only open for a few hours so the wait was a little bit long. Thank goodness SF has so many cafes so we went and kept ourselves warm in one. Overall, I love this place and would come more often if I live in SF.

P.S. If you go in a group, you must get the Das boot! It's just fun to see how humongous the beer cup is and sharing a drink is a great way to socialize with friends.
author: Thy T.

description:
I would actually give a 4.5 stars if it was allowed!

I have walked by this place many times before and it seemed so cool, ive always wanted to try it. I finally got the chance tonight and everything was awesome!

Potato Pancakes: ordered these for an appetizer. AMAZING. seriously the best i've ever eaten -- it comes with three big pieces (we had 7 people at our table) and the apple sauce it came with was amazing. DO ORDER THIS.

Weiner Schnitzel: this came with 2 large pieces of pork. it also came with potatoes fried with onions and ham (?). this was absolutely delicious but I dont think its as satisfying for a meal. I'd recommend getting this and sharing another dish

Braised Beef: came with sour cabbage (surprisingly delicious), a berry sauce that I dipped everything in, spatzle (a little too dense for me but still pretty good), and big pieces of beef cooked in a red wine reduction. Every singly component of this dish was delicious and so flavorful and came together so nicely. 

Other people at my table also ordered their special (1) roasted chicken with dumplings and potato pancakes (2) grilled pork chop (3) lentil soup

EVERYTHING was delicious and super flavorful.

I didnt try the beer but every single person in that restaurant was drinking beer so im assuming its like amazing.
author: Isabella L.

description:
I've been eyeballing this restaurant's exterior for years, maybe over a decade.  it reminded me of my high school German class, and how to pronounce an ü properly.

Ü for ümlaut, Suppenk  üüüü  che....

Finally went in for the first time ever the other evening for a business meeting/dinner and....

WOW..why did I wait this long?

Maybe those subconscious thoughts of "German food" being comprised of boiled sausages and soggy cabbage?  Unrealistic to be sure, even more so, as I grew up with sauerkraut, funnel cakes, bratwursts,  and other German-American dishes that were pretty darn good.  For some reason, over time, those dishes got bland and boring in my mind as I got older and exposed to the many wonderful flavors from other parts of the world as our nice little city is able to offer around any street corner.

Anyways, dinner here was great, Tony the Tiger grrrrreat!  The apple drink thingie was wünderbar!  The pretzel appetizer was sehr gute!  My main course of stuffed roasted chicken with potato pancakes on the side was ausgezeichnet!

My wife is of German descent and would love this place.  This place would happily remind her of her mom's cooking when she was growing up.  Maybe even better.  I'll be looking forward to taking her here when she takes a day off from her paleo regime.

Ja, suppenküche is is da schnitzzle! 



I'LL BEE BAACH...

~ oh snap, Arnie is Austrian...my bad....
author: Patrick M.

description: This use to be a 5 star for me. Now, the new staff went down hill, bread and butter has a price, the menu is limited.
author: Will F.

description:
I really don't give two shits less whether 'communal seating' is trendy now or not.

Last night we were forced to move IN THE MIDDLE OF OUR DINNER.  I realize that 21st century America is abandoning the idea of good taste, but this is insane. If you are so keen to jam an ass into every single seat, then we must part ways. I brought someone from Switzerland there last night and she was absolutely mortified.  I really should have gotten up and walked out saying: "Here's your goddamned seats, happy now?"

A former favorite place of mine will never see me again.
author: George S.

description:
We were sent here while on vacation on a recommendation by a friend and it did not disappoint. As others have pointed out, it was packed on a Tuesday night, but we got right in and sat with two other couples. The bread guy really did pop out of nowhere as soon as we were seated, pretty cool!

Beer list was great, and I loved both my choices even though I know nothing about German beer.

I had the venison and my only complaint and the reason for 4 not 5 stars is that one piece was really over cooked. The potato pancakes were to die for as well!

This was definitely a great find, too bad we live on the other coast, I'd love to go again.
author: Kat W.

description: T-O-O---L-O-O-U-U-D-D-D!!!!!!   Great German food and beer. Love the ambiance of sitting at tables with strangers.  But you cannot have a conversation.  You spend the evening yelling at each other. My dinner mate used a sound level monitor on his app -- which said we'd spent the evening sitting next to the equivalent of a motorcycle engine or blender.   Come on guys -- how about a little sound absorbing treatment on the walls, ceiling.... maybe on the floor? under the table? Would love to come more often....  but don't want to have to learn sign language.
author: Kristine P.

description:
A friend and I have been wanting to try this place but have always been turned away by the long long waits. Solution - get there early on a weekday and you're seated after 5 minutes. (6:15pm on a Wednesday)

We shared the cheese schnitzel and grilled German sausage (pretty much a brat) and it was super delicious. Creamy (though a little gritty) and rich schnitzel. That brat with the accompanying mustard and kraut was also hitting the spot. Add a cold refreshing IPA, it was the perfect dinner. 

We finished it off with the flakiest, freshest,  warm goodness of the apple strudel and I went home happy. 

I also loved the communal seating style of the place.
author: Cristina W.

description: If you want a good German food experience, come here. Great beer selection, solid German food, and a great vibe. Came here for dinner at 8 and had a little bit of a wait but das bier totally helped. Can't wait to come back here again.
author: Juan T. K.

description: This place has a weird smell and an overall dirty appearance. My girlfriend and I had the house made sausage today. I told her that it tasted a bit funky. In the end we thought I was being paranoid. We both got terribly sick tonight. Painful cramps, vomiting and diarrhea. The sausage was the only thing we had in common all day so it's definitely that. I hope others who had the sausage will write similar things here. I will never come back here again.
author: Renan C.

description:
I like this diamond of a restaurant in a nice area. Yes eat here. 

The appetizer I had of asparagus wrapped in a bundle of bacon was unique and fantastic. Get or. Hell, go there just for that. the beer choices are limitless in my book. Sample and enjoy. 

The service was fantastic. Really, attentive and friendly and not overbearing. 

The jagerschnitzel just was dry but I think the chef had a bad night. Still go there.
author: Todd J.

description:
Besides Leopolds, the best German restaurant in San Francisco, no wait, in the US.

As a German, I can totally recommend it: it's absolutely delicious, and authentic, the choices of food are just great! 

For all those who want to enjoy non-alcoholic drinks: order Bionade (Lychee) it is fantastic!
author: Henriette K.

description: So good!! Great German food!! Outstanding service and friendly staff. We arrived on a busy Friday night around 7:30 and we got seated at a comfortable community table with nice people. Hostess was really nice. Great German Kolsch and other tasty beer. My wife grew up in a mostly German town in Long Island and we've been to a great German restaurant there. Suppenkuche is just as good and the prices here are very reasonable for food and beer. They have a beer garden nearby also. I highly recommend this place. All age groups and types are drinking beer, eating and having fun. Don't miss this place!!
author: Kevin D.

description: I've been to Suppenküche many times for dinner, but only once for brunch. I ordered the bread dumplings, which come with eggs over easy, pork sausage links, and potatoes. The bread dumplings were in bread slice form underneath the eggs. They were like very moist, dense bread slices. It doesn't sound great, but trust me in that the whole thing worked well together. The restaurant was much less crowded for brunch, which was also nice. I'd definitely recommend this restaurant for both brunch and dinner. Keep in mind that they only do brunch on Sundays.
author: Drew C.

description:
Das Boot, Das right.  You've heard it all before.  The infamous beer boot restaurant in SF.  I'm not a big beer fan, although I wish I could've tried it.  I reckon you grab a few friends and order this cold, 2-liter,  gold-amber colored glass of wonder.  Just don't set it down, don't spill, and remember to flick... or so I've heard.

Suppenkuche serves up some good comforting grub, if you're a native.  Otherwise you might be a bit surprised by the all-so-German fan fair.  The trout tasted delicious and the grilled pork sausages with mashed potatoes were divine.  If only they were a little bigger (think long breakfast links served with mustard as garnish).

I will be back Suppenkuche, and that boot is mine!

The soup kitchen was wunderbar!!!
author: Kevin J.

description:
FOOD: Hearty is an understatement at this restaurant. This is hibernation food, I just conquered a new continent food, Rumpelstiltskin sleep for 1,000 years food. The portions are massive, but the flavors are very well balanced, it doesn't feel like the same bite over and over. There was a great mix of savory flavors, crisp vinegars and tartness from the sides like the sourkraut. 

I had the Pork Knuckle. It was about the size of small football. The crisp on the skin was amazing, like the best chicharrón you've had, covering succulent tender pork. It had big chunks of fat on it, but you knew that when you ordered it didn't you? It's a pork knuckle, not a pork loin. Sides were great

Also had the spaetzle, the onion butter sauce was delicious.  Big enough to treat as a main if you wanted. 

BEER: Don't know what to say, broad selection, great quality, and ice cold. We drank from the boot, I felt like a man. 

ENVIRONMENT: This is where the star gets taken off. It's jam packed inside. Wall to wall, with the entire standing area full of people drinking and waiting for tables. If you're drunk and willing to stand shoulder to shoulder in a brightly lit room, than it's fine, but it's a little off putting at first. Also, the wait is brutal, we sat down as a table of 5 with a 1.5 hour wait, and felt lucky. Seems like all the tables are communal, which is a toss up. The first group sitting next to us were pretty grumpy, and the second group we're nice. Don't want you meal to be ruined just because of the people next to you. 

PRO TIP: Get your team of 6+ drunk hairy pillagers together so you can make a reservation, the wait is frustrating.
author: Patrick T.

description:
If I'm ever in the city with a craving for legit German food and beer, this is always my first stop. We came here on a Sunday for dinner and though we couldn't be seated immediately, it gave us more reason to grab a beer or two at the bar while we waited. The space itself can be pretty cramped, especially by the bar on a busy night. Oh, and loud, so you do have to raise your voice a bit. It was about 20 minutes before we were seated at a table with two other groups.

I came here for the first time about 5 years ago and somehow I ended up ordering the same thing: venison medallions with spätzle and cabbage. The venison wasn't gamey at all. In fact, it was very moist and flavorful. I'd definitely order it again, clearly. The portions were pretty big, and after a beer and a half, I could barely finish half of my food. Good food, good beer, definitely a keeper on the list. Good company always helps too :)
author: Amanda E.

description:
beer. german food. friends. mixed together!

they serve beer in vessels the size of your torso or in the shape of your boots. the atmosphere is pub-ish with communal tables to share your cheers. the food was exceptionally good, especially the jaegersnitzle served with buttered spatzle. consistently and evenly malloted pork, breaded and fried to a golden hue, covered in an amazing mushroom cream sauce, and accompanied with buttery homemade pasta. every bite was better than the last.

we had a few appetizers to share like the potato pancakes with apple sauce. it was fried crispy without the lingering oily effect. the pretzels were fluffy and chewy and very savory when dipped into their cheesy onion mixture. 

suppenkuche is the place to be. start at their biergarten down the street then move over here for dinner when they open their doors at 5pm. just do it.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
I would have given it a 5 star but when I gave the waitress my credit card and some cash, she asked if the tip was going on my card because she never gets tipped the full amount when it does...

Then after giving her a 20% tip, she tells me she lost my card.
Prob the worst service I have ever had. It's not my fault a bigger group didn't tip you, however if you make people feel uncomfortable with their form of payment, and then lose their ATM card, you don't deserve a 20% tip...


Moving on to the restaurant, I loved the beer, the food, the atmosphere and everything else but this waitress. Def a good place. Just be careful who is serving you...
author: Brittini S.

description:
One of the first places I can remember with communal tables in SF. 

I'm a sucker for the venison. The sausages, schnitzel, and potato pancakes are solid choices as well.

Great selection of beers on tap and bottled. 

TIP: If you're getting toward the bottom of the boot, be sure to point the toe up and away from you or hilarity may ensue as a toe of beer splashes you in the face.
author: Andrew C.

description: Great German restaurant! Very authentic. Another delicious meal. Great service.  Best tasting beer. The Bavarian pretzels are amazing. It's a family style restaurant. Nice size portions.
author: Shelly P.

description:
I had my dinner, I came back home, I'm calm and I still think the service was really bad. I don't like that they make you write your name on a list, have you wait 40 minutes and let anyone who comes in and sit in any table take it even if you are waiting, happened twice, waitress did nothing.

Food is good but they didn't had available some items from their menu. Still I'd recommend the sausage with sauerkraut 

The fat waitress is really mean also.

tl:dr; unorganized service, good food and beer
author: Perro H.

description: German food done right - even better than in Germany and Austria in my opinion: more flavors and more vegetarian options. Excellent service too. No complaints
author: Annie C.

description:
My friends and I got really lucky and scored a table for 6 people at 6PM.  We originally couldn't get reservations, but another group canceled so they called my friend at 3:30PM and said we secured the reservation.  We were told to be prompt or else they'll give our table away.  Upon arrival, I could totally see why they wanted us to be on time.  This place is soooo popular!  The entire place was packed with people holding pints and eating bratwursts.  I kid, there was way more food than just sausages.

We sat in the back room, which was pretty cramped, but we made it work.  The seats were actually benches and weren't the most comfortable, but we made do.  Given the instruction that we only had 2 hours to dine and drink, we hurried and scoured their drink menu for the appropriate beer of the night. Our waiter was awesome and brought out a couple samples of beer for us to choose from when we got a bit indecisive. I think we got a hefeweizen in their famous glass boot.  We were told that if anything happened to the boot, someone's CC would get charged $50!  

I wasn't feeling that hungry so I ordered their lentil soup with an extra order of bratwurst.  I was a bit disappointed because it tasted like hot dogs in tomato soup...and it cost $10.  I tried my friend's beef dish and hers was amazing.  I also tasted the currywurst and that was good too.  I think i just got the wrong thing that evening.

Everyone LOVED the potato pancakes that came with a side of apple sauce.  Each order had 3 pancakes the size of a palm and were about an inch thick.  They were crispy and golden brown on the outside and moist on the inside.  Awesome stuff...definitely craving me some of that right now.

Overall, the service was awesome and friendly.  They don't have a large menu, but still had something for everyone to choose from.  I'd say their meat was a bit salty and I wonder if it's so people would buy more beer to quench their thirst.  Anyway, Suppenkuche is a really fun and relaxed environment to check out if you have a lot of beer lovers in your group!
author: May W.

description:
Finally made it to Suppenküche. Very yum, very pro servers, good stuff going on here. 

Walked in 5:45PM on a Sunday, led right to two seats at a shared table. Basket of chewy tasty bread with nicely paired compound butter presented promptly. Busy but not crazy at that time. Had some questions about the beers, ably answered and the beer suggested was perfect for my preferences. BF had already done his research and knew the beer he wanted. All good.

For dinner, he ordered the Jägerschnitzel with mushroom sauce, spätzle and nicely dressed butter lettuce and I ordered the Nürnberger Brats with mashed potatoes and yummy sauerkraut. Skilled waiter took the time to ask if we wanted to move to the recently vacated seats closer in... we did and all was good. Both meals were really delicious, came fast and well prepared. Nom!

Really liked that waiter came through the room often and made eye contact with everyone. Present but not hovering - righteous pro! The moment I thought we might want the check and a to-go box (because the portions are generous), he was there and we got both in like a minute from another skilled crew member. They dance nicely there.

I really can't even think of anything they could have done better. The food was great, the service was great, the beer was great. I understand why everyone always says good things about this place. I usually hold out on the fifth star until I can assess consistency but I don't get into the city often and I'm not going to hold that against them...based on friends' experiences and a great dinner tonight... yeah, they really are as good as it gets in this genre.
author: Susan M.

description: Great little spot ! Very good ! Had a light dinner Weiner schnitzel and apple strudel !
author: Lori S.

description: A little loud place, but super good food, it was worth of long wait.
author: Caroline C.

description: Soooo full.  The portion sizes are very big here, and my girlfriend and i were stuffed after an app and two entrees.  No room for dessert.  Came here at 630 on a Friday night and was able to grab two seats of the bar after just 10 minutes (2 seats at a communal table opened up 10 minutes after that).  We got the potato pancakes, which actually were a bit disappointing.  For an entree i had the roasted pork, which tasted great with the gravy and sauerkraut.  The beer selection was extensive and both beers i had were excellent.  Overall, it was a very good meal in a really lively atmosphere.  By the time we left the wait outside was pretty long, so i'm glad we came early.
author: Simon L.

description: I really like to pair their raspberry beer with their lamb chops and mashed potatoes topped with truffle butter and mixed vegetables.  You may want to clarify how you want the lamb chops cooked since last night it was more rare than expected.  However in the past they have tasted unbelievably good.  (The photo below is from another time I ate the lamb chops). My friend had made a reservation ahead of time and it still took about 20-30 minutes to get seated so keep that in mind, their seating can get limited.
author: Andrea V.

description:
Being from Germany, I felt skeptical on both the quality--mostly because of the name... ha ha--and authenticity of the food, as most "German" places in the states offer little more than sausages and watery sauerkraut. I was pleasantly surprised by the food here. 

Staff was polite but seemed overwhelmed at times by the crowd. Service was a little slow at first, but our waiter became more attentive as the evening went on. We were told we had to finish eating by 8pm time because they were going to seat us at one of the party tables in the back, and they held true to that promise, promptly telling us to get up and leave at 8 on the dot to make room for a large group with a reservation. Gotta love that German punctuality!

Pretty decent selection of beer. The spread of food on the menu is pretty straightforward and expected: a handful of wursts and schnitzels, and of course a potato pancake with applesauce. The standard appetizers are pretty meh, but when we went, there were fresh pretzels and mustard on the daily menu which were better than expected and quite tasty. I wish I could remember the brand of mustard, it was so good I want to order some for myself!

Some of the components in the entrees seemed odd, but the dishes were well received by everyone at our table. The sauerbraten was very tasty and though the sauce was a little lighter than I am used to, it was definitely a dish I'd like to eat again. Spaetzle was clearly fresh, made on-site, and very good.

I am not a vegetarian, but one of the people in our group was and she was (unsurprisingly) underwhelmed/disappointed with her dinner of lentil soup. I personally wouldn't expect much in the way of vegetarian fare from a German restaurant, but being a restaurant named "soup kitchen", one would expect more selection of soups and maybe more interesting/better tasting options?

Decor is very minimalist and basic, which I personally love. It was a relief to not see a permanent Oktoberfest theme inside. 

Atmosphere was extremely loud and though our party was not bothered by it, the communal seating may not be for everyone. The people who were at the table when we were seated seemed extremely put off that we were seated next to them. They were a party of two at one of the 12-seater tables! What did they expect?? If you are looking for a quiet evening or have personal space issues, this restaurant is probably not for you.

All in all, I wouldn't say this food teleported me home to Germany, but it was pretty close! We will be back again.
author: Linda H.

description:
AMAZING place for good sausages that actually taste like meat, not salt. Add their homemade sauerkraut with draft hefeweizen beef and you have a meal. 

If you are with company, order Das Boot! The giant glass boot with beer will amaze your friends. You have to put a 50 dollar deposit on the boot in case you break it! 

If you don't like sharing tables with strangers (they may put 2 parties on one large table) or do not like loud restaurants, you wont like this place. However, I LOVE the loud environment, the great staff, and the restaurant decor! It feels like I'm really in a old fashion German kitchen with their large family style wooden table tops! 

I rate 4 stars because during peak dinner times, good luck finding a seat without waiting at least 1 hour.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
If I'm here on a Sunday, I come to have brunch. The food is filling and delicious. I'm a fatty so I finish my entire meal and nibble on half of my friends'. Most people, however, will be content with half a breakfast entree.
Bread, beers, and food are delicious.
author: Steffen G.

description:
YESSS! I LOVE THIS PLACE! Such legit german food!

Came here for dinner yesterday and of course many people were celebrating Deutschland's win for the World Cup. The environment was fantastic and so lively.

I ordered the jagerschnitzel and spätzle. It was so delicious that it left me wanting more. I just can't wait to go back! All my friends had good things to say about what they ordered from the fish to the sausage. I got a taste of both and they were just the best. Cooked perfectly and filled with flavor!

I also love how you can order beer in a boot!

Overall I'll definitely come again!
author: Jeanette L.
Johnny T.

description:
After promising my husband he can one day drive an exotic car through Germany, I came here to satiate my craving for German fare. When we came here on a Saturday before 6pm, we were met with a 45 minute wait. 

My gregarious husband enjoyed the communal seating. It is definitely not for everyone but if you are social, it's a great place to meet new people. It's also a great place for drinks! Four of our table mates were drinking 2 liters of beer out of a glass boot! Apparently, they hold your credit card in exchange for the glass boot so make sure you don't drop it! There is actually a chart on the menu that covers the spectrum of beer vessels. My husband and I settled on .3L and .5L.

The food impressed me less than the ambiance and the beer. We shared the bacon wrapped asparagus. Although the bacon itself was quite tasty, we were both disappointed by the single strip of bacon for the many spears of asparagus. I was not a huge fan of the bratwurst. It wasn't bad. I was just expecting more flavor. I preferred the venison medallions, which were much more flavorful. Game can be chewy but the venison was surprisingly tender. 

Located in the Hayes Valley area with its cute shops, I would definitely bring out-of-towners here, especially to see how much beer they can consume!
author: Christina L.

description:
I haven't had too much German food to compare and so maybe this is how it is.  The brunch prices are very affordable and you get a lot of food. Service was good but it is a noisy place to go.

Liked:
The fries were good.

Decent:
 - I expected more flavor from the pork and chicken sausages dish with tomato curry and thought it would have a natural casing.  
- The ravioli dish isn't like Italian ravioli with filling inside.  It was cooked pieces of dough mixed in with eggs and other ingredients.  While it wasn't bad its just like any other scrambled egg mixture dish.

Meh:
Some of the potatoes in our side dish were burned.
author: Kenneth H.

description:
I was sitting at the table, eating that pickled herring and remembering the good old days back home, when your grandma boils some potatoes, puts herring and onions and that simple dinner - is the best one you ever had. My thoughts exactly when I tried this place . 
Came on a Tuesday night around 6 and it was already packed, we waited about 20 min to get the table, and I was worried about food coming out late, but it was pretty fast. 
The place itself is small but cozy, tables are family style, so you might gonna have to share it with other people, which doesn't bother me at all. 
They also have a small bar area, where you can order food as well. 
Good selection of draft beers, as well as bottled. 
The menu is not too big, but there's a lot to choose from. 
We started off with potato pancakes and pickled herring. Both came out delicious! I immediately felt like I was a kid again eating at my grandma's kitchen. For dinner we had trout and other friend got cured pork chop. Trout was cooked perfectly, wasn't too dry. My friend said pork was delicious too. We wanted to try the dessert as well, but we were really full. 
Definitely one of the fav SF restaurants now! The atmosphere and the food is amazing. I could just eat that herring everyday and be happy! Must try when you in town!!!
author: Z P.

description:
This place is full of energy--and if you don't mind communal tables and a lot of noise, you'll have fun here. The beer flows and the bartenders are knowledgeable. 

The food is yummy (a little on the salty side for me, but maybe that's what the beer is for) and exotic for what I'm used to eating.

Be prepared to wait to get in if you don't get in right when they open. Reservations are only for parties of six (6) or more.
author: Ivan C.

description: When I want German food, very few places come to mind. Suppenküche has the best German food I've had so far, as well as an excellent beer selection. If you're feeling ambitious you can order your beer in the boot (a hefty 2 liter glass). Last I came here I had the wild boar sausage and it was delicious. Portions here are large so come hungry (and thirsty). The place can get pretty packed so expect a wait, but you can spend it at the bar with a cold beer so it's not so bad. I wouldn't recommend coming with a party larger than 4 unless you enjoy waiting
author: Alex P.

description:
Been about 5 times.  It's always delivered.  Reasonable prices, hearty meals and appropriate atmosphere (It's a beer hall, it's loud).  

I'd highly recommend the Potato Pancakes, the Meatloaf and the Jagerschnitzel.
author: Andrew L.

description:
+ good beef
+ friendly service
+ yummy pretzel
+ marinated and braised beef with red cabbage - really well cooked and flavorful

soso: portobella mushroom stuffed with spinach & feta cheese - pretty heavy for an entire entree
author: Margaret R.

description:
A friend from San Diego was visiting and we were looking forward to getting a big group together to party in the city.  On the recommendation of a Yelp employee friend, we decided to check out the always busy, traditional German eatery Suppenkuche, in Hayes Valley.

We started off with several hefeweizens to try before ultimately ordering a 2 liter boot glass of something that I can't currently remember since it was that crazy a night.  The boots require a $50 deposit in case they break and the beer itself ranges between $22-45+ per glass.

I went with as traditional a meal as I could get with the veal weiner schnitzel for $17.50.  It sort of reminded me of a huge chicken-fried steak and was served with potatoes cooked with bacon.  With just a shot of lemon juice over the steak, the flavors were intense and excellent.  The veal itself was very tender and the breading was perfectly browned.  While the portions weren't huge, I think that we were all perfectly satiated.

Ultimately our San Diego friend didn't show up to the party, but we had a great time of it anyway.  The atmosphere was super fun but the experience was certainly not cheap.  It's definitely worth checking out but make sure to go early because seats are very difficult to get.

Food: 8/10

Service: 9/10

Price: $$$

Atmosphere: 10/10
author: Joe M.

description:
German grub at its finest. Even though it's tucked away in a nondescript corner of Hayes Valley, it seems like everyone knows about this German gem. It is particularly crowded for Brunch which only occurs on Sundays. My most recent visit involved an unfortunately timed arrival when a stampede of people breezed past us. We were offered a seat at the bar immediately, which is actually a dark alcove behind the bar with bar stools and a thin slab of wood to place the food plates. After stewing there for awhile and contemplating how we were going to fit all our dishes in the limited space, we decided to generously relinquish our seats and keep waiting an actual table, which was also communal, but hey - at least it entailed more surface area. 

We ordered Bananaweizen; this was the first time I had banana beer and it certainly won't be the last. The banana juice was very concentrated and left a sweet aftertaste. Just remember to stir it up because the juice tends to sink to the bottom. The beer comes in different liter increments and different vessels, including a boot of epic proportions. 

I ordered one of their brunch specials - a spin on their emperor's pancake, which came with banana and apple instead of the usual brandied raisins. The portion was generous and the pancake was crisp on the outside, not too doughy. I really liked the plum compote on the side, not so much the apple one. 

The other entree we ordered was the schnitzel and spaetzle. I told them I wanted to trade the breaded porkloin for the sauteed one which came with the entree. They gave us the breaded porkloin, but covered it nonetheless with the mushroom sauce. They also gave us potatoes as a side instead of spaetzle, and ended up bringing us some spaetzle on a separate plate later. What a lucky mistake - the potatoes were the best home fries I had in a while. 

The service was slower than snails. It took them nearly half an hour to take our order, but they were really trying to hustle, so I have to give them credit. It was still really awkward since we made eye contact with the waitress multiple times and she took orders from people sitting at the same table as us and promptly left, but I think they have a systematic system of serving who was seated first. We chewed on complimentary bread during this time. The bill came fast enough but had two overcharge mistakes. It was fine though because they rectified them before anybody got hurt.
author: Alice L.

description:
I came here one Friday night for a reunion dinner with some old friends and was immediately overwhelmed as soon as I stepped in. It was jam packed (literally standing room only) and insanely loud. Now don't get me wrong, I like the boisterous, friendly atmosphere and it's good to be around people having a solid good time, but this was pretty ridic. 

So as soon as I walk in, I spot my friends near the bar and have to fight my way through the super dense crowd to get to them. We're waiting for our table for about 20 minutes and sweating bullets because it's just a mass of bodies. Two people in the group ended up getting the beer boots, which is pretty ambitious for one person to finish. (They have you pay a $50 deposit beforehand in case you break the boot.) We finally get a table and end up sharing it with some couple, but it's a good time and no one minds. 

This place is just meat and more meat, with some paltry salad options, but definitely not vegetarian friendly. All the dishes we ordered were variations on mashed potatoes and slabs of meat, but it was all super tasty and satisfying. There's nothing to fill you up quite like a German meal! 

The service was good and the staff was super friendly. I'm surprised they managed to get everyone's food to them without spilling, given how crowded it was. The line for the bathroom is pretty long, so if you're drinking a lot of beer, be aware! 

Solid place for a weekend dinner with a group (and the bigger the group, the better it seems!). I took off a point for the price (maybe par for course in SF) and one for not being able to hear anything anyone said.
author: Shelly T.

description: The food is great but the waiting time will make you want to off yourself.  They discriminate against small parties also--I once waited for hours and watched several 6 tops get sat immediately because they were the correct size for the table.  To add insult to injury, after all the waiting they sat me at the shitty table by the door where people are constantly bumping into you.  Food is seriously amazing, but the experience is utter shite.
author: Elizabeth W.

description: Sometimes too crowded for my taste, but I still go, because this German food is better than in Germany!
author: Stefanie S.

description:
Wait, WTF? I've never reviewed my favorite place to spend an evening in the entire Bay Area? Really?

There are places that you go to for great food, there are places you go to for incredible ambiance, and then there are places like Suppenkuche where you get both. Everything from the Potato Pancakes to the Vesperplatte to the Jaegerschnitzel to the Sauerbraten and everything in between is awesome. They've hit a real sweet spot in their cooking. 

The atmosphere is not for those who want a quiet evening away from strangers. There's communal seating and a boisterous atmosphere. They have a really nice beer selection. Nothing obscure, but everything is delicious. 

There is only one downside to Suppenkuche: the probable wait. However, if you go in expecting to have a wait, and say, order a beer or two at the bar, your night goes from upsetting to fantastic!
author: Aarash Z.

description:
Styled after traditional German bier halls, Suppenkuche is THE place to go if you're in the mood to eat like a real MAN, even if you happen to be a WOman. Here you will not find small, light, or dainty plates this is a MEAT 'n' POTATOES and PASTA with CHEESE kind of place with an enormous mug of beer on the side.

Speaking of beer, the beer selection is fantastic, with at least 20 or so German beers on tap and another 15 or so available by bottle that you just don't see anywhere else. Beers come in a variety of sizes ranging from a reasonable .4 Liters (everything is done in metric here in European style) to a WHOPPING 5 liter beer marathon. Last night I had the Salvator which came in a .5 liter mug roughly the size of an ogre's fist.  

The potato pancakes are AWESOME, super crispy and served with an unsweetened apple sauce. The cheese spatzle is a MUST-TRY, served with an incredibly creamy onion sauce. Suppenkuche is also well known for their soups, the mushroom soup is awesome!

Suppenkuche is basically a home run, there are only two tricky parts. 1. It gets really crowded and the wait can get long even on week nights. 2. The seating is communal, and gets VERY jam packed. As a result, you will sit with people you don't know amid the dim of loud conversation, with servers/waiters constantly reaching over you and trying to walk around you to reach other seated customers. 

P.S They have DAS BOOT, a 2 liter glass boot FULL OF BEER!!!
author: Tomas K.

description:
This has become our new favorite restaurant. In the past months we have been coming here on a weekly basis and it simply doesn't fail.

Venison w/ spatzles is brutal, bratwurst with mashed potatoes ist wunderbar, portobello mushroom with feta is a serious deal, beef with cranberry sauce nailed it, potato soup is one of the best I've had, and I could go on (not to mention the great amount of delicious beers they have). 

It's this good:

After eating a plate of 3 bratwursts I thought it was so good I ventured to try the schnitzel, and then topped it off with a strudel. I downed it with 1 liter of delicious beer. I almost rolled out from the restaurant but it was totally worth it.

We will continue coming. Can not get enough.
author: Daniel S.

description:
To begin, my personal experience with German meat and mead is minimal but open for curiosity to say the least. This specific location, which I can't even pronounce correctly, was suggested by a couple peers after a morning of rock climbing in SF. Hours are limited at this location and only open their doors during the evening at 5pm. After arriving at the location roughly 30 min before opening, the line to enter was already starting to snake its way around the back side of the restaurant. Soon after being seated at the bar, we were quickly provided excellent service by a friendly bartender who knew much and more about the German food, beer, and culture of what was being served. We started off with a recommended beer that was ages away from disappointment. Very smooth to the taste that surprisingly accommodated a kicker of inebriation  to start off the evening. After the first round of drinks was served, we were given an appetizer of pretzels with butter and mustard to help wash down. This ultimately lead to a few more drinks and snacks which made the evening fantastically enjoyable. Bottom line is this place has great food, excellent service, and sets an environment that is both classy and enjoyable for people of all types to experience. Minor tip: get there early, tip well, and sit at the bar.

Cheers!
author: Ralphie V.

description:
Portions are good, food is consistent quality, has that stamptisch feel, and let's not forget the selection of beer!

Come with friends and share a boot -- traditionally you pass it around, so don't do this during the flu season ;)

Only downside -- this place gets a little crowded and waits can be long. Best plan is to put your name on the list early and try some beers at the bar or go across the street to two sisters for a drink.
author: Christophe C.

description:
Great food. Came here awhile ago. The line was alright, not bad. The food is pretty unique and flavorful. Who could have thought are couple sausages and mash potato can make. Great meal! I was pretty impress with they food. 

A little price for they small portion entree. But it's good enough to fill me up. They have pretty good and dark beers here also!
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
Waited for about an hour for our party of 4 but it was worth it! I realized that I really like spaztel. The potato pancakes were great too!

The only thing to note is that it is very loud and crowded at suppenkuche. I wouldn't recommend this place if you want to have a conversation with the people that you're eating with! But I also feel the need to re-emphasize this: the food is sooo good!
author: Jasmine O.

description:
Strictly going off the food this place would be a 4 star for me. I had the jagerschnitzel with spaetzle and a bananaweizen. The food was fresh and simply scrumptious. The beer was a tasty twist on the standard hefeweizen.

However... the reason this place is getting a 2 star is due to two glaring issues.

#1 - the atmosphere is love it or hate it, I hate it. When you walk in there's no waiting area and it immediately feels awkward as you try and find the hostess while stumbling over patrons trying to enjoy their meal. It's also VERY loud, beyond what I consider acceptable for a restaurant. Hell, it's even loud by bar standards.

#2 - the wait. Granted, I showed up asking for a table for 2 around 7PM on Friday so I'm expecting a wait but we were quoted 20-30min by the hostess. We came back 20min later to check on our position and the hostess gave me a puzzled look then chuckled and said "did I say that? wow, I'm sorry... yea it's going to be at least another hour or so. Please check back every 20min with me." This may have just been an off night for them but none the less it left me with a poor taste for this establishment. We ended up waiting a total of 70min.

The food was good and if I'm ever craving german food again I'd consider returning but by no means will I ever go back just for a meal.
author: Tony S.

description: Cheese Spatzle In Onion Butter Sauce.  Read: Mac & Cheese.  Wasn't bad but this is not a place I'd come running back to...blood and pig not being my thing so there was little for me here.  But I'd still say A-OK.
author: David S.

description:
Totally stunned by all of these five star reviews. Don't get me wrong, this restaurant is darling (aww, birds on the ceiling!) but it has not decided whether it wants to be a beer hall (which in that case choosing a two-bedroom apartment-sized location wasn't genius) or a restaurant. 

Because oh my fucking god, brosef, while you full-belly-holler at your friend across the restaurant/bar about the progress of our meal ("SHOULD BE DONE ANY MINUTE, BRO!") please also step back so you're not breathing down my neck with a full glass boot of beer. Thank you.

We waited an hour (totally legit for a Saturday) and were seated at a table that was surrounded, and I mean SURROUNDED, by standing people waiting for other tables, drinks in hand, for the entirety of our meal. As Danny G. said, "It feels like we're eating at a house party." Correct. 

The cheese/noodle veggie option was pretty bland, while the beet/carrot/cabbage salad served alongside it was the high point of the meal. We also had the trout, which was, you know- trout. Nothing spectacular. And for $25? Nicht sehr guht.

With the din, and the wait, and the atmosphere of total out-of-control mob-scene, this is not someplace I'd go again unless I was committed to doing a night of hard, rowdy drinking.
author: Leah O.

description:
There's a fine line between a crowd and a mob, and given how packed this place is on Friday nights, I'd describe it as "mobbed" and not "crowded," if you catch my drift. They do the trendy restaurant thing of putting in as many tables as possible, so between the large amount of drunks and the large amount of everyone else, it is loud. I'd go so far as to call it "deafening." 

I'm not interested in eating at  Suppenküche  for the same reason I'm not interested in eating in a wind tunnel or the tarmac of an airport. Even if those places served beer in glass boots and adequate German food, one of the best parts about restaurants is the ability to talk to your companions, something  Suppenküche makes it quite difficult to do. If I walked by and it  was practically empty I'd still hesitate on going back because frankly I feel the food is priced a bit high for what it is. 

The food and drinks are good enough, and if you enjoy getting soused on imported beer you could do a lot worse... but you could probably do a lot better.
author: Aaron Y.

description:
I'd been advised to arrive here as close to opening as possible.  

The 25 people in line at 4:59 confirmed this advice as extremely sound. Fortunately this left plenty of table seats as well as the bar by the time I reached the door.  Equally fortunate, the Oktoberfest beers had arrived that day, allowing a rare draft of Weihenstephaner Korbinian.

While waiting on my schnitzel I ordered pretzels, which came out unbelievably perfectly: hot, just a bit crusty and perfectly chewy, with a side of obatzda. Many restaurants provide tubs of the stuff like it's cream cheese for your bagels; Suppenkuche's is a small, rich dollop that nonetheless is more than enough for its two accompanying pretzels.   Between that and the Korbinian I was well on my way to being satisfied with my dinner.

But then the jaeger schnitzel arrived and further elevated the meal. Perhaps the best, succinct impression of the dish is that one could reasonably expect fried pork covered in mushroom gravy to be an absolute rock in the stomach. But it's not.
