Even after pretzels and beer I found myself cleaning the plate in a few minutes. Hearty, satisfying, yes, but surprisingly light for all of that.  The accompanying salad -- one in the asian slaw style, simply lettuce dressed with vinegar -- is a simple and excellent contrast to the pork, gravy, and buttery spaetzle.

I had been told what to expect from Suppenkuche, and they still wowed me. I will definitely be back the next time I'm in the city.
author: Josh M.

description: Absolutely amazing. Food was very fresh and out of this world. Waitress gave great suggestions. Bar tender was extremely knowledgeable of the beers and very friendly.
author: DiMee M.

description:
Chicken Meatloaf special was a delight! Wrapped in thin strip of smokey bacon, the flavor infused the meatloaf beautifully and added moisture. The hard egg cooked in the center was perfect. I wish I knew how to make the yummy chicken gravy, it was light and not goopy or starchy. The mashed potatoes were also very light.

I was raised in Germany and the true test of an restaurant that claims "Bavarian Cooking" is the quality of the farmers meal of Wiener Schnitzel.  Suppenkuche holds it's own and can lay claim as one of the best "Bavarian" style restaurants in the US in my book.

The german beers are some of the best tasting ones I've had in years. I really enjoyed the people watching of American 20-somethings, drinking the boot.

I can't wait to go again and I highly recommend this restaurant of all foodies to try. It's a genuine experience.
author: cailyn m.

description:
Delicious beer, pork, and a fun and lovely environment! I will definitely be coming back!

They are big on community tables if you are a small party.
author: Dorie S.

description:
While having a "daycation" in SF on 4/28/12, my friends and I checked out this spot. It opens at 5:00 PM and when we arrived a few minutes early there was already a small crowd. Obviously this place is popular!

The restaurant is a bit small but they have large tables for a big crowd or for you to sit with others. I liked the simple decor, which included birds "flying" by the ceiling. The bathroom was clean and spacious.

I shared a boot of draft Paulaner Märzen with a friend. It was very delicious! Note that if anyone at the table orders a boot the restaurant needs a credit card in case the boot is broken or stolen. They'll charge you $50.00 if that happens.

We had a few large pretzels, which were good. But the most delicious item for me was the Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus (Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce). It was so tasty! The outside looks crispy, kind of like hash browns, and the inside is a soft textured, mushy potato.

This restaurant is worth returning to!
author: Perla A.

description:
Shared seating, very good food and selection of beers (try the smoked beer).
Abundant portions.
author: Marco L.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in all of SF. A great place to take people from out of town to show some of the amazingness this city can offer.

Their beers are incredible. The rotating selection of over a dozen taps are all stocked with amazing German beer. Every time I visit I am surprised by their selection. They rival many of the pubs I frequented while living in Dresden.

All beers come in a variety of sizes, even if that isn't listed clearly on the menu. You can order the standard 0.5L mugs, a 1L mas, all they way up to a multi-liter boot. Drinking more than your stomach volume of good german beer is an experience everyone should try at least once.

Their food is also great. After many visits I have sampled a half dozen different entrees off the menu and each has surpassed my expectations. I feel like I am living in Germany again. Everything is perfect and authentic from the meats to the sauce to the tables and silverware.

They are also the hidden gem of Hayes Valley for brunch. You can usually sneak in without having to wait and get to sample their rather large selection of brunch menu items. Couple this with a hefewizen to ward off the hangover and you have the best mid-Saturday meal the neighborhood has to offer.

I love this place and it will continue to be my go to place to take out of towners for dinner and myself for brunch.

Prost!
author: Scott C.

description:
Things You Can Find at Suppenkuche.

1. Wonderfully large boots of delicious German beer.

2. Communal tables full of people enjoying life, which is always better with wonderfully large boots of delicious German beer.

3. Countless people absolutely butchering the pronunciations of many a German word. Most of us because we never knew how, but some because they had too many wonderfully large boots of delicious German beer.

4. Heavy, hearty, tasty food. I loved the bratwurst I had for my meal, and the wiener schnitzel, jagerschnitzel, potato pancakes, German ravioli, spaetzle, oxtails and roast chicken that I either stole from my friends, or finished when they gave up. All these things are best washed down with wonderfully large boots of delicious German beer.

5. The tallest women I've ever seen. Every girl there was a head taller than me. They say everything's bigger in Texas, but I think they meant Germany. I know no Texans that can fit two liters of beer in their boots. I may or may not have commented on the huge women to one of the huge women; my judgment is occasionally questionable when I have drank multiple wonderfully large boots of delicious German beer.

6. A great staff. The host and was appropriately and humorously apologetic for our very German waiter, and the subsequent wait beyond our reservation. That same waiter was hilarious and straightforward, and took a little too much delight in telling us that if we broke the boot, we would owe him $50 or he would owe us five whips. But we didn't have to worry, because there's no way I'd allow anyone at my table to break wonderfully large boots of delicious German beer.

7. Me, every chance I can get. Because I love good food, having fun and, of course, wonderfully large boots of delicious German beer.

Oh, and if a member of your party is a bit germaphobic, and already disgusted that you are passing around a wonderfully large boot of delicious German beer, apparently it is in bad taste to insist that he/she "drink the toes."
author: Peter D.

description: Dear Suppenkuche, We both enjoyed our Weds. evening dinners -- bratwurst plates, great beer.  But I hope you contact a noise expert to find out how you can make the space less loud.  We were sitting very close to each other on a corner of a group table, but my husband and I could not comfortably converse. We just gave up talking and ate in the nearly-painful din. It seems like the noise creates very hard working conditions for the staff, straining to hear the orders, etc. I'm sure it could be improved! We exited with another couple, young people we don't know, and as soon as we were all outside, all of us expressed the wonderful relief of getting out of there. "Loudest restaurant I've ever been to," said the guy. You need to take action on this!
author: Melody C.

description:
I already know I don't like beer, and after eating at Suppenkuche, I'm starting to think I don't like German food.

The onion soup (special of the day) and pretzels were mediocre.

Potato pancakes were crispy crunchy yummy.  This was my favorite, but that's probably because i love all things deep fried.

Got Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes, plus a side of mushroom gravy.  Eh . . . pork sausage was good, sauerkraut was not sour enough, mushroom gravy made the mashed potatoes and gravy super delicious.

Overall, I was underwhelmed, so would have given Suppenkuche 2 stars if it weren't for the top noche service.
author: Christina L.

description:
Decent german food but the menu is pretty hit or miss.   

If you're a beer fan...you'll probably love the place.  All kinds of flavors and sizes of german brews.  

The place is extremely noisy and crowded with an extremely young crowd.  We had a reservation and a large party so we got to sit in the slightly quieter back room.  Had I been in a smaller group there's no way I would have enjoyed sitting in the packed dining room.  Can't even hear yourself think in there.

The pretzel appetizer is pretty good.   The meat loafs (chicken or beef) were both very average.   The spaetzel is terrible.  The potato pancakes are great.  

Food: 2.5/5
Ambiance: 1/5
Service: 4/5
Value: 2/5
Parking: 0/5
author: Lauren D.

description: German food at it's finest.  I had the schnitzel and also my friend (I came here for a bday) gave me the pork knuckle
author: Daniel Y.

description: This place is my new favorite, pickled herring was delicious, meatloaf with bacon and egg was out of this world. Really loud but fun. The beer choice was impressive. Service was great
author: Marshall W.

description:
By far my favorite German Restaurant in SF.

The food is good but dinner can get pricey with drinks.
Portions are a nice size and the bread they serve before the meal is very good.

The beer variety here is good, but it seems to change often, they tend to run out of beers you might want and i've come here and had bad experiences with staff drink recommendations.

I've also come here for brunch and enjoyed it; the prices are a lower (dishes are smaller) and without the alcohol (hopefully you aren't pounding beers in the AM) the bill is decent for a brunch place.

Overall, in my opinion, the best german restaurant in SF.
author: Ayall S.

description:
I LOVE getting my Supp fix. I will try the suckling pig next time as it comes with deliciousness minus the spaetzle. But am still so so pleased with my latest order of braised beef (an oxymoronic safe yet adventurous choice for me).  It was $19. 

..And oh so good!!! I liked how a cinnamon stick was spooned into my serving because I really would've never guessed cinnamon flavored the red cabbage. But anyway, the dish was amazingly good. I loved how egg-y and buttery the spaetzle was and will order something with spaetzle again and again. I appreciated the mixing of the cabbage juice with the marinated braised beef juice. The side of cranberry sauce was smart.

The 'tate pancakes were to die for as well. I really like how thinly they shave each 'tate down to. It makes for like 1/3 of the width of a hash brown. Boys, it be crispy on the outside, and moist on the inside. MM mm mmmm! At $11 for 3 pancakes it may sound a littttle pricey, but it's totally worth it. The boy and I even sopped up the remainder of the apple sauce with, well, our mouths.

As for our imbibes, we got a stiegl and konig. $5 each for 1/2 litres. I was too full to drink most my beer (girl fail) but really appreciate the refined, light taste of mine, the konig. It was golden yellow, not too hoppy, and oh so smooth. 

Plus points to going on a saturday night and only having to wait 20 minutes. (Context: they don't take reservations and parking is a beezie.)

Now GOOOO!
author: Sarah W.

description:
**3.5 stars for Suppenkuche**

I was in town for a conference and decided to try something different. This place was packed, thank god we had a reservation---highly recommend it if you have a big party which we did, there were 10 of us. First off, the service was great. When we were running late, they were very accommodating and held the table for 15 minutes. Then as we slowly trickled in, we ordered the pretzels. Wow....one of the best pretzels ever. It comes with this amazing spread which melts in your mouth. Talk about yummy goodness. 
For the entree, I ordered the venison. This was my first time trying venison so I was a bit scared. The first few bites were great---it was different. I loved the sauces it was in and the pasta like sides. I have to admit, after the first piece of venison (they give you 2 generous piecies), the flavor of the meat got very strong. A bit overwhelming for me, so I stopped there. I think I just didn't like venison but I ate everything else. All in all, good food, except I personally decided I don't like venison, great service, and a trendy spot to grab a drink. The neighborhood is very cute also--there are tons of other restaurants and boutiques nearby.
author: Regina W.

description: So I came here for dinner and the food was very authentic! Only down side to this place which is way it gets 2 stars is the noise.  Dont come here thinking you will have a quiet relaxing dinner.  More noise then a restraint should ever have, even louder then some bars/clubs!
author: Stephen O.

description:
The bartender was friendly. The beer was delicious. The food... omg the food. I will be coming back. :D

Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße and Sauerbraten mit Lingonbeerkonfitüre are fantastic dishes.
author: Dean T.

description:
I like shoes. I like beer. Why wouldn't I like Suppenküche?

A girl never forgets her first beer boot and this right here, was my first. Plus, how much fun is it to say Suppenküche? 

Suppenküüüüüüche.

Das boot was das business. Never had a seen such a glorious, chilled masterpiece. Pete D, Yelp master of Brooklyn claimed ownership of this bad boy, but the rest of the East Coast crew put a nice little dent in it. (Or just took novel pictures as such.)

Did I like that we had to wait a pretty 20 minutes with reservations. No, I didn't. The restaurant is fairly small, so it's an awkwardly tight fit for a large party since you're literally forced to wait in the entry area, hovering over diners if the bar is crowded.

Once seated though, the environment felt much more festive. Or maybe that's what happens with food in your belly and the booze a flowing with an amazing group of folks that feel like family?

The food that I ordered was pretty tasty and hearty, but nothing that I ordered would be something I'd come back for. The Maultaschen in Pilzrahmsoße (German Ravioli filled with Pork and Vegetables, served in Mushroom Sauce) was a tasty and filling for an appetizer. I decided to double up on the appetizers for dinner and also split the potato pancakes as well. Those were particularly delicious; thick, crispy, delicious and served with a side of criss, cross, applesauce.

I would definitely return for the lively and warm atmosphere, beer and bites. Just make sure that you eat a light lunch because you'll need to make plenty of room for Das Boot.
author: Tara L.

description:
I may not pronounce it right, but you know what I can say correctly? 

FIVE STARS. 

Boom. 

Why? 

I just had such a wonderful time. Maybe it was the company. Maybe it was the two huge boots of beer. Maybe it was the hearty German fare. Maybe it was the raucous vibe with sound beams bouncing every which way. Maybe it was the cool June evening, the warm smiles, the stellar service. Potato Pancakes? Possibly. Spaetzle? I actually wasn't a fan, so I drank more beer instead. Carbs for carbs, save a beer's life and drink it. Desserts? On point. 

The real highlight here though is the experience. Sure the food will fill you up (My pork loin was quite good, actually), but what keeps you whole is the company you keep. And well, the company I keep is pretty damn swell. The spot-on service just capped off a great evening, beers remained full, plates whisked in and out...no complaints all evening. 

Add to it a somewhat Spartan interior, a long table for my 11 coolest colleagues, a few boots of beer and a great meal. Well, for about $50 pp (with tip) we all left pretty happy. Great for a group dining experience. 


A couple of notes...

Suppenkuche = "Soup Kitchen" in German. Thank you to my German colleague, Uli B, for the translation. 

Das Boot = "Boot of Beer" in English. Thank you to my colleague, Peter D, for ensuring that we did not have to pay the $50 breakage fee. Ain't nothin' broke 'bout the boots, we just drank it all. True story. 

Potato Pancakes: They are good. If you don't want someone else in your large table eating them before you realized they arrived, ask the server to deliver them directly to you. Ooooops. 

Reservations made for parties 6+. I called a few weeks out and they accommodated and communicated masterfully.

Props to Jane K on the selection...!
author: Colleen C.

description:
I cannot get enough of Suppenkuche! I have gone a handful of times, and each time is better than the last. When I went recently I got their potato pancakes with applesauce, the bacon wrapped asparagus, and to finish, I ordered the cheese spatzle. 

The potato pancakes are great. They have the perfect amount of crunch to them, and with the apple sauce, it is just a wonderful melody of flavors on my tongue. The bacon wrapped asparagus was absolutely delightful. After eating all of that, you can dip the bread that comes with your meal into the cream sauce.

Finally, the cheese spatzle. I am a huge fan of spatzle, it's probably one of my favorite German dishes. They definitely do it right. Perfect amount of cheese, just enough sauce. I had a bit left over, so I took it home, and it reheated perfectly! 

I got a bananaweizen for dessert... come to think of it, I don't know how I was able to walk home.
author: T M.

description:
If you like good German food, good German beer, and a good time... come here.

If you don't like the any of the above, waiting for any of the above, or hearing people loudly enjoy any of the above... don't come here.

Cannot wait to come back.
author: B. B.

description:
When I heard my team dinner would be held at a German restaurant, I wasn't super excited. Despite being 25% German, the only regional fare I had previous experience with was sauerkraut, potatoes and pork. In my mind, German food meant gray mystery sausages.

I learned two things at my dinner at Suppenküche last night. First, ALWAYS trust your Yelp colleagues to lead you to a great meal. Second, German food is delicious!

The Franziskaner was already flowing by the time we received our apps. A plate of potato pancakes was accidentally devoured by my bud Damien* before reaching the end of the table, so we just ordered another round. The wait was well worth it. The patties were like gourmet hashbrowns served alongside a cup of applesauce. Delicious. A soft pretzel wasn't as well-received by me, since I hail from the land of soft pretzels: Philadelphia. 

My entree of sauteed pork in mushroom sauce was supposed to come with spaetzle and a green salad, but being my grandmother's kin, I requested mashed potatoes and sauerkraut instead. It turned out to be a most excellent decision, as the meal tasted like something straight out of my gram's kitchen. So delicious. 

From now on, if a colleague suggests trying a new cuisine, I'm going to shut up and eat. Can't wait to check out the German restaurants in my own city! 


*Do it again and I shank you. Punk.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Totally amazing! This place was fun, loud and good!! It's family style seating so if you're not comfortable with sitting at a table with people you don't know then this place ain't for you. We came in and there was a 45 min wait but we got seated within 20 mins. The bartender was so helpful in helping us choose the right beer and it was gooddddddd.
The food is delicious. Potato pancakes? Yes please! Sausages? Hell yes! I could not find one thing wrong with this place.
author: Andrea A.

description:
I suppose it was a mistake for me to come here without the intent to consume large amounts of beer with a huge group of friends, but this place did not impress me one bit. 

Maybe I just have no appreciation for German food, but I thought the food was mediocre. According to the menu, this is what I ate:
Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße
mit Spätzle und grünem Salat $18.50
Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce
served with Spätzle & Green Salad

wat.
 
Normally I'm all for crazy sounding new food adventure... and the mushroom sauce was pretty good, but the porkloin was really just barely ok and the meal overall was very much not worth the $18.50 I paid for it. The spazle is something like a chip made of unsweetened pancake batter splattered over the stove and scraped off. The salad was also edible but not worth my time or money. I also ordered a lemonade beer, which was not as sweet or lemonade-y as I had hoped. It was drinkable. If I ever have to come back here, I just want to get the pretzel an cheese and hopefully that won't be so blah.
author: C K.

description:
No matter how you pronounce it, Suppenkuche is a winner!  Friends told me about going for some German food which intrigued me.  When they told me about drinking beer from a huge boot and I was sold!

Suppenkuche is a great corner place which does not seat very man people, so go early even if you are going just to drink beer because the bar area gets super swamped, and there will be a line to get in.  We lucked out by getting in a few minutes after they opened on a late Saturday afternoon.  Our party of 4 shared a table with a wonderful group of experienced diners and helped us choose entrees, and filled us in on some culture.

Our boot of dunkle beer came and we were in awe of the TWO WHOLE LITERS OF BEER! Of course we all had to take a picture of ourselves drinking the ice cold goodness, which hit the spot on such a hot day. Yes, the four of us split the boot, maybe on another day I would consider sharing with only one person, but we were already all one pint in from somewhere else.  Our food came out in an instant and it was all very very good, and rich, and I wanted more of it all!  I had one of their specials, which was a quarter chicken in gravy, which was moist inside and crispy outside, with two potato cakes which were like two hash brown patties but super crunchy.  My fiancee had pork stuffed cabbage rolls also in some kind of gravy, and mashed potatoes. Everything was in German, but had descriptions in English.  My other friend had some pork something with their homemade sauerkraut, which was AMAZEBALLS, and my other friend had pork in mushroom gravy with spatzle, also really really good.  Dishes had plenty of food to gorge yourself on and range from $12 to over $20 depending on your fancy.

I wish there were places that had offerings like Suppenkuche in my area, but there isn't, I can only dream.
author: Scott F.

description:
Legit German food and beer. Yes please. I got a German beer and my girl decided to get a banana beer? I'm not sure who came up with that one but it totally worked and was pretty tasty. We both got a pint of each and were sipping in no time. We came on a Friday night and the place was busy but they were cycling tables pretty quickly so we got to seat in there in less than 20 minutes. 

The place reminds you of a tavern or something where you go and sit together with all your friends on some wooden tables and just all hang out. The seating is like that, no individual tables, just a bunch of big tables that they seat everyone in where they can fit you so you won't get a romantic, intimate atmosphere from that. Our waiter was this guy with a heavy German accent and he explained all the beers and helped us find something we would like, I loved the choice he made for me. 

We ended up getting the potato cakes which is almost a hash brown but really crunchy. It comes with an applesauce and the mixture seems weird but works well with each other. The crunch and starch of the potato mixed with the little sweetness of the applesauce complimented each other perfectly. Some bits were a little burnt so maybe an issue with consistency but it was tasty nonetheless. I then ordered the brats and my girl got the schnitzel that comes with a side of spatzel. The sausages were the best German sausages I've ever had. It came with sauerkraut and mashed potato and some spicy mustard and I was in heaven. It's essentially a sausage plate instead of putting the whole package on the bun but it was so damn good. I'm thinking about it right now and my mouth is watering. My girl's schnitzel was breaded well and cooked well but the sauce was just a tad on the salty side but I love me some salt but the girl was not a fan. The spatzel was also cooked perfectly and the whole package made me feel like I was in Germany during Oktoberfest or something. 

The portions are BIG so we were so full after food and beer that we decided to pass on dessert. Great place to come grab some food, beer and hang out at the bar. I will be a repeat customer for sure.
author: Jeromy G.

description:
The thing I love most about this place is the ambiance. The workers (and even the patrons) are so friendly. Every time I go, no matter how busy, everyone is having a great time and joking with each other, even strangers. I love Leopold's so much, but I do like the feel of this place more. 

The beer selection is great and the food is excellent. I love the chicken with potato pancakes, as well as the schnitzel and jagerschnitzel dishes. Dooo ittttttt.
author: Kelly B.

description:
I love Suppenküche, and have been going there for 15 years, and always enjoyed it.

Until tonight.

There were 3 tables with toddlers around 3 years old there.  One table had twin blonde toddler girls; a cook or waiter (unsure) came out to greet them and hugged one of the women at the table, so I guess they knew him.

In any case, what are kids that young doing in a beer-soaked German restaurant?  I've always gone there because it was a place where I could enjoy an adult time - good hearty meal, hearty beers, general boisterousness from the crowd, quite jolly.

But the toddlers at the various tables - who's screeches of joy I could hear above the general din of the bar - should not have been there.  The parents accompanying them seemed oblivious, and thought the antics of the kids - jumping on the benches, playing little games, and the aforementioned screeching - were oh-so-darling.

Me - not so much.

If Suppenküche has started to be invaded by the hipster parent "our kids should be welcomed everywhere" set, I may be spending less time there.

Jesus, Suppenküche management - what are you thinking?
author: Tim B.

description:
This place is all good...hands down.  It can get super busy at any given time, brunch and dinner I've found to be the most insane seating wise but it's always fun to see who you end up sitting next to. If they are friendly, do they hog the communal jam during brunch or gladly share.  This place is loud but laughter is in the mix.  Food is very good, never been disappointed with the staples I get, the apple pancakes, the Jägerschnitzel.  The omelet with pasta for bunch is quite good, ask them to bring a side of their mustard - YUM!  You have to give this place a chance once, but don't come here if you are planning like an intimate first date, you're not gonna get that vibe. Bring for a fun date or a wonderful family dinner.

OK, listen...if you want a more home style quiet but cool (ok super cool) place to have German and you can't get into this place for whatever reason go to Walzwerk.  Chances are you will have to wait there too but maybe instead of 45 minutes it might be 40.  TRY BOTH!
author: Zin M.

description:
LOVE this place.

Roasted chicken with potato pancakes was unbelievable. The chicken was perfectly seasoned and juicy (and huge). It was close to the best roasted chicken I had at Oktoberfest in Munich (the Okto chicken was less juicy but saltier/crispier skin). Came with big, thick, super crunchy (but not oily) potato pancakes. It's not standard pub food, this is a legit restaurant.

Beer - predictably awesome German selection.

Main downside is the wait is ridiculous and no reservations. We came at like 5pm on a Saturday, had only 6 of our 8 there, and had to wait about an hour for a table. On the bright side they have a decent bar you can stand at and drink while waiting.

If I lived in Hayes Valley, I'd be lined up at 5pm every weekend.
author: Adam W.

description:
I'm a huge beer snob and this place has a fantastic German focused beer selection. Seasonal and select brews are rotated through regularly to give patrons tons of options.

On the food side, I know everyone loves the potato pancakes but the pork chops are also incredible. The chop was perfectly cooked and wasn't dried out. The chops are thick cut, moist and juicy. I also thought the Bar Staff was incredibly helpful and attentive. I'll be back a lot
author: Justin O.

description:
Great German food in the city.
Who would've though.
Drink a beer from a boot to the cheers on a weekend night.
author: Richard S.

description:
I have to say I was a little dissaponted. I had been lookng forward to going here for a few years now and finally my family (a party of 13- 9 adults ordered) went here last night for my 53rd birthday.

We arrived a few minutes before our 6pm reservation. We were told our table would be ready in five minutes. 15 minutes later we were seated. As we were seated, the hostess wispered that there would be a second seating a 8pm and we should have plenty of time to eat. What The Hell Is With That?  Now we are rushed to get the overbusy staff to get us our dinners, drinks, and deserts in time to try to relax on this special event before being bum rushed out the door as our seats have been promiced to other diners. If I kad known this was going to happen I would not have had our three families drive to SF. A bit of a buzz kill.

Food was good but I have had as good with better portion sizes and much better service and price  at  DJs Bistro in Concord. Looking forward to getting back here. 

SupenKuche  has  a great beer selection ( main reason I chose them) but the waitress kept forgetting to bring our drinks, making us reorder. If you know me (and you are lucky if you do :-) I order by the liter or pitcher when I go out to avoid this experience. The waitress did apologise but a beer on the house was probably in order.

I might go back if someone offers to pick up the tab. $275 and getting dinged with that crappy  manditory % 18 tip since we had the nerve to bring too many diners-  leans me against making another trip from the East Bay to SuppenKuche.
author: Chad P.

description:
Das Essen ist Wunderbar!
Oh man oh man, I have been waiting years (no lie) to get into this spot. All I hear about is the amazing food and beers....well Suppenkuche did not dissapoint. Granted it took about an 1 hour and some change to get it but just head down the street for a starter cocktail at Two Sisters and you'll be fine. It's worth the wait...believe me.

I ended up getting pork and veggie dumplings in a mushroom sauce...delicious.
The potato pancakes though...yummm....I could have eaten a whole plate by myself. The restaurant itself is a no frills type of joint. wooden tables, utensils in a jar on the table, limited decorations...makes it all the more authentic. I am excited to go back!
author: Eva C.

description:
The atmosphere in this place can be best described as "Biergarden"! benches form the bulk of seating with heavy hewn wood tables that remind one of quaffing beers and apple brandy in Bavaria! Communal seating is the norm here, so don;t be surprised to be seated next to folks with an empty chair(s) or having people be seated next to you.  Service is always friendly, efficient and accommodating (like making something vegetarian for someone in a group we sat next to!).     The schnitzel is light, crispy on the outside with perfectly tender and juicy meat inside ..be it the chicken or pork! All this needs is a gentle squeeze of lemon and you are good to go.  It does not hurt that they serve fabulous mashed potatoes and a side, crazy good cabbage and cucumber salad.  Bread dumplings are the right amount of heavy,  saurbraten is perfectly seasoned and cooked with a a panche that balances sweet-sour flavors very well with the meatiness of the beef.  This is solid German cooking meant to be enjoyed with groups of friends on a cold day.

 A small but very well designed wine and beer list round out the gustatory delights in this place.
author: Sunay P.

description: I was happy to find out the ratings were accurate on the beer AND food here. The Jagerschnitzel was delicious, especially the pan-seared looking pasta lol. Just saw the menu, it's called spatzle... YUM!
author: Thomas P.

description:
This place is crazily crowded and it's very dark in a cave type of environment. maybe that's what they're looking for. it's just very hard to get the waitor's attention. 

the potato pancake was good, the snitzel was good, but other things are just mediocre to me. also, the beer was huge.
author: Ashley C.

description:
I love the communal atmosphere! At Suppenkuche, they ask you to share tables of 6 or 8, or else sit bar-style in a tiny alcove.  Beware, this doesn't mean you should bring large groups unless you come exactly when they open or want to wait! My friend and I came at 5:10 on a Sunday, and it was completely full by 5:20, and rightly so. The servers were very nice and helpful and not pushy at all, which I always appreciate. Hostess was also accommodating and patient. 

Some dishes were definitely better than others. I wasn't a huge fan of the potato bread and leek (?) butter. The sausage was pretty good, but I have never had particularly memorable sausage. However, the mashed potatoes were absolutely perfect! Just wish they came with some gravy. My issue with German food is meat and potatoes gets old after the 10th bite. And the green salad is just five pieces of lettuce, haha.
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
Suppenkuche is quickly becoming my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. After dining here 5 times and ordering something different every time, I can say with confidence that this place absolutely ROCKS. 

The food alone is enough to make me come back for more, but what I really LOVE about this restaurant is the ambiance. With the communal dining, intimate lighting, and endless beer on tap, you are guaranteed to have a good time. With luck, your neighbor might challenge you to a boot race... And if you're like me, you win that boot race like a freaking CHAMP. 

A special shout out to the bartender, Rusty. He is a total sweetheart and always greets us warmly! He waited on us once and has remembered us ever since. It's always a highlight seeing his smiling face! 

Thanks Rusty and everyone else at Suppenkuche for always showing us an amazing time!
author: Nina B.

description: It's not Germany, but the food is still really good. I'd give it four stars easily for food and services. But there is usually a long wait, and it's deafening inside from all the shouty bros. I heard there is a regular shuttle between Marina and here.
author: K T.

description: Growing up in the midwest, I never really acquired a taste for German food. The problem as I found out is that it's all bland in the midwest. Imagine my surprise when I tried SuppenKuche for the first time and realized even spaetzle had flavor. Everything here is amazing, and this is my all-time favorite german dining experience. I'm not a beer person, but they seem to have a good selection. It's out of the way, but I recommend the trek to have some great german food.
author: Eric H.

description:
Great German food that is full of flavor and not just a bunch of fried meat covered in varying types if gravies.

Our party of 12 all enjoyed our dishes, beer and the Black Forest cake. Our server was busy as hell but still gave us attention and was upfront by telling us to feel free to just grab him if needed.  

I was disappointed that San Franciscans aren't aware of what Das Boot is all about :( 

Das Boot is actually a drinking game, not intended to be drunk all alone!

Rules:
1. Drink a sip and pass to your left
2. Must flick glass before passing, or you have to drink again
3. The boot is never to touch the table till empty
4. If the boot touches the table, the person who puts it down drinks
5. If you get splashed upon your turn, you must drink again
6. Whoever finishes the boot buys the next boot of beer

It's so fun and a great ice breaker if not everyone in your group knows each other! I hope next time this place puts the rules on their drink menu or on the wall. Other than that the atmosphere was wonderful, close and loud, you make friends fast with all the good food and beer floating around :) loved that we got to know our neighboring tables a bit!
author: Lauren R.

description:
I know German food mainly from brief visits across the border from Czech Republic when renewing my student visa back in the day (you had to renew it *outside* Czech Republic, and the Czech embassy in Dresden was the closest option). But my partner spent a summer in Bonn & Frankfort. Based on our experience, the food at Suppenküche is very authentically German, as was the hostess who seated us. 

We've only been here once, for brunch, but will probably be back soon. My partner had the Kaiserschmarrn, a baked pancake that was fluffy and only very slightly eggy, sliced up and served with applesauce, plum compote, raisins, and bananas (it was a special; the regular Kaiserschmarrn doesn't have the bananas or the plum compote). The plum compote in fact tasted the way Czech povidla is supposed to taste but never does, and reminded me of my Czech-German grandmother's plum sauce: tart, tangy, full of plum flavor. 

I had the Jägerschnitzel (hunter's schnitzel), which I love and can only rarely find.  Classically Jägerschnitzel is made with a veal cutlet, sauteed or breaded and fried, served with a mushroom & wine sauce. I have had better in Vienna, but mainly because I like the heartier version with red wine and caramelized onions. Suppenküche makes theirs with a white wine sauce and light on the onions--also sauteed without breading. It was tender, tasty, full of mushroom flavor and the delicate veal cutlet. The spätzle on the side were perfectly done as well, tender and slightly buttery. It came with a salad of butter lettuce with an oniony vinaigrette. 

Suppenküche has an impressive selection of German beers, both bottled and draft. They also have a number of German soft drinks, including redcurrant and elderberry juices and sodas. 

The only downside to our experience must be noted: at one end of the dining room was a table of about a dozen people, mostly in their 20s, who were louder than I have ever heard in a normal restaurant--loud to the point that people next to us were commenting on it. When they were paying, one of the men walked across the dining room to clarify something with the server, and then literally screamed the answer across the length of the dining room to his friends. I can only hope that they are not regulars, and they did not appear in any way to represent the normal tone or volume of the restaurant.
author: Cage H.

description:
My only disappointment with this place was that I did not come here sooner, because I have been missing out all these years. So THIS is German food. I am in love. The beer was awesome and different. The food was amazing, definitely the best German food I have had and then some. I am stuffed and making plans to return. Awesome jams if you come for breakfast, great pretzels. I had the Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße
mit Spätzle und Grünem Salat and that was amazing. The people are so nice. The patrons were super nice the servers were super nice and the owner was super nice. Wonderful service. All around such a happy experience.
author: Sasha D.

description:
There's not enough good things to say about this place. Not a ton of the typical Bavarian gimmicks, not pretentious, and just overall delightful. 

I arrived with a couple friends. The hostess was hard to identity and track down at first (place was bustling with people), but after I did, she was a sweetheart and after a beer at the bar, a seat had already opened for us. The ambience is great -- though, I might add, it can be super noisy, so don't be afraid to raise your voice ha. The food was fun... I've frequented a couple other German restaurants in SF, and this was my favorite so far (doesn't hurt that it's in Hayes Valley). Wiener schnitzel, pork chops, meat loaf, potato pancakes, spaetzel, homemade pretzels.... Our table was beautifully adorned. The company, drinks, conversation and great food made our visit memorable, and the first of many more. Prost!
author: James S.

description:
Like many SF establishments, this place is tiny but the food is amazing! I've heard about Suppenkuch because they serve the Das Boot (my gfs love to drink) but never knew they served such delicious food. Came here on a tues night and it was a packed house! We waited about 25 mins for a seat (make sure you let them know your entire party is there or else they will skip you). Not sure why but the hostess assumed my bf was alone so she didn't seat us until we followed up with her. Anywho, the seating is communal so you will share tables. I wasn't thrilled with the seating arrangement at first but it actually turned out fine; we had plenty of room, but I had to try really hard not to eavesdrop on other's conversations...

Onto the food, the potatoe pancakes are SOO GOOOD. They were crispy on the outside and soft inside and not too greasy. They also went very well with the applesauce. I LOVE potatoes so I might be a little bit bias but the potatoe pancakes are a must get in my book, so good! We also had the sausage and pork chop dishes and both were very delicious, super flavorful and not too salty. I also really liked their sauerkraut! Wash it all down with some beer and you got yourself a super tasty dinner. The portions were hefty as well. 

Service was kind of lacking but nothing to complain about. Delicious food at a reasonable price. I think we spent about $70 for appetizer, 2 entrees and 2 beers? I will definitely be back, and I will definitely get the potato pancakes!!
author: Kim N.

description:
A true Bavarian corner kneipe in San Francisco.  My friend and I went on a Saturday evening and there was an hour wait.  The time flies at the bar with friendly patrons and bartenders who were attentive, informative and friendly.  
My parents are German with a home in Germany and I can tell you the food is authentic and delicious.  I ordered a jagerschnitzel with mushroom sauce. It was delicious.  My friend had potato pancakes and chicken and she was also thrilled.  
You need to try the apple strudel and ask the bartenders their advice on beers.
The place is packed and cozy with a lot of friendly community tables.
Mixed age groups. Everyone is welcome.
author: Natascha G.

description:
Darn near Oktoberfest... so I better get on it and review Suppenküche - one of my fave German restaurants in the Bay Area.  I ALMOST give it 5 stars, but any German Restaurant is going to have an unfair disadvantage with my reviews... as my Mother-In-Law's Sauerbraten und Spätzle has set the standard - and it really cannot be touched! ;)

This place is a blast, though.  Classic Bavarian family style dining.  You're going to meet new people here, and eat along side them.  If that makes you uncomfortable, I recommend just ordering another fine brew... you'll loosen up! Ha!  

Food is darn good. My favorite dish is the Venison (Gebratene Rehmedaillions) - it melts in your mouth & tastes unbelievable!  The Sauerbraten is okay - but tougher/drier than I like... just go with the Venison, you will not be disappointed.

The Potato Pancakes are good, but I actually prefer the Pretzel with that super yummy cheesy dip (forget the name - but it is SO classic Bavarian!).  

Every single dessert I have ever had here is Schuhplattler Slappin' good! Seriously - they will blow you away! The Black Forrest Cake is pure heaven.

Parking is a bear & this place gets super busy. My recommendation? Get there early for dinner - around 4:30pm. Go across the street for a Happy Hour Beer, if ya want (little café has coffee, tea, beer, wine) & watch 'till they open the door.  Worked great - no wait time.

Tip #2 - Check their web site! Lots of fun stuff goes on there! Oktoberfest celebrations (9/21/13 this year), Gnome Week (how can you NOT love that??), and more!
author: Reena R.

description:
This place has simply become ridiculous.  For the past 10 years this has been my all time favorite restaurant, until my last visit.  I've had great experiences here in the past, with a fun and social environment, great beer, good German food, what's not to like?

We recently tried to take an out of town friend here, and after years of explaining how awesome this place was to her I was truly embarrassed.  We waited nearly two hours to be seated after initially being told it would take only one, and continually were told it would be another 15 minutes when we asked an hour in.

The family style seating is one of the fun things about this place, but also its achilles heal.  Since there were 3 of us we continually watched party after party who had put their names in AFTER us be seated in front of us; as explained by the hostess this is because they filled the capacity of the table more efficiently.  Apparently their seating policy is to fill the table to capacity first, and secondary is the order in which you put your name in.  Fair?  Sure didn't feel like it to me after watching this for nearly two hours.

The food this time was good, but not great like it has been in the past.  I usually get the schnitzel which they do very well, but this time it was quite salty and not as hot and fresh as usual.  Potato pancakes were also not as hot and crunchy as they have been in the past.

I'm not sure if I'll be back.  Perhaps if I get there before they open to insure I don't go through this again, I might try it once more.  I wouldn't dare getting here after 5:30 PM.
author: Derek W.

description:
Coming back from a trip to Berlin we failed to find to find and drink a das boot. Whether it's a bastardized American perception of German culture, we didn't care and needed to fulfill our destiny with the glass boot. 67 ounces of sweet golden German pilsner later, our mission was complete. And then we proceeded to knock back a couple more boots. Schroeder's is another favorite in my city, but there's something about the warm, cozy, (cramped, sweaty) atmosphere of Suppenkuche that makes the experience all so unique.

That said, logistically this place is a mess to get a reservation. I'd definitely recommend getting a group of 6 or more and making a reservation. Otherwise be prepared to wait around an hour to two hours for a table. Weekend nights this is definitely typical. Still, it's worth the wait to me. I'll be back for you das boot.
author: Brian L.

description:
I've come to the conclusion that I am just not a huge fan of German food. It seems slightly... one dimensional to me? Not there's anything wrong with sausages and potatoes, but I think I get bored after awhile. That being said, I still think Suppenkuche is very good, for what it is. Definitely much better than some other German food I've had.

A large group of my friends stopped in for brunch. We were able to snag a table for ourselves with not too much of a wait time. While I am not completely opposed to communal seating, I can definitely see how sharing that cramped table with a bunch of strangers could detract from the experience. 

I ordered the jagerschnitzel, which I thought was very flavorful and tasty. The mushroom gravy on top was delicious. I also tried some of the potato cakes, which were good, but I'm not sure why everyone is raving so much about them. It's still exactly what it sounds like... cakes of potato. I love potato, but this isn't something to get so starry eyed about.

I'd probably just want to come back to try my hand at Das Boot. But otherwise, I won't be yearning to come back here anytime soon.
author: Sally T.

description:
My friend wanted to come here solely for the boot, which is 2 liters of beer.

A few of us came here on a weeknight and the wait was going to be around an hour. We decided to get a drink somewhere else because the bar was so packed. We went back about 45 minutes and our table was ready.

We decided to split 3 entrees and got the potato pancake as an appetizer. We ordered the pork chop, pork loin with mushroom sauce and a sausage special. Everything was so delicious. The potato pancake is like a hash brown...but much crispier. All the meat dishes were so flavorful and tender. 

My friend did finish the boot...it was kind of painful to watch.
author: Terry C.

description:
This place is memorable because of the name. How often can I say I ate at a place call "Suppenküche"? I searched the name on Google and it means "soup kitchen". Not as cool once you translate in English. 

I came here during brunch and ordered the Emperor's Pancake with brandied raisins, served with apple & plum compote. It was rather yummy in my mouth. The pancakes was cut up and semi-drenched in the compote and with the apple and plum compote, it provides a sweet and sour taste. At first glance, it looks like old-people mushy food but go ahead and take a bite! After this meal, it might even convince you to eat more mushy food. Well...maybe.

What makes this place neat and kind of not neat is the limited seating. With few seating areas, you can share a table with strangers. This is a fun way to socialize with the other guests because you may be seated next to an older couple who dresses quite trendy for their age (red-frame glasses and a faux mo-hawk!) or nearby a dude with the bluest eye ever. But if you would rather not  then you'll have to wait for a bit. Suppenküche is a busy place but worth the wait if you want something uniquely different.

P.S. Did I mentioned they served beer in a boot? Ooo...
author: Vicky L.

description:
All I remember was having a couple of really good beers, one of which was the Erdinger Dunkel.  And the only reason I remember the Erdinger Dunkel is because I kept saying to fellow Yelper PNotHere E. that Erdinger Dunkel sounds like a name Frodo would give to his weenis.  

Oh, and they have really good sauerkraut.
author: Joc V.

description: Having been an expat living in Switzerland this place was delicious and brought back fond memories of living in a German speaking nation. En guete!
author: DeMarus A.

description: I really want to like this place - the atmosphere is very gemütlich (cozy), and the menu looks inviting. However, I've now eaten here three times, and the food just isn't very good. I should also mention that I've spent 6 years in Austria/Germany, and was really excited to discover this cute, Hayes Valley German spot...but excitement has turned into disappointment. Third time, same lack-luster food!
author: Michel P.

description:
Let me first say, the food was phenomenal, some of the best German food I have ever had, and it was also brought out very quickly. I had the Sauerbraten with Späetzle, Red Cabbage, and Sauerkraut, while my girlfriend got the Cheese Späetzle and we split Potato Pancakes. Everything tasted great! and that is the reason this get's a 4 star review, because the service was not as great. 

It was very crowded which is no problem, it just shows they have a good business. My girlfriend and I are both young adults (19-20), we had waited for over an hour for a seat, and they continually gave away tables to people further down on the wait list. I think it was because they were adults, but whatever. Another thing that irked me was the two older couples sitting next to us were given bread before their meal complimentary and waited on immediately, while we did not receive the same treatment. I don't feel we shouldn't get the same treatment just because we are younger. Regardless, I would recommend this place, the food is great, just make sure to have a reservation, and to be very upfront with the staff, they are a nice/friendly staff, they just overlooked us a lot.
author: Jonah G.

description:
I came here with a large group and we ordered two of everything on the menu. My favorite was the schnitzel, complemented perfectly with the butter lettuce salad. I think there was also something potato-y that I liked but when don't I like potato? 

Tips:
- Entrees are HUGE so try to share. I think 2 entrees for 3 people is a perfect ratio. 
- Try the many beers! There is a shortage of boots so you might want to get there early or tell your waiter right away if you want a boot. 
- It gets VERY crowded so come early and try to make a reservation.
- The neighborhood isn't all that dandy so if coming at night make sure you have a buddy to walk with to the car.
author: Jenny J.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal here...

I had their Wiener schnitzel and it was very good: savory and slightly juicy for being fried pork.  It arrived with a small side salad and some tasty potatoes cooked with some small bacon pieces to give it a nice saltiness and smokiness.

They had some unique sodas and I had the Lychee, which was good.

Suppenküche has some great food items and a nice lively German-pub atmosphere...I can definitely see why it's so popular.
author: Ken G.

description: Amazing beer selection and delicious/authentic german food. Small and packed but seated us quicker than expected. Community tables allowed us to meet new friends. Loved our time there!
author: Garrett R.

description:
Way to go Suppenkuche. You have removed my negative review for the second time and did not have the decency to respond to my letter addressed to owner/general manager detailing the whole terrible experience.  Do you have video inside your establishment? I suspect you do and could verify every word in my letter.
Where is your management and why don't they care?
author: kathy b.

description: Excellent food and service. A wonderful experience for the family. Venison was melt in your mouth tasty. Mmmmmmmmm potato cakes.  Wiener Schnitzel terrific. Beautifully seasoned Farmers Bratwurst. German Ravioli filled with Pork and Vegetables served with Mushroom Sauce, amazing!
author: Jeanne H.

description:
Who doesn't love a good sausage fest? (And I don't just mean the Urban Dictionary definition of the term...)

I came here for brunch (no lines!) while my mom was visiting and, despite the warning from our server, way over-ordered. (He actually said "no" when I asked if I could order a 4th dish. He stopped objecting after that.) With so many sausages on their menu I had a hard time choosing. So I got them all! Well, most of them anyway. To make it a more balanced meal, we got some non-meat items too.

Before I get into the food I gotta mention their SAUERKRAUT. Suppenkuche makes my favourite sauerkraut I've had outside of Germany--not too acidic and soft without being mushy. (I'm not a fan of crunchy kraut). It just kinda dissolves onto whatever food you put it on. If you order it on the side it also comes with cubes of braised pork meat/fat, so it's NSFV (not safe for vegetarians). I gobbled up two orders of this stuff with all the sausages!

*3 SMALL BRATWURST (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/DGyoVB9PdI9_jw0CNi_OPg?select=-MpLUN6oyp7QmsUMFUJlEQ): These were small, indeed. (Imagine 3 long skinny fingers.) The texture wasn't as fine as I'd expected but they were still plenty flavourful. Perfect for pairing with their fantastic sauerkraut!

*WEIßWURST - WHITE VEAL & PORK SAUSAGES IN BUTTER BROTH WITH PRETZEL (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/DGyoVB9PdI9_jw0CNi_OPg?select=4d9SHiKni5ikl1HJ7NUljw): My favourite of the sausages. (And great with kraut!) The white sausages were plump and moist with a really fine texture. Milder in flavour than the bratwurst but the texture totally won me over. Very comforting--like the congee of sausages. I also enjoyed the way the casing "popped" as I cut into it. The pretzel was also very good but the butter broth was way too salty to actually drink.

*20CM FRANKFURTER SAUSAGE: Ordered as a side, this didn't look quite as impressive since they cut it into two 10cm-long sausages. It was tasty, but nothing all that special. (Unless, of course, you eat it with the sauerkraut!)

*BAVARIAN MEATLOAF WITH EGGS & ROASTED POTATOES (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/DGyoVB9PdI9_jw0CNi_OPg?select=Ju7PE1kvIRdFdPqU3xqdYg): Not quite a sausage but still a processed meat item. The meatloaf reminded me of spam (which I love) but more refined and with a finer texture. It had some bounce to it and tasted great with the sunny side eggs and sauerkraut. The roasted potatoes were pretty yummy too.

*GERMAN RAVIOLI SCRAMBLED WITH EGGS & ONIONS (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/DGyoVB9PdI9_jw0CNi_OPg?select=We8wHUPgVxvWx0RiPFEmwQ): A very hearty and flavourful egg scramble with cut up pieces of ravioli and slivered onions mixed in. I loved it, especially topped with some kraut. The light and refreshing cucumber salad provided a nice balance too.

*EMPEROR'S PANCAKE WITH BRANDIED RAISINS (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/DGyoVB9PdI9_jw0CNi_OPg?select=sCSMFRwBiRPiplCadbuuOQ): This comprised of cut up pancake pieces loaded with raisins and dusted with powdered sugar. The pancake was of a thinner variety but still very moist. The raisins added sweetness and the apple sauce was the perfect accompaniment.

*APPLE STRUDEL WITH VANILLA ICE CREAM (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/DGyoVB9PdI9_jw0CNi_OPg?select=-GG_djHCUlxStRWDVEVILA): This would've been a lot better if the strudel was warmed and the crust was crispy. I liked the filling loaded with thinly sliced apples though.
author: Steph L.

description:
Suppenkuche is something of an institution, at least based on the number of reviews it has received here on Yelp.  And to sum up my opinion concisely, the place is OK.  Now bear in mind that beer is not my thing, heavy food is not my thing, and uncomfortable bench seating is decidedly not my thing.  

We got an array of appetizers and the highlight was certainly the potato pancakes.  These were perfectly fried and not at all greasy.  The warm pretzels likewise were good.  Everything else fell into the just OK category for me.

Split pea soup with sausage was ample but the sausage was tasteless and the soup had no taste of peas.  Other than that it was perfect.

A main of lamb chops came with brussels sprouts and mashed potatoes.  The brussels sprouts were the stars of the plate as they had been perfectly cooked through. The chops and potatoes were OK.

I took a taste of someone else's wiener schnitzel.  It was heavy but not greasy.  

This is the kind of food that requires alcohol of one sort or another and as I rarely drink it was not my thing.  But most other people will have a good time here.
author: David D.

description: Best meal of my life twice in a row. Everything is glorious. Eat here. Incredible beer, incredible food, little things, like the herb butter and dark bread they served before the food came out, the heavy steins, the birds hanging from the ceiling, good service...really made the experience great.
author: Sam S.

description: First time trying germany food with my family.  Got there a little passed 5 and it's already packed.  Staff was friendly.  Love the beer.  I got the meatloaf and my husband got the pig and both are very tasty.  Would definitely go back.
author: Crissy C.

description: The food is amazing and a good beer selection. My only complaints are that you always have to wait for a table and it can get very loud inside. The jäger schnitzel is by far my favorite and the asparagus wrapped in bacon is to die for.
author: Alexa L.

description:
This place is not for you if you don't like beer and/or don't like sharing a table with strangers.

I'm all of the above and the food itself just isn't good enough for me to come back.

They don't have a full bar and all their tables are communal. We waited half an hour for a table and we come to find ourselves sitting at a corner of a table shared by two other parties.

It's a pretty noisy place so it's not a place to go if you want to have a conversation. And even if you are ok with the noise, you won't have any privacy.

The food is fine but like I said earlier, the food itself is not good enough to bring me back. Their wiener schnitzel taste like tonkatsu, their cured pork chop taste like ham and their spätzle taste like mac and cheese. I'm not saying there's anything wrong with tonkatsu, ham or mac and cheese, but this would not be the place I would go for that kind of food.

Suppenküche is not for me.
author: Andy W.

description:
Always a good time coming here.  Started with a side salad (of beets, shredded carrots, cabbage) - it was colorful and flavorful and pretty big for 1 person.  I probably could've called it quits, but a girl needs meat.  And the wild boar sausage was calling my name.  Served with Spätzle and Sauerkraut.  The Spätzle was ok.  Felt like it was needing more salt.  The Sauerkraut was fresh - definitely not the overly sour stuff you find at a baseball game.  The winner of the plate was the wild boar.  Yummers!

If possible, come early cause the place fills up quickly, especially if you're bringing a large party.  Oh, and if you don't like noisy places, bring ear plugs.  You'll need it as the acoustics promotes a very lively atmosphere.
author: Anonymouse C.

description: I think what drew me to this place was that they have venison.  I think the sauce is a little heavy and overpowered but overall the venison was good and the spaetzle was YUM!  One bad thing about this place is the noise.  If you are looking for a place to talk...you won't be using your inside voice.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
I had high hopes for this place and maybe it was just an off night *shrugs*

We sat at the bar and will not do that again if I don't have to.  I like to be served.  If you are looking for a casual bar atmosphere with self service then sit at the bar.  It will get crowded and loud so it's not the most comfortable space to eat at (the counter space is small).

We had the ravioli which was not appealing to me.  The mushroom sauce was superb, but the pasta itself was more like a dumpling with dense filling. The filling wasn't flavorful.

Of course my meal would not be complete without potatoe pancakes and apple sauce.  I was really disappointed that two out of three of my pancakes came out burnt on the outside and the apple sauce was nothing spectacular.

So I know you're probably wonder why it's getting 3 stars.....well the spatzle saved it.  My entree was the jagersnitzel served with spatzle and a green salad.  I hardly touched the green salad because the leaves were so big I just didn't feel like working my way through it.  The porkloin was a little overcooked, but the mushroom sauce saved it.  The highlight of the night was the spatzle!  The texture and flavor was perfect!  It was light, but had substance.  It was heaven when I drenched each one in creamy buttery mushroom sauce.

I would come back to give it another shot, but I wouldn't be in a hurry to come back any time soon with so many other German restaurants to try out.
author: Michelle S.

description: Great atmosphere, friendly people. Love the community tables and meeting new people while you have a beer.
author: Jack A.

description:
I really really really really really really really really wanted to like this place. I've heard only good things, the menu seemed good, and I had high hopes. I knew it was communal seating, and I am NOT a big fan of that kind of thing, but I thought maybe the food would be so good I wouldn't notice how uncomfortable sharing a table with other people and being forced to to basically eat with them would be. 

What I ordered was pretty bland and mostly starch on top of starch. I ordered eggs over-easy and it was written on the menu that it came with bread dumplings and sausage. What I actually got is not what I pictured from what I read on the menu. What I got was one over-easy egg that was done more medium (really didn't like that) served over 2 gigantic bland mushy pancakes made of something (I guess bread? I pictured small round dumplings, as described on the menu), and it was on top of a ton of fried potatoes and two small breakfast sausages, which I didn't like. 

The coffee was okay, except it kept getting cold fast. The service was super nice, I really loved our waiter. Absolutely no issues with him whatsoever. My husband ordered potato pancakes, but he wasn't really happy with them. Everything came out to about $30 which I thought was pretty high.

Also, if you come here, be prepared to sit at a small table with other people. I am not into communal seating, but i've done it before, and usually the tables are pretty big so it's never that bad. The tables at this place are fairly small so you are cramped together with whoever you're seated with. I was pretty annoyed because ten minutes into dining, the hostess sat a big family with a screaming kid next to us. Really? I looked around and there were two other tables with families that had children with room for more people, SEAT THEM WITH THE OTHER KIDS. I don't think i'll be back, I just can't do it. :(
author: Catface G.

description:
Let me start off by saying that if you are not willing to start lining up a half hour early before it opens for dinner service, you will not be a happy camper.  Unless you want to wait two hours to be seated, I suggest trying this place on a quieter dinner night (Sunday, Monday, Tuesday and right when they open).  
Once you get in and sit down, the service and food speak for themselves.  I have never had anything less than an impeccable meal here.
The Roasted Chicken special and the Venison Medallions are two favorites of mine, and the staff is very good with beer suggestions to compliment your meal.
One of my standout favorites in the city.
author: Jenna R.

description:
Super easy to miss. If you don't know what you are looking for exactly, then you will miss this place. Also, the entrance is very unusual! Doors are heavy and always closed, but once you go in you are met with a heavy curtain that you must push aside to be met with a dark, packed dining room. You definitely can't wait in there.

Our party had reserved the dining hall in the back. Huge bench tables! With benches! A little bit inconvenient, but that is why you try to get the outside bench seats. Regardless, it is a little awkward because right behind you, there is a window where you can see the food being set out for the wait staff to deliver the food.

Our waitress was really sweet and friendly and was ready to answer any questions and make good recommendations. We got the chicken meat loaf, and it was good! Juicy, soft, warm, and very satisfying! The shallot sauce was better than gravy for both the meat loaf and at the mashed potatoes. Portions are big, so rather than getting separate entrees, if you are very hungry then it's better to go with one entree and one appetizer, or just one entree. 

One thing to note: most entrees are pork or beef. I'm not a huge fan of either (unless it's a burger or a hot dog), so if you don't like either meats, then be prepared to have a very limited choice in food.

The only complaint I have is that we weren't told until the last minute that the boots are restricted to four per table. My boyfriend had also ordered a boot, but he wasn't told that they would cancel his order if the boot quota was filled. It's ok though. I didn't want him to drink that much anyways.
author: Hayne P.

description: Great environment!  Community tables, so you're seated next to people you don't know, with tasty food. Great beers. Great ambiance.  I've never been to Germany, but my friend said that this is by far the most authentic German restaurant he's been through in the states. Fun area to walk around, after you eat.
author: Tom W.

description:
I'm a planner. Usually that gets me lists of things to accomplish that I never get around to. Traveling though, it's useful. We had a great food itinerary, with backups to backups if we couldn't get in certain places. Since we were crashing at some kind friends of ours though, we became the guests that would not leave and as such ran out of places to eat. Fortunately our hosts like to grub as much as we do, and they had some great ideas. 

Of all the wondrous meals we ate on our trip, this was the most fun. By far.
 
It would have gotten stars just for that. Stars for the poor sap on a date with his girl and her mom, trying to impress them by downing an entire Das Boot (2 liters of his beverage of choice). Stars for one of the most abominable things you can drink, but more on that later. Stars for fantastic company. 

But surprisingly enough, it really earned the stars for some absolutely divine German food. Hearty lobster soups, perfectly wondrous meatloaf and mashed potatoes, magnificent John Holmes sized sausages (tmi?), filling potato pasta with cheese. At some point I stopped taking notes, as the mugs emptied, only to be refilled immediately. There was more food, desserts, drinks, joy, laughter. My three year old sneakily trying to dip her finger in the raspberry beer. Hey Mikey, I think she likes it. And best of all. An aperitif (Underberg Bitters) that is seriously the most disgusting thing I've ever swallowed. So small and so vile. You must try it.

We're already coming back for a birthday, and everyone has to finish a boot. Good times ahead.

Best Plates: Meatloaf and Mashed Potatoes, Lobster Soup, Potato Pasta and Cheese, Sausages, Underberg Bitters)

Palate: mainstream

Food - A
Ambience - B
Service - A-
Value - A
author: Forrest D.

description: I'm now since a year in the states and I was sooo happy that I found this restaurant. The food and the beer is amazing. The food was really typical German food. This place makes a Germangirl very happy :)
author: Isabel L.

description:
Came here on a Sat night.  Yelp let me down this time.

Dinner bread was cold and burnt with chewy skin.  It left charcoal on my fingers after touching the bread.  Very unappetizing.

Meat is over cooked.  We ordered a venison and a beef dish.  I had to try very hard to cut through the meat.  Both taste meh to me, not to mention the price of a dish is around $20.  Could have gotten much better quality else where with this price tag.

Service was so so.  No water ever offered to us. Maybe cuz we ordered 2 small glasses of beer.  Waitress was not so attentive.

Bathroom smells and not so clean.

The only thing good is they got decent selection of beer.

You often have to share table with strangers.  I am fine with that. If it's not your thing, don't come here.
author: A L.

description:
My parents are german.  But I grew up always thinking that German food was "just okay."  The first time I came here, which was about 15 years ago, I feel in love with German food.  And it was the place I always looked forward to going to when we made trips to SF.  But the last time we were in SF, we enthusiastically planned another trip to Suppenkuche.  But sadly it just wasn't the same.  Food wasn't as good.  Some of it was overly salty.  

On the plus side, I still kind of like the chaos of sitting together in a table with strangers.  And I'm glad I experienced Suppenkuche years ago when every time we went there was such a great experience.  It gave me my first real appreciation for German food.
author: Karen M.

description:
We'd been drinking. But Sarah and I both agree the venison, it ain't venison. 

Tasted like a juicy, well prepared, well seasoned sirloin.

Again, we'd been drinking, but we're from Michigan where every child takes gun safety and can pilot a boat by the time they're 10. I mean, her mom sends us venison in the mail. 

And in my youth visiting relatives in Tirol, Austria, there's venison on the menu at McDonald's. Well not really, I'm just trying to illustrate how much and how common it's served in the area.

We'll be back, but not for the sirloin.
author: Corey H.

description:
One of my two favorite German restaurants in the US, fo' sho.  Love the communal tables for the experience.  The food's always dope, but it's the beer that keeps most people coming back for more.  Venison dinner with red cabbage and gotta get that amazing German salad.  Next time - gimme a boot!

Who should come:  lovers of dope beer, meat, sauerkraut and potatoes.
Who should stay away:   people who love their personal space.  You'll probably bump elbows with someone else's date or somebody's hot mom.  Also - the impatient; it takes forever to get into this joint.  Be prepared to wait a while.
author: Monkeybank S.

description:
worst dining experience in SF. it was my first time visiting this place. I was so disappointed. It was like a jungle gym. So loud (I couldn't hear my friend sitting right next to me, we were yelling at each other, we ended up switching the table and sat at the different table, but the situation was not getting better) Rude waitress (I could tell they were very busy & anxious) 

I don't even remember what i had for dinner, i just wanted to get out of this restaurant, again, worst dining experience in SF. it is impossible to have a conversation here.
author: Kristy K.

description: Been here twice enjoyed everything from the beer to environment to the authentic German will be back soon for that boot .
author: Droger S.

description:
Nice service, really great food, make sure your entire party is there to be seated.

Have the boot if you have the tolerance haha.

Our group really liked the potato pancakes and applesauce and the featured appetizers.  I'm biased toward the veal medallions.

Would go back :)
author: Charles V.

description: Way crowded. Need a better way to resolve crowd control. Spilled on by steins a couple of times. Make sure you come off an off night to otherwise enjoy the great food. Pork knuckles was delicious and the beer - well its a German bierhaus - of course it's kick ass
author: Calvin C.

description:
A boot of Edelweise and a big, heaping bowl of cheesy spaetzle, a mound of red cabbage, and a couple of good friends. That's the fixins of a great Friday night.

Remember the rules: 
* Once you start the boot, it CANNOT be put down! 
* Toes should always point to the person next to you
* Turn that sucker to get rid of the air bubble!
* EAT
* Order food at the halfway point of your boot
* Order your next boot halfway through your meal

Food was fantastic. Cheesy spaetzle was creamy, garlicky, deliciousness. The red cabbage (not the best I've had), but still yummers. Next time I will be having brats. And the salad was a nice, needed green to add to the meal. You can sub your sides, FYI. 

Be prepared for a long wait. Be prepared to share your table. They only take reservations for parties of 6+, and you have to call them as they open. However... if you get there before 6:30pm, your wait should be less than 10 minutes.

I need to come back for brunch. It sounds amazing.
author: Mar A.

description:
Fours stars for excellent food! 
I don't know the names of the dishes nor do I want to butcher them, so bare with me. 
We LOVED all the dishes we shared - potato pancakes, veal, lamb and something that was very similar to mac and cheese - all absolutely delicious!

A few things to consider beforehand: 
- hard to find parking, its always packed in that area
- LONG waits and no reservations
-not a large place, be prepared to share your table with another party
author: Charlene R.

description:
Deffo one of the best German Places in town. 
I am from Germany and just recently moved to SF so I know what I'm talkin about;)
The food is pretty authentic and they have a good variety of standard meals u would get in German restaurants in Germany. 
The beer selection is awesome!!! If u are into dark beers, u just have to order the "Weltenburger"!!! (I think they only have one. If more then ask for barock).

The service is cool too. Nice people and I feel like they know how to deal with crowds. 

The only reason I'm givin 4 stars "only" is that it's almost always packed and there is lots of waiting, but dude it's worth it and not their fault for being amazing 
ALSO the fact that Nürnberger Würstschen are 14.50?!?! Sausages?!? 

Still all the other dishes are fair priced, will deffo fill u up and don't forget the beer I mentioned above;) 

Prost und guten Appetit
author: Ilias S.

description:
For appetizer we got the Boot of Beer. There was only two of us and there was no way in hell were we going to finish it. Had the Dried Pork and Roasted Chicken for entrees. Both were Amazing. The dried pork was grilled, which was quite interesting cause i don't think I ever had any type of jerky meat eaten hot before. They went great with the potatoes and onions. Chicken was roasted to perfection. Well seasoned and crispy on the outside. 

Ended up talking to our neighbors at the shared table especially after all the drinking. Its extremely loud in here and always packed but its part of the atmosphere and the food is so worth the wait.
author: Charlie L.

description:
I live two blocks from this pace and I absolutely LOVE it.  

First off, their beer selection is awesome (although I tend to always order the same one, it's good to have choices).  The bartenders are super nice.  It's almost always busy in there, but they have always been nice to us, and even manages to share some jokes.  I have seen them take shots with other customers around the bar also - so great attitude and friendly/chill atmosphere!

Then there is the food.  The potato pancake and meat loaf are my absolute favorite, and I don't even usually like such meat heavy dishes.  However, since I've taken so many  friends here and they've ordered different things, I've gotten to taste other dishes and it's all been good.  I've had the pork sausage, trout, schnitzel, and chicken and none of them disappointed. I'm slowly trying to work my way down the menu, but it is extremely difficult to stray from the meatloaf.  

I would highly recommend this place, but the waiting could get pretty horrendous.  If you come late enough on a popular night (i.e. Thursday-Saturday), you could actually be turned away.  

A good way to avoid a long wait if you don't mind is to try and get a seat at the bar (you could also order food there).
author: Carrie L.

description: The greatest of partying German beer garden atmospheres! And great food too! The place is always packed, but just squeeze your way in and enjoy a huge selection of German beer while you wait for a table, it will be worth the wait.
author: Peter K.

description:
Wow, 1.5 hour wait time! We went down the street to Noir Lounge for drinks and small plates. The service was outstanding and smiley and quick. I had the Radler - beer mixed with lemonade, which I'd never had but which my date said was a bit sweeter than it should have been? The beers come in nice heavy mugs, very satisfying to drink.

We got the potato pancakes as appetizer, which were delicious and possibly the best part of the meal! My date had the venison medallions and I had the bratwurst (comes with THREE HUGE SAUSAGES). Neither of us could eat more than half our meal and are still gearing up to face the leftovers 2 days later.

It's good, but it's real heavy and you have to wait awhile. Be prepared.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
DAS BOOT!!! need i say more?????

We were shopping around the area, waiting for this place to open at 5pm.. and we got here a little before 6 on a Saturday evening..This place is very small so it was packed!!!! Now I know why, its awesome! I am definitely coming back next time I'm in town.  My group of 8 managed to squeeze in and made some room at the bar and ordered a couple DAS BOOTs and some food.. The food was amazing!!!! Not sure what the names of the items were exactly, but we had the meatloaf and bratwurst meals which came with delicious mashed potatoes and green peas..I don't even like peas, but this was sooo freaking good!
