They also ordered a HUGE soft pretzel with some cheese dipping sauce which deliciously melted in my mouth!!!  My only disappointment was that we didn't come early enough to grab a table to have a full sit down meal, but everything we enjoyed at the bar was great!  Great service, great vibe, great food and beer!!!  I'll definitely be back!
author: Mimi P.

description:
The porkchop was awesome.  Nicely brined, cuts like ham, superb taste.

The venison was perfectly seared on the outside, juicy and slightly red on the inside.

The pork chop with schnitzel was nicely done, the mushroom sauce was superb.
author: Koalie W.

description:
Cramped quarters, but a lot of fun if you're down to get a little rowdy. If you know me, i LOVE planning events. We had a group of 12 people at 8pm on a Saturday night, and they were so good at honoring our reservation that they actually kicked the group ahead of us out who'd been lingering for a couple hours just so we could be seated (oops!). Our group was coming from all over the bay, so while we were waiting for everyone before we could order, we decided to order a couple boots of beer. The waitress was really helpful in suggesting beers that everyone would like, and in the end, everyone was happy with what they ordered. 

Honestly, I can't remember the food (I tried some of the wiener schnitzel and the bratwurst), but I remember it being delicious. Come in a big group, don't come here for an intimate night out...because you're gonna have to practically shout to hear each other. By the end of the night, we were making friends with the nearby tables!
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
This place is awesome...but because of that, it's always crowded no matter what day or time you go. So far the few times I've been there, we've been able to squeeze into the bar and find some seats, but have yet to get a table without having to wait at least 45 min. 
Food is pretty good and their beer selection is great. They always have at least one Hofbrauhaus brew, which are typically at the top of my list.
author: George M.

description:
Pales in comparison to Biergarten in my opinion. Beer is the same quality but the staff here is full of pretentious pricks. 

My friends and I waited an hour to have some beers. We get seated and order our drinks. They ask us for our dinner orders, to which we politely explained that we ate somewhere else because of the wait, but still wanted to enjoy some beers. 

They essentially kick us away from our table, even though we were spending over $110 on alcohol. If it's such a big fucking deal that we eat, then fucking throw people a bone when you explain they have to wait over an hour so they don't end up wasting their money and time to eat at an overrated yuppie cramped shithole. 

We even offered to share a couple appetizers and the waiter almost suffered a coronary. He said we could eat our appetizers at the bar that was crawling with other humans that had been duped. 

Are you fucking serious?

God, the staff... Waiter was a total douche and as helpful as someone putting out a fire with a bottle of Jack Daniels. Don't ask for any beer suggestions - he basically snapped off my friend's head for attempting to educate himself on the selection.

The annoying part too is there were plenty of other people at tables sitting around picking their teeth and sitting on their fat saggy asses taking their own jolly time. 

Our waiter basically chucked our check at our heads and said "It's been 20 minutes". Sorry I am not a fucking camel and can't down 1 liter of heavy beer like an alcoholic. 

Just so overrated. I don't get it. The hype makes zero sense. 

I've have bad experiences before at restaurants but I am fucking appalled to the point where I actually want to go back in and demand to speak with the manager. And I can't even confront my roommates about cleaning up their fucking dishes or call the doctors office to set up appointments. So you can imagine how fucking terrible this place is.
author: Kory A.

description:
This place is INCREDIBLE. I have never really had German food and after reading all the positive reviews on Yelp, my boyfriend and I had to try it during our mini VK to San Francisco.

Walking in, super crowded but that is always a good sign because that must mean it is good! We are told it might be a bit of a wait, but as soon as my boyfriend and I go up to the bar, the host tells us he has a table ready. They are all community tables so if you are friendly, they are great to meet new people!

The beer selection is fantastic, not to mention all the different sizes it comes in. We started off the the pretzel and cheese plate and OH MY GOD. It was easily one of the best things I have ever ate. So light and yummy!

I ordered the pork ravioli with mushroom sauce and my boyfriend ordered the venison medallions and they were both completely and utterly fantastic. I was a little full after the pretzel and beer and even told myself I am probably not going to eat the whole thing. I practically licked my plate clean, same with my boyfriend. I seriously wanted to order more food after we finished and the whole walk back to our hotel all we could talk about was how amazing the food was. HIGHLY reccommend this place if you are looking for something new and different!
author: Melanie C.

description: The food was phenomenal, portions were huge, and service was great! They change the menu often and I wish I had more time to go back and try more options!
author: David A.

description: This German restaurant was really packed on a weekday for dinner. I got the Wiener Schnitzel with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. Everything was really good except for the mashed potatoes. They were just okay. This is a really cute, cozy little restaurant with long tables/benches so you'll be sharing the table with strangers. The food was really good but I wasn't blown away which is why I'm giving 4 instead of 5 stars.
author: Tanya Y.

description:
I'll admit, this place has grown on me. I would have given 3 stars on our first visit. We found this place when my husband wanted a nice, cold beer after a long day of shopping at Union Square. We yelped "beer", and Suppenkuche popped up. Hey why not?

Walking in, it's a fun, lively place. They have cozy, cafeteria-style seating. They'll even seat you with strangers if there is room at the table.

My husband ordered the bratwurst and I, the sauerbraten. Now I've never had sauerbraten before so I didn't know what it should taste like or what the texture should be like. The flavor was great but when I read the words "braised beef", I expect fork tender meat. This was not but then maybe it's not supposed to be? I enjoyed the bratwurst more than the sauerbraten.

This place has grown on me though. We came back on a second visit to catch up with some friends. This time I ordered the salmon (boring I know!) and my husband ordered the meatloaf. The potato pancakes with applesauce we ordered as an app were delicious. I could have eaten that the whole night with my glass of riesling and been a happy camper!

Here's a tip: If you come here with a large group, expect at least an hour wait. We put our name down for a party of 5 and waited almost 2 hours. Luckily there was a bar (Smuggler's Cove) a few blocks away where we had a few drinks to pass the time. We got lucky on our first visit since it was just my husband and I, and were able to snag 2 empty chairs with another party.
author: Bernadette A.

description:
Go for the potato pancakes and the Käsespätzle. Yes, right now. You won't be disappointed.

As many other reviewers have mentioned, this place gets very crowded and very loud. There is a much more relaxed environment if you go in the early evening, and the wait time isn't very long, if you have to wait at all. Regardless, I'd wait a long time (and have) for the delicious food they serve here. I'll definitely be returning.
author: Leah M.

description:
When I walked past the restaurant, I thought it was mainly serving soups (as its name implies). So, when my friend who lives in San Fran suggested having dinner there, I was prepared to have a light meal. Oh, it suited me just fine that Suppenkueche turned out to be a restaurant with a full kitchen and plenty of solid and liquid choices on the menu.

We didn't have a reservation and were therefore gladly surprised that the waitress showed us to a table immediately even though the restaurant was already teeming with people. I guess it helped that we were just 2 pax.

We ordered the Potato pancakes with Apple sauce, and the Nuernberger bratwurst with Sauerkraut. I would highly recommend the pancakes for they were crispy and delicious, but the sausages weren't up to the mark (neither flavorsome nor well-grilled enough).

The restaurant was boisterous so come here if you like a crowd but maybe not if you want to have a good conversation.
author: Jess C.

description:
I am so happy to have found a German restaurant that serves an assortment of tasty vegetarian food! This place is by far better than Leopolds. 

A group of 10 of us put out name on the wait list around 6:00 and had a 2.5 hour wait. They wouldn't take our phone number so we had to be there when thy called our name. If we weren't, they moved on to the next people on the list. We were at Sugar down the street and every half hour checked to see what the wait was. We ended up sitting down around 8:30.  They put us at a table that was too small and not enough chairs. We ended up grabbing chairs from another table. The customer service was ok. Not the best but if you eat here you will know why. They are very, very busy and you can see how hard they are working to keep up with the demand. 3 of us wanted to order "the boot" but they were all bring used and after our 2 hour meal, only one of us ended up getting a boot. 

We ordered 2 plates of the potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce. There are 3 large crispy pancakes with each serving and they are worth it!!! Yum. We also ordered the bread dumpling in mushroom sauce but the waitress forgot about it and remembered halfway through our entrees and we were too full to eat then. Next time, I would love to try them.

By the time we got there, they were running out of food but we got the suckling pig, braised beef, pork wiener schnitzel , cheese spatzel, and portobello  mushroom stuffed with spinach and feta covered in a pepper sauce. The cheese spatzel and mushroom are the only dishes I can really comment on since I am a vegetarian and thy were delicious!!! The spatzel is very rich and heavy but yummy. I would order the mushroom again. 

The beers were all tasty. I loved the light spaten and the frambroise lambic

The restaurant is loud and hot but that is all part of the charm. We had a blast and te food was great.
author: Whitney S.

description:
If I lived near here..I seriously would be here EVERY DAY!!  What a cute and very German bar/pub.  GREAT atmosphere and very friendly service.

It was a Thursday night in October 2011.  They have big tables to seat about 10 and we were seated on the other side of a table with a group of other 'patrons' at the other end.  We didn't mind this at all - very European which was pretty cool..AND makes great conversation after dinner or drinks.., ya know.. the conversations on the ride home that start with:  "OH MY GOSH, did you hear what that girl said to that guy??!!" ha ha

After being seated, the lady handed us the menu.  Thanks to fellow Yelpers, I got the Banana Hefe..AMAZING!!!  and yes, LIFE CHANGING!! ha ha ha.
The food was great!!  The POTATO PANCAKE, salad, Meatballs, Schnitzel..ALL VERY VERY YUMMMMY!  When ever we go back to SF, we will definitely come back!
author: Jill Y.

description: Pure Germany!! Authentic food, authentic atmosphere, authentic beer. . . Enough said! Prost!!
author: Paul K.

description: The food is nice, the beer is great, but fuuuuuuuuuuuuck me, how is it so loud in here? I would come back here if I would here the person next to me enough to have a conversation. Also, they try and ram this place so full that we were seated literally *in* the doorway, so people were pushing into my chair every 30 seconds trying to squeeze past. Annoyyyyying!
author: Kate H.

description:
Came back here after quite a while away. One of life's little pleasures is how some good things don't change ... Suppenküche is one of those pleasures for sure.

Suppenküche is by now a very popular spot, and for good reason. The food is fantastic, the beer is amazing, and the scene inside is casual but refined. You might be rubbing elbows with a tattooed hipster wearing a Fedora and stunner shades, but is no Pabst to be found. Conversely, there could be a man and wife all dressed up, and they're sitting next to you on the big group tables, sucking back suds and eating bratwurst just the same. Great place.
author: Wes T.

description:
So disappointing... 

The beer selection was good, and priced well. The bartender was friendly. I really liked the potato pancakes and curry wurst.

However, we were quoted a 1.5 hour wait, and it took well over 2 and 1/4 hours. I realize that the quotes are not am exact science, but jeeze. One of my beers was served in a hot glass. The server never came over to refill waters. 

The biggest sin, the Wiener Schnitzel was not good. It was dry, chewy and salty, salty, salty. I should have sent it back, but I was starving. As I tried to eat the leftovers today my tongue was drying out from the salt content. I'd been here 10 years ago, and I loved it, so I was really looking forward to the schnitzel. Ugh...
author: Chuck K.

description:
SUPPENKUCHE is like a trip to Germany, but only the good stuff.  
 
Good German Stuff:  Massive Quantities of Beer, Massive Quantities of Fried Food.
 
Bad German Stuff:  Being stared at like you are the only Asian person in the entire country, Shady German dude trying to get you to go to nude co-ed spa.  
 
BEER:  Bier ja!  Everyone liked their selections, especially me.  Radler is the perfect beer for a summer night (Beer + Lemonade = Refreshing!).
 
FRIED FOOD:  Gebraten ja!  We had the Fried Camembert with Cranberry Sauce and Parsley.  And yes, it WAS as delicious as it sounds.  Even the parsley was fried!  Then we had the Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce.  One friend willingly bought his ticket for the bullet train to hell when he said, "These are better than my Grandma's latkes!"  But actually, I think Grams would understand after eating this crack in crispy, potato form.  My Chicken Schnitzel was ginormous - and organic even.  The mashed potatoes that came with it were buttery, carby yumminess and I also loved the Tomato Cucumber Salad with generous amounts of dill.   
 
Since the tables here are communal and everyone knows communal means "Amy C. gets to eat your food so step aside," I tasted my peeps' Organic Wild Boar Sausage, Sauteed Trout in Lemon Butter Sauce, and Spatzle.  It was all spatzletastic!  And then we communally shared the delicious Apple Strudel with Vanilla Ice Cream for dessert.  
 
I was so full, I had to unbutton my plus size lederhosen.  Did I get some weird looks?  Ja.  
 
But it was WORTH IT.
author: Amy C.

description:
The wait is always brutal, I mean always. But this is one of the few places I'll suck it up (albeit rarely). I love their selection of German beers and the potato pancakes with apple sauce always makes my stomach smile. Last night I had the weiner schnitzel which was a delicious gut bomb; I was still full when I woke up this morning.

 The atmosphere is lively and will keep you awake, so bring a couple of friends (though not a date) and make an experience out of it...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Birthday dinner - bacon covered meatloaf, braised beef brisket, trout, salmon, wienersschnitzel, and mixed salad.

All that was okay, a bit bland and safely prepared - the fish actually was done quite well.

Now, the 2 liter boots were phenomenal - 5 stars.

The 5 LITER BUCKET of beer was freaking unreal, for that they earn an extra star easily.

Make sure to make reservations, this place is as busy as a French whore house during the Vichy regime.

The service is as best as can be expected given the utterly cramped conditions, and they stuck around and hung out with us as we closed the place down TRYING to finish our 5 liter bucket.

I had a lot of fun, unless you're claustrophobic I would imagine that you will as well.
author: Theo R.

description:
Our table ordered

Pea Soup
Breaded and Sauteed Pork loin with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad- Perfect pork loin, cooked to perfection , great with the lemon,
Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes - You can't go wrong with this order . Sausage is flavored just right,
Roasted Chicken with stuffing and  potato pancake - Chicken was juicy and stuffing was great. 

Also had a Heff with banana  which was better than i expected

Overall loved this place !  I will def come back .

Thanks to great wait staff that hooked us up with a cake for my sisters birthday.
author: Michael T.

description:
DAS BOOT.  It's 2 Liters!!  And for someone who swore off beer ... I sure do drink a lot of it.

This place was alright ... didn't live up to the hype for me.  I was annoyed that we were asked to leave so the next seating could have their table.  Maybe this was arranged with our friend who made the reservation ... but it was news to me.  No one likes being rushed through 2 liters of beer.

I tried a bunch of the stuff that everyone raved about on yelp ... /shrug.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Solid place, with the crowd and lines to prove it. Came here with a group of 10-ish for my friend's birthday, and we waited about an hour before we could get seated. It's all good though, because we were just hanging out in the bar drinking and munching on some potato pancakes to pass the time. They have a great selection of German Beers on tap and food from the kitchen. I'm not a big fan of German food in general, but I had the schnitzel and was satisfied (think of the German version of katsu; breaded and fried pork). 

Of course, THE thing to do here: DAS BOOTEN!
author: Morris C.

description:
The wait is over an hour long, but we wandered around the neighborhood and got a drink at Biergarten.

Whether it be the meatloaf, weinerschnitzel, breaded porkloin, potato pancakes, asparagus soup cake, or beers (I forget the names, but the last 0.5 liter I had was something Salvator). You can't really go wrong with what you eat or drink here. 

The atmosphere is loud and casual, with people having a great time, pounding on sturdy tables.
author: James L.

description: Meh. Pork sausages, mashed and saurkraut are not worth nearly $20 no matter how good they are. The shared tables, vibe and beer list are nice but I'm not sure why people are so into it. My husband's drunken pork was better but it all seems to be pushing the acceptable level price-wise.
author: Rachel M.

description: I'm shocked I've never been here before. This place is just so cute and the service was great. Amazing beer poured by an experienced bartender who's suggestions were spot on! Brats were great, my friends had the lamb, and meatloaf...both exceptional. I'll def be coming here more often!!
author: Jenny K.

description: All I will say...it takes me back to Germany. Incredible. The beer on tap was just like it is in Germany. If your ever wondering why the beer in Germany is always talked about, then you have to head here and try it. Augustiner is my absolute favorite, they only had it in a bottle though. However, the paulaner on tap was great. Food was good as well. Loved it here! The family style is fantastic too. It's something most Americans don't know how to handle
author: Micah R.

description:
This is THE German place in the Bay Area.  The food is super-duper-totes authentic (I'm living in Germany now) with a good representation of various regional dishes, like Swabian kasespatzle and maultaschen (mac & cheese and sausage raviolis, respectively).  

My friend threw us a bachelor/ette & going away party here, which was a little weird because we were in fact moving to Germany and would very quickly get sick of German food, but I'm still glad we tried it before we left, because it was an interesting contrast to "Californian German" and "Swabian German".  We sampled a bit of everything, from a cheese and charcuterie platter, to a few mains, and schwartzwalderkirschtorte, complete with a shared boot of beer.  To be honest after that much beer I can't really accurately review the food, but I remember being a little disappointed in German food once I arrived in Germany - the standards at Suppenkueche are higher than most.
author: Sarah D.

description:
So glad we came here, have been jonesing since my last visit 4 years ago. The wait at this place can be quite long but not to worry there is a biergarten two blocks away that's associated with the restaurant so hop on over for a liter of beer or you can wait at the bar but that's gets crowded. Needless to say they have an impressive German beer selection. 
Having a girlfriend that's German always helps when you go to a German restaurant or so they say. We ordered the herring for starters which paired very well with the apples covered with a yogurt dill sauce and farm fresh vegetables, the beets were delectable. 
For the main course we were excited to try the various dishes so did family style. We got the Marinated beef with Lingonberries, red cabbage & Spätzle, the veal wiener schnitzel with potato salad, and the cheese Spätzle. For me the schnitzel was excellent as good as the ones you get in Vienna followed by the cheese Spätzle. The beef was decent but the red cabbage lacked the tartness and the plain Spätzle was too bland. The serving sizes are what you would expect in Deutschland so we didn't have any space for potato pancakes with apple sauce. Well hopefully will be back soon to try the rest of the menu.
author: Harshal V.

description: Had the best time here. Such a fun ambience. It's the type of place that brings people together. The staff is wonderful. Great vibe. German beer is the best. Everyone has fun and gets along. But beware....it's very loud and its hard to have an intimate conversation. And food was good....not as good as German food in Deutschland but close for California. Highly recommend with friends or family. Urge someone to get a boot.
author: Daniel P.

description:
I dont remember much about my time in Suppenkuche, however what I do remember were awesome. Prior to eating some schnitzel and the bratwurst we came from the Biergarten. The food were delicious, but it was ZE BOOT that made this place so memorable. We got the konig in the boot.

+authentic German cuisine/culture experience, minus all the music and dancing you would normally find at an Oktoberfest. 

I may or may not return, I would definitely be on a whim though.
author: Ralph B.

description:
This spot is out of control good! Dishes that make your mouth water and have you longing to go back! Sorry its that's laying it on thick, but these are the kind of meals I live for...their plates are large, meaty, flavorful, and authentic! Astray from the average restaurateur in the city, and tucked in Hayes Valley which has much more to offer than people realize. Suppenküche is on point with the beer selection to compliment the menu.

Just go! Enough said!


I take that back, one more thing.  I showed up there on a Thursday night, had my meal with my party of two, enjoyed the atmosphere and happy staff conversations, and literally 5 before closing a group of 20 [insert judgmental labeling here] showed up asking to be served. Kitchen we literally closing up, we know because we were offered to add to our orders, but the staff without a shift in smile kindly took their orders.  Advise: Don't do that, people...that's not how it works.

I commend the fine establishment!
author: Geremy L.

description:
This place reminds me of the greatness (is that a word ?) of the SF food / restaurant scene, which is truly a special occurrence, great cuisine from all corners of the planet. 

Suppenkuche (commonly called soup kitchen.....but no relevance to the soup kitchen featured in the classic Sienfield episode...you know what I mean?)  has been in biz for many years, and stood the test of time, and has always served great German fare the whole time. A focused joint, with the food menu items with about the same number of beer options. While it is not a "low cal" joint, they are true to form....  yup, da Germans like to eat (but who among us doesn't?)...and drink (hows that for a stereo type, ooops now have incited the ethnically / PC correct crowd) . Soooo, portions are appropriate (read generous).

Never disappointing, communal tables, great environment. 

Current  food favorites (great for what it is):

Lentil soup 

Porkloin/ Mushroom Sauce/Spatzle/Salad

Also like the venison (yup not denizen) / cabbage & Spatzle

Parking can be a pain. Service can be rushed. Beer is plentiful w/ great selections "on tap" . 

Last time, noticed more vegan options.  Ahh Hmm, keeping up with the times and not tradition, its all right, its ok, keep those vegans happy anyway.....cos its the right thing to do. Otherwise they might protest and hit you with a carrot stick.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Love the authentic German setting in the main dining room with the wooden benches and what not, but the waiters didn't speak any German, nor did the bar tenders. Not to mention the waiter was rude when we asked to be seated further away from the door, since it was rainy and chilly outside and all they had to insulate the cold was a door blanket (?). 

Came to this place on a rainy Sunday morning with two German Natives who were hungry for some German food. For a party of four, the wait was about 30 minutes (try not to get seated by the door, even though this is California, it still gets quite cold). Hubby and I sat down, each ordered 3 dishes. My two other friends ordered one each, and shared an Emperor's pancake. 

We ordered:
- Cheese, meat and bread platter (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/HSCzEy1BROPD-0CJy4tNNA/l.jpg)
- Sautéed Getman Ravioli scrambled with Eggs & Onions served with a Cucumber Salad (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/luLGoGNcf6fkL2XXBx47tg/l.jpg)
- Currywust (http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/lgnXG48-3QZpNN76M2mB8A/l.jpg)
- Emperor's Pancake with bananas and Nutella (http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Gxq1Ecrpca9Ts25fxjHkHQ/l.jpg) 

The platter was very authentic, but not enough to fill a grown man's belly. And, I am speaking for the German Natives: the Currywurst were horrible. According to them, Currywurst is a very generic street food in Germany and it's kind of sort of pretty much impossible to mess up - they weren't happy.

But hey, I'm happy with my ravioli scramble and emperor's pancake (best pancake I've had yet). Cucumber salad is also quite refreshing and delicious! 

If I were to be given the option to choose which German restaurant I wanted to go to, I'd pick Speisekammer in Alameda in a heart beat.
author: Ximeng W.

description: Wish I could give this place 3.5 stars, but I'll err on the side of caution and go for 3. Went with a large group that had an 8pm reservation, but weren't seated until after 8:30. The German ravioli is phenomenal - definitely the best thing we got. The fried potato pancakes were mediocre and the pretzels weren't as good as I was hoping they would be. Ultimately the reason why I'm a little disappointed in this place is because the Sauerbraten (braised beef) was overcooked and tough. The atmosphere is rowdy and fun and the bartenders are very helpful with beer selections, but next time I think I'll order a schnitzel.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Had my Bday dinner here and must say it was Amazing!  This place is small but cozy and the energy of the crowd is great!  Everyone is drinking beer outta large boots and grubbing out on traditional German Cuisine. 
Love it!
author: Lily S.

description:
Don't go here for the ambience unless you like a traditional German restaurant - bare wooden tables that you share with whoever is there, noisy and crowded.

The food, however is equally authentic and took me back to my many trips to Germany. Great beer and real German food - what else could you want?
author: Ed G.

description:
I must have came to the wrong place.  Obviously I did not experience anything like everyone else did.  Sadly, because I do want to like this place.

The food was disgusting. Potato pancake was burnt, braised beef (so-called traditional dish that "every German's godmother know how to make") was loaded with salt, when i say salty i mean SUPER SALTY.  The dishes were all not eatable, they were saltier than ocean water.  The Deer dish was completely raw.  The only good thing was tasty beers and a nice server.

1 star bc not only was the food nasty ....They charged my credit card $60 more than what its supposed to be charged. WTF?!?! come on... it is unethical for them to do that if they wanted "additional tips" on top of our 18% gratuity.  We are not going to pay $150 for TIPS when the bill was a little over $400! COMMON SENSE, i will find out! 

NEVER COMING BACK HERE AGAIN!
author: Anna W.

description: Had the most amazing time at Suppendkuche's 22nd birthday party last night. The music played by on of their very own staff was unreal. I danced my heart out. Isn't great when you find staff that love their jobs -- that's a sign of a good business.
author: Kelly C.

description: Coming from a German household this place is amazing!  Great beer selection, pretzels come with cheese and mustard, the venison and the schnitzel were to die for! I would go again and absolutely recommend this place to anyone!
author: Alan R.

description:
Not sure if today was just off-kilter for them, but was generally disappointed with dinner. For the assault on your wallet (and your ears), one would expect at least better execution of basics.

One appetiser (ravioli) was tasty enough, but the pickled herring and our mains fell very short: the fish was bland and meatballs (from the daily specials) dry and mealy. The sides, some decent mashed potatoes and creamed peas and carrots, were small compensation for the general lackluster of the rest of the meal. 

The black forest cake I ordered to-go is awaiting its turn, but I'd be loath to return for an entire meal.
author: Adele T.

description: Our son shared Suppenkuche with us. Delicious food and an interesting interior. It has communal seating creating a very casual atmosphere. The food was delicious. My son had the boar sausage special, my husband had the Sauerbraten mit Preiselbeerkonfitüre, and I had the Käsespätzle mit Zwiebel-Buttersoße und gemischtem Sala - all delicious. It was  crowded while we were there so quite noisy but great fun.
author: Cindy D.

description: Excellent authentic cuisine and beer selection- quality of food was excellent and portions very filling and large. Such a cute ambiance, only thing that didn't do it for me was the seating- very open and family style- multiple parties seated together at the tables. For me, I wanted a more private dining experience, but the food and beer (beer + lemon soda is a MUST) was well worth that minor personal inconvenience.
author: Jacie C.

description: So the wienerschnitzel was really good! It was a little loud but to be expected in a beer bar atomosphere, would come back with a small (1-2 peeps) group. The staff was super nice.
author: Andrea T.

description:
A friend wanted to reacquaint me with Suppenkuche.  He wanted to convince me that the restaurant not only provided the most authentic German experience in San Francisco but also the best German food in the city period.  I've eaten at Suppenkuche in the past, and although I enjoyed my meal then -  it was nothing like this.  I was absolutely blown away!

What to Order Here:
Main Course: Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce (with Red Cabbage & Spätzle) (20.00)
Beer: Scneider Wiesen Edel-Weisse 0.5 liter (8.00)

The venison was perfect; a slight smokey flavor on the outside, tender and juicy within.  Not to mention, the portions were extremely generous.  (In Europe, this definitely would have been considered a portion for two.)  The red cabbage and plum sauce complimented the venison perfectly.  An extremely good deal (the best on the menu) if you consider the portion size and quality of meat.  

I highly recommend the Scneider Wiesen Edel-Weisse if it is available (it might be a Oktoberfest special brew).  Although I usually like sweeter beers, the the Scneider Wiesen Edel-Weisse entranced me because it was fragrant like jasmine flowers!  This bouquet of flavor was something that I've never experienced in a beer before and made me realize how intricate and interesting German beer culture can be.

I'm definitely coming back to try the potato pancakes!
author: Fei L.

description:
I finally made it here!
I loved the energy of the place -- loud, a bit raucous, crowded....
The food was so good. We ordered the salad, which was german potato salad buried beneath sliced beets, shaved carrots, pickled cabbage and lettuce...yum!
To start we also ordered the soft pretzels served with a side of some amazing cheese spread. I could have made that my entire meal...seriously.
For entrees we ordered the lamb chops with truffle, brussels sprouts and mashed potatoes and the braised beef dish. The lamb chops were incredible and the braised beef was ok. 
I will definitely be back!
author: Teryll H.

description:
A great hot spot in Hayes Valley. From outside, the bar/restaurant doesn't boast its awesome reputation.

1. get there early or be prepared to wait. The bar isn't very big so it's easy for it to be jammed packed. 

2. Beer list is long so I suggest sharing to taste as much as you can. If you're in it for the long haul get the boot!! this place looks a little classy to get sassy with that much beer, but if they weren't ready then they wouldn't have it on the menu!

3. Share the food too. The cheese spatzle, pretzel and potato pancakes are to die for!

Overall, great place to grab food and beer.
author: Mimi D.

description:
I absolutely love this neighborhood. I loved walking through Hayes to get to this restaurant. But that's just a plus.

We made reservations (I'd imagine that is a must) and we were told they don't seat partial parties and that if our party wasn't seated by 15 after our reservation that our table would be given up. Either they didn't need our table right away or they're a bunch of softies because they seated us before our party got there and our last friend was 20 min late, so thank you for not letting our table go.

We came for my birthday and were seated in the back at a huge table alongside another smaller party. Once my friends arrived we ordered and received our food very quickly. I ordered the venison medallions with plum sauce. It was amazing. I was sad I ate too much bread before hand and couldn't finish my venison. It was so moist and if you've never had venison, you're missing out. I've never had warm red cabbage but it was great!

They have an excellent selection of beer and other drinks. I had a nice pilsner that I cannot remember the name, one of my friends had a Raspberry beer, and another had a glass of Reisling.

I hope I'm able to return, if not, I hope you enjoy this place as much as I did.
author: Rachael M.

description:
I had eaten here most delightfully a few years back, and I remembered the meal to be delicious, which is what lead me to bring my friend there.

We were lucky to arrive to empty tables at 6:30 PM on a Tuesday. Hurrah! 

As I did not want a large meal, the waitress recommended the soup, which I hadn't ever had, and the ravioli, which I had enjoyed before. My friend had the Cheese Spätzle.

Hits:
Mushroom Soup -- amazing consistency and flavor -- filling enough to be a meal in itself
Cheese Spätzle -- tasted like the best mac and cheese I'd ever had -- I was envious that I was not a vegetarian at that moment

Big Misses:
German Ravioli -- the filling had a gritty and crunchy consistency, as if the meat hadn't been properly ground and the sauce was lacking.
Woodruff Soda -- odd tasting soda, definitely an acquired taste, per the waitress

Initially, the service was prompt. But after we got our dishes, we didn't see the waitress again. This didn't give me a chance to let her know that my dish had inconsistencies, which I would have preferred to do to remedy the situation there rather than writing about it here. 

When we did see her next, she dropped off the check, picked up our plates, and was off in a flash. Since we were on our way to a performance that was about to begin, there was no time for discussion.

I'd like to think that this was just an off night.
author: Diana V.

description: Don't try to plan any party or reservation here. :-/ they don't return your call after you leave multiple messages. Then when you finally reach them, they give you one available time slot. Tough to make plans to visit this restaurant when you can't make reservations. Unfortunate customer service. :(
author: Alexa N.

description:
Food: 4 stars
P/C: 4 stars
Service: 4.5 stars

I've been frequenting Suppenkuche for quite a while now and I owe these guys a review.  Good, stick-to-your-ribs food, dynamic beers on tab (mostly German and Austrian), and friendly service (in the midst of all the chaos).  It's a solid joint, whether you like the German beer and the Sauerkraut or not.  

The Goods:

- the atmosphere - communal table, funky deco on the wall, wooden stools are very inviting and minimal, folks dressed up in suits for some pre-theatre bites or college kids in shorts - it's for all.
- the service - friendly at all times and knowledgeable.  what else can you possibly want?
- food - nicely done.  i've had wienerschnitzels, goulash, sausages, latkes, pickled fish etc etc - and every time it's consistent.  if you have a couple dishes that you like, you can't go wrong.
- always rotating kegs of beer (10 or so, mostly from Germany and Austria).

The non-so-goods:

- the back bar area with the stools - technically it can seat up to 10 people, but really, if there 10 people of my size, the place would explode.  The bar stools make for inefficient use of space


Definitely my go-to place for some down-home good food and quality beers on tap all of San Francisco
author: Mike P.

description: The food is great and the delicious beer flows freely. Next time we've got to get Das Boot!
author: Mike V.

description: I've been trying to call for a reservation for the past ten minutes and haven't been able to get anyone! Was hoping to check in on availability but it seems that being accessible isn't very important to them. :(
author: Hayes T.

description:
Arrived at 9pm after bar hopping around the financial district and decided to make this our last spot for dinner/more booze.  Wooded tables, loud men holding mugs full of beer and pounding tables.  

Def not a place where you would go, if you wanted to enjoy your meal in peace. I shared the breaded pork loin entree with a friend and almost couldn't finish it. They were nice enough to put our split meal on different plates.  The pork was a bit dry and they provided me with a mushroom cream sauce which made it taste a lot better.  Watching my friend finish the 2liter boot was the fun part about dinner,.  which he ended up throwing up at the end.

I had a .5 liter of beer,. perfect size for me.  it starts with a K, dry and its similar to guiness?! it was good,. 

We also had a noisy crazy loud table next to us,. which made the experience a bit difficult to enjoy.  I heard tables around us telling them to be quiet,. tables leaving and giving them stares,. creating a pretty hostile environment to be in.  The waiter acknowledged the loud noise, complaints and approached the loud table,. telling them that tables were leaving and they weren't going to serve them anymore. I was shocked, but very proud of the waiter for stepping up. 

We also ended up leaving,. after we finished our food and booze.  

Def a place you should try out once,. for the 2liter das boot,. but def not a great place to be at,. when there is a bunch of roudy drunks!
author: Chanel L.

description:
This place was amazing! I haven't had an authentic Radler since I was in Germany!

The first thing I thought of when I was thinking of coming here was "are they just going to have Wursts and Bier and call themselves a 'German Restaurant' because I hate that..." -- The answer was NO.

I was greeted by someone who sounded like she was German by her accent... and told that they seat you as you come and the tables are mixed. For someone who was traveling solo, this was perfect... and if I was in a group, it would have been fun too. (For parties of 6 or more you can make reservations).

I was so tempted to get the Käsespätzle mit Zwiebel-Buttersoße (essentially a mac and cheese with an onion and butter sauce) as I loved this dish when it was made for me in Germany... and as much as I wanted it, I decided to go with the Wiener Schnitzel which came with potatoes and a side cucumber and tomato salad.

Everything was SO good... and took me back to when I was living in Bavaria. I wish that I could transplant this restaurant to where I live so that I could come here all the time... I would be the Dutchess of this place if I lived in SF. Whenever I go back to SF, I truly hope that they are still around so I can come here again!
author: Jen H.

description:
What is German food? I looked at the menu and had about as much idea what it was as how to pronounce it, which was zero. My only other experience with German food was at a sub-par Gastropub where food was bleh and service was worse. I expected Suppenkuche to be similar but with better food and booze. I was so pleasantly surprised in every way.

Suppenkuche is actually a small restaurant of two adjoining rooms. It has picnic-like wooden tables that were all lit with candles for a warm, cozy atmosphere. Although the hostess said the wait was 30-45 mins, my bf and I were seated within 5. They had a good selection of beer so that's what we started with - a dark Doppelbock for him and a sweet Hefe for me. I'd read great things about the sautéed pork w/ mushrooms but neither of us were pork fans. My bf ordered the skirt steak from the Christmas Eve menu and I ordered the braised beef.

The food was amazing! I love that it was so savory and bursting with flavor. It had a different taste than what I'm used to with Asian or other ethnic foods. The braised beef was soft and had a slight alcohol taste as if were marinated in cider. It came with cranberry sauce and spatzle, which I think is sauerkraut immersed in a red sauce. The spatzle was good but I ate it sparingly so I wouldn't drown out the beef which was already drenched in its own sauce. 

The piece I had of my bf's steak was also delicious, so flavorful that I'm sure it wasn't just cooked with salt and pepper. It came with a side of fried potatoes and bacon bits that was a trillion times better than grocery store-bought bacon. Although a little pricey at $18.50 a plate, the portions were so large that it completely filled my bf's hearty appetite and left me with leftovers. 

I still don't know how to pronounce anything but I do know that I've become a fan of German food. Things to order next time: potato pancakes, beer boot (2 liters!).
author: Thuy T.

description:
Not bad. 

Service = great and everyone is really attentive. Great selection of beers!

Atmosphere = this place is cute but TINY and the waits are really long as hell. Don't come here during dinner while hungry! I finished two 1.5L's at the bar while being crushed between my party and random people trying to get the bartender's attention. This is not a place for intimate conversation or catching up because it's so loud you have to yell even if you're a few inches from someone. There are a few long tables and benches so most likely you'll end up sitting with other parties.

Food = good. The sauerkraut was quite salty and unlike any other sauerkraut I've had before. The sausages were okay but a bit small, the mashed potatoes are AMAZING, buttttttt I didn't exactly come here for mashed potatoes. We tried the potato pancakes with apple sauce for apps, and I was expecting something mind-blowing but I think they were just good because they were fried. I had a bite of the meatloaf and wished I ordered that instead! 

Dessert = strudel was O-K. The black forest cake was quite tasty, and the slice was big.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Suppenküche was certainly a new experience for me. Not usually open to places that only have a niche food menu, but it's not a bad place at all.

Bummed I wasn't 21 - they've got boots and beers on tap. That being said, their food was alright. I forgot what the menu name was in German, but it was like a breaded pork chop with mashed potatoes and peas. Portions were huge, a little over-salted, but overall good food. Also, their mustard was amazing.

Everyone else really stuck to the meat and potatoes theme as well. I think the bratwurst was okay, and the "ham that someone ordered was basically Spam you get at a market. The sauerkraut was probably the best part, and maybe the Spätzle.

Probably will have to come back when I'm 21. Cool atmosphere, and okay food.
author: Sam A.

description:
Lots of beer and really dope food.

Went here and got a boot of beer and split one of the breakfast plates. Portions are LARGE. Cucumber salad that was provided was delicious - I ended up eating most of it and not sharing (a boys gotta grow).

Overall I got a nice feast on and a few looks for getting a boot of beer before noon. Had a nice conversation with our server about the best way to attack the boot - drink it with the foot part sideways so you don't have the gulping sound towards the end (think beer fest)
author: John N.

description: great food and beer menu. very noisy so it was difficult to chat with friends
author: Tera D.

description: This place was amazing. Going back for my birthday in a few days. I recommend the meat loaf with gravy and mashed potatoes. I drank a glass boot with paulaner Oktoberfest and it's been hands down the best beer I've ever had in my life. Great taste aroma color and drinkability. I drank 2 liters of that stuff!
author: Jose P.

description:
Was here with family not long ago and I really don't get the appeal.

The food is okay.  Not great.

The beer selection is okay.  Not great.

The wine selection is okay.  Not great.

The service is okay.  Not great.

The prices are... pricey for what you get.  Not great.

What keeps this place from a solid 3-stars is the noise level and how crowded it gets.  I really think they could stand to just lose a couple tables so that people could enjoy themselves more.  Honestly, even at the back tables closer to the kitchen, you are quite literally (and I do mean in a literal rather than emphatic sense) yelling at the people at your table and they still can't hear you.  The lighting and seating makes this place seem like it could be really warm, family-style... but it's not.  It's full of drunk people yelling and diners sitting in awkward silence.

There's just nothing redeeming enough about this place to make it worth dealing with the volume of people and noise.  I'd just as soon grab a German cookbook, head over to BevMo and have a German dinner at home.
author: Tierney H.

description:
Get the Schneider Weisse! Has a delicious banana nutmeg after taste!  Will always be packed off the German meat rack on a Friday or Saturday evening, so be prepared to wait at least 45min to an hour for seats at a large community table.

It's super loud inside so don't expect to have a nice quiet conversation.  On the other hand its really lively inside and with the wood decor has a friendly rustic feel.  Good for meeting with friends at the start of a night out.

Food:  I'm really picky with food.  The food here was just OK.  Tried the Potato pancakes as that is supposed to be a German favorite.  Tasted very bland.  Also had the Sauteed Porkloin In Mushroom Sauce.  Meat was dry, sauce was too wet for my liking.

All in all . . . come here for the drinks and the gregarious german atmosphere.  For food, try elsewhere.
author: Carlo S.

description: Went for a friends birthday dinner, the wait was 2 hours for the 11 of us, but that is to be expected. The food was absolutely delicious and the beer options were cool as well. My boyfriend got the half chicken with potato pancakes (which I may or may not have stolen a lot of) and I got the cheese spaetzle, which was also yummy. The only reason I took off a star was because of how loud the restaurant is. I wasn't able to call our waitress (she couldn't hear me) and due to the cramped space I wasn't able to get up to grab her either. Otherwise amazing!
author: brittany s.

description:
loving this place...rivers of great beer...large quantities of high quality food...service right on it. If parking was just a bit easier I'd be by too often than is good for my waistline. fair warning, this place is usually hopping, and gets pretty loud, so if you are looking for a quiet, intimate dinner, stay away during the weekends or go off peak hours. 

Hoping to review this place again soon.
author: Phuoc K.

description:
Delicious. Had a Hefeweizen boot and then a weiner shnitzel. Absolutely delicious. I also enjoyed the inside decor and the different type of atmosphere as everyone shared tables. 

If I come back to San Francisco, this will be a place I will stop by.
author: Bruce K.

description: This place is always a fun experience that makes us feel like we are back traveling through Germany. The food is good & the beer selection is awesome. Seating is family style along long tables throughout the restaurant. If you have a party of 6 or more, make reservations. If not, it's first come, first serve and you may have a wait...but you can saddle up to the beer bar and enjoy a drink while you await your seats. The only drawback to Suppenkuche is that it is LOUD. There's nothing done acoustically to dampen the crowd noise, so either bring ear plugs or be ready for this experience. I will say that it's been about 10 years since we last went, so when we went again last night I was surprised to see that this place has not lost it's allure with the 20 - 30 somethings. That says something for it's enduring charm.
author: Artina M.

description:
every time i come here, i always wonder what i should eat.... even then, it's always the same thing.  for brunch, i get the meatloaf, which comes with roasted potatoes and an egg on top.  i'd really say it's closer to pressed ham (like spam), rather than the traditional meatloaf they serve at dinner.  i like to switch out the potatoes for spaetzle, although i have to say, the potatoes are good too... probably because it's roasted with onions and bacon.  either way, you're good to go ordering that.

try the potato pancakes, too, for brunch or dinner.  always crispy and served with a side of cinnamon-y applesauce.
author: Tina L.

description:
Who has 5 liter steins.... WHO?!?! This place does! That's an automatic 5 stars in my book. Granted I could never drink that amount of beer, but the fact that the concept exists is comforting. You can order your beer in boots and in specific aliquots ranging form 0.2L to 5L. Again... who has 5 liter steins?!?! I was quite happy with my 1/2 Liter, though. Plus the stein size was cute. (Yes I am a girl)

Not only is there a great selection of beer with a variety of stein sizes to match, the food is actually quite good. I had the lobster bisque and salmon which were incredibly tasty. My friends had ordered the entree dishes, which were ginormous. Granted they are pricier, but you do get what you pay for.

I recently moved from Philadelphia where I had a go to German spot... I must say, this may be my replacement. Hooray! Clink clink.
author: Chiara I.

description: Really surprised this place got so many good reviews. Disappointed, this place is over crowded and low quality American-German food. If you are German and know what German food is supposed to taste like this not the place to go. Do yourself a favor and for to walzwerk!
author: Kelly R.

description:
crazy good, authentic german food.

Always packed, get there early.

The Spaetzle is to die for.
author: Nikki H.

description: Delicious food, great serving portions and German ambiance! First time visit for us and would definitely return.
author: Julie C.

description:
We arrived when the restaurant opened at 5:30, and the wait was still over an hour.

It was absolutely, without a doubt, worth it.  Everything we ate was amazing. Filling, but amazing.
The potato pancakes were delicious. We tried two entrees, both amazing.  I can't wait to go back. Trust me, the wait is worth it!
author: Ian C.

description:
Love this place! Most delicious weinerschnitzel around...and by far the BEST potato pancakes ever!!  Not to mention they have an excellent German draft beer selection... it is so wonderful everytime i come here.  Always outstanding service too, never a request they can't accomadate.  

Been dining here for years and will continue to for many, many more!!
author: Sara W.

description:
A friend loves the sausages here, but it just seems so much like Saag's ( which I do like ) that I am not at all thrilled about eating here.

But, the German meatloaf is really great.

Brunch is probably better for those who do not come here to drink beer.
author: George T.

description:
Suppenkuche is another one of those places you can't possibly judge by its looks.  It's an oddball little joint that looks tremendously unassuming until you walk in the door, and into a Bierkeller that looks like it just happened organically on a San Francisco corner.

By way of warning - vegetarians, don't bother, unless all you want is good beer.  This is German food, not German-style, with all that entails.  Meat, meat, meat, cabbage, potatoes, spaetzle, and meat.  The saurbraten was a callback to my youth and dinner at my grandmother's, and the liter of Franziskaner Weisse I had along with it went down perfectly. My companions tore through the jaegerschnitzel and the venison medallions they ordered.

With three of us, we did a fair amount of damage to a gemischte salat (potato salad, slaw, red cabbage, pickled beets, pickled carrot) and a sausage and cheese sampler plate (head cheese FTW!) with cornichons, as well as a goodly sized chunk of apple strudel with vanilla ice cream.  

Is this high cuisine?  No, of course not, but it's solid, enjoyable food in an interesting venue with good beer.  A decent value for an evening's meal in the City. Portions are generous for the price  They are not skimping with their plates, and you will waddle out with a smile on your face no matter how sprightly you sprang in.
author: Rob N.

description: Fantastic. I'm from Ukraine (Europe) and I instantly felt transported back to Europe. From the atmosphere (communal seating, standing bar, big mustache on my server) to food (Wiener schnitzel was great) to drinks (draft German beer, including huge portions), this place is just excellent. Fills up fast so get here early!
author: Alex N.

description: Came in with a few friends and ordered I believe most of the vegetarian items on the menu. The lentil soup was fine, but the mushroom soup was really good. The potato pancakes by themselves tasted like gourmet hash browns, but the applesauce took it to another level. The cheese spatzle was really nice - I don't usually like very cheesy dishes, but this one with the caramelized onions was very well balanced. We had the stuffed mushroom too which was quite nice. One thing that I found surprising was we asked the waitress to recommend beers to go with our food and she proceeded to ask us questions - light/dark, smooth/sharp etc and I would've preferred if they just paired the food with beer.
author: Manjesh N.

description:
Attended with a group for brunch on a Sunday. So crowded, had to wait nearly half an hour for our seats at a table. The food was good -- not wait-half-an-hour-stellar, but still decent. I ordered their Wurstgeröstel... (Roasted Pork Sausages scramble).

If I had tried their beer boot (that thing is huge!), perhaps that might be worth another star. They do have friendly service TO BOOT!
author: Garett T.

description:
The Beer boot was ridiculously a challenge... especially when you get to the bottom of the boot where you need to avoid the bubbles popping out at you.  http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/71vbu41Gt8HuWKww2T8WPg/l If you can't handle beer, please share the boot.

The whole entire time I was there.. I was wondering how on earth people call this restaurant.... SUPPEN- KUCHE.....SUPPEN-KUCHEY ??? haha Then as I read on other yelp reviews, I figured how you actually say it.. my bad!  It was funny while it lasted.

We had to wait a good hour until we were able to get seated.. Ridiculously crowded even at around 9:30pm!  We put our name down on the list and in the mean time, went down the street to try out some Frjtz.  After an hour of getting seated, we ended up at a table-like picnic table.  You might end up sharing a table so don't be surprised!  Friendly atmosphere! The decor is pretty simple.  Nothing fancy or modern.  There are christmas-like lights hanging everything on the ceiling and has a dark atmosphere.  But who cares!  We were there for the BOOT!  Service was friendly, and while we were at it, we ordered one dish to help us not get tired of the beer, we were about to intake.  Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes for $14 !  The sausage was actually delicious.  Very juicy but since I have never really tasted sauerkraut, this complimented well with the beer boot we ordered! 

Parking is a biz-natch here!  We ended up touring the blocks for ages.  But hey! Who knows if those meters are now setup in those areas now.. SF parking meters where the rates depend on the availabilities of parking at certain blocks!

This was definitely a good experience.  When I come back here, I hope to be tough and be able to finish that damn boot without any difficulty!! ( yea right! )
author: Kathy D.

description: Some of the best meals of my life were here. I crave the giant, soft pretzals...
author: Melissa R.

description: Delicious food. A little too crowded. Some wait staff are incredibly rude but most are nice and professional. I might've liked this place more if I didn't come here on a Friday night for the first time.
author: Neek W.

description:
5.0 Stars

"If you're havin' girl problems I feel bad for you son.
I got 99 problems but SUPPENKUCHE ain't one"

Hey, that song is so fitting for my 99th review. That's right only one more to go before I hit the big 100.

I just have to say that SUPPENKUCHE is delicious! 

I came with a big group of about 10 friends and everyone enjoyed their experience here. The food, the beer, and the overall environment just summed up to an awesome night. If you have a slightly larger group I highly suggest calling in to make a reservation. They'll seat you in the back room where the tables are a lot longer and can fit more people.

The restaurant is casual and fits the name of the establishment which means "soup kitchen" in English. You'll see what I mean when you walk in and see the bench like tables.

Our group started off with trying the Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce (Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus) as our appetizer. These scrumptous discs of joy are SO addicting! Any fan of hashbrowns will immediately fall in love with these easily. I know I did. The potatoes are shredded and are extra crispy when fried. The apple sauce might seem like a weird combination at first, but it works! 

For my main dish I tried the Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce with Red Cabbage & Spätzle (Gebratene Rehmedaillions in Rotwein-Pflaumensoße mit Rotkohl und Spätzle). I didn't taste much of the gamey flavor with the Venison so that was good. The meat consistency was a little tougher than beef, but aside from the meat being a little chewy it was still a great dish. 

The Red Cabbage has a sweet, tart flavor that can be a hit or miss with people. I personally enjoy it so I didn't mind having it on my plate. It actually comes with most of the dishes at Suppenküche. The Spätzle look like little pieces of noodles and works as the carbs of the dish.

I got to sample some of my friends dishes so I know what I would like to order and not order next time I come.  The Grilled Cured Pork Chop with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes (Kassler vom Grill mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei) has a really delicious and tender pork. It tasted like a chunk of ham. I would like to get this the next time I come.

What I probably won't get is the Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin
with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad (Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein
mit Bratkartoffeln und grünem Salat). This tasted like Pork Tonkatsu and I wasn't a fan of the roasted potatoes. I'm a hashbrown person all the way.

On to the BEER. I'm a big fan of Belgian brews so I tried the Blanche de Bruxelles that comes in a 0.3 liter size. It's a Belgian White beer so it has a light and cloudy/hazy apperance, but it also has a bold flavor that I thought was stronger than the Hefeweizen. It didn't match too well with the Venison, but it was worth trying.

With all the beer and food I was totally ready to K.O. after my meal. The portions are huge and you'll get full unless you have the appetite of a monster!!

I really enjoyed my experience Suppenküche and I can't wait to come back again.

== A MUST TRY! ==
author: Jason H.

description: This place is delicious! I loved the scenery and the people were very lively! Bartenders as  well as hostess were very accommodating.. Check this place out it's awesome!
author: Ryan Sonia B.

description: What a surprise! Would have walked right past this place if someone didn't recommend that we visit during our stay in San Fran. Delicious! The family style sitting may turn some shy folks away but I would highly recommend this place.
author: Kate R.

description:
Loud!

But that's what you get for going to a German restaurant.

Their spatzle is reeaally good, that is the only thing I've tried there!

There are communal tables and always a long wait, but you can always hang in the bar with a German beer in your hand while you wait.
author: Martie K.

description:
Community type of dining with a great selection of beer and amazing food. Their chicken ravioli appetizer is extremely tasty and I love their brats. Plus you can drink out of a boot!!!

Its a smaller place, so we took a little long to eat (we eat a lot of food) and were asked to hurry up. I wasn't a big fan of that but respected people were waiting, so we finished up quick.
author: Analisa S.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in SF. Last night I had one of the best meals I've ever had. HONESTLY! Rusty was a fantastic server, the bartenders are super knowledgable when you want to try a new German beer and the ambiance is fun.

You MUST try:
THE SUCKLING PIG - I'm told it's a special typically reserved for Saturday night.
The vegetarian spetzle - cheese and onion. THE BEST THING EVER!!
All their food is wonderful and very consistently delicious.
author: Cameron E.

description:
I'm trying to cut down on red meat so I got the trout.
It was tasty and the spinach that came with it was nice.
But there were hella bones, which made it hard to eat.
author: David C.

description: The restaurant refused to sit us because one member of our party was on the way. They then let another table add a member that was late to their existing table causing us to have to wait longer. When we complained, the hostess was unapologetic and rolled her eyes at us. True hospitality in German nature I guess!
author: Bradley V.

description:
Well, I love this place. We come here often especially since we have a better timing about this place. Mainly that we need to get here early to avoid the rush. Plus it helps that we're closer to the area so we feel a bit more free to drink as much as we want.

So... the food. I've never had a bad meal here ever. I've tried almost everything on the menu at this point and everything has been delicious. I was just there last night getting the meatloaf (again, though it's been a long time since I got it). The service is great, the people are jolly, and overall, this is one of our favourites places.
author: Shauna S.

description: Worth the wait. Great authentic German food and lovely atmosphere. Very reminiscent of my grandmother's cooking! Great spot when in San Francisco
author: KaLeigh R.

description:
Great German beer selection and the bartenders are really nice. The two vegetarian options are good but extremely rich and fatty, I am not familiar enough with German food to know if this is authentic or not. Good but definitely not healthy. The place itself is pretty small and it seems crowed when you walk in. I don't mind tight seating but if you do, take  note that it's tight. 
All in all I would recommend this place, especially for a beer or to dine with a small group.
author: Anastasia S.

description:
This is hands down my favorite German restaurant in San Francisco. When you order the Wiener Schnitzel, order it "a la Holstein." They bring it to you with two eggs sunny side up and criss-crossed with sardines.
The beer selection is pretty on point too. It is organized lightest to darkest on the chalkboard, so it makes it very easy to navigate to your specific taste. 
This place is magic. Get there early or spend the whole night there waiting on a table and drinking really good beer. Either way you win.
author: Luke S.

description:
Ladies,

Came recently to "KICK OFF" something spesh by drinking a boot with another lady friend, to whom I promised to never repeat that bootsy pun but, gulp, canthalpit.  The bartender allowed us an ample sampling of beers before taking the two liter plunge, because that shit is LITERally a commitment.  Suppernice.  Meanwhile, met a delightful server here who took a fancy to our robust liquid order.  

Ladies,

Do you know in 16 years of working here said server said (that's almost an anagram, alfalfa) he has never seen two women each order a boot of beer?  For real?!  

Ladies!!  

Why not?!

Ladies, and this time I really mean it, lady-to-lady,

Come break the glass ceiling and drink a glass boot of beer (but don't get those glasses confused or as mentioned here!there!everywhere! ...it'll cost you).  You can do you at Suppenkuche marvelously: whether you are a lady in the seats or a freak in the bench, just come sit your pretty self down at one of these tables, order a boot, and drink it until toe up. 

I did it power hour style wearing lipstick.  Trust, you can handle it babes.  In fact, yous a shoein.

Lady out!
author: Keeks K.

description:
This place looks unassuming, you may prepare yourself to be underwhelmed, it is really just a giant crowded room- but it is really one fantastic place. Came for the German food and ended up getting so much more! The beer selection is great (and having a real live German with me to vouch for the fact you can't find this beer anywhere else than Germany). 

The food was so good I will write the rest of this review in German:

Es war mein erstes date mit einem Deutschen. Ich war so nervös und die Tatsache, dass er holte Deutsche essen, das er mich nur noch mehr nervös. Zum Glück war das Essen hier ist wunderbar und ich hatte das Schnitzel und kartoffelpuffer und es war sehr viel wie southern food, soul food. Würde ich wieder zurück? Natürlich! Jetzt das, was gesagt werden kann über das Datum ....
author: Sarah M.

description: 4.5 stars for sure. Food was amazing, beer selection fantastic, service was really good. Like the atmosphere, could be a little more comfy, but very nice. Will be returning.
author: Cole G.

description: arrived at the place at 4:45pm today and there was already a line of 30 people waiting for dinner session opening.    by the time it's open at 5:00pm, 50 people were waiting.   It's a small restaurant and not everyone can get a table right the way.   They let everyone to come in and wait at the bar with beer and drink.   People are happy and waiter and waitress there were friendly and gave service with personal touch.    I ordered the fried pork chop and it's pretty good.   food is around $18 per plate and beer is $7 per glass.
author: Kin W.

description: Nails the German theme, has a wide selection, and everything I tried was very high quality.  I would go back; maybe not frequently because of the prices (there I go again--my budget and San Francisco's don't match), but it's a solid choice for a hangout.
author: Patrick R.

description:
I came here with a friend for dinner on Saturday around 6:30, and we were told the wait wouldn't be too long because it was just two of us, so we headed to the bar for a couple of beers. The restaurant has a good selection of beers for the beer enthusiast, including some Belgian lambics which I'm a huge fan of.

While at the bar, we ordered the herring, which had a weird cinnamon-y spice to it that I could have easily done without. 

We were finally seated around 8pm (this was definitely a huge downside to this place because we were repeatedly told that we were the next ones to get seats, but saw at least three or four parties of two get seated before us). By this point we weren't as hungry as we were earlier so we ended up just ordering the wiener schnitzel with cheese spatzel, which was absolutely delicious and huge (two huge pieces of pork) and followed it with a black forest cake for dessert (also really good, and not too sweet).

Overall the food was very good and hearty; perfect for a cold January night. The restaurant is fun and the communal tables are a fun way to talk to strangers! The wait was far too long though. I will, however, definitely be back to try their soups, venison and pork sausage.
author: Maria G.

description:
I was visiting from Las Vegas and my friend took me here to eat on my last night in town.  It was a Monday night, but the restaurant was packed.  The host took our name and told us it shouldn't be too long, since it was just 2 of us.  We waited less than 10 minutes and had just enough time to order a beer from the bar.

The food was great (although not as good as Hofbrauhaus here in Vegas) and the atmosphere was fun.
author: Teri W.

description:
DAS BOOT!

So much fun! There is NO way one person can drink an entire Das Boot by themselves, but it's so much fun to share! Be careful when you get to the bottom when you drink it,there's an air bubble just like in Beerfest :P Go for the Schneider Weisse, it's the best beer on tap. It has a nice robust flavor, with an almost chocolate-like taste. 

Food - DOUBLE YUM! Let me tell you the Wiener Schnitze is the best and it is wayyyy better than Wolfgang Puck's. Hats off to the chef :) Don't forget to get the potato pancakes too. You think it's good wait until you try it with apple sauce, ohhh wow.

This place is definitely a lot of fun and totally worth the wait. Can't wait to go back!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Freakin' love this place from top to bottom!

Its a perfect combination of SF & Germany...hipster, artsy German restaurant w/ delicious food

Food: a bit pricey, but worth it! Flavorful, hearty dishes & amazing beer
My ultimate goal is to come with enough people to share a boot! (photo op!)

Ambiance: Lively, noisy, and unique...love the sparrows on the ceiling & the beautiful people that hang out here ;)

Service: Busy but friendly waiters...be prepared to sit at a table w/ other people if you're in a smaller party 

Bottomline: If you're looking for a vacation on the cheap, head here for a short trip to Germany in SF
author: Bahar R.

description: Let me preface that our server, she was 5 stars. However, the food, drink, and general ambiance was average. We enjoyed Speisskamer in Alameda a lot more.  The beer selection was ok, but not a full bar (just wine and beer). The food was average. The sauerkraut was mediocre, the sausage undercooked/tepid. The mashed potatoes were just super buttery. The pretzels seemed frozen and microwaved and the cheese dip was so cold it was still partially solid. The lox and salad was ok. The venison was good and the spaetzel very bland (not at all cheesy). Probably won't be back...the quality for the price isn't do hot. We'd rather drive to Alameda if we are craving German. However, let me reiterate their service was good. No complaints there. :) interesting experience all in all.
author: Zara S.

description:
What is 'Mittagessen'?

This really neat German food establishment in Hayes Valley was a great find, thanks to Yelp reviews.  You will see immediately how cool this place is when you walk in to what feels like a small Eastern European dining hall with curved ceiling and wooden rectangular tables.  There is a bar in the center with several chalkboards on the walls with a list of German biers on tap.  Next to the bar is a slightly hidden cove which is an area that gives you more of the bar feel.  If you come here as a party of two, expect to share one of the wooden table for 6 with strangers, which isn't a bad thing.  Tables are large enough that you could carry on your conversation without bothering your neighbors.

We went here for brunch, so I cannot comment on their dinner, but I ordered their breaded and sauteed porkloin in mushroom sauce served with spatzle and salad ($9.50) which is something that is also featured on their dinner menu.  I loved the dish which went well with my beer --- yes, you'll feel like a beer with your brunch when you are in this space.

Service was good although our server couldn't tell me the meaning of 'Mittagessen' on the menu.
author: トモ T.

description:
I'm kicking myself.  I've avoided this place every time we're in Hayes Valley thinking there would be nothing there for me, because I am vegetarian.  Now that I've been there, I'm SUPER bummed that it took me this long.  

What a find!  The atmosphere is fun.  The food is amazing.  The German beer is fun to try.  And there are a lot of yummy choices without meat or animal juices in them.  This is a place that totally lifts your spirits.  You can let all your worries fall away and just focus on the variety of German beers, the sweet sweet applesauce, and the crispy shredded potatoes you're munching on to absorb the beer.
author: Sara B.

description:
Comfortable German pub with excellent food, always busy but the wait is never too long.   I have eaten here on a number of occasions and always come away well satisfied.  If you want a table for 2/4 it can be tough, most likely you will sit at one of the larger tables with another party.

Stellar selection of draft and bottle beers from Germany/Belgium, the beers listed on a chalkboard behind the bar show daily/weekly specials, this in itself makes the wait for a table almost a pleasure.  I have never tried the wines and again they seem to have a wide selection with a number of weekly specials.

Food is wonderful.  On this visit we had - Potato Pancakes with Apple Sauce; Pork; Lamb; and Venison Sausages.  All very very good as were the side dishes.

Service was spot on.  Place is clean.  Nice crowd.
author: Des D.

description:
Yes, there is a bit of a wait...make a reservation if you have 6 or more!

Before dining at Suppenkuche, I hadn't experienced much good German food. This place definitely changed my mind about German food....

My 5 friends and I shared a few dishes.....They had a daily special of GRILLED STEAK WITH TRUFFLE BUTTER AND POTATOES AU GRATIN that was sooooooo juicy and yummy! I wish I had it all to myself. Other good stuff: POTATO PANCAKES WITH APPLESAUCE, VENISON WITH SPATZLE, BREADED PORK LOIN WITH ROASTED POTATOES, GIANT PRETZEL WITH CHEESE SPREAD...Oh and their  PORK SAUSAGE WITH SAURKRAUT and MASH is pretty bomb dot com! They serve it with a hot mustard that compliments the sausage and homemade kraut perfectly. mmm, sooo good. My friends got 3 two-liter boots of beer, they have a good selection of german beers. Oh they also have lambic, Framboise (Rasperry beer! It tastes like a popsicle! :P) 

P.S. The Apple Streudel was good, but I could've done without the raisins in it. Can't wait to come back and try other goodies.
author: Diana L.

description:
Yay! German food! German beer! Wooden tables! Big loud bartender dudes!

Beer is really good (I had two fancy German hefeweizens and they were both great).

Food is spectacular. My fiance and I had venison medallion thingies, which were tender and tasty, and wienerschnitzel, which was bready and hot and tasty. I really like the pickled-ish cabbage stuff, too, and the macaroni-like pasta things.

Good ambience, too. Bunch of hipsters mingling with older gentlefolk and happy families. Everyone gets along in fake Germany!
author: Michael B.

description:
DAS BOOT

Doesn't matter how many carbohydrates you'll eat at Suppenkuche. It won't be enough to slow down the beer swimming through your liver, even after 1 liter.

Excellent German food! The potato cakes contain crack, I think. So good. I'm not a beer person, I'll be honest, but I love drowning myself in their hefes. Great selections all around.

The only thing this fun establishment needs is another restroom. 2 are just not enough.
author: Colleen V.

description:
Pros:  good beer, good portion, good food

Cons:  it can get loud and crowded but food was good enough to bear.
            Parking is hard
author: Bayarea K.

description:
There aren't many "biergartens" in the SF area, and this place was surprisingly good for a group.

If you like traditional German food, they have all the good European stuff like pickled herring (Scandanvian?) and blood sausage.  Pretzels aren't my thing, but people seem to like them with their beer, especially when topped with melted cheese.  My personal favorite German dish is the traditional Wiener Schnitzel - tender pork pounded thin, breaded, fried, and served with traditional potato salad.  I've had a recent obsession with spaetzle, so the Jägerschnitzel is perfect - mushroom sauce over pork loin and spaetzle.  They do pork well, including a pork chop and sausage, but they also have venison if pork isn't your meat of choice.  They also had a half roasted chicken that was super flavorful.

They have tons of beer, but I might be the only person who prefers the Gruner Veltliner (one of my favorite types of Austrian/German wine) goes better with the pork dishes.  Though they have red wines by the glass, I'm not sure how well they go with the food.  As for the beers, the list changes every so often, but I'm a hef fan (with a squeeze of lemon!) and they have plenty of draft options (and bottles).  For the most authentic experience, you have to try your beer out of a boot.  Surprisingly, they even have non-alcoholic German beer (umm I guess if you just like the flavor and don't actually want the EtOH...), but it's the same price as real alcohol (if not more expensive).

For vegetarians (and non vegetarians), I love potato pancakes with apple sauce.  Mushroom ravioli is on the heavier side but is also good for vegetarians.  Cheese spaetzle is like a better textured mac n cheese, but it's also on the heavier side (but that's why Germans are so traditionally well built, right?  j/k).
