I've never seen a place where the line for the men's bathroom is longer than the one for the girls, but I guess it's because all the guys are drinking the 2L boots.

They do take reservations for larger groups (max 20 people, must all show up on time).  They don't do split checks for large parties, though, which can be a pain.  Parking can also take a while on a weekend night.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Sorry to rain on the 4 and 5 star beer parade. The bartenders here are GREAT. Super helpful and really want you to like the beer you pick from the large menu of deliciousness. I would suggest grabbing a beer pre-meal if you can and stand at the bar. Also, smaller groups were eating at a the bar which is a great idea if its packed.

My favorite plate is the Wiener Schnitzel, breaded pork goodness. The Marinated and Braised Beef was not as good as the schnitzel in my opinion BUT I love the Ligonberry sauce. I also really enjoyed the delicious butter that comes with the bread.

Negatives - the hostess is not so friendly. We were told it would be about a 30 minute wait, which was no biggie since we could grab a beer at the bar. One hour later I think its perfectly okay to go back and ask how much longer they think it will be. Well let me tell you, she did not think that was ok. I get you are swamped, but its as easy as saying your table is up next, or its going to be a bit longer. No reason to be rude!
author: Natalie N.

description:
I had bunch at Suppenküche and-- surprise-- I did not die and go to heaven. But still- go there. Though I am fond of Stacks', Absinthe, Altano and all of the cozy breakfast options that Hayes Valley offers, I'd be hard-pressed to declare that any of them can hold a light to the simple and hearty Bavarian yums that are to found at Suppenküche. 

It's a bit of a commitment for your peace of mind so early in the morning-- I found myself far less amenable to bumping elbows with strangers (with babies, no less, and those manipulative SFers know that you get better service with a baby in tow-- drat) and packing down really warm, rich food in the AM hours, and I'd say the best options are mostly still available for supper. But are you really one to sleep through an opportunity to chow on gravlax and Suppenküche's wonderful (once personally doctored with salt) crispy tater cakes? If so, I don't know you and I'm not surprised that we're not friends.
author: Nuri K.

description: Checked out the oktoberfest lunch the other Saturday the verdict: spatzle with cheese and a half liter of Polaner really hits the spot on a hot day. And those giant pretzels are soooo whatsup
author: Oleg H.

description:
New Years Day--BFF and I are searching for a place that's open for dinner and we come across pictures of the infamous 2 liter boot of beer on yelp. We know that we HAVE to have it.

The atmosphere here is wonderful. It's a small place and because there aren't so many tables, if you're with a small party, you will be seated with other small parties at the same table. A little daunting to me at first since I've ever only shared tables at asian restaurants where no one talks to each other and everyone just sits and eats their food while conversing with whomever they came with. BUT, the atmosphere at Suppenkuche is not the case. We ended up meeting so many different people as they came and gone with their meal. There is so much energy in the restaurant. A table was cheered on for drinking 5 liters of beer. (JESUS CHRIST!)

Our waiter was very friendly, so we decided to leave him a FAT tip. We ordered the venison, the pork sausages, the potato pancake, and the black forest cake along with our boot. All were good. The venison was not bad for being a virgin deer eater. We ordered the potato pancake because of the reviews on yelp, but honestly, I could have done without it. It was a little too fried for my liking, but that's just me personally.

In short, this place is amazing!

Edit 05/15/11:

Came back here for dinner again. Ordered the trout. IT WAS HEAVENLY!! You must ORDER THE TROUT!
author: Lily Z.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for sometime now.  I tried going there on a friday night around 8pm and was told that there won't be anything free till 10pm. So we left and went to another restaurant.  We really wanted to try German food so we came back the following week on a random wednesday around 7pm and was seated right away.  We didn't know how to pronounce anything on the menu but with the help of our waiter we chose some pretty yummy stuff

THE "MUST HAVE": 
1. Grilled wild boar sausage - flavorful, not too fatty or oily, and came with yummy sauerkraut.  

2. potato pancakes - it came with our chicken dish ( which wasn't too impressive) but the pancakes were perfectly fried, crunchy on the outside but nice and soft on the inside.

3. fried pork chop- crunchy and delicious but it was a little bit on dry.  

THE " YOU CAN DO WITHOUT":
1. The chicken - It was grilled but it was very dry and did not retain much of the flavor from the seasoning. 

2. Braise beef - very rough and not very flavorful. 

OVERALL: the portions were huge, we ordered 4 dishes (not including the salad) for 5 people and all of us were extremely stuffed.  The service was great too.  there was a mix-up with our salad order so they ended up giving us a free order of the salad.  With a beer each and the 4 dishes our bill was ~$140 pretty good considering how full we were.  I can't wait to try their other dishes and beer!!!
author: JY L.

description:
Great place for your group of friends! Their menu is simple but delicious! Can't go wrong with meat, potatoes and beer! 

This place is usually busy every evening, even during the weekdays, but it's well worth the wait, just have a beer at the bar while you're waiting. 

I ordered the Roasted Chicken with Dumpling that came with the most amazing potato pancakes. This chicken is by far the best chicken I've ever had: it was moist and flavorful. The dumpling is stuffed inside the chicken so eaten with the succulent chicken--it's to die for. Potato pancakes: they're like hash-brown pancakes, you get the crispy outside and the potato-y inside--perfection! Eat that all with beer and you have a meal that you'll never forget!
author: Evangeline W.

description:
Vastly overrated.

I've never been to Germany, but I did live across from a Weinerschnitzel for five years.   I therefore feel entitled to comment with some authority about sausages/and/or Germany.

The first thing about this place is the overwhelming aura of hype.  Before I had even unpacked my apartment friends were asking if I had been.   Friends of friends were raving about the sausages.   Little birds sang out 'Sauerkraut, sauerkraut!' in the Hayes Valley morning.

I cruised by several times, only to be dissuaded by the enormous lines wrapping around the corner.   I'm not waiting an hour for what amounts to mashed potatoes and a hot dog.

On my actual visit, I came just as they opened, and scored a prime table, and had the joint pretty much to myself.

The food is... well, it's okay.  There's a lot of it.   By the time you pile through a plate of sausage, sauerkraut and potatoes you feel heavy, listless, sleepy.   One wonders how the Germans almost conquered Europe twice eating like this.

The staff were indifferent, as staff tend to be at popular joints.   

I did like the hyperminimalistic decor-- just wooden tables and simple menus-- every baroque extravagence stripped away with German engineering efficiency.

The net experience left me confused:  At the end of the day, the food reminded me if anything, as one of those places at a busy airport terminal:  Bland, non-offensive, designed to put you to sleep and sell some liquor.   

Within the 45 minutes my meal took, the place went from 'Just me eating alone' to 'jam packed birthday party celebrations' with loud clinking and cheering.   This is the opposite of an intimate place for a date or a quiet meal-- come here prepared for revelry and drinking.   

Did not impress.   Reccommended only for out-of-town frat reunions or serious sauerkraut cravings.
author: Brill S.

description: I always visit this place while in San Francisco! The food and service are outstanding, love the communal, dressed down feel.
author: Natasha S.

description:
It's not bad, but it's not Leopold's.  I've been to Germany twice and I will say that both restaurants have good food and beer, but Leopold's just takes it to another level--with better decor, better energy, and St. Pauli girls.

A group of friends and I came here for dinner on Sunday, and there was no wait.  We began with a round of cold beers and the appetizer plate with ham, blood sausage, salami, and cheese.  It was delicious and diverse in pig parts (my favorite was the pate), but I much prefer the house-made salumi platter at Leopold's, which is not only bigger but cheaper.  We also had the pretzels, which I can't say were superior to Aunty Anne's Pretzels.  Yikes. 

I wasn't hungry, so I ordered an appetizer as my entree.  I selected the currywurst, an appetizer that wasn't much smaller than an entree, substituting potato pancakes for fried potatoes.  The currywurst was so unimpressive.  This is my favorite German street food, and Suppenkuche's version was just bland sausage in mostly tomato sauce with a hint of curry.  

I was so happy with the potato pancakes, though.  Suppenkuche does them better than anywhere else, including Leopold's.  Here, they're crisp outside, soft inside, and packed with potato.  I especially love them with the homemade apple sauce as an appetizer.

I also tried some of DF's wiener schitzel and MS's bratwurst and spatzle.  Their dishes were much better than my currywurst but equally heavy and unhealthy.   Where are all the veggies besides potato (sauerkraut doesn't count)?  How can a culture's cuisine be based solely on meat and potatoes?  Even a porkivore like myself enjoys a cauliflower here and there.

Despite it not living up to my great expectations, Suppenkuche does have one of the most fun names in the restaurant business.
author: Liz T.

description: Having been here a few times. First time 15 years + ago on a date who's, I guess, Germanic, returned again this past year and have been back for a few times. Dinner, brunch, breakfast, in reverse order.  Dating situation with the said date, as I vaguely recall, ended after that meal, not because of the food, obviously, because the food was the strongest impression of that date. Fast forward a decade and half later, came here for dinner, then brunch then dinner. Have since gone to Germany a # of times, married a guy who's spent a year living in Germany as a foreign exchange student, speaks decent German, and then brought my foreign exchange student, from Germany here as well. If you crave German food, this is Bavarian food so not the same as Northern German food. I love Munich and have been there a few times, so food here is closest to my beloved country and region of Germany. For some rather strange reason, I still like the breakfast cheese / meat / spread that I had 15 years ago with the date. It is not always on the menu, I think it's only for Brunch, and it is the closest thing I feel that I could get to the typical breakfast found in Germany and Austria. I also like the pancakes, children love them anyway. I have to attempt not to compare its food from the food I get in Munich, it would not be fair. But I like the food enough to come back over and over again. Seating is always an issue. I usually go with a large crowd and get the backroom table. Hosted a dinner party there at the back room with 12 people attending. It was a lovely Sunday dinner and I love that they gave me the largest table that fit 12 people.  Not pricy for what it is. I just remember it was a great meal and I never stressed about the final tab.
author: Victoria E.

description:
It took some good research to find this place, and another 15 minute walk from our hotel. However this place ended up being everything I was expecting and more!

Ever since spending a week in Munich for the Oktoberfest last year, I have been yearning to replicate the German experience. I have been let down at most of my attempts so far, but Suppenküche is about as good as it gets.

When we arrived, within seconds we were greeted and had our name put down on a list. We barely were able to order a couple of beers (Hofbrau and Spaten, naturally) at the bar before our table was ready. Its all communal style, so we shared our table with two other parties of two. It was all good, nobody go in anyone else's space and it was rather comfortable.

After getting seated and finishing up our warm-up .5 liter beers, we ordered my main reason for coming here: DAS BOOT! It seems to be more of a novelty stateside than it is in Germany, but still awesome nonetheless. When ordering a boot, keep in mind their policy is to keep a credit card on hand, as they will charge you $50 if you break the boot. So drink carefully!

Our food came out pretty quickly, we shared two separate orders. One was two pretzels with a cheese dip, and the other was the 20cm sausages with eggs and potatoes. The food was good! And everything seemed authentic, even down to the spicy mustard and the snap of the sausages. I was used to bigger Bavarian pretzels but at least Suppenküche got the lye right.

After all was finished, naturally we ordered another boot. This time it was of Radler, a very tasty and refreshing mix of mostly beer (Helles) and some lemon lime soda. There is a precise skill to getting this mix just right, and the Radler we were served here was just as good as anything I had in Germany. I find Radler to be a good choice for the last drink, and I made sure I was pretty buzzed when I drank it in Germany and here too.

I will definitely be coming back when I am in the city again, my only disappointment that quickly faded here was the lack of a TV. With Munich and Dortmund playing in the DFB Supercup, it was the only thing missing from the German experience here, other than the actual language.
author: Chris B.

description: This was one of the first places I visited when I had moved here to San Francisco and was extremely pleased with the visit.  I'm no German but I have had the opportunity to visit many a time.  The atmosphere and setup reflects the typical German pub.  Community tables always throw people off but this is exactly how it is back in Germany.  A great way to enjoy full, wholesome food over some brews.  The staff is extremely chill and helpful.  Hayes Valley in and of itself is beautiful but this location adds a nice taste of culture to the quaintness of the neighborhood.
author: David W.

description:
So much fun!!!

I came here as a group of 6 and got one of back tables where you share with other parties.  Das Boot? Of course you have to order the Boot (2 Liters of fun -- roughly 66oz).  ** Tip: if you still want to enjoy all the food, don't get too full off the beer.

What else I (we) order:
Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce - Awesome! Like hash browns on steroids.  Wasn't sure how the apple sauce would taste with it, but it ended up being very good.  A definite must-order item.

German Ravioli - Also very tasty!  Not too heavy and I would say is great to have with the beer.

Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce - I may sound like a broken record here, but this was also an excellent dish.  It was a generous portion and the Spatzle was so so good.  It's kind of hard to describe Spatzle, but I thought of it as pasta.

I would do it all over again!  5 stars!
author: Kevin L.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Sunday. Food was good and deserves 4 stars but the service was not great. The waitress practically ignored us after taking our orders. One of our party wanted to order a beer during our meal and we couldn't even flag down the waitress to get the beer. It's a shame since 18% gratuity was added to our check automatically.

The food on the other hand was great. The pretzels with cheese were warm and tasty. The Apfelschorle was delicious. The sausage that came with our breakfasts was amazing. I think the Kaiserschmarrn with Nutella and banana was a nice twist on the normal dish. The stand out dish was the Jagerschnitzel which was moist and flavorful.

Highly recommend if you are looking for mostly authentic German food!
author: Katherine T.

description: Great place! I loved the German beer and the sausages. Felt like I was in Munich.
author: Slava B.

description:
I just have to "review" this place for the sake of reviewing.  All of the other 1400 or so reviewers have said enough about this place, so there's really nothing I can write that hasn't been written before.

Come here for food, come here for beer, but most of all, come here for an experience.  It was awfully loud when I went, but the staff actually did what they could to manage the noise.

Drink copious quantities of German beer from novel containers.

One last cool thing.  If you ride your bike there and order certain items, you get a nifty little bicycle-sparrow patch.  Look at my pictures!
author: Jesse M.

description:
If you're in the mood to drink a ton of German beer with some buddies, Suppenküche damn near guarantees a great time. It feels like you're at home, just hanging out and kicking back more beer than is good for you. The star of the show is the Das Boot, a huge 2+ liter glass boot that is guaranteed to induce speech impediments and balancing issues. As a German beerhouse with a great selection of German beers, Suppenküche is as good as it gets in SF.

As a restaurant, however, the food just isn't that great. I mean, you'll get tons of deep-fried, sausagy, starchy goodness, but overall it's just average German food. 

-----------------------
FOOD:

Braised Beef w/ Cranberries & Red Cabbage = This was just average. The braised beef was decently-tender, but tasted a bit like canned beef stew. The gravy was bland and unexciting.

Appetizer Plate w/ Blood Sausage & Head Cheese = This tasted like your run-of-the-mill deli meats and offal that you find inside those pre-packaged deli platters at Safeway. It was okay, but nothing special.

Spaetzle = The spaetzle here is too dry and too overcooked.

-----------------------

Suppenküche is definitely a must if you're looking for a fun German bierhaus. The beer is the main star of this venue; the food is the lackluster supporting cast.
author: Roy C.

description: Love, love, love this place! It truly is German food. For the beer drinkers, a great selection. I had the frambach which is my fave for beer - yes girly. Anyway, the asparagus appetizer is so good, must do. I meatloaf entree is also delish and the spatzle is done perfectly. Def coming again.
author: Jessica C.

description:
We've passed by this place so many times, and it always looks busy.  We never really bothered to look at what type of place it was, or why it was so crowded.  When our friend suggested eating German food, we agreed (because German food is awesome), and were surprised to find out that it was this place.  We got there at the perfect time, and only had to wait about 15 minutes to get a table in the back.  We sat right next to the kitchen, and even though the order bell was super loud, it was pretty cool to see all the food being set out.  We got tons of food.  I got the Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus (potato pancakes with apple sauce), and the Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und Grünem Salat (breaded porkloin with potatoes and salad), and the boyfriend got the sausage with spatzle.

Everything we had was really good - the potato pancakes were great, and my schnitzel was awesome as well.  Our friends got the chicken special, the porkloin in mushroom sauce, and the meatloaf, all of which were great as well.  Love how much food we all got.  Of course, some beer was had as well (you can order super gigantor beers here).  Really awesome place, would love to come back again sometime soon!
author: Jenna L.

description:
My second time was as great as my first!  I will definitely throw this into my normal rotation (even though there's too many great places around Hayes to try!)

I'm assuming this is authentic, but I'm not German, so I can't gauge that to anything?  But in my mind, it's authentic :-D

The beer is great, the food is great and the communal tables are great!  

We met a German couple, with accents and all, who have lived in SF for 16 years and a Romanian couple, also with accents, who are visiting from Pennsylvania!  Aside from my dancing taste buds, my ears were delighted to hear the conversation between all our different backrounds! 

My not-so-authentic, aka 3rd generation German boyfriend was impressed I could pronounce spaetzle so authentically (o:  

Whatever you do, get the VENNISON!  Even you vegetarians out there will love it, ha, jay kay.  Kraut's good though.
author: Alex T.

description:
Great food, horrible wait. 

I'm always amazed at Suppenküche's wait staff. They deserve some kind of an athletic award, I'm sure. This tiny restaurant that's probably the size of a barbershop gets filled to the brim with people, and the hosts and hostesses are still able to provide service where some restaurants the size of football fields with legions of staff can't seem to even muster a semblance of service. I really think they should post a capacity limit sign somewhere because Suppenküche might be a fire hazard. Either that or I've just never seen it because the fog of people always seems to obscure my view of it. All in all, I have never been to a restaurant where tips seem so justified. 

The food here is great also. It isn't too expensive considering the quality, authenticity, and quantity. The food here is an all around crowd pleaser. They also have a great selection of beer.
author: Alan H.

description:
OK, if you are a beer-drinking dad with a toddler or two this may be the most important thing you read on the 'net this year:  Sunday brunch @ Suppenkuche is your O A S I S !!!

Place has great German food and the beer list is the best west of Zum Schneider.  Place is SUPER kid-friendly on Sundays and if you get there before lunchtime proper you'll be seated at big communal tables in the room closer to Fell St.  Highchairs so no chasing, place is loud so screaming youngsters fit right in - eat, drink & relax!!! 

Seriously I'd have brunch here every non-working Sunday the rest of my life if I lived closer.
author: Glenn L.

description:
Beers, beers and more beers. Also käsespätzle - aka German mac n' cheese - and potato pancakes. Not to mention a variety of heavily meat-centric dishes this vegetarian girl won't go near, even after beers, beers and more beers. However, I've never heard a carnivorous friend complain. As for me, I've been happy with the food the half dozen or so times I have been to Suppenküche, aside from finding the potato pancakes to be way too greasy once. However, washing them down with beer (at brunch, no less!) solved the problem nicely.

The only other downside I can think of is that I once went there with a party of six and they totally spaced on our reservation. Not cool; however, mistakes happen - what can you do? They were very apologetic, made sure we got beers right away, and seated us as soon as the possibly could. Nice recovery, and we had a great time regardless. 

Good food + beer + friendly ambiance = awesome.
author: Janna M.

description:
Went to celebrate brother-in-law's 24th birthday.  Food is excellent (first time trying German Food), but of course the beer is what you go for.  The boot requires a $50 deposit (in case you break the thing) and the cost ranges from about $5-$7 per .5 liter.  So a boot is 2 liters, so do the math.....total cost is going to be around $20-$24. You can also order smaller or larger sizes of all their draft beers. 

I have no complaints about the food or the booze and although it's family style seating, when you go with a group, it's not really an issue.  I could see it being a little weird if you were on a romantic date or something.  =)  Only reason I'm not rating a 5 star is that it was my first visit and I tend to prefer to rate 5s to places that are also consistent.  So I will definitely be going back and when I do, if everything is as superb as it was tonight, then this will be a five star review.  

PS:  The prices are reasonable, but it's the kind of place where you may have the tendancy to order a lot (especially the beer) and so that final tab will creep up on you.  We went with a party of 5 and the final bill (with gratuity) was roughly $225!
author: Stephanie D.

description: We snuck in here on a Wednesday afternoon and still had to wait a while with a party of 2. You will get sat with another group of you don't take up an entire table so be prepared to be social and meet a few new friends. There is a reason why the line is so long here, food is good and the beer is even better. We would go here more often if it wasn't so packed.
author: Amanda C.

description: Every time I eat here I leave satisfied. The steak is my favorite. The chicken must have been raised by Jesus himself and the potato pancakes are everything.  I'm guessing not a lot of black people come here because every time I come the room stops for a minute lol but this review is based on the food.
author: Eshawn S.

description:
I had their special lamb chops with brussels sprouts and mash potatoes and shared the salad. The salad was super good. Beets, different types of cabbage and potatoes. I can be happy eating that everyday. The lamb was smothered in some sort of gravy. The meat was surprisingly tender, given that it was cooked through, more braised and less grilled. 

The place was packed and loud. Definitely a good place for a small group. They don't take reservations, by the way, so be ready for some standing around/waiting.
author: Alice W.

description: I came here with my Midwestern mother on her last night visiting San Francisco! Amazing comfort food, great service, LOUD ambiance.
author: Kit S.

description:
The food was good, but nothing to rave about.  The portions here are rather large.  But maybe I stuffed myself with so much beer that the food became less enjoyable.
To start off, we got the Potato Pancakes which had a soft interior with a nice crispy exterior, but they also tasted like burnt oil.  Eh.
I ended up trying a little bit of everyone's food.  (Hey that's what happens when everyone else ends up buying a boot of beer, and is too full to finish their food.)

In order of favorite to least, these were the entrees I tried:
Bratwurst (Pork Sausage) ~~ Pork Knuckle ~~ Wiener Schnitzel (breaded porkloin) ~~ Venison Medallions (Gebratene Rehmedaillions) ~~ Half chicken.

The chicken was dry and overcooked.  They came with bread dumplings, which just tasted like mushed-up bread stuffing.  The venison wasn't as tender as I would have liked.  I loved how the bratwurst was sitting in a bed of mashed potatoes... mmm.

The interior is small, and decor is minimal.  It had a dark-underground-cellar kinda feel to it.  I think overall if I had to get German food in SF, I would opt for Leopold's, or maybe just hang out at the Biergarten a block away. 

Overall, somewhere between 3 and 4 stars.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Suppenkuche is always packed during the evening and rightfully so, they serve some pretty great, no-frills grub and brews. Their menu is kept pretty simple, and their beer selection is plentiful. We waited about an hour on a Saturday evening, 30 minutes less than what we were estimated for.

Both the sautéed venison medallions and bacon wrapped meatloaf were worthy of high-fives. The red wine plum sauce on the venison was wonderful and the red cabbage and spatzle were surely shut-up-im-eating mouthfuls. I'd come back here for those, but really for the beer! Try the Franziskaner Hefe-Weisse; nice and crisp.
author: Bruce M.

description: When I first ate there several years ago I thought my grandmother was in the kitchen, the next time I was absolutely not impressed and I tell people that they waste time, money and taste buds
author: Michaela M.

description:
I just want to eat their sausage for the rest of my live long days.  

Too good.  Honestly.  And it is the perfect place for big rowdy birthday parties, especially when the birthday girl fits the entire bratwurst into her mouth and gets a round of applause from the whole banquet room.  

That being said, if you are coming here and are going to be anything but loud and boisterous, you may be very annoyed.  It is extremely busy and crowded, and everyone is shouting and clinking.  Not a good one-on-one/romantic place.
author: Rachelle P.

description: Very helpful with beer selection. Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce are just the right crispiness- ask for a side of sour cream. I promise best combination ever. Make sure to order pretzels to go with your beer!!!
author: Julie R.

description:
I really wanted to like this place a lot. The pictures of my friends ordering large boot glasses, essentially 2 liters of beer, always really impressed me. If you were enjoying strictly drinks here, then I would give this place a strong 4-5 stars, but I was here for drinks and a meal to celebrate my friend's birthday.

The curb appeal of the restaurant is currently lacking because of the street construction but that's not really their fault. Once you step inside, you feel transported into a cellar like atmosphere. The walls are painted white and are nicely litup by natural light. It may be hard to spot at first because there are so many people and the atmosphere is lively, but the ceiling is decorated with wooden birds hung by hooks on the wall organized in flocks. It looks like the owners rearrange them for fun frequently because there are so many hooks all over the ceiling. The bar area is a key focal point as you step in and is really inviting.

I really liked the selection of beer on draft and bottle that they had available. The bartender was really helpful too in asking how dark of a beer I wanted and pointing to the right selection. I had a Weltenburger Dunkel, which is a really dark caramel colored beer. It went down really nicely, and I brought it with me over to my table once my friends were all together. We decided upon sharing a Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus (or Potato Pancake with Homemade Apple Sauce) to start things off. Unfortunately, I found a long hair strand in my portion. Not a very good start. Then the entrees came out. We ordered: two rib eye steaks (a special); two half chickens; one Wiener Schnitzel; and one Lentil Soup (for a Vegan amongst us). For myself, I had the rib eye steak and I was not blown away, but it was certainly good and cooked to my liking (medium-rare) with some nice truffle butter. This made up for the hair in the potato pancake. I tried some of the chicken, which I wish I had ordered instead. That was moist and tasty. 

Being a special day, I pulled the waiter aside and let him know that it was my friend's birthday right after I ordered. Usually you don't think twice about it, but there was a long pause after all our entree dishes were taken away. I was waiting for the waiter to come by with the slice of cake for my friend, but instead he came by with dessert menus and asked if we would like dessert. Some friends who didn't exactly know either, just said, "Oh its his birthday!" The waiter then admitted he completely forgot! Classy move! So we waited several minutes as the waiter came back out with a slice of cake for the birthday dude.  Hoorah! This was the second hiccup of the meal. Although, these were personal things that I experienced as a diner and some of my other friends had less of a feeling towards this, I felt like the staff could have tried harder. 

The meal ended up being around $26 for each person, not including drinks. You might add $6-8 dollars for a beer to that tab. I would say it was slightly overvalued, but being my friends birthday certainly good times. Another thing of note, the decibal level is off the charts, because of the acoustics in this restaurant. I was sitting about 2 feet away from my friend at the table and I could not hear what she was saying. I would come here again for the drinks or happy hour, but most likely not for the food.
author: Michael C.

description:
Boot! Boot! Boot! Boot! Boot!

I had the fresh corn soup, which was delicious but a tad too sweet towards the end. I also had the meatloaf and I finished it. That speaks for the dish itself.  I also  had a bite of the rib eye and it was chewy like bubble gum. I don't approve.

Suppenkuche is one of the best places to wind down after a long week. The noise fills the room with adrenaline. And it's a great place to pressure your friends to chug a boot filled with beer!
author: Christina W.

description:
My husband and I really enjoy this place.  The food selection and beers are great!  However, you have to be in the mood for this experience -- yes, experience -- because it's loud and unlike any other.  

Things we like:
- potato soup (best ever!)
- wiener schnitzel 
- roasted half chicken 
- grilled pork sausage

Honestly, you can't go wrong with any of those dishes, they are SO good.  However, it's not healthy at all haha... which doesn't totally matter, but worth mentioning.  My stomach is always a little grumbly when we leave.

As I mentioned, you have to be in the mood for the experience.  It's SUPER loud and has communal seating.  I think the setting kind of brings out the macho in people, especially little men, because people seem to like beating on their chest here.  It's all good if you're drinking and in the mood to join them.  Also, it's just kind of a fun place to take someone who's never been -- they definitely won't forget it.  

Also, be prepared to wait especially on weekends.  Enjoy!
author: Jade F.

description:
The thing about customer service is that the customer is not always right, but the server shouldn't be rude. 

Maybe I have high standards bc I wait tables in this fair city and know that customers are super demanding and insatiable at times....Maybe bc my adopted grandmother is from Germany and is gruff, but always conscientious and courteous, but whatever it is I left Suppenkuche last night fuming.

A group of folks and I went here around 6pm to get drinks and what we thought was dinner. We were delighted to get a large table in the back and promised we would be out at 8pm as they had a large reservation. Our server was quirky and on the ball the whole time, promptly bringing us drinks (even when he told me I should finish my beer before ordering another) until we decided we didn't want dinner after all. 

When he found out we weren't going to order mains, shortly after seating, he told us that their policy is to allow drinks and apps at the bar. We told him we were sorry, we would be leaving shortly and we wouldn't do that again. We all felt bad about it, after all we did change our mind and it was costing him in the pocket. 

But what angered me was that he came back not once or twice, but THREE times more to tell us their policy. To drive it home. On the fourth time, I told him that we told the hostess upon entrance that we were going to get snacks and maybe food. Maybe there was a miscommunication. Either way we got it. WE TOTALLY HEARD THE FIRST TIME. But to just drive it home even more, he had the hostess come over and explain the miscommunication.

I went to the bar manager and spoke with him about the situation. His response was fairly nonchalant: "Sorry, the German gruffness is hard to relate too." I pointed out that that wasn't the case at all. We had in fact heard the 1st time. We had even apologized to him for our mistake. What was the point of the server to tell us 3 additional times? I tried to explain that the gruffness wasn't the problem, the problem was the server was rude beyond nationality.Who wants to be belittled? Is that how you make people feel comfortable and want to come back? Or because you already have a customer base you can treat people poorly? But then the bar manager just turned to me, arms folded across his chest, and said, "I understand, you just want to be heard." Jesus Christ! Doesn't anyone in that restaurant listen?

No, I wont be back, even though it is in my hood, my Gran's favorite resto, and the best German beer around. Nor will the other people who were there with me.
author: Sara A.

description:
I was first introduced to this place by a friend and from that point I was hooked. I've been here several times since and will keep coming back for more.

This place is crazy to say the least. The restaurant is not that big and on top of that, it's crammed with people most of the time. Unless you come here right when it opens or towards the tail end of service, be prepared to wait a LONG time. Usually it's under the amount of time the hostess tells me but the last time i was here, it was double the time. Definitely rubbed me the wrong way on that one.

The beer selection is great if you are a beer drinker and even better is that they have boots (2 liters) and even one bigger (5 liters). Assuming you don't have to wait too long, the food is pretty damn good. I've never been disappointed by anything I got here and I can't imagine getting disappointed anytime soon.

Word of caution, this place is loud and cramped. If you are looking for a cozy quiet restaurant for a date or something, then this is NOT the place. Come here with a bunch of people if you can and make reservations (6+).
author: edward k.

description:
I can't believe this has over 2,000 reviews!  It's so easy to look over this restaurant because we walked right passed it the first time.  We had to backtrack and look at our handy-dandy iphone to locate it.

Everything is in German and the English translation is underneath.  This made it quite confusing but we realized just to look straight at the smaller words printed underneath.  

For starters, we wanted to try the pretzel but it was out. Boo.  So for our appetizer we got the:

-Reibekuchen Mit Hausgemachtem Apfelmus  (potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce): If you like fried, crunchy chips, you'll love this.  You've got the hard, crunchy layer on the outside with a soft, mushy center on the inside.

For our entrees we got: 

-Wiener Schnitzel Vom Schwein Mit Bratkartoffeln Und Grünem Salat (breaded and sauteed pork loin with roasted potatoes & green salad):  I thought the wiener schnitzel was going to come out in sausage form but that's a bratwurst to my understanding.  That's how much I know about the German language.
-Lamb chops: I don't know what the German translation is but this was a very delicious dish. 

All the dishes were quite heavy.  I was hankering for some vegetables, which they brought out in the form of some butter lettuce and vinegary cucumber slices.  If Suppenkuche is an accurate representation of German food, that makes me concerned that I will not get enough vegetables in my diet.  I would most certainly have some bowel problems if I visited there.  

Seating is family style.  And it's loud.  Not a good place to take a first date.
author: Tori Q.

description:
I can only continue to reinforce the great reviews before me.  This place is a find!  Toting a great selection of beers, I was blown away when I had the opportunity to choose between 6 different hefeweizens, not to mention the huge collection of other styles.  

The food is solid German fare - expect large portions of meat paired with potatoes, cabbage and spatzel.  Its flavorful, well prepared, and while the menu for the beer is bigger than the menu for the meals, it has a good amount of diversity.  

My party of two was greeted immediately and able to sit at one of the family style tables.  Our waitress was polite and attentive.  

Other notes - the restaurant does get busy, so arrive early, or be prepared to wait - thanks to the family style tables, you shouldnt wait too long, and there are plenty of beers to enjoy while you do.  Since it is a bar, it does get quite noisy, and with strangers sitting beside you at the table, it may not be the best place for a romantic date.  Lastly, try the black forest cake - its to die for.
author: Virginia B.

description:
Suppenkuche has been on my bookmarks for years (literally) and I finally got the courage to brave the long wait with a friend. We arrived around 6:30 and was told it would be an hour for a table for 2. The atmosphere was VERY loud and lively, with everyone drinking large boots of beer and having the time of their lives. It was much smaller than I had imagined and sparsely decorated, with communal tables scattered around. 

2 glasses of wine and 2 hours later...we finally got seated after pestering the hostess. Starving, we ordered the potato cakes, veal, and duck. In my opinion, the dishes were okay and definitely not worth that long of a wait or prices. In hindsight it was probably not the best place to catch up with a friend, as I felt like I was about to lose my voice trying to talk over everyone there. However, I hear they do take reservations for a larger party, so perhaps I'll give Suppenkuche another shot.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Came at 6:30 with a party of four. The place was already packed, but we barely had to wait for 5 minutes, because our entire party was there. So take note, if you're smaller than a party of 6 (only parties of 6+ can make reservations), make sure everyone is there when you want to eat, otherwise you won't be seated. 

Service was prompt and our waitress was nice. Now on to the important part: food and beer! Both were awesome. Don't come here if you're on a diet. I had the cheeze spatzel, and it was like beautiful german mac & cheese on steroids. Also tried some of the bratwurst - amazing saur kraut and the pork bratwurst had a really nice flavor. Overall I'd definitely recommend this place, but for the sake of my waist line I don't think I could come here for food more than once every few months!
author: Jennifer M.

description: First time here and will definitely not be the last. Definitely a community gathering place. They have some great beer on tap with boots! I had the potato apple sauce, pork sausage sauerkraut mashed potatoes, beef with cranberry sauce and red radish. Everything was very delicious although unique for me since I hardly ever eat German food, but it was very tasty and a good change of pace. This is a good place to take friends and dates if you're looking for a solid place to eat and drink.
author: Kevin H.

description:
If there's a great selection of beer, I'm pretty easy to please.  Yeah, it's super busy, yeah, it took forever to get our table (even with reservations), and yeah, there was a super annoying laughing hyena all night, but the beer more than made up for it!

The bartender I happened to order from set me up with an awesome beer.  Honestly, I can't remember what it was, with all their beer names, but he was good at recommending me something based off a few questions.

All I had to eat that night was the cheese and sausage platter and potato pancakes.  The potato pancakes are basically fancy hash browns, but they were scrumptious nonetheless.  I really enjoyed the wide selection of cheese and sausage on the platter, but my friend didn't seem to care for it as much.

Alas, DAS BOOT!  We've all seen Beerfest (at least you should have...), so it was pretty cool getting to drink from the boot.  Careful not to break it because they keep a CC as a deposit and will charge you $50 if you break it!

Come back for food?  Maybe... Come back for beer?  Definitely!
author: Christopher L.

description: Loved this place. We had the best German food outside of Munich here. I was especially pleased to see that they served their wienerschnitzel with prieselbeeren as they did in Munich. The beer selection was excellent and the service was too. Some soft pretzels, and I would have thought I was in Munich again.
author: cathy s.

description:
After enjoying a show at the Orpheum Theater, we went for a walk with the intention of spoiling ourselves rotten on good German food. The website said "Come on in! No reservation needed!" So, we walked over and we happened to get there at the 5:00pm opening. We were the last in line, and thus had to sit at the area behind the bar.  Being hungry and excited, it was acceptable. 

The bartenders were very attentive to their regular customers, and rather nice to us first-timers as well (since we had to place our orders through them). It was stuffy and cramped, and then got even MORE stuffy and cramped when the second wave of customers came in. It got loud, but you know what- this place made it seem so enjoyable. San Francisco charm plus European atmosphere. 

The food was superb. On a scale of one to "made-by-eine Mutter", this was right up there with a home cooked meal. Everything we ordered was plentiful portions, meats deliciously hot, and cabbages perfectly pickled. The beer and wine selection was fantastic. It's a little slice of Germany.
author: Jamie H.

description:
What a fun evening. Maybe it was because the bf and I were with great friends, maybe it was because it was our first time at Suppenkuche...who knows, but it was lovely. Hostess was very friendly, but super slammed with the wait list, Baretenders were nice, but also crazy busy. Once seated...service was fast and very friendly. Prices were just right and portion sizes were fabulous (enough to be full and take leftovers home). Below are a few of our favorite dishes...

Highlights -
*Potato Pancakes (comes with apple sauce, but i love thr spicy mustard instead)
*Gemischter Salat (Mixed German Salad with Cabbage, Carrots, Beets, Potato Salad & Butter Leaf Lettuce) $8
*Vesperplatte mit Schinken, Blutwurst, Salami und Käse (Appetizer Plate with Ham, Blood Sausage, Salami & Cheese) $19.50
*Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße mit Spätzle und grünem Salat (Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spätzle & Green Salad) $18.50

Beer and Wine only, but a pretty large selection of both. 

Note - they don't take reservations and there aren't that many tables...so expect to wait, especially on the weekends. Put it this way...we showed up at 620p on a Saturday and our wait was roughly 2 hours. I admit...it was long, but worth it. 

Overall...besides the long wait, everything was fantastic. I highly recommend you give them a try, even if you're not a German fan...there's something for everyone. Go...NOW!
author: Dru M.

description: Käsespätzle forever! What is better than fresh plump noodles with butter, cheese and onions? Nothing, that's what. I've been told that the meaty meals are delicious and authentic too, but give me all the noodles with the side of beets and carrot. The dense bread given out is also really good with the dill butter. So much butter everywhere. The beer selection is excellent as well. This is a great place for groups of 4 or more, but not great for a date. It gets loud, and you have to share a table. Do as the Germans do and talk to strangers! Or just sit uncomfortably next to people you don't know and hope they don't ask you to take a picture of them eating their food.
author: Kristy S.

description:
I was on the fence on this one. 

Four star rating: 
*BEER! You have to give it to them for having the boot. 
*The food was good. The spatzle was incredible, but very heavy. The pickled herring was a surprising winner.
*Hip, young crowd (20s/30s)

Three star rating: 
*The wiener schnitzel was a surprising boo. Very dry.
*Service was lacking, no fault of the waitress; it's plain bedlam. 
*Super loud, makes conversating difficult. I mean like really loud. 
*No room. Ladies, don't wear a skirt or dress, you might have to do some tricky maneuvering to get to your seat.

I'm glad I went.

Deciding factor: 
I just won't go again.
author: Cassie C.

description:
Boom!

If you are a big man who likes big food and big beer and big tables - this is your place.  Getting a seat is hard - but just stand by the bar and drink until a table opens up.  I had breaded and friend pork chop here that was several times bigger than my head and perfectly cooked.
author: Michael S.

description: Excellent space and great food. Good for groups. Make sure you make a reservation beforehand or you'll have to stand in the cold and join the queue.
author: E. O.

description:
Of the three German places I've been to in SF, this is my favorite!  The goulash soup was delicious, as was the schnitzel.  The braised beef was pretty good - good flavors, but maybe I was just overwhelmed that it looked like I had the whole cow on my plate.  Portions are huge.  Leftovers!

Their beer glass collection is quite a wonder - goes up to the 5L.  I think I saw someone chug a 3L.  Puts the 2L boot to shame.  I'm not sure what you call the biggest one, but it's like the size of Gulliver's boot. I feel like I could fit inside!  I also had the best beer I've had in ages but I don't know what it was called - I was going to settle on the Spaten Feistbier but he recommended something else and it was like heaven in a stein - I need to find that out.  The Marzen was pretty good, but it had a little bit of a bitter aftertaste.

This place is loud, you get seated with other people sometimes, service isn't all that friendly, but it still is extremely civilized - it's no Hofbrauhaus, but thank goodness it's not.
author: Traci H.

description: The best German food and beer in the city! I have not had many good experiences eating German food in my life time but this place definitely turned that around. The location is ideal, corner right in the heart of a flourishing neighborhood (Hayes Valley). The outside is subtle, with a very small sign it's pretty hard to miss. The inside is very cozy with dim lights and a bunch of family style wooden tables. They also have a bar but it is pretty small with about 7-8 seats. You HAVE to try the beer here it's essential. Amazing menu of authentic German beers with something for every pallet. The food was awesome. Started with the potato pancakes served with applesauce, filling and very savory with a good texture. For my main course I got the fried pork, it was very flavorful and tender. It came with some delicious potatoes with bacon as well. Overall This is an amazing place, highly recommend it to stop by for a quick tasty beer or even for a date night, you will leave very content.
author: Josue V.

description:
Now, I am no expert on German food, but Suppenkuche definitely takes top honors in my book. They have a fantastic selection of food and they also have a great selection of German beers in all sorts of sizes!

The restaurant itself is fairly intimate and airy. It has a very communal feel to it that just makes you feel like you are in some aunts kitchen. 

The food was great. I opted for the grilled pork loin that was served with sauekraut and mashed potatoes. It was just downright good and perfect. The loin was cooked perfectly with just a twinge of pink in the center and full of hearty flavors. I stole a bit of my friends braised beef which was fork tender and a great blend of spices and another friends grilled pork sausage was great!

The beer selection was top notch and for those venturous enough can order a 5 liter giant glass. I opted for the 3 liter glass boot of beer and barely finished it but it was just downright amazing. 

It makes me happy and warm inside to think of suppenkuche and I will be there again.
author: Chad Y.

description:
A good place for a night out with friends. I've tried the sausage and the steak, and both were decent. What you're going for is the fun ambiance and of course the alcohol.

If you like beer you have to get THE boot! It's just like in the movie beerfest where you drink from a ginormous glass boot filled with who knows how many cans of beer. It was quite entertaining watching my coworkers compete to finish the boot.
author: Alice J.

description:
Finding a real authentic German "Wirtshaus" in the US isn't always easy. Yet, the "Suppenküche" in SF comes very close to it. A crowded place with long plain wooden tables a beer mug filled with cutlery and paper towels just as you would expect in Munich or other south German places. 

The beer selection is big and so is the menu that will convince you by the German names in the menu. Servings are on the big size and so are the prices. Try the Potato pancakes as a starter. But I have had better Wiener Schnitzels than the one here. It was a little on the dry side. In general, expect to pay $40-60 per Person if you are going for a 3 part menu, not including drinks.

Parking at the restaurant can be tough. Though we were lucky and found a spot one block away. but I can imagine it being tougher on a weekend night out. 

All in all I would definitely come back. Perhaps just for a main dish and a authentic German beer. Prost!
author: Samuel R.

description:
I have wanted to try this restaurant since I moved here and finally got the opportunity when I friend from Florida came to visit.

The atmosphere is fun.  Expect to share a table with fellow diners. Our food was great- we had the pork with mushroom sauce and the chicken meatloaf.  I also had one of their beer on tap in a huge mug.  

Our waiter was attentive, friendly, and helpful.  He recommended a great beer to go with my food.
author: Christy L.

description:
Pork sausage all day everyday. NOM NOM NOM. The food is so yummy I just have to be here again, I also ordered the boot drink filled with 2 liters of beer of your choice. Food and atmosphere is just the way I like it. I don't like how the place is cramped but I can't complain because everyone here loves their quality german beer and food. Pork sausage with potato and relish was the best I had in a while. Normally I don't eat pork but this pork sausage made me go onk all night long. 

You only have 2 hour limit reserve at your table to finish up your food and the back room has bigger tables for bigger parties. The reason why you only have a 2 hour limit is because people have made reservations which go from 7-8 weeks ahead. I would suggest bringing a party of 3-6 people because the place is very crowded especially with the bar in the first half of the room. The beer boot I ordered was a medium smooth sweet flavor which was delightful. I pretty much got my a$$ kicked by the beer boot towards the end of my dinner. Never try to finish the boot beer by yourself or not. LOL
author: Chris L.

description: Nice room to eat in with an amazing range of beer and excellent menu.  Food is quite good.  Good location and decor.
author: Phil G.

description:
The place looks like sleek restaurant from the outside, but once inside you may as well feel like you've stepped into a quaint little German cottage.  I came during the holidays so they still had cute Christmas decorations up.  

They have a small but nice group of beers.  Unfortunately, they were out of their dark beer so I settled for one of their specials which wasn't as rich as I would've liked.

We ordered one of their daily specials, the Gebeizter Lachs - cured gravlox with dill-mustard sauce and potato pancake.  First of all, their potato pancakes are amazing, crispy on the outside and chewy in the middle.  I could eat these all day!

We also ordered the Kassler vom Grill (grilled pork sausage with sauerkraut & mashed potatoes) and the Jägerschnitzel (porkloin in mushroom sauce with spaetzle).  I noticed a lot of people eating the breaded porkloin and was debating on which to order, but our server was very nice and offered the option of substituting the regular porkloin for the breaded. 

The food is hearty and the portions are large.  We took home what was left of the food.  And when I heated it up the next day... boy was I amazed!  It still tasted great~  I liked how the spaetzle soaked up the juices and was even more flavorful the second time around.
author: AJ K.

description:
Good beer. Good food. Good times.

Another positive review to add to the multitudes. We have come in groups over the years, ordered everything on the menu, and frankly never had a negative experience. Will Germans look at the menu and double take on the prices? Yes. Am I German? 

You get it.

Come hungry and with an elastic waist band if you are a member of the clean plate club. Probably take muni too.
author: Easwud C.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend on our weekend food hunt. First thing we noticed when we walk in was the giant glasses of beer and the boisterous atmostphere. There were a few people standing waiting for a table, the hostess told us that there waiting list was full and the earliest we could get a table was at 9pm, which was about an hour and half away...so we decided to come back. 

Came back at 8:50 or so, the hostess was able to seat us at a table with two other couples. We were all okay with it so there were no awkwardness, plus the jolliness of the atmosphere made it seem like we were all in the same big party.   

We took a look at the menu, there's a daily special menu, unfortunately the item that we wanted on there was out that night. =(

So instead we decided to order:

Kartoffelsuppe (Potato Soup)
Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus (Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce)
Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße
mit Spätzle und grünem Salat (Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce
served with Spätzle & Green Salad)
Franziskaner (Beer)

There were complimentary bread and some sort of sourcream-ish butter. Wasn't a big fan.

The potato soup was delicious, a little bit on the salty side for me, but the taste was great. Don't expect chunks of potato, I described it to my bf that it was like a smashed potato soup. 

The Potato pancakes were also very good with applesauce! It was something like hashbrowns, except it didn't feel or taste oily (but it was still fried so you can see the oil...) but still very good.

Next we tried our main dish...the Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom sauce. This was an awesome dish! The pork was very tender and moist. And with the mushroom sauce it was absolutely DE-licious! The Saätzle was like noodle but with a more dough-y texture. It was very good with the meat and sauce as well. Wasn't a big fan of the green salad...I think it was cabbage with a light tarty sauce.

Everything was really good with my Franziskaner.

Service was good, street parking. Great place to bring a bunch of friends for happy hour and good food. Would definitely want to come back and try some other items on the menu.

Btw, all our food came out pretty quick!
author: Amy L.

description:
The food is good.  I strongly dislike German food (I ended up in the ER after a week in Munich from not eating since I hated the food so much), but I really enjoyed my meal at Suppenkuche.  I kind of wish I ordered nothing but the potato pancakes with extra applesauce.  I don't remember the rest of the food that well, but those were the bomb.  I'd eat them every day if it wouldn't turn me into Fatty McFatpants.

They have a glass boot that you can buy to drink your beer out of... The boot is a cute novelty, but really you're just paying for your beer to get warm.  I guess if you have a hardcore foot fetish or you plan on chugging it ala Beerfest, it may be worth it.  It comes in a 1.5L and 5L sizes... Good luck with 5 liters of beer!  FYI, you don't save any money buying the boot... the 1.5L beer is 3 times the cost of a 0.5L beer.  But hey, you drank out of a glass boot like some kind of drunk cowgirl Cinderella and no one can ever take that away from you.  

The reason I rate this place so low is how uncomfortable the actual restaurant is.  It's SO DAMN LOUD and crowded.  When you open the door, chances are you can't actually walk into the restaurant.  I had to interrupt people's dinner to ask them to move their chairs to be able to walk in.  Sucked for them, sucked for me.  Once you find the host, be prepared to wait an ungodly amount of time to eat.  I think we waited 45 minutes on a weeknight.  Once you're inside, give up any hope of communicating.  The noise level is somewhere between dance club and jackhammer.  

I was eating dinner with 2 friends and we were sitting on the end of a communal table with 3 other strangers on the other side of the table.  In case you missed that, here it is again:  Communal tables.  I thought this was America!!  Huh?  Is this America?  I'm sorry, I thought this was America.  

Good food, but overall the wait, crowd, communal tables, high prices, and insane noise level just make it not worth going to.
author: Stu R.

description:
Had some potato pancakes and beer. Pancakes were very crispy, and went nicely with the applesauce. A touch of salt out of the fat would go a long way. But tasty.

Obviously, great beer.
author: Eric B.

description:
Yummy food AND yummy beer! Score!! We came here about 15 minutes before they opened for dinner on a Saturday. There was a good amount of people in line at that point but we were lucky enough to get one of the last seats. Some randoms were seated with us since there were so many people and little seating, but it was no biggie.

I couldn't pronounce half the things on the menu, nor the name of the restaurant, so there was a lot of pointing and question asking during the ordering process. We ended up getting the wiener schnitzel, lobster soup, some sort of pretzel thing, and OF COURSE a boot of one of the Hefeweizens that the waiter said had undertones of banana. Everything was suuuper good!

They were a bit slow in taking our orders, but that was kind of understood since they just opened and already had a full house. I'd definitely come back and recommend this place to others. Come early to avoid the long wait and make sure to order a boot of beer! You can never go wrong with beer and plus it's great for photo ops! (:
author: Malyssa C.

description: Hey, the potato pancakes are so good, that's all I can remember.  I don't know much about German food, but what I ate was filling and seemed like ideal comfort food.  They have an extensive list of beers and the bar seems to be the centerpiece of the dining room. The place draws a crowd quickly and the noise level also gets high.  They have communal seating so the tables get quite crowded when your dishes arrive. Overall a good experience and I'd come back for more food and beer.
author: Renee L.

description: I came here for my friend Steve-O's bday party. It was an excellent choice. I had the Cheese Spatzle and several sizable steins of beer. The Spatzle was so tasty that it made me melt in my seat and the beer was splendid. We all sat around a rustic looking table and it felt like I was in the tavern from Beowulf. It was an awesome experience.
author: Bobby N.

description: Possibly a 3.5 but I would need another try. Not a bad place, has good beer and a nice and loud atmosphere. The food could be worse but definetly better too. Since we r far from Germany this place will satisfy ur cravings.
author: Matey P.

description:
Great food all around and a nice selection of beer. The meatloaf is excellent. The apple strudel is just the right level of decadence without weighing you down.  The mashed potatoes were silky, buttery, and absolutely perfect!

I am obligated to dock them a star since their sauerkraut is too sweet, and thus not sour enough. But I am a sauerkraut snob, so take that last statement for what it's worth. 

That said, if you want to go to a place with solid German food, I definitely recommend this place. I'll be returning for sure.
author: Art W.

description:
Summary based on 1 dinner:
--good, classic German food
--friendly service
--reasonable prices
--good queue management for the hordes waiting
--very noisy
--challenging parking (try north on Laguna)
author: Rich H.

description: Minus one star because it's SOO loud, but the food and beer are great! Their salad starter is fresh and helps you feel better about the rest of the food coming up. Beet salad, carrot salad, German potato salad, white cabbage salad, red cabbage salad. Yum.
author: Susan B.

description:
Hearty and flavorful!  I had a half a chicken with the potato pancakes.  Great flavors and lots of crispness.  

It is extremely loud in here, but the service was great.  Two guys at our table were drinking 2 litres of beer in a large glass boot!  

We ordered the salad to start and it is a pickled extravaganza!
author: Amy H.

description:
Haven't had this place in years, but the quality of the food has remained the same since the last time I've been.

Nice, quaint restaurant located in Hayes Valley. My only complaint would be the parking, but it's San Francisco, what else could you expect even on a weekday? They seem to have a butterfly theme going around the restaurant and the loud noisey atmosphere makes it the perfect place to wind down after work. No worries about being too loud at all.

Onto the food! Their potato pancakes were perfectly made: crispy on the outside and warm on the inside. Their apple sauce wasn't too sweet and complimented the pancakes very well--good appetizer. Tried three entrees: lamb chops, salmon, and their sausages. How can you go to a German restaurant and not try their sausages, right? Best ones I've tried yet. Moist and well seasoned sausages which were paired with sauerkraut and mustard. Fresh salmon was served with capers, which gave it the perfect amount of sourness to it. Last, the lamb chops were perfectly cooked to how it was ordered: medium. Not tough at all.

Homey atmosphere, but bear mind that if you have a smaller party, you might be sharing tables with another small party. I'd recommend a reservation because this place is extremely popular for the food and the beer, rightly so if you ask me.
author: Kerri L.

description:
Pure heaven.  

Vibrant atmosphere.  Amazing service.  Mouthwatering food.

Between the 5 of us (and the two people at our table who willing shared THEIR meals as well) we covered just about everything on the menu and most of the appetizers.

I know you look to yelp for menu suggestions (and I did too last night), but as you'll notice, people recommend EVERYTHING here.  

So just throw caution to the wind (as well as your cholesterol count) and dive in.

Portions are HUGE though.  So feel free to share.

And if someone at the table orders the 2 liter "Boot", you must politely applaud when they finish.  It's the first rule of Suppenkuche Club.
author: Mike V.

description:
Ich liebe Suppenküche! This has to be one of my all time favorite restaurants. After a trip to London, and staying at a hostel with a large group of hot German guys, I became obsessed with all thing Germans, especially the guys hahaha.  So I decided to learn German and take a trip to Germany last summer.  But I then realized that I had never really had German food except bratwurst ( and even then probably not authentic bc I've always had them on buns).  So i did my research and decided that Suppenküche was were I was going to fall in love with German food.  And guess what...I did!! Not only was the food amazing and the atmosphere cozy but they served beers in 2L boots?! Wunderbar!  

Over the many times I've been here since last year, I've has the Potato Pancakes (the BEST I've ever had), the Pickled Herring (not a fan), Gemischter (mixed salad), Wiener Schnitzel, Jägerschnitzel, Sauerbraten, Gebratene Rehmedaillions (venison), Bratwurst (the way it should be served), and Käsespätzle (German version of mac and cheese).

I have honestly loved everything I've ordered, with the exception of the pickled herring.  Every time i eat here though, I have to order the Potato Pancakes.  I slather on the extra apple sauce and it's pure perfection.  On my most recent trip, I ordered the Käsespätzle, spatzle smothered with a onion cheese sauce, because of my Lental obligations. I was glad i gave up meat because this dish was AH-mazing! My bf who isn't a fan of spatzle was trying to eat my entire meal! How rude! But I couldn't blame him.

Getting a table here can take awhile, but it's worth it.  Most of the times I've eaten here with my bf were shared table with other folks, but it's never a problem.

Well I love German food but I love German food from here. I've tried others but none have compared to where I feel in love....
author: danielle l.

description: I went here last night and really liked it. Very attentive and helpful staff, delicious potato soup, like really delicious, as were the dumplings. The beer choice is ace too. In the evening when it's dark, and the candles come out on the communal tables with the hubbub of the other diners drinking beer, the atmosphere was great. Very tasty apple strudel too! Would go back, would recommend!
author: Chris M.

description:
Itch lie be Mich Inge Nietzsche Essen! 

I know I've been with my boyfriend for a long time because as we drove to SF on Friday, we both thought of going here with his cousin and his newly fiancee, who came to visit the Bay. Now it wasn't a spur of the moment thought, it was a whole day of thinking where we should go to dinner and we both thought of this place before we even discussed it. Okay I bored you with this nonsense, on to the review. 

It was CROWDED. And the meh part (and almost a minus) was there was no real waiting area other than the bar. Than I thought, "WTF is wrong with that, Jamie?!?". Whew where was my head that night. Now if you asked me what my boyfriend got me to drink, I couldn't say. I just know it was amber-like, delicious, and enough beer to inhibit my thoughts of silliness to my scorn of no waiting area. Pffft what a seating snob I am. 

What I loved about Suppen is their community tables which and bench sitting. I love that environment because I wasn't expecting an intimate double-date evening, but a celebration of visiting relatives and new engagement into my boyfriend's familia. 

I know we ordered appetizer, I think it was the Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus or was it the Maultaschen in Pilzrahmsoe? Hell if I know because that is what happens when you have good food and company, you so do not pay attention to the details except getting to know the people around you. 

My boyfriend and I shared the Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst
mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei, which is sausage (pork) served with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. I believe his cousin ordered the Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein
mit Bratkartoffeln und grünem Salat  and his fiancee ordered IDK. I think I was more engrossed in the proposal story of my boyfriend's cousin then I was in the food. 

However, this is what this place does to you. Makes you comfortable. Makes you happy go lucky. Makes you wish you cleaned out your liver after sizing up the boot. Has you counting your pennies to the next time you can come in here and share a 4-liter of beer with friends/family or the people at your table. 

Danke and guten zeiten
author: Jamie L.

description:
Das Boot!!! Its a crap load of beer! I don't drink often, but watching my friends drink while I was eating was funny. Service is great! They always make sure everything is fine and very attentive. It was kinda small and a little cramp. Anyways, besides great service, the food was definitely good.

 Highly recommend the meatloaf bacon with gravy and mashed potatoes, OR the pancake waffle meat thing. haha already forgotten the name. Little Pricey, ( that's if you get the Das Boot with Meal) but hey its freaking worth it and awesome. 

If you're looking for bud light, corona, and other stuff, look else where. Mainly German beer. Oh word of advice, don't break the Das Boot. It's a pretty expensive mug. Too bad, they don't give the Das Boot when you finish or it'd be perfect! Definitely coming back!

Oh did i mention they have a cool theme in there too? Can't seem to figure what it really is. It made me feel as if I was in Germany. Great feeling and good vibe.
author: Andy L.

description:
After living in Germany for 2 years it was like I was right back in a German beer house. The restaurant is set up in the typical German style of long tables that you share. There is a good beer selection with the typical beer steins as well as the das boots an 5 liter mega steins. The food is delicious! Everything we had was great and very authentic. 
The only downside is that is very difficult to get into. If you have parties larger than 10 you are able to make a reservation. If not you better prepare yourself for a few hour wait on a weekend night. There are a lot of nice bars in the area where you can wait and continually check in if you pick this route....
author: Paul P.

description:
Disclaimer: this review is about Suppenküche's beer only; I did not get to try out much of it's food so I'm unable to comment on the food itself.

My roommate had been waxing lyrical about this place for about a month before I broke down and finally decided to try it out. I made the amateur mistake of trying out a restaurant during peak hours on a friday night so my posse and I had to resort to stand around the bar looking like a bunch of creeps the whole time we were there, but this didn't negate from the drinking experience at all.

As for the drinks... where should I start?

I have yet to visit another restaurant that offers two types of Erdinger and Bitburger on TAP, and I don't think I'll ever find another one that lets you enjoy those German masterpieces in a 2L BOOT! 

There was actually a wait for the boot, since I guess every healthy male over the age of 21 has seen "Beerfest" and consequently have heard of the much-romanticized DAS BOOT. Suppenküche also makes you put down a deposit for the boot in case you drink yourself silly and either crack/break the boot. But in either case, if you have a penis, I believe I don't need to say much about this place other than IT HAS DAS BOOT! If not, I should tell you that the bar/beertender is very knowledgeable on the subject of German beers; the place has a very rustic "tavern" feel to it; the place is in the nice part of Hayes Valley, and is a great place to enjoy a drink or five to kick-start your weekend.
author: Scott S.

description:
5 Liters of Beer?!!??! MISSION ACCOMPLISHED
1 Guy, 2 girls and sips from others.
$60 for 5 Liters 

They ran out of the boots...WTF forreal?!?! Get more!!!

If you want that much beer go to Chug Pub 2.5 Liters for $30 with free fries or nachos..and enjoyed by everyone.

Food was really GOOD! and Really hearty! Compared to another German place I went to in the city...I left that place still hungry!. The wait staff was really nice and gave us plenty of attention and food came out fast and hot! really good!

I had the pot roast..it was a pretty tough piece of meat...It would have been better if it was a bit more tender...
author: Brendan L.

description:
Five of us visiting San Francisco had Sunday brunch at Suppenkuche last week. Each of us ordered something different and NO ONE was disappointed. A really nice experience away from the more touristy areas of San Francisco. The quantity and quality of the food was excellent and didn't leave you wanting for anything. The young lady serving us was as nice and attentive as you would want in a server. This may very well be the best meal we experienced during our stay in San Francisco. 

I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this restaurant based on our experience.
author: RW U.

description:
BEST BEST German food in town. 

I like to order the Bockwurst but switch out the mashed potatoes with spätzle. Runs me about $15 without a beer with no extra substitution charge. You should always come with a smaller group and earlier in the day. One time I had to wait about 2 hours to be seated. I'd recommend getting there about 6:30-7:00pm on a weekday to avoid the rush. 

But even if you are caught in the rush, it's very well worth it for the food and drink. Consider pairing your visit with a stop by Biergarten down the street.
author: Paul B.

description:
Definitely a place that you can enjoy with a huge group of friends. A place that seems like it would be ideal for: Going away parties, welcome back parties, anything that would allow you to group together, drink, be merry and have a good time over some fried food while gulping down a tremendous amount of beer.

I actually came here with my boyfriend, and we were seated at the end of a table of 10 at the last minute. We are good sports, so the idea of sitting with 10 potentially very rowdy people didn't deter us too much from having a good time. others, however, would probably feel differently.

Highly recommended are the Weinerschnitzel and the Potato Pancakes!
author: Lillian N.

description:
Good bar with nice atmosphere. Saw a lot of people with funny shaped beer mugs, like the boot!

I had a nice hefeweizen
author: Michael W.

description: Suppenkuche is a fun time.  Boisterous bar with German beers on tap, belly-filling food, and shared tables. Its a little frantic and loud. The cheese spatzel was, by far, the winner. The other dishes were forgettable. The german rye bread was dense and delicious.  The wait staff friendly.  Overall not amazing, not terrible.  Just 'good.'
author: Drew J.

description:
Finally, my long overdue review of Suppenkuche.... 

Long wait (1.5-2 hrs on a Fri/Sat night), getting your feet stomped on while trying to get a drink at the bar, cramped seating, and having to yell across the table in order to have a convo... 

Awwww, so WORTH it! 

So far I've had the pleasure of coming to Suppenkuche twice: 

1st visit: I ordered had the venison medallions in red wine sauce with spatzle. MmMm....the venison was very tender and flavorful (not salty). The red wine sauce was rich and had a depth in flavor; eminent that it was been sllloooowwwwllly reducing. Ohhh and the spatzle (fried noodles) was SOOOOO YUMMY! It was crisp on the outside and had a bite to it. *drool* 

2nd visit: After seeing people order the Pork Knuckle the first time I was at Suppenkuche, I knew I had to have it the second time around. Man, it's like a heart attack on a platter, but worth every bite. The knuckle is MASSIVE...probably as big as two of my knuckles put together. The skin is roasted to a perfect crackling crunch; similar to the chinese suckling pork...YUM! The pork meat is soft, tender, and flavorful. If it weren't for being in a public setting, I would have eaten it Fred Flinestone style! I wasn't too crazy with the bread dumplings as it tasted liked mushed up bread. But, who cares, when the star of the dish is the pork! 

SERVICE: This place is ALWAYS packed and the staff is always on the move, so expect to have to wave them down if you want something. But, they're very friendly and accommodating. 

AMBIANCE/DECOR: LOUD AND CRAMPED. If you're claustrophobic, don't even think about coming here. The place is always packed and you will be elbow to elbow with others esp if you sit in the communal wooden picnic style tables. Thinking of chilling at the bar to wait for your table? Forget about it, you might as well get a stick just to beat your way through to get a drink. Prepare to be yelling at the person next to you, just so they can hear you. 

Despite the drawbacks, the food at Suppenkuche is definitely worth it. Stomp on me, shove me, yell in my ear; but you can't keep me away from that damn heart clogging Pork Knuckle!

And, oh, don't forget about them beer boots...hopefully, one day I will get there...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
