Came here last Wednesday with my BF and was very pleasantly surprised!! Thinking "German Beer House" I thought it would be more like a dark mead all or something...quite the opposite! Although it is small and can be very loud, it is light, airy and have wonderfully cute decorations! 

We arrived around 7pm and there were people milling about outside and at the bar, but we were seated right away. Its family-style seating so we were at the end of a table with a family of four, I don't mind seating like that at all (especially if it means we get in quicker) but the woman at our table was weird...so 0 Yelp stars for her! 

I ordered the Potato Soup, which was delicious. Creamy but full of flavor! My BF ordered the Mushroom soup special and he liked it a lot. I thought it tasted like mushroom-water and needed more flavoring, but he ate it all so that was fine. 

For diner I had the Goose Special which was so mouthwatering delicious! It came with some red cabbage that had been pickled (or something) and a potato ball, which was interesting, but the Goose was divine. I got a huge portion, expertly gazed, and sooo tender and juicy. It came with some cranberry sauce which further enhanced the great flavors.

My BF got the Wild Boar sausage and those were excellent as well, I think he gobbled them up in a matter on minutes. 

The service was great, we had a female waitress who was nice without over doing it, and their bussers are efficient and keep a good eye on the diners and the plates. We didn't have enough room for desert, but the German Chocolate Cake that the weird lady and her family got looked really good!
author: Alissa C.

description:
Living in the IE, it's hard to find good German food that isn't hours away. So whenever we travel, I always make a point to find German food.

I found this little gem and it was ABSOLUTELY amazing! The wienerschnitzel was crisp and delicious. I got the spatzle with it and I am SO glad I did! It is literally the best spatzle I've ever had.

They also serve a spatlese riesling, which is hard to find. It was perfectly sweet.

The only part I didn't like (and I'm not marking them down for it, it wasn't their fault!) was that the people sharing the table with us were a bunch of snobby rich boys (their gucci shoes and Rolex watches gave them away). They left us alone for the most part but they were loud and it was hard not to roll my eyes at their conversations!

But go, eat here! The food is superb!
author: Casey V.

description: Loved the atmosphere. Sitting with strangers but leaving with new friends. The food was really good and the bier was excellent. Wished we lived closer.
author: Ice T.

description: Best German food I've had in the United States let alone San Francisco. The beer menu is superb. They had hard to find half liters of gelled beer.  We got potato cake appetizers for a starter which was excellent. I then got the bratwurst with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes, wow it was incredible. Other people in our group got the schnitzel and the salmon and all the dishes were superb. This place was incredible.
author: Randall H.

description:
Pros: accepts credit, great food
Cons: $$$, communal seating, loud/rowdy crowd

I came into Suppenkuche around 6:30pm. My friend and I were given the choices to sit right at the door or to wait 20 minutes. We took the seats closest to the entrance just so we didn't have to wait. The other guys at our table were almost done but they were still have a grand old time. This was my first time eating German food. My friend told me that I should try Spatzle because it is one of those traditional German foods to try. I ended up getting the Wild Boar with mushrooms in cream sauce with spatzle, with the recommendation of the other guy sitting next to me. I tried some of my friend's beers and they weren't too bad, very deep flavors. For entrees, I felt there should have been more boar on my plate for $23. Sure the food was good, and I do love spatzle now, but I would say I got a handful of boar meat, few mushrooms and a ton of cream sauce. I thought that dish, like the others on the menu were priced very steeply for the amount that was given. It was really loud and crowded the entire night. There was a birthday party further into the dining room and beers all around. Suppenkuche seems like a nice place to come have dinner, but I am not that big of a fan of communal seating, especially because the party of guys that came to replace the remaining seats at our table were just awfully loud and annoying. It may also have been just me, but I felt that it was hard to get the waitress's attention since it was so crowded....

In the end though, I probably won't come back unless; there's a promotion, party, or I can't find another place with good spatzle. This place is so overpriced and expensive and just loud and busy (good for them, but just hard to be comfortable in sometimes).
author: Alex T.

description:
This place is fantastic. We had never been before, and since I'm not German I had no idea what any of the beers were. The bartender asked a series of questions to find out what type we'd like the best and gave us her recommendations. 

The guys all ordered the boot. $28 for the entire thing (plus a $50 deposit in case you break it). I opted for a normal people beer, and it was delicious. The bartender definitely knew what was up. 

The food is FANTASTIC. We had the sausages and the venison. Next time I definitely want to try the pretzels - every table seemed to be ordering them and they looked so good. 

At the end we had a German shot (similar to fernet but with more bitters). You pound the shot on the table to mix the herbs and liquid and then take it with no hands. Defnitely a cool atmosphere. Wait is long, but its totally worth it. I'll definitely be back again.
author: Lauren D.

description: This place had a great vibe. The food was amazing and the beer was awesome. Service was very prompt and fast. I highly recommend this place if you like German food and beer.
author: Travis T.

description:
I like the vibe. I like the Boots of german beer. I like that they serve Coca Cola out of a bottle! I also really like the pretzels they serve with mustard.  The food was eh! for me but since you can't have it all, I still really enjoy this place and am looking forward to going back to tackle the boot of beer alone!

I would recommend making a reservation.  Without one, you will be left circling the bar area like a vulture until a space opens up, which may or may not happen!

Tip: When at the bar, look up! There is some fun and funky decor hanging from the ceiling.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Lived in Germany (non-military) four four years.  It is hard to find great, real German food. This place has it. Have been here four times. The staples are always good. The specials can be a little hit or miss. The beer is the real deal. Service is very good, although when the place is packed, as it often is, the service can suffer. The room noise can get up there in level. So with the complaints,why the five stars?  Because it all works.  Don't know how exactly but it has been four out of four. Great food, great true German beer (not Kalifornia Koelsch) , reasonably good to great service and you want your good friends to be there. So bring them.
author: Makrsch 9.

description: Man, this place rocks! From the potato pancakes to the bratwurst to the Sauerbraten, unbelievable! Lots of great German beers to pick from and the service is top notch! Be prepared of a the noise but that's typical of a great beer hall! Only thing that was disappointing was the apple strudel. You need to have great Strudel if you are to be a good German restaurant! Need to improve on that BIG TIME! Otherwise, go here for a great German experience!!!!
author: Peter S.

description:
One Liter Krugs.                                !CHECK!
50 plus German Beers.                   !CHECK!
Loud Clatter of Beer and Chatter.  !CHECK!
Schnitzel, Spaetzle, and Wursts.   !CHECK!
Wooden Community Tables.         !CHECK!

They've got It. A Beer Hall straight from Deutschland on the corner of Laguna and Hayes. Come early!! You will wait and it is worth it!!

I had the Venison and it was the best cut of meat I've had in years. 
Dankeschön Suppenküche!
author: R J.

description:
As much as it pains me to admit this - the food here is well worth the wait!

I've been here twice, both times I waited over an hour for a table. On both occasions I nearly hulked-out and destroyed the entire building before being seated. It's at that moment that I hate Suppenkuche.

Until the food arrives. 

Holy cow on a plate, what an experience! Every single bite will have more than your mouth watering. And imagine the experience with a boot of IPA. 

Yes, it is worth the wait. Yes, they know the food is awesome, which creates an air of douchbaggery among certain members of the staff. But calm that green monster down and head up the street to grab a beer while you wait, you'll be grateful you did, and your appetite will only be preparing itself for the goodness that is Suppenkuche.
author: Scott Z.

description:
No reservations means more time to stand around drinking beers out of a boot til you can drink no more.  But wait, you can order food while you're standing and drinking!  The potato pancakes were DE-LI-CIOUS!!! They were perfectly fried without being too oily.  And to wash it down with some beer was heaven.  We got two orders since my group totaled me and 3 guys.  I wasn't about to share my pancake, damn it!

About a hour and half later we got our table.  Too bad I was full already of beer and potatoes, the best combination ever, by the way.  Well, that didn't stop me from ordering a full meal where I ate all the spaetzle first.  My dinner wasn't awesome but I ended up eating everything anyways.  My night of carbs ended with some chocolate cake, German no doubt.  We left full and entertained despite the long wait.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Dear Suppenkuche,

I am a fan of your food and beer. I would like to suggest you get more non-alcoholic choices for those of us who go to your restaurant for the food, to be with our friends and for the beer hall ambience -- at your restaurant or at the BierGarten! The 
"French" lemonade you currently serve is sweet lemon bubbly water. Just like tastes in beer, some lemonade fans like a tart lemonade. The day after I went to your BierGarten, I went to the deYoung Museum. Then serve a sparkling lemonade called spindrift -- squeezed and bottled in California $3.50/12 oz. Made with 1 whole freshly squeezed lemon. It's from Healdsburg. Please consider adding it to your menu in addition to the current lemonade you serve at $4/12 oz.
author: Suzy B.

description:
Very rude host.  It is communal seating there, and a long wait. So two of my friends went ahead of me since I had to drive from work.  they ordered drinks and orderves before I arrived, and were there no more than 20 minutes. One left shortly after I arrived, meaning we were not taking up any more seats, and both me and my remaining friend still ordered plenty more food and drink. Even so, as my first friend left, and then AGAIN at the time of getting the bill, the host made a point of coming over and sternly scolding us for 'holding up seats while others are waiting' because I arrived late.  

To add to this, while the food and drink were good, it was very loud and we could barely hear each other despite being seated side by side. 

You know, I love good german food and good beer selection. And this place had both. But I also don't appreciate being scolded like a child and being made to feel like I am an inconvenience for taking up their seating while I am paying them good money. I will not be visiting here again.
author: Angela V.

description:
Suppenkuche,

I'm deeply sorry for turning your beautiful, candle-lit, family style restaurant into a scene from that broflick, Beerfest. To be fair, the entire restaurant DID chant, "CHUG CHUG CHUG!" as my friend and I inhaled your 2 liter boot in under 8 minutes. On the other hand, I probably shouldn't have done it again, almost immediately after, with a second boot. In 8 minutes and 45 seconds.

Now I'm part of the family right? Because I can drink your beer and still have room for your delicious Sauerbraten and Spatzel! I mean, I didn't feel too good walking out. I'm only 120 pounds and 5'2" you know. There's only so much meat and beer I can stuff inside my body before falling over from a faint gust of wind.

For what it's worth, you had me before the beer boot(s). You had me at potato pancakes and charismatic bartenders and beautiful ambiance.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Food, Delicious.
The Wait... not so awesome. 
Our party of 5 on a Friday night waited almost 2 hours. I'd suggest making reservations here but they only accept reservations for parties of 6 or more. 
 
They have a standard and special menu. We ordered 2 smaller dishes to share as appetizers: potato cakes and pork/mushroom ravioli. Sausage/ mash potato/ sauerkraut plate, braised beef/ pickled purple cabbage, and prime rib/ brussel sprouts/ potato pasta. With all the fried foods and meats we ordered, I was surprised that there wasn't much grease or oil. Everything ordered was seasoned well. The meats were cooked perfectly medium rare and was so full of flavor and juice. All the simple sides that came along weren't disappointing either. 

They had a good selection of beers of all sizes... including Boot sized draft. For the girly girls out there, you should try the bottled raspberry beer. Those who like reds and ambers, definitely go with the Lancaster on draft. 

Although I haven't dined at many German restaurants, I know good food when I have it and judging from other reviews, Suppenkuche is probably one of the best, if not the best,  in the bay.
author: Karen C.

description: Probably the best German food I ever had since relocating to the U.S...."schmeckt wie bei Muttern" :-). It is load, it's crowded but the food is awesome and the German Beer selection is really impressive. I love the little corner behind the bar...just enough room to hang out with friends and eat but very close to the supply chain. Also check out the beer garden a couple of blocks away!
author: Joerg B.

description:
The folks at Suppenkuche were great!  Friday last we had an early dinner here before a concert at the Nourse Theatre and it was awesome.  My parents have limited mobility and the staff were very accomodating, ensuring that my mother was seated at an appropriate table.  We lined up with the small crowd at 4:45pm and they sat everyone promptly, right after 5:00pm.  

The German and Belgian beer selections are extensive, and paired well with the food.  My father and I each had the half chicken with a dumpling stuffling, coupled with two awesome potato pancakes.  My wife and mother each had the jagerschnitzel (sp?) and they too were vary happy with their selections.

The ONLY downside is the noise level.  We were not bothered by the noise at all, but I can see that this would cause some issues with a date night or something more formal.  This is a place to go and have a good time.  It was a great place for us to eat and hang out before the 7:30pm show. 

We shall return.  

ps: Best wishes to the pregnant waitress that served us!  I never got her name, but she did an amazing job!  She was very sweet and accomodating.  Cheers!
author: Nathaniel A.

description:
Tried their apple cider + mineral water plus the venison dish. Big big portion -- if you are not hungry, you might want to share one entry and one appetizer with a friend.

The food was tasty if you can bear the long wait.

Super loud. Do Germans speak like that? Hope the waiter/waitress all wear some ear plug for hearing protection.
author: Amy L.

description: This is a good restaurant with fun environment. Although I don't know much about beer, the waitress recommended two hefeweizen beers that my friend and I enjoyed. We shared the potato pancakes and the trout. They were both flavorful and rich. We sat at a community table with two other couples but we barely even noticed them and it made the overall experience more fun. I will return again!
author: Tori B.

description:
Sure you could complain about the group seating... but why? That's part of the charm. This place is awesome. Great staff that's on the ball, I think the place has been packed every time I've gone. Real Deal German food. They even have a boot you can drink from. 

Come prepared for noise, great food, and great beer selection.
author: Ben R.

description: This place is so so good. If a hearty German meal is what you are looking for, you'll get it here. The place also looks awesome. Service wasn't so great, but she was busy.
author: Nat L.

description: Great German food and German beers ! Will definitely come back again. Good atmosphere and it seems always very packed.
author: Tracy D.

description:
BEER AND MEAT. A year ago I wouldn't have stepped foot into this place, but times change and now I'm a beer-drinking, meat-eating fiend! Let the good times roll! 

Step 1:
Get a group of friends together. Order the boot. Pass the boot around. Do not let the boot ever touch the table. Whoever takes the second to last sip from the boot buys the next round.

Step 2:
Eat the free bread to soak up some of that beer. It's sooooo good.

Step 3:
Order something that comes with Spätzle. It's my new favorite thing other than the boot of beer. I had the Venison, it was good. I would not, however, ever again heat up my leftover venison in the microwave. Gross.

Step 4: 
Pay bill. The boot will be about $30 and the entrees will be $16-$20. Go home feeling like a real (wo)man. 

Step 5: 
Wake up and get on a treadmill. This place is too crowded for its patrons to take up too much space.

Final Note: The fact that this place gets crazy crowded and doesn't take reservations for parties smaller than 6 (or 8?) is the only reason I give it 4 stars instead of 5. Also, they serve brunch on Sundays but not Saturdays.
author: Talia G.

description:
I wanted to surprise my mom with German for dinner, because let's just say Sacramento is lacking in this department. 

Made sure to get there around 5. We were immediately seated, so yay. 

Our server was wonderful! 

I am not quite sure how I feel about this place. Don't get me wrong, the food was good..maybe it was where we were seating. Or maybe it was the tons of people trying to get to the bar, not caring whether they smack you in the head with their purse, or elbows, or belly. I am pretty sure there is some kind of fire code law breakage going on here when the restaurant is seated to full capacity, and the line to the bar is like all the way to the door. And I think by the time we were finished eating, I had lost my voice due to having to scream to hear myself and the other person talk. And also I think I saw some bruises. 

I guess they reaaaaaaaaaly wanted it to be like an authentic German restaurant. I asked my mom if this is what the restaurants are like in Germany? She said yeah pretty much, except they have more room. I mean I was literally hitting people with my elbows with I tried to cut into my food. But the noise is pretty much spot on. I then said well, I am glad you decided to move back to the states before I was born. Maybe this is one of the reasons why MY SISTER IS SO FREAKING LOUD!!!

We ordered potato soup and potato pancakes to start. The soup was good, but different than what I am used to. The pancakes were tasty. Although my mom usually cooks onions with her potatoes. Loved the crunchy edges. And the applesauce was amazing. Just how I like it!

I had the succulent pig :p and my mom had the Jägerschnitzel. I really really wanted the Kassler, because I love love love it... but I didn't. Mine was good, except some of the meat was dry. My mother was pleased with hers. 

Didn't really want to bother with dessert. I just wanted to get the heck out of dodge. I'm not a football player ya know! Stop banging me around! 

Wenn Sie wirklich wollen, eine deutsche Essen, Reisen in Deutschland essen
author: Whitney B.

description:
Most horrible dinner ever! 
When I went there on Friday, it was really crowded. It was understandable, but i never expected it to be that bad. After waiting like 20 mins, we asked the waitress for an update, and she snapped back "You need to be patient!"
Then, they put us with another big group. It came out to be 9 people sharing one small table. I could't move at all or hear my friends talk. When i asked about this to the waitress, she said " We are always like this". The close contact with the other group resulted in a tense situation throughout dinner.
Overall, the service and tone of the waitress were really HORRIBLE.  I do not want to go there again!!!
author: SS K.

description:
I finally had the pleasure of eating at Suppenküche last night.  This place is always packed, so my group arrived at 5:30, so we could be seated right away.  I immediately ordered a Radler (lemonade and beer) and it was good, but I didn't feel like I was in Germany.

My meal was very good.  I ordered the butternut squash soup and trout and both were flavorful and delicious.  Other people in my party had the lentil and potato soups, which were also very good.  The only complaints were that the main courses were a bit salty (not the case with my fish).  If this place weren't so crowded, I would definitely become a regular.
author: Sarah K.

description: I really loved the food here! It's awesome and delicious. Would totally recommend it.
author: Nemesis J.

description: I like a loud German place with big portions and big fun so I enjoyed this place. I'm a cocktail lady, but every now and then I love a giant beer. You can't go wrong with a Jagerschnitzel and that's exactly what I did. I really liked the vibe here though and can't wait to stop by again. Also, it seems like making reservations is a good idea.
author: Janette W.

description:
I think this place is way overrated. I mean yes, it's authentic and has a warm and cozy atmosphere, but the food didn't have that wow factor for me. The One thing I liked though was the potato pancake.
Oh, and noise level is SUPER high.
author: Shirin E.

description:
It's just too crowded in here on a weekend night to justify the wait and the price. My party arrived at 5:30 on a Saturday night and were told it would be a one hour wait. Wow! We said okay and went to a bar across the street for a drink. Came back after 45 minutes, not wanting to miss our table....didn't get seated until 7:10 PM! Far longer than one hour. When we were sitting, it took about 15 minutes for them to take our orders, and the journey to the bathroom was harrowing. There were just way, way too many people inside. I feel like this place could get shut down by the fire marshal for overcapacity. It's so loud inside because of the overcrowding that we were unable to really have a conversation the entire meal. 

The beer selection was great and delicious, we enjoyed being able to order beer in copious amounts, and the food was quite tasty. Thus, three stars for good food and drink. I had the potato pancakes (first night of Hannukah, how could I not?) and the asparagus appetizer, which were both delicious. My fiancee had the pickled herring which was surprisingly sweet but the pickled salad underneath it was incredibly tasty. My party shared the pretzels which were just okay.

I'd come here on a week day night, or maybe for lunch, because the food and drink is worth the price. But the Saturday night vibe is not worth the cost of the food.

I'll also add that my party of six was seated at a table that we found quite small for us, but then the hostess seated a party of TWELVE at the table identical in size to ours directly next to our table, and my jaw dropped. One of the people in their party was standing for a good 15 minutes before a waiter brought over a chair for him to sit in. I can't imagine waiting as long as we did and then being squished in like that. Ridiculous!
author: Molly N.

description:
Do you need to be German to enjoy the German food? I hope not ...  because I found myself enjoy the food from all around the world, thanks to my work that allows me to travel around the world. 
   Yet Suppenküche and their food could not captivate me in any ways. Please don't get me wrong, their food was NOT bad at all but considering everything else that I've tried in my life, Their food was just OK for me. 
     For me, I only hope that their food will be more flavorful, I felt that their food was just a bit bland for me. 
     Service was decent. But there's not much to talk about their decor, it's very simple. 

3 stars for over all.
author: Dom G.

description:
The food & beer will never let you down. The best German restaurant in San Francisco as far as I know.

The service and wait can be a let-down though, so dont take an impatient group here. The seating is cramped and the service is slow/non-existent.
author: Jordan W.

description: Having just returned from a trip to Germany, I had an immediate craving for pretzels and Spaetzle. This place was able to fill the void with the addition of a refreshing Radler to drink. Suppenkuche is rather authentic and I have to say that the Spaetzle is on-point with it's mesh of onion and butter; not too salty or sweet. Make sure to ask for sweet mustard to go with your pretzel because that's how the Germans do it! Although the beer cheese isn't bad. Its a tiny place so expect long waits and a smudge of elbow room.
author: Allison M.

description: This is an interesting place to get some German specialties and good beer. It's a little small and it can get pretty full, at least it was on the occasion we visited, but that only added to it's charm. We sat at a communal table and met some interesting folks.
author: William F.

description:
I honestly rate this as the top German restaurant in the Bay Area. The only warning here is, be prepared to wait a bit. But, come on, it's a hopping venue in a trendy area of town with amazing food, great service, awesome bier selection and the most happy crowd you can imagine! It's social bierstube-styled seating, where you sit next to the party next to you on the same benches in the front, an alcove near the front door that offers cozy yet still bustly seating for those on a date and an individual party seating area in the back which is much quieter. Fabrizio the owner has also just opened a Biergarten at the end of Octavia, which is a great new venue in it's own right!

Go to the Biergarten with several friends, drink amazing drafts (HAVE TO HAVE SCHNEIDER WEIßE! BEST BIER IN THE WORLD!) and then trundle up the street to the restaurant for dinner after you have received your "adequate personality adjustment" and laugh heartily with new friends and old in this wonderful restaurant!

Massive fan here!!!!
author: Jim O.

description: I love everything about this restaurant. It's in a great neighborhood, the food is incredible, and the atmosphere is... well, it's unusual. Unless you come with a party of 6 be prepared to share a table with strangers. There really isn't much space between tables, so occasionally you'll be aware of the people at the table next to you, as well. That's the closest to a negative that I can come up with, and the food more than makes up for whatever discomfort that might cause.
author: Jaime O.

description: The atmosphere of this place is fantastic-- loud and fun. It was exactly like the pubs/restaurants I visited in München and Köln. It's not a place to have an intimate conversation-- it is a place to get rowdy with friends, drink some amazing beer, and have delicious food. Being Eastern European, this is very similar to our version of comfort food. We will definitely come here again.
author: Julia T.

description: I'm giving 4 stars just because the hospitality and food in this place are superb, I want to recommend you guys the potato pancakes with apple reduction sauce (it's amazing) and also if you and you buddies are thirsty as hell you guys should go down for the 5Lts boot full of beer.
author: Joshua M. A.

description:
Came here with a party of five on a Friday night and waited 1.5 hours since they don't take reservations unless it's a party of 6+. We had the option of waiting for a table at the bar but it was absolutely crowded so we huddled in the cold on their tiny porch area instead.

We forgot all our complaints once we got inside. I felt like I was instantly transported to Germany. During our stay, we chatted with the couple sharing our picnic bench-esque table (they warned us to be certain that we LIKE the beer before getting The Boot), participated in a birthday song as beer glasses and boots alike clunk in celebration, and gobbled up the moist pre-meal bread.

Now the food...I shared the Sauteed Venison Medallions with Red Wine Plum Sauce with Red Cabbage and Spatzle (doughy, firmer than noodles). It was perfect for two small girls who love trying new things in terms of portion and flavor.

The venison was juicy and paired nicely with everything on our plate, especially the plum sauce.

My one complaint is that the place is so crowded that, before switching to a spot near the wall, servers and customers were constantly bumping into me and our table with enough force that it bruised my fragile limbs. 

Wish I had gotten The Boot but it's $24 for the cheapest beer and it's $24 that this college student doesn't have.
author: Furai X.

description:
Horrible...really bad Fake German food..
15 dollar plate of throw away food.
Over cooked..roasted potatoes instead of german potatoe salad ..tough.inedible
Pork fillet..just god awfull.please try another place near by.dont waste you time on this. I eat in Germany every few months.nothing like it in this noisy cramped non atmospheric except place except names of dishes. So bad i wanted to start swearing.staff dressed like bums..dirty..unshaven..
How can thus be allowed?How could people give it positive  reviews?they must never have eaten in a proper german eatery. 6 thumbs down folks.
author: Dpn W.

description:
I freaking love this place. Let's all band together and discourage people from coming so it becomes less crowded and one can actually get a table on a Friday night, eh? 

No, but for reals, their food is always superb, their beer is delicious, and it feels like a German Hofbrau! No wonder it's always packed. It's the real experience, cramming in next to strangers as you sip on a boot of beer. I've witnessed the place explode in song as simple "happy birthday" song became a drinking chorus. The spatzl (spelling?) and the potato latke things with applesauce are amazingly delicious, but after trying the Pork with mashed potatoes and sour kraut I can't bear to order anything else. If I had all the time and money in the world, I would eat here at least once a week. It's worth the money, and I won't begrudge them their crowd- they earned it.
author: Courtney W.

description:
Considering that I didnt get to enjoy a full dinner here, maybe 5 stars is a bit much...then again when you have a perfect experience 5 stars is what you get.

We stopped in here on our way to meet up with friends down the street and Im so happy we did. Considering that it was a busy Thursday night around 8, I thought that we would have to wait to be seated, but to my surprise we were seated right away.

Positives:
Decor
Food 
Beer in boot shaped bottles
Pleasant servers

Negatives:
You are seated with strangers if your party is smaller than 6

At first I was taken off gaurd by the seating. I felt a bit uncomfortable sitting down with two couples who were obviously on dates. After we were there for a minute or two we adjusted and just became a part of their evening. We were ok with it...I hope they were too.

We ordered their famous potato pancakes and a beer. Our server was very knowledgable and not annoyed by our beer questions ( I like to act like I have no idea about beer to really see if servers know their stuff)  and she helped us both pick out brews that suited our needs. Our potato pancakes were cooked perfectly and they tasted amazing. Crispy and flavorful on the outside and a great potato texture on the inside. The apple style glaze for them could have had a stronger flavor but it complemented them well enough. 

The next time Im in SF Ill be back to Suppenkuche!
author: Shelley C.

description:
Great Brunch meal on a budget, most of the entrees on their menu less than $10, totally awesome for me!

We ordered:
- Kaiserschmarrn mit Afel und Pflaumenmus $8.00
Emperor's Pancake with Brandied Raisins, served with
Apple & Plum Compote
- Leberkäse mit Spiegelei und Brakartoffeln $8.00
Sauteed Bavarian Meatloaf
with one Egg sunny side up & Roasted Potatoes
- Wurstgeröstel mit Ei,
Kartoffeln, Speck und Gurkensalat $8.50
Roasted Pork Sausages scrambled with Eggs,
Potatoes & Bacon served with a Cucumber Salad

Drinks: 
- Erdinger Wheat $6
- Berliner Weisse with Raspberry syrup $8

The best meal out of those 3 would be the roasted pork sausages, it looked like meat-lover skillet from Denny's but taste-wise totally incomparable! This one was really good. mine looked like a spam but definitely not a SPAM!!! and the Berliner Weisse was good, but the Raspberry beer I tasted at FO was better =)

The place was nicely decorated, very cute flowers and wheats hanging above us. Also, there were rude customers sitting beside us, but the way the waiter handled the situation was great, he's courteous and being understanding, try to apologize for the tight space that's available. So, I like their customer service.

Parking could be a b**tch, but we got lucky, got the spot in less than 10mins, so no complain for me there. 

Very satisfied and will definitely come back, I think the best time to come is Oktoberfest!!!
author: Jenny B.

description: We saw this restaurant come out on the travel channel and decided to try it when we stayed in San Francisco. The plates we ordered were delicious. The meatloaf which is the main dish we saw on that travel channel special lived up to the hype it received. The plate with pork sausage was really great as well.
author: Annette H.

description: I remember when this place opened in the 90's.  Amongst the first of the Hayes Street renaissance restaurants.  The food and beer is quite good, the noise level crazy high, the  wait for a table at dinner long, but a fun place to bring friends.  I would probably give it 4-stars but for my experience last week.  I had friends in from NY.  We put our name on the list around 8 p.m., were told it would be about an hour but to stop back in 45 minutes, got back in 45 minutes and were told there was some sort of kitchen problem and they were closing early.  Surprising because we continued to watch food coming out of the kitchen and orders seemingly going in.  Also, after making us wait almost an hour (and we were hungry), seems to me that the least they could have done was offered some kind of gift certificate for a free beer on a future visit to those people on the waiting list.
author: Richard E.

description: I'm obsessed with this place. The beer selection is so great and the staff makes great recommendations. They will help you find the perfect beer. The food is also really great! Everything we ordered from the menu was amazing. Ask the waiter for suggestions if you're confused.
author: Allyson B.

description:
Felt like I was in a cozy (VERYVERYcozy*) beer den in Eastern Europe. My Swiss German friend had to explain to me some of the words.

Spatzel= homey-tasting doughy, dumpling nibblits from Germany. Duly noted.

The jagersnitzel was good, but the venison medallions were beautiful, luscious things. Oh and the Radler (beer+ lemon soda)!!! My new favorite drink!

NOTE: This place is DEATH to parties of 3-5 at night. Prepare to wait up to 1.5 hrs outside in the cold (or try to fit your big self and your big friends at the teeny tiny bar). Save yourself the trouble, grab a few more buddies and make a reservation for six.
author: Kathy L.

description: Good stuff! Superb German food and drink. If your a beer drinker I think they have a nice selection.
author: S B.

description: Very good German food. Loved the little gnocchi spaltz side, potato cakes,pork chop, Brussel sprouts. Food has great Flavors! Portions are decent. Can share 3 plates with four people. Very good selection of beers. The only downside is they are a very small restaurant so more then likely, a wait will be involved esp since they don't take reservations for parties under 6.
author: Carrie T.

description: I highly recommend this restaurant. The food is simply amazing! My hubby ordered the trout with lemon butter sauce and absolutely loved it! I had the pork loin with mushroom sauce and couldn't even finish it with such a large portion. It too was just delicious! Will definitely be coming back to sample the rest of the menu!
author: Linda R.

description:
Excellent! SF needs more good German restaurants (so far I've found Suppenküche and Walzwerk).

The beer list is *extensive* and almost exclusively in German style if not actually German. I was pleased with both of the beers I tried.

Food:

Get the potato pancakes. Deliciously crispy and browned on the outside, soft and moist in the middle. Om nom fucking nom.

I had the oxtail special for my entree. If they have this on the menu when you go, GET IT! The meat was fall-off-the-bone tender and the broth/sauce it came in was rich and flavorful. Lingonberry sauce was a good accompaniment, and the spätzle was perfect.

No reservations for groups smaller than six, so if you come on a busy night be prepared for a wait. Service was friendly and helpful, particularly when we picked beers they were out of at the moment and needed suggestions.
author: Sam K.

description:
The actions of one douche-bag waiter has skewed, what otherwise would be, a raving review for this unique and delightful eatery.

6 of us showed up hammered on a Saturday night - having walked to Hayes Valley after a 6 hour mid-day-lower-haight bar extravaganza. Famish and fatigue, coupled with the signs of a looming hangover, left little-to-no conscious ability to exercise patience with one cranky member of the Suppenküche staff...

BF was to my left, cursing the world for having "long food lines", Favey (Norma H.) was to my right, ready to runaway to Sam Woo for a cheap platter of Orange Chicken and fried rice. After politely asking DB waiter/host if our party of 6 could occupy an empty table in the middle of the room, he responded with a foul, "Oh oh oh. ABSOLUTELY NOT!" (In almost a "yell" might I add...)

WTF, right? My jaw dropped.

By 950pm, we were finally 'allowed' to occupy one of the (now many) open tables, but were advised that the kitchen was to close in 10 minutes... this left little time to thoroughly inspect or question the menu. Thankfully, having immediately tunnel-visioned on the cheese spatzel (while others preferred the lamb chops & meatloaf), I was able to order promptly, and within 15 minutes, was served one of the most delicious ethnic renditions of pasta-n-cheese I've ever had to date. It was glorious.

Pros:
- Cheese Spatzel, Mashed Potatoes, Potato Pancakes, Meatloaf.
- DAS BOOT!
- Location & Ambiance
- Gal Pals say that the bartenders were "cute and nice..." lol.

Cons:
- DB Waiter.
- Cannot make reservations between certain hours.
- Must check in after 930pm in order to be seated (without a reservation).
- DB Waiter.
- Kitchen closes at 10pm.
- DB Waiter.
author: Ro D.

description:
Reluctant to try this place out because beer has never really been my beverage choice, I finally gave it a shot.

This place is a tease of how crazy Germany can get. Delicious food, rare beer selection, and good service. Yes, they have the BOOT !! The wait is absolutely ridiculous. This is one of those places where you wait outside for 30 minutes before they open. For sure this is not a family resturaunt because after pounding cups of beer, you can only imagine how rowdy and crazy people can get.
author: Brenda C.

description:
I wanna go to Germany now. The German government should definitely pay this place for promoting their country by opening up shop. Delicious food, an amazing beer selection, and impeccable service, you can't go wrong. I tried my first smokebier here and it changed my life forever. I never realized how unrefined my palate for beer was until the sweet taste of smoked malted barley touched my lips. I daydream and dream about our first time everyday. I salivate at the thought of meeting again. I wish it would ask me to marry it and have its babies. Who needs a real man when you have smoked beer?

Anyway, I spent my birthday here with a party of 9 on my 3rd visit. No reservations on a Thursday night and I was the last to arrive at 7pm. My friends had arrived at 6:30pm and was seated right away. The staff was very accommodating to all of us, though my friend complained about her water not being filled; I forgive them for this as I was drinking beer all night anyway. I had the rotisserie chicken with the potato pancakes which were both delicious. I got to sample my friends' plates as well, including the pork chop, Weinerschnitzel, and Jagerschnitzel. All delicious, and everyone seemed to be very satisfied with their food.

Towards the end of the night, I had to use the girl's room. I waited outside the bathroom as I watched the staff lighting up candles on a birthday cake. As they walked past me, I peek over at the cake and see "Happy Birthday Anita!" Oopsies. I ninja behind the staff, in natural hiding because my small stature, but in a huge smile as my friends looked at the cake with horror with me absent at the table. Surprise on you suckas! I was behind them the whole time. The entire restaurant sang for me, which made my night. Nothing more perfect than the perfect company, the perfect restaurant, and the perfect beer to make the perfect birthday.

Until we meet again Soup Kitchen. I love you.
author: Anita W.

description:
Authentic German food, just like we had in Munich - EXCEPT!  The sauerkraut is too sweet - it's supposed to be tart.  Everything else was great though, we had the potato pancakes, the onion soup and the half chicken with dumplings.

The place is really loud, and the seating arrangement though authentic for a small Gasthaus restaurant or the like will annoy some people.  

The only way you'll get in here without a wait is coming early.

Oh, and for the car nerds, they have some theme-painted chairs, such as a BMW Motorsport colored chair.  Weird, but I noticed it.
author: Scott S.

description: The food was very good, but not mind-blowing. The best part was that we get to share a big table with other people sitting next to us. I don`t know, but It was good. Loud noises, people chatting, and food comes pretty fast. I didn`t try it, but there was Belgium beers, German beers. Might be better if you go there and drink. Overall it was a good restaurant, I would try it another time if I have chance.
author: Shinji K.

description:
I always thought German food wasn't much to write home about, but Suppenkuche definitely left a great impression. 

Ambiance: An authentic german pub feel with dim lighting and rustic seating. It's quite loud, but IMO that adds to that pub-like ambiance. If it gets busy you'll get seated with a random group of people. Not very touristy either, most people there were locals..huge plus.

Food/Drinks: They started us off with a butter/dill spread with bread...quite yummy. We ordered the baked chicken and the meatloaf. The baked chicken had an amazing sauce, and I wish they gave more of it! Super tender meat and great potato pancakes, good enough to split between 2 girls. Didn't try the meatloaf, but my friend thoroughly enjoyed it! They also had quite a great beer variety...and they'll serve you beer in a giant boot cup if you wish!!

Service: Definitely satisfactory . Even though it was busy, food came out relatively fast. 

Overall: For german food, they definitely have quite a variety aside from schnitzel that all sounded very appetizing...too bad my group didn't come on an empty stomach. Great place to hit up if you're in the area - don't think you can go too wrong here!
author: Melissa C.

description:
I'd give this place a five stars for food, but I subtracted a star because it is SCREAMINGLY loud.  The volume in the place is seriously unpleasant and caused the folks at our table to yell at each other (which only added to the din.)  

The food is great.  I had meatloaf wrapped in bacon with a hard-boiled egg, and it was delicious.  My wife's chicken was great--tender and juicy.  The beer selection is excellent and the potato pancakes are recommended. 

I'll be back, but I may try it at a less  busy time.  (Not sure what that would be, considering we dined at 8 pm on a Tuesday night.)
author: Augie R.

description:
We had to wait an hour for a table but it was worth the wait. We had a few beers at the bar while we waited and talked with the bartenders who were very informative about the different beers. They let us try samples of each beer since we were having a difficult time making a decision.  

I liked that we were seated family style at tables with random customers. It was loud and festive. 

The bread was great to go with the beer and the spread that accompanied it was delicious. I ordered the Maultaschen in Pilzrahmsoße (German Ravioli filled with Pork and Vegetables served with Mushroom Sauce) and it was delicious. Two others I was with had the Spätzle which was very filling. Our tablemates shared their meatloaf with us and that was amazing as well. 

This is your place if you want to share a great meal and some beers with friends.
author: Jackie L.

description: Love this place. Great atmosphere, surrounded by good people and awesome German food. I would definitely recommend this to anyone. Feel in love with this place ever since the first time my girlfriend took me here. Be prepared to wait for a seat, this place gets packed fast. In the meanwhile you can grab some great tasting imported beer from Germany. Especially when in season, celebrator on tap.
author: nick r.

description: Outstanding. Traditional German cuisine. I went to Sunday brunch a few weeks ago when I visited San Fran. I was immediately impressed that they had my favorite German beer, Weihenstephaner Kristall Weissbier on the list of beverages. Having lived in Bavaria for a decent amount of time and coming from a German family, I have a pretty good idea of what great German food tastes like. The bread sampler to start off was a nice mix. I ordered some mini brats to start off and finished up with the Wiener Schnitzel. Both were amazing. The portions were well more than gracious. The cucumber salad was also a highlight of the meal. Highly recommended.
author: Scott S.

description:
Have you ever wanted to drink beer out of a boot?? If so, this is the place for you! 

Suppenkuche is a great place to come with a crowd. For those who appreciate high-quality beer, you will not be disappointed. For those who could care less, you will still not be disappointed. They have a German Black Lager on tap, which is so hard to find and by far one of my favorite types of beer!

I have been here a couple times, always for dinner. A favorite on the menu is the potato pancakes with apple sauce-- totally where it's at. The combination of the sweet with the crunchy and yet soft pancake is amazing. The cheese spatzle is like a German version of Mac n Cheese -- incredibly creamy and delicious. I wasn't particularly impressed with their pork filled ravioli, but their pork sausage and sauerkraut is great. 

Highly recommend Suppenkuche if you're looking for a hearty, fun-filled night :)

Note: if you're coming in a small crowd, they have communal tables so you'll probably have a chance to get cozy with others at your table.
author: Kimya P.

description:
Our last night in San Francisco and my partner and I were pining for some of the kick ass German food we had here 8 years prior and wanted to share the experience with his son.  

Unfortunately the wait was about an hour -- after strolling around Hayes Valley for half an hour, we learned that the wait wasn't getting much shorter.  We opted then to order take-out and take it back to the hotel.  Which they were happy to do.  Order came out hot in less  than 15 minutes.
author: Bobby K.

description: I absolutely LOVE suppenkuche, it's my go to German spot. It's literally the closest thing I've ever gotten food-wise to what I eat when I'm in Germany. Definitely a must if you're in the mood to try something new or taste that little bit of home away from home.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I went here with a group of friends after a whirlwind day in SF. The food was fantastic, we got in pretty quickly and the beer was delish.

Only reason why I took away a star because the place is incredibly loud and maybe a little pricey. But then again, I'm used to cheap Houston prices. And the loudness just kinda adds to the atmosphere.

Would definitely go back again! Our group of four shared our dishes and there was nothing that I didn't like. Favorite was the stuffed mushroom and the potato cake / hashbrown side.
author: lauren c.

description:
I've been debating on whether to give this place a 4 or a 5, but when I think about it, I really did enjoy it. I was starving when I came in as I had just finished a super long bike ride around the city. I hesitated coming here because the first time I tried to go, they said they were at capacity for the entire night and wouldn't be able to take anymore people. That actually made me want to come here even more. To my surprise there was absolutely no wait, and not only did we get seated right away, but the food came out pretty fast too.

Everything was delicious. The potato soup was yummy and flavorful. It was a red color so I thought it might be spicy, but it wasn't - it still tasted like potato without all the heavy creaminess you might think of when you think of potato soup.

The weinerschnitzel was soo good. I came in 2 thin pieces, the meat look tenderized, and it was breaded and served on top of roasted potatoes. All the flavors came together really well, and I definitely left feeling full and happy.
author: Sabrina T.

description: Consistent, spot on German food. Great atmosphere very warm and bench style seating. Beer is awesome, dessert is a must with the German bitters.
author: Ribec F.

description:
Be prepared to put a credit card down for the boot.
Try to make a reservation for a large party, but if you're not in a big group, the communal tables are pretty cool. 

Great beer selection, loud, warm, and generally an awesome vibe. 
Food is traditional stick to your ribs kind of drinking food. Wiener schnitzel was ok, brats are good, cheese spatzle is awesome and is the special (if they have it- stuffed beef medallions).

Love this place!
author: Caroline D.

description:
Suppenküche ist das Beste!

The restaurant is super lovely (nice tables, nice lighting, nice bar) and the menu is extensive and (as far as I know) relatively authentic. Also communal seating, so our group of three ended up sharing a table with three Iranians who we chatted with at the tail end of our meal.

Vegetarians are limited to a few entrees, but shouldn't be too disappointed... especially with offerings like Käsespätzle, which is a dish I grew up eating in my home. Vegans have fewer options, but there are some (lentil soup, potato pancakes, mixed salad minus a few ingredients).

But considering there are a lot of dishes I can't speak on behalf of, let's get on the selling point here:

REISSDORF KÖLSCH!! ON TAP!! The whole beer menu is excellent excellent excellent but I didn't pay any notice to it because I was too busy downing the Reissdorf. As someone who became slightly addicted on my first visit to Germany, I can certainly attest to the fact that there is no thing like the real thing, and try as they may, domestic microbreweries who attempt to emulate Kölsch never quite get it right. And now there's no need to; they can all just come here instead! Ich freue mich wie ein Schneekönig!
author: Natalye R.

description:
This place has has a lot of meat and potatoes.. which means, being a vegetarian, I got to eat a lot of potatoes
I ate
potato salad
potato pancakes
fried potatoes
mashed potatoes
some type of baked dish which tasted like potatoes !!!!
(On that note, someone once told me the following about potatoes - 
you can barbeque them,
boil them,
broil them,
bake them,
saute them..
there's potato kebabs,
potato creole,
potato gumbo,
pan fried potatoes,
deep fried potatoes,
stir fried potatoes..
there's pineapple potatoes,
lemon potatoes,
coconut potatoes,
pepper potatoes,
potato soup,
potato stew,
potato salad,
potatoes and shrimp,
potato burgers,
potato sammiches,
.. well that's about it!!)

Anways, the food was not bad, but the place was way too crowded and hence really really noisy.. could barely hear people from across the table.. not a good place to go with people who you want to have a good conversation with..
but definitely a sure-fire choice if you want to eat some potatoes!!
author: Aditya M.

description:
My first German food experience, and it was surprisingly awesome!

Loved: BRATWURST!!, jagerschnitzel, spatzle, bread and butter
Their bratwurst was easily the best I've had. Flavorful and juicy, I savored every bite.

Liked: potato pancakes with apple sauce
Never would've thought to put the two together, but it was good.

Disliked: occasional awkward eye contact with the guy seated across from me

Minor discomfort from sharing a table with strangers aside, Suppenkuche is a winner with great food, big portions, and reasonable prices. My bf loved their beer selection too.
author: Sophia B.

description:
YUM (& I don't ever say that about German food!)

Speed 5/5: Came in with a friend on a Sun early evening, and got seated within a few minutes.

Ambiance: 4/5 Large wood tables & benches (around the perimeter of the restaurant) communal style isn't my thing, especially when I had to maneuver around those heavy table legs in order to sit down/get up. The interior is quite simple, and upon the entrance my eyes were immediately was drawn to the butterfly display at the ceiling. I kept on dazing at it throughout the evening... It's a comfortable place for all sorts of occasions. Thumbs up.

Food:5/5 Really LOVED the special of the day - the boar sausage with spatzle/noodles & sauerkraut (and I'm not a sauerkraut girl by any means). I was tempted by the potato pancakes and the herring and more... but well, I'll just have to come back. DELISH!

Service: 5/5 The server made us happy - just the right amount of everything, and overall very pleasant (especially noticeable after NYC).

Danke Suppenkuche!
author: Anna G.

description:
Delicious authentic German food and great beers.
Awesome staff. 

Too bad it fills up with a lot of douchebags over the weekend who only come here to drink "Das Boot" but can't handle their actual German beer (cause are used to Bud-Light).
author: Helen D.

description:
This is the definitive German food experience stateside. This place has been open for 18 years! How many places can say that? I've been going there for almost 8. They carry a nice range of authentic German Biers, the best German food I've had and an experience that's hard to find stateside. They have great Vegetarian options on top of their extensive meat options. The desert is also fantastic, pending it's not late in the evening and they haven't already sold out. True German style. 

They also offer a Sunday brunch that is one of the best I've had as well. Omelets the size of a child and Emperor Pancakes with fresh fruit.  

It's loud, there's no reservations for less than 6 and it will likely be a packed house (there's a reason for this!). So have a Litre of Bier, order too much food and indulge!
author: Justus P.

description: Great food, great beer, always a pleasure to find a way to get here.  It can be crowded, but that is a testament to the overall wonderful quality.
author: Ryan D.

description: On Sat., Aug. 31st: Checked in at 7:40 for a party of two, told the wait would be 45 minutes, after checking in a couple of times, I wasn't sat until 9:20. After seeing so many people sat in front of me it's really hard to really understand why. When we were finally sat, after a few minutes, we were asked to move to ANOTHER table so a larger party could be accommodated. The only good thing here was that we were offered a free appetizer after we moved. Overall though this was a super disappointing experience. Who knew if the food was good considering how starved I was by 9:50 when we finally ate.
author: Justin R.

description:
Tip: Das Boot, sausages, bone in ham steak, potato pancakes

Very festive spot albeit a bit small and packed. Make reservations or else be stuck waiting for a minute. 

Getting a boot is a prerequisite for this spot. Its about 60 ounces of beer so be ready to share or man up and take it down yourself. Beer selection is solid and many drinking games can be played.  A popular one is to pass the boot around your table while making sure it does not touch the table until completely empty. 

Bone in ham steak was very juicy and had tons of flavor. Comes with some really delicious sauerkraut. Potato pancakes with apple sauce are LEGIT. They also have an appetizer platter with all types of sausages. Very good!
author: Roth S.

description:
I came here due to a solid review by a good friend and I was not disappointed. I had the most delicious soda (Elderberry Bionade Organic Soda) I have ever tasted that has caused me to reconsider my ban against sodas.
Their herbed butter was fantastic - very fresh herbs just exploding with flavor on the excellent house bread. 
I had the pretzel with was very good. I had a sip of my friend's beer and it was fantastic.
The meatloaf had my name on it and it was excellent. 
I tried my friend's Jägerschnitzel and I can't say it really had my number, but it was good and the Spätzle was very tasty and unusual to me.
I think this is far better than the German joint out in the Mission (y'all know what I'm talking about).
author: Lovina H.

description:
After hearing such rave reviews about Suppenkuche, I decided to try their Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus....also known as a potato pancake or an ELEVEN dollar hashbrown. Sure, it was a crispy, well-cooked potato pancake accompanied by their homemade applesauce, but in my opinion it definitely was not worth $11! For the main course, my fiance and I split their wiener schnitzel. It was a tough piece of meat and not juicy at all....We were so disappointed! 

The place was crowded and the wait was an hour long, but that did not surprise us since it was afterall a Friday night. However, the management should learn to control or at least limit the number of people standing around the bar. While seated at our table, people standing near the bar kept on bumping into us and our table. In my opinion, Suppenkuche is not worth the wait or the money.
author: Carrie W.

description:
I had a great Suppenkuche experience lately which unbound my poor-er one from last year.

This woman knew I was a veggie and was extremely flexible on what I could change/order. I simply ended up getting the spatzle, spinach and cabbage and, with the potato pancake and lots of beer, was perfect for dinner.

I also really dig their beer selection. Nice malty ones next to the usual crisp lagers you'd expect.
author: Paul C.

description:
While looking this place up for one of our contractors at work, I realized they did not get my fan status as they should have for the handful of times I've grubbed here over the past couple years ... (as if they need more reviews).

So, that said, here's a 5 for the beer, ambiance. Food is between a 3-4 in my opinion, as if you care.

fyi: Thursday & Friday nights here are ridiculously busy.  I hate smelling schnitzels and seeing beer boots and waiting for an hour.  Think Monday or Tuesday night if you're hungry.
author: Athena S.

description: Had dinner a few weeks ago in hopes to find Some good German to inspire our German menu were working on. Walked in on Friday and the hostess said the wait would be an hour. She lied. We got seated in like 10 minutes. It was soooooooo loud in there with a bunch of drunk annoying bros screaming and yelling at each other. Ordered the pretzels. They were good. Herring was so so. Spätzle needed major seasoning. The braised beef or whatever was the driest thing I've ever put in my mouth. The sausage was not not juicy or anything and flavor was flat.  Mash potatoes tasted like there were boxed cause they had a cardboard flavor to them. Just a huge disappointment and to top it off we sat at in of those big tables which had 6 people on it and then add my friend and I, that makes 8. We were pretty cozy by that time at a community table AND then the party of six we were eating with has 2 more people show up!! Wth. They literally squeeze them on the table. There was NO room for me to even have my silverware or glass of water On  table. Pretty shitty. By that time we were Itching to get out and never return. They get a start for their beer selection. That's it
author: mel l.

description: I only was able to stop in for a couple adult beverages.  That being said, the atmosphere was awesome, the service was awesome.  And the German beers were fantastic.  The bartenders knew exactly the region and gave you the history on the beer.
author: Chris H.

description:
Not much can be said that hasn't been outlined in the 1775 reviews thus far for Suppenkuche but I'll take a shot. 

Named after a German "soup kitchen" this restaurant is both casual and rowdy. Bring a big group, slurp down some 2 liter boots of beer and eat carb-laden starchy foods that you can't pronounce. The group component is important with their large portioning but I imagine it's also fun in pairs. If you're on a diet, just avoid. There's no salad that doesn't involve a potato and the Radegast is too yummy to pass on. My chicken was perfectly seasoned, and included a dumpling lump of potato puree flavored like stuffing. The potato pancakes seem to be deep fried with a tempura-like texture. 

All in all, expect to be rolled out of here drunk and fat.
author: Jane K.

description: 4.5. Cozy and bustling. Nice waitress returned a dish that didn't look appetizing. AMAZING price on brunch. Like the same price as Cafe La Taza. Stacks had a huge wait and this place took us straight away. LOVED the scramble with pork sausage and bacon and the butter lettuce green salad with a light vinaigrette. For like $9.50. Yes, baby, yes.
author: Andrew K.

description:
This is such a fun, fun place to hang out with a group of friends. 

I love coming in here because I know I will get a hearty meal and leave with a full stomach. 
I am not a beer fan but I do enjoy having a pint once in a while - a good pint of beer and Suppenkuche delivers that - always. 

I do recommend coming in early for dinner or else you will have to wait with the crowd for a table. 

All in all, I say this restaurant is one of my favorites in San Francisco.  I have enjoyed every meal, I have no complains, and I will definitely be coming back occasionally.  


TIP: Hard to find parking - leave the car at home.
author: Liza B.

description: Awesome wiener schnitzel and great beer selection!
author: Amanda B.

description:
This is a enjoyable place to spend some time with your friends. Order some German food and beer booty, and you have got yourself a good start to the weekend. The servers are very attentive, despite the place being crowded and busy during the weekend nights.Servers are also knowledgeable about the drinks if you have any questions or want recommendations on what to try. 
I arrived minutes before it opened to make sure I can get in with my group of friends. If everyone is not there, you won't be seated. Don't be surprised if you see people waiting in line to get in before it opens. I have never eaten German food until I visited Suppenkuche, but I did enjoy my braised short ribs. The food was very filling and I could not finish off the plate. I tried from someone else the roasted pork suckling and that was divine. That one is a must-have. I would order it again in a heart beat if I go back again.
author: Jenny F.

description: This place is amazing. My partner and I were walking around Hayes valley looking for a place to eat for our anniversary. We saw a line sat this place...everyone waiting to get in. We decided to try it since it was something new and I never had German food ever.  Service to food to experience was great. I would recommend this place to all my friends.
author: Edgar C.

description:
I WANT TO GO BACK NOW. I REALLY DO.

I love Suppenkuche. Everything I tasted there was different and delicious. I would love to visit Germany if all their food tasted like this.

Half liter of beer for $5-6? COME ON. Most restaurants charge this for smaller quantities of shitty beer. DEAL ON.

My only regret is that I don't have two stomachs for even more beer, cuz I love their Stiegl. NEXT TIME I'M ORDERIN' APPETIZERS AND A 1 LITER.

Like your red meat? Get the sauteed venison medallions in red wine plum sauce. It comes with Spätzle and Red Cabbage.

Cmon. Even look at the word Spätzle. Doesn't it look cool?
author: Andrew M.

description:
Suppenküche, yes you are pretty darn good, and pretty fun too.

I wish i could have all the goodness without so much loudness... but then again.. wtf am i thinking... fists pounding and beers chugging is why i'm here right?

The food is good... the little side salad that comes with your main dish on your plate... is mediocre at best... whatever the main dish you order, expect it to be great... the trimmings look like something from fresh choice... but that's not why we are here is it?

BOOT BOOT BOOT BOOT BOOT!!!!!
author: N S.

description: This is GERMAN and I love beer! Best place to enjoy your loud family which I have. Plus we always makes friends with our table mates. Get the potato pancakes!!
author: Holly G.

description:
Whoa, this place fills up in a hurry.  We got queued up in line before it opened and when the doors were released, people flooded in.  

Communal seating had us at a table with a couple and a little baby.  The baby definitely had his game on, as he was tapping glasses and toasting with his milk to his parent's beer.  Tables were heavy wooden affairs that aren't that comfortable, but the upside down gnomes hanging from the ceiling more than compensated.

I had the food envy going on again.  I ordered the venison, but I think the meat loaf was much better.  Not that I'm a meat loaf guy, but it was exceptional.  I didn't get around to drinking from a boot, but it might happen in the future.  

Suppenkuche didn't get 5 stars from me because of two issues.  One, the noise was deafening, even with some of the windows and the door open.  Two, it had these tiny bathrooms that you have to line up for, very reminiscent of being on an airplane.  

Still, very fun.  Just pee before you go.
author: Clint W.

description:
I've heard a lot about Suppenkuche and have tried twice to snag a table here, but both times, the wait was over 1.5 hours and my groups didn't have time to spare.

I guess the third time's the charm because my friend and I came on a Monday around 7:00 pm and the wait was less than half an hour. Score! We each ordered a beer at the bar and found some cozy stool seating in the candlelit nook behind the bar while we waited for the hostess to get us.

Shortly after, we were seated at one of the communal tables. It may not be for everyone, but I thought it was fine and it lent the restaurant that authentic beer hall vibe. (Tip: Coming in a small group of 2 definitely helps cut down your wait time.) My friend and I split a plate of the potato pancakes. He ordered the spatzle as a main course and I ordered the braised beef which came with spatzle. I purposely ordered that dish because I wanted to try the spatzle (cheesy pasta) but as other Yelpers have alluded to, it really wasn't very good. I found it to be rubbery and pretty bland. I did try my friend's though and his was pretty good--definitely a lot cheesier and flavorful. I'm guessing they make the spatzle sides and the spatzle main course differently. The potato pancakes were nothing special--I found them to be just like thick hash browns.

I will say that the braised beef was excellent though--tender, flavorful and went great with the tartness of the red cabbage and sweetness of the lingonberry sauce that accompanied it. But overall, I probably wouldn't try Suppenkuche again. It's a little pricey for what the food is and I think the food doesn't deserve the hype, nor the long lines.
author: Steffi L.

description:
I have been eating here for nearly ten years and - with the exception of maybe one dish and some daily specials - I have had everything on the menu. Every item has been amazing. Last time I was there, one of the special appetizers was freshly baked pretzels with this cheese to dip them in (I craved it for two months and still do sometimes when I have a beer!). Try anything, you really can't go wrong.

Something to consider: I am speaking as a home brewer and beer aficionada. With all of the fantastic beers on the menu, you might want to reconsider getting a boot. If you don't care about variety and have someone to hold your hair out of your face for later, by all means, get the boot. =)
author: Sarah D.

description:
I can't pronounce the name of this place for the life of me but I sure can eat their Schnitzle in about one minute. The beer selection is amazing and the atmosphere is downright jovial.  

This could be the PERFECT date spot depending on who you're here with. You'll most definitely be yelling across the table about how awesome the food is and how much you wish you were German while drinking a beer you can't recall the name of. However, it's not the best place to take a date that you have any interest in getting to know better because you won't be able to hear much through the busy chatter and laughter of other guests. Without a doubt, this is the best place to go with a group of friends. 

IMPORTANT NOTE: get here at 5PM or after 9PM to avoid the dinner rush. Booking a same-day reservation is almost impossible. 

My only beef with this place has to do with the service staff. I understand that they have a tough job feeding the masses but it's not that easy for us to put up with this place either. We make a lot of sacrifices; like having to wait for a seat and subsequently for our food, sharing a table with random people, sitting on uncomfortable wooden seats, yelling across the table to have a conversation...etc. I'm just saying you could be a little more friendly...I'm talking about the bartender too. 

But, the food makes all of this worth it. I'd do anything for a Suppenkuche potato pancake right now.
author: Raha G.

description: Food was okay, but when we walled in they didn't want to seat us until they were sure that we were eating, then they asked us to leave as soon as we were finished and had paid. I understand that they are busy but forget this place.
author: Spencer R.

description:
The short version:
-very authentically German (community seating, boot biers, molasses bread, etc.)
-pescitarian friendly (amazing salmon)
-fast kitchen
-no reservations for parties smaller than six

The long version:

My mom, brother, and I went up to the city for the Nutcracker and, being the foodies we are, we wanted to have a good familial dinner before--and Suppenküche met our needs! We were sat within ten minutes and shared a table with a young group of college students. 

We immediately ordered potato pancakes (rated 9/10 by the group--really a must have) and mixed salad (very german with beats, red cabbage, carrots, potato salad, butter lettuce, and green cabbage). 

For entrées, I ordered a delicious salmon with buttery mashed potatoes (an amazing 10/10). The fish literally melted in my mouth and it was a great pairing with the mashed potatoes. My mother ordered sauerbraten, which she gave an 8/10 because the sauce was "very good" but it didn't melt in her mouth as much as it should for such a tender meet. My brother's entré was the biggest disappointment, however. He ordered a weinerschnitzle, which was brought without sauce.  Both he and my mother commented on how it was too dry and was "missing something." He added lemon and ate it that way. 

Overall I thought it was a great place with lots of character. Louder atmosphere with people talking over each other--like a bier garden shoved into a small San Francisco pub space.
author: Mel D.

description:
I've never been disappointed here! Best German restaurant ever!!

The wait can be really long (1 hour and a half to 2 hours). What you should do is, send a friend or 2 to put down their names, they can walk around in hayes valley, explore cute little boutiques, chill in the park with some grocery bought drinks, or even sit at the bar in the restaurant to pass time. We'd always go put our names down, get some drinks in a liquor store and walk around/play in the park. Time flies when you're in good company.

It's not a very big restaurant, if you go in a small group (3-7), they can put you with another party at the same table. So probably not the best place to go if you're shy and going on a first date. I've always made friends with the tables around us/chatted with people sitting at the same table. It's a fun crowd, the people who go there are usually out-going, loud, and really friendly. 

Boot beer!! You need to get one. It's fantastic. The whole restaurant will cheer you on to finish the boot. 
The service is as good as it gets, it's very very busy, you kinda have to try hard to get someone's attention but they're doing their best, and you have beer on your table, so try to be patient and have a good time. I've always had waiters/waitresses that are on top of their stuff when I go.

Now the food. Everything is good. 
Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus $11.00
Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce -- It's delicious. It's crispy and sweet. It's perfect as a desert in my opinion. 

Maultaschen in Pilzrahmsoße $11.50
German Ravioli filled with Pork and Vegetables served with Mushroom Sauce -- How can you look at this and not want to get it? It's creamy and yummy. 

Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und Grünem Salat $18.00
Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad -- It's bready, thin, but delicious. 

Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße mit Spätzle und grünem Salat $18.50
Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spätzle & Green Salad -- This is really really tender and the mushroom sauce is amazing. I wish I could buy it in a jar. 

Kassler vom Grill mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei $16.50
Grilled Cured Pork Chop with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes -- Nice thick pork chop, they know how to cook their pork. 

Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei $14.50
Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes -- huge pork sausages, good for group sharing.

Falscher Hase mit Zwiebelsoße und Kartoffelbrei $14.50
Meatloaf with Bacon and Egg served with Onion Sauce & Mashed Potatoes -- Only the best meatloaf ever. 

My advice is, get a few dishes to share amongst the group, because you will want to try everything. It's good hearty food. 

Girls who don't like the bitter beer taste, they have fruity beers. The framboise is my favorite. It's sweet and tangy. You have to try it!
author: Erica L.

description:
German food seems oddly familiar to American comfort food... or is it the other way around? Either way, you'll find common things like mashed potatoes and sausages here. Mostly food that goes well with beer are served here. SuppenKuche is a nice restaurant that serves up beer and food. Atmosphere in this place is like a tavern where people come to drink and get drunk at. It's a hard place to fit a large party into.

The food is pretty okay. It's hard to say that these types of food are great, but they goes well with the beer.

Beer selection is really huge there. They have all kinds of German beer ranging from light to dark of all kinds. The interesting thing about this place is their "DAS BOOT"... it's a huge boot shape mug that you drink beef from.

Bottom line is come here for the atmosphere and their beer and you'll have a good time. The food is alright, but there's nothing special about it.
author: Steven B.

description: Been here about 20 times now. It's the only German place I go. Started because we wanted to drink boots of beers. But then tried the food. Literally everything tastes great. The special chicken dish they have is my go to dish. Show up at 5 or you'll be waiting a bit for a seat. Regardless, worth the wait.
author: Cëma M.

description:
I was running late (thirty minutes before closing) on a Wednesday night.  My friends were already there, so I called them and told them to order for me.  I don't hang around Hayes Valley, but it seems like a cool area (nice bars and restaurants).  From outside of Suppenküche, I could see that there are two dining room.  The smaller room in the back looked like it was reserved for larger parties (two big tables), while the room in front looked like it could sit about forty diners.  My friends said they waited a while for a table, so come early.  The dining room is casual, but stylish (very welcoming).

They ordered me a 7oz glass of German beer which was really good.  I'm not really a beer drinker anymore (preference - whiskey), but I really enjoyed it.  I quickly wanted another one, but they ran out and served me a Pilsner instead.  I was good, but I enjoyed the first one more.  While we were drinking, a bowl of Kartoffelsuppe (potato soup) arrived (with two spoons).  The two people who tried it (I was still enjoying my beer), said it was really great.  Chris, this dude from Germany, mentioned that Kartoffelsuppe is a time consuming thing to make and not an everyday food served in German homes.

Our entrees arrived soon after.  I had Sauerbraten mit Lingonbeerkonfitüre, serviert mit Rotkohl und Spätzle (Marinated Braised Beef with Lingonberries, served with Red Cabbage & Spätzle).  It was pretty good!  The beef might have been brisket and was tender (but a little dry).  It tasted best when eaten with the Ligonberries and Spatzle (a egg noodle dish - similar to macaroni) all at the same time.  I didn't notice the red cabbage, until I finished the beef (they're both very similar in color).  It tasted like a mild sauerkraut.  Tona ordered Kassler vom Grill mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei (Grilled Cured Pork Chop with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes).  I had a bite.  It was perfectly cooked (very tender and flavorful).  It was a good smoked pork chop (which basically tastes like ham - which I am not a huge fan of).  Everyone enjoyed their dinners and beer.

We would all visit Suppenküche again.  Next time, I will come early and order the venison or the trout.
author: Jeff H.

description:
This place is so fun. It was packed solid and the wait was over an hour, but so worth the wait. In the Hayes District, you can go to a bar nearby [Absynthe or Sugar] and have a drink while you wait.
