There is a bar in the middle of the restaurant, and the tables are large so you may be seated with other people. We had 5 of us, so we were fine. Took over a table and ordered a bunch of dishes to share. It's packed and super loud so be prepared to scream to your friends instead of talk. 

The sausages are so good. The German sausage with mashed potatoes are amazing. So is the fish. I'm not a fan of sauerkraut but its good here! The beef was not my favorite. The sauce for it was just too sweet I think. 

They have some beers that are all good. I prefer the medium bodied ones, and I really liked mine. They also have this BOOT that can store 2 liters of beer. It's something to get when you have a large group and everyone drinks out of it. 2 liters is A LOT of beer. I saw the boot and got scared.

I have never been much of a German foodie, but this place really impressed me with all the flavors and the simplicity of the food. Also, the authenticity is proven by all the German speaking people surrounding our table.
author: Debby L.

description: The next best thing would be a trip to Munich in late September.  This is much less expensive.  If you're training for a beer drinking competition this is your place!  Don't let your head get the best of you, a boot of beer that's 2 liters is a lot of beer for the average human being.
author: Scotty 7.

description:
A few weeks ago I organized a Hayes Valley foodie outing with a few coworkers and guests.

Stop one: Suppenkuche.

Their selection of German beer on tap is excellent.  We had a La Chouffe, Edel-Weisse, and Hoffbrau Helles to start.  It comes in different sizes, I'm guessing depending on how potent the beer is.  Since it was stop one, we definitely weren't crazy enough to do Das Boot.  Thank goodness we didn't.

We ordered food, too.
I think it was beef with spaetzel and the potato cakes.  The potato cakes were AWESOME!  You must get.  Trust me!

Get there early because it gets packed, quickly.  We actually had to split our table and share the other side with strangers.  They were definitely jealous of our food.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Great beer on tap and bottle selections, it was date night so..we went BIG!!!
To start we had ah-mazing bread with a compound butter, they were out of the fresh pretzels with cheese :(. We shared Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus $11.00 Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce...Yummy!!! My wife had Gebratene Rehmedaillions in Rotwein-Pflaumensoßemit Rotkohl und Spätzle $20.00. Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce
with Red Cabbage & ...really hugh portion and delicious. I had the dinner special: Suckling pig..hmmm..so tasty. We passed on dessert but would go back to try the other hearty food anytime!!! 
*A little noisy and space is small, we recommend to sit in the bar nook.
author: Joshua And Rose-Marie E.

description:
With so many positive reviews it feels a little redundant to add another "it's great!" but that is essentially what I'm doing

The place is always packed so your best bet is to stop by in a small group (and by small group i mean not a group, two people) a bit after dinner starts. Otherwise you are stuck waiting for a space to open up watching everyone else smiling and eating happily.

I'm not a beer person but tried it anyway and it's definitely as good as beer gets for me, so I definitely didn't mind it. The food was delicious and homey at a good price. We had the ravioli and the sausage plate while sharing the pretzel appetizer. Ended with the strudel for dessert and I loved it as much as my meal. 

It's loud and I love the community feeling to the space so definitely drop by for a relaxing and filling meal with no pretentions. Perfect for a group of friends if you can grab a table.
author: Sam H.

description: Great food...veal wienerschnitzel and German potato salad is one of the best I've had.  It's a definite "go back and indulge" when I return to SF.
author: Carlos F.

description:
Booh.
They now bread the Schnitzel in Panko and forget to rinse the salt of the brined venison. Complacency always is the death of good food.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
Maybe it's because I don't drink, I don't get the hype about this place at all. It's extremely noisy, I pretend that I heard what my friend was saying so I didn't need to repeat saying "whaaat?" for the 5th time.

I ordered the cured pork chop. While the pork chop is good, the sauerkraut is kinda sour for my taste. It kinda throws the food taste because the pork chop absorbs that sourness as well.

The potato pancake isn't bad, but I find the apple sauce on top of it is a bit strange. I probably will like it more if it has siracha on top.

Service isn't too bad surprisingly. As long as she can hear you said EXCUSE MEEE, she will stop and acknowledge your request. The food seem to get delivered to the wrong people a lot. Maybe it's hard for them to identify the correct people that order since they have communal seating.
author: Novalina N.

description:
I always knew I loved German beers, but I wasn't aware of how much I liked German food until I came to Suppenküche. Suppenküche!!!!

This place is totally fun. It's got an open, raucous atmosphere that's totally welcoming and lively. Our group of 11 was accommodated quite comfortably, although we did have to wait a bit to get our (previously reserved) table. We ordered everything from stuffed portobellos to braised ox tail, and everyone was satisfied. 

The most fun aspect were the giant boots of beer. I mean, GIANT. Two liters, I think, and we went through two boots in addition to several pint glasses around the table. Their selection of beers is pretty impressive, with something for everyone and very helpful descriptions of each one. They also offer wine - red or white - and the server was more than happy to aid in the selection of those. 

I have to say the highlight of the meal was the roasted half chicken. This thing was tender, moist, flavorful and all sorts of good with it's dumpling stuffing and side of potato pancakes. Awesome. It reminded me of home-cooking, and actually made me want to acknowledge my Bavarian roots for the first time since I can remember. What's that all about? Suppenküche!!!!!
author: Hilary H.

description: Love this place. Reminds me of my Oma's german cooking. Great ambiance too.
author: Natalia K.

description:
Comforting delicious good food & plenty of good beer.

I had a half a roasted (organic :) chicken with caper sauce and potato pancakes and my BFF had pork with mushroom sauce and homemade egg-noodle stroganoff. Everything was perfectly yummy. I confess I knew we were going to Suppenkuche for dinner, so I skipped lunch. This food is the stuff that makes people grow bigger, indeed. 

The beer, is not as bitter and hop-crazy as many of the micro-brew beers crafted in the USA lately. We tried four traditional German beers that were new to us. They were all very nice beers. We are going back.
author: Uva D.

description:
Every time I come here I need to remember it's the only meal I'll need all day! So much food.

I had the giant pretzel app. Brought me back to Oktoberfest...delish!

If you don't have a res, get here right when it opens for your best bet of getting a table on the fly.

I've tried various dishes, but I think my favorite was the jager schnitzel.  The mushroom cream sauce is good stuff.  However this is not for the faint of appetite.  They stuff you to the gills here.  

Oh yes, and there's the beer.  Oh the beer...the boots of beer, the pints, the half pints...all of it.  Great selection of some German brews and the also have Radlers which remind me of my trip to Austria.

Can't wait to go back. (to Suppenkuche, and to Austria!)
author: Lu E.

description: First time having German Food. Not disappointed at all! Service was great, food was delicious. I think I'll be coming back for sure.
author: Khamille W.

description: Really cute spot, stopped in for a drink while we waited for a table. I ordered the Radler which is Helles with lemon soda ($7 I think). I'm not a beer drinker so I got this because I knew it would tone down the bitterness and take away from the hops (I know, I know, I shouldn't be drinking beer). While I appreciate the effort to please those people you bring here who aren't that into beer, I didn't really like this drink. It tasted like watered down beer and flat soda. I'd definitely come back for the atmosphere alone, though; the space is really neat and can handle a rowdy crowd. Next time I'll suck it up and have a real beer.
author: Amanda C.

description:
I've tried both Leopold's and now Suppenkuche...honestly you just can't compare the two. They are both delicious depending what you're in the mood for.

Suppenkuche - I love the community feel to this restaurant. There is almost always a wait to get in but hell it's worth it. The food is great and the beer couldn't be better. 

I love the potato pancakes, bratts, sauted venison - I'm getting hungry just thinking about it. 

Basically, be paitent and have a small snack before hand just in the event you have to wait a couple of hours! :)
author: Leanne S.

description:
We came here for a surprise birthday dinner for a friend. The beer selection is fantastic! Just ask the bartender for a recommendation and he'll let you try a few to see what you like. We got the birthday girl a boot of beer, which is 2L and something she is not likely to forget anytime soon.

Get the grilled pork loin! Not only is it delicious, it is HUGE!

I'd give it 5 stars, but I have to take away a star because we were asked to vacate our table after we finished our meal. I can understand why, as it was 8pm and we showed up 20 mins late to our 6pm reservation, but it still seemed unwelcoming to be kicked to the curb.
author: Bartlomiej K.

description:
This is not a great restaurant to go to on a date.  Or in a large group.  I won't talk about what Suppenkuche isn't and contain my dreams that it occupied a whole city block.  Instead, I will tell a tale of some delicious wheat beer and a roast chicken.  Well, I guess it's more a short anecdote and less of a tale.  Johnny Appleseed makes no appearance here.  Oh, right.  The chicken.  Super moist.  Lovely gravy neath it's crisp body.  It was supposed to be stuffed with a dumpling and said dumpling was mighty fine, but stuffed is a bit of a misnomer.  The chicken more sat on top of the dumpling as if it were trying to keep it warm.  And how could I forget the potato latke taking up the rest of plate's real estate.  It was thicker than I would make myself, but lost nothing in crispiness or in soft potato goodness.  Complimentary apple sauce was appreciated.

Come expecting to pay a little more than some other restaurants nearby.  But come hungry.  And come with a friend.  Just one.  So make it a good one.  Come before 6.  Or right at 6.  Ok, you may be fine if you arrive at 6:05.  Don't go at 8 on a weekend.  You will have to make a sad retreat down the street to Marlena's and drag queens and bud light are no substitute for this thick German sausage.
author: Jeremy G.

description: This place is good be warned though, I've never seen it anything but absolutely crowded. But still, if you want a German beer, this is the place to come. The beer menu offers an exceptional variety of options from Deutschland!
author: Stephen S.

description: Kudos to Suppenkuche! We got there 15 min before they opened for dinner and there were already about a dozen people in line. They opened exactly on time and got everyone seated very quickly and efficiently. This place is like a well oiled machine. Everyone from the host to the waitress to the bus boy to the bartender knows what they're doing and how to do it like clockwork. Best German beer selection in SF. Awesome food options. Great fresh bread to start, yummy sides, delicious meats. We came on a night they had suckling pig = one of the tastiest things I have ever eaten. Everything tastes fresh and the portions are generous. Plus it is 100x quieter than going to Leopold's. Love it.
author: Tracey K.

description: If you want good, typical German food and beer, go there. The sausage and banana beer was excellent.
author: Anup K.

description:
Came here on Wednesday evening, just after 7. Was fairly full, but got a table for 5 right away, though that may have been with a reservation. Service was mostly pretty good, although very slow to bring waters after us asking for them. Food came super fast though. Appetizers almost shockingly so and then entrees followed fairly swiftly. Didn't feel pressured to rush or anything though; felt like a nice environment. 

Portions were surprisingly generous as well. Cheap it is not, but a reasonable value for the money, given that it's SF, and that the food seems to be pretty high quality. Venison medallions, for instance, was maybe 2 or 3 3" pieces of venison I imagined, but came out as two serious pieces, about 4"x8" each. And it was damn good too. And they had a pretty impressive list of (daily?) specials. 3 appetizers, and ~5 entrees. 

We got:
- mushroom soup (special): very mushroomy, but also very creamy. fairly thick, and rich. big bowl too, so great for sharing, at least as much as soups can be
- potato pancakes: disappeared pretty quickly from the table. nice and crispy, especially the outsides. and comes with a homemade apple sauce, which is pleasantly light for apple sauce, and pairs fantastically
- German pretzel: surprisingly not that popular among the table. came with a special buttery spread, not sure what it was. one of the few things that lingered to the end
- Sauteed Pork loin: huge portion, along with everything else. didn't try this one, but it disappeared fairly quickly
- Venison medallions: very tender and rich. probably my favorite of the entrees, as much as I love salmon
- braised beef (special): also fairly popular, and a good size portion, but still disappeared
- grilled salmon (special): decent, but drowned in a cream sauce, which was a little sad
- sides:
-- red cabbage: fantastic red cabbage, and very true to what I got in Germany when visiting a couple years ago. Soft, but not overdone and still a bit of firmness to it. A little bit sweet.
-- spaetzle: dense, but still somewhat light, and not too firm or too soft. light flavor.

Bill came to $37/head with tax and tip, about $150 before tax and tip, with a beer for each of us. Great selection of German beer on draft, as well as a decent bottle selection too. Would happily return here.
author: Kris K.

description: I have frequented only a few german bars before and never liked any of them because they were all just pork dishes and beer. This place is of course the same, but done so so well. My friends had ordered pork knuckles, pork loin and pork sausages and they loved it. I had the Venison medallion for $22 and I would definitely be back to order the same! Trout was done well but serving was a little small. We had the ciders and beers - and i particularly loved mine among all the others it was the Banana Weissen one! 5 stars.
author: Sara N.

description: This is just a fun and  happy place to eat and mingle with your copatrons at the communal tables. Having lived in Berlin, we felt our palates might be let down but that was completely not the case. The beer is always excellent. So many choices that you won't find anywhere else. The spatzle and potato pancakes - to die for. We have been back 3 times in 2 months. The last time we even came with the rambunctious rugrats and the staff was equally accomodating.
author: Lola Z.

description: I was tempted to get the half chicken with potato dumplings and potato pancakes again. Instead, I had some of my honey's bratwurst plate. It came with some creamy mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. I also got a potato soup with some thin sausages. The potato was blended into the soup and it was like drinking liquid pate! I suppose that might sound nasty to some, but I love pate. It went well with the complimentary rye bread, after I finished off the herbed butter of course. And this goes without saying, but we topped it off with bier. I don't remember the last time I was ever so bloated in my life. Service was great.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Literally just returned from consuming over 3,000 calories in under 2 hours.

Unspeakably good food. Went for lentil soup with a side of sausage to start, then the meatloaf with bacon and egg, covered in onion gravy on a bed of mashed potatoes --- heaven! Matched with a La Chouffer belgium and an Enzinger Hefeweizen...which can I say I usually don't go in the lighter beer direction, but our waiter was dead on. 

And now my pants don't fit.
author: Alita M.

description:
my friends and i ordered potato pancakes, salty fried pork, porkchop and a plate of bratwursts. They were all really good, especially the potato pancakes, ohh man every potato based dish should be like these potato pancakes, crispy and the flavor is just awesome, the fried pork was freakin good too, just greasy and fattening, perfect to go with many beers they have here

the wait was pretty long but it was worth it for me...but...

funny everyone has to mention DAS BOOT at some point in all of their reviews here, but i wonder how many ppl actually finished DAS BOOT....i finished it....and i immediately regretted it, but i manned it thru, of course my friend had to drive me home cause i was done! no one should finish DAS  BOOT, it literally is a boat full of beer!

4 stars
author: Michael K.

description:
Absolutely delicious!
My friends and I (all 21) came here for a goodbye dinner to one of our friends heading back to Riverside (eww!) so he found this place on yelp. A bit pricey for a bunch of poor college students but well worth it. The service was excellent. We obviously ordered beer and the waiter recommended us a few based on our preference. And his suggestions were spot on!
The potato pancakes were perfectly crisp, seasoned just right and came with a side of applesauce?! 
I ordered the wienerschnitzel and it was cooked perfectly. My other friends ordered the pork chop (which tasted like ham!), the venison medallions, and the wild boar sausage. All of it was absolutely delicious.
Would come here more often if the University of California didn't take away all our money. :(
author: Steven L.

description:
We went here last Friday for my bf's birthday - and what fun!! Yes, they have communal dining tables, so we sat with another couple and then were later joined by two fun-loving jet-lagged guys - what a mix! We got there at around 5:45 so we beat the dinner crowd (a lot of people were also distracted with Outside Lands going on the other side of town so all the better for us). 

We ordered the potato pancakes with the apple sauce (I think this was a major highlight besides the beer - yum!). I had the pork chops with mushroom sauce, spätzle and side salad (loved the salad dressing!) and my bf had the beef with red cabbage (he enjoyed this!) and spätzle - we thoroughly enjoyed it! 

And then I whispered to the waitress while my bf stepped away for a sec that it was his birthday -- she brought a slice of black cherry chocolate cake with a single lit candle!! He was surprised and I got a kick out of his smiling, shocked, happy face!! Yay!! 

Beer steins and boots clanked with a cheer - oh happy day & Happy Birthday, my dear bf! :) Danke, Suppenkuche!
author: Maile N.

description: Fantastic atmosphere, great service, and delicious authentic german food (and beer)! First off, the group seating was tons of fun and the wait staff are downright cheerful but that's not the best part about this small german restaurant, the reason it is truly a gem has to be their incredible german cuisine. Their pickled herring was out of this world and came with a large variety of vegetables. Their homemade warm pretzels with bavarian cheese were exquisite and matched perfectly with our imported beers. However, their crowning achievement was our entrees. For myself, cured grilled pork with warm sauerkraut and creamy mashed potatoes and for my husband, venison medallions, spätzle and traditional shredded, red cabbage. We laughed and ate till our bellies were achingly full. Unfortunately this left us with no room for dessert, so dissappointingly, we had to leave doggy bag in hand without sampling their apple strudel a la mode. 10/10 will eat again!
author: Natasha W.

description:
Fantastic German restaurant with exceptional food and a nice, traditional feel.  I believe we had the potato pancakes, sauteed trout, and grilled pork sausage amongst other dishes and all were very tasty.  Even the mashed potatoes were several steps up from the usual.  I also liked the extensive German beer selection.  I had the Erdinger Dunkel Weizen myself and was most pleased =D  

On the downside, the place is a bit cramped and the wait was quite long - so come early or plan accordingly for the wait.  Service was fine, the food and drinks were brought out in a timely manner though that was about it.  Overall, a very good dinner spot, ideally with a smaller party given the popularity and somewhat limited seating.
author: Eric F.

description:
As good as Germany, almost as good as mom's spatzle....

Wait until Roger finds this place! Wow, I actually felt like I was in Germany.. Amazing beer selection...
author: Troy S.

description:
Ok ...
my husband is from bavaria and the pretzel was very close to what you get there, beer was the same as what you get at oktoberfest in Munich.
But, the bread was day old (common in germany for rye bread though)
sauerbraten was served almost cold
schnitzel didn't taste very good, the breading wasn't right, potatoes were good but overall very dry. Portions were huge 
room is so noisy you have to scream to talk to peopl seating next to you.
and it is very expensive
but after a beer, everything is nicer.. so 3 stars
author: Tal S.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night with 8pm reservations for a party of 15+.  I think we got seated by 8:15pm or so--not bad considering how crowded they were.

I enjoyed the atmosphere the most--loud, but not too loud and friends just having a good time at big tables.  Of course you know coming to Suppenküche that the beer is why many people check this place out.  They have a good selection but my only question is, why do they have such a limited amount of boots?  They really should offer the option to buy the boot as well, and keep more on hand.  But maybe it's a liability issue to have people then leaving their premises with these huge boots ha.

We tried a good amount of the entrees and while big portions and nice presentation, not the best food I've had.  The suckling pig didn't leave me craving more--it was slightly dry and I didn't notice any skin for the crispiness.  The wiener schnitzel was good, except it completely reminded me of Japanese tonkatsu lol...so the whole time I was eating it I craved some tonkatsu dipping sauce.  And this was after the potato pancakes reminded two of us at the table of McDonald's hash browns--no offense.  Side note, the sauerkraut was very flavorful!

I would come back for drinks with friends, but don't think I would necessarily pay ~$19 for most of the entrees the second time around.
author: Christopher W.

description:
The pork chops are to die for!  I would eat them everyday, all day.  Yum!

Potato pancakes are decent, but basically like bigger crispy hash browns with applesauce. Not sure they're as good as others have said. 

Yes, the wait on weekends is long but it's worth it.  

Beers are better than advertised.  Any of the marzens will do. 

I almost don't even want to post yet another awesome review for this place as I don't want the wait to be longer than it is, but they really deserve it.  Go here and be happy.
author: David L.

description:
Oh my god. My taste buds were dancing...but that might have just been DAS BOOT talking. Guys, this is two liters of beer that comes in a boot. I literally cannot think of a more awesome way to drink. They have a fantastic (and large) selection of German, Austrian, and Belgian beers. Our waitress was super knowledgeable and more than happy to offer recommendations. 

This was actually my first foray into German food, but as a meat and potatoes kind of girl I was not disappointed. Everything was so hearty, tasty, and generously portioned. Embrace the food coma, because it will come. I got a special they have now, the suckling pig with sauerkraut. It tasted a bit like carnitas to me (but unchopped). DELICIOUS. I also tried some of the pork sausage (DELICIOUS) and the portobello mushrooms stuffed with feta and spinach (DELICIOUS). I was happy to see that they had such a yummy vegetarian option, because now I am dragging my veg roommates back here.

The decor and ambiance are really charming and rustic as well. I pretty much felt as if I had been transported to a quaint German farm and was eating unpretentious comfort food. There's a bar in the front of the restaurant, so I can also see coming here for just a drink as well.

They have a 5 credit card max, so make sure people have cash if you're coming with a large party!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Pretty good german food in a really noisy space.

Good beer selections and a good vibe from the crowd, which was quite large for a Thursday night. The schnitzel was good, and the portions large, although the pretzels and cheese were a bit disappointing.
author: John B.

description: Some controversy about authenticity as it pertains how they do it in Germany. Standing in the crowded aisle at the bar, eyeballing the plates served, it all looked pretty familiar to my occasional visits to the Rathaus in Wiesbaden or the restaurant in Cologne or even the famous Hofbräuhaus in München. Schnitzel with fried potatoes (mit Bratkartoffeln?) and a salad. That's it. Let's not dismiss two little-known-to-Americans beer: Andechs from a monastery in Germany and the delightful thirst--quenching Stiegl from Salzburg Austria. Some owner knows precisely what they are doing. We get to pay dearly for a few moments in Deutschland in San Francisco. Just wish it weren't so noisy. Maybe that's authentic as well. Well not so much.
author: G M.

description:
First and only time I had German food. When you walk into the place, you will have a sudden feel of traditional German place. 

I was warned about how hardy and heavy the food is. But BLAH good food is good food.

I had the Jägerschnitzel which was awfully tasty. (a nice generous piece of pork chop) . 

In looking at all the other tables orders, this place ain't NO JOKE it will leave u full and wanting more at the end.  Also, a nice added thing to this place good selection on Belgian beers
author: kent c.

description:
I'm on the fence with Suppenkuche.

My experience wasn't mind blowing but also wasn't horrible.

We went here for my friends 26th birthday.  We made reservations in advance so we were seated right away.

They have an extensive beer list (if you like beer) although I'm more of a gin/vodka-type myself.  I ended up with the Raddler (beer with lemon soda) which was actually quite good for such an odd combination.

We started off with the potato pancakes and the pretzels.  The potato pancakes were pretty good, although reminded me of potato latkes.  The pretzels were alright.

I had the Jagerschnitzel, which was pounded pork with a mushroom sauce which was pretty good.  I wish they had given us some steak knives because cutting meat with a butter knife is beyond absurd.  The schnitzel was good, but not memorable.  It also came with Spätzle which I didn't care for.

I was a bit disappointed for my first taste of German cuisine as I was expecting more.  I would probably come back again but not with such high hopes.

Expect to wait for a while.  Suppenkuche only takes reservations for groups 6 or larger, so if you are planning on coming with a large group, I would highly recommend making reservations.

Also, this place has the infamous boot!  Our friend who turned 26 ended up getting one which was 2 massive liters of beer.  You also have to give them your credit card for a $50 deposit if you end up breaking the boot.
author: Kameron K.

description:
This could be THE place to get your beer on!  They have Das Boot! Ok, thats what they called it on the movie Beerfest.  Its actually a 2 liter glass boot of beer.  So for those stomachs that can handle that much liquid and love beer, this is the place to be.  So many different varieties of all beer from Germany.

Food was good.  I especially loved their potato pancakes!  This place is super filling....with all the food and beer.  Plan to walk home or workout for the next week. 

Oh and the staff is super great!  Especially Katie!  She's from Germany and that girl knows her beer!
author: Gina S.

description:
After our last final of the year, a few friends and I decided to come here and eat/drink our misery away.  This place was really loud but that just means everyone was having a good time right?  The beer selection was good and the food portions are huuuge.  I had the breaded pork chop with the side of peas and mash potatoes and the peas had pieces of Canadian bacon in it mmmmmmm 

I kinda like the long tables because we had a pretty good conversation going with the people sitting next to us.  

The German sodas are nice too.  

Overall, it was a chill place to drink and eat - but a little loud to talk too much. (Also pretty cracking on a Tuesday evening).
author: Tina L.

description: A nice, packed place. I was a bit worried at first that we had to share a table with complete strangers, but luckily we were seated with nice and funny people. The food was great. I loved my jager schnitzel with spatzle and a tall glass of dark brew.. yum yum yum. My friend and I killed the strudel in under a minute. I loved the servers they're so nice! I'll come back soon
author: Dimples P.

description:
Amazing service, great beer, and AWESOME food. Every chance I get, I come here to get potato pancakes (SOOO GOOOOD) and their salad. Oh, and of course beer :) 

It is always busy, and it can get pretty loud. But it is very friendly and so worth it!
author: Michelle H.

description:
Casual atmosphere, fantastic Bravarian beer selection, and hearty plates!

I've been here a few times the last couple of months, and while it's always packed the service and experience have always been great!  Perfect if you want to gather with friends and enjoy a taste of Germany in San Francisco or just go for a fun informal dinner.  It can be crowded, the bar area is a bit tight, and theres a good chance you might be sharing your table with other guests (because it always packed), but honestly thats all part of the places charm.  

The menu features some excellent choices including the traditional potato cakes, ravioli, deer cutlets, schnitzel, fish, and an unbelievable meatloaf.  In the past 6 months I've introduced the place to about half a dozen new people and they have all become fans.  

If you like beer and meat then this is a must visit, and if your really feeling brave ask them for 'a boot' - 5L of beer.
author: Honeya O.

description: Don't need to add much to what people have already mentioned. They do have a great brunch (Sunday only) at a great value. You won't leave hungry. You might not leave sober, either.
author: Dan B.

description:
Arrived here 5 minutes before opening and the line was down the block..

dont expect to get a table here unless you call way ahead.

I settled for the bar. Their selection is great and you can order your drink in any size imaginable.

Its really not that big of a place so its kind of hard to move around once you have been situated. I have no idea how the waitresses manage maneuver through the crowd.

The vibe is unique. The artsy ambiance has very natural, simple feel to it.

A great place for an after work pint.
author: Josh W.

description: I am a big fan of German food. From Katia in NYC to Speisekammer in Alameda, when the suggestion to go here in SF came up, I jumped at it. We lucked out on parking and found a spot only a few blocks away on a Saturday night after 6pm, which is obviously rare. The place inside is small but very German beer hall, with communal tables in the front and back, and the bar on the right side as you walk in. We only waited a few minutes before we grabbed a few seats near the front of the door (be warned, when it's chilly outside, you'll feel the breeze every time the curtain gets thrown back for people coming or going near the entrance--bring a jacket). The appetizer plate had tremendous meats on it. More bread would have been clutch though. I almost regretted getting this due to its girth; I could have just had this as my meal and been set. But who goes to a German restaurant and doesn't try their other fine fare? The braised beef is always a go-to, and I wasn't disappointed. Really flavorful and the lingonberries were fresh. The spatzle wasn't really anything to write home about, but I ate it nonetheless. And of course you have to wash that all down with a cold one, and the Belgian triple (at a German place? I know, blasphemy) packed just the right amount of hops for me to consider this a successful venture into Deutschland. The service was also on point, as even though it was busy, our server was quick to accommodate us with any requests. You'll have to spend a little here, but I think it's worth it for some quality food and beverage.
author: Dan M.

description:
I loved this place and would definitely go back. One of the few places that I've found who's food price, food quality, and food portion are directly proportional. 

Our waiter was excellent. We were able to order and converse in German, which made the experience fun, his recommendations and knowledge of the food were spot on, and service was FAST! 

I think the best part was the fact that this small establishment that seemed to be popular was very nice in letting us stay and talk for a bit after our food had been eaten and plates removed. They didn't seem to be in a hurry to turn the tables over, which is what really made the experience.

Things to Know: 
-you need to have your whole party to be seated (although, they were flexible with us, even on a busy night without a reservation!) 
-the facility is small so they do fill up
-their beer is excellent, all of it!
author: Lily K.

description: hands down my favorite restaurant in the city! I gotta get a boot every time I'm here. I have never had a bad meal, and never had any dish  that wasn't as delicious as the next. Have pretty much tried everything on the menu, and I'd have to say the venison is my favorite. its always cooked perfectly and just tastes delicious! Hmmm.. I think I'll go talk to my wife and see about going again soon!
author: Chad G.

description:
I am definitly a fan!  Foods great - I ordered the dumpling stuffed 1/2 chicken, with shallot sauce.  It was fantastic, and the potato pancakes were great too...  And I have to say it's nice to see someone put a chicken dish on a menu that I would want to eat.  Usually its just treated like the restaraunt just had to have a chicken dish to tak up space on the menu.  

Atmousphere is fun and conversational.

I ate at the bar, got great service, and the food came out super quick.  I will be back.
author: Adam R.

description:
If Hitler was alive, his drunk ass will always be here w/ his drunk Nazi buddies.

I recommend to arrive early as possible before it open because the place can get really crowded. The restaurant is small and only have limited tables. This means sharing a table with random people. 

The dos boot is so amazing. The potato pancakes taste like McDonald's hash brown but not too greasy plus it comes w/ apple dipping sauce. The bread is free to sober your ass up.
author: Richard C.

description: This place is the reason why we drive up once a year alllll the way from San Diego. Love their beer, food, and super friendly staff.
author: N. M.

description:
I now know that a wienerschnitzel is not a hot dog. 

My first time having German food. The food was great! The lobster soup was really creamy and flavorful. We actually got the BOOT. The boot is a glass boot filled with your choice of beer. It holds about 1.5 liters. We were suppose to share it between 5 people, but 4 of us chickened out after 2 or 3 chugs. So one person finished about 2/3 of it. He was drunk. 


Fun, noisy, loud atmosphere! Gotta speak loud to hear other in here.
author: Phil P.

description:
DAY-um good German food. 

Big 'ol boot of beer that you can share with a good friend. 

Family style seating that lets you get friendly with total strangers. 

simple but fun decor. 

This place is good times. Enough food to send you home with leftovers you will be craving the next morning. Their Bangers and Mash are dank!!!


my only complaint is the whole credit card deposit for the boot of beer, but then again, I'm sure plenty of drunks have broken or made off with the mug. So, they probably have good reason.
author: Jason _.

description:
Let me preface this by "I don't understand German food", which probably explains why I am just putting an "A-ok" rating. 

Done, so people don't think I'm a hater!

- Place is more suited for groups, you have to share the table with randos, which can be a fun experience if you like this
- The food was ok, nothing too exciting
- Ravioli/Mushroom sauce: Loved the sauce, the ravioli itself was so so
- Pork sausage, mashed potatoes, sauerkraut was ok - Nothing exceptional about the sausages unfortunately

Summary: I don't think it is a bad place, you need to like this type of food, heavy and comforting. The atmosphere is definitely German... I think this is overpriced, prices should be 10% less
author: Meryl C.

description:
The food here is great, no doubt about that.  The Weisswurst I had was just okay, but the food I tasted from my brother and friends were great.  I'm also not a big beer fan, but they had good beers that I liked. This is my first time here, and I wasn't wowed with my dish, but I'm willing to try this place again since I think I just ordered the wrong thing.

However, I have to mention that I had a weird experience with the server.  The server had forgotten something I ordered, and while she did admit that she had totally forgotten about it, she just kind of...stared...at me after she said it. Honestly, it was probably only a few seconds but it kind of felt like an eternity, prompting me to sheepishly say "So...uhh...can I have it...now?" Not the best choice of words, I know, but it was an awkward response to an awkward moment.
author: Sylvia S.

description:
Great service, yummy food, and a great selection of German alcohol. 

The waiter brought out a large dish of Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus to compensate for bringing my bf's portabella mushroom dish a little later. Super kind!!!!

I like the picnic table concept and eating dinner with random people.
author: Jister Y.

description: Great breakfast plate, I ordered the bratwurst with egg. the plate came out and everything was in perfect order. The eggs were shaped perfectly round and tasted really hot and creamy. ALso got a beer in the boot (for brunch)! they have a great selection of brews from home land and Austria. Very simple food yet good and hearty.
author: James W.

description:
2 hours to get seated but the beer was fantastic and it got us through the wait. 

The food came out so fast it had me wondering how fresh it was.

Potato cake is a big hash brown patty.

Waited 20 minutes to get our change but never saw the waiter again.
author: Nathaniel C.

description: Love love this place!!! The food is delicious , service is really fast. I wish the wait was not so long. But it is well worth it! Their sausages are very tasty. The beer boots are definitely worth a try. Make sure to get there right at 5. Or later at 9 pm!
author: Lexi C.

description: Delicious!! Found this place while visiting the area. Being German I know what real German food tastes like and this was great! The guy behind the bar was really nice too. This place was super packed when I went on a weds so I'd say get there a lil early.
author: Laura W.

description:
This place was amazing! My boyfriend and I stumbled upon it walking around Hayes St. and were delightfully surprised! The place was rowdy and fun but I wouldn't expect anything else. 

Boyfriend and I were lucky to get one of the few tables that just say two people. I would feel a little awkward sitting at a table with a bunch of other people. So hooray for just plain luck!

The food was delicious! The veal wiener schnitzel was incredible! We also ordered the saurbraten which was still good but couldn't compete with the first. 

I definitely want to go back and try everything else! Plus maybe a boot of beer! :)
author: Jamie S.

description:
Food: 3/5 - Great place to have some authentic German dishes, but the flavors are pretty standard - nothing amazing. They do give you a lot of food, but in this case quantity cannot make up for quality. I tried the Brat, and I tried a little bit of friends' Wiener Schnitzel and Pork Chop, and I'd say they were all pretty standard. I will say that even though I don't like Sauerkraut, theirs tasted authentic and I actually enjoyed it. If you are going strictly for beer, then it does have a great selection and of course, the boot! But I honestly feel that ratings here may be based off some cloudy judgement.

Service: 2/5 - Given that it is almost always crowded as hell, the service can be slow to come around, and they are very quick with you and not attentive after that. While it's totally understandable that they are just trying to get around to everyone and that it's busy, it's annoying when you can barely even flag someone down, let alone get them to stop by on their own.

Ambiance: 2/5 - Our group had a table to ourselves since we had just enough people to squeeze everyone in. Yet, as usual there were masses of people just standing around and crowding the hell out of the place. We were against the wall, but even then it felt crowded with the groups standing on the other 3 sides of us. 

Value: 3/5 - It's pretty low cost here for most dinner items, but at the same time it's really simple food. You get a meat of some sort, and then a large amount of mashed potatoes and sauerkraut in most cases. I'd say for the quantity you get it's not a bad deal, but for the actual quality as mentioned above, it's just ok.
author: Kevin T.

description:
A 2 liter boot beer, blood sausage, venison and a 18 table full of drunks = craziness!!! Katy? Kathy? I don't know but thanks for your patience last night. She's about the best waitress I've had... even though they were so packed they ran out of glasses and boots she did her best to accommodate us... the food was good AND fast... it's just getting in that takes a long time but it's well worth it... I loved the deer meat and tried some of my friends mashed taters... yumm... I definitely recommend the venison but the mashed yummy goodness had the consistency of butter... I enjoyed this place very much... whether you're a fan of Oktoberfest or German beers or good food or just an alcoholic... make a reservation and come here... 

And to the people we annoyed last night... sorry =P
author: Nathan D.

description:
Definitely one of my new favorite places. Despite the crazy Saturday night rush - people packed in the benches at each table, people packed around the bar, people packed in the small area behind the bar - my two friends and I managed to snag 3 seats at the bar, thus avoiding the hour and a half wait we were told to expect when we first checked in with the hostess.

We had a great view of the entire restaurant (not that it's a huge space) to really get into the atmosphere and even better, a great waiter/bar tender who was entertaining and attentive. I was skeptical when we first arrived because I am NOT a fan of crowds and/or feeling uncomfortable while I'm eating but it turned into a great evening and we stayed for a couple more beers than originally planned. Oh and the food was great. I will definitely go back here, maybe later on a weekend night (9:00 or 9:30 when the crowd seemed to clear out a bit) or during the week.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Prost!!!

If you do not mind waiting for 2 hrs on a Saturday night, knowing that you got there early for SF time, 6:15pm, crowded around the busy bar and surrounded by people with eagle eyes trying to find a spot/table at the bar, and customers hovering over your shoulders to make sure you get sooo irritated that you would want leave, then this is an AWESOME place!!! =)

After a couple of beers, it did not faze me at all, in fact, I was even passing potato pancakes around, sharing my boot and having a good jolly time with my friends!! (Do not chip, lose or attempt to steal the glass boot, it'll be another $50 to your tab). Oh and once you hit the bathroom, beware, you may NEVER come back!! That's it, your spot is TAKEN!! Yup!! Or, if you are a nice customer like me, say "excuse me" and then push your way in!! =)

...2hours later, my hostess holla and said "Do you still need a table? It will be another 10minutes." I could not believe she REMEMBERS, I feel so welcomed!! Heart to the hostess w/glasses!! =)

Food Award goes to...the Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce
served with Spätzle & Green Salad. 

*If you do not want to wait this long, I HIGHLY recommend reserving at least one month in advance for a party of 6 or more. Any party less than that, good luck on the wait! This place gets booked SUPER quickly.

Yes, after gone thru all that, I am still a FAN!
author: Leeseuh K.

description:
I came back as soon as my stomach fixed itself, with guns blazing, and I'm so glad I did, because I got a five star experience out of it. 

To reiterate, the beers were amazing. This time I had the Kolsch, the Konig Pilsener, and the Korbinian. The former were lighter beers, not too hoppy, and with a pleasant aftertaste. The Korbinian was a dark, malty beer that I definitely should not have had last, because I was about to explode and the heaviness did not help. But boy, was it delicious.

The four of us split a pickled herring appetizer, which was delightfully fishy. I got the meatloaf with the mashed potatoes, and it was everything I hoped it would be. By the end of the meal, I was about to explode from deliciousness, fullness, and drunkenness.

I keep raving about the food and the beer, but the service is what brought this up to five stars. My boyfriend ordered a chicken dish (which I can no longer find on the menu) and we noticed that the table next to us had also put through an order, shortly after we did. Not only did they get their chicken before the bf did, but the server came out and told us that they ran out of chicken! However, she immediately apologized, acknowledging that the table next to us got the chicken before we did, despite putting the order in later, and promised to comp his order, as well as our next round of beer.

If there was a way to handle it, that was DEFINITELY it. We drank so much beer and ate so much food that the bill ended up pretty steep anyway, but the free entree and round of beers definitely helped. Well done, Suppenkuche. I would gladly give up my first choice entree in exchange for a round of beers and my second choice, free.
author: Angeline P.

description: Fun evening!  We waited about an hour at 7pm on a Saturday night, which I guess is typical.  Got a great table at the windows and since we were 5, shared with a couple.  Wait staff was efficient and attentive.  The pretzel appetizer wass good, as was the reisling.  I had the roast chicken special and loved it, especially the stuffing.  The potato pancakes were a little thick for me, without enough crispyness, but were good overall.  Others in our party enjoyed the brisket and the special roast pig; husband loved the meatloaf.  It is loud -- especially during the world series when a couple of tables were watching on their tablets.  But we had a great time and the food overall was really good.
author: Geralyn H.

description:
Wonderful beer, great atmosphere, amazing food!  This is a great place to take a group - especially if you have over 5 people (the number needed to make a reservation).

Unfortunately, it's really hard to get a table here.  For less than five people, you need to go and put your name in and then wait for a very variable amount of time.  Not the place to go if you're in a hurry!  It's also extremely loud and hard to hear inside.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
So kids friendly. Kind of noisy but have communal style tables and kind of fun place to go.
I'm not much of a meat eater but found lots of options which were delicious!
Potato pancake filled us up but I was still able to enjoy my portobello mushroom dish. We were there around 5:30 on Friday but by 7, the place was packed!
author: Akiko I.

description:
I wish I could say you should stay far away from brunch. But I can't. Go early for no wait and order a Schneider Weisse, smoothest beer of all time. We've loved the Jaegerschnitzel, sausages with potatoes and sauerkraut, and many many more. 

Obatzda is delicious and, though adventuresome, worth a try. 

Love you, Suppenkuche!
author: Megan G.

description:
I went to Suppenküche for the first time on Wednesday night. Word of advice: if you're going to go, show up for an early dinner. The good news is that if you have to wait, you can head over to the bar and have all the delicious beer that you want while passing the time.

The food was excellent. I can't offer an opinion on the meat dishes since I'm a vegetarian, but my boyfriend really enjoyed his nürnberger bratwurst, and said the sauerkraut was the best he'd ever had. That's a pretty huge compliment coming from him, since he's half-German and grew up on German food. I had the käsespätzle, and it was awesome. Totally hit the spot since I'd skipped lunch that day.

The only reason I gave this place a 3 instead of a 4 or 5 is that our waitress and guy that cleaned our plates off our table were making it very clear that they wanted us to leave as quickly as possible. I totally understand that they stop serving dinner at 10:00 and they were tired, but you should never make your customer feel like they're imposing, especially because this place isn't super cheap and I'm not super rich.

When we happily told the waitress that we were surprised that they got the food out so fast, she responded with "Yeah, well, end of the night--  we try to get everything out as soon as possible." Then when I was taking some bites of mashed potatoes from my boyfriend's plate, a guy came over and grabbed the plate so that I had to put the fork down and stop eating. I got a "Sorry, I don't mean to interrupt," but seriously dude, I wanted those damn potatoes.

The worst part was that it's not like we were the last people there, and we didn't lollygag through our meal. The place was still packed, and there were plenty of tables of people that were sitting there taking their sweet time to finish their beers before leaving (as they should). 

So long story short, awesome beer, tasty food, but the wait staff should stop treating customers like obstacles to their shift ending.
author: Beth K.

description: Great German place in the city - It may lack fancy decorations but food and beer are extremely good. It gets REALLY crowded, so plan accordingly, especially on weekend. Schnitzel is a must have.
author: Steve E.

description:
I always leave happy and full from this place. Schneider Weisse was the choice of beer this time and a good choice it was! We got potato pancakes to start as always with the delicious applesauce. I tried the organic chicken meatloaf with mashed potatoes special, which was okay. A little dry, but the good sauce made up for it. The mash was good. My friend got the porkloin jagerschnitzel with mushroom sauce, my absolute favorite dish!

Always a bit loud in there so it's hard to talk, but everyone is just drinking and having a good time. Service has always been nice. Food never disappoints!
author: Linda C.

description:
Heil Suppenkuche! I mean, where else can you gobble on some home-style bodacious Bavarian food? Minimalist decor, communist (communal) seating, unique food and beer (I have yet to try sipping on "The Boot"); what you see is what you get - and what I see is wunderbar! Got a German relative visiting and yearning for the taste of home? Take the Nazi here and he'll spare your life. 

The wait can be ree-dick, so, after hours of internal debate, I decided to tack off a star.
author: Scott G.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night around 630PM although we arrived at about 540ish to find parking.  So depending on what is happening that evening the parking will be tight.  Expect at least a good walk or a good 15-30 minutes drive around the blocks to find parking.  The farther you park -- the better chance you have at finding parking. 

Food wise -- super food.  Go for the food -- not the parking.  I had the meatloaf and mashed potatoes paired with a good beer (of which I cannot recall).  I cleaned the plate with the bread.  Yes -- it was that good. 

Ambiance -- Very tight squeeze.  The place is busy.  The seating is wood benches in the back on long tables.  The back area where we sat had 3 longs tables for groups of 10 or so.  The front area had a smaller seating areas made for 3-6 people.  The bar area had a tight squeeze for space for beers.  Let's just say -- expect to rub bodies with people when coming and leaving.  

Service -- good for our group.  I can say that we were paid attention to.  We got water, beer and food pretty fast.  I did not observe any bad service.  All the servers were friendly.  

I will be back later than sooner --- too much food in San Francisco to try.  But if you're looking for German Food -- this is one place to try for sure.
author: PNotHere E.

description:
Yum---applesauce and potato pancakes, mushroom dumplings, and cheesy spaetzle.  Basically, nothing has fiber in it and everything tastes delicious.  My husband is a wheat beer nutzo, and just browsing the beer menu made him giddy.  The Woodruff syrup & mineral water tastes like liquid marshmallow.  

We were stuffed after dinner, but couldn't resist ordering a piece of Black Forest cake to go.  When my husband flew back to DC on a gray, drizzly Tuesday, I was really sad. But the breakfast cherry, chocolate, and whipped cream cheered me up slightly.
author: Lynn M.

description:
I've been here twice now although the second time I intended to go to Leopold's but they had a 2 hour wait there so we went here to keep the German food theme for the evening.

We were told it would be a 30-40 minute wait but got seated in 10 minutes.  The beer selection is great and they do have wine also.

We had the suarbraten which was not as sour as I am used to having it but still very good, red cabbage which was excellent, pork sausages with mustard which were amazing with beer, saurkraut which was seasoned to perfection and mashed potatoes.

For dessert, we had black forest cake which was excellent except the raspberries inside were too cold from being refrigerated.

I came here as a couple and we got seated at our own table but I think this place is better for groups who can sit at these big family style benches.
author: Mark G.

description:
Great place for german food, but always busy. They dont take reservations so be prepare to wait at least 30mins+ depending what day and time youre there. But if youre happen to be there with a group of 6+ call them. They will try to grant that, even though it is a big cozy restaurant. 

if youre not in for loud crowds, this wouldnt be the place otherwise it'll be a great place to hang out with other people, because tables are tend to share with another party if youre there just for 2 or 3. The bar area are always busy but definitely for the food take advantage of the daily specials. Theyre delicious. 

For the food, we ordered, The corn soup was made freshly with grated soup that has a texture that tasted like smooshed up corn bread. Then we had three entrees, all off the special menu of the day. The veal is just perfect texture, the half chicken is delicious too, not too dry, and the meat almost practically falls off the bones. The pork was okay, a bit dry but not a bad choice to try. I over looked over another table and they had the beef, looks delicious something to try another time. 

Dont forget the beer boots! Great for sharing if you cant finish it!!
author: Linh D.

description:
I went here probably three years ago for my German Grandpa's birthday for an early dinner on a weekday.

I didn't have a chance to try any of the beer's on tap, just the dinner but I look forward to coming back very soon probably this month to give this place a second try.

I had the Sauerbraten last time I was here, and I remember it being as good as my own Oma's.
author: Doug R.

description:
When the seasons change in San Francisco.  wait.  the seasons never change in San Francisco, and when that happens, when things stay about the same, then it's time to gain weight in San Francisco.  The waiter came in with a blue bic and scratched out the clam chowder.  strange anyway, that they should serve clam chowder.  

Scratch that out with a blue bic. 

It was raining cats and dogs.  Gutter flow made my flip-flops a terrible liability.  Hands tight in my pockets, tip-toed flight on the street and launch over gurgling parallel streams consecutively.  What's the difference between anyway, between rocks, between moss, between mighty redwoods, and asphalt, sewer grates, the sound under an umbrella, a quiet moment under a tree, a synthetic tree, clouds painted below the eaves, just a bit more kick to the soul.

An engaged couple sat: opposite, pleasant, self-fulfilled.  They ordered a boot.  If you ever want to give people a fighting chance, or ever sit down in a restaurant without tearing the world apart, never work in a restaurant, at least don't fall in love with a restaurant. never give a heart to a heartless thing.  it will never love you back.

We ordered dark, smokey, German beer, as per consultation.  The waiter was a show as should be.  His best move: handfull of dishes, stop-short, non-inquiring acknowledgement.  "Hi, how's it goin?"  we all exchanged glances and he flew off, to the pit i suppose, returned shortly for our order, but he had shown us the compliment of acknowledgement amidst chaos. 

On my second best bathroom trip of the evening, I surveyed the kitchen.  I'm always drawn to the kitchen, the beautiful view from the pass.  This was an outfit, a real bubblegum crew, chewed together, spit out, tucked under the table.  I can see a million things gone wrong, and what counts though?  The plate, aside from requisite error, enjoyable.

The ideas are all there for a place that we San Francisco should always have, a fixture, an indelible birthmark, like Swan Oyster, or Boulevard, maybe just some fine-tuning, another shake of the salt, a change of the fry oil, but I hope the clam chowder is still there when I return.

only to be scratched out with a blue bic.
author: Queso G.

description:
Tried this place a couple of weeks after I first tried Walzwek's.  To me, they are very similar..crowed, noisy, old world ambiance and great food.  I have
no complaints for this place.  Lots of people making lots of noise drinking lots of beer having lots of fun.  I was a 'solo' diner so I sat at the bar...had a great view overlooking the bar and dining area.  All the food was great and since I am a fan of the red cabbage I ordered an extra side of that.  
Recommend that you go early since it gets crowded!
I would be happy going to either Walzwerk's or to Suppenkuche.  I will return to both places.

4 1/2 *s
author: Dale N.

description:
The restaurant itself is probably a 3-star (for a vegetarian) but we had such a fab time here that for that I would give it a 4-star! went with a bunch of girlfriends from work and was a fabulous evening. One of the ladies at work won a $100 giftcard to suppenkuche' and she was so kind to share it with all of us! Great service and loved the ambiance, so quaint and warm! 

They do have a wonderful selection of beers and I really can't remember what I got but I am sure it was a pale ale. One of the restaurant patrons insisted that I try his beer (it was green or was it red? in color) and he LOVED it and i thought it was just aight. Some of the girls also ordered it and they also were not enamored by it :) But overall great selections and everyone was happy and I think atleast one person indulged in the boot. LOL

As for the food itself all the meat lovers really loved it and i was recommended to get the spaetzle and it was SO HEAVY! omg, i couldn't eat even quarter of it. Another friend (who is not vegetarian and is a foodie) actually customized her order - spaetzle with the mushroom sauce from the apps menu (i should have taken her lead). 

It was my first german food experience and its probably safe to say that i probably had a better time here than I would if I really ate in Germany!
author: Sapna E.

description: Amazing food and beer. Service was great. Enjoyed the family style seating. Had the pork sausage and mashed potatoes with sour kraut and Bavarian mustard, all terrific. My friends had the meatloaf and couldn't stop raving about how great it was.
author: Matt E.

description:
Edit and update:

woke up in the middle of the night with terrible stomach cramping and all of the hallmark signs of food poisoning.  Also muscle cramping and night sweats... Received a text from my friend asking if I got sick last night after dinner.  He had/has the same stomach issues and we only met last evening for dinner.

Review went from 4 stars to 1.  If a restaurant can't practice good food safety and keep it's patrons from getting sick, it shouldn't be in business.

FYI, we both had the venison medium-rare, I can't think of anything else that really would have caused the food-born illness other cross contamination to the vegetables or grains.

I wonder how many people in Hayes Valley are late or missing work today that ate at Suppenkuche last night...

-----------------------
original review:
-----------------------

food = 4/5
beer = 5/5
atmosphere = 3/6
service = 3.5/5
price/value = 3.5/5
Overall = 4/5, pretty darn good

Been here a few times.  Tonight had the german ravioli and smoked herring plates for appetizers.  Both were excellent and I highly recommend.

For entre had the venison.  The meat wasn't that tender but tasted pretty good.  Actually, tasted pretty much like beef and lacked a little bit of the gamey flavors I like about deer but was still tasty.

For drinks I had a couple different beers.  One was a a dunkel hefeweizen and the other was a in the "specialty section.  It was something Alt. and was awesome.  It was bottled but I highly recommend it.  I can't remember the name but it's the only beer with Alt. as the second name.

Anyway, we sat by the door and draft was sort of nasty but overall it was a good experience.

Total check for 2 appetizers, 2 entrees, and 4 beers was $98 + tip.

It was probably a little over priced.
author: Joseph H.

description: Great place for a hearty meal. Potato pancake was crispy but not greasy.   This is German food so its a very meat and potatoes type of place. nothing fancy. you share tables. but the food fills the belly and the beer keeps flowing. come if you like imported german beer. while food is german, its not scary to americans. not for your light weights and dieters. come here and get ready to grub.
author: Jason C.

description: A very merry place to come for lots of beer and good food. Had the lamb, which was amazing. had a bite of the goose, also yum. Weiner schnitzel looked really good too. It's definitely kind of a rowdier place, so not good for a first date (sorry, couple sitting next to us, our table probably killed your conversations). But definitely good for a fun night out.
author: Vivian H.

description: What an awesome restaurant! We turned up around 730 and had to wait for a table, so we went across the road for a beer as it was packed inside. We were seated after 45mins and it was well worth the wait. Service was great and fast. Our food and beers arrived in no time at all and we were impressed. Huge servings and just delicious! I had the potato cakes and a schnitzel.
author: Mel H.

description:
we came in around 9pm, ordered a beer and signed up on the list. beer was delish and our we only had to wait about 10 minutes for our table.
love the communal tables. our server, ashley, was totally nice and patient with us. we order 2 apps and 2 entrees and couldn't finish even half of our mains.
this was my first time here but most def not my last. next time i hope to score a seat at the bar so rusty and fill me in on more beer info then i could ever dream of.
author: tinkerbell e.

description:
What's the best way to end a night of martinis and intense discussions about your least favorite teams in college football (Michigan*)?

MEATLOAF WRAPPED IN BACON.

On the night before Thanksgiving, all through the Bay, not a creature was stirring, not even a gay**. After walking through Hayes Valley and trying to find a spot to eat that was still open, we decided to give Suppenküche a shot since we had never been and both had been dying to try it. 

We walked inside and were told it would be 15-20 minutes. Totes doable compared to the usual 1-2hr wait. As we stood near the bar, admiring the boots of beer for no more than a minute, a waitress passed us and said she had a table for us. Score. 

Sitting down at a community table with 4 other strangers (soon-to-be-besties), our friendly waiter got us some drinks pretty quickly while we were buzzed from the lederhosen atmosphere***.

I ordered the meatloaf wrapped in bacon and it came with a side of mashed potatoes. I'm not sure if it was the alcohol, but it was amazing. I ate it all. Every bite. Very quickly. My tummy might have ached soon after, but no blame is to be placed on Suppenküche. 

The lines and reservation wait time can be intimidating, so try to come before they close or right before a holiday when all of us transients have headed home. Well, except for heathens* like myself.


_________
* Also: USC, Texas & Michigan again.
** False. There were a few gays in Marlena's.
*** The multiple martinis may have also played a factor. 
**** My words, not my Mom's. She just calls me "ungrateful of my love." She means well, though.
author: Jared S.

description:
My favorite spot on my recent trip to San Francisco.

I have never been to a German place, but this place seems as good as it gets.

Its loud, its packed, and there is alot of beer drinking going on.

Unfortunately, I did not get the opportunity to eat here because we were starved and did not want to wait. The food we saw looked amazing and people I met all raved about it. The only thing I got to try was the bread and spread (because we ended up getting a table after our dinner) which was super tasty, so i cant IMAGINE HOW GREAT the rest of the food was like.

I really wanted to take my bf to a German place (since we were celebrating his bday) This spot couldnt have been more perfect.

Beers range from .4 littler to 5 liters! We ordered DAS BOOT and had a great time drinking it. although we encountered, DA BUBBLE !! (lol)

I can not wait to go back to SF with our group of friends and have a good old merry drunk time here.

We will be back and this time we shall tackle the 5 liter!!!
author: Evie O.

description:
Alright, so I've been dying to try this place for SUCH a long time.

Unfortunately, despite the fact that I called in ahead of time to make a reservation for my party of 6, they weren't able to give me the reservation since they had a party book the back room. So instead, I waited 2 and a half hours for a table to open up.

Obviously it didn't start out that great. I was hoping the food would be the redeeming factor, but perhaps I didn't order the best thing (I got the trout), but it was just alright. My friends also found their food alright, but not jaw dropping.

Didn't mention that this was my birthday dinner, but it was. I was excited for dessert and the poor waiter, I think he was embarrassed because when he came back to the table to clarify who's birthday it was, he asked me. The dessert was great though. What's also amazing is that they comped both the Black Forest Cake and the Apple Streusel we ordered. Never have I gone to a restaurant where they've come out with two full sized, delicious desserts and took it off the check for a simple birthday dinner.

Oh right, the beer. Definitely try a bit of everything. The boot. The boot... is all everyone has said it was.
author: Tammy C.

description:
My friend, Ivanne T., and I came here for dinner before heading to the ballet. It's a very lively, jovial environment so I imagine it would be fun with a group. But even just the two of us, it was pretty enjoyable. It's set up in true German beerhall tradition so lots of large tables and different groups all seated at the same table. 

Service was hit and miss - the food came out quite quickly (much to my surprise) and was pretty delicious, but getting the check and ordering additional beers required lots of waving down of our waitress.

But on to the good stuff, the food and the beer :)
I had the Marinated and Braised Beef with Lingonberries
served with Red Cabbage & Spätzle (I'm not even going to attempt the German). It was pretty tasty. Salty and tangy and a little sweet. And the Spätzle breaks it up nicely. Sidenote: even better as leftovers!
Ivanne T. had one of the specials which was a breaded pork cutlet, sauerkraut, and a potato dumpling. Her's was good but I liked mine better. I'm a sauce person and my braised beef had a large portion of a very tasty brown sauce.
We also had the Potato Pancakes which were of course quite scrumptious. Fried potato goodness with applesauce, how can you go wrong?

Now for the beer. The variety of German beers is great, and from what Ivanne T. told me, also pretty authentic. I'm not normally a dark beer drinker, in fact, I usually stick to what I know, which is Blue Moon and different Hefeweizen. But upon entering the restaurant (late, as is usually my style), Ivanne, who had been waiting at the bar area, offered me a sip of her dark beer - Köstritzer Schwarzbier.
Thoughts in my head: *sip* "There's no way that could be a dark beer, that was delicious! It had hints of caramel and molasses, and wait was that a chocolate hint too? I need another sip." *sip* "Forget the food, I know what beer I'm ordering!"
Real life: I'll have one of these! *Points to pint in hand* (again, I don't bother with the German, it's not like anyone will understand me anyway)

Maybe it's the German side coming out in me (oh yes, I have a streak of German in me, it's true), but I didn't even have a need for water at dinner. Haha, maybe I shouldn't be admitting this, but my Schwarzbier was a wonderful accompaniment to the tasty and very salty German treats that comprised my dinner.

Beer enthusiasts, I highly recommend this place for you! 

Note: Street parking is horrible on any night, so give yourself extra time. If you're heading to the Opera House after dinner for a show, and don't mind paying, I suggest parking in the $10 lot across the street from the Performing Arts Garage (on the corner of Gough and Grove).
author: Claire L.

description: Good not great German food.  I had the wiener schnitzel and spaetzle (I was happy they allowed me to substitute the spaetzle).  The portions were gigantic!  Service was very quick and polite.  We had lovely table mates.
author: Marsi N.

description:
Was a little hesitant showing up here on a Saturday night about 30 minutes before their posted closing hours ( due to the ungodly parking situation) To our surprise we were quickly seated in a full house and were not given the usual "You got 10 minutes to order, buddy" mentality we'd seen one to many times at late night spots. The server was extremely attentive and friendly and gave what seemed to be very personal suggestions on food selections rather than the mundane we'll everyone likes this dish, blah blah.

 Went for the Pork Knuckle and Schnitzel. The Schnitzel was  perfectly breaded, juicy, and tender. The potatoes had a surprise! element of bacon mixed in to it and the cabbage was a nice touch of greens within the pork apocalypse . I envied the mammoth that was the pork knuckle, but i sadly had trouble convincing myself to try it after the waitress had to describe it as the  "the cute little piggy's hoof." By then i connected the hoof to the animal, and the animal to a pig, and the pig to a cute smiling little face. Maybe next time cause it looked like yum all over the place.

Last but not least, the beer! Great selection, even i was bombarded with an array of unfamiliar juices. I'll have to put on my German pants on next time though to conquer one of the 2ltr Boots.

Oh, don't forget to look up at the ceiling while you're there too!
author: kelly e.

description:
Closest to Oma's cooking!!!

I have been here several times and never written a review about it--sorry Suppekuche but you don't need any more business!!!  We came here on a Saturday night after the truly awful Oktoberfest at Pier 48.  Suppenkuche was just absolutely packed to the gills.  We came with 9 people and were seated within 30 minutes.  The service and ambiance was superb as always.  The star of the show is the food!  German cuisine is not the most celebrated or sophisticated, but those of us who grew-up with it appreciate it and crave it.  Truly good German restaurants are hard to find.  Schroeder's in the FiDi tries and is a good place for a beer, but the food lacks and it has become just ridiculously expensive since the big renovation.  Suppenkuche nails it.  The Sauerbraten is just unbelievable as are the Spaetzle, Rotkhl, etc.  Superb!!!  Thank you Suppenkuche for again exceeding our expectations!
author: Mike B.

description:
how do you say "nom nom nom" in german? finally, after so many years of wanting to try suppenkuche we stopped in last night. so busy! on a monday! 

it seems going on the early side for dinner any night would be best. that food is good, darn good. the spaetzle that comes with the delicious jagerschnitzel? dreamy little pillows of goodness. their version of a salade composee, with beets, carrots and cabbage (we had a small one, w/out the potato salad, which i am sure is yummy)? TO DIE FOR!!!

the communal dining set up works well since most have indulged in the ultimate social lubricant, beer. unless you have some with very sour faces sitting near you, as we did. hey there! lighten up while you still can! you're in a beer hall. 

Worth a detour absolutively.

P.S. I forgot to talk about the FABULOUS dark brown bread and herb butter they put on the table. CRIMENY that is good.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Potato pancakes were delicious and the spaetzle was awesome! Really good selection of beers. Good service. Small dining room.
author: Chera T.

description:
i will make this simple:

As for the Das Boot filled with their thickest and darkest beer.  Now drink without spilling a drop.

Good luck!
author: Jai D.

description: The bratswurst was really good. Not too salty and is very juicy. Must try!The trout is absolute amazing. Went very well with vegetables garnish. The suckling pig had an interesting taste. And the service was v good! Also the good came very fast so I am very satisfied with the service. would definitely head back again!
author: Qianqi L.

description:
Damn, their schnitzel is good. Thin with a perfect breaded crust. The lemon wedges and the potatoes that accompany it make it one fine meal.

Love their beer selection, especially during Oktoberfest. Service is sub-par but what do you expect from a German beer hall? With that said, it is great for groups but is also VERY loud. Good times will be had.

My favorite thing about this place is brunch. It turns into a completely different space on Sunday mornings (no brunch available on Saturdays). Quiet, hardly ever any wait, and the schnitzel is sub $10! A steal, I'd say. They offer may other breakfasts in the single digit dollar range as well, which makes it tops on my list. 

Beer with breakfast? Winner.
author: Jasmyn M.

description:
I always enjoy my visits to Suppenkuche.  

The food is rich and flavorful, the servings are abundant, and always cooked just right (hard to do, I think, with German meat dishes).  The selection of fine German beers is a delight.

The vibe is fun and friendly, and the dining room has a clean, arty, bright feeling.
author: Adam C.

description:
My bf loves this place, I am not a huge fan. Mostly because its SUPER LOUD (ok, I get it's german stylo) and the majority of the food is fried. Think weiner-schnitzel-everything. The best thing on the menu is the trio of pickled salads and the big boots of beer. 

You will be sitting at big tables with other groups of people if you come as a 2 top, so be prepared to get comfortable. But this group seating has it's pluses, you can get your food-jealousy on pretty easily and ask them what they ordered.  Be prepared to yell, and drink!
author: Amaranta C.

description: After trying Walzwerk, Suppenküche was the next to try. For appetizer we got the pretzel, and i ordered the Jägerschnitzel which i've tried at Walzwerk. This one is just as good, it felt like a nice warm home cooked meal, and it really hits the spot. The pretzel was really good too, nice and soft, the garlic dip was amazing, i would come back just for the pretzel, but everything i had was so good. For dessert we had a very delicious apple strudel, loved the flavor and how light it was. I left with a full satisfied tummy.
author: Darnell L.

description:
no wait for sunday brunch (mind you though it was either shared table or bar seat...but we didn't care)

we ordered the potato pancake..delicious, and definitely a first time having it with a side of apple sauce...was tempted to ask for ketchup but decided not to look like an idiot

weiner schnitzel...not so sure about this one, more like chicken katsu, but it was tasty

meatloaf with the poached eggs, simple and delicious

really like the roasted potato, crispy crunchy just like potato chips
author: Long C.

description:
A brunch at Suppenkuche is the perfect way to get a San Francisco German eating experience.  And you aren't quite gonna be breaking the bank either to get a complete meal.  Matter of fact, the 4.5 hour time slot on Sundays is the only time you can enjoy a brunch at this fine establishment.

My group had a sauteed porkloin in mushroom sauce served with spatzle, a veal/pork sausage in a butter sauce w/ pretzel, and a cut up sausage entree covered in tomato curry sauce.  While all the entrees were superb, I would definitely go back for the pork sausage in the tomato curry sauce (which doesn't taste like curry at all).  The sauteed porkloin was breaded and the spatzle was a first time experience for me.  And the butter sauce was more like a buttery soup bowl with a couple tender veal/pork sausages thrown in.  

I also thoroughly enjoyed the "made in germany" sweet mustard that was probably for the pretzel but I also used it for the warm fresh bread they served with the meal.  I didn't really enjoy the hair that was in my entree but regardless, can't wait to Suppenkuche again sometime soon!
author: Albie F.
