description: this place is AWESOME!  the food, the service...everything.  when you walk in you are greeted by a very sweet hostess, ashley, who has a warm smile and is very helpful.  the bartender (i didn't get his name) was very kind as well!  the food is so lovely.... we had the smoked salmon appetizer and it was great, the roasted half chicken was cooked to perfection, the sauerbraten was so good i thought of it all night, lol!  and i have to say, the potato pancakes are SO good you will want more and more.  our server was so wonderful and the whole experience leaves you wanting to come back the next day.  :)  highly suggest!
author: Samantha B.

description:
The food is excellent but I don't like the wait. You can manage to get a seat without waiting too much if you're with one other person, but if there are more of you, go when you're not too hungry yet and be prepared to wait around 45 min- 1 hour during prime dinner hours. 

My favorite dish there is the portobella mushroom stuffed with spinach & feta cheese. It comes in an amazing tomato sauce and I use their dark bread to soak it up. I also love the giant pretzel with cheese sauce they serve as a special during october fest month - too bad it isn't around the rest of the year.
author: K C.

description:
I have since learned that Suppenkuche has a disabled entrance which they will set up if you ask. How I could do so if I was alone, since there's no doorbell at the main inaccessible entry, I don't know. We went by there again thinking we'd try it, and the wheelchair entrance was blocked because the back room (with the entrance) was very full, with a large table in the way. I would've had to ask at least eight people to move. 

I like good German food and beer, but not that much. Nowhere near ADA compliant, and I'd never be able to get to the bathrooms, even if they are accessible. And without bathroom access, I'm not drinking beer. Forget it. I give two stars because I'm feeling kind, and because everybody inside seemed to be having a good time. But I'm not invited.
author: Anne K.

description:
Yum! My favorite German food in the city can be found right here! If you're in the mood for beer and meat, come here. There's no way you can possibly have an unpleasant time-- especially if you're into drinking lots and lots of beer out of a huge glass boot. I believe you can order up to 5 liters of beer in one glass if that's what you fancy.

Warning: there's always a wait time. But who cares? You're around lots of merry beer drinking conversationalists! On a very busy night, you might actually be seated at the same table with strangers. It's the German way. Make friends with them. More than likely they're great.

This place is also great for large parties, as long as you call and let them know. I came here with a group of 15 and we were seated in the back room because of the reservation we made.

I recommend for those parties of 2 to split a few things. My personal suggestion is to order the potato pancakes with apple sauce as an appetizer (comes with 3 large cakes and a bowl of sauce), and split the wiener-schnitzel for dinner (comes with 2 large schnitzels and a side of dressed lettuce and potatoes). I've also had the bratwurst and mashed potatoes with sauerkraut which comes with a little dish of mustard-- GOOD.

I've never had a bad meal here from the many times I've been. I've tried other German restaurants in the area, and this is the best. Take my word for it.
author: Ashley D.

description: Had Sunday brunch here and was very impressed by the bread, butter, and jam to start (we couldn't stop scarfing this down). The meal was also very good- I had the German Ravioli and my friend had the Wienerschnitzel. The food was very good but did not blow me away, and the atmosphere was very loud and crowded which made conversation difficult. The price of the meal was fantastic. Solid 4 stars!
author: Jenni M.

description:
as a vegetarian, here are my thoughts: 

The "Gemischter Salat" delicious salad option, with heaping mounds of juicy beets, cabbage, and carrots that is huge enough for 4 people to share. I am a fan of butter lettuce, it really is an underutilized vegetable. 

Onto the cheesy goodness... white, rich, and creamy..the cheese spätzle is my brother's fiance's favorite dish, the kind that calls to you in the night, leads you down the street, and straight into a delicious bowl of saucy spätzle! yes, seriously it is that alluring. comfort food! 

After two sips of the hot spiced wine and two Erdingers, I started to imagine sitting in a cacophony of Germaness and notice how crazy loud and excited everyone looks in here. It was packed on 6pm on a rainy Monday evening, the servers wore wreaths of christmas lights while serving giant boots of beer. My theory: communal benches, giant boots of beer, and an excited dining crowd really makes this place a fun place to celebrate!
author: Laura F.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place and finally went for a friend's birthday with a pretty large group. I really like German food, including sauerkraut, and I wondered how well it compared against places like Walzwerk and Schmidt's in the Mission.

My verdict was that the food is just as good. I ordered schnitzel, in all its fried goodness, and I was not disappointed and filled to the brim by meal's end.

Beer selection better, though. That famed beer in a boot is no joke. Given the fact that you can even get a beer in a boot, it should be no surprise that the atmosphere is much more lively and fun than any other schnitzelhaus I've tried around here.
author: Tara R.

description:
Suppenkuche's food is always going to be awesome, and the food is just as German as it comes without having to buy a plane ticket to Berlin or speaking with my relatives (okay, they're Swiss German, but whatever). 

I decided a sausage with massive amounts of sauerkraut were in order and I'd be set for life. The beer was a delicious accompaniment to the meal, and the bread was fantastic. Before my best friend moves out of Hayes Valley, I'm going to take him here. What a delicious, selfish excuse to take someone out.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Suppenkuche claims that it offers the atmosphere of a German pub - it winds up being the loudest restaurant I've ever been to.  Due to the noise and perhaps the famous beer served in a boot, raised voices are the norm.  I don't personally find that noise level relaxing though it may be authentic.  The quarters are very cramped and uncomfortable.  There are two rooms and we were seated in the one with dried flower bunches and wreathes.  I liked the wood floors and tables but everything else was uncomfortable.  The food is what you would expect - hearty.  Surprisingly, they also have a few vegetarian options.

For dinner they serve their standard menu and they have a page of daily specials.  During our visit the specials included an organic chicken schnitzel, salmon with a thick slab of truffle butter, roast suckling pig and braised lamb shanks.  The entrees come on large oval plates, average $16 and should satisfy even large appetites.  

I chose the German ravioli ($13) which consisted of three large, misshapen sized dumplings in a creamy mushroom sauce.  The dumpling skins were thick and chewy - obviously homemade.  The delicious mushroom sauce was infused with deep mushroom flavor.  Each dumpling had a light dusting of toasted breadcrumbs and parsley.  I wasn't too fond of the pork & vegetable filling because the filling was so dense and not at all juicy.  

The service was okay.  They never refilled our water glasses and I don't think they brought more bread either. 

Reservations are suggested but only accepted for parties of 6 or larger.  Be prepared to wait outside because there isn't any room to wait inside the restaurant.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I don't care how good your food is or how great of reviews you received on Yelp or how much money you're making or how many loyal customers you have, if you're going to ask my friends and me (while we are in the middle of drinking our beers purchased from your establishment) to GET UP FROM OUR TABLE BECAUSE YOU HAVE ANOTHER GROUP WAITING TO BE SEATED, you can go fuck yourself.

ZERO STARS, ASSHOLES!  Get some class.
author: Michelle W.

description:
This place is could get me in trouble.
Loud, warm, jolly with 5 liter & 3 liter beer options (!) along with 2, 1 & .5 for light weights. Tasty beer!
My friend got a slice of b-day cake, but I was too fat with beer, bread and potato pancakes to have more than a polite bite.
I wanted to snatch it tho, just sayin'.
Service was friendly, quick & charming under pressure.
author: Crystal N.

description:
Came here around 8:30 and the waitress said there were no open tables, so we stood by the counter. Shortly after, she cleared she moved some 4 people on a 6 table to the side so my friend and I could sit down. Boo ya!

We order the German Ravioli filled with Pork and Vegetables served with Mushroom Sauce. This was sooo delicious! I literally wanted to lick the mushroom sauce off the plate when I was done.

For my entree, I ordered the Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes. What a great hearty dish with a nice meaty sausage flavor. 

My friend got the braised beef. I thought it was good, but a bit on the tough side.

On the negative side, this place is NOISY, and the people at our table kept pounding the table with their beer glasses which made for constant shocks to the heart for me and really loud banging to the ear drums. A bit tight on space, but I guess it's kinda like being at a biergarten
author: Ed H.

description:
This place is truly awesome. I dont get german food very often since this is the only german resturaunt within 50miles of me. I went here with my girlfriend and there was about an hour wait for a table and to my surprise it was the cafeteria style dining I guess its called where you share tables with complete (and drunk) strangers which is fine since it was a small place. And the place was very loud but but totally ok. 
the girlfriend had Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße mit Spätzle und grünem Salat and I had Kassler vom Grill mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei and oh boy was it good! 

The beer here is truly epic as well, I dont think I've ever had a better tasting beer. I just asked what the server would suggest and I think he said Franziskaner, but it was loud and could barely hear him but it was yummmie!

I think the funny part of my trip here was seeing a tiny asian guy, probably only 120pounds at most order DAS BOOT! that beer was about as big as he was!
author: Casey H.

description: If you are looking for a quiet place, this is not for you.The restaurant was close to our motel, which was near civic center, but because we didn't know the building, we walked past. I didn't expect 525 to be on a corner. It was full of people when we arrived. Communal tables, nice selection of beer and food. The sauerkraut was amazing. I wanted a little bit of everything, red cabbage,kraut, spaetzle, mashed potatoes, all reminiscent of my grandmother's cooking .I thought the sausage was flavorful. Patrons were there for a good time. There was a very welcoming vibe. Black forest cake was very good too.  Everything was reasonably priced and service was excellent for us.There were several large groups so timing was critical. Other people at our table waited longer for their food. I think I will be craving the kraut.
author: Gayle C.

description:
Good beer selection and the beer glass style definitely reminded me of Germany.

As a vegetarian, I wasn't ideally suited for this restaurant. But they do have a few veggie-friendly options. I wasn't that into the mac & cheese plus onions, but I think I would've enjoyed something else off the menu.
author: Kimberley D.

description: Big fan. Beer is well priced, portions are HUGE, bratwurst delicious. One star off because it is so so loud when it's packed, it really bangs off the walls. If you love beer and German food, you gotta go.
author: Mary-Kathryn N.

description:
Suppenkuche is a blast! Made a reservation a few weeks in advance for me and 7 of my favorite beer drinkers.

The boots are so much larger than I imagined, but completely worth it. The prices vary depending on the beer you choose. I went with one of their ales, marking mine up to $40. But it was amazing. The experience, the beer itself, the photo ops, and the memories.

It turns out the boots are in fact limited in quantity. Apparently my table got the last of them.

The food was solid, although German cuisine has never really been my thing. And to be honest, the beer alone could have been my dinner. The service was very friendly and helpful, and didn't seem to mind that part of my party was late. The crowd is very lively and vibrant. The fact that people complain about the noise level surprises me. For a place that is famous for DAS BOOT, did you honestly expect people to use their library voices?

I definitely recommend Suppenkuche for groups and birthdays, or if you want to impress some out-of-towners who like to let their hair down. It is a very memorable experience.

I can't wait to go to their Oktoberfest celebration for another boot and an oversized pretzel.
author: Katie S.

description:
LOOOONG wait.

Really nice beers on tap.  Good food.  WHY DON"T THEY TAKE RESERVATIONS!!!!!!
author: Michael E.

description:
Came here with a large group - not sure if a reservation was made (is it even possible?)  but even though we got there super early, they said that they won't be able to put aside a table for a group of 11 until the whole group arrived.   If the whole group had arrived, and if there were no tables available, then we would have had to wait.  I think the whole table organization thing could have been done better, but we did end up getting a table at the time we wanted so I won't complain.

Food...

I'm not a big beer drinker - I had the beer mixer and that was okay.  Nothing to rave on about.  I just knew I needed something fizzy to cut through the grease.

Potato pancakes with apple sauce - good. (I think I gained 10lb even though we shared). I think you get 3 per dish (or maybe 4? can't remember) - so definitely share.  Also if you get chicken as your main, I think potato cakes come with the chicken.

I had the smoked pork chop with potato mash and sauerkraut.  Pork chop tasted like ham (it was smoked) and while I didn't hate it, I didn't love it either.

Blackforest cake - I was told that this was a must.  So we shared this.  If you like soft fluffy spongy cake, then you'll probably like this.  I enjoyed it, but again I didn't love it.  

All up, okay experience.  It's noisy, so don't come here if you are wanting to have a conversation.  Also definitely not a place for dieters! 

We had a german in our group and I think she said that the food was pretty authentic.  So if you want authentic german style food, this is the place.
author: Sujan H.

description:
I have manly taste. I blame my dad for the repeated viewings of Delta Force and Die Hard I was exposed to as an 8-year-old--or maybe it's the strange goiter/half-Adam's apple I have in the middle of my throat. Whatever the reason--if you just supply me with potatoes and beer, I'll be a happy camper.

So it shouldn't come as a surprise that I lurrrve (just trying to tap into my feminine side) Suppenkuche.  I love their conversation-stopping potato pancakes--so much that I'm even willing to eat them with applesauce, which I've long since considered to be a mushy mess of intolerable tartness--and their jagershnitzel with the amazing mushroom sauce! Everything I've tried here has been absolutely delicious, including the bratwurst, braised short ribs, mushroom soup, and black forest cake.

The only thing I'd ever complain about is that you either have to show up 30 min before they open or 30 min before they close to get a table easily if you don't have a party large enough to make reservations, but it's totally worth it. Take it from me, the she-man.
author: Jen L.

description:
Delicious bier! I wanted to try more, but had to save my appetite for food as well.

Potato Pancake: crispy goodness and goes great with a bit of apple sauce, but not too much.

Sausage: Not as good as what I had in Columbus Ohio's German village.

Venison: Great! Best I have had!
Beef: Pretty good and well marinated.

Trout: Finally a western restaurant knows how to cook a fish without being too blent nor loaded with spice (a bit exaggerated here).

Great customer service. Parking is a bit hard to find in this area though.
author: Lance C.

description:
One of my favorite place but the wait is just painful.  I love going there for dinner and sunday brunch.  Their brunch is surprisingly good.  

Must have: their large variety german beer.  get the boot if you can manage or share it with your friends.
author: D C.

description:
Step aside the French, the Italian and the English (not too much because you are far to the side anyway - can't do much with fish n chips and bland roasts with gravy!) let the Germans lead the way. This place is for hard beer drinkers and big eaters (such people don't ask "could you pack this to go?"). 
The beers on tap are unique and refreshing, not the ones you get in-every-single-SF-"pub". They are far apart from those losers: Heineken and the joke of a beer that they call Budweiser. These beers don't need fancy ads to be aired on prime-time, they sell themselves! The bar tenders, the waiters and the door receptionist set the ambience- they are fast, efficient and pleasant. After two pints you want to eat and eat you will because the food, it's delicious! The chef does a great job at preparing it to the right point. I had the chicken roast which had a stuffing and it was succulent, crispy and tasty. The sausages are delicious, needless to say because, well, they are authentic German. After having a ball of a meal, you'll sleep well, wake-up and would want to leave such a review. A solid 4.5 stars (because 5 stars are overrated!).
author: Ethan H.

description: Order the Jagerschnitzel! I strongly recommend it! It's worth the wait for the food, beer, and authentic Deutsche atmosphere!
author: Matt J.

description:
Suppenkuche is always crazy busy and crazy loud for dinner.  We finally squeezed in for dinner one night and had a good time, even though the restaurant is SO loud and at least half of the diners are drunk off their boots of beer.

We started with Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus (Potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce) and then enjoyed Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein
mit Bratkartoffeln und Grünem Salat (Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin
with Roasted Potatoes and Green Salad).

The food is amazing and the best German fare I have ever had outside of Berlin.

The place is great for parties but be prepared to hear everyone's conversations.  Maybe they could work on the acoustics.
author: Chad S.

description:
In search of a pre-Scavenger Hunt brunch for The Meatbuckets, I serendipitously came upon Suppenkuche on a Yelp search for brunch spots in Hayes Valley. I mean, come on, we're the freakin' Meatbuckets, and this is a German restaurant! We learned several lessons on this beautiful Sunday morning:

1) "Bavarian meatloaf" = large slab of SPAM, minus the fatty spots (aka "luncheon meat").
2) "Potato pancakes" = hash browns.
3) Beer and lemon soda tastes really good together.
4) Nutella should be served with bread at every restaurant.
5) If you do not order the baked Emperor's Pancake or the Weiner Schnitzel, rest assured that someone at the neighboring table will, and you will be sorry that you didn't.

At 11AM on Sunday, we surprisingly had no trouble securing a table for 6.  However, by the time we left it was abuzz. I'd definitely be up for coming back, if only to try that Emperor's Pancake and because it's DAMN cheap (most items $7.50) for a huge, meaty brunch!
author: Steph P.

description:
Got some noise-cancelling headphones and maybe walkie-talkies to communicate across the table?  This place is LOUD!  It could use some soft surfaces to soak up the sound.

The service is wonderful and the food is great.  But when you pour 2.5 liter beers for your customers, the crowd is going to get a bit sloppy and loud.  Half the people in there seem to be there not to eat, but to drink.

I started with the potato soup (delicious!) had the pork roast with sauerkraut and a bread dumpling... tasty! I finished with the black forest cake and it was also very good.

I'm thinking Take Out is a great way to enjoy this place.
author: John D.

description:
I'm honestly just preaching to the choir here, so I'll keep it short. Yes, lots of beer. Yes, great food that strangely goes well with great beer ;)

Not a lot of people mentioned this, so I recommend the pickled herring appetizer. It's very good and there's lots of stuff going on so it's perfect for 3 or 4 people to split.

One more thing of note is that when I came here once, I ordered the daily special and they ran out of it. The girl came back and apologized profusely and I got something else. Not only did she comp that dish, but she also comped the next round of drinks (there were 4 of us.) Amazing!

-0.5 star for yuppies clogging the place up every day of the week!
-0.5 for not being able to book a table without 6 people in your party.
author: Josh K.

description: Fantastic home style German food. Nothing fancy, but well done. They have an excellent selection of German draft beers as well. Recommend the veal or brats, but honestly it's hard to go wrong!
author: Giuliana K.

description:
Ate here last night with family members and our group was poorly treated.  

Not by everyone in the restaurant mind you.  Everyone in the restaurant was just fine except the most important person involved in our meal -- our server.

The GINGER HAIRED GUY who is a SERVER there right now (Sept 30, 2010) is NOT a good server.

I have been a server off and on for over 15 years and he did thing after thing that are big no-nos and just make you unhappy that you came at all.

I have eaten here many times and have never had a difficulty being served a plate that they create made up of little bits of the veggie sides because I am a vegan and they have no vegan option on the menu.  They make up a reasonable price for this veggie plate each time I've come -- usually around 10 bucks.  

Not so last night.  The ginger haired server was not accommodating or interested in this - a bit of a bummer, especially as another in our party of 4 is a vegan as well...... and came from out of town and was told all about this restaurant and how great it is.  So that's one thing.

He also seemed exasperated from the get go --- as he was taking our drink order and facing us for the first time!  When you're just so exasperated with everything around you in your world and you push that exasperation onto people you've never even encountered before --  that doesn't sit well with patrons.  It made me feel uneasy.  Had he been on a first date and done this sort of thing the person he was with would have gotten up and never looked back.

When he served our plates he sort of tossed them down heavily and clumsily and sort of side-armed and not in any order or to the plate's eater.  That makes me feel unimportant and almost like he was the evil headmaster at the orphanage and we were the loathed children getting our gruel.  I shouldn't be feeling this feeling when I go out to eat - part of what I'm paying for is the service.  If I didn't want service, I could just make good German food at home.

He never checked on our table after he dropped our food off.  Not once.  

We actually needed a couple things during the meal -- for instance, drinks.  He just never came back and seemed not to notice any gestures from our table.

Hastily came with check though.

Actually scoffed and eye-rolled toward me in some sort of commiserative look when the father-figure of our group placed down a credit card that I guess was not accepted at Suppenkuche. 

Again side-arm reached for the checkbook once an accepted card was placed AND with a hand that already held another table's just retrieved checkbook in it - stacking them up poker chips style - doesn't make you feel like a special patron, just like a representation of money for him.  Not a cool vibe, disrespectful.

Also, sighed when we needed a to-go box.

We were a quiet unobtrusive low maintenance table but he made us feel like he was serving a group of 4 Fran Dreschers when he did interact with us. 

I get that Suppenkuche is busy and servers might be stressed but I've worked in busier restaurants with crazy stuff going on behind the scenes and I've never treated patrons like this.  This just seemed a case of server having no restaurant etiquette OR maybe he's just naturally a brute in general.  Why would a restaurant hire such a person when there are so many people out of work in this city who have excellent restaurant skills?  Me included in this group.

Bummed.
author: Dizzy L.

description:
Um.. i'm a girl who can eat A LOT. I also LIKE to eat A LOT. Don't judge me by my size! hahahaha

So I can't have beer, but that's okay... I have plenty of others to enjoy it for me. Anyway, my friend took me here and i've been wanting to try it ever since I saw it on an episode of "Check Please! Bay Area." 

It's a small restaurant, cafeteria style seating, and it's LOUD inside.  I loved the ceiling!!! Little paper butterflies and birds are hanging from the ceiling, and when the doors/curtains are opened and a slight breeze comes through, the wings flutter ever so slightly. 

Ok but on to the food!!!! I don't know any German. I don't NADA ZERO ZIP ZILCH about German food and German beer. All that mattered to me was that the food was GOOD.

I had the potato soup with sausage then porkchops in mushroom sauce with a green salad. The soup was DELISH. Smooth creamy smoky meaty goodness in my mouth, mmm MMM mMMMM hahhahaha.
The porkchops were thin and done up nicely, but the mushroom sauce..  ohhh yeessss reminded me of stroganoff but yes.. again, creamy goodness. 

The only thing i didn't like were those weird noodle things.

but i'd definitely come here again, especially since i work so close by! 

YESSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Susy C.

description:
I will start out by saying the food was okay. But the service was APPALLINGLY bad. Although it was busy, it wasn't slammed. There was no excuse for the bad service, which was disappointing, as I had looked forward to trying this place for years.

It took 20 minutes to take our order, and we had to flag them down and practically beg our waitress to take it. It took about 45 minutes to get water.  Our bread arrived without bread plates, but we did manage to use napkins as plates. My iced tea didn't arrive with a spoon. 

Our food was cold when it finally arrived. It had good flavors, but it was cold. The thing is, while we were waiting, I could hear the kitchen bell dinging repeatedly (for pick up) and NONE of the waitresses even looked in the direction or made a move to pick up the food.  I'm guessing we were not the only patrons who received cold food.

The only remotely prompt service we received was when we asked for the check and even then, the check was incorrect and charged us for an extra entree (20 minutes after we had ordered, our waitress came by to let us know that they were out of one of our entrees).  At least the woman who I asked to fix our bill did that promptly. 

Pity. The best thing about this place was the beer.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Fantastic German food! This is as good as the real deal in Deutschland if not better! I've been to Germany more times than I can count and I became accustomed to their many traditional dishes. Suppenküche's dishes are some of the best examples of my favorites...

Ok, before we get to the food, can I just get one thing off my chest here?

One MAJOR pet peeve of this place is the willingness to perpetuate an often overlooked American faux pa...the tragedy that is DAS BOOT. Hey, people, remember that German Film called Das Boot? Guess where it took place? In a BOAT!!! (Ok a Submarine, but you catch my drift.) Not a BOOT! Boot in German? = Der Stiefel. I know it's much more scary and foreign sounding than das Boot, but it's accurate...So even if you can't pronounce it right, it's much less ignorant & embarrassing sounding than drunk Americans getting schnamered while chanting "THE BOAT! THE BOAT!"  meanwhile drinking out of a glass boot. And we wonder why people see us the way they do in other countries?  

What's more...couldn't the waitstaff at least be taught a word or two of German? Seeing as it IS a fully German place? I mean, for the respect of the country and it's culture and language? 

Sorry, that's my rant...

The FOOD:
Hopefully I didn't completely lose you all there. It would do a strict injustice to the glory that is the 100% Authentic German cuisine at the Suppenküche. I ordered the Holiday Duck. The duck was so succulent, so juicy that I was beside myself in bliss. It is SO rare for a duck to be cooked this perfectly, with no gamey flavor either, that I made sure to savor every last delicious bite! On the side was Kartoffel Knödel which is basically a large potato dumpling. I find that sauces is really where German cuisine stands out and this dish was no exception. The Knödel was so wonderful and fluffy. It has a gelatinous texture, I know, not appealing sounding, but trust me on this! It's like nothing you've had before and is one thing that I truly miss after not being in Germany for a while. 

The DRINK:
Of course, they have a nice selection of German beers to chose from to put in your..."boat" ;-) ...my favorite is Augustiner Helles, but it all depends on my mood...sometimes I prefer Weissbier...In which case, I chose Paulaner most times. You basically can't go wrong. Beer is what Germans do best. 

So I knicked the one star for not only the Das Boot silliness, but the fact that they didn't have Apfelstrudel left by the time I ordered it. I know, pretty petty to hold that against them, but I really had my heart set on it. And If you're such a popular restaurant that has people waiting for 2 hours to get seated, couldn't you at least make sure you have enough food to feed their hungry bellies?! 

All in all, wonderful dishes. Great Atmosphere. Just STOP IT with the Das Boot garbage already!!! It's embarrassing.
author: Kristin G.

description: Not sure if some of the lower reviews simply don't like German food, but the food here is outstanding!
author: Mike I.

description:
Poochie hat Bayernisches Hendl am liebsten!  Meiner Freund Johannes wird nicht mehr trinken, aber dan wir Suppenkuche gefunden hatten.  Ich erinnere mich im Deutschland, wann ich sechs mass bier in einer Tag getrunken habe.  Meiner Freund glaubt das nicht, aber sie ist ein Madchen das trinkt kanst.  Suppenkuche hat Hofbrau Oktoberfest Bier mit 6.3% alcoholischeness.  Poochie mag Bier.  Poochie hat Bier gern!  Alle sollen Bier trinken!  Das Essen geschmecht und die leute sind sehr Freundlich.  Ich muss jetzt trinken gehen.  Prost!

Approximate translation:  Bavarian roast chicken is Poochie's favorite.  My friend John wouldn't drink anymore, but then we found Suppenkuche.  I remember one time in Germany when I drank 6 (liters of) beers in 1 day.  My friend doesn't believe me, but that's because he is a girl that can't drink.  Suppenkuche has HofBrau Oktoberfest beer, which is 6.3% alcohol.  Poochie likes beer.  Poochie likes beer alot.  Everyone should drink beer.  The food tasted great and the people are so friendly.  I must go drinking now.  Cheers!
author: Poochie M.

description:
3.5 stars, but the potato pancakes alone bump it up to 4.

Being the Type-A/borderline obsessive-compulsive personality that I am, I brought my family and bf here to brunch at 9:45a.m. Suppenkuche opens at 10am. My anxieties were vindicated when I arrived and 4 people were in line in front of me. Turns out, there was no need to worry. We were the only tables in there for about 30 minutes. 

Here's what my table ordered:

-Potato pancakes: CRACK. Like the best hash browns you've ever had. They were soft and fluffy on the inside and crunchy and golden on the outside. Served with applesauce. I don't even like apples and I doused mine in this sauce. There were 3 potato pancakes for a party of 4. The last one was eyed politely by each of us and we ended up splitting it 4 ways.

-Roasted Pork Sausages scrambled with Eggs, Potatoes & Bacon served with a Cucumber Salad: Underwhelming. M least favorite dish. The scramble was just ok and the cucumber salad was underseasoned and soggy. 

-Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes: such a spot-on combination. The salty, savory, juicy meat + slightly sweet sauerkraut + velvety and creamy mashed potatoes. A definite re-order.

-20cm sausages: I can't remember what these were served with but the actual sausages appeared like really slim hot dog franks, but tastier.

-Pork sausages in a tomato-curry sauce served with french fries: the surprise hit of the meal. I was suspect about the tomato-curry combination but the pairing of the slightly sweet tomato and subtle curry sauce was fantastic. The saltiness/crispiness of the french fries were a perfect compliment to the juicy meat in the sauce.

I'm a meat and potatoes kind of girl. And I like sausage. (that's what she said). And Suppenkuche has plenty of meat, potatoes, and sausage. If you want a hearty meal (albeit no healthy), brunch at Suppenkuche is the place to be.
author: Monelle A.

description:
DAS BOOT! DAS BOOT! DAS BOOT! DAS BOOT! DAS BOOT!

This is the first place I've heard in SF that has it!!! I've tried it in Europe and I was dying to do it again because you know you all want to try that last twist move from beerfest.  

SO HERE I AM, WITH DAS BOOT IN FRONT OF ME. I am a prideful bastard that would rather throw up for hours the next day than to not finish that das boot, so i did! and i did the pivot at the end!

As for food, I've tried the Marinated and Braised Beef with Lingonberries served with Red Cabbage & Spätzle, Grilled Cured Pork Chop with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes and Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce.  Allllllll REALLY surprisingly good. 

We had a huge group, which by the way, this place is not that great for because it's really crammed inside.  However, they did do a wonderful job accommodating all of us. 

Also, you can bring your own wine but the corking fee was basically the same.
author: Anna C.

description:
For appetizers our waitress recommended the potato pancakes. She mentioned that this restaurant is known for their potato pancakes so we gave it a go and it was not bad. It looks like a giant hash brown with a more interesting texture.

For brunch we got the steak with egg skirt. I was surprised to see how large the steak slice was, it was definitely worth the money! A friend of ours got bread dumplings with her brunch. I had a piece of it and it tasted good. I'd definitely order that next time!
author: Helen C.

description:
Went back a second time and ordered something different to eat. This time, I got the 'roast' pork with a 'beer' gravy and Knödel.

1. The pork had been twice cooked, deep fried.
2. It was over seasoned, way too much salt.
3. The Knödel was from a packet. I've bought this kind before and I recognized the shape, texture and taste immediately.

Disappointing.
author: Chris C.

description: Super awesome and really authentic little german restaurant. Craig provided us with excellent beer recommendations and really good company, he and the rest of the staff made us feel right at home! All around a fantastic and delicious experience.
author: Anna M.

description:
food 4/5
service 5/5 service was just outstanding, at the tables and the bar
atmosphere 3/5 

Ditto everyone else. The decor and layout wasnt that great, but the food and service really make up for it. You'll be squished with people both at the bar and communal tables. The staff and bartenders are really helpful when you're ordering and don't know what the heck you are reading. I never had german food so even the english descriptions were like "ok...." But I don't think you can really go wrong at this place. Be warned though, the food here is really hearty and heavy so come with an empty stomach. Alot of meat and starch. I managed to polish off a whole dish to myself even though I'm a small girl. I felt really full afterwards. Without drinks the tab is about  $22-25 per person. Most dishes ranged $15-25. Beers are around $8 per glass from the tap. I would come here again but not that often. Meals are a little pricier than what I usually have, but it is worth it.
author: Cecile S.

description:
Excellent spot for tourists and locals who want to provide a fun time to their out-of-town guests. Also great for just going as a local now and then, as their food is fresh, their beers flavorful and well-selected.

Great chicken sausage, pork sausage, saurkraut, and suppe. A bit too pricey for the types of foods, but I'm sure that has to do with the freshness, the high rent in the area, and the import of the beers. 

Would come here again with friends who haven't been, but probably not a whole lot as a regular.
author: Stephen H.

description: Love this place!  Atmosphere is awesome.  You feel like you just stepped into a German pub/restaurant.  Though a little crowded at times, that is kind of what I like about it.  The bartenders are super friendly and great.  The food is so awesome - very delicious and comforting. Will definitely go back.
author: Jill C.

description:
Review for BRUNCH
was recommended curry sausages and fries. failed to be impressed.
awesome that there is good beer and the service was great, but not that impressed with the recommendation, maybe...i just don't like german food?? but i do..i love spatzle and schnizel,...
author: Skye W.

description:
Mmmmm...yummy German food. It's like you walk into some old school German food hall. Everything is wood. There's a gang of German beers to choose from. It's very busy and warm inside. I've only been here a few times and I always get the wiener schnitzel and it's delicious. 

Good for big groups but can be a long long wait. Service is efficient even though how busy it is. And beer. Lots of beer to choose from.
author: David C.

description:
Low and behold, my favorite German restaurant in the City!  After living in Germany for two years, I thought I'd never run into a place with authentic German food, close to what I had been eating for two years during my time in Deutschland. 

I have been to Suppenkuche three times and have never had a bad experience.  Eine Boot Bitte!  So far, I have tried the the Schnitzel, the Pork Chop, and the Spaetzle. The beer is awesome and I can't get enough of it.  German beer is definitely stronger than your norm.  The last time I rolled up in here I ordered a stein, then had a half liter of the Hefe Dunkel.  I was doneski!

My best advice to anyone who is planning to go here for the first time, get there 10 to 15 minutes before the place opens and make sure that your entire party is there, or they will not seat you.  

Enjoy!
author: Shad B.

description: Our sons and I thought the food was great (1/2 chicken, meatballs, meatloaf), my husband thought it was good but not exceptional (pork chop...honestly did taste like a slab of ham to me also).  The service is good. NOTE:  If you have a party of 6 or more make a reservation, otherwise you will more than likely be sharing a table with another party.  We arrived at 5:30 and it was already busy and we were sharing a table before we left at 6:30.
author: Caroline K.

description:
Delicious food and beer!  

Searched around for a German place to take my boyfriend to who loves German food, and my mother who is German suggested this place.  After hearing praise from friends and reading the great yelp reviews I had high expectations, and I wasn't disappointed.  From what I remember eating in Germany the few times I've been there, this food seemed very traditional and authentic.  It's family style seating, so prepare to sit with some strangers and make new friends. 

Downside is that it can be very crowded, and you are really pushed to finish your food and leave to open up the table.  Also, they serve giant portions, and if you have a small appetite like me it may be wasted on you.
author: S. F.

description: On a Friday night, there is quite a long wait for a table. However, you can order drinks and food at the bar and ends up being a fun social scene.
author: Ashley B.

description:
I love Hayes Valley and this place is just another reason why. Suppenkuche serves authentic German food in a comfortable atmosphere (think picnic tables). 

I highly recommend the soup of the day which happened to be  this broccoli puree today. YUM! Next time I'm going to try the organic chicken schnitzel.

Suppenkuche, ich liebe dich!
author: Helen Y.

description:
Got there at 4:50, 10 minutes before opening,  and the line was already ridiculous. We were able to snag second to last table, but it was right by the door. People kept coming in to put their name on the list and no one made sure the door got closed.  Made for a very uncomfortable, crowded and cold experience.

The waitress was very efficient and the food came out fairly quickly given that everyone came in at the same time. 

Everyone started with dark, heavy bread and butter with a beautiful crust - absolutely delish. We ordered potato pancakes for the table which were perfectly crispy and very one enjoyed. 

For main courses - schnitzel was ok. Having traveled Germany extensively, it really didn't come close to the real thing.  Very thin, dry and bland. My son was a trooper and covered it up with hot sauce to make it more palatable. 

Pork chop was very soft and moist. However, beware, it's cured pork so is more like a thick piece of breakfast ham.  It was served with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut - both really good. 

Husband ordered goose and was not really impressed. 

I had lamb chops with mashed potatoes and brussels. Lamb was a bit too chewy, probably a bit overcooked.  

Overall an interesting place, but the food was hit or miss.
author: Irina N.

description:
I'm reviewing this quite late, as I haven't been there in a while. 

They have THE BEST beers EVER. The food is very very delicious and pairs well with the beer. It is a great experience because the beer and the food seems authentic (I'm not German so maybe I'm wrong) and very high quality. 

My only issue is how damn EXPENSIVE this place is.  You won't get out of there spending less than 22 bucks on a beer and a plate, after tax and maybe tip. Maybe.
And it's not really the sort of place you'd bring a date, more the place you go to hang out with a big group of friends and be merry. 

The spaetzle is especially good but their sausages, mashes potatoes and sauerkraut  are very well done as well.

More good news: the food is so filling you'll have leftovers! Now, if only you could take the beer home too...
author: Susan N.

description:
Been here twice, overrated.
Schnitzels are ok; there are better choices for austrian/german food.
You know Schnitzels are traditional Austrian food, not german.  Ghoulash is more German.

Decor: low rent, blah.
Customer service: meh
author: Bert K.

description: Dropped by here after work to see one of my colleagues off.  I think we all got different selections of beer, from the traditional to the eccentric.  I tend to lean towards weird food so I was intrigued with the Banana Hefeweizen.  Luckily it was surprisingly good and an instance where both my curiosity and my tastebuds won.  The other beers were also good as well, though since it was the middle of the week, none of us got a boot.  The food was enjoyable too (my other experiences with German food have been lackluster so that's fairly high praise) - we mostly stuck to cold cuts, sausages, and spaetzel.  Definitely a fun place in Hayes Valley for some beers.
author: Alan W.

description:
I went on a Sunday for brunch and I ordered the potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce.  I also tried my friend's chicken schnitzel which was also pretty bomb-tastic.  They've got some great beers on tap and can serve them in boots too! 

The place is a little small so come early or else you may have to wait a bit.  Overall, this place reminds me of my visit to Germany and Austria and I was satisfied with everything.
author: Cristina D.

description: Suppenküche is a cool lil German eatery w/excellent choice of German beers on tap and bottled.  But the food is pretty dang delicious! Love their Mac/cheese, fried potato pancakes, lambchops and veal schnitzel ! Only drawback is that the venue is small that the wait time is hours!!
author: Jason P.

description:
DELICIOUS!!!! I've never had such a hearty meal! My friends and I ordered these entrees:

- Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin
- Marinated and Braised Beef 
-Grilled Cured Pork Chop 
-Grilled Bratwurst

All were just cooked to perfection! Unfortunately for us, we didn't order up the famous potato pancakes. And now there's another reason to head back into Hayes Valley and enjoy future German meals.

Highly recommended? You betcha!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Came here for a get together and everyone enjoyed it....be ready to wait a while. It's a cozy, medium sized place so I wouldn't come here with more than 6 people.
The food was awesome with pretty decent portion sizes and it's a great place to try out different beers for a social get together. You can read all the other reviews for the food details. It was very enjoyable, I'll be back :)

Beware, it takes some patience to find parking.
author: Jayme N.

description:
Miserable experience here - beer tasted "funky" (most likely due to tainted draft lines) and the fish was inedibly fishy-tasting.  The server had attitude when I asked to return the fish, largely uneaten.

The lentil soup was good but it didn't compensate for the inhospitable experience.
author: Adam K.

description:
You know you've had a hearty dinner when you wake up 12 hours later and breakfast sounds like it might push you over the edge. Such is the case this morning after last night's excursion to Suppenkuche.

We arrived around 6pm with reservations, and by 7pm I was glad we did both. The place was packed to the brim, with every seat taken at the communal tables and the bar was 2 deep. Sundays at local restaurants in Dallas certainly don't look like this!

I started with the Kristall Hefeweisen which arrived in tall draft form in a cool shaped glass. I found it to be crisp and really light, making it easy to drink and not super filling.

We started with the potato cakes with apple sauce and fried cambert. I didn't try the cheese, but I did love the sauce that went on the potato cakes! My trout entree was quite delicious and came in a huge potion, with the fish head still on the plate. The mashed potatoes were extra creamy, and when I mixed a bite of spinach, trout and taters it was the perfect combo.

The waitstaff is phenomenal here. Very personable, welcoming and attentive. The only thing I wasn't a fan of is the communal seating. Although we made friends with the other party at our table, I recommend getting a table up front for easy access in/out.
author: Nikki B.

description:
This is now my third time at Suppenkuche and all I gotta say is that this place does not disappoint.  My oh my, I can't believe I haven't reviewed it yet!  Yes, it is loud (and proud of it) and parking is a pain in the butt, well actually so are the lines and the regular throngs of fans that throw themselves here on every given night.  However, if you get yourself a seat at the bar in the back and don't mind being immobile for an hour or so and/or work up an appetite at 4:45 pm - you should be good.  The service is very friendly for being fast however I wouldn't go in expecting them to pull out all the stops.  I'm surprised at how good they keep track of you (and your water) for a place that is always so crowded.  

Now to the food and drink - their portions are really kind and the food way past par.  Their venison is yum and so are their porkchops.  And of course if you have a hankering for some sausage and mashed potatoes - this is definitely the place to do it.  I've also had their trout, which isn't by any means authentic or anything but yummy nonetheless.

In short, just come here already and try it out.  And if you don't like German food but like entertainment by way of people watching, come here anyway - it's guaranteed someone will be chugging from das boot!
author: Jean A.

description:
Went here for a friends birthday the other night and it was an alright place. The acoustics of the room made for an extremely loud evening, lots of shouting conversation. The food was good enough. I had the potato soup with bratwurst which made for perhaps the cheapest option on the menu ($10). 

The selection of beer, however, is where it's at. The Oktoberfest beers are great, watching your friends drink a 3-liter beer out of a boot is hysterical, and the staff is friendly and great in helping you navigate the bountiful beer selection.

If you're looking for quiet this isn't your place. If you're looking for cheap keep looking. If you're looking to drink beer from a boot you've found your home.
author: Aaron M.

description: Traditional German food brats and brews. Really great for that but was overall heavy and the place was crowded
author: John L.

description:
This place is amazing.  When I went for the first time, I was a little apprehensive, since it is so authentic.  Although I really wasn't sure if I would like it, they had beer, so I figured that I'd give it a shot.  

When we sat down at our table, which has bench style seats that you share with other patrons, we were given the very expansive beer menu.  The menu is a little intimidating since they have so many choices of German beers that you have never heard of before.  I usually like to play it pretty safe (my favorite beer is Blue Moon), and I don't usually like really full bodied beers like Ale's etc.  I was pleasantly surprised that the waitress was able pinpoint my taste and recommend several beers which were right up my alley.  I tried two, and they were both fantastic, even possibly the best beers I have ever tried.  You can also get beer in really really big glasses, like the Das Boot!

Next we started to go through the menu, which is all in German (with translated English below).  At this point I started to get even more scared.  They have things on the menu that I have never tried before (like blood sausage and goose), and everything is in German.  Luckily I'm the kinda girl that will try just about anything.  We also decided that we would try to order our meals in the authentic German names to make the experience more fun.

When the food arrived, we realized we had nothing to fear, as everything was delicious.  We got the potato pancakes (with apple sauce) as an appetizer, which are the best I've ever had.  For my entrée I got the lamb chops which were also amazing.  They came with yummy mashed potatoes too   Everyone else was very happy with the food as well.

Since my first visit, I have gone to Suppenkuche several other times, and even once for brunch (also fantastic).  I always have fun here, and the food and beer are unmatched.  The only thing you have to look out for are the long waits.  There is generally at least an hour wait (I guess people know what's up).  Although you can make a reservation, you can only reserve for 6 people at either 6 or 8 o'clock.  You gotta try this place though.  There's nowhere else like it, and you won't be disappointed.
author: Liz L.

description:
I lived in Germany for many years, and this place reminded me of eating at a fest. They have the long shared picnic like tables and German "comfort" like foods. Types of sausages, meats, heavy potato dishes (like the potato pancakes!!), and other traditional type foods. The food is actually really good, and very German. If the people who were there were speaking in German, I could have found myself thinking I was back there again. And yes, they even have a bunch German beers.

When I went here it was pretty packed, so I'd suggest showing up early or making a reservation. For real, it's totally worth it.

So hey, if you want a taste of Germany I'd for sure suggest hitting up Suppenkuche. I'm totally going back!
author: Erik B.

description:
I like the authentic German food, but there are definitely other German restaurants in town that serve good German food.   

With that said, my main issue is that the restaurant is a tad oversold for its size.  The tables were constantly over-loaded.  Tables for 6 sat 8.  Tables for 10 sat 14.  It wasn't just our table, it was every table. 

As others have said, it was very very loud.
author: Victor P.

description:
I had an absolutely delicious Pork Chop - over 2 inches thick and seared to juicy perfection - served on a bed of mashed potatoes and substituted creamed peas (in place of sauerkraut, which, despite my ancestral roots, is not a taste I prefer). Wie lecker! 

Meine Verlobte had a half chicken stuffed with a suspicious potato creation we didn't sample more than once. But the chicken itself was enthusiastically seasoned and roasted such that the skin was ever-so crispy while the meat was still moist and tender - We'd order it again, strange stuffing to boot. (at least, I would...)

Both of us had fantastic german beer! 
I was blown away by the enormity of the selection (and glass sizes) of hoppy and/or smooth and rich brews. 

Go here. Snell!
author: Razoo D.

description:
I'll admit this place is cute and it's got a lot of charm.  You walk in and it really it like being in a tavern.  Long rich wooden tables line the resturant and the ceiling has these rich wheat wreaths and faux birds which great movement and are super cute with the decor.  The whole place is small but the charm isn't lost even when it's crazy crowded on a Saturday night around 7pm.

We met some friends and luckily they were early and snagged us some room on the benches.  it's first come first serve so I could imagine it hard to find a seat some times.  So cozy up to your new friends on the bench and have a great time.

It is Oktoberfest to the spirits are pretty high in the bar with German music playing and people singing it's midly rowdy.  Pair that with people waving HUGE steins and GIGANTIC pretzels you really can't help but smile and laugh at the place.

Sounds great right, so why 3 three stars?  Since it was Oktoberfest the menu was VERY limited.  I got the brautweirst that came with mashed potatoes and saurkraut.  It was pretty good, the kraut was supringsly flavorful and tender but the brauts were just ok and the mashed potatoes were pretty good but plain.  But it was $13.50 for 3 brauts, mashed potatoes and saurkraut.  Too expensive for what it was really and pretty good food.  I got wine, and it wasn't cheap for $8 a glass - a well balanced riesling though.

Service was good but not great.  Tons of people though and I understood the lag in service.

Great, novel experience, good food, tad privey and I would love to come again when they have their full menu.
author: Sabrina A.

description:
Epic.

The Mt. Everest of good time German beer and heavy, delicious meals!

The options for traditional German fare are considerable and the Wienerschnitzel and other pork products are truly fantastic.  The veggie strudel is no slouch either and MUST be considered!  

The giant pretzel might kick your ass, so be careful...

The beers have ALWAYS been fresh- I've never detected "dirty lines" when tasting their beer.  Considering how SLAMMED this excellent restaurant is, their service is ethereal in it's perfection.  It's a tall order to run a business that is this popular and this busy.

Part of the excellence in the ambience is that it ISN'T trying to be some kind of schlocky German/Cali fusion BS with linen and soft music, it's a high quality meal, served with efficiency and a minimum of pomp.  It's crowded, it's loud and it rocks.

The artwork is always super-cool, original and refreshing.  Not many places can boast constantly-evolving original artwork.

Love it.
author: Stirling E.

description:
As a German expat, it's hard not to eventually get nostalgic for German food, and even harder to find a place where the Sauerbraten tastes "wie bei Muttern" (just like Mom used to make). Suppenküche is as good as it gets, especially since the food is anything but a time capsule of culinary childhood reminiscences.

True to hearty Teutonic traditions, the menu offers a good range of German fare such as Bratwurst with Sauerkraut, Wiener Schnitzel, the already mentioned Sauerbraten, and various seasonal offerings such as venison and roast goose (around Christmas time). But the chef puts a vibrant spin on these dishes that extend their appeal far beyond the nostalgic, making Suppenküche a favorite destination for simply great food and not simply German food. All of this is, naturally, accompanied by a tasty selection of beers (I very much recommend the eclectic Weihenstephaner Hefeweizen).

The place has only a few drawbacks: (1) it fills up rapidly even on week nights, so arrive ahead of opening times, (2) the acoustics are horrible, expect to shout your conversations even at the closest table mates, and (3), options for your vegetarian friends are extremely limited and, in my estimation, a mere afterthought. Other than that, you can't go wrong with anything on the menu here.
author: Cult H.

description:
Absolutely the best dinner we had in San Francisco! Get here early for dinner, but you'll still be seated with strangers--makes it a better experience in my opinion.

It's easy to miss, so don't pass it by!
author: Vicky N.

description:
It's not like I've made some effort to eat tons of German food or anything, so grain of salt, but I've been to a few of the most popular ones in the Bay Area. This is by far the best German food I've had. Everything was perfect, seriously. Everyone traded bites, and nothing was wrong with anything. I had one of the specials, some fried porkchop thing, and it came with hella buttery mashed potatoes and creamed peas - omg. People tried some schnitzels, they were awesome. 
Star marked off because:
1. IT'S SO LOUD IN THERE. We were four relatively sober people that were yelling at the tops of our lungs to be heard, and we still all missed giant chunks of the conversation.
2. IT'S SO CROWDED. Standing by the bar, I was constantly slammed and knocked into. 
Please note, I'm old, this is shit I would never have cared about when I was 22. And despite it I will absolutely be back because I have to find some way to save room for the black forest cake (haha yeah right).
author: Elyse P.

description:
Wow!  Two gals and two guys-the guys wanted THE BOOT...lol you actually have to give them your credit card to hold in case you break the boot!  Anyway the men drank their entire boots!(that's 2 liters)

The guys had lamb chop and mashed potatoes which was excellent and the girls had the half chicken and apple fritters-to die for!  

The entire place is really homy and relaxed!
author: Kat D.

description:
I used to be a fan of this place. I thought this was the best German restaurant in town... until I had dinner at Leopold's on Polk Street. 

I am still a HUGE fan of their Gemischter Salat though. I think this German mixed salad is really the best salad in town!!
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
As we walked in, these poor tourists in their 70s or 80s came crawling out of the restaurant with hands over their ears.  "Too loud!" they said, and plaintively asked whether there was a quieter place to eat dinner somewhere else.

Well, I think they were on to something... not that I didn't enjoy the rowdy atmosphere, but do expect a mild sore throat the next day after yelling across the table to talk to your buds.

Oh, and guess what?  German food is kind of fun.  I can't imagine the poor slobs who eat this stuff on a daily basis, but the occasional schnitzel and red cabbage indulgence sure beats the pants off of all those other ethnic cuisines that we've all gotten sick and tired of.  Pad Thai anyone?  No thanks - pass the schnitzel!
author: Laurence W.

description: It is crowded, it is hot, but I always manage to have a blast here. The food, which you should take some time to eat given the massive quantities of beer consumed here, is terrific. Try the veal, seriously.
author: Bob R.

description: I had the pork chops, which were made medium rare and tasted great! Also, get the pretzel with cheese. Make sure you include a bit of onion in your bite, it gives it a bit of a spicy zest to it.
author: Eric J.

description:
Dining here is definitely as much (or more) for the experience as the food.  Don't get me wrong, the food is tasty and arrives to your table quickly.  But, as others have noted the place is lively, loud, and warm.  

I came here with a date and joked about the communal tables as they generally aren't my thing (as I am an aloof, snobbish East Coaster still living with the remnants of a Valley Girl accent) but this place is all about conviviality.  That doesn't necessarily mean you're going to bond or even have a conversation with your dining table (one lady at our table studiously ignored the rest of the table and only made eye contact with her date) but you will soak up the atmosphere.  

You kinda have to be in a social (or more social than usual) mood to eat here, though I did see one brave soul who apparently REALLY wanted German food sitting alone at the end of a communal table with her head down reading a magazine the entire evening the party at the end of the table laughed it up.  Other solo eaters were at the bar happily bumping elbows with other spaetzle lovers.  I've never been to Germany but the atmosphere did remind me a bit of bars during the weekends in Spain.  It's super crowded but everyone is there to be in a good mood.

This is an *excellent* place to bring a date if you're being sneaky and want an excuse to sit up real close to your date and whisper mundane nothings into their ear.  I noticed most of the couples were seated corner to corner, I guess to facilitate hushed conversations amongst the mood-lit din.

The bar is a tiny, crowded island in the corner of the restaurant.  I was initially taken aback by the cluster of people radiating around the small bar but since most at the bar are waiting for tables then leaving we found a space pretty quickly.  I ordered the Bananweizen, the banana juice really did cut the bitterness of the Hefeweizen.  I'm not really a beer person either, I know, what the heck was I doing at a German restaurant in October?  Eating shnitzel, that's what! 

For the food, I can't comment on its authenticity.  It wasn't as heavy as I expected but it was good comfort food.  One of the guys at my table was German American and commented on how many times he eats there a month. 

I'd go back again.  Maybe in a large group to practice yelling at one another.
author: Czarina B.

description:
Our party of 6 arrived here promptly at 5pm and got ourselves seats.

There's a good selection of beer, the food was terrific (people were skeptical at first but everybody loved their food). The sauerkraut and red cabbage was *really* good, and they're the kind on the sour side.

Only bit of complaint that made this a 4-star was the space. We were sat right next to the door, and every time somebody came in, the friend that sat closest to the door has to move. We asked the waitress about it and the response was "well the people coming in just have to squeeze". This was to accommodate an extra seat in the next table. I understand the restaurant is crowded but...a meal without constantly moving around for people with baby strollers would be more pleasant.

It's worth to be an early dinner though.
author: Alice C.

description:
There are certain criteria to becoming an Ubermensch (or Ubermadchen). They can be self-selected: perhaps eating fugu or getting asked out six times in one evening.  One is universal:  Eating at Suppenkuche TWO times in one day.

I did this recently.  I'm not a glutton or a masochist, but circumstances led me to have both brunch and dinner here one Sunday.  I don't regret it, either!  Brunch here is fabulous: the german egg 'ravioli' is very hearty, but not to the point that you need to nap afterwards, though I think you may need to if you eat the pancakes. Wow, that's a lot of food.  By dinner, I was still not very hungry (but I was essentially forced to eat here again), so I opted for the lightest option on the menu, the house cured gravlax, which is phenomenal.  My tiny friend got the half-chicken, and I don't think I have seen her since....

My only other time here was years ago on an outing with my german class.  I was unabashedly vegetarian then, so I only had beer, but I more than made up for it on this lovely Sunday.
author: Joanna M.

description:
SUPPENKUCHE IST SEHR GUT!

And that's the extent of my German...don't let my name fool you.

(Photos uploaded)
author: Heidi C.

description:
Came here on a busy Saturday night with friends, this place was PACKED! If you can, make reservations ahead of time! My 4 friends and I sat by the bar after ordering Das Boot for my friend. (btw, Das Boot requires a credit card for a $50 deposit in case you chip/ break the boot) It wasn't a table so it was kinda hard to talk to each other, but it was pretty loud so it's not really the best place to have a quiet conversation. 

We ordered :
-the crispy potato pancakes as an appetizer (this is a MUST!) so delicious and fried and yummy
-Sauteed Trout in Lemon Butter Sauce with Bouillon Potatoes & Spinach , also yummy, but beware of the small bones
-Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spätzle & Green Salad, pretty good, but the meat wasn't as amazing as I thought it would be, but everyone had fun eating the Spätzle
- one of the specials of the day was a roasted Chicken dumpling dish. I'm not sure where the dumpling part comes from, but it came with 2 more delicious potato pancakes! The chicken was one of the most tender, juicy, and flavorful dishes, and it even had stuffing inside! It was our unanimous favorite. 

The food came out pretty fast, and when we told the waiter we were celebrating our friend's birthday, he brought out a free piece of black forest cake that had a candle! That was also delicious.
author: Tina F.

description:
BOOT!! I would totally come back here just for the boot!! The waitress was very knowledgable and helpful in suggesting beers for me. She helped me choose a hef that was perfectly complemented my food.

We (three of us) arrived at a good time because, after we sat down and ordered, the line was growing! We actually had to share our table with three guys... kind of awkward, but it's not like I've never done that before.

The bread was alright, nothing special...it was served with sour cream and onion dip I believe? 

Ordered the potato pancakes and the trout. The potato pancakes were served with a side of apple sauce; the trout was actually the size of a real fish! Nothing tasted off, everything tasted the way I liked. It was actually my first time eating German food, and overall, I had a great experience!

Now next time... we're ordering two 2 liter boots... ;)
author: Jamie Y.

description:
The food was pretty good. I got the potato pancake its like a really good hash brown.  For the main course i got skirt steak.  the steak was super juicy.  Food wise your looking at a 4 star.

However

We had a party of 18 and they sat us at 2 different tables and the 2nd table had 2 strangers on it.

The waiter we had was kind of rude. bald white dude that seem to speak german.  kept bumping into my back without saying sorry.

Parking is kind of hard but thats SF for you.

So food is 4
service is 2 waiter and split table and strangers on table
price is normal

thats 3 stars
author: Justin I.

description: Greta place and AMAZING food. The portions are great and the price is right. Wish the have more space because you feel a little bit tight and too close to others
author: Vik P.

description:
You know what you need with your traditional German cuisine? Some traditional German drinking game:

You order a boot of beer (Das Boot!) for the table and pass it around. Everyone is allowed to drink as much as they want, but once they stop gulping they can't take a breather and drink again; they have to pass it to the next person. The person that finishes the beer is the champion and the person before him/her (the one that couldn't quite finish the beer but probably should have) has to pay for the boot.

Play on!

side effects may include drunken belligerence, cooties, and German accent
author: Amir H.

description:
I give it a four stars for the selection of beers and the ambiance.

I waited for a little more than an hour to get seated. But that was okay because my friends and I got to sit at the bar to get some beer before seated.

We tried about 5 kinds of beer.

All of them were good and they reminded me a lot about my time spent in Germany.
So that added to the experience.

Staff was friendly and they were really knowledgeable about the beers~

Food wasn't bad~ It's not heavenly but good and greasy enough to protect my stomach from ridiculous amount of alcohol!

We had an apple strudel for dessert. It is good! I just wish there was more flavors in it that would resemble the good one I had few months ago in Berlin. :)
author: Mel C.

description:
They don't have schnitzengruben, but I still titter a la Homer Simpson when I see their menu because I'm completely immature and the thought of German sausage brings Lili Von Shtupp to mind:

Lili Von Shtupp: Would you like another schnitzengruben?
Bart: No, thank you. Fifteen is my limit on schnitzengruben.
Lili Von Shtupp: Well how about a little...
[whispers in his ear]
Bart: [shocked] Baby please! I am not from Havana!

Oh Madeline Kahn you were genius.

As for Suppenkuche, well it's dandy - a great place to meet a bunch of friends for brunch.  A good wurst and a round or two of Julius Echter or Schnieder Weisse and you're good to go.
author: GIR ..

description:
Sure, you know that Suppenkuche is a cool place to go for German food, and awesome beer.  Yeah, it's hip, and those communal table things are great for meeting new people.

Betcha didn't know that you can walk in with 3 small kids, roughly an hour before you're supposed to be at the SF Symphony, and still have a meal in record time?  Yeah, I was amazed too.

From the woman who greeted us at the door and told us the wait wouldn't be bad (when she could have easily dismissed us in favor of a group of hipsters) to our waitress Julie who was calm and polite despite whirling around like a dervish trying to serve umpteen tables and dodging food coming out of the narrow hallway (which for some reason connects the other dining room, the kitchen AND the bathrooms) the staff were super nice.

The food was authentic (by my standards), fairly priced, and I thought the beer was actually pretty inexpensive.  My only SF-area comparison is Schnitzelhaus, and while I wouldn't rate one over the other, I would say that Schnitzelhaus is where you want to go for a large meal with friends, whereas Suppenkuche is more about the overall dining experience.
author: dan s.

description: Got the Venison in plum sauce the other night. The meat was super tender and delicious. Still not really sure how I feel about spaetzle, though I think they do it right. Wash it down with a glass of sparkling red wine. Different but delicious! Plus I love the bustling warm environment. This place is always packed!
author: Aleyna S.

description:
Arguably the best German restaurant in town.  I take that back.  There is no argument about it.  

The food is great, the beer selection is amazing, the mood is always festive.  The bartenders are extremely knowledgeable about their German brews (no surprise) and if it's not too busy at the bar and you're not sure what to order, they'll ask what you like, offer a suggestion and then give you a little try first.  Sweet!

It's a great place to come with a group of hungry and thirsty friends.  Especially during Oktoberfest when they bring in a bunch of seasonal Festbeers on draft. 

The only miss on this place is that the bar area is not really somewhere you go to hang but rather a stopping point as you wait for your table.  Too bad because on its own, it's a great place to chill with a half liter of hefeweisen or marzen for $6!
author: F. P.

description: Prepare for a wait. That is the downside of eating here. If the owners considered getting buzzers for their patrons to hold instead of them having to "check in" on their status, that would be a huge plus. The food is amazing and justifies the price of your meal. You will not leave hungry and will be saddened that you left so full you couldn't eat their dessert. Just a heads up... If you are going to this establishment with the intention of having intimate conversation, forget it! The atmosphere is loud and you will be seated at a communal table but that is what aids in providing you with a true German dining experience. The beers that are offered are awesome as we'll. Do yourself a favor and make sure you try this place out whether you live in San Fran or not.
author: Marquelle S.

description:
I came here for Oktoberfest and it was SO much fun.  The menu was limited because it was special just for the occasion. Next time, I'm definitely trying the potato pancakes that everyone raves about.

TIP 1
- Grab a seat-- fast!  Seating is first come first serve, so be sure to scout out the area, let one of the wait staff know you're keeping your eye out for a table (in case they can help you) and grab the first available seats.  The sitting arrangement is a long row of a wooden tables and connected benches, so be prepared to get cozy and comfy with strangers.

TIP 2
- Get beer!  How could you not?  :)  The beer here is imported and delicious.  I'd recommend getting a huge thing of beer so you can enjoy it with your food.

TIP 3
- The food is awesome.  I'd say you'll pay ~$15-20 per entree.  My bf and I ordered a chicken dish and strips of pork tenderloin or steak ( I don't remember, but I know it was red meat ).  Both were so good and marinated in some kind of sauce that made everything moist and delicious.  I see a lot of people just order sausages too.  

TIP 4
- They have something on the menu that's a giant pretzel that comes with tasty mustard dipping sauce.  I'd recommend trying it out, but the pretzel is GIGANTIC and there's really only so much bread and mustard sauce one can eat.  Interestingly, I saw a ton of people sharing their pretzel bread with strangers because so many people wanted to order it but were intimated by its size.  So my suggestion is to ask for a sample of it from your friend (or whoever) or get one to share.  Some people ordered it as their entree (since it's the price of an entree (~$15?), but I'd suggest eating it as a side dish.
author: Sunny S.

description: My husband and I came here for a late lunch on Sunday just before 2pm.  There were a couple seats available at the bar, so we decided to sit there.  We shared a pretzel which came with mustard and obatzda (cheese dip).  The pretzel was perfect!  Hot and crusty on the outside but nice and chewy on the inside.  They have a really good beer selection.  I ordered a hefeweizen and my husband got an Oktoberfest beer.  We also shared the bratwurst with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes.  Food was excellent!  Beer was excellent!  I'd want to come back during their dinner hours to try more food.
author: Charlene P.

description:
Suppenküche is the first meal I had back after my Europe trip. I enjoyed the rustic atmosphere - I felt like I was still on my travels. 

Monday, late night dinner, this place was busy. Expect to be cozy with your fellow diners. Communal dining format.

If you sit in the bar area, order food through your bartender. 
We found a spot in the nook behind the bar area - nice candlelit ambiance with old world prints and branches above with a gold-toned soccer ball stuck on one of the limbs. We didn't realize that we also had to order food through the bartender in this nook area.

The mixed salad included shredded beets, cabbage, carrots, potato salad and butterleaf lettuce. Pretty monotone taste, vinegary.

I also ordered the lentil soup with slices of bratwurst. Was okay.
author: Cathy K.

description:
A little piece of Deutschland in our wonderful city. Great beers with some hearty food to go with it. Skinny, tiny models, need not apply here to Suppenkuche. My favorite dish at Suppenkuche is the pork chop with the spatzle. You have to try the spatzle!! You have to try it to believe how yummy it is (make sure you try some with the gravey from the pork chop). If they are serving it as a special, try the cheese balls--also very yummy. 

Atmosphere here is basically like Oktoberfest--it is pretty loud and crowded. However, it is worth the wait. Meals tend to run $20-$25 a person, depending on how many beers you want to drink (das boot, anyone?). Get here early to avoid the wait or try to make a reservation. Give it a try!!
author: Angela L.

description: LOVE this place! Any time I have people in town I take them here. Food is as I remember it from Austria. Get there early if you want a "boot" beer.
author: Brian H.

description: pork loin was excellent, but the spatzle was even better.  Potato salad was really good too.  Pricey, but worth it occasionally.  BTW, I went with my ex-German girlfriend for her birthday along with all her German friends and they said it was authentic and really good for them, too.  In fact, they made the reservations.
author: Gregory N.

description:
The food is okay, the beer is great!

I was in the mood for sausage and beer. The sausage, sauerkraut, and mashed potatoes were okay (that sweet mustard was fantastic! Thanks for the tip mysterious server-guy!) but the beer made it all worthwhile. 

I happened to be in a wheat beer drinking mood and they had multiple wheat beers to choose from. My lumberjack got a bock and washed it down with something else.

The last time we got here it was noisy and packed. This latest visit was about the same, but I felt better prepared for an unquiet meal. Still, I didn't feel comfortable engaging in a worthwhile conversation with my partner - particularly since it was like sharing the conversation with the two other couples at our table.

Luckily, the lumberjack and I were more hungry and thirsty than talkative, and no one at our table appeared to have outrageous relationship issues that resulted in throwing stuff, crying, or making phone calls. A good night, not a great night, but our thirsts were happily quenched.
author: Loli L.

description:
Being a social butterfly on a Thursday night!
Had a fantastic dinner at Suppenkuche with coworkers, then made it to Creations for dessert!

This place was kind of confusing at first because I couldn't tell where the entrance was! Suppenkuche is right on the corner is Laguna and Hayes and there's a door that opens and you're greeted with a large, heavy curtain. What? I open it up, and there are tables right there! i quickly turn away thinking I went in through the back entrance!
