Luckily I just spotted a coworker and followed him in the same way and was soon after greeted by a hostess (with a cool German accent!). 

The spread for the night included:
Appetizers:
* Potato pancakes w/ apple sauce
* giant pretzel w/cheese and beer mixture

Entrees:
* Cheese Spatzle
* Jagerschnietzel
* Wienerschnietzel
* German Meatballs
* Wild Boar Sausages
* Braised Beef
* Organic Chicken

Other:
* Das Boot (2L)

Everything was just amazing! The waiter suggested we get the giant pretzel wince there were 9 of us, but now in retrospect, we could've done with the pretzel. Maybe then we could have finished more of our entrees. The potato pancakes are a must-get! They are deliciously crispy with the starchy taste of potato, not oil. 

The entrees were all really good. I ordered the jagerschnietzel and finished almost all of it - although my stomach did hurt after a while. Other entrees I definitely liked was the cheese spatzle (tasted like creamy mac and cheese), the wild boar sausages (interestingly enough, not gamey at all), and the wienerschnietzel (can never go wrong with anything fried!). 

Because we were all so full, we only got the 2L das boot - the the enormous 5L bucket. 

This place is a great place for large groups and for friends to catch up. You can be rowdy, loud and crazy - it's great. love it.
author: Julia K.

description:
My mom is German and I grew up eating her wonderful cooking. I have really high expectations for German food, and where the food is concerned, Suppenküche comes very close to being authentic. They have some of the best Sauerkraut I've ever had (sorry, mom) and their Nürnbergerwürste are delicious too. I only wish they still served goulasch.

What I didn't like was the atmosphere. There was no Gemütlichkeit. The place was overrun by hipsters, and the waitstaff was eager to communicate to patrons that they would rather you weren't there. 

When you go to a place like this, you pay for atmosphere. While the food was solid, the atmosphere was "meh" at best.
author: Jason K.

description: The jagerschnitzel was amazing. Got to have, the sauce was amazing and the meat was tender and tasty. Das Boot was the shit!
author: Jexter D.

description: It's cool for brunch.  The staff is friendly.  Lots of quality german and belgian beers.  The sausage omelet thing was good.  The free bread they have is excellent, some caraway seed thing and a cheesy one.  Have to come back to try the pancakes.  Only issue is it's hella loud.
author: Matthew P.

description:
Das Boot! Yes, they have it here... Just don't forget to twist it!

Let me start off by saying that I typically *loathe* German food. Can't stand it at all. I'd rather put a stick in my eye than eat it and when my friends told me that we were having German food for dinner, I thought "oh well, I'll order a few beers and hit Taco Bell on the way home."

With that said, I *almost*, for the first time in my life, liked sauerkraut. Whatever that crazy little ripped up pasta was... T'was good. The lamb was a little on the gamey side, even for lamb, but tasty all the same. To my disappointment, they did not serve liquor, but I believe that is a requirement of German restaurants. 

I still hate German food, but this place did it's best to make it palatable and, if I'm ever required to eat it again, this would be the place I'd pick.
author: Steve G.

description:
My type of place....good beer ...fresh tasty food..all in a communal and very inviting setting.

Ordered the boar sausage, Spätzle and kraut for dinner...what a great combination!  

Service was great as well. Waiters were knowledgeable and prompt.  

Looking forward to my next visit!
author: Tim W.

description:
It was my first time here, I would most definitely go back to write a more extensive review. 

Overall good food and 'bier'
author: Bruce A.

description:
mmmm...MAN FOOD!!

Though my love of man food runs deep and strong, I do have one characteristic that will keep me from being accepted...I think beer tastes like gross.  Through the magic/tragedy of peer pressure I'll drink it, I may even drink a lot of it...but still, gross.

And so, I came to suppenkuche not for the famous boot, but purely for the food and company.  The bread is dense and hearty, and delicious with their whipped herbed butter.  Dip it into the potato soup.  I ordered the pork sausage, which came with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut, as well as a creamy zing-y mustard.  It wasn't the best sausage I've had, but it's up there in the top 5.  Maybe next time I'll try some schnitzel or a seasonal specialty.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Suppencuche demanded a 1.5 hour wait, but it was WELL WORTH it! We were directed by good hands to the back bar seating area, where we promptly served by trusted and swift bartenders. I truly believe that good service breeds happy people, and this place was definitely the nucleus for happy beer drinkers! 

I highly recommend the roasted chicken dumpling with potato pancakes. Just the right amount of tender and crunch. Awww, heaven....
author: Cristina M.

description:
Loved this place.
Real good German beer, like Augustiner (bottle only). And great food. I tried it for brunch on Sunday and came back for dinner on Monday.
For brunch I got the German ravioli, Excellent. For dinner I got the half chicken and potato pancake. The chicken was perfectly roasted and flavorful. The potato pancake wasn't what I expected, but I loved it. There was no batter, unlike eastern European potato pancakes.
The Black Forest cake was soft and tasty.
I will be back.
author: Steve T.

description: Go early, it's a small venue so at a certain point they stop taking names. I also recommend trying beers you haven't and trust that no matter what you order-it's good (because it is).
author: Katie M.

description:
After what felt like the longest week of my life I was ready to unpack the week with a relaxing dinner with friends. 

That's when we got the text:
"Meet at Suppenküche in 20 min" 

Okay, the text didn't have an umlaut in it, but bottom line is, a relaxing dinner had just been kicked to curb with a 5 liter das boot. 

You don't come here to relax. You come here to drink. 

If you're lucky, you happen to like potato pancakes and dumpling stuff chicken (delicious) or venison because you happen to be a 17th century nobleman who hunts on his own land. 

But, you don't come here to eat. You come here to drink. 

Dunkel weiss (erdinger). Radeburger. Lagers blacker than the darkest night in Bavaria. That's why you're here. Let's do this.
author: Gabe b.

description: German cuisine is a rare find, and obviously foodies know to flock to Suppenkuche to indulge in some comfort food and beer. The communal tables contribute to the whole beer hall feel, and the food is perfect for beer pairings. The bread they start you off with has an almost smoky taste, and the herb butter that comes with it is amazing- this coming from someone who never butters her bread.  My boyfriend had the special for August, which was a stuffed half chicken with potato pancakes. The chicken was extremely moist and the portion was generous as well. The potato pancakes were like giant hash brown cakes, with the ideal crunchy exterior. I wasn't as satisfied with my wienerschnitzel because the breaded pork needed some kind of sauce to cut the dryness. I loved the spaetzle, but again, the entire dish needed something to add flavor and texture. I wanted to love this place, so I'm willing to give it another try!
author: Ashley T.

description:
Ok. SUPER LOUDDD! 
We left there still talking loud cause we couldn't hear any more after we left. It may be a good place for a romantic dinner if you like sitting really close and yelling in to your dates ear over boot shaped glasses of beer. 

Don't get the trout unless you need to eat healthy in a not so healthy restaurant. I did sneak a few pieces of Awesome German bread and spread (I cheated). My Friends lobster soup was pretty phenomenal. I tried my friends dish of the potato latka things and those were yummy and so was the roasted chicken.
My sister who lived in Germany was impress by the food. Just not the volume.
author: miss k.

description:
I lived in Germany as a young'un, and now again as an adult (just moved here from SF).  So let me attest to the authenticity of Suppenküche - this place is legit.

First thing you'll notice is that seating is more often than not at large tables, and you may be seated next to total strangers.  In Germany, it is okay to take the empty seats at a partially occupied table if you ask permission from the people already sitting there.  So, wilkommen in Deutschland.

The food is great, and the beer selection is solid.  Jägerschnitzel is my personal favourite dish, but the Reh (venison) is also delicious.  As for beer - they are all fine specimens of their respective arts, so just choose a type of beer that you like and order it.  They do offer beer in a boot, but unless you know the trick to drinking them, I advise just to drink from a normal glass.  Your beer stays colder that way too ;)

Minus one star for the prices though!  It really shouldn't be so expensive to throw a combination of potatoes/sauerkraut/pork/mushrooms on a plate, and maybe coat one or more of those items with flour.  Of course, price will also depend on how much beer you drink.  Assuming you come here to drink a few beers (because you came to a German restaurant, see?), this place can easily reach from the $$ bracket into the $$$ bracket.

A great dining experience, and very authentic.  I just wish it weren't so pricey for what they offer.
author: Dmytro A.

description:
Suppenkuche is quality food.

Service is great, atmosphere is rowdy and loud. You get to share big wooden tables with strangers, but thats part of the experience. Wait can be long and no reservations accepted for parties of less than ten, but its worth the wait. 

Portions are humangos. Absolutely HAVE to HAVE potato pancakes and herring, but truly food is just great, you won't go wrong eating here. 

We enjoyed being served by a tall muscular waiter with lean veiny arms :))
author: Mila Y.

description:
The environment and the people are great.  However, the food is sub-par and the prices are painfully high for what you get.  

The best part about this particular German restaurant is that it takes reservations so it is easy to get large groups in.  Buy a bunch of boots and the food will taste better.  If you want a good german restaurant, go to Leopold's on Polk St.
author: Jordan F.

description:
This place was pretty good for German food. I'm not used to German food - so I'm not sure what good should taste like.

But I will say - their beer selections are fantastic. They have all kinds of beer and specialties and an array of selections of sizes! 

The place is extremely small, make sure you have a reservation or come super early. We were there with 6 people and ate very close together.

I got the Pork something with pasta and others got the sausage - which was extremely delicious and the chicken is nice and tender.

Everything on their menu is amazing - I ESPECIALLY loved loved loved the potato cakes. Tasted like fried hashbrowns kind of but really good ones. They have them on a main dish or can be ordered as an appetizer. Highly recommended.

This place is a little bit pricey, but once in a while is okay. :)
author: Chloe C.

description:
First time having proper German cuisine... 

Really enjoyed the simple welcoming ambiance and the German beers.

I had the grilled pork sausage with their ADDICTING mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. It also comes with a tasty spicy mustard.

The potato pancakes with applesauce are an excellent way to finish off.

Very friendly service.
author: Derrick V.

description:
This place is pretty good. There were four of us and we all really liked our food. They have an authentic German menu and as you would imagine, they have a great beer selection. It's a bit hipster... as are most things German these days but the food made up for it. 

I took a star off because they won't even put your name on the list until your whole party is there so we had to wait about 30-40 minutes for a table at 7pm on a Monday night... then we ended up having to share a pretty small table with two old women and their 8 year old grandson which was odd at a restaurant that serves beer in a giant boot. Meh. 

Seriously though, the food is pretty great. The potato pancakes are not to be missed.
author: Rachel R.

description:
A friend of mine recommended me this place for my Birthday Celebration dinner and I must say I'm a fan. The place was a bit odd especially since it gets quite packed and we even ended up sittng next to strangers. But that was easily overlooked once the food was served. My friends and I ordered steak and chickens and trust me on this one I say that the food was just perfection. I think it's safe for me to say this is the first time, I ever had chicken that wasn't dry at all. 

Aside from the delicious foods, they also served delicious beers. I mean it is a German restaurant after all. My friends really enjoyed their beers. So for beer lovers, and food enthusiast definitely check this place out.
author: Julie C.

description:
A wait is expected, but at least this place serves great beer and has a trying staff.

Amazing chicken and dumpling dish served with potato pancakes (heavily fried, not my fav) that all together makes one killer German dish that my mom even approves of.

Skirt steak= tasty, but not as jaw-dropping delish as the chicken.

The schnitzel leaves a little to be desired.

The spaetzel is cheesy goodness at its best.

I've been here many a times and won't stop! 

Heavy food and beer... What more could I want?
author: Sabrina S.

description: I've only heard great things about this place, just never been in the right place at the right time to dine here. I love German food and have been to every other German restaurant in SF.  That said, the lentil soup tasted like it came straight from a Campbell's can. Apple sauce paired with tasteless potato pancakes definitely came straight from a Mott's jar. Venison medallions were swimming in some sort of mediocre sauce. Boring boring boring. Ambiance- I've never seen so many fist bumps and high fives in one night at dinner. Button up bloated frat bros, as far as the eye can see. Suppenkuche is substituting quantity over quality and it seems to be working with this crowd. They can have it as far as I'm concerned.
author: H.S. G.

description:
Delicious food and a fun atmosphere! 

Def a fan of the BOOT!!!! They have a HUGE selection of beers that are delicious! Great for big groups although the place is a bit small - they take care of business and the service is great despite the crowd! 

We had the Gemischter Salat, which is delicious and BIG! 

Also had: 

Sauerbraten mit Lingonbeerkonfiture, 
serviert mit Rotkohl und Spatzle - SOOO good - braised beef was delicious! 

Gebratene Rehmedaillions in Rotwein-Pflaumensoße 
mit Rotkohl und Spätzle - Venison was sooo tender and the cherry sauce was amazing! 

Was too full to go for the dessert menu but it looked really good from a distance! 

Would recommend getting there a bit early as EVERY time I have been the place is packed!
author: Kelly B.

description:
If there is anything you need to know about me, it is that I am a sucker for German Food. I am partially German so I constantly thank my genes for this little gift. I have actually heard about this place from other people for a while, but being someone who doesn't venture into Hayes Valley all the much, it was low on the list. Thank God my friend suggested this place because after my experience last night, I have decided I need to 1. Spend more time at this place and 2. Spend more time in general in Hayes Valley.

So I am a brawt girl all the way. Add in a beer, and you pretty much have unlocked the key to my heart. I went traditional and ordered a hefeweizen to go with my brawt. Complimented with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut and it was D-E-L-I-C-I-O-U-S! The only sad thing was the fact I could not finish my meal if my life depended upon it. My friend had the pork special which came with a dough ball thing that was really good as well. I actually liked his dish just a little bit more.

The service was a bit lacking in speed, but I really didn't mind. I was having a good night anyway.
author: Diana R.

description:
this is where i fell in love with German food.  Delectable delights all around.  I ordered the white veal sausage and pretzel for lunch and had an amazing brunch.  So good and sooooo exciting.  I even scooped up the broth, i never do that.  I just wished i had some German drinks but there will be a next time at this place because I am even more excited because it was featured on Check Please Bay Area! a month ago.  

New secret place to go to.  Damn good.  it was damn good.

I really had a merry Christmas after this because it was the only fancy meal i had that month last year.
author: Daphne A.

description:
Love this place!! It's a wonderfully decorated place with boots of delicious German beer. The atmosphere is always top notch and the food is delicious. Everything here is very German, from the staff, to the menu, to the beer. 

They serve rare finds in US such as the blood sausage, sauerkraut, and Spätzle. My favorite was the porkloin and the braised beef. True to its German heritage, the portions are generous as well. Having been to Munich and the Black forest regions of Germany, I must say this place is as authentic as it gets in terms of food.

To add to the fabulous food, they have a list of beers that would make any German proud. They've got everything under the moon here: Belgian, German, Austrian...Although I'm normally a fan of Belgium beers, I personally enjoyed the dunkels, which are dark beers that at times taste like chocolate. And of course, you gotta try the boots!!

Tip: come early to avoid lines, or if you do encounter the long waits, have a drink at the bar!!
author: Yue Z.

description: Wrote down this place as somewhere I had to go on our SF trip! I'm so happy I did! We just grabbed beers at the bar! The beer selection was pretty great! I really wanted to get the cup in the shape of the boot or the huuuuuuge mug they had but I didn't want to get too wild that night! Hahah the food is kind of pricey,  but the atmosphere and ambience are chill. I like. They also had the cutest decoration by the bar of origami butterflies! I was in loveeee!
author: Rachel G.

description:
It doesn't get better than this place!!! 

The food is spectacular, the staff is amazing, and the ambiance is what every restaurant should wish for, comfy, warm and inviting. Great winter hang out, imagine SF freezing outside and you walk into this place feeling like you stepped into some good friends warm home.

I haven't come across one bad dish, I would try everything on the menu if I could!!
author: Sunny D.

description:
Atmosphere / Decor - Very open.  Liked branches hanging from sealing and large solid wood tables.  I really like "share your table with strangers" type of place for drinking.  I love talking to strangers!  

Drinks - I really liked their draft beer selection.  Many dark selections.  They have  2L boot size at $21 (cheaper to get 4 of regular size 0.5L at $5...) 

Food - Wiener Schnitzel was very tender not too much breading.  Gebratene Rehmedaillions (Venison Medallions) were cooked perfectly medium, very tender and not too gamey.  Sptzle was very simple, buttery and yummy.
author: Chie J.

description:
Two words.

Pork. Chop.

The pork chop here was so succulent, on par with Nopa's. I went for brunch, and was pleasantly surprised that there was no line Sunday at 1pm. Though there was a lack of variety of food on the menu, it's quality not quantity right? They totally make up for it with the quantity of food they slap on your plate, plus, the staff were super nice.

Roasted Pork Sausages scrambled with Eggs, Potatoes and Bacon served with a Cucumber Salad: This was pretty ordinary, but then again I'm not a big fan of sausage. 

Special Omelette: Also quite ordinary, a vegetable omelette. Not really sure what I was expecting. Meh. The next few dishes is where they completely redeemed themselves.

Emperor's Pancake with Brandied Raisins, served with Apple and Plum Compote: I was surprised that I liked the combination of fruit sauces with my pancakes. Typically I don't like putting sauces or syrup on pancakes because they get soggy, and I was disappointed that the pancakes were swedish-style. But the tart apple compote complemented the nutella pancakes perfectly, and they didn't get soggy. You Germans have magical pancakes!

Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes and Green Salad: This was a thin cut of pork, but huuuuge. It was perfectly crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. Mmmm...

Grilled Cured Pork Chop with Sauerkraut and Mashed Potatoes: a thick cut of grilled porkchop. Sounds simple, but its amAZING. Succulent and moist on the inside and so very flavorful.

Can't wait to come back to try their other types of pork chop!
author: Jess C.

description:
I go for the beer. It's wonderful.

BF loves this place because when you go there you will notice that every single person in the place has a smile on their face. All of them. It's just a happy place. 

The bartenders know all about the large variety of beer that they serve and are very friendly and talkative (when the place is not slammin' busy - which is not often). You can just walk up to them and describe the flavors that you would like in your beer and they will pair you with something nice. They'll even let you taste little samples to make sure it's what you want.

The Food: BF and I are vegetarians and have eaten here once. We both suffered from acute cheese overload and I felt ill. I didn't feel ill because anything was wrong with the food...it's was just too much cheese/dairy. BF and I had the soup du jour: cream of asparagus, some sort of cheese ball appetizer that was the special that night (literally balls of fried cheese), a small side of cucumber salad and we shared the Spaetzle entree - which was huge). Don't get me wrong, it tasted good...it was just so rich. And to top it off with the amount of beer that we drank, we both rolled out of there afterwards. Perhaps next time the salad will be fine for us. Perhaps even the potato pancakes. 

I have to give it 5 stars for the beer and atmosphere. Love this place!
author: J D.

description: Loved this place. Very interesting and warm ambience with shared tables and a flurry of activity.  The food seemed very authentic and even if it was not, it was delicious.  Good beer available at decent prices. How can you go wrong? Definitely try the pretzels with cheese.
author: Miron L.

description:
Love this place because of the dynamic combo of great beer, food and atmosphere. When we bring friends here, they all love it and have a great time. 

Do try:
Potato pancake (so good)
Pork chop (best I've had and I'm not even a fan of pork)
Schnitzel
author: Cindy W.

description:
I finally made it here.  My dear friend said that she had the best steak ever here, so I've been wanting come for quite some time.  My sister and I ended up grabbing dinner here last night after winning the lottery to see Wicked.  We arrived around 6:30 and were seated immediately.  I've had German food only 1 other time in my life, so I let my sister do the ordering - she was President of the German club in HS and had the pleasure of visiting Germany a few years back.

The complimentary bread was blah.  It was hard, dry, and sour.  My sister said that's how it is, so I guess I don't like German bread.  The herbed butter though, was quite  yummy!   

Jagerschnitzel - I enjoyed this dish very much.  The pork chops were thin and moist, and the batter was just perfect.  The mushroom sauce was creamy and full of flavor - it went well with the chop and the spatzle.  It also came with a side of salad (butter lettuce) with a vinaigrette sauce.  I cleared everything on my plate and was completely stuffed!

Marinated and Braised Beef with Lingonberries - This was my sister's dish.  It had a very unique flavor and was very different from any other dish I've had.  The beef was really tender and the sauce was quite vinegary.  It came with a small side of cranberry sauce which is supposed to help balance the strong flavor.  I don't care for red cabbage so I can't fairly review that.  

Both dishes were excellent which I would highly recommend!  The family we shared a table with had the potato pancakes which looked delicious.  I seriously was going to grab one from them since their son wasn't eating any of it.  They also had the ravioli with mushroom sauce that also looked really good.  

My sister and I also shared a glass of beer.  I think we had the dunkel weiss w/ lemon soda.  It was nice and light, just enough to give my sis a good buzz.  ;D  

Our meal came out to about $50.00 and the service was super fast.  I'm definitely coming back and know exactly what I'm ordering next time.  I only wish they were open for lunch during the weekdays.
author: Cynthia H.

description:
I never knew I liked German beer so much until I saw it in a size six knee high glass boot. The beer selection here is... well... German. That being said, the selection of German beers is awesome and they come in sizes from half-pint to the enormous 5 liter (I have yet to see someone drink one of those.) The birthday favorite is the Boot: Two and a half Liters of golden goodness.

The beers pair well with a variety of German foods like schnitzel and pork knees. Yum.

The atmosphere is quirky and can get a little loud. Reservations are only taken for parties of six or more, so if you are less than that, belly up to the bar til a table opens up for you.

How do you say "Bon Appetite" in German?
author: Peter C.

description:
Great Atmosphere, Great Bear and Hearty Tasty Food!  Definitely recommend it.

Thanks to my bro-in-law for turning me on to this place.  We hit it before catching Black Joe Lewis at the Independent last night.

The restaurant itself is pretty bare bones itself.  It's simple in its decor; and I like that.

We started with Beer of course.  Bock was recommended by some folks.  But we opted for a Pilsener; the Bitburger.  Very smooth and very tasty.  Went down way too easily.

It was recommended we try the Mixed German Salad; but we opted not to.  Next time.

We ordered the Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce.  These are a must. 

Entrees were . . .

Saurbraten - Marinated and Braised Beef with Lingonberries served with Red Cabbage & Spatzle.  The beef was good; though not great.  The Lingonberries were a very nice touch.  But the stars were the Spatzle and Red Cabbage.  Awesome.

Special for the Day - Breaded Pork Chop with mashed potatoes and peas and bacon.  My buddies were pretty happy with it.  The Pork Chop was HUMONGOUS.

Great restaurant; I look forward to returning again sometime soon!
author: Brandon S.

description:
After attempting to eat here three times, but failing due to its extreme popularity (and my impatience for waiting for 1+ hour), we FINALLY got in.  Definite go early on a weekend, or go on a weeknight (because drinking a whole boot of beer is totally appropriate on Wednesdays).  Once, we went on a Saturday and they weren't even taking names anymore because they couldn't seat everyone on the wait list by the time they close.

Anyway...two friends got the boots (2 liters) of beer.  Needless to say, they had fun.  I, on the other hand, had just .5 liter of one of their hefeweizens, which was realllllly good.

Their food was hearty like most German food.  I ordered the grilled cured pork chop, which came out looking like a pork chop but tasting like ham.  Interesting.

Make sure you try to order in German, especially after having a whole boot.  The waiter will think you're just slurring.
author: jon y.

description:
I hate when you go somewhere knowing nothing, and the person helping you makes you feel like an utter jackass for asking questions.  Being a beer moron, this was a concern going to Suppenkuche and being intimidated by the hundreds of beer choices.  There was no cause for concern, however, since Rusty the beertender came to my rescue, answering all my questions and requests for recommendations in a friendly and knowledgeable manner.

There's something about the decor in Suppenkuche that is comforting yet whimsical.  Flocks of cut out, colorful birds adorn the ceiling and little, black and white paintings of butterflies and trees spot the walls.  The dress and wooden cross hanging in the corner . . . wonder what that's all about.

The food . . . like other reviewers have said, the potato pancake is a bit like an over sized, round and crispier version of a McDonald's hash brown.  And I really don't have a problem with that.  I was happy with my marinated beef and spatzle . . . until I tried the cheese spatzle.  Then I was just sad and jealous that I didn't have cheese spatzle.
author: Jenny R.

description:
Good place.

Very "different"...they have the traditional German setting in this restaurant, which can either be daunting or enjoyable. For me, it was daunting. I was going on a *FIRST DATE* here, and I was extremely excited. My date got me one of the oldest German beers you can have at the bar, and we waited to be seated. Low and behold, we get seated at a table with a bunch of other *FIRST DATES*...I nearly shit my pants. Talk about awkward. We all sat there making bouncy eye contact and exchanging awkward smiles. hahaha. I will forever remember that feeling. Trying to shove potato pancakes nervously down my mouth as I am trying to impress a table full of strangers, and my first date. 

This is not a good place for a first date...that's the moral of this story, but the food is excellent and the vibe is great. Plus, the beer is phenomenal.
author: Tessa R.

description:
Interesting conversation we overheard from between the bar tender and the last table of customers in the restaurant (we are the second last table tonight):

Bartender: Please concentrate on your drinks.
Customers: Why? what? ?????
Bartender: Please concentrate on your drinks. This is a restaurant not a bar. (implying: we are kicking you out!)

I didn't eavesdrop the rest of the conversation but it probably didn't end well. As my German friend said, it didn't sound like German hospitality at all. 

I have been to this restaurant before and the food & the beer are not bad but as I remember the services is only so so.
author: Hinling Y.

description:
I missed Lena, our German exchange student who worked miracles in our limited college student kitchen. She would have approved of Suppenküche which did justice to German food. 

Suppenküche is loaded with beer, bratwurst and it is busy! My date and I had to wait a while to get seats for dinner here and ended up going to a bar nearby to load up on pre-dinner beer because even the bar was full! 

Eating here is quite the experience. The restaurant felt very casual and low-key. I liked being seated next to people who had the same appreciation for wiener schnitzel as I do. It was difficult talking to my date over dinner, so we made plenty of time to do that afterwards.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Thank you yelp!!!!! This place is one in a million, I haven't been able to find another German place in California that even comes close to competing against their bratwursts and beer. And I hate beer! But by golly, this place had one that was just...WOW...it is the only beer that I can say that I like the taste of and it is called Weltenburger Helles. OH SO GOOD and thirst-quenching! 

We got here before it opened so we waited a bit and after 5 minutes, we weren't the only ones waiting! This place was poppin even before it opened!! Luckily we were one of the first ones in because the place filled up in an instant and got busy in the blink of an eye. Almost immediately, someone ordered DAS BOOT. Seriously, they have the freaking boot. It's like we got teleported to Germany during oktoberfest. They started us off with a basket of bread and their own herb butter. I LOVE FREE BREAD. And the herb butter complemented it so well. We ordered bratwursts with mash and sauerkraut to complete our German experience and my god did we pick a winner! 

Every time we come to SF, we want to go to this place but somehow never end up here....but nonetheless, I WILL BE BACK! (to try their apple strudel!)
author: Melody R.

description: It's Friday night and my girlfriend and I entered Suppenkuche for the first time.  We were greeted by a lively scene of young people drinking their beer filled glass mugs and a friendly staff of people.   We sat down at the bar and ordered our food from the loud and friendly bartender.  The moist and soft starter pumpernickel bread was where this fairytale ends.    Once the pre thawed store bought pork sausage entree greeted our eyes and mouths we realized we had been spoiled by the homemade plump juicy sausages from Leopolds we had visited earlier in the year.    The half chicken dumpling entree for another 20 dollars was just as uninspiring.  We left this place 50 bucks poorer with heavy stomachs and vowed never to return as a couple.  I was generous and give this place two stars because if i was single with tons of friends i would come here for the social ambiance and beer culture.
author: Robert N.

description:
Wow. Never really tried German food but if German food is anything like Suppenkuche, I AM A FAN!

1) Their portion's are effing huge. I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw these enormous plates of food being waltzed around table to table. 

2) Though I can't pronounce ANYTHING on their menu, pretty much whatever you order, it's going to be freaking delicious. 

3) The beer is good. Enough said.

4) The restaurant itself is so comfy and welcoming. Sat next to a bunch of strangers on a bench (yes, on a bench) but had the best time of my life conversing with them about their meal.

5) Staff is so cool and service is great! They definitely help you out and recommend great dishes and beer if you are a newbie like me! 

Highly recommend trying their weiner schnitzel, spatzle and their POTATO PANCAKES!
author: Hanna P.

description:
i love love LOVE this place. I come here every time i'm in SF.
their wiener schnitzel is so moist and flavor, I always get a side of their braised red cabbage. The cabbage is warm, vinegary, yet sweet, it accompanies the schnitzels perfectly. 

their potato pancakes with apple sauces is good as well. the potatoes are cruchy and the apple sauce slightly sweet and so delicious, but i might be bias, i do love potatoes
author: Amy K.

description: Such good German food! Lots of great beer selections too, with very knowledgeable bartender. The place is so good that a line regularly develops outside before they open for dinner, and the small place fills very quickly. The only downside was the volume, it was hard to hear companions in the din. But, the food was so good that I can forget the noise.
author: Emily H.

description: Love this place! It's fun and loud. You sit at family style tables so be prepared to meet your neighbors. When I go out, I usually drink wine but I have found theirs to be a little too sweet so I either get beer or sparkling. The beers are delicious. The food is amazing! I strongly recommend the Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße mit Spätzle und grünem Salat. Give it  a try, you will enjoy yourself and Hayes Valley is such a great, unique area to walk around.
author: Cheri M.

description:
Suppenküche is one of my favorite restaurants in SF! Not only is the ambience fun with the long tables and benches AND boots of beer, but also the food is fantastic. This place has me in love with spatzle which is just a side to their many amazing dishes. 

I usually hate waiting for a restaurant, but this one is worth grabbing a drink and coming back to... and also worth bringing a group of 6 ppl together so you can make a reservation ;)

Much love Suppenkuche. Danke.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I have a rule concerning ethnic restaurants.  If you see or hear (German, Greek, Chinese, Mexicans, etc.)  people eating at a (German, Chinese, Greek, Mexican, etc.) restaurant you are sure to have a 'real meal'.  Well, that goes for Suppenkuchen.   Sat next to some German lads enjoying a liter.   The food is amazing.   Lots of hearty dishes loaded with meat.  Vegetarians beware.    The  German beer selection is par excellence!   The beer sizing chart will blow your mind.  This is a good taste of how Europeans dine, if you have never traveled to Europe.   

Regarding kids... I would say this place is fine for 14+ year olds.  My teen son felt so hip and grown up nursing a bottle of German organic lychee soda.   Would not recommend bringing younger children, unless they are really well behaved and are accustomed to eating out.   Strollers would be HIGHLY discouraged, due to the tight spacing.  Don't know how wheelchairs get around.
author: Diana D.

description:
Based on Yelp reviews, I've been wanting to try this place out for well over two years now. We finally managed to get our shit together last Friday and get ourselves a table. I'm warning you though... On a Friday/Saturday night it's jam-packed! We put our name on the list at 7:30pm, went back to SOMA to pick up three friends, then headed back at about 8:45pm. After parking the car, we still had to wait till 9:15pm for out table but at least we had a chance to stand up at the bar and taste some sweet German ales. They put us in the back room next to a couple of groups of "merry" frat boys. They challenged my friend to a drink off but crapped their pants when they found out he was Scottish. Hahaha. 

As for the food... stunning! Well worth the two year procrastination and 1hr 45m wait.

Everyone on Yelp was raving about the potato pancakes & apple sauce. As Alan Rickman might say, "we were not disappointed". They were so tasty! I could have easily just ate another couple of platefuls of them all night. We also shared the appetizer plate (ham, blood sausage, salami & cheese) which was yummy too. 

For mains, I went with the chicken and truffle sausage special while JZ had the marinated braised beef with red cabbage. Mine was great but I preferred her beef. She liked her meal but preferred my sausage. Oo-er matron! Afterwards we were pretty well full up with hearty food and beer. The only thing left to do was sing a chorus of "Kling, Glöckchen"


Kling, Glöckchen, klingelingeling,--
kling, Glöckchen, kling!
Lat mich ein, ihr Kinder,
ist so kalt der Winter,
öffnet mir die Türen,
lasst mich nicht erfrieren!
Kling, Glöckchen, klingelingeling,
kling, Glöckchen, kling!


~~
Sehr Gut!
author: Michael H.

description:
This place is a San Francisco icon... and justly so.  It's a Hayes Valley jewel with a fabulously hip, yet casual ambiance, and truly authentic food - off of the charts fresh, flavorful, comfort German food.  There are even lighter choices for those watching their calories.  

I'm not a beer connoisseur so that part of the experience is lost on me, but my friends always enjoy the unique variety.  

Don't forget brunch.  San Francisco has a dearth of good, special occasion, satisfying Sunday places.  This is it.
author: Nancy G.

description:
Probably the best restaurant in SF - after the Front Porch, that is. 

You get a ton of food, great service, great beers. The only downer is that it's usually so popular, that you'll have to wait a while for a table.

Well worth the wait, though!
author: Mr E.

description:
Suppenkuche is the loudest restaurant I've ever eaten at.

Now the food is good, their beer selection is mind-blowing and I salivate just recalling the dark amber fluid I imbibed...   But way too noisy!  My girlfriend and I went there on a Thursday night, on the later side, and although the food was good, we didn't enjoy it so much as it was so crowded and we couldn't even converse with one another.

Maybe just getting old... If you want to go eat some serious german grub and drink like you're at Oktoberfest, this is the place to do it at!
author: David O.

description:
Glad I gave German food a second chance.  My first time was years ago in Chicago and it was not appealing.

At Suppenkuche...not only is the food good but comes in hearty portions!  
Good bread and butter at the tables!  My starter was actually the lobster soup, which was full of flavor, and not too much cream, and just very savory.  
 
I had the Cheese Spatzle in Onion Butter Sauce served with a small Mixed Salad...the Spatzle was delicious, creamy, cheesy and full of good flavors.  My salad was interesting...mix of beets, carrots and cabbage.  I loved the cabbage.  I also tried the potato pancakes, which were very good, starchy and just huge portions!  
They have lots of beer to choose from, and a few non-alcoholic beverages.  

The service was good, even though it was busy, they were attentive enough.  The decor is very simple and utilitarian, felt like a cafeteria but more cozy.  I love the paper butterflies on the ceiling...and the painted trees on the upper parts of the walls.    

I can't say enough good stuff about this place.  The food was great, the service was good, and the beer selection was awesome, and I'd suggest you give it a try too!  (And they have a few vegetarian dishes too!!) And get reservations for parties of 6+!
author: Fannie S.

description: We had lunch here and I overall I wasn't impressed.  Maybe my boyfriend hyped it up too much.  I ordered the German ravioli, which turns out is not what you think of when you think "ravioli".  It was good, but really heavy and I got bored with it after a few bites.  The really enjoyed the cucumber salad, however.  All in all, it's a fine place to go with friends to drink a ton of beer but foodwise, not my favorite.
author: Elizabeth P.

description: Great, authentic German food! Make a reservation because it fills up fast!! It's a small place but the food is absolutely wonderful. You can't NOT like a place that has 2 liter Beer Boots and a FIVE liter mug of beer. Good place for fun with friends but not the best location for an intimate dinner since it can get very crowded and loud. It's a great time though!
author: Natalie L.

description:
DAS BOOT.

Hahahaha, I didn't think it was a real thing. I'm not a big bar person and that might be why I didn't know. But this place was really crowded when I went but after an hour of waiting at the bar drinking ourselves silly, we got a table... for 15! yeah. they were pretty accommodating which was really nice of them. The place was packed but they served us good food on a timely manner. There was a deposit for the boot, i guess it's pretty expensive and most ppl are drunk by the time they finish so they need to put a deposit so no one breaks them. Makes sense. Good place.
author: Dominic C.

description:
5 Stars - Atmosphere
4 Stars - Service
3 Stars - Food
2 Stars- Price points

This is a fun restaurant to go to with friends but don't expect any mind blowing culinary masterpieces.  The food is decent, with no major mistakes made but, I feel it is the atmosphere and novelty of ordering several liters of beer at once that draws most people. 

Food wise I always judge a German restaurant on its schnitzel recipe.  If they can't get this staple right, it's a telling sign of the rest of the menu.  Their particular recipe when I went smothered it in a delicious but overwhelming mushroom sauce.  Which in all honesty, I feel it is used to mask an inferior schnitzel.  Schnitzel should be able to stand alone (with the exception of a wedge of lemon) in it's greatness by having the perfect balance of seasoning, perfect amber golden color, and have a crispness you can cut with a fork.  This schnitzel wasn't even close.  But I will admit the seasoning of the sauce did a decent job of making up for it.  The entree came with a delicious and buttery side of spaetzle that in all honesty, out performed the schnitzel.  The spaetzle was cooked perfectly and seasoned just right.  The side salad of butter lettuce was good but not cut into small enough pieces.

I also tried a bit of the suckling pig, with kraut and dumpling.  The pork was good, not great.  But the kraut was a major winner with that entree.  Seems to follow the same trend as my schnitzel.   

In all, I would definitely recommend this place to people looking for a fun night out and decent food.  Although the popularity of this place can definitely detract from making it a normal pit stop as well as the prices.  At almost $20+ dollars an entree, serious consideration should be made regarding value of meal vs. quality.  Our group of 5 spent almost $500.  Granted much of that expense was beer but imagine spending that much at any finer restaurant in the mission and it would not doubt be a incredible meal.  I think I will save this place for an every once in a while event.
author: Darin E.

description: I've been a few times to Suppenkuche for brunch and never been disappointed either by the food or the service. Lately I went for dinner and I enjoyed the place even more. First, it is a great place if you are looking to book a large group as most of the table are communal. While I'll rarely been impress by German cuisine in the past Suppenkuche was a totally different experience. I ordered the pork chop which was delicious. It comes with mash potatoes and sauerkraut. The sauerkraut was absolutely phenomenal. I'm not sure how they cook it but even if you generally don't like sauerkraut you should give a try to this one. I tasted many other dishes and all were equally delicious. On top of that, the excellent beer that accompanies the meal make of Suppenkuche one of my favorite spots to eat in SF.
author: Jean C.

description:
I went here to celebrate Oktoberfest and had a grand 'ol time. Great atmosphere and super crowded, but with a group of 12 we got reservations and sat in the back area near the kitchen without the huge and noisy crowd.

The food was quite amazing. My favorite was the gigantic preztel with cheese spread. Apparently they only serve this during Oktoberfest. The spatzle and bratwurst were also good picks.

Don't forget the BOOT!
author: Lisa C.

description:
We got very lucky, and snagged a table for 5 during brunch with very little wait. That being said, I would gladly wait for a table at Suppenküche. 

My fiancé had the potato pancakes, and they were perfection. Beautifully crispy outside, tender moist inside, and not greasy at all. 

I had the veal and pork sausages in a butter broth. They were very fresh, wonderfully spiced and yet mild. Quite similar to a British banger  but with a more mellow flavor. 

If you are a Riesling fan like me, the wine menu will make you incredibly happy. 

My friend had the sweet/savory pancake combination, and I only had one bite, but that one bite was a blissful explosion of tender cake, sweet-tart preserves, and savory egg. I don't know how he ate over half his plate. 

The atmosphere is very like a tavern or pub - some of the tables are communal, and the minimalist decoration allows the sound to bounce all around off the walls and floor. Noisy, cozy, and cheerful. 

I especially liked the plain wooden tables and lack of formal place settings, which allowed the food to stand front and center. 

Side note -- the gentleman who sat us, either the owner or main manager, was a sweet, friendly man who acted as though we were visiting his home. Love it.
author: Andrea B.

description: consistently great german food. beer selection is incredible and the service is terrific. the only issue is the wait. one recommendation--substitute spatzle for the potato on any dish you order--very authentic and yummy
author: T M.

description:
This place was fun, fun, fun!!  

The beer flows, and so many to chose from.  The wait staff helps you pick from their vast list of beers they serve.

I had very juicy Chicken with potato pancake, and awesome strudel for desert.  My friend had sausages and sauerkraut, we both loved our food!!

Bring the kids because when they scream, no one will hear, very loud? Yep! Problem??  Nope!!  Lots of fun!!
author: Paul L.

description:
I rather look at "most reviewed" than "highest rated."  So, when it comes to exploring Hayes Valley, I pick none other than Suppenküche for dinner.  As always, with all the restaurants that have an extreme high number of reviews, there is a long wait.  If you want reservations for a Saturday night, you have to call them a month in advance, according to the hostess.  We put our names down at 6:30, we were seated at 8.  They do not call you if you're not available when the table is ready for you.  We had to share a table with two other people, that always makes it a lil more interesting.  

The décor makes you feel like you're in Germany, and somehow everyone around you looks German at this restaurant.  And everyone is so nice, these ladies offered some of their appetizers to us while we were waiting for a table =)

The boot - we ponied up a credit card for a $50 deposit in case we break or chip the boot.  If you're waiting for an hour, and if Suppenküche will probably be a once in a year/lifetime experience, do not miss out on the boot.   The buzz is so worth it, it makes the food taste even more delicious.  It's $28 if you don't break the boot, $50 if you do.  

The food - We got Gemischter Salat (salad), Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus (Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce), and this special - it was stuffed chicken, I can't put the name down here since it's not on the online menu.  I love potatoes, so that was a winner for me, it tasted a lil like hash browns, but I love those too.  The chicken was okay, nothing amazing.  

I would go here again, just for experience, the food wasn't worth the wait.  This brings me to one key question - why the ef do I put myself through these lines?!?
author: Anoo L.

description:
Two words: DAS BOOT. 

The chicken and potatoes was very tasty and served in a delicious gravy-sauce thingie. I would just watch for the waiters as they are kind of quirky. My bill had a big mistake on it - $10 charge from nowhere.

But order the hearty, filling food and enjoy the lively ambience. You'll really like it.
author: Peter F.

description:
Came here for a late dinner on a Friday night.  The place is super crowded and fairly loud.  It was going to take an 45 minutes to be seated so we came over to the bar to have some drinks.  Quite good tasting beer and had a pretzel as a snack.  Pretzel was great!  We were seated and had 

*Spätzle -wonderfully tasty- would order again

*Pickled Herring with Onions, Apples, Pickles & Potatoes-where is the herring?  we literally had 1 piece and was just ok 

*Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad-wonderful meat and potatoes.  soo good.  id come back for this any day!

pros-real bar feel and great beer and wine selection
        -pretzel from the bar, Spätzle, and  Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad

cons-loud, long wait, and potential odd seating.  possibly this establishment would do better if the bar and the restaurant were separated.  I have not had the exposure to this type of food, environment,and or culture so it was all a good shock for me.  

Definitely come with a friend who can help with beer and menu choice.  I felt somewhat intimidated and lost at times.  I'd come back and give it a go.
author: Stan L.

description:
Come on people, have you no taste-buds??!!

Suppenkuche has some of the worst food I have ever had.  My wife and I love trying different foods...French, Thai, Indian, etc, etc.  However I would not eat at Suppenkuche again if they gave away food for free.  I had pork sausages with mashed potatoes...the sausages were no better than those that you could buy at the grocery store.  My wife had the "famous" meatloaf, which again was barely edible.  We had to have a second meal that night.

Yes, the beer and the atmosphere were good.  And the communal seating made it feel authentic.  But the food...never again.  There is a reason there are not many German restaurants around.  This place is for 1- people who like to be trendy 2- college frat boys and 3- die-hard German food lovers, but no one else.
author: Robert M.

description:
This was a fun place to go. The biggest downside is how freakin popular it is! We were a large group of about 10, and were told we had to wait until the entire party was there to be seated. Fine. So we were waiting inside, but this place is just too small to accomodate the tables, the servers, and anyone waiting for tables. 

Anyway. The food was good. I had the vegetarian cheese spatzle which was really really tasty. And I love any place that has Lindemans beer.

I would consider going back, sure. Great food and drink, but I'm just not usually a fan of super crowded places.
author: Evey G.

description:
FINALLY, I get to knock this one off my list.

I'm just going to warn you now, if you come on a weekend night, you will most likely have to shout at the person sitting next to u in order to have any sort of conversation.  The place gets packed but I think the room itself magnifies sound 10 times so that you feel like you are smack in the middle of a NYSE trading floor.  

We came with a large amt of people and they were able to accomodate (but we did have to make a reservation).  Def was busy so obviously people really like this place, but for me personally, I don't think I would come back.  I mean the food was good if not a tad bit salty, but I just don't see myself craving it.  I think people come here more for the beer too.

Fried potato pancakes with Apple dipping sauce - good
Stuffed Chicken special with potato pancakes - like a thanksgiving meal.  The chicken was cooked well but the gravy was on the salty side.
Black forest cake - Others really enjoyed this but I didn't care for it
Apple Strudel - decent

Overall an ok experience.  I def think you should try this place at least once, but for me, it's not on my list of repeats.
author: C A.

description: Awesome German beer house decor and atmosphere.  Food could be better.  Potato pancakes are over fried, and the omlete has too much salt.
author: Alf O.

description:
I came here for a birthday feast Sunday night and had the best time. It was the perfect dinner: tasty, indulgent, comfort food with a couple of great friends and my amazing boyfriend. 

I had the pork bratwurst (which was on special) with red cabbage and mashed potatoes. It was a meal that sounded delicious and was in fact even more delicious than I imagined.. It literally blew my expectations out of the water. We started with the potato pancakes which I completely smothered in apple sauce. Can you say yum in the tum? 

Can't wait to come back here because there are a few things I want to try: the giant pretzel, beer out of a boot and their brunch. 

Only downside here is, like many popular spots in the city, the space is small and the wait can be long. You might also have to share a table with other people if your party is small. If you can possibly help it, get a table away from the door. We sat at a spot nearest the entrance and we kept getting a draft every minute or so. Luckily for us it was a nice evening!
author: Julia N.

description:
I came here for a 5- people group dinner and some of us arrived a bit late.  I felt a bit uneasy as they do not allow seating until all party is arrived.  We only had one more person to wait for and they still made us stood outside the street, even with the fact that 2 of us are 9 month pregnant!!! 

Aside from not liking the waiting part, let's talk about the food.  We ordered a lot of dishes from the menu, the highlights are potato pancake with apple sauce (tasted like McNugget, with apple sauce) and wiener schnitzel.  The other dishes such as meatloaf,  sausage and medallions were not bad as well.  

The place is very loud inside, it was hard to talk, so probably not a good place to take your date to.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night to celebrate a buddy's birthday and was amazed to see how  crazy-popular this place is. The beer selection is one of the best you'll find in the US for European brands on tap and is the only thing that would bring me back.

With a 6 PM arrival It took more than 2 hours to be seated sharing a table with friendly strangers - this I liked a lot. The clearly overcrowded environment forces folks to be sociable. Standing room only would be an improvement as it was really hard to find a place to be out of the way - lots of movement required to make way for servers and other customers.

Suppenkuche is one of the noisiest experiences I have ever had and brought back memories of rock concerts at Winterland when I was foolish enough to stand too close to the speakers. Conversation was difficult, even just across the table. 

The food: Was interesting and different.  The potato cakes were great but the Weiner schnitzel pork and potatoes were bland and dry. I ended up adding the applesauce from the cakes to the pork to add moisture and make it more palatable. The salad that came with it had a sweet & sour dressing that was light and not overpowering. A flavor I had not experienced before but found really good, particularly in combination with the rest (it added the much needed moisture and balance).

Service was great - attentive and quick. Couldn't hope for better. All the staff is outgoing, friendly and efficient.
author: Mitch N.

description: One of my favorites on the planet. It helps that they have one of my favorite beers on tap - Schneider Weisse Hefeweizen. Food is excellent. Best thing about this place is the atmosphere. You sit at shared tables. Naturally, you get to know your neighbors. It's always a very entertaining visit and good food/beer is the cherry on top.
author: Dan W.

description:
Mmm, I always get the weiner schnitzel.  The flour dumpling as appetizer is also good.  the back room is for groups, you can get a seating at 6 or 8 pm. 

A large selection of beers, of course. And steinware.  You can order a boot-shaped one, but unfortunately both of them were broken by drunkards so we were were unable to partake. There's only 2 of them, and they both needed to be re-ordered from Germany.  Next time!
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Seems sad that there have been over 500 reviews written about Suppenkuche...and that it has taken me so long to go to Suppenkuche!  I dragged my friends here for my birthday, and it was a great place for a large group.  Beyond the large tables with bench seating, the lively atmosphere and conversations all around make it easy to be loud with a big group.  I made a reservation a few weeks in advance, and it was perfect - we were seated quickly and without any fuss.  (You can only make reservations for parties larger than six.)

While we were waiting for our table (we arrived a little early), we waited by the bar.  The area right around the bar is crazy crowded, but the little alcove behind the bar was a relatively roomy space to wait on a Monday night (maybe a "slow" night for Suppenkuche...which is still pretty busy).  

I wanted to start with the potato pancakes but my friends weren't that hungry...so I just had the wiener schnitzel which was delicious.  The selection of beers is also great.  My friends brought cake to the restaurant, and I was thrilled to find out that they wouldn't charge us any fee for eating our cake at the restaurant.

Yay, Suppenkuche!
author: Wendy L.

description:
Pretty epic really. Suppenküche is unique. You just can't find a place that serves Munich cuisine this authentic along with plenty of rare German beer on draft this side of the Atlantic. Suppenküche can definitely compete with similar restaurants in Germany and may even be better than most of them.

Don't miss out on their Oktoberfest celebrations. They're awesome.
author: Aaron V.

description: Too bad yelp doesnt allow me to give half stars, because I would really rate this place as a 4 and 1/2 stars because of the wait, the crampness (table sharing), and the fact that boys here cant seem to understand girl bathroom is strictly reserved for girls (but considering the amount of beer I see guys drinking here, they are excused in my book, although creepy and gross, but excused).  But other than that, I am all for this place. Great helles beer, love the soup (my passion! :)), and great atmosphere as well.  A good place to chill with friend, get buzzed on the good beer, and to grab a bite to eat.  Did I mention they carry 1, 2, and 5 liter size beer.
author: Young N.

description: Luscious and buttery flavors, good beer, fun aesthetics and hearty portions. I love that you often share a table with fellow diners- incorporation of cultural elements from a warmer climate culture makes me very happy!
author: Stephie M.

description:
I had never had German food before going here - what a way to start off! 

Everything I have had here has been great. The potato pancakes are crunchy, the mushroom raviolis are to die for - what appetizers! While the apple sauce is good, I like to mix the mushroom sauce with the potatoes. 

I am not even a big beer drinker, yet my last visit there we all drank out of the Boot! 

I like the Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und Grünem Salat (Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad.) I do like to substitute the roasted potatoes for mashed ones when available. The also do this dish in Veal sometimes, not on the menu, but will make it if you ask! 

An awesome restaurant, a very cool experience, and great for a group of 4-6, although finding enough seats can be difficult, but worth the wait.
author: Sam A.

description: Tried their Wiener Schnitzel, it was delish! It was a little loud though, hard to have a conversation, but worth a visit.
author: Sasan A.

description:
Suppenkuche is SO authentic! Everything from the rustic table settings to the steins brought back vivid memories of our vacation in Germany. 

I ordered the schnitzel and was slightly wary that it might taste like cardboard since it was completely fried, but the flavor was amazing (much better than the one my boyfriend made...he also agreed). I also asked for the spaetzel instead of the roasted potatoes, and it was cooked perfectly. It wasn't too dry or sticky. 

The only, ONLY sub-awesome part of the meal was the apple juice with mineral water that I ordered (yes, I'm 25 and I ordered apple juice instead of beer. I welcome ridicule). It just tasted like sweetened mineral water. 

I would eat here everyday if I could. Suppenkuche is that good!
author: Vivian S.

description:
My high school German class came rushing back to me suddenly but nothing could have prepared me for the amazing dinner I had at this place. 

I came here with a group of co-workers (library folk) and was blown away by the boot sized beer we passed around and lush, butter rich goodness we stuffed our bellies with. I had the cheese schpatzle (sp?) but had a taste of almost everyone's plate. The staff is wonderful as well, and the beer just kept coming jesus I ate good sooooo good!

Afterward we passed around a box of Parisian macarons (yes not German) but the night was swell and sweet mmm
author: Penelope B.

description: Great beer and pretzels. Beers are a bit sugary and will add to your hangover. Main dish was good, if you like German. The secret is to hang out in the back and grab a bar seat. The wait to get seated was the only negative.
author: Robbie K.

description:
Bro as shit, but the food & beer really can't be beat.

A few things to note:
- Stop saying 'soop-en-cooch.' You sound like a redneck.
- Don't just order boots of beer. Try a few different ones, especially the specials (try the rauchbier / oak smoke beer - you won't regret it)
- If you're not sure what to order, the saurbraten is pretty hard to not love. Tender beef with a berry sauce alongside some pickled veggies and some spatzle? Yes please.
author: Matt J.

description:
This past weekend has been food indulgent to say the least and Suppenkuche stole the show.

As a warning, parking will be pretty terrible if you go on a Fri or Sat night and the wait will probably be 2+ hours long but it's totally worth it.  If you see the giant pretzel on the menu--GET IT!  It's really giant and it's served with bavarian cheese.  Make sure you ask for the hot and sweet mustard.  The sweet mustard was probably the best I've had.  The rest of the food is good and the beer is amazing!  

With good food and good beer, I can see why people may never want to leave--heck I didn't want to leave--but it's always nice to be mindful of the 50 ppl standing outside waiting for a table.  

YUM APPROVED!
author: Kim C.

description:
I don't get it.

I have a sneaking suspicion Suppenkuche is popular because so many of us "dying to be hip" San Franciscan hep-cats heard about it's hipness, and now must proclaim our love for "cool because it's not cool" German food.  
Lucky restaurant....too bad a trendy San Franciscan's love is fleeting.  After nearly 5 years, there is still a line out the door, so I could be wrong.  Time will tell.

Go for the atmosphere:  Fun, young boisterous
And the beer:  Interesting selection
Not for the food (which I tried on 2 occasions, both brunch and dinner): Dried out, tough meat. Greasy eggs.  Flavorless pancakes.
author: Patricia L.

description:
Go with a liter when considering beer size. Get it done. Size up, have another!
I can honestly say I've never had a bad tasting meal, or meal lacking quality. This is always "our" gathering place!
author: Bobby L.

description:
Where do I start??? First, just to give some background, my mom and I live in Fresno, CA. We went out of town for her birthday, and decided on SF. One reason was that the only German food to be sought in our area is Der Weinerschnitzel. We looked on Yelp! for such a place, yet none was to be found. According to the reviews I saw on here, Suppenkuche had an exceptional reputation. And did it deliver! This place was amazing! The food was fantastic. The ambiance was communal. The place was packed to the hilt, but service was quick and responsive. I felt as if I was in a Germany itself, particularly in the Bavarian provinces. The wooden beams were an awesome touch, along with the wooden tables. Suppenkuche was very rustic and had the natural feel of being in an actual Biergarten. 

The options for drinks were plentiful. My mom had the Riesling spatslese, a very sweet white wine. 

We first had the dumpling appetizer in a mushroom sauce. The appetizer hit the spot, especially since it was getting chilly outside. The food was phenomenal. I had the Jaegerschnitezel; I found it to be perfectly cooked with the side of spatzel noodles. The schnitzel was delicious.  Not only did the food actually look tasty, I consumed it with a happy zeal! 

My mom had wild boar sausages with spatzel noodles. The sausages were savory. There two on the plate and served in a mushroom sauce. Complimentary to the sausages and spatzel was the sauerkraut. Prior to that evening meal, my mom's opinion on sauerkraut was pretty low. After eating her meal, she now loves it. There were small chunks of ham in there as well. My mom's last words are: wonderful, tasty, delicious, big portions, and AUTHENTIC. 

The dessert was exceptional! My mom and I shared the apple strudel with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. The strudel was laying in a pool of vanilla ice cream on the side. It was flakey warm and it gave you a sigh of contentment. 

The only downside of this little place was parking. Like anywhere else in San Francisco, desired parking is lacking. We parked about 2.5 blocks away. So if you have plans to go to this establishment, give yourself plenty of time to get parking.  

As far as prices go for the food, Suppenkuche's entrees are in the mid range. Our meals were little less than $20/person. So keep that in mind.

I would reccomend this little restaurant to anyone who has a yearning for AUTHENTIC German/Bavarian style food. I am glad to have read the reviews on here and am hopeful people will read this and have the same type of experience. Also be prepared to share a table with someone, we did and it was a good experience. It's loud, but an enjoyable place to feast on amazing food
author: Adrienne T.

description: Been coming here for years!! Love this place! I recommend going when they first open or be prepared for a wait. But it is totally worth it! Meatloaf is a must try!
author: Ryan M.

description: So much to love about this place, the crowds do not deter me. The beer- tenders are fast and friendly even with the undecided folks. Have had a great meal every single time I eat there. (As opposed to just swilling beer.) If you're thinking German food is boring or tasteless, you will be proven wrong!
author: Nora M.

description:
German Heaven

I can not believe that I have not made it to Suppenkuche yet. Always mean to.
Got there early, before 6pm - they sat us right away. We chatted, ordered drinks and then food all in a timely manner.

Ordered the steak special and honestly have been craving that taste ever since. Friend got the schnitzel. Pancakes, Kraut and Spaetzle as sides, mmmm.  Both of us used to live with German families and agreed - this is the place to get your german fix!

 Noone rushed us, everyone that worked there seemed part of a team and all said hello, goodbye and helped if our table needed it. 

Upon leaving the place was PACKED - Like nightclub style! What a scene!
author: AK S.

description: Excellent food. Great gasthaus feel with guests seated together at large tables and a lively bar. A great place to interact with other lovers of good German food.
author: Jack S.

description:
DAS BOOT!  Literally the size of a small child's boot who has super sized calves.  I didn't do it personally but it was equally entertaining to watch the bf race his friend.  Apparently you have to drink toe up to be a man, get that air bubble going.

Food was decent.  Skirt steak was super tender and flavorful.  My potato pancakes were too fried and somewhat bland, applesauce also too cold and sweet.  No ciders offered but the beer mixed drinks are sweet and yummy.

Environment is super crowded.  Our party of 6 had to share a table with random people.
author: Hanna H.

description:
Don't get me wrong, the food here is good (not great, but better than average), and the beer selection is wide

It is very loud and extremely crowded. Service was slow and seemed very impersonal

But the real reason, this place gets one star is that they overcharged my credit card after I left... ran it for more than I authorized after adding on plenty of a tip. A few bucks is not worth fighting over, but dishonesty is not a good business practice
author: Robert F.

description: Really good beers, really good food. What else I suposed to ask for?  This place fits perfect for me. I ate the Venisson Medallions and I loved that - the meat was very soft and tasty.  Also, I liked the sides - the spatzle remembers me when my grandma used to cook that for me when I was a child.
author: Marilia S.

description:
A very resounding MEH... After an hour wait with a round of beers (understandable b/c we came here christmas eve) we were seated at a shared table with some strangers (which was also understandable because it was packed). Then we proceeded to order dinner. When the food came, my wiener schnitzel was dry (crossed the line). A few other friends had complaints about the goose and the bratwurst, but said that the lamb was great.

I guess due to the sheer volume of customers, something had to be sacrificed. The service was still pretty good, they kept us updated on the time, took drink orders, menu item replacements, and everything else fine. The food was just not there that night I guess..
author: Colin H.

description:
We didn't eat here, just came in for a drink, so this review isn't for food. (Although I'll update this review after we eat here... the menu looked good).

- tons of beer choices on tap and in bottles with accurate descriptions of the beer so you don't end up with something unexpected
- draft beer in liter mugs!!! (half liters also available)
- friendly bartenders, not hard to get a beer when crowded
- bartenders will let you taste a beer if you're not sure about it (but don't push it on a busy night... the beers here are all well selected, so it's hard to go wrong if you read the beer menu and know what kinds of beer you like)
- fun atmosphere (both the crowd and the decor)
- nice standing bar
- able to order food off the bar menu
author: Emily C.

description:
After going to Oktoberfest in San Francisco, I was told that I had to come here.  I'm not quite sure what to write that hasn't already been said. Definitely get here an hour before expecting to eat. The place is pretty small but if you find a spot at the bar, you will be set. Half of the bar allows for sitting while the other half is a free for all, stand wherever there is room.  We got here around 5:20 (place opens at 5).  There was already a 45 min wait!  I couldn't believe it.  Good thing we arrived early.  We started at the bar with a couple of beers and the potato pancakes.  The pancakes were super crispy. The apple sauce provided a great sweet flavor.  It's not like your typical apple sauce but maybe that's because it was lightly chilled.  The consistency was a little watery but it did not lack in taste.  I would probably start out with a pretzel next time so that you have a bit more sitting in your stomach while you are waiting.

If you want to make a reservation, make sure you have a large party.  Otherwise, no go.  I really wanted Das Boot but with such a great beer selection, I couldn't settle on one.  

For dinner, we got the Wiener Schnitzel and grilled pork and bratwurst (I believe it was on their special menu).  OMG I could eat this every day!  Everything was tasty and delicious.  The gravy on the grilled pork and dumpling was the best gravy I've had.  I could drink it.  They also provide a small plate of lettuce that looked really plain.  However, the dressing made this "salad" delicious.  I love the sour dressing they used.  We also got a side of the spatzle (German noodles) since I had to try it.  Of course I drenched the spatzle in the gravy and it was mind blowing.  I really wish I had room for dessert.  Next time Suppenkuche!  :)
author: Ken W.

description:
Been back here a few times since my initial review, and it's still really fantastic.

To be honest, I have no idea why it's so popular, and that popularity can... get in the way.  But it is really, really good Bavarian food, and their beer is pretty decent as well.
author: Nils J.

description:
This place is delicious. I think it's better to go here on an off night and enjoy the wonderfulness that is this place. Holy crap, it's just so good but the long wait questions how worth it is....

I loved the beef, loved the venison medallions...loved loved the boots of beer and all the silliness that came with it.

I came here with a group of 5, and it kept changing on whether or not it was 4 or 5 but it worked out in the end and the waitress made sure to get us a table asap! (What a nice birthday present! Really appreciated that!)

I thought the service was good, the ambiance was fun, and the beer got me pleasantly faded.

All in all, definitely one of my new favourites!
author: Lauren S.

description:
Food was delicious! I got the roasted chicken with potato pancakes. I went to heaven with this entree. A friend of mine gave me some of her apple sauce to try with my potato pancakes. I didn't think that those two would work so well, but it did! Portion is huge enough for two people. For dessert, I got the black forest cake, which I thought was a little dry and not so yummy. 

Staff takes a while because they also have to take other people's orders. This place gets pretty loud. I had to yell to people sitting next to me so they can hear me. 

Overall, good experience. Would definitely come back here again and get more of the potato pancakes.
author: Angel S.

description: Suppenkuche is "Das Good". Despite the long lines on a Wednesday or Thursday, we had a fantastic meal and the server was kind enough to put in an order of the extremely delicious pork chops for us before they ran out. Normally German food can seem a bit dark and heavy but the pork chops was one of the best I've had in a while. I also loved the charcuterie platter that kept us from being hungry while waiting for the food. I will highly recommend this place to all my friends. My next goal is to tackle Das Boot by myself. Wish me luck!
author: Kwoky L.

description: Service was great, the food was excellent and the ambiance was a great experience. I will certainly try to come back.
author: Alma L.

description: Very disappointed, We have come here for years, but had not been back for about two. We ordered potato pancakes that were as crisp as potato chips and fried in old oil. No flavor at all. My wife's potato soup was more like ham and bean. My son (who eats everything and has been to Europe) spatzle was in a soupy mix of butter, cheese, sour cream and onions and none of us ate it. My Sauerbraten was not sour, tough, although the red cabbage was super sour to the point of not pleasant. We shared the table with four German students who all kept saying 'This is not how it is in Germany." The beer was good.
author: LH H.

description: This place is AMAZING. The food is great and just like what I had when I was in Germany for the summer. Great selection of beer too! Just all around great place to be. The wait might be long, but it is TOTALLY WORTH IT!
author: Kristina B.

description: Really impressed by the beer list and the food here.  Authentic all around.  The sausages are great along with the lamb dish I had.  The only drawback is the line, but with a place so good, that is to be expected.
author: Virl S.

description:
PROST!  

I have been dying to try Suppenküche forever, but rumors of long waits and a noisy atmosphere deterred me.  An impulse trip on a Sunday night turned out to be the best decision.  Our party of 4 was seated immediately at a communal table (this isn't everyone's cup of tequilla, I know, but the couple at our table was fun...and didnt get mad at me when I drooled over their dessert with lust in my eyes).  I think the crowd was more subdued on a rainy Sunday evening, but trust me the place was jammin' enough.  

Now, I went  to Munich last summer (yeah  yeah, I know...how many people have stated this in the other 1,327 reviews of this place??)  and I have a little bit of a hard time with German cuisine.  I don't eat pork and Germans love their swine so my options are always limited.  I can hang though.  I went with the braised beef dish.  My fellow diners ordered the lamb chops, meatloaf with bacon, and the trout.

The beer selection is phenomenal.  They carry my two favorite Hefeweizens in the world:  Franziskaner and Erdinger.  I enjoyed a vase of each (yes, the smallest beer size here is "vase").  

This is hearty food that will really stick to your bones.  My braised beef was superb.  The dish has a sweet and sour flare with red cabbage accompaniments.  The spätzle (German egg noodle) that came on the side was the best I've had this side of the Atlantic.
