The waiter delivered my friend's trout and as he set it down he said, "You know, this looks over-cooked to me.  If you want to send this back, please let me know."  The trout was pretty charred, so he took the waiter up on his offer.  The next trout came back perfectly cooked.  As a former waitress, I really appreciate that sort of service.  

The atmosphere of this place is pretty rad too.  In comparison to Schroeders which is darker and more traditional, Suppenküche is a more modern, hip scene that still remains loyal its roots.  Imagine a beer hall decorated by Anthropologie.

Come to Suppenküche hungry and thirsty and you will roll out of here sehr glücklich!!!
author: Kerry D.

description:
A friend was in town on a conference and wanted to meet up for dinner on a Monday night. We found this place on yelp and were forwarned about the cramped spaces, close dining quarters, loud atmosphere and large beer selection.
we walked into the restaurant through the curtains that made us think we entered through the back of the restaurant, but we were approached by a nice hostess that will wrote our name down. In the mean time, we waited by the bar with a nice cold beer. The beer selection was quite large, but the bartender was nice enough to give us a sample before we ordered. My friends got the pumpkin Lambic which was on special and I got the raspberry (pumpkin was a little too sour for my taste). About 15 minutes later we were seated at a large table and were sitting directly across from another party. A little awkward in our case since it seemed like the people across from us weren't up to socializing with strangers. the menu is in German with English written under so we had no issues with understanding. We got an appetizer, main dish and dessert to share. All of which came out pretty quickly.

What we tried:
German Ravioli in Mushroom Sauce: The raviolis were stuffed with some kind of meat that I can't remember, but it was very tasty. the raviolis were obviously handmade because each of them looked different. There was a scrumptious mushroom sauce that tasted typical but was good nonetheless. 

Pork Sausage with Mashed Potatoes and Sauerkraut: it came with a hefty three sausages and a scoop of both sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. The sausage itself was quite tasty. The sauerkraut was less pickled then I was used to, and it was a little too soft for my liking. The mashed potatoes were almost a puree, they were very smooth and probably the best part of the meal. 

Apple Strudel: The apple strudel came last and since the three of us shared all the items, we were more then ready for dessert. I'm not much of an apple strudel connoisseur, but i do know when we have hit the jackpot and we probably didn't hit the jackpot here. The strudel was decent, not to die for but definitely on par.  

Pros: 
-Very authentic German feel
-Large beer selection with friendly bartender
-Friendly servers 
-Old school yet innovative seating style

Cons:
-Food only decent
-Very loud, we were constantly yelling (we expected and were prepared for this)
-On the pricey side (it wont break the bank, but definitely not cheap)

If I was to go again, I would probably opt to try more Germanish food like schinizel or spatzle instead of just sausage and mashed potatoes.
author: Betty C.

description: Recently ate here with my boyfriend & I mean I'm all up for trying new things new places and I was really into the whole new food place. So we walk in get seated right away which as I always say it's a good start that way; the tables are community style tables or for larger group which I do not have a problem with we order our drinks we notice thAt it's so loud we can barley here anything but were ok but more and more into trying to talk it was hard to do so one of my reason for my 3 stars! Food we started off with the bread they brought to the table cold and tough is my way in describing ! Then we ordered the pretzel which was great warm and a really good Size then we ordered entrees which I had the pork chop it was cooked perfectly but very plain the server was kind of missing through our dinner! We didn't try dessert because it was so loud we needed to go out! A good try but do not think well be coming back
author: Vianett E.

description:
I have only been to Suppenküche once (so far) but coming from a German family, I can tell you that the food is the most authentic I've had at a German restaurant period. I ordered the Jägerschnitzel and my husband had the meatloaf. The spätzle was to die for, the schnitzel was cooked perfectly, but I will say the meatloaf my husband had was terrific! The food came out in good time, so while we were waiting we chatted with our fellow table mates.
I must say that I didn't think I would like the communal seating, but it really adds to the experience! Great beers, good conversation I have no real complaints. I just love this place.
author: Jessica R.

description: Go here!!!! Great, fun and delicious dining experience!  Long waits (between 30mins to an hour and half) but totally worth it. Try the specials and ask the bartender for beer recommendations if you want to explore German beer! Have fun!!!
author: Sara M.

description:
The wait was long, but the food and drink were so good. It was a friend's bday and yes, we made him get the boot and drink it all by himself.

I had a beer and lemonade concoction which made me adore beer just a little bit more than I usually do. For dinner we ordered a cold cuts plate that when it came out was shaped like a piggy. Cute and delicious. 

For dinner I ordered a healthy portion of lamb and remember it being incredibly yummy. 

I do recommend sharing the boot however. It was so much drink to be had that the bday party was over for the bday boy before we knew it.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I love this traditional German restaurant. It has long tables where random people sit next to each other.
The food is very German too :)
author: S ..

description:
I don't even like beer and I love this place!

So after hearing amazing things about Suppenküche, I finally found time to check this place out. And yeah, I will be back.

Full disclosure: I don't like beer. 

Go ahead, jump to the next review, its not like there aren't enough or everything has been said before. But with that said, this place rocks. I mean two-liter glass boots of beer!?! Are you kidding me!?! That is pretty f***king awesome.  It may not be my drink of choice, but I can respect the boot of beer. Oh, and it comes in "glasses" up to 5 liters. Someday, I will come back with the rowdiest group I can muster and order like multiple 5 liters. Epic.

And a rowdy group of old college buddies/bay-to-breakers teammates seems to be the ideal company for this place. With the comunal tables, and walls that absorb exactly zero sound decimals, Suppenküche basically is designed for a guys night out. Except, for some reason it that wasn't when I went.

Did we come at a weird time? I'm not sure, but whatever happened the place was full of families and little children. Ugh. Nothing ruins an atmosphere for me more that a crying baby or toddler throwing a sh*t fit when I just want to have a nice evening. Minus one star.

But back to the beer. the selection is great. I obviously didn't get to try all of them, but from what I did get, (and sampling from friends' beer at my table), its top notch. Good beer + kick ass sizes = two stars. 

As for the food. I wish I can say it was all amazing, but it seemed more hit and miss. We ordered the potato pancakes since Yelpers have raved about 'em. Not too impressed. They seemed over-cooked to me. 

To be fair, my meal was a win. I ordered the Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes. Perfect. The only critique I can find is with the mashed potatoes. I was raised in Idaho so I know a thing or two about 'em. While they are very good, I've had richer, creamier ones back home. 

The other downside was the Wiener Schnitzel I tried. Again, it didn't blow me away. Maybe I needed more beer in me, but they seemed dry. 

Finally, kudos to the apple strudel. While some people at the table were disappointed that it wasn't "traditional" enough. I didn't really care b/c its amazing. Like I could have ordered another one amazing. 

So, to sum it up, I'd give my experience 3 stars. If the food had better consistency and they banned children, I am sure next time I'd give it a significantly better score.
author: Jeff C.

description: Great beer selection, best German food in the Bay Area.
author: Kevin H.

description: It's the only German restaurant in the city that I will eat at. I won't name names but the other restaurants don't offer tasty veggie options. Suppenkuche offers great veggie options which taste good. Their spatzle is soooo yummy! When I could eat pretzels, I had theirs and they were fantastic. The place has a very cool vibe too.
author: Lisi G.

description:
This place is absolutely fantastic! 

My mom is from Germany and I've flown over there several times, and I love, love, love German food. Of course, on numerous occasions people here in the U.S. will tell us of X German restaurant and claim that their German food is really good-- which 99.9% of the time turns out to be a complete embarrassment to the German culture. 

Anyways, that is not the case with Suppenküche. The atmosphere is cozy and welcoming. There are several wooden tables where the patrons eat together, often sparking interesting and neat conversations with people you would normally never have met (because all the cool people eat at Suppenküche;). Often people will start singing with huge glasses of beer, or rather out of a huge boot(!) The ceiling is always artistically crafted and it's just a really lively place to eat. 

I would recommend getting there right at 5 p.m. when they open. There is often a line of people waiting and it fills up really quickly. If you miss the 5 p.m., then get there around 6:30 because that's when the first wave will start finishing their meals and paying. As for the food, love, love, love the German pancakes! They taste delicious. Also make sure you have it with their homemade applesauce-- I can't get enough of it. I always get the Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und Grünem Salat (Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes & Green Salad), but instead of their green salad, I order their red cabbage. Also, a little dish of their applesauce on the side. It's a pretty large portion and I always feel stuffed afterwards, but in a really fulfilling, I'm-going-to-sleep-well tonight, kinda way. The other food is also delicious. To be frank, we've never had a bad meal. 

The waiters/waitresses are so completely kind. You can tell they enjoy working there and most of them, if not all, speak German. Next time you're in Hayes Valley or in SF, definitely stop by. I've taken numerous friends and family, and it's always been a very positive experience. What's better than great food, great company, and a great atmosphere. I'd drink to that. Prost!
author: Fawn H.

description: Pretty good and hearty German food here in this massively popular Hayes Valley restaurant.  People must realize though that food for Germans is an after thought.  First, second and last is Bier!  Food just helps with the drinking...  Definitely have the venison as you typically cannot find this at many other restaurants in the US.
author: Laurence H.

description:
I went to brunch here on Sunday morning for the first time to celebrate a friend's birthday.   I can't believe it has taken me this long to try this place.  It was nothing but pure delight...good friends, great German food, and a big tasty beer.  

I had the pork sausage with egg skillet (Wurstgeroestel mit Ei) and a very tangy and delicious cucumber salad.  The portions are ample but not huge, which is just fine by me.  I hate taking food away.  Very delicious.

The ambiance is basic with just a touch of artistic edge....nice enough without trying to make a statement.   

The service was excellent.  We had a large group, which I am sure can be frustrating for servers.  But they were friendly and attentive the whole time.   Towards the end, they asked us very nicely to consolidate after a few people left so they could seat more customers.  Understandable. 

I love this place... definitely coming back!
author: Kurt L.

description:
This was my first foray into German food in San Francisco, and I wasn't disappointed. 

Interesting notes: This place is NOT for fat people. After one gets through the door (which is not handicap accessible either), there is about a one-and-a-half foot wide gap between two tables squeezed around the doorway. I have a 30 inch waist and I had to suck in air just to avoid bumping over someone's water when I came in. 
They have a great beer selection (and giant boot-shaped glasses, well, to boot), but unfortunately I was a little under the weather when I came here, so I didn't get to try anything. Definitely something to look forward to next time. 

DO GO HERE: If you like beer, sausages, really tall, skinny german people.

DON'T GO HERE: If you're a vegetarian, hate beer, or are carrying around a few extra pounds.

I am looking forward to going back!
author: Peter F.

description: It was my first time trying German food and let me tell you it was one of the best I've ever had! I had the pork loin with mushroom sauce and spatzle. The pork was tender and the sauce complemented the dish well. I also tried my friend's venison medallions and it was the most tender and flavorful piece of meat I have had. Who knew deer can be so delicious. This place gets really packed for dinner and it is hard to move around in the restaurant since it is small. You are also dining on communal tables so be prepared to sit with people you don't know.
author: Shirley W.

description:
SPATZLE! MEAT! CABBAGE! HO-DI-HI-DEE-HO-DI-LEDERHOSEN!

did i mention Spatzle?
author: Ivy S.

description:
I went here last night. What a great place to eat! LOVE IT!

EVERYONE NEEDS TO TRY THE RED CABBAGE PLATTER!
author: Seth W.

description:
Have you ever had spatzle as good as in Germany? I have and it was here. Great brats as well as the other dishes we tried. Beer selection great and Underburg to finish. 
I was transported back to Europe for a few hours with the communal tables and accents around.
Service was great from the bartender, took great care of us and had a fantastic personality.
Will I be back, hell yes!
author: Alain K.

description:
A girlfriend and I went there at 9:00 on a Sunday night. Let me tell you, it was PACKED. We waited to be seated for about 10 minutes before we decided to just order to go. We stood at the bar talking to the bartender and drinking a beer. The bartender(s) was friendly and talkative and helped the time go by faster.

So just to warn you (as you can see on the website), most everything is in German. We're two Korean girls, so we had to pretty much guess what everything was. We ordered Maultaschen in Pilzrahmsoe (German ravioli with a mushroom sauce) and... something else, I forgot.

The ravioli was perfectly cooked; the dough wasn't too thin or soggy. The mushroom sauce was perfectly creamy, and it complimented well with the herby, textured meat in the ravioli. It had a nice chew to it and didn't completely fall apart in your mouth.

I would definitely go again if the wait is a lot shorter than before :)
author: Becky K.

description:
Went here to try a boot that I've heard so much about. Managed to finish it without any problems. Looks bigger than it actually is. They have a prety nice selection of beers to choose from. 

For dinner I ordered the Maultaschen in Pilzrahmsoße which is German Ravioli filled with Pork and Vegetables served with Mushroom Sauce. It was quite tasty. The ravioli filling was flavorful and juicy (not dry at all) and the the mushroom sauce was great. Not too rich or overpowering.

I will be going back here again to try some of their other dishes.
author: Ajay K.

description:
Dudes. Here's how you win the game: you wake up on Sunday, sun's out, you're in moderate pain, food is of the essence. Suppenkuche is close, but god damn! It's honestly one of the most crowded restaurants in the solar system. Ridiculous. But wait. You find their menu for the day online. They're still open. You call them. Why yes, I would love to pick up food shortly and take it back home so that we may enjoy it languidly and in peace.

The only thing that could have made it more awesome would have been this: before I paid and took my treasure trove of sausage over delicious potatoes with bacon, topped with perfect sunny-side-up eggs, the waitress asked me if I wanted any beer with that. "You mean I can take bottled beer with me? To go?" My knees went a bit weak and I looked at the chalkboard listing more delicious draughts than I could comprehend in that moment. In a truly perfect world, the answer would have been yes. As it stands, the genuinely look of sympathy in her eyes when she realized that she actually couldn't fulfill that dream was enough.

Anyway. It's a bit overpriced, but what do you expect in this neighborhood? Braving the crowds for dinner is worth it from time to time. Come early, bring friends, and drink a boot for heaven's sake.
author: Peter B.

description:
What can I say about my favorite unpronounceably-named German restaurant ever? My South African friends says I need to pronounce it "zoo-pin-koo-keh". I'm not capable of doing that without sounding like a moron. If you read it in english "soup-n'-cooch" doesn't sound appealing either. so this is now known as "my german place in the city". It actually means "soup kitchen" in German.

I am not a huge fan of German food, however I love the non-challenging items such as the Sausage plate and the Wienerschnitzel (the best I've had). Spaetzle and sauerkraut are good too. But the reason I come here, of course, is the beer. They have what seems like 20 imported german beers on tap which cover the whole array of german beer-making. The bartenders, when not ridiculously busy, are EXTREMELY knowledgeable, which is a help for fledgling beer snob wannabes like myself. 

One bonus point goes to their Oktoberfest celebration. The first Sunday of the celebration has a huge party with an accordion player, music, Mas of beer for $3 and "Das Boot" being passed around from person to person.

One more bonus point goes to the decorations and artistic stylings in the place. The cieling decorations are always changing and interesting when you stare up there in a drunken daze. They also make fantastic t-shirts, posters (dont try buying one though!) and I have scored some pretty cool coasters and postcards as well.

I love this place.
author: Tolga E.

description:
I will begin by saying that I loathe (yes, loathe) this establishment. It's kind of a fond loathing, however. 

When I arrive at 4:45 (fifteen minutes before opening), there tends to be a crowd waiting at the door. That's a good thing, in a way. But it's a /symptom/. 

The beer requires almost no comment on my part. It's fresh, it's almost entirely German and highly proven and respectable labels. Hofbräuhaus München is almost invariably represented. 

I have never eaten a not-awesome meal here. Half a roast young chicken stuffed with potato dumpling. Bratkartoffeln with bits of real thick house-sliced bacon. Hangar steak with truffle butter? How can that possibly ever go wrong, since everything touched by truffle butter turns to gold?

The restaurant is just too damned small. Reservations are hard to come by. Frequently the wait for a table is over an hour and I'll give up and to to Fritz. Unfortunately, I'm sure the management has no desire to change, expand, or otherwise alter their approach to doing business. They will make money hand-over-fist whether or not I have the patience to wait around in an incredibly crowded and loud space so that I can then drink eat in the same incredibly crowded and loud space and have considerably less money than when I walked in the door.

Ahh, Suppenküche, how I hate thee, how I love thee. Ich hasse du, Ich liebe dich...
author: Darby H.

description:
As you walk up to Suppenküche you can hear the crowds enjoying their food and the clanking of steins....well, no, not really but I'm sure people inside feel like they're as close to Munich as they can get in San Francisco.

I had only been here one other time for drinks so I was excited to check out the food as I had heard so much about it.  What a surprise that on a Sunday evening around 6:00 pm that it was so busy!  Clearly this is a popular spot with the neighborhood.  We waited about 35 minutes for a seat which wasn't too bad considering the great selection beer they had as well as the affable bartender.

Since it was just two of us, we were seated at a table with 4 others.  That's a pretty common occurrence at Suppenküche so be prepared if you don't like sharing your table space.  The one thing I was really excited to try was the potato pancakes as they're a favorite of mine.  I was slightly disappointed at how fried they were....I'm used to potato pancakes having a bit more potato texture and less fried potato.  The applesauce they were served with was delicious though.  For my main course I had the bacon wrapped meatloaf.  As good as this sounds, I was so unimpressed, I didn't eat it all.  That being said, I should know better than to order meatloaf at a restaurant as I generally only like my Mother's meatloaf

Overall I'd probably not choose to come back here although I wouldn't be averse to coming back if it was with a bigger group.  I'd just set your expectations low for the food and if you're impressed, then you'll be pleasantly surprised.  The beer is definitely worth going to check out and the atmosphere is boisterous and fun.
author: Melanie N.

description:
I am not in the city too often during the night but came here with a few coworkers a few nights back. It's a tiny place so it fills up fast (come early if you want to get a seat) This place reminds me of http://www.yelp.com/biz/gourmet-haus-staudt-gifts-and-cafe-redwood-city but without the mom and pop feel. It's still very good though. They had a dish of braised beef and cabbage. I was just assuming I would dislike the cabbage but I was mistaken. It was actually spectacular. 

The beer selection is pretty good too. Lots of stuff I can't even attempt to pronounce, but ranged from the lightest of pilsners to the darkest schwarzbier.  And they are served in boots and even the 5 liter, you know for when it's been a rough week or just a time to share a large beverage among friends :) Anyways I'm a fan
author: Greg G.

description:
What a fine introduction to German cuisine. 

When I walked in I honestly thought I was going in through the back entrance because once you walk through the door the space is so narrow in between tables. It wasn't the back door, space is just kind of scarce in this place, especially since it was consistently jam packed through out the 3 hours I was there on a Friday. 
Perhaps not for those who have a serious need for personal space. 
The beer was great, my group of 4 tried 4 different beers (one had the beer mixed with lemon soda, which she thought was interesting but in a good way.) 
No one ordered a boot (to my dismay) but the boys drank enough over the 3 hours to have ordered a boot (which is 2 liters.) Plus they have a 5 liter cup (I keep imagining a straw must be necessary) , but I didn't see anyone in the restaurant order that. 
The staff was super friendly. From the host, to the bartender, waitress and bus boy, well...bus man, they were all super nice. 
The tables are, I hear traditionally European, I've never encountered anything like it before though. There were about 8 tables or so, some bigger than others, but if you have a group of 2, they WILL sit you with a group of 4 at a table for 6. This might seem a little weird, but the people we sat next to were really nice, awkwardness did NOT ensue. (Really.) It was an excellent way to chop it up with your neighbors.
Now, my favorite part .... 
The food. Good grief, was it delicious. I had the half chicken & dumpling (which is cooked INSIDE the chicken) and instead of potato pancakes I had spatzle. YUM! Everything was soooo delicious, it's hard to even explain it to you. The chicken was perfect, the dumpling inside was delicious, the spatzle was.. well gone pretty quickly. Others, got the trout & pork chop which they both liked. The portions were really decent. (That means they weren't paltry or obscenely large.)  
Oh! And the decor was adorable. It was really simple and darling, the ceiling was covered in a little tiny hooks that they had butterflies attached to. Very cute.  

Despite the small spaces and crowds everywhere, I adored this place.
Be forewarned, do not come here for a "quiet" evening because while I wouldn't call the bar crowd rowdy, they were loud (and cheerful!)
author: Ashley S.

description:
Fun place to go with a group. Great birthday place if your group is 12 or less. 

Beer in a boot. Frambois beer. Beer in a HUGE 18" tall ceramic mug. Amazing Bavarian style food... total comfort food in my mind. Tasty portabello mushroom for the vegetarians and lots of yummy meat options for the meatatarians. 

Fun ambiance, fun bar. Great service. They take reservations for groups of 6-12, but if you don't have a reservation you will wait, and while you wait you can um, drink at the bar or go to another bar down the street. Worth the wait. Trust.
author: Shannel G.

description:
We have not been here in a long time, but nothing had changed. The place is still super loud with bare-walls echoing 130db of beer hall "atmosphere", while you are being asked to share a table with two other parties, your entrees are served while you are not even halfway done with the starters. Granted the beers are awesome, but for a German dining experience, I would suggest something more mellow like Schröder's or Speisekammer. 
Food was decent. the fried camembert and soup were very good, but the schnitzel was not breaded and also tough. Maultaschen were chewy. 65$: WAY OVERPRICED!! 
Overall, great for a bar, not so great for dining, which already was true 4 years ago.
author: D L.

description: Such a unique restaurant...truly German! It's community seating (you might sit with strangers.) As long as you like the true German foods then you'll this place. It isn't cheap but is definitely worth it! You must try to appetizers too!
author: Brandon G.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night and there was a 1.5 hour wait for a table. The place was very loud and packed inside, so instead of waiting by the bar, we waited outside in the cold. One thing I did not like was the hostess telling us we were next to be seated, but seating 2 other parties before us. I'd rather have her be honest. 

Once we were seated, service was okay. They have a nice selection of beers. My absolute favorite thing on their menu was the potato pancakes! Their salad and meatloaf was tasty. The venison was too gamey for my taste.
author: Jen S.

description: Food was pretty tasty, atmosphere was loud and boisterous, the staff were very friendly and accomodating
author: R C.

description:
Suppenkuche is the best German food I've had in the City, hands down. It's pretty delicious. The schnitzel is so good and so is the wild boar sausage if they have it. I LOVE SPAETZLE.

The apple strudel is yummy too, with rich vanilla bean ice cream. Way better than any of the desserts I've had at other German places. 

It's a cool atmosphere and a great place to go if you're looking for someplace fun, casual and with good hearty food.
author: Abbey S.

description: Make sure you're hungry (and thirsty, if you're up for trying the 1L boot-shaped beer). The portions are hearty and the food is delicious. Picking something can be a (good) challenge, as there's a decent selection of dishes and beer. I wasn't expecting communal seating, so that was a bit weird, but it's okay for the right occasion.
author: Brett B.

description:
Suppenküche is the type of place that I wish was available in every major city. A bar with character, where the food is excellent (and authentic), the beer is flowing and the crowd is lively. I shouldn't be so harsh to the bars of my own city, but its hard not to hold all other bars to the standard that has now been set by Suppenküche.

It should be noted that at 6 o'clock on a Thursday, it was freakin' crowded. People who were not lucky enough to grab a seat at the bar were waiting for up to an hour and a half for a table. This is not where you should go for a quiet night out. This is not where you should go if you want any elbow room.

That being said, I still adored the bar. The bartender, Craig, was one of the most helpful bartenders I've ever met. Not only did he really know the beers he was serving, but he knew how to recommend the beer that you wanted to drink. He was extremely friendly, and happy to have a conversation even as he was being swarmed by hoards of thirsty customers on all sides of the bar. Also, the beer was good. Really good. I don't remember which kinds I had. A pale ale? There was definitely a lager in there... I was not brave enough to tackle the boot of beer. Maybe next time.

We had conversations with all sorts of people from all around the world while we sat and enjoyed our time.I hope I can make it back soon.
author: Becky M.

description: Everytime I eat here I am disappointed. The service was slow and forgetful, friendly at least. My salmon omlet sounded great but was very bland and dry.  All of the meals here are starch and meat heavy, typical of german food I suppose, but there is very little color on anyone's plate. Blech. Go here for a good german beer and a pretzel, skip the meal.
author: Mark S.

description:
I came here based on Jane S's recommendation. Three of us were at a communal table with 3 other people. We came earlier so it wasn't too loud nor crowded. Great number of beers to try and delicious food. 

I came here just for the potato pancakes, because oh how I love potato pancakes! These were definitely on a completely different plane from the IHOP pancakes of my childhood, or potato pancakes from a box, or other such monstrosities as I have once eaten.

I also loved the spaetzle, wienerschnitzel, cabbage salad...and next time must try the "german salad"!
author: Ryan C.

description: Great place to grab a beer and even better place to grab some füd!!
author: Genevieve G.

description:
Louder than loud.

Waiter shouts to be heard.

Diners shout to be heard.

Normal conversations are impossible.

Beer selections good.

Dinner entrée = good.

Restrooms filthy.

Maître d' and waiters allowed a dachshund to run around loose within premises; then denied there was any dog when queried, despite  the fact that it ran between their legs.

Don't need indifference, especially if it is imposed to food preparation, service, etc.
author: Paul T.

description: Warning:  Das Boot -  5 stars if I could say I tasted the food that my native German colleague and foodie claims is amazing.  It was an awesome, high energy, table pounding experience.   Go with a fun group and you will have a night to remember.
author: Loc V.

description:
The wait may be long and the seating arrangement might freak out some of the misanthropes (it's family style seating), but the food will win over anyone.

If you come here for brunch or lunch, prepare to take a long nap after. Between the potato pancakes and the sausages, you won't be sorry you came.
author: Max F.

description:
Delicious German food and beer!
I went with friends for dinner and its a tiny place but worth the wait.
Its great that the bartender and one of the waitresses are married, it makes the atmosphere for home-like and welcoming. 
the service was just great
author: Oana T.

description:
My friends and I joke this is the perfect sort of place to go when you can only get one drink: the boot. 

5 stars because I LOVE this special, special place where upon any visit I know I will enjoy three of my favorite things: quality beer, pork sausage and sauerkraut. If you could only see my smile when I speak of this! 

Hands down, the beer here will rock you. Its the kind of beer experience you fantasized about when you watched Anthony Bourdaine's Prague episode. " It's just good, man!" 

This place has a nice warm feel to it. Depending on the number of your party you may be seated at a communal table with other diners. If you are like me you'll appreciate added variables. 

The food is definitely of the comfort variety with hearty portions and great combinations of sweet, savory and sour flavors. When its on the menu I order the lamb which is excellent. Although, often I devour the sausage and sauerkraut and yes its embarrassing for my dinner companions but they chronically blame it on my recovering vegetarianism. 

From my experience this place is more low key during the day when you can see grandma enjoying a golden pint., I did. Then at night it can get a bit loud, think groups of guys with giant boots of beers, seemingly celebrating their 21st birthdays. -Bless 'em.
author: Jodi R.

description: Holy Taiwanese ghost - went here again and this time we brought some reinforcements to try out their other stuff. This time i managed to stuff my face with their grilled cured pork chop, which tastes like the most amazing ham that is soft, tasty, and buttery.  Wife tried the breaded chicken schnitzle with the spatzle, and if you German loving sauerkraut eating hipsters in the Hayes Valley haven't tried this dish yet, you are missing out. It's like saying you love porn but don't watch Sasha Grey. Others had the Emperor Pancake, and it was very nicely presented- the pancake was served not as a whole, round thing, but all broken and torn up like a twink after an all night rave at the Castro. It was delicious. Someone else had the salmon salt baked omelette (dammit, don't know how to spell this damn word) and from her expressions, it was damn good.
author: Jerry C.

description:
I normally don't care for German food but this place is delicious, and they graciously give you very large portions of their delicious food.

Big tables so you'll sit with other parties, cozy and dark.
author: Lynn B.

description: Delicious meals here. Big too. Be sure to try their desserts, they have only 2 choices though, but OMG, you'll love those!
author: ForgetMeNot B.

description: Beer with banana juice?!  Who knew that combo would be so divine! I'm still in heaven from the pork chop.... days later. Not an ounce of dry meat on that bone!
author: Justin W.

description: The beer and the food were fine but I wasn't really that impressed overall. I guess having been to places similar to this around the country and Europe has made my standards a lot higher nowadays.  The only reason I didn't give it one more star is because of the bad service my date and I received from one of the waitresses.
author: Jova E.

description:
No better place in SF to get your Doppelbock on when you're celebrating the 20th anniversary of German unification!  

Don't feel like actually chewing your food?  This is like bread in a glass.  It's how monks survived fasting during Lent.  I'm serious. That kind of sounds like cheating. I wonder what they did to get around not having sex.  Oh, wait....
author: P J.

description: Long wait, great service, delicious food. I won't be able to add much here that hasn't been said elsewhere, but if you don't grab one of the bazillion options for beer, at least order a dish with spaetzle, because those noodles were dang tasty and perfect counterparts to whatever succulent meat and vegetable pairing. Soup made me feel like home, despite cramming in a table with four other strangers. There's a sense of camaraderie there that makes it alright. Good times.
author: Karen T.

description: I cannot recommend suppenkuche enough. I love this place. Classic german comfort food. The saurbraten and potato pancakes are my favorites. Great place for groups. Huge beer boots to drink from. Don't forget a shot of underberg!
author: Lisa M.

description: I loved the creamed peas and the potato pancakes.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Positives:  The mixed salad, the breads, the soups, beer selection, staff...

Negatives: If there are more than 6 people in the restaurant, it is super loud and nearly impossible tot alk to the folks you came with unless you scream.
author: Heather S.

description:
Authentic German food with a basic design.  Come for the beer stay for the food.

Food:  Hearty German food, perfect to serve family style.  Great selection of German beers.

Service:  Friendly but can be slow when it's busy.

Atmosphere:  Loud, and can get crowded.  You possibly share tables with other parties.
author: Andrew C.

description: What a great and comfortable place! Definitely the spot to meet up with friends, have a great brew, and catch up. The potato pancakes are the bomb! Perfectly fried and crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. I had the grilled pork sausage and bratwurst special. It was very tasty and the sausage was oozing with juiciness. My friend had the grilled cured pork chops and we all couldn't stop picking at his place! Probably the best dish there! Perfectly seasoned, moist inside and crispy outside. So good!
author: Vivian A.

description:
Nothing's better than food. 

Unless it's German food. 
I'm not talking about the heavy, laden meats and starches that you prejudging bastards all THINK that I am talking about. Serious German food is about flavor, method and taste. 

This is where you can get serious German food with authentic atmosphere. In San Francisco. 
I lived in Deutchland for a year, and were I able to be gainfully employed and housed longer, I would be there now. That's right, I'd turn traitor. It's gloriously gorgeous - but most of all, I'd be there to eat. 
Since leaving, I have missed my German favorites like schnitzel, hot sauerkraut and the bountiful salads. No one does a salad up like they do. 
Suppenkuche's got the standbys. Buttery spatzel, flavorful meats and all the fixings, including brown bread and butter. Appetizer of potato pancakes with applesauce - simple, but so right. 

Let's get down to it: dinner. We had a menagerie of chicken schnitzel (which was the one UN-authentic thing - as you rarely see chicken anything in the Deutchland), crispy potatoes, wild boar with mushroom sauce and the star, which is of course what I had; the venison. Tender, buttery venison. This meat wasn't "gamey" at all. No game. None. Served with a cherry wine reduction, hot red sauerkraut and spatzel, this was a seemingly humble dish that delivered sweet, sour, savory scintillation. 

This is a German Traditional place, you will sit at long tables with people you don't know. You will drink beer from a boot bigger than your body. You will eat too much. You will LOVE.
author: Katie W.

description:
Ok, this place is awesome

pros: food, shared table atmosphere (don't come here if you don't want to talk to your neighbors or dont want your neighbors overhearing your conversation). you MUST try the potato pancakes (crispy heaven) and the beer selection, please, try, as many beers as possible!

cons: the wait can be long, get there early on a weekday. other than that, enjoy!
author: Noah P.

description: Masyadong napaka-ingay. Hindi ko marinig ang katabi ko. Masarap naman ang pagkain kaso ung server hindi masyadong mababait. Hindi ka masyadong papansin. Pagkatapos naming kumain, hundi man kang binalot ang natirang pagkain. Sayang!
author: J C.

description: LOVE the fruli (strawberry beer) and grapefruit radler!!!  i also had the salad for the first time last night, and it was delicious...butter lettuce, beets, carrots, potatoes, pickled onions, yum!
author: Helen T.

description:
FUCKING. AWESOME!!!

and by the way, any involvement in the holocaust... bygones
( @ 1:55 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3bObItmxAGc )
author: Thömas F.

description:
Oh man. After visiting here, I am left wondering how I've made it 28 years on this earth without ever trying authentic German cuisine. 

We came in Christmas Eve and were immediately dazzled by the simply stunning Christmas tree on the corner of the bar. The ceiling was adorned with butterflies and disco balls, sounds tacky, but it was one of the most simple, beautiful Christmas displays I've ever seen. 

The mulled wine warmed me all the way down to my toes. It was expectantly strong, perfectly mulled and certain to be a craving on cold days. 

The food was beyond describable. 

We will certainly be adding Suppenkuche into our family Christmas Eve traditions.
author: Heidi S.

description:
I know it's unfair to rant about a place if you don't like the type of food to begin with but I'll try to be as objective as I can with my review of Suppenkuche.

I never really liked German food.  I think it's the sauerkraut.  And I am not a big beer drinker either.  I was going to give Suppenkuche a good review for the festive (sometimes rowdy) ambiance, friendly and fast service and adorable decor BUT their dessert just sealed the deal.  I was hoping for some German chocolate cake but was disappointed with a forgettable black-forest-type cake. 

Been there done that.
author: Jun B.

description:
Oh love at first sight~! Plenty of random overhangs and wall prints right when you walk in... and wooden communal tables! Hooray! 

I had the Kassler vom Grill. It's seriously a huge slab of perfectly cooked ham! Really tasty. Great with mashed potatoes. I really enjoy German fare :) The schnitzel is well fried and well seasoned.

The owner (assumptions again, he sounded German..?) is really apologetic but cordial. He really understands that you've been waiting a long time.
author: Margaret S.

description:
Who wouldn't want to drink a beer the size of their head??

This maintains to be the best German restuarant in San Francisco. I have a very fond spot in my heart for German food, studying abroad for a year in Germany will do that to you!

This is very much traditional german food, this is quite literally the food my German grandma cooks every time my brother and I go home.

Word of caution, this food is HEAVY especially if you enjoy it with 1.5 liter beer. Don't expect to be able to go out dancing after a full meal at Suppenkuche. 

If you enjoy German food with a very german atmosphere you will enjoy this place.
author: Veronica T.

description:
As a vegetarian, I was skeptical about a German restaurant - nothing but sausage, right? Wrong!  Their vegetarian food is SO good.  I had the cheese spatzle - literally the most delicious thing I have ever eaten.  I have dreams about it.

Also, I'm definitely a beer drinker - I love beer and the taste of beer - so I has hesitant to try to Radler (beer + lemon soda).  Why water down beer with soda?  

It was unreal.  So delicious.  So refreshing.  Get the radler.
author: Maggie J.

description:
Decided to grab a late dinner on a Wednesday night and there was still a line! The wait wasn't too bad. They have long tables that are meant for big parties (up to 6 people) so they tend to seat two different parties together. I was part of a party of 3 and shared the table with a couple and later a family of three. Sharing tables and downing some beer made the experience really authentic. I absolutely loved the ambience of the place! 

The food was absolutely amazing. I had the lamb and I have never tasted lamb so good before! The meat was so tender and juicy and it was very well-marinated and very fragrant. Definitely going back to try their duck special!
author: Pauline L.

description:
This place never disappoints. And I'm not even a beer drinker.

May have something to do with the fact that I was partially raised in Germany, but boy, the food here hits the spot every time. The spatzel is nice and doughy, the sauerkraut is always fresh, and nothing beats their wild boar sausage special.
author: Vince L.

description:
Wild boar plus a side order of potato pancakes equals a GREAT foodgasm!

A 5-liter boot of beer (plus a $50 deposit) equals GREAT fun for the entire table!

The HUGE selection of beers equals a GREAT distraction from the ridiculously long wait in line to get a table!
author: Lan H.

description:
Great atmosphere! Delicious food! Lots of BEER! Awesome service!

Gets full pretty quick, so get there early! If it's full when you arrive, have a drink at the bar and WAIT. Believe me, it's worth it!

4.5/5
author: Dee K.

description:
been here twice.  make reservations or it'll be a long wait!

first time, i ordered some typical german meal- think i had the sausages. it was alrite. of course good beer. 
the second time i had the pork chops and the waitress got me a bit worried because she "warned" me it was the typical pork chops...i ordered it anyways and it was DELICIOUS!! it was smoked PERFECTLY. SO DELICIOUS!
author: Janet Y.

description:
Bierrrrr!!!! No, really!...Das boot is the glassware of choice....unfortunately Daphne A. and I arrived for Sunday brunch for our german foodie day, so we voted to go breakfast instead of late night binge-o-rama...

We had a choice of the bar area which is nicely dark but cozy with candles or the communal tables where we watch strangers sit with us and gorge on sausages...the bar it is!

I ordered the divine (Gebratener Semmeknodel mit Zwieblen Ei und Bratkartoffeln) sauteed bread dumplings with 2 sunny side up eggs over a plate of potatoes with smoked bacon, and 2 sausages on the side...OMFG...that was awesome...the runny eggs made the bread dumplings moist and the bacon...T_T tears well up over the awesomeness of the bacon....I bow down to the hog that died for this meal. Daphne A. ordered the (WeiBwurste mit Brezel) white veal and pork sausages in butter broth with a big fresh pretzel....the sausage was soft but she had a hard time cutting the casing...looks like she needs more muscle on her arms.  Let's just say she didn't leave any of the sausage left and she was so full from the soup and pretzel...we had to roll out of our chairs. I would have gone for the dark forest cake, but again, there's only so much room in the belly...next time!

Parking around here is 2 hours around Fell, and there are meters along the street.
author: Pauline L.

description: Even on a Tuesday evening at 7 there was like an hour long wait. [Tip - if you come with a large group of like 6 try to get there earlier and try to get everyone there at the same time - they won't seat partial groups.] Good thing there's good German beer to drink while you wait. Also helps soothe your throat because it's get loud and you'll be shouting a lot. The food is solid. And in some cases sublime - like the meatloaf. So light and fluffy! The spaetzle is good as always but best with cheese as a vegetarian dish rather than plain as a side dish. I have to admit the allure of their spaetzle has gone down just a tiny bit since I made the effort to learn to make it at home (or rather got hubby to learn to make it). They were also nice enough to bring out a slice of black forest birthday cake (no charge!) which was the fluffiest cake I've had. I guess I have a thing for fluffy and Suppenkuche does fluffy well.
author: Jean K.

description:
I think if someone had just told everyone to sing and swing their steins from left to right, we'd have done it and we'd have done it RIGHT!

I don't think I'll ever, ever stop talking about how wonderful everything was at Suppenkuche.  

The potato and split pea soups were amazing.  The ravioli-ike appetizer we had was served with a mushroom sauce that I would bathe in, but only privately.  (Well, unless you paid me A LOT).  

The skirt steak special melted in your mouth.  The roasted half-chicken special was enough food for the entire table, and delicious to boot.  The venison was delightful, the red cabbage with it divine.  It was as though someone came down from on high and said "This meal must be a blessed, blessed event!"  

And so it was.

Fantastic beer selection (my preference was the hefeweizen that ends "Dunkel").  And just when I thought I would have to be removed on a stretcher because I'd actually INJURED myself I'd eaten so much, along came Underberg.  Underberg (just say "oonterberk" to be extra German) is an medicinal, alcoholic, HEALING beverage that I had the pleasure of coming to know at the end of the meal.  Our server was kind enough to tell us how to drink it properly, and then show us how.  Twice.  He did two "shots" with us - and for that we loved him even more than we thought we could have.  

Top-notch food, great service (thank you JOHN), outstanding atmosphere, easy-to-get-to location.  Ich liebe dich, Suppenkuche!
author: Evan G.

description: Lovely little place. Very homey. We have lived in Germany  and so we know exactly how the locals like it. The food is exactly like that here. We had the Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst,Wiener Schnitzel and Jägerschnitzel.  Polished off with Black forest cake. Everything was perfect.
author: Joy D.

description: Probably the best German restaurant on the west coast. Great selection of beers and can't say I've had any dish that I didn't like there. Beer hall type atmosphere. It's ALWAYS busy yet the wait-staff takes care of everyone well! Highly recommended.
author: Rajiv P.

description: This place served a nice brunch when I came with a couple friends.  We sat at a bench with a bunch of other people, which made for a loud and lively morning.  I've come for dinner twice, and I think I had the potato pancake both times (I'm not a big meat eater, but my date was).  The food is of course very meat and potatoes and drinks focus on beer, but I had nice german wines both times at dinner.  Another time I came with my brother to hang out at the bar, which was fun because he loves beer and he tried a couple of them.  This is a loud place, fun with friends, definitely not a place to bring a date that you want to get to know well unless he or she has a very loud voice and doesn't mind raising it.
author: Andrea T.

description: I was pleasantly surprised when I walked into suppenkuche and smelled the incredible aroma of German beer and weiner snitzel. The tables are wooden, like a typical European pub, and the menu gives you the option to order huge kegs of beer. We ordered the bacon wrapped chicken loaf with an egg on top, which sounds very rich, and flavorful which is exactly what it was. Although it was very salty, the chicken's sweetness evened it out. We also ordered the breaded veal, which was surprisingly light and tasty. however, the noise level at suppenkuche was a bit too loud for me. the sound of chattering people bounces off of the wooden walls and creates a very loud atmosphere. But, if you enjoy great German food and don't mind a bit of yelling to get a message across the table, I would say suppenkuche is a good choice for you!
author: Grace S.

description:
So I thought Schnitzelhaus Restaurant on 9th St had the best GERMAN food in town, but I thought wrong! and Schnitzelhaus is no longer open for business! Suppenkuche is a great place to meet your friends for dinner and BEER. They do not take reservations and many groups come in parties of 4+ so come before the crowd or expect to wait at least 45 min. 
They do have a bar that you can wait around at. 
Our party shared a large PRETZEL and each person ordered an entree. No DasBoots at our table but it was exciting to see others carrying them in their hands. 
I had the porkchop w/ mash potatoes and sauerkraut. I thought it was cooked perfectly but it was very salty. I would go for the weiner- schnitzel (crispy breaded porkloin) for next time. The waiters work hard and are very attentive. I am not sure how they maneuver so quickly in that crowded space. Lots of laughter and fun!
author: Oanh N.

description:
Heard good things about this place so my BF and I came to check it out. We showed up at 4:30p and the line of people to get into the place started just after we showed up. 

The seating in this place is very 'cozy' and you will soon meet some new people they sit at your table with you. We got to meet a great old woman who was from Munich and she talked to us about food, beer and her homeland. 

We ordered a boot to start and that was EPIC. For an appetizer we ordered bacon wrapped asparagus (which was to die for), then a half chicken stuffed with a dumpling and potato pancakes (absolutely delish!), then finished it off with apple strudel and ice cream.

This place definetly surpassed my expectations and Im sure we will be back :)

Just make sure to show up early on the weekend cause this place is popular.
author: R. F.

description:
Hearty good food and great beer in really big boots. You can't get better that this! For those weak-ones (me included) they have mini-boots full of beer! 

The Spaetzle (German pasta) was tasty, and highly recommend! All in all the food was great as well. 

The venue is a bit small, and can get noisy, but that's what you get when you combine big boots of beer (or small boots for me!) and adults.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Great, great, great German food. Lots of great beers. It was quite busy when we were there, so service wasn't spectacular. However, our server knew his German beers and was very helpful. If you are not used to it, just to warn you, they sit multiple groups at one large table. Typical of some urban restaurants. Great pretzels! I had the trout. Fantastischen!
author: Chrissy T.

description:
This place gets BUSY! 

Really good food. Everyone in my party enjoyed their food. From Salmon to pork schnitzel. I don't know if you can miss with this place.

However, this spot really is a place to drink. Great variety of German beers. Also, because its so small and people tend to hang out and drink at their tables after they eat its hard to get a table for food. So have the expectation going in. You can always try and sit by the bar and eat food there...
author: Mike I.

description:
Hey guys, it's 2010; where's your wheelchair access?

Yes, I know they have a wooden ramp. 
The Suppenkuche matradee that evening was standing on the sidewalk in front and used his walkie-talkie to call for the ramp to be brought out...
I was checking out the posted menu with my companion and then I got into a ready-to-use-the-ramp position.  [please look at my  YELP photo, look at my wheelchair]
They placed the ramp down; I looked at it, I looked at them, I looked at my friend. 
I shook my head and told them, "I cannot use that."  
I have a motorized wheelchair which I drive.
To use their ramp, which has a very steep incline and is too short, I would need to backup, rev-up and drive up the ramp AND then, I would immediately bump into the SECOND door threshold with NO WAY to get up it and into the restaurant!
author: Corinne d.

description:
wow!
ok, so I went here for a bday dinner. I didn't know I was invited until after I had an enourmous lunch...big mistake!
I had a salad because I was waaaaaay too full. I ended up having a bite of everyone else's plates, good move!
My salad was super delicious, butter lettuce with beats, so flavorful, mmmm
The stake was PERFECT! wow, the taste was quiet, but oh so good. It was perfectly cooked, the texture and color, mmmmm
The salmon was really really good too, and I am not a big fan of salmon. The lamb was also very yummy. 
I had wine because I am gluten-intolerant, they have a decent selection. If you can drink beer, then you must have some, its a German restaurant!!! If you are man enough, then get the 2 gallon boot, yea, get some hair on your chest....
The atmosphere was simple, wooden tables, dark walls and lots of people, get there early and make reservations if possible.
author: Rocio S.

description:
What can I say that has not already been said.  We went here based on reviews during a SF trip and were very very very pleased.  Seated immediately since we went in at 530pm, soon after opening, and by the time we were done eating, the wait was 1.5 hrs.  

The food was excellent.  I had a delicious jagerschnitzel, and my wife had a super moist roast chicken filled with stuffing and potato pancakes. Appetizers of asparagus wrapped in bacon with boiled potato, and bread dumpling in mushroom sauce were flavorful and delicious as well.  Potato soup was thick and tasty.  Service was fast and very friendly.  Apple streudel was very good as well.  One of the best german meals I have ever had anywhere.  Also, at $80 for all that for the two of us, I found it very well priced.  Superlative.
author: A. L.

description:
With over 2,000 reviews, there's no need to divulge every detail that someone else has probably mentioned. So, my quick tips are:

+ Bring friends. While a bit cozy, this place can surprisingly accomodate group sizes pretty well.

+ Order beer early because there will always be a wait

+ Get the Spätzle. Many dishes include it, but order get it on the side if it doesn't. This egg noodle goodness puts American mac n' cheese to shame.
author: Phuong M.

description:
shopencooch. soupandchooch? sup an' cook? oooohhhhh Suppenkuche. However your inviter says it.  Don't question them. Just go.  

I downed a plate of potatoes and meatloaf like my mama had made it.
The atmosphere only furthers the sensation of a cozy homemade hometown friends and family joint even more. The staff tops it off.
author: L P.

description: The food was good, but the service was disappointing and killed the experience for me.  My party of two got there on the late side, around 9:30. The place was packed, but we were able to get seated. The wait staff rushed the entire meal. When we got the check, despite not asking for it b/c we weren't done, the waiter came by three times to see if we were ready. Then, another waiter came over and began taking the candle and salt/pepper away. Rude. Why seat us if we can't be allowed to enjoy out meal?
author: Pam F.

description: Seriously great German food and great prices on beer. The seating is a tad awkward since its communal seating without the typical German longtables.
author: Dustin W.

description:
My friends and I (there were 3 of us) were really excited about this place. We put our names on the list, waited for an hour and half, and finally the hostess told us she would seat us in 10 to 15 minutes. Yay! It was crowded, so she asked if we minded waiting outside and she'd come get us.

Twenty minutes goes by, then thirty, and we come back inside to find out how much longer she thought it would be, only to find her seating not 1 but 2 of the parties who came in right after we did. Both were parties of three, so it wasn't because they were smaller than we were or larger than we were. 

But we're pretty easy going people, so we didn't think much of it at the time. We just waited to talk to her to find out if we'd be seated soon as well.

She saw us, made eye contact with me, turned bright red and then deliberately turned her back on us - ignored my friend when he tried to get her attention - and started flipping through her list of names. Again and again. She then walked right past us to talk to a couple who had just come through the door and were waiting behind us (who made a loud stink about having to wait an hour and a half, but ultimately decided to put themselves on the waitlist) and then she finally deigned to speak to us only when a waiter knocked into her and she turned to smile at him and wound up facing us. I kid you not. She tried THAT hard to ignore us. It was weird.

She told us she didn't have any tables available. When I asked how long it would be, she said about half an hour. I have been a hostess, so I know how hard it is, and I had absolutely no tone or attitude when I mentioned that she'd said it would only be ten minutes nearly half an hour before that and did she have any better idea of how long it would be at this point.

This is the part that pisses me off: the hostess snapped at me (SNAPPED at me) that she didn't know how long people would sit around at a table once they'd paid.

A) She'd given our table away, obviously.
B) She didn't have the decency to own up to it.
C) She treated me like dirt when I asked how much longer she thought it would be. A question it is part of HER JOB to answer.

Dear Suppenkuche, people are pretty easy going in SF. This isn't NYC. If you make a mistake, like giving away someone's table, just offer the customer a free beer to make up for it. Seriously. We would have been FINE. Instead, you treated us like crap. If I could give you zero stars for service alone, I would.
author: Kaitlin H.

description:
Attended a friend's birthday event here and thoroughly enjoyed everything from das boot to my delicious sauerbraten.  Sauerbraten is my go-to German dish for a new restaurant and they cooked it to perfection.  And don't take my word for it, this place is never empty.  I can say with some certainty that's it's a wee bit popular.

DO: Eat and drink beer with five of your friends so you can make a reservation.  If you try to go without, you will wait for over an hour (I almost guarantee it).
author: P D.

description: I absolutely loved the beer and food!! The restaurant is a bit cramped and it gets super packed, but the food is so delicious, the claustrophobia is worth it.
author: Magdalena G.

description:
Ok, totally charming atmosphere, totally nom-lishus food, and amazing German beer selection!!! 

It probably didn't hurt that I had a rather awesome and charming date with me, but I really did enjoy my experience at Suppenküche.

She had the Jaegerschnitzel w/ Spaetzle, and I had the...well, it was Cornish Game Hen stuffed with bread dumpling (can't remember the German name for this ,sadly) which was positively out of this world. Everything was cooked to perfection, the flavors were rich and delicious, and the beers paired with these dishes were just wonderful.

If you like some hearty, comfort type food, and love a good German beer - then I highly suggest making your way to Suppenküche. The staff was friendly and helpful, and the overall experience was definitely a great one. 

Highlight of the evening was watching a guy whose birthday it was be carried out from one too many beers...classic!
author: Marco M.

description:
I love this place!!!! My husband & I were visiting San Francisco for the first time & while on a wine tour earlier that day one of the local girls we met suggested this place. I must mention that it was our 10 year wedding anniversary & we had already spent the day wine tasting, which was Amazing, but we're definitely more beer drinkers, so this seemed right up our alley.

Anyways, when we walked in it was very busy & the hostess let us know it would be a 45 minute wait. We decided to head to the bar & order drinks. The bartender named Craig was so nice & helpful. He gave us beer suggestions & food suggestions. As soon as a seating area near the bar opened up he moved our food over here so we could sit down & eat. Let me tell you, that I thought we had already had a great day, but this was the cherry on top!! We ended up staying for hours, trying good food, & so many good beers! Craig was so much fun & he gave us not only Amazing service but great beer suggestions. I called him the "beer whisperer" because he knew exactly what we wanted. My husband is not one to care about or make a big deal about customer service & even he couldn't get over how awesome our bartender was! He loved this place!!! I hope Craig reads this one day, because I want to say Thank you. You made our night so fun & it was our best Anniversary to date!!!! Hopefully we get to visit San Fran soon, because I can't wait to go back to this place!!!!
author: Marie E.

description: Great place for beer and sausages but is not place for a dinner where you want to converse with your significant other.  This place is so popular, crowded and noise filled that it was hard to hold a conversation without amplifying your voice. Probably, have to time your arrival to avoid peak hours.
author: Robert M.

description:
can you say SPAETZLE?! OMG! I had spaetzle for the first time and it was so good. It tastes like pasta tossed in butter. Any Carbivore would love spaetzle. =P MMM! 

The restaurant is small and you share a bench/table with other parties. I ordered the bratwurst plate and it tasted like...bratwurst.  I think the spaetzle won my heart over that the bratwurst didn't get enough love. Although I'm not the biggest fan of sauerkraut, I enjoyed theirs. It had pieces of salty ham in it, which balanced out the sour flavor. I'd definitely come back and try more of their food. If you don't mind the really loud atmosphere, you'll enjoy yourself here! 

Downside is it can be a long wait. I think it's worth the wait. Enjoy!
author: Jillian B.

description:
I'm reminiscing from my visit a year ago, and really missing Suppenkuche. It's a great place to hit up friends in the city for brunch. 

I say go! You say eat! Go, eat! Go, eat! :-p
author: Snowmagnolias M.

description:
One thing to say: The pork knuckle special. . . .but I should have asked the server not to toss the two pieces of perfectly crackly skin that I left on the side when she packed up my leftovers.

My partner in dining was so happy about his bitburger beer, which two other patrons were happily drinking out of the giant bootshaped glasses . . .
Delicious and Happy atmosphere. And the price is good too for the whopping amount of quality food you get!
author: Summer L.

description:
oh suppenkuche, let me count the ways i love you! 
I had been to suppenkuche a few times before and always had a great time, but this review is specifically related to a recent visit. 

I was planning a party for 15 ppl for my best friend's 30th and trying to figure out where on earth could I get 15 guys to get together, sit down, and somewhat behave for 2 hours to have dinner? 

Suppenkuche! 

The staff here was great when I called to make my reservation, and even nicer when I had to call 45 more times to modify the numbers. They seated us staggered , as of course some of my friends were running late, they did a great job with the birthday cakes I brought, and our server was just generally awesome and accommodating! It is one thing to be pleasant and accommodating when you have a sober-ish group of 4, but to continue this level of service and hospitality when you have a group of 15? Whole different story.

Service, food, and beer was great and Suppenkuche is now one of my gotos for planning large dinner events with friends.

Thanks!
author: LeeAnne T.

description: Everything about this place screams germany. Unfinished wood tables, unpretentious art all around, big steins of beer and authentic german food. I love coming here, but I don't go often because it's so hard to get a table. Usually an hour wait at least. And drinking at the bar is a bummer because its so crowded. Open a second location!
author: Daniel B.

description:
I've eaten lots of German food. But I've never had *good* German food. In fact, I wrote a review a few days ago that claimed, "I hate German food." One meal at Suppenküche and I'm a changed woman!

My party of 6 arrived to find our spots saved at the communal tables next to a fun group of people who were a few steps ahead of us in their meal and quick to offer tips on what we should order, which was great. I have never eaten at a place with this style of seating and I thought it was a lotta fun!

We ordered beers. Giant beers. Suppenküche has a pretty decent selection of German beers and wine and they don't mess around when serving them to you. My only complaint about huge quantities of beer is that it seems to get warm too quickly. And I like really cold beer. But, it still did the trick.

We started off with potato pancakes (my favorite!) dipped in applesauce and fried balls of cheese. Both amazing. I ordered Goulash for my entree. Moist, tender chunks of meat swimming in delicious gravy with veggies. I may or may not have admitted that it was better even that that made by my German grandmother. I hope she doesn't read my Yelp reviews...
author: Kay T.

description:
I hate reviewing places with over 1,000 reviews.  I mean, I doubt I'll add anything unique and special for whoever reads this... so I'll just hit all the points you have to for a place like this:

1.  GET A RESERVATION.  We didnt.  THinking we could "fool the system", we had one party member show up at 7, in the hopes of having a table by 8.  At 830, they told us it would be 20 more minutes so we started drinking.  i don't think we sat down before 9-930.

2.  GET A BOOT! i don't want to hear it.  I don't care if it looks big.  I don't care if you're worried about the $50 deposit.  And I definately don't care if you're worried that it'll get warm because you drink too slow.  just do it.  DAS BOOT!

3. Get the potato pancakes.  We got em for free (since we waited like 50 years), but i'd reccomend them to anyone.  Very tasty, and an excellent appetizer.

4.  get another pint after the boot.  Ok this one is optional, and you'll probably hate yourself for doing it (i did), but goddamn i needed SOMETHING to wash down those sausage!  

5. The food is good, not great.  If you drink a boot before your meal (as reccomended...) it'll be great.  Why? Cause that's how german people eat their food.  Drunk.


All in all? Suppenkuche is a GREAT place to get drunk, and a good place to eat. woohoo!
author: Joseph F.

description:
Considering this is the only german place I know of in the city, it automatically gets 5 stars. Yes, it lives up to it.  Pretty much every time I've been here for dinner its been packed.  We're always seated next to huge birthday parties with "colorful" conversation.  Its always a fun time and the staff makes it even more enjoyable. 

The space is very simple, but some how manages to have a huge amount of charm.  I always leave feeling warm and like I need to put on some sweatpants.

Only recently did I learn that they have brunch,  this. blew my mind.

Dinner: The potato pancakes are more than enough to keep anyone satisfied, but if you need more the weiner schnitzel is pretty awesome.  If you feel like getting wasted go for the Boot of beer.

Brunch:  Brandon and Keith had the Emperors pancake special, which involved a lot of bananas and nutella.  It was AMAZABALLS.  I had a breakfast dumpling with an egg on top which was also AMAZABALLS.  This was also the first time we had walked in and been seated immediately, so I'm a bit angry with myself for writing this review.
author: jessica b.

description: I've been to Germany and ever since, I'm always comparing German restaurants to what I had when I was there. The Weinerschnitzel with bratkartoffeln was amazing, even when I heated up the leftovers the following morning. My friend had the Käsespätzle which was almost exactly the same as when I had it in Germany. The German beer selection was also very diverse, something for everyone. Overall a great experience and will definitley be back next time I'm in San Francisco
author: Tim C.

description:
This is a neat little place, just far enough off the beaten path to be considered a small locals only place.  

Drinks - A lot of different choices and all are well worth the prices.  From the smallest pint to the biggest boot, you will be happy with your beer.  Wine is available, but I did not partake.

Food - Amazing.  I went with the potato soup which was steaming hot and delicious.  Sort of a mix of potato with possibly a hint of cheddar and some garlic.  On a cold rainy night it was perfect.  Followed up with Jagerschnitzel which was beyond tasty.  Meat was cooked to perfection with a delicious mushroom gravy.  Not a dark brown gravy, but a very light gravy.  Unfortunately no room for dessert.

Ambience - Plan on sharing with strangers unless you go in a large group.  Family style seating throughout.  It is a neat experience.

Noise - Gets very loud.  So if you are planning on an intimate setting, you may want to consider an alternate location.

Bar- Small area dead center of the room, so you have to work your way past the tables to get there, but still a cool little bar.

Service - This one is a downer.  Friendly staff, quick seating, but don't expect a whole lot of attention since the place is so busy.  They are attentive, but do take a while to come around.  They will not split a check either even if you ask before hand.  Still ok though.

In the end a neat experience with some great food and drinks.
author: David C.

description: Had reservations but weren't seated for over 30 minutes after our reservation. We were seated in the back, and it was very loud. Not a lot of space, but the food was excellent.
author: Joe L.

description: My favorite place for German food in San Francisco.  I alway get the Wiener Schnitzel which comes with this amazing butter lettuce salad and potatoes.  The pork chop is good too. The beer never disappoints since they have a good selection on tap.
author: Kerry F.

description: One of my favorites! Its modern folk style has definite appeal, and the food is great. Try the spaetzle!
author: Jake R.

description:
My girlfriend and I went to the weekend brunch and really enjoyed ourselves, in spite of the fact that the place was packed and the wait staff was slammed. We had the organic chicken schnitzel, which came with a tasty cucumber salad and mashed potatoes, and the berry pancakes, which came with a very yummy compote and apple sauce. The sides were as delicious as the main courses. 

We also had two rounds of beers. If you are into German, Austrian, and Belgian beers, you will looove their draft and bottle selections. The only negative was that we wanted a side of over easy eggs to put on our schnitzel and the order got lost in the shuffle. 

We paid $70 including tip, which is a little high for two at brunch, but we really felt it was worth it considering how delicious things everything was. Definitely recommend it!
author: Byrne B.

description:
To my dad San Francisco is basically the Disneyland of food.  He lives in Miami where there isn't such a wide variety of cuisines so he usually comes with a list of things he wants to try. This time it was Burmese and venison. When we searched 'venison' in yelp, Suppenküche came up so we headed their way with low expectations - I wasn't THRILLED about the idea of eating Bambi. 
I was sold from the moment we stepped in.  The place is so effortlessly cool, I absolutely fell in love with the decor.  I wish they took reservations, but apparently they only do so for groups of 6 or more.  The wait wasn't that long though - about half an hour which we spent at the bar drinking beer and enjoying an array of cured meats. 
I didn't know that they were communal tables since they aren't that large, but we were seated in a table with four other people which felt a tad bit crammed but we made it work.  I think it would be a good idea to ask patrons if they mind sharing a table or would rather wait for their own - especially when you are dining with the parents. Sometimes you want a little more privacy. 
The menu was FANTASTIC, at least for a meatatarian it was. WOW, I wish I could have gotten one of each! Everything sounded delicious.  My dad obviously had the venison which was good but nothing out of this world, my husband had the goose which was ridiculously good, my mom some other meat thing that was really good, and I had the meatloaf which I am head-over-heels in love with.  
I will definitively be back for buckets of beer and meat soon.
author: Mrs. G.

description:
This is the best authentic German restaurant I have ever been to outside of Germany. 

My favorite is their 'Spaetzle' noodle dish. Make sure you ask for Spaetzle as a side if your main dish doesn't include it already. 

Great place to go to anytime. We usually always go there before the Symphony (just 3-4 blocks away). 

the only drawback is that there is no noise canceling padding anywhere, meaning it gets very loud and can be hard to have a good conversation..
author: Chris K.

description: My favorite restaurant in the city. Period. ALWAYS delicious, always fun and always memorable.
author: Meredith M.

description: Finally an authentic German restaurant on the west coast. From the historic theme, to delicious dishes, this place is hands down one of the best places to try in San Fran.  Unfortunately, the place is pretty small and can get very packed since the hours of operation are a bit exclusive.
author: Bob P.

description:
Went there for Oktoberfest!

Such good food....

So in love with Oktoberfest beer "Paulaner Oktoberfest-Märzen" - my favorite!! So good...

Loved the giant pretzel that was bigger than my head, and all the authentic german food. The sauerkraut was really good. 

Love the atmosphere here - it's like you're in Germany without having to travel. Highly recommend....
author: Will W.

description:
Went here for a beer with an old friend that is friends with everyone there (that doesn't hurt ;))... had a great time, what a neat concept and a time tested thoroughbred.

We had already eaten dinner at a nearby korean spot (Arang-check them out too, about to Yelp about them) so we were only interested in drinking but I snuck in a taste of the red cabbage (inspiring, reminds me of what my grandmother makes (and shes German).  Great selection of smaller, less well known German beers (dont remember which I had but it was great!).

Pros: cool atmosphere, great patrons, beautiful art installations and the Manager's brother, a artist/graphic designer has designed so many cool logos, t-shirts and pieces for the restaurant

Cons: It was pretty busy... and it was a Wednesday night... wouldn't want to try to go there on a weekend (not too bad of a "con" if you ask me).

Check it out!
author: Niko P.

description:
I love this place. It's loud, so not the joint for a relaxing dinner or romantic date. Its a place to eat great food, knock back great beers, and have a plain good time!
 
Always enjoy joking around with new people at the communal tables. Best German food in the city!
author: Natty C.

description: Get the currywurst and potato pancakes, you will not regret it for the rest of your life. If you have a chance to go there for brunch, you should go, because the basket of rolls will make you question any other roll you've had.  Get beer too because WHEN IN ROME.
author: Linda L.

description:
The world needs more beer halls.  Something about sitting down with a giant stein of Hacker-Pschorr and a giant plate of bratwurst and sauerkraut is really enjoyable.  Suppenkuche nails it, with a great selection of German beers on tap and pretty typical (which is to say delicious and filling) German food on the menu.

It didn't turn out to be the rowdy mug-clinking, beer-spilling Hoffbrau House West experience I was expecting, which ended up being a good thing.  This place is a little bit more polished and subtle than that, even if they do have 2L bief stiefels.  Think groups of friends, unpolished wooden tables and benches, and tasteful art on the walls.  It's the kind of place where I'd actually feel bad about spilling beer on the floor.  On the other end of the spectrum, they do have a 5L (!) mass that you can get for $60 (!!) which makes for an adventurous evening.
author: Ted B.

description:
You can't go wrong with this place! Really!
