Whether its brunch or dinner, whether its just a casual get together, a celebration or an all out party, whether its just you, or two or a posse... each and every time is a great time here! They are great for groups.

And the concept of community dining (you share the table with other folks) is just great and takes me back to India.

BRUNCH RECOMMENDS (all are quite filling):
- Musli is a winner each time
- Cured Gravlox is simple (how German) but filling
- Cucumber Salad side is always a good idea to get
- Potatoes and Bacon will appeal to the spud lovers amongst us
- Sauteed Bavarian Meatloaf is my staple every time I come here
- Emperor's Pancake is AMAZING and makes you wonder "why IHOP then?"
- Sauteed German Ravioli you have to try just for the fact that its a different spin on traditional Ravioli
- Coffee in their humongous mugs is awesome!

DINNER RECOMMENDS (all are quite filling):
- Lentil Soup is simple yet tasty
- Mixed German Salad is always welcome
- Breaded and Sauteed Pork Loin is my all time favorite, especially if you like pork loin
- Cured Pork Chop... refer to above
- Grilled Pork Sausage is another nice addition
- Beer... its a German place, folks. They DO beer!!
- Wine they have a good selection but its the beer that you go here for

I've gone here for brunch, birthday celebrations, wedding celebrations, dinners, some by myself, some with friends and some with a group and no complaints to date. Staff is great! Crowd is so friendly and laid back.

Can be a bit of a wait for both brunch and dinner but hey! the end goal is you will be satisfied, satiated, copacetic, in a food coma, probably made some friends with the folks at your table and you'll walk out wanting to come back for more.
author: Amit S.

description: Best service! Excellent food! Cleanest restrooms in town! Greatest beers!
author: L T.

description:
What the whaaaaaaaaaat.

So, I have never eaten German food before. I've never been to Germany, nor have I watched fellow diners drink a 3 liter glass of beer. I feel like I've crossed two out of three of the above off of my list.

What to say about Suppenkuche? First of all, I know it's totally immature of me, but the name makes me giggle. Secondly, I have been told that when I'm eating something I really like, I tend to look angry. I must have looked FURIOUS at Suppenkuch because my meal was A. MA. ZING.

I decided to start simple since it was my first German meal. I went for the bratwurst with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. I ate EVERYTHING on my plate. This usually does not happen. But once I started eating, I could not stop. The bratwurst was so flavorful and juicy and stayed nice and warm the entire time. The mashed potatoes are not your run of the mill fare. They were excellently prepared and went fabulously with the bratwurst and sauerkraut.

Omg, writing this review is causing me to salivate.

The staff! Our waitress was really great. She didn't judge my ordering style... which consisted of me pointing at my desired menu selection and saying "can I have this one."

I can't wait to come back to Suppenkuche. The good food, family style seating and welcoming atmosphere made for a comfortable and satisfying dining experience.
author: Tatiana J.

description:
I love this place, have been going here since it opened and am never dissappointed. German food doesn't get the respect it deserves among other European culinary traditions!

I had my first date with my wife at this place...what more can I say, we're married now.

The food is always delicious, the service is always great and the beer, well, don't get me started.

Go to Suppenkuche!
author: Marc T.

description:
Beer out of Boots! That novelty never gets old.
Delicious German Food?  That never gets old, either.
My weiner schnitzel was nothing remarkable, but everyone else in my party was raving about their dishes, so they must be doing something right.  

Service was prompt, even during the Saturday Night Dinner Rush with a party of seven.
author: Emily P.

description:
Make a reservation in advance.  This food is worth it.  

Get yourself a ride here because the boot is going to be your beer scooter all the way home.  

If you seek German in SF, this place takes the spaetzle.
author: betty b.

description:
I came to this restaurant with very high expectations - and I'm sad to say that it was just "a-ok." First of all - I think it's rather ridiculous that they only take reservations at 6 or 8 pm. Nothing between! 

Anyway, I ordered their version of a cheese gnocchi and it was quite delicious, but very heavy. I also don't really like feeling heavy after a meal, and I can assure you - all of us were feeling quite stuffed and heavy.

The beer selection looked great and the boot looks fun (and dangerous) to try.

Nonetheless, I heard that brunch time is great! (I came during dinner time), so maybe I'll come back for Sunday brunch someday.
author: Christina C.

description:
I'm assuming this place is a winner if I went for the beer with a loud, large, fun group that would distract me from really analyzing the tastiness of the food and the other people seated at the end of my table.

On Mother's Day for brunch, we were immediately seated and quickly served a basket of bread (so soft, so crunchy mmmm). Our waiter was a bit slow, but since he's oh so cutely German and very nice, I forgive him. 

The couple at the end of our 6 seater table left and soon enough a family of 4 moved in to take their place. This really isn't Suppen's fault, but boy, was the father obnoxious. His teeny daughter couldn't move up to the table and refused a booster seat so he shifted the entire table towards her, which means I, at the other end of the table, got shafted. I'm just warning ya, sharing comes with consequences.

I got the potato pancake while my friend got the brandied raisin pancake. The potato pancake tasted like a really good hashbrown. That's it. Good with the apple sauce, but not really worth all the hype. The other pancake was fine, nothing special, not as glorious as the waiter presented it to be. (Or since my friend professed her vegetarianism, he may have gotten offended...) 

The atmosphere is fun and perfect for bigger groups who want to raise hoopla, but not for 2 girls simply wanting a good, tasty brunch meal. I think we should've gone for some of the other places on Hayes...
author: Hana J.

description: Great place to check out while in SF! German Beer awesome German food and great times to be had here!
author: Justin R.

description:
Holy Crap! This place kills!!! Gallon beers, delicious German bread, amazing schnitzel! You sit family style with everyone else, so its a great place to meet new friends. 

Just a little hint, be ready to wait, this place is super popular with the locals. And if your not from San Fran, be ready to search for parking. If not, take the Muni and walk it. Its worth every step!
author: Chad H.

description: LONG waits, Tons of people, good food and beer.  This is one of the most authentic German restaurants I have been to.
author: Larry C.

description:
Holy mother of belt loosening.... 

Suppenkuche is about as German as it gets here in the states. Not that I would know, having never been to Germany. But I am part German and I do have a real German friend. 

I wish we had tried the potato pancakes. But that's what happens when you stumble into a place without reading all your friends/ favorite's reviews of it first. (Lesson learned Yelp. Lesson learned.) 

Tables are family style, even if you don't come with a family. So be prepared to be stranger friendly. This probably isn't the best place to have a catch up dinner with your BFF to tell her about your drunken escapades or to tell your mom you're gay or to tell your boyfriend that you think you are pregnant. 

The best part about this place? The beer! Lots of it (type and size). 

The food we ate: 

Mushroom soup - heavy, creamy, similar to a lot of German sauces. 

Venison - Good, but not better than my family's venison recipes. The funny looking pasta was interesting, but I wish there was a sauce on it. 

Pork (wiener schnitzel I think - it was flat and breaded) - This was my favorite of everything probably. Just a good, tasty dish. Came with a side salad (refreshing after all the heavy stuff on the table) and really good potatoes. 

Trout - I liked this dish. Came with the skin on and bones in it and was quite lemony (which I like). If you aren't interested in a really heavy dish, I recommend this one. 

Overall, I'll be back, but maybe not right away (I'm still full from my meal last weekend). Although I've heard amazing things about the brunch, so maybe that will be my next visit.
author: Ali R.

description: Food was fantastic. Atmosphere was a little disappointing. Had a party of 3 and had to share a table with another party of 3. Volume in the room made it impossible to talk.
author: Dennis D.

description:
Shatangi was STARVING!!!  Good thing the prices are right and the portions are enormous.  What is there to complain about? 

Quality of the food?  Nope!!  I had the best schnitzel EV-AR!!
Service? Nope!!  Patient, friendly and fast.
Ambiance?  Healz naw!!! Funky, homey atmosphere, perfect for comfort food.

I am a convert.

Shatangi told you...
author: Njon W.

description:
WHY haven't I been here before? Within minutes of walking in, we're at the bar with a rowdy crowd doing shots (involves banging the little bottle on the bar) and being served up tasty German drafts by one fine, flirty bartender. [how do you say hot.com in German?] 

Didn't have to wait long before we were sat at 1 of the large wooden community tables, which is cool, b/c instantly you are chatting up your neighbor... InstaFriend- just add beer.  ;) The fare appears deceivingly simple, but the taste is exceptional.  We had weiner schnitzel (if only for the name.. teehee) which is lightly breaded pork loin and served with mashed potatoes. Damn!  Tender, light and wunderbar!!!  The portions are huge, so recommend splitting.  (definitely a first in SF)

Will be back & next time with a large group! :-D
author: Jamie R.

description:
At first I was not a fan of the communal seating. Who wants to sit next to a few strangers while you are trying to have a dinner with your man? Actually, I didnt mind it so much. It made for gret conversation sitting next to him rather than across the table. It was still private enough to hear him talk. 

The food. Dont you just hate it when you try and order something different on the menu and wish you'd ordered the same old?
This place is good as far as German food goes but nothing so mind blowing it hits the top of my list. Next time ill try the combo appetizer and the veal brauts and maybe even just chill at the bar with a beer.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Finally i made it here to try the cuisine of my homeland.
I can say, it's authentic and yummy.

German cuisines vary a lot across the country, a lot like in the US. There are different specialities everywhere. So the potato pancakes you can get pretty much all over Germany, they are just made a little differently everywhere. Pretzels and white sausages are Bavarian and so are a lot of the wheat beers.
I was lucky enough to get a Koelsch from my German hometown of Cologne.
Did you know that only breweries with a view of the Cologne Cathedral are allowed to brew Koelsch?
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Wow! Authentic food, atmosphere and beer on tap.  You must eat the following: 

Best ever homemade potato pancakes with homemade cinnamon apple sauce. Wish we'd ordered double!

Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei $14.00 (Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes) the sausage was FANTASTIC! For each bite combine it with a little sauerkraut and dip it in the horseradish mustard for a mouthful of germanic goodness.  The horseradish is strong so start small and build.

Order anything as long as it comes with their homemade spaetzle! Best I've had since actually being in Germany.

It is small, loud and crowded which is perfect and you will share a table with strangers, but that is part of the authenticity.  Know this and go in with a smile, you will not be disappointed!
author: Jessica S.

description:
I highly recommend the giant pretzel appetizer if available

Favorite main dishes: meat loaf w/ mash, champignons w/ spinach and feta cheese, apple strudel

great beers

long waits but worth it
author: Captain B.

description:
I know other people love this place, but I have just have to go on my experience.  I felt like I was eating at Ikea.  Only Ikea is tastier, and a lot cheaper.

It was incredibly loud, much more so than  I might have thought  based on the number of tables.  I think the concrete floors and lack of any table cloths to absorb sound contributed.  I couldn't hear the person across from me.

The waiter was very inattentive and surly.  We had to wait forever for him to come by.  The meat was very dry and tough; I've had much, much better German food.  In Germany I actually had quite a bit of good vegetables as well.  Here, the salads were very disappointing, the cucumber salad was basically a soup of dressing with old, sick looking cucumber slices and the green salad was basically just lettuce.  I'm not into creamy rich fish, which is unfortunate as the fish was floating in cream sauce.   The spatzle and wurst was decent.  I know the bare, simple furniture and the old, scratched, dirty looking plates are supposed to be part of the charm, but it didn't excite me.

Also, I'm afraid I'm a bit of a spoilsport, and the whole experience had me down, but when people at my table got boots full of beer, I didn't see it as that exciting.  There are lots of places where you can get a 'yard' of beer, and that seems more like a Spring-break style novelty.  Unless you drink really fast, the beer gets warmer and flatter at the end.  You can just get a glass at a time, and a good waiter will keep filling it for you.   Maybe the boot was justified by the scarcity of the waitstaff and their unwillingness to bring more drinks.
author: Stanford M.

description: Best German food in the City. Love this place. Always delicious food, best German beers on tap and decent pricing. Highly recommend it.
author: Christoph O.

description:
Broiled pork sausages on a bed of mashed potatoes, sauerkraut on the side, and a dallop of spicy mustard makes me a happy camper!  Spicy mulled wine gets me even happier.  A glass of Bavarian beer makes me forget that I am being suffocated by other patrons on a crowded Tuesday night.  Our awesome waitress seated us at our own two person table and We were offered free chocolate at the bar!  Great service, fun communal restaurant. 

Prost!
author: regina k.

description:
The food was good but not great, and the communal tables can get a little loud, but the beer list is extensive and the atmosphere makes for a fun change of pace from your typical night out.

I hope to be back, but I'll probably be drawn more by the beer instead of the food.
author: Brian D.

description: Came here last week for a friends going away dinner. We had a party of six people and we were told to be on-time for our six PM reservation or our table wouldnt be saved. We arrived promptly and were seated towards the back of the restaurant. Lots and lots of German beers to choose from- daily entree  specials on the menu I decided to go with the Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom  served with Spätzle & Green Salad. SO yummy. Reminded me of something my Grandmother used to make. Cant wait to go back -make sure you go when you are hungry!  Prost!
author: Tara M.

description:
We were a group of 12. That made getting a reservation crazy. We ended up reserving a table nearly 2 weeks in advance of the day. 

Once we did get here, the place was lovely! A very interesting kind of ambiance, with wooden benches to sit on. It is rather small, and so can get very cramped for room. 

The food was amazing, as was the beer. I wasnt sure what beer to try, so the waiter recommended one for me, based on my dinner selection. Goes without saying that we were treated well, in spite of over-sitting our reservation by a good half an hour! 

Will definitely go there again!
author: Gurpreet S.

description:
I've only been here once but look forward to going back thats for sure.  They have good traditional german food served in big portions, all washed down with lots of good german beer.  how can that be bad?

The appetizer platter was great (meats and cheese), the grilled sausages with sauerkraut and Potatoes was satisfying and the meatloaf that friend had looked equally tasty... oooh, and they have DAS BOOT! though there were none available when we were there.

Good times.
author: J. B.

description:
Yes, after my friend threatened to buy me the three liter beer here a year ago, we compromised on a boot (2L). There's a five liter size, btw. And, to get the 2L boot, you need to put a deposit down because if you break it, it's $50. Anyway, we had it filled with Paulaner--a very good recommendation by our server. Just the (free) bread alone was great, with the chived butter (awesome). We then split a half chicken stuffed with dumplings and with a side of two nice potato pancakes, as well as a bratwurst plate with roast potatoes and kraut. Better 2nd time around. Slight edge over Walzwerk.

I COULD NOT WAIT TO GET HOME TO LET THE BEER OUT. Thank goodness it's a short walk to BART...
author: Maximillian M.

description: Such a fun place!  Perfect place to grab a few drinks with friends.  A must-go if you are around the area  :)
author: Mindy H.

description: As always great food. Love this spot. Close your eyes and point on the menu, Get what ever it is, its great. Food and great beer, ya cant go wrong. Two boots up for this place.
author: Bryan F.

description:
Awesome German fare and beer selection!!

Had a boot of the Paulaner Marzen!  Delish until later that nite! Haha

German Ravioli with Mushroom Sauce - Damn, it's good!!

Everything else I've had on the menu thus far has exceeded my expectations!  All super hearty, comfort food!  I've sampled most of the draft beers on the menu, all awesome!  The Korbinian is the long island of German beer IMO, so watch out! haha

Love the casual atmosphere, wooden tables and having to share the experience with strangers at the table.  Get here before 6PM if you want a table or space at the bar.

I've come to this side of the bay from the East Bay on random weekdays just to get my German fix!  Definitely well worth the drive!
author: Leo B.

description:
this is a hard thing to do, rag on this place. I have eaten at suppenkuche a few dozen times over the last 6 or so years. I live in the neighborhood, and have always been amazed at the sort of perfection of their business. As testament to that perfection I have rarely eaten there recently since it is always crowded and waits on a tuesday have been 40 minutes at 8pm. Good on 'em. 

But last night I felt lucky. it was monday and there was a spot for three at the end of a table. No problem. the little alcove was full of people and they were making a bit of noise but nothing too terrible at first. then our food comes, and the group in the alcove starts shouting at the top of their lungs, "ausie ausie ausie", or some crap like that, then cheering. I couldn't see what was going on, but I figured someone was drinking alot. 

Okay once, fine, twice, a little annoying, but it went on for an hour, louder and louder. I mean, this is a restaurant, and not a bar menu type place, but a good solid $20 a plate restaurant, with 70% of their costumer space dedicated to dining.  when the group in the alcove began we had just taken our seats, the only seats in the place available. by the time we were done eating the place was cleared out.

This San Francisco, and San Franciscans are polite, they say nothing, leave quietly, tip, but the place cleared out. the waitress was a on edge. it was just ridiculous.

Now this large group of guys who came from some place where it is completely okay to yell at the top of your lungs in a crowded little restaurant over and over again (I know this is normal for some people, but really, are those normal people, or just rude effing a-holes who can't hold their liquor. seriously, what kind of backwoods hick hoots and hollers at full volume without regard to others in a restaurant) and this wouldn't reflect badly on the restaurant if it weren't for the joy and encouragement the bartender was giving the group in the alcove. He seemed like he was finally living his dream of working a shots bar in Tijuana. It is just a mentality I don't easily get. Really who thinks it is okay to yell next to people as they are eating and chatting to their friends. 

I did the bitching routine to the manager and got a lot of sorry, but "you know it is a german style place" no shit. so german means yelling over and over again in a tiny restaurant. So germans are idiotic loud bastards who can't hold their liquor? that seems unlikely.  and a bit of the excuse thing, that "well this is how this place is. here is some drink tickets come early when it will be more mellow" 

So if suppenkuche is fostering as much frat/marina sports bar atmosphere as they can these days, no problem, I will gladly avoid the place like the plague.
author: harty s.

description:
Do as the Germans do... drink out of a boot!!  

Despite my eager attempt/thought to drink a boot... my friend changed my mind... I am a girl and I have a small bladder--the boot is 2 liters of beer.  There was no way I could have finished it.  I wanted to save room for the delicious food.  Everything that came out of the kitchen looked sooo good!  In our 1.5 hour wait, which actually turned out to be less than that, we decided on what dishes we wanted. We ordered potato pancakes at the bar, and within 5 minutes, it came out! Talk about quick service!!  Before we even finished our appetizer, our name was called for our table.  

It is interesting how they seat you with random people, but again... do as the Germans do!  We ordered the venison medallions, the holiday goose special, and the breaded red snapper to share as family style.  Since everyone raves about the spatzle, we all got sides of that.  The spatzle was just OK... nothing special.  It just tasted like pasta with no sauce.  Aside from the plain spatzle, all of our dishes were delicious!  The goose was interesting in that the texture was like pork, but had a poultry-like taste. The mushroom sauce that came with it was delicious.  The venison also had a good sauce, and was cooked nicely.  It was similar to eating steak and didn't taste too gamey.  The red snapper didn't taste "german".. it was a pretty typical giantic piece breaded fish that came with pickled tomato and cucumber salad.  The tomato cucumber salad was definitely the favorite of the night! 

Overall, the food is pretty good and comes in big portions--enough to share! The service wasn't too bad either.  The food came out pretty quickly for how packed the place was.

What I really liked about this place aside from the food, was that this restaurant has got to have the most lively and spirited crowd... when it's someone's birthday here, everyone in the restaurant joins in on the celebration and pounds on the table.  It happened probably 5 times since I was in the restaurant either waiting for my table or eating my food.  I feel bad for the neighbors upstairs!  This place gets pretty loud.

Overall, good food, simple yet cool environment, and good service. Would come back again!
author: Diane L.

description: Wow! There are so many reviews! We loved this place. My husband came here with friends for his bachelor party and "remembered" that they had really good food~ I'm sure that had no beer while here, hahahahahahaha. We walked here from our hotel and got there just in time before a big dinner rush. It is communal seating, so be prepared to have many conversations with various peeps. My Husband got the "boot" of beer which is 2 Litres of fun. We took photos. The food was so good and fresh, spaetzle, schnitzle, side salad it was seriously the best german food that I've had outside of Germany and not too crazy prices. Super lively atmosphere-People gotta cheer you on when you're drinking the final part of that boot of beer! Soo looking forward to going back.
author: Tera M.

description:
Executive summary: Five stars for excellent food, big beer selection, professional service. Minus one star for being unpleasantly loud and crowded at all hours, and worthlessly crammed on weekends.

We tried:
- potato pancake, wonderfully fried and not too salty, with applesauce, mmm!

- the fried camombert with cranberry sauce. A great appetizer. 

- the lamb chop with truffle butter. Lovely cut and tender, nicely cooked (although on the bone, so avoid it if you don't prefer that). If I had it again I would order it medium rare, but still good cooked medium. Served with green beans that were not overcooked. 

- the jagerschnitzel, not quite as good as waltzwerk but still with a yummy, mushroom sauce.

- the sausages and kraut, an ideal example of the old favorite.

- the chicken with dumpling stuffing, a huge meal with tender, well cooked chicken, savory seasoned skin.

I just wish it wasn't so incredibly loud. I was just guessing what my friends were saying to me, as we were all shoved and jostled by the huge crowd of people that were allowed to stand in every inch of floor space, drinking and shouting at each other.  This was early on a Sunday afternoon, so I can only imagine what Saturday night would be like.
author: Rus H.

description:
First German restaurant I've ever tried. As a vegetarian I didn't know what to expect. Even though there were only two vegetarian entrees, both looked delicious. I had the Champignon gefüllt mit Spinat und Schafskäse (Portobella Mushroom stuffed with Spinach & Feta Cheese
over Pepper Sauce) which was unbelievably good. I also tried the potato pancakes. Overall I was very satisfied and definitely would return, especially to drink out of boot.
author: Karishma S.

description:
Still the best German restaurant in The City.

Great beer selection, good food, and cool ambiance.

Might have to give one of 'em boots a try some time.
author: Francis M.

description: Got here right around 530 on a Saturday, was getting busy but we snagged a seat at the bar.  Anyplace with a boot gets four stars from me, add the good food and awesome service and I'll go back anytime I'mi in the area.
author: Drew Z.

description:
Awful service.
Walked in w/ a party of seven, I had a small stroller we were moving to the back to our table. As I was takign the baby out of it and trying to fold it up, the waiter said rudely that there was NOT room for it.  Got it, just trying to pack it up.
We then told him we were ready to order.  "I am not your waiter," he said rudely.  We said sorry.  He said "there is no need to be sorry" in a snarky way.
He then removed our appetizer plates and told us to take our silver ware off the plates to keep it for our entrees.  Excuse me?   New forks are NOT too much to ask for!
It went on and on like this.  He was just so rude to us.
Food was fine.
Restaurant way too loud in the back.
author: Rainforest C.

description: Had a great brunch. Everything was very good, potato pancakes are a must! Pork chop was great. Steak (medium rare) and eggs (medium) were both cooked perfectly. Also GREAT beer selection. If you dare step up to the boot or even better the 5 liter stein.
author: Will V.

description:
Suppenkuche is one of my favorite SF places to eat and drink! The beer selection is pretty large and the food is pretty authentic.  
My only complaint is that it is a pain to grab a table and half the time we are too hungry to want to wait...but...can't hate on a place that is sooo good it takes an arm and a leg to get into! A+ in my opinion! Oh, and the mulled-wine is dream-worthy!!!
author: Emily g.

description:
it was 6:15pm on a saturday night. Extremely Hard to find parking. waited for around 40 minutes for a table of two. no it's not really a 'table' for two. we were sitting w/ two other groups in the same table. some people don't like it but i don't really care.

Broccoli soup was very broccoli-sh, i liked it.
Potato Pancakes w/ Apple Sauce - so crispy on the outside, yet the inside was not too mushy like those usually served at other places. i loved how i could still feel the small strips of potatoes when eating them.
Grilled Pork Sausages - delicious, but nothing to 'wow' for.
Roasted Suckling Pig - this was on the dinner special menu so i tried it. i was quite disappointed b/c the pork was wayyy tooooo dryyyyyy. i didn't even want to finish it after the first bite, given the fact that i was already quite full. 

Friendly waiters. not always attentive but that's reasonable. the restaurant was really crowded. i would go there again, but not for the suckling pig. pork chops, maybe.
author: Jam C.

description:
Suppenküche was the scene of the most sacrilegious last supper I had ever been a part of.
The 12 of us sat at a long, birch wood slab table in the back of the cramped restaurant with decor reminiscent of a medieval banquet hall.  My coworkers and I were gathered together to hang out for good times and good food and to have one "last hurrah" before two of us switched to another team.  There were no wenches, no mead, but there was a GIANT glass boot of beer (more than 16 inches tall and four inches wide by eye-ball measurement) passed around from person to person.  Each took a gulp, wiped their lip, and passed on to the next.  The Catholic school girl in me shook her head at the bad kids and their bad communion, but the bad kid in me kept the good times going and passed it along.  I didn't take a sip though.  Beer is not always my thing and I was feeling more like wine anyway.  I ordered the sweet Riesling which was the BEST Riesling I have ever had.  I am no one's wine connoisseur, but I could actually taste the medley of grapes mixing and interacting with each sip. FABULOUS!  I had a taste of my co-worker's dry Riesling and it too was great, but not as great as the sweet in my opinion.
To start out the meal, our waiter brought out pumpernickel bread with a dill/onion spread.  The bread alone was a bit sour and definitely needed the spread for the taste.  We also sampled the potato bread with apple sauce which had a nice, light and crunchy texture.
As I scanned the menu for my main course, one of the items struck me: Oxtails?  Anytime I had had oxtails before, it was in Latin, Caribbean, or South American cuisine.  'What the heck did Germans know about some doggone oxtail,' I wondered... There was nothing else to do but order it.  Turns out, the Germans do in fact know what they were doing. LOL!  The meat was so succulent, it was falling off the bone.  It was drenched in a very salty reddish brown sauce (I had to move the oxtail out of the sauce and onto the side of the plate a bit to get it away from the saltiness toward the end) and served with buttery, delicious Spätzle.  It was a lot of food. I could hardly eat it all and gave a good portion away, but it was definitely the right choice.  The rest of my table happily munched along as well, so it seems that all the meals were crowd-pleasers. I was too focused on my own to ask.  For dessert, we ordered the apple strudel and dark chocolate cake.  Neither one was mind-blowing, but they were ok.  In the end, the entrees were the real show.
For all of you who claim they don't like German food (and there are surprisingly a lot in my circle of friends and acquaintances), I would say hold your declarations until you try Suppenküche.  If any place can change your mind, it's here.
PROS: large portions
            delicious
            authentic
            great for groups (need a reservation)
            fun and festive atmosphere
            fair prices
CONS: Food is heavy, so be prepared
            Crowded and small (but worth the hassle if you have to wait)
author: Elsa M.

description: It's really loud here so I suggest rolling in tipsy or having a giant beer immediately.  I prefer brunch here but dinner is quite nice.  Good German bread and an enormous sausage platter.  Huge potato pancakes.  Lamb chops were good but bratwurst is the star.
author: Poppy C.

description:
The best German food i have over had outside Germany and my mom's house! 
The place is fun and has loads of great beer!
I only wish they had a bigger place!
author: A R.

description:
I used to love Suppenkuche before it became the go-to place and it was impossible to get a table.  I've been there a few times over the past few months with a party of 4 or less around 8pm and have been turned away at the door because they weren't taking names.  Considering they don't take reservations, that's pretty damn annoying.

The food is perfectly good German food.  I find it a bit on the bland side but you can always salt your food to get it where you like.  I do love the bread basket and the potato pancakes with applesauce.  And they make a great Radler.

But the crowds and the noise are just too much for me.  It's a great place for a large group of people, I suppose, if you can get a reservation.  But if it's just 2-4 people who want a nice dinner out to catch up on life, this is so not the place.  You'll never be able to have a conversation, though you might not have anything to say to each other anyway after waiting for 1.5 hours for your shared table.

My germanophile tastebuds and sensibilities prefer Schmidts hands down.  But Suppenkuche can be a cool experience, especially if you think that 8 people passing around a huge glass boot full of beer and taking a swig of Spaten and saliva is fun.  Five years ago, that was fun.  But I think I may have outgrown the place.
author: Courtney N.

description:
I don't understand what all the fuss is about.

The food is pretty good, and it's cool that you can get beer in a boot, but the experience is completely ruined for me by the ambiance.  This restaurant is very LOUD and overcrowded.  Seriously, you can barely hear the person sitting across the table.

The process for waiting for a table is a bit unfriendly.  They'll quote you a wait time (say, an hour and a half), but they won't take your phone number or roll your name over if it comes up early.  If they say 90 minutes and your table is ready in 45, you're out ot luck.  When you show up 20 minutes later, you're back on the bottom of the list.

Since you can't wait anywhere else, you have to wait at the bar.  It's always loud and crowded.
author: Dave B.

description:
Couple things you should know before you head out here:  Parking is difficult so walk; the seating is communal, so you share a table with other parties, which can be fun or isolating depending on how extroverted or introverted you are.  Also it can get kind of loud.  The ambiance is chill and check out the ceiling art with birds and branches.  

I recommend the potato pancakes with apple sauce.  I always screw up the sauce to potato ratio and end up with no sauce for the 2nd half of the potatoes.  The potatoes are thin, crunchy and hash brown like.  It is in the appetizer portion of the menu.

For the main portions, I always get the Jägerschnitzel porkloin with the mushroom sauce.  It's an excellent choice if you can't decide, though you really can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  There is plentiful mushroom sauce to go around with your pork cutlets and also comes with a side of Spatzle, which is like cheese or pasta...I actually don't really know what it is but sometimes I like it and other times its meh....

Huge selection of beers; I always go for the Bitburger.  There is also a bar area and you can get the boot for 2 liters of satisfaction.
author: Summit S.

description:
I really can't complain about the beer selection and food at this place. They have delish Belgian beers and the shnitzle, spaeztle and potato pancakes are killer. 

In the past when we've come here the crowd and noise level has been an issue, but not enough to prevent us from coming back for the food. 

Last weekend however, everything changed. We went for brunch, knowing that it would be less crowded and thus, not as noisy and because they have our fave dishes on the brunch menu. We were seated in the cramped back room on a bench so smashed against the wall, I couldn't get in to sit down without performing some cirque du soliel acrobatic maneuvers. When we asked to move to the front or even to another table in the back we were met with attitude. 

Here's where our experience started to deteriorate. During the entire course of our breakfast the cook (whose station was directly in front of us), would bang on the bell for food pick up NO LESS THAN 20 TIMES every single time he put a new dish up. The first time we brushed it off, but then he starting banging on the bell incessantly even when the waiters were all hovered around the counter waiting for the food. My dining companion said, "Hey, take it easy with the bell..." and the cook just looked at him with this surprised expression like, "what?"

Not only did this ruin a peaceful Sunday morning, but seriously made me reconsider coming back here in the future.
author: Melissa W.

description: Ever since my time in Germany, every now and then, I miss the meaty German meal with the great German beer! And this place provides a cure! I had the Sauerbraten mit Lingonbeerkonfitüre,serviert mit Rotkohl und Spätzle. It was actually really close to what I had in Germany. Especially the spatzle. Just identical. And you might wonder how you eat all those meat, and the heaviness! the answer is that make sure you get enough beer to go with it! It is totally an authentic experience.
author: Fung S. O.

description:
I was so excited to find this place.  It was awesome.  It was like being in Germany (where I lived for half a year...) or as close as I think I could get...being in the USA.  

The stars are as follows:

1. The menu actually contains German words and phrasing.  I'm not so fluent that I can tell if it's correct, but I know it was at least a better attempt than I could do.  And I don't just mean they included the words "wein" or "schnitzels" or "bier"...the whole entree was described in German...and then in English also.

2. They have a radler! I haven't seen or had a radler in such a long time, it was very awesome to find one.  The beer selection is not large, but it is well varied, based on different beer styles, and served in special beer glasses for each beer (as they should be...).  The menu mentions a 50 dollar charge for breaking the glasses.  Don't come to get wasted! Also, 25% off of radler and radeburger for those who ride their bikes, and can prove it, to suppenkuche.

3. Food tastes fabulous. 

4. Simple decor with German style seating.  It's like going to Munich and eating at the hofbrauhaus...a very miniature one.  There are long tables and benches to sit on.  Don't worry, there are some tables/chairs too.  But, if you sit at the benches, you will most definitely sit with others.  Another thing that was great, we entered right as they opened...and the entire place was full before we left.

5. Great servers, who can squeeze though a crowded room with ease.  The room became full, and it's not a huge place, but somehow they maintained good service.

The only issue we ran into was that they can't split checks.  We had to calculate the value of our part of the bill, and give the split totals to the server.  Not such a big deal, the check was still split and everything was fine.
author: cyndi t.

description: THE BEST GERMAN FOOD. EVER! Go here with a bunch of your friends, order boots, and you will have the best time. Ever. Great atmosphere, great service, amazing food + drink. Can't wait to go back.
author: Olivia B.

description:
Solid 3.

If you're looking for a fun, loud, boisterous place, this is the spot. It's a good place to go with friends that like to drink beer and eat heavy, heavy food. 

We order the .3L pilsner beer (well I did, first round), brat with mashed potato, potato pancakes (it's like a salty, thick hash brown) comes with a delish apple sauce on the side for dippin' and a beef stew (really good!). Everything was really heavy but o-k. 

They have a huge list of beers to choose from and what size cup/pint/boot to choose from as well.

They take reservation for parties of 6+. Others can wait at the bar.
author: Anna S.

description: Excellent beer! Delicious food with hearty portions! Come ready to wait - i.e. be patient and carry a bag of nuts. It's worth the wait and if you've planned for it and grab yourself a beer, you'll make it through. On the other hand, your timing may be impeccable and you can be seated pretty quickly. It gets pretty loud, but I feel like that makes it all the more authentic.
author: Colleen M.

description:
came here for the DAS BOOT and its no lie...that thing is REALLY BIG 

We came here for one of our friends birthdays to just drink. We got there around 830 and it was packed and they were not taking table reservations anyways so we just went to the bar. Me and my other friend got there first and went to the bar. We ordered the big boot and the bartender looked at us ( we are two asian girls) and asked us "are we sure...have we seen it before?" We said yea! And I think we surprised him by finishing it too. But its totally worth it! 2 liters of beer and that thing really is huge! Hard to hold up! We also got an order of the potato pancakes to snack on it was soo good! Especially with that apple sauce tasting thing it came with! The meat smelled really good too but it was too late to order dinner. I would definitely go back there again and try some of their meat dishes and do another boot!
author: Annie L.

description:
OK, I got to admit. I was to drunk to write a review on the night I went to Suppenkuche. Overall experience in there was beyorn my experience at any bar.  However, when the bartender tell me I have to make a $50 deposit for the boot. At first I though he was joking, but he was not. After we got the table and drinks for an hour, now I know why they have to charged $50 for the deposit. So, don't break it when you're drinking one. 

I have to say, I love the food the drinks and the service. The 2 litters boot, I believe, I can empty it if I don't have to drive home. I have to give this place a 5 stars. It was that good and the last star was for the good time I had that night.
author: Chris S.

description:
Had breakfast here.  Great service, good pancakes, and yes, you can have beer with your breakfast!  

Arrive early to avoid the crowd.  They open at 10 a.m.

I would have preferred that they not blast music on a Sunday morning, but other than that it was a good experience.
author: Bay G.

description: Tasty food, a great beer selection and a cozy atmophere...but, full of hipsters, like roaches. But its not all bad. There were also families scarfing good German food, and beefy men quaffing great smacking steins o'beer, so thats cool. They need more dessert selections. My German grandpa would be disappointed, but in a very understated way.
author: A D.

description:
Ich liebe Suppenküche!   

Love the beer. The König rocks! Love the Schnitzel. Love the big busted "Helgas". Love the crowd. Love it. 

The bartenders were cool too. They were quick to give German lessons on just about anything. From how to pronounce Volkswagen to the misconception about "Das Boot". 

Suppenkuche is a pretty cozy place to be after a hard day's work. Everyone in there has the same thing in mind: Drink as much beer as possible. 

Prost!
author: Angelo B.

description: It just dawned on me I never left a review for this place. Why am I doing it now? Because I'm totally craving everything I've had a bite of while there. Seriously good food with a cool atmosphere. I've luckily not had as long a wait as others but next time I show up if there's a 30 minute line I'll happily wait my turn.
author: William S.

description: Loved the selection of beer! I had so much fun sitting with at a table passing around a giant boot. Although I did not try any of the food, my friends ordered some tasty looking dinner plates. The only bad thing was that the mashed potatoes were slightly on the cold side by the time all the dinner plates came out.
author: Grace C.

description:
I love this restaurant. I love the food and the atmosphere. I love all of the drink options. My friend Jason normally ends up with five or more different drinks in front of him. I've been going here since 1999 and I have never had a bad experience. I am a bit of a picky eater but I feel I have to challenge myself with foods that scare me... so I can say I tired it once. This was my reason for ordering the venison medallions in red wine sauce the first time. My friends couldn't believe I was going to eat Bambi. Bambi was delicious. I was surprised that it wasn't gamy at all.
So if you are feeling adventurous give it a try. All the dishes here are great so order whatever sounds good to you at the moment. 

The staff here is very friendly and attentive. The owner is over the top hospitable.  He is always in the restaurant and checking up on his guests to see if there is any little extra he could do. I had bought my favorite beer for my dad and when he tried it he mad a face, the owner saw it and offered to get him a beer he would like better. He asked him what kind of beer he liked and my dad told him, "Coers Lite" He smiled and got him something he said he had brewed himself. My dad loved it and still talks about it to this day. 

Brunch! best brunch in the city. please don't tell anyone else. They only have brunch on Sundays and you must order the Stuffed Emperor Pancakes with apple strudel dipping sauce, they are amazing. Last time I went my friend Michelle was eating her when the owner came over and asked her if she wanted to try Nutella and she said it made them even more amazing.

Believe it or not this German restaurant is good for Vegetarians. I have brought a few who were apprehensive but are now regulars. Their egg dishes for brunch are amazing! 

Now the warnings. This is a very German restaurant, It's full of loud people having fun and enjoying conversation so if you are looking for a quiet romantic dinner, look elsewhere. Also if you are a small group you will likely be seated with other people at your table. It helps keep the line of people waiting down. Very German. I think it's fun.  If you get the right people sitting at the table with you make new friends. I like to talk to people, so if you get sat at a table with me and would rather not meet me. just ignore me and enjoy the yummy food. I'll get the hint.
author: Eric M.

description: My favorite German restaurant outside of Germany.
author: S S.

description:
Suppenkuche- the perfect place for a German beer and food lover!  I came here when my bro was in town and we both loved it.

Expect long lines. There isn't much bar space, but the bartenders are great and very attentive.  They have a pretty wide selection of beers on tap and we went with the special pilsner of the day which quenched our thirst.  They also have these giant boots that they import straight from Germany.  I wouldn't recommend getting one unless you can drink fast or you'll have yourself a whole lot of warm beer!

Expect rich, hearty, delicious food.  This place is definitely not for the health conscious.  We got the potato pancakes, meat/cheese plate, porkloin and venison.  Every dish was great but my favorite was definitely the crispy, savory potato pancakes with applesauce.

Overall, a great meal, great drinks, unique atmosphere.
author: Christine L.

description:
Is it the downturn in the economy?  New staff?  Not sure, but you get all 5 five stars for improvement.  Massive.  
In the last year you've shown a whole new face.  Yes, the waitress did nearly drop the plate of wienersschnitzel on my head, but with a genuine smile this time.  Food's better, too.  perfectly fried potato pancakes, pork chops.  Portions seem even bigger than ever. And the room feels less cramped these days.
author: Nikki F.

description:
Two of my colleagues and I had dinner here the other night.  We were seated immediately at a communal table which was to our surprise since it was just after the Oktoberfest weekend fiasco...though we noticed we had just beat the crowd as people began filtering in shortly after we were seated.  

I thought the ambiance and decor of the place, though it is small, minimalistic, and you're seated with strangers, was strangely welcoming and comfortable once seated and settled in.  It feels like a place where you can imagine a fireplace keeping you warm from the cold winter evenings with a bunch of friendly people dining and drinking beers.  The dim lighting is also pleasant.  The only thing is that the noise is a tiny bit overwhelming but given everyone is probably a little buzzed off of beer, it's not a surprise.

I ordered the Jagerschnitzel (fairly thin cuts of pork floured and flash fried then drenched in a creamy mushroom sauce served with a side of Spatzle and a butter lettuce salad) which I thought was very good and hearty...though I haven't had much German food so I don't have much to compare it to.  The pork was very flavorful especially with the tasty, creamy mushroom sauce that it was drenched in.  The Spatzle I found to be somewhat more like gnocchi in its texture.  It was especially good with the mushroom sauce.  The lettuce salad though covered in olive oil, was refreshing to have with the heavy meal.  I also had a bite of the Weinerschnitzel which my colleague ordered.  It was a veal, thicker in cut, that was breaded and fried.  I thought it was okay but definitely not as good as my dish and much heavier.

After our meal, I saw the giant pretzel and wished we had ordered that but there would have been no way to even get through a quarter of it given the portion of our meals were HUGE let alone the size of the pretzel was GINORMOUS! 

I will definitely go back again!
author: Jessica T.

description: This place is awesome! Das boot, schnitzel, potato pancakes! What more can you ask for? Honestly, this place was great. The food portions are large to say the least, all the beer is from Germany. So if your expecting to get by on with a Coors light or Budweiser this is not your place. The menu is not large, however everyone with a decent palate will be able to find something wonderful to enjoy. The food is delicious and shows just how wonderful Germanic cuisine can be. Then feel free to wash it down with the wonderfully wide and diverse assortment of authentic German Biers! I also didn't think that i would enjoy sitting next to complete strangers but found it to be of no concern. The ambiance is a little different, very similar to what you find at an actual German beer house. All the more reason i love this place.  If you go, hope you enjoy this place as much as i did!
author: Jeff T.

description:
For a place that made me wait 1.5 hours in the cold and rain and also made it to 7X7 Big Eat SF, I sure was not impressed.

The place is very small and crowded with poor circulation. If you are claustrophobic, I would not recommend this place. The volume is also a bit loud, so if you don't enjoy shouting while you are eating, this may not be the place for you. 

As far as the food is concerned, I did not find it to be mind-blowing. I ordered something off the specials. Venison Sausage with red cabbage and spatzle. Spatzle is on the list of things to try, so it was a must have. I wasn't really sure what Spatzle is, it pretty much tasted like dry noodles... waht's the big deal? The sausage was okay. Maybe I'm just not into german food. 

Not really sure what the hype is. If you're really into the whole german beer drinking theme, then i guess this is the place for you.
author: Mei C.

description: I'm sad to give this a bad review because I used to be a big fan.  The food is still good if you can stand the atmosphere.  Suppenkuche has turned into a frat house full of people trying as hard as they can to be louder than the next table and getting drunk on purpose.. Its sad because the staff is excellent and knowledgeable about the food and beer but you can see it in their eyes, "Please Don't Ask Any Question's My Throat Is Worn Out..."  Its the same look of panic i notice from cabin crew on airplanes when they are getting nailed by the Give Me Give Me crowd.  The restaurant throws the food at you as fast as they can is it because they want to be out of the madness or because they are fostering this environment and have gotten greedy? "Keep it Loud and Fast and turn the tables".  Anyway, not a very enjoyable dinner last night at all, the food was just warm and arrived so fast we didn't have time to enjoy a beer. The chef really likes his DING DING DING DING DING bell...  The waiter had little to say in the way of offering service because he was so overwhelmed by the cacophony of chaos.  The beer and food are heavy, the atmosphere was suffocating.
author: Jason S.

description:
I was amazed at how crowded this place was on a Tuesday night.  We made reservations for 8, so we had no problem with seating, but the place was *packed*!  There wasn't even really enough standing room near the bar to get one of their delicious beers.

To give my liver a break, I passed on the giant novelty boot-beer.  I did get to try out a schwartzbier, a heff, a double bock, and an amber.  Out of the 4, I was most impressed by the double bock's strong and sweet flavor.  As a side to the alcohol, I had a portobello mushroom with tomato sauce and soft cheese cubes.  I didn't think it looked very impressive when I got it, but it satisfied the palate and my growling stomach.

I'd love to go again if there's a less crowded time.
author: Jerry C.

description: I make it a point to come here at least once a month. I love the ambiance!! They have a great beer selection and the staff is friendly and very knowledgable. The food is tasty and authentic. The spaztle and the kraut are yummyyyyyyyyyyyy. The menu is simple, the space is cozy, and the crowds love it. There is never a time that we have been to this place that it wasn't packed. Come early as they do not take reservations unless you have a party of 6 or more. We've waited an hour or more, but it was well worth it for the superb food and drink. You won't be sorry!
author: Candid K.

description:
AWESOME!
DELICIOUS!
GERMAN!

This is THE hotspot! packed haus every night! 

simple, crafty, atmosphere and wonderful food. MY friend tried a vegetarian mac n' cheese thing that was very tasty (I think there was even sauerkraut in it) I had the lobster bisque (the best I've had), and my other friend the beef ravioli type thing or whatever. ALL 3 AMAZING, hearty, and filling. Great beer too! Hot wait-staff! and friendly elbow-to-elbow atmosphere.
author: jane l.

description:
Ambiance:
The place gets packed so be ready to share a long table with strangers (it's a friendly, warm environment, so leave your elitist attitude at the door). 

Food:
Gemischter Salat- Salad with Cabbage, Carrots, Beets, Potato Salad & Butter Leaf Lettuce - not really any butter leaf FYI. Just piles of the aforementioned items. All marinated in a vinegar-based dressing so don't order if you don't like strong flavors.
Sauerbraten mit Lingonbeerkonfitüre, serviert mit Rotkohl und Spätzle- Marinated and Braised Beef with Lingonberries  served with Red Cabbage & Spätzle - the meat was a little tough but I liked the sweet flavor from the berries (disclaimer: I'm not a big meat eater) Spatzle was a noodle-like texture- very tasty. Very carb-y. Red cabbage- barely touched it - berries overpowered it. too sweet..
Also had a special for the night: Salmon with mashed potatoes and sautéed spinach- Highly recommend this. Salmon was moist and a generous portion was given. Spinach was flavored with lemon perfectly. 

Overall:
Most people come for the beer (you can order a 2 liter boot of beer but they require you give them a credit card to hold until they get their precious boot back.. They also have larger & smaller vessels..) and traditional menu. I liked the atmosphere best. The good service, friendly people, unique experience and generous portions make this a great place to try. The wait is long though. Come expecting a 2 to 2.5 hour wait on a Friday or Saturday. Do not come hungry. There are bars/cafes within walking distance so you can put your name in and hang out somewhere else before hand. Around 8:30 I noticed they just stopped taking names b/c there were too many people on the list already. Crazy. But worth it.
author: Amanda G.

description: I love this place! My friends and I have been there a few times including to watch the World Cup and absolutely fell in love. The atmosphere changes from time to time and there's huge wooden tables so everyone can sit together. Everything except the descriptions of the food are all in german so the staff is very nice in helping you what huge beer you want to choose from. Ive never had german food before this and I am a pretty picky eater..but the food here was so tasty! I had pork chops with mushroom sauce and spakle?? I am sure I spelt that wrong..but It was amazing. It does get crowded and the wait is a bit much if you dont make reservations. Also it gets pretty loud in there but honestly with as much beer as you get in one glass I am not surprized! Definitely go with a group of friends and have fun because this place is a blast at a group setting!
author: Belinda A.

description:
Huge-a$$ portions and amazing beers! I took my fiance of German descent along with his dad and uncle (also big & tall German men) and they were all stuffed and very impressed. You gotta come here with an appetite for sure. 

My fave: Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoße mit Spätzle und grünem Salat or in English, the Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spätzle & Green Salad. YUUUMMM
author: Lizette R.

description:
Yes, parking can be a pain but there's a plus.  If you can get there before it opens, parking will be more bearable and you can eat in a less hectic environment.  Just cut out of work early.  Tell your boss you're feeling sick.  If you down enough beer it won't be as much a lie!

Thus far here is what I can recommend:
Braised beef: Well cooked beef and well seasoned.

Venison: Same as above but more tender.

Potato pancakes with apple sauce: Essentially a glorified hashbrown.  Still get it.  If you have the craving for something a little oily this is your ticket.

Swartzbier: Heavy, dark beer. Best in a boot of course.

Black Forest Chocolate Cake: Very moist and rich.  Get it if you have any space left, you hedonist.

That is also everything I've had.  I don't know if I happened to land on the good dishes or if everything is this great.  I'm inclined to think the latter.
author: Pickles T.

description:
I would love to give this place the five stars it richly deserves.  The German food is absolutely delicious, the specials are interesting (wild boar sausage makes an appearance from time to time), and the solid selection of German beers goes very well with the food.  

But I cannot give Suppenkuche five stars because its a**hole patrons are ruining it.  My last three or four visits were marred by ongoing frat parties throughout the place.  It was so loud that I could barely hear my companion, even though we could not have been sitting more closely.  Suppenkuche desperately needs to get the "bro" factor under control.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Suppenkuche was crazy busy when we arrived, but we put our names down for a table with the hostess who was floating around the place.  We had a beer at a nearby pub, killed an hour, and came back.  

As there was only threeof us, we were seated at a communal table with another random group of five.  I ordered a 2 liter Das Boot of beer, and my buddy bucked up for the 3 liter.  The novelty of drinking Das Boot is a good enough reason to check this place out, but I have to say the food was legit.  I had the jagerschnitzel and it was really good.  

Fun atmosphere, friendly people, excellent food, and the fun of drinking multiple liters... how much is a liter of beer?  I don't know or care, but we'll be going back!
author: Jordan A.

description:
1000th review for Suppenkuche,  to my credit.

Lovely ceiling.
Great ambience.  Cozy yet lively.
Great beers.
Hearty food.
Great company.
Friendly Staff.
Prost!!!

Must haves are the ravioli, pork, grilled lamb chops and braised beef.  You'll danke scher me later.
author: Jane K.

description:
Let me preface by saying that i've never had German food. Not that i'm opposed to the idea of trying new things, but being an Asian Jew, I tend to stick to food closest to the Pacific Ocean.

Anyways, I took a CL escort there the other night, who was 10-feet taller than me for some drinks and food.

First off, as a  beer drinker, I am happy with their selection of brew. Good selection of Bocks and Belgian Ales. I had a beer before dinner, and another one during my feast. While I was tempted to order the 5-litre glass of brew, I had to contain myself as I drove my expensive luxury automobile there.

As for the food, it was OK. Nothing outstanding and nothing really stood out. I liked their appetizer plate full of meat and cheese, but meat and cheese can be had at my local Safeway too..

My main course was the venison. Why venison? I guess I like to eat young things. It was tender, but a bit overcooked for my tastes. The kraut or whatever the red stuff was next to my young piece of meat was a bit too sour for me. Honestly, it was good, but not damned good.

The crowd was a bit rowdy and youngish.. Not that i'm an old man myself, but come on now.. Who wants to go to a restaurant full of rookie drinkers?

While this review may sound somewhat negative and cynical, I did have a good time there. Communal seating is a blast if you're not paired with a bunch of squares who doesn't enjoy a good sex joke over dinner. What's the big deal?

Oh and one bathroom for a place that prides itself on serving copious amounts of beer? Well, that's just another rookie move right there...
author: Stanley C.

description:
This is a really great place to go with friends and spend money and become drunk and eat a ton of food.

I love the communal tables and the hip-rustic decor thing they have going on. I always end up getting the spaetzle, whatever meat is on the side.
author: Miranda E.

description:
Maybe it was the company, maybe it was the food, maybe it was the beer, but I have never been happier at any restaurant.

Considering that we were a group of over 15 (for a birthday), each person got their food at about the same time, no orders were mixed up, beer refills were prompt, our waitress put up with our increasingly loud banter, and everyone enjoyed themselves immensely.  My end of the table kept passing our plates around, so I got to try the venison, jaegerschnitzel, wursts, potatoes, spaetzle, sauerkraut, sauerbraten, plus whatever else the tasty, tasty beer later fuzzed out in my brain.  And every time I tried a new dish, I got SO JEALOUS that I hadn't ordered it for myself (but this also happened when I tried the food that was actually mine, so I don't really think you can lose with whatever you order).

And yes, we were that group that made it a little hard for you and your girlfriend to hear each other over your pork chops.  I'm sorry-ish.

I don't think my friend could have had a better birthday anywhere else, and I can't wait to eat and drink myself silly at Suppenkuche again!
author: Rachel S.

description:
Awesome

Went for Boys Night 2010. Good beer even though I couldn't really tell difference if it was bad beer. Bomb.com brawts and kraut with mashers.

Very crowded so much so that it is hard to walk without grabbing ass. Make sure to make reservations. Really good times.
author: Bryan K.

description:
This is a fun and very popular German place.  The layout is very simple, you are likely to be dining with some others unless you are in a big group (we - a couple - shared a table with 4 others).

The beer is great, the food is pretty good (close to what we had in Munich).  Too bad they didn't have the currywurst last weekend, I really need to go back to try that , and also the 2L beer in the boot.
author: Durif M.

description:
Ah, Bavarian bliss!

The Boyfriend and I were ready to embark on our much anticipated tour of Germany and Austria, but felt first a culinary primer was in order.  Off to the charming and ethereal Suppenkuche for something light and dainty, like Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei and spatzle smothered in cheese.  

Loosen the dirndls before you go, girls, so you have room for a few beers and the surprisingly refined black forest cake.
author: Vanessa C.

description: Went here for Sunday brunch.. My husband loves all things German and was impressed by their beer and cold meat breakfast plate which was huge! My farmers omlette was just ok but the bread and Riesling were delicious. Our host was fabulous and personable and my husband already wants to make the trek back for dinner!
author: Heather L.

description:
I came in here around 9:30pm on a Tuesday, the place was still pretty crowded but the experience was not all I thought it would be.  But I just moved in to the neighborhood so I'll give it another chance.

They did not have my initial beer on tap and the beer I got was a little bit on the disappointing Miller Lite tasting side.  This would be ok, but for a $6 .5 liter combined with the plain and sparsely decorated interior were a bit of a letdown.
author: Joey S.

description:
5 stars for the boot!

Great beer selection and I loved the beer concoctions.  The food here is great too.  We ordered the sampler dish which included blood sausage.  I'm not a big fan of blood sausage in general but the one here was excellent.
author: Brian A.

description:
This place is crazy!  It's really small, really crowded, but definitely a good time waiting to happen!  We came here for a birthday party and were seated in the back room.  The beers are ginormous so if you enjoy brewski's, this is the place to be..in fact, they only serve beers!  I personally went with the a sweet raspberry beer, which I highly recommend for those not into beer.

For my entree, I went with the Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoe, which was the pork loin with mushroom sauce.  I think on a normal day I would have enjoyed it more but I just couldn't eat much that day.  The meat was moist and the mushroom sauce was good.  I would probably try something else next time around.   I think most people are so drunk that they don't really pay attention to the service but the waitress' seemed nice enough.  The prices are reasonable - less than $20.00 an entree.  As everyone says, definitely give yourself extra time to find parking and squeeze yourself into the restaurant as it is rather crowded.  Another tip.  Get ready to wait a long time for the restrooms because there is only one stall for men and one for women.  Otherwise, all in all, a good time!  i recommend checking it out.
author: Jess C.

description:
Love. This. Place.
Can't say enough about Suppenküche.
Wish I was there right now!!!
author: F G.

description: It had been awhile since I'd been to Suppenkuche because I've to be on a permanent diet and German food is a no no. It's pretty much the same very loud, festive, and hard to get a table. However, one thing did change and it's the most important element: The Food. I think I must have stopped by on a off night because my weinerschnitzel was really dry (wow that sounded wrong) and I was disappointed. Anyway, maybe Friday's aren't good days for schwein.
author: Sheila T.

description:
I heard such good things about this place, and as I particularly enjoy sausages (cooked, cured, dried...), I thought this German restaurant would be awesome.  The meal turned out to be kind of underwhelming.  The service was good, and they had a nice beer selection--but first and foremost the food must be good, and that's why it's getting 3 stars.

I ordered the house-made pork/chicken sausage in curry sauce with potatoes, and a side of eggs.  The breakdown:

-Sausage: being the star of the dish, it was lacking in flavor and the texture was drier than I would like.  I've had this type of sausage juicier and more flavorful elsewhere.

-Curry sauce: there just wasn't enough sauce, and the dryness of the sausage just begged for more sauce.  The tomato-based sauce was sweet, but rather odd was that I could not taste any curry flavor at all, but as the meal progressed I could feel a raw curry powder aftertaste. (Maybe the curry powder wasn't mixed well or was added late and did not fully cook with the sauce?)

-Potatoes: well cooked and seasoned.

-Eggs: came out in a really small dish with two eggs, kind of cute.

I also tried my friend's dish, which was meatloaf with potatoes and eggs.  The meatloaf was kind of like a better version of Spam--a big slice of it.  I like Spam BTW, so it's definitely not a bad thing at all.  

Note on the service: I also really appreciated the fact that the chef (or I think it was the chef) came out to check our dishes.  Things like that go a long way, because it shows that the customer is cared for.  For this alone, I will give this place another try.
author: M B.

description: Excellent Foods, reminds me of days in Dusseldorf and Frankfurt,I would say everything is A++ or 90% and higher. We must go for the Chief tasting menu. This is great. Sometime you can find a good priced excellent bottle that is still at old prices. I still think it is a marvellous dinner and great experience and more surprises each time I go!  I miss Debaratiji with me  Good fun in a pleading venue Austrian tapas? True Bavarian Food
author: Ramesh M.

description:
Initially came for the comically large beer portions, now for the food and everything else.

I have had pretty much everything on the menu and many of the seasonal specialties and have always been happy.  The jagerschnitzel is such an amazing dish I find myself craving it when I have been too long away from Suppenkuche.

This is a special place. Its not for every person or every occasion. It can be a little loud, and since you may end up sharing a table with other parties, it may not be the best location for an intimate dinner. That said, I wouldn't change a thing about it and am really happy its here for when my friends and I want to grab some dinner. And a glass boot full of beer.
author: Rondeep C.

description: This place is so much fun. Great for groups and great for drinking. Has a beer garden feel to it - everyone is buzzed and lively. The food is a perfect compliment to your beer - german sausages, etc. Definitely good to begin a night out with friends.
author: Mia M.

description: I really liked the Empress or Emperor pancakes.  They were great!
author: Suz L.

description: I'm not big into German food, but if you're looking for something different, this is a good restaurant to try out. Try the half chicken and potatoes pancakes.
author: V N.

description:
A couple glimpses into my thought process during my birthday dinner at Suppenküche that my sister took me and my friends to.

Oh wow look at the beer selection!  I haven't even heard of half of these before!  (I love trying new beers but rarely come across beers I'm not familiar with).

Wait, I can get a delicious German beer served to me in a 2 liter glass boot!  Or a 5 liter stein!  Wait I gotta work tomrrow. . .screw it, I'll cross that bridge when it comes.

The meatloaf here is wrapped in bacon!

Oh man this beer is good I couldn't drink this fast enough!

. . .

(period of haze where most things I can remember aren't Yelp appropriate)

. . .

How am I not hung over at all right now?

My sister is awesome!
author: Ryan C.

description:
What a great place! My friends and I were so stoked to actually go here. I honestly have wanted to try this place since I saw it on Check Please Bay Area, and also since a little movie called "Beerfest" came out. Once I heard there was a boot of beer, the deal was sealed.

This place can get super crowded, especially on a Friday night. Luckily me and my friend Greg were there right before the rush (around 6pm, and even then it got pretty busy). We had to wait around for the rest of our party to arrive, so while doing so we partook in some beer drinking. The bartender was really nice and helpful, especially since the both of us don't really dabble in German beer. I forget what we had, but the bartender actually took the time to ask us what kind of beer we enjoyed AND he also gave us some samples. When we finally did settle on a beer of choice, we were rewarded with these huge pint mugs. 

And because the rest of our party didn't arrive at the same time, we had to wait. That's the thing about the whole commune seating that I don't really like at all: you have to wait for your whole party to get there before you can get seated. We were going to get seated anyway, but the hostess informed us that if our party arrived after they would go to the bottom of the list and wouldn't be able to get seated. That was a bummer, and that called for more beer, but this time in standard Oktoberfest mugs!

The atmosphere of the place is so amazing, too! Everyone is really friendly and fun, though I guess that's due in part to the beer. But once we did get seated and once we got our hands on the boot (der Steifel, as the bartender had told us it was really called and not "das boot" ... the "Hollywood" term). Let's just say there was banging on the tables as each of us tried to chug that thing. People from other tables were talking to us. It was great!

So if anything, my message is to go here to have a good time. By the way, there is food here (haha), and that night I had the salmon. It was really tasty, and my friend had some sort of mac-n-cheese dish that was really good too. I would like to go back and have more of the food, but more importantly conquer the boot once more, and that thing that is huger than the booth. Oh yes... there is something bigger than der Steifel.
author: Caroline L.

description:
I've never had German food and didn't know what to expect.  

First off, I love the ambiance.  Very good for loud friends on a social night.  Like a great big feasting hall it was.

I had a nice mixed salad, and a meat dish I can't pronounce.  Seriously, it's my new favorite comfort food.  The beer was divine and I walked away full and satisfied.  

I'll be back for sure.
author: Robert M.

description: Went here for my birthday and the food was awesome. Good portions and unique stuff to choose from
author: kyle d.

description:
Jagerschnitzel: Very, very good.

Split-pea soup: Amazing. More brothy than you'd expect, but that was not a bad thing. Upon leaving, was irritated that I didn't know how to make this at home. 

Bread: Kinda dense, woulda preferred it warm, but chive butter was a nice touch.
author: D.B. C.

description:
Fantastiche! Ich liebe Suppenkuche. The interior was bright and clean and felt very authentically German. Though it was a tad brighter (light wood and lots of lights). It also has some nice modern interior designing touches-- could have been done by the same person who designs for Anthropologie.

My friend sold me on the Radler (lemon soda and beer), which were nice and refreshing. For dinner, I had a traditional sausage, sauer kraut and potatoes which were delicious. 

Great cheerful environment, very German, good beer and I'd love to come back more often.
author: Corinne M.

description: Consistently good! The waitstaff is friendly and willing to help you find the right brew.
author: Jenne T.

description:
Drove past this place months ago and was intrigued with the massive amount of people waiting outside, decided to Yelp it and was surprised it was a German food joint. 
Finally decided to try it out last night and was overall satisfied and impressed! 
If you come here on the weekend you need to be ready for a wait (ours was an hour-ish for a party of 4). The good part is if you're not in any rush you can hang around the bar and try the many types of German beers that they serve in giant glasses or a German boot! 
Beer was refreshing. Food was hearty, rich and filling. My boyfriend and I both had the  Wiener Schnitzel that was a wonderful pretzeley-salty breaded pork loin. Meat was delicious and the potatoe pancakes cured my carbohydrate craving! My brother had meatloaf with bacon and an egg inside (sounds odd but great) , and my sister in law had the vegetarian eggplant that was served with some sort of delicious creamy tomato sauce with fancy cheese on top. 
The part that made this place extra great is my heart broke when they ran out of the german pretzel served with cheese. When we received our check our server took off $7 dollars on our check for the pretzel. Don't you worry Suppenküche,  I'll be back to try the pretzel. 
Overall great service and fun environment. Only come here when you are really hungry, craving big portions and are up for a loud and bustling environment. My opinion, well worth it.
author: Kristina P.

description:
So...  German's are hot :)  I'm a big fan of the German's and their Cheese Spätzle!

I've wanted to go to Suppenkuche for about a year and I finally had the chance to do so.  I thought it was a bit weird to be seated with strangers -when you come here, don't expect to get your own private table like at normal restaurants.  

The two of us came here on Saturday just when they opened, around 5:30pm, and were seated immediately.  It gets pretty crowded here!

We started off with the Linsensuppe (Lentil Soup) and that was tasty.  It was my first time having lentils and I thought it was pretty good. For the main course, we had the vegetarian courses; Cheese Spätzle in Onion Butter Sauce served with a small Mixed Salad and Portobello Mushroom stuffed with Spinach & Feta Cheese over Pepper Sauce.  Our entrees came with sides, such as sauerkraut, beets, etc. 

I was in love with the Cheese Spätzle!  It was creamy, rich, and cheesey!  It was a bit heavy on the onions but I didn't mind.  If you're not an onion fan, I wouldn't recommend this at all.  There really was nothing bad about the spatzle -the noodles were cooked perfectly and the texture was just right. 

I tried the Portobello Mushroom stuffed with Spinach and Feta and I wasn't a big fan of that.  I don't think the flavors matched nicely -I'm not a big feta cheese fan so perhaps that is why.  

Overall, I'd totally go back here for the Cheese Spätzle and the beer :)
author: Brenda T.

description:
Top 5 all-time restaurants, easily.

Excellent beer, amazing food, cozy atmosphere. It gets pretty crowded, so show up early and get drink at the bar. 

My biggest complaint about this place is that it closes too early!!!!
author: John K.

description: Beer, Delicious Beer! A great casual place. Hearty food. Love that they have communal tables-can meet some fun interesting folks while dining on great German meals. Their dishes are to die for good. My favorite is the pork tenderloin with mushroom sauce, their weinershnitzel and famous potato pancakes. Tried a taste of the mushroom soup and it was incredible. Lines are long should be up to an hour and half wait, but with the fun bar and lots of beer, time goes by quickly. The bar tenders are friendly and attentive.
