Not a place to bring a first date. too loud to get acquainted.
author: Nancy M.

description: It is super affordable, huuuge portions (so you can bring a doggy bag for lunch the next day), great beer, friendly staff and a lot of new and fun flavors for me. It's a good spot to go to if you are hangover too, cause the food is heavy. I love the commute tables, I always end up meeting some interesting people every time I go here.
author: Linn L.

description:
It's authentic, so I hear from my girlfriend who heard from one of her best friend's boyfriends who's from Germany.  Or my other friend, who recenly spent two months backpacking through Germany, "It tastes just the way I remembered it." 

We came to Suppenküche the other night with some friends and ordered all kinds of goodness, including the wiener schnitzel, jägerschnitzel, bratwurst, and chicken.  The jägerschnitzel (gravy slathered pork cutlet) with spatzle (a kind of rustic pasta) was my favorite, but really, you can't go wrong with any of the entrees.  

Dishes range from $14-$20, a decent price considering you'll be leaving with a take-out box you can nuke for tomorrow's lunch.  Suppenküche also delivers a fantastic selection of imported draft beers, friendly and knowledgeable service, and communal dining that you may find awkward at first sitting at a small table with strangers, but you get over it in about two minutes.

I'm told they have a fantastic brunch menu, so I'll definitely be back for that.  If you're looking for an introduction to German cuisine, or simply hungry for a hearty meat and potatoes kind of dinner, Suppenküche is the place for you.
author: Tony L.

description: Had a blast at this place! Good German food, Beer, and general atmosphere! So, if you're not into that, I would not recommend going. I am most definitely into it, and would easily spend the money to go back anytime!! I really can not wait!
author: Jamie S.

description: Nice German bar with traditional german food. Just went there for a beer before dinner. They have a wide variety of beers. They service beer in the boot. I was tempted to order one, but was going to dinner afterwards and didn't want to be full on beer, so just ordered a small mug. Would definately go back and try the beer in the boot. Very friendly bartending staff.
author: Ronette B.

description:
Not much to add to my old review. Fortunately for me I am in San Francisco a lot more often which means I get to go hear more often. I still don't get to come here nearly enough. A couple visits back I went with a big group and did not have a reservation but the host was cool like they always are and made sure to work it out. They just told us that a reservation was late and if they didn't show up in five more minutes we will get their spot but we would have to be off the table by a certain time. Sucks for the people who did not show up. We all shared everything and my head wanted to explode it was so good. Other times I have gone, have been there to just hang out with a beer. The bartenders are fun and always take good care of us.

I think this has to be my favorite restaurant in the country.
author: Sasha V.

description:
I am on a quest for good German food. I love the atmosphere of this place. It is on the small side, but that leads to shared tables, much like an actual beer hall. However, that means getting seated next to a nice, drunken guy that was waiving his boot (and later a coffee cup) around and coming quite close to spilling it on my head.

We started with the potato pancakes. I love these in general, so I think they'd have to be miserable for me to dislike them; conversely, I can't be impartial in evaluating them. But the apple sauce was very good...not too sweet and it tasted very fresh. Perhaps it could have been amped up with a squeeze of lemon.

I had the pork knuckle. I thought this was actually pretty tough. But kudos for serving this. Anyway, I believe it was roasted, which doesn't serve a piece of meat like pork knuckle as well as a braise. However, the skin was so crispy. It was like I got bonus pork rinds! (Can you say chicharrones?) YUM. The serving was gigantic. But if you have leftovers the skin does not  keep well....so eat that part first! Also came with sauerkraut, which I can totally eat for a meal. The dumpling was really large (it reminded me of a meatball soup I had in Munich....clear broth with one gigantic meatball the size of my fist in the middle of the bowl).

BF got the venison. Two steaks, seared, and served in sauce. A little tough. But again, it's nice to see venison on a menu. Red cabbage was on the side. yum. Spaetzle was meh. I wasn't impressed. It was "different," but also bland...needed some kind of seasoning. They tasted like little gobs of noodle....nothing more, nothing less.

And hey, if you're coming here for the food, get a beer. You won't regret it. Please don't be the priss that orders wine with dinner or else I will give you dirty looks. If you're going just for the company, you should still get a beer, because I still will think you're being a priss and will give you dirty looks anyway. And beer is good.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
quite delicious! I have a limited knowledge of german food so I stayed with what I was familiar with. 

potato pancakes! dumplings! a divine roasted suckling pig! sauerkraut! It was so heavy and filling. I'm surprised I was able to squeeze out. This place was crazy crowded. A fellow diner had the big boot of beer which was quite excellent, I was tempted to take it home. Why shouldn't beer always be served from a glass boot?
author: Angela S.

description:
I waited for 2 hours in line on a saturday night for the meal here, but it was worth it!

I had the pork chop with mushroom sauce and it was sooo good. The spatzel was also awesome, a combination of spaghetti and egg noodles, i love it. I don't drink beer, so i probably missed out, but the restaurant is awesomeeee. Make a reservation if you hvae 6 or more people, it really is a long wait.
author: Laura t.

description:
i love beer. Okay, I never used to love beer, but I have come to love beer now and Suppenkuche has some good beer. 

Came here with a friend, grabbed a beer at the bar, and in about ten minutes we were seated at a table with a few other people. I settled on the potatoe pancakes to share and the appetizer plate with various cold cuts and cheese and pickled veggies as my entree. 

Oh yea, and we ordered a BOOT
MmMmMMmmm.... that boot killed me, but I loved it. 

Food was good, couldn't stop drinking and eating. Whats not to love about this place? Beer and meat. 

I'm definitely coming back!
author: Jennifer T.

description: I was so pleasantly surprised coming to this quaint little place! My friend asked me if I wanted to go to eat some German food in Hayes Valley, and being a typical marina girl, both of those things sounded less than exciting, so I was a little hesitant. But this place was super cute and cozy, excellent beer and everything we ordered was soooo delicious. Lots of germans speaking german, so at first was a little embarassed at my friends' reading off the menu in ridiculously horrible accents, but after a few boots was all in all a great time!!
author: Laura M.

description: went here for a team lunch with work.  a friend who i work with and lives in the city recommended this place.  my wife is german so i know german food.  holy smoke this place is amazing.  worth the wait no matter how long.  all of the food is incredibly delicious but I got the spetzl and the ale in the boot.  wow.  the bread is as good as you would hope.  nuff said - go here, you will be pleased.
author: Sean L.

description:
I was excited when I ordered the 2L DAS BOOT and have wanted to take one down since watching the movie Beerfest. When our waitress told me that if I broke it I would be charged $50, I held and cradled that boot full of beer (Stiegl) like a newborn baby. Scared of even just leaving it on the not so sturdy and often inadvertently nudged picnic-like table that was jam packed, shoulder to shoulder, by our party in celebration of a friend's birthday, I downed over three quarters of das boot within the first 15 minutes. Also, just like how they explain in the movie Beerfest, when you are close to finishing das boot and are drinking it with the foot pointed upwards you need to turn the boot so that the length of the foot is parallel with the ground otherwise confront a rush of bubbles in your face from the air pocket that's created -- I experienced a mild version of this first hand just to test it out.

As for the food it was very tasty, quite authentic and reminded me of when I visited Germany. I had ordered the meatloaf with mashed potatoes and sampled a bit from some other dishes, all of which were good. Between the beer and the food I was definitely one satisfied and extremely full patron wishing I had worn looser pants.
author: Erich D.

description:
My German ancestors are rejoicing in their graves.  I have finally tried German food and I LOVED it!

The beer I tried was Blanche de Bruxelles, so a Belgium beer, not German, but it was possibly my favorite beer ever!  I am a fan of beer, but I'm very picky on which flavors I like and don't like.  I got a small glass because I was intimidated by the towering pint glass, but I finished it so quickly I had to order a second small glass with my meal.  Should have just gone for the big kahuna!

Speaking of big, my meal was immense!  I ordered the Vieder Shnitzle, which I am told comes from Vienna, so it's not German - again.  Maybe I will have to go back on my original argument of loving German food.

Anyway, my shnitzle came as two plate sized, breaded pieces of veal on a huge platter with potatoes as well.  I mean, they were literally plate sized.  I ate as much as I could and still didn't quite finish one.  My date was, however, very impressed by my attempt.  The meal was sooo good and I left feeling that I'd gained 20 pounds, but that's what German/Belgium/Austrian food is all about, ya?

The service was great, and though at first I was a little thrown off by the family-style seating... it turned out to be fun.  You are put at a big rectangular table with a bunch of strangers.  A little odd, for a first date -  but fun nonetheless.

I will totally be back for the food, the beer, the great location, the service, and the joy of rediscovering my German ancestry.
author: Laura W.

description:
At Suppenküche, imagine you've left the Bay for Bavaria.

Luckily, we didn't have a wait, and got seated right away on a Sunday night.  The atmosphere of the restaurant is certainly German - dimly lit, wooden tables, and candlelight.  If that's your thing, which it is for me, it's romantic.

The beer and food menu are both overwhelming - but our server was happy to make suggestions.  I opted for the Franziskaner - appropriately served in a large glass .  For appetizers, we shared the artichoke soup special and the German ravioli in a delicious mushroom sauce - both of which were absolutely divine.  Don't forget the delicious sourdough bread and herb butter served at every table - delish.

For the main course, it was of course, the wiener schnitzel, which we chose to substitute the potatoes with the spätzle.  Two huge pieces of porkloin were served up with a hearty serving of the spätzle and salad. Don't underestimate the potatoes, however - those were also incredible, with bits of savory fried bacon.

Certainly this food isn't for the health-conscious, as other reviewers have remarked - but it's a classy, organic take on the best of German food.
author: Sara C.

description: I've never seen a beer so big in my entire life!!! its amazing. So to start with whats important the beer selection is godly, I can honestly say that I cannot pronounce a one, embarrassing yes, but isn't care cause its delicious delicious beer! On to the food exceptional German food. I went to a german school for high school and my best friend straight up german so I consider my self a second hand expert on cuisine.
author: Sean MC E.

description:
If you are considering going to any other German restaurant in the bay area- don't. Save yourself the time. Other places are fine, but you will never find a place this side of the Rhine that touches Suppenkuche. It is amazing. From the beer list to the menu (which is nothing but delicious items), to the mood and feel of the place...it can't be beat.

The lone bummer of this place is that the word is out and it gets slammed. This rarely deters me as I am more than happy to stand at the bar and sample something new by the liter.
author: Buren R.

description:
Food and beer are both great.  Spent some time working in Germany and this place brings back so many fond memories.

Very crowded and their door control is abysmal.  People walk in and stand inside the entrance (typically leaving door and curtain open as well).   The night we went it was very cold and there was a horrible draft.  Not to mention, I had some dudes ass on my arm for several minutes until I asked him to move.   Got an attitude in return.  It is incredible disrupting and honestly sapped any joy out of what would have been a nice meal.

I honestly don't know why they don't resolve the latter.  Post someone outside with a list and take down people's names.  DON'T let anyone inside unless they are 1) going to the bar or 2) have a table ready.
author: Cubicle D.

description:
I've been to Munich and I have to admit Suppenkuche is pretty darn close. I mean the beer is awwwwesssoommmee! No lie. I love their beer on tap. All of it. Way good. And then there is the food. It is so authentic German. You've got your meat like the spatten or the pig knuckle and then you've got your carb and cabbage. Dead on accurate.

Gotta say, this is one of my top destinations when I'm hanging in Hayes Valley.
author: jennifer s.

description:
Came here for brunch one rainy sunday morning. One of the few times that I did not consult Yelp before choosing a brunch spot, this was a delightful serendipity. We were originally heading out to Stack's in Hayes Valley for pancakes but after seeing the huge crowd in front of the restaurant, we decided to venture out to a new place. 

Please note to anyone looking to do Sunday brunch in Hayes Valley: come early or super late (like 2pm) since people head to brunch like it's the last meal on earth. 

We walked around the block trying to figure a place to our liking and after the third or fourth cafe/restaurant, we came across Suppenkuche. Seating was much faster than other places since the tables were communal. We sat next to a nice family with kids. The bf ordered smoked salmon scramble and I ordered the deconstructed pancakes. I have to say mine wasn't a pretty sight as the pancakes were broken up like scrambled eggs, looking very similar to the bf's plate. But it was quite delicious. Parts of it was slightly crispy while the other part of the pancakes was very moist. On the side was some sort of berry compotes and applesauce. A perfect compliment to the pancakes over the usual maple syrup. 

This place definitely requires another visit and maybe even another order of the pancakes. Yummm...
author: Jane K.

description: Suppenküche is less of a meal and more a place of perpetual bliss, like nirvana but with more beer and pig parts (read as: ALL OF THE BEER AND PIG PARTS).  My friend and I always start with their baked pretzel and bavarian cheese mix, followed by their silo-sized steins of beer and their expertly crafted pork sausage with sauerkraut.  Yes, the seating is cramped and the noise level high, but once your food comes all you can think about is the next time you'll be back at Suppenküche, tasting the thing that's making your taste glands swoon.
author: Michael D.

description:
After years of wanting to try this restaurant, I finally went with a neighbor on a Sunday.  We got there about 10 minutes after they opened and had no problem getting a table, but it was rapidly filling up.  In the past we always showed up when we were too hungry and couldn't bear to wait, so I was really excited to get there.

The atmosphere was fun and the dining was communal, which wasn't a problem since we had nice people at our table and plenty of room.  We weren't in the mood for beer (shocker), so we each had a glass of Merlot.  The bread was delivered to our table and included a huge soft pretzel and a nice flavored butter.

We started with a fresh salad with cabbage, carrots, beets, potato salad, and lettuce.  The small side was more than enough for the two of us.  We then split the sauteed trout that was bathed in a tasty lemon butter sauce.  For dessert they only had the Black Forest Cake, but fortunately we both love that and split a huge hunk. 

Loved the food, but I would like to go again with a less diet-restricted (ahem) dining partner so I could try some of the other things on the menu (like the venison, pork sausage, or pork chop).

I would highly recommend this restaurant as the food is good, the atmosphere is lively and fun, and the service is attentive (but not overly so).  Just make sure you get there early or make sure you aren't too hungry if you have to wait!
author: Kimberly B.

description: Great place! Lots of beers to choose from, many I haven't had elsewhere. Service was friendly and it was worth the trip for the potato pancakes alone. Next time, I'll have to return with a bigger appetite so I can eat and drink more.
author: Kellee K.

description: Really good, authentic German food and great beer selection.  Potato pancakes were wonderfully crispy and there was even a nice veggie dish of portabello mushroom stuffed with feta cheese and spinach as an alternative to all the meat.  My only gripe  was, sadly for me, a big one, though others might not care as much:  the noise level was almost unbearable.  I hate eating in a place where I have to shout to be heard and cup my ear (and say over and over, "WHAT???") to hear.  Really.  When I left, my ears were ringing for over an hour.  Can't they invest in some acoustic tiles?  I don't think the noise level is necessary for the Germanic authenticity.  Otherwise, it's a fun, friendly place -- huge portions, so go when you are really hungry.
author: Nina G.

description: I really love this place.  It's just down the street from where I live, the beers are overflowin, and what little girl doesn't love large portions of meat?  If you're not afraid of carbs, definitely check this place out for a casual dining experience.  Oh, and wear your stretchy pants.  Yum!
author: Aya S.

description:
It might be my German heritage, but this place is great! They have good, well priced beers and a fun little room you can sit in if you're just there for drinks and don't want to crowd the bar. Food is pretty delicious too, unless you're a vegetarian... then you just came to the wrong spot. I had the Jägerschnitzel and had to stop myself from licking the plate clean. The fresh warm bread served with the meal was also awesome (rye?) and served with some sort of herbed butter I probably could have eaten plain.

Only reason it didn't get five stars is its almost always too crowded. Catch it early or at an off time, and you're good to go. Otherwise be prepared to either wait for awhile or be crammed in. They could also reorganize tables/seating organization to make things not so hectic...

All in all, fun atmosphere, good food/drinks, bring family and friends and you should be set!
author: Heidi H.

description:
Das Boot!  They have it! (even a mini-one)

I haven't found a German brewhaus I like in California as much as this quaint little charmer.  Soup kitchen style communal seating makes for a fun and friendly atmosphere.  Plenty of good brews to choose from to fill up those boots and steins helps the mood too.

Food-wise, I say the potato pancakes with applesauce are winners.  I liked their bratwurst plate too.  Can't seem to remember how to spell anything else to save my life, but gotta give all the food a try.  Come here with friends or make some new ones.
author: alex C.

description:
Mikey says that I need to stop using Yelp as my public dating diary.  When it's about him, I don't think he'll mind...

I learned the hard way to never make a bet with my man Mikey D.  Yet I think paying him back by taking him to Suppenkuche ended up being pretty win-win.

On a cold drizzly SF night like we had the other day, Suppenkuche truly hit the spot with an ice cold beer, friendly service, and, in all its glory, the bread ball smothered in a rich, thick mushroom gravy.  Since I don't want to gain 50 pounds I won't plan on next time just ordering three of these as my appetizer, main, and dessert, but I'll be tempted.  God that thing was so good.

I don't know anything about beer except that I like what's cheap, so Mikey ordered for me.  Fortunately what I lack in beer snobbery/knowledge Mike makes up for and then some.  Whatever it was, it was crisp, somewhat light, and had a little spice to it.  Very tasty.

I'm a carb whore, so I was also obsessed with the bread and butter.  The butter they serve the bread with is smooth, whipped, salty, and seasoned.  Despite only having four slices of bread we slopped up the entire butter crock.

For mains, I had the braised beef with cranberries and Mikey had the venison (sauteed in red wine plum sauce).  I wasn't crazy thrilled with either, but they were both very good.  The meat was super tender (I could pretty much cut it with a spoon) and seasoned to perfection.  It *almost* made me crave some veg, but Mikey was thrilled: http://www.myspacebrand.com/funny_pictures/quote-images/_img/quoteimage28.gif.

The dishes did come with gravy, spatzle and pickled red cabbage, though, which were delicious.  I'm usually not one to leave meat behind, but when it came down to it I scarfed up as much as the spatzle as I could stomach and let Mikey eat about half of my meat.

From reading reviews, I think I'm going to go with chicken or pork next time--seems like those tend to be a bigger hit than the red meat at Suppenkuche.  And I'm definitely getting a bread ball all to myself.  Fatty alert!

Our dessert was an apple strudel with ice cream, which was also very tasty.  Even Mike could barely finish it, which is an indication that I got my money's worth at this place.  Trust me, if this guy was full (http://www.summitpost.org/image/470993/155422/ice-step.html), they did an amazing job.

My main complaint was probably the wait and the noise.  For two, we had to wait 45 minutes to be seated.  We ended up going down the street to Place Pigalle (really chill bar with a decent beer selection when they're not sold out) for a few beers before having dinner.  Then, when we did get seated, we had to practically yell in each others' ears to have a conversation.  Don't get intimidated by the crowd, and just don't try to have a romantic date here--the food is worth it!
author: Kara R.

description:
I don't even normally LIKE German food, and I loved this place!

I was VERY impressed that they had Currywurst on the menu. I have never ever seen this on any menu anywhere outside of the street vendors of *Berlin*. Naturally, it had to be ordered. While it wasn't quite authentic Berlin Street-meat, it was still very yummy and close enough to the real thing be satisfying.  My fiance ordered the Meatloaf which was so delicious.. and I had the Cheese Spaetzle, which was RIDICULOUSLY tasty and filling. 

We only had to wait about 15 minutes before we got a large table (for our group of 7) at the back. The service was quick, attentive and knowledgeable. Their beer list is incredibly extensive.. and if you are a beer lover you NEED to try 'Das Boot'. The biggest glass of beer ever! I just wish they had maybe a cider or two on the menu.. because if you aren't a beer drinker (like yours truly) your options are fairly limited.  But well.. What can you expect from a GERMAN restaurant, right? Oh well.

Expect to sit at long wooden tables, next to people you don't know. It's very traditional german in that way. The benefit is that you're bound to make a new friend or two! Shared wooden tables, noisy, boisterous, glasses of beer everywhere, and big sloppy portions of food. A great Deutsch night out!
author: Tamara B.

description:
Suppenkuche what a fun place to be at. When we first got there it was packed got our names in the waiting list and went for a walk. The area is nice it has a lot of boutiques, something to do while you wait. We got in about 30minutes after we checked in and the service was great. The night we went was very live... Imagine; Beers banging on the table from a table of 7 then on the other side of the room there are a group of people taking shots with the waiter... the bar was always packed and everyone is just having a good time. Best way to end a work week where everyone can just let loose. When started to order we ordered some beer first and We didn't know what to get so the waiter asked us what type of flavors we like and he gave us recommendations to what drinks to get. We ended up trying all of them and all fitted our needs. Then off to the food the food was great lots of taste to it and the soups were just to die for!!!

Scenery: Fun, Romantic
Food: Fantastic
Drinks: VERY GOOD
SERVICE: GREAT
Visit Again?: Most definitely
author: John B.

description:
Best German food I've ever had. Great energetic atmosphere and such friendly staff. Everything was delicious, large portions and the best sauerkraut I've ever had. Brought my husband and his out of town friend here on a Tuesday night, based on a coworker's recommendation, The boys were floored with the food, they were happy campers and I came out looking like a super hero! :P
it was crowded as usual, but we waited at the bar for only about 20 minutes. FYI, its very loud and crowded, not a great date place if you're looking to have intimate conversations
author: Lai T.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for a long time because everyone seems to love this place...finally made it this past Valentine's when I had dinner with some friends. 

It's cool that you get to share a table with strangers rather than waiting for an empty table just for your party (but if you're anti-social or needed the privacy, I guess this would be a negative thing). We all shared the Potato Pancakes to start; it comes with apple sauce. I liked it.

I got a Wiener Schnitzel--that was really yummy! I also got to taste my friend's Spatzle and that was yummy, too. One friend got the Ravioli and another one just had dessert, Apple Strudel, I heard both were good. Another friend got the Pork Chop, that was the least favorite food on the table because it was too salty for our taste. Also, don't expect the typical Pork Chop, it's more like a big chunk of ham. So if you like ham and salty foods, then the Pork Chop would be a great choice.

I can't wait to come back for Sunday Brunch!
author: Barbra C.

description:
Mach schnell, mach schnell!! (move it!) 

One of the limited German phrases that's fun to say for no freak'n reason, and it's the same equivalent for the fuck'n tards on KROQ (106.7) who are constantly saying "hai" - Japanese for "yes".  Well if KROQ is going to say "hai" to anything "Asian", I'll go ahead and say "mach schnell while drinking my dunkel/dark beer, but It's also something you luckily won't have to yell at the staff because they were very friendly and somewhat attentive on a very packed night. Hai!

It's been probably more than 10+ years since I went back, but I didn't forget the giant wooden picnic like tables which are great for a large group of your friends to pile around. Especially when enjoying a giant glass boot of beer - ok, we suck because we didn't do the boot, but the table next to us did. Instead we just had to make due with our "just as manly" huge steins while eating our brautwurst with a spicy mustard and sauerkraut. 

The only thing that I really didn't care for was my friends venison which was unfortunately prepared medium/medium well. Definitely overcooked for my tastes because it's such a lean meat, and fat is "flavor". Basically venison, especially elk and deer is the equivalent to that skinny hot toned chick you check out all the time at the gym.

Definitely a great place to drink, eat, and have fun with medium sized groups (6-8). Now, mach schnell because this place gets busy.
author: Greg T.

description: Always crowded so get there early or make sure to have a reservation. I think the food is generally pretty good and somewhat authentic from what I'm told. The restaurant is not that large so it gets real crowded and loud very quickly. I think it's ideal for casual group gatherings rather than a place that you go to for quiet conversation. They have a pretty extensive beer menu and serve up in boot size glasses if you wish to top brave it (...all the beer must have something to do with the loudness here).
author: Kent W.

description:
Very good food, and a great selection of german beer on tap and bottle.  Very friendly and helpful bartenders.    

Of course the 2L boot is intimidating and requires some serious sauf-time to consume.   What's with the wusses sharing it??

The only reason I dock a star is because on Saturday it was so full there was not even standing room all the way to the door, and a 1.5 hour wait for a table....
author: S C.

description: Hands down the best German food I've had in a long time. Environment is warm and friendly but I suggest if you have more than 2-3 ppl come early (literally right when they open because a line will have already started to form outside at five on the dot). SO WORTH THE WAIT. I was ravenous and waited an 1.45 minutes if that says anything.
author: Natalie S.

description:
HANDS DOWN my favorite restaurant in all of San Francisco. Great style, people, drinks, and delish food!! I recommend it to all.

I'm a vegetarian so I recommend getting these three side dishes (which comes out to be something under $12 bucks): 

1.Spaetzel (kind of like small lil fired dumplings) with the mushroom gravy 2. Sauerkraut (just eat around the lil chunks of meat)
3. Mashed potatoes!!!! 

Ohhhh its all so glorious. Plus go big and get the glass boot of beer! This place is worth the wait!

***Their spicy mustard is to die for***
author: Kacee S.

description:
Came here from a friend's recommendation on a Friday night at 9pm. At that time, every decent restaurant in the city was already packed, and of course this one wouldn't be an exception. Luckily, we only had to wait 20min to sit down (compared to 1.5hrs at Nupa =_=). 

Got a drink at the bar first. I had a glass of red wine, which was decent...while my friend got the german beer, which is definitely a specialty. It's definitely the best beer I've ever tasted, even compared to the ones IN germany. Highly recommend trying the beer!

The atmosphere was very vibrant. It's pretty crowded and noisy, but also has an interesting ambiance because the rooms were still slightly dimmed with candle lights. If you want to have a nice and chill conversation, probably shouldn't come here, unless you want to lose ur voice, or if you're looking to a fun place to go to snack and drink and laugh with your friends.

Food-wise, it was pretty decent. Between the two of us, we shared the LOBSTER BISQUE and PENTIL SOUP for appetizers. They were both pretty decent. I liked the veggies one more. I got the GRILLED LAMB CHOPS (friday specialty) while my friend got the pork chop. The lamb chops were pretty good...it came with mashed potatoes, which I didn't eat much of. The pork chop and macaroni wasn't the best...probably should have gotten the meat loaf. overall the food wasn't bad.. Definitely reminded me of Germany again, which I had just gone to a month ago.
author: Louisa L.

description:
Well.  I'd heard so many good things about this place from friends that it was probably never going to live up to my expectations...and it didn't!

Suppenkuche is very popular and always seems to be busy busy (it was packed when I went there at 1pm on a Sunday afternoon) but it just wasn't somewhere I could get excited about.  You sit around the tables on wooden benches, so there is a pretty basic, chilled out vibe.  There is an extensive selection on beer...but I don't like beer, which is also probably part of the problem.  I suppose beer enthusiasts would be more inclined to get excited about this place.

The food itself wasn't bad...but it just wasn't at all exciting or something that would make me go 'mmmmmmmm', as good, hearty food normally does.  I got the sausage, sauerkraut and mash.  It was alright, but I've had better.  I would rather go down the road to Moishes Pippic and grab some food from there instead.

Most of my other friends got the brunchy items, like the farmers omelette, and although it looked good, I'd probably go to a breakfast/brunch place if I wanted eggs...

Meh.  It wasn't bad, I was just underwhelmed.
author: Melanie B.

description: Visited with a group of five.  The place was packed we pulled up to the bar and started one of the best nights in recent memory.  Found the beer to be good and the atmosphere intoxicating.  The food topped off a great night.  I did find it a bit loud.
author: Scott R.

description: Friendly service with excellent food - what's there not to love?!  I can't wait to visit germany to see if this place is authentic! ;)  But either way, it was delicious.  It's a small restaurant so the communal tables are a good idea to maximize table utilization and turnover.  Food comes out fast too!  If you don't like sharing tables with strangers, you may be a bit turned off but honestly, it was lots of fun!  I had the potato pancakes, dumpling stuffed chicken and meatballs.  Delicious on all accounts.  Parking can be difficult in Hayes Valley so leave yourself extra time :)  By the way, the restaurant is a bit loud but it's festive.
author: Win L.

description:
I just found my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco. This is also the place to go if I suddenly decide I need to gain a few pounds - because I want EVERYTHING. 

It's my hubby's birthday today, and I was deciding to go for either the fancy 'special occasion' restaurant, or try a place where the menu read like a favorites list. Yes, we went with the latter. No regrets here. 

I ordered the Wiener Schnitzel, but with spatzle instead of the potatoes. OMG - my tummy couldn't be happier right now. My husband ordered the marinated skirt steak special. Tender steak grilled to a perfect medium rare. Potatoes au gratin that I couldn't stop helping myself to. Fabulous. My entree came with a small salad with a creamy, sweet dressing. Delish. My husband's came with a cucumber type salad - not so fab. But that's ok. The veggies were not our priority tonight. 

For dessert, we shared a warm apple strudel with creme fraiche and a small scoop of ice cream. 

I already know what I'm having next time, because there WILL be a next time. Bratwurst with mashed potatoes, and maybe the potato pancakes with apple sauce. 

Really nice service from our waiter. He was spot on in picking out an ale for my husband to try, based on hearing a little of what my hubby liked. Very attentive and helpful. 

Only thing that caught us off guard in the very beginning... if you have less than 6 people in your party, be prepared that you will be seated wherever there is room at a table. We were seated with two other couples we didn't know - who didn't know each other either. A little awkward at first, but then you get preoccupied with the yumminess from the meal.
author: Denise M.

description:
First impression: Suppenküche is far larger than it appears from the outside. The main room is quite spacious, with several private and communal tables, as well as a bar that includes a darker niche in the back. There's also a back room with a larger communal table, where you can see the staff peel potatoes and chop vegetables during off-hours. The high ceilings are adorned with a three dimensional bird and leaf motif - unexpected but cool. 

You can't make a res as a small party, so even during a Wednesday the bar was packed three-deep. No matter, because once you've fought your way to the front and secured one beer, you're set (assuming you can pronounce the name). Pretty sure the smallest glass amounted to a liquid dinner in itself...can't even imagine tackling the boot.

If you still have an appetite left, good, because the food portions are large and pretty rich. We split their specialty appetizer - the potato pancakes - to start.  Loved the pairing of homemade apple sauce, but we both agreed that the dish would've been better had it been served hot and crispy...our pancakes were on the greasy side.

We ordered Riesling to accompany the entrees; the sweetness was a nice balance to the heavier food. Never thought I would order (and enjoy) meatloaf with bacon and egg atop a generous mound of mashed potatoes, but it was hearty and flavorful - the ultimate comfort food. The other dish we split was my favorite: veal medallions in a plum sauce with cabbage and spätzle. I still don't truly understand what spätzle is - a pasta-gnocchi hybrid perhaps - but i am obsessed.  

Not sure how there was room for dessert, but we had to try the bavarian cream. Topped with fresh berries, it took cream to another level - sounds weird, but you'll see what I mean. 

Overall, a great meal. It's packed and rowdy, so don't expect to be able to hear yourself think, but if you order right you won't care.
author: A M.

description: Very fun traditional German gastropub that serves a large selection of beer in giant glass boots. These things are like a meal in itself. If you actually want a meal, they have some great German dishes like brats, whole chicken, and schnitzel. The last come in ans amazingly large potion and is delicious. Golden fried thin sliced pork with some potato pancakes. Yes it is greasy but so satisfying. Chase all of it down with a bottle of Underberg digestive bitters and you have one heck of a binge eating / drinking experience.
author: Ed L.

description:
Food and beer is excellent... but don't try to push your baby stroller into this place. Or wheelchair for that matter, it's just not that handicap accessible. There's a big step at the entrance, it's super crowded, the spaces are tight, and it's very loud. 

Probably a lot of fun for a few rowdy friends to meet up at to enjoy each others jovial company... but don't expect to be able to hear each other unless you're raising your beer steins and voices.
author: Maria L.

description:
Tragically, my five-star German darling has fallen from the sky.  Well, just one of the stars actually. 

I've finally had enough entrees that arrive with firmly overcooked meat. God, the best damned wirsthaus in the bay, and the owners are too scared of food poisoning to actually cook German dinners the right way. Oh and don't you dare try to tell me "well that's just how venison is... very tough."    

Add to that the general mood-swing of the staff in '08. Most Suppenkuche patrons already know that when you dine large (a party of 8 or more), then after your bill is paid, the staff will "boot" you off the table and back to the bar. This clean-sweep readies the table for the next patrons, and it's jolting the first time it happens, but lately the waitstaff ask you to leave as if ungrateful and unforgiving.  This is no five-star service to me.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I'm very torn on this one.  On the one hand, the food is delicious.  On the other hand, everything else about this place sucks.  Allow me to elaborate.

Went here tonight with my girlfriend because we love German food.  We were seated relatively quickly, considering how crowded it was, which was a nice start.  The first thing I noticed, however, was that this place was LOUD.  Like, seriously the loudest restaurant I've ever been in.  And on a Monday night, no less.  They need to put some carpet down or some wallpaper or something to muffle the sound.... it's really, really bad.  The whole night I had to lean in and shout every time I wanted to say something, like I was at a bar.  Except I wasn't, I was at a restaurant.

We got two appetizers: the potato pancakes and the fried cheese balls.  The pancakes were delicious... basically little hash brown patties with some really tasty applesauce to spread on them.  The cheese balls were kind of gross.  They came out cold and were served with this cranberry sauce that tasted more like wine than cranberries.  So one good app and one bad; those even out.

For our entries, we got a bratwurst with sauerkraut and roasted potatoes and the bacon and egg meatloaf, which came with mashed potatoes and gravy.  The bratwurst was very tasty (although my girlfriend bit down on something that seemed like a piece of bone and almost chipped a tooth) but the roasted potatoes were meh.  The meatloaf, however, was really really good.  It came with a hard-boiled egg in the middle of it, which was a really nice touch.  The mashed potatoes on the side were quite good as well - certainly better than the roasted potatoes with the brat (which I was surprised by).

I haven't even mentioned our service.  The service was downright abysmal.  We had some blonde amazon who was either the busiest a server has ever been or decided to dismiss us after we didn't order any alcohol.  The group next to us got their appetizers a good 10 minutes before we did, even though we ordered ours 3-4 minutes before them (and they got the exact same appetizer we did).  Our entrees took forever as well, which is fine, but once she brought them out, we pretty much didn't see her again.  One drink refill before the entrees came out, but none after.  We had to flag down a different server to get us a to-go box and to notify our server to bring us the check.  Of course, when we got the check, it had 3 items from the group next to us on it.  She fixed it after we pointed it out.... that is, after waiting 5 more minutes for her to come back to pick up our credit card.

So, in summary:
- Food ranging from good to very good.
- Horrible service.
- Bad atmosphere due to how loud it is.
author: Chad H.

description:
Overall the experience was pretty random. I think I might've enjoyed the boot liter of beer more so if I hadn't already had two cocktails prior.

Came here a little late on a Sunday night so there wasn't much of a wait for 2 people. We felt a little awkward being seated in a long table with a completely random group so we requested a seating change as soon as a table for 2 opened up. We ordered the potato soup, braised beef with spätzle, and a chicken special with dumplings and potato pancakes. The bread starter with some sort of herb butter was incredibly delicious (well, the butter was).  

The soup, beer (we chose one of the beer-lemonade mixes), and the bread was more than enough to fill us, so when we saw the generous portions of the entrees, it was a little overwhelming. The spätzle was definitely the best tasting part of our entrees, although nothing tasted bad. 

Overall I wouldn't mind coming back but the communal tables and the overall (lack of) ambiance makes you feel like you're eating at a hostel, but paying restaurant prices. Also, I wouldn't wait over 2 hours here so I don't recommend coming during the typical dinner rush.
author: Leily P.

description:
-vibrant atmosphere -- perfect for big groups to gather and chat
-you can practically hear the noise standing outside
-perfect place if you enjoy beer - they have this giant glass boot filled with beer for you to pass around and share with your friends
-great service - the waiters were very helpful answering questions about drink selections and food
-i enjoyed looking at all of the decor. there were rows of paper birds throughout the room
-the sausage and meat dishes are flavorful and savory
author: Rob N.

description:
Dang, what's left to say after 1,366 reviews?  I've been wanting to eat at Suppenkuche for a long time, and it did not disappoint.  I'm not really a fan of German food, but maybe Suppenkuche changed my mind.  

We ordered the roasted suckling pig, sauteed venison medallions, braised beef and organic chicken.  All were great with the consensus top-two being the suckling pig and organic chicken.  Sides of spatzle, mashed potatoes, roasted potatoes and sauerkraut all good too, and props to you if you can finish your meal.  Lots of fancy European beers with names you can't pronounce to choose from, and get to know your neighbors with the communal seating.  

Be prepared to wait 45+ minutes (just grab a beer down the street at Place Pigalle), and know it's LOUD, rowdy and cramped--but whatever.  Go eat here.
author: Manny R.

description:
after seeing friends' photos of drinking beer out of boots we decided to get together here for a small bday dinner.  the camera flash lit photos and black and white website dont really do the place justice.  the ceiling is artfully decorated to bring winter inside without the chill.  tables are communal and lit with multiple candles.  it feels homey and comfortable yet modern.

i made a reservation for 6, came in 15 minutes late with only 2 and 2 less people in our party.  the host was totally gracious and fine with it and seated us right away.  i started with a beer and lemon soda mix.  the servers were attentive with taking away our dirty dishes and making sure we werent thirsty.

the 4 of us shared a small salad of Carrots, Cabbage, Potatoes, Beets and Butter Lettuce which was just enough.  we also shared the special starter of currywurst which is chicken and pork tomato curry sausage and potatoes.  it was very good.  

i had the game hen with brussel sprouts and mashed potatoes.  the game hen was stuffed with a bread stuffing.  at the table there was also Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin, Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce, Spätzle, and Grilled Pork Sausage.  everything was delicious.  we cleaned off almost everything except the Wiener Schnitzel  because it came with 2 huge pieces.

i would come back again because i still didnt get to drink beer out of the boot
author: claudia y.

description:
First let me say that I really want to give this restaurant another shot, but Saturday night was definitely not ideal. I have several friends that have raved about this place so my friend and I decided to check it out. 

We got there probably about 6:45 knowing that we probably should have gone earlier, and that a thirty or forty minute wait would be doable. An hour and 15 minute wait is what we were quoted though. Not so cool.

We were pretty hungry so we went and got a snack to hold us over. Got back and we had gotten looked over, but were seated immediately--sweet. Sat down, ordered beer and an appetizer and voilá, lesson learned--you need an empty stomach for this place if you plan on eating AND drinking heavy German beer. We couldn't eat anymore so didn't get to try any of the entrées that looked delicious, hence why I'm willing to go back.

The potato "pancakes" we ordered are really more like hashbrowns than anything else--not that they weren't good, just not what I expected.

The atmosphere seems more conducive to large groups of people...seems like everyone was there for someone's birthday. It was pretty rowdy on the Saturday night, so I might try going on a weeknight next time. I'm the kind of person that doesn't like to yell across the table to be heard or strain to hear someone--however 2 liter beer boots may be the reason more so than a Saturday night :)
author: Krystha B.

description:
I can explain....

The food was great. Blew me out of the water.

The reason why I had to take 5 star flavors to a 2 star overall:

1) After a long week at work, the last thing I wanted to do on a Friday night was be in a very stressful environment. They don't take reservations so we had to wait an hour (maybe a little more than that) to share a table with 2 other parties. Now, I don't mind the family style seating and getting to know the people sitting with you but it was just too rowdy for a restaurant environment.

2) The boot. Now, the boot is cool. Essentially it's a huge glass of beer that's shaped like a boot. Now the downside of that (yes...there actually is a downside to that giant glass of goodness) is the crowd that it attracts. The people were douchey and loud. Lots of banging on the tables and screaming at the top of your lungs. I wanted to have a nice dinner, not feel as if I were in an overcrowded sports bar.

3) Because I waited soooo long to be seated, I lost my appetite and had to take 75% of my dish to go. I guess I am partially to blame for that.

The food was great...but I can't bring myself to go back there again even though the servers and bartenders were absolute sweethearts.

I'm sorry Suppenkuche. This isn't your fault. You can't control the crowd.
author: Jacinta H.

description:
Suppenkuche is a fun place to dine with friends. It's a pub-style restaurant with drunk, merry people here and there. I love their boot style beers.. how clever! I didn't try any of their beers however because I don't like beer.

I had the Meatloaf (with Bacon and Egg served with Onion Sauce and Mashed Potatoes). This entree appealed the most to me and I'm very glad I chose to order it. The sauce went very well with the meatloaf and the bacon added even more flavor to the meat.

My bf had the Suckling Pig which came out with Breaded Dumpling and Sauerkraut. Now, I am usually not a big fan of sauerkraut, but it was actually pretty good here! I ended up taking a lot of the sauerkraut on his plate because it went very well with my meal. :)

Overall, I had a pleasant and unique experience at Suppenkuche. If you want to try something different, casual and fun, check this place out!
author: Yun K.

description:
Will and I had dinner at Suppenkuche in November of this year.  

The interior is kind of rustic and simply decorated.  We sat on a wooden picnic type bench and we shared our table with a friendly, local family of three.  They emphasize communal dining at Suppenkuche, which is a good way to meet some of the other folks in the restaurant.  If there's space at your table, you may eventually have some company.  

The food was good and hearty.  

I had the Gegrillte Nünberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei (Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut and Mashed Potatoes) for $13.50.  Will had the Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoe mit Spätzle und grünem Salat (Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spätzle and Green Salad) for $16.50.

The sausage, all three of them, were served on a heaping portion of mashed potatoes and a generous portion of sauerkraut.  The sausage was good, but not great. The sauerkraut was a bit disappointing, it was a bit bland without the pungent kick that I'm use to.  

Will's pork loin, though, was excellent - tender and flavorful and swimming is an abundance of rich, creamy mushroom sauce.

We started the meal with Hering nach Hausfrauenart mit Schmand, Zwiebeln, Gurken und Kartoffeln  (Pickled Herring with Sour Cream, Onions, Pickles and Potatoes) for $9.50 that was really good.  The herring was perfectly seasoned and set in a large portion of vegetables and potatoes that was a small meal in itself.

Service was kind of slow, they seemed in need of additional help in the front.

It's loud inside, but that's a good sign. We were there on a Tuesday night and the place was packed with customers, customers who were in a festive and happy mood.  They've got a great selection of German beers, they've got up to 20 beers on tap.  

It's a fun and festive place to go with friends to enjoy some German beer and hearty Bavarian food.
author: Clyde R.

description:
I was trying to figure out if this was going to be a 3 star or 4 star review so I went with 3 on this one because the more I become a foodie, the picker I'm getting. 

So, why DID I leave it only at 3? 

1000+ reviews on Yelp should equal a place that rocks my socks off hardcore, but when I arrived to meet friends this last weekend I was kinda disappointed. 

So I arrive, and as I expect, the place is JAMMED but not to the extreme of not being able to move at least, so that was good.

Waitress at the front kinda gives me the "May I help you" look so I answer "Just meeting friends for dinner" without her saying anything to me quite yet when she responds "Well, do you have a reservation?", "No, what's the current wait?", "Actually we're done taking customers for the evening but if something opens up, I'll let you know, in the meantime you are free to eat at the bar" 

It's now 8:30 on a Saturday, ANY place that has stopped taking customers MUST have awesome food and although I wasn't quite in the German mood, I'd figure I'd find something that would do.

So I pony on up to the bar and start chatting it up with the bartender, younger guy like myself that knows one thing more than anyone I've ever met.

Beer Selection.

I was served some of the most unique Bavarian suds I've ever had and even got to check out the "you must be in the know" menu of hard hard hard to find treasures, so 5 stars goes to that.

I was VERY dissapointed with the food though, perhaps it's what I had, which was the Lentil Soup with Farmers Brat and bread. Just kinda tasted bland and meh, like I said, NOT what I was expecting from 1k reviews. 

It lost another star because every time someone (or a group) finishes some sort of boot, everyone in the restaurant cheers and the person takes in some sort of false sense of accomplishment, it's a boot for christs sake, it's NOT that hard to drink on your own.

I was impressed though and did cheer for the guy that finished the 5 liter beer, now THAT was an accomplishment, until that is, I saw him get sick just outside but whaddya gonna do?
author: Patrick O.

description: We got to the restaurant for the first seating at 5pm and it was packed within 20 minutes!  A nice clean family style restaurant with a friendly staff.  We tried three different beers, potato pancakes, German ravioli, venison and pork loin entrees.  I would definitely go back to try the different beers and more potato pancakes ~ they were awesome!!!
author: Lena L.

description:
I was away long enough for my memories of SF to be somewhat romanticized.  I thought of it as a smaller, quieter, cleaner NYC.  Upon my return, I walked through the Mission and had to get around a guy blowing snot onto the sidewalk, avoid what might have been human feces and got hassled by the crazies outside the 16th Street BART station.  I am home.  

Another night, outside of Suppenkuche, some homeless lady asked Euge when the Chinese Christmas was and he didn't lose his mind.  Some things do change, I guess.

Once we were seated and the boys got their half [*correction: full] liters of beer, they were all smiles.  Some things do not change.  Mine looked so dainty next to theirs.  We started with the potato pancakes and the asparagus with bacon.  The potato pancakes were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside deliciousness.  I had the wild boar sausage as my main and it was tasty.  I also tried the brat, meatloaf and pork with mushroom sauce.  All hearty and good.  

I may only eat potato pancakes next time.  That's ok, right?
author: Seong P.

description: My husband is a bit of a Germanophile (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germanophile) and after a stein at Biergarten we decided to grab dinner at Suppenkuche. It was a Thursday evening around 8 so we had to wait quite a bit (45 mins) but there was room at the bar to hang out. There is a large choice of beers (husband approved). The food is *surprisingly* good.. it's carby german food but oh so good. I recommend the weiner schnitzel (sp?) to go straight authentic.
author: Seema M.

description: I'm reviewing this late, so its not so fresh on my mind. But I cam here with some friends after the ballet. The appetizers: potato pancakes tasted like Jewish latkes which i love and the second dish had assorted salty food which was typical but being a russian-jew i eat bigger portions of that same food more frequently. For the main dish i had some food of the day---which was interesting, the sausages turned out different from what i expected, but its probably an acquired taste. Desert was home made strudel mmmmmmm delicious. The service was a bit slow and the place was crazy packed, and we had to sit with other people at our table..... a little awkward considering they were a bickering couple. Overall, pretty good try for my first German food.
author: Nikita K.

description: yeyeyeyeye echte german crowd with great sellection of beers and food. little too noisy but defenitely one of my favorite okace in the city.
author: Norbert H.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Sunday. We had to wait about 15-20 minutes, because the place was pretty crowded. When we finally got seated, it was kind of like being in a Beer Hall in Germany (both in food and decor). They seated us at a table with other people, because all of the tables seat like six people.

I contemplated getting the Schnitzel, for old time's sake. I didn't feel like something that heavy, so I got the emperor's pancake with nutella and apple sauce. It was good. Covered with powdered sugar. Probably too much food for one person, but I ate it all anyways. They only gave me one refill on my coffee, but that was probably all I needed.

Would definitely come back. Don't know why it took me so long to finally come here...
author: Dana L.

description:
This place is awesome!  

I would do 5 stars if I wasn't standing at the bar for an hour (stools, anyone??), but the place is great just the same!

I was nervous about the food because I'm vegetarian, but the food was fantastic.  I had a salad, and the spaetzle, which is a bit like German-style Mac N Cheese, which paired perfectly with my boot o'beer.   Gotta love it.
author: Alicia K.

description:
I want to love Suppenkuche.  But I brought my Kinder and that was a Kerfuffle.  Well no.. they were sweet with her, and she behaved great.  And we shared a table with other Kinder und Parent-en.  But OMG our ears bled.  Ok, nearly bled.

I kid you not.  The little boy at the next table, and my daughter both had furrowed brows and seriously put their hands over their ears throughout the meal.  The room was just way, way too full of people.  Anyone with tender ears (and I don't have tender ears, really), needs to pick either off hours or maybe brunch?  

GREAT beer.  3.5 to 4 star German food.  (Good but the meat was dry). Spaetzle were lovely.  Gravies very nice, and authentic.

But OMG the noise.  OMG, OMG, OMG.  I've never sat through a noisier meal in my life.  The ear drums were perceptably POUNDING when we stepped outside into the night air.

But hey - brunch sounds good!  I'll be back with earplugs, early in the day.

Vierdersehen!  Tjuss!  *mwa*
author: Juliana C.

description:
I think my heart is protesting. 

Heart: Gah!

Me: Hush. It will be okay.

Heart: All that cream! All that meat! What are you trying to do? Kill me?

Me: Now don't be silly. You know it was good.

Heart: I mean really. Fried Camembert? Is that really necessary? 

Me: Um.... Yes. Yes it is.

Heart: Why do you hate me so much? You KNOW you have cholesterol issues!

Me: I have been good for the past week. Veggies and all that. AND I'm missing out on NYE this year specifically to do a detox. That is for you and your neighbors benefit. The least you can do is allow me the creamy awesomeness of pork ravoli & fried camembert. 

Heart: Well I don't have much of a choice do I?

Me: No you don't. And you know what? I'm totally going to do it again. The feel of German beer hall was too cool, the food too good and the possibility of a 5 liter glass of beer is too much to only do once. And did you SEE how many amazing dishes there were? Did you TASTE Ben's venison? Holy God! No we are totally doing this again. And you should be able to handle it. You are a half German heart after all.

Heart:... 

Me: Hey, I have to go back if only to have the full Suppenkuche experience with their many fine brews. I didn't get that tonight you know. And what is this life worth if I don't live it?

Heart: Fine. But only as a treat. And you have to warn me about these things! And go take a walk so I don't pass out!

I'm so sad that I am on antibiotics and therefore couldn't enjoy any beer along with my meal. But at least my liver isn't complaining. There might be a revolt next time.
author: Alexis B.

description:
All I got to say is "the boot" 


... and the food is very filling and delicious if you decide to soak up the alcohol. I always leave here feeling nice*
author: Noel E.

description:
I LOVE this place!!

Great beer, BIG portions of food, their potato pancakes are fantastic, I get it every single time. Shared the Black Forest cake for dessert last time...incredible. 

If you have a large party, make reservations. If you're going there, go early because it's going to be a little while to wait. But you can always hang by their little bar and have a few drinks.

Sharing picnic bench tables with others and meeting friendly people is always fun for me!!
author: Andy L.

description: visited for first time on tuesday evening. the beer selection is good. the food was excellent especially the schnitzel, however the roasted potatoes were a little soggy:-( the place is very busy and the noise levels are high. hope to return again soon.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
I like big things. 

Big, hot, filling and bad but feels too good kind of things. 

So....I ordered the Meatloaf with an Egg and Bacon and Mashed Potatoes and a pint of Bittberger. I was served a big hot plate of fattening yummy deliciousness. 

I most definitley left contented. Even the guilty feeling was worth.
author: Jay H.

description:
Yum for the brunch-- it's always too crowded for dinner and it's first come first serve so I don't have the patience to now know when I will get food.  I had the bavarian meatloaf which was so good and salty, and came with eggs and potatoes with bacon/ham? bits.  Again, good and salty.  Needs a beer to wash it all down.  

When you want something hearty and meaty, this is a great place to try.  Oh, it's super loud all the time so don't go if you have a headache..
author: Kari L.

description:
The food here is really good, as is the beer. And you an get it in bulk form , if you want to drink for a misproportioned glass boot. I guess I would rather have four pints than one giant 2 liter boot if given the choice, but that's just me...

It's also a pretty good value, considering the size of the portions. It's very meatcentric of course, but the sides (carbs such as delicious spaetzle and mashed potatoes) and cabbage type vegetables are also delicious. I've not had room for dessert either time I've been here, but they do look fairly tasty.

The service here is a bit spotty. For a place that endears itself to large parties (bench seating), it seems that not all their wait staff is competently trained in how to handle such parties - oh like making sure everyone gets a chance to get their drink order in. -1 star for that, for sure.
author: neil c.

description:
this was a super fun time. drinking das boot has been on my alcoholic to-do list for some time now. 
you will need:
-$50 deposit for boot (these are limited in quantity)
-$30-$50 for the beer of your choice.
-to order food? 
-stomach of steel 
-no shame
-an hour or more to kill

the entire boot experience was what warranted the 4 stars. as for the food, its pretty passe. german food in general isn't my favorite but i've had better. also, the food is very overpriced considering what it actually is. that said, this place is tons of fun and i would love to make a return visit.
author: Joseph N.

description:
The place is small, crowded, extremely loud, but I absolutely love it! We squeezed our way to back of the bar, had a beer while waiting for a table..and everyone was friendly even though I was elbowing my way through the crowd.
Its a fun atmosphere so if you have to wait a little longer than most places..who cares!
Our table ordered a little bit of everything...pork loin in mushroom sauce, the meatloaf, braised beef and stuffed portobella mushroom dishes...all were tasty! But go hungry!
author: Marie O.

description:
I've been a few times, which is the only reason I'm giving three stars. Based on today's food and service I would otherwise give 1 or 2 stars. 

Went for brunch on my first father's day, so was really looking forward to some pretzels and sausage. On the brunch menu was weisswurst and pretzel - perfect!

Long story short it comes out stone cold. The sausage had obviously been refrigerated and not reheated properly. I tried a few bites and gave up. The waitress to her credit came quickly and as I'd she'd get a new one for me. 

Nope. Microwaved. Came back out with that gross microwave taste and in pieces. 

Very disappointing and a total fail.
author: Tim C.

description:
I hate German food and hipsters. So why the heck did I come here? I was out maneuvered by some friends who had a sauerkraut craving. I lobbied for Bar Jules but lost in the election. 

So Goulash is it. And we did actually get goulash which was too salty. However the potato pancakes were fantastic. Totally deep fried to perfection. 

My friends got the jagerscnitzel (sp?) and it was okay. I'm not generally a fan of thick gravy. Upon the waitress's second recommendation (she offered sausage first and I don't like sausage. I like my meat in pieces that resemble the animal. Call me crazy.) I ordered the chicken dumpling special of the day and substituted spatzel for the potato pancakes. I thought the "chicken" was really a Cornish game hen and very game. I liked the moist texture and the crispy skin. However the dumpling was kinda funky for me. I don't really like mushy bready dumplings. The spatzel was salty and a bit soft for my taste. 

The good points are that they have interesting beers and serve them in proper stijns and, the portions are huge and I had enough for lunch the next day. However, the place is ridiculously noisy and a mecca for hipsters.
author: Monica L.

description: This place is fantastic!  Others apparently think so too, since it was crowed the entire time my family and I were there. The German food is authentic and delicious. . . but the best part about this place is the beer selection. Some of their beers you can't find in the U.S.; specifically, they have Augustiner!!! A beer that's difficult to find outside of Bavaria. I cannot wait to go back.
author: Carly S.

description:
This place is just plain awesome, I mean, i can't really think of any other places that serve German food, let alone good German food.  Couple good food with awesome beer (served in a boot) and you're in for good times. 

We came here for a birthday party and had boot races between 3 tables, which was awesome, and led to a little inebriation, which was also awesome.

Definitely don't miss the potato pancakes, they're...wait for it...awesome
author: Craig E.

description: To be honest, I don't get what all the hype is about. My sister and her fiancé love this place, so I was pretty stoked to try it. I got the bacon wrapped meat loaf-sounds bomb right? Meatloaf was dry and not too flavorful, very mediocre. In the lowest tier of meatloaf I've ever had. My dad got the pork chop. It tasted like it was marinated in salt water, and tasted nearly identical to a simple ham. Maybe this is the German way but we were not impressed. I will say the beer situation here is pretty legit. They have a good variety of imported, quality German beers that are very reasonably priced. I would go back here only for the beer, as there is bar seating available. Overall very unimpressed though, so don't get too excited.
author: Galen W.

description:
The only place you'll find German food on par with this local SF favorite is Deutschland.  

Any place that has Erdinger on tap is an extraordinary establishment.
author: Grant M.

description: Absolutely fantastic food. I don't recall having better pretzels and the sauerbraten was amazing. VERY BIG portions, too.
author: Matt M.

description:
I would be giving this place a serious 5 stars because the food is amaz-o, but I was so annoyed by the cook dinging the bell repeatedly last time me and my fella were there. Seriously, somebody needs to say something to him. The back room is right by the kitchen and he was banging on the damn bell like crazy! I could tell other people were annoyed too and the poor waiters! I know that kitchen was pumping out plates of food like mad, they do really good business, but I saw those waiter busting their butts and I KNOW they could hear that bell because it was echoing around that room like torture. 

Other than that, I love the place. Great selection of beer. The cucumber salad is so good. The spazle was so yummy. Those lamb sausages seem wrong they are so tender and good. Love the interior too. I think the little bar seating room is the best place to sit if you are just two. Cute place.
author: Maria D.

description:
I can not rave more about this place...already.
I had a Sunday Brunch here with my close friend Francesca and we had
so much fun. People were eating breakfast and beer. 
And AGAIN the staff was great. I want to live here!!
I told you that I would be back and I will keep on coming back
Vass Its Los!!
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
Great place for deutsches Essen. I always get Nurnburger Bratwurst (I used to live in Nurnburg) and Jaegerschnitzel. 

Would have been 5 stars but for inconvenience of no reservations for parties with fewer than 6 peeps.
author: John D.

description: Have had many happy times at this place over the years. Great German beer and food. Can't go wrong here!
author: Nicholas B.

description:
THIS IS HANDS DOWN ONE OF MY FAVORITE RESTAURANTS OF ALL TIME.

As soon as you step into this bier haus, you are engulfed in the aroma of delicious German fare and traditional biers of Germany/Europe.  Yes, there was a crowd, but it was Friday night and this place is sweeeet.

Food
I had the roasted chicken with potato pancakes.  The experience was like having your mom slave over an oven roasting you a meal all day.  The skin was perfectly seasoned and crispy.  The stuffing felt extremely homey.  The meat was very tender and even served with some drippings!  The potato pancakes are a very nice touch and complement the dish very well.

Beverage
I had the German black bier.  The bartender/an Old 'Weiss' Man named Criag, who was super awesome gave me the recommendation for food/beverage.  Great combination.

All in all, I am pretty much in love with this place.  It reminds of the Heidelberg in Ann Arbor, MI except with more boots and better food.  I am sure to come back with more friends in the future.  I plan on renting out the back room and playing the boot game.....If you dont know what the boot game is, all I can tell you is that it's like a Z-jay.  If you have to ask, you cant afford it.
author: Jayson F.

description:
I saw this place being reviewed on Check Please Bay Area and it has been on my list of places to go for a while, but mostly for the beer since I'm not too fond of German food. Well, not too fond until now! 

This is definitely NOT A DATE PLACE. Please don't try to impress your girl/guy by taking them here for a date. This is a bring your friends and drink beer out of a boot place. It's VERY loud and lively. Great for groups. But not too big of a group since each table can only seat up to 8 people (only 6 if you want your own elbow room) and be prepared to wait for a table. And they only take reservations for parties of 5 or more. 

I went with what I like to call the German Version of Tonkatsu. It was a deliciously seasoned, pounded pork tenderloin deep fried and cover in a mushroom gravy. Came with a side salad and spatzel. It was superb. I also had a bite of a pork sausage and boar sausage. The boar sausage was my favorite! 

The potato pancakes.. Omg... I mean, technically it's just a really well executed hashbrown, but this comes with a side of apple sauce or apple jelly. It was great! But I'd like to smother it with cheese, bacon and scallions. YUM!!! 

The beer selection is large and interesting. And don't get me started on the sizes. Compared to Eugy and Dan's .5 liter, me and Seongs beers looked like tiny baby bottles. :( 

Prices are CHEAP and service is good! GO!
author: Jen D.

description:
We came here last Sunday.  I had such high expectations for this restaurant and I'm sad that I didn't have a good experience.  

They didn't take reservation for our party of 4, so we went in and put our name on the list.  The hostess said the wait would be 1 hour.  We waited and got beer at the bar and got seated in 30 minutes.  The restaurant was very crowded.

We got seated on the same table as another party of 2.  The waiter didn't know that we weren't in the same party so he only gave us 1 basket of bread.  The sharing was a little awkward but eventually, he gave us another basket.

We ordered a second round of drinks, a curry and sausage appetizer, and our entrees.   Our appetizer was good.  My something-berry soda was pretty tasteless.  The beers were good.  My husband's entree was veal sausage and sauerkraut, which was good.  I had breaded pork and mushroom sauce which tasted like something you order from Denny's.  

To make it even worse, some waiter dropped utensils on my husband's back which left a stain on his shirt.  We told our waiter and he brought us some warm soapy water to clean up after ourselves.

We will not come back.
author: Tracy D.

description:
I've been here twice now and both time I left so stuffed that I didn't need to eat breakfast and lunch the following day. The trick, I think, is to share an appetizer and main course. Along with beer. Lot's of beer! 

Enjoy the group/beer hall style seating--especially if there's friendly people sitting by you! Quite, romantic, secluded date-spot this isn't. 

Seems like there's always a long wait, so don't be surprised by it. Instead, walk around and enjoy the neighborhood.
author: alejandro p.

description:
Pretty solid place.

Portion size: Big, shared the venison with a friend and we still had leftovers.

Food: Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce
with Red Cabbage & Spätzle - Venison had the sauce on the side. Very filling. Tasting just like the food I had in Germany. Don't love it, but it tasted legit.

Drinks: Many types of beers on tap. I had the Radler (beer with lemon soda). Loved it!!

Atmosphere: Fun place. Loud. Good place to grab beers and drink with friends.

They are known for their boots filled with beers. I even saw pitchers that you can fit your head in. The 5-6 of us ended up sharing a rectangular table with 2 people. Pretty cozy table, but that was fine with us.
author: Anita C.

description:
Do NOT eat here if either you have a food allergy or you're a strict vegetarian.  Here's why:

I'm allergic to lobster.  If I eat lobster, within a couple hours I get extremely hot and I get these wonderful hives that are bright red.  Basically, if I eat lobster, I look like a lobster.  In my case, you really are what you eat.

When I was looking over the menu at Suppenkuche, I noticed they had a lobster bisque.  Not for me.  The waiter suggested the pea soup and he verified that it was vegetarian, so I went with his suggestion.

Aaaand a couple hours after dinner, I started having an allergic reaction.  Frightening.  I'm assuming something sloppy was going on in the kitchen, and they were using the same utensils in the two soups.  I'm not terribly allergic, but there are plenty of people who are deathly allergic to seafood.  That warrants Suppenkuche's kitchen to be careful about what ingredients are getting in their dishes.  

Additionally, it's disrespectful to explicitly tell customers that dishes are vegetarian when, clearly, meat is finding its way into the vegetarian dishes.

I'm appalled.  I'll definitely never go here again.
author: Nicole K.

description: The beer was, as expected, great. The restaurant is very loud and you are elbow to elbow with strangers but it is a fun atmosphere. If you are needing to hold a conversation you might want to skip this - but if you're out for a beer and a good time stop in.
author: Carolyn B.

description: food was okay. nothing memorable. we had the ravioli mushroom. i would give a higher rating had our waitress not try to add 20% tip to a table of 4! when the menu mind u, states that gratuity is added for 5 or more ppl. so we kindly alerted put waitress and she actually said " o oops my mistake, well ur leaving tip anyway" really!? yea we are but hey its ur restaurants policy, so kindly make the adjustment on the bill and we will gladly leave tip as we were planning on anyway consumerate the service we actually recieved. She looked annoyed when we asked her to adjust our bill. minus another star. minus a second star for kicking us out when clearly there were still ppl at the bar drinking! get the f***out of here with that bull! so we left, and trust me will never go back. thanks for ruining my first time visit based on other friends suggestions.
author: Christina M.

description: Potato pancakes and DAS BOOT is all you need to know and get.  You will be happy, hyper, and hungry!
author: Vien T.

description: Never been there till last night. It was crazy packed. Beer was awesome. Bartender's were amazing and cool. Zero attitude in the place. The clientele left a little to be desired. Lot of young Dot.com looking baby yuppies. But screw them the food was awesome the beer was amazing and it was loud and crowded. Loved it!
author: Mr. K.

description:
What?? 
Huh?? 
I can't hear you!! 
What? 
No, I am not queer.
Oh, another boot of beer? No thanks, but a to go box would be great! 
No, not a toboggan, a to go box, for my food!! 
No, I did not call you rude, I want a box for my leftover food!
I am not a wreck, how dare you say that to me! 
Ohhh, my check. Yeah, got it. Thanks! 

To say it is loud in here is an understatement, but for some carb heavy German goodness it is almost worth the awkward exchange you will have with the waiter at the end of the meal.
author: Drue C.

description:
Just had dinner there on my way to the symphony.  I love this place!  Very friendly service.

I'll start w/what i loved...
Loved the vibe.
Very friendly service
delicious strudel & ice cream dessert
Serving size is huge
Decent drinks menu

What i did not like on tonight's dinner.
I had their oxtail special.  Unfortunately it was very salty and not all the meat fell off the bone easily.  had to struggle a bit.  the sauce tasted a bit gelatinous...  too much corn starch or something.

but will go again and try the classic sausage & mashed potato.
author: Marcia B.

description:
LINGUISTICS AND LANGUAGE FAMILY HISTORY 201

Guten Morgen and welcome to the second week of LALFH 201.

I agree with the more than 400 reputable reviewers who unanimously praise the charm, excellent latkes, and schnitzel of this spartan restaurant.  I'm a potato queen devoid of personality who knows her sausages, so I know what I'm talking about.

But we are here to LEARN! [pounds podium]

Suppenkuche -- or rather, "Suppenkueche," since this primitive yelp text box does not allow for umlauts -- is a noun with a rather proletarian meaning: "soup kitchen."

We can use this noun in the following ways:

1. Hans Castorp starb an der Tuberkulose in der Suppenkueche (Hans Castorp died of tuberculosis in the soup kitchen)
