2. Herr Baader und Fraeulein Meinhof sprengten die Suppenkueche (Mr. Baader and Ms. Meinhof blew up the soup kitchen)

3.  Friedrich Nietzsche ist verrueckter als eine Suppenkueche (Friedrich Nietzsche is crazier than a soup kitchen)

4. Es ist die suppenkuechezeit!  Es ist die suppenkuechezeit! (It's soup kitchen time! One says it like "IT'S PEANUT BUTTER JELLY TIME!  PEANUT BUTTER JELLY TIME!")

For some linguists, controversy regarding pronunciation rages to this day.  Does one say SOO-pen-KEW-ka? Or soo-pen-KOOSH?  Or the Italianate ZUP-pa-koo-CHEE-na?

Fortunately, this issue is irrelevant as German is a dead language not spoken by civilized people.

And that ends today's lesson.

EDIT: Many thanks to Cootz and Mary for the in-depth discussion of German phonology.
author: d s.

description:
Germans have bought much joy into my life. For example:
1) Even Dwarves Started Small
2) Kraftwerk
3) La Bouche
4) Run Lola Run
5) Heidi Klum
6) Nekromantic

And now, by way of the 21 Hayes, they bring me two of my other favorite things, meat and beer. You'll be sharing a table for sure, which means you can overhear wonderful conversations including a heartfelt monologue from some poor guy admitting he had no self confidence and was finally going the way of the personal ad.  

Gigantic portions, which defeated even me and as you probably tell, I think that I have had about 2 meals in my entire life that I did not finish.
author: Maria D.

description:
Groaningly good and hearty in a pants-expanding, calorie-loading kinda way. Always loud, raucous and jam packed with shiny happy people. You WILL wait for your table and you WILL drink a lot of very good beer. You may drink it out of a giant glass boot or just an obscenely large stein. 

(Semi-interesting fact - "klein" means "small" in German.) For the record, there is nothing "klein" here. Even the "klein" salad is big - loaded with beets, boiled potatoes, pickled cabbage of varying hues and shredded carrots. It serves as a colorful contrast to the heaping piles of mainly beige, brown and white food that surrounds you on all sides (communal seating you know). Mountains of mashed potatoes, spaetzle, sauerkraut, various schnitzels and pork tubes (yes, wursts) juicy chops, meatloaf, thickly sliced rye bread with herb butter, blastingly hot mustard and yes, yes, yes - potato pancakes! Those oily discs of love so very tasty with applesauce and sour cream.

I hear the apple strudel is very good for dessert. Oh yeah - like there's lots of room left for dessert. Now that's rich.
author: wendella a.

description:
Arrived at the restaurant between 530 and 6pm, and was able to get a table very easily, but it was a communal table.  But within 45 minutes the restaurant was full.  Service was good and quick, and the food is excellent.  
I deducted a star because of the noise level.
author: Matt W.

description:
I want to give Suppenkuche five stars based on the food alone. Unfortunately, considering the entire experience, I am dropping it to four stars, simply because we had to wait for over an hour for a table. (BUT, it was worth it!) 

While we were waiting, we ordered the potato pancakes with the applesauce. Delish! Of course, we washed it down with beer! 

Finally, we were seated, family style, with a fun couple. I would hate to see how dinner would play out if you didn't like your table mates, but luckily for us it turned out well. 

Our waitress, Katie was really sweet, and very apologetic for our long wait. She sat down with us, chatted it up a bit, found out I had just graduated nursing school, exchanged emails because she is interested in nursing school, ya know, just being super nice and hospitable. (Katie, I was serious, you can email me if you need anything!) 

Then, she suggested some yummy meals, of which, I chose the pork chops with sauerkraut. My grandma, who is German, ordered an onion dish, which she did not like at all, so I would not recommend that. I, on the other hand, thoroughly enjoyed my meal. 

I left with a satisfied stomach, a bit of a buzz, and a number from a cute boy. Maybe I will be back, but next time, on a date?
author: Marta C.

description:
We stopped in for brunch yesterday with some friends, and was reminded that those Germans (or at least the people who work at a German restaurant) know how to have a good time. 

The nice thing about brunch is that Suppenkuche is slightly less busy than at dinner, so you can manage to walk in and sit down pretty quickly, even with two babies in tow (just one was our little man).

While there were some tasty-sounding specials, I played it safe with the wiener schnitzel and spaetzle, and fiNished up both happy and full. German food to me is about simplicity and heartiness, so why break from tradition!?!

Washed down with a pitcher of grapefruit mimosas, and then a shot of Unterberg (down with Fernet!), the rest of Sunday just seemed like a walk in the park.
author: Nish N.

description:
I have lived in SF almost 12 years and this is my favorite restaurant here. 

Excellent food, beer, service and vibe. 

They have the best and most German beers on tap as any place I have ever seen in North America and all are served in the appropriate and official beer glass of the brand. Also, the food is hearty and delicious. The Jaeger Schnitzel in a mushroom cream sauce is by far my favorite and I love the spatzle (german pasta) that comes with it. If the epic food and beer were not enough the seating is all family style so you are likely to share a table with one or more other festive groups -- making your meal a very social and enjoyable time. 

I have taken a few clients there before and have been favorably reminded of the event a year or more down the line so that is further testament to this wonderful restaurant.

Note that the place is small, the close tables are utilitarian, the seating is family-style and the place gets crowded but if you embrace the beer-haus type setting you will have a blast of an evening.
author: Mike L.

description: This very popular, extremely busy restaurant is far from the city center and does not accept reservations -- big, big minus. My German friend and I tried to eat here on three different occasions but we have not yet been able to get a table. On every occasion, when we entered, the staff was rude -- they did not even acknowledge us. When we approached them, we were told to have a few beers while waiting for a table and it might take an hour but there is no guarantee to get a table. WTF?!? I don't mind waiting 30-45 minutes but at least guarantee a place. It shows complete arrogance otherwise. Until they move to somewhere central  (e.g. Powell), this restaurant should put aside a fraction of their tables for reservations.
author: Damian E.

description:
When my friend and I were thinking of the place to go to for dinner, his suggestion seemed anything but pleasing. My friend described a restaurant that sounded serenely beautiful and inviting, but something didn't add up.  His suggestion was Suppenküche, a small German restaurant at 525 Laguna Street in San Francisco. I was apathetic about the choice for several reasons.  I thought of parking, crowds, cramped spaces and more, but what really made me wary was the fact that the food was German.
 I will admit that prejudice and stereotyping had a lot to do with why I was hesitant to try the cuisine of the Fatherland.  The German culture of efficiency, hard work and stoicism seems better put to use in creating the finely tuned engine of BMW's M3, but not kindly tending to a delightful dinner with friends.  Sauerkraut and cabbage sounded as intriguing to me as a tour through an office park. But I had no other options, we were going to Suppenküche. Also, the name translates to "Soup Kitchen"--no points added for creativity.
 With the decision made and the date established, we rounded up the girlfriends for double points.  We crammed into my Honda Civic Coupe, and we were going off on our dining experience for the evening. Scouring the streets for any resemblance of a spot, parking in the area was difficult as predicted, but we finally arrived.
 The restaurant was tiny and nearly invisible if you weren't looking for it.  I was getting claustrophobic simply thinking of the enclosed space. I noticed all the tables were full, but the tables were huge and most were seated half empty.  This is when my friend informed me that we will be eating with total strangers.  I panicked. I hate being on the near strangers at all, let alone being on a date with John Doe San Franciscan breathing down my arm. When we were seated, I chose the farthest spot from the nearest unknown hipster slurping down some soup.  My breathing back to normal, I started to look around, and up.  The place was really something else.  Tiny black paper birds flew around the void white ceiling, their motions captured in a single still instant. The sight was calming. I continued to look around.
 Behind the bar were taps of different shapes and sizes sprouting out of the bar and walls like mushrooms.  Glass boots were filled with golden ales and pitch black brews.  My shoulders loosened; I smiled for the first time since the car ride.  The conversation picked up in our small group, and we talked like no one else was there.  The waitress greeted us and asked for our drink order, but I had been so caught up in the scenery that I had forgotten to look at the menu. I ordered the first beer that I saw in the tiny bi-fold menu.  She came back so quickly it hardly seemed like she had left.  A big frothy boot was slammed down in front of me. I ordered the Franziskaner, a hefeweizen wheat beer. In the faint light coming through the windows, the beer glowed bright yellow and gold.  It was like candy and about half way through the enormous glass I had a strong buzz and was ready for a hardy meal.
 I really had no idea what I ordered, but I stung together a series of syllables as best I could, and what I got was Sauerbraten mit Lingonbeerkonfitüre, serviert mit Rotkohl und Spätzle.  It was braised beef with lingonberries served with red cabbage and Spatzle.  The Berries were something I've never heard of, but they tasted amazing. In fact, I haven't had most of the food before, but even something as foreign as spatzle tasted surprisingly familiar.  The egg noodles reminded me of an old recipe my grandma once made for my family. I am not German, my family is not German, yet German culture is so available to Americans that it's hard to make the distinction between the two.  The ingredients and spices weren't all the new to me; it was like tasting the predecessors to all the food I grew up with. The whole experience seemed archaic, like I was going back in time.
 I wanted to try more; I pulled a pork sausage away from my friend for a bite.  The sausage exploded with spicy flavors as I bit into it.  I ate more than I probably should have.  The meals were gigantic and I finished my plate, some of my friend's.  Each dish, heavy with meat and potatoes, was unique and flavorful.  When I finished, I was tired from the food, beer and the chewing. I was exhausted.  We had left we surprisingly little squabble over the bill and hobbled back to the car. In good form I leaned over to my friend driving from the back seat and exclaimed "Donke!"
author: Graham U.

description:
Its no wonder Germans are fat.  That is a broad generalization...I'm referring to the ones always pictured in leiderhosen...the women carrying 15 liters of beer at the same time, etc. So, if you are German, and not fat...kudos to you...I'm not talking about you.

Their beer is cheap, their beer is huge, and their beer is 7% by volume.

Their pork is huge, their potatoes are buttery, and their everything else is drenched in sauce. Their potato pancakes are amazingly fried, (highly recommended) served with sour cream and apple sauce, and even their "healthier" option of a stuffed portabello was topped off with a generous portion of cheese.

Fatty bobatty is what i felt....but at least I left with 3/4 of my meal in a box for later....so i can relive the fat feeling again tonight.

Careful your fat doesn't roll over onto the chair next to you however... cuz its possible community seating, and they might not want to touch your muffin top like i do.  And...boy, do I.

------------------------------------------
Original Review 12.13.06
Really good beer, really large beers, great place for beer.
Good German food too.
Went here on a really weird date, but the really large beers helped me out in the lack of conversation area....cuz i just got hammered.
Made me feel like i was in Germany all over again.
author: Lauren F.

description: I love this place. Just went for the first time last night, and I'm surprised I didn't go sooner! It's a cute little place that gets packed fast. We had a large group and they were able to accommodate us even though we hadn't made a reservation. Which is awesome! The beer is super good, especially the Köstritzer Schwarzbier, half of our group ended up ordering tons of it. The food is also super good- I ordered the potato pancakes and they were delicious! Not to mention totally filling. Next time I want to try the stuffed portobello mushroom, looked soo good. The food was a bit pricey, but for the whole experience it was totally worth it.
author: Sonya D.

description: I started going to Suppenkuche after they first opened sometime in the early nineties. I used to live in the neighborhood and I used to be married to a German girl so we went there often. While Walzwerk in the mission is gaining ground as my favorite Suppenkuche still has a fond place in my heart. I like the communal tables, they give you a reason to chat with your neighbors. They have the best selection of German beers in town. Also where else can you drink beer out of a two-liter glass boot? While it is no longer convenient for me to get to Suppenkuche I will still stop by from time to time for years to come.
author: Manny F.

description:
I realize we live in one of the dining capitals of the world and most good restaurants in San Francisco are always crowded and hard to get into.  But my experience at this over-packed, extremely noisy restaurant was THE WORST I have ever had.  

They don't take reservations, so you always have to wait.  We (party of 3) decided to dine at Suppen Kuche on a Saturday. We knew it would be crowded, so we decided to get there early - 7 p.m.  We were very lucky to get a parking spot right in front of the restaurant, but our luck was soon to turn to disaster as we entered a very packed, loud restaurant.

The hostess told us it would be an hour wait.  We decided to brave the wait and enjoy some German beer at the cramped bar.  As we attempted to enjoy some great German beer, we kept getting bumped and stepped on by people cramming into the restaurant. At one point, a woman stepped on me and told me to move. I couldn't move anywhere, so she got pissy and flipped me off.  The hostess seemed overwhelmed by the crowd and was stressing out.  One of the waiters, trying to squeeze through the crowd to deliver to a table, got bumped and dropped and plate full of spatzel all over the floor. Everyone in the vicinity got it all over our shoes. Yuck!

Well, an hour and a half later, we were losing our patience. The hostess, noticing we had been waiting so long, pointed to a table and told us that we could have that table as soon as the people there left. The people finally left, the table was cleared and we maneuvered through the crowd so we could finally sit down only to watch in horror as she seated another group of people who had been there half the amount of time as us.   I couldn't believe it!  With spilled beer on my shirt and spatzel all over our shoes, I finally lost my temper.  I tried to stay calm and asked the hostess why she sat another group who had only been there half as long as we had and she said something about not being able to sit the group at another table. Another guy with his date had also been waiting an hour and a half and was promised half of our table. He lost his temper too.

Once she realized that she screwed up so bad, she sat us at a table next to the bar. I had to sit right in front of a bunch of drunk people who kept bumping my chair while I ate.  It was so loud we had to yell at each other to speak. 

After such a horrible experience, it was hard to enjoy the food. It was ok, but definitely not worth the wait.  The only saving grace was our very nice waiter, Brian, who apologized and fed us.  Me and my partner ended up getting in a huge fight because he wanted to leave and not give our money to a business who would treat us like this. Me, on the other hand, figured we waited this long - we mine as well eat.  We went to bed mad at each other and didn't speak until the next day.  If a restaurant dining experience can do this, it's probably a bad idea to go there.

They really need to have reservations here - to at least help people know when to show up.  Reserve half the restaurant and have the other half for open seating.

And the hostess!  Horrible. She never communicated with us, she didn't know how and when to seat people in order of their waiting time, she never apologized for giving our table to another group and she kept giving us excuses for why she did so.  But, I don't think she really cared about our experience. She seemed to care less about us.  That's the problem when restaurants get too popular. They lose the concept of good customer service. Who cares about 3 little people when the restaurant is always crowded.  It wasn't really that we had to wait an hour and a half. It was how we were passed up by a larger group - it was how she never communicated with us - it was her lack of interest in us.  It's kind of like when an airline screws up or a flight gets canceled and no one at the airline seems to care and they won't communicate with you.

Obviously, you'll never find me at Suppen Kuche again.  And I have been on the war path telling all of my friends about our experience. It's funny - I'm finding that a lot of my friends have had similar experiences here. Long, long, long waits, extremely noisy, and poor customer service.
author: Bubbles S.

description:
What bad food!  I've had better bad Chinese food.

We ordered the Schnitzel and it wasn't particularly good schnitzel either--it was more like some sort of pork meat that had been pounded too thin.  

My husband (who studied under a European sous chef and was stationed in Germany for two and a half years while in the army) said the mushrooms and sauce tasted like it came out of a can.  The spatzle didn't have enough butter and clumped together. It was a very dry spatzle.  He never had food like that in Germany! He also said that there was too much chicken on the menu - German menus had pork, beef, and sausages.  That's what they had back there...

The place was noisier than a Chinese restaurant, more on par with a baseball game.  It was like being in a successful bar.  There were many drinkers with big beers in hand in the middle of the room talking very very loudly. 

The Schnitzelhaus has better schnitzel, and if we had wanted chicken we could get 1/2 a chicken for dinner and many more sides at the Chicken N Coop at about half the price. (A whole roasted chicken at the Chicken N Coop costs about $7.50--you could bring it home and enjoy it without the obnoxious noise.)

We went there ten years ago, and we realized last night why we haven't been back.  We obviously forgot that it wasn't such a great place.

Why the hell would we want to pay for mediocre overpriced food, share the table with complete strangers, and listen to "bar" noise.  

My husband surmises that the place is really a bar that serves a little food on the side. Serve a little food = can serve a lot of alcohol without being a bar.

Thank God, we've been married for ten years and didn't have to talk to each other.  If it were a date, I wouldn't even know the guy's favorite color because I wouldn't be able to hear a damn word he said.

I guess this would be the place _I_ would take my husband to if I were divorcing or separating from him... the last brutal slap before the ship sunk.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
I have never had a bad meal here. Ever.

Hands down one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Highly recommend the meatballs, herring salad, and jagerschnitzel. 

The ambiance is fantastic, the only bummer is the wait! There will always be one that's at least 30 minutes long.
author: Eli B.

description:
Why write the 773rd review for one of the city's favorite restaurants?

(1) just in case you miss the other 772, you should really try this.  Unless you're a vegetarian, don't like beer, or have no sense of taste.

(2) it's so not San Francisco it's not even funny.  The only thing SF about it is locally grown organic ingredients, intelligent waitstaff, and proving that a normally yucky style of peasant food from Europe can be amazing if you cook it well and don't Americanize it.

(3) it's hella food for not much money, no wonder it's so busy

(4) the average rating is now 4.242 stars.  WIth my 5-star vote it's now 4.243.  

(5) communal dining tables are fun, and everyone is in a good mood so there's lots of conversation

(6) if you're Jewish you grew up on schnitzel.  this is the best schnitzel I ever had.

(7) it's not Asian-inspired fusion.  

(8) I don't think there's any seasoning in it at all.  Yet you can taste the food, it's delicious.  It reminds you that ingredients have flavor too.  Weird, huh?  

(9) the decor is eccentric but also German, you expect the St. Pauli Girl at any moment with a band of bearded tuba players.

(10) If you haven't been yet, go.
author: Gil S.

description:
Owner was the biggest asshole I've ever run into at a restaurant.  I've never been back since. 

He literally pulled the table away from my wife as she was attempting to eat a bite to let other customers into a the adjoining table.  When I said something to him about it, he said something to the effect of "it's my restaurant".  

auf wiedersehen!
author: Douglas S.

description:
Not sure why it took me so long to get to this place, but I'm so glad I finally made it.  I was expecting a long wait from what I heard, but fortunately I beat the rush.  Got there around 6:30 pm and it was half empty.  The decor makes you feel like your in the alps, wooden communal tables, very simple but warm.  

Started off with a KSTRITZER, which you can't get everywhere and that always makes it that much better.  Then I had the homemade raviolis smothered in mushroom sauce, mmmmmmmmmmm!!!!!!!!!!
I could've have had just those and my dark beer for dinner.

Of course I had the potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce,mmmmmm!!!!!!!!!!.  I didn't want to fall for the hype and have too high expectations, but I couldn't help it they lived up to the hype.  I kind of feel like it should be desert though, must be the sweetness of the apple sauce.  

Finally I had the venison medallions in red wine plum sauce with cabbage and sptzle, mmm!!!!  The venison was slightly dry, but the red wine plum sauce was an excellent compliment to the taste of venison.  The red cabbage, mmmmmmmmm!!!!!!  I don't how they make cabbage taste so good, but DAMN!  I've heard everybody makes sptzle differently, but I thought it was great here.  Gotta love those staples.

This is a great place, food, service, and ambiance.  Our waiter was most friendly and even started talking classical music facts with the table next to us.  I recommend having a group of 3 or more so you can try more dishes or 6 to get your own communal table.
author: Aaron I.

description:
Awesome euro-vibe!  Went to dinner here and enjoyed the SCHNITZEL immensely ... 

But apparently someone had a different kind of SCHNITZEL to share with us.

Someone dropped a freaking BOMB on us at the bar.  It was the kind of methane that's so thick it STICKS to you.  I actually walked OUT of the bar, and came back , only to discover that it was STILL WITH ME.

To the GUY who LAID an EGG and walked AWAY and left us with your STINKBOMB:  the least you could've done was LIGHT A MATCH OR SOMETHING.  Bring a VOTIVE.  DROP the KIDS off at the POOL on your own time.  We're not interested in YOUR KIND OF SCHNITZEL!

Thank you.  Public Service Announcement now complete.
author: lulu p.

description:
This place I like a lot. The beers are great and it's a nice to come here either for a drink or for dinner. I'm no food critic but I for one love the food. And many others who know their food like it as well.

Craig, the bartender, is also very attentive, knows his beers and is more than happy to recommend a beer depending on your tastes. Great guy.
author: Emmett K.

description:
This place is AWESOME. It's my own little slice of Bavarian heaven with an array of beers and beer marinated foods. You can suck it snotty SF health freaks, it's all love in this joint. 

First off, be forewarned that Suppenkuche (how it's pronounced, I will never know) is packed every day of the week. Reservations are available for large parties only so you're pretty much stuck waiting on that much dreaded walk-in list. The upside however, is that you get to push your way to the bar in hopes of possibly tasting some of the best German beers in town. Reading other reviews, its understandable how the place can sort of have you wanting to bolt out that door as soon as you see the sea of people inside, but trust me, it's worth it. I mean, my MOM loves this places. So you don't get you're own table. So you sort of have to chit chat with other people who may or may not be a little bit odd. It's SF... suck it up.

The food is hearty in both quantity and quality. You will not leave hungry that is for sure. The wiener schnitzel and jägerschnitzel are classic favorites and most dishes come with their excellent spatzle. Try them but if that doesn't float your boat, their daily specials are always spot on. The service is, I must say, a little hit or miss. Maybe they're channeling that age old German smugness but they aren't the friendliest bunch of folks. All that said, I have had countless great meals here and can whole heartedly recommend this place to you, yes you, the one reading this.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
A great German dining experience! The food combined with ambience, dining area, and service really was a treat. 

The food was excellent with many dishes of sauerkraut, delicious creamy cheese spatzel, tender sausage, and yummy beet salad! Start off your dining with a basket of bread and top it off with a good selection of beers ranging from light to dark. Of course they offer "The Boot" and of course my next visit will consist of this. It would be well worth the time hanging out to drink the boot! 

The food was delicious,  all set at a reasonable price for the amount you get ($10-20). The service was great, and the wooden tables along with the decor made the dining experience great!  It gets pretty packed & loud, but enjoyable still! 

"Prost!"
author: Catherine O.

description:
I felt like I was at one of my parents party's sitting at a table with their friends that I didn't know. Um, kinda awkward. The people who sat beside us obviously didn't want to share a table with us. *Hmpf*

I ordered the trout which was delicious! Well done and crispy on the ends.  Love that crunchiness in fish! Portions are big so feel free to share you entree, or be a pig like me and eat it all! Hubby ordered the wiener which was pretty tasty as well but the sauerkraut I could've done without. 

Dinner was done and we waited for about 20 minutes for our waitress to get us our check. Um more awkward moments with my parents 'friends'. 

Next time you come here, make sure you come in a group so you can take up a whole table!
author: Aim E.

description:
NEW UPDATED REVIEW 7-16-07:
Went back to Suppenkuche this weekend.  I made a reservation for a large group.  I had planned a birthday dinner there for a very special person.  The hostess was very rude.  We were 10-15 min late for our 6pm rez. When I approached her, she threatened to give up our table.  I mean, it's impossible to get 9 people to show up exactly on time.  Really.  Being that I was with the birthday boy and he really wanted to eat there, I was all nice to her and I told her I understand.  I then said the rest of our party were on their way.  Then she said that the rest of the group needed to be there in two minutes and even though we had a reservation, we'd have to get out by 8pm no matter what. ( Having worked in the restaurant business, giving two hours for a party of nine is ridiculous!  Near impossible.)

I told her that I didn't realize that there was a two hour eating limit.  She then snapped back (as if I was lying about not knowing), "well, I KNOW that if you spoke to ANYONE where who takes reservations they would have told you that.  Regardless, you have to be out by then."  

Now, maybe I'm old-fashioned, but I don't like having to speed eat to please a hostess or the management of a restaurant.  I mean, I go to a restaurant to eat my food, relax and enjoy company.  it's not as if we'd be sitting there not ordering.  

We managed to get the whole party there in just a few minutes, and they seated us in the back, which would have been great except that the only way to access one side of the table was by crawling under it.  The hostess and waitress couldn't have cared less about this.  It was totally demeaning to have to crawl under the table to sit!  I mean, they could have tried to pull out the table or something so we didn't have to, but no!

By the way, we finished by 7:45, 15 minutes before the hostesses/"restaraunt management's" allotted eatting time.  On the way out, the hostess had the nerve to say to me "good job" for rushing through dinner.  I thought an "I'm sorry" or a "thank you SO much for putting up with our HUGE egos and attitudes" would have been much more appropriate.  

Overall, the food is fantastic, but the staff's attitudes and the general "you should feel SOOOOOOO privileged to eat here" mentality of this establishment have worn on my patience.  Our birthday boy was unnecessarily stressed about his dinner being canceled by the hostess, he had to crawl under a table to sit down, we were rushed through our meal, and all without an apology or thank you.

Yes, we were 15 minutes late for our reservation, but everyone in the restaurant industry knows that large parties are late. 

I'm really disappointed that this place went from one of my absolute all-time favorites to a place I abhor solely because of the staff's attitudes.

OLD REVIEW:
This is a favorite of mine.  It's hard to get a table unless you go early - even on a week night.  It's all German food and all delicious.  I wouldn't recommend eating here if you're on a diet.  The beers are fantastic and served in steins and boots!  

I'm looking forward to my next trip back.

Update - I went back after talking up the 2 liter beer in a boot to all my friends.  First item of business was to get the boot.  We were sadly informed that they only owned one boot and the boot was broken!  Boooo!  They need to work on getting another one (or several).  We managed to salvage the evening by ordering 1 liter steins.  The beer was great and the food was as good as ever.  Good enough to forgive them for denying me my boot.
author: Angie C.

description:
Three stars, but that's not to say that Suppenkuche is mediocre.  Instead, it does some things very well, and some things not well at all.  Bottom line:  this is a great place to drink beer, and a great place if you're looking for a lot of food.  It is not, however, a place to find good (or even passable) food.

Beer:  great selection, with hard to find German beers on tap.  Reasonable prices.  I'm a big fan of places that have the option of smaller beer servings -- here, in .3 or .5 liters, which is the same as a half pint or pint -- so I can try more things or, you know, exercise moderation.  The beer menu is very helpful in breaking down the beer selection by types (and sub-types), though they don't tell you what the types are.  

I found it remarkable that the hipster bartender corrected people's German pronunciation (it came off badly, too), but then the waitress couldn't pronounce words common to SF menus, like "gnocchi."  At any rate, I'm sure you could ask questions, but far be it from the bartender to be gracious if you don't know the difference between bock and dobblebock beers.

Atmosphere:  great.  Fun, communal.  Big shared tables, cute people.

Food:  not great.  I'm not sure if the mediocrity of the food is because German cuisine is really just meat and potatoes.  The classic boring American food (meatloaf, steak, mashed potatoes, sausage) that has thankfully disappeared in the age of eating consciousness and global awareness has its roots in German cuisine (those were the big immigrant populations from a century ago), and Suppenkuche is does little to improve upon those dishes.  It is a faithful adherent to the form, and because of that it's nothing very new, and it's nothing special, even if calling the food German makes it sound somehow different than middle American cuisine.  

The meatloaf (highly recommended by the waitress) was flavorless, which is shocking since it was wrapped in bacon.

The trout was good, but conventional.

The venison medallions were completely inert.  I expect game to taste, you know, like game, but I tasted nothing because the dish was slathered in a thick red sauce that obscured any flavor the meat might have had.  

The appetizer sampler: -- a total joke.  Ordinary ham and bologna and pickles.  It was as though someone put an Oscar Meyer sampler pack on a butcher block and charged $13 for it.
author: Ben A.

description:
The first time I had real German food was here and I can't stop going back!  I love their meatloaf wrapped in bacon, their pork ravioli appetizer and the cheesy spatzel- can you say AMAZING!

I've had a good portion of the menu and can't say enough about every dish.  I love the fact that you are sitting at a table with strangers and they serve beer in a glass boot!  The beer list is great if you enjoy beer that has flavor and the selection is pretty big.

If you want a fun night out and great food check out this spot!
author: Heather S.

description:
First of all, I think people overrate the food b/c they eat it after drinking 36 ounce beers.  It's tasty - a little overpriced and nothing so special.

Second, this place is really really a mad house.  I'm young (23), like to go out, etc. and it was still bordering on too much for me.  People bumping into you left and right, everyone hovering trying to get a table.  It's really nutty.  Don't go unless you don't mind shouting your dinner conversation and fighting for a table. 

Third, it was the worst service I've received in a long looooong time.  Now, it's a beer hall, I expect gruff and busy service....that is TOTALLY cool with me.  But, do NOT tell me and my party of 8 that just paid a BIG chunk of change for beer and sausage that we have to move.  That's right, our bitchy ass waitress literaly told us we had to move as sooon as our food had been cleared.  Some of us still had drinks to finish ($10 beers)!  It was the most outrageous scenario I have ever experienced in my life.  Nothing I will write here will do it justice.  

In case you're wondering we didn't move and I told her "no way am I moving until I'm ready".  What a crazy bitch.

The host also smells.
author: Katie M.

description:
Disclamer: hellllllla long, but it's purely for MY personal entertainment on how my evening went & stuff we ordered, don't read it if you'd rather pick your white hair out. remember, no one's forcing ya & I WARNED YA...meow!

***

NOTE TO SELF: NEVER EVER EVERRRRRRRRRRRRRR DRINK WITH WILAFUR! =D (are you reading this dork?)

What was I thinking? Despite me hanging out with Wilbur in LA awhile back, I should've REMEMBERED... and not only that, how he always had to use his "UCLA" card bashing on my school... don't chu forget Wilbur! We still won the last game.. =D

Now? The SF version... 
The night started out HIM "lying through his teeth" stating how he had gotten me the smallest drink POSSIBLE, when to realize, that there was something BYFAR smaller... but, I eventually gave in, as I decided to chug down my .5L for his birthday, his belated birthday! *giggles * & *does a lady burp* (uh, im drinking beer?)

So basically yesterday, we texted each other the whole entire day on how I was a "weaksauce" in NOT planning to drink & how us rubberheads (TROJANS!) can't hang (ey, at least, we protect ya) and etc (uh HELLLLL~~~~~~~~~LO! Some people have work on NYE!) or NOT being able to keep up with an OLD FART'S status. 

UGH!

So, the last text was, "Reservations 6pm @ Suppenkuche."

I show up, ON TIME, when OF COURSE the Asians show up ASIAN time, not W, but just other people, when after 30 mins or so, we get this corner seating. We prolly looked like mini cockroaches sqooshed into the corner.. WHY? because... after grilling W, he states that no ressies were made. (slaps forehead) SHOULDVE KNOWN! boink

What do I remember throughout this evening? Having to be called "weaksauce" the whole ENTIRE night.. HAHAH. Fun times tho! Took 2 fotos. (one of W's "lovely" stain on his shirt & the difference in the drinks. Mine's the one in the middle, and the left, well, it's called "the boot" and that's what he ended up getting. I wish they had a lady version of "the boot" or how about "a stiletto?")

Overall, the place was super crowded, hella loud, which I think is a great charm, and def a low key, friendly, fun establishment. It's a family style type place where you can grub (the portions are sincerely generous) drink and share endless laughters..

Service: Took the guy a great awhiles. Literally had to GET him at one point. He was friendly and accommodating but hella slow.

Key point: There's ONLY 1 restroom, one for the guys and one for the gals. (scratches head) ... ironic, IMHO. You're at a drinking place, and you only have one. Weirdos. (-1)

So we came with a few... 

DRINKS: Wide variety..
-Franziskaner .5L $5 (so, this is MY drink, which W TRICKED me into saying that this was the smallest one they had).. it was good, not too strong, not too weak, and refreshing ... heck, it's GERMAN beer.. kudos to that. Took me back into time when I drank in Germany. They had some others but I only remember mine but they were relatively cheap) +1

APPETIZERS
Potato Pancakes w/Apple Sauce $9 (too crispy, I don't seriously recall tasting the damn potatos! Argh.  Came out donkatsu style. You get 3 huge chunks)

Shrimp $11 (You prolly get like 10, and the minute it came, everyone was rushing to get a piece of the sucker. It was good, nice size.) 

ENTREES
Sauerbratan Braised Beef $18 (so, this is what I got, and it's not as great. The meat was cooked too well, and a bit hard to chew, and a tad bit salty). It was like another Thanksgiving entre because they had cranberry sauce that came out with it.

Lambchop $19.50 (this was Wilbur's. Couldn't get my paws off his dish. It was soo good but luckily he was nice enough to let me take one chunk of his, which he prolly got a bigger profit out of MINE since he took 2. I got 3 chunks, but it just wasn't good)

Pork Chop $16 (this was good. very juicy.)

Meatballs $15.50 (this isn't on the regular menu, it's on their specials. You get 4 huge meatballs and few chunks of potatos. I totally recommend this... if you've tried A16's meatballs, the only difference is, A16 is more with marinara sauce, whileas this is more soupy. The soup was good tho)

Bratwurst $14 (so yes, you're at a German place. You MUST get their sausages, right? Came out damn wrinkly.  You get 3 and it wasn't good at all, kinda rubbery too...)

Sauteed Trout $16 (fish was cooked and seasoned well but I would personally pass since I'm a meat eater, even though I heart fish)

Overall, MY personal input? I'd say to get the meatballs, pork chop or the lambchop.

Don't ferget! 18% gratuity will be added to parties of 6 or more..
.
.
.
DANKE Suppenkuche & Wilafur for the endless laughters!! Lead way to the "fun wei" ... eh? 

LOL

PS. This place bumped up a star purely based on the guys I was hanging out with and yes, I'd come back, but MAKE SURE TO MAKE RESSIES UNLIKE WILBUR, if you plan to have a bunch. meeeeeeowwwwwwww
author: Jennifer S.

description:
HATE the crowd, LOVE the food and beer
Craig the bartender FTW
author: Mona N.

description:
This place was awesome.  The beer was delicious as was the food.  I had one of each of the dark beers (a bit excessive for me), the potato pancakes, and the pork chop.  It was exceptional.  I will probably hit this place up again this week when my colleagues get into town.

The service was very helpful.
author: Eric S.

description: Went there today with some friends for brunch.  I undoubtedly picked the worst thing on the menu, their breakfast Bavarian meatloaf.  I thought it was the bacon-wrapped meatloaf with an egg.  Instead it consisted of a slice of finely ground meat that resembled a thick slice of baloney.  I couldn't finish it, it was yucky.  The eggs were perfect, and so were the potatoes; would have been better to stick with the basics.  Service was excellent and it was quite loud.
author: Veronica W.

description:
Last night I consumed two liters of beer standing at the bar in this joint.  It was fantastic.  Beer was delicious, the waiters were drinkin' and I only spent about 25 bucks.

What a wonderful place to have a few beers on a Tuesday night.
author: jack p.

description:
Great food and beer - very authentic German food. Our friend comes out to visit several times a year from Germany and ALWAYS requests to come to Suppenküche. He says their schnitzel reminds him of his oma's (grandmother)

My only complaint is that they do not have curry ketchup - neither has any other German restaurant I have been to in the bay.
author: Mirinda M.

description:
This place was delicious! The food was unbelievable.  Started with potato pancakes and then dinner.  We got two of the specials for the day: breaded lamb chops and salmon.  Both dishes were out of this world, however, the lamb took the cake by a long shot.  

This place has a great feel.  Feels like an every day, inviting and familiar restaurant.  Very close seating in the establishment.  The beer selection is fantastic. Would definitely come back here if I had more time in San Fran!
author: Sharad W.

description: Loved the ambiance and the food is super authentic! Had a schnitzel that was incredible - tasted "right" - and their beer selection is awesome too. I really felt like I was at a nice, friendly, trendy place in the middle of Berlin. Would definitely come back and would recommend it to anyone!
author: Ana M.

description:
Schnitzel. I grew up on schnitzel. As such, I find it a bit difficult to get past the (a) over-fried lack of delicacy in Suppenkuche's execution and (b) massively inflated pricing for nothing more than an unremarkable slice of breaded veal and some potatoes. 

However, I am ecstatic to have found a place with a lively, convivial atmosphere where I can get a decent bauernfruehstueck, a reasonably faithful rendition of Schwarzwaelder Kirschtorte, and... a fantastic selection of German beers including Schneider-Weisse on tap!! Also, I very much enjoyed the venison with red wine plum sauce, red cabbage and spaetzle, which I can best describe to the unfamiliar as delicious pasta-like dumplings.

German cuisine is capable of far greater heights than you'll find at Suppenkuche. But, if you take it for what it is -- authentic German comfort food meant to assist copious beer consumption -- and understand that the pricing reflects its novelty niche in the SF market, then go forth with friends and demand of your hipster beer-frau, Bitte ein Bit!

Note to Tyler S.: The variation in spelling is due to the transliteration of the umlaut, which Yelp does not support. Strictly speaking, the restaurant should be spelled Suppenkueche when not using an umlaut.
author: Tom L.

description:
Came here with the honey for a pre-concert grub fest. He loved it as much as I did and we had a great time. Everyone is so much fun, the food is excellent, and the beer....oh the beer...its so good when it hits your lips! 
The potato pancakes were tasty with the accompanying applesauce, the venison sausage was to die for and the weinerschnitzel...get outta town. Absolute Heaven.
author: Stacy T.

description:
Supp on what?!

I'm not feeling German food.  As a pescetarian, there wasn't much for me to munch on during the weekend brunch.  The BF has always enjoyed his meat filled dishes here, so that must explain the difference in our experiences.

I tried it twice to no avail...
author: Tamiko J.

description:
The one downside of this meal -- I realized, to my dismay, that I haven't eaten nearly enough German food.  Delicious meats -- the venison comes highly recommended.  I almost passed because the sauce sounded strange, but as it turned out, definitely in a good way.  Sweet with some kind of berry or fruit, what it was escapes me...  But it went great with the red cabbage and spaetzle.  And if you can't find a good beer to go with your food, that's your own fault.

Well, maybe there's another downside.  This place can get packed.  You could easily run into a wait of over an hour for a table.  Or, as we did, you can fight your way to the back of the bar to grab a beer and, hopefully, some table space for a meal.  Were we lucky?  Skilled?  Either way, this plan worked for us, and we had a good one.
author: Dano W.

description:
** Note** - I didn't actual go to the restaurant, but this was my experience over the phone. 
So my birthday was coming up and I called in to see how the reservations were for the upcoming saturday night. I knew i had to make reservations because I had at least 10+. I called in and the guy said I needed to make reservations on a saturday night A MONTH IN ADVANCE! I asked for any times, he said there were no openings. However if my whole party was at the opening time of the restaurant(5 pm) then he would seat us. If not he said the wait could be anywhere from 15-2+ hrs. WOW.

I heard this place was good, but I guess my dining experience here will just have to wait for now.
author: Anita W.

description:
Whenever my boy drives into the city from the south bay, we always go here. 

I've been to Munich and I have to admit Suppenkuche is pretty darn good. It is so authentic German. You've got your meat like the spatten or the pig knuckle and cabbage. Dead on accurate. 

Gotta say, this is one of my top destinations when I'm hanging in Hayes Valley.
author: Brian C.

description:
I've been to Germany; twice.  I lost 5lbs the first time because, well, I don't "dine on swine" and most of what everyone around me was eating was sausage.

Leave it to my Yelpish friends to invite me to a German restaurant that serves so many varieties of yummy goodness.

From their starter menu we ordered the fried Camembert and potato pancakes served with applesauce.  Yum yum.  I could have just eaten that on it's own, but that wouldn't be very adventurous, now would it?
So, for dinner I had a grilled and fried trout with a very nice lemon butter sauce and spatzel (that's a German word I'm not sure how to spell, but it tasted like heaven).  The rest of the table indulged in a various treats consisting of venison, wild boar and lamb.
And as a non beer drinker, I quenched my thirst with a concoction of beer WITH lemonade.  Very refreshing.
Top all that off with some totally tasty apple strussel and voila, you have a delicious dinner for all.
I only took away a star because they only serve wine and beer.  Perhaps there is no whiskey in Germany?
author: lily p.

description: I really enjoyed my meal here. We came about an hour after they opened and had to wait a little while but it was totally worth it. The place is small and full and therefore loud. We were probably the only people in there that didn't come for the beer but for the food, which makes you feel a little weird. I was excited to hear that they have spezi, but they are lacking some of the American musts like diet coke. The sitting arrangements with another group and a random guy who was on his own was not my favorite but it was okay. (This is not a German thing, but due to the space problem) I loved the food and it tasted just like home (Germany). My American friends liked the food just as much as i did, one of them swears it's the best food she has ever had. We had kaesespaetzle and the steak with salad, then apfelstrudel As dessert and it was fantastic! The food makes up for any negative there might be!!!!!
author: Annika W.

description:
Sehr gut! I took 6 years of German and was overly excited to finally be able to try Suppenkuche (where is the umlaut on this keyboard?). 

Potato Pancake appetizer is Out Of This World. For my entree I had the Weinerschnitzel and was very happy with it. The roasted potatoes were delicious and green butter leaf salad was really refreshing. 

Bier. Und, Bier. I had the Erdinger and the Helles Spaten. The Erdinger was really delicious. I haven't had a bier in MONTHS and this was really delicious.

I'm not so sure if MY review out of the 900+ will convince you to go or change the world's perspective on this restaurant... but I needed to sing its praises!
author: Hannah K.

description:
Ich liebe Wurst und Bier!!!

That's right, I like sausage and beer (and if that didn't exactly translate, hey, I used a free online translator, so sue me, hehe). Anyhoo, I have been wanting to check this joint out for a good year now. The German place in Hayes Valley! The one with the beer boots! The plates of sausage! Hell yes!!

And so last night after a long and tiring day, my girl Audrey and I made the scary trek on the #21 bus (good god, is there a worse bus to take, ugh) and arrived here to this packed little spot full of happy, jovial, fun beer lovin folks. Yay, this was gonna be fun and only a 20 minute wait. I could deal, especially since that just meant we'd need to order a beer appetizer. Hey, beer is a food group :)

Now, truth be told, I don't really know my beers all that well and I always feel like a drinking dummy when asking about them, but hey, how else are ya gonna learn, right? I asked the bartender what he recommended in the light to medium category and he immediately poured me 3 samples of stuff and after I picked one, he encouraged me to drink them up, cuz alcohol abuse is unacceptable at Suppenkuche! Haha, I hear that, brutha man!

We then found ourselves getting way too hungry to function and mingled our way to a seat in the tiny little bar area and to our relief, a couple left and we swooped in on their seats and took full advantage of the eating space. We wanted a plate of several sausages with a whole lotta mustard, much like the Red Lion does in Silverlake in Los Angeles (love that place!), but much to our chagrin, they didn't offer anything like that and so we settled on the potato soup with the wieners floating in it and the pork sausage with the sauerkraut and mashed taters. 

Both were tasty and of course paired excellently with our huge beers. As for the crowd, just a really friendly and cool bunch. One group at the bar even acted as check passers for us which was cool and all around, this was just a really fun time! I'll be back!!
author: Stephy S.

description:
OH MY GOD. I'm a bit embarrassed that I have never been to this beautiful establishment before last night. Never once have I been told that i'm going to have to wait 40 minutes for a table and not put up a fuss about it. This place has an amazing beer selection...obviously. But most importantly the food is awesome. 

Now I've never actually had German food before and could not pronounce anything on the menu, but I know a delicious combination os ingredients when I see them. 

I ordered the meatballs and had my mind blown. They were tender and flavorful and, for lack of a better word, awesome! See I'm the type of person that will savor a good meal and will go as far as eating only half of my meal simply to reenact the mouthgasm that I had the previous day. I made sure that I went home with half of this masterpiece.

Now there was a semi scam going on. I mean I could be wrong it could have just been that particular night or maybe it a tradition that we didn't know about. So we finish our meal and the waitress brings us the desert right and she's all, "So since I began my shift today there has been this weird things going on. My first table bought my next table's dessert and so on and so forth, so this dessert is yours from my last table. Feel free to join in if you'd like." So at this point you're stuck. I mean we HAVE TO buy dessert.... So we did. And by the way, the dessert was delicious so I wasn't mad. Then again i wasn't paying either so what did I care.
author: Brittany D.

description: I went there on weekdays, but the restaurant was so crowded. we had to wait around 30min. But after we came in to the restaurant and order foods, they were coming relatively soon. So I didn't feel bad about that. Foods are delicious! They had a lot kind of beers, so try to order some next time.
author: Saki K.

description:
This is the place where I discovered my love for german beer & food. I don't even know where to begin. 

Awesome tables, its like these long communal tables made out of wood but not varnished so they are super soft. IDK I just love them, lol.

Super clean and so is their bathroom.

The staff is german and good looking & nice.

The food is phenomenal! My absolute favorite dishes at Brunch are the schnitzel, potato pancakes, and  Emperor's Pancake with Brandied Raisins, served with Apple & Plum Compote. This is exactly what I order to eat in 1 sitting. I inhale it and then enter a food coma which lasts the rest of my sunday. Not to mention the delicious beers I have with it.

On sundays they serve the schnitzel with an egg on top! It's the perfect meal: perfectly breaded, crispy and with lemon on the side with I use every drop of to top my dish.  

I suggest ordering a side of sour cream for the potato pancakes and then leaving the emperor's pancake for dessert (not the same as potato pancake at all). 

On a sunday I always get seated fairly quickly and while I wait I have a beer at the bar. HIGHLY recommend this place!!!!!!
author: Veronica P.

description:
Oh. my. god.

I love this place.

I just got back and I'm so full I can barely move.

The potato pancakes were amazing.  I absolutely love the apple sauce.  So was the potato soup and the potatoes that came with the Weiner Shnitzel. (Notice a pattern forming here?)

The staff was super nice as well. They pointed me to a couple of German beers that I had never tried before - and I absolutely loved them.  They even came by and did a shot with the people at our table. It was some German variant of Fernet.

This place is highly recomended if you are into hearty German food.

The atmosphere was nice too - very family style/mini beer hall -ish.  The candles everywhere gave it a very nice touch.  It just felt very warm and cozy inside.

I'll be back. As long as I don't die from my food coma.

Update: Price was just under $100 for two, with 4 beers and tip. Parking sucks in this area.  If you drive and can't find a spot, there is a valet service run by the place across the street for $7.
author: Matthew R.

description:
When I'm hankering for some classic Bavarian food, Suppenkuche is my immediate standby. Chat up the bartenders while waiting to be seated, and they will ensure that you find a bier to your liking. I didn't even think I liked beer until they turned me on to Fraziskaner. Mmmmm...

If Wiener Schnitzel isn't your thing, they do an excellent Kasespaetzle (cheese spaetzle reminiscent of mac 'n' cheese) sure to satisfy any vegetarian. I'm a serious carnivore and I order it every single time :)

Also, their house salad is amazingly tasty: butter lettuce, beets, German potato salad, shredded carrots. Even their classic rye with chive butter is delicious! Make sure to split an order of the potato pancakes with your dining companions, and if you can't finish it, you can make friends with the others sitting at your communal table.

Word for the wise: don't forget to wear your elastic lederhosen!
author: Jill M.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for nearly five years and had never been to Suppenkuche.  My new roommate (Glamorous Cynthia) is 1/2 German - as in her Mom is full blooded German & an immigrant to the US - and though a recent transplant to SF from NY has been there a couple of times now.

She insisted that we (La Bonne Bon, me, Rosie & Ben) go there for dinner together last night.

The ambiance is cool - a little touristy - but, nice German ale house vibe going on.

The food... FING AMAZING.  I had bratwurst, sauerkraut and mashed potatoes - I normally can't finish my meals when I go out to places with "comfort food" because it tends to be too much for me to digest - but, damn if I didn't nearly lick my plate clean.  I'm some part German, so I appreciate good - GOOD - sauerkraut, this was amazing - sweet with a little tang, lots of spice & good pork flavor.  The bratwurst was tres yummy & everything bled into the mashed potatoes to make an amazingly tasty mish-mosh of comfort food.

I'm actually still full from this.

Plus Rosie introduced me to Pomme Lambic - crap is that stuff yummy.

It was a good night - save a waiter knocking over Rosie's Cassis Lambic onto Ben's new sweater.  Though we did snag a piece of German Chocolate cake because of it...

Yum!

This is not a place which one could eat at often, due to the richness and heaviness of the food - but, one you'll go back to often.
author: Kate R.

description:
OK, I am the only person in SF who is not a fan.
I guess it's really not such a surprise as I didn't really like the food in Alsace all that much.  So, perhaps it's just the genre of food/preparation.
I dined here with a good friend who loves the place.  However, my boyfriend and I were not so taken.
I must admit, I did like the saurebraten, but the BF fared worse.  My friend was happy as a clam.
I'm sure this is a great restaurant, the reviews show it.  I just would like to warn others who aren't such a great fan of German cooking, this might not be the right place.  
If it is, I recommend the sauerbraten, a marinated beef with cranberry something I did like.
author: Kara H.

description:
Any way you want it, that's the way you need it...any way you want it. That's their theory on pork. And beer. And potatoes. These are a few of my favorite things.

The family seating is interesting, wish it was a bit bigger since when it's busy (and boy it gets busy) the scene could get a little cramped.

If you're feeling overzealous, have a 2 liter beer boot.  I hear they only keep one since they break so much. Tis a shame. Just remember to drink it: TOE DOWN!!

The Spaetzle was to die for, the mushroom sauce great, the portions are huge, and the staff friendly. They dealt wonderfully with a party of 20 for a 30th bday party. The beer never stopped flowing and the meals fantastic. I'll be back for sure.
author: Jessica P.

description:
We had to wait, and the place is crowded and noisy.  That said, we had a great time, and the food was wonderful.  In soups, my wife's Goulash was basically a vegetable soup with a paprika broth.  My corn soup was creamy.  The goulash was a tad salty, the corn soup a tad sweet, but both were executed very well.

My wife had the beef roulade, which she loved, and I the venison, which was delightful, too.  Both came with red cabbage and spaetzle, which were tasty and well-done.

Suppenkuche has a wide variety of German beers on draft and in botthles.  My wife's Stark and my Dunkel were both great.

Both desserts, apple strudel w/ ice cream and black forest cake, were enjoyable.

With two beers and dessert, the tab was $82 for two.

We enjoyed Suppenkuche very much and look forward to returning.
author: Andrew E.

description:
this place is way cool. Why ? 
THEY SERVE BEER IN BOOTS !! 

yes thats right folk's, beer in boot form. the weird part ? you have to put a 50$ deposit on the boot you wish to drink from...


Other than beer in boot for this place is consistently european, and by european I mean german. Beers I have never heard of, Long communal tables, help yourself bread out of buckets, amazing fruit spread, nutella, and traditional fare. Overall its a top notch place (not fancy or anything) great for brunch. The olny downer is they have dried plants hanging above you as deco, and well dried plants crumble and get into your food.. kinda icky, but tolerably so.
author: Camille A.

description:
Great, authentic German food and an extremely respectable beer selection.

Let me preface the rest of this by saying that I've lived in Munich (the capital of Bavaria, which is totally the part of Germany with the best food anyway) for about 14 months. I've had lots of real German and Bavarian food over there, but not so much in the U.S.

I've been to a couple of German restaurants in New York City before on a quest to find real German food and both times I've been extremely disappointed. Both places had only a very poor imitation of German food, despite the fact that they had pretty good ratings here on Yelp (I don't remember their names though). I remember having pretzels that were basically just normal bread roll dough shaped like a pretzel with salt on it (hint: that is not what a pretzel is).

This place finally satisfied me. From start to finish, everything was spot-on or near it. The bread they serve is pretty authentic, dense, chewy, slightly sour, dark, malty, German bread, complete with Kräuterbutter (herb butter). We started with an appetizer of Obatzda (a Bavarian cheese spread made with ripe German Camembert, cream cheese, paprika, and one or two other spices including caraway or fennel seeds I think) and a giant pretzel. The Obatzda wasn't exact -- it had a bit too much paprika and was a little spicier than the real thing -- but it was very close and extremely good. The pretzel was perfect -- real and chewy like a pretzel should be.

At this point I'll stick in my discussion of the beer selection. There's a wide variety of German beers on draft, including lots of choice Bavarian beers from breweries such as Schneider (my suggested Hefeweizen out of the ones they have on tap) and Weihenstephaner. The available bottles further augment an already impressive selection with choices such as Schneider's Aventinus (a Weizenbockbier, strong, dark, spicy wheat beer), the rare (in the U.S.) Augustiner Edelstoff, and the delectable Weihenstephaner Weizen. The bottled beers should be enjoyed from a glass, of course, which they offer you on serving. The glassware and beer serving themselves get high marks. They have proper sized glasses (0.5 L and 1 L, in addition to the many ludicrously large glasses ranging in size up to 5 L which are great for groups), and they serve each style of beer in the appropriate style of glass (Weißbier should be served in a different glass than a Lager, for example). Half the time the logo on your glass will even match the brewery of the beer you're drinking :) For reference, my beer selection was Augustiner Edelstoff, Weihenstephaner Korbinian, and Schneider Weisse. All of the draft beers were very fresh.

Now on to the main course. The selection of dishes is good, and they seem to have specials which might change from one day or week to the next. I was pleasantly surprised to see that they had Semmelknödel (a delicious Bavarian bread dumpling which pairs nicely with just about any sauce), which I didn't see on the menu online. The main dishes give a good coverage of real, standard German dishes. My only complaint is that they should drop the salad that comes with many of the entrees and replace it with sauerkraut or blaukraut (rotkohl, red cabbage spiced, lightly sweetened, and stewed). I ordered the Jägerschnitzel (a tender porkloin sauteed and served with a rich, cream-based mushroom sauce), which by default come with Spätzle and a salad. I substituted the sides, however, for Semmelknödel and Rotkohl. I also tried some of my friend's Sauerkraut. He (a German) and I both agreed that everything they served was very authentic. It was also all extremely delicious.

The prices are pretty decent for the quality of food. Entrees are all around $20, and the beers are all about $8 for a half liter serving (roughly 16.9 ounces). Even the ambiance inside was authentic -- it feels like any given Gasthaus in Munich. The only thing that wasn't authentic, luckily, was the service, which was also very good with friendly servers. We are definitely going back to this place in the future.
author: Josh M.

description:
Ah yes! German cuisine... Meat and potatoes. Potatoes mit meat. Oh, and beer... lotsa beer!

We started off with fried camembert.
Camembert?! Mais non! Oh..... but ja, mein Freund. Most definitely ja! 
It's a good thing they don't sell this as a microwavable snack or my kitchen would constantly reek of unpasteurized, artery-clogging goodness.
We added potato pancakes with a side of apple sauce. Yum! (wait, my heart just stopped.... ok, there it goes again).
For a main dish, I devoured breaded lamb chops with mashed potatoes and a side of brussels sprouts (something green!).
Others had venison, chicken schnitzel, broccoli soup, trout, and wild boar sausage. I had a taste of each and came away nodding my approval.
For dessert, two servings of sinfully good apfel strudel mit vanilla ice cream and six spoons, bitte!

Yes, I'd recommend this place.
author: Green L.

description:
OMG is this what Germans eat everyday? I tried potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce and Wiener Schnitzel which were SO amazing.  $18 for Wiener Schnitzel is pretty expensive though, esp since it tastes exactly the same as TonKatsu :)

They have a variety of beers to choose from, which are overall pretty good and interesting. I don't recommend their flavored stuff though, it's a little too sweet for me. Oh, and the place is super cramped. Make sure to get a reservation beforehand!
author: Jen K.

description: One of my favorite places in San Francisco! Their soups with (or without) sausage are amazing, and the same goes for the beer. The portions are generous and most foods I tried were delicious. It's a bit loud at communal tables, and the place gets packed - if you don't want to wait, come shortly before 5pm and get a quiet table (the space in the back is roomy)
author: routa s.

description:
Delicious spatzle but the rest of the meal was just eh. Skip the bread and butter that they bring out...the bread is dry and when I walked by the kitchen, I noticed it's just bagged bread and not baked in house. Not worth wasting calories over, in my opinion. The pickled herring appetizer was bland and too much (and not in a good way). 

I had the bratwurst, though tasty, weren't as good as Schnitzelhaus' version. Ditto for their Jagerschnitzel, which was completely soggy thanks to the mushroom sauce that was generously slathered all over it. No crispy breaded cutlet here! 

If only there was a way that I could combine Schnitzelhaus' Jagerschnitzel with Suppenkuche's spatzle...
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Met a large group of peeps from work Sunday mid-day. The quality of food was excellent and fair priced. Beer was plentiful, but I was little confused by their beer menu. 

Great food, although it didn't really satisfy my German/Oktoberfest craving.
author: Ahna P.

description:
You know, upon my third visit in almost three years to one of the few German establishments in the City, I walked away feeling quite dissatisfied. 

My first mistake was bringing a date to this restaurant. Don't even consider it unless you enjoy conversation in the front row of a Motorhead show. It was so obscenely loud that at one point we just gave up on yelling at each other and ate in silence. On this night, there was a large group of drunk yuppies pounding on their table and singing at the top of their lungs. That was bad enough, but then they had the audacity to try and rally the whole fucking restaurant into singing some god awful 70's soul song. 

The servers? Oh, they didn't do a damn thing about it despite the horror on many diners faces. The service was terrible as they seemed to just rush you through the process. While we didn't inquire about any of the dishes I don't think they could have been helpful if they wanted to. Still, even with the noise, they didn't make much effort to provide other than a Denny's-like mechanical effort. 

The food? Yes, the food is terrific and always has been. The Weiner Schnitzel is delicious. The beer selection is great as its great to find some off-the-wall European beers you won't find at any other pubs in the Bay Area (except Walzwerk). 

All in all, the experience was far below what you would expect for the price range of the range. I fully understand that its a festive, fun restaurant, but this went far beyond usual revelry to become downright obnoxious and obtrusive. I probably won't return with massive coercion.
author: Brandon B.

description:
I thought it would be a good idea to write the entire review in German, until I realized its been over 20 years since I wrote anything in German.  So what do I have to say about Suppenkuche....Gut, Wunderbar, Köstlich.

Starter:Salat mit Karotten, Kraut, Kartoffeln, Rote Beete und Kopfsalat.  Salad of Carrots, Cabbage, Potatoes, Beets and Butter Lettuce.  All very tasty.

Entree:  Gebratene Rehmedaillions in Rotwein-Pflaumensoe mit Rotkohl und Spätzle.  Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce with Red Cabbage and Spätzle.  I asked for potato pancakes instead of spätzle and was told it would be no problem.  The venison was tender and delicious.  The red wine plum sauce was sweet but subtle and used sparingly allowing the flavor of the venison to come through.  The red cabbage was excellent.  Cooked through yet still with a slight crunch.  It definitely hadn't been sitting in a steam table all night waiting to be served.

I had two .5 liters of Weltenburger Dunkel.  It was served cool but not cold and was perfect with my meal.

The food and beer were excellent.  I ate more than I thought was humanly possible and still got out of there for just over $60 for two of us.
author: David H.

description:
I am going to keep this short and sweet... just like the wait for a table!
Oh wait, I waited two hours on Saturday night, so never mind. 

The first time I was here I saw some guy faint by the bar.  His eyes rolled, his body wobbled, then BAM! He got up semi-quickly and appeared sober so my bet is that it was a hunger induced faint.  He probably had a light lunch because he planned for an early dinner. One beer, two hours and no food later, his body just couldn't hang any longer.  Is that how good the food is here, people would rather starve than take their name off the list and go elsewhere?

The wait is why the food is sooooooo good. They practically starve you so when the food comes you scarf it down so quickly your brain says "wow that must have been fantastic". This is just a theory because my food has always been AMAZING and I am beginning to wonder if it really is. People here wait long for a table not strictly for the food. It's the place. The decorations. The beer selection.  The seating. It's a room full of former European backpackers who are all secretly wishing they were going back to a hostel after a night of "too" much beer and great conversation. 

My friend made the mistake of taking her parents here on Saturday night. I saw her mom rip off pieces of napkin and stuff them in her ear. Okay, so it does get a bit loud but that is half the fun. Bring good friends, a partially full stomach, drink beer, eat food... and enjoy!
author: Rebecca S.

description: Pork loin in mushroom sauce is the best!
author: Tanasan S.

description:
I am German...

I ordered the pork roast marinated in beer, bread dumplings and sauerkraut....WOW!

Tasted just like my Omi made it.  I was so impressed.  I ofcourse also had a Doppleboch.  

I scraped my plate clean, maybe it's because it was so authentic that I felt like I would get introuble...or it was just that good and I am just that big of a pig...
author: Inga B.

description: Minus one star for the noise and wait but what an awesome experience!  The owner is very nice...maybe drunk...and the food was absolutely amazing.  Potato cakes, venison....and even the meatloaf which I thought would taste like shitty meatloaf was really good.  Love the decor but it is fucking loud in there and wait times are a thorn.  Definitely worth it or maybe worth going on a earlier in the week.
author: Adrian E.

description:
I had a couple friends in town visiting from Japan so I searched for a restaurant that you wouldn't be able to find there.  Based on a rec from my bro and his gf and the fact that this place seemed right up my friend's alley, this is one of the places we chose.  

I loved the cozy atmosphere.  Unfortunately, the couple who were seated at the same table as us seemed like they were on a serious date, so it kind of put a damper on the spirit a bit, but that's not the restaurant's fault.  We would have loved to be seated at any of the other tables around us with people were happy to interact and have a good time.

The food was delicious.  It was like German comfort food.  I'm not expert on German food, so perhaps it was just food, but regardless it was delicious!  The staff was very friendly and helpful and I would definitely come back here.  

The only drawback was the wait.  We were hoping to eat at 9:30 pm on a Sunday since our friends were coming from Outside Lands.  We got there at 7:45, thinking we might even get in a bit early, but it wasn't until 9:45 until we were seated.  Fortunately, they weren't too strict about their closing time otherwise we would have been out of luck.
author: Cindy N.

description:
I briefly considered writing this entire review in German, but decided against it for two reasons:

1. it would be more obnoxious than funny (or "cool," or "useful")
2. I don't speak German*

Food is delicious (though extremely heavy and not to veg-friendly -- which even I find almost refreshing in this city despite being an almost vegetarian myself)

Beer is awesome (in both quality and selection)

But, be warned, the place gets LOUD. Don't bring your quiet friends here. Don't do it.

*Actually, I kind of do. Or did. But it wouldn't be pretty.
author: Beah B.

description:
Before yesterday, My heart would have leapt with joy at the prospect of Sunday brunch at Suppenkuche. See, Suppenkuche used to be REAL German. Like, my German friends visiting from Germany worked there, the staff was all German and knew how to pronounce the German menu items, and the food was available in abundance. 

Yesterday's trip yielded little resemblance to the Suppenkuche of yesteryear. I am pretty much always on a diet and I don't eat pork, so the real draw for me here is the PITCHERS of MIMOSAS. Well, yesterday they were ALL OUT. Yes. All out of one of their biggest draws. BOOOOO! Not helping things, they were out of three dishes on the menu ordered by our party AND they were out of two beers. For a place as notoriously busy as Suppenkuche (about one hour for a party of 7), you'd think they'd just go whole hog and stock up on the brunch essentials like o.j. and sparkling wine. Not to mention beer, which they are typically known for.

They managed to serve the party next to us first, even though we'd been there twice as long. Then they managed to dress my salad even though I asked for the dressing on the side. When my replacement salad came, it was dry BUT there was no dressing on the side...no coffee refills for Christopher K, one menu for a table of 7, and you see where I'm going with this...

On the upside, Basi and Amir had a delicious curry, fries, and sausage dish. My better half had a glorious bacon and potato omelette, and the helles with lemon soda (light beer mixed with lemon soda) quickly became my new favorite brunch beverage. The bill was a low $110 for 7 people, which means the meal practically paid for itself as not one of us walked away hungry or sober.

Our server appeared to be having an off day, as she brought the wrong orders to the folks next to us, repeatedly forgot to get things or bring food, and generally seemed really out of it. I'll probably go back again for a helles-lemon soda and an omelette like the one I ate off of matt's plate (what else is new?). But I think next time we'll make a reservation and get there bright and early to take advantage of those $23 pitchers of mimosas.
author: Autumn K.

description: I came here with my friends on the first day of Oktoberfest. Thank goodness, my friends got there first and were able to find/get seats. Suppenkuche is pretty small on the inside and the seating is like sitting in a cafeteria as you are sharing tables. It is pretty cramped and very loud inside, so you definitely have to speak up in order for others to hear you. That night was really packed and people were still waiting outside for others to leave to get seats. I thought their decor inside was pretty cool. We ordered the following food to share: Schweinebratensemmel auf Brez'n Laibl mit Krautsalat (Roasted Pork Sandwich on Pretzel Knot and Kraut Salad w/ Bacon), Halb Hendl (1/2 Oktoberfest Chicken), Zwei Gegrillte Nurnburger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut (Two Grilled Pork Bratwurst with Sauerkraut), Gemischter Salat, Pretzel, and Pommes-Frites. For my drink, I had the Erdinger Oktoberfest Weissebier. I'm usually not too big of a fan of beer; however, I really liked this drink. It was perfect for my taste. What really sucked was that they didn't have the potato pancakes that night. I was also not a big fan of the Pommes-Frites. I have had way better fries elsewhere. The fries here were just average... Otherwise, I thought the rest of the food was pretty tasty and definitely worth an experience to try.
author: Philana C.

description:
Do you remember that episode of Seinfeld where Jerry has problems renting a car?  Why make the reservation if you're not going to hold a car???  Yeah, that's what our experience was like here.  I acknowledge, we had a large group of 10 people.  THAT'S WHY WE MADE A RESERVATION.   All but one of our party arrived within 5 minutes of our reservation.  We didn't get seated until almost an hour later.  This is NOT somewhere that has a lot of room to wait, so we just kind of crowded around the bar.

When we FINALLY got a table, they did send over free appetizers, which was nice.  The food was yummy and our server was a delightfully attentive, but not obtrusive.  I can recommend the venison, and the pork with mushrooms and the snitchzel.

Be warned, if you're a vegetarian, there are not a lot of options for you here.  Our veggie was able to find at least one dish on the menu, but she did find wine she liked!
author: Nikki c.

description:
I don't get it.

Let's pretend that my group of 6 friends didn't make reservations and still stand around uncomfortably for 30 mins waiting for our table.

The food was mediocre at the best.  One friend sent back his potato soup because it tasted like they accidentally dumped an entire bottle of salt in it.
