The fish I got tasted bland and overcooked so the meat wasn't tender at all.  Kind of like chicken.  The portion wasn't GIANT as everyone had said.  The beer was the only light of hope guiding me away from the terrible food I was eating and down into the warm, fuzzy pits of inebriation..  Super cute decor though!

I would never come here again, even if it is right outside my doorstep! :(
author: Wendy T.

description:
This place is fun and better when you get the boot, if you catch my drift!  The food was exceptional, the staff is friendly, and the atmosphere is lively.  
Zum Wohl!
author: Paul R.

description:
Love their soups (especially mushroom when available), salad, wiener schnitzel (two LARGE pieces), and anything with Spatzle. Service was great, she checked on us throughout our meal and they cleaned as soon as we were done. Very German, definitely on top of things. Don't forget to check out their specials! Had pork stew, which didn't sound as appetizing as beef but I tried none the less, and it was melt in your mouth tender. There also seems to be less of a wait these days...bad economy?:( 
Makes for easier parking & immediate seating (or at least less of a wait) =:)
author: Sabi M.

description:
I hadn't eaten here for years and decided to come back recently. All I can say is thank god I was there early. I knew ahead of time that all the reservations were taken for parties of 6 and over and it was more a "first come, first serve/walk-in" basis. We got there 10 minutes before they opened on Saturday evening and by 5:10, there was a crazy line forming. I had no idea this place was so popular. Thank goodness we were second in line and most of our party had already showed up (have you party there to get seated or you might be out of luck!). 

Drinks were great and food was even better. The atmosphere seemed very festive. How could it not be with all the tipsy people eating a hearty, German meal?
author: Qx T.

description:
Loud, boisterous, and crowded this little restaurant is the closest many folks will ever get to Deutschland. The food is great, especially the Jaegerschitzel, and the wide selection of German beers on tap is impressive. 

When my friend Art D. turned me on to this place I joked with him that we should order a Stiefel (glass boot with 2 liters of beer) for one of our more advanced beer-drinking buddies. The waitress overheard and said that we couldn't since the table up front still had it -- what a concept: a Stiefel in S.F.! Our buddy had to settle for ein Maas--a liter of beer in a big Octoberfest-style mug.

I've always had fun here even if I had to wait 20-30 minutes for a table. I can't wait for next time! NDT - Na dann tschuess! ...
author: Nivek M.

description:
Really amazing food and great beers. Love the community tables -- so SF, fun and friendly! Came here for dinner at around 8pm and heard the hostess telling people there was a 2-hour wait as we were being seated (oof). 

I had the Portobella Mushroom stuffed with Spinach & Feta Cheese
over Pepper Sauce which was hearty and amazing in itself. My friends dug into their meat dishes and enjoyed beers as well. I sampled one of the beers, which was totally great-- and I'm not even a beer drinker. 

The atmosphere is really fun and cheery. The guys sitting next to me overheard me commenting about the huge boots of beer and whipped out their cell phone to show me pictures of the even bigger steins that Suppenkuche apparently has. Crazy. Will definitely try their food again!
author: Cheryl F.

description: Suppenkueche brings back fond memories of the year I lived in Germany and the many comparable (if less trendy) meals I took at family-owned spots in villages and large cities alike.  My Jaegerschnitzel the other night   was tasty, authentic and only topped by the surprisingly-rare-in-SF spaetzle.
author: Geoff D.

description: You can't go wrong with a pint of hefeweizen, potato pancakes and a side of bacon at brunch. Really, you can't.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Food was good, and they brought us free potato pancakes for waiting....but guess what, we waited TWO AND A HALF HOURS for a table for 4.  They told us an hour when we came in.    I don't think I will ever go back for that reason, or I'll go in 3 hrs b/f I'm ready to eat. 

That said, the wait staff was really nice despite dealing with a massive crowd.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Ate here for the first time last Friday night with some friends to celebrate my birthday after hearing a coworker rave about it. I think what caught my attention was the fact that they had great beer served in big ass glass boots. The place was loud, crowded, and there seemed to be a long wait to be seated. I'm told it's always like this.

We had attempted to make a reservation about 2 days in advance for 8:30, but they were already booked up. On a Friday night, I wasn't surprised, so this was our bad. However, they said as long as someone gets there around 7 to put our name in then we should definitely be seated by 8:30. My thoughtful girlfriend took it upon herself to be there at 7 while the rest of us were getting off work and making our way there. She had put a reservation in for a table of 6, but by the time I arrived around 7:45, we needed to add another 2 to the reservation, now totaling 8 in our party. We were told at first that 6 was the max they could seat, but once our table became ready the waiter told us that we could squeeze the other 2 in at our table. This was a relief because I was starting to think our last-minute additions to the party were going to have to wait for a separate table of their own. We fit comfortably at a table that had a booth on one side.

I drank a lot of beer that night so the details are kind of fuzzy. I do remember everyone in my group loving the food and the beer, though. I ordered the Pilsener, which was excellent. The whole table shared a communal boot filled with a light Belgian ale. Next time I'd like to get the light Hefeweizen. I don't remember any of the actual names, but if you describe what you're looking for, the bartender and/or server should be able to recommend something, and we were also provided samples before we committed to what we wanted to pay for.

As for the food, we ordered two appetizers: Bacon-wrapped asparagus and the potato pancakes. Both were delicious, and for dinner I had the wiener schnitzel, which continued the trend of awesomeness this place provided. The only thing I would have changed was instead of the red potatoes provided with my entree--I wish I would have gotten the mashed potatoes instead. Just a personal preference, the potatoes were still great though.

We took our time sitting at the table BSing and never felt rushed, although I do feel like our food call fairly quick considering how packed it was and how big our party was. I honestly can't find anything to complain about. It's even close to Bart! I'll be coming back, hopefully sooner than later.
author: Brandon M.

description:
400+ reviews and counting? Also currently the only popular place that has lived up to their fame in my book?? Must be because this place rolls off your tongue like Soup and Cootchie!!

Just kidding.

It's really because of their mouth watering snapper schnitzel, their bomb ass plain and unadulterated mashed potatoes, their cucumber salad that manages to taste healthy even though it's drenched in butter, their shandys, bread served with nutella, great service, good prices and cute cute cute atmosphere! Plus I love sharing tables!

In the holy name of meat and potatoes, ahhh fuck it I've given into the brunch part of the hype!
author: Faffy L.

description:
Thank you Check Please Bay Area (PBS) for enlightening me to this gem. We spent the day in SF shopping and we wanted a good meal. After recently seeing a review done on the above mentioned television show, we gave a call and went. 

I don't mind the whole sharing of tables thing. Actually it was kinda cool. We had to have a beer so I asked for the darkest beer they had. It was good too. My better half enjoyed an amber beer as well. as for food...... German fare is very hearty and Suppenkuche does not disappoint. Potato pancakes and potato soup to start which arrived promptly. Both were delicious and not at all what you would expect. Potato soup was a deep reddish orange and was flavored to at T. The potato pancakes were crisp on the outside and soft in the middle and with the applesauce they went like hotcakes!!! 

T enjoyed lamb chops and I had the weinershnitzel. We always share and both dishes hit the spot without question. The toughest part about dinner was driving home so full afterward. 

Not the most romantic place but who needs romance when you have the love of good food in the air! And in your tummy!!!!
author: Johnny J.

description:
Who knew that German food could ever deserve 5 stars? The soups and spaetzle are wunderbar. Bratwurst with mustard is delish. The beer that's like Guinness but starts with a "k" is so smooth and yummy. I looked at the menu 5 times trying to memorize its name but kept blanking, as happens to me with most things written in German.

It's great for birthdays because you can all do the boot and drink from it using your elbows and bond over shared backwash while everyone at the other medieval benches joins in lustily on the birthday song. And somehow it isn't Chevy's cheesy. Tonight my bf and I did the romantic nook by the bar filled with candles and tree branches. Those Germans think of everything. They even had a faucet hanging from the ceiling...
author: Katrina D.

description:
I'm certain I've gained 10 pounds in one night if not more.

But was it worth it?

First order of business, BEER. Very very large glasses of beer. They even have a 5 LITER to offer. How the hell you even begin to drink that one, I don't know. I ended up with a 1 Liter.

For my meal I had the trout, as did a friend. For some reason though mine was a lot more crispy than his but alas they were still delicious. Stealing some of my boyfriends stuffed portobello mushrooms resulted in satisfied taste buds as well. The company I was with were willing to share as well and I'd say my favorite was the pork!  Turns out even their deserts are excellent.

I left feeling warm and fuzzy thanks to friends and food. Or maybe it was just the gigantic 1-liter of beer I drank. 

So yes, it was completely worth it.

-1 star ONLY for my reference because of the extra bowel movements I experienced in the middle of the night. I do not have a steel stomach like the German folk do.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Very yummy but reeeeaally expensive for what it is. I've never paid so much for German food. That's why Suppenküche gets 3 stars instead of 4 from me. Honestly, no quibbles about the food. I'm just not a fan of paying almost $20 a plate for stuff my dad makes at home. But home is 2,700 miles thataway and Suppenküche is in Hayes Valley so ya got me.

The communal seating might bug some people, but it certainly adds an air of authenticity. The decor is really interesting, a bit like eating in an Anthropologie store.
author: Julia D.

description:
Hayes Valley landmark. One of the few German joints in the City or at least one of the few well known ones. 

Ambiance (5): Very festive with long tables that I assume should be reminiscent of Oktoberfest. Similar to Schmidt's but much more crowded, which I think is a plus. However, one complaint, the wait for a table is outrageous. An hour and a half wait, ouch!

Food (4): Food was similar to Schmidt's; lots of carbs and some protein. The mashed potatoes were solid and are a perfect vehicle for the sauce that accompanies the protein. In my case I had the meatloaf wrapped in bacon and with egg. The egg was not a plus, but the bacon took it to another level. My girlfriend had the pork sausage which was awesome, but I was surprised they didn't have more sausage selections like Schmidt's. Blutwurst, anyone? A buddy had the venison and he complained it was too well done. And finally, the potato pancakes were well executed; imagine perfectly crisp hashed browns discs with some apple sauce. The beer selection was varied and they have lots of size options, including a handy size chart with silhouettes and all...kind of like the old plane silhouette charts from WWII (saw it in a movie once).

Service (4): Friendly staff, prompt service, no complaints.

Value (4): At first I thought the prices seemed excessive, but the portions are good and I didn't mind them at all in the end.

Overall: Strangely enough this place is far different from Schmidt's. Sure, German beer on tap, long wooden tables, but the menus were vastly different. The carb-protein-kraut combo was the same but Schmidt's had more sausages and just seemed drier, if you will, compared to Suppenkuche's plates which always seemed drenched in some kind of gravy sauce. Not that that is a bad thing, but they are vastly different food experiences. You should try them both.
author: Alvaro H.

description:
"So, you want to go to SoupandCooch?"
"Wha-wha-WHAT?"
"Soupandcooch.  Here, I'll show you the website."
"Dude, that's 'Suppenkuche'."
"That's what I just said."
"Whatever. Fine."

Pronunciation notwithstanding, the only thing that makes you wonder about this place is how the Germans ever got a reputation for being efficient after you've eaten there.  Service is very friendly, very slow, and as dependable as an Italian train (in that swings by when it feels so inclined, unless the conductor is on strike...scratch that last clause).

Carbohydrates of the world:
The Jews lay claim to the bagel, the Indians naan, the Japanese sticky rice, the Italians pasta and the Germans spatzle (and pretzels).  Suppenkuche serves first-rate spatzle, not to mention kartoffle.  And meat. And beer.
author: Phil K.

description:
Oh fuck yeah!

The rest of the reviews are right- the place is damn good and its also damn crowded and loud. But hey, this is the price you pay for a pork chop that is so good you begin to think that maybe the world wouldn't have been so bad if Hitler had won. 

My GF got the pork chop and I got eh Breaded pork with a mushroom sauce, not to mention we spit an appetizer of the spud pancakes and sauce. Each thing was its own separate flavor of awesome. 

The only reason I'm not giving this place 5 stars is that they have a tendency to short you on your beer. The thing is that when they pour it, they wont let the pour run until the head has been removed. This means that while they aren't committing the cardinal sin of wasting beer, they are giving you less by leaving the head on it. 

Eh, what are you gonna do? That is a small price to pay for the kind of grub that makes you oddly okay with the notion of a master race; because hey, lets face it, a race of people who produces food this good cant be wrong. 

Just kidding, don't get all bent out of shape san francisco.

k.
author: kenton y.

description:
Yum, yum, yum!!!  Great little place.  Came here before a show at Davies Hall.  You might need to "share" the 6-person table with another group, but that is how you make friends, right? ;-)

Food was pretty tasty -- can't comment if it is authentic though.  Not a "romantic" place, but I still would recommend this place if you want a good, meat and potatoes type meal!
author: R M.

description:
Alles ist gut.

Everything was wonderful and authentic, including the atmospher
author: Tom H.

description:
*update 10/8/2007*
Another year, another successful Oktoberfest at Suppenkuche.  We had to wait 40 minutes or so past our reservation time but it was fine - we had beer to keep us company.  Mmm, beer.  

*original review*
I love me some hearty German fare and Oktoberfest beers.  Sure, the place gets loud but does it really matter when you're throwing back potato pancakes and boots of beer the size of your head with friends?  I think not.
author: phil h.

description:
Does anyone EVER finish a meal here? Who lawd! With the heavy gravy, meat upon meat and rich beers, I felt 20 pounds heavier when I walked out of there and I didn't even clean my plate that I shared with my BF. Yes, TWO people couldn't finish the "Jgerschnitzel in Champignonsoe mit Sptzle und grnem Salat." Granted I also had the potato pancakes, which were quite delicious, but still, we usually eat a lot and it was already too much.

The service was lovely. Our server was very friendly, attentive and knowledgable. The kind of guy you give a big tip to just for smiling.

The place itself is quite cozy and unassuming. Wooden tables where you may have to sit family style with other patrons. We lucked out as we ate during Oktoberfest which meant that the whole restaurant was decked out in dried flowers. It may sound like some country clutter nightmare but it was actually a work of art if you ask me.

As for the food, I guess this is just a personal preference but in general, German food does not excite me. I like bold flavors and spice. Not gravy on gravy. Yawn. Nothing against Suppenkuche, it's just not my place.

But doesn't mean I won't try it again. Next time I'll order the sausages. You can't go wrong with sausages.
author: Viv C.

description:
My mom and I have been dying to eat here.. I was born in Germany and she has not had good German food since we moved to the US (a long time) 
I had the meatloaf, which was moist and yummy with an egg in the middle. 
Mom had the portabella mushroom stuffed with spinach in a red-pepper sauce. (piquillo i think)
Our potato pancakes were crispy.. and the applesauce  was tartl Yum!
I was too stuffed to try the Black forest cake.
Next time. Definately.
author: Karlee D.

description:
The only negative is the noise level on a busy night.  Be prepared to basically be shouting to your neighbors from 7-11 on Thursday and Friday nights.

The food of course is hearty.  How else could the Germans gather so much strength to be a major part of two world wars?  After visiting Germany several times I am amazed they any small mammals left.  That rings true for the menu here...lots of meat in various forms.  However, the pork knuckles are missing...bummer...really.

The portions are huge so keep that in mind so try to share as much as possible.  

The food is always done very well and service is as good as you could expect with European ex-pats running the show in a super crowded place...read order what you can at any sight of the server.

Beer choices are awesome.  I've done the beer backpacking trip through some of Europe's finest breweries...many of Germany's best are represented here.

Go have fun here...talk to your neighbors since it is family style.  One good sign is I've met numerous Dutch, German, and Austrians here that were locals not tourists.  There is your best hint on this place.
author: Chris D.

description:
This place has an amazing beer list. Amazing. Types that I would never expect to see in a restaurant in America. That alone is incentive enough to visit. But their food is pretty good, too. I mean, German food can be heavy and have portions that are a little daunting, but Suppenkuche manages to keep it still large, but do-able. The wienerschnitzle wasn't too oily and was remarkably delicate. I tried the venison from my friend, and despite my initial aversion to eating venison, I have to admit that it was good. If you want German fare that is executed very well paired and with a delicious beer (or several), this is a place for you.  

I do have to say, parking is bitch. I tend to park at USF and just bus it down. Also, I heard that it gets really full on the weekends; I've only been on random weekdays. Still, it's worth a visit.
author: Veronica W.

description:
Don't go if you're not hungry.  If possible, don't eat all day before you go to Suppenkuche (I don't have the willpower, unfortunately).

I am half German but my encounters with German "cuisine" generally consist of my aunts' soggy, smelly cabbage and noodles with maybe some pork in there if you're lucky.  I had to take my family here on one of their visits to SF and it was probably the only meal in this city after which my father did not make sarcastic remarks while paying the bill.  And it's not cheap.  And he put the "ass" in "sarcastic" (hey, it works if you rearrange the letters..).

The food is fantastic and hearty, the interior is rustic and warm, and the service is generally good.  The beer though.  The beer.  So good.  Hmm, this is making me crave German food...gotta go call my beau and see if he's interested in some Suppenkuche.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
Great beer selection, awesome German food; I can't really call it authentic because I'VE never been to Germany, but it is really good.  In fact, we'll often take a boat-load home and eat it the next day.  The place gets REALLY REALLY CROWDED, almost unbearable crowded but as long as you know what you're in for, grab a liter of beer and STFU.

I don't know how long they've been serving the boots for, (since Matt Damon sang "Johnnie Doesn't Know" in Euro Trip?  Likely) but they seem to be all the rage now.  I prefer my beer in vessels that aren't shaped like something you put your foot into, but if that's what gets your rocks off, rock it out, you filthy podophiliac.

Everything I've had is good but I seem to continually gravitate towards the Sauerbraten (braised beef).  Maybe because it's because it melts in your mouth, maybe because it soaks up lager so well, maybe it's because it comes with both red cabbage and spatzle (my two favorite sides).  I don't know for sure but I like it.

Auf.

PS all:  "Auf" is short for aufedersein.
author: Dave K.

description: I generally don't think German when I think great food, but this place crushed it.  Sharing tables is fun, but if you don't like this place, definitely don't come with less than 4 people, and be prepared to wait for a longgggggg time.  Food was excellent.  Beer was excellent.  Great place all around.
author: Matthew C.

description:
I don't love Suppenkuche because I live right above it; I live right above it because I LOve it!  

I have had many a schnitzel here and boy are they DA bomb.  Their butter lettuce salad consists of the MOST perfect specimen of butter lettuce I have ever seen, it is delicious!!!!  The simplicity behind their German fare is what makes this place such a success.  There is a great selection of beers (they add new ones per season) and they serve Lambic which is always a nice alternative.  It is seriously buzzing every night of the week...they do not have a slow night!  

Suppenkuche is a great place to go with a big group just make sure and call ahead to ensure your party will get seated.  

Their brunch is killer too.  I love getting a couple soft boiled eggs, potatoes with bacon, cucumber salad and a mimosa.  Here's a little insider tip, If you are not presented with Nutella along with your rolls, MAKE sure and ask for it, because it's there and it is damn good on those brunch rolls!

My friend recently told me that he read about Suppenkuche in this month's Continental Airlines In-Flite magazine at which point we cracked up about it's over-exposure.  But with this goldmine; I think they are here to stay!!
author: Catrinel A.

description:
Ok...we went here because our roommate told us that this was the only eatting experience that he ever wanted 'to throw up, so he could eat more'  Well, I beg to differ.  
If you wanted a good German restaurant, Schnitzelhaus (the old haus) was way better than this place.  

They did have good beer on draft and non-alchie alternatives.  

The server was Irish and not German.  The decor was aweful - bunches of grains tied on a string near the ceiling.  Also, We felt slightly ignored by the waitstaff.  

The potato soup had bacon in it - which I am allergic to, which was not indicated on the menu, which it obviously should be.  And, the spatzel was okay, but had too many onions in it.  The schnitzelers said the schnitzel was disappointing and not very authentic, sadly.
author: Jenn D.

description:
Spatzle...Schnitzel...Schwein? Sounds like something Daffy Duck would say or spray, I wonder if he was German? ;o)

I think I can definately learn to love German Beer. Try the one with caramel & chocolate, its a great "gateway" beer to get you hooked. Quality in German beers shine through, they're a cut above the crap served out there!

I took the advice of a yelper and tried the meatloaf with mashed potatoes and onion sauce, and damn was it freaken delicious! I also didn't think I would like German food, but Suppenkuche changed my mind! I'm sooo coming back!

Minus one star for the "loud" atmosphere, but hay its half pub too.
NOTE: Make reservations, it gets quite crowded in here!
author: Venatius P.

description:
The food is great, the beer is great (and available in normal to absolutely astoundingly large sizes), and the family tables are fun.  On Friday and Saturday, it's kind of bedlam in there, but do not be deterred.  The place is full of joy and delicious German eats, and you should go at your first opportunity, and then often after that.

Note - if you are of large proportions, either vertically or horizontally, you should know that the tables and chairs are not very ample, and you'll be packed in with your fellow diners.   You'll still have fun, but some strategy in the spot you pick at the table will be well rewarded.
author: Heather S.

description: It's a wanna-be German beer hall with bland food.  The schnitzel was dry and tough.  If this is good German food, then good German food is just as bad as good English food.  The potato soup was the only thing worth eating here, but I wouldn't go back for it.
author: Joseph C.

description: I am German and can say it's San Francisco's best German restaurant. Nice staff that has worked there for long time now, good beer selection, great bread to start off with but it got way too busy and loud now. There is always a long wait in the evenings and I had the feeling the quality of the food lacked a bit therefore. Last time I had a Jaegerschnitzel and there was just too much sauce, also the Maultaschen were a bit mushy. the red cabbage is too sweet, but they make excellent Sauerkraut, got nice sausages, good Wiener Schnitzel and the ambiance with the beer benches is as close as you can get to Germany here. Try the German salad, or the trout it's really lovely!
author: Angela R.

description: Had my birthday dinner here two years in a row. Great at accommodating large groups, and some of the best food I've had in San Francisco.
author: David R.

description:
It's like I died and went to Germany:  loads of craft wheat beers (manna for my current hefeweizen phase), rich Bavarian dinner staples, and an opportunity to finally utter the phrase "religious pea soup experience." 

It gets crowded quickly and stays that way, and the noise level can rise above the decibel level of your average stadium-sized soccer match, but our party found the service both punctual and extra friendly, and the whole place seemed to exude an ambience of revelry.  Which, if you thnk about it, is just how the Germans might have done it.
author: Kevin N.

description: Long wait but worth it. The hostess gave us a time estimate, so we went down to their beer garden up the street. Good food, long tables, and big beers make for fast friends.
author: Megan D.

description:
I just found out Suppenkuche is pronounced "zuppen-koo-ka," which means that whenever I recommended this place to people as "Soup 'n cooch," I was pronouncing it wrong.(Even though it made me laugh  to say soup-n-cooch) But I digress. 

If you've had enough standard upscale San Francisco fusion/asian/american/french/italian and want to try something different, this is the place. It's loud and raucous, but that's part of the charm. They don't take reservations for less than 6, but I wouldn't really advise going with a group unless they're people you don't want to talk to - it's too loud to carry on conversation with more than one person. 

For a romantic dinner for two, this place can be surprisingly awesome.  They sit small groups together at huge thick wood ikea- looking tables, which means you're sitting with strangers, but ask to be placed kitty-corner to each other, which gives you a surprising amount of privacy, ample space, and the ability to cuddle a little - after downing a few of their enormous mugs of beer. 

The beer selection is great. I don't know much about German beer, but I bet many of the beers they have on draft are not widely available in SF or in the US, even. We had the Ayinger and Paulen Oktoberfest beers last night and they were smooth and really tasty. My Ayinger was even a little spicy! Last year they had hot mulled wine in the winter. 

The food is unbelievably filling. The beet salad is a must-eat. Each ingredient is individually pickled or marinated and delicious eaten together. The meat dishes we got (sauerbraten and a pork special) were very tender, but I think the items that accompany your meal are the standouts - the spatzle and cooked red cabbage with the saurbraten, and sauerkraut and dumpling with the pork dish. Spatzle, for those who don't know (like me before I started going here) is a sort of boiled or baked dough like a noodle that tastes like it might also be sauteed in butter. Just wonderful.

You will leave here drunk, happy, and very well fed.
author: Alyssa S.

description:
I'm fairly certain that this place is as close to heaven as you can get without spending a night with John Krasinski, complete with a champagne toast at sunset followed by a romantic dinner followed by a bubble bath followed by... well, you get the point.  

At least, that's MY idea of heaven ;) 

I had never been to Suppenkuche, although I had heard nothing but incredible things about it since moving to the city.  Of course, my girlfriend and I were both in the mood to take on a challenge, and each ordered our own boots.  I'm not talking shoes, people. Beer, and lots of it.  Each boot consists of 2 Liters of fantastic, carbonated goodness.  Now don't get me wrong..... when I say this was a challenge, I wasn't referencing the quantity of liquid consumed, because I can more than hold my own in that department.  The difficult part is finishing it before it gets warm, because nobody likes warm beer. Yuckers.

The atmosphere is warm, casual and perfect for lively conversation.  The potato pancakes were clutch - crisped to perfection on the outside, soft and flavorful on the inside.  And the homemade apple sauce that accompanies said pancakes was absolutely out of this world!  (Disclaimer:  They were so good we devoured another order in lieu of ordering an entree).

I absolutely, positively cannot wait to return.  I'm bringing my coworkers. I'm bringing my mom.  I'm bringing the lunatic woman who lives down the hall from me, because from the looks of it she is in dire need of a good drink.

***On the weekends, be sure to get there on the earlier side.  They only take reservations for parties of 6 or larger, and the wait can be intense.
author: Whitney H.

description:
Witnessed a dude drink the 5 LITER mug, by himself this past saturday night.

To put that into perspective, me and my 2 buddies each drank a 1 Liter mug ourselves with dinner, and we were belching and feeling pretty good after that.

Lemme know if I didn't calculate this right.
1 gallon = 3.8L 
5L = 1.32 gal = 169 fl. oz. / 12 fl oz = ~14 beers.

Mad props dude... that's Disgusting.

Rest of dinner was cool.  Extremely loud, but fun atmosphere.  The trout was good, and they serve it with a lemon butter sauce in a bowl the size of a cup of soup ... overkill.
author: shaun l.

description:
Update: 
We were at Suppenkuche for the girlfriend's birthday brunch of all things. There was a large group of us, about 15 people. I definitely had my doubts about this place for brunch. Dinner had been super great but I was doubtful that Germans even ate breakfast and did have any idea of what to expect. It was great. I had a sausage, stuffing, egg thing with a German name that I absolutely loved. My girlfriend had the potato pancakes which were excellent as well. There were salmon omeletes which people enjoyed, mimosas all around and great coffee. I would highly recommend this place for brunch too. 

If they did chicken wings I'd never have to leave!!
author: Bill G.

description:
I ate here monday with some friends for dinner,

boy was it packed, after our server seated us, they came back a few minutes later and asked us to move since the group we were sharing a table with had plussed their group, no biggie. Although i think some of the diners were a bit puzzled by the communal tables. 

the menu is full of standard german fair, and they have a larger selection of german beers then i've seen at most places here in the states.

I ordered the wiener schnitzel von schwien mit Bratkartoffeln und grünem Salat, although i ordered in German the server definitely did not speak it, so i went back to english, bummer.  I was not overly thrilled with my meal as i found the schnitzel to be too thinly sliced so when it was fried it was way too dry and all i tasted was the breading, the potatoes were a bit blander then what i expected as well. 

My friends ordered the Gebratene Rehmedaillions in Rotwein Pflaumensoe mit Rotkohl und Spätzle (venison) and the Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei (sausage) they are both huge fans of the place, one of which drives up from So-Cal for the food, i tasted the venison and WOW, it was fantastic, the cabbage was not as spicy as i like but good nonetheless.  

If your in the search for some hearty german fare, then try this place out!  I would definitely like to come back and try some of the other dishes.  Maybe earlier in the day, and have DAS BOOT!
author: Cooper M.

description:
solid 4.5 stars! went with a huge group, crazy 1, 2 and 3 liter mugs of beer, the beer boot, and awesome food.

Check out their specials, they have chalkboard in the kitchen on how many special items they have left !
author: Vimal P.

description:
We came here after a walking tour through Sutro Heights.  We were definitely hungry and this place did not disappoint.  There were empty seats at 5:15 on a Saturday evening, but by 5:45 the place was packed and buzzing.  I really like the atmosphere.  It had the feel of Europe, it is all in the details.  For example there was community seating.  Sitting next to complete strangers is definitely weird at first, but after a while I didn't even think about it.  The place is decorated with paper butterflies and dried flowers strung across the ceiling.  

My wife and I ordered the weinerschniztle, bratwurst, and goulash.  The goulash was NOT good.  It was way too salty.  I was wondering if they  tried the soup before they served it.  I think they forgot to add water.  The weinerschniztle is good, two large pieces.  They need to accompany it with a sauce or gravy.  Its a little dry.   The plus is they were willing to swap out the mash potatoes with potato pancakes.  The drawback is they charged us for the apple sauce for pancakes.  The dinner was $17.50.

The Bratwurst was ~$15.00.  It comes with three links, sauerkraut and potatoes, again we swapped out for pancakes.  

The experience was great, we'll definitely go back again.
author: Rhinocort D.

description:
Wow! was it crowded on a Friday night! Everybody was jolly, everybody was chatting, everybody was excited to be there! 

Came here for a bday dinner and sat at an overly crowded table - but we made it work. We shared the potato soup which was hearty and flavorful. I had the trout with capers and butter - I thought the butter flavor was too overpowering, too rich. Ryry had the veal schnitzel - it looked so good, I had to try it even though I'm not a fan of veal. And good thing I did because it was delish! Wish they had chicken schnitzel, though... 

It's hard to have a conversation with your tablemates because there are a bazillion loud drunken conversations going on throughout the restaurant. But the food is good, the staff is efficient and you'll have had quite an experience at Suppenkuche.
author: Christine C.

description: A horrible place to come for dinner. The hostess was really rude, the place was obnoxiously loud (too loud for conversation) and the food was flavorless. Fortunately the bartender and waitress were friendly and the beer is great. I'd definitely go back with friends for the beer, but I'm never eating there again (frozen dinners taste better)
author: Kyle L.

description:
Ohhhh...what did I *dew* to myself today? Suckling pig and roasted duck from the Sunset for brunch, a fried chicken sandwich from Bakesale Betty's for late lunch, and a late dinner at Suppenkuche, which is, let's face it, glorified comfort food (but how very glorious...).

The restaurant is as cute as a button. Dried flowers, family-style seating (get ready to eat with total strangers), and whimsical things hanging from the ceiling abound. Service is always good, if a bit distracted. If you go for brunch, prepare yourself for some seriously orgasmic lingonberry jam. Dinner...well, no jam, but you'll fill up on the slightly bigger portions anyway. And the beer....Mein Gott.  I HIGHLY recommend the rauchbier, which is fun to order in an Eartha Kitt growl, especially if you are the type to enjoy a good applewood or hickory fire (it's smokebeer, ladies and gents). 

Food: everything is good. The menu is not huge, and my friends and I are gluttons, so I've pretty much tried everything there. Favorites are the jagerschnitzel, the trout with lemon butter sauce, and the veal medallions. If you think you can handle an appetizer (you can't; don't blame me if the seat of your pants burst like a comical burghermeister in a silent film) try the German ravioli. I know, I know, sounds like a bad "fusion" idea, but it's really just meaty, mushroomy deliciousness.

The only cons: the wait can be long and the parking difficult. Plus, the particular breed of douchebag that abounds in that area  tends to wait for their tables in the tiny bar room whilst taking up AS MUCH ROOM AS POSSIBLE with their stools and overly-groomed bodies. Honestly, folks, sit on your barstool like a normal individual -- this means no leaning back and splaying your legs out like a man who is about to be fellated or tattooed on the inner thigh -- and we can all fit into the tiny room comfortably. 

Thankfully, reservations are available for parties of 6 or more, making Suppenkuche the perfect place for celebratory events. There's a smaller back room that is highly recommended for birthday parties an the like, so just call up, reserve the space, and set some Tylenol and a bottle of water on your nightstand for the hangover that will surely result. Prost!
author: J N.

description:
I don't like this place. 
I never have.
The fact that it happens to be in my neighborhood has never made it more appealing. 

The food is overrated, I can find better and cheaper German cuisine at any number of other places that are less crowded and have a better wider beer selection.

  Its always packed, the servers are always overwhelmed and sweaty usually in to much of a panic to serve you or pay attention. If you do have to wait for your table in the "bar" area or as I call it the hobbit hovel. Prepare yourself for the experience of being shoved into a corner with a lot of really uncomfortable old wooden furniture and far to many drunken boot revelers. 
There is not enough room to sit on a chair in there let alone try and talk,eat, or move at all. The staff seems to ignore the fact that its near impossible to move or function comfortably in this area and gives you menus anyway. Ive had to eat in this hole and it was awful having a strangers arm perpetually over my food while they are drunkenly falling into me is not my idea of a great eating experience.

  The food is aight....its in no way exceptional German food however. To much grease and not enough flavor for myself. 
One star for the potato pancakes with applesauce and the beet salad. The two best things on the menu. One star for the boots....yes the damn boot.

 If your gonna go here, get a boot, drink it, and then pass out on the sidewalk on the way home. Same experience less shoving and yelling.
author: Charlie B.

description:
As a little German girl from the Midwest, who grew up on excellent German food... I can't say enough about this place.  The food, the beer, the potato pancakes!!!!  And, as long as I remember DO NOT GO ON OKTOBERFEST WEEKEND (when they have the event at Fort Mason) - I never mind the wait.

Brunch here is a definite must have experience - where else can you drink 2 1/2 liters before noon on a Sunday and feel that it's not only acceptable but it's your civic duty?
author: Katie D.

description:
Four words:  Asparagus wrapped in BACON.  Hell, wrap anything in bacon and it'll get five stars from me.  I also recommend the "chick beer" called the Ramden (I think?)  Its 1/2 lemon soda and 1/2 beer for some extra fun refreshing freshness.  This does not come wrapped in bacon.  

Also, since I am half German and grew up visiting my grandparents there each summer, I can personally attest to the fact that the little wall-hangings of the boy and girl peeing on the doors to their restrooms is, in fact, a very German thing.  They're not trying to be disturbing, they just have a wierd sense of humor over there...
author: Jennifer K.

description: I've been to Suppenkuche twice now I really enjoy the place and the food.  I wish I could give it a 4.5 stars, but being torn between a 4 and a 5, and I had to go with a 5 just for it's originality and character.  It's not a quiet place, so if you're going with someone you're hoping to have an intimate conversation with than this is not the place to go.  The food is great, the beer selection is very good, and it's just a fun place.  To get a table we showed up before the opened and we weren't the only ones waiting to get in.  You sit at a table where if your group doesn't fill all the seats, there's going to be another group sitting at the same table.  I thought it was fun and it reminded me of being at the Hofbrauhaus in Munich.  The whole meal was good both times and I'd gladly go back.  It's not a very big place, so you may want to go right when they open or you may end up having to wait for a table.
author: Scott L.

description:
Wow. I've heard great things about this place before and have meant to try it for a long time....but even my high expectations didn't prepare me for the  bliss that was Suppenkuche.

I'll start with the amazing beer selection.  There are no fewer than 20 beers on the list, making this place the German Toronado in terms of beer selection.  And the waiters seem to know a bit about the beer, because when I asked for a recommendation of something like a belgian trippel -- thick and strong, he brought me some 9% beer that was absolutely delicious.  He said it was $6 and came out of a bottle, so I was expecting a tiny glass of beer...but what I got was a 1 liter tall glass.  I just wish I remembered the name.

Now -- the food.  I read the menu going "yes, yes, yes!" to everything I read.  I'm not a picky eater, however it is also rare that I want to order *everything* on the menu.  I ended up getting the potato soup and the beef with spatzle and sauerkraut.  It was fucking amazing.  Really.  I'm definitely coming back again and again so I can try everything else on that menu.


One little note though -- take a cab or a bus.  The street parking is very limited, and the area is kind of ghetto -- we had a bottle thrown at our windshield as we were driving around looking for parking.  No damage, but it's probably not a good idea to leave a nice car here.
author: Eugene F.

description:
Thank you, Yelpsters, you did it again!  The week before my bday, one of my friends found Suppenkuche on Yelp.  It was rated one of the best restaurants in SF for large groups.  Woo hoo!  12 people on a friday night in SF, I dare you to find something reasonable that isn't a chain or Chinese.  

My reservation was for 6:00.  I get a text from RBL at 6:03, "if everyone isn't here by 6:15, they will give our table away."  We ran.  
It was pretty busy when we first walked in.  I was a bit overwhelmed.  It's smaller inside than I expected and the restaurant was already bustling with big groups everywhere. I didn't recognize anyone in there.  I started to get nervous.  Silly me, the hostess walked us to the back room where I saw RBL and two of my other friends.   

We really lucked out with a terrific waitress who was super cool and understanding.  The hostess came back every so often to check in on us and fortunately for me, most of my friends showed up within ten minutes of my arrival (with the exception of one, Ms. Mare).  I honestly think that timing is everything.  Since I opted to celebrate my bday one week late during 4th of July weekend in the City, it wasn't as crowded as it probably is on a "regular Friday night."  But don't get me wrong, it was still crowded.

Anyway, to the food.  My gracious friends ordered the German ravioli and potato pancakes for apps (and probably to appease the anxious wait staff while my tardy friends were waiting to make their entrance).  I enjoyed both dishes tremendously.  The potato pancakes had the best consistency - crispy on the outside and deliciously starchy on the inside, just like the perfect hash brown.  And the german ravioli tasted like a dumpling to me, but it was still very good.  I ordered the beef with red cabbage and schnitzel.  It was a LOT OF FOOD.  Or maybe it was a lot of beer?  Either way, I highly recommend this place and those of  you brave enough to guzzle a liter of beer, by all means.  This is the place to do it!
author: Christie X.

description:
A lot of people I know go to Suppenkuche for the beer. They also don't know how to pronounce the name. Both of these facts are acceptable, but I got to Suppenkuche for the BRUNCH:
1. Pancakes that are a cross between the most amazing pancakes you have ever had and the most amazing muffins you have ever had.
2. Chickensnitzle - one of the few times/places you can get it in SF and is it deliche!
3. Fresh authentic museli with german yogurt and berries
The list goes on and on.
Oh, and you can get beer at brunch too (yes even the boot). Best way to cure a hangover I have found yet...
author: Virginia M.

description:
an average "4-star" rating after 642 reviews should indicate that this place is just one face-melting, high-kicking good time.

I've only been here twice, and both times were for the Sunday brunch.  The atmosphere feels as though you've happily been invited to the bi-monthly Wurzburg Town Hall meeting, where any second now we are going to discuss installing a new roundabout to slow traffic and the possibility of importing a new Dunkel from Augsburg for Oktoberfest, rather than brewing in town.

Its as authentic of a place as there ever will be outside ... maybe even inside ... the country of Germany.

The food is delectable, the sausages, the potato cakes, the pancakes ... everything ... and sitting at the bar make the views of the beer  taps/other patrons CLEARLY enjoying themselves all the better.

This place is on my CAN'T MISS for every trip to SF from here on out.
author: Maurice G.

description:
If you too like to get trashed on boots full of beer surrounded by hipsters, the elderly, and children, then give me a call and I'll start heading over.

As a head's up, there's a $50 deposit on said boot should you break it, so I don't recommend getting one if you're already sauced. But  the lady-friends and I were feeling adventurous and were still sober, so we ordered a shoe of booze (how feminine!) from Rusty and Craig, who are now my favorite bartenders in all of the city. They're fantastically knowledgeable about German beers, friendly as all get out, and even offered to put a stop to the creepster who kept hitting on us at the bar (and eventually ended up flirting with one of the elderly). 

I will be back. Oh, how I will be back.
author: Carla C.

description:
I've beent trying to go here for the longest time and finally had a chance to yesterday.  I lived in Europe (Denmark) for a year when i studied abroad and was hoping to relive a glimpse of that here. 

We put our name down and went across the street to grab a beer as we waited for a seat. When we got back, we figured that our name was already called and needed to put it down again. They were nice enough to seat us next, unlike many other restaurants that put you at the bottom of the list. 

The drinks and soup came out pretty quickly, but it seemed to take a long time for the entrees.  I was sad to find that the food was really salty and not the best I've tasted. =(. I really had high hopes.  (i got ordered off the specials menu, Wild Boar and mushrooms.)

The place was cool. Very loud. I went with my sister and we shared a table with two other pairs of people. it was interesting, but not as awkward as i would have thought. 

I'm glad i finally got to go...but i'm not sure if i'd go back anytime soon.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
Mixed bag on ratings for this place.  Great selection of beer and a fun environment.....Can get really loud and crowd is targeted more toward frat-like boys.  The seating is caferteria style and so is the taste food. 

Food---to be fair, maybe I'm just not a fan of German food. I was definitely not impressed with the food.  Food was very heavy and rich and there was nothing that really had me wanting more than two bites before wanting to puke due to the heaviness.  Had some cold plate appetizer that was like eating bologna and cold spam.   The one dish that was good was the potato pancakes with apple sauce.  Crispy on the outside and warm on the inside.

Service is spotty, and waitress was nice but oober slow.  Had a party of 12 and would come back each time with one water in her hand....why make 12 trips each time...its called a serving tray people.

Would come back here for the beer in the cool boot, but not for the food or the service.  If all you're about is the beer and a loud place to get drunk and yell, this may be the place.
author: YumCha L.

description:
900+ reviews and a solid 4 stars should tell you this place is good.

I'm a big fan of German restaurants heralding back to the good 'ol college days when the local German restaurant would have drink specials on boots.  Of course in those days I'd be next to a table with someone puking while trying to chug the last of the beer.  This place was a slightly classier establishment...

There's just something comforting to tuck into a plate of spaetzle and food covered in gravy.  Delicious food and the prices are totally in line with every other German place that I've been to.  What's even better is that the food is so filling you won't have to eat the next day - what a value!  

If it's crowded you can expect to share tables with strangers.  We sat next to two German dudes and it felt like we were thousands of miles away.

I could spend a year talking about the beer but I'll keep it short 'n sweet and say YUM.
author: Jaime C.

description:
Loud, offbeat, deservedly popular, absolutely delicious. Incredible beers. Very helpful, smiling staff in a room that must be pretty exhausting to work when it's crowded, which is always. Toddlers, magpies and others will appreciate the artful, bird-themed 3D ceiling decorations, one of the few softening notes in a room that NEEDS a pack of delighted diners to feel hospitable--and so it does.
The "Christmas beer' I had was delicious.  
Wish they took reservations for smaller parties.
(ARE there other German restaurants in SF? The other one I've been to was laughably bad. The wiener-schnitzel breading tasted like a kid's art project. That place appeared to be out of business this week. Forgot the name)
author: John H.

description:
The lentil soup, salad, and cheese spaetzel (spelling?) were all delicious.

I drank the pilsners like I drink my water (fast).  They went down THAT easy.  

While many in my party were not fans of the rye bread they serve before the meal, I loved it not just for the taste but for the authenticity it added to the restaurant.  I could've felt like I was in a quaint German town if not for the gazillon people crammed into this small space.  

The wait was a little bit stressful.  After a good 1.5 hours since we put our name in we still were not seated.  It made me a bit nervous that there were so many tableless people lurking around, ready to swoop in as soon as they detected people were leaving.  Fortunately, the host  proved to be on top of his game and managed to seat us when a six person table finally finished.  

This place is LOUD.  Not a place to catch up with old friends or get to know a new one.  The radius within which your voice can be heard is extremely small.  Choose your immediate neighbor carefully here.  I was with great people so I had a great time!
author: Jennifer R.

description:
When my friend called me and invited me to go to dinner to a German restaurant, I admit I was a bit hesitant. I have been to Germany and experienced the food. However, I am a pescetarian, which means I don't eat meat. German food is famous for the sausages and I didn't know if this restaurant would be veggie-friendly. Anyway, after checking out the website and a little encouragement from a couple other friends, I gave it a go.

Since the restaurant was located in Hayes Valley and there is not a lot of parking available there, a few friends and I decided to carpool. After searching for a good 20 minutes, we didn't find anything so ended up valeting it (which, for $7, is not bad at all).

As soon as the rest of the gang arrived, the boys were ready for their beer...in the famous German boot. My brother and I scanned the menu for veggie-friendly food and to our luck we found something! I ended up ordering the Portobella Mushroom stuffed with Spinach and Feta Cheese served on a Pepper Sauce and a glass of red wine.

We anxiously awaited the boots that boys ordered and, when they finally arrived, cheering ensued. It was so exciting. I just kept thinking about the movie "Beerfest."

Shortly after, our food arrived. It looked absolutely delicious. Other than my brother and myself, everyone else ordered pork chops or sausages. And everyone was definitely pleased. The food was really good.

I think the highlight of the night, other than the food and the boys and their boots, was the tiny woman sitting at the table next to us who ordered the wheel barrel, which was a giant mug of beer, much larger than the famous boot. I couldn't believe she finished the entire thing.

Great food. Great company. Great times.
author: Jillian J.

description:
The food here in one word? Hearty. The Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes was really good. I've never really been a fan of sauerkraut, but at Suppenkuche it was amazing. The tanginess of the pickled cabbage paired perfectly with the sausage. The Wild Boar and Spatzle was alright - it tasted very meaty and hearty. It was my first experience with spatzle. I thought it'd be like mac&cheese, but it was more doughy and the texture reminded me a little bit of stretched out gnocchi. It didn't really have much of a taste on it's own but it was good with the meat and the sauce.

Make sure you go with an appetite! Being a little thirsty doesn't hurt either - they have tons of German and Belgian beers on tap including Oktoberfest special Marzens that taste great with the food.

We showed up on a Friday evening at about 7pm with no reservation and the place was packed but we were able to get a table for two immediately. This would be a great place to grab a beer with friends, if you like loud, tightly packed places.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Of all the restaurants in the great city of San Francisco, one will not find an authentic experience such as this. Suppenkuche offers an intimate atmosphere right off the bat. 

I walked in and, since the place is packed (as it should be), I went to the bar with my party (4).  We enjoyed some great beers (I recommend the Erdinger Dunkel) and in about 20 minutes were seated next to a couple. It's great how it can seem like family-style dining (very intimate) but you are not impeding on the conversations around you.  

Between the Potato Pancakes, Wiener Schnitzel, 1.5L Boot of Beer, 2.0L AND 3.0L beers one can really enjoy their experience here! This is the ONE place I consistently refer my clients to if they want to get away from the "Wharf Life."  This place is truly a gem in Hayes Valley!
author: Dominic P.

description:
This restaurant doesn't need any more reviews, but I love the brunch here -- so many options, bottomless cup of coffee in a solid diner cup & saucer, and sun streaming through the windows in the back room.

My favorite breakfast item is the veal sausage with a pretzel, and I love that they bring you a little pot of sweet mustard as an accompaniment.  The second favorite breakfast is the cold cut platter.  In addition to a lovely soft boiled egg and slim jim, nearly none of the fifteen or so slices of cured meats, which are arranged across a pig-shaped wood cutting board, are repeated.  Sprinkled with some chives, this plate also provides me lunch for the next two days.

Super competent and informed staff, as well.
author: C H.

description:
Okay so it's been about 2 months since my visit to Suppenkuche...however I think I'm still actually full!

Never having had German food, I was under the impression that when you ordered Wiener Schnitzel, I'd get a plate with a foot-long sausage or something...I means it's in the name..."wiener". To my pleasant surprise, what came about was this perfectly fried porky goodness, in essence combing my two favorites foods...anything fried + pork = yummy in my tummy.

The other star of the show was the potato pancake, which I hate to say puts the hash brown at Mc D's to shame.

Minus 1 star for being seated 45 minutes after our reservation. I suppose once you're sitting down you never want to leave.
author: David H.

description:
I went to Suppenkuche on a tuesday night, a very busy tuesday night with a group of about 11 people.  I've got to say that the amount that I drank and ate was plenty, and the experience as a whole was pretty sweet.

Passing around a big heavy beer boot (with a $50 deposit) was a little sketchy, but once the beer hits your lips...

I'm just thankful the tab was covered by the company, otherwise I would have never stepped inside this Hayes Valley madhouse.

The servers were working their asses off, food was delicious (especially the giant pretzel), and the beer was FANASTISCH!
author: L J.

description:
Could say bustling atmosphere, but when you can't hear the person next to you, might want to call it loud.

Food was OK, a bit overpriced.  

I noticed that the foreign language on the menu seems to imply that they can charge European prices for non-alcoholic drinks (e.g., $10 per liter).
author: S E.

description:
This place has the best food ever...I love their potatoe pancakes!!! Taste as good as they sound..if u like crispy fried hash browns with mushy center potatoes then this is the way to go. I ordered the curry sausage and im still thinking about the whole meal til this day. This place has really good food but it can be loud cuz so I wouldnt reccomend u bringing ur parents unless they are prepared for a stadium meal. Also they have great beer and if u can drink this is the place to be. They have 3, 2 & 1 liter beers which are fresh from the kegs. 

Honestly I will be back there soon...feel free to have a beer with me and share some of ur potatoe pancakes  if u see me...lol
author: PETER H.

description:
I've been here before, for my best friend's birthday, and loved it. I happened to be in the area and decided, what the hell, let's see if I can get a seat.

Started with a Schneider Edel-Weiss while I waited. It's a favorite of mine, especially on tap.

Got a seat behind the bar, which was damn convenient.

Between the weiner schnitzel (with roasted potatoes and green salad) and the special grilled venison sausage (with sauerkraut and spatzle), I was recommended the schnitzel. It didn't disappoint.

Hey, wait, why are my potatoes so tasty? Oh, hello chunks of bacon! How are you tonight?

To accompany the meal, and in recognition of Oktoberfest, I got a mass of Spaten Helles. Damn fine beer, a new favorite.

After a leisurely meal I decided on another beer. Again, from the Oktoberfest special menu, I went with a Ayinger oktoberfest.. My plan was to get a .5L, but when the bartender asked if I wanted a mass, well, who was I to refuse. The beer, rich, malty, and crisp, was excellent.

The beer, food, and staff, are all amazing.
author: John C.

description:
It's hard to go wrong with fried chicken, mashed potatoes, and beer. And Suppenkuche does it sooo right.  Although, I did sort of miss vegetables (no the green beer and the pile-o-lettuce don't count).

Great rowdy atmosphere was almost complimented by our impossible to find server, since it encouraged yelling and playful grumpiness.  Perfect for big groups but make a reservation about 1 week in advance.
author: Tessa M.

description: This place holds amazing amount of character without aesthetic glits and glam. The place is simple with rather white walls and minimalistic art. They have an amazing beer list, the food is un-matched by any other German restaurant I've been to (and I come from a purely German family). The place is packed every single time Ive been inside. I recommend it to everyone I meet!
author: Alex H.

description:
I was in search of a fun place to go out and celebrate, well, nothing, with a good friend and remembered driving by this place in Hayes Valley with a line around the block - enter Suppenküche. 

While we waited for two seats to open up, I put down a $50 deposit and a whole lot of faith on a boot full of beer. Best decision ever...we made new friends as they took pictures with our beverage, too timid to get one of their own. 

We were seated next to two couples who were as interested in sharing plates as we were. I don't even remember everything I tried that night, though it involved lots of mushrooms, asparagus and rich cream sauce. The meatloaf, however, is something I won't soon forget. We ordered it on a whim, and it definitely wasn't how momma made it (God love her). We returned the boot in-tact and traded in the movie we were going to see for our beds - the food coma hit hard.

For my next trip, I intend to bring a group of good friends and attempt to concquer one of their more creative drinking vessels.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
This place is so much fun!  Loud, boisterous, and extremely German.

I've been here multiple times, but recently I went here for my birthday with about, oh, 17 friends...which is hard to imagine most places accommodating us, but this place did it with ease due to their benches and semi-communal tables!  So much fun.  The food is delicious, and the beer...SO GOOD... DASSS BOOT.

It's a place that is always in my suggestion box.
author: Kristin E.

description:
So far, I've only come here for Brunch but I love it!!!  I think the value is tremendous and drinking a Pitcher of Beer on a Sunday morning.  Well, that certainly hits the spot for me.    

Most of the food is really good and you may make new friends with the community tables.  Their free bread was fresh and the jams that came with them are very tasty.  Not sure if either the bread or the jams are homemade but it's been hard for me to keep from eating them before the actual meal came out.  I've been getting stuffed before the actual meal came out everytime I've come so far.  And the portions were huge on the things we ordered.  The Farmers Omelette is really worth it at $8.50 or so....  

So, at this point, the Sunday brunch has been outstanding.  But I am a little afraid to come at any other hour because I am afraid they have nowhere to go but down from my Brunch experience.  

But we'll see, if I have any friends who call and say, "Hey, want to go to Suppenkuche for dinner?", I'll probably be hesitant initially but will eventually give in and check it out.......
author: Mark W.

description:
I had Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce with Sauerkraut  and Spätzle for $19.50. For the price, the way they make you sit at the shared table with other people is so wired. I would expect this for places where the food is under $10 but when the food plate is $15 to$20, it would be nice to at least have your own table. 
Venison was not the best . The best venison I had is still at MESA grill in Las Vegas. Sauerkraut was good, but spatzle was......But there were a lots of German people, so it may be just very authentic. 

Over all, I had a great time with a friend, but this place should be charging 1/2 price.
author: Mika G.

description:
I'm not German, but Dad was such a fan of the German Food and lifestyle that I think it somehow trickled down. When I need comfort food, it's German I seek. Mac and cheese??, not when there's SPAETZLE available. I went with the Sauerbraten mit Preiselbeerkonfitüre, serviert mit Rotkohl und Spätzle. Um, yeah. Whatever it was it was awesome.

My cohorts tackled the sausage and game hen, looked just as good.

One downside is the acoustics are crazy in here- its super busy and LOUD. I'm not taking a star off though, this is about yummyness and they do that well. 

Oh- I also had the largest beer of my life, turns out that's not the best idea right before a red-eye across America in a window seat, I give myself one less star for that move.
author: Rhubarb M.

description: Waited for 1.5 hours for a table that never appeared. Finally, got sick of groups ahead of us being seated. Rude and arrogant maitr d. Even the giant beers didn't keep us there. We ate across the road. No big loss, its German food anyway.
author: Stephen M.

description:
For those random moments where you need loud entertaining dining companions and don't have the circus in your dining party you should definitely check out this Bavarian dining establishment!

Expect to wait, have a beer and be social. This isn't really the place for a vegetarian or a light small appetite. its not a quiet romantic dinner where its just the two of you, its loud and with communal seating you get to sit with all sorts of people. This includes the little lady who orders the Boot of some bier. 

I had the sauerkraut and i was glad it did, little bits of pork were in it, not to mention it wasn't just the taste of vinegar and salt, but something more.  Next time I'm trying the sausage but they have some awesome looking specials. The Saurbraten just melted!! It was soo damn good i was tempted to place another order just to have left overs later that night, But you wont be hungry for awhile, nor will you be done fast. Its a hearty meal so bring your appetite!!!

Oh and ask for the Black forest cherry cake, they will tell you they don't have it, but ask!! OMG SOOO GOOD!
author: Brian Y.

description:
Wie gehts? This place for sure! 

Again, another one of my most favorite restaurants in the city of San Francisco. They have fricking Reisdorff Kolsch on tap and Jagerschnitzel. I like the fact that you share tables with people -- especially the introverted ones. 

Enough said!

Alles klar!
author: Chris G.

description:
It is a wonder Suppenkuche doesn't move to some place bigger.  The food is so good, that it is always super crowded.  Most of the time, I seem to be hidden behind a crowd of people while I eat.  And, I can't get the wait staff to notice me.  Also, the wait to get seated can be very long.

But, the food is great.  Classic German food, but not incredibly refined.  It is really just well-made bar food.  But, not like those fried bits of whatever you get in an American Bar.  This food is stuff that actually goes well with beer.  I am a big fan of the great meatloaf and the potato pancakes.  They have a nice selection of draught beers from Germany.  Several different styles from light Helles to dark Dunkels.  

The place itself is very crowded.  It is small so you usually end up sitting with someone you just met.  Classic beer-hall style.  The decor is sparse from the bare wood tables to the unfinished hardwood floor.  Despite its unrefined character, the crowd seems to be rather trendy.  People are in casual wear, but rather expensive brands.  I guess it is the Hayes Valley crowd.  But, some thing seems ironically out-of-place.

The service is spotty.  Because it is so crowded, it seems hard to get noticed.  So, be prepared to either go out of your way to get your waiter or to wait for a while.

In short, if you are in the mood for German Beer Hall food and don't mind the crowds, Suppenkuche is the place to go.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Highly recommended. I've never had German food prior to visiting Suppenkuche and it obviously didn't disappoint.

The food was to die for and the crowd was amazing. The tables are communal - so this place is definitely more for groups rather than for couples or dates.

Try their beer - it was amazing especially when served in the boot. 

Lastly and the only negative about this place is how busy they get. I suggest that you try to get to this place as early as possible as they can get pretty crowded and wait time can go for 3 hours.
author: Jon T.

description:
Still a fun place.  Had my b-day here two years ago and had a pretty good time with my crew.

Bavarian style seating with total strangers, but people somehow behave.

Food is traditional German pub fare, but they get it right.  Pretty authentic and I've been to Germany my fare share of times.  I just wish they'd have kasespatzle.  Goes great with beer.  Portions are "German size".  You won't go away hungry.

Good German beers on tap and even some Belgian beers.  Can't go wrong with a place that has Franziskaner, Spaten, and Leffe on tap.

But get here early.  Otherwise, it is quite the mob scene.  Crazy packed.  I think they take reservations, but they have to be made well in advance.  Otherwise, first come ... first serve.
author: Patrick K.

description: My advice is to go to the bar, get a great beer and order some potato pancakes. Unless you are with a large group it's not worth it to wait for a table. If you are prepared to wait you will be unblinkingly satisfied; If not the hectic environment is best enjoyed by the bar. The beer here is fabulous and served properly and with pride.
author: Luz R.

description:
First, some background.  I'm not German but I did spend part of my childhood in Germany as a USAF brat.  I was a fanatically picky eater as a child (how I've changed!) but did eventually warm to a good Jaegerschnitzel.  

Skip forward twenty years and I had a moment very much like the scene in Ratatouille when the critic tastes the namesake dish and is transported back to a childhood memory.  But my moment was at the now-closed Schnitzelhaus.  

So German food is dear to my heart, and I was indeed quite heartbroken first when Walter (Schnizelhaus owner) died and later when the restaurant finally closed.  Since then I have visited Walzwerk and, recently, Suppenkuche.

We started with the potato pancakes and and one of my personal favorites, Erdinger (Weibier).  I thought the pancakes should have been a touch warmer, and the beer a touch colder.  (Not authentic, I know...)  I also ordered a side of potato soup.  It was darker and spicier than expected.  It was good, but it didn't meet my expectations.    

The Jaegerschnitzel itself was very good...fresh mushrooms, awesome gravy, and the veal was grade-A.  But the Spätzle was a bit dry and rubbery for my tastes.  And the side of salad was, well, underwhelming.  I longed for picked beets as a side.

Would I go back?  Yes, in a similar set of circumstances: early dinner, party of 6+, in order to get reservations and beat the crowds.  But given a choice, I'd pick WalzWerk.
author: Chaz B.

description:
This place is the best for a hearty german brunch.
I have even bribed them into letting me use the back room for our big group. They have a nice bar area for sitting on your own with the paper and coffee. (not many spots have that)
After a few mimosas and that huge breakfast though- I am ruined for the rest of the day. Diets be damned!!
author: Melissa B.

description:
After hiking all over San Francisco with my favorite travel partner (the huzzband) + carrying my school crap (which weighed one million pounds) we ended up here for dinner.  

I don't think I'm fond of sharing a table with other people (it was just the two of us and we were seated with two "strange" looking men) so that leads to a MINUS One.

For dinner I had their Butternut Squash soup which was yummy but think enough to stick a fork in it and have it stand, but still yummy.  Hubby and I shared potato pancakes which were deliciously fried and accompanied by a very liquified applesauce.

The bread that they start you with is pretty good...i think the butter was infused with chives...but I can't remember.

Overall, it was just "A-Ok"
author: Karen B.

description:
My boyfriend (now husband) and I went to Germany a few years back and I fell in love with a typical German dish called Maultaschen. It's like ravioli, but a different shape and different texture, smothered in a mushroom gravy-like sauce. Very dense, very meaty and very carb-licious. 

We couldn't get enough of Maultaschen while we were in Germany. A German colleague of my husband's made it from scratch for us and it melted in my mouth. I still think about it once in a while. 

I have never seen Maultaschen in the states. Until tonight. It was a bit different than I remembered, but still very good and the mushroom sauce was perfect. 

It would have been the perfect authentic German meal if my Sauerbraten (braised beef) hadn't been so tough. Braised meat is supposed to be tender, but Suppenkuche's version was tough and dry. 

Despite the lackluster Sauerbraten, I really enjoyed the overall dining experience and I want to come back and check out the Sunday brunch.
author: Lee H.

description: This place is great! Really great aesthetic, really amazing food, and great service. Headed there for brunch this afternoon, would head back anyday.
author: Jaclyn M.

description:
My favorite thing about this place are the large number of shiny disco balls in various sizes hanging from the ceiling. There were just so many! I was captivated.

The seating is fun, because sometimes you get to share a table with a couple other people, and i'm not being sarcastic... it jsut makes the whole vibe of the place comfy. sort of like home. (this place is the size of my apartment it's that small people)

The food I ordered was great... the braised beef if I remember correctly, I opted out of the cabbage stuff (ack!) and substituted mashed potatoes in it's place. I've never been a fan of cabbage... its like eating marinated shredded paper, yuck.

Overall, we had a great dinner here... it's in Hayes Valley which is always nice. 4 Strong Stars :)
author: Richard T.

description:
So my friend lives like two ft. from this place and whenever we pass it there is a huge line outside and we swear we're going to try it.  Finally, we had a friend in town and a reason to go.  Luckily we had a party of 6 so we were able to make a reservation for this place.   We didn't have to wait at all, although they seated us with a single eater who was almost done with his meal.  

Now to the food...mmmmmmmmmm!!!!  Now my german best friend and her family introduced me to some good german grub.  This place totally lived up to my expectations.  I had the cheese spatzle in onion butter sauce and although my arteries were ready to burst , my stomach was in heaven.  I actually shared this dish and two others with a couple of friends and this was the favorite all around.  One friend had pork sauteed in mushroom sauce and the other had the breaded & sauteed porkloin.  Both were good hearty meals, but nothing really topped the spatzle.  Other than that, we all had a different german beer so that everyone could try them.  Then to top it off we ordered both desserts...although I preferred the apple strudel.  The fresh whip cream just made it that much better! 

Overall, I will definitely be back.  The only reason there are 4 stars is because of the strange man at our table who wouldn't stop talking.  Prost!
author: Kimberly C.

description: Delicious German beer & food! Good selection of beers. Warm lighting. Great service.
author: Anna R.

description:
I grinned from the moment I walked in until the moment I left.  After living in Stuttgart for 4 months last year, this place was a perfect reminder of all the things I miss about Germany!

The minimalist interior, kitchen-style tables, and boisterous community atmosphere was an instant reminder of the WeiB brauhaus in Dinklesbuhl, Germany... one of our favorite medevial towns. 

Start with the salad... or rather, 6 salads (beets, red cabbage, carrot, potato...), the jaegerschnitzel mit champignons and spaetzle was particularly delightful, though my husband loved his slightly gamey wild boar.  Wash it all down with a golden riesling or heifeweisen dunkel... and you will swear you have left California behind!  

We loved sharing our table for 8, with a boisterous Eastern European group, swapping recommendations from the menu, and exchanging thoughts with our neighbors on the right... heartily gesturing wildly over their beers.  The only non-German experiences of the night were the awesome use of English and the amazing service.    What a perfect place!  The wait can get long... but the neighborhood is great for a stroll in the meantime.
author: Ananda Z.

description:
Add one more to the legions of devoted customers.  Great food and fantastic beer make for a delightful experience.

There are vegetarian options (potato pancakes are a must), but if you eat meat, it would be a shame if you passed up the chance to have one of their meat-atarian plates.  On Saturdays they roast a whole pig.  Their sausage, not surprisingly, is top notch.

Get a group together and you can drink beer out of a giant glass boot, a la "Das Boot" from Beerfest... I kid you not.  It does require a $50 deposit.

The decor is plain and simple - it looks like a bunch of picnic tables.  But when you get the food, it really doesn't matter.  It does get crowded, and they don't take reservations, so getting there before 6pm is probably best.
author: Chris R.

description:
So good! i LOVE german food and i am soo happy to have found this restaurant. Of what i tasted nothing was less then awesome.. for a main course i ordered the sauteed pork loin (jägerschnitzel) in mushroom sauce with spätzle and i was downright sad when there was no more room in my stomach for another bite. As an appetizer we shared the potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce which was fabulous! All of the other dishes i tasted were really good to, the cheese spätzle in onion butter sauce was so rich, creamy and delicious mmmmmm ;) of course any meal is more enjoyable with great beer, especially when it comes in a huge boot haha. Beware the wait is a little long but quite worth it in my opinion. 

Other then the food i loved the decor and vibe here. the service is very friendly and helpful in picking dishes as well as your beer.
