When i walked in i felt that someone had invited me and all of their friends into their home for a feast, with picnic bench style seating and a homey decor i really enjoyed every minute.
author: Barbara C.

description:
WHOOO HOO, how can you not like beer in boots and sausages.  Really fun place for a large group.  Like all the reviews below, the restaurant is on the small side, and there's usually a wait if you don't have a reservation or get that right at 530.  

My friends and I were there for a while, and enjoyed a lot of the food.  The potato pancakes and bacon wrapped asparagus were my favorite.  I didn't realize their vast beer selection which is awesome.  I hate that light beer crap.  It's a really unique place and the dining experience couldn't be complete without a boot.  My first reaction was wow, this place is smart.  They ask for a credit card to hold while you have a boot, which will be returned on the return of the boot.  Apparently, people try to steal the boots.  The boot was really cool too, the foot itself is super small with a massive calf.  I was really excited when I got to the ankle and the bubble got my face (I choked, I forgot the beerfest scene to turn the boot).  

Great ambiance for large groups and looking forward to go again.  Teeny problem and unfortunately, why it's one star shy, I probably consumed 5000 calories in one night.   Oddly, I didn't feel gross after, but my gut was not happy with me.
author: Laura H.

description:
It has only been a little over 24 hours since I left here and I am already having withdrawals.   I met a friend here from brunch yesterday and couldn't have been happier with this place.  I loved the communal seating, the menu in German and the tasty rolls and marmalade on the table right when we sat down.  I am not normally a meat eater at breakfast but base on our waitress' recommendation we both got the egg scramble with bacon, sausage, potatoes and onion and it also came with a cucumber salad.  It was sooo tasty and the portions were big enough to feed a very hungry giant.  I think each of us only made it 1/3 through the scramble.  

Anyway, not only am I psyched to come back from brunch with the BF in tow (who adores all breakfast meat products) since spatzle is on the dinner menu, I cannot wait to come here for dinner -- OK, and I want to check out some of the beers on the menu.
author: Katie P.

description:
I was very disapointed with this place. I love love love German food and I was really looking forward to the food, the beer, and the overal atmosphere.

First of all, the host was a COMPLETE AND TOTAL dick to my boyfriend, whom happened to be the first to arrive. The host treated him like he was a homeless person off the street begging for scraps of wienershintzel. Just because a young man with tight pants and piercings comes into your place, doesnt mean they dont have money! If you want young cool people eating at your establishment, dont treat them like garbage.

I made the reservation 2 weeks ago. And I even called to confirm. Of course, they fucked up and didnt have a table large enough to accomidate our 7 party guest. We were crammed into tiny ass table, and then later told by the same host that we were blocking the door because we had too many people sitting at the table.

The food was pretty good. I had the wienershnitzel (breaded pork cutlet), spatzle, and a green salad. It was just okay. 
A friend at the table got the meatloaf (which was DELISH) and another got the sausage (also delish). 

The beer was great, and the black forrest cake was amazing. 

I might be back for the two dishes I just mentioned, and of course, the beer. But I will probably just get it to go, cuz the service was definitley lagging.
author: Keila E.

description:
I grew up in Germany so I've been to a few German places. I'm sorry to say I was disappointed by this one. I arrived at about 6:30 on Saturday night. The place was crowded. I didn't realize that German was trendy. I guess you can't blame them for that. We had a reservation for 6 people, but a few more showed up. The hostess was nice enough and brought us an extra chair and we squeezed in. 

The place is so small that we could not sit anyone at one end of the table and we were pressed up against the wall and the table on the other side. The place is so loud. The walls are bare and the sound fills the room so that we had to yell to be heard by the person sitting next to us. They badly need to fix the acoustics in this place. 

Our waiter was nice enough when he finally managed to push his way through the crowd and took our orders. Service was less than attentive. I think our waiter was having difficulty getting back to us through the throng that was standing around the bar. 

My food finally arrived. I had the Jaegerschnitzel. It wasn't like anything that I have had before. It was tough and dry. The sauce was overly thick and salty. It was a poor attempt at German food.   

I've had much better German food in other places in this area. I'm not sure what is going on at Suppenkuche. Perhaps success is hurting them. I first went here many years ago and enjoyed it. Sorry that it isn't what is used to be.
author: Michael L.

description:
THE SKINNY:
Dropped by during a trip in San Fran. My cousin was craving for some German food so I did some research and found this place! Reviews don't lie! The Food was Great!

THE GOOD:
For the entire trip, My sister, My Cousin, and I would order different meals and try each others food. Great way to sample new restaurants. We were so Hungry by the time we got here (we literally walked from Pier 39 to here because the Cable Cars were PACKED). First off, the complimentary bread was good, but the butter was even BETTER! It had some sort of seasoning in it. It had this really unique flavor that I can't explain. Amazing. I ended up ordering the Wienerschnitzel. It was fantastic. It was lightly breaded pork that was cooked perfectly to a crisp. The presentation wasn't memorable but the food definitely was. I added a little lemon juice to the fillets and it was absolute heaven. My sister had the Grilled Pork Chop. Ohh that was amazing was well. It was a generous sized Pork Chop with appetizing grill marks served on top of some creamy mashed potatoes. OMG. Thank you to the pig who sacrificed itself to let me eat him.

THE BAD:
My Cousin had the Pork Medallions in Plum Red Wine. It was really good at first, but it was one of those dishes were you get tired of the flavor after a while. In my opinion the Plum Wine became a little too overwhelming that it killed the flavor. I tried their beer with the Chocolate, Caramel, and Molasses flavor. It wasn't anything exciting. I should've just gotten a boot. But the chocolate flavor in beer had me curious. Oh well. The waiter kept talking about how great the apple streudel was, but it really wasn't as great as she made it sound. The presentation made it mouth watering. It was a nice strip of apple streudel topped with Powdered Sugar and nice scoop of Vanilla Ice Cream. It was Good no doubt. But not Great.
author: Christian I.

description:
Never really had German food at a restaurant so I wasn't exactly sure what to expect.    Just looking at the menu though made me very excited to see how things actually tasted.  From the start, the experience was good.  They have a nice selection of beers which is what you have to start with.  Nothing goes better with some hearty food than a nice cold beer.

So I came here with a few friends and we started with the potato pancakes and fried Camembert cheese.  Both were excellent. The Camembert was nice and crunchy on the outside and warm and melted on the inside.  It was served with a side of jam (forgot which kind) and fried parsley which went well all together.  The potato pancakes served with apple sauce were crispy but not too greasy.  I really enjoyed the sweet and savory style of both dishes.

For myself, I got the Jägerschnitzel which was awesome.  Two nice big pork cutlets sauteed over a nice mushroom sauce.   The only minus would be the Spätzle (for me).  I just wasn't a big fan of it.    It's probably made how it should be but it just wasn't for me.

The food is definitely hearty though so I couldn't see myself eating here more than once in every 3-4 months.  The prices are about moderate.  Not a cheap eat but not through the roof either.  I paid  $35 for a beer, sharing 2 appetizers, and an entree.
author: Steven H.

description:
This place is SOOOOOOOOOO D-Liscious! I went there with my family to meet up for dinner with a hand-full of other families one Sunday night. Good thing a reservation was made, because it's very tight in there, and get's packed (body-to-body) by 6PM, and it opens at 5PM. The first time, we ordered potato pancakes ("crispy-fried goodness", a descriptive I took from a BFF Shannon, who coined it from her voice teacher down in Alabama, oh wait... maybe it was "juicy-fried goodness"!) which comes with a yummy bowl of apple sauce to spread over the potato cakes.

Then I ordered the wienerschnitzel! Huge portion, but I ate every last morsel. Then we ordered the apple strudel, which was quite close to the strudel I had when I was in Fussen (which was back in the summer of '98, when I was SAF - Single Asian Female, backpacking around Europe before the Euro came along...). 

Friday we took my father-in-law, who was in SF for a conference, and we tried some new things... He ordered the skirt steak (WHOA, as Joey from Full House would say), and it was like butter. SO ordered the Bratwurst, and it also melted in your mouth and the sourkraut melted as well... And since my daughter loves chicken nuggets, I ordered the wienerschnitzel again. We had little tastes of each other's dishes.

I can't wait to have another excuse to go back to the city to eat there! Oh ya, go there right at 5PM on a weekday. Seriously, or you will be waiting forever for a table... and it gets loud in there. 

For those of you who have kiddos, there is a little park, just up the hill on the same block/same side of street. I think it's a community center, but they have an awesome play structure and a little merry-go-round. We got there a little before 5PM, so it was a great little happy accident to have run into, as to waste time and entertain a rambunxious 2.5 year old.
author: Katie T.

description:
I lived right by this restaurant and I have friends who come from out of town just dying to try this place, but I have to inform them that it's not as great as it is made out to be.

I've been here once and the food was decent, the service was decent, and the drinks were decent. But nothing spectacular or that makes the place stand out. 

It is majorly crowded and once I was informed, at 8pm on a Saturday, that they were no longer taking names on the waiting list because they were that booked! You couldn't even walk into the restaurant because it was so packed. (Either it shows that it's a good restaurant, or people just come here because it's a fun place to hang out).

Now when I eat, I know we live in an urban place, but I'd like not to fall over people. I'll probably be back here when someone wants to come here, but it's definitely not one of the Hayes haunts I'm a regular at.
author: Radha S.

description:
Seriously one of my favorite locations to dine in San Francisco.

I love everything about the place. From their fabulous, hunger satisfying dinners and thirst quenching beers (ask about "das boot" --- a two liter glass of beer shaped like a boot, and filled with your choice of delicious beer. It can be shared but you can also go solo, like me *brushes shoulder off*) to the warm, festive decorations and gorgeous staff --- this is not the place for calorie counters and the image conscious. This is a place to EAT and be MERRY. 

They don't take reservations for parties under 6 people. So grab a buddy of two (cab/walk over there) put you name on the waitlist (there ALWAYS is one) with the server, and belly up to the bar for the first (of hopefully many,) beers of the night. And you can totally ask the bartender for samples until you discover your favorite.

Oh, and try and sit in the front room. It gets kind of loud, but after a good meal and a few drinks, the tea-candle lit tables and restaurant hustle-and-bustle generate a truly enjoyable and relaxed evening.

Enjoy.
author: Reza A.

description:
This place is awesome, can't believe it took me this long to find it.

We went on a Friday night and this whole place just had this warm, slightly debaucherous holiday party vibe that was really comforting.  We had a large enough group that we took a whole table so we didn't get the eating with strangers experience but we were pretty packed in.

Yes it took us an hour and a half to get a table, and yes as we were sipping beers at the tiny little bar in the center we managed to be in everyone's way that passed, but somehow that all didn't matter.

It was my first time having German food and I went pretty conservative with my dish, but what I did have was really tasty. The beer was really what left me with the most lasting impression though.  I tried several different kinds and all of them had these unique tastes.

I'm not sure I can toss out too much more advice than the previous 575 or so yelpers have, but one thing I didn't notice until after we'd already parked is that they have a valet for a mere $7.  We must have driven around the hayes valley area for 20 mins looking for a spot, and we weren't at all interested in the $20 lot.  We ended up parking way over by city hall.  But right there by the restaurant was this nice $7 valet - make sure to take advantage of it.
author: Raven B.

description:
*Disclaimer: I don't eat pork.*

That said, there are a few things on the menu that I can eat, but none of them are really any good.  Maybe I'm just not a fan of German food but I personally feel like most people like this place either because they love pork in any form or because they enjoy mispronouncing the name.   

If I go to Suppenkuche again it will strictly be for the upbeat vibe, the delicious beer, and the free Nutella.
author: seema s.

description:
Wow, 196 reviews and counting - popular spot..  My complaint, if I had one, is that it is too crowded - but it's hard to complain that the place is successful.

I've had some delicious brunches here.  The food is great, the portions are generous, and the atmosphere is relaxed and friendly - if crowded and sometimes a bit loud.
author: Rose Q.

description:
You and me are like two ants on a schnitzel.

I cannot pronounce the name but I will lick their plates clean. One weeknight, I think Tuesday, after a long-ass training session and 3 pints did my amigo and I walk into this F'n cool spot. I was so dang hungry that when Dave suggested German food I pretended like it was exactly what I was thinking. "Great idea man, perfect...just what I was going to say, man no wonder we are such good friends, you and me are like two ants on a schnitzel"

I figured that the beer would rock, but I did not know what to expect from the food. I love ethnic foods (yes, Germans are an ethnic group); I'll go out of my way to try different types of cuisine but German food?...come on now...WW2 or Dachshunds have nothing to do with it. To be fair, the only things I know about Germany come from the history channel and the title of U2's seventh album, Achtung Baby!

So we walk into what feels like some ones home. It was a cold evening so the warm room, the long tables, benches and giant wreath made me feel like Christmas....not sure why, but it sure felt good. 
The fact that you have to share tables with people you don't know is part of why I like this place so much. On the surface it seems like a minor event, but interacting with strangers makes people uncomfortable. When you choose to put yourself in this cituation your attitude changes. You act differently and you start to enjoy the contact, you become one with nature and eventually stop killing ants....

Meatloaf and mashed potatoes. Get some. My piece of loaf had nearly and entire hard-boiled egg in the center! One of the best dinners I have ever had. No shit. This food was awesome. I have no real experience with German food but my guess is that this is very close to traditional. Also, the server was cool and polite. 

I have one of their business cards in my wallet so I can find Suppenkuche during my next trip into SF. I highly recommend this place, Achtung Baby!
author: Crow M.

description:
Food: Meh
Beers: Alright - extra star for the "boot."

Ridiculously loud and crowded.  Which is fine, if you're at a bar, not trying to eat dinner with a good friend.

I'll go back, but only if I don't want to talk to anyone, and eat just-ok food.
author: Mollie T.

description:
A great vibe with the long tables, beer, plates of steaming food and the omigod-i-ate-so-much-i-can't-move-for-an-hour  clients lingering over their candle stubbs.  One of my favorite places in the City and where German food isn't synonymous with grease and bratwurst (not that there's anything wrong with that).  

One of my favorite places.
author: Asia N.

description:
We took my sister here when she came to the city for a visit.

This place is so good and a lot of fun as well.  There is something authentic in the air of this place.  Although not a beer drinker myself there were many people enjoying the largest amounts of beer I have ever seen served in one container at a time.

Staff was great and the Wiener Schnitzel was awesome.  Yes I had the Wiener Schnitzel.
author: Stacy Y.

description:
Finally came for food, and it's exactly what I expected: decent German food which is not really my favorite cuisine. Came with my Swiss friend and he approved the authenticity-exactly his grandmother would have made it.

Fried Camembert with cranberry sauce and parsley: it came COLD. Apparently have been sitting there for a while. I was so disappointed because it was a cold night and I was expecting something hot and cheesy and gooey that would burn my mouth, but nope, they were cold. And because they were cold, they were extremely greasy and tasteless. We sent it back, came back a lot warmer, and a lot better. We regretted not sending it back after the first bite. With fried parsley....it's really just too greasy overall.

Braised beef with cranberry sauce, red cabbage and spatzler: Beef was very dry and tough, liked the cranberry sauce, LOVED the red cabbage, and spatzler was good. I should have just ordered a side of red cabbage.

Probably would not come back for food, I don't really drink beer, so...I'll only come back if I HAVE TO hang out with my friends here since they love the beer here.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
I heart this restaurant! Every now and then, I get a craving for some good ol' German food, and this always hits the spot. The spaetzle is especially off the hook! They have an extensive beer menu, and someday, perhaps I'll be enterprising enough to order the boot of beer. The portions here are very generous, so you could consider splitting an entree with a buddy. 

This place is uber popular, so be prepared to wait for over an hour during PDT (prime dining time). Also, on a crowded night, it's quite loud inside, so not the place for some sparkling romantic dinner conversation. If you go at a more random time, like 9:30 on a Monday, you can snag a seat with no problem. Now that I started writing this review, I'm totally jonesing for some Suppenkuche now!
author: Rachel G.

description:
I'm not sure what I was thinking coming here on a Friday night. This place is LOUD and packed! Since they don't accept reservations for less than 6 people, my group of four waited an hour to get seated at one of their communal tables. We waited outside because the volume in the Suppenkuche was deafening. Once the hostess called us it was a challenge getting to our table. The entrance into Suppenkuche was blocked by 2 tables filled with people eating dinner. I felt bad squeezing through and shoving my ass in their faces but it ain't my fault the restaurant had it set up like that. We were lead to a table smack dab in the middle in the front room of the restaurant right next to the bar full of beer boot drinkers. 

Our server got to us pretty quick for our drink order. I asked her for a beer recommendation. I needed it to help tolerate the noise. Her pick was great and I'm not even a beer drinker. 

We ordered 4 different appetizers. Our servers was like....uh, you do realize the entrees are huge right? We didn't care...we were starving! We got the German ravioli, pickled herring, potato pancakes w/ apple sauce, and the bread dumpling w/ mushroom sauce. I had everything but the pickled herring. The ravioli wasn't anything special. It sat in a pool of mushroom sauce which was tasty, but it's an appetizer I could skip to make room for the absolutely delicious potato pancakes and the bread dumpling drowning in mushroom sauce. Talk about comfort food. 

I ordered a roast dumpling filled chicken with potato pancakes because the guy sitting next to me had it and it looked incredibly good. It was probably the best roast chicken I've ever ordered. I normally never order chicken because a lot of restaurants overcook it and comes out a dry mess. Not at Suppenkuche. Moist moist moist! I barely ate half of my entree and took the left overs home. 

Overall a good time, good service, and great food. I would've given it 5 stars if I didn't lose my hearing.
author: Jean L.

description: Best schnitzel in town. Get a group of 8 together, call a week in advance, and reserve a table in the backroom. Order a few boots, gobs of good German food, and you're set for a great night with friends!!
author: Neal P.

description:
German food is a little like British food in that, unlike most European food, it is heavy, greasy, unhealthy, and simple.  This is probably why it is wonderful.

Suppenkuche is one of the closest versions of a real Germany eatery I have seen in the US.  The interior is sparsely decorated, as it should be, tables are unvarnished wood of the long picnic variety and many of the tables just have long benches for seats, no chairs.  Various dried flowers hang from the ceiling and beer posters and tin signs dot the walls.  There could be a bit more dark wood on the walls (a small bar alcove in the back has that in spades though), but otherwise, very Deutch.

The food was classic Germanic fair, lots of meats, many of them encased, with various breath freshening side dishes that are heavy on onions.  The beer selection is pretty good, all of German origin of course.  No Bud Light here, just the good stuff from Heffewiezen to Dunkel.  

The service was quick and friendly and the food was simply presented.  My friend and I had the potato pancakes for an appetizer (deep friend with apple sauce) which were very good, crunchy on the outside and mashed potato-like on the inside.  We then split an order of pork sausages and venison sausages with sides of sauerkraut, mashed potatoes, and egg noodles.  The sausages were very good, not too rich but filling, and the sides were well prepared.  The sauerkraut was excellent.

The missing star is lost to the noisiness of the place.  The small, cozy setting creates a warm and folksy atmosphere (so cozy that when you walk in the door, it seems you are walking into a back corner of the restaurant, not the entrance), but also make for a loud dining experience.

Certainly a great place to come with a bunch of friend though.  Saddle up to a pair of benches, order yourselves some boots of beer and sausage and dream about life back in the Fatherland in the Alps.
author: Eric M.

description:
They only get four stars because it's freaking hard to get a table! You have to call ahead (weeks in advance).  It's only a family style restaurant not some 5 star place.  We waited an hour and a half to get a table and stood at the bar..not sat! 

HOWEVER!  Amazing beer!!! Boots full of Beer!  So much beer and yummy! THe food is AWESOME!  Totally authentic and to die for!  I def. would come back.  I hate the wait but i did have great time talking to people also waiting for a table.  I went with my bf and big group!  We had a lot of fun!  It's really a fun place to go to with a bunch of friends!
author: Lexie S.

description:
Ich liebe Suppenkuche!

The warmly lit soup kitchen features long wooden tables to share beer, schnitzel, sausage and conversation with other happy folks in leiderhosen. Waiting at the bar is fun albeit cramped - kinda feels like drinking at your rich friend's bar in the basement. 

Feeling too sober? Order a 5 liter stein (glass bucket) of German wheat beer such as Fransichkaner - then move to your table and use it to wash down cheesy schnitzel (german mac'n cheese) or the best pork bratwurst you've had outside of Wisconsin. 

Everything is straightforward and delicious from the rye bread with herbed butter to heaping sides of red cabbage. 

Also swing by for Oktoberfest's special seasonal beers. One of the best places to eat in Hayes Valley.
author: Brady K.

description:
BEER IN A BOOT!!!  BEER IN A BOOT!!!  Never seen anything like it before in my life--coolness times five.

If you like beer, this is the place to go.  Got a friend who likes to get loud, but you don't want people staring?  Come here.  Feels like eating dinner at a restaurant filled entirely with your friends and family--super cozy.

Food is homey and heavy, the way it should be.  Gimme moh Wiener Schnitzel and Spatzle.  If you're into beers like some people are into wines, you'll love this place!
author: Jennifer H.

description: Really wanted to like the place, but both my boyfriend & I got very upset stomachs after eating brunch here!!  The lady behind the bar was somewhat rude & unaccommodating.  Our server was nice (but slow).  The beers were great.
author: Godot -.

description:
What struck me about SPK wasn't just the food (which was delicious and hearty), but also the atmosphere. it's how I imagine German restaurants to be: throngs of burly people raising oversize steins full of amber beer and bringing down the house with their shouting, ranting and occasional singing. This place is as much a purveyor of drunken good times as it is a restaurant. So if revelry's not your thing, and if you're not into sharing large wooden tables with friendly strangers, then this place probably isn't for you. Check yer tude at the door. Needless to say, not a place for intimate conversation. On the other hand, the noise will fill any awkward silences in your dialogue.

I have to give props to a courteous and efficient wait staff who somehow manage to make order from chaos here. Perhaps no where else does this ring truer than the modest but cozy bar in the main room, where you can down glasses of fresh beer in comfort and merriment while you wait for a table (which could take quite a while on a Thurs-Sun).

As far as beers go, I recommend WELTENBURGER for something dark and the Franziskaner or Kolsch for something light. 

Dinner, you say? Definitely start with a plate of warm, crispy potato pancakes. Follow it with the German-style ravioli with pork and veggies filling and a rich mushroom sauce. 

Dessert? Why do dessert when you can have another beer? Cheers!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Yes on the schnitzel.  Yes on the Ready-Made Mag meets german pub atmosphere. And yes on the boot of beer.

I went there with friends that were visiting from out of town and we had an excellent time sampling the food and beer.  I had never been but I am definitely planning on returning.

While one member of our party thought it gauche and touristy to share the boot, I loved the experience and the beer.  They have an excellent beer selection and you will leave satisfied, if not at least, slightly buzzed.  

I had fun checking out the stenciled wall art and many hand made paper objects hanging from the ceiling (it was a nice distraction from my commitment to the boot).  The staff was also very friendly and exhibited the precision of german engineering in the preparation and delivery of each of our dishes.  It's german pub food but it's GOOD german pub food.  We were all very satisfied and there were even two vegetarians in our group.  

If you can go on off night and a little earlier than usual (say around 7pm), you won't have to wait for a table and you can start practicing your german, spit spot.
author: Corey F.

description:
Coming back from a summer abroad in Europe was no easy feat...thankfully Suppenkuche's cheese spatzel and meatloaf eased me back into the grind.

Suppenkuche is delightfully authentic, offering communal tables replete with napkins and silverwear in steins (just like in German Biergartens). In addition to the aforementioned dishes, my friend and I ordered a pickled vegetable salad to split (it was huge). I washed it all down with a German soda of the berry variety. 

The couple next to us had a gigant pretzel with cheese sauce- I can't wait to get that next time!
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Unpretentious german hofbrau-style. Come and get your grub on and be ready to talk loudly and bang elbows as you squeeze into picnic-style tables with your group of friends.

Das boot! Yes, they serve beer in a various volumes, the largest being the boot. Just don't drop it; they hold your credit card as collateral.

I've had both brunch and dinner here, and all the bartenders and servers have been great. The food is hearty and carby, mmm mmm good. 

The only thing Suppenkuche lacks is space, and it gets quite crowded. An outside beer garden is truly what they need.
author: Sonya Y.

description:
Amazing German food! Reasonable prices, too. Good selection of beers... I can't say enough about this place.

Bratwurst with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes + beer + excellent bread for less than $20. How can you beat that??

I have never been disappointed with Suppenküche.
author: Paul B.

description:
I love german food. I woke up Sunday morning and dragged myself out of bed to get to Suppenkuche before the rush. Arrived just before 10:30am and sat down, enjoyed a delicious cappucino followed by the non-conventional breakfast food, weinersnitzle... anywhere I can get weinersnitzle before noon is my kind of place.

Nursing a hangover, eating the crispy breaded pork, perfect for soaking up all the remnants of the night before... topped with spaetzle.. life could not have been any better.

A little noisy, but a great neighborhood joint with a variety of patrons... a cozy place, out of the rain for good german comfort food.  A+ in my book.
author: Aimee C.

description:
I dreamed I died and went to heaven.

It was a magical place, with glass boots brimming with beer, new friends sharing tables (and giving you their autograph on a soft cloth-like paper napkin because they are your new hero because they drank all that beer from a giant glass boot), warm candlelight, cozy gatherings, and butterflies, trees and wreaths adorning the vault.

I almost asked to have a word with God because I couldn't tell whether the mashed potatoes were from a box, but I'd had too much beer, albeit not from a boot... "and it was good!"  So I decided that when I reviewed this heaven on Yelp to subtract a star from God and his heavenly manager Peter or whoever (I don't know this shit, I'm Buddhist).

Oh, and did I mention I died of drowning in an incredible rich buttery sauce surrounding a raft of tender roasted salmon on a bed of asparagus, which effortlessly disintegrated in my mouth?
author: Melanee N.

description:
One of those wait for HOURS for mediocre brunch places. Here's an excerpt from my blog:

"we went to Suppenkuche. My dish - farmer's omelette - was forgettable. When I order something with bacon, I want to see bacon. If I had my eyes closed, I would not have known that there was bacon in that omelette. It was seriously 99% potato. Whatever. Not somewhere I'd go, wait for more than an hour, and pay more than $10 for a plate of taters with some egg around'em. puke. Mandy's tiger prawn omelette did have around 2 tiger prawns chopped up in minute pieces tho, was tasty, I give you that."
author: DANIEL T.

description: I went here for dinner last week and had the ravioli.  I thought it was done well.  The complimentary bread they serve was good.  I also tried some of the special items that night (veal and truffle sausage, mashed potatoes, and peas).  The peas were excellent!  I also had the lentil soup (also good).
author: Serina K.

description:
I have been here twice and have had 2 outstanding experiences.  I have been to Germany several times and this place is very similar to the beer halls I have dined at.

The food is fantastic!  I recommend the schnitzel and cured pork chops.  The sauerbraten is also good if you prefer something more German.  

They have a great variety of beers and all are excellent.  Wine selection isn't too bad either as my girlfriend really likes their Rieslings.  

The service is attentive and they make sure you are taken care of but also respect your privacy.  Their location is easy to find but parking can be hard to find.  We went there this past St. Valentine's Day and found parking right away.  There is a $7 valet parking available.

There will be a 3rd visit in the future!  Tschuess!!
author: Marvin C.

description:
If you don't like beer or meat, then what the hell are you doing reading this review? =P Just kidding.

My man and I rolled into Suppenkuche randomly one day after some drive-by shopping after work. I had a Lean Pocket for lunch, my stomach was digesting itself, so my mind focused on the most satisfying, homey, comfort food it could find. What better place to get your grub on than at good old fashioned German biergarten? Right on.

I had the house Gewurztraminer (say that 10x fast) and my man had a Weltenburger Helles beer. It was so good ... we promptly ordered another after smearing our mouths clean with our shirt sleeves with a satisfied smile.

Yes, this place gets packed pretty fast, even on a weekday, and the seating is communal. We decided to ditch the tables and sit in the bar area in the back, which has a much better "pub" like, intimate ambiance and yet, has plenty of elbow room. 

The bartender was very attentive, and we got our food within 15 minutes, no joke.

We ordered the potato pancakes with apple sauce. The apple sauce needs to be bottled and sold. You can't have one without the other. Perfectly crisp, just the right spicy sweetness. 

Skip the bread. Don't do it. What a waste of calories.

I got the Grilled Cured Pork Chop with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes and he got the Sausage with the same sides.

The pork chop was great, but it was SO cured, it reminded me of ham. If you want the traditional German fare, get the sausage, which I preferred. Smear it with mustard, eat it mischievously, and threaten not to share.
author: D N.

description: Love this place but don't bother trying to order takeout - there is absolutely no way to reach them by phone
author: Anthony L.

description:
My parents raised me on pickled herring.  Therefore, you must trust everything I say in this review.

The Goulash here is fantastic, slow cooked, with a mild stock, tender beef, and delicious vegetables.  Now, the pickled herring could use a little upgrade to the Polish style with onions, bay leaf, peppercorns, packed into a clear brine and pickled to tender perfection.  

However,  this isn't a Polish cafe, it's German.

The herring is served with a varitable cornucopia of pickled pleasantries including red cabbage, carrots, beets, and apples in sour cream.  Mix and match with the long clean fillet of herring that tops the plate, and you'll find yourself reliving the good ol' days in my Eastern European homeland.  Mom and dad would be proud.

You'll love it here. Go.
author: Bartosz S.

description:
This Wisconsin boy gets very homesick when he eats here -- the food is that authentically German and good.  Their bratwurst are the best the city has to offer, and anyplace with trout, venison, and sauerkraut on the menu has a special place in my heart. 

There is an orange-colored Schneider-Weisse Hefe-Weizenbier on tap that they special order directly from Germany that I've never found anywhere else and is my all-time favorite beer ever!  Heads up:  this place is loud and gets rowdy as the evening wears on. Minus a star for the beer being too expensive (as compared to say, Toronado).
author: Adam Z.

description:
Excellent (German) beer selection? Check!

Incredible brunch on Sundays to cure a hangover? Check!

GIANT PRETZEL? Check!

Food:

Some of my favorites (other than the aforementioned giant pretzel with delicious cheese spread) include the meatloaf with onion gravy, potato pancakes, beer with woodruff syrup in it (tastes like marshmallows, mmmmm).  I haven't met a meal I didn't like there.  Rich, but not heavy; filling, but you'll have leftovers; simply honest food with high quality ingredients.

Service:

Friendly, cute, usually very attentive.  A couple times it was a bit slow, but the atmo is so much fun.  Love the ceiling decorations that change with the seasons!
author: Kat M.

description: Ich freu mich!!!!!  Makes my tummy happy every time :-p twice a month, since I live a short walk away, I LOVE the weinershnitzel w/ spatzle and a side of mushroom gravy.  That's how I like it but not the way you see it on the menu.  The Gravlax (a special) is amazing!  Almost as good as my ex-german-boyfriend's mom used to make.  Butter lettuce salat!  It's very loud and noisy but I don't mind.  However not an intimate date spot.  Ya Vol!!!!
author: emily b.

description:
Suppenkuche you are the king of my heart. 

Situation: Birthday Dinner
1. only three of us were on time. 
2. we apologized a lot of not having are party there.
3. you didn't care/ smiled and said "i don't care"
4. attentive even though it took 20 min for the next guests in our party to arrive.
5. Still apologized for not having the full party yet. 
6. the last remaining three got there and you took our orders and filled our beers and made us full and happy. 
7. You put birthday candles on the birthday cake... i forgot candles. 
8. I later told the birthday girl about that, and now she too is in love with Suppenkuche. 
9. Everyone left full and happy and you now have 8 new fans.
10. Sorry for being their after 8, I know we needed to be out by then. 

Thanks for the magic moments.
author: danny e.

description:
Almost missed this spot because (a) the dim sign is hidden by a huge tree and (b) I passed the smaller dining room first and thought, No way that broom closet is the restaurant.  But my party entered on the corner of Laguna and Hayes into some kind of Dwell Studio / Old World tavern crossbreed and I think it's a good sign if on a random Wednesday evening, a restaurant is packed.  We didn't have to wait long for a table, but spent that wait at the bar indulging in some huge beers.

Pleasant and not overly pushy or rushed service (especially for such a busy place) made for a nice meal; they fulfilled all of our requests without making us feel like an inconvenience.

And the food!  Mushroom soup was simple for the price, but delicious.  Spaetzle was wonderful: smooth, creamy, hint of sweetness from the onions, extremely filling that I had to take more than half of it home.  Friends got roasted half chicken with dumplings and potato pancakes, jagerschnitzel, and meatloaf.  Can't speak for the last two, but the chicken was delicious, especially soaking up gravy.  Potato pancakes are a bit salty on their own, so definitely get their smooth applesauce puree and sour cream to go with.
author: Irene C.

description: Family style German brew hall, noisy, and filled with multiple options for hearty dinners.  I've been several times.  The place is unpretentious, consistent, and fun.
author: Patrick B.

description:
This is a great place to celebrate. 
I really like the fact that you can share tables with strangers and the fact that the place is loud makes it even more german. 
I went there a few times, and really the bock was my favorite beer by far. For the dinner, I highly recommend the Gegrillte Nünberger. 
The little things that made me give them a 4 out of 5 only is that I went there twice and they never had the boot ( they were going to have some more, but never happened). Also, when you order your beer in a special glass, they remind you a few time about the $50 fee if you break it. Tell me once, remind me once but then this is my responsability
Other than that the staff is great, they will advise you on the beer and will let you sample it before ordering, which is nice.
author: Pascal P.

description:
Suppenkuche is always so much fun.  Perfect for a chilly night.  Lots of delicious beer, delicious German food, and always super friendly service.  It's kind of like an amusement park ride, though, in that it might need a few warnings:

1. It is usually super loud and super busy so this isn't a good place to go if you're looking for something quiet and cozy.  It's a great place for large groups, but make sure you make a reservation.

2. There will be obnoxious drunks around you.  If you get easily irritated by this, I would suggest ordering das boot immediately.

3.  You will get soooo full.  Keep that in mind when ordering appetizers.  Your meal will be huge.  But try the potato pancakes anyway!  The food is all really good.

This place is so good and a lot of fun.  I would recommend trying at least once, even if it's just for the experience!
author: Amanda M.

description:
ACH!  A straight up BOOT of beer.

I prefer to drink mine out of a glass slipper, but to each their own.

Food is good too. Very meat and potatoes. (or sausage and spatzle in this case), and very me.
author: Rocky K.

description:
I thought about giving this place 4 stars but i would probably give it 3.5 stars overall. The place itself is pretty cool and the workers are really friendly and cool. The service is nice too and we got our food in no time. I did think we got jipped on our schnitzel. Schnitzelhaus is the same price and you get a lot more. We also ordered those potatoe pancakes which in my opinion were awful. 
What saved this place in my opinion is the beer selection. They have some amazing beers on tap. They are very tasty and you can get a boot. I may come here and try the food again but most likely not since I think it's a bit pricy for what it is. However, I can see the owners charging the prices that they do since the place always has lines and there is not too many authentic German places in San Francisco.
author: Nir B.

description: Awesome omelettes. Brunch and a pilsner. Solid, hearty food. I'm a fan of their service too, great friendly people.
author: Adelle C.

description: What can I add that hasn't already been said?  I give it five plus stars for being a perfect go-to place and an even better brunch spot, then I take the plus away for world's worst acoustics--hard to hear yourself think in this place once there are more than the staff and your companion.  But everything else is such a delight, why quibble with their take on conviviality?  A great restaurant.
author: Steve F.

description:
My husband grew up eating at Schroeder's decades ago, while I readily admit to having no experience w/ German food.

It's a communal table kind of place so just be prepared to chat with tablemates.  

Pickled herring appetizer:  all of the pickled veggies it came with were very good.  The herring was itself very sizable and well done.

Jaegerschnitzel:  hope I got that spelling right.  The meat and sauce were both very good but it was a pretty small serving, and not sized at all like the pictures posted here.  I could not eat the spaetzle after a while because they were soooo heavy handed with the nutmeg.  Is it really supposed to taste like Thanksgiving?  A pinch I can understand, but a pinch in every piece was overwhelming.

Sauerbraten - Soooo disappointing.  This was not what my husband remembered from childhood.  The meat was tough like inadequately cooked brisket and you couldn't "cut it with a fork" and was very very mildly soured. And finally the sauce was super sweet...did they really throw in that many gingersnaps or just unload a ton of sugar into it?
author: L A.

description:
Update:  I go to Suppenkuche whenever it's a cold Friday or just about anytime that the wind's a blowing and my tummy needs some meat.  This is often, too often.

That said, Suppenkuche would have 5 stars EASY regardless of the endless waits if you don't get in there by 6pm, if the ONLY could get some good white wine.

Craig the local Suppenkuch bartender is awesome!  Find him sporting the latest trendoid/hipster/iconic/ironic? T-Shirt and ask him what to drink.  I KNOW the bar focuses on the largest beers available this side of the Atlantic, but there IS good, nay, GREAT wine coming from Germany these days.  Altho Craig hooks me up, they haven't had the awesome Kabinett Weins they had just a year ago and insist on posting on their Yelp linked website.

Take it from a repeat offender, Suppenkuche is the joint just needs some better wines.
~ Ms. Ali
author: A W.

description:
Get the soup! Seriously, this place ain't called "soup kitchen" for nothing. Anyway, even if you don't like whatever vegetable they are currently using in their special soup of the day, get it. It will be fucking amazing. I had asparagus soup last night (normally, I wouldn't dream of touching the stuff) and it was fantastic. Similarly, the broccoli and cauliflower soups have impressed in the past.

Other standouts: the beer (um, natch!), the super dense grainy bread with herbed butter (drool), the potato pancakes (heaven), and the spatzel. Also, the pancakes at brunch are tasty. I usually get the bratwurst, which is fine, but not spectacular. German food in general doesn't really appeal to me, so I'm kinda surprised I like this place so much. 

Suppenkuche is always crowded--I went last night (a Tuesday) at 6:30, which is not exactly prime dining time in SF--and only one table was empty, though the bar was pleasantly empty. 30 mins later, the bar was fairly populated and the restaurant was full. And this is a TUESDAY. I have been here Thurs-Sat evenings as well, and it is just straight up insanity. The bar area is packed to the point of ridiculousness, and they really cram people into the tables as well. Consider yourself warned: it is loud and you WILL be sharing a table if you're not a large group. Still, I've always experienced friendly and attentive service. And there are always a couple of pieces of eye candy on staff.
author: Jasmine F.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in SF. I ordered the Jagerwurst which was a soft tender pork tenderloin served with a green salad and some mashed potatoes. the pork was definitely some of the most tender tasting loin i have ever had. The wide variety of german beers is outstanding and each is definitely worth a try. 

THe table next to us had ordered a boot of beer ( 2 Liters) and it definitely served a couple of people and got them quite drunk. Although I could probably drink a whole boot myself. If you really want to get drunk they have a 5 Liter stein that  will probably get you shit faced.

On another note, Suppenkuche's environment is just like german tavers, biergardens except on a much smaller scale.

Overall, the food was the excellent, service was great, and beer was exceptional. A must try for every German-food-beer lover!
author: Kenneth M.

description:
Loud, cool beer mugs, yummy raspberry flavored beer, long wooden tables with benches on both sides for seating.

Menu was in German and in English.

Food: it was alright, I ordered the trout and expected the fish grilled, but it came out deep fried.  I guess it wasn't the right place to order fish. Maybe I should have gotten some sausages.

We had a big party so I got to try a few other dishes other than my own.

Breaded Sauteed Porkloin: I wasn't craving for anything deep fried that night. Deep fried Pork= not my favorite.

I tried the Potatoe pancake. ONE word: weird. I don't like applesauce with my food, maybe because it reminds me of baby's food.

Also tried the Portobella Mushroom stuffed with Spinach & Feta Cheese. DELICIOUS!! I wish I had gotten this instead.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I come here often for brunch/early breakfast. 

don't get me wrong - I've been there for other meals too, and that was great, but breakfast is just stand-out delicious. they have a lot of great treats; my favorite is Semmelknödel, a bread dumpling, which is served with eggs and sausage.

plus, nothing beats a black cup of coffee followed by a full litre of kölsch with the first meal of the day!
author: vinay d.

description: They have a 5L (five liter) mug called The Cylinder, and they will fill it with beer.  We drank 3, along with a few boots and some auxiliary liters here and there.  Our waitress was very understanding, and is probably using the umbrella that I left behind.
author: steve m.

description:
Despite the wait being over an hour and having them run out of certain foods including bread and the potato pancakes*, Suppenkuche still managed to far exceed my expectations.  

The atmosphere is lively, the food is delicious and entirely nourishing, and the staff was very sweet and helpful (the bartender even managed to find us a basket a bread while we were waiting, after they thought they were all out).  

Suppenkuche was on my list of places to try before I move out of the city and now I feel compelled to go back several times before I'm gone.  

*It was Friday night at 10 pm by the time we were seated, so I'm sure this doesn't happen unless you happen to be dining at the end of an extremely busy night.
author: Katie S.

description:
The wait here on a Friday night was unbelievably long (2 hours) but the delicious food and beer and VERY friendly waitstaff made it all worth it.  Having been to Germany myself, I can say the food is authentic.  Large portions of "homestyle" German food - I had the grilled venison with wind berry sauce, red cabbage, and spaetzle, and it was too much for me to finish so it made a nice doggy bag for the next day.

And the beer!  So many different kinds to try from, and so many glass sizes ... I've never seen the glass boot in the US before, only in Europe.  And they have the giant ceramic steins!

Love this place.  I'm going to go there again sometime mid-week and hopefully the wait for a table won't be so long.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
When visiting a friend who lives in the city, I asked him to bring me somewhere 'unique', so he brings me on down to Suppenkuche.  On a Thursday, this place was absolutely SLAMMED with people crowding inside outside and around the corner.  We put our name in, grabbed 'das boot' bottle-o-beer a piece, and continued to hang out for the next hour in this great place waiting for our table--not a problem as he had given me the heads up there was usually a long wait. 

The seating here is interesting - we were put at the end of a large table with 6 other people we didnt know (who were kinda sloshed), putting me off at first but turned into a great time.  We both had the brats with sauerkraut upon his recommendation, and I swear I have never tasted anything better in my life at that moment in time.  It is absolute perfection, and the best German food I'd ever had.  And great portions, too!

They have a fantastic beer selection.  Though sometimes loud and noisy due to the small restaurant size and copious flowing beer, the general crowd this place attracts seemed pretty cool and fun.  The staff can be a bit slow, but are hard working and patient from what I saw.  

I will be going here again, I hope you go here too, and tell your friends cause this place is a jewel of San Francisco.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
First time I came here in October for a friend's birthday, it was a friday night and crowded. We sat at the bar and tried lots of good oktoberfest beers at bartender's suggestion. That night I had their meatloaf - I still think it's my favorite item on the menu. 

I've been here a few times since and their menu keeps changing with seasonal dishes, so you'll always have something new to try. I'm not too fond with sitting at the table with random people but it doesn't really take away from the experience. I find the best time to come here is right before they open for dinner, that way you won't have to wait for a table to open up!
author: Tatyana K.

description:
Food:  good.  Wait:  bad.  Beer:  fantastic.

I tried the Erdinger Dunkel because it was a hef, which I usually always like (yes, usually always), and I liked saying the name... holy crap it was delicious.  I dream about having another glass of that beer.  Praise baby jesus for good german beer.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
This place is not for those looking for a quiet healthy dinner. Be prepared for a rowdy crowd, a packed, and I mean like the Judah line after outsidelands packed, restaurant, and at least an hour long wait on the weekends. If you happen to make reservations, you're lucky, they fill up a month in advance for the weekends, and if you do get one, they will encourage you to not linger, as they keep the patron rotating from start of service to close. 

But, let me tell you. It's all so worth it. If you can go with a crowd, order Das Boot. It is literally a glass boot full of beer, and it's a real crowd pleaser. 

The food is traditional german food, and everything is rich and heavy and awesome. The sausage dinner with mashed potatoes is great, as is the cheese spaetzle, the wiener shnitzle, and potato pancakes, and on our last visit, the special of the roasted chicken stuffed with potato dumplings. 

I would imagine that some weeknights might be slow, and you'd be able to get in no problem, but part of the fun of this place is the atmosphere, and the large crowd of people all there to eat drink and be merry.
author: Kelly F.

description:
Yes there's always a wait. Yes, if you are semi-veg like me, you may have some trouble amongst a heavily meaty menu. And yes, there's a good chance you may have to share the large wooden benches with other random diners.
BUT the chicken shnitzel is perfect. with a little lemon squirt on it!...mmmmm. Oh, and with a gigantic hef beer. wow.  I want one right now. All together, it's heavenly refreshing. And the butter lettuce salad- so simple, but so fulfilling. even the breads are unique.
Definitely the best eats in Hayes Valley. Just be prepared to wait (while you drink at the bar). And if you're ballsy, get  the beer boot!
author: Nicole L.

description:
Ok, everybody knows this is a popular place.  And everybody knows it's located in a hip neighborhood with some parking problems.  And everybody also knows that German cuisine has not inspired many shows on the Food Network.  Hopefully everybody knows that despite all of the above, this is a fun place to have dinner.  The food itself does not stand out for me, but the entire experience makes it a fun night.  

We went with a big group for a birthday party.  The waitress was very patient with us.  (It was a classic cat herding situation.)  The service was excellent throughout, and she constantly checked on everyone's beers.  Which brings me to the most important aspect of Suppenkuche:  das beer.  The beer here is awesome.  Really awesome.  Credit the owners with bringing over the cream of the hop from Germany.  

The appetizers were a little heavy, but we're talking German food here.  The Germans have never been known for subtlety.  We had the potato pancakes and fried cheese.  Both were excellent.  I went for the trout for my entree.  The portion was a little small, but I was not complaining because that saved room for the delicious beer I nursed through dinner.  The trout comes with some excellent cooked spinach.  The spinach was a little on the salty side, but I enjoyed it anyway.  

The decor is very sparse and utilitarian.  (What a shock.)  Definitely a place for a group outing rather than a date.
author: Chris I.

description:
Suppenkuche ist WUNDERBAR!

if i could, i would eat here once a week... but then i would get really fat chowing down on the delicious german food and drinking their yummy brews! i love the homey atmosphere and loudness as well. always a good time!

fave beer:  salvator doppel bock (if you like really sweet beer)
fave entree:  cured pork chop with kraut and mashed potatoes

you can also get a "boot" of beer... which is 2 liters of beer in a clear glass boot shaped glass. $21 for 2 liters of primo beer is a good deal to me... but it does require a $50 deposit (they hold your credit card) since the heel and toe of the boot are so delicate that drunkards often break them! one day.. i shall conquer the boot... 

just thinking about that place makes me want to go there.... YUMMMMMMMMMMMY
author: Bobbie L.

description:
This review is for the bar only since I didn't eat here: 
I LOVED the late friday night crowd and environment - totally casual, fun, friendly (and yes, loud), attentive bartender(s), and FANTASTIC german beers served up COLD in a large stein. What a fun, little corner spot for socializing over a few brewskies...
author: beth l.

description: How can you not love this place,  feels like home.   Big on meat, Big on beer,  Big on sauce!!  Lots of smiling people!
author: Henritte H.

description:
Where else can you drink beer out of a glass in the shape of a boot? (At least I THINK it was here? I could be losing my mind again, don't worry this happens to me a lot).

Oh, but their Spatzle I will never forget- I think I gained 10 pounds just from that dish and it was WORTH IT.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Just had dinner at the Supp last night and it was awesome!  This is a great little restaurant this is filled with all the goodness that SF has to offer. 

You have to be prepared for the following:

1. Great German Food
2. Large portions
3. lots o bratwurst and spatzle
4. communal sitting 

Yes they seat you with strangers.  I was intimidated at first but after getting comfy in my seat with my boyfriend we shared a lovely meal with two other couples. One of them was an older couple from Wisconsin whohappened to be german and recommended some great dishes. 

I'm no German food expert but the meal we had was tasty, warm and filling.  It was a great way to end a Thursday night.  

Highly recommend this restaurant if you are ever in Hayes Valley!
author: Julie K.

description:
I'm another happy patron of Suppenkuche.  I've been here more than 5 times and every time I feel the same.....stuffed.  Partially due to the .5L of beer I drink before getting seated and during my meal.  

If you have yet to try this place and want to start of with something basic but oh so delicious, start with Wiener Schnitzel or the Jgerschnitzel. The Wiener Schnitzel is breaded where as the Jgerschnitzel is sauteed.  Even though the Wiener Schnitzel doesn't come with sauce, you can ask for mushroom sauce for only $1.50 more.  Also the Trout is highly recommended.

For all of you non meat or seafood eaters, tonight was my first night as a vegetarian going to the restaurant.  I thought I would have been disappointed since I ate the pork dishes many times before, but I was happily surprised with two veggie entrees and soups to choose from.

I chose the Cheese Sptzle and the broccoli soup.  I was going to order the potato soup, but the kind waiter asked if I was vegetarian, which I hesitatingly said yes since it's only been 4 months since I started, and he told me there was bacon so I opted for the broccoli soup.  I would have had to return the potato soup if it had bacon, so I was happy that he warned me ahead of time.  Loved Cheese Spatzle and the soup.  Next time I am going to try Portobella Mushroom, which I am sure will taste yummy.

In regards to the bench seating with strangers, at first I thought it was awkward, but really isn't so bad.  You make small chit chat, if at all, and you get to see what your neighbor has ordered.  I am one of those people who like to see what someone else has ordered because it might persuade me to try something new.

Unfortunately tonight my neighbor didn't order the Portobella Mushroom, but instead chose the Wiener Schnitzel and she ate it with a smile.

4 stars out of 5 because of the wait if the restaurant is already packed.  Since you wait at the bar drinking beer the time goes by quickly.
author: Michelle S.

description: Eh....I don't see the big deal about this place.  We were told the wait was 45 minutes, but like idiots we waited for 2 hours.  The food and beer were okay, but I have better things to do than yell at my friends (the restaurant is LOUD) while trying to wait for a table. To soften the wait, go across the street to Cafe Altano and have a cold one. They have nice outside tables and you can hear your name being called from across the street.
author: Nita K.

description: Quiet place during their first hour of opening, and during one of the damn world series games... so it was wonderful here!  No TV's and screaming idiots at the televisions, just polite conversation about the German beer, food, glassware, etc.  Many options here I have not seen at other craft beer bars, or German places in general.  It was quite a treat.  Bartender was wonderful as well, and was kind enough to share his iphone video of a parade with paraders in electric wheelchairs buzzing by.
author: Albert H.

description:
Last night's dinner at Suppenküche was amazing! The wait was about an hour which was fine because it gave us time to grabs some drinks at a bar down the street. The restaurant was packed and cozy, exactly like the other reviews said. I ordered the Jägerschnitzel in Champignonsoe
mit Spätzle und grünem Salat (Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce
served with Spätzle & Green Salad) and it was delicious! I've never been to a German restaurant before and after going to Suppenküche, the bar has been set. VERY high!
author: Robin M.

description:
According to Babelfish, Suppenküche translates to "Soup Kitchen."  Which is interesting because soup is probably the LAST thing I think of when I think of Suppenküche.  (Though apparently they have a sweet corn soup that's pretty good...)

Things I think about when I think about Suppenküche (with German translations via Babelfish [and apologies to actual German speakers]):

Beer in a Glass Boot (Bier in einer Glasaufladung)
Giant Wooden Tables (Riesige hölzerne Tabellen)
Huge Portions of Delicious Meat (Sehr groe Teile köstliches Fleisch) 
Cheese Spaetzle (Käse Spaetzle) 
Seasonal Ceiling Art (Saisondecken-Kunst)
Delicious Bread with Herb Butter (Köstliches Brot mit Kräuterbutter)
High-Quality Paper Napkins (Hochwertige Papierservietten)
Soup (Suppe) 

Seriously though, the napkins are like cloth but not.  I always steal a few clean ones and bring them home and use them.

The brunch here is good too, with stuff like German pancakes and potato pancakes that you won't find anywhere else.  A great place for big groups becasue of all the big tables.  Seating can be shared so if you go with just two or three you may end up at the same table with some stranger.  But hey, just order a few boots of beer and you'll all be friends in no time!
author: Kevin H.

description:
Good, authentic German food -- and if you're into it, lots of beer (boot style).

Fun service and interesting seating arrangement (sometimes communal if your group isn't large enough).

If you're looking for German food OR just a good/rowdy time -- good place to go!
author: Christina P.

description:
This place is a sausage fest,  literally! Hearty German comfort food combined with great, soft candle lit atmosphere, bench seating and the best in German beers on tap (Herr Mr. Rogers: Can you say Franziskaner? I bet you can. Sure you can. We'll say it together Frrrranziskannner.) Some of the favorites for Die Metro: Potato Pancakes, Veggie Spatzle, Porkloin in mushroom sauce and of course more sausage than you can shake a stick at. But wait there's more....they do brunch. Metro's favorite: A fat ass German raisin pancake served with fruit compote - FREAKIN' YUM! Just a jaunt from the Castro and located in the fashionable Hayes Valley, you can bet that this place is always jumpin'! 

5 Super Duckets for Suppenkuche.
author: Johnny C.

description:
one of my favorite meals 
Beet Salad
+
Spatzle (heaven)
+ 
Framboise

OMG Suppnekuche is great...
author: aynne v.

description:
In the mood for meat, cheese and potatoes? Then there is no place like Suppenkuche!! 

FOOD: I had no idea what spatzle was before I ate here (it's like pasta's german cousin) I had the pork which was seasoned perfectly and the potatoes on the side were sprinkled with herbs and butter- YUM. It played perfectly on my palate. They even have dishes like Wild Boar for the more adventurous. Large portions, lots of options.

BEER: I haven't seen this many options in a long time- the pints are HUGE, but if they aren't big enough for you...you can order a boot of beer (think beerfest-same thing)

WHY NOT FIVE STARS: They only take reservations for parties over six. This creates a ridiculous crowd around the bar- prepare to be bumped into and squeezed into the only available three inches of space.....they turn the tables as quickly as possible, but expect a 45 min-1 hour wait during peak dinner times. 

PARKING: If you have never parked (or attempted) in Hayes Valley, it's probably not the time to start (save yourself the stress) they have valet parking for $7.....consider you will burn three times this amount circling.
author: Beth M.

description: 2 of us went last Sunday around 9 pm and got a whole long table to ourselves which was nice! Had two types of beer - both v.g and also the venison sausages with spaetzle and red cabbage  which was delicious! Rounded up the meal with an apple strudel upon recommendation by waiter and it was just ok!Upon reading yelpers' reviews now, wish I had ordered the potato pancakes w apple sauce instead - oh well!Good excuse for another visit for sure!
author: Renuka V.

description:
Boy, has this place gone downhill.
I came here regularly from the very first month they opened,
many years ago.  It was wonderful in every way. 
Now it's just another deafening, squat and gobble touristy pigsty.
Thank you, Internet.  The ruin of everything.

Favi has lost interest I guess or gotten old--the mojo isn't here.
Just a lot of rude screaming creeps, and dare I say,
the soup, which is it's raison d'etre, is better at Denny's.

Too bad.
author: harmonia b.

description: It was good. Try the bannana juice and beer, AWESOME! The portions are huge, and the potato pankcakes were, ehh, ok.  Service was good not over bearing. Liked the bench seating idea but at one point I had to get up so one lady could scoot down the bench and be freed from entrapment.. Which becomes more difficult with more of the little boots you drink. Would go back and  would reccomend it to a friend.
author: Heather P.

description: Jagerschnitzel in mushroom sauce with a zesty salad!  This is the meal of all german meals. It is simple perfection.  This meal and any variety of beers are a perfect combination.  These guys really  know how to do it right!  You might find a place just like this anywhere in Germany.  It is loud, crowded most times, and just plain awesome. The servers are great, they know their beers and keep the place moving.  Come here for a great beer(s), with really great friends to talk with, and enjoy a bavarian feast!
author: Lori T.

description:
As a vegetarian, I took one for the team and brought a big group of friends here. German food isn't normally my thing, but I was impressed. There are two entree options for veggies and they are both delicious! The food was shockingly filling, but very tasty. 

We called ahead to get a reservation and they told us that they couldn't take our name because they had already booked up for the night. So we arrived an hour earlier than orginaly planned to put our names in and headed a half block down to a really great bar on Hayes called Place Pigalle (comfy couches and excellent beer options there). After an hour or so, our table was ready. The service was excellent. 

Because this place is so jammed, the hostess has a hectic job and she was very helpful and friendly nonetheless. The whole beer in a boot thing just kept me laughing the whole night, and I really appreciate the decor in this place. 

If cleared of all the people, it could pass as a gallery. There are some amazing paper cuts on the ceiling and intricate stencils on the walls. Plus, disco ball art! If you can drown out the chaos and the crowd and focus on the walls and ceiling, the space is so handsome! 

My only complaint was the noise level, so try to get a table in the much quieter back half (back room) of Suppenkuche if you decide to brave all of the hurdles.
author: Stumbalina b.

description:
I ate here a couple of nights ago and the first words that comes to my mind is authenticity. This is probably the most authentic German restaurant I have been to outside of Germany. It is in a really cool little space, and the decor is a minimalist nature them meant to evoke the idea of eating in a beer garten even though you are in a cramped 15 x 15 foot room (it's probably a little bigger than that, although it doesn't feel that way right after work). 

The food was really good. I had an organic wild board sausage with saurkraut (it had bacon in it - not thin crappy bacon but the good, thick kind) spatzels, and a beer. The spatzels were OK, but the board sausage and saurkraut were amazing (I am not sure how they classified the board as organic if it was also wild, but whatever).

The only problem i had was the price. that is kind of unfair to say, since for how good the food was, I didn't pay too much. My problem is that, no matter how good it is, I have a problem paying $30 for a bratwurst sauerkraut and a beer. Especially if i share a table with other people.  That being said, i still reccomend this place - very good.
author: Adam W.

description:
Great place for boozing it up, being served a big plate of meat and having a very VERY loud laugh! 

Other than having to wait a bit to be seated, settling down to a steiner of any one of the fairly large number of VERY good beers, eating a big plate of Hering nach Hausfrauenart mit Schmand, Zwiebeln, Gurken und Kartoffeln, followed by the best Gegrillte Nünberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei you'll ever have is my idea of a great night out!!
author: Ramsey J.

description:
I am not a heavy meat eater.  Neither am I a beer aficionado.  But if I was on death row, I'd easily request the potato soup + beef franks, and a Helles beer as my last meal.

Atmosphere is awesome; I *heart* communal tables.  What better way than to meet your new BFF than over beer, franks, sauerkraut and more beer?

We went at 6:30 on a Sunday night and it was full, loud, and really fun.
author: S G.

description: Lots of people love this place but my friend and I decided that they never have had real German food.  I ordered the sauerbraten and it was simply sliced beef, good beef mind you,  but not even close to sauerbraten.  The meat did not fall apart, it had to be cut with a knife and came with spaetzle not kartoffelkloesse(potato balls) so my heart was broken.  The potato pancakes were ok, the jaeger schnitzel was not to my friend's liking because it was pretty ordinary and the only thing that was perfect was the red cabbage.  I am still pining for a good German meal but almost all of the restaurants are gone now except for Koenigs in Queens.  The staff were very friendly and efficient and the shared tables were not a problem for us although not to everyone's taste.
author: Alice B.

description:
This place is rowdy! Don't come here looking for a quiet, relaxing atmosphere. You're here to drink, eat and be merry.

That being said, the food was delicious. I don't think Gernan food will make my normal food repertoire but it's definitely a welcome divergence from my everyday eats.

All the things I wanted to order were out! No suckling pig special, no short rib special. So I settled on the venison and that was oh so good. The potato noodle things served next to it was delicious (I love potato in all forms) but I'm not a big fan of the red cabbage thingy.

You know the saying "when in Rome...?" Well, when in Suppenkuche you should drink like you're in Suppenkuche - don't order frou frou sparkling wines (though delicious), you order BEER! Lots and lots of beer. I was there for a birthday bash so we ended up splitting a 5L of beer with the birthday boy and maybe 6 others. What out though - drinking that thing takes some skill/strength to keep from dropping the 5L boot or knocking it into your teeth!
author: Karina G.

description:
5 Stars all around...except for the slow valet parking service.

The service at Suppenkuche is lightening fast. We had the squash soup (perfect), the pickled herring (good), the potato pancakes (just ok until we added sour cream - then amazing), the venison tenderloin (very good) and the halibut (great). Our waitress was a rockstar. Everyone who works there was fabulous. 

It was a little different being seated with strangers, but I thought it added to the experience. 

Just go! And make sure you look up while you are eating...cool things are to be found on the ceiling!
author: Megan L.

description:
Definitely not my grandma's cooking, but then again... what is?!

As people say, it has "charm" and you sit with people you don't know. In fact, on a friday night, it practically exudes charm in the form of Hayes-valley-ites that need to be reintroduced to deodorants... but it's ok, the liters of Kostritzer kept coming, so I stopped noticing.

The venison medallions was a solid choice, although they were under seasoned. The spaetzle was the same. The rottkraut (they call it rottkohl) was too sour, and not sweet enough. That could be a regional thing. Rottkraut is supposed to be sweet and sour, perfectly balanced to complement each other. This was sour sour sour.

The jaegerschnitzel was good, (The schnitzel itself was amazingly well executed.) although the sauce lacked depth and seasoning. It did come with a little bibb lettuce salad that was pleasantly tasty.

The meal alone warranted three stars, the pleasant and competent service as well as the great beer in liter mugs bumped up the rating to a 4 star. I'd definitely rank this as the #2 SF German Restaurants. (Granted, I only know of 4, and I've not yet tried the Schnitzelhaus.)

*Veg-heads beware... there are two, count them, two options for entrees for you. German food in the US is not vegetable head friendly, so abandon all hope now, go to herbivore.*
author: Dave M.

description: This place is awesome!  You can't beat a 2 liter boot of delicious beer with some pork sausage, sauerkraut, and mash potatoes.  The food is just incredible!  I've been here a few times and have never been disappointed with the consistent quality and service. Also, the crowded candlelight atmosphere feels really authentic and cozy.  Only problems are it's really loud so all conversations consist of yelling and the wait is always over an hour, but neither detract since this place is so good!
author: Scott L.

description:
100% for Suppenkuche, 100% for Katie the hostess.

We went to Suppenkuche tonight for the third time (used to live in the 'hood), and somehow managed to love it more than we ever had.  It was Erin's birthday (my fiancee), and we casually mentioned it to Katie the hostess when we came in.  

Katie went out of her way to remember it throughout our bar beers (top notch Pilsner and Hefeweizen) and meal.  At the end of the meal when we were too full for dessert, Katie, unprompted, told me on the sly that she'd bring out a slice of cake on the house for Erin's birthday.  Complete with candle and a cohort of boisterous folks at our table who were game to sing, Erin had a terrific birthday.

Reliable for its delicious cured pork, fresh pork sausages, the marinated braised beef, and tasty spatzen (tasty potato-based side dish), Suppenkuche is a great place for people who like to have a good time!

Katie - we loved you tonight!
author: Loren S.

description:
I came out to Suppenkuche for a friend's birthday so I never knew it existed before this. Though I don't drink beer, I hear they have a very good selection including Belgian beer. They even let you try a few sips of what they have on draft. The birthday boy ordered a boot size and it's about 2 liters. The party next to us order at least 5 boots. 

I have traveled to Germany quite a lot for my last job so it felt pretty authentic. Ambiance was pretty loud, like a beer house would be. As for the food, I thought my food was pretty good.  I had the stuffed half-chicken. The prices were pretty expensive... just for a wiener schnitzel entree was about $17. 

Service was really good but they got really busy and needed the table so they kind of told us to leave after being there for 2 hours. 

I thought it was overall a good experience and would visit there again, especially when my German colleagues come visit.
author: Mochi L.

description:
I'm not so into meat, however the beer is authentic - try a Radler if you like sweet things.  
The potato pancakes are thicker than I remember from Germany, but eh, I wasn't in Bavaria, so what do I know?
The salat is tasty, the Spaezle is heart warming, and the servers are kind.  Faboo.
author: Erin F.

description: Really good German food...crazy loud but and fun experience
author: Tony H.

description:
The first time I set foot in this place - I was overwhelmed by the smell. It smells like HOME! Yes, correct. I am born and raised in Munich, so I think I have good judgment on the food....
It is by far the best German food I have gotten around here and yes, it is pretty authentic. I love the cold cuts plate and many of the dishes are good and as heavy as they should be. I just remembered we ordered game one time and that was not the best, but hey at least they offer game! 
The beer selection is just plain awesome! You can order from Koelsch Kranz to Augustiner to Schneider! So BIG PLUS here! 
It's the place I go to when I feel homesick or I want to educate my friends on (southern!) German food and beer.
author: Sonja S.

description: I was not impressed with this establishment at all. Very unorganized, and customer service isn't their best attribute. I'd think twice before eating there again.
author: Brandon S.

description:
By far one of my favorite restaurants in the entire city of SF! The food is amazing; of all the dishes I've tried, I still can't say which is my favorite. Who would have thought pickled herring with an unusual salad could be so good? Plus the beer selection is out of control. 
I definitely recommend you get there early but to be honest, this place is always super busy. Either way, it is definitely worth the wait.
author: Rita P.

description: If I lived in SF I would be here ALL THE TIME.  Amazing German food and beer.  Restaurant is pretty tiny, and the tables are communal.  Only complaint is that is can get quite loud. Pretzels are really good.  I had the jaegerschnitzel, which was amazing.  Just as good as the food I ate while in Germany.
author: Ashlee B.

description: This place made me happy.  Really happy.  And really full.  We were lucky to get a table in the back at the bar.   it was an hour wait, but the bar was open.
