It's a small cozy space, which after a liter or two of good strong beer began to feel real comfortable.  We ordered at the bar and the bartender was awesome, even with so many people waiting to be served.  Service was great, and the sausages and sauerkraut were phenomenal.  The real treat was the three different types of blood sausage with hot mustard.  It was right out of the Hofbräuhaus in Munich.
author: Adam E.

description: Found it by accident, was trying to get into Sushi Zone that was booked out. We got there right before it got busy on Saturday night (and I mean really busy). Liking the idea of more people sitting at the same table. Definitely makes you feel European (which I am) and could really appreciate the beer selection and the food quality.
author: Igor S.

description:
I went here with my family for my 26th birthday! It was a lot of fun! Great beers and great food! Meat, potatoes, and sauerkraut!! They take reservations for groups over 6 people, with seatings at either 6pm or 8pm, other than that it's first come first served.

Bring your appetite! And lots of room for beer!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
There is something oddly exotic about an authentic German restaurant in San Francisco.  Granted, if given the choice to eat, say, Thai food every day for the rest of my life versus German food, I would undoubtedly opt for the former rather than the latter.  Nonetheless, some days nothing sounds better than some good Bratwurst with sauerkraut and a mug of beer.

Okay, so I went with the (quite good) Pinot Noir instead of the stein of beer.  But I did get the Gegrillte (grilled) Bratwurst with sauerkraut, substituting the very tasty spaetzle for potatoes.  I sort of scandalized the waitress asking for some cheese for my spaetzle, but spaetzle are still basically noodles, and cheese on noodles is delicious, so there.  

Seating is family style, which is fine by me (and I could definitely see it leading to raucous good times), although our waitress sat us sort of oddly at a table with other people where one in our party would have to be sitting closer to the other people and shouting across to us.  I was also semi-thwarted in my nerdy desire to speak German with the waiters.

Oh, and the cheese/salami appetizer plate was quite generous with a nice assortment of goodies, particularly the landjaeger-like salami (my FAVORITE).  I know where I'll be come Oktoberfest!
author: Tanya N.

description:
Make reservations.  It is key.  Otherwise, I imagine the wait to be really long.  Not only do they serve great beer, but they also serve great food!  It's a great place for a group, although it could get really cozy.

I fell in love with the potato pancakes and applesauce.  When I think about it, it makes me want more!

I don't eat pork and the organic roasted chicken I had was to die for.  I can't wait for the next opportunity to check it out.  Hopefully it happens sooner, rather than later.
author: Annalynn C.

description:
I speak French. I pimp the French restaurants. Husbandido speaks German, but no, we haven't had the opportunity for him to go all kraztenjammer on any cuisine yet. Poor Schnitzelhaus was closed, so we headed out to Suppenkuche and we weren't disappointed.

We started with the appetizer platter...enough to feed four, but enough to make two quite giddy. The assorted meats, cheese, pickles and bread are seriously enough to get you through a happy hour with friends. I got the chicken schnitzel (bomb for me), and he got the skirt steak. We were SO not disappointed. The plates were huge enough to have leftovers for lunch the next day. 

I liked the communal seating, and when you're sippin' your lager, we're all friends. People here are rather friendly all around, from the staff to your new homies at the other end of the table. The noise can kill your romantic hushie hushie, but it's all good. The good food will keep you from choppin' it up cause you'll be too busy eating. Save room for the Black Forest cake if it's there. It's quite delish!
author: Charlene L.

description:
Authentic German food with just the right amount of high-end flair, like smoked bacon in the sauerkraut.

The only thing that you can really complain about here is having to wait for a table.  And yes, sharing tables is part of the authentic experience, so if that turns you off then don't come here.  Quite frankly it's crowded enough already and I don't want to share a table with your grouchy punk ass anyway.  If you're a hater looking for a traditional quiet romantic dinner then this is also probably not the place, although my fiancee and I (along with several other people we know) think that this place just oozes with romance.

Beer selection is wunderbar.

The schnitzel is great, but not as good as Schnitzelhaus.  The cured pork chop is so damn good that it proves vegetarians are complete idiots.  There are also always at least 3 specials on the menu that sound outstanding and usually are.
author: Doctor L.

description:
OMG, I did not know German food could be this yummy... 'German Food' evokes pigs feet, sausages and sauerkraut.... And truthfully, it is still a lot of meat & sauerkraut here, but it's done really tasty-like.

I had the skirt steak with scalloped potatoes. I have had this impression that skirt steaks have a tendency to be tough (the impression comes from watching Top Chef, however reliable that may be), but this skirt steak was incredibly, incredibly tender. Melt in your mouth good! 

I also had a real kick eating here cause the atmosphere is engaging. The decor is a bit whimsical with paper birds strung on the ceiling & reflecting the mirrors on the wall. The seating is abnormal because you sit around large tables together with other patrons instead of separate tables. This is an interesting way to meet people. I met the owner of Mexico DF here. He told us he was a frequent patron at Suppenkuche and also told a lot of amusing restaurant stories.

I would want to come here again for sure.

*This probably is not a good place to go for groups larger than 6 because of the seating & crowding.
author: Helena S.

description: Pull the curtain aside and you walk into what feels like someone's living room - complete with a full service bar!  I loved my experience at Suppenkuche.  We arrived at 6pm and was told there was a one hour wait for a table.  Luckily, after hovering for about 20min by the bar, we were able to grab some bar seats in the back alcove, which makes for a cozy dining experience.  Craig- one of the bartenders - was absolutely phenomenal. He had excellent recommendations on the beers, and remembered me by name so that he could keep tabs on my party re: when we needed more drinks/food.
author: Tracey H.

description:
Ok, another high rating from me based solely on the booze. But that's why I end up here. I have a German friend who lives in Hayes Valley, so whenever I hang out with him, he always suggests that we grab a beer here before or after whatever else we are doing. According to him, the heffeweissen is just as good as the heffeweissen is Germany. I can't really compare, but the beer sure tastes good. 

I have only had the potato pancakes here, and I really wasn't impressed. We tried having dinner here last week. I called to make a reservation on Tuesday for Friday night, but their 8:00 seating was already full (the only take reservations for 6:00 and 8:00, and only for groups 6+). Since we couldn't make it there by 6:00, we had to pass.
author: Lauren H.

description:
I think this place would be a great place to come with a big party. I came here with my mom for mothers day and we scored the only two top in the restaurant and were pretty happy about it. Although I like the idea of sharing a table with others. 
While we were waiting for our table the very nice bartender helped us in selecting the right beer. All he needed to know was light, medium or dark and he picked the right one. 
I had the jagerscnitzel and it was delicious! 
The interior of the restaurant is plain but it's just fitting. The restaurant was bustling and overall it was a great experience.
author: Erin O.

description: This place serves top notch German food alongside of top notch beer. The beer selection here is awesome. If they have it, make sure you try a Rauchbier ( a smoked malt ale). I had the Gänsebraten (roast goose) and it was out of this friggin' world Ausgezeichnet (excellent)! I will definitely be going here again!
author: P K.

description:
9/2004--I finally made it to this restaurant! YUM! And it's really fun to share a table with strangers if you're in the right mood! Try the Jaeger Schnitzel or the cheesy spaetzle -- decadent goodness. And so many different kinds of beer and beer glasses!

I've been several times since then and the food is always good, but not always great. I do like sitting family style though, and it's always loud and happy.
author: Dana B.

description:
UPDATE: WTF. I just found out they have massive beer boots and I did not partake?  And here I thought the boots were unique to Wisconsin bars!  The boot instantly ups this German hall to 5 stars.

Four and a half stars on balance between my somewhat disappointing sauerbraten and my boyfriend's amazing wild boar sausages.  The potato pancakes were tasty as was the black forest cake.  But really, those wild boar sausages were so tasty I was ready to commandeer that plate.  Plus the mustard/horseradish sauce for the sausages made everything taste better, even my sauerbraten.  I'll definitely be back to try some other stuff on the menu.

One last aside, the russe was excellent.  It's beer with a touch of lemon.  Yum, yum!
author: Helen C.

description:
I've only had a true German meal one other time in my life that I can remember. Suppenkuche has pretty much assured that I will have more. Went last night to have dinner for a group of 6. We had a reservation for 8 and finally got our table at 8:30. Normally this might bother me, but when you're drinking a giant beer it tends to smooth things out.

I'd heard the portions were large, but despite that we ordered 4 appetizers as well as an entree each. And another beer.

I had the organic something or other sausage with red cabbage and mashed potatoes and I ate every bite. The meals are very meat and potatoes in that oh so German way. Very hearty and filling. I had to ride my bike back up the hill to the panhandle and I about went into a meat and beer coma.

Next time I'll drive :)
author: keith h.

description:
Super taps of german beer here!

bartender was on top of it.  she laid out samples of the different beers i've not had before and was really good about describing them.  I wasn't really hungry, but the potato pancakes with apple sauce were really enjoyable.  

i'll be back soon with an appetite and more friends!
author: Daten S.

description:
Great food.

Typically, I'm not a fan of German food, but Suppenkuche does it right.

I highly recommend Suppenkuche.
author: M S.

description:
This german establishment is a raucous party. I started the night at the bar with gargantuan sized beer glasses filled with eclectic german beers . I came here after a long hike and a gurgling stomach to boot- the way to go here. Its a great place to come with a slew of loud friends (no quiet talkers allowed) and order several main dishes to share along with large glasses of beer. The family style seating sets up an open, friendly vibe. Come and pound your beers on the table.

I loved the potato pancakes with a little bowl of tasty applesauce to start- really nice crispy texture just like grandma used to make

I also heartily recommend the braised beef with purple cabbage, the chicken schnitzel (off the daily menu) with fried potatoes, and pork sausage with sauerkraut. Its healthier than it appears to be. 

Ask for the bavarian sweet mustard to go with the sausage. 

The service is as fast as it can be on a crowded friday night. They work hard, roll with sometimes rude drunken requests and deserve a 20 percentish tip.
author: David S.

description:
A place for groups of 4-6 as determined by suppenkuche's table size. Big wooden family/picnic style tables, perfect for a big group meal. Amazing food and beer. I really had a tough time deciding what to order. I will be returning many times to make sure I try it all.  If it's your first visit here, be sure to order something that comes with the Sptzle. It's yummy and they have it as an appetizer with Cheese! which basically turns it into the most amazing mac and cheese, you've ever had.

I ordered;

Jgerschnitzel in Champignonsoe mit Sptzle und grnem Salat $16.50
(Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Sptzle and Green Salad)

It was delicious. I would order it again in a second. Be prepared for big portions. Make sure you are really hungry.  

Besides the food, the beer, beer, beer  is awesome. It's all about size here. You can get beer in a boot!

Make reservations, and be patient. The table arrangement in the front room makes for a bit of an unusual situation for walk-in and meeting here. The table layout has customers walking into the middle of the front room to wait to be addressed by a host. It makes for awkward meeting/waiting place because you are surrounded by groups enjoying their meal. I found it easier to wait outside until our name was called. Or try to sit in the back room if possible.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
One of my new favorites.  

The atmosphere is just so very different from any other restaurant I've been to.  Though I must admit I've never been to a German restaurant before.  Either way, I love the decor, and I love the outfits they have their waiters and waitresses wear.

The food was absolutely stunning.  I had their seasonal fried sole... So good.  And obviously you must get a beer here.  I got one from their dark beers menu and it was fabulous, and came in a fabulous glass.  German beer totally exceeded my already high expectations.

Very casual atmosphere.  Great for group hangouts.

I love Hayes Valley.
author: Diana C.

description:
This place is delish!

Pluses:  
awesome jaegerschnitzel - flavorful, creamy, but not incredibly heavy, great portion size
onion cheese spaetzle - creamy, delicate, mouth-wateringly good
a quality beer selection that makes my hubby very happy

Minuses:
the reason i didn't give it 5 stars - it's incredibly crowded and doesn't accept reservations unless you have a party of 6 or more...then, there are only 2 seatings (6pm and 8pm)

** this place is awesome if you're happy to wait and enjoy the company you arrive with...you can always drink some of their yummy beers while you wait, or dare to get a 5-liter stein! **

** also, order take-out if you live close - they're really quick at preparing your items **
author: Ching-Pei H.

description:
A group of 10 of us went here for dinner on a Friday. We had a reservation for 9pm and stood by the bar for like, i dunno, an hour maybe, checking in periodically with the hostess. That was annoying on principle only, because I didn't mind hangin at the bar, which was packed. The crowd was a good mix of people, mostly groups, and the rustic decor makes you feel like you're really in a little old-timey biergarten (minus the garten). 

Great beer selection and the bartenders were very cool and attentive. You can get beer served in a glass boot and the food is pretty good, traditional German fare - schnitzel, wurst, potatoes, etc.  

Awesome place to bring a big group, but double-check your reservation before you go if you want to decrease your likelihood of waiting (which is the only reason it didn't get 5 stars).
author: Moira M.

description: The food here is really good.  How good you ask? Have you ever been to a place where everyone wants to try everyone's food and everyone AGREES?!  Its that type of place where you want to share the joy that has just touched your tongues both food and drink.  Come here with old friends or people that you feel comfortable yelling at (its ridiculously loud in here) and drinking from their boot.  (come on you have to get a boot and play the boot game.  the second to last person to finish buys the whole dinner. :)
author: Sarah C.

description: yes, it's crowded. but it's a great atmosphere. the potato soup;s unbelievable. and the beer... enough said. the lovely staff doesn't hurt, either.
author: I S.

description: Come here with an empty stomach and an appetite! The portions are hefty and so delicious! German comfort food at it's best. It can get crazy busy starting on Thursday evenings and the place does not take reservations. Expect to wait up to 2 hours if showing up during rush time.
author: Pamela v.

description: This was a nice place to eat. The beer was very good. I enjoyed the pork sausage and the potato pancakes. It took a very long time to seat us but it was Oktoberfest day so there were so many people. Definitely a place to go and have a drink.
author: Larry V.

description:
Gemutlichkeit is a German word without a literal English translation. It means something like "sence of well-being." In the case of Suppenkche it means friends, long tables, good beer, and hearty food.
This is the first place I think of when I miss the Tyrol. That could be because it's the only Bavarian/Tyrolean restaurant I know of. And like restaurant there, if you are a vegan your option is to watch me eat.
If you aren't you won't go home hungry, and you are going to need to eat too, because the beer selection here is great. Order a Radler on a hot day and they actually know what you are talking about.
author: Jason D.

description:
Vegetarian approved.

Doesn't count a "vegetarian restaurant" in most peoples classifications, but you can eat, and eat well at Suppenkuche without biting down on anything with eyes or a mother.

The set of options is small, but tasty and varied enough to please 3 picky vegetarians eating family style.  The soups are excellent, as is the beet salad, and the spatzle is pure indulgence.

Couple with a shandy (they call it something different) and you have a pleasant, light Summer dinner in a cuisine normally off-limits to non-carnivores.
author: kellan e.

description:
As a vegetarian traveling through Germany a few years back I recall I was always either starving or eating potatoes-- the good ol' German cuisine didn't seem to cater to us herbivores!

But not so at Suppenkuche!  Amidst those raving over their pork chops, sausages and meatloaf-- I was wowed (the kind of bites where your eyes shut in delight as you taste it in big ways) with the flavors in their veggie selections.

Huge kuddos to the lentil soup-- $5 for a large, filling and delicious bowl!  Their cheese spatzle is creamy, sweet and perfectly comforting and balanced by the cabbage/beets/carrot salad.  The rye bread and butter is a great variant on the usual.  They had a portabella mushroom on the menu stuffed with spinach and feta that sounded divine except I got full.  But next time!  :)    

I was ignorant to think that the Germans couldn't make my veggie belly happy...  this is a case where I'm glad to be proven wrong!
author: Shasta N.

description: OMG, love this place. Friendly and cool staff, great beer selection and authentic German food. I had the schnitzel with spaetzle and it was sooooo good. Definitely one of the best German restaurants in California....
author: Bjoern R.

description:
Love this place for the ambiance, food, and beer! It hits on all sensory levels.  This place is the spot I try to hit up after exam days at USF or when my buddy is in town. 

Beer
Great selection of beers and the bar tenders are very knowledgeable on beers and will get you what your looking for.  Next time I go, I'm definitely tackling the boot.

Food
I have not tried every item on the daily changing menu, but I love the stuffed roasted chicken with potato pancakes on Saturdays.  The suckling pig is also good. The skin is crispy and the meat is juicy and packed with great flavor.  Pair it with a beer and its just hits another layer of flavor. 

Ambiance
The layout is communal. Your seated with random strangers who will end up striking a conversation with and have a great time with, unless your group is greater than 6. 

Service
The waiters and waitresses are very nice and attentive.  Its always packed and popular food items sometimes run out (like my chicken) so I recommend getting there early.  Doors open at 5pm.
author: Sid E.

description:
My entire life I've eaten bratwursts and frankfurters and my entire adult life I've been drinking Spaten. Turns out that this experience counts for practically nothing towards figuring out what German food is all about. 

For a lesson in German cuisine and beer, go to Suppenkuche. The food was good, yea, but the entire time I was eating my plate (Venison medallions with red cabbage and spatzle) I kept thinking, "Damn this is German!" And then after tasting my buddy's plate (roasted pork with onions and mashed potatoes) I said, "No way THIS is German!" And then after tasting yet another plate, the Cornish Game Hen stuffed with dumplings and with vegetables and potatoes, I knew that yes, that was also German, and this was what German food was. 

Now I have one more cuisine to match to a country on a map, and am a better, healthier, stronger, more intelligent person for it. For that, I thank you Suppenkuche.

Extra information: really fun - shared tables, loud, beer. Slightly pricier than I expected - $19 or so for the high end of the menu, $13 for the low end.
author: Dibital N.

description:
Solid menu (3 stars for food quality) and pretty novel even in SF (1 extra star for being so unique)

We went for brunch  and got there pretty late (1:30 or so).  There wasn't any wait which was nice.  The decor is all light rough hewn wood.  Staff very friendly.  

Overall, I thought the food was solid and authentic to the German food I've had in Germany.    I don't think there's a country in the world that knows how to do more things with flour and potatoes.  

I had the German ravioli scramble which is their standard ravioli cut up and mixed with eggs, roast potatoes, and sausage.    A nice reasonably light combination.  My dining partner had the special emperor's pancake -- baked pancake with berries and sprinkled with powdered sugar.  Both were solid -- textures good, moist, etc.    

I'll definitely go back to try the dinner entrees and the potato pancakes.  The beers were top drawer.
author: Krista G.

description:
Great German lagers, available in HUGE glasses.  

The wait is terrible, but if you can get a spot at the bar, especially on the backside with the padded seating and little table, the wait isn't a big problem.  

It's probably the best German food in town.  That being said, the best German food in town isn't the same sort of accolade as the best French food in town, or the best taqueria in town.

If it's too crowded there, the beer garden at Fritz is a fabulous alternative (great date spot too).
author: Owen C.

description:
You really feel like a lumber jack when you eat the portions of food this place gives to you. It is as authentic as you get. we ate here several times before we actually went to Germany and I have to say they nail their food to a  "T" The beer is off the charts. great place to go with friends. the wait is a little long but worth it, you drink the tasty beer while you wait.   Just a heads up if you don't have a party of 6 or more you can't make reservations. 
cheers
author: erin D.

description:
Minus 1 point for the bathroom situation. After 2 steins and playing the Boot game everything is a big blur, but I do remember the delicious taste of German beer I recomment Spaten.
Craig the bartender knows his shit about the different types of beer, he taught me and my boys the boot game, cuz @ 1st I thought the game was just like the movie "BeerFest" where u pound the boot as fast as u can...I'm so glad Craig was there.
author: Angelisimo G.

description:
Just came back. Below my summary of this restaurant:

1-food: wonderful but a bit too salty for my taste. Remember to order some German beers to go with that.

2-Crowd: It's Wednesday but wth...ppl DO NOT cook dinner at home, they eat here...we arrived and were seated immediately at this one corner, cramped with a couple of folks/strangers...felt a little bit like canteen/cantina

3-drinks: ordered a non-alcoholic bitburger drive, it's kinda cool..it's not friday, friday is official booze day 

4-Service: had no problem at all with our server, he's nice, i think German, but they told us to get out by 8.20pm ( we were there @ 7.20), so we had everything in one hour..apparently someone reserved the table or something...we're totally cool with that because we didn't want to wait any longer..

5-Price: hey, $16 for pork chop!!!! delicious....good price...they got some specials going on, also ordered lamb chops, good stuff.,....i'll give the lamb chops 5 stars!

Overall, 4 stars for my dining experience!

Here you go...suppenkuche!
author: Amy Y.

description:
I've been here on both crowded and quiet nights, and despite the contrast in vibes the results are still always good.

The food is great.  The beer options are never-ending. 

The names are a little crazy and fun to (try and) pronounce in your head.  But when it comes to actual ordering time I always chicken out and just say "porkloin please" instead of butchering "Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und grünem Salat."

I wonder if they substitute sides - I like their red cabbage and spatzle combo more than anything else.
author: Andrew P.

description:
First of all, I'm German, I know my food and I cook it a lot. So if I go eat at a German restaurant I expect their food to be better than mine. My family took me there for my birthday since they knew I wanted to try it. We had reservations, didn't have to wait long. The ambience is great, friendly waitstaff, great beer selection. First we ordered the Split Pea Soup, it had incredible flavor but the peas were sligtly undercooked, a little on the crunchy side. The split pea soup I'm used to is green, here it was more of a clear broth. Could be that the cook is from a different area in Germany and that's how it's done there. Ok, on to the venison with red cabbage and Spätzle. Venison had little flavor, no gamey taste, my husband was wondering if it even was venison. I had a few bites of the red cabbage, it was too sour for my taste and I kept biting on those darn Juniper berries! After 3 of them I stopped eating the cabbage. Now the Spätzle were absolutely incredible! Sligtly pan fried, delicious!! 
Not sure if I would go back. Too far from the Peninsula and parking is a hassle.
author: Sabine S.

description: Food & beer just great!  It's so crowded & loud though.  Love sharing tables like they do in Europe.
author: Donna W.

description:
A snooty host dropped a star from the otherwise four-star experience.

This is german beer garden action in a chic environment, kinda sorta. The food is quite tasty, consisting of all your monochromatic German treats -- schnitzel, kraut, potatoes, etc.  Went with the ladyfriend, and we both enjoyed ourselves, had  a great waiter, had some fantastic beers. As many have pointed out, this is communal eating, with large picnic tables, so it's almost awkward for a couple. Next time I will arrive with a gaggle of drunkards.  

They have gigantic beers, so what's not to love?  Oh yeah, that host. A total weasel, with a superior attitude. Seems like a German restaurant with piles of meat and beers that encourage beligerance is not really his scene. May he drown in kraut.
author: MeatMaster X.

description:
Delicious.  If you like German food, this is the spot.  

LOVE the ambiance.  Minimal decor.  Friendly server and staff.

At first I thought that sitting with other people at the family style tables would be annoying, but it was actually very comfortable.  

It is noisy, but that's part of the charm.  

I knocked off a star, because the busboy used his fingers to move my food into the to go box.   Don't get me wrong, I'll still eat it, but  I would have preferred he use a fork or something.
author: Erinn B.

description:
Mmmmm....Schnitzel.

Suppenkuche is an oasis of butter and liverwurst and lard in a desert of trendy salad and small plate pretension.

The food was fresh, the beer cool (but not cold) just the way it should be!

This is the joint where I fell in love with the gooey, deliciousness of bienenstich cake.

Little hard to find, and I suggest taking public transport as parking is nigh impossible to find.

Oh and if you're not down for making new friends, this might not be the place for you.  The German-style bench seating means you'll be bending elbows with someone you just met.  The S.O. and I had a great time chatting with some folks from the Netherlands.
author: Michael M.

description:
Dining here is more like an adventure than a night out for casual dinner. The atmosphere is straight-up Oktoberfest, family-style dining which is always a crapshoot who you end up eating with. Usually it is a good thing and a good way to meet new people from the area or tourists. Really, don't come here if you are feeling anti-social! 

Waits can be ridiculous lengths, but the food is good and the beer it is a-flowin by the stein.
author: Nick V.

description:
This is some of the best German food I've ever had, inside or outside of the Fatherland.

Large portions, and large beers (sold by the .5 liter, as God intended) including my favorite Austrian beer, Stiegl.

The place is super, super loud, so this probably isn't the place to take a first date, unless your potential lover has nothing interesting to say, in which case, this would be the absolutely perfect spot.
author: Adam B.

description:
Let me lay out what our Saturday night looked like at Suppenkuche. 
5:30 p.m. arrive and put our names on the list- a group of ten. 
6:40 p.m. check back after having some beers down the street and we were told we were next on the list. 
7:30 p.m. checked back again- after waiting outside- and again were told that we were next on the list. 
8:00 p.m. we all decided that maybe we should move inside and crowd the bar, after all, we were getting pretty thirsty. 
8:40 p.m. seated. 
Yes, we waited over three hours for a table- but we did have a group of ten so I can understand how hard it is to accommodate a group that large. 
Once we were sat it was awesome- boots of beer brats, venison, delicious bread, tons of laughs. Mind you- by the time we sat down who knows how many beers we had all consumed- and the boots, well, you can't NOT have a boot after waiting over three hours!! 
You do have to put a deposit down to get a boot of beer (which is smart on their part) but its totally worth doing, just don't break the boot. 
Our server was friendly and fast and we all left happy and full. 
I will be coming back to Suppenkuche at some point- but not with a group of ten on a Saturday night...
author: Janell D.

description:
I came with a large group of little Asian girls to give J2 a grand sendoff before her long trip overseas. I enjoyed the food, but wasn't really impressed (although T and I had quite a long and snicker-filled conversation about how the spatzle looked exactly like sperm. That was impressive). The beer on the other hand, was quite delicious. The two men at the table next to ours shared the huge 5L glass, and at least 4 more rounds of boots and other large containers of various beers.

Overall, Suppenkuche seems a little overpriced, and definitely boys-club-ish.
author: Susanna W.

description:
Food and service was so-so, beer selection and quality was great.

We started off by ordering the potato pancakes with apple sauce.  This dish was probably the best dish we had, although it was overcooked -- we're used to crispy on the outside soft and warm on the inside, not crispy through-and-through.  Nothing a little apple sauce couldn't fix, however.  Then we moved on to venison with red wine sauce and spatzle, and bratwurst with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes.  Nothing remarkable about these dishes, and we felt a bit stupid forking over $13.50 for bratwurst and mashed potatoes.  Ironically, the bratwurst was better than the venison.  The venison was a bit tough and gamey, but I suppose that's expected with venison.  The beer was definitely the highlight.
author: JoKr M.

description:
The drunken douchebags are the only things knocking this place from five to four stars. 

I dream of wild boar and marzen on a normal occasion because of this awesome German joint.
author: Susanna D.

description:
So the only reason I'm giving this place 3 stars is 100% because of the hostess. To me I usually ignore the service aspect of a restaurant cause I'm going there for the food, not the wait staff, so I over look a lot of things that most would have issues with. However, this experience pushed me to my limit.  This place would have gotten a 5 star rating from me otherwise.

The food was awesome, our waiter was great, and in general we were having a blast. HOWEVER- while we were literally in the process of signing out check (literally some of our party were even putting on coats, etc), the hostess approached our table and very rudely told us that we must vacate our table immediately since the party behind us had arrived and this table was now their's. I was shocked. Now, I sympathize for every waiting table, as we have all had that annoying group that just won't finish and lags at the table. BUT I have never had someone from the restaurant come and rudely tell us to leave like that before - nor have I ever witnessed this before (even when I was the one waiting for a table for over an hour). It was not as if we were dawdling, we had just received our check and were passing pens around to sign the check. On our way out, I apologized to the people who were waiting for our table since the hostess made it seem like we had made them wait a ridiculous amount of time. The person looked at me and was obviously confused and said that there reservation for was at that moment (we had not held them up at all- the hostess kicked us from the table the second the entire party arrived). Needless to say this is when I got offended. 

This event happened a few months ago, and self admittedly I'm still bitter over it. I thought I would eventually get over it, but I have found myself twice now chose to go to a different restaurant when this place is suggested, which is unfortunate because the food was good. However, in this city with great food literally on every corner it's hard to go back and support places like this, especially after being treated so poorly after spending a large amount of money (there were 9 of us at dinner).
author: Lacy T.

description: beer and wild boar sausage.... sooooooo good its redonkulous!!
author: Jason P.

description: I love Suppenkuche! The food is amazing, the beer selection is great, and the different sizes of beer makes this place a really fun dinner spot. A few years ago for my birthday I drank das boot of Radler (German beer and Lemon soda) (oh so good!). The potatoes, sauerkraut, and Wiener schnitzel is  AMAZING!!! the portions are worth the price and the communal seating just adds to the Bavarian feel of the restaurant.
author: Bridgett H.

description:
The employees here are really friendly and patient. I had the meatloaf with eggs and potatoes. The meatloaf was ok. I think the eggs helped a lot. And the potatoes are outstanding!

My bf had the sausage with tomato sauce and french fries. Pretty good as well.

I asked the waitress if she recommended any beer and she brought me the ayinger heffenweizen and it was amazing! 

The wait can be long because this place is super popular, but I think the wait is worth the opportunity to experience German food!
author: Hue M.

description: Absolutely awesome. Had the half chicken, was super tasty, crispy skin. We'd forgotten it was the start of Oktoberfest, and it was madcap in there. Tons of fun, everyone being social, drinking a mass instead of the usual pint, brilliant!
author: Jeff B.

description:
Patience is a virtue.  It really is.

It takes patience (and a working knowledge of drinking establishments in Hayes Valley) to endure the wait outside Suppenkuche.  With a little luck, the horribly long wait the hostess said you would endure may be cut short from no-shows for reservations, there is always that hope.

For those with the patience to endure such a wait, you will be rewarded with some of the best German food that this writer has ever tasted.  

This place is a little bit pricey, but I wouldn't mind coming here to sample more of their menu on a somewhat regular basis.

One of the things that really wowed me that the servers had great German diction when it came to the names of the dishes.  It made me wonder that if my German was better if I could have carried a conversation with my server auf Deutch.

The good beers served in "Das Boot" makes a good place even better, but if you attempt to finish Das Boot by yourself, prepare to be totally blasted upon leaving this establishment..
author: Kenny L.

description:
Suppenkuche is awesome. An ex GF years ago convinced me to go here, and its one of my fondest memories of her (well besides one I won't be a cad and review here.)

My reaction when she proposed it was the same I have gotten repeatedly when I have told employees, friends I am taking them their....German food? *nose wrinkles*....I am not one that thinks the Germans are culinary geniuses, and while I have eaten at other German places mostly around the NorthWest (sorry no trips yet) I have never found a place that rivals Suppenkuche...although they were easier to spell.

I went again recently, and since I am still bribing/sleeping my way to Elite guess I'll keep writing.

Couple of things about this place.....

12 stars out of 5: the beer selection. Many beer iliterates have no idea how many great beers, and variety come from Germany. I kinda stumbled onto them by accident over the years, being a Belgian-phile. But I digress....(yes thats rare, I know.) And the various shapes and appropriate glasses to go with it. Uberdom.

Food is very good, for German I think its off the charts, it holds its own in any genre.

Service: very good and friendly, despite it always being busy. Make sure you feel social, as its a bit loud, and you may have to share your table, community style with a few other people. I especially love it when big social mismatches get the same table, makes for big amusement. Unless you do it to me. I keep hoping for a pair of lipstick lesbians to be enamoured with each other...until then....

Hayes Valley used to be my stomping ground, and this place is a mainstay. Skip it at your peril.

Viva La Suppenkuche. er....drink beer and expose yourself!
author: William A.

description:
Easily 5 stars, for many reasons!  I loved the seating; wooden picnic tables that seat about 10 so you get a chance to make some new friends.  It reminds me a lot of a few of the quaint restaurants I visited in München and Salzburg, though it can get loud (which is ok  by me).

As far as the menu, it was an extremely difficult choice.  I went with the Bratwurst with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes.  This was on the brunch/lunch menu, so it was around $9.  Absolutely delicious!  Since we  each ordered something different, I had a chance to try the Jägerschnitzel and Currywurst as well and would highly recommend them both.  I believe the Currywurst is actually a new item to the menu, and was surprisingly good, though not exactly like what you might find in Berlin.

And then there is the beer!  I had to go with the 1L for this trip.  Its actually funny, they have from 1L to 5L sized beers; what the 5L looks like, I can't even imagine.  About half the beer there is what you would find at Oktoberfest; Spaten, Paulaner, etc.  I went with a Franzikaner hefe weizen that was perfect  with the food.  

This is a great place to sit down for an hour (or 2) and enjoy an authentic German meal.  I can't wait to come back!
author: Chris R.

description:
PROST! Make sure you bring a hefty appetite for a casual, authentic German Grub Haus dining experience. The place is cozy and just like a little indoor version of a bier garten I went to in Berlin last summer. Complete with big wooden tables and a giant 5 liter boot to drink all the Hefeweizen till your head explodes!

What to order:
Shrimp appetizer
Meatloaf (with a hardboiled egg surprise in the center!)

What to drink:
Hefeweizen (no lemon though, lemons are for American amateurs)
For the more refined drinker...a glass of Reisling or Gewurztraminer (after all the best is from the O.G. Germany)
author: Kristina L.

description:
The wait is bad (though you can nurse your discomfort with tasty beer) and the place is super-cramped. 

That said, it's a LOT of fun with a group. And I've enjoyed the porkloin with mushrooms and spatzle both times I've been there. Food is rich and heavy and not gourmet, but good and a great way to pad your stomach for a night of drinking!
author: Emily M.

description: This was my first time ever going to a German restaurant and I must say the food and the beer will definitely get you full. The restaurant is located on a corner area and parking isn't too bad to find for those commuting. I've previously made a reservation (which I suggest you should, if you plan on having a party of 4 or more) but was late due to SF traffic. Fortunately when my buddies and I arrived the hostess understood our situation and was able to grab us some seats right away. My first impression was wow! This placed is totally packed for a Thursday night. It has a nice German ambiance but at the same time felt like I was in a very small restaurant having to squeeze my way into my seat because the place is literally cramped for space. We had to share a table with another group of 3! The furniture in the restaurant is definitely on the underside which looked like they bought them from Ikea but what made up for it was their beer and food. I ordered the the cured pork chop with mash potatoes and sauerkraut and a couple of the fine beers They really have a great selection of german beers and I think is the highlight of the restaurant. The pork chop was very tasteful but honestly looked like cured ham that was grilled more than anything but it did satisfy me and it lived up to my expectations. My friends order the meatloaf with bacon and eggs, the schnitzel, and the sausages platter. They too all thought it was good. We also ordered appetizers such as their pretzels which I think we're awesome and a sampler filled with sliced meats and cheese. Having never eaten german food before it definitely was a good experience. Although I didn't get to try the das boot it definitely looks like you would need to share it with another person as that thing is humongous! I wouldn't mind coming back here again but unfortunately german food isn't really my type but I'm sure this a good place to go if it is your first time or if you are a big fan.
author: Alvin T.

description:
I have not really had too much experience with German food but suppenküche that I know of was really really really good. It all started out about a month ago when my housemate returned home with one of the most delicious porkchops I have ever had. The german way of cooking a porkchop is pretty damn good. It did not matter if it was cold or right off the grill it was THAT good.

So last week we decided to make a trip up to the city and try it first hand.  We ended up arriving late no thanks to my housemates that decided to fall asleep.  It id not matter we still made it up there although it was almost 9 by time we did arrive. The place was packed and I mean packed. We entered through the curtain that hides the look of the crowd so as not to know how crowded the place really is. I enter to see a man on my left drinking from a 60oz Das Boot made famous in the movie Beer Fest.  I realy want to come back and challange my friends to a Das Boot drinking content just for kicks. 

We checked with the hostess who was being asked every few minutes as to a place to sit and eat it was packed, so packed that she was not even taking names for another 20 minutes. NOt just to get a seat but would not even take our names due to the overwhelming response of people that were at suppenküche that night.  I was not offended at all i was actually even more excited this place must be good I thought.

You can not go to a German restraunt and not enjoy the fine german beers to offer. Enjoy we did mmmmmmm they were good.  I decided to take my fair at the dobble bocks which were good. They had a few on tap and some in the botle.  I started out with a draft dobble bock which was realy good but my real treat was the dobble bock from the bottle (name of which I can not remember) that had a special process to be poured.  A pour and a swish and swivel of the bottle as this double bock is brewed in the actual bottle it was poured from, and that last little bit of yeast and beer in the bottle is the best part. Let it sit for a few minutes and enjoy. It was all the bar tender said it was going to be.

We ended up not being abel to get a table but found a nice place in the cubby near the bar which had bar style seating which honestly was perfect. ONce a large crowd that was squeezed in there left we made our selves at home with the candle list area to enjoy some good German Eats. I debated and debated on what to choose to only return to the savory porlkchop that had led me to want to experience suppenküche for myself.  Right off the grill oh man I am about to make porkchops right now and they will be of no match to suppenküche.  overall the food was tasty the beers were delicious and the bathroom which is always a part of the review was nothing special but was neither grand nor foul.

This place is on my list to bring my friends.  Next time i Need to remember to come a bit earlier so that we can really sit down relax.

Due to being overcrowded and having to wait about 20 minutes is the only reason for not receiving 5 stars the beer was able to win me over here.  I really want to come back here soon.
author: Robert S.

description:
Let's face it - Germany did not export it's cuisine in success like Italian, French and Spanish cuisines.  But I like German cuisine, it is heavy and yummy all at once.  i like jagerschnitzel (think a German country fried steak- but made with pork).  the interior is Germany efficient-- think biergarten or Alpine efficiency.  the decor is very German-- very very little.  Go and have a great meal and enjoy some German beer.

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: German beer and sausages. Food is tasty. Beers are huge. Hard to get seats, but it's pretty and light inside, so once you're in, it's nice to sit around for a while.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Cool, hip, kinda overpriced german place that has good food, and really good beer.

The food wasn't really that good, quite un-impressive. The famous potato pancakes are more hype than anything else.

Beer is excellent, just watch out for the price, it can be a surprise to discover that you just spent $26 in beer, $16 in sausages and $6 in a strudel.

Overall, from my point of view, this is a hip tourist trap, kind of a "must go" place in a popular area of San Francisco.

Edit: Ok, ok, a friend told me WTF was I thinking with my review. Ok, I edited it a little bit, but I really didn't find this restaurant that impressive. Really!
author: Jose G.

description: I am a big fan of German beers and Suppenkuche's drafts does not disappoint. All of the food is delicious and is a definitely a good change up to the food I normally eat. Get there early because the wait can get pretty lengthy, especially if you have a larger party and need to have your own table since it is family style seating.
author: Lou T.

description:
I love this place.  I have only ever gone alone and sat in the bar area, had a few drinks, and dined alone.  While the place is insanely loud, and if you are on AT&T you are likely not not get cell service (1. it's Hayes Valley, 2. the restaurant is built like a German bunker), it is certainly worth a stop.  On one visit, I had the roast chicken and another the meatloaf.  Both were delicious, but if I had to pick one over the other (and I guess I don't, but I will), I'd go chicken.

I just had a flashback to the Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce.  So yummy.  I want some now!
author: Jason S.

description:
Super crowded, super hot, but super good.

You need to go at least once. The portions are large. The bier selection is terrific and the desert... well... if you expect to have any after that dinner, you'll need to lean across the table towards your neighbor and say "Save some room for later, Augustus!"
author: J Z.

description:
Great beer selection, friendly service, great menu selection if you like german fare.  Must order the potato pancakes!
Great place for large groups.
author: stephanie ..

description:
I'm vegetarian, so while you'd think the menu would be too limited to bother more than once, I've been five or six times, and still haven't tried all the options. Also, their daily menu often has interesting veggie options. And so good! So healthy! Some of the only edible bread in the city/country (also see Modern Tea across the street), and a fantastic beer selection.

The only problems: it can get pretty loud (which can be a good thing, too), and I'm always too full to try their desserts.
author: Blaine C.

description:
While I strongly disagree with the "Michelin" rating system, I can say that 5 Stars should be reserved for a dining experience with true "wow" factor.  That being said, I absolutely love Suppenkuche.  This restaurant deserves all 4 Stars, aligned side-by-side with strict German precision.  German food, by nature, isn't delicate and it doesn't go to extreme measures to engineer new flavors like some high-end French or (brace yourself for the most over-used word in the history of dining) "Fusion."  

Suppenkuche is neither fancy nor pretentious.  It's a pretty small place and always crowded during peak hours.  You can only make reservations for a party of 6+ so make sure you do that a couple weeks in advance.  Otherwise, you're in for a 45+ minute wait for a table which for a change, isn't exactly a bad thing.  Squeeze your way up to the bar and take your pick from a dozen+ German beers on tap - the most recognizable brand being Spaten - so try something new.  Beer prices are pretty reasonable raging from roughly $5 for a pint up to $12 for a Liter.  Be forewarned though, this isn't your daddy's Miller Lite - real German beer packs a punch and you'll feel like doing the Vogeltanz (Chicken Dance) after killing a Liter Mug.  Just don't hop into a Porsche and turn up the Kraftwerk to volume level 11...

Your table will be a bench (again: Hoffbrauhaus style).  Service is pretty prompt considering how busy this place can get.  Order some Potato Pancakes for the table...they are perfectly cooked and prepared every time.  If you want to get adventurous, try any one of their specialties which consist of a hearty meat served with a flavorful sauce (some fruit-based).  I prefer to order off-menu and get the Kasespatzle with a side of Bratwurst.  Make no mistake, you will not have room for desert and you will not be able to go out drinking afterward.  This is a place to go as a "destination" for an evening.  It will take you a couple hours and you will leave with a full stomach and slight buzz.  

The best part is Value here.  You can enjoy the full spread including beer for less than $40 per person.  Great for a group of friends....not so great if you really want to have a conversation with someone because this place is noisier than almost any other restaurant in the city.  Be prepared for a crowd of 20 & 30-something's (which is a good thing) and lots of noise...you'll have allot of fun.  PROST!!
author: Ari G.

description:
It's loud.  It's crowded.  The food is solid but not that great.  I love this place.  Why?  THE BEER!!!!!!!!  I love me some German and Belgian beer :).

I've got my salad and entree I always order (they only have one salad, and I usually get either the shrimp and scallop appetizer or the trout) which both make me happy.  But I just love sitting in that little space behind the bar and hanging out with someone and drinking fantastic beer.   So fun and sooo good!
author: Jenny S.

description:
Sausages and beer...can't go wrong, right?  Wrong!  The decor looks like a camping retreat dining hall and you got to share tables with strangers!!  In Asia, sometimes you share tables but that's okay because 1) the food is really good and 2) the food is really cheap.  Neither for Suppenkuche.  Why 3 stars?  The food wasn't bad. The staff was nice. Can't go wrong with beer.

p.s.  Hey asshole (the one we shared a table with), next time be a gentleman and make room so others can have some table space!

p.s.s.  Also, get a clue!  The girl you were with likes you ( I don't know why cuz you keep talking about yourself.....we were eavesdropping).
author: Ezduzit S.

description: Yes go there with friends,you will have a fun time .the noise level is like a time bomb but the hearty food and delish beers make up for it .Cozy space and friendly staff make it a win win to start your night.Go there hungry as servings are  generous or drink at the bar with helpful staff that point you to what style of German beer fits your taste buds.Hint if your there alone head straight to the back part of the bar usually you'll get a seat quickly.
author: wilma m.

description:
Finally came to this restaurant and have never tried German food before.   I tried the braised beef, which was alright...not that great.  We tried the pretzel and cheese appetizer, which was good, but not that great.  

The beer, however, is EXCELLENT!!!  LOVE THE BEER!
author: Annie S.

description:
So ... I waited over an hour if not almost two hours to get a seat. The place was so noisy that I eventually gave up talking. Hey, and when I got my table, I had to share it with strangers. But I am not whining about it. In fact, I loved it.

It was last Friday when I got to Suppenkuche at like 8 pm. The place was packed with people, as always, whether it was outside of the restaurant or around the bar. Since it was so packed, we decided to walk around. When it was around 9-ish, the hostess came outside, apologized about the wait, and asked if we needed bread and water. I have been to much expensive places, but the hostess was one of the most sincere I have met.

When the crowd died down a bit, we started drinking at the bar. With all other comments on yelp, there's no need for another one to point out the vast variety they offer. And the size they offer. AND the reasonable price. I have to point out how friendly and patient the bartender was on making suggestions, imagining he does that all night and every night.

So eventually, we are seated and what is more fun to sit with other strangers. Not ordinary strangers, but drunk San Franciscans, which requires no more elaboration. For food, we shared the lobster bisque and their famous potato pancake. I had their sole for main, which was a special. It came with spinach and boiled potatoes. It was citrusy, fresh, and creamy.

Around that time, I saw that the hostess was about to go home. I am just glad that she still had her voice. So, after 2 liters of beer and a full stomach, I left Suppenkuche happily. What a great place to drink, to relax, and to start off a weekend.
author: Jose K.

description: This is a good place to have beers wt friends. Not sure about the food. It's not healthy. :)
author: Tannaz G.

description:
Yummy yum yum yum yum. I had the grilled pork sausage with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes, which were fine on their own but made even better when mixed all together at once. 

Only downsides? I had to be the sober driver (no beer boot - boo) and the boyfriend got deer farts from hell from the venison sausage for the car ride home. 

Beware the aftereffects.
author: Jessica F.

description: Everyone and their mother raves about this place.  I think it's just O-K.  If it's German food you want, I've had better.  Beer is pretty much going to be standard stuff in most of these joints.  Ordered a Jägerschnitzel and wasn't that impressed.  The meat had this slightly plasticky texture to it.  My buddy ordered something else and that was slightly better (don't remember what it was called).  Also not a fan of the communal seating arrangement but which is also a German thing.  There were 6 people at our table, or 3 pairs of guests that didn't know the other 2 pairs.  We all sat sort of strangely in attempts to share our table, each person would have a corner seat.  It would be a great arrangement if you're all in the same group.  I heard monstrous waiting times and after coming here, despite beating the crowd on a weeknight, I can understand why.  It's a tiny space and way too popular for what it is and priced.  Had it been any other night, during peak times, thank you sir but no.  I'll go wait 45 minutes somewhere else.
author: A t.

description:
this german hall is pretty tight. i must admit...along with the cool decor and the delicious dishes, it has awesome beers. The food was good, a little bland in some places and a little buttery in others. But all together its one of the finer places to eat. 

low-down: 
atmosphere: solid (unfinished) pine tables in intimate, family style seating
price: $$ (25 -soup + entree + tip)
notable: beer 

a few callouts though: 
long..and i mean long, ass wait (hour and a half on a sat. night)
pretty loud
beer guy was nice...but talked in german accent (when he's not german)...really...it's just annoying. 

a word of wisdom:
get there early, put in your name, and head over to momi toby cafe for a round of beer or a bottle of wine beforehand.
parties of 6 or more get to make reservations...and most likely end up having their own table!
author: Kaleb L.

description:
I have this friend.  He's the kind of guy you bring into a room full of strangers, and after 10 minutes, he's made everyone in that room fall deeply in love with him.

So we get to Suppenkuche, and it's packed.  This guy bats his eyelashes, gets cute with the hostess, and we're seated in under five minutes.

The food is awesome, but really heavy.  I advise not eating lunch if this is your dinner destination.  

Great staff.  Great beer.  Totally yummy.
author: Carrie A.

description:
Yeah, Suppenküche is worthwhile. It's original and authentic from the atmosphere to the beers, German bread, and the various very hearty dishes. I can imagine the extensive beer selection draws a drinking crowd.  

The night we went, we adventured with the daily specials. Since my boyfriend is a major fan of potato gratin, he went for the skirt steak. To diversify our servings, I picked the organic hen, stuffed with dumplings, and a side of brussel sprouts. What a regret! There was more brick heavy dumpling stuffing to my hen than meat. The accompanying mashers and brussel sprouts were good, but I  still wound up picking at the pickled cucumber and tomato salad that came with the skirt steak and drewled out of envy over Eric tender cuts of meat. Oh, well, next time...With hopes it regularly appears on the daily specials menu.
The regular menu offers downright German comfort food: Wiener Schnitzel (breaded cutlets), spaetzle, pickled red cabbage and the like. The entrees are very generous in the range of $16-20.

The atmosphere was a couple notches too loud for my taste, which is the primary reason for the 3 stars total. Also, you are seated at dinner tables that fit 6-8 people. So, unless your party is big enough to occupy a table of its own, you will be seated with strangers. Perhaps not the best choice for an intimate/romantic dinner.
author: Kirsten L.

description:
Excellent place to meet up with some folks, grab some food, and drink good beer.  I'm not an expert on Bavarian cuisine, but this is the third "German" restaurant I've been to and it is has proven itself to be the best so far. Standard fare with Schnitzels abound, and great potato/veggie/red cabbage salads as side dishes. The spaetzle is good enough to mention as well, tasty stuff.  I really dig the potato pancakes with apple sauce, you can make a meal out of those suckers on brunch days.

What impressed me the most was the pure zeal and joviality that the staff displayed, especially while I was waiting to be seated at the bar.  The bartender walked my girlfriend and I through some brew descriptions and helped us make an informed choice.  I went with the current special, Hoffbrau Oktoberfest, which is a great medium bodied beer with a sweet bite of an aftertaste.  I'm sure you have read at some point about the 'Boots' of beer they serve here, so I won't go into it too much. If you're the last to drink from one, make sure you turn it 90 degrees at the end or face splash-back.

I dig the atmosphere as well, which is usually loud and animated.  The seating is communal unless you have a large enough group to snag a whole table.  The only downside is that the place doesn't take reservations for under six people, so you need to put your name in an hour or two earlier than you intend to eat. 

Definitely worth the trip, put in the time and check it out.
author: TJ D.

description: Super good selection of beers. Nice German food. I also liked the decoration. I will repeat, for sure!
author: Vanessa R.

description: Very good food! From the table bread to the spaeztle. Potato pancakes are a must-have. I'd say 5-stars for food, but took down a star since it's SUPER LOUD in there. You pretty much have to yell to talk to your guests, even the ones right next to you. I was told by someone that lived in Germany that this was louder than any authentic German restaurant she had ever been in. I agree with the other posters about it being too crowded. There's no lobby or desk, so people waiting for seats flow from the bar right into your dinning experience.
author: Porfirio L.

description: Something kinda cool about beer, German food and a long table.  Keep an open mind and you'll have a great experience.  We try to get here once a year with a large group.  Good times.
author: Paul A.

description:
great German beer list, great Weiner Shnitzel.  Very authentic.

Get's packed and they don't take res for parties fewer than 6, we had to wait 2 hours to eat and we had 5 people.  Still giving it 5 stars...that is a testament to the food/beer/aesthetics of this place.

A must try.
author: Rich S.

description:
Excellent German food

Excellent German beers

Why am I not back more often? I'm a brokeass art student and I can't afford to come back twice a week (that would be ideal) and the wait can be a pain.
author: Ben L.

description:
I've never been for dinner, so I can't really speak to that.  For the most part though, it's become like a good version of Denny's in our group of friends.  If you are willing to step out of the box a little bit and try some German cuisine for breakfast, you'll enjoy this place.  I took my sister here who is notoriously picky and only eats typical "American"  breakfasts and she loved this place.  Additionally you can't knock the beer selection or the feel of the place.  

If its available, i'd recommend the organic skirt steak.

Update:  6/12/07 - Suppenkuche went from excellent brunch choice to great all around.  Try to get to the bar area by about 9pm and throw back some liters of beer, served in real krugs.  The bartenders are usually able to recommend something based on what you like and are more than hospitable if you bring your own beer drinking vessel (let's say, for instance, a 2-liter glass beer boot).  I do wish it was open later but hey, I'll take Suppenkuche when I can get it...
author: Steven R.

description:
As a German food novice (outside of some meals in Leavenworth, WA- a recreated Bavarian town nestled in the mountains of Washington state), I was pleasantly surprised by the hearty food at Suppenkuche and enamored with the communal seating and ecclectic crowd. What was fascinating was that folks of all types- hipsters, frat boys, nuevo-yuppie mom and dads and their babies, and SF old-timers were all gathered in the same German beer hall all at the same time, and often at the same tables. The noise level does make coversation a teensy bit hampered, but scoot close enough to your party and talking should be fine. 

Meals start off with some nice and dense bread and herbed butter (as well as some German beer from the bar while you wait). We ordered the potato pancakes (more finely shredded potatoes than latkes, but otherwise pretty similar) served with applesauce ($9). My friend ordered the meatloaf, which came with an egg secured on top and wrapped in bacon ($14.50). One of the specials of the night was suckling pig, which the waitress informed us was only served once a week and would run out by 8pm, so it made my own decision clear. The dish came with a good portion of tender pig, a huge bread dumpling, and a heap of sauerkraut ($19.50). Although we worked up quite an appetite waiting to be seated (about 30-40 minutes on a Friday night at 7pm), we were very well stuffed by the end of the night. A nice walk down Hayes will take care of the food coma you'll get at Suppenkuche.
author: Lydia C.

description:
Bear in mind (is that the right bear? Bare in mind, beer in mind, I don't know) that I am writing this review after having the boot... a 2 liter boot of  Weltenburger Dunkel from this place. Maybe I should have waited until the boot wore off. It doesn't matter, I loved this place. Who'd a knew that Germans loved pork as much as Puerto Ricans do.

I had a pork chop that was so moist I wondered if it was even cooked. It was cooked because I saw the grill marks. It came with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes and was so good it put me in a dream state. OK, maybe the beer put me in that state but I'm pretty sure that the food was good too.

The people sitting at the communal table with us were as fascinated with the boots as we were. Mind you I'm no stranger to drinking liters upon liters of beer but when it comes all at once in a giant boot people stare. There was a bigger glass that was 5 liters but I think there was a giant turkey on top of the glass and that would have made it hard to drink.

All the food I saw going by looked good. It was hearty, German comfort food. I tasted the sausage and fish from other people's plates and they were delicious too. There are two dishes for vegetarians but this is a meat lover's restaurant. Awesome beer and belly-satisfying food makes this one of my new favorite spots in the City.
author: Hunter G.

description:
Okay, let me start by saying that I'm a vegetarian. 

There's not much on the menu for someone like me, but what there was is incredible. 
Potato pancakes rocked. 
The fried Camembert with cranberry was to die for. (mmm my mouth is watering just thinking about it now.)
And OMG the cheese spaetzle was awesome! I want to go there again and again, but my waist line will never be the same if I do.
But the real clincher for the 5 star rating? They have my favorite beer, which I haven't seen since I was in Germany 2 years ago. mmm beer.

So with all that out of the way...
It was a Monday nite, incredibly busy, we had reservations for 6 and were sat on time. (shared tables, but who cares?) The service was fast and our server was awesome. I can't wait to go back.
author: Joy T.

description:
Zee Germans!  Suppenkuche is not quite the typical american bavarian hoffbrau (as defined by Wiener Schnitzel, right?)  But it does have lots of yummy going on.  Yummy Sausage.  Yummy Potatoes.  Yummy potato soup.  Yummy organic game hen.  Yummy brussel sprouts.  Yummy dry soda (woodruff and mineral water!).  Yummy waiter.  Yummy gargantuan beer in a boot.  Yummy guy that takes our reservation.  Yummy bartender.  Ok, you get my drift.  Everything in the place is tasty like a bavarian cream puff but with the bonus of being very good quality meats and produce - NOT boiled to within an inch of retaining cellular cohesion.    

Downside - loud as FUCK.  But merry and social, and not obnoxious and annoying, so it didn't bother me as much as it could have.  One thumb up but the other one is covering an ear so I can hear what you are trying to say.
author: amy l.

description:
Food is consistent. I've tried everything on the menu and the only thing that wasn't good was the chicken schnitzel. The bratwursts are probably the best. Meatloaf is OK. Personally, I like mine drenched in gravy.

Service is where Suppenkuche loses it. With a large party (6 or over), they will rush service to clear the table. One waiter would clear the dish as soon as you put your fork down and the waitress was hard to flag down. Maybe they think it's OK to do this because the 18% gratuity is already included, but it's not my fault your restaurant is too small that you can't accommodate everyone.  

I would go back to Suppenkuche, but with 4 people max.
author: rosanna c.

description: Started with the mixed salad.  A plate heaping and generous with lots of COLD & crunchy [well, not of course the potato salad] things to eat, served with tangy just slightly astringent dressings - it was nice to have extra salad in addition to those that came with the meals as I ate a lot of rich food and stripping down my palette and breaking things up with cold raw crunchy things from time to time enhanced my enjoyment of this amazing meal.  There were three of us and we also shared a plate of the fat well-browned potato pancakes, German ravioli, and two dinners: Wiener schnitzel and dumpling stuffed roast chicken.  I don't live in SF and don't get to visit as often as I once did so it's been awhile since I've eaten here but I am amazed that the quality of the food has remained constant, even seemed better with a bigger menu.  Maybe it's just that absence has made my heart grow fonder and fewer brain cells.  None of the meat that we had was dry.  Chicken that was not dry.  Un-dry meat, can you imagine?  The kitchen understands the importance of browning and can go well-beyond golden brown without burning things.  Gravies and sauces taste like the things they are served with, not drowning in, and are not obviously enhanced with stocks from cans, powdered granules, or things from squeezable plastic bottles.  Things are not slopped on your plate in indistinct homogenous mounds.  Fried things do not sit in nor ooze pools of oil once plated, nor do they reek or taste of stale grill grease.  Fried potatoes taste like potato and are browned to a deeply caramelized color on the outside maintaining the integrity of the potato on the inside.  Thank you for that - just that one thing is all about 5 stars.  The Wiener schnitzel wore a beautiful crumb coated jacket which had taste of its own and was perfect with the pounded-flat pork filet fitted inside.  There was really no room left for the desserts we ordered but given food quality and being with people I am crazy about required it and knowing I would not be disappointed - went off the deep end.  Gosh, someone cares about the food they make.  Things tasted so good I wanted to cry.  It was beautiful like a fireworks show.  I was irritated with myself that I had wasted an opportunity to have eaten here the night before [um, may I?  If you crave expensive-for-what-you-get institutional cooking served from warming pans - by all means have dinner at the Opera House].  There's a main dining room that's a big square with a combination of both communal and smaller tables.  There's another rear dining room separated by a narrow passage way toward one side of the building.  It's a simple un-fussy space but by no-means unappealing.  It feels as though it has a fireplace.  Ventilation is good.  I've never been to Germany nor known anyone with know-how who has cooked me German food and I don't know anything about beer, but I don't eat here because I'm looking for a German experience - I eat here because the food is so universally delicious and must necessarily be prepared by people who worship at the shrine of tasty expertly prepared food.  Suppenkuche, ausgezeichnet - and thank you for having us over.
author: Nikkei C.

description: It's pretty cool that this place serves beer in a boot-shaped glass, which is 2 liters large. Then I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw a 5 liter option. Crazy! By the way, the food is really good too.
author: Vien T.

description:
Took a friend here for her birthday, she likes being German, I like beer. It works out well. The portions are MASSIVE. No really. I love love love to eat and I struggled to finish everything (although I managed, yay) 
A giant plate of meat and potatoes? Well that makes my inner Midwest girl say "Thank you Jesus!" 
Community seating...is a little odd at first, especially if the peeps at the same table are way cooler than you. Sorry I didn't wear my uber skinny jeans. my bad dude.  
The server was big eyed and seemed a little scared, oh bless your heart! My veteran, hardened restaurant employee self couldn't help but tip him 25% even though he fucked up my order. 
Go, but bring your hollow leg.
author: D H.

description:
This place is da bomb!  Really good food and beer and fun. The portions are huge,so my GF and I usually share things and are still incredibly full afterwards.  I sat at a table once with a German and she said the food was very typical of Germany.  She was happy with it.   I recommend the herring appetizer.  It is delish.  If you order a boot beer be sure to properly follow the  ritual of this massy amount o beer.  If you don't someone at the bar will come help you.  Hint: NEVER drink with the toe pointing up there's a good reason  (i think... I kinda forgot actually which way to point the toe, so observe others, grasshopper).  

GREAT place to go with friends and out- of- towners.  EVERYONE has fun.  Expect to share a table with total strangers.  It is oh so European that way...Go early --it gets packed fast!
author: Jorah N.

description:
I shared a fabulous evening here with my bday pal MSE (and all our wonderful friends of course!!!)  The service was great and the beers and food were delicious!  I had the Jagerschnitzel and spaetzel and was full and very satisfied.  We split a bunch of appetizers too... you must try the potato pancakes and dumplings with mushroom sauce.  Mmmmmm, I would go back here and enjoy another delicious meal on those picnic tables any day!!!  

And to top it all off... I was spoiled with a free beer and free piece of amazing chocolate cake for my bday!!!  I was a very happy German girl!!!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I love this place, from the schnitzel to the spaetzle,  portions are hearty and the food always tastes great. 

Due to the heavy Fri & Sat night crowd, I mostly frequent this place for brunch. Portions are a wee bit smaller (still filling though) and the menu isn't as extensive, but the food is still delicious.

Can't help but feeling like Augustus Bloop each time I leave  this place :)
author: Tra-La-La P.

description:
Brunch or Dinner - Suppenkuche hits the spot.

For Brunch:
Groes Frhstck mit Aufschnitt, Kse und gekochtem Ei & Beer.

For Dinner:
Start with Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus
then Jgerschnitzel in Champignonsoe mit Sptzle und grnem Salat & Beer. Vollkommen

Danke Suppenkuche!!!
author: M E.

description:
Ah how could I have not yet written a review about the 'Kuche?

This is quite possibly the best restaurant/bar experience in San Francisco. Let's look at a few ways this classic Bavarian establishment delights:

1. Amazing food. I am a vegetarian, and there aren't too many of those in Germany, but... The potato pancakes and lentil soup and salads are to die for.
2. Amazing beer selection. And if you bring in your own glass boot, they will gladly top it off for $20 bucks. Ya!
3. Very cute waitresses. Some friendly. Some sassy. Always sexy...

On the con side, if you really want to eat dinner there, look forward to a 1-2 hour wait. It's worth it though. Have a boot of beer in the meantime. Got a group of six or larger? Call ahead and make a reservation.

Danke, Suppenkuche.
author: Trey F.

description:
GREAT Beer (you can get a sample taste if you like)
GREAT big salad (a small size is enough for several people to share. It has all good tasty healthy stuff like beets, potatoes, carrots, cabbage)
GREAT sausage, mashed potatoes and sauerkraut .

You will not go away hungry!
author: Bill B.

description: Came here around 9pm on a saturday night and they ran out of das boot glasses! Quite disappointed but will come back hopefully with the opportunity to take on the das boot challenge!
author: Robert Y.

description:
if you are a meat eater, you can't go wrong at Suppenkuche!!!

i got the lamb chops... divine. 
tried braised beef, pork chops and chicken... all amazing!!!!\

careful with the boots in a big group...  it can do some damage to your bill!!! (but so worth it)
author: Emily T.

description:
I have gone to this place over the last 3-4 years and I can only recommend the food.

It is fresh, you don't have to wait too long and the prices are reasonable.

It gets crowded/overcrowded on weekends and the place is rather small so it is probably better to go during the week unless you have a larger group and you are able to reserve beforehand.
author: Peter K.

description: Oh Mannn!  What a great place!  I have never been disappointed here.  It is not just a love for German food.  I've had really bad German food in SF.  This, however is the bomb!  I think it is the best German restaurant in San Francisco.  Meat, potatoes, dumplings, good beer!  I had their Christmas goose dinner.  It is to die for!  Venison, not like anything you'd expect.  Flank steak -oh yea!  Pork -in several incarnations, mmm, mmm.  Well worth the money.
author: Pamela R.

description: The wait time here is insane, but that's mostly because it's a small place and they try to cram as many folks in there as they can. I can't say I blame them for it, and there's a reason why it's so crowded. The food is good, the beer is epic, and the ambiance is like some kind of wonderful cross-breeding between Norse mythology and German kitsch.
author: Kathleen P.

description: If your looking for German food, this is the place.  A little small but that only adds to the experience.  I make sure to stop here every time I visit this city.  The beer is absolutely awesome.  Try a boot of German Dark sometime and you"ll have an evening you wont forget anytime soon!
author: John R.

description:
I've almost always made sure when I travel to the Bay area, that I goto this place. In fact, I've driven and flown from LA just to go there. I've had little luck finding a comparison to te fine Bavarian food from Germany and Suppenkuche is a fine alternatative to flying to Europe. 

A quick reminder...Saturday is the only day for the Roast Suckling Pig in beer sauce with the bread dumplings. I recommend swapping sour kraut in favor of the red cabbage...it's a better pairing in my book.
author: Matt P.

description:
If you have a soft spot for rowdy German atmosphere with great beer and hearty food, this is the place for you. Some other nice touches are:
- consistent food/beer quality
- consistent, friendly but professional staff (there is hardly any turn over so the staff must like the place too)
- beautiful and frequently changing ceiling decoration
