- seating strangers at the same table

There is one negative that is due to the place's success: sometimes it is too loud. I am not sure what can be done about that--maybe you should go on a week day and not the weekend.
author: Boris R.

description:
Beer Beer Beer Beer

Best selection of beer I've ever seen at a german restaurant. And they're all really good! Potato pancakes and the meat raviloi were delicious but the sausages were just kinda so-so. Get yourself a beer and a breaded deep-fried piece of meat and go to town ;)
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Ever since I had heard of Suppenkueche, I had been dreaming of schnitzel and spaetzle  and boots full of beer.  But I had never gone because, well, I had never really felt like my body could handle that much meat and starch without imploding and creating a black hole into which the rest of the world would be sucked.  I know, right?  You can thank me later.  But my dad was in town, and my dad is a meat and potatoes kind of man.  And my dad, the meat and potatoes kind of man, decided that he wanted to eat some meat.  And possibly also some potatoes.  And so I broke down and acquiesced to fill my body with Incredibly Tasty Things I Should Not Eat (ITTISNE).

At the advice of a friend, we arrived at Suppenkueche very early on a Friday night, and it's a good thing we did.  There was just enough space for us at one of the communal tables in back, and we wedged ourselves into the spots as best we could.  The decor is rather minimalistic, and the wood of the benches and tables isn't really even finished.  The silverware and napkins are stuffed into steins that are placed at intervals along the tables.  That, in my humble opinion, is hard core.  It says "We don't need to worry too much about our presentation.  You're here to get completely drunk on food and booze.  You won't even remember what this place looks like when we get done with you.  Seriously, just enjoy the ride."

And that assessment is really spot on.  In our hedonistic meat-starch-bingefest, we started out with the pickled herring and the German dumplings.  The dumplings were amazing - I loved the thick, chewy dumpling skin, the dense, porky-chivey filling, and the creamy mushroom sauce that was shmeared all about.  We also had the pickled herring, which came with a nice salad of all kinds of shredded, chopped veggies.  Amid all the rich food, it was the light and fresh relief my body needed.  The herring itself was also delicious, but sadly there was very little of it.  It would have been fine for one person, but with three of us sharing we each only got one bite.  The main course, for me, was cheese spaetzle.  Holy cow, I love cheese spaetzle.  and I love Suppenkueche's most of all.  The pasta was just doughy enough and just tender enough, it practically melted in my mouth.  Each piece was cradled in a mass of cheese and onion/mushroom sauce.  It was so rich, and so very worth it.  The only reason I didn't force the whole thing into my already-exploding stomach was because we decided to save some room for dessert, which was black forest cake.  I don't remember too much by that point in time, except that it was very large, very chocolatey, and contained cherries.  I remember liking this cake.  I bet by that point in the meal, you would also like such a cake.  Perhaps you would also like it even earlier in the meal.

Our waiter was very friendly, though clearly very busy - that wasn't such an issue, as he was always there to offer us refills on our drinks; drinks being an important part of the Suppenkueche experience.  The downside, as a few people have mentioned, is the sound.  So.  Loud.  We were sharing our table with a large party of young folk who were kind of on the brink of screaming and, while I appreciate that's part of the fun of a German ale house, it just got a little old.  It also didn't matter quite so much because it's hard to talk when you're fervently stuffing everything within proximity into your gaping maw.  It's also not so hot if you're trying to keep healthy.  Sure, you can get the healthy veggie option - but then you're not really doing it up right, are you?  And this coming from someone who's really rather paranoid about such things.  Am I a couple pounds heavier now?  Absolutely.  Have I probably lost a bit of hearing I'll never get back?  Sure.  Would I go again?  Eh, I'd maybe make it an annual tradition.  But if I am ever again looking for someplace to throw it all out the window, Suppenkueche will definitely be on my short list.  Prost!
author: Becca S.

description:
I made the mistake of meeting friends here to catch up on a SATURDAY NIGHT.  What in the name of all that is holy was I thinking?
By this I mean that this place is freakin loud.  I don't mean - having to ask "what?" every once and a while loud.  I mean attempting to have a conversation with more than one person is well nigh impossible loud.
By the end of the meal I was exhausted, seriously, from trying to carry on a conversation.
That said, I thought the food was fairly good. My beef was OK, but my husband's venison was delicious.  I couldn't have beer, but those that did enjoyed it. (And the bartender was extremely knowledgeable about it.)  
It did take a lot longer than they estimated to get our table, but they comped us for our potatoes pancakes - which were yummy - so I have forgiven them for that.
I think I will definitely give them another try, just not on a Saturday night.
author: Chrissy S.

description:
Is it a restaurant or a beer hall? That's what I wondered when I showed up and saw the long tables, all full. My girlfriend and I waited at the bar for a half hour before the hostess finally explained that it was "family" seating and that we would never have our own table. 

Anyway, we finally get seated. At this point the place is packed and very loud (definitely more like a beer hall). Our waitress seemed busy but attentive including when an old guy at the next table was bumping my chair with his butt. She asked him to stop.

On the positive, the beer selection is great! I had a dunkelweizen that I hadn't had since my last trip to Berlin. If you're familiar with the many beer styles of Germany you'll be pleased with all of the choices.

On the other hand, I found the food to be just OK. It seemed like a California light version of the real thing. Granted, its probably healthier than your average German fare, but I prefer the real thing.

Overall, when I compare Suppen Kuche to my favorite German restaurant Walzwerk, I choose the more authentic, more cozy Walzwerk. That being said, Suppen Kuche is a great place to drop by for a beer.
author: Christian K.

description:
The place is wunderbar! Great beer, EXCELLENT food, and generally a good time. Go early before 6, otherwise you'll wait a really long time. Great place to go on a date for two or with a group. It is a little pricey, and very loud - well, with all the happy bier drinkers - so expect to do a lot of shouting and "what?" saying. There's a lot of hearty meat dishes, but they do offer fish and one or two vegetarian options.

Go! you'll love it!
author: Angela M.

description:
Yes, I drank from the boot...in fact I drank a whole boot.  i was challenged and I won.  There, are you happy...I'm an alcoholic (no...not yet).  But before I lay on the beer (of which they have a great and splendid variety of), I must commend them for their superb German cuisine.  The setting is cozy, bustling, and mad, but the food brings it all into focus.
  Venison, pork, beef, cabbage, etc.  None can be wrong in the many choices they offer.  The waiting staff are always on hand to help should a snap decision need be made (trust their word, they know their food best).  The same can be said about their guidance towards the many beers.  Oh, and one must try to save room for dessert.  Their cakes and tarts are quite delicious!
author: Scott N.

description:
Suppenküche is an experience as much as it is a restaurant. I've eaten here probably four times and never been disappointed. 

You can expect perfectly cooked pieces of meat, delicious beer in glasses ranging up to 5 liters (the boot is always a crowd favorite), and a unique dining atmosphere in which you sit at park benches. 

I recommend showing up early, or on a day other than Friday or Saturday. It's not their fault they are packed, and getting a reservation can be difficult.  More than anything though, you should go to Suppenküche with a hearty appetite and a sense of adventure.
author: Nate D.

description:
i love the food when you finally get seated. For some reason they don't accept real reservations so what you are supposed to do is go in there, put your name on a list, go to a different place to drink till your time slot is finally available, then go back to Suppenküche for your food. I once was in there for 2 hours drinking at their bar and i was seeing all these people who were not there just show up and get seated. Turns out they were putting their name on a list and going  somewhere else to wait it out. I was very upset and made it clear to the waitress and the bartenders that this was not the way to treat the customers that had been waiting there and drinking at their bar ,and in effect, they were giving reservations.

I give the food and beer choices 5 stars, its their reservation program that is pitiful and brings it down to a 3 star restaurant in my book. I will not soon go back.
author: Robert S.

description:
Having lived in Germany for 5 years, I find this to be a very authentic "Gasthaus" type of restaurant.  They have a great assortment of beers, served in one liter mugs if you like!  

Community seating, and even when it seems crowded, there's not much trouble to get a seat.  Last time I went, we were told the wait would be an hour, yet were called about 20 minutes later.  I had only gotten through 3 liters of beer!  (I guess one drawback is that the men's room is small!)

The food is great, and as good as I remember from my days in Germany.  The sausages are great, and they have awesome sauerkraut!

Good service.

Recommended!
author: King O.

description:
I had the bread dumpling with fried eggs.  Delicious.  Don't know about having beers for breakfast and the tables are communal if you have a party less than 5.  You could wait in the their tiny, stuffy, dark bar area, but it was sunny and brisk outside.  Wait time of 25 minutes was accurate for 11am on a Sunday.

The food was fine, but German food is HEAVY.  None of that California fusion influence here.  I don' t know what they put in with the bread but I felt like there was a big ball of lard in my stomach after I ate here.  Yes, I was full and walked to Noe Valley to help me digest.  No veggies, just hearty German fare that helps you pack on the pounds to keep warm in winter.  I also had the apple streudel which I couldn't finish.  You get butter and Nutella with your bread but the server forgot to give us Nutella.  But service was very friendly despite being extremely busy.  

They were also kid-friendly to our detriment as the 4 toddlers at the table next to us were screaming and crawling under our table, standing on their seats and elbowing the other diners.  And the parents just benevolently ignoring their behavior, trying to catch up with the other parents at the table.  Dogs are better behaved and they don't allow them in restaurants...I'm just saying!  There are well-behaved kids and there are not so well-behaved kids.  Yes, parents deserve to go out for brunch but other people do as well; and when your kid wipes their sticky mustardy hand on a friend's dry-clean only sweater, people are going to get upset.
author: kiwi l.

description:
If you like German food, it's a good place.  The food is quite expensive for 2 sausages and coleslaw.  

However, great selection of beer, and huge boot beer!
author: Rusty W.

description:
Always good and festive.  Love the food.  It's a great neighborhood place.  The people who work here are super friendly and cool.  

Best to go with a group.  It gets LOUD.
author: Brian R.

description:
there was a 7 year gap between the 1st and 2nd time i went here.  my memories of the 1st visit were that i had very good beer and great meat based foods.  my impression upon returning was i had very good beer and great meat based foods.

went here around 7pm on saturday and it was packed with the wait being about 2 hours longs.  thankfully they have walk-in seating at the bar.  sitting right at the bar is the perfect spot to mingle with the very knowledgeable bartenders along with people watching.

food wise, i had the vension medallions and two very good beers whose names elude me.  everything about the meal was great though i wish the venison was a tad bit more flavorful.  my sis-in-law's hubby got the sucking pig and two other beers whose names elude me but he was incredibly happy with the meal.

we were wondering if we should go for the boot but realized that it would marry us to 2L of beer and we wanted to try as many beers as possible.  next time maybe...
author: Swarup B.

description: Well I used to love the place but my last few experiences have just been alright.  For some reason their food isn't nearly what it used to be.  So if you're going mainly for the food... Sorry.  However they still have a great selection of really good beers to choose from.  Note that this place tends to get extremely busy (cramped) during the evenings, so leave yourself plenty of time to get a table.
author: Nick P.

description: This place was great! Went with a friend to try something "different" and OH MAN was it different! Very German (at least as I would imagine). They sit you at a table with complete strangers and you will end up talking to them. People are very friendly, the bar is always packed (probably due to the awesome beer). Portions are HUGE, and definitely get the boot of beer ($20) for a good time. May not be your kind of place if you are uncomfortable around strangers or do not like strangers talking to you while you eat because that WILL happen. You definitely do not get your own table or reservations. Great place for a first date! Easily my favorite German spot in the city. BOOTS!
author: Giancarlo G.

description: The best Schnitzel on the west coast (: We loved the venison too. You have to try the food here if you like German food.
author: Frank W.

description: Ich habe Durst.  I drink a tha German beer.  Es ist gut.  Ich habe Hunger.  I eatta tha potato pancakes.  Es ist gut.  Especially topped with sour cream and apple sauce.  I also tried the special which was lamb topped with truffle butter.  So amazing.  Loved the german salad as well.  Delicious beets and vinegary carrots.  Ich mag Essen!
author: Christina S.

description:
This place= good times.  The beer is awesome, and so is the food.  I've only had one snotty waitress experience.  

If you go with a group, order a "boot".  I've come to realize that this isn't traditionally German, but it is big.  And full of beer. And it comes in a big ol'  glass boot!

Just don't break it.. they will chase you out of the establishment with pitchforks and torches.
author: Tatiana N.

description:
There are already a ton of great reviews for this place so I'll be brief.

1. Awesome German food.  The bratwurst with mashed potatoes or the wienerschnitzel are my favorites

2. Beer.  In the liter mug.  Or the boot.  Having just one beer is a lot of fun here.

3. Communal seating.  If you don't have to work tomorrow, have just one beer and make a ton of new friends.  Unless you're uncomfortable talking to strangers in which case this might not be a fun place.  that is, until you have your one beer in a boot.

Don't forget to rotate the boot on the last gulp.
author: Luigi D.

description:
Ausgezeichnet! 

It's actually kind of sad how limited the selection of German dishes are but it makes recognizing things on the menu easy. Seriously, Suppenkueche offers every authentic German dish you might find in Deutschland so go here and save yourself the airfare to Europe. 

Last time I was here, I had the split pea soup with sausage, the fried camembert, and the entrecote. Oh, and how could I forget, a Weihenstephaner Bier, supposedly the world's oldest brewery. All, excellent and authentic.
author: Jan Michael K.

description: German restaurants in Germany should offer food this well prepared. I grew up in Germany and my parents owned a restaurant. On a very busy Sunday evening on December 1st 2013 ,  four of us  shared a bit of the following, Herring Hausmacher Art,  very tasty and colorful, split pea soup nicely done, outstanding Sauerbraten with great red cabbage, the smoked porkchop, best I ever tasted, Jaeger Schnitzel and Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein were also big winners. Spaetzle and fried potatoes were wonderful. The beer selection was well chosen. Zwickl Keller Bier from Bayreuth, Koelsch was my choice, a beer from Cologne. Bianca, a very competent  and very busy, german  hostess from Fuerth, Germany  took the the time for a quick chat with me in german.  Thumbs up. Alles war einfach wunderbar. I will be back.
author: Heidi B.

description:
As I entered this place my brain was washed over with memory of being here ten years ago while i visited from seattle. We drank from the glass boot that night.

Ten years later this place is still in existence and i had a good feeling of completeness.

Anyway, my schnapper schnitzel was delicious. Pickled veggies are always a winner with me. You can't go too wrong with german beers. The group seating didn't even disturb me at all. i got to eavesdrop on four very interesting and odd people at our table.

I want to eat here again and i'm already excited to.
author: Robert V.

description:
Two years ago I came here for the first time ever, and my memory about it is quite vague.  All I remember was it was super crowded and about 8 of us were crammed into a table.  This time around, there were only 3 of us and we ended up sharing a table with 3 nice complete strangers.  Surprisingly, if you come around when it opens up for dinner (we arrived at about 5:30) you can find parking nearby and won't have to wait for a seat. 

One of my coworkers and I shared the meatloaf entree. Very hearty meatloaf served atop a heaping amount of mashed potatoes.  Being the light weight that I am, I washed that down with a .3L Spaten, which I wished I would have gotten a .5L.  For two girls, the shared entree was just enough, otherwise, I think I would have been over-stuffed.  My other coworker ordered the Bratwurst entree, which he enjoyed even though he dislike the Sauerkraut.  His entree was similar to the polish kielbasa that I ordered at Old Krakow (http://www.yelp.com/biz/old-krakow-polish-restaurant-and-art-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:262AArvJ-7yOhwm0Fnog6g).  But it was definitely more worth it, and cheaper here.  

I'd definitely come back here again with friends who want to enjoy some good German food and beer!
author: Lisa C.

description: Delis but they could work on the dumplings and less sugar in the cranberry sauce
author: lisa m.

description:
Great German Food! Great Beer selection.
Go here for semi-heavy, delicious german food. 
The menu needs a bit of non-pork items though. I would add 1 more fish dish, I would add Veal  & Chicken Schnitzel also to the Schnitzel variety then it's a done deal.

The decor is hip, cool, and everything that goes with it.
author: Honor G.

description: oh man that 2L of deliciousness...i would definitely go back and order some sausages next time!!! i say if you don't have enough money to go to Munich for its October Fest, then come to Suppenkuche!
author: Louis O.

description:
Ja Ja, hier ist gut....I think spaetzle is swiss, but heck, it's close enough for me. Great German beer selection. And where did the restaurant find all these German/accented/speaking waiters/waitresses/bartenders? Oh, here's a dirty German joke, as a bonus: 

What is the German word for vaseline? Der Weenerslider.

Haha?
author: Peter S.

description:
amazing service & food.
for how cool the ambiance is here, you'd be fearful there would be an air of hipster pretentiousness...but nope.

food was so good.
potato cakes, potato soup, schnitzel, and venison medallions, beer......all so scrumptious.

our server was so nice & attentive; we will be coming back real soon.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
Good times.
The food is a bit heavy, but it goes great with 59086155697615 toasts.

Be prepared to wait a long long time if you're not on their list.
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
My passion for this place knows no bounds.

Do not go here on a date, unless you want to be shit-faced and making out on the corner an hour later. It's loud, crowded and hot as balls. The food is amazing and expensive and the beer selection is delightful. Last time I was there, they were selling adorable pre-faded hipster ready Oktoberfest shirts. This place is phenomenal. You're going to be wasted when you leave. There's no way around it. Split 5 liters of beer with friends. Drink your own liter. Have a boot of beer. Whatever. Doesn't matter. Just do it. I don't understand how you can leave this place sober.

Additionally, if you have a large group, make reservations. The jaegerschnitzel is out of this world. Drink, eat, be merry.
author: megan r.

description:
Ahh .. Suppenkuche.   The one place to stop by for an early evening beer on an empty stomach just to get so wasted you go home and make grilled cheese and jello sammiches.

Although I will fuck up some deep fried Camembert with Cranberry sauce anytime. 

Alternate:  
Ahh Suppenkuche ... the one place to go with your office group and hear your boss's boss talk in an "I'm imitating a black person" voice.
author: Jerkey J.

description: This was some of the best German food I have had in a while. Brought back great memories for me. Greg and Toby where a couple of original "Barmann". Thank you. I was so happy to be able to share a little of my history with Michelle. She really went berserk for the "Spatzel". The food was very authentic which made the experience all the better. We will definateley be back for another pint or two. LOL
author: Patrick N.

description: Nice neighborhood. Friendly staff, nice place but I have to admit, I'm a Walzwerk kind of girl. The schnitzel just wasn't as juicy here. It wasn't bad but it wasn't mind blowing either. Maybe I'll give it another try if I'm in the area.
author: Joan S.

description: Great place, great food, great beer, and friendly staff.  Always crowded, get there early. Specials are always that. Potato pancakes and meatloaf are always great. Never had a bad time or meal there. Love it!
author: Jordan G.

description: 3 stars for the food but 4 stars for the ambiance and the beer.  This has the feel of a legit indoor biergarten with family style service and seating.  The brunch was very good especially the potato pancakes and the cucumber salad.
author: Jay B.

description:
Going to this restaurant was like going to a fun party...with a kick ass menu. The beer selection was great, and the food was superb! There was about an hour and a half wait for a table but it was fine, because we went there in a group of friends and many of us had not seen each other for a while so we got the chance to chat and catch up. We didn't get Das Boot this time around, but we will for sure the next time!

If you get the chance to check this place out, DO IT!
author: G B.

description:
I think this place is "the bee's knees" as they say.  I'm not sure who they are, and what the hell that saying means, but I suspect it means the place is rad.  

Suppenkuche has a great German beer selection - perhaps the best in the city.  They offer excellent authentic German food (meaning, in part, that there is a very large number of pork-based dishes).  Many of these dishes are served with sauerkraut or various potato based dumplings.  Really, how could they go wrong with that combination?  

I like the large tables and candlelight.  It is loud, but I'd propose to you  that this just adds to the ambiance.  Try this place at least once if you haven't already!
author: Matthew H.

description:
I love Suppenkuche for so many reasons. 

1. Long tables with bench seating
2. Location - convenience, corner, so many windows
3. AMAZING beer selection always in a generous portions
4. One of the best steaks I have ever tasted
5. Two really good vegetarian options - my intro to the Portabello delight
6. Great atmosphere - lighting, curtains, service
7. The beers always last longer than the food and they don't mind
8. I always seem to have good conversations here
9. You score a table when you are sure that you won't
10. Really good potato pancakes and apple sauce

Things I still need to do: Get a damn boot. I always tell myself that I will, but have not to date.
author: Alicia J.

description:
Went on a Tuesday night with friends I met at Place Pigalle nearby. The place was packed. We ended up eating in a bar-like nook away from the main huge dining tables. Looked uncomfortably cramped, but turned out to be really fun. That was definitely where the party's at!

Exuberant conversation with Germans about all sorts of random topics. Good German beer makes quick friends out of strangers. (btw, an excellent selection of German beers they have)

Soup was good. Wow, was it good. Best lentil soup I've ever had.

Had the meatloaf. Tried the Schnitzel and spaetzle as well. Superb! Better than Schnitzel Haus. 

Good time all around. Definitely a place to go!
author: Boris C.

description:
This place really brought me back to Berlin.. one of my favorite cities.  I love the vibe and decor of this place. I found the ambiance, food, and bar to be simply authentic. The only downside was that it was extremely crowded when I went (weekend night) and the wait was predictably long (almost an hour). But no worries-- there is a cozy wrap around bar to grab a beer and mingle while you wait.

In short-- Fun for a weekend night with a few friends.
author: Sun M.

description: This place is amazing. I highly recommend the pretzels and cheese. It's busy on the weekend nights, but is always well worth the wait.
author: James B.

description: I can't get enough of this place. Every time I'm in San Francisco I come here. First time I came here I ordered off of the specials menu and got the lamb chops topped with a truffle butter. They came with a side of scalloped potatoes and brussel sprouts. Everything on the plate was amazing and gone in about 10 minutes. The lamb was cooked to perfection and the generous amount of truffle butter melted all over the plate on everything. Washing this down with a liter of hefeweizen also adds to the experience. The second time I went I ordered the veal medallions. Once again the meat was cooked to absolute perfection. This time the meat came with a side of spatzle and red cabbage. The spatzle is great and the red cabbage was good but just wasn't to my personal liking. This time we had a longer chat with our server about their beer selection. He took the time to explain the different beers they offered and what we were looking for in each of our beers. Thanks to our waiter I have found my new favorite beer, Erdinger Dunkel. I love coming here and I can't wait to be in town again to have some great food.
author: Chris G.

description:
I just went there last night at 6pm for 8 adults on 7/12. I went and ate and it was nice. The bier was fantastic. I split the bill with two credit cards.

I signed and then went home. This morning I check my and my friend's statements and I see one charge for $355.99 and one charge for $400.00. We didn't stay lots of hours, we had a total of 10 biers between 8 people and dinner. 

I -still- have my receipts and I know how much you were supposed to charge. Not only did you over charge me, you charged an entire meal for a different party on the other card. THREE CHARGES, oh yeah, I just found another for $57.

Whose dinners did I pay for? A meal over $700.00 - really guys? The food's good, but it's not that great!
***********************************************************************
Update: 1:31pm - 7/13

Aaron the General Manager did return my call promptly and explained the smaller charges (which were appreciated), but we are still waiting on the extra $400 to be removed.

If all goes well and it was a mistake, like explained, the charges will be removed in 5-7 business days and then this review can be moved up. Again, this is not about the food or the bier - that experience was lovely. I'm just not going to pay an extra $400 for any meal.

*************************************************************************
Update: 7/15/09 - 1pm

Aaron (GM) was very helpful in explaining and helping us clear the mess of the extra charge. My bank has confirmed everything is A-Ok. 3 Stars because the food and especially the bier is really good. The prices are reasonable for the portion sizes and the atmosphere itself was lively and fun.

I had to minus two stars because a little honesty on the waitress' part would have gone a long way. However - I would recommend this place to others - just bring lots of cash!
author: rei a.

description:
OK, seems like everybody loves this place.  A bunch of old friends were in town for the holidays and this seemed like a fun place to eat.  Fun is an understatement.

Suppenkuche is freaking awesome.  I spent a couple weeks in Germany for fun, just eating sausages and drinking some kick ass beer and Suppenkuche brought all those good memories back.  The sausages, the beef stew, the corn soup, the potato pancakes... it was all so so so good.

And the BEER.  Oh my god, the BEER.  I love beer.  I especially love dunkel weisse, and they had it, and I indulged in it.  I indulged a lot.
author: Dietrich H.

description:
For one of my girlfriends classes she had to write about, and experience, another cultures cuisine. She chose German, which I originally thought was a bit bizarre. "What's German food?", "Do we even HAVE any German restaurants in this city?" I asked. 

I soon learned that German food is delicious. AND there's a decent number of venues in San Francisco to try these Germanic treats. The first we hit up was Suppenkuche, with their excellent potatoe pancakes, fine beer selection, perfect spatzle, and amazin' schnitzel. 

(I know I'm not the only one who thought "wiener schnitzel" was a sausage? Well its not)!

The atmosphere was loud but happy, the service good, and the food incredible. The only downside is the price, which is a bit too steep to make it a regular spot, but if you're looking for a German treat this is a great place to start.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Went out on a limb and ordered German wine - not a big fan because of memories of sweet Leeb-Frau-Milk back in Ye Olde Country in the '80s (purported to be windscreen-washer de-icing fluid) - but I had a rather nice, dry Riesling (apparently the Hot New Thing in the wine world according to snobby wine merchant in Tahoe). Very nice, it was. 

Had the potatoE pancakes - off the chains, man! If they served these instead of hash browns at brunch I'd be as fat as a house (instead I'm as fat as a small condo). Also had the stuff cabbage rolls (I know, I know, cabbage gives me gas, but then, what doesn't at my age) - also Very Excellent as Martha S. would say. Couldn't eat 'em both (see note about potatoE pancake). 

Lucked out on a nice older couple from Alaska and their son and his Boo at the shared table thingy - this ain't really the place to go for a romantic tete-a-tete, but then, who gives a rat's ass when you're going with friends?
author: Mi M.

description:
There are so many reviews already, so I'll keep this short.

I was skeptical about Suppenkuche when I looked at the menu (and yes, I have eaten German food before).  However, the food was excellent!

I ordered wienerschnitzel, and my friends ordered the roasted chicken and pork chop.  The meats were perfectly cooked, and the sides complemented the food well.  I especially liked my roasted potatoes with bits of crispy pork in it!  

I also have to give props to Suppenkuche for promoting communal tables and their wide selection of beers!  I haven't heard of most of the beers before, and the menu did a good job of categorizing the beers.  I'm looking forward to visiting again and trying the 5 liter beer mug.
author: kim n.

description:
A hint:  Find a friend that lives in Hayes Valley, walk to the Kuch and put your name in, go back to your friend's place and wait at least 30 min before trying to get back in the restaurant.  Felt like we didn't wait at all!  

By the time we got back, we had enough time to order a couple steins and Prost! to our new favorite restaurant before being seated with a couple other randoms... who were "just a-boot drunk" (and also Canadian ha. ha. ha.).  They were fun.  We made plans to come back the day before Bay to Breakers 09 with them.  Swweeeeeet - I love planning a year in advance!

We ordered our meals, chomped on grainy euro-bread and enjoyed our fine Beir und Wein.  Our meals came out very quickly, or so it seemed, and I was enjoying my bratwurst almost immediately.  Yummmm Nuernburger!  My companions got the Hangar Steak (wow, it was very good), and some Wienerschnitzel (quite tasty).  The sauerkraut was pretty sweet for my tastes, but hell, it was all good.

Our randoms ordered the Apfelstrudel and kept moaning about it, so we got one too and joined their moaning chorus.  Crrraaazy good.  The Beir here is excellent.  Makes me long for the homeland.  

I'm only disappointed that no one in our party got anything with Spaetzel - especially since after we read the menu online, the whole day we ended all of our sentences with "und Spaetzel!"  Next time I guess.

Bis dann, Suppenkuche!
author: Laura B.

description:
I'm gonna drop a star cuz the beers were a little pricey...  Food was on the edge of being overpriced...
1st time for German food, and it was a little stereotypical.  Lots of schneitzel and other pork-choppiness and brats, combined with equal amounts of kraut.  I normally hate cabbage, but have to admit it they made it pretty good.
The place gets pretty packed... we were 4 to a 6-person table and they told us to leave a corner open for a couple, which was okay with us.
They have big glasses, you can order your beer from a boot, but they charge a breakage deposit for those novelty glasses.
Service was good considering how busy they were...  interesting "black forest" decor.
author: Roni L.

description:
Made me love German food again!

the beer is awesome and comes in sizes fit for Germany!
yummmmmmmm

the people are friendly too!
author: Briar G.

description:
To get five stars, there would have to be a bitter snow storm outside and roarign fire inside.

Why can't they serve this type of food in Tahoe?
author: Jerry C.

description:
Maybe there's something wrong with me, but I like Suppenkuche.  And except for that time they invaded Frjtz, the staff is really nice.  Get it?  The Belgian fries place?  Ho ho ho... okay I'm done now.

Usually pretty packed and pretty loud, this is pretty German.  Giant Actual Germans are here.

I recommend spaetzle.  Just saying it is cool!  When they have it I get venison.  And beer!  Can't eat German food without beer!  Ironically I've never had "soup" at the "soup kitchen."

If your Suppenkuche experience doesn't work out, don't worry- there's another hip German restaurant in SF- Walzwerk.  Which, if possible, is more East German.  Maybe do a progressive dinner for a Cold War-themed evening.
author: Brian D.

description:
Man oh man do I love German food!

Suppenkuche is in Hayes Valley and is a small and comfortable place to enjoy some beer, wine and a diner. The food is fantastic and not for a person on a diet. The food is traditional German fair and is very good!!


When you walk into Suppenkuche, it's a smaller place with a bar in the middle of the restaurant. They have tables for 6 people and if you're a party of 4, you will end up sitting with two other people as they need to fill in the wholes. I think this is a good thing, very reminiscent of a Bavarian Hofbrau house but with MUCH smaller tables. Being that it is October, we ordered a few of the Oktoberfest beers and some potato pancakes to get started. Both were KILLER!

Now for dinner!! I ordered the Falscher Hase mit Zwiebelsoe und Kartoffelbrei which is basically meatloaf with an egg in the middle wrapped in bacon...that's right I said wrapped in bacon! (I think my heart just slowed a few beats remembering it) The other guys had the traditional Sauerbraten mit Preiselbeerkonfitre and Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln. All very very good!!!

I was impressed with the quality of food. Since Speckman's closed several years ago, I have not had German food that is this good in SF. I can't believe it took me this long to try this place, but I PROMISE I will be back very soon!
author: JR H.

description:
Love this place - the jaeger schnitzel was the highlight of it all as it was tasty to me and very close to the original article in Germany, except that they used porkloin instead of veal; regardless it was tasty.  All of their other plates were good too, worthy of being called a German restaurant.
Wait was a bit long, so a tiny bit penalty on this, but the glhwein made it more bearable (yummy!).
Its a bit cozy, maybe by design, maybe by real estate limitations, but still makes for a fine dining experience - my brother and sister-in-law and I sat with another family in a bigger table.  It was cool being there as they were friendly, as were everyone else.
Oh, and need you use the W.C., its towards the back - its a bit tricky to find it.
author: Y.D. K.

description:
This is the 3rd German restaurant I've been in the city.  The other 2 I've been to are Schnitzelhaus and Walzwerk.  For food, Suppenkuche is the most average.  4 of us went here on Christmas Eve and that was one of the few places that were opened so we gave it a try.  

Positive Setting Comments: The atmosphere is nice in that they have a bar that you can stand around w/your friends while you wait and they have a lot of beer to choose from. 

Negative Setting Comments: Seating wise, we had to share a long table with 2 other parties of 2 so it felt a bit cramped.  Plus we were sitting right outside the door where the dishes were washed so it was alot of clattering sounds from the dieshes.

Positive Food Comments: 
1) The schnitzel was very delicious.  Portion size was very generous and if you like large portions of meat, you should try this.  Schnitzelhaus and Walzwerk both have very delicious schnitzel too and they are all very good in their own way.

Average Food Comments: 
1) We also ordered the Goulash soup (special of the day), which seemed like typical beef and vegetable type of food, nothing extraordinary, nothing bad about it.

2) The cold meat appetizer was good portion to share for a party of 4, maybe even 6, since the entrees are huge.  There was a variety of meats to choose from.  Caution - if you like your cold cuts more of the salty size, this dish may not be for you cuz it was a bit bland.

3) Venison medallion - If you like game meat, try this.  It's hard to find venison. One complaint is that it was overcooked.  I wanted medium and it was more on the fully cooked.  It came with red cabbage and spatzel (this was not that good compared to the other 2 German restaurants I mentioned earlier).

4) Sausage - Sausage is such a German thing, I would have expected something better.  This was very average.  Schnitzelhaus's was alot better.  This came with a big pile of mash potatoes.  I would probably not order this again here but it's certainly average, not bad.

After the big entrees, we had no room for dessert.  Maybe next time.  But I would probably go here after Schnitzelhaus and Walzwerk for food and if I want good beer to hang out with friends, I'm come here.
author: Irene C.

description:
Another addition to my foreign themed restaurant list. Suppenkuche is a German beer and food lovers paradise, and is not for those people who only like small plates (I actually doubt this term exists in German). The food options are great and I have tried everything from the Wiener Schnitzel to the Meatloaf and most recently the Venison special. That is not to say you cannot get some healthier options here, the Trout is very tasty. And the beer, the beer options are bountiful. Plus the beer is served in an amazing range of glass shapes and sizes. 

As far as reservations, they only take a limited number of reservations for 6 people or more, otherwise be prepared to wait a little while for a table. This place can get packed quickly, which is not so bad when you can enjoy a beer. And for those who are looking for a nice romantic spot, this is not for you. This is a loud and boisterous restaurant, very similar to many dining experiences you would have at beer garden or restaurant in Germany. Including, being seated with another party at one of their larger tables.
author: Raymond M.

description:
Fantastic!!! Don't miss out on the suckling pig!!! Get passed the fact that you are devouring babe and chow its slow roasted ass!!!  Perfection.  The  beer is an added bonus and the wine list is mostly German which is awesome!!!  Go with a group, make reservations or plan on waiting.  

Worth the wait in every way!!!
author: Don I.

description: When you are need of das boot, this is the place to go. They are great with large groups ( expect a short wait, but plenty of beer to help you wait) and the food is good. The prices are totally reasonable and this isn't a bad stop for a "theme" type restaurant...portions are huge!
author: Alisa S.

description: I am giving this restaurant 2 stars because it looked really fun and I wanted to eat there Sat night but when I called and asked for a reservation as I would be there in an hour, I was told I could only make reservations for 6 or more, as is stated on the web site........well, when I got there with my party of 4 I was asked if I was on the wait list. Wait a minute-what wait list? I was told I should have called ahead. I called an hour earlier and was told no reservation, just show up. Shouldn't I have been asked if I wanted to be on the wait list? Then I was informed that it was a 2 hour wait to be seated. I overheard some people milling around outside that said they had waited an hour after being placed on the wait list and had been told to return in an hour, but now were told it would be another 45 min.  I have eaten German food all over Germany and Austria and my grandma's last name was Geiger. No tight wound German would accept such poor service-have you ever used their public transport? On the dot spot on, ALWAYS on time. My suggestion is to go down the street to the beer garten and have a nice hot steaming brat with a good German beer without the crazy wait and learn to make your spatzel and kraut at home. Far more like old country!
author: Gayle C.

description:
Couldn't get past the attitude at this place.  Came in for brunch and tried to get a beer at the bar while I waited.  I guess I didn't "look right" to the bartender who ignored me and didn't look up until someone else walked up and got his order taken.  I walked out and went somewhere I was more accepted.  

If you decide to come here, leave your pink buttondown shirt at home and maybe wear a black t-shirt I guess.
author: Billy B.

description:
One of the only places that I will always go back to knowing there will be an hour wait. How can you not love a bar staff that will walk you through beer tastings even when the crowd is 3 deep? Yes, the beer selection is good and it changes so there's always something new to try. 

Food is great. tried almost everything on the regular menu and it all hits the spot (and goes great with the beer, obviously). I have been disappointed a few times with the specials, so now I stick to the regular menu items. Sauerkraut is amazing. I eat it off other people's plates it's so good. 

Gripes: Crowded and only one toilet for each sex.
author: Andrew D.

description:
WOW. people love this place and for years, i have heard nothing but good things. maybe i didnt have enough beer for my meal, but i was underwelmed. i ordered the jagerschnitzel and it was ok (the spaetzle was good but cold)..and had some bites of the 1/2 rotis chix (stuffed). the FRIED cheese was delicious as well as the potatoe pancake (reallly a glorified hashbrown). More beer maybe? though i did have two .5Ls. the waiter was charming and patient with our group of 7.

i liked the eurostyle seating, wish more restaurants would do that...but we had two giggling girls sitting at the end of the table who did not readjust spatially after our party was seated, yeah i know they arent mind readers, but come on, be a little aware of your surroundings. we certainly didnt have an amazing experience like others i have heard from...

next more beer, less food, maybe hover around the bar instead.
author: Hilary H.

description:
Beer and sausage, mmmmm.

Worth the wait and the chance you'll share a table with another party.  And yes, it is perfectly ok to order a beer with your breakfast!
author: Kyle R.

description:
I think I like Suppenkuche better than their cousin Speisekammer (http://www.yelp.com/biz/hzcbj-gz-A8yTc4tp0G69g).  The service is leaps and bounds better and the food very very similar.  I really enjoyed the Kolsh (think umlaut over that o) beer, a very effervescent and slightly sweet beer from Koln (again with the umlaut).  Wienerschniztel was great- who can complain when eating breaded and fried pork?

The wait here can be brutal on a weekend night, but we went for an early Sunday dinner and got seated right away (communal seating next to an authentic crazy German lady).
author: Sarah L.

description:
Any place that serves beer out of a boot automatically gets 4 stars.

I tried the potato pancakes and I must admit I prefer the ones at Schroeders, but these ones were solid.
author: angela k.

description:
I love sauerkraut and schnitzel over mashed potato's, especially when it is served at Suppenkuche. I also like that I am able to put 7 years of German to the test by trying to translate the menu for my friends.

5 stars= Sehr Gut!
author: Rae H.

description:
Before my last visit, I liked this place. It has everything a good German restaurant should have: a huge european beer selection, a lively/noisy/fun atmosphere, an authentic menu with lots of meat and potatos type options (which means I ate a lot of potatos...)

The last time I *attempted* to go, we had a 8:00 reservation. The woman who took the reservation said "don't be more than 15 minutes late, or we'll give away your table." Fair enough, you guys are popular.
We showed up at 8:10 (according to ALL of our cell phones and watches), and our table was gone. The host went on to explain that by their restaurant clock, it was waaaay past 8:15, and therefore, it was okay seat another party in our table. Douche-logic, for sure.
author: Chadwick M.

description:
I went to Suppenkuche on a Wednesday night and I cannot wait to come back on a weekend night where 1) I'm not driving and 2) I don't have to get up early the next day. 

Must. Try. The Boot.

Update:
I came back on a Friday. Didn't try the boot (sniff), but I still love the beer here. Huge selection of German beers I can't spell or pronounce, available in all kinds of sizes, from half a pint, to a liter, to, yes, the boot. The food here isn't great, but it's German food, so I guess I shouldn't expect more than meat-and-potatoes.
author: Ranjit S.

description:
ich liebe suppenkuche!!!!

i love everything about suppkenkuche:
~ food
~ beer
~ service
~ prices
~ ambience
~ location (2 blocks from my house!)
~ das boot!

i especially love it when they have schweinshaxe..  no matter what you order, i am sure you will love it!
author: Mon C.

description: We went here for a birthday and it was a blast.  I had the meatloaf but we all traded bites and truly everything was super tasty.  The leftovers the next day really held up (which is good because you get LOT of food).  I say it's a fantastic place for a med-large group. It's loud, has great food, lots of beer to drink plus you can actually make a reservation for large groups.  I'm glad this place is still around.
author: Julienne G.

description:
I know many of the reviewers of Suppenkuche LOOOOOVEEEE this place...and don't get me wrong, it was good.  I definitely enjoyed the bratwurst that was enveloped nicely in a volcano of mashed potatoes.  

The reason for the "A-OK" rating instead of "Foodgasmic" is because the wait is kind of daunting, the space is small, and pardon my ethnocentric / culturally-unsavvy-ness ... I think it's odd to be crammed with a bunch of strangers.  Yes, I know my patience has nothing to do with my tastebuds, but still - dining is an OVERALL experience, yah?

Sure, I can strike up a conversation.  But, uh, it's kind of hard when you've got schnitzel, beer, and bratwurst in front of you.

Oh - and don't get the herring as an appetizer.  It comes with beets and random cabbage, and doesn't taste nearly as fun as it sounds.  Though I guess I'm weird enough to think 'herring' = fun.  

The corn soup tasted like "mashed captain crunch" to my dining partner because of the sweetness.  After that comment, I couldn't stomach it anymore.  Apologies to anybody if I've just ruined this soup for you as well.
author: Shay F.

description:
Spatzle - what's not to love? I'm a big enough spaz that I felt an immediate kinship just with the WORD! The buttery, curly piles of it that came with our entrees were effing fantastic. 

I liked the pork loin with a mushroom sauce a bit better than the braised beef with cranberries, which could have been a bit more tender, but all in all - yum, yum, yum!

Suppenkche definitely put me in touch with the (somewhat) latent porcine facet of my personality: the red cabbage was slighty tart and sweet - tasted like it had a tiny bit of cinnomon and/or allspice - I couldn't scarf it down fast enough. 

One very small area for improvement could be the service... though prompt and courteous, all interaction was directed toward my dinner partner. I got the feeling that our server assumed that due to chromosomal dictum, I would not be picking up the check. (I was.)

Overall Suppenkche was a fantastic, cozy, and very enjoyable meal, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone who hasn't yet checked it.
author: Beverage Appreciato R.

description:
This place is the reason that I come to San Francisco.  Let me just say, that I love just about everything German.  The Weiner Schnitzel is THE BEST DISH by far, and the atmosphere is great.  It makes you feel like you are in a German beer hall back in deutschland.
I have been a number of times and have never been disappointed, sometimes there is a wait for a table, but the Bar is always accommodating.  A group of friends and I have tried the 5 liter stein, and it was a blast!  Ask for the boot beer glass and you won't be disappointed!
author: Peter B.

description:
Excellent! Excellent!

Seriously, you can't possibly go wrong with this place. This place deserves in stars twice the amount of rings in the Audi logo. It was a blast.

What Porsche did for cars, Klaus Kinski did for deranged acting, Suppenkuche does for German food.

The atmosphere is great, has the feeling of a Stuttgart dive full of old friends and the service was excellent. The 'biergarten' layout further enhances the ambiance and induces a sense of 'come here, talk to anyone...want more beer?" We are not really beer drinkers, but alas, I had to order one (and 2) of the Doppelbock. If your taste of beer ranks about the same with your passion for Joy Division, dark and bitter, this is the beer for you. They also served it the right way, not too warm, not too cold. Further down the path of beer loving...they have Das Boot!...really a full glass boot of beer....i thought it only existed as a shenanigan in Broken Lizard's Beerfest...but no, we saw it, and not like a UFO over Omaha, it exists!! But I will admit, I am not man enough to do it.

Food also got to me. The mustard is the real thing...the one that burns your nostrils..yeah! the nasal masochism...harsh..but it does feel good!!! I ordered the grilled cured pork chop:

Kassler vom Grill mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei

and Garcia #2 ordered:

Gegrillte Nnberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei (pork sausage)

Believe me, it was delicious. Pricing, service and items were all excellent. Go to this place faster than a Benz on the Autobahn!
author: Jesus G.

description:
Beer was amazing.

Food was beyond amazing on the way to legendary.  Get the potato pancakes.

Atmosphere cool, but beyond loud.  It made meeting the group at the communal table a bit difficult.  But I did enjoy the experience and would go back with my own fun big group.
author: Becky A.

description:
The wait at Suppenkuche is RIDICULOUS. I am not a big fan of waiting - especially for FOOD. When tough times like these occur, I become the Wicked Witch of the West.

After almost 2 hours of waiting impatiently and spitting attitude at my date, we were seated amongst strangers.

The food kept my bitch of a mouth shut, the beer emotionally lightened me up. Physically however, it did some good damage. Meatloaf, potato pancakes, sausages, mashed potatoes and beer crept right back up my oral tract and found itself in the toilet.

Amazing.
author: Thao T.

description: Great place to eat and have good beer. I love the dining room....just don't get stuck with a annoyingly loud group of drunkies. There is always a wait so plan on making your way to the bar to have a drink before eating. Service is quick and good. The place is super loud on the weeekend so it's definitely not a place for romance. The wiener schnizel is excellent as well as everything else on the menu. The blau kraut is sehr gut, tastes just like my Oma's. I love everything. It really takes me back to being a child and eating all that good food my grandmother made. Great place to go and have a great meal. The reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is because it's way loud and small, long wait, and no parking. They have valet....but come on...this ain't L.A.
author: Feleciana S.

description: Good place to sample German beer but food and atmosphere are lacking. Basically the food would have been better at a Chilli's, yes, chain restaurants would have out done them on the food. Lets just say my "side salad" was cut-up iceberg lettuce with dressing, yum! Our waiter was basically a rude hipster, who brought us the wrong food and then got annoyed with US and tried to convince us that we did order it.  You won't see me here again, there are far better German restaurants out there.
author: Olga S.

description:
This was my first time here and also my first time eating Germany food.  I came with a party of five on a Saturday night.  We put our name down around 6:15 and finally got a table at 7:30.  The wait isn't too bad if you come with other people or get there early enough to walk around the shops in the area before they all close [most of them close around 7].

We ordered the potato pancakes with applesauce to start.  They sort of tasted like hash browns but with the applesauce, it tasted much different.  They were fried well though and I would order them again.  I ordered the braised short ribs for my entree.  The meat was so tender!   The sauce was a little salty though, but luckily, the sauce was easy to scrape off the meat so it didn't ruin the meal.  I found another use for the sauce though... the spatzel was on the bland side so I just mixed the sauce into the dumplings and it made it much better.  The red cabbage wasn't what I expected: they're slightly pickled, but they were still good.  It balanced the saltiness of the meat and spatzel well.  They also have a fairly large beer menu.  Ask the waitress/waiter to help you pick a beer if you're as clueless about beer as I am.

It was VERY loud in the restaurant as well.  It's a bit crowded and loud with all the people from the bar standing around.  The beer probably also brings out the loudness in people, too.  When you are here, BEWARE THE MEN LURKING AROUND THE RESTAURANT WHO ARE THERE TO PICK UP GIRLS.
author: Denise C.

description:
Got there at 8pm and we had to wait over 40 minutes to get a table.. the bar was also crowded so we had to do most of our waiting outside. I was ready to suggest another restaurant when our German party member said this is The Place to eat real and authentic German food. Not only he was right but the environment and beer was phenomenal.

For a non-German individual, the menu can be very intimidating . However, safely I can say there is no way to go wrong. Out of the 5 main dishes we tried, ALL of them were great and not too fatty (as I was expecting). The beer selection is perfect with hard to find beers from all over Germany. The service was as good as a very crowded place will allow you. 

The Bad: Waiting time, over crowded dinning room, very loud (I kinda like it like that tho)
The Good: everything else.
author: Luis G.

description:
mmmmmmm, this place is so tasty. If you're looking for something healthy, I would recommend running far away from Suppenkuche but if you're not too concerned than dig in! I've only come here with a big group of people but it's been a ton of fun. we've sat at a huge table and the relaxed feeling in there is great. I am personally obsesed with cheese spatzel (don't know if I spelled that right), but everything is really good here. The potato pancakes with applesauce are a great appetizer and the meat I've tasted off the plates of my friends has been delicious too. 

My only word of warning is that you'll definitily be in a bit of a food coma when you leave so I wouldn't plan on going here before going to the club or something like that.
author: Lindsay A.

description:
so everyone says the german food is authentic and great, but i haven't tried to eat there. it would require too much of a time investment especially when i'm much more interested in the beer.

one of two SF places i'm aware of that serve boots, 2 delicious liters served from a glass boot :)
author: Kelsey O.

description: I am German and usually don't eat it unless myself or better yet my mom makes an authentic meal. This place is the exception, it is as fabulous as it was years ago and would rate it orgasmic!  My boyfriend was laughing all evening at my reaction to the braised beef with red cabbage and spaetzle, he is ready to take cooking classes so he can get that reaction all the time.   Though loud, it is worth it to give up ambiance for the flavors that will dance on your tongue and wanting more!
author: No One In Particular S.

description:
I come here for brunch a least once a month, if not more. I haven't made it for the schnitzl, but I'm saving it for a special occasion. 

Brunch is on Sunday only. The bread dumplings are the best, but they usually run out around 1:00, so get there earlier if you want to hit that. Always ask for mustard. They have a variety of yummy mustards that really bring out the flavor of the foods. Cucumber salads is light and if you order sides, try the salad to round out your meal.

There emperor pancakes are amazing, as everything else on the menu. You really can't go wrong here.
author: Nadine S.

description:
This says it all...

My girlfriend made reservations at Boulevard for my birthday a couple years ago.  My response: "Cancel them.  We are going to Suppenkuche. You know it is my favorite restaurant in the city!"
author: Aberdo G.

description:
Still Wondering how it is possible to be in San Francisco AND...Germany at the same time ;-)
  Good work Suppenkuche... that's some tasty black magic you got goin ;-P
author: Marsha S.

description:
Meat with meat isn't part of my usual diet, so it wouldn't be fair to say I'm familiar with Germanesque food. Authenticity aside, and just eating food for food, I thoroughly enjoyed my experience here.

As many have noted, the ambiance is casual and fun. Long wooden benches and tables fill the dining areas, and beer comes in large, sometimes boot-shaped steins. Also, you order beer quantity in metric. That's hot.

The potato cakes were my favorite - deliciously crunchy and deep-fried, topped with applesauce. Yum. The venison in red wine plum sauce was the clear meat champion of the night. Hooray game meat! It was tender and the tang of the red cabbage was a nice complement. All the other dishes were solid as well, and was very pleased with the meal. Even their courtesy nod at salad was made with fresh leaves of butter lettuce and lightly dressed in a vinaigrette.

Next time I find myself with a gaggle of men, I will happily come here.
author: Jen S.

description:
Wowsers!  No wonder the friggin German's are so friggin' big and happy!  The food is so wonderfully delicious.  Besides having to wait an hour to be seated and the lack of parking in the area there is nothing bad I can say about the place.  The portions were generous, it's very lively, and they have such a large variety of beer!  My friends and I started with the blood sausage cold cut combo and salt baked salmon as appetizers.  The salmon was cooked to perfection!  It was so moist and perfectly seasoned.  The cold cut combo was pretty great too.  There was an assortment of meats like pate, bologna, ham, and head cheese.  

As an entree I ordered the suckling pig served with beer sauce.  I was like come on!  Friggin beer sauce?  If I was an actual pig, curly tail and all, I'd resort to cannibalism just to eat this dish.  After that last statement I really don't think I need to tell you how it tasted do I?  

The place is really happening and loud.  So I would advise against taking your baby/kids there or a first date.
author: Phil Y.

description: Great place, even better food, and aweome atmosphere!!!!! I love the beer boots and the menu has a lot of German specialties to offer. This place is very very noise and you will have to wait a while to be seated. However the wait is very worth it. Mingle with friends or meet random strangers at your table (they will seat you with others when seats open up).
author: Heidi K.

description:
Cozy, comforting, and delicious, Suppenküche is where its at!  Perhaps the thing I love most about Suppenküche is that I know when I walk out the door I will be filled to the brim with good food and good beer.  With a layout and atmosphere reminiscent of a German beer hall patrons are seated at wooden tables with strangers to maximize the number of people they are able to serve and to give people the chance to socialize.  

They serve the German classics like Gegrillte Nürnberger Bratwurst
mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei (Grilled Pork Sausage with Sauerkraut & Mashed Potatoes) and Käsespätzle mit Zwiebel-Buttersoe (Cheese Spätzle).  My Personal favorite is the Bratwurst and Sauerkraut which is served with heavenly creamy mash-potatoes and spicy mustard.  When you mix all four together it provides for a delicious experience, and for me it is the ultimate comfort food.  Add in an impressive beer selection and good service and it is easy to see why the wait gets so long.  

In order to beat the line and a crazy wait time its best to get there just as they open and then take your time enjoying the meal.  Its the perfect spot for an early dinner on a Sunday night with family and friends.
author: Jessica E.

description:
I walked in for lunch, well it was my breakfast but it was lunch time, and I sat down at the bar and immediately smiled upon hearing the most homely laugh in the world. I looked around and I spotted a little old man smiling his ass off in the corner. He was wearing a leather blazer and one of those visor beanies pulled down to his eyebrows. His face was leathery with features that remind me of the Teton mountains. He was squatting there bundled up on the bench joking with and goading everyone who would stop to listen. When his waitress stopped by he kept her there for 5 minutes laughing and flirting with her. 

This was three days after Thanksgiving and I was feeling a little lonely because I did not get to see any of my family, but this squat old man made everything better. Sitting there I felt like I was at Bavarian family reunion full of laughing and smiling family.

Thanks Old Guy! You Rock!

The food rocked too, but seriously, Suppenkuche needs to hire this guys to sit in the corner all day and laugh and joke with everyone who passes by.
author: Pirate B.

description: Hmn... Well judging by the number of reviews this place has gotten, it was pretty obvious that the food would be good.  It was.  If you enjoy German food this is probably the best place in Northern California to enjoy it.  That said, you'd better get there early.  Its very difficult to get a table, the smaller the party, the better.  You will most likely end up eating with other people at your table so best be prepared to be ... effusive .... I am not friendly.  For you first beer, I'd recommend letting the waiter/waitress pick for you.  In true German fashion, they have excellent beer.
author: anthony c.

description:
I have eaten at this restaurant three times, and maybe the saying "Third times the charm" really meant something else in my case. 

After having traveled to Germany a few times, I can't say that I'm the biggest fan of traditional German food. The food at Suppenkuche is a lot lighter than the German food that I have had in the past and I was pleasantly surprised. I love the brunch options, such as the Jgerschnitzel and the Kaiserschmarrn (type of pancake). Besides the food, I must say that the wide variety of beer has to be the high point of this restaurant. Even if you are not a beer lover (seriously, what the hell is wrong with you?) there are other drinks that I haven't seen in many places outside of Germany such as the radler, which is a combination of Sprite and beer.

So, for my third visit, I went to Suppenkuche for dinner instead of brunch. Once again, excellent food and beer. I had the Wiener Schnitzel which proportions were so big that I had to give the rest to my brother. So was it the Wiener Schnitzel or something else that had me kissing the toilet the entire night?? I wasn't the only one from my party that had problems, so I'll let you be the judge.

Despite my last experience that makes me shudder when I think about it, I would still recommend this restaurant. Great service, friendly staff, and great beer!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Breakfast - 

Five stars all the way. Excellent location, love the communal (but not crowded) tables and a diverse brunch menu. It was hard to decide, but went with the emperor's pancakes with an apple and plum compote. One of the best dishes I've had in a while. Portion was filling, price just right. And good karma too - the older gentleman across from me had his tab picked up by a random patron. That was cool.

 Can't wait to go back for dinner.
author: Jason B.

description:
I spent half my life in Germany & I love this place!  Fun country tables and decorations that give it a cozy but elegant look.  Great, straightforward German food.  The Jaegerschnitzel is amazing!  
I was, however, a little disappointed in having to wait an extremely long time to get in - for my dad's birthday dinner.  They will only take reservations for more than 8 people - take advantage of that though.  Also, sound really carries - its not really good for a first date or romantic dinner for two.  Then again, the Germans have never really rivaled the French in 'Amour', right?!  
Go there for the traditional German beer hall atmosphere of loud conversations, clinking mugs & lots of laughter.
author: Katie H.

description:
This place was great!  I wish I could give it 4.5 stars because I had a great time, but it wasn't a 5.  

 The beer selection was very good. The dark Heffeweisen was awesome, it was the first time I have had something like it.  The waiters were actually super friendly, something I have come to NOT expect when dining in SF at a non-expensive restaurant.  I can honestly say that this made my experience much more enjoyable!  

The food was pretty good, nothing amazing, but portions were generous and it came out pretty quick.  The food seemed like "comfort food" and I'm not even German.  I think everyone in our party of 9 was happy with their food.  

I would go back for some food, but definitely for the beer!
author: Vinny M.

description:
OH MY GOD GOOD! I think i rolled out of there last night and still feel full this morning.  

I had the pea soup (wonderful!) and venison medallions (amazing)! My friend had the steak and I was lucky enough to get a bite - like butter. OH, did i mentioned the huge steins of beer? Fantastic!

Our Waiter - John - was great and even did this after dinner "shot"  with some at the table. Fun fun fun!
author: Terry C.

description: Stunning food, amazing beer selection...one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I have never been disappointed by a visit here. Suppenkuche is my go-to place when I want to "wow" visiting family/friends with an incredible meal for $20/person.
author: W J.

description: Love love love the authentic German cuisine and selection of German beer here. I really enjoy the community tables and the fact that it doesn't look like a cheesy German tourist shop inside. This is on my must visit list every time I get to San Francisco.
author: Martin M.

description:
"Sauerbraten mit Preiselbeerkonfitüre, serviert mit Rotkohl und Spätzle" Um, Yes please. Add a beautiful tall beer from the massive selection to that order and I'm pretty much in German Gastro-Heaven. So the Marinated and Braised Beef with Cranberries served with Red Cabbage and Spätzle is my favorite, also try the Potato Pancakes.

Missing a star for the fact that you have to go early right at opening to get tables or late around 9ish when stuff opens up as well. Otherwise pretty crowded ,somehow muggy and tends to be dark in the corners. The bar will serve you food, so if that's the only seat available grab it! Hard to find parking in Hayes Valley, walk if you can or grab the 21. There is valet service being offered now so if you must drive just save yourself the circling-around-the-block grief.

Two Stars for the amazing food, beer selection and fun atmosphere (although you have to be in the mood to possibly share a table). Third Star for its proximity to mi casa (seriously that is such a big factor, especially with those huge beers involved). Fourth Star for the fact that a few days after P and I got engaged we went with close friends for dinner here and ended up in the back room at one of the huge tables. We ended up sitting with actual real Germans on vacation, who were totally into the beer and into hearing our engagement story. As the night went on they bought us all a round of Underberg and the bitter taste still makes me think of superhappiness.
author: Rosy H.

description:
why-oh-why can they not have the giant pretzel at all times.

oh yah, coz id order that, three beers and the meatloaf and proceed directly into a coma...

but, i still think about that pretzel all the time...
author: Ameigh F.

description: BEERRRRRRRRR....Great beer, tried the schnitzel and their sausages, the sausgage melts in ur mouth like BUTTA! And their mustard for dipping...holy moly u must love horseradish if u dare to try...stellar place fo sho!
author: maria c.

description: First time here. My German friend was appalled that I never had German food and said this place was authentic enough. We came on a Sunday for brunch. There was no wait, which was surprising after reading the reviews. We sat in the back room next to a rowdy group. The food was homey and nice, I cannot even pronounce the name but it was a pork cutlet with noodles that resembled Pops cereal with mushrooms. Very tasty and I was wishing for a larger portion. Service was good. Only complaint was the noise. It was so loud, we had to shout to converse. I think if they had opened the windows, that would help as it was a sunny day. I think next time I'd sit in the front part of the restaurant.
author: Olivia N.

description:
First of all, this restaurant is so unassuming in the neighborhood.  It's right on the corner once you enter the door and go through the curtain, it's a crowded house.  Good thing my buddy already had a table but I saw many people just hang out waiting for a table.  Reviews about sharing tables is absolutely true.  It's pretty cool because everyone tonight was friendly and it was a lot of fun.  The room is loud too but I didn't mind.  
I started out with a Erdinger Hefeweizen.  It was a good start.  My friend's friend who lived in Germany for a few years told me that I should try Sauerbraten mit Lingonbeerkonfitüre,
serviert mit Rotkohl und Spätzle.  (I just copied and pasted it from their menu.)  It was marinated beef with a lingonberry sauce in a small dish on the side, with a red cabbage that was pickled and spatzle (I thought it was some kind of pasta.)  I destroyed that meal.  Very hearty and delicious.  First time.  It was a great combination of foods served together.  The bread is good, only with the spread you put on it.  After dinner I had a Edelweiss (a suggestion from another friend- he said close my eyes and think about the mountains in the Sound of Music!).  I liked the Edelweiss better than the Erdinger.  My friend had a beer in the boot.  He just barely finished it and that was the small boot.  There is a big boot but we passed on that.  For dessert we had a strudel with a small scoop of vanilla ice cream.  
I would definitely recommend this place for a fun night with friends.  Good luck with parking and good luck with getting a table.  I thought it was well worth it.
author: Brent T.

description: Great place.  Will definitely be back.  Had the suckling pig.  Yum!  Great selection of beer.  Expect loud and crowded.  Don't be surprised if you are sharing a table.  In fact, expect to share a table.  Don't expect "white tablecloth" kind of service.  It's not that kind of place. Embrace the atmosphere, accept what is offered, and you'll have a blast.
author: Dean H.

description:
I've been to Suppenkuche 5 times and now I'm ready to review.

Food is excellent! Like what I grew up on....5 stars

The atmosphere sucks!...deduct 3 stars
Too crowded
Bad ventilation- suffocating
Bad service..eg.taking a glass out of ones hand before finished.
Too loud-conversation without screaming is impossible.
The wait on average has been 2.5 hrs.
Seems like a large number of bridge and tunnel people wanting to hang in "Hip Hayes valley". They were obnoxious..especially the incessant flash from the cameras.

I dont understand...
How one could work there
Why one would want to eat there

LOCALS!!! DO CARRY OUT AND AVOID THE TOURISTS!
author: Wolfe G.

description: After a few business trips to Hamburg, I was excited to go to Suppenkuche to relive German dining sans the smoky rooms.  For the most part, I thought they were right on.  The weinerschnitzel  was just as good as i remember it.  The sauerbrauten was overly sweet, but still decent.  Next time, I'll try the semmelknodel.  Another plus is the good beer selection.  Seating is communal, so as long as you are fine sharing the table, it will be a fun evening here!
author: Peter L.

description: Get their meatloaf! Oh my god - it's so freaking good. Good selection of beer and the place is just cozy (communal tables, I wouldn't bring a first date here) and fun. This is a great place to bring a friend or two and enjoy some classic German home cooking.
author: Martin S.

description: While it was a long wait for dinner, it was a really tasty experience. I had the venison medallions and couldn't finish my meal because there was just too much goodness to eat.
author: Colene C.

description: Great place.  Had the Jagerschnitzle with mushroom sauce and Spaetzle.  My stepmom always used to make home made Spaetzle and the stuff here is just as good.  They have a great beer selection and you can get it ranging from half a liter to 3 liters of beer.....($100 deposit on the glass).  It can get very busy in there and they only take reservations for parties of 6 and over.  True beer hall style seating, they will combine small groups of people at tables to fill the place up.  Very fun time and a great place to check out.
author: Alex C.

description: This somewhat hip, corner restaurant is a good place for a group who wants some hearty German food. The bare and loud environment doesn't make it ideal for a date or a great conversation, but along with the beer, it's great for a fun time with friends. Watch out, it gets packed.
author: Barrett I.

description: Solid schnitzel, thats about it. If you want to get a lot of beer, this is probably a good place to go.
author: Tuhin S.

description:
I waited 2 hours to eat here.  Yes, 2 hours!  Came here with a group of friends who were all well inebriated by the time we got our table.  My advice: do not try to come here on a Friday night with a party of 8.  

The reason why I'd come back:  the pork chops were delicious.  The moistest, thick cut pork chop I have ever had.  Also, I need every reason I can find to relive my experience at Oktoberfest.
author: Sylvia L.

description: Went here for my bday in 2009.  Came back for more with friends in 2010.  Will return again and again because I like beer.  And I like schnitzels!!!  The food here is awesome!  Don't go here if you are taking someone out on a romantic date since all the tables are communal.  And it gets kinda loud.  Fun joint!
author: Curtis H.

description:
I took my boyfriend here for his birthday to celebrate with some good beer and hearty food and we were definitely not disappointed! 

Dinner started with some German beer and for someone who doesn't even like beer, I did pretty well (I drank two .5 L glasses! WOO HOO!). My boyfriend had planned on getting "the boot", 3 L(?) of gloriousness in a boot shaped glass, but decided to stick with smaller glasses so that he could try a few different beers. The prices weren't bad with the average price of a .5L glass around $6. For an appetizer we ordered the Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce and it was amazing. The pancakes were big and crispy and the apple sauce was so good that I wanted to order more! 

The bacon wrapped meatloaf is orgasmic. No, really, I'm not kidding. It is THAT good. My boyfriend ordered it so I only got to have a few bites (boo!), but it had me wishing I could trade dinners with him the ENTIRE meal! I ordered the sauerkraut and pork sausage which was good but a little underwhelming compared to the meatloaf. The sauerkraut was a little too sweet for my taste (I like it super sour), and the sausage didn't have much flavor but the mashed potatoes were creamy, buttery and delicious.

Dessert was an apple strudel type thing (topped with a birthday candle) and it was warm and delicious as well. Dessert is free if there is a birthday, so that was nice. I'm always a fan of free dessert! 

We finished up our meal with more beer, of course. I had a rasberry flavored beer that is perfect for someone who's not a huge beer drinker. It definitely left me wanting more! 

Overall, food was yummy, service was attentive and friendly and the atmosphere was fun and beer hall-esq. $75 for 5 beers, 2 entrees, and an appetizer - we'll definitely be back!
author: Amanda R.

description:
