Having never been here before, nor having gone to a German restaurant, I wasn't quite sure what i was getting in to. Nestled in a not so great area of Hayes Valley, we nearly walked passed the little place in search of it.
      As my girlfriend and I walked in through the monstrous  wooden door, and through the leather curtains, we were taken aback by how on a Monday evening, this place was crazier, wilder, and full of more spirit then most places are on peak hours on a Saturday. 
       The ambiance of this place is quite unusual, though, the word unusual seems to fit this place perfectly. There's hanging artwork of sparrows on the ceiling, a neat little coat rack in the corner for your big winter jackets, very simple, what seemed to be sponge painted trees around a plain white background. The place being so small, amplifies the noise level to a point that hearing a baby scream is something of a whisper. Walking in to this vibe, i was almost certain i'd be turned away or at the very least be forced to wait about an hour. The sweet hostess took the two of us right away to a kindergarten styled lunch bench where 3 other people were already sitting. This was unsettling at first, seeing as how i wasn't quite ready for it, but upon sitting down, realized, this is most likely how sitting down somewhere in Munich would feel (bring on the haterade). I was instantly welcomed by a birthday boy and his friends where they made us feel part of the party. This though was seemingly going on at every single table! Families, couples, businessmen, all sitting down with boots, liters, or steins of delicious high quality beer.
        Upon looking at the drink menu, it's no surprise that there was not one person having wine, or mixed drinks. With around 15 German beers ranging from regulars like Spatten, to rare Belgian styled Tripple IPA's that i can't even pronounce on tap, it's almost a sin to not have one. This little nook is a place where you can find young and old alike, and even the occasional cute little brunette or blonde, drinking the same styled beers. Winning.
       The waitress took my order and so went my adventure. how does the saying go, "When in Germany, do as the Germans do"????
       As we ordered our food, we were given nothing but pleasant and intricat help in choosing a dish from the waitress. She spent what seemed to be very rare time for her since it was so busy, explaining to us Noobs (For all you computer nerds up in here) what dishes were must tries.
       Our dishes came out in timely fashion. I had ordered the grilled Venison (i was feeling adventurous) with a plum sauce, stroganoff, and a candy flavored purple cabbage. My girlfriend ordered the chicken sausages with peas and pancake potatoes.  All i can say is wow. This was cooking surely made by the German Grandmother i never had. It was some of the best food i'd EVER had (and judging from my growing gut, that's a lot). My meat was tender, juicy, and not in the least bit gamey, which i've learned is now an insult to that style of meat. Her sausages were exploding with flavor (that's what she said), and for chicken, that's hard to do. Our veggies were delicious and our starches were right up there as well. 
       If you are up for an excellent beer this place is for you. If you want a high quality meal cooked to perfection, this is for you, if you want to go to a place where the service is spectacular this is for you. If you're looking for a place to take a first date, a place that's quiet and uptight, and you hate meeting new people, this is NOT for you.
author: Logan M.

description: Good German restaurant, great beer and really chill atmosphere. Pretty busy and fun people. Disclaimer: I am German :)
author: Manuel R.

description:
great beer, ok food.

forgot my evening after I drank a boot.

great potato pancakes, kind of shitty pork main courses.
author: Robbie B.

description: Fun and lively spot with good, solid German comfort food.  I liked the communal seating, which led to some good conversation with our fellow diners visiting from Germany and Demark -- forgot for a moment that we were in the US and not on holiday in Europe.  The food was hearty and delicious, definitely filling so plan your after-dinner activities accordingly.
author: Cara W.

description: Great food! I ordered the wiener shitznel (sp?) which is basically tonkatsu (Japanese) and was a bit worried that it'd be dry without some kind of sauce but it was great. Also everyone else's food I tried was great. Also beer in a boot rocks. It was a bit crowded when we got there and it seemed to take forever to get a table even though we had reservations but I didn't mind too much, others might. Also something about the acoustics of the front room seems to magnify sound. They should invest in some sound dampeners.
author: Christopher U.

description:
7 reviews so far mention the spaetzle and 3 mention the spatzle. I could probably look up the spelling and tell you which is actually more accurate, but everything is tasty. 

It's the kind of place you can tell the German designer you work with to go to and he will go skeptically but then fall in love with it, finding it to be nostalgic, though it is more the Platonic Ideal of German cuisine than the real deal, he'll say.
author: Tyler S.

description:
Good food.  Great atmosphere.  Great Beer.  

I'm not sure which I like better, the beer or the people watching.
author: Nelson W.

description:
Hot Dog! I love this place...  Wurst! Ich liebe dieser platz.

Great atmosphere, great beer, great food. Only problem is that the waiters/waitresses don't speak German :(
author: Flora B.

description:
Well, okay. I just griped about Speisekammer, so I am going to make myself feel better by extolling the copious virtues of Suppenkuche.

Oh Suppenkuche. How do I love thee? The only thing I don't love about thee is the fact that I always have to wait forever. Damn you for being so popular because you are so excellent! Tip: bring a book or a really interesting group of people. Or come on, like, Tuesday when all of San Francisco isn't beating down the door.

I'm not big on beer, but The Boot is a hilarious and brilliant group beverage. Make sure you're up on your Herpes exams, folks. Or at least taking Lysine! Seriously, though, there is quite the extensive selection of potables, beer or otherwise. My personal fave is the Gewurztraminer wine.

I have eaten both the pork sausage with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut and the sauteed trout. Spot on. The sausage was nicely cooked, and the sauerkraut was tart and delicious. The trout was among the best I've ever had, and the lemon butter sauce was just lovely, and neither too buttery or too lemony. Wonderful balance. 

I love the decor as well. There are usually interesting things hanging from the ceiling, like paper butterflies or autumn wreaths, depending on the season. I have yet to experience Oktoberfest there, but I'll bet it woulk be fun. Hooray for Suppenkuche!
author: Mea H.

description: Even though I'm not German and both me grandpappys fought the Krauts, and cant not call them krauts, I love this place. Might be my favorite place in the city. Amazing food, nothing is bad here, and giant beers. If they hadn't of fought us I would say nothing is wrong with these people. Go here, so chronic
author: Brett L.

description: Germany ... seriously?  Two world wars? ... And then just when I thought it couldn't get any worse, you go and pull a stunt like this ... AND TOTALLY REDEEM YOURSELF!!  And thus The Good Grub presents to you ... Suppenküche, the über-sophisticated, dimly lit, German gastro-pub, dishing out steins of German lager and plates loaded with spätzle ... side note, the double dots over the "a" stand for "sweet-lederhosen! this is the freakin' food of the gods."  This was our second journey to this magical place thanks to our Grub-guide Grant M. and both times, as soon as we stepped inside, we were instantly hit with the sensory overload of elbow-to-elbow beer laden Grub-mates, a constant buzz of noisy excitement, and an energy threatening to break out into an all-out Oktoberfest at any moment.  And don't come unprepared, because Suppenküche packs its bar with some serious brews on tap.  We played it safe and got a liter stein of our personal favorite, the Franziskaner Hefe-Weisse ... ahhh, just like our Great Uncle Franziskaner used to make back on the farm.  There aren't many things better than a nice big gulp from one of those beveled-steins-filled-o-golden-glory.  That is until you catch sight of the five liter stein up on the shelf... no typo my friend, five liters!?  It's so big I feel like it needs one of those warning labels you see on the side of buckets that read "Caution! Baby could suffocate if unsupervised"  ... but I want it ... badly.  One day it will be mine ... oh yes, it will be mine.  But for now I'll stick with my liter and focus on the amazing plate of sauteed pork tenderloin paired up with a side of spätzel, which is how German's do pasta ... if pasta was a plate of rich and creamy egg noodles, perfectly designed to soak up the beer about to enter your belly.  They've also got some veggie options which will change your view on all those "shouldn't-we-just-force-them-to-live-by-themselves-on-an-island" non-meat eaters.  Our veggie-mate went for the "Champignon gefüllt mit Spinat und Schafskäse auf Paprikasoße" ... and to save you about 3 years of German language lessons ... it's a portobello mushroom stuffed with spinach and feta ... then stuffed with love .... then covered in a rich, but not overpowering, red pepper sauce.  Finish it all up with a tiny vile of Underberg ... aka an after dinner alcohol that will definitely put some hair on your chest ... in a good way I think.  So grab a few Grub-buddies, prep yourself for a night of malty-goodness and German-delight, and check out Suppenküche ... as Good as Grub gets.
author: Jeff B.

description:
So...I went to Suppenkuche a couple months back and had a great meal with friendly service and a very nice experience.

A month later I went to Feierabende in Seattle (which is essentially the same thing) and had almost the same meal for about half the price.  Now I know that we're not in Seattle, we're in SF and if you want 'inexpensive' to be a word that you get to use more than twice a year then you should probably choose another place to live...but it still chafed the old wallett a little to know that the prices are as inflated at Suppenkuche as they are.

But here's the thing...Suppenkuche has fried cheese.

I'll repeat that: they have FRIED CHEESE.  Camambert with cranberry sauce.  So yeah, I expect I'll be back there again shelling out a little too much for a beer and some schnitzel, but do to the food quality and good service I'll have a smile on my face while I'm doing it .
author: Jonathan B.

description: Best pork chop I've ever had in my life, and I love pork chops.  The 2 liter das boot was everything I hoped for.  It's about a six pack so if that's not enough try the 5 liter.
author: B J.

description:
Suppenkuche is good. Not great.

I've probably been there 10-15 times -- mostly for going away parties or general big group gatherings. Drinking beer out of a boot is awesome...no matter where you are.

However, in all the times I've gone I don't think I've really loved the food. The veal medalions are good. The Jagrscnitzle is good. But the only things that are really "great" are the potato pancakes. They are AWESOME. But I'm not going to a place just for potato pancakes. 

I prefer Schmidt's (in Potrero Hill) for good, authentic German food in the city -- in a much more pleasant atmosphere for eating....and I prefer drinking out of my boot at Schneider's (downtown). 

The service is always avg at Suppenkuche, never stellar. So when my friends suggest doing a big group thing here I always secretly wished they would choose another place. The whole ordeal usually takes upwards of 2-2.5 hours...and I'm never satisfied.
author: Jason P.

description:
Yes its loud and the tables are communal, but its loud because everyone's having the time of their life and tables are communal because its supposed to be a German-style pub.
To my eternal regret on my first visit I ordered the Weiner Schnitzel which, while great, does not come with Spaetzle. I spent the first half of the meal gazing longingly at the gf's Spaetzle (her eyes closed, head swaying Stevie Wonder style) until she took pity on me and kicked down some Spaetzle. Potato pancakes are a great starter and fun too.
The beer selection is a big draw; many of your fellow diners will be marveling at the glass boots of bier, but be careful- they'll splash ya. I order the 1 liter 'krug' of beer- its just right.
Great comfort food like my German grandmother used to make!
author: Todd B.

description: I'm German and I just can say: that is delicious German food!! Homemade Spaetzle are really good! A little pricey but worth it!
author: Katja J.

description: While the food was very good, we were there on a Tuesday night and it was so loud, that you couldn't hear anything anyone was saying.  Plus, the tables were too close together.
author: E. E.

description: wtf? i would not eat here in 6 billion million trillion years. i walked inside and was instantly turned off as i felt like i was being shaked and rattled inside a steel box of nails. this place is louder than a rock concert. Congratulations Suppenkuche for being the loudest place in San Francisco.
author: Libra J.

description:
Hearty, authentic German food what you're looking for? You'll get it here. Not an intimate atmosphere by any stretch, but more of a rollicking German sausage & ale house, and a great selection of German beer both on tap and in bottle. Try the smoke beer if they've still got some!
Read my full review at: http://sibilous.blogspot.com/2005/04/suppenkuche.html
author: Don H.

description:
You know, I really don't like huevos rancheros. I really don't. Never have. 

And you can only have so many eggs benedict in your life--or florentine omelettes. 

This is why I really liked the brunch at (I can't say the name properly so I'm just not going to say it) ...this place. No florentine omelette. No eggs benedict. No f-ing huevos rancheros. 

"Well, what do they serve, then", you ask? 

Wurstgerstel mit Ei, Kartoffeln, Speck und Gurkensalat (that's "Sausage with Scrambled Eggs, Potaotes, Bacon and a Cucumber Salad" to us english speakers). That's what. 

Fantastic. 

My friend had the Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und grnem Salat (that would be "Breaded Pork Cutlet w/Roasted Potatoes and Green Salad" to you), which looked really good--but substituted Spatzel (like little fried drops of pancake batter) instead of the roasted potatoes . 

As I have written in other reviews, I love communal seating, and this is what they seem to be about. It's nice sometimes to  strike up conversations with strangers and share your food with them...or get some of theirs.
author: N B.

description:
Grandpa Rauschenberg would be so pleased that I went here to try the cuisine he ate as a child. I think he might even be impressed with the decor, with it's utilitarian tables and extremely organized flowers, leaves, or grasses hangling from ceiling hooks. 

The spaetzle is sooo rich and cheesy, with golden onions that are meshed so delicately. When you wrap your arms around your bowl (or plate, cause it's also a side dish, folks), you know you have found the true mecca of comfort food. Yes, my little cheese dumplings, yesssss. 

Beer selection is fab. I like beers that are dark, that are light, that are hoppy, that are fruity. I especially like the variety of cups. It makes me feel a little classier when I drink beer out of a glass that has a stem.
author: Vanilla P.

description:
I'm buying a wheelbarrow when I go to Suppenkuche in the future. Allow me to explain


 My friends and I needed a decent option for semi-late dining Hayes Valley proximity and opening hours fit the bill, so we got ourselves seated for a nice German dinner.


 Going by numerous recommendations and our envious looks down the communal table, we shared a plate of the potato pancakes. Additionally, we got some soup for ourselves. And, of course, piles of meat-based dinners. Everything was delicious. The mushroom sauce on my schnitzel was excellent, the green salad was yummy, and my friends' meatlof was surprisingly tasty, and oh so satisfying!


 And it goes without saying that the beer selection is up to par. You can get anything from a wussy pint glass to a standard Stein or the manly-man of German beer vessels, das BOOT.


 Bonus points? Just reading the menu, I got to use the most German I had since taking one year of it in high school. Sonntag 18 Juni. How awesome!


 Here's where the wheelbarrow comes in. I walked out of the restaurant, took a few labored breaths, and instinctively reached for my mobile phone to call a cab.


 I lived half a block away.
author: Omid T.

description:
Review #200 (personal count)!!!
Pwned by countless rounds of beer in glasses that were literally half my size and probably twice my weight. I actually had to have people help me hoist the glass to my face (which it engulfed and at one point, flooded). Great crowd, great space, great service. Food? What food! Bring on the Franzinkaner and a rally cry, huzzah!
author: Jessica L.

description: Threw a bday party for 10 here - they were fabulous. Avoided all waits and the reservations were easy peasy. No problems at the door and accomodated an outside bday cake. The food was great, atmosphere was festive the das boot was ginormous.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great/cheap  beer selection and tasty pretzels.  Definitely a fun spot for some schnitzel.
author: Chris G.

description:
I never knew you could do beer pairing with your meal!   I had my first taste of venison that night and it wasn't so bad.   It is on the corner of Hayes and Laguna and it is easy to miss.  Just remember it across from the Indian restarant.  If you're yearning for German, this is a great place to end up.

We had the:
Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce

Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce with Red Cabbage and Sptzle

Sauteed Trout in Lemon Butter Sauce with Bouillon Potatoes and Spinach
author: Jason A.

description:
Mmmmm...sausage...mmmmm...beer...mmm. 

We all asked ourselves tonight, "Why don't we come here more?"  Even after all these years it's still excellent. Fantastic beer and the best bratwurst. Tonight I tried the special Wild Boar Sausage which was meaty and rich. The Black Forest cake was boring, but the Pinapple Bread Pudding with Caramel sauce was surprising.
author: Thanya S.

description:
Nothing compares to the 'kuche.

Looking for a staggeringly good brunch or a dinnertime sausage fest?  The buck stops at Suppenkuche.  Very generous portions at this Hayes Valley haunt help round this place out as my favorite place for beer, brats, und good times.  Don't miss the cucumber salad or the beer selection
author: Chris M.

description:
It's cozy.

Sometimes too much so.

This is a common complaint. There is a large love of heavy carbs in San Francisco that finds people crowding the tables at Suppenkuche for Spaetzle, Beer and Potatos.  And beer.  And Meat.  Lots of Meat.  Pork Chops bigger then anything you've ever seen.

I love this place, but I also loathe it.  I had a birthday gathering here one year and we ordered a boot (i.e. a glass boot filled with 2 liters of the beer of your choice) and our party ended up quite a sloppy mess.  No amount of potato pancakes could stave off the drunk foot shufle we all did out of the corner restaurant, spilling into the street, full, messy and awful.

I love this place because some menu items are worth the $16.  The Jaegerschnitzel is a favorite and one to try if you're a fan of mushrooms.

On ocassion they have a fried Camembert cheese thing with crispy parsley that makes me mess myself everytime they have it.

The sparse decor is nice.  

I don't have many bad things to say about Suppenkuche but I can't seem to give it 5 stars because it's a place I can't go to frequently without getting bored with the menu.  I can only go every once in awhile or I get the Spaetzle burnout.
author: Jen I.

description:
Amazing selection of german beer. Good food.

Likes: the bar at the back, the boot

Dislikes: so many potatoes
author: Ben S.

description:
Such fun, way too much food, ample beer.  Shared tables with others consuming ample quantities of food and beverage.

The weiner schnitzel fed a party of 6, yet they ate every bite.  Such fried yet not drenched in oil.  Partook of the goose special.  What a delight.  Came with mashed potatoes and green beans.  Enough to feed two hungry people.

Nice pitcher of cold wheat beer.  The potato pancakes are highly recommended.  

Shared a table with others but that was fine; able to walk in without a reservation on a sunday evening.  

Overall a tremendous bargain.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Suppenkuche is my new favorite place to eat in the city.  Authentic food, an excellent beer selection; my only regret is not pairing a riesling with my Bratwurst, which was amazing.  Try the "salad," basically a huge plate of cabbages, potatoes, etc.  Just great!

Very noisy and crowded, but this fits well with the pub-type atmosphere and "communal" seating scheme.  You may be crammed next to randars at your table, but it all seems to work.  Authentic, unique....I will return SOON.
author: Nate H.

description:
haven't been here in years, and went recently with a friend, and was super happy with the experience! 
the service is friendly and knowledgeable, the beer selection is great, the food was great... i was a very happy puppy there! :)  
all in all a great experience!!
author: Ilovelife Z.

description:
I am half German, so I should probably be a lot more stoked about German food than I am. But I have not had super great experiences with it. I have either found it to be bland or stomach-rippingly bad. The latter may be due to my intolerance of a lot of dairy and the presence of a lot of dairy in much of the food of my people. However, Suppenküche changed all of that for me!

My friend and I went on a busy weeknight but managed to get a seat at one of the communal tables. I thought this would be annoying but it wasn't. We were all in our own little conversations although we did stop at times to do the "Ooh, what did you order? That looks great!" thing. It got a bit noisy being that it's two smaller rooms but not so much so that I couldn't hear my friend talking. The food was absolutely delicious and the service was friendly. I had dessert, which was wonderful, but I will say this: think twice about how much you need that dessert. The food is really rich and I probably needed to let my dinner settle a bit and realize I was full. Because after dessert I was totally immobilized! This is not the fault of Suppenküche in the least - just my greedy self! And my friend and I had the luxury to sit and chat some more as the restaurant was emptying out by the time I had finished my not-so-necessary dessert. But every bite was scrumptious and, as luck would have it, a cab was right outside to take my super-full self home when I was done.
author: Chris O.

description: I love screaming at my friends when I'm drunk and have a belly full of good food. So of course Suppenkuche is the perfect place for that. Amazing beer list to get drunk off of. Amazing hearty rich food to chow down on. Don't go with your low talker friends. It is pretty loud up in here, up in here.
author: Sophia C.

description: Came here as a first-timer on a date. I had the Spatzle to eat and the Radler to drink. Neither one disappointed!
author: Natalie R.

description:
Leben Sie lang Suppenküche! Hurra!

Meatloaf, real gravy, mashed potatoes, eggs, beer, strudel--these are the ingredients of pure love and joy. Remember when your loving grandma (extra points for Slavic grandparents) would lovingly make you your favorite meals perfect every time? Oh! How they tasted so good! How she spoiled you! 

That is Suppenküche. And for Hayes Valley, pretty reasonably priced. 

One more note: The winter forest branches, birds and sparkling ornaments covering the ceiling are like finding oneself in a magical Russian fairy tale. If you are brave you will order the boot of beer! It will make you strong like ox! You will then be able to defeat the wolves and save the peasants' cabbage crops from an endless dark winter of misfortune! Go little rabbit! We are counting on you!
author: Elina R.

description:
horrid service, couldn't even get a second beer.
Loud and horrible all around, but the worst service ever, made things not enjoyable.
beer was great, food was fine but service and atmosphere made it bad.
sure you might get bad service/ no service in Germany, but they don't expect a tip. So if you go to Suppenküche don't expect to tip--you likely SHOULDN'T.
author: Bill K.

description: Schnitzel and beer - oh, my! Yum-yum. I eat there as often as I can. Not crazy about any of the deserts but who has room for it anyhow?
author: Adelia C.

description: It may be a tiny hole in the wall but the food is amazing!  The restaurant opened at 5:00pm, we arrived at around 5:30 and it was already pretty packed.  The tables are "family style" meaning you may be sharing with other diners.  The atmosphere and decor are pretty casual, but don't let that fool you.  The wait staff was amazing and service was really quick.  My nephew and I each ordered a heffeweisen and my sister ordered a glass of Reisling and they came right away.  You also get a basket of homemade bread and herbed butter while you're waiting to order.  I ordered the weinerschnitzel and it came with a salad and fried potatoes, my nephew ordered the meatloaf (which was bacon wrapped) and came with mashed potatoes and sour kraut and my sister ordered the bratwurst which came with sour kraut and mashed potatoes.  We all cleaned our plates!  They also offer a couple of vegetarian options, but not much to chose from if you're vegan.  I'm a true fan of German food and will definitely be back when I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Lisa S.

description:
I don't really get a pretentious feeling from the staff at all. 

Everyone was nice and helpful. 

The beer was top notch. 

The food was very good. 

I have had the skirt steak on my previous visit that I enjoyed and would order again. 

This time however, I went for the breaded pork loin, with the side of peas and mash potatoes. 

For an app we shared the fried cheese plate, that came with a side of this jelly jam stuff. 

I also like the cucumber and tomato salad. It's soaked in a vinegar like dressing thing...yum.

Did I mention the hella yummy beer? That come in all sizes...bottled or tap. Next  time, I'm totally going for a boot. Imma do it! Totally!
author: Marivel M.

description:
I love the atmosphere of this place. It makes you feel like your at Oktoberfest or some Bavarian restaurant.  We had a group of about 12 people and they accommodated us very well in the back room.  The place does get a little loud but that probably because they offer a huge variety of imported beer in ridiculous sizes.  They range from .5 liters to 5 liters.  I had a couple friends get the boot, which i believe was about 3 liters.  
As for the food, i had the pork chops.  This was amazing.  they compliment it with some mustard, and the combination was amazing.
author: gareth l.

description:
I don't get into snausages and your various 'wursts, but I do like my beer and this place has some DAMN good beer! And a lot of it! If you're really feeling thirsty, they have a big boot of beer for ya. Oh man, just thinking about that beer is making me thirsty!

Oh yeah, the atmostphere with the wood tables and benches is right on. Dark and intimate, how I like it!
author: Susan L.

description:
Excellent spatzle, especially if with mushroom sauce.  I didn't finish my meal because until I figure out how to install a door to my stomach so that I may take out my full stomach and put in a back-up to continue eating, I will never be able to finish a meal here.

BEER!  A must for German beer lovers.  You can actually get a BOOT (2.0L) of beer here.  I have a friend that managed to drink one by himself, which made me understand why they make you put a credit card deposit on the boot.  2.0L of beer + glass boot = bloody schnitzel.

My only real complaint is that the fried camembert appetizer that I had the first time I ever went there was a special.  How can someone give you a taste of fried camembert and then just take it away from you like that?!
author: Michelle P.

description:
I would give it four stars simply because I'm wowed at their success:  On the Saturday I was there, by 5:30 there was already a long wait!  (Luckily, we snagged seats just after they opened at 5)  And this is August, when there's no "pre-theater" crowd bc the Symphony, etc. are on vacation....

I've only been there once so far -- had the great salmon-spinach strudel -- but I'll be back!
author: Steve O.

description:
I'll be there again tonight. 
I can't get enough of this place, although it's making me fat.
Def NOT healthy but who cares about health when you are drinking a 2Liter boot of german beer? Not me. 

I have yet to see someone order the biggest stein of beer. that would be funny.
author: Scott K.

description:
Unfortunately, I was all beered out from a crazy weekend, but the beer options (and sizes) looked pretty amazing, if I could have stomached a boot (!) of ale.  We had a long-ass wait for a Wednesday night, and because of a little seating mix-up, our host comped one of our appetizers -- yummy potato pancakes with a nasty but avoidable applesauce dressing.  Everything tastes better when it's free.  

Then, fried Camembert, a distant  and overpriced relative of that old Denny's favorite, the mozzarella stick.  Probably wouldn't order that one again.

We split some venison because I'd never had it before, and it was... fine.  Meaty.  Felt like something I'd crave if I were pregnant.  It came with a dessert-like cabbage side that complimented the game nicely.   Our friend's schnitzel was kind of bland, other friend's ravioli was really good (but it's hard to mess up ravioli).

Food here gets 3 stars in my book, but I loved the loud, boomy atmosphere, thick-wooded tables, and family-style seating (no music, though - whassup with that?).  Sitting with strangers is always a fun trip.
author: Sharon M.

description:
The beer selection is great. In fact, I would think that this spot could make it as just an Oktoberfest kind of place and skip the food altogether.

Most brews here are imports that you might or might not recognize. The good thing is that the bartenders and wait staff know enough about beer that if you tell them what you like they can find something that will suit your taste.

My favorite thing about this place is the fact that you can get a glass boot full of beer.  I think that it is 3L, god damn,  that is almost too much beer.
author: Thadd L.

description:
"Time/Date: Sunday 11 AM

Type/Quality: Hardy German Food, if you need to soak of the previous night of drinking this is what you want. * just don't be nauseous 

Price/Quanity: Around $16 w/out tip gets you two entrees for brunch. If you eat there they have some bread and butter to munch on.

Service/Accesibility: The service is friendly and the food comes at a regular pace. The parking is okay and consists of circleing the block for a spot. I guesstimate 2 blocks of walking max.

Structure/Ambience: Its like walking into a German Frat house. Part of the effect comes from giant glass of beer at 11 am, but the other half is from the baited groups of hung over hipsters. Luckily the place isn't intimidating and has a really great atmosphere. Its definately a place to take a group of friends
author: Justin L.

description:
This is another experience every SF resident should have.

I've brunched it here twice.  Both times I've been impressed.  Decided to hit this place up again this morning. They do the communal seating thing where you sit with random people, which I always like.  We didnt' really end up talking to our table mates but thy were nice enough. 

Any place where it's cusomary to drink a beer before 12 am with your breakfast is going to rank high with me.  We had a medium ambery hefeweizen.  It went nicely with my steak and eggs, which I inhaled because it was so so sooooo good. I wish I had eaten slower. The beers were a bit pricey at  $7 a pop but I guess the impor them from Germany so you can't really get them anywhere but here. 

I'd be tempted to try a dinner here in the future, but for now I'm very very happy with my brunch experience.

Finally the service was great.  Our hostess new what she was talking about and she was pretty cute as well. The sealing decorations were intersting.  I just love the overall feel of this place. True beer hall style.
author: Adam L.

description:
Part 3 of a dining Trilogy

Almost stumbling out of Absinthe we need to find a meal before we disappear into a bar for the rest of the night. So, the Saleslady and myself put our soggy brains together to find a quick meal. Most people would think the scallops, oysters and cheese would have been enough, but we need something hearty, savory. We needed some CARNE.  Ahhh Suppenkuche...thank you for your meat and potatoes.

We roll into  the wooden door on the corner of the building and are told that we could share a table with another party if we didn't mind. Belligerence was eminent if we didn't eat something of substance soon so we sat with a group of wonderful Latin ladies right next to the bar.

This place has an awesome selection of beers if you are into good beer. My absolute favorite is a German Triple Bock call Aventinus. A sweet rich wheat beer from Germany that packs 8-9% golden elixir in it.

First thing is first we get a couple of cold beers and check the menu. The Saleslady starts chatting up the Latin ladies and we soon find out that one is the owner's wife and one is her Mommy. This is good.  The owner comes over and chats with us for a sec and I tell him how I had my graduation dinner here blah blah blah. Don't quite remember if he sent us a beer or not.

So, we order the Bratwurst which comes with potato pancake and sauerkraut. The Brat is salty and got hints of nutmeg and cinnamon. With a dollop of the whole seed mustard each bite is fantastic. The gooey in the middle crunchy on the outside potato pancakes are perfectly salty.  I've had these at other restaurants, but none compare to those made here. Sauerkraut is really not one of my fav things to eat, so no comment on it, but I hear its good.

So the with FULL bellies and alcohol coursing through our veins we venture in to the streets of Hayes valley.  I can't really remember if we went out after wards or not, but I know we had a memorable food tour.

Service is quick the scene is loud at this casual restaurant with wood table and wood benches. The food is hearty and savory, the beers are great. Its the kind of place I could go with the boys and eat and drink all night.

Three restraunts in one night was a pretty cool experience. This is what I love about the neighborhoods of SF. 
Thanks Hayes Valley!
author: Michael S.

description:
Went on a friday night with a buddy of mine. I thought their staff was fantastic. Very helpful and on the ball. I loved their beer selection. I have to go back for the beer.

We also had dinner there, their fooodd... hmm not sure how to put it gently, is ok.  Lets say I would not go back for the food. I guess after a couple of beers it really does no t matter how the food taste.

I would go back for the beer and then go to eat some where else.
author: Amlan S.

description:
I was skeptical, not gonna lie.  Not that I don't like beer, because I'm not that kind of girl... but I was concerned about the food, because I've never been to a restaurant that serves only German food outside of Germany.  My mistake - I've been missing out!

So, I just moved to town, and when I tell people I'm in Hayes Valley, the first thing out of their mouth has commonly been "Have you been to Suppenkuche yet?"  Last night I finally went, and it really was as good as everyone said it was.  Potato pancakes - I need more of these in my life.  The beer was delicious, and my friends got boar sausage - great - and the weinerschnitzel - best I've had in the U.S.  I got the goulash, which could have been spicier, but still was pretty solid.

Final word: Go to Suppenkuche - the wait is worth it!
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Caveat emptor!

Hm, I used to have fond memories of Suppenkuche - until last night. I lived in Germany for three years, so when it comes to knowing what authentic German cuisine tastes like, I'd say I have a pretty darned good baseline to compare against. What I experienced last night was disappointing.

When I first discovered this place some years back with friends, I loved it, and the food was great. But last night, I found the food to be not only subpar and mediocre, but I simply didn't enjoy the atmosphere of the place at all. 

The hostess seemed more interested in jamming people in at the bar to sell beer, with the subtle threat that if you leave the restaurant (where there was hardly room to stand) they may not hold your table. What a bunch of crap. So we stood at the bar, ordered a beer (which was damned good), and then were consistently bumped in the arms and back by servers and people trying to squeeze through the crowded bar. I wondered to myself if this kind of crowding was actually exceeding the capacity limit set by the fire marshall...

When we did get seated, we were totally fine with the table-sharing; that's cool, no problem at all there. Most people around us seemed to be having a good time (thank the beer), so the mood was good. We ordered, samped the over-dry bread and bland spread, and waited for food. And waited. And waited. When it finally arrived, the server SPILLED some food on me when somebody bumped his arm... why? BECAUSE IT'S TOO CROWDED. I can't stress it enough.

During the entire dinner, my SO and I were constantly bumped by servers and people being seated or trying to get to the bar or out of the restaurant. It sucked ass, and made the experience completely unenjoyable. I'm in a freakin' restaurant trying to eat food, not at Oktoberfest trying to squeeze my way to the bar!

The food was uninspired. The Jaegerschnitzel was just ok, but really didn't match up to expectations. The flavors were muted, and we both agreed that they'd probably pre-prepared it during the day and then reheated it for service. The porkloin I had was a thick slab of meat, and I'd have been impressed if it didn't taste oversalted and bland... I think that must also have been pre-prepared during the day and heated up for service. On the plus side, the Sauerkraut was really good.

Price-wise, for the quality of what we got, it was way too much - entrees averaged about $16-18, which we both agreed was about $5-6 too much per dish for the quality of the food we got. The quantity was great, but the quality was just not worth that much.

I guess if you have no sense of what real German food is and don't care about paying too much for bland food in an overcrowded environment where you can hardly hear the person sitting right next to you, this is the place for you. But if you want solid German food that tastes great, is reasonbly priced, customers aren't jammed in like sardines and you can have a conversation at normal speaking level, then go check out Waltzwerk down on South Van Ness - overall that place offers an extraordinarily better value than Suppenkuche, which IMHO has lost everything that I used to like about it.

My recommendation, skip this place. You're being jipped and paying for a faded reputation this place no longer deserves.
author: Gregg G.

description:
I went here during Oktoberfest with a few of my German classmates in my German class....ANYWAYS,  I was really pleased with the food. I ordered the Salmon something-or-other and it was pretty awesome. I really wanted to try some of the potato pancakes, but I didnt get the chance. I know a lot of people bitch about the fact that it's too crowded, but I think that's part of its appeal. Since we went on such a busy night, there was literally no room to eat. I was slamming into the people next to me, and they had to encroach on our table b/c they had too many people

Now I dont drink at all, but I would have liked to have tried their beers. So yeah, can't say anything about that. Pretty good overall, just got a little sardines-in-a-can syndrome going on
author: Dustin H.

description:
Reibekuchen mit hausgemachtem Apfelmus 
(Potato Pancakes with Homemade Apple Sauce)

Split Pea Soup

Jgerschnitzel in Champignonsoe mit Sptzle und grnem Salat 
(Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Sptzle and Green Salad)

Large Spaten

The above were my menu selections this past Saturday night, and I enjoyed all of it from the soup to the beer! We had a group of six, and had 0 complaints. I liked the party atmosphere and meeting other patrons you are sitting with at the picnic table type seating.
author: Justin M.

description:
OMG, OMG, OMG, I love this place.  I dream about going to Germany and simply eating myself silly...now I just head down to Hayes Valley to this gem.  I just wish it wasn't on so many other people's radar.  The only annoying thing was the noise from the revelers trying to out-noise their noisy neighbors was a bit much for a relaxing dinner, it's more about the comfort food here.  

The service was good despite the hecticness of the restaurant....the server was very accommodating when I wanted to switch a couple of things.  I can't wait to bring the bf to eat some more German comfort food!
author: Brye L.

description:
Yummy food and yummy beer.

Just thinking about this place makes me drool for potato pancakes and cherry beer.

If you're not totally stuffed after dinner then the black forest cake is a must try. It's fluffy and light without the sugar overload and the cherries are a great complement.

I love the specials they have and always have to order a couple of things from that menu as well as the regular menu. If you're looking for hearty food and good beer then this is a great place. If you're looking for a quite table for two then go somewhere else.

Best times to go are off hours so that parking and waiting aren't a total pain.
author: Vicky C.

description:
There's really not much to be critical about.  I went with a group of friends at around dinner time and though the place was completely packed and we had to wait for about 30 minutes, we had a fantastic time!  It's loud and hectic inside, but it makes for a really fun, energetic atmosphere. 

'Can't remember what we ate but I do remember that it was good!  We had the blood sausage appetizer, which is oddly tasty and worth trying.  I loved the little analogies for the different sizes of beer steins.  My friend got the biggest, a 5 liter---as much as would fit in a wheelbarrow.  

This place is also walking-distance from the Civic Center station.
author: Oksana Y.

description:
Yessssss.

I came here years ago for the bread dumpling.  I remember it being delicious and serious comfort food.
I came here recently for my friend's birthday.
4 dishes + 1 boot of beer + 2 pitchers = $150 bucks.
Pretty phenomenal.
I ordered the meatloaf, two guys ordered the veal medallions with the spatzle, and one guy ordered the franks.  Everything was delicious and the plates were FULL of food.

The food makes me want to take a nap afterwards.  

Also, get there BEFORE 6!  We got there at 6, got the boot of beer and were seated right away.  But by the time we left (8pm), the place was crowded and it was hard to find someone to get our check.  There was literally no room to move.  
Sausage party.
author: Meh M.

description:
My partner and I regularly have dinner here and love it. There is a great selection of Beers on tap as well as friendly staff despite the crowds. The food is very consistent so I never have to worry about a sub-par meal.

The one draw back is the wait for a table and if you get to the restaurant after 8 pm you can basically forget about a seat. However, it is easy to avoid this by showing up at approx 6 pm. 

Enjoy
author: John A.

description:
Delicious beer, wonderful food and seating where they don't try to kick you out quickly - what's not to love?

This is my third time at Suppenkuche, the others were all just as good. We came on a wintery Wednesday night around 8pm, the server in red said the wait was 15 minutes, but we were seated faster than that. Thanks.

My date went the vege option - a small salad ($6.50) which was not small at all, and the potato pancakes ($9) which like every reviewer here has mentioned - are great.

I went with the daily pork special ($16.50) which was medallions of grilled pork, peas w/ bacon and mashed potatoes. Unbelievably good, and very filing. Rounded out the meal with 6 beers between us, and you rocking out $87 lighter and toasted.

The couple sitting across from us got the two litre boot, even got carded buying it, and admirably finished it off together. That's how young love starts...
author: Joseph T.

description:
It was an hour wait for a table, so my friends and I decide to pass the time at the bar. I look at the chalkboard beer list and I'm only familiar with one of the German beers on tap (Spaten), so I ask the nice gentleman next to me what he's drinking. All of a sudden, he and his hoard of drinking buddies start yelling "Dunkel!!" as they clang their one-liter beer glasses together. The guy takes a swig and a good amount of beer drips down his chin.

Immediately, I think to myself: "Oh God, it's going to be one of those nights." I order the Dunkel (a.k.a. dark) in a respectable 0.5 liter size (because you can order whatever size you want). A bit later, the restaurant's seemingly normal patrons start pounding their tables as one of the tables passes around a 2 liter boot of beer as they gleefully chug it within a span of minutes. That's Suppenkuche for you.

By the time you do get a table, you should order the potato pancakes (accompanied by a delicious applesauce) and the schnitzel. Both pair very well with any of the beers. And take a look at the ceiling too, they have an absolutely bizarre assortment of ornaments hanging there. Those crazy Germans.
author: Dan V.

description:
Man, this is some good food.  Was with my Pennsylvania Dutch friend who grew up on German-American food.  She loved it!

And the beers...very impressive!  Nearly impressive as the alcohol tolerance of some of the patrons who drink them by the liter.

I had a special: veal sausages, spatzle and red cabbage.  All were incredibly good, and I will definitely go back for other menu items.  Value is good, as well.  Lots of food!

However, after about an hour of ear-splitting din, I wanted to stand up and scream "SHUT UP PEOPLE STOP YELLING!"  So loud.  I hope the servers wear earplugs.

Also, I too was awakened by nature at 3am.   Those Germans.  Was it the cabbage, I guess?  Just be aware!
author: Dwayne A.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I am German. I grew up eating potato pancakes, schnitzel and the many other delicious things that Germany has to offer. I was really disappointed by Suppenkueche, mainly because of how awful their potato pancakes are! I mean give me a break, probably one of the easiest things to make and you managed to screw it up! Mine tasted like hash browns fried in week old grease. I did give them 3 stars because everything else that the large group and I ordered was very tasty. I had the stuffed chicken and it really was very delicious. The service was so-so, nothing to rave about.

All in all, don't call yourself a real German restaurant if you can't make potato pancakes!!!
author: Henriette P.

description:
My first time at this place, after living here 11 years!

The atmosphere is crazy busy, but cozy and jovial (like any German pub would be like, right?!).

We went during what we thought would be a 'down' night and the place was packed which really added to the 'communal' tables they have for sharing with your neighbors.

I got the sausage dish (can't remember the name) and the potato pancakes were the crispiest thing I've ever eaten I think. (very yummy!) They hit the spot after drinking the wonderful Belgian ale (blonde)!

Its a great, friendly atmosphere but just be patient if there is a wait.  Even with having a reservation, we had about an hour wait.  Good thing I came about a half hour late!  And worse case, you just sit toward the back, right side of the bar, hangout and have more great beer!

Great decor as well!
author: Ahnee M.

description: This is a real piece of Germany right in San Francisco. I am German, so I know what I am talking about here. Great, very authentic food, great atmosphere, A bit loud,  always packed, tables are shared, so might not be the best place for deep conversations, better for dinner and some beer or wine with friends.
author: Jan H.

description: Friendly waitress! Excellent beer! The food was very good and very authentic. We had the wurst plate with kraut and mashed, and lamb with spaetzel and Brussels sprouts - excellent beer hall food. These folks have the runnings of a real beer hall and should look for something a little larger, I will be back.
author: Gerell L.

description:
It is flipping loud up in this piece. Fo' Sho'.

That being said, the food is pretty good, and after a recent trip that happened to include a binge on the kind of food served here, well, they definitely are close enough to eating in Germany or Austria. Huge portions abound, the apps are fried-licious, and bless them for not having the entire place smell like it is a Weiner Schnitzel fry basket.  It's hard to pull off.

We ate lots of different menu items; We all finished off the potato pancakes - like a good hash brown, but with better flavor and crunch,  the weiner schnitzel was a little dry, the pickled herring app was bomb - I heart apples and pickles, the cheese spatzel I will order next time because I kept diggin into my friend's bowl full, and the sauteed pork loin was well received by the gal next to me eating it.  I had the black forest cake for dessert, it was so flipping good after all that food.  Best part is that it was actually light and fluffy for a typically heavy cake.  Totally necessary after the feast that preceeded.

Highly recommended at least once.  They don't take reservations unless there are a bunch of you, so plan to wait.  We waited at an art bar across the street, it was lovely.  Service was great, speedy, friendly, and able to hear and talk over the loud din.  It's a little bright, but that lends to it's easy going atmosphere.

Would totally go back, although I'm a bit partial to the other Eastern German joint in town.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
THE BEST BEER I've ever had in SF.
Beware: You might enjoy their beer so much that you end up completely broke and chugging Festbier out of a huge glass boot. Just don't take it too far, I've seen someone puke here before. 
...
Regardless do your self a favor, and for your next Bday party come here.
Oh yeah did i mention the amazing German food.
Also be sure to check out their brunch. Its a total steal.
author: Austin F.

description: A friend took me here when I was in San Francisco for a business trip, and I am so glad she did! Being from the Midwest, I've been to my fair share of German bars that serve spaetzel and beer in boots, and this place does it just as well as the ones owned by real Germans. If you get there early enough to get a seat, this is the kind of place you could stay all night. Great food, great beer and great service = 5 stars!
author: Erica W.

description:
It's rare to find an authentic German restaurant.  But upon arrival I was impressed.  First, you must get reservations or else expect to wait at least an hour.  If you happen to wait, no problem, order some imported German beer at the often very crowded bar!  We ordered the Optimator, an excellent imported beer that was so good, I couldn't get enough of it and yes, we had a designated driver!  

Once seated, the service was acceptable.  The place was packed and you should expect it to be for dinner.  The food was very good..large portions, tasty, filling and good value.  I had the half chicken with potatoes and it was VERY tasty and filling.  The atmosphere caters to both families and singles and is very accomodating to both crowds.

I recommend this place.  But just be aware the you will have to deal with crowds, the noise and long lines.  Its definitely not a quiet place - but that's all part of what makes this place special.
author: John Y.

description: This place continues to rock my socks off. Great place for dinner, but I just love getting me a beer and talking to Craig or Rusty behind the bar. Everyone who works here is so friggin nice, and the beer is so good. Sometimes the though of a rolling rock on my couch does the trick, but for a treat, love having this place a stones throw from my house!
author: Isabel L.

description:
I made a reservation for my first Suppenküche experience with a party of seven, including the very German mother of a friend of mine.  Everyone loved the food and the drink... my only complaint would be that it was VERY loud in the restaurant and pretty difficult to have conversation with everyone who was at the table.

Be prepared to wait to get in here, and even with a reservation we needed to wait 10 minutes or so before we got in.  (I was fine with that because not everyone from our party had arrived yet.)  By the time we got in we were still 2 people short of our 7 so they made us sit with another party of 2.  It ended up being fine, though, and they were actually dressed up in German clothes for a Halloween party they were headed to afterwards, so in a way it made the place feel more authentic.

10 minutes later when our final 2 people arrived we did have to squeeze everyone in for a total of 9 people at the table.

All said and done I'll probably go back at some point.  Plenty of good stuff remains on the menu and I'd never turn down another chance at the potato pancakes or the Black Forest cake :-)
author: Scott M.

description:
3.5 Stars

This is a cool place with nice atmosphere. Service and beer selection are decent. I've gotten the schnitzel which is good, if a bit overly fried. The potatoes are delicious.

However, I think Leopold's is much better for this type of cuisine.
author: Eva B.

description: With serious boots of bier, large german sized plates of food, and community style tables, its definitely a fun Hayes valley find. The outside is pretty non descript and the wait can get crazy and you may find yourself sitting with random folks, but the beer they brew is amazingly delicious. A pint is pretty much all I can take, but the bartender is nice in letting you taste the different brews to find the type of beer you like. I enjoyed their lemonade beer blend as well as their darker porters. The chicken dish is literally half a chicken! Go for a good portion dinner or if you just want good beer. Warning breaking the boot costs $50 buckeroos if you break it, so no chugging guys! Still a fun place to see if you have what it takes to drink that much bier.
author: SF Diner A.

description:
4 stars is a bit much for this place.  Wait wait ... wow I'm back writing reviews on Yelp?  I guess I have 7 minutes to kill before my next meeting so I might as well.  The boots are a fun idea, but aside from 2 liters of beer the food I experienced was just ok.  I think I know what to get next time though ... that spitzle pasta and cheese thing FOR SURE.

The other night I got the suckling pig and it was dry like turkey (I hate turkey).  My buddy got the cured pork (ham) and it tasted like ... ham.  Our dishes failed miserably, but I was hardly mad because I was 1.5 liters into my boot.

I think I'd go back and try again because it's great in groups and I love heavy, hearty and rich food.  Next time I'll do better ... maybe 3 liters.
author: James F.

description:
Loved this place! The food is great and authentic, with more than ample portions, and the atmosphere (in spite of the tasteful/modern decor) manages to create that nice feeling of Gemütlichkeit that anyone who has visited Germany has come to love.

The only thing I did not appreciate was the crowd. The wait is really long and they really pack people in on the tables (I guess it was our fault for conceding to share one), so between that and the large parties of office coworkers pounding down bootfuls of beer, it is almost impossible to have a civilized conversation.  Would give 4 stars because of that, but I don't want to be too contrary ;)
author: Beth H.

description:
Sunday brunch is a must -- good excuse to start the day off with a very large beer.

Really fun for large group.  Get 'da boot (it's something like 3 liters of beer and it's served up in a huge boot shaped glass).
author: Jenn S.

description:
Great for groups up to about 8 if you call ahead and reserve.  Big, big beers, pretty good food (the meatloaf is my favorite).  Even German ex-pats claim it to be pretty authentic.  Not exactly inexpensive, but reasonable by SF standards.

Always busy, reservations highly recommended, even during the week.
author: Doug M.

description:
Extremely good hefeweizen, and a very friendly staff.

I finally made it to this restaurant on Friday while prawling Hayes Valley.  My date and I arrived exactly at closing time, so only had an opportunity to order one round.  But the staff let us relax and nurse our drinks for 2 hours past closing while we enjoyed a really intimate conversation.  I doubt that customers should expect this as a rule, but if this is a sign of their service during regular hours, than this place definitely deserves 5 stars.

Oh, and the beer was excellent too :)
author: Miller H.

description:
Great for big groups who just want have a good time eating schnitzel and drinking beer.   The potato pancakes, spaetzl, and schnitzel are fine, but this is really a place to get drunk with a big group of friends.  The atmosphere is loud and boisterous, with picnic-like settings.

However, this is not a place for a quiet romantic dinner.  I would not go just for the food, but for the total experience.

Do not fall into the trap of over-ordering as 4-5 entrees and a few appetizers is more than enough for 8 people. Remember beer is a food group too.
author: Zk K.

description:
So I went here in the summer, kind of randomly because we were looking for some place to eat. It was probably 3rd July, and this place was open. Fabulous! (unlike another German restaurant that chose not to open that day..hmph but anyways..)

The restaurant was pretty crowded, and a lot was going on inside. We waited probably about half hour to get a seat, but in the mean time we settled down in the bar area and ordered some bier (obviously). Can't go wrong with bier, especially German bier.. but I'm slightly biased on that. What others mentioned about shared tables is true, although we didn't really share a table. We sat behind the bar at the countertop areas, so it wasn't really "shared" per se. 

Now I know German people tend to eat a lot of pork, and I'm not a big pork fan myself but I always seem to make an exception when it comes to German food. I ordered the bratwurst while my bf ordered the schnitzel. Both were quite yummy.. Again I tend to be a fan of the German sausage and beer...

I'd say the only downside was that it was kind of dark in the room.. mainly candles if I recall. Also it was kind of hard to get some service. We had to go up to the bar to order our food. Maybe it's the norm but I wasn't used to doing so. Pricewise, I'd say the schnitzel for 16.5$ is ok, but sausage for 13.5$? Maybe I should have ordered a schnitzel too. You can get curry wurst off an imbiss for 2 Euros. I'd really say it gets a rating of 3.5, but since there are no half stars, I'm rounding down to 3.
author: Yosie G.

description:
Call me crazy, but it just doesn't get any better than 2 liters of Hofbrau Dunkel and meatloaf.  

I do wish the bar area was a little bigger, as you can get jostled a bit during the wait.   Having the glass boot full of beer is fun, but it is NOT a cause for a celebration when it is consumed in group fashion.   One person, one boot- that is a celebration.


===============
4/24 Update:  Meatloaf recipe changed & temporarily out of Hofbrau Dunkel.  Rating in danger.....
===============
author: Matt T.

description:
GREAT german fare.  VERY LONG WAIT. too long when you are very very hungry. if you may get irritated because of that, stay away, even on weekdays. if you are ok with it, come in. have a riesling. enjoy chitchatting with good looking and friendly staff and crowd.  

LOVE the de minimus german decor. HATE the ugly t-shirts plastered on  the wall. 

BE PREPARED to share table with strangers... could be fun.
author: Sharonrose B.

description:
Tasty German food.

My Step-father is from a German town from Wisconsin and said that the saurkraut was the best he ever had in his life.
author: Joe R.

description:
I love this place. The beer knocks me off the bar stool really easily. I always like to come here with another female friend and enjoy the atmosphere. As a vegetarian, I find the choices good enough with lots of flavor. The potato pancakes always seem to go well with a large pint of beer and their salads are mighty tasty too. The tables here are family style which I love growing up going to Basque restaurants. This place just has a nice warm feel to it.
I would highly recommend this to people whose parents are in from out of town who want something different without being too different, since it is essentially a meat and potatoes kind of place.
author: Gina c.

description:
Always a great meal!!

love the staff and the food is is great!!! Just like grandma made it!!!

plus beer beer beer!!!!
author: Danny B.

description:
Absolutely delicious. Not a place I go to regularly, since I don't live too close and it's e-x-p-e-n-s-i-v-e, but it's definitely worth it on occasion. Best with a 3+ group of people, it's not so great for intimate dates.

The atmosphere is the perfect combination of neighborly and crowded bar, but you still have enough room to breathe and stretch your legs. The people (patrons and staff alike) are all very friendly, so be prepared to share your conversation.

The beer is so good! At least one time in your life you need to get the 5 litre (yes, I did just say FIVE LITRE) stein, but make sure you have some friends to split it with! Passing around that gigantic ceramic stein is a magical experience. If 5 litres is a little much for you, they also have a stein in the shape of a boot, I think it's more like 2 - 2.5 litres.
author: Rachael W.

description:
Loved the potato pancakes with applesauce, loved the black forest chocolate cake, loved the giant Franziskaner I washed it all down with. But heavens to Betsy this place is loud! The folks at our group table were pretty tame, but I still spent most of the night trying to read my husband's lips.

If the wait is long, and I gather that it usually is, just pop over to Momi Toby's for a coffee. Do not give in and get a slab of carrot cake. You'll spoil your falscher hase.
author: Christina S.

description:
Nice, cozy fun place that has German beers other than Becks. They also have some of the culture alcoholic drinks, like Radler, but I'm hoping someone will want a Diesel so they can put it on their menu.
The food was good, especially since I love a good spaetsle and red cabbage. The service was very accommodating, even after 50 people came in after us and groups of people started ordering beer in a boot (5 Liters full of German-wheaty-goodness). I certainly recommend it, as it is one of the many unique restaurants in SF.
MMMM, Lecker!
author: Neal L.

description:
Every restaurant should have bench seating and a 5L option for draft beer.  What better way to make friends?

Since my first visit in 1999, I have drank at least 3x my body weight in beer and eaten 0.5x my weight in kraut at the Kuche.
author: Matt S.

description:
Authentic German food that is delicious. Best German food in the Bay Area.
They have different specials.
Awesome beer selection.
Usually crowded later in the evening, but you can have a beer while you wait.
author: Samuel L.

description:
Das Boot: 2 liters of your favorite beer, served in a boot.  http://blog.tinou.com/2007/08/das-boot.html 

The food is great, if you like it hearty: meat, sausage, potatoes, more meat, more potatoes.  

Good selection of beer;  I like the Erdinger Hefeweizen.

Just don't ask the Polish waitress where in Germany she's from.
author: Tinou B.

description:
Great food, but German food can be soooo heavy sometimes!  It's loud and crowded, but definitely worth going to.  I like the communal table setting and the beer is (of course) awesome.

They also have a great brunch.  I had the emperor's pancake (I think that's what it was called) which was super tasty but very sweet.  Just wash it down with some beer and everything will be fine.

Oh, and the decor is really interesting.  A lot of unfinished wood and some weird stuff hanging from the ceilings.  Cool stuff...
author: Tamara M.

description:
Wow. Amazingly rich and full-calorie laden delicious meat and potatoes kinda place. The bar is a fun atmosphere with loads of beer. Literally loads of it. I told the bartender I wanted a hefeweizen and before I could say anything else he interviewed me. Dry or sweet? Light, medium or dark? With his help I received a scrum-diddly-umptious beer that kept me satisfied all night long. As for the food...amazing! I ordered the fish with potatoes and spinach. To die for! Melts in your mouth kind of good. For dessert we did the classic chocolate cake with cherries and shaved chocolate topping. OMG! Had to get to the gym today just cause I had that! Not a great selection of coffee but then again you aren't there for that so who cares...

The five stars is really for the service. We had a rowdy bunch next to us ladies who kept insisting on turning around throughout our meal and talking to us in drunken rambling. Nice boys, totally harmless, just drunk. The waiter came by to make sure we were comfortable and to check on whether or not we wanted the guys put in their place. So sweet! We were seated in a timely fashion and the food came quickly. They were more than accommodating!
author: Stephanie J.

description:
My boyfriend and I got there at 5:10pm and we barely got a table. A few minutes later and we would've probably skipped it for the night. I've been looking forward to coming here since my boyfried is half german and loves beer. I'm personally not a huge fan of german fare. Anyway, we had:

Potato pancakes - yummy and crispy with great applesauce ( not Mott's)
Lentil soup with bratwurst - very good, esp the sausages!
The main wienerschnitzel (spelled wrong I'm sure), it was super thin and the breading was super crunchy! Very generous portion of it! They gladly substituted the salad with sauerkraut.

Even tho it was crazy busy our waitress was really good and never missed a beat! Definitely would go back again!
author: Bonnie K.

description:
Eating at Suppenkuche really brought out the German in me. Namely, beer and heavy food consumption. I guess in the end, I learned two things about Suppenkuche:
1) It is actually possible to get a table; it just may require a little planning and effort (and perhaps a 4-block dash in heels)
2) It is veggie-friendly, in the end.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Who knew a girl could have such love for the schnitzel? This place is super fun and the food was so delicious! I was bummed because it was so incredibly tasty but I couldn't finish my entree because the crispy, yummy potato pancakes with applesauce put me over the edge. But I'm not really complaining because I'd do it all over again in a second.

I agree with the other reviews that if you're looking for a quiet table for two, this is not your place. It was my first time here but I'm thinking it's usually pretty packed on a weekend evening, so 1) be prepared to wait (but just put your name in and go to a bar and have a cocktail - it'll be a long enough wait) 2) be prepared to share a table with other peeps 3) get yourself on the jagerschnitzel train and be prepared to be rocked.
author: Kate S.

description:
Ever since I returned from my graduation trip to Eastern Europe, I've been a bit obsessed with finding authentic and quality German food. Initially, I was reluctant to dine at Suppenkuche because of its hype. I hate being disappointed! 

However, Suppenkuche's traditional fare of swine, potatoes, and sauerkraut exceeded my high expectations. I had wild boar sausage, with sauerkraut and bacon. More filling than I usually prefer, but no one expects to have a light meal when they're stepping onto German cuisine territory. I wish I tried some of their beers, but my meal was heavy enough. 

I would have given 5 stars, but I'm not a fan of communal seating. I didn't like it when I was in Berlin, and I don't like it now. I know it's part of the culture, but I prefer to be in a more private, intimate setting while dining. 

Either way, I know I'll be back to Suppenkuche very, very soon. I can't wait to try their schnitzel!
author: Christine N.

description:
You don't go to Suppenkuche for a salad.  Expect a big meal and it would be just plain wrong of you to not order a few beers.  I feel that this is pretty great authentic German food, or at least is trying it's very best to be.  

It is certainly loud and I have experienced anywhere from 15 minutes to an hour and a half wait, so be prepared for that.  The vibe in Suppenkuche is just fun and loud and boisterous.  A good find.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Suppenkuche is fun.  Suppenkuche has great service.  Suppenkuche has good, fairly authentic German food (as far as I can tell after one exchange year sometime in the 17th century). 

The problem is . . Suppenkuche is packed! 

We had a reservation and I still ended up sitting half-assed on the narrow end of a wooden bench -- literally, half of my butt, which really isn't that big, was falling off of the bench and my already compromised skills with utensils were severely challenged.  Its very hard to manipulate a knife and fork with less than a centimeter's elbow room.  This place might be five star, if everyone didn't already know that it was four star.  Its also not cheap - so when you go with 9 people, be prepared for your $300 check.  That makes sense to me when the meal is more than an impromptu burrito-bite, but when I'm making  a meal an occasion with friends I want to be able to hear them and I want to be comfortable lingering over coffee and cake.
author: Laura M.

description:
Really good authentic german food. The organic cornish hen was juicy and stuffed perfectly with bread stuffing. The vegetables were tender and not too crisp or too soggy. The spatzen (i think) was very tasty too. 

My friend had the cured pork chop which was a little too raw for my liking :P but was supposed to be very tasty. The mashed potatoes were nice and creamy with no lumps. YAY! :) 

Must warn ya... the portions are large and hearty. Not the best place for vegetarians but they do have 2 veggie dishes. The noise level was fun and loud. The best part of the restaurant was that you got to share the table with other people. Not the best place to go on a first date..... :O

Do get a pint of some of the authentic beers they carry. And dont forget to have the salads... overall a great experience!
author: Soham K.

description:
Crowded, dark, noisy, tasty tasty tasty.

I've ordered the meatloaf and the pork loin and I've been quite satisfied. The spaetzle is great (though how could it not be?), and so is the complimentary bread and butter. It's too expensive for my regular patronage, but it certainly is a treat reserved for special occasions.

I'm dying to try their pickled herring.
author: Amy Z.

description:
I heart Suppenkuche! I have never had a bad experience there. The food is always delicious and filling, and I love their selection of various German and Belgian beers. I especially love the cucumber-tomato salad and anything that involves pork. (Chop, schnitzel, loin, sausage, whatever, I'm in heaven!)
I don't really have any complaints about the price. Entrees are anywhere from $12 (for the Spatzle) to $18.50 (for the Venison). I think that the prices are fair, especially considering how much food they give you. I have never been able to finish my entire entree. Ever.
At first, sitting at a table with strangers was jarring, but you get used to it with repeat visits. The restaurant is a generally loud and boisterous place, and the communal tables serve this atmosphere well. This is a German restaurant, after all. Think Oktoberfest, every day!
author: Steffany F.

description:
JH wanted to dine here on a Friday night, but it was jam packed and the wait time was an hour and half. On Sunday, I decided to give it a second try with HH and we lucked out grabbing seats at the bar. 

Bar service is first come first serve. It's fast and efficient for those who are hungry and have a party of 2-3. You order your food and beer at the bar. When the food comes, the bartender will yell out your name to come and get it as HH discover when everyone at the bar started calling out his name. I like to think it is kinda like "Cheers" where everyone knows your name. 

The beer selection is so diverse that we pulled out our blackberries to google the beers. (*Can we say DORKS???*) As it turns out, they were out of the  beers we had carefully chosen so we threw caution to the wind, closed our eyes, and let  our misguided finger select the beverages. HH ended up a light lager and I had a hearty ale.

The food is hearty fare with pork, pork, and did I mention pork? I had the meatloaf with bacon and eggs with a side of potato. It had me at bacon. This dish is "TO DIE FOR" because you will literally die from eating it. It's that good that I inhaled my food. HH had the venison which disappeared faster than I can say "Can I have a bite?"

Overall, this place is fun, crowded, and definitely worth trying out. Think Fridays are hard to get in, so definitely good for small groups and make sure you eat before you go in case you have to wait! Oh yeah, please note that at the bottom of the beer menu, the little depictions of what 0.5 liter compares to in real life is hysterical. Check it out for laughs!
author: Sophie C.

description:
A girl can only dream of saying Schnitzel and Spatzel in the same sentence when ordering a meal. Kind of rolls of the tongue with such delight....It's really quite sad that those are the only German words I can pronounce effectively and without spitting uncontrollably across a table.

I've been to Suppenkuche several times. Most recently with a girlfriend for a nice afternoon in Hayes Valley.  And I can say that each and every time, I have been pleased with the service, atmosphere, and most importantly the food! 

The restaurant is set up in communal style tables, so if you don't come in a large group, you will have some neighbors--usually friendly locals. The restaurant gets very crowded. Dinner is served from 5-10 daily and my advice is: Get there early! The restaurant gets very noisy and boisterous, so come in good spirits! This is not the place for intimate conversation.

My favorite dishes are obviously the Schnitzel and Spatzel. The Jagershnitzel is my recommendation as it comes with a mushroom sauce over the breaded pork and without the sauce, the Schnitzel can be a bit dry for some. The Sauteed Trout in Lemon Butter Sauce is also one of my favorites when I'm not in the mood for pork.

Suppenkuche only takes reservations for 6 people or more and usually there is street parking available nearby. 

Hope you try this delicious restaurant!
author: Laura L.

description: Bratwurst is the epitome of joy in my life. When I miss my mom's I know I can always eat Suppenkuche's and feel the pangs of homesickness melt away.
author: Zachariah Q.

description:
I have been there twice. the last time was last weekend. it was very beautiful day and I kinda wanted German food that day. it was around 2 PM when I called them because it said on this website that it'll be closed at 2.30 PM on sunday. The guy who picked up the phone sounded very friendly. and he said that as long as I got there before 2.30 PM. I will be fine.

I got there and I love what they decorated the restaurant. it made you feel like you are not in the city. it was kinda like I was in outskirt somewhere in Germany which was very cool. I ordered chick and pork sausage in tomato sauce with curry powder on top. tomato sauce was nothing special but the sausage was so good, so soft. well it's german .. 
I love the cola they have. it was not coke or Pepsi. just small local cola company in NJ. I love the taste and the sweetness but it's kinda pricey though $3.50/bottle. I had my lunch as the same time as the servers had theirs so they had their lunch on the table next to my table. overall, I give 4 star for food, drink and their casual style.
author: Sansiri S.

description: The definition of comfort food.  I lived in Germany for a while and the food here very much reminded me of being there.  Delicious schnitzel, potatoes, sausage, everything.
author: JJ M.

description:
I lived in Germany for a year many years ago. I stumbled on this restaurant while walking around one of my favorite areas of this city--Hayes Valley. This restaurant added to the charm of this area.
The exterior of the small place looked very quaint, including a very nice antique sign on the side of the building. Once inside, I instantly felt transported back in time to the few months that I had spent in wonderful Bavaria in the 70's.
Not only was the decor authentic German, rough-hewn and farm-like , but as an artist I was mesmerized by the funky hanging things--like ceramic dwarfs, birds, musical instruments, etc. hanging from the ceiling!!--wow! What an installation.
The spatzle was very authentic, and being a veggie now, I had that with a salad--the rest of the menu was for carnivores. I did try my son's wurst--a very tiny piece, just to see if I missed it--the verdict..YES!!! I did! Not only was I upset that I became a vegetarian, yeah, right... but it tasted JUST like the wursts that I experienced while living in Germany.
The girls sitting at our table also raved about the food, as well.This restaurant is TOTALLY German--with it's authentic fare, communal farm tables, and bier, bier bier and more bier! BURP!
I was expecting the feathered hats mit Leiderhosen and dirndl skirts to come waltzing in at any moment.
YODEL--A+ -- EAT --OH!
author: Maura B.

description: Fun atmosphere and good German food in the heart of San Francisco, what else do you need? The dumpling stuffed chicken was insane and the mulled drinks are really yummy.
author: Don C.

description: Authentic German food with casual setting. Be prepared for a long line and to take your own table.
author: sherry g.

description:
I have yet to eat here but it reminded me of the Hofrau house in Munchin.  
Dont  forget to order the da boot.
Prost!
author: a a.
