description: Love coming here during Oktoberfest, but their food never disappoints regardless of the time of year. And who doesn't love a boot of beer?? Try the grilled lamb chops with truffle butter! Melts in your mouth. But honestly, the sides did it for me...brussel sprouts and mashed potatoes. Yummy! Grab a group and go already! Make reservations early because you could be waiting 1-2 hrs in the SF cold.
author: Evie B.

description: Hey fellow yelpers! This place is hands down the best German food I've ever had. It even has beat German food in Germany. There schnitzel is amazing especially if you get it with spatzle instead of potatoes. The staff are amazing and so friendly. Because I do come here a lot we have gotten to know the staff and they are always kind and ask us about previous things we had talked about. They also bring us cake on our birthday. There green salad with potatoes, butter lettuce, beets, cabbage, and carrots is amazing! I never liked pickled cabbage or beets but it is amazing. Sometimes I just come for the salad. The decor is also very rugged and artsy. I would definitely recommend this to all my friends. I also recomend their beer garden a few blocks away
author: Stella L.

description:
I've been here twice and each time I've had a really good meal. Compared to most German restaurants this is an understated place without the seemingly-requisite German kitsch scattered across the walls. Here, the food is the star not the bar or beer selection. 

As always,  I had the Wienerschnitzel with sides of Spaetzle and Red Cabbage. While none of the food items inidivually were  of "best ever' quality" they were of extremely high quality. As such, it's a place I look forward to goign to whenever I'm in SF. If I lived remotely close to Suppenküche I would definitely be a regular. 

They are a busy restaurant so I would recommend a reservation if possible. Both times i've been I had to wait to be seated.
author: Flinch B.

description:
things to know:

-the seating is very communal so don't come here for private conversations.  i believe there is only one table for two in the back. 
-it's very loud and lively
-avg entree is about +$15
-the portions are huge, enough to make two meals out of. 
-schnitzel was 2 pieces of pork, very light and crispy, about the size of my plate.
-potato pancakes are like super thin potato hash browns.   very very crunchy and reminds me of those pikniks in a can (but better of course.)
author: Josie M.

description:
So, I am actually German. Once in a blue moon I fancy some authentic German meatfeast and am too lazy to cook it myself. 
I tried Suppenkueche (German for "soup kitchen") and here's the official German verdict:

First of all, they dont take reservations for parties of less than 6 people. Dont assume (wrongly) that that means you ll get a table for two easily, because you wont. We had our names put on the waiting list with expected time to seating of 30 minutes. The restaurant is super crouded and very loud and definately not a place to have a quiet drink or a quiet anything.
We got seated after 30 minutes and had to pretty much scream to make conversation. Authentic so far :-)
Then we ordered the starters. Onion soup (Zwiebelsuppe) for my friend and potato pancakes with apple sauce (Reibekuchen) for me.
HUGE protions for under 10$ each. Wow. We were both pretty much stuffed after our great tasting appetisers. The pancakes were only lukewarm but super crispy and delicious and the onion soup was a concoction of rich, hearty awesomeness.
Then the main course. My friend ordered the "spaetzle" (gnocci like cheesy pasta) and I had the meatloaf (falscher hase). Both was very satisfying and plentiful. I recommend to share a starter and maybe even a maindish between two people. Its loads.
Then the absolute highlight of the evening. The black forest gateau (schwarzwaelder kirsch torte). Wow. Thats pretty much as good as my Mom makes it. Creamy, light tasting, chocolate-cherry magic. Definately a must try. Save room!
Overall we got a lot of food at a very reasonable price. An enjoyable experience! And pretty authentic too.
Two thumbs up!
author: Sandra T.

description:
I cannot say enough good things about Suppenkuche.  If I could celebrate every occasion here with close friends. . . I would die a happy and beer-bloated man. 

Great crowd, people looking to chow down on good German food and pass around boots and 3L's of the finest doppelbocks, marzens, and dunkels.  Most of the time we come to SK, we reserve a table ahead of time for ten in the back room (otherwise you need to put your name down and wait 1-2 hours).  The food is fantastic. . . try the shredded pork. . . I think it only comes out on Thursdays and Fridays?

This place is often packed, so be prepared for the long wait and a rowdy crowd on certain nights.  Glad to have this as a neighborhood tap for a quick beer as well.
author: E L.

description: If you like communal tables and loud environments, this is the place to go. Where Gourmet meets dive bars, this restaurant give you the gourmet feeling with amazing beer on tap.  The wait is long but worth it. Nice "bar" setting but dark and small bar, felt squished but you know that it'll be crowded walking in. So no hard feelings
author: Tipay C.

description: This place is pure love!  The atmosphere is relaxed and though people are drinking and enjoying themselves, it has never been rowdy, either times i've went.  The food was delicious, chopped up pancakes with delicious apple sauce and plum compote and the portabella mushroom (which they kindly substituted cheeses) - pure joy.  Absolutely lovely staff both times and prices are in cheaper mid-range.  Draws family + low-key locals and out of towners, never obnoxious.  Go here now.
author: Tim D.

description: Come for the food, stay for the beer. Good atmosphere, crowded, but the food is amazing. Wild boar was soooooooo good and I wanted to eat everyones food around me. Can not wait to come back. Loud and fun.
author: Craig S.

description:
food is great , serves crap , very poorly managed restaurant , run by kids 
again food is great ,and hard to get in :(:(:(
author: matt p.

description:
A little taste of Germany right in Hayes Valley.

Suppenkuche serves authentic German food and beer in a lively atmosphere while playing anything from Michael Jackson to the Cranberries.

Great German beer selection and a cozy little bar area.  

Be prepared to sit with folks you dont know as the staff will max out all spots at a table - with different parties...and watch out for random objects the seem to just float in the air...
author: Ken S.

description:
Update:
Have been back.  Twice.  Still love it.  Still gets 5 stars.  Second time was for brunch, which was actually great considering it was around 1130 and I found that a reasonable time to eat a schnitzel.  Why not?  I went back for brunch a second time and the food is just always great.  I also love the atmosphere.  The staff are so friendly and warm, just like the place itself.  Everything is cozy; the food, the people, the seating, it is like a big comfy fireplace, a place to feel at home in!!




Absolutely delicious.  Would go back in a heartbeat.  Only downside (or positive quality depending on perspective) was that the portions were so big and filling I ate about half of what was there.  Just got to enjoy more the next day.

Love it!
author: Amy H.

description:
Great food, great beers and wines. Nice decor. Most of the other reviews here sum it up pretty well. I went with a Swiss person who grew up with lots of Bavarian food and she found it all authentic and delicious. You've heard about the noise. It's not so bad you can't hear each other, but you ears ring a bit once you finally leave. 

Service was friendly and good (the staff are all nice to look at, too, without the usual attitude of many restaurants). Despite the noise, I'm giving it 5 stars for the delicious food, charming space, and good service. Now I'm off to bed to sleep off my food coma.
author: Mark V.

description:
Oh baby!  Very good and authentic German food in a packed atmosphere with a German draft beer selection I can't imagine is matched anywhere in the Bay Area...  Seriously, per other reviewers, the atmospere makes this place (though the food *is* awesome).  If you have a big party, make a reservation and be prepared to wait.  Oh ya, and you might have to sit with folks you don't know Hofbrau-style.  Awesome!

It's kind of a pain in the butt to wedge yourself in here, but come expecting that and you can weave it into the experience and meet a bunch of new folks.
author: Brett M.

description:
Great beer choices!
Great authentic German food! (Mmmm... venison.)

But, oh-so-noisy.  Fun to go with friends? Yes. But able to converse with friends? No.

But it was fun to watch in stunned silence as the table next to us tried to conquer the BOOT O BEER.
author: Jess S.

description:
This place NEVER disappoints. Whether it's a special dinner when you have visitors in town or a casual early dinner on a Sunday after a bike ride - you can always count on a great service, delicious and incredibly authentic German treats and of course, very good beer. The Erdinger Dunkel is the best!

The atomsphere is casual, but also modern and sophisticated without being the slightest bit pretentious. The location is great too, in the heart of Hayes Valley. 

My only gripe is that I'm SO full after I leave I can barely move! But there's something very satisfying about being full to the brim with tasty german food and beer.

I prefer the atmostphere here to Walzwerk and Schnitzelhaus.
author: Kim M.

description:
Dieter from Sprocket's Would Eat Here!

I would love to go on and on about this wonderful restaurant however if I do I'll be forced to stop writing and run over there to eat!  The service is great, the atmosphere is always upbeat and happy and the beer in a boot is a challenge to drink!

Try anything on the menu and you wont be disappointed.  I personally cant get enough of the potato pancakes served with apple sauce and the Wiener Schnitzel is a meal in itself!

It does get loud here, but drinking beer lowers the volume, so be sure to have a few!

OK. Enough! I'm off to Suppenkuche right now!!!!
author: Chris G.

description:
German food!  Beer by the Mass (litre).

They have a Sunday brunch that I'm going to have to start a club to go to.  Everything I've had here has been excellent.
author: James D.

description:
In a region with an above-average number of good-quality German restaurants that aren't hofbrau houses, Suppenkuche is a good choice for anyone wishing to indulge in Bavarian-style German food (i.e. bratkartoffeln, schnitzel,, etc.).  Having grown up with a German immigrant mother, it's a surprise we didn't go to this place when it first opened.

Sunday brunch is the best value for most of Suppenkuche's menu items (and is my preferred time to go, just out of a hesitation for paying SF prices for what is essentially homestyle food in Bavaria).  One can munch on the brotchen (bread rolls) with jam and butter while waiting for the meal.  If you're really adventurous, try the Grosse fruhstuck (big breakfast) with German coldcuts and a softboiled egg.  Other favorites are the farmer's breakfast, schnitzel, and lieberkase (which occasionally gets overcooked by the kitchen).  If beer at 10 am isn't your thing, wash things down with a apfelsaft schorle (apple juice mixed with sparking water).

I can't speak for dinner, but if you're planning on coming for Sunday brunch, arrive early, as the tables tend to fill up around 11.  Diners share seats at big wooden tables--it's the German way.
author: Oski B.

description:
If there were six stars, I'd happily give them.

I've waited for an hour for a table here. I don't think I can say that about any other place.

When I was 16, I spent a year in Germany (Dresden, to be exact). The year was great, but the food left me a little cold. It was heavy, traditional, the kind of thing you'd eat dutifully at your grandmother's but never something I'd have paid to experience. 

One decade later, we moved to the Bay Area and I was gradually led to Suppenkuche. I had low expectations. But the vibe when I walked in was different--hip, exciting, comfortable, all at the same time. Definitely not your grandmother's restaurant...or was it? All around, people were downing bottles of Underberg, which my German host-grandmother swore by as an after-dinner stomach soother. Hmm...

I'll cut to the chase. The food is fantastic, but the vibe and the beer list contribute considerably. It is not unlike going to a beer tent at a festival--people sharing tables convivially, lots of parties and drinking out of enormous boot-shaped beer glasses, and great plates of warm comfort food.

Because I'm a creature of habit and don't make it up there, I usually order the same thing: Kassler (a cured pork chop that tastes more like ham--comes with a side of real German mustard) with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut (except that I always ask for red cabbage instead). I'm getting hungry just thinking about it. Another winner is the Jaegerschnitzel (schnitzel covered with mushroom sauce) with spaetzle (little South German egg noodles) and a side salad. 

Wash these down with a Koelsch, or a glass of Weizen, or, if you're girly, a Radler (half beer, half Sprite) or a Berliner Weisse mit Waldmeister. You will not make it to dessert.
author: Katie B.

description:
Best German food I've had in the area.  It's far superior to Teske's down in San Jose.  The beer selection is great.  We ended up eating at the bar because the wait seemed like it would take a while, and we got great service from the bar staff.

I had the jaegerschnitzel, which was fantastic.  The chicken was tender, the sauce was great and the schnitzel was cooked to perfection.  Yum.

I also love the decor - everything's very white, and there's high ceilings.  This helps one feel a little bit less like a sardine, because it's PACKED in there.  The vibe of the staff and customers was so pleasant that that didn't bother me at all.

Apparently, drinking 2 liters of beer from a glass boot is the thing to do if you're in college.  I must say that it was amusing to watch a couple groups do it.
author: Scott B.

description:
Suppenkuche's awesome.  I had potato pancakes with apple sauce (I asked for a side of sour cream, also)  And I had venison with cabbage and  spaetzle.  It was good.  A little sinewy, but all good.

Great German beer selection, also.  They have the boot, too!
author: Alex T.

description:
I first heard of this place on the PBS program "Check Please! Bay Area" and thought I HAD to check this out.  Sausage, onions, lamb and other German...things, yes please!

It's been a couple months since my visit, but the flavor of the meatloaf I had is still calling me back.  I especially like the way the dining is set up.  No single small tables assigned to just couples or singles.  If you're a small group, and there's a couple of seats left at somebody's table...that's where you're going.  It's actually kinda cool, you get to meet and socialize with strangers at a restaurant, and it's not as awkward as you think.  It's really quite refreshing in a town that's becoming more and more disengaged with each car horn that honks.

Go for the German delicacies and if you're a drinker, get the boot mug!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
This is pretty much the only german restaurant i'll actually eat a meal at, because the food kicks ass. Not ideal for vegetarians, atkins dieters (just dieters in general, i guess) or people who fear loud noises/crowded places. If you like good beer served in 2 liter boot-shaped pitchers, though, this is your second home. The seating is communal, so you'll probably end up next to an old man or a group of hipsters. They might even try and talk to you, so prepare to be social.

Word of advice: if you want to turn a red meat hater into a strict carnivore, force feed them the braised beef with red cabbage and spaetzle. so tender that theres no need to even chew... just inhale. Only a 7 foot tall german man would be able to finish one of these dishes without help, though, so if you are anything other than that i'd suggest sharing with a friend.
author: A K S.

description:
Best German restaurant in SF, period. 
Simply excellent atmosphere and food. I have been here several times and the menu changes often enough and food is always good tasting. It gets a bit crowded so do not go there for a romantic dinner. I love the feel of the restaurant.
author: Nariman R.

description:
Sometimes you just don't want to eat "healthy". You just want to shove froo-frooey lettuce up someone's nose and just get down with some hearty eatin'. 

Meat and 'taters.What's 'taters Precious? POH-TAY-TOES! And everything else you want to taste before you down that quite tasty beer. 

Great setup. Love the tables, though it does present some challenges when people want to get up. But hey. One love. We're all friends here. Except that guy with the kraut in his beard. He's freakin' me out.
author: John S.

description:
Great brunch, with flawed service.

OK, you're not going to come to this place expecting impeccable service.  

You're coming for some great German food.

Was here for the brunch, and I was suitably impressed by the food - we had the mushroom creme soup, the sausage scramble with cucumber salad, and the pork chop with saurkraut.  All of it was just as wonderful as I've come to expect from this place (it's my third trip to this restaurant in the last 5 years).

But the service was really overwhelmed.  While polite and cheerful to a fault, they forgot our bread, forgot the soup, and took a very, very long time to bring the food to table after it was ready (we sat next to the service window, so it was possible to tell).

I'll go back whenever I can, I love brunch here.  Just be sure to set aside lots of time.
author: Jim D.

description:
There are no words... you must try for yourself.  Personal favorites are 1) potato pancakes with homemade applesauce.
2) halibut with lemon cream sauce (seasonal)
3) jagerschnitzel with spatzel
4) beer (pilsner, I think) with limonata... .soo sooo refreshing
5) gluwein... mulled wine (seasonal)
You can get a boot of beer if in the mood but must leave a 50 deposit (too many dipsh*@s have broken them and they are costly!)
Dining is communal, no reservations are taken, and parking in Hayes is very very difficult... but this Bavarian establishment still get all five stars!  Oh yeah, come HUNGRY!
author: Anne L.

description:
MMMMM Pork chop.

The food and atmosphere are great.  Love the beer and the bartenders even more.

Craig, you rock - especially when you where your Dollywood shirt!
author: Kiki I.

description:
A good place for sure.  I live around the corner and have now been for dinner three times and once for brunch.

The real draw of Suppenkuche is the combination of a good vibe and great beer.  Though good, the food doesn't really warrant the absolutely nutso lines that congregate outside every night.  Though, weirdly, I have never had a problem with seating (mostly had reservations but even walked in with my dad once and we got a seat within a few minutes).  This deserves note.

The food is certainly tasty, but again the food alone is not worthy of the masses that gather outside the door.  I've now had a range of their dishes and have to say that brunch was the most delicious meal I have had there.

Anyway, the vibe is LOUD and fun--a mood certainly helped by the awesome beers they have on tap.  I don't even choose my beer for myself--I just tell the waiter to bring something good and it has always been excellent.

It's not really what I would consider a date place, but really is the perfect spot for a big group dinner.  They put you at a big table and start pouring beer and soon enough you're in a great great mood.

See you there sometime.
author: Stef A.

description:
It was my first time eating German food and I'm glad Suppenkuche popped my cherry.  They serve lots of pork. Lots. I had the breaded pork loin, broccoli soup, and black forest cake for dessert. deeeelish! the rye bread they serve... not so yum, i needed tons of that butter spread, i may have clogged an artery.

Its a definite hipster spot, incredibly loud(perhaps because they serve a lot of beer) and priced in the somewhat reasonable zone, as they  do serve good sized portions, so i think you get your money's worth. 

Overall a fun spot to hang with some buddies.

Eat and be merry!
author: kim l.

description:
I love me some hearty German fare and Oktoberfest beers. Sure, the place gets loud but does it really matter when you're throwing back potato pancakes and boots of beer the size of your head with friends? I think not.


 Make a reservation or you'll be in for a wait!
author: tvham

description:
Great, fresh food, excellent beer selection, fun party atmosphere.
I drank a whole glass boot myself last time i was there.
Try it
author: Chuck D.

description: Awesome place, space is very well utilized, food was great (ravioli was perfectly cook and seasoned, chicken/truffle sausage was amazing served with the best peas I ever had) and last but not least...the service was top notch.  Craig our bartender was not only on top of making the experience awesome but very helpful with recommendations for other great places to go.  Kudos suppenkuche for an awesome dining experience!
author: Jim K.

description: Beer is for breakfast around here, drink or be gone!  i love it, I really wanted the special they had which was roast suckling pig, however, they had just ran out and I was stuck with jaegerschnitzel.  It was pretty good, I really wanted suckling pig, and I'm one of those people that can't get over it.  But I love German beer for brunch and the butter and jams they have are amazing.  Waitstaff are hotty hot hot!  Suckling pig = 5 stars.
author: Matt P.

description: I was starving, so the wait to get a table took a bit of a toll, but it was WELL worth the wait (and completely understandable).  Quality and portions of the food were outstanding.  My wife and I had the venison medallions and the roast chicken.  Easily the best chicken I have ever had.  And that's honestly saying something.  Portion size was excellent.  The staff was very friendly, even though we sat down to eat about 20 minutes before their published closing time (or at least when the kitchen closes).  The beer there is, as you would expect, outstanding and very authentic. I am literally craving the meal two days later.  SO good.
author: Jon P.

description: Our meal was good (especially the potato pancakes), but a bit too heavy for my digestive system. On the plus side, great beer.
author: Christine T.

description:
what's not to love about a hearty meal surrounded by happy patrons with an endless supply of beer? 

sad because i did not try the dunkel, happy because i saw a party taking shots of underberg, and relieved for the wait since yet again i went to dinner still full from lunch.  (though my poor dining mates were starving).  

family style seating, but we got the table to ourselves for the majority of our meal.  the butter served with the bread: delicious.  the potato soup i was kindly allowed to try a sip of: delicious.  my wiener schnitzel: delicious.  the sausage, mashed potatoes, and cucumber salad: delicious.  the pork chop: ham.  yes it tasted like ham, not the loin of  pig. i'm not a big ham fan, but i love pork chops.  a really thick, tender, juicy piece of ham is what you get if you order the pork chop, so choose wisely.  

an excellent and popular choice for sizably portioned german fare.   Guten Appetit!
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
yum yum yummm!  first time i went here i had the german meatballs.  they were soooo delicious!  the gravy was just right, not too thick and not too rich.  i also had the potato pancakes and they were amazing.  the second time i went here i had the sausages.  not as good as the meatballs but still amazing.

this is such a cute place.  the first time we came with some friends from singapore and the second time the table next to us had a couple that just got married and they were still in their wedding clothes.  needless to say, the little romantic in me got all flustered and my heart melted a little bit.

FUN FOR ALL OCCASIONS!!!
author: Loan H.

description:
The food alone here is good.  Not the greatest German food you will ever eat in your life, but good.  What makes this place a big HECK NO in my book:

WAY TOO CROWDED and they take NO RESERVATIONS...
Waiting an hour or two to eat BLOWS...
The set up of the restaurant is HORRIBLE - with the bar in the middle, it's way too loud - never ever come here on a first date (or any date for that matter)...
God forbid they stick you in one of the tables by the door, so you can enjoy your $20 entrees while being pushed, shoved and prodded by the countless masses coming in and out of this place...

There is a lack of amazing German food in this town, we all know that, and Suppenkuche comes closest to being most authentic, but the crowds, noise and potential for getting stuck sitting in the chump seat are all enough reasons I won't be coming back.
author: Amy S.

description: Love this place, makes you feel like you're in a popular restaurant in Germany, excellent traditional dishes and fantastic beer.  It's very hard to get in, go early!
author: A Z.

description:
THE BEST brunch in San Francisco (well, if you can handle the wait)

Their trout is soooo fucking tasty, so is their stuffed portabello and their cheese spatzle!

Their black forest cake is bloody decadent! 

And OMG the beer!!
author: Maddy S.

description: Authentic german food and beer. They have brunch on Sundays.
author: Matthew B.

description: I just can't get over how good my roast suckling pig was.  Crispy on the outside, juicy inside, smothered in a gravy I would like to bathe in.  I love this place, and the only problem is it gets really crowded.  Get a reservation.
author: Paul M.

description:
Solid food. Literally. Suppenkuche offers some of the heaviest food I've eaten in SF. If you're up for potatoes, breaded meat and spatzle all on one plate, then this is definitely the place to go. Oh, and beer too I guess...:)

Food: 
- Potato pancakes- crispy on the outside, nice and soft on the inside. The apple sauce was a nice complement. Order a plate and split with a group...there's a lot of it! 
- Meatloaf- very very heavy, paired with a side of heavy mashed potatoes. A little bland--I wish there was more sauce on the plate. Flavors were on the bland side.
- Grilled lamb chops- AMAZING. I believe this was a special for the night, but the three lamb chops were cooked nicely and topped with a big ole' slice of truffle butter (YES) and sides of mashed potatoes and brussel sprouts. The lamb + butter combo was sooooo good. The rest of my butter melted on the plate and I def used it as a sauce for my veggies and potatoes...best decision ever.
- Apple strudel- The only complaint I had was that it would've been better if they had heated up the strudel. Other than that, how can you go wrong with ice cream and apple strudel?

I definitely could not frequent Suppenkuche...this is maybe a once every few months type of deal. My heart just wouldn't be able to handle it! 

PS. Get there early or be prepared to wait--they don't take reservations for less than 6 people and it gets crowded quickly!
author: Stefi C.

description: I thought the food was okay but the beer is awesome (price, selection, flavor, and size) and the atmosphere is well... quite a scene.  What a fun place!
author: Ally C.

description:
Love this place!  Beer great, waiters awesome... always packed... 

Food is good, I love the mixed salad... really reminds me of Germany... Lucky me we live close by!
author: J R.

description:
after living in hayes valley for longer than a year, i finally ate at suppenkuche.  i tried to eat here numerous times, but everyone and their mom just had the same idea.  the first thing i learned was that this place is not called (phonetically) SOUP-EN-COOCH, but rather ZOUP-EN-KOO-HEY.  i was starving.

logistics aside, i love this place.  i only had one beer for myself, a hefty half-liter of a marzen beer that hit the spot.  i tried some others, dark and light, but i don't remember the names.  first came out some potato pancakes (but dont call them latkes!).  these were ok, but more like glorified hash browns.  i prefer the jewish style.  i ate a lot cause i was hungry.

next came my dish, which was a celebration of germany to the fullest.  wild boar sausage.  did i mention i was ravenous?  cut some wild boar sausage, which was swimming in its own juices, and dip in some spicy house mustard.  perfect.  spatzel...the perfect texture and compliment to the sausage.  sauerkraut.  WITH BACON.  and thick pieces too.  how amazing to eat these three together.  absolutely perfect.  i licked the plate.  i believe i was hungry.

i went to three twins for dessert and bought a pint of lemon cookie.  i know that has nothing to do with the restaurant, but i advise you to do this, considering that it is the perfect finish to a meal here.
author: Robert S.

description:
Let's call Suppenküche what it is: a busy, loud, energetic place where the German beer flows freely and the food sticks to your ribs (usually). The concept of "soup kitchen" (translating the name from German) is evident in such touches as wooden communal tables and simple menus. The wall and ceiling decor is something else, though, and has to be experienced for yourself.

Every time I've been to Suppenküche, it's been busy, even on a Monday night. Keep that in mind if you are aiming to bring your posse for some Weihenstephaner Hefeweissebier and schnitzel. There's a little alcove off the bar area that can be handy for 2-3 people to eat in or just wait for a table while drinking some Korbinian.

The beer menu covers all the German styles, from Hefeweizen to Märzen to bocks (with the exception of, perhaps, Roggenbier, but then that one is pretty rare). Last time I had a good Höfbrau Helles and my dining companion, Melanie N., opted for Mahr's Weiss Bock, which was delicious, if a bit yeasty. As much as I enjoy German beer, I can't necessarily say the same about German food. I mean, most of it is meat and potatoes and cabbage - or spätzle, I guess - in various permutations. Great, if that's what you're after, and perhaps my experience is limited, but I haven't had any adventurous or fusion styles in German restaurants here. Suppenküche doesn't help in that regard. While its standbys like schnitzel (both pork and veal) are decent, the potato pancakes we got last time were terribly overfried, for example. All in all, I won't hesitate to come back here as a part of a group dinner, but it's not about to be my regular dining place.
author: Andrei Z.

description:
One could never go wrong with German beer. But I gotta say, the people work there makes all the difference in the world in terms of how your experience would go.

DO NOT EVER GO WITHOUT A RESERVATION ON THE WEEKEND. Repeat after me, NO RESERVATION = NO TABLE FOR AT LEAST 2 HOURS. This happened to me and friends and it was unpleasant. But the again, I wouldn't want to be the hostess dealing with unhappy waiting people. Props to her for handling everything. But making me wait until 9:30 to see if I could be put on the waiting list? O PLEASE.. NO!

Well, how my night rolled out wasn't great. But bartenders are really nice and they are quite knowledgeable of their beer. No, I am not kidding. I have been to a German restaurant where their own workers don't even know how to pronounce half of their things on the menu. that's an offense cause I didn't come to the fatherland to not receive the full treatment. know your beer!

I would come back, on a weekday or at least with a reservation. Didn't get to try their food so I wouldn't know. But I really enjoy the ambiance and it's not the beer goggle that is talking.
author: Chen N.

description: I'm not a fan of German food, period. Spaetzle was sorta tasty, but after awhile I got tired of the taste. Portions are way to large. I don't really care for beer. So this was probably a bad choice on my part. If you like German food, I hear this is nearly as good as it gets in the city.
author: L R.

description: I lived in Germany for almost three years and had a lot of opportunities to sample delicious food while living there. When I came back to the States I was really disappointed at the lack of good german food. Frankly the German food in the US is garbage. Thankfully a coworker from Germany turned me on to this place a few years ago. She said it was the best she'd had outside of home. I couldn't agree more. The food is beyond delicious and the assortments of German brews to accompany the meal is equally as good. The understated location can be a bit difficult to find, but its all fun and delicious food on the inside. It's usually pretty packed, so be prepared to cram up against the bar and order a beer while you wait to share a table with some other diners. This place is a treat and one of my all-time favorites. I hope you'll check it out.
author: Jaymes C.

description:
It was on the second or third trip to Suppenkueche that I began to see the influence that German food has what here is called "Comfort Food".  It's a great place to eat on one of those cold and foggy SF days...Just think of the Cheese Spatzle in Onion Butter Sauce as Mac 'n' Cheese, or order the Meatloaf with Bacon and Egg (Falscher Hase) and it's like you've been transported to a small German town in the Midwest. Or, if you still can't stand to think about what those Red States did in the last election, it's also just as easy to imagine that you're hanging out in a pub in somewhere in Munich.  

Suppenkueche is also a great place to go and drink beer on a hot day....Their selection is huge, and thier largest size comes in a mug shaped like a boot, filled to the brim.  It's good for sharing with close friends, or someone you've just met (the seating is Euro-style...If it's busy, you share tables).  

This is a great experience that shouldn't be missed.
author: Peter Z.

description:
If they don't screw up your order, the place is good for brunch, good comfort food.  The Emperor's Pancakes are tasty, as are their bratwurst.

Their coffee sucks.  Sometimes the place feels a little dirty.
author: marie m.

description:
I went here with a group, I don't remember exactly what I had, but I remember I didn't reallly enjoy it, and nothing that anyone else had looked all that great either.  Not that the quality was bad, just that the style of food was not appealing to me, way to greasy and meaty german-style. 

My Opa and Oma will probably turn over in their graves for this, but I'm just not a fan of the German cusine. other than that it was a nice place small and cozy (which can also mean cramped if you like your space), and good service.
author: C D.

description:
This place rocks my socks, seriously.
I don't know why it wasn't my first review, but I've loved this place ever since I set foot in it in 1999. It reminded me of my time in germany, yet is only about 10 minutes away from my house!
Fabi is freaking awesome too, but the whole staff is always great.
I've been here for several birthdays, and they always deliver.

Sunday Brunch here is just indescribable, you have to go.

BTW, nobody will look at you funny for drinking 2L of beer here, amazing huh?
author: Tom S.

description:
Had it not been for the RIDICULOUS wait we had before being seated, I would have rated them 5 stars.  We were told we couldn't make reservations under 6 people, so we came and waited for a table.  They couldn't guarrantee if we would be seated before the kitchen closed??!!  What??  Then we saw them seat a atable of 4.  Apparently the other 2 in their party "never showed?"

I sampled from everyone's plates, but was extremely satisfied with my Bratwurst and Sauerkraut... yummy.  Had I not been 8 months pregnant I would be reviewing the beers too... looks like I'll have to take another trip!  And yes, I would visti again... with a party of 6 of course!!
author: michelle g.

description:
Good German food and beers.  They don't take reservations for parties under 6 people.  You sit at communal tables.  It's a fun time.

Minus two stars for the frenzied host.  It's laughable how they let the night get out of their hands.  The servers, however, are nice.  Ours comped us some delicious potato pancakes.

A place as busy as this should take reservations.  It's totally ridiculous not to.  It's not worth a long wait.
author: Scott W.

description:
I'll get the bad stuff out of the way: it's loud, you will have to wait for a table and when you DO get seated, you'll have to share with others. My experiences with sharing a table has varied widely (from sharing plates, exchanging numbers with newly found neighbors to sullen, mean people glaring at me while I stuff my face) and service can be spotty at best. Why, you ask, do I love this place so much? 

Two words: mashed potatoes. The best you'll ever have. Also, the chicken schnitzel, the cheese spaetzle, the beer!, the potato pancakes, the beer!, the salad (i love you, beets) - really the only thing I don't recommend is the fish. (But you knew that)
author: Hayesvalleygirl ..

description:
PROS:

1.  Reasonably priced German Beer.  YUMMMMY!
2.  Friendly staff.
3.  Good friendly vibe.
4.  Good Food.

Cons:

1.  Always busy and crowded
2   No drunk, young, German women looking for Americans!
author: Justin C.

description:
Awesome, Awesome, Awesome!

I've been here a few times and always have a hard time waiting to go again. I want to go everyday! I went with two friends last time, and we drank a few liters at the bar waiting for a table, then we got a 5 liter mega mug of beer, then finished it off with the 2 liter boot! We had over two gallons of beer, and the tons of great food. The potato pancakes, weinerschnitzle, brautwarst, and meatloaf are excellent. I haven't had anything else on the menu yet because I can't stop eating the listed above! Cant wait to try the rest that they have to offer. The communal tables are tons of fun, especially when you get to show off how much beer you can drink! HAHA! Service is always great and super friendly. See you in a few days Suppenkuche! 

P.S. I have been there sober and its still awesome!
author: clint e.

description:
Two words: pickled herring.    

Everyone is seated at large tables with long wooden benches no matter how large your party.   Often you end up sharing a table with others, which makes for a good atmosphere but be sure to ask the host not to seat you next to the crowd of "bears" that just walked in the door.   

Unless that is your thing. 

Not that there is anything wrong with that.
author: Jim Z.

description:
I know only how to congigate one verb in German: drank
trank
getrnk
betrunken

At Suppenkuche You can drink beer out of a huge glass boot.   Germans know how to drink, eat and socialize.  The seating is on picnic style tables.  You'll most likely be seating with people you don't know, which is a bonus if you like to make friends.  

Generally there is a wait of about an hour.  Grab a beer at the bar (try the Pilsner!) and time will fly like an arrow.
author: Jay B.

description:
I've been an enormous fan of Walzwerk for a long time and had somehow avoided trying Suppenkuche, but hey, it's in my new 'hood so I had to wander down the hill and check it out.

Only brunch so far, but the food really was good. And a perfect match for the crap it's foggy do I really want to go out brunch days. Although it was hot and sunny when I went. But you get the idea.

Anyway. It can't match Walzwerk in atmosphere and the waitstaff are clearly less German - the authenticity feels ratcheted down a notch, and the whole thing more like a business than hanging out with friends eating great food (a la Walzwerk), but I certainly won't be complaining when I find myself sharing a communal table there again.
author: Joe D.

description:
I went with a German friend who said this place cooks up some good, authentic German food. The dishes were delicious, and the type of food that's heavy, filling and sticks to your ribs! You'll quickly fall into a food coma afterwards. I was also introduced to my newest love of a beer drink--the radler which is basically half a beer with half lemonade or 7Up. It's more authentic when lemonade is used. Mmmmm, I can drink that stuff like koolaid.

Anyway, I loved the tavern-y feel of the place and the communal tables. It brought back memories of vacation time spent in Austria. Ok, so it wasn't Germany, but close enough.
author: Fern D.

description:
Just went there for my first time with a group of friends for my birthday-- none of us had been there before, and all of us vowed to return again soon.  The food was filling and delicious, the atmosphere was simple but warm (and gave me ideas on how to decorate my apartment) , there was an amazing selection of beers, and there is nothing quite like drinking one of these beers out of a boot.  A boot!

Everything I tried was delicious... the spatzel , the meatloaf, the schnitzel... i can't even pronounce or spell the things I tried but I can't wait to try more! I can see this place becoming a favorite.  But be warned-- the food is heavy and you will definitely have leftovers so you can relish in the flavors again the next day at lunch. What a treat!
author: Carley A.

description:
This place provided the solid German fare I was hoping for.  Ja.

I had the jagerschnitzel with spatzel and salad.  Pork schnitzel with mushroom sauce.  It was delicious.  Spatzel is a bit boring- always has been and always will be for me.  But the schnitzel was really nice.  And the beer selection is sumptuous.  

Our server not only spoke German but he was adorably charming.  Fantastic service.  If anyone wants to know- he is on monday nights and shaves his head.  

Oh and the potato pancakes.  Thank you Suppenkuche.  Oddly enough, my potato pancakes addiction began at IHOP.  (What do you want?  I grew up in an LA suburb.)  IHOP has since retired that menu item (along with the only other reason I went there- buckwheat pancakes) and I have not had my fix since.  I loooooooooooved real german ones from real german restaurant.  So savory.
author: Staci M.

description:
Let's get it out of the way early. This is one fugly place. There. Now...the night I recently went it was pretty damn chilly outside. The place was packed and I was seated near the door. Every time the door opened, I got chilled. Sucked. Okay...bitching session over. Onto the food and beer.

This is a place to go for food and beer and everything else be damned. I started off with a Marzen and naturally it was great. Every beer gets its own stein type. Didn't much matter to me since mine was empty pretty quickly. After being shown to our table I went with the potato soup, hoping to keep the chill from the open door manageable (sorry, I did say I was done bitching). The soup was hot and hearty. Yum...not too salty and good consistency. Next up was entree.

For my main I ordered the Sauteed Venison Medallions in Red Wine Plum Sauce with Red Cabbage and Sptzl. Really good. Just like somebody's grandma used to make. Comfort food from the fatherland. The meat was cooked a bit rare as I like it and was very tender.  Sptzl was a bit bland but it was Sptzl. Everything was good. The service was excellent and the waitress was very cute.

3.5 stars but could be 4 in better weather.
author: Gary C.

description:
Why didn't anyone tell me there was a German beer hall in Hayes Valley? This place is great - they even worked hard to find something that fit my "Bud Light" palate. The atmosphere was wonderfully communal which is not something I've experienced much in San Francisco.

Food was good but very heavy. I could have eaten the potato pancakes and left it at that, but the beer interferred with my good judgement and I also ended up ordering the Cheese Sptzle. Tasty but to be honest I could only take a few bites because I was so full.

I'll be back for Brunch which I've heard is fantastic.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Thank you for being and staying authentic and not "californiazing" the German cuisine so authentic for the area I was born and grew up in; The good old "Schwoabalaendle"! 
I feel like a little kid just before christmas with a smile on my face when the Jaegerschnitzel arrives. 
The food here is consistently yummy, so good for your soul and the beer selection is amazing. My favorite, which I can't seem to get anywhere else: the Koestrizer! A nice black beer, but not too heavy, so there is still room for food ;-) 
The atmosphere is that of a German beergarden, except it's not a garden...  
Not a romantic spot, since it can get quite loud. 
To sum it up, this place makes me feel like home and the food makes my belly smile.
author: Sandra Sky H.

description:
I am German, and let me tell you, this is the best German food I have ever had outside of Germany. Or outside of my Mutti's kitchen. 

Try the Jaegerschnitzel. Try any of the beers. Come for brunch-- it is FANTASTIC. Do not bother to go to any other German restaurant in the city (or the greater Bay Area for that matter). Not that we had a wide variety to choose from or anything, but still. Suppenkuche is owned by a true Bavarian who knows extremely well how to prepare the classics. If you love German food, you will love this place. If you have never tried German food, you will love this place. If your have never liked German food, YOU WILL LOVE THIS PLACE. 

Seriously.
author: Kristina H.

description:
I always tell myself I'm going to get something different but I never do, the Spaetzle is just TOO GOOD. I dream about that stuff. It's a little like mac and cheese but with Swiss, nutmeg and sweet onions that make it almost desert-y. Delicious.

I've also had the side dishes of course, the mashed potatoes are just slightly garlicky and slightly buttery, not overpowering and the red cabbage is an old German standby that I cannot live without.

The bar serves several national beers (German national, of course) and the bartender is pretty on spot. You're never waiting too long to get your pint slid to you. They also serve it in in boots if you ask. They require a $50 deposit, which you get back as long as you don't break the boot, which I've been told happens quite often. Don't worry, the staff usually instructs you how to avoid that.

My only issue is that this place is always packed. PACKED. They allow you to wait at the bar but sometimes you're at the bar for an hour or more. It's a small place and its popular, so I guess that's not really their fault. Just load up on beers and wait your turn.
author: Torey B.

description:
My favorite restaurant in the city.

Yes, it is RIDICULOUSLY LOUD on weekends and yes, sometimes it takes two hours to get your spatzle, but the beer selection is awesome and the food is really good.
author: Jeff K.

description:
Yes, it's often crowded.  Yes, people amble around clueless as to where they should stand whilst waiting for a table - and from time to time some chopper will dig his or her elbow/purse/ass/hand/rucksack/knee/crotch/hip into you as you're trying to eat, jostling your schnitzel - but screw it...you can't argue with the food.

Was there last night with some friends and we shared the mixed german salad (beets, potatoes, carrots, more beets, lettuce, something else I couldn't identify) and then the schnitzel, the sausages, and the ham steak.  My god - the ham steak!  I had no idea ham could get so hot.  Every bite was like putting a hog-flavoured sauna into my mouth.  

Always a pleasure, never a chore.  Careful not to fill up on the bread and butter - it's insizzane.
author: David K.

description: I should take a star or two for the breakfast..but I wont because others will like it...what is right about this place is everything else... once you step in the doors you are in Germany- period.
author: Ricote F.

description:
A friend of mine drank the boot last night.  THE BOOT.  Ugh.  I guess it comes down to like four beers, which isn't THAT bad, but still.  I had a nice glass of some German sparkler (I didn't even know they did that) and a couple of Rieslings.  The Weinerschnitzel is as good as always, the skirt steak on special was to die for, and the pork in beer sauce was like German carnitas - nom.  That was everyone else's food though.
I was unfortunate enough to order the butternut squash soup - a fave of mine, though this version was way too sweet.  Nutmeg (and maybe cinnamon or clove too?) OD big time.  Good thing everyone let me eat all of our bread with herb butter to add some savory to it.  And then I thought I'd be "healthy" by NOT getting deep fried meat with a side of dough globs by getting a salad instead.  
Note to diners - the "salad" is a giant plate of side dishes on a piece of butter lettuce, of which I only saw about a quarter inch, poking out from under the mounds of: sauerkraut, pickled cabbage, beets, potato salad and shredded carrot.  And when I say mounds, I mean MOUNDS.  But that's what I get for trying to be good and order a salad at a damn German restaurant, right?
Learn from my mistakes please.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
after 1124 reviews, this one is just another drop in the bucket. just writing so that i'll remember i came here and how damn good it was. this was some hearty german food.

bread dumplings = yes
salmon omelette = ginormous
communal seating = fun
bird/gnome decor = character
giant 6 ft something blonde waitress = scary

my yelp reviews are turning into equations. after watching the old grandpa across the way drinking, i regret not ordering a boot of german beer. but i guess that proves the adage, it's never too early to drink.
author: Jen C.

description:
Dinner on a Saturday night.  Hour wait to be seated?  No problem when there's plenty of good beer and a fun and lively atmosphere to help pass the time.  The bartender was awesome.  He saw the empty glasses and asked what the next drink would be.  When I wasn't sure what I wanted next he let me sample a few to help me make my decision.  

And dinner was totally worth the wait.  Hearty, delicious.  As much as I didn't want to cart around my leftovers around for the rest of my Saturday evening, it was well worth the sacrifice.
author: Frances L.

description: I expected to love this place because of the hype but I thought it was just okay. The pluses: great selection of beer and it's a great location. The negatives: the menu lacked variety, the tables/chairs were kind of uncomfortable and it was very noisy... we were shouting to hear each other across the table.
author: Gina C.

description:
Authentic German food, and I should know. I had my German mom there once, and she concurred. I also had my 10-year old there and he can't wait to go back. Meal sizes are huge. A great selection of beers and Bionade (a German organic lemonade) helps getting everything flushed down. 
Whenever I am there the place is packed and it takes a while to get a seat -- of course, you can hang out at the bar, which can be rather entertaining with the burly bartender. The best part is probably what I call "the dungeon", which is a tiny room behind the bar with barely enough light to see your food. Once your eyes have adapted to the darkness, you may be able to make out the people around you, and there are quite interesting photos on the walls of Bismarck and colleagues. 
Great for people who like crowded, tight, dimly lit places; not so good for people who are intimidated by big, heavy-built, noisy, and beer-drinking guys.
author: Baer B.

description: Haven't been here in a while. But used to be a regular at this place. How can you go wrong with schnitzel and a litre of beer.
author: amit s.

description:
Drove to San Francisco for a dinner with my husband who has spent part of his life in Germany and loves German food. Living in Sacramento we don't have many choices for German food so when we see one elsewhere we give it a try. 

We were very pleased with our meal and experience. Knowing the traditions I was not surprised when we were sat at a table with another couple. If you like a great beer, you will like this place with their great selection of German beers and sizes. The food was unbelievable and just the right portion that you finish your plate, not wanting more and not overstuffed. The flavors mixed for an unforgettable meal. Before the dinner I said I wouldn't be eating the red cabbage because I have never enjoyed it but after tasting a bit I was ready to lick the plate. 

To end the meal we shared a apple strudel. Another unforgettable part of the meal. 

The prices are high compared to our normal dinners out but definitely worth it. The atmosphere was nice and simple. When more people arrived the noise level rose but there was a large party and no place for them except next to our table which was near the bar. 

I look forward to returning to Supperkuche another day and will recommend it to anyone that wants to try something new and delicious.
author: Stacey B.

description:
Really, really good food - had the pork loin with mushroom white sauce and spatzle...wow, I could not stop until plate was empty and shining! Beer is very good as well and I am not a beer person... 
But, oh my, the noise...the noise...takes away the pleasure of having dinner with friends because...you can't communicate with them! 
And it is full, space is not very big, people speak loud, laugh, etc...they have a good time, obviously, that is the good part of it but it is really too noisy and I am not a especially noise sensitive... 
In any instance, food is worth the effort, thank you!
author: VIORICA C.

description:
i love suppenkuche. the atmosphere is very cozy and relaxed. you may be seated at the same table as people you don't know, but i don't mind that. it makes it seem more family style. it can get a bit loud so this might not be the best spot to go for a soft, romantic date scenario, but it's a great place to share some starchy comfort food with a group of friends.

as for the food, the potato pancakes were thick, soft and very flavorful. the apple sauce went really well with them and i'm not usually a fan of salty and sweet together. 

the meatloaf with bacon and egg is a total heartstopper. if you like your food very rich than go for it. the meatloaf is good, a bit of a smoky taste probably from the bacon, but i found it too heavy. 

i highly recommend the german ravioli with mushroom sauce. they are like big doughy pierogis with meat in them, and the sauce is phenomenal. 

the breaded and sauteed porkloin is my favorite thing i've eaten here. i like my food extra salty and this was very much in keeping with that. it tastes like a lighter, juicier veal. 

the bratwurst is very solidly good, but it's not the most exciting thing you can get here. 

i am very curious to try the pretzel. i saw other people get it and it's practically the size of a toddler. i guess they weren't messing around when they called it "giant."
author: Jane P.

description: Would have given 5 stars, but the whole sharing a table thing is weird to me. It was a small table and it is not possible to have a private conversation. I would only go back if I have a group big enough to get our own table. The food was amazing.
author: Emily W.

description: Suppenkueche is amazing. The real star of the show is the food. Get the half chicken if they have it while you're there. The beer is great too, but I know many people in this part of the world are more interested in American Craft beer than imports from Germany. Try this place, you won't regret it.
author: Michael F.

description: Although I am not a big fan of German food, this place is pretty good and pretty authentic... but  still light (not as heavy as the authentic stuff) enough for the health conscious Californian. If you don't have a reservation and want to go at normal eating hours, I probably wouldn't come here any of night of the week. This place totally packs up and wait is forever. I came here with a group of 9 on a Weds night and they waited for 1.5 hours. Most people that come here come in pretty big groups. This place is definitely good for large groups. It's decorated and set up just like a German drinking hall except its 1/100th the size of a genuine one.. hence the wait. They definitely have good drinks here and the atmosphere is really fun... very German... it's even run by Germans.
author: Susan L.

description: Favorite restaurant in the city.  Hands down.  Get ready for a rowdy time.  Whether sitting at the bar, sharing a table with another couple, or with a large party at a long, wooden table...this place is by far my favorite.  Great beer and great food.  Best bet is to get a group of 6+ and make reservations otherwise you are in for an hour or so in wait time (totally worth it, just grab a beer at a bar a few steps away while you wait).
author: Shalina P.

description: We went here for breakfast and loved the atmosphere. The service was really good and the food was awesome! We definitely felt like we were eating lovely German food, however, when we left, Chef J saw that instead of old german men in the kitchen cooking (from our imagination), we saw latinos. Not a bad thing, of course, we were just surprised :)
author: EJ G.

description: If you are looking for an authentic German restaurant / pub, this is your place. They have a great variety of German style beers, draft and bottle. We tried the potato pancakes, meatball special, spatzle, jagerschnitzel, meatloaf, and sauerbraten, even the apple streusel. All was terriffic. The key is to arrive early. We got the last open table at 6:00. By the time we left, it was four deep at the bar with a line for tables. Highly recommended!
author: Dustin H.

description: These guys don't know how to treat customers. I've tried calling about 4 times to make reservations and they say they do not accept reservations and that we can just walk-in. However when we walk in it's complete chaos and they basically said that they can't seat us since they are overwhelmed by the wait-list. They need to find a better way to organize themselves before people stop going here. I'm just done with their nonsense, there's other restaurants in town.
author: Anitha I.

description:
doorbells and sleigh bells and schnitzel with noodles...yes, go here. yes, eat too much and drink WAY too much. yes, your stomach will ache as you shove bite after bite of german fare into your mouth. but how often do you have german food? uh, for me it's about once every 15 years or so. and no, weinerschnitzel does not count. here's how my group's brunch went down:
farmer's omlette: um, i would say this plate consists of about 1/2 a dozen eggs. i am not kidding you.
sauted pork loin with mushroom sauce and spatzle: yummy! this is what i ate. and spatzle is pretty much rolled up pasta noodles that are fried.
and there were other items that were ordered, each delicious and each extremely too large of a portion for one person. 
definitely go here for some great german food, HUGE portions and very cheap prices.
author: mary c.

description: I waited a long time to go to this restaurant and when I finally went I was not impressed. The food was good but not that good. I've had better German food in TEXAS.  The waitress seemed to be bothered by helping me. I asked questions and she looked around as if to say really. My questions were about the menu and the beer. The place was over half way full but was extremely loud.  The servings were plentiful. The beer was typical German temperature. One person who was patrolled the dining area kept asking if I had anything he could take away. I was barely halfway thru my meal and he kept coming back and looking at our table. Go take a coffee or beer break for Pete's sake. I had to waive the waitress down to get another beer. When we did finish our meal our check came as if to say get out. So much for the hype about this place. It's too bad, I really wanted to go back and try their chicken, steak and meatloaf.
author: Traveler 9.

description: I love fried food because I'm a glutton. This place delivers. I had the schnitzel, potato pancakes, and strip steak. I highly recommend the these pancakes, they are fried, fluffy, crispy and well cooked. I tried to sneak in the kitchen to see how they make them, and was kicked out. I was not the first to question there black magic. Nothing can taste so good without some kind of zoodoo. Oh yeah! Don't forget to try the berlinerwizen.
author: Spoke K.

description: I love this place. The food is always. The wait to get a table (which you have to share with other diners) can be brutal. If you go right when they open, you will be ok. I def recommend this place.
author: Ana M.

description: Oh yah, we all know the food is great but this business is pretty much organized thieves.  I came in last week with a group of 5 to eat dinner and drink das boot.  The end bill with 18% gratuity came out to be about $200 or $50 a person.  For the people who had cards, me included, asked the waiter to charge 50 per card.  We get back a receipt showing some shady calculations...$42 and an $8 tax which came out to $50.  Being under the influence of das boot, we signed our lives away.  The next morning, checking my account, I notice a 57.50 charge from Suppenkuche.  I asked my friends who paid with cards and they also had a $57.50 charge taken out.  If it was a mistake, I can forgive.  If it was just one of us, it may be a mistake, but all 3...fuck that.  While its only $7.50, its the principle.  They either wrote in more money or just charged a higher amount from our charges.  If you drink das boot here, make sure you pay cash to avoid headaches with these thieving scoundrels.  Suppenkuche, your food here is good, but your ethics, not so much.
author: Brian V.

description:
Suppenkuche is a great place to go with a group of friends.  

Pros: 
-Awesome atmosphere.
-Great layout.. the benches and decor are fun.
-Food is great (though [to my palate] not amazing).
-Beer selection is fantastic.

Cons:
-Tough to get a table.  You either need to reserve weeks in advance or wait for hours.
author: D G.

description: Why I love this place; Potato pancakes, Cheese Spätzle, Sauerkraut, sausages, and great beer and wine! This place has AMAZING food! And for the businesses of the restaurant, the servers are very attentive and helpful!
author: Andria N.

description: Excellent schnitzel, German beers sold by the liter, communal dining next to complete drunken strangers; what more could you ask for?  I only wish they would add creamed spinach to the menu as a side dish!
author: Hamid J.

description: Came here for the Beer and lively atmosphere, the food here is pretty good too.  I liked their soup with matzah balls in it.  The beer is enough to get you full from the boot.  But save room for the food, its pretty good and I didn't think it was heavy.  This is my first German food experience and I really enjoyed the taste.  The only thing I have to say negative about this place is it gets really packed and it can be a bit of a wait on a crowded weeknight (an hour or more) so be prepared to rub shoulders inside this cozy drunkness lively place and that's after you get lucky and find parking outside.  Might I suggest you drink and be merry while you wait at the bar for seating.
author: Peachie Y.

description: Great food and beer! Fun atmosphere. Loud and rowdy.
author: Henry C.

description:
soooo delicious!!!
spatzel, sauerkraut, and sauerbraten :-) mmmmmmm
and das boot is always a good time ;-)
author: Angela B.

description:
Although we once went there for Labor Day and Suppenkueche was closed, they really deserve these 5 stars.

If a German tells you this is the best German place in the city, you can't really argue and just have to go.This is what I did after my German friend insisted so much this spot is great both for the food and the beer. 

We got there pretty early, but the restaurant was already filled with people drinking at the bar in the very center of the main room or eating  at the big tables all around. The idea is people are mixed up in tables with different customers, which really makes it easy for the atmosphere to get crazy soon. I'm just sorry for the dating couple which had to sit at our tables for a while...I do not really believe this is the right spot for dates, although so many people seem to do it.

I really suggest to try their bottled beers, which are almost impossible to find outside Germany and are really great. If you also strive to brew your own bottled beer like Germans do  (which I still don't really get...) you're on board.
My favourite ones are the Augustiner and the Weihenstephaner Dunkel. Please refrain from ordering Belgian beers - everyone will shout at you. 

As for food, everything was amazing. We first shared their big Vesperplatte, full of various meats (including the blood sausage) and cheeses. Have it with that gorgeous dark bread and you'll feel happy like Heidi up on her mountains (although she was Swiss, anyway...). I then got the Jaegerschnitzel with Mushrooms: the mushroom sauce was really delicate and savory at the same time, and the spaetzle tasted the way only great German grandmas can prepare. The other three friends I was with tried different plates, like the Wiener Schnitzel, the Rehmedaillons and the Grill meat: everyone was supersatisfied.

In the end we had no more space for any dessert, especially after we each drank five among bottles and pints... good excuse to go back!
author: france d.

description:
My biggest fear about moving from NY to SF was that I wouldn't be able to find Reissdorf Kolsch on tap anywhere. Luckily, I found Suppenkuche within a week or two of landing.

Nothing kicks off the weekend like some schnitzel and a kolsch. And these people know their schitzel! Between that, the spaetzle, and their potatoes (with bacon), this tops my list of culinary experiences in the Bay Area. I know that  may sound like a stretch given that we've got places like Gary Danko and Boulevard, but when you combine the food, the beer, the service, and the atmosphere (big, plain wooden tables and bench seating), it doesn't get much better than this. And if you get there early enough on a weekend, there isn't even much of a wait!
author: Jeff P.

description:
I have been loving this place since it opened.  Great, hearty food, etc.  Even my Berliner friends raved!  They also know their beer.
The worst thing about the place is that it's deafening loud. The interior is stark and all the surfaces are hard, no muffle at all.  I love sharing tables with strangers, though.  I've met so many fun folk there.  I avoid Friday and Saturday nights b/c of the crushing crowds, and I have a general "never wait more than 20 minutes" policy.
I still remember a blood sausage I had there a few years ago.  Yum!
author: Rob B.

description:
Being half German and having grown up with some amazing home-made German food (especially from visiting my grandmother in Germany), I can say with some authority that this place has some of the best non-home-cooked German food outside of my second homeland. 

For the most part the dishes are true to their German roots. The potato pancakes are quite good, as are the Spaetzle. For some of the more adventurous eaters, there's usually a venison dish or some other "wild" meat option, which always makes me happy and reminds me of meals in the Black Forest. 

Of course, the typical staples are also present, and you can't go wrong with a Sauerbraten or a Wienerschnitzel (even though it is originally a Viennese dish!). 

Perhaps one of Suppenkueche's best features, however, is the extensive beer selection. They have a great range of German and Belgian beers which is reason enough to visit this place!
author: Peter B.

description:
Good service, great beer, yummy German food. Spatzle is superbly delicious!

Only downside is the noisy crowd. I spent the last half of the dinner shouting "What??" and trying not to get elbowed in the back of the head by people making there way to the bar.

Still,  you can't go wrong with a boot of good German beer.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
Because I grew up in Germany, I was very anxious to try this place.  

The food was good.  The beer was great.   The ambiance of the place is completely overdone and ridiculous.  It's trying way too hard to be Artsy-German.  I'm not a big fan of family style seating.  I often feel obligated to talk to the strangers I'm eating dinner with and I'm not into that. 

But other then that, not a bad place for a good German meal.
author: Susan T.

description:
I've been here soooo many times now. It feels as though it is where my company goes whenever we go somewhere!

I have issues with how loud it is, however it is warming on me. The beers, and the food are wonderful. I love getting a Mab (I dont have the german char for it!) of dark beer. Having been to an authentic Oktoberfest in Barvaria I can say the beers here are top notch.

The portions of food are a really healthy size, and the price is right. Thinking about it is making me hungry!
author: mike o.

description:
Oooh one of my faves! The beer is great and so is the food. I love the food here and everytime there is a special occasion I go there. It is super crowded though and you have to wait a long time to be seated. You often have to share tables with others but that is what you have to do in Germany sometimes so I am ok with it.

The service is always excellent.
author: Anna H.

description:
This place is awesome!  i've been to the area so many times (for huf and frjtz) and never noticed this place right on the corner.  So I originally I came here for a school assignment, but I'm really glad I came here and not some other restaurant.

First of all...beer, beer, BEER!  Believe me, I'm not a beer drinker at all, but this place has really good beer on tap.  I have no idea what I was drinking and felt silly trying to say their names, but everything was really flavorful and smooth.  My favorite was their mixed beer.  It's either a light or dark beer mixed with lemon soda.  Diagnosis: Delicious.  Also, they have a large assortment of glass sizes, including small 0.2L for lightweights like me.  We were lucky to be around when they had their Oktoberfest brews, which were no doubt tasty.  But the thing that really attracted me to this place was Das Boot.  I think I'm going to have to build my tolerance first before i can attempt to conquer this 2L mammoth.

As for the food, everything was very rich and heavy.  I gave this place 4 stars only because I've never really had german food and I have no other references to how it's suppose to taste.  However, my boyfriend said that it's the best german food he's tasted thus far, and I trust him, he's a foodie and a cook.  There wasn't anything that I didn't like.  Well maybe the liver from the appetizer plate, but I don't like liver to start with.  I even liked their apple sauce, and I don't generally like apple sauce.

It's a good place to people watch, too.  Everyone's having fun.  Beware, this isn't a place to take someone on a first date.  It can be cramped and very loud.  It kind of reminded me of vegas clubs, with the restaurant dimly lit with candles and the bar crowded.  I didn't mind it though.  It was fun.

Suppenkuche, you will see me again...and with a boot of your finest in my hand.
author: Katria C.

description:
Love it! 
It's perfect if you weigh 300 lbs since they serve as if you where. 
You could probably could feed off the plate for the next 3 days. Ginormous beer glasses.
author: Sandra M.

description:
I just got back from eating German food at this place and honestly, I just imagined it would be just a bunch of beer or bratwurst. Everything that we had was delicious and there were so many things to try...well, different varieties of a like 10 things. :)

We of course had the free bread, my friend had a nice big mug of Ocktoberfest beer and I had my non-alcoholic beverage of Eden berry Soda, which I must say was pretty good. My friend had the infamous pork knuckles with potatoes and sauerkraut, while I had the meatloaf with sauerkraut on top and mashed potatoes. Out of the two, mine was more flavorful and I thought tasted better, but they were both really good. 

I like this place because of the atmosphere and everyone just seems so happy. Although this is partially due to all the beer on every table, I also liked that the wait staff was really nice and still sober. 

Overall great service, atmosphere and food.
author: Katherine F.

description:
so so delicious.  you definitely have to have your tummy prepared for some large portioned platters and ginormous beers.  if you can handle all of that, you'll love this place.  my absolute favorite dish is the pork loin with mushroom sauce.  if you like heavy creamy mushroom sauce and delicious meat, you'll love it here.

it has such a great ambiance.  it's super crowded which, funnily enough, matches the tone of the place.  the decorations are so lovely as well.  

only downside, i definitely wouldn't recommend this place to vegetarians.  i believe they offer possibly one veggie plate in a sea of meat plates.  

suppenkuche is a true gem.
author: Kristine S.

description: I think that 1445 reviews says it all, but I had to put in my two cents. Excellant food, great atmosphere and service. The Rauchbier (Smokebeer) is quite possibly the greatest I've had.
author: Nicole V.

description: This is probably the only place I will wait hours at to get a table. Probably because I can just sit there and get plastered while I wait! The beer selection reminds me of my good ol' European vacations. The boot is amazing to have if you can stomach 2L of beer. You'll have to leave a CC deposit of $50 to get it though. This place is not too great for a date as it can get boisterous and very loud. The food is absolutely amazing. Giant pretzels and lobster soup are great starters. The schnitzel is amazing as well. You simply can not go wrong here. If you don't like loud places or sharing tables with randoms don't even bother coming as it's pretty standard here. Either way this is prob one of my favorite restaurants in SF. Hurry up and go........Now!
author: Cesar H.

description:
This spot never gets old, it has been open for years and still great ;-)
Super busy but worth it and what i love is the community table concept, sometimes you end up w cool cats next to you and you start a party on your own ;-) I was chocked to see 1 night so many fam with their kids tho!!
author: A D.

description: I have a penchant for this place, and as a vegetarian that doesn't really make sense - though I do love beer.  I like the family style, rustic tables and the Spaetzle is really good.  I've come here with my parents a few times when we visit them in the Bay Area.
author: Laura K.

description: good german beer, super friendly service, awesome food.  this place can't be beat and is now one of my favorite spots in all of SF.
author: Scott K.

description: This place isn't lacking in anything, well maybe one, more space, but the semi cramped accommodations and sharing a table with strangers does add a lot to the luster. The authentic German food is definitely ranked high in my book a plus is almost every side dish comes with bacon or sausage... mmmmm, the incredibly large beers are not only fun to drink but the selection is also top shelf. So go, be prepared to scream to talk to friends, drink a lot of beer, eat a lot of heavy food, and leave smiling. And always order a boot or 2 liter goblet if they don't have the boot, there is something that is over the top fun drinking for such glasses!!
author: Christopher F.

description: Solid German food. Don't be afraid to order the wiener schnitzel with mushrooms, even if it's not on the menu.   Great positive atmosphere but plan to wait.... it's always crowded.  However, they have Sunday brunch, which I did not know until tonight.  They said it's mellow at that time.
author: Mark G.

description: I think maybe I just don't get German places. I know that there is supposed to be appeal in sharing a table with strangers, but it was honestly awkward for us more than anything. One of us got some kind of spatzle and loved it, but the other two were not as pleased. There definitely wasn't a lot to complain about, but nothing particularly stood out for us, either.
author: Zach Y.

description: Communal tables, German style.  Fantastic German food and incredible beer selection.  This is one of the few places that serves rauchbier, which I order everytime.  If you've never been here for brunch, please keep it that way.  I don't like having to wait for a table on a Sunday.
author: Joseph M.

description:
i would totally wait two hours to eat here-even on night's like tonight (st.patrick's day), when it was completely packed, loud as hell (odd the german restaurant is packed on the irish holiday...) and there was a group of obviously confused as to where they were frat boys in green t-shirts with ironic sayings downing the famed "boots of beer" while screaming loudly and throwing each other high fives.  my old lady annoyance all melted away when the lovely bartender slapped down a plate of their delicious potato pancakes and so kindly poured my sad and beer deprived preggo self a pretty damn tasty erdinger non-alcoholic.  hubby and i were able to grab some seats at the bar counters so we were able to forgo waiting for a table, which i would highly recommend as it's all crowded communal seating anyway and those come up much quicker.

can i just say the staff here is incredible?  they are probably one of the busiest restaurants in the city with the least amount of space, and from the host they have diligently trying to find you a table to the bartenders that still manage to be extremely friendly, smile and even offer suggestions when the bar crowd goes three and four people back i think they deserve a seriously big gold star.

*also this restaurant is totally "dad approved".  we have taken both of our pop's here and they have not stopped talking about how delicious it was and how "cool" the interior is.  perfect father's day place!
author: Jessie J.

description:
L and I dropped by for some hearty grub and beer.  Friday nights here are busy, as one might expect, and it was unbelievably loud.  I could hardly hear myself think, much less talk.  If you're expecting a place to have a nice sitdown meal and a good chat in relaxed surroundings, Suppenküche is not the place for you.  

However, Suppenküche *is* the place for you if you're after a well-drawn uber-stein of [insert German beer here] and a hell of a meal.  I ended up quaffing a few liters of Köstritzer, Weihenstephaner Weissbier Helles, and Weltenberger Klöster Oktober-Festbier ... all of which were excellent complements to the melt-in-your-mouth wild boar/spätzle/rotkohl entree.  The boar was tender and perfectly spiced, the spätzle pleasantly al dente and politely out of the way of the bold flavors of the meat, and the rotkohl was almost refreshing in contrast.

All of this was had at very reasonable pricing given the quality. Even though I wish the ambience was a bit less raucous, Suppenküche is well worth a visit.
author: Susuk L.
