description: Yes, yes, yes! This place rocks my world every time I go. I always end up getting the same thing because I'm vegetarian and they only have two different veg entrees, but I don't care. Portobella mushroom stuffed with spinach & feta cheese over pepper sauce.. Muy delicioso! The sauce is incredible and I want to swim in it. Their lentil soup as an appetizer is fantastic as well. The atmosphere is great, loud and always seems to be crowded. The service is friendly and you get to sit at picnic table style wooden benches. I love a good Schwarzbier and here I can get one served in a big sexy boot!  What more could you ask for from a German place?
author: Sarah S.

description: OMG!!! Let me tell you that this place made me sooo happy. I am from Germany..and I mean born and raised then moved here a few years ago. So I know what German food is supposed to taste like and this is it. I had the cheese spatzle with cream sauce and my mom had the salmon filet with mashed potatoes and salad. To wash it down we ordered a Franziskaner beer which was very refreshing and tasty. The food was sooo good!! And yes it did get crowded really fast but c'mon people..its SAN FRANCISCO! Every good hot spot in the city is crowded. GO THERE! Trust me its totally worth the money.
author: Katharina L.

description: Great German food & beer!  Love the loud atmosphere. Reminds me of beer halls in Germany. Community seating which worked just fine for us. Be prepared to wait for a table. We got there at 6 on a Saturday & waited 1.5 hours for a table for 4 people. We just went to a bar down the street & got some drinks. Definitely worth the wait.
author: S M.

description: My group of 5 came here on a Friday night around 6:30, and the wait was 1 hour and 15 minutes.  YIKES.  We decided to wait it out anyway because we had heard such glowing reviews.  (Note: there is no waiting area.  Your options are to stand outside or wander around Hayes Valley and find a bar, which is what we did.)  And it was totally worth it.  The food was FANTASTIC.  They had fresh pretzels served with this delicious, soft buttery cheese, which we named "butter cheese".  Brilliant, I know.  I had the cheese spaetzle.  It was very good and the portion was big.  The beer selection was also really good.  I had a belgian beer that was quite tasty.  Minus one star for the service.  It kind of felt like after taking our orders, our server was MIA.  I will definitely be returning, especially on a cold and rainy day when all I'm in the mood for is passing out after dinner with a massive food coma.
author: Chelsey B.

description: Fuhgeddaboudit! So freakin' good it's not even funny! Schnitzel, bratwurst, spaetzle, bier...skip the wine. Brought my kids so the volume was perfect- cranked up to 11.
author: Robert L.

description: WOW - what a find. Not clear how I did not come accross this place before. Reason being I am not a great fan of German food but I am changing my mind now. I loved it from the minute I walked in. Simple decor of a German village pub, wooden communal tables, party atmosphere throughtout. Very friendly waiters that look like they know all the beers on an expansive German draft / bottle list and make great recommendations. Nuremberg brackwurst slightly sweet tasting that melts in your mouse. prices that do not break your bank.  What else to say? Well deserved 5 stars and I will be back soon
author: Alex k.

description:
This place:
-has GREAT German food & beer
-is an amazing place for Sunday brunch
-designs great t-shirts (buy one, you won't regret it)
-is run by 2 brothers who are creative and genuinely nice

I love telling people to go to Suppenkuche.  I can't say enough positive things about my experiences here.  Deserves each of the 5 stars PLUS some.
author: Nicole S.

description: This place is great.  I've been here twice and loved it both times.  They have a huge selection of amazing beers that always come in their appropriate glasses, which is really cool.  The interior is really fun and most of the time you'll be put at a large communal table.  The food is also really delicious.  The only problem is that it's always packed and you will most likely have to wait a while for a table.  Once, I tried to come here at 8 on a saturday and they wouldn't even be able to get us a table before they closed at 10.
author: Aaron L.

description: Suppenkuche your are one of the most festive and fun restaurants in SF.  The beers are amazing.  The food is some of my favorite ...although in all the years I've come here I've had the bacon wrapped  meatloaf almost every time.  Your bartenders are all charming and don't throw attitude if you can't pronounce the names of the bier properly and are always good for at least one gut busting story with each bier I order.  So why is it you have an annoying waitress on your staff who always throws attitude when you come in a little too close closing time (say around 9).  I brought friends in from out of town and country.   There were 10 of us. But was 9pm and we were  turned away because one of our party was late.  And there was so much empty table space available.  You are so close to perfection Suppenkuche.  The only sourness in your festive place should be the saison not a saucy wench seating your guests.
author: Samir S.

description: Great atmosphere, especially for groups! Can get crowded for dinner so you'll have to be prepared to get chummy with your neighbors.  I'm a vegetarian, so I can't speak for the meat dishes, but the portobello mushroom dish was great.  Get the boot for a festive night out!
author: R P.

description: Fun atmosphere with bench, group-style seating, good beer, and good spaetzl. I didn't love my venison on the first visit, but I'll definitely return to try it again, or order something different.
author: Sally M.

description:
went there the other day and  had a great time!  The food was fantastic and beer selection is a great change from your usual beer choices (corona, heinken, budlight, sam adams).  The food was fantastic. potato pancakes and sauerkraut was awesome.  Loved the whole thing.

note: the entrance is a little funny so just be ready for it.
author: John B.

description: What an extraordinary authentic German restaurant ( ok, maybe a little Americanized and gourmet-icized). The beer "boot" is the most fun I've had drinking with a friend.  Not only is it a built-in game, but the beer itself is great -- lots to choose from on tap. I don't eat too much meat normally, but when I do, I now always hope it tastes as amazing as the venison here. The sauce was so flavorful and really moistened the meat. The spaetzl was also delicious.
author: Carlyn W.

description:
Belly full of Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und grnem and Erdinger

service = good
food = fantacular
price = medium high

Take a hostile or first date here. You new found pals at the shared table will help you break the ice.  Expect to pay about $75 for two if you do it right.  do not get stuck at one of the tables by the door.  The back room is always the best

Love this place. LOVE IT!
author: Garyn W.

description:
Amazing. Great Wiener Schnitzel, sausage and beer!
Service was as good as you'd expect given the place was packed (guess it always is). No complaints here.
Just damn good food in a fun atmosphere.
author: don l.

description:
German you can count on to be there for you.

Great casual restaurant with authentic German food.  The beer selection is large with imported beers hard to find at other establishments.  The community table is great as most of the patrons are chatty and interesting to talk to.

Better to make a reservation than go without.
author: Jenny K.

description:
The food is good, BEER is excellent, but the place gets overly crowded, so it doesn't really feel comfortable.  At the bar, people are basically almost pushing one another just to walk to the other side or get to their table.  Once you're seated, it gets a little better, but not much.

I ordered the cured pork and mash potatoes which was pretty good, but the spatzle was just ok.  

This is probably a place I would go to get buzzed with friends, but not for a date or one of my girl night outs where we want to catch up and relax.
author: susie b.

description:
I was really blown away by this place. The good was great, the portions we great, the staff was friendly and knowledgeable about the beers and wines. I love Riesling, and they had a decent selection to choose from. The vegetarians in our party were a little underwhelmed, but for those of us eating pork, it was wonderful. 

The seating is cramped to say the least, but it adds to the atmosphere of this place. We sat in the backroom so it was much quieter than most yelpers have said. I'd totally come back when we're in town again.
author: Andrea F.

description: I've had the opportunity to try home cooked German food in southern Germany in the country side. For nearly three weeks, I had home cooked meals from various homes, but mainly from my hosts.  Suppenkuche somewhat resemsbles the style from that region.  Its not up to par, but it works.  I would go back.  The jaeger schnitzel at suppenkuche was really different....  my German friends tried it and they didn't like it at all.  Other items were pretty good.  Great beer...
author: Demanding T.

description:
Been here several times, food is alrite. Most dishes reasonably priced, others not. Usually try to go for something different, since I do not believe in paying 15 bucks for some sausage and mashed potatoes. They used to serve salads with the meals, but last time I went there was none - don't know if they forgot or if they no longer do this.
 Please know: this is NOT the place to bring a date, or even anyone for that matter unless you plan on drinking and having to shout to hear eachother. Also I would not suggest coming with less than 3 or 4 other people. The waiters/waitresses do not seem to care much for you unless you are with a large party of people and are interested in drinking copious amounts of beer.
 Such has been my experience. If you want to get drunk and eat some decent German food, and have at least 4 people with you, this is the place. If not, go buy some saurkraut and sausage, cook it yourself at home, and have an equally enjoyable meal minus the deafness and environment of hipster-wannabe's acting drunk and feeling like you're at a frat party.
author: Bonifatius B.

description: Meat, potatoes and beer - all of which are high quality - yum!  A great place to hang out with friends and the staff are really friendly.  I had the skirt steak special, which was super delicious!  It was really tender, marinated to perfection and topped with truffle butter - what more could I ask for?!?!  I love that they have quite an assortment of hefeweisens - my fave beer - and the one I had was absolutely delicious.  I tend to be so-so about beer, but I think I may have found a potential addiction!  Hahaha!
author: Fontane L.

description: Suppenkueche is exactly what it's supposed to be.  I had the potato pancakes for an appetizer and the sauerbraten with spaetzle and cabbage for the main course.  I love meals like this.  The potato pancakes were a little thicker than I am used to, but they were delicious--a must get for every time you (or at least i) ever go there.  I was surprised that the potatoes seemed to be instant (they looked and tasted like the instant ones my grandma used to make)--I won't fault them for that--it tasted like the food I know, which made me happy.  The place was absolutely PACKED--which was both encouraging and sweaty.  I had a great time there and was one of my favorite meals, particularly because I got to eat and drink so much goodness.  The next, and every subsequent trip I ever make to SF, I am going here without a doubt. Prost to Suppenkueche!
author: Rob P.

description: This place is let-out-a-belt-loop good!  And that's exactly what I did with the belt around my dress after eating here.  Bonus points for having my favorite beer (frambois lambic Belgian ale).  My friend and I were lost trying to find the place, but then a stranger gave us directions and told us we would love the place.  We were a little confused when they seated us with other people, but it was part of the atmosphere.  We had the potato soup, roasted butternut squash soup, fried Camembert with parsley and cranberry sauce (amazing!  the cranberry was the perfect touch), potato pancakes with apple sauce, and their bratwurst special.  We would have gotten dessert if we weren't so stuffed and didn't have to make the San Francisco Ballet.  I definitely want to organize a small birthday dinner for a friend here so I have an excuse to come back next week!
author: Alice P.

description: This became a Hayes Valley restaurant crush. First off, we went within an hour of their opening and it was still an hour wait for 3 people. Good sign? Maybe. We ended up going to the place next door to get a drink - Bar Jules, possibly one of the most pretentious places in Hayes Valley, let alone the city, but still enjoyed our bites there. I ordered a pilsner (Raderberger), and one of my comrades ordered a dark beer, and surprisingly I liked hers better!! I ordered the half chicken, and aside from the chicken bone I swallowed was A+, complete with potato pancakes. Really, stunning flavor. The dumpling-stuffing underlay was incredibly flavorful. I kind of wish we had ordered the streudel, but we were so stuffed by the time we left! Delicious!
author: Angela H.

description: Amazing!!! Im really picky when it comes to german food and this place is in my top three german restaurants. Yes, its a little small but aren't most restaurants in sf? I liked the ambience, reminded me of Europe. When i visit sf next time I will have to stop in.
author: Dustin W.

description: Not the worst food, but if you are looking for authentic German do not go here.  First complaints are that the atmosphere is attempting to be German with shared seating but falls short of the true hoffbrau feel.  The potato pancakes are just deep fried hashbrowns, the herring was way too sweet (not to mention where was the herring... two tiny pieces?), and everything was more fusion than true German food.  Perhaps it's just my expectation that let me down, but I guess what would you expect from a SF joint :(.  Makes me sad that we made the trip out to this place.
author: Tadas P.

description: This place is awesome! It is really fun and is lively every day of the week. They have the 'boot' glasses for beer. the bartender (Rusty) is awesome. And ... the food is awesome. Really authentic. Get the sausage and mash or the cheese schnitzel. Yum!!!
author: Laura A.

description: Mmmmm...pretentious. Let's pretend we are German when we are actually just jerks who still don't know how to cook ourselves a meatloaf because we spent all our time spilling beer at mediocre punk rock shows. It's fun to come here and make Hitler jokes though (well, that's fun everywhere). Be prepared to wait a long time for your table unless you are attractive and well dressed.
author: Eggs M.

description: Brats, beer, boots!!    da best german food i've had ever.  be prepared to share the table!!
author: Bing S.

description: I had been supposed to go to Suppenküche ever since I moved to the city. Every attempt was ill-fated: the line was too long, we couldn't get a reservation, plans were cancelled. I thought it wasn't meant to be. Then I went 3 weekends in a row. Let's just say I've had my fill of meat and beer for awhile. I went on a Friday, Saturday and Sunday night. Friday was the busiest - craziness all night. Saturday was not too bad. Sunday was easy to get a table. Food arrives quickly and you aren't made to feel guilty for nursing boots for hours. Those boots pack a punch.
author: Lara C.

description: Great food, my husband LOVES the beer selection. Portions are very large. We get here right at opening and don't have a problem getting seats, but if you get there even 45 mins after opening you might have to wait for 2 hours to sit. You can always drink around the bar though. Great German food and a fun place with friends!
author: Lisa V.

description: This is the most euphoric dining experience I've ever had, in the midst of two groups of barbaric drunk men at a table that seated six. My vegetarian boyfriend and I came in after hearing about an exotic "communal seating arrangement" and were pleasantly surprised by the fantastic variety and enticing specials for the evening. He had cheese spätzle, I had a half-chicken with stuffing and potato pancakes. This place makes German food accessible and fun, and impeccably affordable. It's a bit unhealthy that I live around the corner, as I'll be here often.
author: Peter H.

description:
Best German Beer Selection in San Francisco

Best German Food in America

Best Atmosphere in San Francisco

What else can be said?
author: Dave C.

description:
Suppenkuche is my favorite restaurant in SF, maybe because Im german and love how authentic the food is... and the beer is the best. The vegetarian portobello mushroom with spinach and feta is to die for. It's a lot of fun going with a group of people and sharing the boot glass or the 3 liter! The atmosphere is great and it is always packed with people having a good time. The staff is great. 

The downside... for a party of three or more, you have to wait about 2 hours to get a table on the weekends. The best time to go is during the week before 7pm or on the weekends from 5 to 6. It is also pretty pricey, but definetly worth it!
author: Tina S.

description:
ah, my newest love...GERMAN F00D!!!

i wanted to try german food, so i dragged my booboo here one night.  after a 1O minute wait, we were seated at a table with 3 other people [they do table sharing].  

after a quick look through the menu, we ordered the gravlox with potato pancakes and the german ravioli for appetizers.  for our entrees, booboo ordered the daily special, which was grilled skirt steak with truffle butter and roasted potatoes, while i ordered the wiener schnitzel.

the potato pancakes were AWES0MEEE!!  crunchy golden on the outside, soft and creamy on the inside.  gravlox was equally as good, but you really can`t mess up gravlox LoLx  the german ravioli were good, nothing to really rave about.

my wiener schnitzel was delicious :]  crispy crunchy on the outside, tender and juicy on the inside.  with just a squeeze of lemon, the wiener schnitzel was perfect!

booboo`s grilled skirt steak was the dish that took the cake.  it was tender and sOoOoOoOo flavorful, with the truffle butter melting down the sides...YUMMMM!!  i wanted to steal his food, it was that good!

both our entrees also came with a salad, which was mediocre, and roasted potatoes, which were BOMB!  there were chunks of bacon in the potatoes, and i happen to LOVE anything with bacon...DELiSH!

we also ordered the radler, which was helles beer mixed with lemon soda...very refreshing.

the food was insanely good, and the servers were awesome.  needless to say, we will be back for more.  ^_____________^"
author: Dee W.

description: Great food, good beer and fun communal atmosphere (aka sitting and eating dinner with complete strangers). Had the meatloaf and was perfect comfort food for a rainy Friday night.
author: Donal M.

description: I don't drink beer (and I know that is an important aspect of this restaurant) so I can't comment on that part. But the food and the service here are EXCELLENT. This place is tiny and feels kinda like being in Germany (although never having left North America, this is only an assumption) and it is always packed! I understand why it is so crowded. The food is ridiculously good! I am not very adventurous when it comes to food, but it is hard NOT to like this stuff. The Wiener Schnitzel and Gebratene Forelle are very delicious, but my absolute fave is the Sauerbraten with spatzle. Mmmmmmm.... I think I could eat it every day. Brunch here is also very good.
author: Elise R.

description: The only thing i dont like about this place is that I can't pronounce the name!  But obviously that's not a big deal and doesn't detract from the fact that the food here is awesome and authentic.  I'm a total bruch-aholic and this is one of my favorite places by far.  the mimosas are awesome here (i would recommend just getting a pitcher for the table), and i usually get the bread dumplings which come with eggs, sausages and some potatoes.  the best part is their awesome mustard which is spicy enough to make it the german equivalent of wasabi. if you eat too much, it'll clear your nasal passages! a little will go a long way.  If you prefer a sweeter breakfast, I would recommend the pancakes which comes with some yummy fruit compote. Also, it has good beer, it's well priced and i rarely have to wait too long for a table.
author: Margit H.

description: Perfect weinerschnitzel, perfectly poured Kostritzer Schwartzbier.   Friendly and accommodating bartenders.    As someone who once worked at what is quite possibly the most uptight and least fun German restaurant in the world (Kaiserhof in SD), I have a special appreciation for doing it right!  Love it.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I love this place because it's authentic German food served up in a unique minimalist, curtain across the doorway environment that makes you feel cozy when you are there. Whether you are standing at the bar or sitting at one of the big picnic-style tables, Suppenkuche is just fun. I've been with a group and alone on a date. Both are enjoyable. 

The beer selection is fun to explore and the food is amazing. Keep in mind that the dinner portions are huge! The weiner schnitzel is my favorite. You won't leave hungry. In fact, you may leave a little pained. But in a good way...you just can't stop eating!
author: Dawn L.

description:
Ah, I love their beers!!
I went there for the first time and I was impressed.
Being a beer lover and living in a city,
I cannot believe I haven't been there.

I liked their loud, friendly environment.
I was surprised to be seated with 4 different people in a same table, but all of us got to know, talked and had a great time together.

I only tried one dish and it was good, 
but I cannot wait to try their other foods and drinks from menu.
I totally recommend here if you appreciate good beer, 
probably fun to go with group.
author: Chihiro O.

description:
The food is great, if you order the right thing. The fancier dishes seem to be better. (The venison medallions rock--the Schnitzel was bland and generally not memorable.) They have a great beer selection. The atmosphere is noisy and friendly, with good, cheerful, knowledgeable waiters. I like the communal seating arrangement, although I know its not for everyone.

The negative is a minor snit. . . . The hostess seemed indifferent and mildly annoyed when we showed up. The waiter erased most of the negativity, but we almost left. There are a lot of restaurants out there--when you walk into a noisy one where you have to stand for a while, they should make you feel welcome!
author: Gary B.

description:
I've been hearing about this place forever, and was looking forward to it.
Extremely dissapointed.
Waaay too loud, overpriced, rushed.
The prices aren't that bad, but you don't really get much. The sides are really just cabage, beets, etc. Pork chop was OK, but I can think of half a dozen better in the city easily. But powdered mashed potatoes??? really?? 
The communal seating wasn't bad, nor the atmosphere (although it is loud).
Won't be going back soon. I'd rather eat next door.
author: ryan a.

description: I'm a big fan of this place.  The food is good, the beer is awesome, and the atmosphere is cool.  This place always brings me back to Germany.  It feels as authentic as the restaurants that I've eaten at in good ol Deutschland.  My favorite dish is the Jägerschnitzel.  Yum!!!  I drink a Radler (half beer half lemon juice) with this dish.  This meal in itself brings back a lot of German memories for me.  I love, love, loves it!
author: Dimps I.

description: Came here the other night and it was packed! The wait was an hour and a half! The place was smaller than we thought but it still had a nice ambiance to it. The decor was nice. The food was good. I ordered this meat platter--assorted things like salami, liver pate, cheese, pickles, etc. It was good but there was a lot of it! Meat overload! The German chocolate cake was okay--thought there would be more chocolate to it. Overall it was a okay experience...maybe next time I will try something else...staff was nice and not too overly priced menu.
author: Mel P.

description:
1h40m to get in on Saturday night.  Was really expecting something special. huge disappointment.
Food (1star). bad for price. 4 dishes, 
potato cakes - very good, crispy perfectly browned outside,excellent unique texture and taste inside.    
cured pork - tasted a bit better than spam with cross grill marks.  
braised beef - incredibly dry, has to be the worse braised dish I've ever had in a restaurant. 
breaded fried something - was the best dish of the 3, it was passable.

Maybe it's good as a drinking place
author: Bob D.

description: I'm not the biggest fan of German food, but found Suppenkuche to way exceed my expectations for the genre. The bread and herbed butter were a perfect start to the meal, and I had to be careful not to overdo it.  I ordered the half chicken special as my entree, and it was enormous. I hardly ate half of it and was totally stuffed. The gravy and potato pancakes were the stars of the dish, and I wanted to eat way more than I did. My date had a different special, the bacon one. It was also really good, but I preferred my choice. Also, the hostess was really sweet and sat us with hardly any wait, even on a busy Saturday night! I can't wait to return.
author: Samantha S.

description: The food was very delicious but it's very loud and many people drinking. Not a very family friendly place but good for the price. Not very long wait times, like 15-20 minutes on a busy day. Elegant yet food-filled presentation. I would recommend only going with children who will eat large portions and want to try exotic seeming food. Overall a good place.
author: Jack G.

description: Coming from Europe, I was so happy to have a proper German dinner. All the dishes make sense and are presented as they should be....Can't wait to go there again!
author: Kamila r.

description: Great German food. Great Germen beer. A Great option for brunch, but beware; a nap may be necessary in the immediate aftermath. The spätzle is great!
author: Mo A.

description: Ja, good hearty food with large portions.  Great beer selection, great atmosphere (lively younger crowd), and great servers.    I think it was Dieter from Sprockets.  And no, I didn't touch his monkey.  Get there early to avoid the long wait.
author: Mark M.

description: Excellent Food - We went here on the recommendation of one of our group of diners. The food was excellent, I think the best Sauerbraten I've ever had. While we waited for a table, the bartender was super friendly and chatty. It was a Thursday night, and the place was absolutely packed. The only slight negative was that the service at the table was so-so, and there was a feeling of disinterest on the part of some of the waitstaff. The place was busy. I thought the service and set up (fish for your own utensils out of a mug in the middle of the table) could be a little fancier. Overall, the food and the beer wins out and it is a place worth going to. Did I say that the Spaetzle is super delicious too!?
author: Kerry K.

description:
dude, brawts, beer. good GOODER!!!

strangely enough, i thought of this place as a grown up bucca de bepo, but with good german cuisine. its loud as a mutha fucker in there, you dont want to bring a date, but if you come with the right group of friends, till be a great night out..... 

i digress, right to it. 

the food was pretty damn good. loved the potato pancakes. definately a winner. the meatloaf was damn good, so was the pork and wild boar sauage, LOVED THE pork loin in mushroom sauce....

but be careful with the beers. i had two beers and i got tispy. apparently i cant handle my alcohol that well anymore.... no i didnt order 2 of the five liter beers. you think im some sort of lush? no i order the tiny liter stiens.

DAS BOOT!!!!!
author: Euge L.

description:
Okay so I loved this place until the last time I visited and now I will not go back again.  
The first time I came here was for dinner...everything was very German and very good.  The potato pancakes are an excellent starting choice.  The second, third, and (unfortunately) final time I came here was for boots of beer.  If you want to drink your beer out of a 2 liter boot the bartender will happily oblige you...but dont expect any service or consideration from the hostess or the waitt staff...
the first couple of times my friends and I cane here for boots we were a small group and sat at the bar with no problems.  The last time there were 5 of us looking for a night of drinking and appetizers.  When we arrived we were missing 2 people...i told the hostess we were here for drinks and apps and we wanted a table but were missing a few.  she asked us to wait.  so three of us ordered 4 boots of beer (about $90 worth of drinks) and found 5 seats at the bar.  when our additional guests arrived we sat for a few minutes then moved to the table, and ordered 1 more boot and 2 orders off potato pancakes.  we got our table about 550, 6 oclock, so the bar filled up while we waited for our appetizers.  When they came the waitress asked us what else we would like and we said nothing for now.  She was not happy with this and immediately let us know that we would have to vacate the table when we were done eating our apps...what?  we just spent over $100...and no one told us we had to order entrees to sit down when we came in or when they sat us.  
I got up and went over to the bar...1 seat left.  I talked to the hostess and she said sorry but there wasnt anything she could do.  She wouldnt let us talk to a manager and apparently it was the sole discretion of the waitress to let us sit or make us go....
Normally we would just finish the current beer we each had and leave but we had 4 glasses of 2 liter beer on the table (over 4 beers each)...and to make things worse, we had to put a $50 deposit down for each boot glass (in case it gets broken).  so now we are supposed to go stand at the bar and drink these massive glasses that we have $200 wrapped up in...
When I pointed this out to the hostess she simply said sorry and walked away.  Luckily there were 2 guys at the bar who saw/heard this whole thing and vacated their seats.  The 5 of us spent the next hour polishing off 4 boots in 3 seats in the very crowded bar area.

Like I said I used to love this place but after the way i was treated I will never go back again.
author: Kelesa S.

description:
We came for our friend's birthday, and it was my first time there. I loved the decor, the casual and warm ambiance, and the beer selection. I took a few years of German in high school, and got a thrill seeing that the menu had German as the main language with English as a secondary one. 

We brought a cake with us in a pan, and our server smoothly kept it in the kitchen until it was time for the reveal. The wait staff even found some candles for it, served it in plates then thoughtfully cleaned the pan before returning it to us. 

What a wonderful experience all around.
author: Saket V.

description: Love the suppenkuche!!  it's a lively atmosphere, with good and reliable german cuisine.  i usually just go for the bratwurst and sauerkraut, a german staple, and it always impresses.  the wait staff is also very friendly and nice!  the beer list is great, but be on the look out for the wine list too -- they serve some awesome rieslings.
author: Jesse C.

description: Outside of Germany this is the best German food you'll find.
author: Christina S.

description:
This place makes me miss Germany, loved the brunch and the ambiance here. I want to give this place five stars but I have to come back for dinner and beer for that. The food at brunch was so good, I went with two of my friends so I was able to taste a little of everything I wanted. I had the Kaiserschmarrn mit Afel und Pflaumenmus  (Emperor's pancake with berry compote), I sigh with pleasure...My friend had the savory Roasted Pork Sausages scrambled with Eggs,
Potatoes & Bacon served with a Cucumber Salad while her bf got this sausage served with Spätzle in a "curry" sauce, who knew that Germans could do curry, it was delicious. The tables are set up family style so you can be sitting next to complete strangers but that's ok, the food is so good, coffee is good, and service is excellent. You get yummy biscuits with jam as you sit while you observe the decorations on the wall and ceiling. They had me with the gnomes on the ceiling as well as the option of having beer 10 in the morning. I guess there's nothing better then a little hair of the dog if you needed it. 
I'm planning to come back and sample their dinner fair and absorb the warm and fun atmosphere, I can say that I fell in love with this place like I fell in love with Germany. Danke!
author: Natasha C.

description: We forgot to make reservation and got there around 8:30. They don't take anymore ppl on the waiting list. Luckily, we found some seating by the bar areas. The food and beer were really good. We didn't get a chance to get the Boot. Will definitely have to come back here again and this time, I'll be sure to make reservation!
author: Kaitlyn P.

description:
The food is very good. 
It happened to me several times that they sat me with strangers even though there were plenty of open tables. That was a little awkward. 
It would be great if the waiters were German as in other SF German restaurants.
author: Iphigenie S.

description:
Hit this Schnitzel with my parents, grandma, great grandpa, great uncle, great aunt, cousin - the whole crew.

Great energy kept me fascinated, requiring very little bouncing while the adults ate.  Large wooden tables proved perfect for balancing me on top of and still having room for all those meaty sausage plates.

Food looked good - pork chop juicy and wild boar tender.  The real reason to come here is the beer of course.  I like my Belgians in .2 - .5 liter increments, thanks.

-1 star for no baby changing table.

Sonnenschein ---
auch ihn verteilt der Totengrber
mit der Messschnur
author: Taiyo L.

description:
The atmosphere is casual and everyone sits at family style tables in a simple, yet styled room. The service is friendly and the waiters wear t-shirts, most of them with an airbrushed unicorn and their name on the front. Our waiter was Brian who chewed gum the whole time but had a great smile and was very friendly. 

Dinner was tasty though way too much food. A bit pricey for what it was. Great beer selections. I had the Pickled Herring for an appetizer which was surprisingly sweet. The beef brisket was tasty and had a delicious rich brown sauce. The spaezel on the plate was flavorless but nice when eaten with the sauce on the meat. My dinner companions had the pork chop (rave reviews on this, highly recommended) and the venison (also tasty but not as good as the beef).

Loud, pricey, but fun and filling. Not good for dates.
author: Foodie F.

description:
I don't know who reckoned Suppenkuche was not kid-friendly but we brought our 2 and 9 year olds and they both loved it.  Crayons and coloring book was provided and the food suited the palates also.

Always an SF evening when tables are being cleared for a second serving at 18:30.  And there was an element of the 'hurry-up' offense about how smartly the table was cleared but we really liked the food, the ambience (ambient noise = child friendly) and the beer (last but not least).
author: David O.

description:
Boy, this place is great!!
I had the White Veal sausages with the preztel and it was fantastic.
I'm a fan!!
author: Shawn I.

description: This place needs to expand because it's always crowded, but I can clearly see why!!!  The food is FAN-TAS-TIC!  It's always worth waiting to get a table here.  The portions are big and we always have to take some home.  The staff is great too!
author: Mark T.

description: The food is awesome! The beer selection was very impresive and tasty! Can't say a bad things about Suppenküche, exept that they should expand!
author: ERIC S.

description: I've been here twice and both times the food was great. This is very authentic German food, so much so that I am not sure why it is so popular. Of course the beer selection is outstanding and the big wooden tables are quite cozy. Parking can be difficult and reservations are only for groups and even then hard to get. If you go without a reservation, be prepared for a wait.
author: Johannes G.

description: Family style seating is a beautiful thing.  The person who just stole your parking space is now sitting at your table and you are raising das boot in their honor and sharing a conversation about how sauerkraut is as good as candy (which it is).  The fog parts and all is wonderful in the city of San Francisco.
author: Rachel Z.

description: Dont be intimidated by the name. I have never been to Germany myself, but if I were to imagine, I would think that the experience would be somewhat similar. Maybe I should have some of my German friends validate that for me ;) Ive only been here for brunch, and I found the food to be very hearty. Not a huge fan of beer myself, but if you are I think that would make your case a little bit stronger.
author: Vivek N.

description:
The terrible service makes the mediocre food even worse. 

The beer and schnitzel might be decent but the potato pancakes are deep fried beyond recognition, the cold cut platter looks more like an autopsy, and the less said about the Bavarian 'meatloaf' the better. 

The atmosphere is fun and the communal seating would work a lot better if it wasn't for the sheer volume in the room.

For a more authentic and much, much, much friendlier German experience try Walzwerk on So. Van Ness instead, where you'll get the comfort food without the incompetent service and attitude.
author: Falcon C.

description: So with a restaurant that has 1000 reviews and tons of information already I don't know what I can add which hasn't been said. I was in SF on a business trip and met up with a friend who lived in Hayes Valley. First night in SF we hit up Suppen Küche for a meal. This was actually my second dinner of the night after having a light bite to eat with my boss at the hotel. Even though I was pretty full from dinner #1 that didn't stop me from being completely devouring every last morsel of my Bratwurst, mashed potates, and sauerkraut. The food was hearty, delcious, and went down amazingly well with my stein of dark German Köstritzer Schwarzbier. It had to be good considering I was already full from that earlier meal! The tables are communal the atmosphere feels like a big loud party and there was hail storm going outside during dinner in beginning of March. So it was a yummy memorable dinner.
author: Felipe G.

description: Went here a while ago, and we had a nice time.  Kinda weird sitting with strangers (esp for a 3rd date...we should try it again now that its been 10 months).  Food is yummy and hearty.  We weren't thrilled with our potato pancake so the waiter took it off the check.  I think it was a bit burnt...I'll try it again next time.
author: Maureen K.

description: Besides for the long waiting time and crowded space [I was almost spilled food on], Suppenkuche is a great place for a large group of people. Their selection of food is great and their appetizers are wonderful for sharing. We really liked the chicken meal and found that many of their portions are shareable. Plus, they give out a shot of Jager+something digestive to the birthday person. It was a fun time with boots of beer all around, just make sure you aren't counting on spending much time at the very crowded bar beforehand.
author: Neha T.

description: Suppenküche made a delicious brunch on a weekend morning.  For some reason I was attracted to the Leberkäse - a kind of tepid, smoked animal part meatloaf with an egg on top.  Let's say I won't probably repeat this choice if I am ever in town again.  BUT, even with that, I would definitely return for the delicious beer and atmosphere.  I would like very much to try some other menu items.
author: Stephen S.

description: I have been there a half dozen times, and have yet to have the food. I go for the beer, just the beer. If you love beer, and fun bars, this is the place for you. But be ready for a crowd. It honestly doesn't matter the day of the week, the place will be wall-to-wall people. However, it's always a good time and the atmosphere is super laid back.
author: Josh G.

description:
shame on me.  search for "german food" in the talk threads, and you'll see that i have the very first yelp talk thread in search of german cuisine.  october of 2005.  moreover, i've lived basically across the street from suppenkuche for almost 6mos now.  i walk by it *every* night on my way back from work.  and it took me this long to finally try it out...  yes, shame on me.

a while back in college, i did a 6 month stint in germany.  while there, i developed a bit of a predilection for my "hometown" duesseldorf's signature "altbier" (competitor of neighboring cologne's lighter "koelsch").  suppenkuche carries dussel alt!  uerige!  omgomgomg!  yum!!  and venison!  and spaetzl!  and cabbage!  oh mouthgasm of mouthgasms!!  why didn't i just die and go to heaven after this meal--it was really all i ever needed...??  i'll tell you why.  it's bc i didn't finish my dinner and had to warm it up and eat it for breakfast the next morning.

yes.  yum.
(i realize that this was a singularly unhelpful review, but for the love of god, there're 561 other reviews so i hope at least a smattering of them are of some substance)...
author: Roshni R.

description: finally came here for some grub, and I was not disappointed.....i opted for the potato pancakes and homemade applesauce. oh...my...gosh....instant food coma. I tried some of my friends choices as well, pork sausage spicy mustard with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut....yum! someone else got a pancake that looked great, and apparently was a favorite with all those that tried it. of course, no trip to suppenkuche would be complete without some beers, so i opted for the lighter beer mixed with lemon soda. very refreshing!! I just love the whole vibe of this place, and all the tasty things offered within ;)
author: Caddy M.

description: Wanted to check out my heritage...was quite impressed.   Our waitress was very friendly and knowledgeable about the menu.  She patient to answer all of our questions and made some great recommendations!  I ended up having brunch there and had the german ravioli-different and yummy!  I tried the spazle (spelling?) with the pork chop=awesome!!!  I'm gonna get that the next time.  My mom makes apple pie, German style (thinly sliced apples, cinnamon, sugar with a nice thin, buttery crust)-this was the closest thing to homemade I have ever tasted our here in California.
author: Gee K.

description: das boot!...it was ze greatest beer in all ze vorld!...or just daydreaming of chugging down glass boot...designated driver for the night...no beerfest for self...entrance and crowded...seven pm monday evening...lengthy wait for communal table to share....waiting across nearby pub....occasional visit back to check on status...roughly forty-minute wait and seated...soup and meal the plan.....linsensuppe (lentil soup) with batwurst fantastic start....followed by hefty meatloaf meal or falscher hase mit zwiebelsobe und kartoffelbrei...tasty saucy mound...fine filling meal..."straight to the hips" as one lady would say.....meatloaf choice fine....tasting of other....braised beef too tough....grilled cured pork chop too dry....though wiener schnitzel (breaded porkloin) a salty tasty dish....fine german meal...and peers enjoying beers....self sticking to water....sad....ending filling meal and driving merry bunch home....
author: Hen A.

description: my wife and I ate here last week during our trip to CA. loved it!!! great authentic German food, amazing beer list!! and a great atmosphere. we were in Germany last year for Oktoberfest and this place felt just like it. 5 stars, would go back in a heart beat. (beware, you will share a table with other dinners if they are busy. didn't bother us, but the people we sat with didn't like it.)
author: Ben S.

description: I'm definitely a fan of the great beers and pork sausage, kraut and potato dish.  I've never had a disappointing dish here, but I will say I'm not so keen on sharing the table with random strangers (I haven't had a "fun couple or group yet) and the service is just completely unimpressive.  We went for our first dinner there tonight (I've only been for brunch) and it gets awfully loud.  That said, if you don't mind those issues or a long wait it's worth while for some yummy food and delicious beer!
author: Chrys W.

description: Went for Sunday brunch - my only complaint was the potato pancakes, which were deep fried and quite oily. Authentic food and good service, mostly by Germans. It was not crowded when I visited, but does get packed according to my local connection, apparently especially at night during beer boot service. I'd eat here again. Communal seating at picnic tables and an ever-changing ceiling art display make this a fun place.
author: Kris W.

description:
What a disappointment!!! I've been wanting to go to this restaurant forever and I'll probably wait forever to go there next time. Only if someone forces me with a gun!
My friend and I went there for lunch. They only take reservations for 6 or more so we got there at 11:45 and put ourselves on the list. We were told it takes 30 minutes to get a table. Yeah, yeah, I know, it always takes longer and so it did. After 45-50 minutes or so we were escorted to our table. It was a table for 8 people and 6 people were already sitting there!!! We were offered two lousy chairs in the back of the restaurant at some other people's table. Come on, folks!
My friend ordered a diet coke and we ordered two Jäger Schnitzels. The waitress came back with two waters because they didn't have diet coke. (Why??????????)
We got our food, only one dish. No clue, why  they thought that we wanted only one. We are not the skinniest chicks, all right, and we didn't want to share because we are NOT on a diet. OK??!! (Well, not today anyways ;-)
The biggest kick in the butt was the food, though. It wasn't even close to OK. My galpal said that she thinks the mushroom sauce from Trader Joe's is nicer and i belive her 100%.
This experience kinda ruined my Sunday. They owe me one!!!
author: Oyo S.

description:
I did not have a Yelp account but these guys got on my nerves so badly that I created an account just to write this review. What can I say? I have been to this place 4-5 times and can honestly say that they have a fairly limited selection of decent German food on their menu. Enough said about the food let's move on to their customer service part. 
My family and I just got back from Germany and were craving German food and beers that come with US customer service. You know what I mean by US customer service if you ever been to Europe.  We got there about 30 minutes before they opened and were second in line. By the time they opened there were at least 40 people by their door. Once we got in, we found out that they are not going to sit us since we are missing one person and they consider this party "incomplete".  Conversation with their staff did not start on the good note either. Waitress was disgustingly arrogant from the get go.  When she was talking to me it seemed that she was doing me a favor rather than doing her job. It did not take long for her to start yelling at us which was completely unacceptable. We had no other choice but get up and leave. I have spent most of my life in Bay Area and I have never been treated in such an awful manner at any restaurant. 
In my mind, something like this would never happen if:
1) They would pick up the phone
2) They would sit people with reservations first and then people who waited in line (based on who was in line first) 
3) Expand their premises to more than 7-8 tables where they tend to pack people like sardines

To summarize, I have been extremely disappointed with the way we were treated and if I would have an option to give this place negative 5 stars I would. I am definitely not coming back again and would not recommend this place to my friends. 

Good luck.
author: Alex T.

description:
Watch out.  It could be a hit or miss.
I've personally dined here several times.  Some were great experience, and some were terrible.

The definite pros:
CHEAP BEER. (I think they only have german selections)  
Delicious beer cocktails.
Yummy appetizers.

The definite cons:
You can't make a reservation unless you have a party of 6 or more.
Small dining area, which translates to ridiculous wait time if you go on a crowded night.
There are almost no small tables.  You'll be forced to share a table with another party if you have 2 or 3 people.  A definite problem if you would like some privacy with your date.

Personal Opinion:

Upon walking in, you're greeted with a rather run-down decor and dim lighting.  Along with the beige wood table, they convey the atmosphere of a cottage.   This place is probably better for a group night out rather than a romantic dinner.

Well, my last experience at Suppenkuche was so bad that it forced me to create a yelp account and write a review.

1. The Service.
I love the potato pancakes with apple sauce and that's the one thing I keep going back there for.  Unfortunately, my friend wasn't that hungry that night so we decided to just order entrees.   However, I had a change of heart and told the waitor I would still like to get the appetizer regardless.  The waitor then questioned me, "Are you sure you want the appetizer?  The meal portion is rather huge!  The couple sitting across from you only shared an appetizer and an entree and they are stuffed."  To which I reply, "Yes.  I'm a big eater."  He said that he thought it was going to be too much for us.  I had to reiterate my choice before he went away unwillingly to put our order in.   I do not understand why I almost had to argue to get my food.  Even more ridiculous was that the waitor came back after he put the order in and said "don't blame me if you guys explode later."    Okay, seriously, was that necesary?

Oh, another waitor took my beer glass away without even bothering to ask me if I would like another beer after I finished my first glass.  (which I was going to say "yes, of course")

During the whole course of meal, our waitor didn't bother to come back to our table and asked if we needed anything (some water would have been nice). 

When we finished our meal (by the way, we cleaned the plates - not because it was great, but because we were hungry), we asked for the check, and he then sat down by the table next to us and started talking to another couple for at least 5 minutes, none of which was meal related - just plain chit-chat, before he went to the cashier and gave us the check.  

Unacceptable.


2.  The Food.
Don't be fooled by the name of restaurant.  This place offers very limited selection of soup.

I took a look at the special menu, and decided I would break the norm and try the cornish game hen with stuffed bread dumpling.   

it was an utter disaster.  The chicken lacked flavor and was extremely dry.  The stuffing was also extremely sticky and dry, which made it really hard to swallow.  The vegetables served on the side tasted rather bitter to my liking. I'm not sure if I just got an overcooked hen or that's how they normally serve it.  I'd definitely recommend you not to get this dish.

With all these negative things said, I did have pleasant experience from this place before.

As I mentioned, the potato pancakes with apple sauce is to DIE FOR.
(A bit on the greasy side, but I am a big sucker for fried food)
Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Spatzle and Green Salad is a rather enjoyable plate.  It doesn't look fancy, but it tastes great like a good home-made dinner.



Oh, they don't speak a word of German, so don't bother trying to order in German like my friend did.
author: Danny W.

description:
review # 166. . .

DINNER UPDATE:
I'm in a food induced coma.  Food good.  No wait on Thursday night at 6pm.  Gruner Veltliner good, Sauerbraten fabulous, spaetzle yum, red cabbage dbl dum, apple crazy with fresh cream triple yum.  I need to go lay down...and, the parents loved it.

Went to Suppenkuche for brunch yesterday.  It's Oktoberfest people!  The Oktoberfest 2006 posters are up on the wall.  Stop by for a beer and check them out.

Arrived at 10 am and yes, that is early to get up and out on a Sunday but, we had our pick of tables in the whole place.  There are many reviews complaining about the waiting time for a table, arrive early and you're all set.

We had a really big beer, and mimosa with fresh grapefruit juice which was quite nice.  

For brunch it was the meat loaf with fried egg and potatoes, and the ravioli with scrambled eggs and cucumber salad.  Good stuff!  I imagine everything on this menu is really good as you can't go wrong with German food.  Schnitzel, potatoes, kraut. . .those are always culinary pleasers.

I especially like the ambiance in this place and imagine for dinner it could be very cozy.  Group tables make for an interesting meal.  You never know who you'll be seated with. . .fun!

The last time I ate here was about nine years ago and it's still just as good!

If you're on a healthy eating regimen I say take a meal off and hit up Suppenkuche!  

Gute Zeiten!
author: James M.

description:
I paid a visit to the Suppenkueche (Soup Kitchen) last week and left with a bellyfull of decent food, although not entirely authentic German cooking.  I had the Maultaschen and the Jaegerschnitzel but I could taste the underlying 'american' out of the ingredients and Ja, I was disappointed. 

Sicherlich besser als manch anderer am Ort, aber ich habe auch schon an Deutschen Autobahnraststaetten leckerer gegessen. Nicht unbedingt empfehlenswert.

update:
----------
Just went there again against better judgement and the food sucked again. This time I had the venison medallions and instead of juicy and flavorful I got two BURNT pieces of flavorless meat I could not tell what kind animal it was from. The red cabbage and the Spaetzle were okay but I'm still kind of shocked what they thing passes for venison medaillions. On top of that and what I forgot to point out the other time I wrote the review is you're going to be sitting at the table with strangers if you're less than a party of four and the place is EXTREMELY loud when it fills up.

Werte Mit-Deutsche:

Mal wieder sehr entaeuscht, diesmal war das Essen verbrannt und bei der Schwarzwaelder Kirschtorte wurde dermassen mit der Sahne gegeizt, das ganze ist schon eine ganz schoene Frechheit, Ich nehm mal an die haben eben einen Amerikaner als Koch. Der Vergleich mit einer schlechten Autobahnraststaette hinkt uebrigens ueberhaupt nicht. Die Bierauswahl ist da schon etwas besser, aber wer hier irgendwelche Erwartungen in Bezug auf das Essen hat, der wird bitter enttaeuscht werden. Schade.
author: John G.

description: I've never had German food before coming to this place, and I must say it was pretty delicious. My favorite thing about this restaurant has to be the beer. They have an amazing selection of German beers and I really need to go back to sample the rest. This definitely nears the top of my list on places to have a beer. The next best thing has to be the potato pancakes. DELICIOUS! The place is pretty packed and rowdy; we got there at 5:30pm to have dinner and still had to wait 45 minutes for a table. Regardless, it is still a must-try restaurant in the city.
author: Brent C.

description: I would actually give this 3.5 stars.  The beer selection is really awesome, and reason enough to go.  The food is exactly what it should be, but not anything I would normally eat.- too heavy for my taste.  The service was good and laid back.  Pretty great place all together.
author: Mister G.

description: Instant Mashed Potatoes at a restaurant?  The beer was great and the food was good - but yikes, instant mashed potatoes.  Really?  I'm not sure if there was an issue on the particular day that I went with their potato order or if they always serve instant mashed potatoes.  Wasn't what I was expecting.  Other than that, good experience overall.  However, I prefer Leopolds.
author: hmich M.

description: The food here is perfect. The atmosphere is fun and friendly, and they have some of the most delicious beers I've ever tasted. My only complaint, which isn't much of a complaint at all, is the name of the place... ugh, 1 star.
author: Morgan C.

description: Very nice German food.thd bread was awesome. It has also bank atmosphere of beergarten.
author: Ali E.

description:
GRUB

What's German grub without bratwurst? Well what is German food exactly? I can tell you it's more accurately named Bavarian Cuisine, but you'll have to read about its history on their website at www.suppenkuche.com because this Chinese dude would not do justice to its beginnings. Back to the brats. Jay had a plate of them served with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. This traditional German sausage speaks for itself. Screw your wimpy Oscar Maeyer wieners filled with pigs toes and horse hooves, this is a man's sausage with real meat that's big on taste. As for myself, I had the Sauteed Porkloin in a Mushroom Sauce served with Spatzle & Green Salad. I assumed the mushroom sauce would function to make up for a dry porkloin, but to my surprise it could've been served on its own without the sauce. The pork was not only moist and juicy, but the flavor just left you speechless. I say speechless because after the first bite I kept stuffing my fat face, and was reduced to mumbles and grumbles of affection for the fare. The mouthwatering flavor of the sauce with its variety of mushrooms in a German red reduction made for more pangs of enjoyment. On the side there was Spatzle which is a German egg noodle which is made like pasta except shorter and non-uniform. Upon serving, it is lightly sauteed in butter. This lends to the unique texture of the noodle which I would equate to a savory funnel cake. It also came with a small butter leaf lettuce salad in a light vinaigrette which balanced the meal nicely. But on to the most important side of all, BEER.

BEER

I've come to find that I know squat about beer but am willing to learn. The bartender overloaded me with a bunch of info, and the little I retained is that Suppenkche offers imported beers from several famous German breweries that aren't easy to get on tap. And these beers are so strong that a place like BevMo would categorize most of them as malt liquor. Hell, if you have a holiday centered around beer (Oktoberfest), you've got to be one of the best at making the stuff. I had a Hefeweizen Dark. Yep, a dark unfiltered wheat beer. No lemon for this bad boy, the taste of this dark but crisp beer stands on its own. The bartender also hooked us up with a few tastes of other beers. I got a half liter, but they serve beer in an assortment of sizes going on upwards to 1 liter mug, a 2 liter boot, or the gigantic 5 liter mug. 

SERVICE

Since I sat at the bar, I got service from the bartender, Aaron, who was awesome. I hear the service overall is really good and friendly no matter where you park your fat ass. As I said, the bartender gave us the inside on the beers and a few samplings as well. He even gave Jay about a 6-8oz. sample of a beer on the house since he was drinking an iced tea initially (what a pansy!). And the thing that really got me was the lengths they go to to take care of you. The deal was that I left my Oakleys on the bar when I left. Jay and I got down about a block, when I hear this thumping approaching. It was Aaron running down the block to catch up to us to give me back my glasses. Now mind you this guy looks like one of those angry Euros that could rip your head off in a bar fight. It was just slightly weird for that reason, but very much appreciated.

ATMOSPHERE

The friendly service is what personifies this place. Traditionally (okay, I will include some history) this type of food was offered at the middle aged monasteries which were not only places of meditation and study, but also a place of shelter and food for travelers. This restaurant definitely continues the "age-old tradition of gathering among friends in a place that is safe and warm." Although plain white walls and unfinished tables and chairs give a dull look, you soon get the feel of the richness of the tradition which the cuisine was based on. 

And if you happen to drop by, sit up at the bar where you get a great view of the establishment as well as a look at the fine selection of German brews on tap. Be sure to look for Aaron. He's gotta be the friendliest man sober, and I suspect a man you want on your side when he's drunk. I swear, us stupid fat Americans have beer bellies, whereas them Euros have beer arms. CHEERS!
author: Al L.

description:
fantastic beers on tap. i went with a couple of pilsners (konig, and bitburger). food was great. we started off with potatoe pancakes with apple sauce as a starter. they were crunchy and delicious and not greasy. i ordered the sauteed pork loin in mushroom sauce served with Spatzle. this meal was awesome - hearty, tasty, and total comfort food. 

the only knock on this place is that you have to share tables with other patrons. also, this place is crowded beyond belief and there are always people bumping into you. it's also super loud. however, these things aren't annoying enough to keep me away from coming back.
author: James J.

description:
boo hiss. maybe i've hear too many rave reviews of this place, it's like when you finally go see that movie that all your friends insist was the funniest thing ever and you leave saying "the 40 year old virgin? really?"

sad that schnitzelhaus was closed for the holiday, we ambled over to hayes valley for a hearty meat, starch and beer fix. the place was just on the cusp of busy, so it seemed like a good bet.

the table we were placed at already had a couple at one end, guarding their food as if they were starving prisoners - i think one snarled when i smiled at them on the approach. they had the table completely pressed against the what can only be called "bleacher" so i had to shimmy in behind the table leg to take a sit down. naturally, i got a splinter from the unfinished "naked" furniture hastily picked up from home depot and just as quickly forgotten about by management. (primer? stain, anyone?)

as i got my bearings and surveyed the scene, i realized that the spartan tables and seating were downright opulent compared to the oddly stenciled - were those pine trees? - shapes high up on the walls, the line of little paper butterflies tacked to the ceiling like a kindergarten project long ago abandoned and thousands of bare hooks in formless patterns also on the ceiling. but first i noticed the serious fly convention that was happening just over my fellow diner's heads.

we got our drinks - and one star for the healthy beer selection. people left our tables, others came. finally one forlorn couple were seated directly across from me, seated side by side which made me sad. i've always been mildly creeped out when at a restaurant there's a couple seated at a four-top who, instead of across from one another or "cornering", they are eating side by side like recently de-conjoined twins. creepy. (strange since i don't feel the same way about couples eating at bars or lunch counters ... just dining room tables.) this poor duo was forced into this kind of awkwardness.

the service was a bit absent minded, but they were busy to be fair.

finally, the food. not bad just not great. i was actually annoyed by the jagerschnitzel - the version i make at home ala Joy of Cooking is much tastier. bright spot was the spaetzle, which i HATE making at home. i'd give it an extra 1/2 star for that if i could.

when it was time to go, i still had about a 1/3 of my beer left, but we had to go - a fat lady kept pushing her chair into my companion's chair from behind.

to sum up: if you've got a hankerin' for some german, it's not a terrible place, but not a top pick either. schnitzelhaus has better food and better ambiance. walzwerk also has better food but even creepier ambiance. or just come over to my house for some tasty schnitzel, you bring the beer.
author: RT G.

description: I tried it way back in 2003 a couple times but without reservations its a long wait.The food is all right but sux & isn't always a pleasant experience dealing with the ghetto heads that dwell in the projects. A year after that the parital owner who was the head chef cashed out & moved to Alameda.He opened a place called Spizeian spelled wrong but its a pleasant atmosphere compared to Hayes Valley outdoor seating,easy parking & hosts an Oktoberfest event...Come & check out Spizecon in Alameda it worth it...
author: grknbohonk g.

description:
My first visit a few months ago to Suppenkuche wasn't the best experience. As a claustrophobe I didn't like how crowded it was on a Friday night which isn't the best night to go without a reservation.  The wiener schnitzel is basically tonkatsu without the sauce. Super dry and I hated it.  The close to 2 hour wait for a table was ridiculous.

My second visit this evening went a little better. I had the pork with mushroom sauce and I ate every bite.  I still don't like the common table set up but my dinner neighbors were very nice.  We made sure we had a reservation this time. It's still busy on a Tuesday night but at least you can walk around.

I'd go again but with a reservation.
author: Mona B.

description: This place is SOOOO loud. But despite that, we had a great time. The food and beer were great and the staff was very friendly and helpful. I'd definitely go back again!
author: Ben E.

description:
#29 On the "Big Eat SF" list  - Spaetzle

disclaimer: i cheated. roomie brought home leftovers from her own visit, and i microwaved a taste the next day.

2nd disclaimer: i have never had spaetzle before, do i dont have a basis of comparison

basic verdict: glorified mac n cheese?
 would probably have been better in the restaurant. though the only time i've been it was a little overwhelming (though the style that others love, since there's always a waitlist to get in!) to rub elbows with strangers and yell at my friend across the table!
author: S V.

description:
While I generally consider myself one of the flock that can be swayed by others reviews, I just can't fathom all the stellar reviews of this place.  
Went here with a big group from work and we had a big table for our party.  At the end of the table there were three people I didn't recognize.  I introduced myself and quickly learned that they were not even part of our group.  No.  they were just sitting at the same table as us.  Odd.  
Also, there were three of us forced to sit at the end of the table.  you know, the area where usually one unlucky soul gets to sit.  Yeah.  There were three of us there.  Our plates didn't even fit.  We also had to wait despite our reservation.  The beers are big and tasty.  The wild boar sausage I had was about the same kind of sausage you could get at Candlestick.   I mean, come on, it's wild boar though!  No, it still tastes like something you'd que up at a tailgate party.  Not that that's bad it was just average food.  Not worth the wait nor the spectacularly uncomfortable seating arrangements.
author: H K.

description: Owner Fabrizio Wiest was a graphic designer in Munich, but yearned to own and operate a traditional wirthaus serving beer and food from various regions of Germany, with an emphasis on Bavaria, where he was raised. His dream was realized in 1993, when he opened this small Hayes Valley dining spot. The decor is minimalist, almost forbidding in its starkness, relieved only by some artwork on the walls. Fortunately, the menu is more welcoming. Plump ravioli, stuffed with pork and vegetables, or bread dumplings, both served with a rich mushroom sauce, make great starters. I tend to order entrees that I would never prepare at home, so the sauerbraten with cranberries and sauteed venison medallions in red wine plum sauce - with their sides of red cabbage and spaetzle - are my most frequent selections. This is a place to eat early, unless you find loud, boisterous crowds of beer-drinkers and an unbearable noise level an atmosphere conducive to a pleasant dining experience and audible conversation with your companions. Five-star cuisine, but the ambiance and slightly high prices bring it down a notch overall.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
As a tribute to my fine dining experience at Suppenkuche, I will attempt to finish this review in German. After 4 years of studying German, I believe it is safe to say that I can write like a 6 year old German child. At least I hope. 

Suppenkuche ist sehr gut. Sie maechen eine gute Spaetzle und ich esse die Spaetzle auf! Aber, seit ich esse nicht Fleishe, ich moechte lieber viel Vegetarianische essen gleich dein potato pancake (?). 

Ich weiss nicht genau was ich sag. 

oh my god, german is hard. i hope this is not too schrecklich! 

anyway, moral of the story is......spaetzle and potato pancake!

(es tut mir leid)
author: bloopie s.

description: I'll admit I'm not a fan of many things German...bratwurst, sauerkraut, weinerschnitzel, David Hasselhoff...just not my thing.  However, I've heard good things and went to Suppenkuche last night for a belated birthday dinner with Lauren S.  We went for the modest, 0.5 liter Hefferweizen called Franzicana-something-or-other and it was really tasty.  Potato pancakes...get them.  They are fried to perfection and the applesauce dipper on the side is a delectable accompaniment.  I went for a safe choice on my entree and got the stuffed portabello mushroom.  It was delicious too.  I wasn't completely closed minded and tried my friend's spatzel and veggies which were both delicious as well.  I'd definitely recommend coming here if you don't mind waiting a little bit and the possibility of sharing a table with another party.
author: Michelle L.

description: My wife and I went their for valentines day brunch. There were already a few people outside before the place opened at 10am. Warm german bread was offered as soon as we were seated. Menu has a good selection of authentic german dishes. I had a currywurst which was tender and tasty. My wife who is German had a chicken cutlet which was also juicy and delicious. Great attentive service, unpretentious ambience and good food. Be sure to get there early as it gets very busy and be prepared to share your table with strangers as the each table seats 6. We will be back to sample their wide selection of German beers. Guten appetit!
author: Rajkumar J.

description: Honestly, I don't see what was so great about it. Spatzle is gross, and the Braised Beef was the only thing edible on the plate that didn't taste like sugared cabbage. Maybe german food isn't my thing. A plate of cheesy spatzle for the wife cost more than a Round Table Pizza.
author: Brandon E.

description: Just brilliant... that's my feeling about this place. The beer, the food the service, it's always been excellent. The cheese spatzle is awesome and the jaeger schnitzel never ceases to please... come early it gets packed and spend some time in that tiny space behind the bar packed in like sardines drinking dunkels and blondes. The only thing that might make this place even better is some authentic munich style beer songs... hehehe
author: Len S.

description: I love communal seating.  It's great way for Americans to be forced to do what they hate - mingle with strangers.  May I recommend the venison with spaetzle?  It's shareable for two, when a lovely combo salad is used as an appetizer.  The beer is great, the atmosphere is fun... the wait can be long.  It's worth it.  As Noah says:  The only thing better than meat is baby meat.
author: Shelley T.

description:
You would think that a restaurant wouldn't be "as" busy on a Thursday night, but you would be thinking wrong. This place was alot of fun once we finally got seated. We stood at the bar for about 15 minutes, not too bad, and each had a beer. Mine was light and sweet, his was dark but still a little sweet. The atmosphere is cute with weird little birds and branches hanging from the ceiling and trees and butterflies spray painted on the walls. You sit at a big table with people you don't know, but it was actually kind of fun and pretty intimate. I ordered the Sauerbraten mit Preiselbeerkonfitüre, serviert mit Rotkohl und Spätzle 
(Marinated and Braised Beef with Cranberries served with Red Cabbage and Spätzle). The beef was extremely tender and FULL of yummy flavor and the Spatzle had a great texture. I did not like the cabbage, it just wasn't my taste. He had the meatloaf and mashed potatoes, which was equally as delightful and we switched back and forth eating from each others plates. The portions are huge and I don't eat all that much, so it's great if you go with someone who doesn't mind nibbling off of your plate (of course, you have to not mind this either, which i don't , so it worked out just fine). It was SUPER busy and crowded, but to me that's always a sign of a good place. This is a definite "Must try" . =) And that's all I have to say.
author: danae k.

description:
Yet more proof that the popularity of a restaurant in SF doesn't necessarily correlate with how good the food is.

To clarify a couple of things. Firstly,  I LOVE german food, so does my Swiss-German BF. I've been to Germany more times than I can remember and I cook the stuff at home, so I know great German food when I come across it...alas, Sppenkche does not fall in to that category.  Secondly, this review would have been three stars, except for two cardinal (in my eyes) sins. #1 - the noise level in the restaurant. Lots of loud, screaming, obnoxious folks. This isn't a cavernous beer hall where you can get away with that shit, so please show some respect to your fellow diners. It was so loud, that it was hard to communicate with the waiter, as a result, the order didn't come out as it was meant to. So minus one star for the cacophony. #2 - only one dessert was offered. WTF? To make matters worse, it was Schwarzwaldkuche which contained Kirsch - being an alcoholic, I can't consume raw alcohol, so there was no dessert for me and my chronic sweet toothh. Minus another star for that bollocks.

As for the food itself, average, average, average. Why this place is so popular when it serves such mediocrity baffles me. Sure, the Sptzle were nice and freshly cooked, but they weren't anything to write home about. The RotKohl lacked oomph, the venison was a tad dry and flavorless, the wild boar sausage was boring. As for the Kartoffelsuppe, I'm guessing the chef couldn't be bothered with it as it was Blandy McBland, served with what were allegedly Wienerwurst, though they seemed more like skanky American hot dogs to me.

Do yourself a favour - if you want good German food, don't go to Sppenkche...try Walzwerk instead.
author: Dan L.

description: Spatzle?  Ya.  Weinerschnitzel?  Ya.  Bratwurst?  Ya.  Sauerkraut?  Ya.  Beer? Oh ya.  Trust me, you will "round out" at this place.
author: ellyk E.

description: It you don't mind sharing a bench with strangers, this gasthaus can be fun, loud and satisfy your belly considerably. Enjoy!
author: Nena G.

description: I'm another vegetarian that loves this German restaurant.  The spaetzle is delicious and comes with a groovy little salad and some nice dark bread.  And BEER!  There are so many good beers to choose from, and they come in these mongo glasses.
author: Andi T.

description:
AN ODE TO SUPPENKUCHE:

Ye dim and romantic establishment
Boasting ever-so-many delightful
Beers
And SAUSAGES
And lovely things that hang

From the ceiling whimsically. 
Sat we in the cozy embrace
Of the candlelit lounge,
Paying no heed to the 
Obnoxious and oblivious

Yuppies that crowded in on us
Like so many bees to
Spring's sweet flowers.

Our spry and friendly barmaster
Aided in easing our comfort
With enlivened knowledge of
The dozen or two intoxicating brews. 

So Kostritzer and Kolsch it was to be
As we sat, pressed by warm backs that
Smelled
Of cigarettes. 

We began with the shrimp! Succulent and plump
Afloat in a beer broth with tomato
Savory.

Then zwei weitere Biere, bitte!
And it was mai bock for her and dunkle for him
And with such fine libations in hand
We greeted the redolent roasted pork special.

Oh, such fine, fabulous, tender pig,
Thou art truly one of nature's great gifts.
Astride red cabbage, 
A fat dumpling at its side,
The roasted pork loin in beer sauce 
---oh, salty delight!

Though fatty, fatty, as you can expect a pig
To be.
And in the dim light, it was hard
To see where the meat ended
And the fat began!
But through dexterous manipulations
Of candles and shadows
We cleaned our plate of delicious meat.

And we groaned, oh we groaned! 
Our bellies so full they nearly split
Down the middle
As we made our way home

To the couch.
author: Sage R.

description: It feels a bit unnecessary to write a positive review for Suppenkuche, given that they already have over 1000 of those, but they deserve it! Yum yum yum!  Went early on a Thursday night to avoid the crowd, and got seated immediately.  Potato pancakes with homemade applesauce are AMAZING, I could eat a whole meal of them. Minus one star for mediocre spatzle.
author: Katie S.

description: This place really seems to be always crowded and LOUD!  But as a native German I am very happy about their success. The beer selection is good and so is the food although some combinations and execution is not exactly what you would get in a restaurant in let's say Munich for example ;-)  All in all it's decent fare though.
author: Kiki W.

description: Aside from the fact that they serve excellent food, I'd come here just to drink their beer. Even the pickled herring is good. Who knew I'd like pickled herring? That's how good this place is.
author: Grace L.

description: One of the best options in town for good German food and beer.  While I think the food is a bit better at Walzerk, the beer selection is quite a bit better here.  The last time I was here I got the boar sausage with sauerkraut and had nothing to complain about.   Call me anti-social, but I find the whole communal dining thing to be a bit annoying.  What some see as an amusing gimmick I see as an excuse for this place to serve more people than they should be able to.  That really makes for this to be a better option when out with a fair sized group of friends.  Think of Suppenkuche as the option when out drinking with friends and you want food to go with it.  Walzwerk is more suited for smaller parties were food is the main focus.  Just beware, those half liter glasses of Spaten Optimator add up quickly.  Does anyone know the German word for hangover?
