author: Joshua W.

description:
I've been here a few times, but it was last night's visit that requires me to break my silence. I love this place because the ambiance is always great, the beer is always flowing and the food is always solid. 

Last night, I had the Pork chop with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes and It. Was. Heaven. I have never had such a thick-cut pork chop, and it was amazingly juicy and tender. Every bite was better than the last. And the mashed potatoes--oh the mashed potatoes! So melt-in-your-mouth creamy, that pairing them with the salty pork and sour of the kraut was a fabulous combination. I am sitting at my desk, dreaming of the leftovers as I type. Heart you, suppenkuche.
author: Kathleen D.

description: Suppenkuche has become one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  It's intimate, very crowded at times, but the staff manages to remain attentive.  On my last visit I met a customer from the mid-West, who makes it a point to eat at this restaurant when he is in San Francisco. I watched as he ate a cabbage salad (?) that could have fed a small Eastern European country, followed by the wild boar.  mmmmm, wild boar. Mid-Westerner's know their German food. So does Suppenkuche.  Get there early if you want a seat, or plan to eat at the bar or the cozy alcove behind the bar.
author: George S.

description: I see your Kartoffelsuppe, and I raise you a Reibekuchen.
author: Shannon V.

description:
i haven't met a meatloaf i haven't liked... good size and nice potatoes!

if you love your meats and beer... suppenkuche has loads of plenty...well actually the menu is pretty short... but portions are generous.
( but heads up... meat usually equal salty) 
tamed on the outside, beer downing Oktoberfest mania on the inside(loud). the service was nice and attentive as possible esp since the place was packed and all the tables were taken. you may end up having to share a table...but no worries the diners are friendly.

try their vegetarian stuffed mushrooms if the huge meaty plates are too overwhelming.

skip appetizer platter, it's just a mini deli with a side of butter.

lesson of the night: cured pork= ham
author: Lynn T.

description: Third visit here, this time was a treat since we weren't expecting to eat here during this trip.  While I was looking forward to their foods, I totally forgot about the beers and atmosphere! Truly unique and quite the SF experience, we loved every minute of the meal (all except for the wait to get a table). I ordered the pork sausage, wife-y had the grilled pork - neither of us venturing away from our picks during the last visit. I gulped down one liter of the frutty, dark weisse beer (schneider), yummy and quite filling. You haven't changed!
author: Jesse W.

description:
oof!

let me get this out of the way first - wear loose, comfortable clothing.  your big jeans, with suspenders.  or maybe a mumu.

reason is, this place is a vanity melter.  after you get a beer or two down, you're going to care little about how you look and the damage you do to your waistline.  all you're going to care about is how cool and tasty and refreshing the tap beer is.  how warm and savory and crunchy the potato pancakes are.  how spicy that damn mustard is.  how good it feels to take another swig of beer to wash down said damn spicy mustard.  

and then of course, there's the organic chicken schnitzel, the sausages, the sauerkraut. all yummy going down.  more beer.  more noise.

more beer.

stumbling home.

oof.

mmm...beer.

(can't wait to do it again.)
author: brian w.

description: SF's little Oktoberfest !  Lots of beer and starch, and you feel sick afterward.  Portions are huge.  Beer mugs are huge - esp the boot which I think is bigger than my entire body.  Only minus is potentially sitting next to screaming babies/children, as seating is in the spirit of a 'beer garden' - I had to endure a child screaming right next to my ear which made it hard to hear/talk with my boyfriend.
author: Nana S.

description: Love this place!! The wait can be long,but its worth it. Brunch here is great and so is dinner.  Note that they aren't open for Brunch on Saturday. Careful coming here with your bros from college cause boots tend to lead to competitive drinking which is a recipe for a great time or the black out express. Potato pancakes are yummy!! Don't come here if you're looking to have an intimate conversation with someone cause its loud and boisterous, but definitely a fun place to knock back some beers and eat a hearty meal.
author: Nathan J.

description:
Well,
Tut mir leid, aber diese wirtshaus nicht soviel gute ist.  OK-OK, mein deutsche sehr sheisse ist...but C'mon people.  Long story short, I've spent the last 10 yrs living just outside of Stuttgart, know Heidelberg well (the owner's hometown per the history page) and am quite familiar with Bavarian/Schwabisch cooking.  I didn't expect too much, but they lost stars for the following reasons:
1- The waitress didn't speak german.  And no- I'm not talking conversationally.  She couldn't understand the menu.  If you're working in a place that serves a distinctly and marketed regional, if not national, food- then your wait staff should be able to understand the menu items.  They are, after all, written in deustch.
2- I witnessed the kasespaetzle incident and frankly, it takes another 30 sec. to sprinkle the cheese on, add some toasted onions (if you're going schwabische), a tablespoon of the (I'm pretty sure) already prepared buttersose, and BAM!- it's done.  
3- Tho my stuffed pork cutlet was divine, the lentils reminded me of those precooked ones you buy in a pkg at Trader J's.  And they were black.  Maybe that's what's available locally, but I've never had black lentils in Germany.  The Rotekohl, a little sweeter than normal, was still yummy.  The brussel sprouts, tho, were bland.  
Last but not least- altho the website touted Warsteiner as available on tap ( and that set my mouth a-waterin'), I was told it was no longer served there, which was a bummer.  The Kur-Pee (Koenigs Pilsner) filled in nicely tho.  

Bottom line, if you've never been to the Fatherland this place'll work.  If you have, don't expect too much.  
Ich gehe zuruck nichts mehr...
Tchuss.
author: Afab M.

description:
3 stars for the food and 1 for the excellent and friendly waitstaff. We had the potato pancakes appetizer and the venison medallions main course. The potato pancakes were good but not mind-blowing (really, can a fried potato be?). The venison itself was excellent in its plum sauce and was the highlight of the meal. The side of spaetzle was good, but really could have used more sauce. And, truth be told, I was not a fan of the cabbage. 

I would recommend trying the ravioli. Although I did not have it myself, the strange girl at the other end of our table had quite the reaction to it (think the restaurant scene in "When Harry Met Sally.") I'll definitely have what she's having.

As mentioned above, the service here was truly excellent and you even get the sense the waiters are enjoying their work. This place is fun, loud, and filled with beer. Just how anything German should be.
author: Matthew C.

description: I love hefeweizen and suppenkuche (obviously) has the best selection I've ever seen. Ergo, I love suppenkuche. I'm not a meat eater, so the menu items are limited, but the spaetzle and potato pancakes were life changing. The wait is long, but well worth it. Only downside is the communal tables- it can get a bit awkward. Also, definitely crowded and LOUD, but nothing a couple beer boots can't fix.
author: Robin L.

description: Clearly, the last thing Suppenkuche needs is another Yelp review. But mine is a bit different from the rest. LOVED the beer selection (and giant mug it was served in), but was disappointed by the food. I had chicken schnitzel, which came with roasted potatoes and soggy cucumber salad. Totally mediocre. I may have ordered the wrong dish, so I am willing to try again (although I felt sick the next day - it's possible it was the 5 cocktails to the face after dinner, but I digress). Also, I suggest trying to pull together 6 people so you can get a reservation and not have a random couple at the end of your table. I still don't know who felt more awkward...
author: Valerie N.

description: Yes, it is a very busy place, but I love the food here.  Their Spätzle is the best...the flavor and texture are perfect.  Their Jägerschnitzel is ridiculously good, and their mustard is the bomb...burns your nose and head real well, yes it does.
author: Pamela S.

description: This is the kind of restaurant where you plan your outfit before you go.  You should wear something with an elastic waist or a long shirt to cover the undone top button of your pants.  the food is VERY hearty, but all excellent. nothing crazy on the menu, just simple good  food.  not the best place to take vegetarians, but there are some options.  i love the minimalist wooden tables.  great beer list.  i've never been able to get dessert, but it always looks real yummy.
author: Liz C.

description: For a brunch change of pace, go here.  Maybe it's cuz it's not the usual or maybe it's becuz I'm not familiar with German food, but it always tastes hearty and good.  Try to go during off hours (if they have any anymore).  I'm not a fan of the communal seating.  Definitely not a place to try to have an intimate conversation or a date.  I bruise my leg every single time I try to get into or out of the tables here.  If you've been here, you know what I mean.
author: Esther R.

description:
updated: 
i came back the other day, and i thought to myself that i should really bump up my initial review to 5stars... and then i realized i already dubbed SuppenK with the highest Yelp honor.  man, i've got good taste.

***
You:  patient, thirsty, discerning palate, hungry, NOT a low talker.
The Reward:  a 5-star meal... 

* If you're not patient, you will be severely bummed out by the wait.  we waited ~half an hour at 8:30pm on a Wednesday night. 
* If you're not thirsty, then you're missing out on the Oktoberfest-portions of Schneider Weiss. (note: they serve both draught and bottled beer... get the bottled, tastes better)
* If you don't have a discerning palate, then you might not fully appreciate the tasty cuisine.  
* If you're not hungry, then you won't finish your plate.  i'd recommend drinking lots of liquids all day just to keep your tummy expanded and ready for the monstrous meal. 
* If you're a low-talker, then no one will hear you.  And don't expect to have a private conversation because the communal style seating ensures that you make a couple new friends during your dinner.
author: Kevin F.

description: Absolutely love this place.  Great service, true german flavor (food, ambiance).  Have to try potatoe panckaces and almost any dish. My faovrite time is Sunday brunch around 11am.  Have to try at least 3 kinds of beer before leaving the restaurant and dont forget to buy trendy t-shirts that are designed by restaurant owners
author: Yan R.

description: This place is so solid and awesome, great beer selection, though a bit tough to navigate at first. Everything i had and or tasted was great.
author: diction d.

description: Suppenkuche feels like a mini-Oktoberfest.  I had a mini-boot of beer (for the experience of drinking out of the boot without the extra liter of beer), and the saurbraten.  The flavorful beef went perfectly with the spatzle and salad plate. The large group tables make for a unique and lively dining experience, and by the end of the meal, our neighbors at the next table were singing drinking songs and looked like they were about to get up and dance.
author: Laura B.

description: Hearty, hearty, hearty is the food. The servers are very attentive and warm. The ambiance is just downright neighbourly. So don't be all suprised if you get seated at a table with some other folk.  It just adds to the experience of being in a biergarten to get your Wienerschnitzel and Schwarzbier on!!  Brunch is very good and fills up fast after 11am.
author: I. O.

description: My favorite German food place in the city.  I love this place.  Great German food, great beer except the lines can be real long on the weekends.  You eat with other people at communal tables which can either be a good or a bad experience.  Just drink a lot and you'll enjoy!  The pork chop is my favorite thing, amazing.  Make sure they bring out the special mustard for it.  If your not into german heavy type of food, then skip this place.  Once in a while it's a good alternative and a fun place to bring people from outside the city. A German friend of mine actually said it's the best German place and most authentic then anything else in the city. Prost!
author: Mitch A.

description: Brunch today was great. Good company, not too crowded -- you have to be up for meat palace and beer though. We had the large breakfast plate consisting of cold cuts and soft boiled egg. I then had the bockwurst in butter broth with a pretzel along with an amber beer. Sounds like stange brunch fare but really it was noon. Loved the pretzel dipped in the butter broth. And the black forest cake is sublime. I can't imagine working in this place. The smell of beer and sausage would really be disgusting after a while. After brunch you can walk over to Miette bakery, before your nap.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: My husband lived in Germany as a child, and even though he's Mexican, he thinks of himself as part German.  Whatever you do, PLEASE don't go here and order wine.  That really pisses me off. German beer is great.  There is something there for you drink - just try.  As a creature of habit, I always order the same dish.  And every time I am pleased.   Suppenkuche is loud and crowded, but would you expect anything else?
author: Carrie R.

description:
I was forced to give at least a star and I prefer to give them zero. Called in to make reservation for 4, no they didn't take it. We needed to be there at 5 pm for dinner and out to make Nutcracker at 7 pm. Whoever picked up the phone said no worry, we will have plenty of time if we got there when they opened. Fine, we did wait in line for them to open at 5 pm, however, two out of our four party were circling around looking for parking. The host wouldn't seat us. When I plead her that they were already right down the street, she wouldn't listen and talked back to us with an attitude that I couldn't believe coming out of a restaurant host, "it's a policy, what do you want me to do?" Our third party soon showed up because her husband dropped her off due to her disability and told her what he wanted to order. There were two tables left at that point. It doesn't matter we told her that we know what he wanted to order, we would be quick to make the show anyway, she just didn't care. When my boyfriend asked for her name and the owner's name, her reaction was "Marie, and the owner is Aaron, and tell him whatever you want, he will back me up."

We were shocked, but now reading through people who have bad experience with them, I'm not surprised why she was so sure that the owner will back her up. Someone here said he is the ass whole himself. Will never go here, will not recommend to anyone I know. One of the waiters though was so nice that he tried to compromise us, but the host wouldn't let him.
author: alkira m.

description: Its not just beer and sausages, they serve wine too.  Good German food and fantastic beers.
author: Mickey D.

description: The beer list and menu were hard to understand, but the food was delicious! I had a Hefeweizen and the schnitzel with a cream mushroom sauce and egg noodles. I would go back, but would rather pay less and get a smaller portion size. Fun place to go with one or a few friends, although it gets too loud to actually hear yourself once the place fills up.
author: Yiming R.

description:
My husband is a big beer fan, so this past Thursday night we were looking for a restaurant with good beer and some comfort food. We have had German food before (at Speisekammer in Alameda) and really liked it, so we decided to try Suppenkuche. 
We arrived fairly early (around 530pm) and were seated right away. We were surprised that it was communal seating, but it wasn't so bad, the people we were sharing the table with were friendly, and we could barely hear their conversations because the restaurant was so loud. 
So my husband had a beer, forgot the name, but he said it was really good. We had the potato pancakes with applesauce and they were crispy and went really well with the sauce. We had the braised beef with spaetzle and it was pretty good too, the meat was juicy and tender, and the spaetzle was nice and doughy and great with the sauce. 
We would definitely go back, but with a bigger party so that we can have our own table, and definitely want to try other things on the menu. 
Great place for beers, hearty food, and lively groups.
author: HELEN K.

description: Like the understated plain but stylish decor, not to mention all the beers (complete with the right beer stein for each beer) (even though I never manage to pick a beer that comes with one of the super cool glasses).  And the food's great.  The jagerschnitzel with spaetzle is one of my all time favorite meals anywhere.  No breading, and the spaetzle's better than any gnocchi I've had (or at least on a par with the best).
author: Laurel B.

description: My friend had been telling me about this place for a while so we finally went there Sunday for brunch and we had so much fun!  The food was amazing as was the kickback atmosphere.  I ordered the skirt steak and eggs with new potatoes.  YUM!  The portions were huge and I had the leftovers for dinner!  Ofcourse we had to order the beer boot and it was such a blast passing it back and forth and people were just watching us in awe (because it was ginormous and not even noon yet!)  I recommend coming here in a group as they sit strangers at your table, but sometimes it's nice to meet new people!  I definately want to come back to Suppenkuche for dinner and will ofcourse return for brunch.
author: anne m.

description: This place is great! They have large tables that look like ginormous picnic tables. I just remember the food was filling...or was that the beer? Either way the beer here is super good and in case you are super thirsty just order it out of a boot! :)
author: Adriana G.

description: But have you been there for brunch? I think I was out of the loop and only realized this past weekend that they were open during the day.  Just as great as their dinners: large portions, fresh and filling interesting dishes. I had their ravioli scramble, a large spinach ravioli chopped up and scambled with fluffy eggs and carmelized onions. Strange-sounding but so right.  Served with cool, dressed, sliced cucumbers.  My friend had the equivalent egg scramble with oregano-spiced sausage instead of the raviolio. Add a Doppelbock and Oktoberfest to wash it all down.  Mmm, the perfect Sunday afternoon.
author: Melanie C.

description: The four stars are for the beer.  The Cheese Spatzle was just a glorified version of mac n' cheese.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Good beer out of a glass boot is good enough for 5 stars, but add on killer latkes and a strange portobello mushroom dish that turns out to be amazing.  I wish Suppenkuche was next door.
author: Joe B.

description: Even as a native German, I must say this is authentic German food presented at a very reasonable price and I am loving it!!!
author: matthias m.

description: Truly mouth watering good.  I lived in the Valley right above it for a year and it was a weekly treat.  Now I miss it, but have been there at least triple digits worth of times.  The wiener schnitzel is the most amazingly fried piece of deliciousness.  I like to split the spatzel, which is the closest thing to pasta that I can eat at a German spot, as a side.  This is the best place to take a large group, the more the better here.  Its family style eating at the huge tables.  If you are planning on raging the bars after dinner I would go someplace else to eat because the food coma makes you oh so sleepy.  Brunch here is heavy and fulfilling with cucumber salad and anything on the menu.  I love this place and am thinking about eating there tonight and maybe tomorrow too, its that goooood!
author: Michelle N.

description: Great German restaurant with lovely food and beer. Whenever bf and I are craving some Schnitzel - breaded veal chop, this is the place to go. Quite often a wait but it's a popular place. Great for group dinners or fun for party of two where you share the dining table with others.
author: Yan M.

description: Great restaurant.  Fun atomsphere.   The seating isn't the best if you want to catch up with someone as you're seated with strangers.  I haven't had a dish there I haven't liked.  If you drink beer they have a great beer selection as well.  You end up with 2-3 meals out of an entree.  Huge portions.
author: Kirsten M.

description: Fun atmosphere, great beers, and extremely hearty food.  Downside is the long waits, and they only take reservations for more than six.  If you can get a big group together, this place is great.
author: Gloria J.

description: Great for Dinner and Sunday Brunch.  Food and tap beers are out of this world.  Specials menu always has something seasonal.  If the mushroom soup or curried chicken soup are available--get them!
author: Steve K.

description: Does life get any better than eating yummy german food while drinking out of a glass boot?  No!  I've tried the Wild Bore sausage and Venison.  Snausage was good, but venison was fantastic.  Bar tenders will helpfully recommend a good beer tailored to what you're in the mood for.
author: Parker W.

description: Suppenkuche is a good place to eat German food.  The servers are attentive and the portions are generous.  Even on a weekday, it's a lively atmosphere.  Potato pancakes were great and plum sauce for the deer was delicious.  However, the dishes were just good.  A little too much salt for my taste.
author: Jeannine L.

description:
this is the only german sit-down restaurant i've been to in san francisco. i really enjoy the decor, selection of beers and of course, the spatzle. the spatzle alone brings me back.

a few too many meat based dishes. i don't really know german food all that well, but it would be nice if they could mix up the menu a bit with some more vegetarian options.
author: Alex L.

description: Let's say for German food outside of Germany, Suppenkuche is pretty good. Only complaint I have is that the Sauerkraut isn't really 'sauer'. Come with a big group and you will enjoy the evening!
author: Doro P.

description: This is the one place that after all these years I should write a review. The word "love" cannot describe my feelings for the edifice, staff, and the food...Dammit! When I come here, I come home. Not for the sake of being half German or anything like that. Suppenkuche has been my neighborhood bar, restaurant, and haunt. I almost always sit in the little cozy area behind the bar. I also run into at least five people I know and like alot when ever I drop in. The food is true to German cuisine. Any one who has spent some time in the country could attest to that. The spatzel makes me want to scream! So..... I am going to do it..... I love you guys!
author: Charise B.

description: Eating their Kassler (pork chops) is truly a spiritual experience!!! My mom couldn't do it better :). And the beers... dreamy... I think I wanna move to Hayes Valley now. So that I can be closer to my Kassler... :)))
author: Julia S.

description: The food was alright.  I had a sausage w/ mashies & sauerkraut.  I almost wanted to ask for a hotdog bun, 'coz thats what it tasted like.  A friend has a weinerschniztel w/c was good.  They also have beer in boots.  You only have your table for 2 hours, so eat fast.
author: Jo B.

description:
you'd be surprised to find out that a german restaurant is actually veggie-friendly, but this place totally is.

their cheese spatzle is so flavorful & perfectly textured and is accompanied by a hearty salad of carrots, beets & cabbage.  their portions have gotten smaller and the tastily-dressed bib lettuce that used to make a perfect bed for the salad is no longer there, but unfortunately i'm too infatuated with this dish to be too mad.

take note of the changing decor.  very simple details, mainly hung from the ceiling, make the basic, open space quite pleasing.  the designer-turned-restaurateur has succeeded with the changing tees, graphics & posters, too.  it pleases this designer.
author: Mary S.

description: Having endured ""Oktoberfest by the Bay"", I feel obliged to remark on a wonderful discovery a few weeks ago - Suppenkuche. $9 for a litre of great beer. With an extraordinary beer selection, great authentic German food & great dcor, this is everything that Oktoberfest by the bay is not. It's not a beer festival, but it is a great restaurant. Anyone who appreciates world class beers, with no rice, or names right off the periodic table in the ingredients, will feel like they died and went to heaven here.
author: Cian D.

description: Everything here is excellent...EVERYTHING. The first time I came here was with a large group that pretty much ordered every appetizer/small dish on the menu and I still remember how it all tastes. The next few visits I tried different entrees so I can safely say that you can't go wrong. From the charcuterie plates, blood sausage, trout, goulash, breads, to the desserts they are all excellent. Their black forest cake is amazing and unbeatable. I'm still trying to figure out how to replicate this cake at home. Mine is good but not like it is here. The vibe is uber-homey and and conducive to making new friends. Great for large groups or a casual date.
author: Thu S.

description: Simply fantastic German food with a wonderful atmosphere and super service. The bench seating might not be to everyone's taste but I love it and have returned on many occasions. A group of 6+ will be able to annex one for themselves in any case. For quick and casual dining you can't beat a seat at the bar, which has a fine selection of German beers.
author: Aodhan M.

description:
this review is for a very boisterous, beer-filled dinner!

helas, us faithful followers of beer ('tis the season to be beer-ful) and all things sausage cannot feast our tummies on anywhere else once suppenkuche is near. it was third time the charm for us, as the wait for dinner on a thursday night was only.... 45 minutes!

be not discouraged, as those 45 minutes give you plenty of time to wet your palette to the generous servings of potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce (why didn't i think of that?) and appetizer plate  with mounds of ham and sausage goodness. also, loved being up front and center with the taps of premium german beers, and bartenders who pronounce them correctly! (heidi klum, you'd be so proud) out of the 4 different ones we ordered, my favorite was the mai bock. 

when finally seated, albeit full, i found the schnitzel divine. the food was not the only fun distraction: as the night wore on, the trend of pounding your wooden table (and little bottles of 88 proof vodka) became ever popular! 

danke shun, bitte shun!
author: Diana L.

description: Great food, great service, though a little crowded but I guess that's to be expected for such a popular place. Definitely don't miss this place if you are in the area and looking for a good german meal and beer.
author: Jason H.

description: Not too much selection for vegetarians, but warm, hearty atmosphere with candlelight and unique furniture.  Beer is off the hook too.. (and the staff looks like they go home yodeling and wearing clogs).
author: Sid D.

description:
Eating German food for the first time and drinking German beer for the first time, i must say this is quite a good experience. Me and my friend were seated right away in a common table, we ordered Blanche de bruxelle on the boot glass, they are huge but they taste so good!
I ordered the broccoli soup which was a little too salty for me, the potato pancakes which is so crunchy and good and the mushroom breaded pork with the egg noodle, they are so addictive. i didn't get to try the dessert because i was so stuffed and bloated by the beer but this place is a must go when u have a big group. its fun!!
author: fourevindo h.

description: Suppenkuche is suppen-tastic!  Their wide range of awesome German beers are served in their specific steins and are always cold as ice.  The potato pancakes are a must!  Go with the pork chop, roasted chicken, or the trout and you will not be disappointed.  The lentil soup is pretty darn good as well.   It's always crowded, but the vibe is dope and the food is worth the wait.   The decor is cute and goes with the neighborhood and cuisine.  Brunch is also a hit and decently priced.
author: Jessica B.

description: Last time i came here i got into a little fight w/ my bf because we had communal seating with like 3 other couples we didn't know that were on dates being all smooshy smoochy snuggle huggybears and everytime i looked at them googly eyeing eachother and giggling it made me all pissed off because my bf was waaaaaay too engrossed in his Linsensuppe (lentil soup): "Mmmnyum, oh gosh this is goood.  mmm, glad we came, so hearty, so robust and filling..mmm." ..not even looking at me, completely ignoring me THE WHOLE TIME. can i be that Linsensuppe? gosh!
author: Rosieposie Y.

description: This place is great, but I am not eating anything with nipples anymore so I doubt I'll go back. Who wants to eat chicken when they have the best pork in town?
author: Mitsi M.

description: Oh Suppenkche, how I love thee. The first time I went there, I ate alone and the waitress totally flirted with me. I ordered a very standard meal: pork sausages with kraut and smashies (that's what I call mashed potatoes). Very good, especially with the Buten Alt (on tap). My other experiences there have been equally good. Wait staff seems to be pretty attentive and friendly. I know of no other place like this in the Bay Area, so that gets Suppenkche extra "unique experience" points in my book. Plus, it's right around the corner from my old place. Highly recommended.
author: Brad L.

description:
I thought this place was pretty good - colleagues/friends had recommended it so it took my lady and parents cos they were in town and I wasn't disappointed.  
After walking in (they don't take reservations for under 6 people) with our party of 4 around 715pm, we were given the option of waiting with 2 others on a table that sat 6, or eating at the bar (not ideal for more that 2 people).  
Initially, I felt a little strange - parents last night of visit and sitting with strangers not quite the intimate dining experience I had in mind - HOWEVER - once we sat down and ordered - have to say I was impressed.
All of us had traveled around Germany and the bier and food smacked of authenticity - and tasted great also.
Price - reasonable - esp. if you're off to the theatre later on and don't want to break the bank.
Atmos - surprisingly intimate - chaps - seriously - this is a potential 'date' venue - you'll impress the lucky lady with both your choice and your ability to interact in a very social environment --- also candle lit --- do it.
Cheers and enjoy!!
author: A H.

description: It's sad but true.  The quality of this place has slipped since my first visit here over two years ago.  I went back and had a horrible experience with the food. My pork was way over cooked and dry, spatzel was flavorless and mushroom sauce was the same that came with the bread dumpling.  This place lost the initial experience charm that I loved so much.  I'm holding back on going beyond the second star-- if I got what I got for half the price, I might say it was worth it.  Until then...
author: Helen T.

description: I went here for the first time tonight and loved it. Though you should expect a little bit of a wait, this is a great place for a medium sized group (6 people) to grab some beers and great food.  I had the chicken special  with potato pancakes.  The chicken was nicely seasoned but I particularly liked the potato pancakes.  The thinly cut potato pancakes were perfectly crisp on the outside and delicious.  Next time, I would just order the potato pancake appetizer, grab a beer or two, and then try a dessert.
author: Josh K.

description: Brilliant interior.  Yummy food.  Busy vibe.  The bartender made fun of me when I asked for a bitter beer, "That's English, not German!"
author: Mandy S.

description: This place is a one of a kind for the area.  There were really nice dried flowers hanging from ceiling and, of course, great German beer.  They had a lot of vegetarian options too, which really surprised me.
author: Joanna S.

description: Two girls walk into Suppenkuche for dinner. Two girls magically are instantaneously transported to Germany. This wasn't just dinner it was an event. There was this ridiculous bachelorette party that rolled up in a stretch hummer . . . classy ladies. There was the old guy at the bar scoffing at our beer decisions (we just let him decide) there was the food being passed over the bar goer's heads and four hours and two pitchers later I really genuinely believed we were in Europe. Transcending  time and space,  that has to be worth five stars.
author: Elektra D.

description:
We went here for breakfast Sunday morning at around 11 and were seated immediately.  One point for that!  Sorry, but I'm still not used to the standing-in-line-to-get-a-table thing in San Francisco.

We had to wait forever before they came to get our order, and then we had to wait forever before we got our food and drinks.  Food was bland and tasteless (gravlox, roasted potatoes, park sausages).  Grapefruit juice was great, so another point for that.

Maybe we will go back to try them for dinner because the schnitzel the couple next to us was having, looked good...
author: Marijke D.

description: Good beer and food. The wait is terrible and its very crowded/congested.
author: viv k.

description: I absolutely love going to Suppenkuche. My suggestions are to arrive early and eat either the Venison or the Stuffed Mushroom. In general the food is fantastic, the staff friendly and knowledgeable, and the dining room is always buzzing. I really enjoy this style of dining and hope that others are open enough to appreciate it. It's very relaxed, chill, and very european. Be friendly and say hi to people, after all they are sharing a dinner table with you.
author: S P.

description: This place has delicious German food.  I always get their goulash.  It is absolutely to die for.  Great ambiance and great service.  A wide  variety of beers...I highly recommend this place for some quality German food.
author: Danielle V.

description: I LOVE SUPPENKUCHE! The food here is amazing! I love German food and this restaurant is on point. The atmosphere is fun and friendly and the beer is sooo tasty and comes in all sizes :) the only thing i suggest is to not eat anything all day because it is a huge meal. Sometimes there is a long wait but it is so worth it.
author: Amanda V.

description: They obviously don't need anymore Yelp reviews, but just a brief one saying the food was yummy and satisfying and I loved the decor!
author: Libby V.

description:
It's kind of ridiculous that I'm writing a review since there are already 900 reviews of this place. But this way I'll remember that I came here and come back :)

First off, I am a vegetarian. My husband really likes German food, so I took him here, recognizing that there might not be a ton of vegetarian options.

When we got here there was a 1/2 hr wait. We stood at the bar and had some beer while waiting, which was fun. I had no idea what some of the beers even were (what is Helles??) so I let my husband order for me. It turned out I didnt really like what he picked though... oops. It was a franziskan weissbier (sp?) which I thought was kind of boring and plain. Anyways, they claimed they gave me a 0.5L, but it looked way bigger than that to me. By the end of the glass I liked the beer much better... hehe.

Then we were seated at a table for 6. My husband and I on one end and a group of 4 on the other. They were nice and it was kind of fun to sit with strangers.

My husband ordered the bratwurst w/ mashed potatoes and saurkraut. He said the brats and saurkraut were better than at his previous favorite German restaurant, but the mashed potatoes weren't as good.

I got the cheese spaetzl. As soon as I tasted it, I knew that although it tasted really good, it was way too rich for me to finish. Oh well. We had leftovers. The salad that came with the spaetzl was also good. It was some funny red saurkraut and carrots which were good. Also beets, but I don't like beets that much.

Final analysis: I like this place but there aren't a ton of vegetarian options. Next time I'll probably get the potato pancakes w/ apple sauce.
author: zoe b.

description:
Gut, nicht Wunderbar.  I wish I could give this place 3 1/2 stars, 3 for the food and 5 for the beer; however they don't make the beer.  
Let's start with the 
Food:  I had the Gebratene Rehmedaillions (braised veal medallions).  Generally tasty and well prepared but drowned in the heaviest bland dark sauce I've ever seen.  The spaetzle (potato dumplings) are good as is the overly sweet Rotkohl(red cabbage).  I would say the food is not good value for the price ($19.50 for this).
Beer: Ausgezeichnet (Excellent).  I really love their Erdinger Dunkel...a dark wheet beer.
Service: This is pulling down the rating.  Our fresh-off-the-boat Irish waiter was not so attentive, slow, and not terribly friendly.  18% gratuity added to our crappy service.  
Ambience: It's loud, but I expect there.  The worst was the bell the prep cook kept ringing super-loudly 1 foot from our table to announce that the food was done. 
Overall:  Tasty, but not excellent over-priced food with excellent beer and mediocre service.
author: Ian P.

description:
Friday night, the whole experience:
1.  Told we'd have an hour and a half wait.  We didn't.  Hostess made sure we knew she hadn't forgotten about us.  She rocks.
2.  Got beers at the small bar inside while we were waiting for a table.  Lots of good choices, knowledgeable/helpful servers.  Marveled at the ambitious "boot" drinkers.  Impressed.
3.  Two girls come up to we three men and state, "We want to talk to you guys."  Flattered, yes, but it turns out they were also hawking a skeeball league.  Fun.
4.  Irish guy complains about line for "the pisser" and informs others in the queue that he intends to use the women's restroom if the chance presents itself.  Entertaining.
5.  The remainder of our party arrives, we sit, enjoy more delicious beers, hearty/dense bread, potato pancakes, and appropriately heavy German food on a chilly November night.  Yum.
6.  Servers made sure we were adequately supplied with everything we needed.  Kudos.

Overall, I don't know that the experience could have been better.
author: Tim B.

description: I love the family-style seating, the candley lighting and of course the food/beer.  I can't vouch for the authenticity of the fare, but then again I don't really care, all I need to know is that its DAMN tasty.
author: Kyla B.

description: On my birthday last yr, I walked in with a cute (if I must say so) outfit and an empty stomach. When I walked -- err stumbled --out, I was bursting at the seams...full of a couple steins of german beer and Wiener Schnitzel. And I definitely did not qualify as cute with a huge belly and the addition of 3 party hats to my previously "cute" outfit. So let's just say that this place is great if you're down with some good ol meat and potatoes, lots of beer and going right to sleep post-meal. Good for groups, not great for vegetarians and perfect for gaining a couple lbs. in 2 hours.
author: Deann M.

description: Brought some German friends here and they said it was right on the money for authenticity.  My Austrian friends enjoyed the Wienershnitzle and my various other assortment of eastern European and Latin friends enjoyed everything especially the beer.  Vladimir had the biggest beer I have ever seen outside of a joke store.  Prices were a little bit high because it is Hayes Valley but we had fun and service was pretty quick for our party of 12.  I really have to give props to the owner and servers for being cool with some of the more tardy members of our party on a weekend night.
author: Jill D.

description: Great beers and good food in a cozy and enjoyable atmosphere.  You can really relax and enjoy your meal at this friendly joint.  Honestly, how could you not love a restuarant with this name?
author: Shiho F.

description: Let me begin by saying - despite the fact that I am 1/2 German and that my last name is so german that it makes most people think I am fresh off the boat, I normally DO NOT care for german food... too heavy, too much meat, etc, etc.  But, I do however LOVE beer.  And this place rocks!  I can't remember which specific beer I had, because I had already had two cocktails before getting here :), but whatever it was it was very tasty.... I was here with a friend on Valentine's day and this place was the perfect antidote to all the lovey-dovey bullshit going on everywhere else.  We just had a light dinner - potato pancakes and cheese spaetzle... and both were great (except the pancakes are not as good as my mama's)... I would come back here - seems like a fun place for a group.  And I love the neighborhood!
author: A B.

description:
This place is LOUD and packed!  The food is big, heavy, and skews toward all things pork.  I was here with a large group, so I was able to get a good survey of the menu - pig knuckle as big as my head, dumplings as big as my fist, meatloaf floating in a sea of gravy, various forms of schnitzel, and did I mention the pork - chops (more like ham - yes, the pink glazed type), sausage, and the aforementioned giant knuckle!  Beers served in boots and beyond...and for Oktoberfest there was a giant pretzel served with a bowl of mustard and yummy cheese spread - it literally took up half of our table!

I enjoyed the Suppenkuche, but alas I will have to fast for the next week - too, too much food for this mere mortal!
author: Lori G.

description:
Tis by my house, but since I've been living nearby I've gone a lot less than I used to. Typically, the "Soup Kitchen" is a perfect dinner spot for large groups on such occasions as birthdays or break up parties. It's quite popular for brunch now, but I have no idea what the menu is like since the only time I've gone was right at 2:30pm when they stop serving. Gee, getting up in time for weekend brunch isn't so easy! Anyhow, do not order the bacon or the eggs. I basically just drank beer since the eggs were undercooked and the bacon way overcooked. Next to us the servers sat down with a staff meal to be very envious of...bastards!
The pork dishes and the schnitzels are fantastic! Their spaetzle reminds me of days in Cleveland watching my friend's parents make it from scratch while we drank beer and Jager waiting for the delicious Eastern European flavors to be served up.
Update: few more great experiences there as of late, exploring all of their specials of the evening and different beer. YAY!
author: Colleen B.

description: For some reason, this place seemed to be "very San Francisco" to me.  Laid back atmosphere, good food, mixed crowd, and fun times.  I don't know many people who are big fans of German food, but it is fun to mix it into the rotation now and then.  While the food is pretty good, there is only so much you can do with sausage and potatoes.  You really want to go to Suppenkuche for the experience.  Great beer and a fun place.  Not sure if my visit was an aberration, but there were a lot of attractive people in there as well, including the girl who I thought was checking me out until she started making out with the girl next to her.  All the better.  Prost!
author: Brad K.

description: What a cute little joint. It's a busy place and you do have to share tables if you have a small party. My first time here, we were actually seated right away..... surprisingly. The beer menu is impressive, too many choice, but if you know what kind of beer you like, then you don't have to sit there and him and haw over what you want. I had the chicken schnitzel. It was good, I liked the cucumber salad and the roasted potatoes that it came with. YUM. We also ordered the wiener schnitzel and a steak. Both were good. I would definitely come here again to try all the other delicious items on the menu.
author: carebear l.

description: Well they've remodeled or something. I hadn't been back in a while. Last time I was there, we ate in the back room, which still might be the  way to go. This time we ate in the main room.  We showed up on a busy weekend night and got seated right away (at a shared table of course). The service was really fast and they kept all the orders, drink and food straight, despite the crowds. However, I almost walked out (stayed because we already ordered and well we like the food) because the place is SO unbearably loud. They need to figure out something. It is so loud that  its hard to relax or talk to one's dining companions. I'll have to find the slow time to come here. It deserves another star, but that noise....
author: Sleepy T.

description: I didnt know what to expect.  Im part German but I don't know German spots at all.  I didnt even know this place existed.  The place has that German feeling-- small, cold, dark room.... big wooden tables with no table cloths, no table settings.  They have a good selection of German beer, and to my delight the food was very good.  I had the meatloaf with the bacon topping and the surprise egg in the middle.  Dee-lightful.  Big hearty meal that left me feeling satisfied for 12 hours.  I also tried the pork loin with mushroom sauce and that was also delicious.  For aps we had the cold cut spread with bologna, salami, etc.  Good and hearty.  I would definitely go back.
author: Dan B.

description: German food?  We didn't really envision the food to be great, but this place does have pretty darn good food!  I went there once, and itching to go back!  I had the meatloaf, and it was awesome!  Not a huge fan of the soup, but just means that I won't be ordering it.  Definitely a loud place, but worth it for the food.  Besides, if you have a group of friends that you can be obnoxious with, then the more enjoyable it will be for you!
author: Tiffany H.

description: I've been trying to get in this place for over a year.  I finally made it on a Tuesday night at 9:00.  On my Birthday!  I wasn't let down, not even a little.  Great service, lots of beers and amazing food.  I haven't eaten like that since I was in the old country.  Not sure which country that was, but it was OLD.
author: Corey V.

description: Delicious beers and very warm and cozy atmosphere. All the standard German fare of schnitzel and spatzle with some really nice touches - the venison was really tasty. Not the place to go if you're feeling antisocial, but if you're going out to a popular restaurant in SF and bitching about the noise and close quarters, you can stop wondering why your friends stopped buying you birthday presents. Nice cozy place to visit on a cool fall night to remind you of places in the world that actually have winter.
author: Wilson M.

description: Maybe because Im not German...but I was not that impressed with the red cabbage laying on top of my meat. It ended up leaving the meat tasting sour. Oh well.
author: Prescott T.

description: What a blast. Went here for Sunday brunch and had an amazing time. Don't think about going without a reservation and be open minded if you're a picky food eater, but definitely give it a try. Great beer selection and a vibe that really plays well to typical German open air dining. It is loud, but not overwhelming.
author: Carl M.

description: Suppenkuche? Suppen - yah! Love the bread basket they give you and the family seating. Fun way to start your meal. Hubby and I split the schnitzel and a small cabbage salad, and that is plenty for both of us. Have tried the soups (a bit salty), but overall, great solid german food. check pleasE!
author: Mashi M.

description:
A friend of mine, who was born and raised in Munich, suggested Suppenkuche for Sunday brunch before the opera.

I got the nutella and banana panckes and two fruit sauces on the side.  It was a good sized plate, a bit too sweet for that day so I couldn't finish it.  Very delectable, nonetheless. 

I think my friend got the pork cutlet with spatzle and green salad.... it was eaten too fast and the plate was cleaned with some bread, so I didn't really get a good look at it.  She made several criticisms on the way the food was presented, but the fact that she ate everything tells me that presentation didn't really matter.  We shared the crispy potato pancakes and apple sauce.

From the atmosphere, it looked like the other patrons were having a good time, enjoying their food and drink.  The service staff was quite attentive though my water glass did not get refilled when emptied, yet, my decaf got refilled.  Parking on the street was a bit of a challenge but we managed to find a spot on Oak.   

I would be more than happy to stop in again and try something else, if I am in the area.

Prost!
author: L R.

description: Yummy food, lovely aesthetic, great beer.  The wait staff does want to pretend you don't exist, however... even when your large group has been ready to leave for awhile and there's a line outta the door and people from both group and line are making polite-to-blatant hints at the issue.  The inattention is more stubbornly apathetic than spiteful, though, so in the end this is one of those cases where vittles and surroundings trump shitty service.
author: Eartha K.

description: Not my typical fare, but the food was good. AND the place was fun. Crowded, rowdy, and fun.The staff was very knowledgable and friendly in recommending beers.
author: m t.

description:
great food, 
sausage!
go with a big group 
potato soup
order the beer boot
be loud
drink more beer
order the apple strudel
author: B. W.

description: This place gets 4 stars mainly for the beer and the people who work there. It's a pretty cool atmosphere and I like the vibe. The food was okay, but had some really interesting tastes. I don't recommend the herring appetizer...it was really gross. Maybe I just don't appreciate German food the way I should, but it tasted really fishy and...well, just kinda nasty. For the main dish, I had the trout, which actually tasted pretty damn good. My date had the pork chop, which I tried, and it was okay, but I wasn't all that impressed with the sauerkraut. Anyway, I didn't leave with a huge impression from the food, but the beer on draft there is YUMMY.
author: Emy s.

description: The beer is great. Boots are sweet but u can even order a 5 liter beer here. My complaint; pork knuckle looked amazing and it was an absolute disappointment. It's deep fried, and more than half of it is basically like eating a bad tasting pork roin.
author: Chris J.

description: I finally made it to this popular establishment. Did not do the beer boot probably should have.Foodwise it's ok. I had the jagerschnitzel.The spatzel was AWESOME, the cut of meat was fair, and the sauce was on the awesome side and totally made the dish. I should go back and try some other stuff, but as of right now I was more blown away by Walzwerk
author: Lauren V.

description: Can't vouch for the food, but beer selection is AMAZING, BT's (who buys all the beer) accent and knowledge of the breweries and beer is even MORE amazing (he was able to pronounce all those pesky umlauts, tell us exactly how long each brewery had been operating [up to 10 centuries!]), etc.). Plus, cool mini disco balls all over the ceiling that somehow blend in excellently with the slightly Nordic-wintry interior.
author: Esther H.

description:
Amazing beer selection -- quality, and variety.  Many beers that I haven't found in other restaurants even in bottles, much less on tap.  Plus a good rotation of even more difficult to find beers.  And where else can you drink out of a mass, boot, or 5 liter "mug"?

Great homey food -- heavy, but flavorful.  It's very good for this type of food, and better than any German food I ate in Germany (but I wasn't trying very hard).

Great boisterous atmosphere, you get to share tables with your neighbors.  This place has a great vibe that always leaves me happy.

The wait can be hellish, and the food is not mind-blowing (especially if you aren't downing a liter of delicious 7% a.b.v. doppelbock).  Hence not 5 stars.
author: Matthew A.

description: I love love love this place. food and beer are great here. the potato pancakes are a must!
author: Cam N.

description: I always take my parents here when they're in town to visit. My parents, being from Wisconsin, love the German food. I love to see my dad fawned over by the cute gay waiters, and we all love the beer. Everybody wins. The decor is sort of "sleek rustic", and the atmosphere is relentlessly friendly - I guess its a hipster vision of a Bavarian pastoral scene. It can be incredibly crowded and loud, but I don't care as the red cabbage is amazing and the salads are made with butter lettuce.
author: Christin E.

description:
The food was fantastic, but everything else was mediocre. My biggest complaint is the wait. I understand that it's a very popular place, but it sucks that they won't take reservations for small groups. When I went the first time with my girlfriend, they told us it would be 45 minutes for a table, then 25 minutes more, then 15 minutes more, each time because "it's moving slowly". Finally, we left. We tried again yesterday and had a similar experience: 40 minutes, then 30 minutes more, again because "it's moving slowly." Meanwhile, the hostess told another couple it will be an hour - even though it's clearly much more packed than when we got there, and she knows now it's moving slowly.

The food was great, but then there are a lot of great restaurants in the city where you don't have to wait so long (and where they can more accurately predict the wait).
author: David P.

description:
Kind of felt like I was in a wannabe hostel's dining room. Complete with rude server, rowdy friends and fighting couples. With a SF touch of course... meaning, artsy graphic designs of painted trees and butterflies. Disco balls and tree branches- oh, how ironic! That being said, it was insanely crowded for a Monday night, so the servers were spread thin, and the food was awesome with a few minor glitches here or there.  

My trusty dining partner and I (aka boyfriend) shared the pickled herring appetizer plate. He was unsure about ordering it, but I assured him it would be a fun dish to try. And it was! The fish was buttery soft and sweet! It went perfectly with the pickle+cucumber salad, pickled shredded carrots and red cabbage. Also went perfectly with our big glasses of beer. I had the Dunkel Weiss (or something like that). For the main, I had the venison, marinated in a red wine sauce, with spaetzel and red cabbage. The venison comes in two pieces. For some odd reason the first piece was disappointingly dry that it could've been any kind of meat. But, the second piece was perfectly cooked- red in the center and moist. Must've been a mishap... I'll let it slide since the correctly cooked piece was delicious. My boyfriend had the pork sausage over mashed potatoes and saurkraut. The mashed potatoes were sort of bland, but that herb butter they serve with the bread basket did the trick. The sausage on the other had was bursting with flavor and when I return I'll probably have that for my main. The waiter said we ordered too much-- he had no idea who he was dealing with =) We finished it all, and were even willing to have dessert, except there was only one option-- German Chocolate Cake. Now, I love chocolate just as much of the next girl, but this cake looked like it came from Safeway. You know, super sugary thick frosting and little cake, which looked more like a milk chocolate than dark. Anyhow, I would come back. Probably with a big group of friends so I don't have to awkwardly sit at a communal table with one gay couple who barely touches their food and one straight couple who would go in and out of a massive fight every ten minutes.
author: Nina H.

description: Noone told me you have to share a table? but no worries. The table was very warm and noone was listening to our conversation. The people that worked there were super duper nice. I had farmer's breakfast. Damn it's good. You can order beers for lunch too. That's what a good lunch is all about.
author: Michael K.

description:
Do you ever just "need" comfort food?  Sometimes, a person needs to eat an indescribable "something" to feel better when a bear hug just won't do the trick.  Lucky for us, we live in San Francisco and Suppenkuche serves up comfort in large, saucy portions.  It's not gourmet and certainly not pretty, but it's perfect for anyone who's in need of a hearty German meal and a sweet Radler (and wants to dress comfortably in stretchy clothes!!).

I had Sunday dinner with a few friends, and our group was large enough to get a reserved table.  It was a tad bit challenging to squeeze my ever-expanding body into a long, benched table, but the benches and long tables lent greatly to the casual and warm atmosphere abounding in this restaurant.  Next time I need something with gravy, I may have to get some Jagerschnitzel to go...

Here is what I ate:

* Kartoffelsuppe (Potato Soup) $5.00 - the temperature was not as hot as I would have liked, but I enjoyed the rich bacon flavor of this creamy soup.
* Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und grnem Salat (Breaded and Sauteed Porkloin with Roasted Potatoes and Green Salad) $16.00 - I tasted a bite of this dish, and it was good ... just a little too simple for me to want more than a bite.  Don't forget to squeeze lemon on your loin.
* Jagerschnitzel in Champignonsoe mit Sptzle und grnem Salat 
(Sauteed Porkloin in Mushroom Sauce served with Sptzle and Green Salad) $16.50 - This was awesome!  The Porkloin was not breaded, so I thought that maybe this would be a healthier choice that the Wiener Schnitzel.  I guess I was just fooling myself, though, because the mushroom sauce was very rich and creamy and soooooo damn good!  My spatzle was perfectly cooked through (not at all soggy) and went great with the mushroom sauce.  The green salad was butter lettuce leaves with a touch of dressing.  Simple.
* Black Forest Cake.  Can't remember how much it cost. - Absolutely the perfect closer to my meal.  Needed something sweet (cherries) to wash away the creaminess from my palate.  It was moist cake layered with whipped cream and cherries.  Delish!
author: Jenny K.

description: Yummy german food in communal seating. Very good german wines, and great beer, including in a boot! The spaetzle is to die for and the cabbage is incredibly tasty. Major drawback is it is very loud; for dinner, do not plan to converse with anyone not directly next to you.
author: Aimee B.

description:
i guess everyone is rating the place based on beer selection.  maybe i've just had a bad experience.  

the last time i went there, i wasn't the only one with a unpleasant feeling in the tum-tum which turned into a full on symphony.  
but if ya want to take your friends for beer and basic german fare this is the place.  you can't hear much above the drunkards by the bar so until i can read lips, i usually chat with the person next to me.

the cheese spatzle is ok.  i usually go for the usual sauerkraut and sausage or weiner schnitzel but my friends like anything pork or the meatloaf.  not the place for a first date unless you wanna cozy up close since you'd be eating with a bunch of loud strangers like my group.  

so four stars for beer, minus one for my hearing loss and wait time.  big groups beware.  rope your friends in since they won't sit you till all your ducks are in a row.
author: Anh V.

description:
i guess it depends on what you are looking for, at a german brewhaus restaurant with big communal tables.

i love beer, so i instantly loved suppenkuche.  i also really enjoyed the bar area, and funky chic decor.  

it is a lively place, and we were surprised that it was packed out and loud by 6pm (okay, i do concede that we were there on a friday, but still). conversation can be tough, but i think the beer makes up for it.  

food--Mister B and I have been on a weinerschnitzel kick this week, and i hate to brag but ours were damned tasty.  i wanted to see how the pros stood up to our simple concoctions consisting of panko, butter, s & p, and lemon.  it really did lack the juiciness and bright flavour ours had.  the potatoes and spaetzle were good but i couldn't finish them (prob on account of my beer-love).  the simple salad of butter lettuce with a wonderful vinaigrette was a nice break from the heavy flavours dominating the menu.

i had a lot of fun, though, and people-watched to my heart's content.  will most likely be back, for the beer.
author: Aimee B.

description: Friendly staff, good food. A 4/5 fits this place nicely.
author: Jack T.

description: I'm sitting in my office desperately wishing I could be in bed...unfort. the night before I violated an all important rule that college students learn freshman year : "Beer before liqueur you've never been sicker". Last night I had a fabulous dinner at Suppenkuche. I had sausages that the waitress recommended with light mash potatoes and a pint of this beer I can't pronounce at the moment but I choose it because it had Carmel and chocolate in it's description --it was really good. Anyways, then we went back to my friend's house where I had a mixed cocktail and now I'm miserable.  Beer before liqueur...yeah I'm definitely remember that rule from now on. Oh Suppenkuche -great food and tasty beers.
author: Kat F.

description:
i mean, i'm a vegetarian and it's a german restaurant.
but then again, this is san francisco.
but then again, i am a vegetarian eating at a german restaurant.
all that said, the portobello was pretty damn good, and the beers make the whole trip worth it.
great wooden tables, but otherwise fairly cold decor.
but then again, it is a german restaurant...
author: Seiji C.

description: We had an awesome time and an awesome meal!  Started out with beer, of course and had some potato pancakes and fried guyere cheese, both yummy.  Entree's were Jaegerschnitzel and Sauerbraten.  While the Sauerbraten was good, the Jaegerschnitzel was GREAT!!  The spaetzel served with each dish was great as was the red cabbage.  No room for dessert!!  Staff were friendly and helpful and we loved the communal atmosphere.  Can't wait to feel hungry again so we can go back!!
author: Ron T.

description: One of my favorite places. Atmosphere is great. I love to sit in the nook behind the bar. Great beers,  I like the Kreik Lambic, although it is very sweet and I can only have 1 or 2. The speatzle is top notch and the grilled pork sausage...delicious! When in SF I always try to make it here. Only downside, it gets super crowded and there can be a looong wait.
author: Bea M.

description: Hefeweizen and bavarian meatloaf for breakfast - need I say more?
author: N J.

description: There's always a loud, fun filled crowd when we eat at Suppenkucke. The potato soup is perfection. A huge selection of beers....for those who imbibe...and the dinner menu is right out of Germany! We've been eating here for 10 years now, and have never had a bad experience. Prepare to wait and then prepare to shout across the table at your friends....but prepare to fill up on excellent German food.
author: Darrin D.

description:
With 1,200 reviews, there's nothing more I can add. Nonetheless:

1) The giant pretzel really is over a foot across. Maybe two feet. Seriously.

2) Just ask the waiter if you don't know which beer to order. They know a lot.

3) Sauerbraten.

4) Go at 6pm if you can. No wait.
author: jason e.

description:
A friend of mine was visiting from Germany and missing food from home so we decided to come here to scratch his itch.

I don't think i've ever eaten at a German restaurant before or intentionally eaten traditional German food so I was a bit wary but also excited.  The beer selection was extensive and I was overwhelmed so I just pointed toward "dark" and was pretty pleased with what came out.  There were only two options for the vegetarians, a mushroom dish or a creamy pasta.  I went with the pasta.  It was extremely rich and warm and filling.  The small vegetable salad that was served with it was a nice balance to the thick cheesy pasta.

My main complaint would be the prices.  Just a bit too steep for what I was served.  Otherwise, it was a fun experience.
author: Sean R.

description: Great beer, good food and a very friendly and neighborly atmosphere. We were seated with a couple that we didn't know but we left feeling like we had made 2 new friends. btw, if you get the meatloaf during brunch... it kinda resembles spam more than your traditional meatloaf but it's still good.
author: James C.

description: It's nice to read about such a well-loved restaurant. And you can bring kids here and they can scream and no one cares because it's so loud. And the bar is fun, and good beer, and good looking people who are chatty, and outgoing, thus to me it is a place to "make new friends," as the euphimisms go.
author: Anna B.

description: Oh man, beer and comfort food. This place satisfies me everytime. A monastic, minimalist setting that is ideal for drinking some of the best german beers in the city. From Kolsch to Doppelbock,  you won't find a better list.  Always a great helpful staff on hand to help you through the great food and beer. I think I'm going tomorrow night.
author: Tim S.

description:
awesome.  great food, great vibe, fun place.
the four of us were willing to wait at the bar for as long as was required, and the wait was much better than expected.  I loved my Jager schnitzel, but everybody's plate was top notch.  a must do scene.
author: c d.

description: It's a great place for a group dinner. Very crowded but friendly, waiters were attentive even though it was super crowded. The white wine that I don't know how to pronounce was really good. The lentil soup was tasty.
author: Maya G.

description:
So, I'm German, and I've eaten there, and since I've done that I tell people back home that for the best German food they ought to go to San Francisco and Suppenküche.

Often regional cuisines get transformed in weird ways when imported to America; but this place preserves everything that's great about German cuisine and adds some. For instance the selection of beers; German restaurants only serve one brand; but this place has a selection that's stunning, plus bartenders that can explain all about it.

Food-wise, it belies the notion that German food necessarily is unhealthy. It's not; Sauerkraut after all is one of the healthiest dishes out there, and they serve a few very lean cuts. Other cuts too of course, so if you want to have your helping of leg of pork they'll do that as well.

Only problem -- size of dishes. Like in all American restaurants they're too large, and so even though the desserts looked really tempting I did not try one. Share, I guess....
author: Christian K.

description: Spaetzle to die for. Really, I didn't know fried noodles could be so good. Chill out in the back bar area with the friendly bartenders or share a table for dinner with some new friends. Pretty soon you'll be tossing back pints of yummy German beers with the rest of the crew.
author: Michelle O.

description: Suppenkuche ist die Bombe! The decor is people... meaning that is is a bit small and there are always a lot of people there. The beer is the best. Germans make the best beer. The food is pretty heavy, but typical German (at least from my experience).
author: John M.

description: Yum Suppenkuche! Really good food that feels like mom made it. Everything from the meatloaf to the mashed potatoes to the veggies is yummy! It's really cute inside but can be a bit awkward when you are a party of two seated at the same table as another group (I'm sure some good stories have come out of it but when I went the guy next to me kept commenting on my aura and wanted to read my palm). I have been with a group and it was a great place to dine. The best thing being the boot of beer (sip toes pointed down). The host can be a bit snobby but it seems to get little hectic for him. It's usually pretty easy to find parking in that neighborhood. One thing to note is that the menu changes daily. I went craving meatloaf on a day that they didn't have it. k
author: All About Town ..

description: I went here for brunch on sunday, july 25th.   we were seated against the wall at a communal table where they managed to stick six more people.  we couldn't even get out.  it took 40 minutes to get coffee, over one hour to get our breakfast and another 30 minutes to pay the check.  the entire brunch (only ordered pancakes- fyi, no maple syrup available) took over two hours.  i couldn't get a refill on the coffee (despite many requests) or more water.  after ten years in sf, this rates as the worst brunch i've ever had.  the food was bland- i could have easily made a better brkfst at home, and i'm a terrible cook!
author: Scott B.

description: Probably my favorite restaurant in SF.  Their beer list alone is reason to go.  Some people dislike the way you can get seated with strangers, but it's really not intrusive, and can sometimes turn out really nicely if you're open to it.  The food is really good, although only a minority of the menu items appeal to me; its one of those places where you always order one of the same few things, but you're never disappointed nevertheless.  The plain wooden tables, the friendly, pierced and accented servers, and the comfort-style cooking make for a warm and enveloping experience.  If you like beer, this is a spot you have to try.  If you don't like beer, well, that leaves more for the rest of us.
author: Ben H.

description:
Man Ich find es echt super das wir so ein tolles Deutschen Kneipe in San Francisco haben.

Hier kann mann ein Warsteiner (Konigen unter Bieren) drinken!!!  Mehr braucht mann nicht zu sagen obwohl das essen auch richtig toll ist!!!
author: Papandreou A.

description: I heart this place. Great customer service which was accompanied by excellent food. I had a boot of beer and the Spaetzle. I have been a few times and like most CA-ers I was running late, my party wasn't all there at the same time and they sat us regardless. I just love good customer service. This goes in the category of places I would bring out-of-towners.
author: Jessica S.

description: WOW.  The chicken schnitzel is amazing.  Lightly breaded, thin, tasty dipped in those super fluffy mashed potatoes.  The best part: CUCUMBER SALAD!  I loved this dish at brunch so much that I ordered it again the very next weekend.  Love the vibe there too and of course, the beer.
author: Andrea R.

description: I love this place.  Went for the first time last night and it was awesome.  The food was delicious and the service first rate.  By SF standards, the price was quite reasonable.  The best dining experience that I have had in the city in quite a while.  Highly recommended.
author: Brian T.

description:
I really f-ing like this place. The beer is awesome. The bartenders are not pretentious and will talk to about the beer. I especially like Craig. The food is good. The mashed potatoes are bomb. And, they'll let your substitute any side for mashed potatoes. 

I've had goose, roasted chicken, fish--- all were damn good. I'm not a douchey food writer for bon appetit or a cocky, fat harvard j.d. food critic, so "damn good" is all you get. (for those of you who get the reference, batali/lagasse were totally robbed.) I don't do schnitzel. but i may change that soon. 

Be prepared to stand awkwardly behind 40 people at the bar and wait an hour for a table. It doesn't matter what day of the week it is or what time you come in.
author: ascheras g.

description: What could be better than a pork chop before noon?  A salt-cured pork chop with mashed potatoes and kraut with a side of dark beer (Kostritzer)  before noon.  Oh, and let us not forget the basket of rolls and jam on the table...when you've got your own pot of jam why would you think twice about being squeezed into a table with complete strangers?  Complete strangers rarely make me squeal with delight, but a pot of jam...
author: L W.

description: I went there with two friends on a Friday night and was amazed at how great this place was.  My one complaint is they stop serving dinner at 10pm on Friday night.  The servings are huge, almost as big as the large steins of beer that are being served up.  I shared an entire with my friends along with the potato pancakes and soup.  Everything was extremely delicious and filling.  I hate sour kraut but found myself eating it here because it was very good, not sure what they do to make it taste so good.
author: Nick R.

description: Oh, the spatzle- the cheesy goodness I so love. The potato pancakes with homemade apple sauce is also delightful. The mashed potatoes were also amazing. And great beer. What else could you want?
author: Noelle Q.

description: An SF institution - this is the best place for German beers! Was here for a birthday celebration and we stuffed ourselves with the ravioli, pickled herring, potato pancakes, and managed to order main courses - my wiener schnitzel was very good but too much food! I guess that is the point. In Germany the portions are only slightly bigger!
author: Mariangela S.

description: Maybe it's just me, but didn't love it.  I have lived in Munich and Berlin, and traveled all throughout Germany, but the place came no where NEAR in comparison.  True, the beers are fantastic, but the hostess and waitress were a bit rude.  My sister was running late (BART delay), so we tried to hold off on ordering food until she got there.  In the meantime, we were drinking PLENTY (I can't emphasize the word PLENTY enough) of beer.  We were drinking fast too, so it wasn't like they weren't making money off of us.  However, they insisted we HAD to order or leave because "there were plenty of people waiting for our table."  I just don't agree with this policy.  Oh, and I thought the food was way heavier than anything I had ever eaten in Germany (and that is saying a lot), leaving little room for more beer--too bad.
author: Marla L.

description:
Excellent selection of beer, with great traditional german food, notably the potato pancake apetizer, german sausage, sauerkraut, chicken dishes and more. And did I mention the beer selection? You'd swear you were somewhere in Berlin, not a trendy San Francisco nook like Hayes Valley. 

The dining room is always packed full, so expect a wait if you don't already have reservations.

They do have a back room caters to larger parties, and if it's your birthday, don't act too surprised when lederhosen-clad, Euro-hotties stroll over to your table, cake in hand, singing birthday wishes to you. 

The dining room is dimly lit and large decorative flowers are strewn everywhere, traditional artwork adorns the walls, and german music is played as well, making it feel as if you're having dinner at a long lost German relative's home. 

Be prepared to leave feeling more stuffed than you probably have ever been in your life. 

Good food, great service, cute waitresses, great atmosphere and great beer make this place a gem in a city full of incredible dining locales.
author: Alex G.

description:
Food was ok but way overpriced.  The place was small and EXTREMELY LOUD.  Had to yell just to talk to the person next to me.  Lighting was very low, making it difficult to read the menu.
Stay at home and make your own.
author: hope g.

description: Come for the laughter, the wonderful beer (try the boot!), and leave completely satiated.  If you expect german food with a personal twist or fusion (like many joints in this city), this is the wrong place.  This takes me back to the small alpine villages of Bavaria and the wonderful city of München.  Very honest, straightforward.  Expect a wait.  Have a beer, I suggest Schlenkerla Oak Smoke, N'Ice Chouffe, or Weihenstephaner Korbinian.  Other likes:  potato pancakes with apple sauce, the spätzle is yummy with a hint of nutmeg, the red cabbage is a must, braised beef with lingonberries, wiener schnitzel, and blutwurst.  The salad is completely unnecessary, save room for the REAL food.  Skip dessert - have had, made, and eaten tastier apfelstrudel.
author: Liz D.

description:
how do you say i love this place in german!?   this place never fails to deliver. beers galot and beers galore in every size shape and taste.  its a traditional bavarian restaurant with communal seating, so dont be surpised to have other diners at your minimalist cedar tables.  

the service is excellent, the shnitzel, bratwurst, pork chops potato pancakes etc are all excellent.  dont sleep on this place for sunday brunch either, its one of my favorites.

the 'douche', my crew's nickname for this place, is also a great place to blow of some steam drinking one of their 4 lite boots of beer which i recently did after a tough day at the office.  its a gooden-timen!!!
author: Kevin J.

description: Yes, 5 stars. Great atmosphere,  fast service, amazing food. I tried the troute, pork schintzel, and beef in plum sauce, and they were all incredible. There are a couple of vegetarian items on the menu (cheeze spatzle and a mushroom dish) but I highly recommend the trout if you're fishivore.
author: Emily B.

description: Our group of 6 had a great time tonight. Unlike other reviewers the restaurant was neither packed nor loud, most likely due to our 7pm Monday reservation. Our waitress was patient and knowledgeable in helping us select our beers (hint: explain your tastes and ask your server for advice). She was also flexible in allowing us to order outside the menu and swap side-dishes with our meal. The food was incredibly tasty (my venison was delicious). Perfect portions, and there were several heavy eaters amongst us. Will definitely return.
author: Brian T.

description:
Disclaimer: What you are about to read is written by a person that has NO clue how to spell in German, so if I spell anything incorrectly, hopefully you will get the point (Really, how hard is it to spell the name of this restaurant?) 
When hearing that Suppenkuche has excellent German food, I said, "Really? German?" I mean, the only German food I have ever eaten was a giant pretzel and an apple strudel. So being somewhat adventurous, I decided to try it out.  First off, the restaurant is tiny, (hey, the bar is a pretty good size!) but I figured we would get a good table.  All of a sudden, we are at the same table with another group: Suppenkuche does family style seating (At least we didn't get seated next to some old guy drinking five boot beers and showing us his fake teeth by the time our dinner was served).
