Off the bat, we ordered some beers and the potato  pancakes.  The pancakes were very good and tasted like hash browns, but they were not greasy or heavy.  The applesauce they served with the pancakes was sweet and very yummy.  We then ordered the trout, Wiener Schnitzel, and saurbraten.  They were all very satisfying but not heavy and rich as I imagined they would.  We ended trading our dishes around (but not with our table neighbors) to get a bite of everything.  My fish was very light, and the potatoes and vegetables were fresh.  Overall, I was pleasently suprised with Suppenkuche, and I will be back (oh yeah, HAPPY OKTOBERFEST!)
author: Shannon W.

description: Although I do like this restaurant, they called my girlfriend on the day of her birthday to say that her confirmed reservation for 15 could not be honored because they've overbooked the restaurant.  Who does that?  Thanks to Open Table, we found an alternative last minute, but this snub will not soon be forgotten.
author: Steve B.

description:
Get here a little before 5pm on weekend if you want to get seated in the first wave! My party of 3 showed up at 5:00 exactly and we ended up having to wait an hour and a half because the line was already down the block! It was worth the wait though and the shops nearby are fun to explore while you waste time. 

The place was really crowded when we got in and there's only communal seating. Things started to calm down around 7ish though (on a Saturday) and the bar cleared enough that my mom didn't keep getting smacked in the back of the head by passing waiters like she did in the first quarter of the meal. Serve time was not the fastest but then again the place was packed... 

The food though: Authentic! Delicious! The beer list was extensive and they had dunkelweizen on tap (my favorite). We all shared the potato pancakes with apple sauce. They were thicker than I like and deep fried instead of panfried... nice and crispy on the outside though and soft in the inside. The seasoning was really well done and the applesauce was the perfect consistency and sweetness to compliment. I had the jagerschnitzel with spatzel, and I substituted the rotkohl for the green salad. The rotkhol is some of the best I've had. The spatzel was burnt in some places like they had a big pan of it that overheated. The schnitzel was tender beyond belief. My mom chose the bratwurst (was very good when I tasted it); she had been thinking about having the sauerbraten but the waiter advised against it and said it's tough sometime because they store it out of the liquid over night. Thank goodness for honesty. And my man had the suckling pig that was definitely the star of the meal! So tender!!! 

Were there some flaws? Yes. But in total was it amazing to find authentic German food in the bay area? YES! I would definitely recommend this place to somebody craving German style fare that goes beyond the stereotypical wurst and pretzels (though they have that too!).
author: Katrina E.

description: It is always reassuring to know that after a stay in Germany one can, upon returning to SF, enjoy a great lager and a well-cooked, central-European meal.   I love this place.
author: Donato C.

description:
the smell in this place alone makes me happy.

sure, its crowded and loud and you have to share tables etc.

i could care less!

wonderful food, wonderful beer and the staff has always been nice to me
author: erik H.

description: I drank great beer out of a boot and it was everything I thought it would be. Remember,.. toe facing out when you get to the end :) otherwise. well... you'll see!  I chose the portabella mushroom with the feta and tomato cream. it was cooked perfeclty and I cleaned off the plate to the last drop of sauce left on it with no problem. yum! I'm not sure how this place compares to authentic german food. but I will say it was delicious. atmosphere is lively. I did find my throat to be a little scratchy at the end of the evening and realized it was because I had been pretty much screaming for the past 2 hours in there! Its pretty noisy. The bartendar with the cute hat is very nice. The waiters were all very friendly. Learned a thing or two about germans and their beer from the cool waiter. No wonder this place has a great reputation. I'll go back again when I'm in a beer-me mood.
author: Food L.

description: The food and beer have been amply covered by others.  I'll just add:  the seasonal decor is inspired, the waiters are angelic, and do try to save room for the black forest cake....
author: Mutant O.

description:
I've come here several times with clients, with my fiance, and with friends...each time I've not been terribly impressed with the food.  The Jagerschnitzel is about the only thing that I've tried that is constantly ok.  Last night I had a particularly annoying experience...I had the sauteed venison medallions and asked for kaesespaetzle instead of plain spaetzle.  The waitress informed me that they do not do kaesespaetzle as a side.  Not true - they've done it for me EVERY SINGLE other time I've been there.  I was a little bitter about this, it's one of my favorites but god knows I can't eat a whole plate of it.  So, fine...no kaesespaetzle for me.  The venison was extremely dry and our friend had the chicken special of the day - which he said was very rubbery.  In the past, we've had the sauerbraten, which is not very sour at all.  My grandmother makes this dish every year for Christmas and has for the past 60 years.

Bottom line - totally over rated at this point and has lost the German flare it no doubt had when it was newer and still cared about the quality/authenticity of the food it served.  Check out Walzwerk or Speisekammer over in Alameda....YUM!
author: Kelly M.

description:
i love german food, but suppenkuche was a disappointment.  the beer was great with a lot of variety and great flavors, but some of the dishes fell flat. 

what worked -- the wiener schnitzel was above average and i might come again just for that; potato pancakes were delicious

what didn't work -- their sides were pretty horrendous, and the sauerbraten (braised beef) i tried was too tough, overly salty, and overall not worth finishing.  the pasta it came with was also too salty and starchy; the butternut squash soup was way too oily.  i know it's supposed to be oily, but it got to be a bit too much after the 2nd spoonful 

i would probably give this is a 2.5 if i could
author: Robyn F.

description:
All of the hype and reviews are on the spot for this place.  I wanted to subtract a star because of the crappy and ridiculous parking situation here but the food and the beer here is so good that I couldn't do it.

I came here with 4 other guys.  It's a small and cramped restaurant but there's a great energy in the air.  Everyone is here to enjoy the food and the beer.  Unless you have a really big party, you're going to share a table - cafeteria style - with othes.  

The beer here flows freely and is simply the best I've ever had.  It's smooth and tasty.  I had the dunkel which is a darker beer but wasn't heavy at all.  

I'm not going to go into heavy detail about the food but everything here is hearty and very home-cooked.  It didn't really taste much like restaurant food.  Also, the portions are huge.  Come hungry and get here early so you can get a parking space and a table.
author: Scott L.

description:
This place used to serve better food. But, I go for their selections of draft beer. I especially like Kolsch beer served in a skinny glass. Their potato pancake is not too good but the sauerkraut is delicious so as pureed potato. I usually order the sausages which are better than any other German restaurants.
This place is too crowded.
author: Yu T.

description: You know you're in the right place when The Food Network walks through the door with cameras rolling during your meal.  Very traditional German fare and great beers, served in a variety of glassware, including "DAS BOOT!"  I had a great brunch of veal and pork sausages in broth with a pretzel and mustard.  My buddy had the potato pancakes which were perfectly done (crispy on the outside and very warm and soft on the inside).  If I was not completely hung-over I may have had more food.
author: Josh F.

description: Great German restaurant!  I really enjoy the hearty food and tasty beer.  The waiters give great beer recommendations.  Though it can be a bit cramped, it does foster a feeling of friendly togetherness with other diners, if they are pleasant.  The host and hostesses can be accommodating for large parties.
author: R L.

description:
i loved this place!  it's not for the picky eater that can only handle half of a plate at a regular restaurant.  i was definitely full after my plate of brat, kraut, and mash potatos.  

the beer selection was also great.  i was conservative with the konig, but had i not been there on a monday night i would have gone bigger than the half liter and hit up the boot.  i'll definitely be back!

oh, and i got to see the houses from full house on the way there.  definitely cool.  go tanners.
author: Hammer Time H.

description: Authentic German food is hard to find but if you've found yourself at Suppenkuche, you'll be satisfied.  I recommend the Kasespatzle mit Zwiebel-Buttersosse und gemischtem Salat $12.00 (Cheese Spatzle in Onion Butter Sauce served with a small Mixed Salad) or the Champignon gefullt mit Spinat und Schafskase auf Paprikasosse $10.50 (Portobella Mushroom stuffed with Spinach and Feta Cheese served on a Pepper Sauce).  Meat entree's run closer to $16+. Don't pass up a chance at an authentic German imported beer with dinner.  The bench seating and micro bar in the corner conspire to give this place a truly German feel. Service tend toward the slow side and long waits are not uncommon.  Over all only the price brings this restaurants score down.  If you want to have eastern European food at a bit of a savings try Old Krakow
author: Ian H.

description: The Yeager Schnitzel is better than what I had in Germany, only it was a third of the price in Germany. Great authentic environment, family style eating. EXCELLENT german beer selection. They had Kolsch, which is made only in Cologne by a hand full of brewries. Definitely a place to try!
author: Jeff C.

description: A must for beer lovers and anyone who likes having a great time. Taken there for the first time for a friend, I was blown away. I had heard from many people that German food wasn't that great and typically bland. Boy were they wrong, or maybe they were just going to the wrong place.  The braised beef was excellent and very tender, coupled with a pint of spring bock it was pretty much divine.  The second time I went there was with a large group. Again the food was excellent but what really highlighted the night was the beer or more importantly the "Boot". A 2 liter glass boot to be precise.  I've never seen something so beautiful.  Well a hour and two boots later, all I remember was stumbling out on to Hayes full and drunk... the perfect start to a night.
author: Chris F.

description: I would have given 4 stars if only for the food but we came in a bit late (9:30 late?) and had horrible service as if we put everyone out just by coming in.  The food was great even for the unexpected vegetarian dish somewhere known for sausage.  P.S. Get the black forest cake, it's amazing.
author: Tricia M.

description:
so this place has amazing weinersnizllzlzellelzle.... however you spell it!

id go there everynight if i was a rich man! i just dont like the fact that you have to wait for hours and the place is always always cramped! maybe they want the authentic german bar feeling? im not sure but i just dont like having 6foot tall dudes breathing down my neck while im enjoying my beer as i wait for a seat!

but really really good place
author: Steven T.

description: I love this place!!! Everything is authentic from the beer (20 beers on tap) to the food to the decor to the atmosphere.  The long bench like tables encourage conversations amongst diners.  So if you're interested in a quiet, intimate dinner with your significant other...Suppenkuche is not the place.
author: Keith S.

description:
worth to check it out.
we love that place we go on a regular basis.
but never went for brunch sounds good though.
author: Sandy W.

description: Got there at about 5pm on a Saturday and drank beer and ate bread and appetizers at the bar for two hours while we waited for a table. We ended up eating and drinking so much at the bar that we left without actually eating dinner. Ironically this place makes a better bar then a restaurant, because you get free bread that tastes pretty good and you don't have to wait at all to get a beer. Beer and bread ends up being a pretty cheap meal too. Also, this place is pretty crowded and not very wheelchair friendly. If I ever go back I'll make reservations first.
author: Luke M.

description:
i've been here a few times now and always have a great time. there's a great selection of beers and you can get them in different sizes...da boot. the atmosphere is great and casual and all the tables are communal, which can be fun. 

they don't take resies so be prepared to wait, although i've never had to wait too long, but it's always just been me and another friend. i'm sure if you have a large group, you may have to wait longer. but grab a beer at the bar and hang out, make new friends or there's lots of other bars in the area you could grab a quick drink and then come back. 

i usually get the pork schnitzel with mushroom cream sauce, but this time i got the breaded pork chop with creamed peas and mashed potatoes. the pork chop was huge and SO tasty. nice and juicy, perfectly cooked. it came with a side of dijon mustard, but i didn't need it at all. my friend got the lamb chop with potato gratin and green beans. i don't usually like lamb, but the chops were pretty tasty, and so was the gratin!! as usual, the food was hearty and tasty. perfect for a slightly chilly sf night.
author: Angela W.

description: German gem of San Francisco. Are you craving really good German beer on tap? Go to Suppenkuch. The food is fantastic, especially the cheese spetzle. Dreamy jagerschnitzel and of course the beer. The secret to Suppenkuche is the mini wooden bar alcove. You can order dinner back here and actually hear what someone is saying to you unlike the main dining room that is quite lively. Keep your eyes peeled for Schlenkerla Rauchbier on tap. A must try for any beer lover!
author: Nikki T.

description: I love the bartender "Craig."  He knows his beer!  I really like the atmosphere and vibe.  The menu is simple and yummy.
author: Cyn C.

description:
[1] the food is very good -- it's refreshing to know that the wait staff actually recommends the food they and/or customers seem to like best instead of just something expensive. my server recommended the meatloaf, which was delicious, and it may just be the cheapest item on the menu. the venison medallions are also tasty.
[2] the beer is outstanding -- there is a good selection of fairly different kinds of german and belgian-style beers. the menu describes them well, and the wait staff gets excited about what you order, too.
[3] the atmosphere is fun -- i like the idea that my friends and i might be sitting at a table with strangers. that can make for a fun meal, but it is also fairly easy to ignore them if that's what you want. i do wish there were a little more space, though...the restaurant is a bit cramped.
[4] spatzel is simply delicious. who knew?
author: Jon W.

description: Very tasty German food with an excellent selection of beers to accompany that food.  You better be hungry, you will full (and happy) when you leave.  Reservations are taken for groups of 6 or more (I believe)
author: Christopher K.

description:
My wife and I come here all of the time, and we take our guests here. It has an amazing selection of beers on tap (incoming my favorite, Kstritzer), and large portions. The food here is also excellent, serving standard south german dishes. The quality is quite high though compared to most german restaurants in the united states -- for example, their breading is always crunchy and fresh on their schnitzel. Also they serve the most amazing potato pancakes in existence! Their black forest cake is also quite tasty, although you probably won't have room for it after eating dinner and a beer or two.

Like others have said, it's loud in here so probably not a good place for a romantic date. You are also seated next to other diners, at shared tables. But it's always lively -- though be prepared to wait if you come during peak dinner hours (have a beer at the bar!).
author: Robert C.

description: Suppenküche has got to be one of my favorite spots. The food is fantastic. The service is first class. The atmosphere is warm and homey. The beer is tops. And best of all, the price is quite reasonable. I've eaten here for brunch and dinner several times, and I've always been immensely satisfied and happy upon leaving. The sausages are amazing, the spetzel is as good as Mom makes, and the red cabbage is scrumptiously delicious. Irish and German food are probably my all-time favorite comfort cuisines, so I am somewhat inclined to like just plain old good food that is cooked well without loads of spices, and this place just makes my taste buds sing. I can't say a bad thing about Suppenküche, let alone the fact that it is crowded (go figure!) and noisy. This is a great place for a group of friends, not so much for a couple on a date, since it is family style. I loves me some Suppenküche!
author: Geoffrey B.

description:
As a fan of good beer and German food, Suppenküche is probably one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  I really like their beer selection, which includes less well-known brews from Germany.  The setting feels like a modern indoor beer garden with the minimalist wall art and wood benches.  Both the main and side dishes have been consistently good in my experience, which puts it a step ahead of Walzwerk (great sides, ho hum mains) and many steps ahead of Schroeders (go for the beer, not the food).

One reason I wouldn't give five stars is I'm excited to eat here about once every 6-12 months. More often and I think I would get burned out. Also, I don't always have a big enough group (minimum of six) to make a reservation.  Otherwise, wunderbar!
author: Jay B.

description:
a little out of my usual price range. 
above average food. 
would go here again but would need to show up buzzed so i could afford to drink here. 

crowded and i guess "trendy" but what isn't these days

will go here again when i am down for some decent food and good beer and a good vibe
author: Trent D.

description:
one of the better german places about the city.  great decor, family style seating, there is a lightness to the place that is really cosy.  we ordered the schnitzel and bratwurst and must say the schnitzel was good.  I probably wouldnt order the bratwurst again...the menu said nurnberg bratwurst so we were expecting smaller, firmer sausages which wasnt the case.  great beers to accompany the food, they serve a 5-litre beer and to watch someone drink this will be a sight in itself.  
they dont take reservations and you will probably have to wait if you arrive anytime after 6:30.  we were there at 5:30 and it started to fill up real quick from 6:30 onwards.  It gets really noisy so be warned.
thumbs up from my german husband so we'll be back for sure!
author: Teresa T.

description:
A friend told me about this restaurant a few months back and I decided to give it a try on a night I had visitors. 

I ordered the skirt steak with truffle butter, some others at my table ordered the meatloaf and another big hit was the bratwurst. My table ordered an assortment of beers and they all tasted fantastic. 

The atmosphere was welcoming and friendly.  We went at a very busy time, yet I assume it's always busy there, and we were seated at a table with some girls who were great about sharing their food and letting us have a chance to taste some of the things we didn't order. 

I've been back a couple times since then and I highly recommend this place to anyone who visits the city. GREAT food!
author: Jessica K.

description: The beer menu is fabulous and the food is very hearty, filling and tasty. If you are in the mood for German cuisine and beers, this is the spot.
author: A D.

description: Amazing! HUGE portions of delicious food and giant tubs of beer. I especially like the Jgerschnitzel and the Venison... and did I mention the beer? Oh... check it out for a great brunch too (Sundays only)... but be forewarned... it's a heavy morning meal!  You can handle it though... I know you.
author: Matt W.

description: Every one of our group of 7 had excellent food and beer.  It's a plus that they really know the beer and serve it in the correct glass.  It's also a plus that the food is prepared and presented well...last time we were in Germany, the cut of meat still had the skin...and fur...on it.  At Suppenkuche, they kindly remove the exterior parts.  Be prepared - the place is small and loud.  We couldn't figure out how the unfinished wooden tables stay so clean and white.  They don't smell like bleach and we couldn't find evidence of sawdust from daily sanding.  We figured it must have been elves.  Or magic.  Or the 6 pints of Erdinger Dark.
author: Joe L.

description: I first came here with my dad 4 yrs ago when he once came to visit, and I thought it would be a great spot to relax and share a memorable father-daughter beer. The I re-visited when a good friend was leaving for a year-long trip and 8of us met for brunch. i have to say i was quite surprised and impressed with a yummy and delightful choice of brunch treates ( I think I was expecting heavy, greasy, but no! con trere mon frere! It was lovely and the windows even opened to the refreshing air outside. i say GO!
author: Howard C.

description: I had a great experience at Suppenkuche!  The artsy decor, variety of drinking cup sizes (regular glass to a 2-liter boot!) and the large picnic tables created a very lively atmosphere...great for big groups.  The staff were super friendly and the food was delicious!  I was starving by the time I got there, so the big portions were definitely to my liking.  As always, I yelped the restaurant beforehand and I made a mental note to order the potato pancakes because everyone was raving about em...and they were delicious!  It was this deep fried hash brown smothered with this homemade apple sauce.  I also ordered the meatloaf wrapped with bacon and eggs with a side of mashed potatoes and gravy.  I usually can't finish my food, but I definitely cleared this plate.  :)  I'd highly recommend this place!  It was just what I needed on a rainy weeknight.
author: Siu L.

description: Just thinking about the potato pancakes and applesauce makes my mouth water.
author: Jenn F.

description: Great selection of beer and wonderful spaetzle.   During my latest visit, I had the roasted pork in a beer sauce.....reminded me of carnitas.  The black bread is excellent.  To enjoy, you must be a fan of sharing tables and noise.  Amazingly little confusion.  The wait staff is always helpful, nice and never too busy to explain options.  Since they don't take reservations for smaller groups and it fills up fast, plan on arriving by 4:45 for a table at 5.
author: Cathy N.

description:
If you love beer , an atmosphere and great food you can't beat Suppenkuche . This is my go to restaurant for a casual dinner with local and out of town friends .  Reservations are for 6 + but plan ahead by 3-4 weeks.

Potato pancakes ,roast suckling pig and apple sauce ! Top notch.


Prost !
author: Conor F.

description: Sausage. Potato Pancakes. Beer. If you think these are good things (and you should), then you'll enjoy Suppenkuche. It can get noisy and crowded, and you might wind up sharing a parsons-style table with people you don't know, but it's a great alternative to starting the weekend with wine and Italian food.
author: Timothy O.

description: It's been a week since I had dinner here and I'm still thinking about it!  The food is just so warm and comforting and the sparkling lemonade and beer concoction is pretty darn tasty.
author: Jen C.

description: Fun, tasty, festive with excellent beer selections.   Food didn't wow me, but a+ for atmosphere.  I think Leopolds on Polk is a bit better, but similar ideas for sure.
author: michael d.

description: Good comfort food.  Be ready to eat because if you dont clean off the plate here you will regret it, maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow but some day you will regret it.
author: H C.

description: Delicious food and hearty beers, what more can you ask for? I especially liked the chicken that tasted like caramel sweetness! Be prepared to be seated at other people's tables though - all in good fun.
author: Apple P.

description: Suppenkueche is a favorite SF German place to eat for this German-American. And the owner is friendly and generous to German-American non-profits, too.
author: Sunset G.

description:
mos def a great time. i will list the pros:

1. GREAT Beer
2. Venison, Stuffed Mushroom, Spaetzle, Beet Salad & Potato Pancakes are yummmmmy. 
3 Friendly attractive staff
4. Beer
5. Jesus Candles at bar 
6. Ceiling art changes 
7. Pop Music
8. Your table neighbors are usually really drunk like you by the time you leave. If you dont swap spit at least swap #s
9. The 100% LATINO Kitchen staff. :-) 
10. Beer
11. People watching
12. Sausage duh

CONS:

1. Some ppl bring their babies during rush hour dinner & let them run around like add monkeys - awesome
2. asshole guests who don't understand the sharing tables thing
3. thats it
author: Abcde Q.

description: Had the special-Organic Chicken Schnitzel mit Kartoffelbrei . . mashed butaydas.  Chicken was tender and seasoned well but I forgot to order Sauerkraut. . .IDIOT!!  Noisy is the only downside in case you already hear loud voices.
author: Jon K.

description:
If it wasn't so crowded and I didn't fall into a food coma every time I went, I'd be there at least once a week. You can't fault a place for being popular and successful, but just once I'd like the place to myself (all the beer I can drink and all the Suckling I want). 
I've been plenty of times, and most recently a few weeks ago with three other people (about a 30 minute wait). Don't even try to bring a large group on the weekends, you will be waiting a LONG time. But do not fear, they have plenty of tasty beer on tap. Having said all that, the atmosphere is great- stripped-down wood decor, and the food/beer combination can't be beat.
author: marty b.

description: Yum yum bring on more beer! This place was an hour and a half wait but it was well worth it! I had potato pancake, it was crispy with shreds of fried potato around a yummy soft filling of mashed potato so good! I then had the meatloaf with bacon, egg and mashed potato. I didn't taste the bacon but did see and taste the hardboiled egg in the middle of my meatloaf. It was a little dry but the gravy helped. Not the best meatloaf I've had but it was good. The mashed potatoes are yumo! The people next to me had Weinershnitzel (I'm sure I spelled it wrong) You know the fried porkshop thing, it looked GOOD! I wanted some. My friend had the beef stew, it was a bit dry but flavorful. My other friend had the pork sausage it was good.
author: Karen T.

description: This place was extraordinary. I had never been to a German restaurant before, but this is the place to go to with a group a friends. For those who appreciate belgium beer, you can order it by the stein. The potato cakes were especially delicious when topped with homemade applesauce(not too sweet!). My friends and I bought a round each of beer and ordered several plates to share. A great place for omnivores. A great place for low lit nights of wind and rain.
author: Calvin C.

description:
My boyfriends loves Suppenkuche and so do I.  I love the ambiance -- they used to have these tiny butterflys smattering the ceiling.  The butterflys are gone but there are some upside-down gnomes that are equally as fun.  The beer is great and so is the food.  The portions are huge so I always end up taking stuff home for my boyfriend to eat later.  
If you have a problem sitting with other people then you may not like it but if you like to socialize then this is your place.  
Did i mention the food is great???!!!!
author: samantha D.

description: Best surprise birthday party ever. If you love beer and eat meat, there's a 99% chance you'll love this place. If you're thirsty, go for DAS BOOOOOT!
author: annie s.

description: First time I came here, I was challenged by the great ach of achilles to an epic night of daz boot. Looking from the outside, the boot in question did not seem too arduous of a task to complete. It was only 64 ounces of beer, paling in comparison to that of Shroeders' 84 ounce boot. However, this was my first time ever accepting a challenge of belch.. so I had no idea of what was to come. Our party of 16 was seated about an hour and fifteen minutes into our wait. I couldnt wait to drink that damn boot. When the boot came, we immediately started drinking. One of our brethren, nicknamed Warren G the sleeze, wanted to be champion as he was filled with hubris. He drank quite fast, and was several gulps ahead of me and bslut. As our night continued, we ordered a couple entrees to accompany our delicious ale. We ordered some german sausages, along with some fries and mashed potatoes (?) they were pretty damn delicious. Even if I wasnt drunk I would have easily rated this place 4 stars based on food alone. The meat was very tender, and the fries were very crispy. They were delicious by all standards. Anyways, back to the boot. Well, two amazon women at our table combined forces and finished the boot first... too bad it doesnt count because we were doing 1 boot 1 person, thus 2 person would mean 2 boots. whattup. heh heh heh. Just as me and Bsleezy were about to finish our boots, hoots decide that it wasnt fair that he was doing all the drinking, so he decided to feed some of that liquor back to the glass boot. Yah he yacked the shit out of that boot into that boot. I finished literally 1 second after Bslut, however because he had given a taste gulp to his gf, he was disqualified, crowning me as champion of suppenkluche sup sup supp. After my victory, Bslut bought a boot for one of our friends, and since no one, including her, wanted to drink the boot, it was only after 1 singular sip of the brand new boot before Bslut dunked all our combined monies into the beer. yahhh what a crazy night. thats what daz boot can do to a man -it unleashes his inner rage, making his hair golden and spikey as he goes super saiya jin 2
author: simon k.

description: Super friendly (but loud) atmosphere that serves up some of the best German food in the city. Seriously, how can anyone dislike a restaurant that has a boot of beer on the menu?
author: Jordan M.

description: Uber gut! This is some damn hearty German food if I've ever had it. Start off the night drinking a nice big stein of Oktoberfest and snack on dumplings, potato pancakes and applesauce. Then we decided on splitting a bunch of entres becuase they looked so good, and man was that a fantastic idea. Meatloaf, braised beef with spaetzel and goulash all split between us with amazing red cabbage and a meatball meal they gave us by mistake (on the house) with fantastic potatoes... Then, because it was my birthday, they topped it off with a free slice of amazing chocolate cake. Noisy, picnic tables and huge, heavy mugs of beer; how every restaurant should be. This place definitely puts my midwestern German heritage to shame. To shame!
author: Michael E.

description: best meatloaf ever ! And such great beer. This place is a must. They open after 5pm and the wait is worth it. IT is fun how they sit you with different people, the place is loud and fun. You can also drink from the boot !
author: Berenice D.

description:
beer, sausage, sauerkraut, mashed potatoes, and beer...YUMMY!

a GREAT restaurant that is not unreasonably priced.  everything we had here was truly delicious starting with the cauliflower soup and the pickled salad.  you literally cannot go wrong with their beer selection.  i can wholeheartedly recommend the following:

(1) Wiener Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Bratkartoffeln und grunem Salat
(2) Gegrillte Nunberger Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut und Kartoffelbrei
(3) Jagerschnitzel in Champignonsosse mit Spatzle und grunem Salat
author: eric g.

description: Casual fun atmosphere with authentic German meals.  My mother moved here from Germany, and Suppenkuche is the first place that can ALMOST mimic her Rinderouladen (meat rolls) and red cabbage.  Make sure take advantage of the beer selection.  The seating is open, so join another group and make new friends.  You can all pretend you're backpacking through Europe.  Don't tip like you're in Europe, though. :)
author: Monika M.

description: Ok, so I guess like everyone else here I had the Wiener Schnitzel and a Pilsner (okay, I lie, more like 5). But hey, they make you ask for your water over there so I just kept ordering beer! The cool thing is that you share long tables with other people if you're in a small party just like in the real German beer halls! I tried a bit of everything from my friends' plates, which included potato pancakes and sausage and sauerkraut, all of which were UBER good. I'm so stuffed I need to go buy some new pants now....
author: Natalie T.

description: I've eaten here many times over the years and have never left disappointed.  This is my favorite German restaurant in all of the Bay Area.  The food is fantastic and priced reasonably; the beer selection is very good and the service is prompt and friendly.
author: Steven V.

description:
first time i had german food and it sparked a new found love...for my tummy. my first instinct was to try the schnitzel, but i wanted to try something i havent had in a while - venison. the meat wasnt gamey whatsoever, was tender, and plentiful. i got two heaping pieces! every entree dinner comes with a starch side and a vegetable. with my venison, i got a potato pasta, almost like gnocchi. i could just not get over the potato pasta. it was lightly seasoned, but was simply tasty. i wasnt too keen on eating my pickled beets (or was it red cabbage?) and it sorta took over my plate...however, when i made a super bite composing of all three elements, it tasted deeelish!

we also ordered some potato pancakes served with an apple sauce dipping sauce. ohhhh, its so bad for my waistline, but yummy in my tummy. 

i LOVE the intimacy because it looks like we're eating in a once dining or living room of the house the building once was. instead of crowing the space with little tables, there are big tables where groups of people can sit together and befriend each other. a gay couple sat with us and were a complete riot! the guy next to me had the chicken, smelled great. when he was done with his dinner, every bone was sucked dry...i think i'll try the chicken or the fish the next time i come around.

i hear they have brunch...i'll try that out with a boot sized beer!
author: marlene m.

description: I really just wanted an excuse to write: "stark, Bavarian decor meets lively dinner crowd." But really, where else could you sample venison and wild boar and cheer for man drinking two litres of beer out of a glass shaped like a boot? (apparently there is a stiletto for the ladies, but I have yet to try..). The portions are quite large with standard dishes featuring a mountain of Meat thronged by a sea of Potato and a field of Cabbage. Which can be really tragic if you wanted to have any room to try the tasty potato pancakes. I have found that if you eat a very light lunch at around 11am, you have a good shot at the main course. Bonus: huge beer selection and opportunity to chat with your neighbors as sharing tables meets truly Deutsch efficiency standards. Negatories: even for a party of two on a weeknight, expect to wait 30min +
author: Greenballoon X.

description: Good food and a great beer selection.  The place isn't that big and I don't recommend trying to go on a Saturday night without reservations.  Can get very crowded and loud.
author: Bryan E.

description: There's not many places in SF to enjoy a fantastic brew and authentic grub from Duetschland at a long wooden no frills picnic style table.  I love it!!!  The service was helpful, friendly, AND quick, which just puts it over the edge!  I have the Schnitzel and spaetzel and I loved every minute of it.  beer+shnitzel=WUNDERBAR!!!
author: Sarah D.

description: Great selection of beers...so going there for OktoberFest!! Bread dumpling, potato pancake and fennel soup were ALL delic!! A great unique restaurant.
author: Anita C.

description: I'm giving it 3 stars but I'm not calling it a destination spot.  If you happen to be in Hayes Valley for some reason though and there's a table available you can get a pretty decent meal there.  It's certainly not the best german food I've had but it's adequate if you're craving some meatloaf or sausage.  I'm not in to beer swilling myself so I can't speak to the large choice of german beers but if that's what you're in to then drink up.  Just don't be surprised that no matter how much you go to the gym you still have that big old jiggly beer belly.  Hey, you might like Nascar racing too...
author: Spidermonkey J.

description: Inspired by the movie Beerfest, we decided to check out this place again and try out "Da Boot" and fine german dining.   Parking around this area can be tough to find and the wait is fairly long, but well worth it.  The food was excellent and the beer variety was exceptional.  If you do try the boot, don't forget to turn it to avoid the inevitable "bubble" death.
author: Jeff H.

description:
German food is the best food for wintertime. Theres nothing better than Bratwurst and a good beer. Its rare to find a German gem in California, Suppenkuche is definitely one of them.
Kaiserschmarrn  is my favorite dessert so be sure to try it. It is also the favorite dessert of Governor Schwarzenegger, it means emperors mish mash....
author: John c.

description: Pros: you can get beer with waldmeister in it. And weisswurst. Cons: horrendous atmosphere, dreary. White walls with black birds spraypainted around the top is dismal. There are nicer German places with equally good or better food. I suppose if your intent is to get drunk it doesn't matter, but if surroundings count, give this place a miss, please.
author: Crystal S.

description: This place is ALWAYS packed, but there's great German food, and awesome apple struddle.
author: Jeffrey H.

description: Suppenkuche (aka "Das Boot" to some of us low-brow culture folk), how I love thee. Where else can you drink quality beer out of a glass boot? Well, probably in Germany...but nowhere else in the Bay Area that I can think of! I went there on last Saturday night with a group of friends--it's becoming 'that place' that I take my out of town visitors to.  Part of me died when they told me they discontinued the "Baby Boot"--a much more manageable drinking boot option than the 2 Liter boot. Great for a unique dinner (splurge on the potato pancakes) & the bar staff is a hoot.
author: Kelley B.

description: Food rivaling the Haufbrau house in vegas (yes it's that good), but unfortunately we had to wait outside in the rain well past the 30 minutes quoted to us, and I'm afraid our service wasn't all that good.  Awesome, freakin awesome beer, and you can buy a 2 litre boot!
author: Anony M.

description:
Now, this may seem hard to believe, but I rarely find myself with the opportunity to drink 2 litres of beer in one sitting. Is it Christmas Day? Nope - it's Suppenkuche! 
 My bro and a friend and I went the other day and had a lovely time. The communal tables were kind of fun. It did get a little annoying when the family sitting with us kept staring at us every time we took a sip from our boots but that was hardly the fault of Suppenkuche. If I have to review our table mates, I would give them only three stars. They were nice enough but they were too nosey and the little girl with them refused to eat anything green. What's that all about? 
 I had the trout from the dinner menu which was prepared quickly and deliciously. I would have like a few more non meat options to choose from but then again, what is someone who doesn't eat meat doing in a german restaurant? I was there for the beer.
 I went. I drank. And it was gooood.
author: Nuvia C.

description:
The foods better then the beer, and the beers pretty good. It can get a bit loud in there when they're packed, and the seating is family style so get ready to make new friends. This is good, because I usually drink alone. The crowd is truly an American one, with Market Street and Haight Street coming together in the name of beer.

They usually have the standard German Lagers and Pilsners along with a couple other fun/more obscure beers on tap. For the most part though, they're straight line Spaten, Hofbräuhaus, and Bitburger types.

More then definitely worth stopping in and checking out, but beware around dinner. The best time to get there is as soon as you can, right after work. You Can only make reservations well in advance, and even then only if you have a group. Good luck, and enjoy.
author: Mr. K.

description: went back for my dads bday last month. amazing again and so much fun i love this place
author: Naomi Z.

description: Great food and service.  Just don't forget to get a cup of coffee.  This was one of the best cups I have ever tasted!
author: Gillian F.

description: This place has a great selection of German beers first and foremost and a small bar with a nook to enjoy them.  The food is also very good but it's not the kind of fare I usually seek out.  I had the venison which was excellent and my fellow diners all seemed quite pleased with their meals.
author: Derek D.

description:
Walk in from the cold night to be warmed by hearty German food and delicious German beer. 
     My first visit I got a seat at the bar where I was educated a little about the glorious beer of Germany. I started with the pickled salad of carrots, cabbage, potatoes, beets and butter lettuce, which was really tasty. I probably will get this every time I come here. I then proceeded with the Wiener Schnitzel (breaded and pan fried pork loin with roasted potatoes). When I finished I just sat at the bar feeling satisfied while I enjoyed the rest of my beer and the great ambiance of this place. The place was jammed packed at this point I am hearing chanting at a nearby table, followed by chugging of beer. I felt like I was at October fest. 
    I had a really good experience here. This is the type of place where you want it to be really crowded. So waiting for a table is just part of the fun. I would go on the weekend!
author: Fernand P.

description:
200 reviews, why bother reviewing? cause it's that good people. the staff always recommend beer i end up liking, the soups are incredible, and i hear the brats are super good too. i like the smaller plates better than the big ones, but i also like to order that way usually. seriously though, everything tastes fantastic. go for it.

oh and the potato pancakes.
author: shaine h.

description:
Ok, honestly the food really deserves 3 stars which is still good but the beer brings it up to 4 and the staff behind the bar shoot it to 5 stars.  Got a date? I understand.  You grab a table and talk.  If you really want to enjoy this place to its fullest, bring a few friends, stay at the small bar and talk to the staff working the bar (boy do they know their stuff!!!).  Order a little food and REALLY enjoy all the beers they have available.  

*note: take a cab - some of the ales are 9% alc
author: Jae L.

description: Suppenkuche provided great service as well with great food! If any have watched "BEER FEST" this place has the  "das boot" (2 liter glass boot filled w/ beer). Highly recommended for beer drinkers accompanied with some appetite.
author: Allen T.

description: I definitely recommend Suppenkuche. Very cool place and the food is great also. But they don't take any reservation if there are less than 6 people. Several times we ended up waiting for a table for 2 hours
author: Sophie N.

description: I called a few days before dropping in for dinner thinking it might be best if I made reservations, however, they only take reservations for groups of 6 or larger. Unable to make reservations my wife and I drove from the peninsula into the city for some great German food. Unfortunately all we got was a rude hostess and were told they weren't taking anymore tables. How can a restaurant without reservations tell patrons that they aren't accepting any more tables at 7PM? I tried to explain we drove almost an hour into the city and that I tried to make reservations, but they didn't care. They shrugged us off, and we were basically told to take a hike. Operating your restaurant that way will eventually piss off enough people and it'll backfire. Why not accept reservations to avoid this? Mind boggling. Anyway, I was really aggravated and despite the reviews of this place it is doubtful I will be back just based on principal. As a side note, we were determined to get some German food, so we went to Walzwerk instead. The food, beer, and service was great at Walzwerk.
author: Nick Z.

description: This is seriously my favorite place to eat in SF. I don't even give a crap about the communal seating and airport tarmac-level volume. I would eat here if I knew I was dying the next day.
author: Chuck L.

description: I like this place, but I do not love it....I do not think it is nearly as authentic as Scnitzelhause or Scroders. Plus Schroders just has that beer hall feel that makes you think you are Munich. The food is good, the beer is great, but for some reasomn it leaves something to be desired.
author: Adrienne G.

description: I thought the food was okay, tasted fine...I might try this place again sometime and order something different?  The place itself was cute and the service was great.
author: Erin S.

description:
Come here for food + beer, not beer to just get wasted.

The food is some of the better Bavarian/German food you can get (I grew up in Munich, so I have a pretty good gauge of Bavarian/German food...) and the beer selection is really great. I like that the place isn't just trying to make a killing on people wanting to get wasted until 2 am, but instead tries to serve decent food as well.

Some tips:
- The boot is a stereotype. Just get pints/half liters. It'll be chilled till the end that way. Yea, Beerfest is totally accurate...
- The Vesperplatte (cold cuts + cheese to share as an appetizer) is an awesome deal and very authentic.
- Try the veal sausages for brunch. Sounds weird, but they're very light and far from what you're thinking is a sausage.
- Best wheat beer comes out of bottles, not kegs. Great selection of bottled wheat beers.

One notch off, because some of the dishes, while decent, could be a little better. Otherwise great, reasonably priced and super-friendly people! We go at least once a month for a taste of home.
author: Tim T.

description: The crowds and the noise can be a bit much, but the consistently good food makes it worth it. I've always found San Francisco to be a bit cold and sterile. Step beyond the heavy canvas curtains and spend a few hours in a much warmer (literally), jovial place. You're almost in Bavaria.
author: Jordan P.

description: This is a great spot for a few friends to have a fun and unique dinner in a cozy European ambiance. I love the spatzle, the potato pancakes with apple sauce and the sausage. It's also a hot spot for brunch!
author: Sara W.

description: This place is loud and noisy, but serves really tasty robust, authentic german dishes. My favourite is the potato pancakes. Best ones I ever tried. Really good beer selection! Mmmm, finally good wheat beer. Serving people "bier stube"-style on benches is cool and makes the place more social, though can be exhausting because it's so busy and loud all the time. It's always packed.
author: Dennis G.

description: This place is sooooooo good! Yes, that good! love the spatzle and the beer. I don't normally drink beer, because of the bitter taste. When the bartender told me their beer was not bitter, I didn't believe them. So I got the Belgian apple beer. Later on, I drank the beer from my friend's boot, it was surprisingly not bitter at all. There are good beers in the world after all. The food was also very tasty, exactly the type of German food I like.
author: Cicie W.

description:
3 of us went there on a (ugh!) Saturday night,  needless to say that it took forever to get a table. But when we finally did, we ordered the potato pancakes and large salad to share 3 ways.  The pancakes were more like crispy hash brown patties.  They were really crisp and good, but not really what I was expecting.  I was thinking something flatter and more cakey.  The apple sauce was heavily spiced with cinnamon, almost overly so. The salad was HUGE! I recommend getting a small one because this was piled so high with potato salad, cabbage, carrots, beets and other julienned veggies, we barely made a dent in it.  It was good, and more like  an assortment of pickled items rather than a "salad".
I ordered the sauerbraten, my friend got the trout, and my other friend got the suckling pig with a gigantic bread dumpling (like a stuffing ball, kinda).
The best thing by far was the suckling pig!  OMG! It was so effing good, with crispy skin and tender almost confit-like meat. Whoa!  Yum.......... The other dishes were good, but the pig took the ribbon. Spatzle was tasty, cranberry sauce was good with the braised beef, but I didn't get the sauce in my doggie bag :0(   
We had no room for dessert, as the food is rich and heavy. Perfect for a cold winter night.  Not perfect if you plan to move much afterwards.  So don't plan on going to boogie after this.  Plan to sit on your ass and pass out watching SNL.
author: Suzanne L.

description: I love the feel of this restaurant. So homey, mountain cabin meets friends house feel. Great German blonde ales and a good place to go for breakfast.
author: Stephanie I.

description: I live nearby and have been looking for an excuse to show up there.  I finally went for brunch, today.  Man, that was a HUGE meal.  Not as expensive as I expected as one dish is more than enough to satisfy.  I had the bread dumpling with eggs and brats.  Tasty, unique, authentic.  The bartender even reccommended a solid breakfast beer to go with.
author: ben y.

description: Great food, great beer and a cool location.  What more can you ask for in a German restaurant?  It's been awhile since I've been there, but the one thing I remember is that the food is a bit more pricey compared to other German restaurants.
author: Art D.

description: This place has great, authentic German food at a reasonable price.  Our waiter was friendly and helpful, and let me swap my sides dishes around (spaetzle baby, spaetzle).  The atmosphere is rustic with a real German beer hall feel.  Oh, and the beer.  They have a great selection on tap, all of which you can drink out of a giant glass boot.  'Nuff said.
author: Trevor F.

description: I think the food is kinda pricy for what it is.  It was just ok, but nice to try something different.  Cool that they have das boots, but I don't think I could ever finish one.  The wait to get in sucks.
author: Derk C.

description: That's some good schnitzel, man.  I like the candlelight, and I love the spaetzle, and I love the vaguelly family-style seating.
author: Kevin S.

description: I'm addicted to Suppenkueche.  I get cravings for their bratwurst and sour kraut.  Everything I've had on the menu has been excellent.  The Riesling  and Gewurztraminer selection is quite good.  They  even have warm spiced wine!  Ok, I need a fix.  Otherwise I'll go through severe physical, mental and spiritual deterioration.  Can't have that!
author: Cyan C.

description: Whose Oma (German for grandma) is in the kitchen whippin' up all those authentic flavors? It's the real deal. If you're hungry, looking for a differnt sort of dining experience or up for a bier you will not be disappointed. Just be sure to check the hours.
author: Michelle S.

description: If you're looking for a fun, casual, inexpensive spot with a group to start your night out, this is the place. We went for one of my birthdays and had a great time. You can get HUGE beers that you pass around the table to share (not recommended for germ-phobes!). Lots of laughs - and good food if you like German food!
author: Sarah R.

description: I had forgotten how great this place is. Yeah, yeah, the wait can be long but for cryin out loud- there is great beer to while away the wait. You get to holler at your dinner mates, not unlike a yelp elite event, and the food is 1st rate. We ate more than we should have, and enjoyed every last bite. When a guy outside begged for loose change, Brian gave him the schnitzl, and the guy was happy.
author: Amy J.

description: Such a great place! The food is good and it's got a nice atmosphere. For the few fruitcake aficionados like me out there, they serve fruitcake at Christmas time.  My favorite place to sit is in the little alcove behind the bar which is dark with lots of candles and is actually sort of romantic.  Who knew beer and romance could actually go hand in hand!
author: shoba d.

description: I like this place.  I have visited several times over the years, and on all but one occassion, the servers and the staff were great.  Once however, they were fairly rude and tried to push us out the door.  I'll let it slide though, as I am always all for a good German restaurant with great beer and a fun atmosphere.  I spent a summer in Munich, and this place makes me nostalgic for the good old days.  The food is hearty but cooked with skill, and the aforementioned beer selection is top notch.
author: Blake W.

description: It's true.  Anything with good beer added to it automatically gets an extra four stars.  Don't worry, though--I would give it eight stars in that case, if I could.  The food here is sooo good--best of the German eateries, of which I can count on one hand.  Plentiful portions, nice atmosphere.  You will leave full, drunk, and happy.   Auf wiedersehen!
author: Mark W.

description:
i had a stiegl at das mobel in vienna 3 years ago and it changed my life.  beer that went down as smooth as a sprite.  it was not until two years later that we were once again reunited at suppenkuche.   THE best beer selection this side of stuttgart.

i love me some pig and every pork dish i've had here is simply amazing.  the sauerkraut is the real deal.  the spatzel is the real deal.  authentic german complete with table sharing.  you will not be disappointed.
author: Steven C.

description: Delicious food. HEARTY food. I had the most expensive thing on the menu - the venison. It was kind of three point five star food to me - it was just above average. This place gets an extra star for being a mind-bendingly unique experience. I'm 25, so take this as you will, but I've never had a dining experience quite like this establishment. It was loud, rowdy, full of merriment and BEER. So if you want somewhere LOUD and FUN with good food and good ambiance, give this place a go.
author: Adam X.

description: The food is much better during brunch time at this German restaurant. I ate thier last week and had the wiener snitzel (breaded pork loin) and it was really good! Thier five egg omelletes are unique as well because they are layered like an italian lasagna. Of course, who can not forget the beers....Dark Edinger, Weltinberger..YUM!!
author: Christian S.

description: The jagerschnitzel is one of the best things I've ever eaten.  Love the minimalist decor, laid back crowd, and good German beer selection.
author: Cully W.

description: Suppenkche is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco and the thing I miss most about living in Hayes Valley.  I have had many amazing meals from the Tageskarte, but fall back on the Wiener Schnitzel frequently.  Must have drinks: Grnes Berliner Weisse and Tucher Kristall.
author: Susannah R.

description: This place has great food , but is LOUD and CRAZY BUSY with lots of smoke from all the candles in a closed  space. They didn't seem to want to open the windows on the night I was there . But great food anyway.
author: Katherine N.

description: Great german food, excellent beer, interesting neighborhood. Anything with the mushroom cream sauce is good.
author: Mike I.

description: The food at this German restaurant is awesome!  Meat and potatoes and sauerkraut...yum.  Vegetarians can eat here, too, though.  Comfort food to the hilt!  The beer and the black forest cake are really good, too.  I keep meaning to come here just for beers and appetizers because they have a very cool, but small, bar area.
author: Rachael K.

description: Minus one star for the rude servers. I understand there is zero room to serve the food and you have to lug 5 liter mugs around, but get real. This is where you chose to work so deal with it with a smile on your face! Anyways, after waiting like 45 minutes for a table (friday night at 8:30) All 8 of us sat down and had a blast!  We got 2 boots and a 5 liter mug ($50).  I shared the meatloaf wrapped in bacon with mashed potatoes. SO GOOD
author: Annette M.

description: I'm not a big fan of German food but I was pleasantly surprised!!!   Cute little place and good food.
author: F K.

description:
i came with a group of 4, and had to wait for an hour for a table. but it was ok since we decided to beer it up :)

the food was pretty good, i ordered the bratwurst. but we also ordered some potato pancakes, which i felt was a bit salty, however it went really well with the apple sauce. I'm usually not a fan of sweet and savory, but i felt that it helped with the saltyness and it was kind of interesting :).

the bratwurst was decent, as all bratwurst tend to be. so not really much to say.

i guess the most interesting thing to me was the boot, since i had never had one before. quite an experience, to say the least. since i'm somewhat of a germophobe, it's kind of weird sharing a cup with other people, but after awhile, alcohol kills all germs right?? i guess people just tend to roll with it.

it's somewhat overpriced for what it is, but it was interesting, and i think i'd come again :)
author: Angela H.

description: Had the venison with red wine cabbage and spaetzle. I didn't know german food could be this good! DELISH. I know it's good when I have cravings for it randomly... will be back soon!
author: Carolyn C.

description: Great Place. Excellent German food. Sitting with other people can be fun. You gotta go early any night of the week. They don't take reservations except for parties 6 or more.
author: Colleen M.

description:
used to come here a lot when i lived in the city. they've got kostritzer on tap which is pretty much the best beer in the world. 

had a weird experience with a pretentious bartender once, who talked a lot of crap about spaten for no apparent reason. 

either way, get here early or else you'll be waiting for a rather long time. if you don't, its still worth it.
author: Al I.

description:
let's just say, when I think about going out to eat, I don't necessarily think 'German!!' but, last night two of my girlfriends were meeting for a couple of beers and dinner and I thought 'why not?'

it was freezing outside, but inside was toasty and inviting. it FELT like a little European eatery. the decorations [both holiday and permanent] were darling. the wait staff and bartenders were knowledgeable, friendly, SLAMMED, and still cheery.

we never got a table but that didn't matter [the back room had been rented out for a private party so the place was swamped]. the energy in that wee restaurant is just great. the family style dining is pretty cool, too. 

I'm a veggie moving in the way of meat again, so the menu was a little daunting, but the spatzle and salad were absolutely amazing, and the taste I had of my friend's wiener schnitzel was incredible, too.

German beer is the best. Suppenkuche offers German beer. need I say more?? I will be back.
author: Rachel W.

description: I'm impressed with Suppenkuche, but I just can't give it more than 3 stars because it's a pretty terrible value.  Good food, good service, cool authentic German food and beers.  But everything is priced like the place is in Fisherman's Wharf- the beers are particularly outrageous.  It's a good place to go once but it's not going to be a regular spot for me.
author: Larry B.

description: Vieder Shnitzle is DELICIOUS.  Downside you'll be waiting forEVER
author: erik e.

description: Love this place. the food is delicious - can't go wrong with german meat dishes - plus it helps that one of my best friends manages the bar, and his taste in beer is superb. If they have the roast suckling pig special, definitely give it a try. yum.
author: Jacqui M.

description: I think that I have mentioned before that I like loud, dark places that serve serious meat - didn't I!  Sup is great, especially if you have a crowd of tankard wielding buddies to help you down the excellent beer selection and soak up the exceptional German dishes.
author: Max C.

description: Great food! I love taking people to this place.... One word of caution. If you reserve a table for 6 or more on a busy night, they are very strict about having your party arrive on time and finish on time... What can I say? they have two turn-arounds a night!
author: Michelle L.

description:
tall glasses (and boots) of good beer and hearty food.  great place for being loud and getting together with friends.  they have family style tables. definitely not a date place.

the potato pancakes are awesome.  i had the salmon strudel special...yummmmmm.  the black forest cake is delish.
author: Julia H.

description: Haven't had a bad meal or beer there yet.  As for authenticy, I took my German girl from Dresdan there and she ate it up.  Said it was the first meal in the States that was as good as home.  Mmmmm....mmmmm, that's what I'm talkin' about.
author: Sasha H.

description: Tasty German food and good strong German beers! Need I say more?
author: Margo M.

description: Suppenkuche is one of my favorite places in SF. The beer selection is almost all German with some Belgians and other interesting European beers and the food is really great authentic German food with big portions and some great homemade mustard and kraut. While enduring the inevitable wait, the small bar is a good place to sample one of the awesome beers on tap or to chat with the bartender who has always been super helpful and informative. Once you are seated you will most likely find yourself at one of the family style tables where you will be sitting up close and personal with some random strangers... IMO this just adds to the neighborhood feel of the place.  The large tables make it a great place for a big group as they DO accept reservations for large parties.
author: Jeff R.

description: PROSIT!!!  My first German experience for a German's birthday.  I had no idea what to expect, but eating at a bench with a party of 12 was quite rambunctious and entertaining.  Mashed potatoes and sauerkraut were to die for.  The pork chop on the special menu was the BEST!  Pretty awesome for some latinos workin' it in the Kuchen.
author: Yoko H.

description: A tad too crowded but worth it.  Beer selection was impressive.  The kraut was surprisingly very good, as was the various wursts.  I'm not from around here but if I ever come back I'll be sure not to miss this place.
author: John K.

description: Great, hearty German food (the first time I ever had any) and great beer. The setting was warm and the staff was friendly. I feel good every time I go, but sometimes it can be too busy and you have to wait FOREVER to get in. Worth the wait most of the time.
author: Frances L.

description: The food and the beer at this place are its best attributes. The crowds and the parking well that's a different story. The cuisine is as good and as authentic as it gets in the Bay Area. The beer selection is the best and rarely will you go wrong if you simply close your eyes and point! Trust me . . . I've got a reisspass to prove my qualifications! The problem is the wait because it can be as long as two hours on a Friday or Saturday. Here's what you do . . . they only take reservations for six or more, make a res then tell them two or three or however many of your friends flaked when they could not find parking or because they refuse to leave their cars in such a bad neighborhood (blame the projects one block up the street to the north and west). Its worked for me every time and the staff has yet to call me on these shenanigans.
author: Ryan M.

description: Is Suppenkuche worth a two hour wait, or making a reservation several weeks in advance? I wouldn't say so, but it is fun! There are a bunch of German beers to choose from, and interesting, extremely large, glasses to drink out of. The food is way too bland for my taste, although they may have good sausages, and I quickly got tired of all the pickled vegetables. However the sptaezle is *really* good. I'd say if you have a large party and want to drink beer out of huge glasses, then go here. Otherwise go to Toronado and get your sausage fix at Rosamunde!
author: Will A.

description: so delicious......... german beer with classic german food.  I went here 2 weeks ago with my German roomate, and we both left with satisfied full/drunk stomachs.
author: Mike L.

description: The atmosphere is fun - community table seating - my friends and I ended up seated at the same table as an older couple and had some great conversation!   It is a bit loud though, so maybe not the best place for an intimate date or anything of that nature.  I had the Jägerschnitzel with Spätzle and it was delicious.  The German beer list is extensive, and service was friendly and attentive.  I plan on returning soon!
author: Christy S.

description: I love this place! I live in DC and always put it on my "must eat there" when I am in town. I feel like I just stepped into a "Wirtshaus" in Bavaria. The staff is great and friendly (well, that piece would not be authentically German (-: ), the food is sooo good (looove the dumpling!), the beer is great.. what else could you want?
author: Eva G.

description: This place has some bomb ass meatloaf. Wrapped in bacon with hardboiled eggs inside and a really good onion sauce. They have alot of really good german beer and many sizes from half a liter to das boot. The only two negative things i can say about it is if you dont get there early your screwed as far as getting a table and parking is a complete bitch. Park a few blocks away and get a cab because the valet charges seven bucks parks 4 blocks away and takes his sweet ass time for each car. As far as the food and beer the place is exceptional.
author: Joshua D.

description: Great food! Been searching for the real authentic German Food since moving here. Downside.... TOO LOUD! Walked out of there with a full belly and hurting ears. They really need to do something to help with the sound. It is really bad.
author: Victoria V.

description: DAS BOOT!!!  Anywhere that you can re-enact Beerfest is an awesome place to me!  Beer was great and food was hearty and filling, exactly what is needed when drinking 2 liters of beer.  The atmosphere is one of the best in the city if you don't mind making new friends at the communal tables.
author: Cameron M.

description: beer and meat and potatoes. what more can you ask for? yummy and big selection of beers. and the wursts are good, 3 pieces on a bed of yummy , creamy mashed potatoes. we also had the cold cuts platter and the sausages and cuts were yum-o.  the communal table thing is fun, cos we got seated with nice people. the guy next to us even gave us a bite of his veal schnitzel and i am definitely ordering that next time. it smelled fabulous and tasted wonderful too.  there were a big group of people outside before 5pm on a sunday, so go early.
author: Sasa S.

description: The potato pancakes were amazing.  The real hook was the great beer for cheap money.  The waitress and bartender were helpful with picking out different types of beers.  I knocked a star off the top because I went there with an understanding that the beer came in a boot glass... I was later told by the bartender that you have to specify.  I am already anticipating my next visit where I request the huge boot glass.    ...cheers!
author: Jennifer C.

description: The beer selection makes up for the surly staff (maybe I don't have enough ironic tattoos), and the food is actually quite good.  I enjoy sitting in the little cove behind the bar.  Nights can get pretty crazy pretty quickly, so I recommend Sunday brunch for a more relaxed vibe.  Service is much friendlier and the food is equally as good. They won't look askance if you want a beer with your breakfast, and the coffee is endless and hot.  The ravioli scramble and sauteed meatloaf (!) are both excellent.  Sehr Gut!
author: caitlin c.

description: Such good food! An fast too!  The bartenders are straight to point with beer and wine options best for you, since they have so much of everything!  Push through the crowd and give this restaurant a try. You will love it!
author: Whitley S.

description: I've been dying to try Suppenkuche, and it did not disappoint.  They had a huge selection of good beers, which is great since we had to wait a little while for a table.  Once seated, service was quick and the food was amazing- the potato pancakes were the best I've had and the German ravioli and wild boar sausage were both unbelievable.  If you're in the mood for good, hearty German food Suppenkuche is definitely the place to go.
author: Katie R.

description:
so 2 reasons to come here
1. foreign beer
2. rural food

some great selections of german style beers.  and some serious size vessels.  you can get a 5 litre 'boot'.
food pretty good, nice and simple and rustic.  i had the venison and cabbage.  hearty and tasty.

get really busy as its a small venue.
can also get a bit rowdy as people get tanked on the beers.
author: david s.

description: I would not go to this place ever again just due to its lack of customer service.  I call twice and leave messages so that I can make a reservation.  They finally call me back 5 hours after the second call and they leave a message offering me two reservation times.  I call back within 15 minutes and they've already given it away.  Way to go on having an efficient and effective process to take reservations.  Unfortunately this is one of the few German places in SF so they can take advantage of their customers like that.
author: Christina D.

description: LOVE IT. wish I can afford to live closer to this place. Excellent beer ... beer...beer, oh they also serve up delicious food on the side. Did I mention great beer? Bring your friends only during the week, :)
author: Byteme Z.

description: Let me start by saying the food was very good and the portions were very large. Sunday at 6pm and the wait was 1 hour and 15 minutes, ugh. Definitely not the  place  to go if you actually want to speak with the person next to you. It is uber loud and like a big beer drinkin party inside.
author: joshua s.

description: Me and the Mr. spent our birthdays here with friends and it was definitely a good time. The food was good, nothing totally amazing, but I will go back when I am in the mood for some German cooking. The beers were great and the 2 liter beer for your birthday is a crazy idea, unless you are sharing it with 3 other people.
author: Erin L.

description: great place for groups who want to drink beer.  i wouldn't say german food is my favorite cuisine but food is pretty decent here.  potato pancakes,mushroom soup, meatball soup are my go tos.  i found some of the meats a bit too dry.  overall this is a great atmosphere if you're in the mood to celebrate.
author: Helen T.

description: Highly addictive German comfort food, excellent beer selection, boisterous and rowdy crowd when things get hoppin', intimate (watch your elbows please!) seating, wonderful minimalist/farmhouse interior... all adds up to a spectactular, though fairly noisy, classic SF restaurant. Not cheap, but not too expensive either. Don't have to ask me twice to go here!
author: Jeremy H.

description: I just love the Spatzle at this place, and just about all the other goodies they serve up.  I've never been to Deutschland, nor can speak the language, but I know good food.  The desserts have never disppointed me.  For some reason, I feel like I'm leaving a Mentos commercial set when I'm back on the pavement, but that's just me.  I like the benches, I've had good conversation with the patrons next to me all the times I've went.
author: brenda b.

description: The only place I've been in San Francisco that serves Pickled Herring with Potatos and Sour Cream. Not for everyone I realize but around Christmas time this is exactly what I need. Oh, and then there is the saurkraut and sausages too.
author: Gustaf A.

description: I was surprised at how good the food was here.  Of course, i was thinking that I'd be filled up with schnitzel and spaetzel (sp?).  Who knew that Germans could make such a mean salad.  And the fish that we had here was quite tasty, too.  Dessert was a delicious German Chocolate Forest Cake, which I hear is actually special delivered by the renowned Schubert's on Clement.
author: Jane L.

description: last time I was there I overheard a guy at the bar say to someone he'd just met, "this is the only place I feel safe." I don't know what that's about, but as I was taking a bite of the scrumptiousness before me (Schnitzel, on that occasion, but I'd recommend everything), I think I knew. Then I forgot, because this place is the only place where I like beer.
author: Renu C.

description:
Suppenkueche is the best German place I've been to in the states so far by far. Most places are way too kitsch are too stereotypical "bayrisch" for me in terms of the space. My family is from north Germany and I lived in Berlin and that kind of stuff rubs me the wrong way. That being said, no complaints regarding that kind of food and this place does it great justice. The Schnitzel is excellent,  the Kaesespaetzle drips melted cheese like it should and, yes, the soups are great as well. In true fashion, the portions are out of control. The beer selection is a (German) beer lovers paradise, where they get Augustiner from is beyond me, if only they could get a hold of some Rothaus Pils! The interior is great and the beer hall seating makes this place rather lively but sometimes hard to get a table. Last time I was in there were a bunch of leaves hung from the ceiling, with the dimmed lights it was a really cool vibe. A word to the wise: if you speak German, do so to the owner (Uli is his name I think). He usually wears a hat and its been my experience that if you do you'll get seated a bit quicker. 

Suppenkueche = voll cool.
author: Nicholas B.

description: Food just like my mom and grandmother used to make. I love it, it reminds me of being a kid again. It's very busy and you need to show up about 45 min ahead to get a table but a great time all around.
author: Morgan B.

description: Sauerbraten, Kassler und Kaesspaetzle dazu Erdinger, Weihenstephan, Spaten, Koelsch und noch viel mehr was das Herz begehrt. Das Restaurant hat Wirtshausatmosphaere und selbst auf den Toiletten haengt Koepi- Werbung. Satte Leistung! 4 Sterne weil sehr teuer. Aber  wertvoll!
author: Johannes B.

description: 342 reviews! Boy, am I late to the party. Well, it's all been said, but let me check it off my list. Supenkuche is a fun place to go. Good beer. Best German food I've had in the area. Lively atmosphere. A little on the pricey side.
author: Billy Q.

description: Five stars cause it's that good! There is a certain intangible energy that resides within the 'Kuche, that makes the crowded bar and the family style seating endearing and not annoying. If you want quite, go on a weeknight. If you want an environment that is truely unique go to the Kitchen. If nothing else go to for the great and rare selection of Bavarian beer!
author: Douglas L.

description:
The decor reminded me of a festive family Mexican restaurant, only instead of pinatas and Corona ads hanging from the ceiling, there were dried flowers and giant wreaths. I suppose it's a German thing. I was going to order the sausage, but then I saw venison, and thought, "When will get another chance to try venison? Probably not for awhile." So I got it. It seemed overdone, although I'm no expert in the proper method for cooking venison. 
On the side was spatzle, which tasted like pasta made out of cheese and/or butter, and was delicious, and a pickled red cabbage stuff that tasted very cinnimony, and was surprisingly good, considering I don't really like cabbage, especially cooked or pickled. My boyfriend had a game hen which I tried, and it tasted delicious. The best part was undoubtedly the heffeweizen. We both ordered a half pint of some complicated German-named beer. It was amazing. They offer a wide selection of German beer in every shoe size.
For dessert I had a beesting cake, consisting of entirely honey-related ingredients, with a nice black coffee that I believe they brewed just for me. All of this and our total bill was about $67. The service was excellent so after tip it was almost $80. I wouldn't recommend it for a first, second, or third date. Wait until you don't have much left to talk about, as it gets crowded and loud shortly after opening. Or bring your German friend, as I plan to next time I go. Picky white American family members from out of town will probably also appreciate the familiar, safe, yet very well done cuisine.
author: Thea K.

description: This place has a wonderful German atmosphere and a great German beer selection, but it is quite expensive.  Who cares though!  Good for a drunken splurge on spaten!  The food is supposed to be awesome, but I have yet to indulge...never-the-less the atmosphere is authentic and German and Austrian patrons are actually getting drunk in here more often than not....highly recommended...
author: Francis K.

description: Honestly, it's not as good as friendly ol' Schnitzelhaus. Noisy, and crowded, and the spaetzle aren't quiiiiiite as good as SH's. Fine in a pinch, but not where I'll go next time I'm craving kasespaetzele.  Service was nice though, food was decent, and I do like saying  "zoo-pen-koo-khuuuh."
author: Emmy M.

description: I love this place! It's authentic, yummy, and the servers are on top of it. If you want the real experience check it out, but come early. And don't expect to be late for a reservation. Germans are "punctlich!"
author: E S.

description: If you like your German food with California fusion added to it then this is the place for you.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description:
This place is awsome! It is a little piece of Germany in San Francisco.
