I lived in Germany for a year and since returning to the states I had been looking for a authentic German restaurant to fill my German food addiction. I stumbled across Suppenkucke about 6 months ago and the food and beer served here is as close as it gets to the type and quality of food you would get in southern Germany. If you have never had German food this is the place to try it for the first time! You will be hooked for life! Also, if you like to enjoy a good quality beer this is the place to go! 

Just a note for those of you not accustomed to the traditions of southern German dining. If you have a small party (2-3 people) you will probably be seated with other people you don't know. I mean at the same table. It is a little odd at first but you get used to it. You might even make some new friends. Other then that the Suppenkuche is very busy during dinner and brunch on Sunday so go early. It is totally worth it! Enjoy.
author: Bradley D.

description: The first German restaurant I've ever tried and it was worth it. Tried the bratwurst, which came with sourkraut and mashed potatoes and my friend ordered the schnitzel, which came with some other variety of potatoes, which I also tried.  The food was really good and the beer selection was great. They actually had Leffe on tap, which is one of my favorite beers (from Belgium).  The seating was tradition German bench style, which wasn't very comfortable, but it makes for an authentic experience. We had to share one table with two other parties. I guess the only way you get a table to yourself is if you have 8 or more people as most tables fit about 8 people. So, if you have group of 8, or if you don't mind sharing with some randoms, it's all good.
author: Boss H.

description: Absolutely the best German food outside of Germany. Yes, there is a wait (1 hr usually) but it is worth it. They have Mexican coke and the best black forest cake ever. But of course they are famous for their main courses: i love the pork cutlet, breaded and deep fried, or the sausage with some potato dumplings. The service is great even though it seams like everyone is working so hard. We all share tables and make friends with neighbors. Overall, amazing experience for a SF visit.
author: Me G.

description: A friend who used to live in SF came in from out of town and demanded we eat dinner at Suppenküche. Sure, whatever, German food sounds fun. Little did I know that I was about to have an explosion of amazingness in my mouth. First off, the place is awesome, I loved the set up of the communal tables, just like breweries I had seen in Munich. The bar in the center is great if you have to wait for a table. Their selection of beers is really broad and the bartenders really know what they're talking about so use their expertise! We had a group of 5 on a Friday night and maybe waited 10 minutes which was great. The décor is really crafty and fun. I highly recommend the Spätzle, seriously a delight! The Gemischter Salat is amazing if you like a fun and interesting salad (think beets, "vinegarized" carrots and yummy potatoes). I can't remember what my dinner was, some sort of sausage dish with peas which was really good, but it was a special and I don't see anything similar on the menu. The Christmas Beer was awesome, as was the different Hefs I tried. Yes, it's crowded and loud but a really fun experience and a satisfying meal for sure!
author: Cinds C.

description: My friend and I had a theory: maybe the food is so good because by the time we finally sit, we'll eat anything. I once saw a man faint at the bar from what I assume was starvation. Recently I went back to prove this theory wrong. Some friends and I got here right as they opened and were sat immediately. We relaxed had a few beers and eventually ordered when our whole party arrived. Drum roll please.....It was delicious. Congratulations Suppenkuche, you are still my favorite restaurant in the city. I've ordered a wide variety of dishes here, and they were all better than the last. The wait staff is pretty knowledgeable about beer so if you tell them what you prefer they usually bring just what you are looking for. Obviously it gets very crowded and they don't take reservations for parties less than 8. I recommend getting there at 5:00 or having a little snack before you go. Oh, and when you drink from the boot you need to turn it at the heel so it doesn't splash in your face.
author: Paige B.

description: Love this place. Good homey and unpretentious food, homemade sausages and a great variety of beers
author: alisa o.

description: The schnitzel here is as authentic as I've tasted since I lived in Europe.  With a side of fries or a pile of veggies, you'll think your bus took the wrong turn onto the Autobahn.   Their cabbage and "Spatzle" are deelish as are their roasted spuds.  Furnishings are very spartan -- even for a German place.  The tables and chairs are like pews and seating in a church - hard and unforgiving.  Even with my big ass I started getting uncomfortable before I had finished my schnitzel.  Prices are reasonable and the beers seem to be really popular (I don't drink beer, so can't really say I've tasted theirs).  The all wood environment makes the place really noisy and conversation across a wood table can be difficult but if you're stuffing your face with a wurst or slice of bread and better, who really cares, right?  :)  I think I've tasted everything on their menu and everything is good although I have to confess I tend to order the schnitzel a lot just 'cos I LOVE IT!  4 stars only because of the noise and hard benches.
author: Paul N.

description: I have a lot of family and friends in Deutschland so I pretty much know good German cooking.  Germany is not known for its cuisine but if you like comfort food Germany does it well.  That being said it is my belief that Suppenkuche  captures and highlights some of the best down home dishes of that before mentioned country.  Its not just sauerkraut and bratwurst anymore!!
author: Jeremy R.

description:
the food is soooooooooo good 
but get there early .. like 10-15 minutes BEFORE they open at 5 otherwise you will end up waiting 1-2 hours for a spot at a table. 
I would never wait for a table though.. and I don't think its a destination place 
The beer selection was fantastic..but you could go to Bev Mo and get the same thing..no wait 
and NO SHARING TABLES
because you will def. be sharing a table with a few other people
service is wonderful though
author: maryanncolby

description: This place is great!  They put bacon grease in EVERYTHING!   Mmmmmmm, bacon.  Great beers, even the non-alcoholic beer is a good one. The meat dishes are superb.  I'd never had a good meatloaf till I went here.   Gets WAY crowded at nights though, and there is simply no decor.
author: matthew w.

description: After weeks of crying over a break up, I called my older brother and was like, screw it, let's eat!  I had been wanting to try this place for years after spending time on the French/German border and getting my first taste of authentic German food.  I ordered the most tender, flavorful beef I have EVER had.  It came with buttered spatzle (like noodles) and delicately spiced red cabbage.  My bro's jagerschnitzel was amazing, so scrumptious.  He ordered a pilsner and I ordered a dark brew with a gorgeous frothy top.  We traded beers and gulped away and were very impressed with both.  The beers came in these really unique (and huge) beer mugs.  I felt like i was in Europe.  Great place.
author: Kandi K.

description: Just had the emperor pancakes and the bratwurst from their brunch menu.  Hands down one of the best brunch dishes in the city.  "Its gut !"
author: tom p.

description: the atmosphere was very cozy and homey. HUGE servings of beer. the potato pancakes were very yummy, but unfortunately, for our 8pm reservation, half the dishes were sold out for the day (disappointing). out of the dishes we had, the schnitzel was the winner. i really wanted to try the german chocolate cake but of course it was out. but the forest cake was very nice and light.
author: eriin w.

description: Excellent. Authentic. German. Familial. Loud. Bar. Food!
author: Lee S.

description:
Had a divine brunch here, Modern Tea really needs to get their act together and open at 10am also

Awesome
- oj (in beer mug)
- currywurst
- sausage 
- cucumber salad
- beer (Delirium Tremens!)
- das boot!

Uhmm
- coffee
- sharing tables
- tableware

Gotta get back there for dinner, the place is cool for drinks too (beeru!)
author: xo x.

description: Is a venison "medallion" supposed to be approximately 8 inches by 5 inches?  No matter!  It was delicious and I had a great time yelling across the table in conversation with my friends while we enjoyed the very reasonably priced beers!
author: Marcus C.

description: I have been to a few Bavarian beer halls in my time; in Munich, NYC and now SF.  Superkuche has great food, a great atmosphere, and the only place with the authentic Bavarian group seating with simple wooden tables.  There is no music, which sometimes could be a nice dining addition.  The menu has some changes, so you don't always need to order the Sauerbraten or Weinerschnitzel.  Waits are standard, so go a bit early and have a weissbier or similar at the crowded tiny bar in the center of the restaurant.  Prost!
author: Rachael O.

description:
Only been once. . . .with a group of ten. . . .sat in the back room. . . . next to a group of 20(or so). . . . instantly jealous of the table thumping boot chugging activities. . . . found out they had ALL THE BOOTS. . . jealousy turns into disdain. . . . server informs us they have something bigger than the boot. . . . disdain turns to excitement. . . . server tell us it is a 5 liter monster mug thingy thing. . . . excitement grows. . . we order it along with a round of "regular" beers. . . . monster mug thingy thing is delivered. . . . holy crap thats a lot of beer. . . . we pound big beer with two hands while bragging to the table next to us. . . .table with boots wishes they had the monster mug thingy thing and are visibly jealous. . . .server informs the table we have the only one. . . . they offer a trade. . . . we laugh. . . .we decide to pass the beast around until it is gone. . . around the 4th time back to me I realize how disgusting this activity is. . . . i continue to drink. . . . definitely drunk by the time the server takes our order. . . . decide potato pancakes are enough. . . . .continue to drink. . . . potato pancakes are delish. . . . . continue to drink. . . .two monster mug thingy things down (yes, 10 liters). . . . we ask for a discount on the third. . . . .server tells us no group has ever finished three. . . manager agrees that if we finish the third it will be half price. . . .we love a challenge. . . . continue to drink. . . . decide I probably should have ordered a full meal. . . . realize it would have interfered with my drinking. . . . continue to drink. . . finish third monster mug thingy thing. . . decide its time to go to the bars. . . . server brings the bill. . . informs us between the three monster mug thingy things and the rest of the "regular" beers we ordered we had imbibed 22 liters of beer. . . . pride sweeps the table. . . . mission accomplished. . . . solidly wasted!

Didn't eat much myself but heard the food was good. Great place to get shitty and be plenty loud while doing it!
author: Sean K.

description: Amazing beer selection and wonderful food.  I had the meatloaf with bacon and eggs and mashed potatoes along with the Konig Pilsener.  A great combination.  For German food, there is no better place in the city at the moment.  A must!
author: Wesley B.

description: Excellent! Really huge portions, with very well cooked steak, chicken, venison, and more (circa $18 for entree). You really have to be a meat lover to enjoy the food here, but if you are it is so much better than most meat heavy US restaurants. It is also accompanied by really good spatzle (small twists of potato pasta commonly eaten in Germany and Switzerland) and other great vegetables including delicious red cabbage. If all that isn't enough, the restaurant also has an amazing range of German and Belgian beers - including some rare ones!. I've been to Germany a couple of times and I really believe that this place could hold its own against the restuarants there.
author: Nick O.

description:
i am so typically german, so i will say i felt a bit ashamed that it took me 4 years to finally check this place out.  i knew that i'd probably walk out of there with my ass dragging, so i walked from transbay terminal to the restaurant in hopes i could firm up before the damage ensues.

we made a reservation - walked in, were seated right away at a table in the back.  the tables are glorified picnic tables really, so we shared ours with a crazy rowdy birthday party of mid-30's guys drinking boots of beer.  needless to say it was hella loud in there, but we didn't need to say much.  all we needed to do was eat.

firstly, i have to say the beer selection is immaculate.  it's a 3 page list of beer.  there honestly is nothing better than that, save for most of those beers are hard to find imports from meine homeland.  jah!  with beers in tow, we ordered soup - lentil soup with a bratwurst sliced into four pieces as a garnish, and clam chowder.  both were just wow...yummy.

follow that up with more bratwurst, sauerkraut and potatoes, and a  pork dish with similar side dishes.  it's all heavy food, and really between the beer and the pork sausage we consumed during appetizers, the meal was overkill.  that's not to say it wasn't good though.  i think our frail whole foods/trader joe's leaf eating tendencies got the better of us that night because we were only able to finish half of our entrees.

the service was great - our waiter reminded me of a goofier shyer version of tom green.  

aside from the loud and crowded atmosphere, i totally enjoyed checking this place out.  i'd suggest not eating that whole day if you plan on going.  srsly.
author: Shelley D.

description:
if you like german beer, head straight to the bar at suppenkuche. the bartender is extremely knowledgeable and made great recommendations for everyone in our party. 
if you are counting calories, or have an issue with carbs - do not even cross the threshold. the food at suppenkuche is intense- heavy, with an emphasis on meat and potatoes. as such, it's my dad's birthday restaurant of choice. i had the lamb chop special last night, which was very tasty- though way more food than i could eat. my 'rents loved the herring appetizer. personally, if i'm planning a major carb blowout, i'd much rather have pasta, but if your preference is for meat that is breaded and fried and served with mashed potatoes, this is your place.
author: oona m.

description:
ich habe hunger!

i'd been wanting to go to suppenkuche for soo long.  after completing german 1a in may (i'm basically fluent), i've been dying to check out the restaurant of meine leute.  or something.  

went for brunch and it did not disappoint.  great coffee, and while i ordered the most un-german thing on the menu (an omelet), it was different and delicious.  my friend had the pancakes - mmm!  

i can't wait to go back for dinner and beer!  it was so fun it just made me smile.  i went right home and signed up for german 1b!

:)
author: Kristin K.

description: This is where I go to relive my glory days as a Praktikant.  Suppenkueche has ridiculously hearty meals and a notable beer selection even in an area with Toronado's and Frjtz.  The wait can be daunting though, and its cozy quarters and communal seating don't exactly lend well to intimate conversations.  But, I hear you can order a VW full of beer?
author: Phil L.

description:
Came with a group, great place for that!  Def good service as our server tolerated our rowdy behavior.  Menu was scant with only a few vegetarian choices which is understandable given the emphasis on Bavarian cooking.  
Käsespätzle (Cheese Spätzle in Onion Butter Sauce)..delicious carbs!  Neighbors got the potato pancakes, good but nothing you can't make at home, and the Jagersnkitcsosifode  LOL (pork loin).  

Look out for "Das boot" they are serious about preserving those boots, our server was cool but another staff member interrogated us and did full on CSI Suppenkuche to find any wet spots on the table since we allegedly cracked das boot.  Just not a good feeling as paying customers (understand the need to respect restaurant glassware but not responsible for normal wear n'tear). 

Would go again only for entertainment purposes and not necessarily for the food.  Barkeeps and servers cool, fast service.  Would give 3.5 for the establishment overall.  Danke!
author: Marie K.

description: I used to love this place but we planned to go here on a Saturday evening only to find they were closed for a private party?!?!  WTF are you thinking to close your place on a Saturday?? I hope you hear this owners.
author: Brian F.

description: MMMMMMMMMMMMMMM...beer so good.  I also liked the beer/soda mixed.  I had an entire 2 liter boot.  I did not really eat my soup.  But when I tried it the next day, very good.  The bread could have been a little more yeasty, but the most authentic I have tasted outside family.  I heard the sausage was good, as was everyone people in my group at.
author: Sarah A.

description: We inquired on the phone with Suppenkuche regarding an early dinner on Saturday night... we called on Thursday (i.e. 2 days before)... when we came for dinner on Saturday the Suppenkuche was closed because they had a private party there... and why couldn't one mention that 2 days before on the phone?... not very "grundlich"... so really in one word "Scheisse" service... we drove 45 minutes for this...
author: john k.

description: Ewww never again. Over priced, food was extremely salty, and the place is overly crowded or loud for me to enjoy my meal. If you to be knocked by couple of drunk ppl sitting or standing next to you while you eat then be my guest. I don't know why this place have high ratings. Probably you're drunk while eating this stuff. Bleh
author: C W.

description: When we arrived, the restaurant was very crowded. I prefer restaurants that have a little more space. When we were seated, the table was kind of like a school bench. It was very hard to get in and out. I ordered the mushroom pasta dish. The bread was very good but the main course wasn't great. It was definetely a different experience and probably would not come back.
author: Jay W.

description: Oh my gosh I LOVE this place. Fun place to take guests. The food is really good I love their meat loaf. The choice of beer is great. Always a bit of a wait but well worth it. A communal setting but fun to share tables with people. I am not a huge fan of beer but I LOVE it in this beer hall setting. Good service, a little loud. Can always go out for dessert afterward since you are in Hayes Valley. My friend got the boot of beer, really crazy to see him shoot the boot!! Lots of fun!
author: julie q.

description: What you need to know if you plan to come to Suppenkuche is that the place can be extremely loud. As in you can't carry out a conversation across the table loud, especially if you sit in the little room in the back. And it also can be a pretty crowded place.
author: Will E.

description: Wow, what an experience! I feel like I was transported back to Germany! Not only does this place have really authentic food, but it also has an incredible beer selection. Perhaps the best part though, is that the staff seem to genuinely want you to have a good time. I will definitely be returning to this place.
author: Drew V.

description: The only thing that could make Suppenkuche better would be a beer garden outside.  It's the perfect heavy German meal, complete with a great beer selection and family-style seating.
author: Jan W.

description: A great place to relax with friends ... cozy, no fuss, yummy food.  A bit costly but such is the price of nostalgia ... it brought me back to my days of living in Germany.  I recommend the Maultaschen in Pilzrahmsosse (Pork ravioli in mushroom sauce).  Lecker!  The only bummer was the cold draft each time someone walked through the door.
author: Miss Purr fec t.

description: Absolutely fabulous! I went here on a Saturday night, a few months ago and didn't know what to make of it. The interior's not all that genuinely German and is more akin to a Bavarian-Disneyland packed with Virgin Mary collectibles. It's also a tad crowded, and the "hip-crowd" can be a deterrent for someone who just wants to get his fix of German food, but this place is definitely worth a visit, regardless of that. The venison I had was wonderfully tender, and exactly the way I remember it to be from Southern Germany. The spaetzle were great, and the self-made red cabbage deserves my respect. Simply the best German place in town.
author: Roger W.

description: Worth coming to just for the beer, even though I've heard the food is good too.
author: Andrew L.

description: Super grubbin!  Damn I love good food...Lots to choose from the menu..i forgot which beer i drank,  (german of course ) but damn! soups were good..but typically this is a good german spot....Good Eats! that says it all!
author: bo y.

description: Yeah, this restaurant is phenomonal. I would never in a million years think that a German restaurant would be one of my favorites. I used to live down the street and would eat there at least once a month. Not great for the waistline, but so delish. Also, the prices are reasonable. There's tons of food (cheese spaetzle for a week, bratwurst for forever) and it's just great to have a giant beer.
author: Michelle B.

description: Oh Ja! I went here a couple years ago. I can't remember what I ordered exactly, but I remember it being really tasty!!! Everyone I was with had a different dish and we all shared. It was splendid. The wait staff were great and played along with our jokes and over abundance of alcohol orders. The large wooden tables and benches seated our big party perfectly, with no reservation needed. Yummm.
author: Miss M.

description: It took us a while to finally get a seat (1h 20m) but it was definitely worth it for both the environment and food.  Bavarian like, we shared a table with another party and there was definitely a neat party vibe in the place.  For a starter, I shared with a friend the ravioli filled sausages which could have been a meal in itself.  For an entree, I had pork sausages with mashed potatoes and 'krout.  Although slightly disappointing that there was only one choice of sausage, the food was delicious and the mashed potatoes to die for.  I'd definitely recommend getting six or more friends together (they only accept reservations for six or more) and heading down for a couple of beers and a few servings of carbs!
author: A K.

description:
Best beer selection around and its great for a group of people.

Tip: get the boot of beer, pass it around letting everyone take a drink out of it until it is finished.  The 2nd to last person to drink has to pay for the whole meal.  Think it through...it makes for good times.
author: Hylton K.

description: We went to this place before a movie so, unfortunately, we were a bit rushed to really enjoy it.  However, the food was very tasty (try the mushroom soup!) and the portions were unbelievable.  2 people shared one bowl of soup and one entree and we still didn't eat everything!  There are communal tables which are a little strange if you're into privacy but it didn't make or break the experience.  I want to go back when I have more time to enjoy!  I hear they have a great brunch!
author: a e.

description: I love you Suppenkuche. You will always be my favorite and I always choose you. You always have my favorite beer on tap and when you don't I can't blame you, it is the damn customs officers holding it up. You make me happy in so many ways from the wienerschnitzel to the cucumber salad to the potato pancakes to my fave, the shrimp and scallops in tomato beer sauce. Yum! Thanks for being such a good friend over the years!
author: sarah k.

description: If you have seen Beerfest then thats all I have to say. They have DasBoot! Also their food is really good. I took my cousin and good friend there for the first time and it was my friend's b-day. We ordered dessert the server came out with a candle and started singing happy b-day and the rest of the table began to sing along. The pople there are so amazing! It is a first come first seated place.
author: M C.

description:
nomnomnomnomnomnomnom

excellent beer, excellent sauerbraten, really excellent spatzle

very happy tummy
author: Uncle F.

description: i love this place. I go for the atmosphere and the beer. The food is ok. The service is awesome. The big tables make it really fun for groups. I have been here more times than i can count... and i will return again!
author: Beth S.

description:
Its already been said here about 900 times, but Suppenkuche is a great restaurant!  Who ever thought that someone could make German food hip and fun?  I've been coming here for probably the past seven years ever since I read about it in a United in flight magazine of all places  -  I think Robin Wright Penn listed it as a favorite restaurant or something -  and it has never disappointed me or anyone else I have brought with me.       Always crowed lively and friendly  with a great selection of food and an even better selection of beer - in huge glasses!  Get the Weinerschniztel if you are really hungry - and anytime there is a special of wild boar get that too.  Also - potato pancakes - and go for brunch too, the farmer's omelet with a heffeweitzen is a great way to start the day - hmm I may have to go there today as now I am getting hungry.  You may have to wait a bit for a table, but a liter of Spaten will definitely help you kill some time.

One thing kind of funny is that with the release of the movie Beer Fest, I have noticed a huge increase in the number of people ordering boots of beer haha - just remember to turn it to the side at the finish to avoid the air bubble or you'll look like a rookie...
author: Timothy S.

description: 1400+ reviews and here's another one you can skim over! I've eaten here about 3 times but only for brunch because what the hell do you want the day you're hungover? German food? YES, you want german food! WHY? The portions are huge and quality of food is actually good.  I wasn't hungover all those times I've eaten here so you can trust me. But if you're feeling hefferish, come here. Their Chicken Schnitzel is bomb, which isn't on their regular menu but when it is available, order it, you won't regret it.. But one thing you'll always find is those magical potato pancakes! They're basically hash browns with apple sauce but they do a damn good job at making these tasty. Apple sauce, you say? You must still be drunk. No, they compliment each other perfectly.  But If you're socially awkward then you might have a problem eating here because you're seated with strangers on communal tables. And if you're one of those people who solves their hungover-ness with more drinking, then you're set! They fill huge glass boots of beer so you can drink some more. That is all, Auf Wiedersehen!
author: Neva R.

description: I ordered the half organic chicken special with the fried pancakes and stuffing. WOW, it was incredible.  The mixed meat plate appetizer was also a treat.  It included liver sausage, salami, ham, and other unidentified meats.  This is definitive German food.  We were tempted to ordered the 2 liter "Das Boot" beer, but wisely decided not to.  The service was great, everyone was friendly, food came out on time, and the pricing was reasonable.  Here's a special tip: arrive early, you'll wait at least 20min to get a table, unless you have a party of 6 or more, then you can get a reservation.  Great place!
author: Roy Joseph D.

description:
amazing food, all of it
great German salads
service is just fine
high energy place, always crowded and difficult to get in,
best to go at odd hours
sauerbraten is cosmic
it would be a hard place to eat repeatedly daily, since dishes are pretty rich;  strong seasonings, marinades
have to expect this and be able to tolerate the load
amazing spaetzle

not heavy or greasy in any way

amazing dark bread comes with dill butter

worth he combat to get seated, as a single party or a group
author: furtivos h.

description:
i came with a bunch of friends on a saturday night for beer. it was PACKED, i don't know how the wait staff deals with it, but they were pretty understanding about people being their way.

we originally wanted to try the food, so  we ALL made a pact to come back the next day for food and more beer. the potato cakes and wienerschnitzel are tasty and the lamb chops and pork chop are excellent. 

it's a good place for a good time, even twice in one weekend. im sure i would be more of a fan if i drank :D
author: Kan L.

description: I went here with a bunch of German friends, and had a very pleasant evening. The food is good old fashioned German food, nothing too fancy, but tasty all the same. The atmosphere is nice and relaxed and as with most German restaurants, the beer was one of the best parts. The prices are ok, and the neighborhood nice so this is definitely worth checking out.
author: Michelle C.

description: loved this Place!bartender was extremely helpful and friendly and the beer Washington amazing. if you plan to go past 8 on a saturday Night, plan on standing !
author: Kaytee E.

description: Probably one of my top five favorite restaurants in the city...I think it is a little pricey but worth it. Everything that I have had here is delicious.
author: Jessie H.

description: The wait sucks...bring a jacket. Awesome meatloaf.
author: Janae L.

description:
Great food, fun times.  If you're looking for haute cuisine, this is not for you.  But if the thought of fried pork chops, spaetzle, and substantial beer appeals to you, then this is the restaurant for you. 

Got the wiener schnitzel, and it comes as two enormouse pounded out pieces of schnitzel accompanied with some potatotes and a green salad.  I don't know what the salad is all about - maybe just for color.  Needless to say the schnitzel was delicious - perfectly fried and not oily.  

Also got the cheese spaetzle, which is a must-order item.  Split it as a side with friends.   Sort of like mac and cheese.  

Finally, the beer selection is excellent - I usually go for the Franziskaner, and did so again this time around.
author: David P.

description: Great food, great beer, great vibe ... If you like the German wirthaus experience, you've come to the right place!  It's definitely a popular watering hole, but the food will keep me running back.  The communal tables are great as well if you like making friends.  Unfortuantely, It's a bit loud and the wait can be unglaublich!
author: Ken M.

description: What can i say, great authentic german food, great german beer  -- loved the "boot" thing but frankly, its a little expensive.
author: Tim M.

description:
Suppenkueche is a small unpretentious pub as one would find in any small village throughout Germany. The beer selection is okay and one can enjoy beers from various regions. The food is not high end 3 star dining but good traditional everyday food, found on the menu of most German pubs. The portions are generous. 
The few tables and bench style seating help to enjoy yourself (especially with family and friends) and relax. While it gets loud do to the size of the restaurant and the croud is pooring in for beer, it helps to meet other people and strike up conversations.
author: RBL L.

description:
I don't eat out for breakfast, or brunch.  But Suppenkuche has made a brunch-eater out of me.  We showed up at 11:30 on Sunday morning and were immediately seated.  Some may not like the communal seating idea, but the food makes it worth it - even for my husband who is super picky about that type of things.

All food we had was delicious: fresh breads with quality jam/marmelade, skirt steak with eggs and YUMMY potatoes, potato pancakes (how can you not get this?), with side of little sausages.  There was plenty of variety: I saw tons of items on the menu that will motivate me to go back and try.  

I'd really recommend this for brunch, and hope to go back another time with a larger group so that we can delve more into the menu and try a few more things.
author: Kristin L.

description:
Absolutely wonderful. 
Love the Wiener Schnitzel - have it with potatoes and saurekraut!! and the small brotchen (bread)!
Wunderbar!
author: Joanna K.

description:
Brief thoughts on Suppenkuche in bullet point format:

- Food is awesome and HUGE. Unless you're a very large athlete, splitting will still leave you with plenty to eat.
- The beer is great and comes in a variety of fun/huge glasses.
- This place is loud as hell. Don't go on a first date, or a fifth date for that matter. Save it for later on. You're usually seated at a table with strangers if there are only two of you, also. Kind of a mood-killer.
- This place is loud as hell. Which, as I just mentioned, makes it bad for dates, but makes it great for birthdays or visitors from out of town who want to do some drinking.
- There ain't much seating, so come early and don't come starving because you'll most likely have a wait for a table.
- Overall, a fun joint with badass weinerschnitzel.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: It's a little bit pricey, I think, but the food is really great and tastes authentic.  And I mean, come on, you have to have beer in a glass boot, just to say you've done it.  I went for a friends birthday--they wouldn't seat us until everyone was there, and once everyone WAS there, they didn't actually have a table ready for us...so we had to spread ourselves in an L shape between two tables with other parties sitting on the opposite sides of both the tables we were using.  The place is small, so it was a little awkward.  Not a huge deal, and eventually we were able to move to one table.  Speed of service was great and our waiter was super friendly, and the food was really outstanding.  The ambiance is pretty wonderful too.  The real downfall is just how cramped the space is considering how busy they get--and we were there on a Monday night.  I still would absolutely recommend checking it out at least once, and I wouldn't mind trying it again myself.  Might be a cute place for a date too.
author: Courtney H.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE that they offer real rye bread! I had the goulash which was flavorful but not too heavy, salad with an amazing vinaigrette, and the hefeweizen I sipped (well gulped) was delicious. This place is very crowded, often long waits, but the flavorful German food, and real German picnic bench style seating is worth it in my opinion.
author: Snora E.

description: Fun place with delicious food! I recommend the lamb chops, stuffed chicken, and ravioli. I'll definitely be back to try more menu items and beer in a boot. Can't wait! I knocked off one star for the crowdedness, but that's pretty difficult to avoid at any restaurant in SF.
author: Susanna C.

description: Only came here for Sunday brunch but man was it good! Lady got some dumping w egg thing- like a German Benedict w German sausage and mustard. That was nuts. I had the scramble which was safer but cucumber salad was really good.  Had to get a beer (it is suppenkuche) at 12 pm so i got  the heff w some lemon soda. It was interesting at the least.  I'm only giving four stars bc I only had brunch but I will be back for the famous dinner and boots and update.
author: shar d.

description: The beer is awesome - the food not so much. A Das Boot goes a long way for a big table - so a must have. I had the potato soup and bacon + meatloaf, both of which were decently good, but nothing to write home about (but of course a Yelp review is demanded) I do have to say that the intricate ceiling holiday display was great, and the german chocolate cake is superb. Great place for large parties and get togethers.
author: Wally N.

description: Not bad.  Yes, the beer is terrific, and the kaesespaetzle is darn good.  But overall I could think of dozens of other places I'd rather go.  Plus, the times we've been there it's been icebox-cold inside.
author: James S.

description: Maybe I'm getting old but everytime I go here I ask myself why I keep coming back. It's too loud. It's too crowded. The food is marginal at best. And I can't get a cocktail. There has never been a moment in side Suppencoochie were I have not felt like someone was screaming directly into my ear canal. Or rubbing all up on me. If Stouffer's opened up a restaurant, this is it. I mean sure it's a good time German Lederhosen food/beer fest. Pass
author: charles p fa t.

description:
This restaurant would totally remind me of all those times I spent at my favorite Bavarian ski chalet, swigging back dark brews with Dieter and Ula.  Except that I've never been to Bavaria, which is fine by me because Suppenkuche is so much more accessible.   And also I'm thinking that the menu is just a little bit skewed to appeal to Californian tastes and I'll take that over slavishly authentic German fare any day.  

Expect to wait at least 45 minutes for a table pretty much any night of the week.  If you can squeeze into a space at the bar, though, then the wait is half the fun.  It's loud and festive, with an impressive selection of beers and wines.  In December they were also serving up a popular hot mulled wine, which definitely put me in the spirit of the season.  

By the time you finally get a seat at one of the communal tables you'll be happy to know that the entrees are generous.  The sausages are great, and so is the spaetzel, of course.  I also recommend the appetizer salad.  It's substantial enough to be a meal, especially if you are lucky enough to be able to nibble off your date's plate a little too.  

The #6 muni bus stops at Laguna and it's just a couple blocks down from there.
author: Katherine G.

description: The first time a spoonful of SPAETZLE passed through my lips at Suppenkuche, tears welled up in my eyes.  I was born and raised in Germany (granted, not in Bayern), and it had been a long, loooooong time since my tastebuds were flung to my childhood and a universe of nostalgia, probably much like that French chap and his madeleine.  If you don't have family members nearby who are able to smother you with meaty, cheesy, noodly love, Suppenkuche is excellent Ersatz.  The HERRING SALAD is also satisfying, as is the EISBEIN.  Sehr.  Sehr.  Gut.
author: Shimmalicious S.

description:
i don't exactly think haute cuisine when i think of german food but suppenkuche is uber-tasty.  fresh, big portions of moderately priced food, great beer, pitchers of mimosas at brunch, and beer cocktails (e.g. beer and lemonade or a shandy to you anglophiles).  if you've got a big group, this place should be on your short list.

oh, and save room for the bee sting cake.  it's yummy.
author: Eric L.

description: My other 'favorite' SF spot. They have a great german beer selection, which takes me back to Oktoberfest. For food I recommend the Sauerbraten w/Spaetzle and Cabbage, or the Venison.
author: Pete S.

description: One of the few good german restaurants I've been to. They have a good selection of beer on tap. Their salad servings are gigantic yet delicious. The crowd tends to get quite boisterous (in a good way) into the night. Oh and their staff is super friendly.
author: Arnab B.

description: "German food? What?" This is the reaction I always get when I tell visitors about this amazing GERMAN restaurant in my neighborhood. For some reason, most Americans just don't associate German food with anything all that special. I never really had any my whole life, so for me it seems pretty exotic, or maybe it's just the succulence of this place that gets me.... The food is incredible - super tasty (though it's not light fare - be forewarned!). The sauerbraten tastes like it's been cooking all day. The pork chop is seriously THE BEST I've had in my whole life. The sides melt in your mouth - the sauerkraut and red cabbage!! One word of warning: the acoustics of the place make it very loud, and it gets absolutely mobbed most nights (especially weekends of course). But it's all worth it.....
author: Phil H.

description: sehr Deutscher in der Tat!
author: Y K.

description: Reminded me of Oktoberfest in Munich. Well, a little more tame.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Want a German-escape for one night? Wanna taste of Oktoberfest in you local neighborhood? Alright alright, I've never been to Oktoberfest, but I think this place would be comparable. 
Basically, if you're looking to drink and dont mind rowdy crowds--- you should come here. I think this place does a pretty damn good job of giving you a taste of German bars; it's not just the Bier ( = beer for those of you who dont know), it's not the fact that the menu is German with English translation--- it's really the happy-go-lucky-type people around you along with the boisterous cheering that makes it different than any other restaurant/bar in town. 
Most menu items are pork -- tasteful & tender alongside potatoes and veggies.
I had the grilled lamb chops, which were also tender, but the sliced potatoes with cheese and the white asparagus is what really stood out and made it... German! 
Appetizers, we had the prawns (tasted Italian) and the German pancakes with applesauce. This was like eating high class McDonald's hash browns minus the grease. 

Suppenkuche is definitely worth going to. 
FYI. Be prepared for the following: long wait time, sharing a table with friendly strangers, having to scream in order to converse, and being able to pay only $7 for valet. 

I think I could say I've been to Oktoberfest now?
author: Nancy Y.

description: definitely a great place! medium size but full of ppl, really loud, so if you are enjoy this kind of crowd this is for u. foods are great, and dont even need to mention about their beer! we order suckling pigs, potato pancake, sausage, and sautee trout. suckling pig and potato pancake are my fav! because u can't make reservation  if u have small group( less than 6), so go earlier than u plan to so you will be seated faster.
author: Kevin T.

description: Of course this place is good.  German food and German beer. Because I'm a scatterbrain I always order the chicken schnitzel- which is not a problem because its good.  Best beer: Dunkel.  Cafeteria style seating is not ideal, but acceptable- just don't sit on the very end of the bench.
author: Arthur K.

description: The Smoked Beer is the best.  Its like pork sausage in a glass!
author: jack a.

description: Awesome, fun place for a great selection of german brews and authentic (and delicious) food.  Suppenkuche was better the alot of places I went to in Germany.  Friendly staff - long lines but quick turn. Go.
author: T D.

description: For the beer and the food I am giving a solid 5 stars (I loooove their Spätzle, Maultaschen, Wiener Schnitzel etc...), however, I have to take one star off for being extremely noisy!!!
author: Bettina O.

description: We did take out  for pork, sauerbrauten and the divine potatoe pancakes.  Absolutely delicious.  Would we eat at the restaurant- not on your life- the noise level is horrendous.  Go for the food as a take out and you will love it.
author: nina l.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for years as some of my German friends say it's a pretty good representation of their cuisine in the Bay Area. I finally made after a matinee show at the SF Ballet not to far away. Of course my big group of 7 had to wait. The place was super packed at 6 pm! So we just did what every other group waiting around did, grabbed beers at the bar. Chatted up with strangers, it was all good. Not a boring place to wait around. This gives one the impression that it's quite the happenin' spot and I can see why. The hostess was very helpful and accomodating in getting us all seated. The waiters with their casual SF hipness knkow how to swerve and swipe through the crowds without dropping a plate. And oh were those dishes yummy. My group shared a plate of cold cuts. Mmm...liver! It all went well with that spicy mustard. I ordered the pork tenderloin with mushroom sauce and spaetzle. So creamy and comforting. German food is comfort food. Good beer and meat and potatoes, how can they go wrong?
author: Farah S.

description: This place has the best German food I've had anywhere so far in America, which is saying a lot! Book early to get a seat as it is popular, for good reason. Perfect ambiance of true German Hofbrau's, lots of people, shared tables and excellent beer selection. Food is exceptional and I'm just thrilled to come back to this place whenever I can. Prost!
author: Habsfan B.

description: Walking in I let out a groan because I didn't realize I was going to share tables with strangers. Sometimes I am in the mood to socialize, others not so much. Do you live in the city... Is this your first time here... Haben sie kinder.... Small talk, ugh. That's when I hear "Bucky..." I look over and see a friend who I haven't talked to in months. Having only lived in the city for three years, this was the first time I had unintentionally run into someone I knew and knew me. And it was a good feeling. I don't know if it was serendipity, coincidence, or just karma telling me to quit being such a baby. We joined the table and had a great time comparing beers and food. My wife is not the biggest fan of beer, but the waitress gave her an excellent recommendation. A very mild beer if you will. The beer menu by itself is enough to draw me back in.The food is hearty, being German you shouldn't expect anything less. I had the Wiener-Schnitzel which came with potatoes and a green salad on the side. The salad was sweet and balanced out the rest of the meal. The drinks and entree left me too full to order dessert. But really when you have good German beer, do you need sweets? Another meal in San Francisco, another lesson learned.
author: Bucky K.

description: I've lived in San Francisco for 7 years and tried Suppenkuche for the first time last Saturday, right as it opened at 5 p.m.  I was surprised when the hostess (who looked more Latin than Fraulein) seated us at a small wooden table with two other couples, but at least we got our own bread!  It was dense, brown, and delicious  - many people don't know this, but Germany has some of the best bread around, and it comes in hundreds of varieties.  We ordered the sole in butter sauce and beef with cabbage and spaetzle.  Both dishes were as good as anything I've tried in Germany, though the fish had too much butter for my taste.  The beer was excellent and plentiful.  Because we got there so early, we didn't have to wait for a table, but the place filled up fast.  I would go back, but maybe with a larger group of people so we can have a table to ourselves.
author: H. A.

description: I usually like this place but this last experience left a bad taste in my mouth.  I went with my friends for a beer and dessert for a birthday and knew it was going to be crowded, even at 9:30pm.  The hostess took our name and we decided to wait at the bar.  She was great with trying to seat us before the kitchen closed at 10pm, and I told her we would just be getting dessert and drinks.  There were six of us so we knew we had to wait.  We were considering taking our dessert to go but the hostess said she could seat us.  We got seated at 10pm .  We ordered three desserts a few drinks and a soup.  One minute later the hostess came back and told us that because we weren't really eating a meal we had to let the other parties still waiting have our table so they can eat.  We had to get up and wait for the next available table!  We just decided to take it to go since we already ordered and just had to wait for a table!  The desserts came out in 15 minutes while we waited outside.  The thing that really got me was the waitress came outside with the bill and the gratuity was included in the bill since we were a party of six!  I couldn't believe they had the nerve to include their tip since we were kicked out of our table as soon as we got seated and just for ordering desserts!!  I was so disappointed.
author: Jen C.

description: Meh, okay food in way too loud a space, that wierd share-a-table-with-strangers seating, and no reservations. No thanks.
author: Jonathan A.

description: Truely an experience! It can get rather crowded and parking can be a bit of a hassle -- but the service, food, and beer -- top notch! Completely worth it ! A great place if you're hanging out with buddies!
author: Michael J.

description: My gf told me about this place after seeing it on Yelp.  We just ate here tonight.  The place is loud as heck.  It's incredibly difficult to have a conversation here.  I'm not sure what all the rave is about.  I guess it depends on your palate.  I had the potato cake with apple sauce for an appetizer, which was pretty tasty.  For the main course, I had breaded pork loins with some kind of potato.  The pork loin tasted like country fried steak I used to eat when I lived in Austin, TX, only the country fried steak had more taste.  This food is really bland.  I've had better comfort food.  I won't be coming back.
author: Loc N.

description: i'm not a fan of german food. german beer on the other hand, i'm a fan. the selection is great and some german beers are as filling as a meal. i had a few appetizers which were tasty and 2 beers. that fulfilled my calorie intake for the entire day... and half of the next day. go there with patience, sample, take ear plugs and stumble home.
author: ray c.

description: Can't say enough great things about thise place. Great food, great beer, excellent service, even when it's wall-to-wall people. Make a reservation or get there early - and try the rauchbier for something really different. Not recommended if you're looking for a quiet evening alone - you may be asked to share a table with other diners.
author: Clint F.

description: all i can say is wow. i was slightly hesistant about going here after reading some of the reviews previous people had left.. it seemed either hit or miss with service and the food. last night was awesome! the place is cramped..no question about it there is little room to move and everywhere you turn it feels like you are in someone else's space-- however the food and the service was surprisingly good. appetizers:  the potato pancakes were not overly fried they were beautifully golden and even all around-- the apple sauce puree-- melts in your mouth... the ravoli and the meatball inside was tender. i highly recommend their corn soup of all things--- the texture was smooth, it was not overly sweet. the main course: was a stuffed half an organic chicken- the meat fell off the bone. the stuffing was not overly salty or seasoned and it was all gone by the time our server came back hehehehe.... dessert: i would agree with the other yelpers that their black forest cake was to die for... however i will also add that paired with one of their lattes-- it definitely ended our meal on an even better note. service: our server was super dilgent and on top of all her tables. she gave really good suggestions for beer and food pairings. i am definitely coming back!!!
author: Vicky T.

description: Good, not great.  The food was pretty delicious, but not really amazing.  My friend made a reservation, so I think we were lucky, becuase the main area looked insanely busy and it would have been impossible to get a table.  This might have been because it was a Saturday night though.  The beer selection is pretty good though.  The place would be amazing if it had a little more space.
author: Amit M.

description: I really like Suppenkuche!  Good food, good beer, decent prices.  It is usually crowded and seating is somewhat communal in the back so it can be really tight, but a great place to come with friends!
author: Jo M.

description: My dad considers himself a beer connoisseur of sorts, so I thought there was no better place to drench his palate and enjoy a dinner than Suppenkuche.  We arrived and parked it in the little alcove of a bar.  At first glance, the interior seemed pretty drab & dull with white walls, until you take in the wintry feel they are trying to go for with the hand-painted tree line and all.  The alcove was cozy with candles and German photos & artwork on the walls.  I stuck to the Lambick beers (black cherry and apple flavors, not too heavy and freaking great) while the rest of our party when on a flavorful journey courtesy of German brews.  After a few, we were seated at a nice window seat, which happened to be the same window seat as 2 other patrons.  I asked them what they recommend, they said everything, and even fed me a little of their yummy veal schnitzel.  Needless to say, it's a communal type of place : )  So, we embarked on a culinary tour of Estonia: Jgerschnitzel- porkloin in mushroom sauce (I just knew anything with "Jager" in it had to be delish), Sauerbraten: braised beef w/ cranberries, the organic wild boar sausage special, and the skirt steak special.  As forewarned, everything was superb and right up my alley... diverse and delectable.  My favorite out of the group was the skirt steak... drizzled with some yummy sauce, tender, and served with a potato & carrot gratin.  Some other parts of the meal that helped compliment were the lentil soup (more like a stew), Sptzle (the german mac & cheese), and the homemade sauerkraut.  We finished off the meal with another beer... this time I wanted to share the LITER OF SPATEN with the bf... I mean, this is seriously the Big Gulp of beers!  I really didn't know what I was getting myself into.  The place got a little rowdier as the night went on... quite a few customers doing Jager rituals (banging little bottles on the table, putting them in their mouth, and holding them up there with only their lips until empty).  But it was just what we were looking for... empty glasses galore, a full stomach, and a memory.
author: Tara G.

description: I'm no German food expert, but Suppenkuche seems to be doing a pretty good job on it.  More importantly, it is a super fun place for dinner.  Once you step past the curtain covering the door, you are instantly transported to a beer hall in Munich.  The atmosphere is boisterous and happy, and if you squint your eyes, it looks like everyone is red-faced and wearing lederhosen.  The beer selection is awesome...it's a ton of fun to pick which size and type you want from their menu.  If you are drawn to all things savory, try the pickled herring appetizer (even though it sounds kinda sick).  Experiment with the different beers.  The best plate is probably the basic sausage and sauerkraut.  I had a surprise b-day party in the back room and it was a ton of fun, drank two liters of delicious beer and had a great time!  Also a great place for a first date because there is a lot going on around you, but it is not too noisy.
author: Mr. G.

description: How can you go wrong with a place that serves their alcohol out of a boot? The wait is a bit long and the crowd rambunctious, but the atmosphere is really fun. The Jägerschnitzel was smothered in mushroom sauce and was the highlight of my evening. The portions are huge so bring along some friends so you can sample everything! I'll definitely come back as soon as I'm ready to brave another two hours in cold SF weather.
author: Michele L.

description: The food here is too delicious. If you see something on their specials menu that appeals to you even slightly, order it! I had the lamb chops with truffle butter (sounded much better in german) and they were the most awesome lamb chops I've ever had. Even the free bread was delicious. We got extremely lucky, walked in around 7pm and there was a table for two just waiting there. Realistically, if you go at dinnertime be prepared to wait a while, because there's something like eight tables and a hundred hungry people in various states of sobriety waiting.
author: Victor L.

description: I know I'm in the minority, but I really didn't like suppenkuche. I went here for a birthday party. The food is totally unhealthy, and we sat right by where the food came out of the kitchen, so i spent about 20 minutes looking at the different dishes trying to pick a healthy looking one. I gave up and got pea and sausage soup, which I tried to pick the sausage out of. But even more interesting, most of the food looked the same -- fried, smothered in fatty stuff... Plus, the restaurant didn't smell great inside -- like a stinky bar. Even the boot couldn't make me a fan.
author: suz q.

description: as a ex-vegetarian, this is the *only* place that i eat red meat.  and boy do i eat it!  the first time i came here i was still going through veggie withdrawl, confused and overwhelmed by menu options and not sure if i even liked meat.  but the boisterous atmosphere and 2 lovely marzen's inspired me to order the venison.  and i was not disappointed!  the potato pancakes were so much better than the ones my mom used to make and my obsession with their red cabbage would make my dad proud.  but last night i had their special pea soup, and it tasted like everything a wonderfully fresh pea should taste like.  fantastic!  now if they only had lebkuchen for dessert, i'd be in heaven.
author: stephanie h.

description: This place was great! Super clean, friendly, and awesome food. I had the chicken my posse ate pork wrapped in bacon and sausage with sauerkraut. Everything was great!
author: yvette h.

description: The second I left this restaurant I told my husband I couldn't wait to go yelp it. I'm a dork I know. We went here on a Monday night and it was still crowded. It has a super chill vibe. There are a few big tables that they seat multiple parties at. It's like high class cafeteria style. I love it. Anyway, we started off with the potato pancakes and apple sauce. Can't go wrong with that. It was delicious. After that followed a liter of Kolsch (to myself) and the Wiener Schnitzel, which is a breaded porkloin. It typically comes with a green salad and roasted potatoes but I substituted for the spatzle and the braised red cabbage. It was amazing. It's worth the drive and the wait. The beer selection was awesome and the waiters are super friendly. GO HERE NOW!
author: Betty W.

description: caught a buzz on sample beers alone, and the bartender would have given us another 10 if asked, super nice and patient as we tried every.single.beer they had.  surprising # of veg options for a schnitzel place and outstanding beet salad.  great.
author: Scott C.

description: I've been to Suppenküche several times, and left happy after every meal. The place is pretty authentic to a German drinking hall, with huge wooden tables and benches they fill to capacity whether or not you know the person sitting next to you. You will almost always have to wait to get a seat, but their fantastic beer selection and bar can keep you occupied while you wait for a table to open up. The service is nothing to rave about, but it's not bad either. The food doesn't come out that fast, but the complementary bread is a delicious way to tide you over. I usually order the potato pancakes to start (so tasty!). I'm a vegetarian, so eating in a German restaurant is potentially a bad idea. Suppenküche offers a few excellent veggie dishes however, and I usually go with the Portobella Mushroom stuffed with Spinach & Feta Cheese over Pepper Sauce. Those who do eat meat will be satisfied also, as their meat plates are great too (according to those I've dined with).
author: Kori M.

description: Revisited and had to shout out just how awesome this place is! It is just one big major Octoberfestivus with delicious food.
author: K O.

description: i made a reservation, but if you do, you BETTER be there on time, otherwise they'll give your table away.. also, don't plan on having a couple drinks after your meal- they will kick your ass out. how fun can this be? not very...
author: katrine n.

description: this place has a fantastic character, mood & quality!!!! we were greeted by a friendly wait staff who offered us to seat behind the bar while waiting for our table. after 10mins., we were seated on this wooden tables, with wooden benches/chairs, and we didn't know that this is a communal dining table, not until four people (two different couples) were seated with us. a quick hellos were exchanged between strangers. we were served breads with nutella spread and butter. we had the fried ravioli scrambled with potatoes, onions and cucumber salad and bread dumplings topped with fried eggs and bratwurst. it was really delicious!!! they also have a superior selection of beer & wine. we will come back here to try their dinner menu.
author: Nelle A.

description: Great German Grub. Especially the Kasespatzle mit Zwiebel ButtersoBe. The best selection of German biers in town which you can have it in glass boot. The most authenic German venue in California.
author: Ralph H.

description: order the BOOT to share with friends,  and the veal schnitzel - sooooo good!  we had so much fun here for my friend's birthday!  i would go back any time!
author: Cyn B.

description: not only can i order a beer with my breakfast and not have people look at me strange, but i can also bash steins with a stranger when our second round of Marzen arrives. i think i'm going to cry.
author: Friedrich G.

description: Hearty food. Great beer. Loud. Cafeteria style seating...easy to make friends. Parking is tricky. Crowded no reservations <
author: Brian S.

description: another, reliably good dinner joint.  the salad with the beets alone is worth the search for parking.  but all around the food, beer and wine are yummy and the atmosphere very unique and fun.  dinner for two: $65
author: cat c.

description: amazing food, friendly + knowledgeable waitstaff,  huge beers.  all you really need.
author: Jessica L.

description: i went here with some friends from germany and we were all very impressed! the food is amazing! the beers are great! the only problem is this place is always packed! well worth the wait though! great for big groups too!
author: Chelsea H.

description: A great place for a large group. The beer selection rocks.
author: Colin D.

description: There aren't many places that I will patiently wait, in the night air, for an hour and a half to eat dinner. There are almost no eateries where I will accept being crammed, after said hour and a half, into the corner with drunken people I don't know, and having to watch out for the throngs of anxious diners knocking up against my chair for lack of space. There are also NO other places that I can think of where I can get a BOOT of beer (2 liters - yes, I shared), enormous and crisp potato pancakes, wiener schnitzel that, according to my Austrian-born friend, is the most authentic he's had in the US and have several tons of delectable-ness left for the next day. Suppenkuche is definitely a unique and welcome respite for German-food seekers in the Bay Area. The space is too small to accommodate everyone, so it gets crowded, which only adds to its "I'm in a real German beer hall" feeling. The food is straightforward, plentiful, delicious and, according to many natives, very authentic. I actually have to commend the service for getting their job done efficiently and with a smile despite being obviously overwhelmed by the crowds. This is a must see joint. Minus one star only because they really did tell us 45 minutes and it ended up being close to an hour and 45 minutes. No reservations accepted except for groups of 6 or more, I believe.
author: Jenni D.

description: im such a fan and i will return, beer was great, food was awesome - i had the meatloaf with bacon and egg and I Soooo want it again. Even though i got the crappy table by the door. If this place is booked up try schnitzel haus in SOMA, both are wicked fun
author: Stuart g.

description: Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm so good. I went with my boyfriend a few months ago and we both loved the food! Okay I was a bit freaked out when my order came out. It was the entire fish cooked...from head to tail.  I
author: Jag B.

description: I rolled my eyes when my boyfriend decided to take his parents here for father's day, but I have to admit the food is not bad. Very reasonably priced, huge portions and tasty plum jam for the rolls. I went here for brunch and they had at least three specials that were not on the menu including a veggie omelet (no egg whites only omelet though) and banana nutella pancakes. I definitely recommend this place for brunch, but go early because it gets packed early and you might end up having to share a larger table in the back with strangers.
author: Mama L.

description: This place is ridiculously good.  I'm upset there's nothing like it I know of in NY because I would go all the time.  I came here for brunch and at first I was pretty skeptical about eating German so early in the day but somehow this place makes the perfect brunch meal.  First off, they didn't have any table space so we were initially hanging out at the bar and decided to order some beer.  These come in several sizes here, 1/3 liter, 1/2 liter, 1 liter and "boot".  I opted for the half liter of Radler and was basically finished with it by the time some space freed up at a nearby table.  This is the type of place where you share a large table with strangers but the table was big enough and we got the corner so it wasn't uncomfortable in the least.  Anyway, I was done with my first 1/2 liter and ordered another with my meal.  I don't remember exactly what I ordered (I should note that the menu is in German which is kinda cool) but it was a huge plate of some sausage/kraut/potato combination.  Long story short, I finished the entire plate, drank the second half liter of beer and left feeling completely satisfied.  I never would have thought I'd be able to eat so much food or drink so much beer for brunch but everything tasted so good I couldn't stop eating.  Also, bonus points for the cartoons of drunk animals on the wall, the bear humping a beer mug was hilarious.  I will definitely return here again when I'm back in SF.
author: Herman S.

description: enh, this was a disappointment for me.  Maybe I didn't order the right stuff..but i thought the potato pancakes were just fancy versions of hash browns.  1 star for the black forest cake, 1 star for huge boots of beer, and 1 star for the decor...
author: jozilla w.

description: the JAGER SCHNITZEL and SPAETZLE is good enough to serve in germany.
author: SF U.

description: I wasn't sure if I would write a review because I want to keep the place to myself.  In fact, I almost wrote a bad review just to scare everyone off.  No just kidding, I wouldn't do that.  Well, I have never tried the dinner but the Sunday brunch is stellar!   GREAT BEER and great food!  I've been several times but the last time my girlfriend and I took my parents and my nephew.  My parents loved the food and the scene and my nephew who is only 6 years old loved the food.  This little guy is picky, picky and not willing to go to far out of his comfort zone but he gobbled up everything!
author: Ty C.

description: Love this place.  Spent a long time in Munich and this place sends me back each time.  Great selection of German beers, Jaegerschnitzel and spaetzle on the menu -- you cannot go wrong!  Lots of fun when it is crowded.  Be prepared to share your table with complete strangers -- just like in the Fatherland!
author: Jon B.

description:
Who knew a night that started at 6:30pm at Suppenkuche would end at 10:30pm at.....Suppenkuche.  Lets just say, our intent was to have a few beers here and then head over to a nearby restaurant for dinner, but alas, it was not meant to be.  

As you walk in, the atmosphere at this restaurant is really warm and welcoming and I felt like every corner and table was filled with groups of friends having a great time.  The communal tables definitely promote this vibe, because our table of six was there for so long, we had two sets of couples rotate through in sharing our table with us and we had a few good laughs with each couple, of course being that we were getting louder and louder as the night progressed, we had a few more laughs with the second couple...or were they laughing AT us...no matter, providing entertainment to others is not a bad thing.  

Onto the beers...I'm not going to lie, I know nothing about German beers, so yes, I looked up wikipedia to learn a little bit more before coming here.  (you are now thinking, "who does that??", I do yes, so get over it).  So I was armed with fresh knowledge about lagers, ales, and further about pilsners, helles, bocks....but when I looked at the menu, my sights were set on the helles with lemon soda...this was sweet and delicious!    My next choice was the black cherry lambic which was a fruity delight and I couldn't wait to order another (also comes in rasberry)  So what if it looked and tasted like snapple, I happen to enjoy snapple! The choices I selected were not followed by the boys, but their selections were just as good, especially the winter lager which was one of the specials that night.  We ended the night with taking shots of the 80% proof herbal concoction that came in tiny little bottles and tasted like a mixture of hennessy and jager.  Whoa did that burn. Apparently suppose to make you "bright and alert" and funny enough, I think it did!  

Before you think we spent four hrs of just drinking, let me assure you that I'm way too much of a lightweight for THAT type of night.  Actually, even with food, I'm somewhat of a cheap date.  I cannot do anything about my genetic make up, and no, I'm not bitter about it, obviously.  Here's what we had -

1. Potato pancakes with apple sauce (large crispy golden cakes with a translucent and soft center because they make these with raw potatoes instead of frying them with fully cooked potatoes)
2. Grilled pork sausage (crispy on the outside, really delicious, especially with a little bit of mustard and sauerkraut)
3. Braised beef (this was flavorful, but a bit on the tough side)
4. Veal weinersnitzel (really, anything fried to a crisp without being oily is generally good in my book)
5. Meatloaf (scrumptious and moist, with bits of bacon scattered throughout).  
6. Blackforest cake (uhh...yeah, make that two, thanks)

All in all, the food was hefty, with lots of starch on the plate and an appropriate companion to the beers.  And with the friendly waitresses, bartenders, patrons and at $30/head for 4 hrs of drinking and eating...I'll skip the poker game (for tonight) thank you.
author: Karen L.

description: Supposedly really good authentic German food. They dont take reservations and its always packed. Good beer and large portions.
author: mike c.

description: herring and pomme lambic like whoa! the staff's pretty good looking, too. nicely lit in the little alcove by the bar...i can sit real close to my honey in there...
author: Joanna R.

description: San Francisco has too many foofy restaurants.  That's one reason I love Suppenkuche.  You can just go with your friends, eat some good, hearty food, drink some great beer and have a great time.  I go for every celebration, and I lovet o drink from the boot.  Also, you can't beat the brunch on Sundays!
author: jessica d.

description: did I really drink 64oz of beer out of a glass boot?
author: james s.

description: I'm yearning for another epicurean foray into the world of Suppenkuche - roast suckling pig, cured pork chop, breaded pork loin, meat loaf drizzled in onion sauce, blackforest cake, & lotsa, lotsa beer!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: just went to this place for brunch. i really liked this place because you were able to enjoy some beers for breakfast. its not very often you get to have a nice buzz with your eggs. i had a good time, though im not sure if i would have gotten the same experience here at night since it seems to get really busy and crowded.
author: Molly C.

description: Sometime the wait can be long, but it is a very entertaining and lively place for a weekend evening dinner with friends.  Great beer selection -- I like the Weltenburger Dunkel.  The Jagerschnitzel with Spatzle is an excellent choice for dinner.  If you are looking for a low-key dinner, don't go here.
author: Luke P.

description: having gone to austria and germany a couple years ago (mostly austria), i've had better.  the food was fine, though, and i did enjoy having a radler again, proving to my friends that i wasn't delusional about its existence. oh, and whatever you do, DO NOT ORDER A SEPARATE SALAD!. it's not worth the money (carrots and beets) and it's all the stuff that comes with whatever dishes you order anyhow.  the meat/cheese platter was good, the rest, not so memorable. i don't think I'd go back.
author: ML N.

description: Visited last Sunday, 1st time for me, family have been several times before, each time begging me to go. Even though I'm part German, I have digestion & milk issues and thought surely I'd find little to eat there. Was I ever surprised! A friend told us they didn't take reservations, BUT they do, and we were told it'd be 60-90 min wait. Not willing to give up, we thought we'd enjoy some of the fabulous beers. The bartenders were so friendly and informative, the host kept checking in with us. He had a large party that hadn't shown, only 4 minutes till they lost their reservation - would we mind taking their spot if they didn't show? Mind, heck no, in fact, super big thank you. I ordered the meat loaf with egg, bacon, mashed potato and onion gravy. Not remotely like the typical meatloaf and I'm glad for it. The egg white under to loaf was an off-flavor to the dish, yolk mixed in would have been better, but the meatloaf ingredients were fantastic. In fact, although usually the last to finish eating, I was the 1st! Hubby loves the venison w/plum jelly, family loves the Jagerschnitzel and venison. Can't wait to return to get the potato cakes and salmon. Thank you for a fantastic time and great prices and tiny but very cool atmosphere.
author: Rachel D.

description: If it weren't for the ass long wait totally would give it 5 stars.  Waitress messed up order but gave us free appetizer.  Much appreciated.  Beer is good..me like beer.  Sauerkraut is great.
author: James L.

description: If only I didn't get so drunk on the stunning variety of beers every time I eat here, I would have a lot more to say about the food. Good for groups of any size and level of pickiness, as long as you're cool with sitting nearly in the lap of a stranger. Seating is mostly shared wooden benches, but who even cares when you're busy shoving starches in your mouth? By the time I get seated I'm usually starving which is perfect because it's impossible to eat light. It's German food, what do you expect? I can't live without the potato soup. It's the perfect balance of thick and creamy with subtle smokey ham accents...which leads to an ever changing menu full of meat and potato based dishes. There are no wrong choices. A few times I've ordered one of the specials and they have been out, which can be disappointing, but my second choice has always proved to be delicious and satisfying and quickly erases the let down. Bonus, I live in the neighborhood so i can roll myself home and take a nap afterward. Even if I didn't though it would be worth a trip whenever I'm in the mood for a hearty meal in a fun environment that never fails. Everyone I've taken here from my parents to my 4 year old nephew raves about it afterward...isn't that enough?
author: ash c.

description: First time eating in the Hayes Valley.  to my surprise, it's a pretty nice little area.  But suppenkuche is a neat little cafe-ish place that has really good brunch.  went there for the sunday brunch served 10-2pm and i had the ravioli scrambled eggs.  pretty delicious.  it'd have to be bratwursts.  my sister had the bread pudding and suckling pig.  pig was pretty good but i liked the bread pudding most.  and her husband had the mashed potatoes and bratwursts which were good.  but the best part as many fellow yelpers must've pointed out is the fried potatoes pancakes that comes with this home made apple sauce.  definitely the winner right there.  some might just say its a giant hashbrown but the sauce makes the difference.  it comes in 3 palm sized cakes and we got 2 orders.  yes, that good.  i definitely wanna come here for drinks since they serve beers in DAS BOOT.  and for a reasonable price too.  definitely will be back.
author: Vincent K.

description:
good
- incredibly tasty German food
- beer... in a boot
- goofy wooden tables

bad
- crowded bar scene can be obnoxious
- goofy wooden tables
author: Anthony W.

description: Excellent German fare - Sauerkraut without too much vinegar and nicely accompanied with bacon, wild boar sausage and Spätzle.  The zucchini soup with blue cheese was great too - schmeckt gut!
author: Adrian K.

description: i am officially banning myself from ever coming back here.  this place is straight up dangerous.  you can get your beer in a glass boot.  yes, it's a HUGE monster two liter of beer.  each time i've eaten here, i've gotten the boot and then the rest of the night has been deleted from my memory archives.  the food is pretty good, the beer selection is great but really.. it's just not safe to go back!!
author: vlad k.

description: I don't think I could say enough good things about this place. The food is amazing! I had the pork tenderloin in mushroom sauce with spatzel (sp?), my boyfriend had a special, brats with sauerkraut and potatoes. everything was delicious! For dessert we had the apple strusel that we devoured in seconds. The beer menu is amazing. for most draft beers they price by the half liter, I had the boot (2 liters) of paulaner marzen, and my boyfriend got a liter of dunkel, i forget which brewery it is from though. the seating is communal, so don't be surprised if you're sat at a table with strangers, it also gets very busy... even on weekdays, we went on a Monday around 7:30, no wait for us, but it got busier through our meal. it is a lively place, so if you're looking for a quiet peaceful dinner, go somewhere else. if you want a true german dining experience, without paying for a flight to munich, then stop in. I can't wait to go back and try their potato pancakes.
author: Shawna M.

description: We were at Suppenkuche about a week ago for dinner.  We didn't have reservations (party too small) and were told the wait would be about an hour and a half.  It was Saturday at prime time. At any other restaurant I'd ditch the place and go elsewhere--not Suppenkuche!  The food here is simply awesome. The atmosphere is rowdy and fun.  Perfect for a German beer hall/eatery.  I'm so glad we stuck around and had dinner, as I'm still dreaming about it.  Maybe I'll go back next weekend!
author: Dave B.

description: Yes, I'll be the first to admit it. I was skeptical about German food. Well, I should have been more open-minded. It was good, very good. Not exceptional, just very good and worth a second trip. I ordered the gebratenes Schwein filet(broiled pork chop) that came with Spaetzle and really liked it.
