Now, if only I could be made to change my mind regarding British cuisine... Anyone know of a place with a decent selection of boiled meats and tepid beer?
author: Steve P.

description: i would give this place 5 stars for the food and beer.  but they don't take reservations and it's so busy it's impossible to get a table; very very annoying.  there isn't even a spot to wait for a table.  anyways, the suckling pig is really good.
author: Phil M.

description: good times here everytime.  best part is the people and the large common tables where my wife and i meet new friends over good german beers!
author: ken h.

description:
someone told me the portions here are super huge, which they're not. or i'm just a big fatty. or i needed something to soak up all that great beer.

seriously great beer selection and the food is super tasty.

read the bottom of the menu. it's $50 if you break the boot.

it's kind of loud and hard to get a table at times, but it's worth it.
author: Saikat P.

description: i met some great people there.  went there last night for the first time and sat at a table with two other couples.  right when we sat down everyone introduced themselves, we all started chatting as if we knew each other!  Michael and I shared a potatoe soup, it was the best!  then I had the suckling pig, apparently they only have it on Saturdays,  it was so good i wanted to finish the whole plate, but i had  beer before and i was already full!  Michael had the venision medallions which were so flavorful and not gamey at all!  they were out of the apple streudal so i guess we'll have to go back!  oh yeah, make sure to order a side of spatzel...  YUMMY!
author: Gina T.

description: this place is wonderful. the potato pancakes are to die for. amazing interiors, tables, and beer selection. nice date spot too.
author: casey c.

description: Most of the stars here are for the outstanding service, ambience, and vibe of the place.  Hubby and I came here before a symphony on Friday night around 6:15 without reservations (they don't take them unless your party is larger than 6 people).  We were put on a list and told it would be about a 20-minute wait but it was only 10 minutes.  We shared a table with a large group and ordered right away.  We got the weinershnitzel and the chicken schnitzel and some medium Heffeweisen.  I ducked out after I ordered to pick up symphony tickets from a friend in the neighborhood and our food arrived before I got back.  The waiter promptly heated mine up again and check up on us many times through the night!  They were so friendly and had us out of there by 7:30, plenty of time before the performance started.  The food itself was pretty good.  I especially like their roasted potatoes that came with the dishes.  It's very festive, a good place to go with a group, and just loved the overall experience!
author: I-Chant C.

description: It would be four stars if it was not for the hostess with the mostess trying to give my boyfriends seat away while he went to use the phone.  Then less than gracious hostess came to berate me about where he was.  FU should have been my answer.  But alas I was heavily beer filled and having a great conversation with our table company.  I let her off easy with a simple "none of your business where he is".  Seemed to work and our server was fantastic.  Food was wonderful..I got the bratwurst.  No complaints here.  We did make the sad decision to get das boot.  Beer was fantastic mind you but between the two of us we did not need more let alone 2 liters more of beer.  We toughed it out, had a great time then happily (drunky) fell in to cab and went right to bed.  What a waste of a great beer buzz but hey, were getting old.  Love this place...please fire hostess....she sucks...(dark haired chick only).
author: Doreen D.

description: The food was excellent....hot and delicious with a wide variety of items on the menu.  Also a great selection of german beers.  The portions were large, seniors might want to consider splitting an order. Went there on a Thursday night at 6:00 pm and was seated immediately, went back on Saturday night at 6:00 pm and was told there would be an hour and a half wait for service....no restaurant is worth that amount of time to wait for service so my advice is to go during the week as I am sure if you like german food you will love this place.  They don't take reservations unless you are a group of 6 or more...bummer
author: james w.

description: i hate vinegar, and i dont drink beer, so its hard for me to order at this joint.  but if you want to go, i'll probably go with you cause there is just something about this place. i like the seating, the service, and the custardy desert.
author: coffeecake j.

description: This is probably my least favorite of the three German restaurants I know about in the city (the other two being Waltzwerk and Snitzelhaus). The reason has been mentioned several times by other reviewers- it is a popular hangout of the Hayes Valley "It" crowd. The "it" crowd stalks from bar to bar, chugging liquor, talking loudly, picking up on members of the opposite sex, and breaking poor Suppenkuche's 5-liter beer boots (yes they have these and they are available for public use should you be capable of chugging 5 liters of beer). Honestly they should not let the well-intoxicated handle these things, although I hear there is a hefty recovery price to pay should you break one. As for getting your foot in Suppenkuche, come about half an hour to an hour before you actually believe you will get hungry. There is generally a huge wait, despite the fact that you will likely be seated in the "German style" = at a large, cramped table full of a bunch of strangers. You may be one of the many lucky individuals who gets to sit either up against the window or wall in the middle of the table (from which escape is near impossible) or, conversely, with your back close to some asshole at the bar drinking beer. But don't worry. There will likely be another group or two seated with you to share your pain... and awkward silence. Needless to say, this unexpected company might make for a rather strange date or romantic evening. But if you are the kind of person who likes to eat delicious cheese spatzle with some strangers, desperately try to talk over those whose voices are hipper than yours, and periliously try to flag down your waitress amid the well-intoxicated-with-good-beer crowd, then this is the place for you, herr yelper.
author: M J.

description: SunnenKuche is an amazing restaurant and environment.  My friend and I got to sit with 2 other couples ( who did not know each other) and discuss  what german beers are good and what to order for dinner.  The environment is awesome but not for the timid ( unless you can get a table for just your group).  I got the Snapper and it was very good.  Also the German wheat beers they have are very tasty.  I hope you enjoy.
author: Tim S.

description: best German food in San Francisco
author: Sarah N.

description: Our experience at this restaurant was fantastic!  The food was amazing only matched by the selection of beers and the amazing bartenders . We especially loved Craig!  He really made our night !
author: karla s.

description:
3.5 stars if I could- good food, great beer, good but not great service, and SUPER LOUD but charming ambiance
The food is enjoyable, and so is the great beer selection, but I always seem to walk out of here groaning about how I am stuffed to the gills.
Skip the schnitzel.  The sausages and the sauerbraten are solid choices, as well as the gravlax if you go for brunch.  My only complaint about the gravlax is that it is literally a plateful of fish with a side of tasty mustard. No bread, crackers or other carbs to go with it, and I for one, just can't stomach an entire plate of cold fish even though I love sushi.
Everyone seems to love the potato pancakes, but both times I've had them, I wished later that I didn't waste the limited space in my stomach with those.  To me, they are just super crispy hash browns that sink like a lead balloon into your stomach and make you too full to eat all the other good things you ordered.  I think I keep wishing they were more like latkes, and less like a deep fried potato hockey puck.
This place is good for a group of about 6 max (based on my experience of going with a group of 6 and also a group of 16).  However, it is extremely loud at both brunch and dinner, so be prepared to only be able to chat with the people who are in a three foot radius.
author: SC B.

description: one word. dasboot! anywhere you can drink in a boot shaped glass if a.o.k. in my book. the cheese spatzel is awesome too. the only problem with this place is that half the time we go, we end up not eating there because they're too packed. i guess that's my bad though. all in all german food at it's best.
author: cj b.

description: i like the ambiance, beer and wine but my entree was just OK (some beef w/ cranberry thing). i did like the spatzel though. we defninitley waited over 45 minutes on a wednesday, but the fun bar made it bearable.
author: miss l.

description: if you're a meat and potato type of person, you will love this place.  the meatloaf w/bacon - yum.  the trout - yum.  the breaded pork chop - YUM. and the schnitzel - YUM.  didn't know what schnitzel was before last night...but i'm glad i tried it.  the dinner salads of lettuce-only plus dressing were my kind of salads...and also yum.  the beers were good (downed my lemon soda beer) and the service was normal.  i will definitely be back.  i especially want to try to the lentil soup with bratwurst.
author: Adela K.

description: loved the food, trout is wonderful, potato pancakes and brocoilli soup were amazing.  nice wines and kind service.  main dining room is quite loud though, if you have the chance sit in the back, still loud but not as bad.
author: Steven K.

description: this place is great! but ou must make a reservartion if you dont want to wait! the food was amazing. i went with a goup of 7 and we all ordered different thing, and because the menu is pretty small i got to try a piece of everyhting. i must say the venazin entree is the best!!!!!!!! the beer selection was great but i really didnt like the idea of the shared tables and they did kind of seem like they wanted us to leave. but the food was good
author: Shauna P.

description: One of the best German resturants I've ever been to. Only the Schnitzelhaus in SOMA is better. They have authentic german gasthaus (family style) seating and tons of great german beers. I don't drink but my fiance does and loves the beer they have there. Foodwise: great hearty fare. Do not come here if you are looking for a light meal or are on a diet! The wienerschnitzel is great and so is the jaegerschnitzel. The spaetzle is great and the side salad that they give you is unique and yummy. The dark bread and chive butter -- awesome. I could eat just that all day. It is a little on the pricey side for a regular dinner but great as a treat for yourself and a loved one. It's noisy though -- don't come here if you want a nice quiet dinner. It's been crowded every single time I've ever been there but the wait staff are great. Generally your food gets to you pretty quickly though the last time, they were kind of slow. The decor is eclectic but cute and changes with the seasons. All in all, a great restaurant.
author: Samantha H.

description: If you are looking for a nice quiet place to dine on America's finest German cuisine or if you are sort of a stiff you may want to reconsider this place. However, if you like phenomenal beer, large portions of classic German food, and a lively environment Suppenkuche is possibly the most fun you will have dining out in San Francisco. The wait typically takes an hour or so on the weekends but that's part of the fun! Put your name down then squeeze your way to the bar and order yourself a liter of beer. When it comes to ordering beer I find it best to either order something you have never heard of or ask the bartender what they would recommend. If you would like to sample a few beers before committing to a liter you're in luck as they serve about 10 different sizes of beer ranging from a couple of ounces to the 5 liter stein. Forget giving props for serving a boot, this place will pour you a 5 liter stein!!! I have never seen anyone order this bad dog but it's worth taking a look at while you are there (it usually sits on the top shelf above the bar). After making a few new friends and downing a couple large beers your table is generally ready. The experience at the table can be rowdier than at the bar depending on who you go with or who you're seated next to. Again, it's part of what makes the place fun. What about the food? You get a ton of it and as far as German food goes it's pretty damn good. Let's face it, the Germans aren't known for their culinary prowess. I've tried quite a few dishes but I think my favorite is the meatloaf wrapped in bacon. Enjoy!
author: Mark B.

description: Pretty much the best German restaurant around...in the US. The closest to mothers cooking. The wait is a little long, but after a beer and in good company time is nearly forgotten.
author: Brigitte D.

description: I love this place so much. the food was fantastic, delicious and amazing !. the only things was thy only take RSVP if you have 6 people or more if not you have to come early otherwise you have to wait in line 40 minutes -1 hr but Trust  me. It's worth it.
author: Grace C.

description: The absolute best authentic German experience in SF.  Every dish is great and nothing beats brunch on a Sunday morning made up of sausages, dumplings and a liter of Doubleboch!  Great place for out of towner's or locals who want to try something different.  Definitely an experience.
author: Ashley K.

description: fabulous brunch - a great excuse to have a giant beer for breakfast.  perfect, succulent schnitzel, perfectly prepared spatzle, yummy kartoffel pancakes, underberg, oh, and did i mention beer?
author: eeeee d.

description: This place is great! A huge selection of beers, excellent food and you sit with other folks which kind of adds the the fun. The only negative about it is that it is a little hipstered out, but if you can get around that you'll find the hipsters are pretty nice. Be sure to get there right at 5pm when they open or you'll be sitting around for a long time drinking beer (oh, wait. Is this a bad thing??)
author: Fawn D.

description:
great german food. decent selection of german beers. great place to make conversation with new folk...what with the oft-shared tables. expect ~$20 an entree at dinner, but know that it's delicious (venison, spaetzle, and red cabbage?...I'm sold!)

well worth a visit or ten.
author: Jason K.

description: Consistently good food, cozy atmosphere, selection of beers, and good staff. Crowded. One of our best times there was when we had a 20 person dinner party in the back room. Fun.
author: Missy D.

description: boyfriend claimed last nights dinner was the "best pork tenderloin (german translation for schnitzel) he's ever had."  great interior, awesome vibe, had a wonderful time with my friends as a party of 10 at a large table in the back.  and of course, "DAS BOOT!"  I highly recommend this place with a large group and reservations who are up for not offended by excessive drinking and outrageous activities.
author: Megan S.

description:
such yummy food!!!! if you really want to check this place out, i suggest coming here early (right when they open), that way you can sit & eat (w/o having to do w/the long wait) & enjoy the german beers (w/o the noise of other ppl).

the 3 of us girls ordered 2 beers (1/2 liter size--$5 each, pretty cheap for german imported beer), 1 potato pancake appetizer to share (there were 3 pancakes--perfect, we each get one), 3 entrees, & a apple struedel to share...all of that food for $96.00 (incl. tip & tax) and i had a little doggie bag to bring home for the bf. the portions are big & considering most of it is all hearty stuff...you will be full, esp. if you drink a big ass beer w/ it.

we ordered the roast suckling pig w/bread dumpling & sauerkraut, i had the meatload w/mash taters, & my friend had the sauteed pork w/spatzle. OMG, OMG, OMG, OMG, OMG, Food-gasm, OMG!!! everything was just so tasty & hearty!! it's definitely a man's meal but the 3 of us girls just ate, ate, and ate til food coma oblivion. the spatzle was awesome, it's this funky textured pasta & b/c it was a little bland, it went so well w/the mushroom gravy all over the sauteed pork cutlet. 
the meatloaf was hearty & there was half of a hard boiled egg in the middle of the piece...and the meatload was wrapped in bacon--yum! i personally thought the suckling pig was excellent b/c it was tender, perfectly seasoned & slow cooked so it turned out really good.

the apple streudel was great, nice phyllo dough & bits of walnuts incorporated w/the the struedel. 

it's a great place to come w/friends, enjoy good food & decent prices!!

i cant wait to go back & make sure im not driver next time b/c i will order das Boot!!  thanks "Check, Please!" & Purl....we're sooooo coming back here--maybe this week??
author: Yolanda L.

description: You must go to Suppenkuche at least once. For the experience. One of the most unique restaurants I've been to in a while. Food was all right. It didn't blow me away. Schwarzwalden kirshetorte on the other hand, gave me a TBO (taste bud orgasm). Anyway, go and have fun!
author: Katya A.

description: So tempted to give it a one star, just so there will be MORE BEER FOR ME! Seriously, I love this place. My husband and I can walk down here after work for some Franziskaner (not sure I spelled that right...sad) after work before the crowds pour in for the awesome food. And I do mean awesome.
author: Sarah Y.

description: I highly recommend this place, I went there with one of my German's Friend, he totally like this place; I did liked it. The food is really good and the service amazing!!!
author: Christina F.

description: I planned to meet my friends at Suppenkuche at 7:30 on a Saturday - apparently that was a rookie mistake as the place was absolutely packed!  All the tables were taken and every possible free space around the bar and in between tables was filled with people and giant beers.  The wait list was full, but with unbelievable luck my friends and I managed to get prime seats at the bar.  Our meal was delicious, the selection of beers was superb, and the bartenders were super cool in a good way.   I look forward to returning, although next time I think I'll try to get together a party of six so that we can make a reservation.
author: Rachel P.

description: Lots of fun here as the drinking vessels are the ultimate novelty in a group dining experience. Can't wait to go back!
author: Virginia N.

description: Coming from a german gal living in the city, this food rocks! Das Boot is also very yummy!
author: sascha a.

description: go there right now and get the chicken schnitzel...sit in the lil' bar area w/ your favorite person and break your diet. it was fantastic...the food was great, the staff was awesome, and the crowd was havin' a rockin' good time.
author: Courtney B.

description: I LOVE the mushroom/feta/pepper dish here. Their dense bread and flavored butter goes great with all the dishes served. Crowded, friendly atmosphere.
author: Kayo S.

description: I had so much fun here with the huge German beers and the unique German ambiance.  I didn't like waiting for so long, but it was worth it.  Definitely a new experience.  We got the meat platter app, and that was intense, just meat and cheese.  Then we got our pork entrees which were pretty good.  If you like big beers, come here with your friends for dinner.
author: Justin H.

description:
We went on a Wednesday night around 7. 3 of us waited for about 15 - 20 minutes for a table. Not so bad as it got a lot more crowded after we got there. 
Great beer list with bartenders that can actually pronounce the beer that they are serving. - I'm half German so that's always impressive.
We ordered the Kuerbissuppe (daily special squash soup), the Reibekuchen (potato pancake), Kaesespaetzle (cheese spaetzle) and the Jaegerschnitzel). The food was good, not great and really a bit lacking on the authentic side. 
Rant on things that did not seem so authentic. Rotkohl is generally cooked, not the raw shredded cabbage we were served. The Reibekuchen were huge balls of shredded potato and seemed to be deep fried within an inch of their life. Waaay to much fried outside, hardly any good potato inside. It's supposed to be a pancake with some outside pan fried bits not all oil. 
The Kaesespaetzle was the best part, cheesy with sauteed onions mixed in. Soup was decent, maybe a bit to much cinnamon, but totally acceptable. Can't comment on the meat, but the BF said it was good. 
Totally coming back as the whole meal cost us 65 (with tip and beer).
Oh - and it is really noisy in there. Very authentic German beer hall loud, minus the smoke.
author: Chris V.

description: i had a delightful dinner here earlier tonight. one of my favorite chums had been out of town for the holidays and we had not yet had the chance to catch up and acquaint ourselves with the recent events of each other's lives. needless to say, we were in need of a good place to nourish our bodies and souls with hearty food and a heart to heart. suppenkuche was an excellent choice for both. we were greeted kindly by and seated immediately by a handsome young man. we decided upon the potato pancakes with applesauce to start, and i had the grilled pork and mashed potatoes. both were excellent choices and i must say that the pork dish i had went beyond my expectations! it was perfectly done and had a very savory flavor - i thought that even my grandmother who loves her pork would be pleasantly surprised. we dined and sipped upon tall glasses of lambic and brew... we connected and shared thoughts about life, love and friendship while enjoying our feast.  after our meal, i admit to being curious so i peeked at the desert menu and i was surprised that there was only had one choice - a black forest chocolate cake - but after the filling and hearty meal (i could barely imbibe a third of my dish) we decided it was for the best to save such an indulgence for a better time. all said and done, it was a wonderful meal and if you have not been, i can only tell you that i personally give suppenkuche a high recommendation. congrats!
author: Karen K.

description: still way too crowded but german food is really growing on me...  i didn't realize this but there's some seating behind the bar that's great for hanging out with friends while you're waiting for your table.  also... i mistakenly thought they didn't take reservations before but they do for parties of 6 or more (but call a few days ahead of time!)
author: jean m.

description: the first time i ate here was about a year too late. i had brunch a couple months ago and was floored. we shared a table with a group of girls who were pretty gabby, but i was staring at my date the whole time. i can't even remember what i had. the second time was with another date. this time, we had the best seats in the house: at the bar, facing the room. i recall the special omelette was amazing, as was the side of mini-brats i ordered. there was so much grease on the omelette--let's say, "jus"-- that i felt full after just half of it. the pickled cucumbers on the side were perfect: tangy, not too salty, and not too much dill. the third time i went was with yet a third date, and while my farmer's scramble was delectable, the pickled cucumbers had actually become pickles-- sweet pickles, at that--  which were just not what i was looking for at all. but, i will go back here at least once per month, because the server is just so goddam hunky.
author: Molly A.

description: cool german spot... we had to wait like over an hour one night but we were drinkin brews at the bar so it wasnt terrible. sausage i got was good! nice fun spot with people around you everywhere getting wasted.
author: Wats C.

description: I got to give it to them, they actually do have german dishes on their menu. I've been to a few places that claimed to be authentic (yeah, right!) and of them, this one really isn't too bad. The interior style is plain, hence the name Suppenkueche (soup kitchen), which was basically used to serve people during WWII. The beer selection is good and the atmosphere around the bar is similar of what you'd find in a german pub. You'll hear a lot of german which is indicative that the place is actually liked by their fellow germans. The menu features a small selection of german entrees and main dishes (Jaegerschnitzel being my personal favorite). Beware of the pricing. I find them a bit expensive (maybe that's just the cheap german in me talking), but hey they are in SF so I guess they get away with a lot. The best item on the menu, by far is their Blackforest cake..... My oh my, it is really darn good (they could add a tad bit more cherry liquor to it tho, again, just the critical german in me talking). They don't seve it every day, I believe Thursday's you might get lucky. It was a nice introduction for my boyfriend, him being from El Salvador it was a first eating german food. It was a nice intro too, especially since we ended up seeing my folks a few weeks later and he had the opportunity to compare the food he had to homemade german grub. The place is popular and fills quickly. One thing that might take some getting used to for some people is that you'll be seated with total strangers. It's real small and the space goes fast. It's not uncommon to see people waiting outside as early as 6:30pm. Parking in the area is a bit challenging. For some really yummy food tho, it's worth it.
author: Trinity X.

description: Yummy food, fun atmosphere and tasty beer!   Went with my parents for dinner and everything was delicious.  Since there were 3 of us we shared a table with 3 others the first set of folks were ok the next tones of fun especially the one flirting with my mom.  We had a bread basket when we sat down with heavy brown german bread and a pretzel both were tasty.  I started with mishroom soup (may parents had lobster soup) both flavorful and delicious.  My dad and i shared a an oktoberfest beer .5 liter which was perfect and too much for one person with the bread and heavy food.  My enteree was venison with red plum sauce, red cabbage and spatzel. It was yummy and a huge portion I could only eat half.  My mom had the souerbraten and my dad the pork snitzel with a creme mushroom sauce both very tasty.  For dessert the 3 of us shared a piece of apple strudel which was falky goodness.  All in a ll a great meal in fun atmospere I will definitely go back here
author: Melanie -.

description: love this place, love it, love it. love the bratwurst, potato salad, cucumber salad, smoked salmon, potatoes in general, schnitzel. i usually have the bratwurst, but my friends confirm that the many other menu items are delicious too. good beers like reichsdorf kolsch (sp?) always served.
author: Y W.
